column2: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A frugal son of the "Emerald Isle," whose better half was lying dangerously ill, was directed by the attending physician to go to the nearest apothecary with his prescription, and obtain the article ordered without delay.

Our news from Cuba gathers interest as we go on. The attitude of the Government is more decided, and all talk of concession and conciliation is abandoned. The apologetic disposition evinced before the sorry blunder our Mr. CONRAD was committed, in placing our Government in the posture of deprecation, with reference to the affair of the Crescent City, is replaced by a contemptuous assurance of security.

The steamship Black Warrior, Capt. SHUYELDT, arrived yesterday morning, from Mobile on the 9th and Havana on the 12th inst. On the 13th, in lat. 26[degrees] 30' N., long. 79[degrees] 46' W., the Black Warrior exchanged signals with ship Pelican State, from New-Orleans for Liverpool.

The season here, though it has been distinguished for unusual and very fatal sickness, has been highly favorable to the sugar planters, and they are new drawing toward the realization of the most abundant crop ever made on the island.
MARINE INTELLIGENCE.

From our Havana files we glean the following Items of Central America news, which is some three weeks later than has been previously received. GUATEMALA.--The elections have passed quietly. The Conservative party has an overwhelming majority. In spite of the inferior harvest of its principal fruit, an augmentation is observable in the public revenues, and other symptoms of success signalize the firm Government of General CARRERA.

Madame SONTAG gave a full dress rehearsal this morning, to about 400 Clergymen and their families. Many members of the Press were also present. The first part consisted of Sacred Music, and was beautifully rendered.

Advancing to the front of the stand or platform, Mr. WEBSTER stand with his arms folded over his chest, like a statue, calmly awaiting the subsidence of the waves of popular applause. It was long before the surges of that ocean of sound ceased, nor did they entirely so, until, as if weary of adulation, he stretched forth his arm, and then "there was a great calm."

New Theory of storms, by Dr. Blasius. These phenomena in our atmosphere, which sometimes prove a blessing, sometimes a calamity, and which constitute the weather, have, in all ages, and in all civilized nations attracted the attention of the intelligent, but never more so than at the present day.

The State Legislature assembled this morning, and Governor MARTIN delivered his Message, the leading features of which are as follows: He commences with a warm congratulation on the social, educational, and political condition of the State, recommending economy and equality in the levying of State taxes:--suggests action for preserving the public lands, and virtually recommends the abolition of the statute of limitations in relation to the collection of debts.
WANTED--Twenty independent Yankee men, under thirty years of age, who dare wear their coats in the street, with a patch the size of a cent and a half on the elbow.
A BEAUTIFUL MISS IN MALE ATTIRE.--About a week since, a smart-looking lad, in appearance, entered the extensive clothing warehouse of SIMMONS Co., Water-street, and applied for employment.

The second meeting for the present month (postponed from yesterday on account of the ceremonies in honor of late Mr. WEBSTER,) was held in the rooms of the Institute at 12, M., yesterday. The Chair was taken by Mr. GRIFFIN.

The second lecture of the New-England Course was delivered Tuesday evening at the Brooklyn Institute, by Rev. H. N. HUDSON--the subject being "Shakspere's King Henry the Fourth" The attendance was quite respectable, and the audience appeared much pleased with the matter and manner of the lecturer.

BRUTAL MURDER.--We learn that a most brutal murder was committed on board of a scooter lying at the Nail Factory cock, on Saturday morning. The times of the parties engaged, the murderer or his victim, we have been unable to learn. The particulars, as far as ascertained, are as follows:
The mall is through from New-Orleans as late as due. Lieut DAVENPORT and Purser SMITH of the Crescent City, declined the public dinner tendered them by the citizens of New-Orleans.

DIFFICULTY IN A TOBACCO FACTORY.--A NEGRO MAN SHOT.--A difficulty occurred yesterday morning about 7 o'clock, in the tobacco factory of Dr MOSBY, between the overseer and one or the ??, which resulted in serious consequences. It seems that a slave named AMOS, belonging to the estate of WILLIAM G WATSON, deceased, had absented himself from the factory for a couple of days, without permission.

There is a manifest determination in certain quarters to misrepresent the action of the Administration in regard to the Havana difficulties, and to use them as material to strengthen fillibustering influences throughout the country.

FIRE AT OLDTOWN--MILLS BURNT.--The range of mills on Oldtown Falls owned by Gen. Samuel Veazie of this City were burned last evening. The fire broke out at about 12 o'clock, when the men were gone to supper. The mills were completely consumed. Loss, to all parties, $10,000. No insurance. By good fortune the block of new mills contiguous, now nearly completed, were saved -- Bangor Mercury, 14.

Suddenly, on the 15th inst., in the 32d year of her age, ANNA KATE, wife of Frederick S. Vinderpool The relations and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 50 Lexington?? corner of 25th St., on Thursday, the 13th at 1 P. M., without further invitation. Her remains will no taken to Greenwood for interment.

The annexed extract from a dispatch received this day from J. H. WILLIAMS, Esq., dated Aug. 13, relating to a next Tariff passed by the Legislative Council at Sydney, New South Wales, is published for general information:

THE ALLEGED COAL BED OF LAKE SUPERIOR.--CHARLES WHITTLESEY, Esq., of Cleveland, has written to the Lake Superior Journal, avowing his disbelief in the existence of coal in that region. The locality of the alleged coal bed is at the southern extremity of the bay, lying between Keewenaw Point and the Huron Mountain district. Mr. WHITTLESEY, who is a skillful mineralogist, remarks:

CITY BIBLE SOCIETY.--A Special Meeting of this Society was held Tuesday evening, at the First Baptist Church, in Fifth-street. The exercises of the evening were introduced by singing, reading of the Scriptures, and prayer. The Colporteurs, (six in number,) who are engaged for the Society in New-York and vicinity, visiting families, distributing bibles, tracts, , were present, and made statements of their progress in this laudable work.

FATAL CASUALTY.--Corouer MORSE held an inquest at Buffalo upon the body of JOHN DORR, a lad fourteen years old, who came to his death under the following circumstances. The deceased resided with his parents on Pratt street, and about two o'clock in the afternoon returned home, having been sent out to purchase some articles of grocery.

ANECDOTE.--" There is something inexpressibly touching in an anecdote which I have heard of a foreign artist. He was an American, and had come hither, (he and his young wife,) to paint for fame and-a subsistence. They were strangers in England; they had to fight against prejudice and poverty, but their affection for each other solaced them under every privation, every frown of for. tune. They could think, at least,'

THE POTATO NOT INDIGENOUS TO SOUTH AMERICA.-A correspondent of the New-England Cultipator, over the initials of J. C. M., and writing from North Parsonslield, Me., asserts that Colonel MORE, of Caldwell. Member of Parliament, for the county of Renfrew, Scotland, has raised potatoes from the germ, obtained from clay thrown up from a depth of forty feet, while digging for water.

By the arrival of the steamship Jas. L. Day, Capt. TALBOT, we have received dates from Galveston to the 5th inst. A letter from Col. LoRING. commander of the forces on the Lower Rio Grande, says there are no Indians in that quarter, nor has there been any since the party that crossed the Rio Grande on the 8th or 9th Sept.

The slavery agitation, it seems, is to be renewed: and that, too, in just the shape which the Anti-Slavery men of the North would prefer above all others. For ten years past the laws of the State of New-York have prohibited slavery within its limits, in every case except that one for which special provision is made in the Constitution of the United States.

Secretary CORWIN has returned to his Post, and it is presumed that he will soon prepare his annual report. He has survived the defeat of SCOTT and the Gardiner case, and will probably live to drive his wagon and make stump speeches a long time yet.

Rev. Dr. CLEYELAND repeated by request his discourse on the death of Hon. DANIEL WEBSTER, last Sabbath evening. Hundreds were unable to obtain seats, so great was the interest to hear. Dr. CLEVELAND took his text from the 48th chapter of Jeremiah, and 17th verse, and proceeded to a consideration of the moral lessons that were to be learned from the event of Mr. WEBSTER'S death.

We take from the National Intelligencer the following interesting article, relating to the highly important Expedition about to set sail for the North Pacific and Japan Seas, in pursuance of an act of Congrcss, passed during the last Session on the Inotion of Senator SEWARD. The objects, advantages, and Equipment of the Expedition, are set forth in a clear, comprehensible, and interesting manner.

Of all that has lately been published in regard to the great departed Statesman, DANIEL WEBSTER, nothing has so deeply interested or affected me, as his two letters to JOHN TAYLOR-one written in March, 1822, and the other thirty years after. The letters are so characteristic of Mr. WEBSTER:

A rumor has obtained currency that during the pendency of the Compromise bills, Mr. FILLMORE, then Vice-President, had caused it to be understood that if it came to his casting vote, he should vote against them. The Republic makes the following statement in regard to this rumor:

CROSSING THE ISTHMUS.--When an uninitiated traveler crosses the Isthmus of Panama, he is likely to be well fleeced unless he possesses more than ordinary shrewdness and nerve. As a specimen of charges made upon such occasionally, we give, from the Panama Echo, the following experience of a small party who recently made the trip:

THE BROADWAY RAILROAD.-An attempt was made In the Board of Aldermen, Wednesday evening, to procure the adoption of the Report of the Special Committee on Broadway Railroad. The matter was, however, finally deferred till this evening, when the report is to be taken up and acted upon. The report of the Committee is decidedly in favor of the Railroad,

Yesterday being the day appointed for the funeral obEequies of the late Duke of WELLINGTON in London, a meeting was convened by the British residents of New-York, in Calvary Church, (kindly granted for the occasion by Rev. Dr. HAWKS) to hold a religious service in honor of the illustrious Commander.

Mr. THACKERAY delivers the first of his Series of Lectures this evening, at the Church lately occupied by Rev. Dr. BELLOWS, in Broadway. It is quite unnecessary for us to direct attention to these Lectures, as the interest already felt in them is quite sufficient to fill the house to overflowing.

The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLINS, has arrived at this port. She left Havana at 5 P. M. on the 15th inst., and Key West at 5.30 A. M. on the 16th. On the evening of the 15th, the Isabel saw the steamship Crescent City, Captain DAVENPORT, from NewOrleans, near the entrance of the harbor of Havana, and also saw a Spanish war steamer bearing down to her,

We have received dates from the City of Mexico up to the 20th ult., and Vera Cruz to the 30th ult. The United States steam-frigate Powhatan, Com. NEWTON commanding, arrived at Vera Cruz on the 1st. She had on board Judge CONKLIN, United States Minister to Mexico. The Powhatan left for Pensacola on the 2d.

EXCURSIONS.-On the 29th inst., the " Anderson and Johnson's Guards," composed mostly or Stone cutters, will go out of town for target practice at some place not yet designated. On the same day the "Buckskin Guards" parade for target practice, under the Captaincy of JOHN KELLY.

The LEMMON slave case has excited great interest and attention here. As an exposition of the laws of the free States respecting slavery, the opinion of Judge PAYNE, published in Monday's Times, has been eagerly read. Mr. LEMMON's case would seem to be a hard one, were it possible to believe that he did not know the risks he ran in taking his slaves to New York.

On Wednesday, Nov. 17, in the 77th year of her age, Mrs. JANE OLIVER, after a short and severe illness. Her friends and acquaintances, also those of her sons, Alexander. John and William, are respect fully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her son, 3d-av. near 71st-st., on Friday, Nov. 19 at 12 1/2 o'clock.

The bark Wm G. Levcis, from the Rio Grande, Oct. 3d, arrived at this port, brings dates from Buenos Ayres to the 11th Sept., and reports that on that day an altempt was made to overthrow the Government of UR??QIOZA, who was absent at the time, attending the Congress at Santa Fe. Many supposed that there would be a civil war.

In a few days more than a fortnight, the last session of the Thirty-second Congress will begin. The usual preparations are already advancing at Washingtoln. Senators, whose long terms justify the measure, prepare their metropolitan residences, if they have not done so before, for permanent occupation, where domestic comforts may solace the labors of Statesmanship.

The steamship Empire City, of which we were a passenger, landed us at Havana about 7 1/2 o'clock on the morning of the 17th instant. We made the More light at 12 o'clock on the night of the 29th, but as no vessel is allowed to enter the harbor before sunrise or after sunset, we were compelled to rise, and the officials of Havana think proper to follow this example.

We learn by letter from Montpelier that the Legislature of Vermont has passed an act remitting to the University of Vermont its claims against the institution, for about $5,000 borrowed some years since from the portion of the Surplus Fund assigned to Vermont, on the distribution of that fund among the several States.

The following are the official majorities in all the Counties in this State, except New-York, on the Presidential Electoral ticket. The stated majority in NewYork is added, and the whole foots up a majority for PIERCE and KING of over 27,000.

One thing at a time, my dear fellow, one thing at a time. If you attempt to lift both the twins and your wife over the stream at once, you will probably drop the doll of one of the little ones, and the bonnet of the other, and set the wife down ankle deep into the stream.

The Marshal's police succeeded in making an important arrest of counterfeiters to-day. Two women were arrested last night at the theatre for passing counterfeit half dollars, and the developments they made led to the capture to-day of LEWIS H. RIGGIN and WILLIAM SOTLER, the former for passing and the latter for making base coin.

By the arrival of the steamer Asia, we have three days later in? from all parts of Europe. The news is interesting in some respects, although not important. Both Houses of Parliament met on the 4th inst., the Duke of NOKTHUMBERLAND, the Marquis of SALISBURY, and the Parl of LONDSDALE representing the Queen in the House of Lords.

A correspondent of the Mayaville Eagle, under date of Nov. 8, says: I understand a mass meeting, consisting of the slaveholders of the Counties of Mason and Bracken. are to meet at Minerva, on the 16th inst, to take some steps for the further protection of slavery in the two Counties. I cheerfully concur in the propriety of the proposed meeting, and trust you will urge through your Paper a general attendance.

OYER AND TERM INER.-Before Judge EDWARDS, Aldermen WARD and DENMAN. The People vs. Nicholas Hewlett, and two others, indicted for the murder of Charles Baxter, by shooting Aim with a pistol, on the night of the 20th ot August last.The prisoner, Hewlett, who is quite a young man, not More than twenty, is a native of Nova Scotia. was put to the bar, and demanded a separate trial.

Mr. JOHN R. VAN RANST, one of the oldest settlers of Williamsburg, died very suddenly at his residence in North Second-street, during Wednesday night. He had been for several days pasts somewhat unwell, but his friends were in no way alarmed about him, and in the evening previous to retiring, he appeared very cheerful and conversed more than usual.

Our regatta came off to-day, and proved a brilliant affair. The first race was won by Mr. CoWPER, of Darien. Ga., with the Becky Sharp-the New-York boats, W. W. Woodworth and New-york being badly beaten-time, 6 minutes.

The British and North American mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, arrived at this port about 1 o'clock this morning from Liverpool, which place she left at 1 o'clock P. M. on Saturday, the 6th, bringing London and Liverpool advices of that date, and 80 passengers.

In 1776, Lord Hows having intimated to Congress, verbally, by General SULLIVAN, who had been his prisoner, his desire to confer with some of the members in a private unofficial way, on the subject of putting an end to their difficulties, BEJAMIN FRANKLIN, JOHN ADAMS, and EDWARD RUTLEDGE , were sent as a committee to hear what he had to say.

The following letter which we find in the lowa Republican, gives particulars of the affray at Sergeant Bluffs, Which resulted in the death of Major NORWOOD, Indian Agent for the Northern band of the Sioux Indians: LUDLOW'S GROVR, Wednesday, Sept 22. WILLIAM HAWK, Esq.---Dear Sir--Myself and Mr. McDONALD have just returned from Sergeant Biuffs, where we beheld, on night before last, Monday, the most awful tragedy my eyes ever witnessed.

SOCIETY FOR THE RELIEF OF WIDOWS WITH SMALL CHILDREN.--This old and most beneficent charitable Ladies' Association met yesterday morning at the Lecture Room in the Church of Rev. Dr. POTTS, in University Place. The following Report, read by the Secretary, sets forth the specific objects of the Institution, with the degree to which hitherto they have been attained:...

THE BROADWAY.--The BATEMAN CHILDREN appear this evening in three of their favorite characters--"Richard III," the "Young Couple," and the "Spoiled Child." To these performances is added the Comedietta of the "Woman I Adore." Mrs. MOWATT is at the residence of her brother-in-law, Dr. Wm. TURNER, in Twelfth-street, this City, recovering from a very severe attack of bronchitis. is.

OYER AND TERM INER,--Before Judge EDWARDS, Aldermen WARD and DENMAN. The People vs. Nicholas Hewlett.-The Jurors in this case, were kept in deliberation all Thursday night without having agreed on a verdict. The Court refused to discharge them, and up to noon they had not agreed. At 2 o'clock they came into Court, having agreed on a verdict.

We have St. John, N.B. papers of the 18th inst. There was good sicighting at Frederickton on the 16th, and it snowed all that day at ST. John. Accounts from Newfoundland, state that the Potatoe crop had proved an entire failure. Election excitement was running very high.

VESSEL LOST, AND THREE MEN DROWNED.--The schooner Asa, Wilcox, of Racine, was wrecked on Saturday, 7th, near Pier Marquette, on the west shore of Michigan, and is a total loss. We regret to learn that three of the seamen were drowned. We are indebted to Mr. HALL, of Pier Marquette. and Mr. HANCOCK, one of the survivors, for the following particulare:

At Saratoga Springs., 13th inst. aged 22. at the residence of her father SARAH ELIZABETH, wife of Henry Fowler Esq. of Chicago, ?? and only daughter of Hon. John Willard, Justice of the Supreme Court. At his residence, Blooming dale, on the 19th inst., JOHN LOW. in the 88th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family and those of her son in-la. Anthony H. McDonald,

Mrs. E. DAKES SMITH, last evening, delivered the Fourth Lecture of her present series, at Hope Chapel.The subject on the occasion was On Our Humanity. The fair lecturer commenced her remarks by observing that she had said in her two formerlectures, "that the sepsration of the sexes into entirely diverse spheres of action is unphilosophic, and at variance with the designs of the Creator, and that manifold disorders have been consequent upon this divorcement."

The Message of Governor ROANE to the Legislature of Arkansas fills ten columns. Its importance does not correspond to its length. A large portion of it is devoted to the consideration of Railroad projects, and the Governor carnestly recommends the introduction of Railways into the State. He advocates Memphis as a central point for Railroad lines from North to South, and adds:

TEMPERANCE MEETING.--The City Temperance Society held a meeting on Thursday evening, at the Methodist Protestant Church, in Grand-street, which was well attended. Mr. JOHN McINTOSH presided, and EDWARD H. ROWLANDSON, acted as Secretary. The Chairman stated that this Society was organized in April last, and had been in existence nearly seven months; during which time 207 signatures had been obtained.

We present our readers this morning interesting letters from our London and Paris correspondents, together with additional extracts from our foreign mail by the Asia, including the eloquent speech delivered by Mr. MACAULAY, the historian, before his constituents, at effort will be found an able and well written document -- valuable for its literery merit, even if it ad nothing else to recommend it.

FRONT EASTERN TEXAS.--The Marshall Republican says that the emigration to Texas this year will be larger than it has been in many years, and adds: "Every thing this season is favorable to immigrants coming into our State. The crops, we believe, have been generally favorable all over the South, andparticularly in Texas, and provisions are plentiful and cheap.

The clergy, unlike those in most other professions, enter into the heaviest part of their work at first. They accept a call, and at once have all their sermons to write, their lectures to prepare, their visits to make, just like their elder brethren, but without their abundance of " preparation " to assist them when cramped. Few other professions are so.

" What is quite as curious, the Times, in its reply, designates SHAKSPHEARE, MILTON, LOAD BACON, COLERIDGE and BURKE, as "at least equal to WEBSTER."--Post. The Phrase "at least equal," when used by the Times, was quoted from its correspondent's letter;--and now, bearing this in mind, will the Post be good enough to explain what there is in this, especially "curious!"

NIBLO's.--" Lucy of Lammermoor" was attempted to be rendered with the English libretto, on Thursday. It was not creditable to Mr. BOCHSA. His orchestra was like a volunteer army without a skillful leader, each playing or running on his own hook; the leader himself, mounted on the conductor's chair, learning his own lesson, book in hand, and beating time with his right foot with an energy only equalled by the fierceness of the big drum.

It is a well settled fact with our Government that the Spanish minister here does the diplomacy of Spain for the Island of Cuba. Senor CALDERON DE LA BARCA is an exceedingly able man. He is cautious and moderate. His vigilance is the most effectual obstacle to the success of the Fillibuster expeditions which are constantly in agitation against that colony of his royal mistress.

The full report of the Census has not, to our knowledge, reached our City as yet. The "Abstract" is before us, and contains some important information in a very compact form. In respect to territory, it appears that during the last ten years, we have extended the area of the United States from 2,055,153 to 3,230,572 square miles, without including the great lakes, or the sea-bays.

NAVAL.--The steam-frigate Princeton, having been completed in her repairs, is excepted to leave Baltimore this week for Aunapolis, where she will join the Mississippi, form whence both vessels will probably proceed to Norfolk. The following is a list of the officers of the Princeton. Commander--SIDNEY SMITH LEE. Lieutenants--B. Avery, Washington Gwathmey, Maye C. Watkins, Francis K. Murray, E. Lloyd Winder.

The events where with the 4th of November was freighted have transpired. On that day the British Parliament met in london, and the French Senate met in Paris. Both bodies played the parts previously assigned them Parliament, after dispatching the forms of organization, passed to the discussion of the funeral ceremonial of the Duke of WELLINGTON.

The Perrysburg Democrat is urgent for an appropriation of forty or fifty thousand dollars for the improvement of the Maumee River. It says that the Maumee is the largest and most beautiful river within the State of Ohio; that it is navigable at all times for the largest lake-craft, except during a gale from the south-west; that a great commercial interest is growing up at the foot of the rapids;

The quarterly examination of the pupils was held yesterday in the Chapel of the Institution, Fiftiethstreet. A train of Cars left the city at 1 1/2o'clock, for the accommodation of visitors, of whom there was a large and most respectable attendance. The seats on either side of the Chaped were occupied by the male and female pupils, while the centre was reserved for visitors.

MORE ARRESTS FOR COUNTERFEITING UNITED STATES COIN.--On Wednesday night, at the Arch-street Theatre, Officer ZELL. of the Marshal's Police, assisted by Conetable BARBER, arrested two females, charged with attempting to pass spurious American half-dollars, in pay for the hire of a chaise. They were taken to the Adolphi-street station-house, and detained untill yesterday afternoon.

DASTARDLY ATTEMPT AT ASSASSINATION.--The Cleveland Forest City of the 17th says: We have frequently been told of outrages committed of the C. C. C. Railroad, between this City and Columbus, by highbanded villains. who have usurped the power to chastise the conductors of trains, whom they conceive responsible for the destruction of property on the road; but we 'were informed on Friday last of a recent attempt at assassination on the road.

The Rev. BERNARD O'REILLY, of St. John's College, Fordham, on Thursday evening delivered the second lecture of a series now being given before the members of the Catholic Institute. The subject of the lecture was " Irish Emigration." The room was densely crowded, and the remarks of the lecturer elicited frequent applause from the audience.

The Washington papers publish the following official announcement of the settlement of the Lobes Islands difficulties. It will be recollected that Mr. WEBSTER, in his letter of the 21st of August, which was laid before Congress and has been extensively published, informed the Peruvian Charge d' Affaires that the United States would still consider the question of the lobos Islands as an open one,

We gather the following additional items of news from our foreign files, per steamer Asia. The Registrar General had issued his quarterly return of the marriages, births, and deaths registered in the divisions, counties, and districts of England. The marriages, births, and deaths in the return exceed tile average, so that the result is mixed; indicating great activity in all the sources of employment, but no general diminution in the causes of mortality.

THE MANCHESTER LEAGUE. The Manchester "League"--resuscitated, and once more in arms in defence of the great principle of free trade--had its banquet on Tuesday last, if "banquet " it can be called, when a sorry set-out of Sandwiches, pies and tarts and other semi-regetarian viands constituted the bill of fare.

NORTH CAROLINA U.S. SENATOR.--It is stated that a Caucus of the Democratic Members of the Legislature of North Carolina has nominated Hon. JAMES C. DOBBIN for United State Senator, to supply the vacaney which will occur on the 4th of March next. It is supposed that the Whigs will unite upon Hon. WILLIAM A. GRAHAM. The Democrats have one majority on joint ballot.

On Tuesday afternoon Mr. MACAULAY addressed the electors of Edinburgh for the first time since' his election in July last. It will be remembered that the right Hon. gentleman was on that occasion elected in his absence, and without his solicitation, and that, on receiving intimation of that gratifying fact, he promised to appear among the electors in a few days and thank them Ior their kindness.

The mail is through from New-Orleans. The papers contain the particulars of the late outbreak at Matamoros. It appears that CARDENAS, on assuming the Governorship of Tamaulipas, established and armed Military. Police, against which the Arguamento of Matamores protested. General CANALES undertook to uphold CARDENAS, but was hissed and hooted out of the room.

Having observed, from the comments ofa portion of the Press, that considerable misapprehension exists in regard to the legal grounds on which we sought to protect our client's rights, respecting his property, consisting of eight slaves, we take tills opportunity to correct that misapprehension. On the argument before Justice PAINE, we opposed the discharge of the slaves on, the ground, first:

The State elections in Massachusetts, on the 8th inst., proved to be a drawn game The majorities in favor of the Whigs were too meagre to denote the character of the future government; two or three votes, and they of an undecided stripe, constituting the plurality of that party in the Lower Legislative body. Thirty four representatives are the subject of a new trial on Monday next.

REPORTING PUBLIC DINNERS.--Among the most unenviable tasks that fall to the lot of reporters for the Public press, is that of reporting the proceedings at public Dinners. If 7 o'clock be the hour announced it is sure to the full 8 before soup is served; then comes the hour and a-half or two hours' devoted 10 knife and fork exercise.

DONATION VISIT.--The managers of the Brooklyn Protestant Orphan Asylum, acknowledge the receipt of $425 50, on their recent annual donation visit. Mrs. WOOD the Recording Secretary, in her report, says: "Although the weather was unfavorable, many of our citizens attended, and others who were afraid to venture out, have since sent in their usual contributions. The receipts in articles of food, clothing, shoes,, were greatly less than last year."

On Thursday afternoon a man, by the name of JOHN PASSANY, was terrialy injured on the Hudson River Railroad by being caught between two of the freight cars. His skull was fractured, his arms broken, and the police of the Twentieth Ward conveyed him to the residence of his father in Twenty-seventh-street, near the Tenth-avenue.

The want of ministers is becoming a matter of more frequent complaint in most of the religious denommations. From the representations of the papers, it would seem that a larger number of Churches are without regular preachers than at any previous time. It was recently stated that some ten or twelve of the large Congregational Churches in Newt Hampahire are vacant, as at Concord, Exeter, Boscawen, Nashua,

Our Regatta was concluded to-day. The following were the results: First Race--Tariff, first; Kate Kenan, second. The other starters care in the following order-Viola, Floyd, Wild Coose. Dickens, Daughter and Marion well up, and last of all DECKER'S Southerner. Time, 7 minutes--won by a third of a length. Second Race.--J W. Booth first by a good how-shot, beating Sylph, American Boy, Coquette, Charleston, and Pilot, Time, 7 minutes, 37 seconds.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In large cities, where but few of the inhabitants belong to the laboring professions, and where there is little opportunity for physical exercise, we must not wonder that offeminacy so generally prevails among both sexes--that soft hands and graceful limbs are preferable to developed forms, a healthy complexion; and vigorous muscles.

MORE PARTICULARS OF THE Loss OF THE BUCREYE BELLE.--D. ZINSMASTER, of Zanesville, was one of the killed. Wm. A. GILL, Esq., of this city, had a little daughter, about eleven years old, on the boat, on her passage from Marietta horne. The solicitude of the family to know her rate was intense, for a few hours, when they learned she had escaped unhurt.

We see it stated that Professor AMASA McCoY, of the Ballston Law School, is about to deliver a series of Lectures on the United States, in Canada. Just at this moment such an undertaking, in competent hands, cannot fail to be exceedingly useful.

The Senate being in session, and the Empire awakening at the present writing, one must say something of them, and if out of mere regard to the proprieties and congruities, though there is little new worth saying. Indeed, as the Empire is a restoration, not a creation, novelty should not be expected. Rumor, as usual, my grand authority, promises for the most part only antiquities.

Mr. Anthony Cogger informs the Newburyport Union that an Irish lad, in his family, ran away from Ireland a year or two since, received a letter a day or two since from some official personage at home, informing him that he has fallen heir to 10,000 besides the annual income of l,000. The boy is about sixteen years old, and came over here entirely destitute of means.

If the following notices are responded to, it is proposed that the ladies described below should meet at the same time and place, with the independent gentlemen advertised for in Thursday's Times, to form an Association or Phalanx for their mutual good.

PRAIRIE FIRES IN MINNESOTA AND WISCONSIN. The fires on the prairies have been very destructive. Between Stillwater and the Mississippi River, the loss in hay alone amounts to hundreds of tons; one man lost sixty. Mr. BISSELL, lost his fences, crops, stables, and everything but his house that could be burned, amounting in the aggregate to a large sum, and several of his neighbors suffered in alike manner.

Our new Gran Vizier, MEHEMET PASHA, is the fifth who has been in tbe office within year. He is brother-in-law of the Sultan, was originally a page of Sultan MAHOMED'S, has sustained the title of Grand Master of Artillery, of Minister of War, of Minister of the Marine, and now is Lieutenant of the State.

Messrs. CRANE and HILL, Reeve and Clerk, respectively, of Dunner and Burleigh, Canada, lately addressed a sort of memorial to the Legislature protesting, in the most republican manner, against the existence of the Clergy Reserves.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Will you please inform your readers if you or any one else has seen the Proclamation of the Governor of Connecticut for a Thanksgiving Day. I have seen a number of lists of the States where it was said to have been appointed, and in one of them only was Connecticut included.

Thanksgiving Day domes on apace, lot us prepare for it. For its turkeys and pumpkin pies, plum puddings and hickory nuts we are always prepared. For the reunion of old friends, the gathering together of scattered households, for the coming up of the old folks leaning on staffs, and the little ones reaching up to take hold of pa's big finger with their tiny hand, or bodily transported in nurse's arms;

SWINDLING BY A SHIP'S CAPTAIN.--The policeof Paris arrested on Saturday the captain of an English merchant ship, the Shakspere, under the following circumstances: In March last the Shakspere left the port of Canton, having on board an American. This American was very badly off, and had no goods; but he and the captain concocted a scheme for committing a fraud on a grand scale.

THE VOTE OF NORTH CAROLINA.-We publish the official vote of this State to-day in full, and also the Proclamation of Gov. REID convening the Electors in this city on the first Wednesday in December next, to cast the vote of the State for President and Vice-President.

The American schooner Gladiator, Capt. MOREY, rom Prince Edward Island, for Boston, with mackerel, barley and oats, struck on Jedore ledges, twenty miles east of Halifax, yesterday morning, and went down in ten minutes. The crew took to the boats, and were picked up three hours afterwards, and brought here.

The morning frieght train on the Syracuse and Utica Railroad, this morning started from the East at 4 o'clock, drawn by two locomotives. When about three-quarters of a mile from this depor, the foremost locomotive--the Achilles--exploded with terrible and disastrous consequences. The boiler exploded in the fire box.
NEW-YORK-THE OFFICIAL VOTE.-An error occurred in the official vote of Rensselaer County, as published a day or two since. The vote as published stood thus :

The brick cornice of RICHE'S Leather Store, on North Third-street, fell this morning upon the pavement, terribly injuring Mr. THOMAS GRAHAM, an elderly gentleman, who was passing at the time. A boy also had an arm broken. Workmen were adding a fourth story to the building.

The membership of the Norfolk-street Baptist Church was formed some ten years since, and service held in a small building on the site of the Church now standing in Norfolk, near Broome-street. The present commodious and handsome edifice was erected about four years since, by Rev. THOMAS ARMITAGE,

One of the Cochituate water pipes on the Boston Common, burst on Thursday morning, flooding the Common, especially in the vicinity of the parade ground, to a considerable extent, before the damage could be repaired. The catalogue of the Genesee Wesleyan Seminary at Lima shows that the aggregate number of pupils during the past year has been 988, of whom 483 were females.

Tile Emperor of the French has thought proper to release ABD-EL-KADER. The unfortunate Arab has suffered a weary imprtsonment, and accepts his discharge with corresponding gratitude. The Emperor spares no endeavors to magnify the favor.
We are glad to learn, as we do from the Journal of Commerce, that the sum of 35,200 has been raised by contribution among tile Merchants, to indemnify Mr. LEMMON for the loss of his Slave.

CANADIAN RECIPROCITY.--The Albany Argus, of the 16th inst., states that there was a conference held at the Executive Chamber on the 15th-Governor HUNT, Mr. MERRITT, long a member of the Provincial Parliament, and Hon. DAVID L. SEYMOUR, Chairman of the Committee on Commerce of the House of Representatives, being present-with reference to the reciprocity question, a matter of high interest at this time in both countries.

Having copied from the Republic a statement upon the relations of Mr. FILLMORE to the Compromise bill, and upon certain statements on that subject in the Albany Evening Journal, we give: the following in reply from that paper:

Captain CARS. TOWNER, and CHAS. ??, canal boatmen, were arrested at New Hope, on the Delaware canal, last night, charged with paasing counterfeit hal dollarss. Several hundred dollars in spurious coin were found in their possession.

PLEASURES OF DISPENSING OFFICES.--The Hon. STEPHEN A. DOUGLAS, Senator of the United States, and prospective Secretary of State for the same, arrived at New Orleans yesterday morning, and departed in the afternoon per mail boat for Mobile, en route, it is supposed, for the Federal Metropolis.

The affairs of Mexico approach the longanticipated crisis. The insurrection in Guadalajara has gathered strength, and resisted all efforts of Government to repress it, until it may be regarded as entirely out of danger. Gen. URAGA, if the telegraph speak honestly.

Letters containing money having frequently miscarried, of late, between Richmond and Batilmore Mr. McGUIRE, Special Agent of the Post Office Department, on Friday mailed a decoy letter in Virginia, addressed to a Banking-house in Baltimore. It contained worthless bank bills and a marked quarter dollar.

On Thursday night, a fire broke out in STAHL'S Mill, situated on the Eighteen Mile Creek, Niagara County, just below the site of the "Old Farmers' Mill," which completely destroyed that valuable property and its adjoining buildings. The fire is supposed to have originated in the smut-machine. Loss in neighborhood of $15,000, which is partly covered by Insurance.

GREAT FIRE IN TODDSVILLE, N.Y. --On Tuesday night last, between 12 and 1 o'clock, the Paper Mill of Messrs. TODD SONS, situated in the village of Toddsville, was together with its contents, entirely consumed. The fire broke out in the upper part of the building. It is supposed that the fire must have originated from spontaneous combustion among the rags. The loss of the Messrs. TODD, over and above insurance.

DEATH OF EX-GOVERNOR SHULTZ.--Hon. JOHN ANDREW SHULTZ, ex-Governor of Pennsylvania,died Friday morning last in the city of Lancaster. Mr. SHULTZ had probably arrived at nearly eighty years of age. He was bred to the pulpit, but was obliged to give up preaching, at an early day, in consequence of some physical affection.

THE BREACH OF PROMISE CASE.--The case of SUSAN MARIA LEARNED vs. ALFRED WATKYNS, for breach of promise, which has occupied the attention of the Circuit Court for several days past, closed last night, with a verdict of $3,500 for the plaintiff. There are but very few points of interest in this case, although the testimony was somewhat elab orate.

MANUFACTURING IN NEWBURYPORT.--The manufactories of Newburyport are gradually recovering from their severe depression, though much more slowly than they would do had they a sufficiency of working capital. At the meeting of the Globe Mills Company on Monday, it was stated that the profits of the last six months had been $12,600, which sum has been applied to the reduction of the debt of the Company.

YALE COLLEGE.--The annual Catalogue of this venerable Institution, just issued, shows that there are four hundred and forty-four undergraduates, and one hundred and fifty-seven in the departments of Theology, Law, Medicine, and Philosophy, now connected with the College-total, six hundred and three.

A meeting will be held in Albany on the 12th of Jan. next, for the purpose of considering a plan for a College, to be located in this State, whose aim shall be the dissemination of Practical Science, Including Chemistry, Geology, Mineralogy, and those sciences most immediately and vitally essential to agriculture and the useful arts, and in whose management the feature of manual labor shall be prominent.

By the arrival of the bark D. Godfrey, we have received dates from Rio Janeiro to the 3d October. The news is not important. The Commission appointed to adjust the Boundary question between Brazil and Uruguay had set out from Rio. The protest of the Brazilian Minister against the Treaty recently concluded between the Argentine Confederation and the Republie of Para guay, had been published.

" UNCLE TOM" LITERATURE.--Norton's Literary Gazette ciphers up the number of volumes, relating directly or indirectly to the subject of Slavery, which have appeared since the publication of Mrs. STOWE'S remarkable work. Three separate editions of that book itself are published in this country, and it is reported that a pamphlet edition has appeared in California.

The U. S. Mail steamship James Adger, Capt. JOHN DICKINSON, from New-York, arrived at her what. in this city, last (Friday) night. PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, Nov. 20. The steamship City of Glasgow sailed for Liverpool at 9 o'clock this morning, with38 passengers and $15,000 in specie.

The mail is through from New-Orleans. Seventeen deaths from Yellow Fever and eleven from Cholera, occurred at New-Orleans during the week ending 15th inst. At Charleston there were ten deaths from Yellow Fever during the past week.

RUM BOTTLES OUTLAWED.--The following case, tried in the Quarter Session of Berks County is reported in the Reading Gozette: A wife indicted her husband for assault and battery, committed under the following circumstances: They were returning home together in a wagon, from market-the husband provided with a 'pocket pistoi,' veil loaded, from which he took sundry ' swigs,' until he became 'shot.'

Issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending Nov. 16, 1852, and bearing date Nov. 16, 1852. Charles L. Barnes, of New-York, N. Y.-For improvement in expanding bits. Levis H. Davis, Samuel and Morton Pennock, ofKehnett square, Pa;-For improvement in seed planter. Lewis S. Chichester, of Brooklyn, N. Y.-For improvement in flax pullers.

The Oneida Telegraph has a piece of news which will be highly gratifying in Wall street in speaking of our remarks on the election of GERRIT SMITH to Congress, it says: "The most unfavorable notice of Mr. SMITH'S election that we have seen is that of the New-York Times, which our readers will find in another column.

The Oswego Times notices an iron frame recently put in the Starch Mill in that city. The statement sounds almost fabulous, and will be apt to make simple people state. The main posts and beams in the factory, which have decayed, have been taken out and replaced by this huge iron frame. which is formed of hollow iron columns upon when are cast iron beams with wrought iron trusses.

The dyeing and drying rooms, two buildings, each 100 feet long, attached to the new bleaching establishment at Gloucester, New-Jersey, were entirely destroyed by fire last evening. Loss, $20,000, insured principally in Providence and this city This part of the same establishment was destroyed by fire a year since, and the new buildings had just been built and put into operation.

SHOCKING CIRCUMSTANCE.--A young man by the name of CAVENDER came into town on Tuesday, the day of the election, and drank more liquor than he should have done. In the evening when a large crowd of men had assembled, in a sort of a muss, on the west side of the square, he mounted a horse belonging to another man, and rode in among them.

TERRIFIC ACCIDENT.-An accident of a very unusual character occurred yesterday about 12 o'clock, In the foundry of James L. Haven Co., on the corner of Broadway and Liberty-streets. In a small room in the second story of the building, were stationed three grindstones, which were propelled by steam-power, and on which three Germans were engaged grinding hinges.

" I have prepared a supper, and am expecting a few friends," said ASMODEUS. Then I saw what on entering the room had escaped my notice, that my little table was elongated and upheld some dainty viands. "A poor collation," he proceeded. " not a supper exactly. Quite supplementary or intercalary quite a poor thing.

Mlle. CAMILLE URSO gives a farewell Concert on Thursday evening, at Niblo's Saloon. For this occasion she has engaged the services of Mrs. GEORGIANA STUART, who sing several popular airs, Mr. ROBERT HEELER, an eminent Pianist, and Mr. BRISTOW, as Conductor. Mlle URSO will herself give several violin performances. ces.

GENTLEMEN-We hand you herewith one hundred dollars towards making Mr. JONATHAN LEMMON good for the loss of his servants, under a legal decision of one of our State Courts-a decision which, in our humble opinion, could not have been otherwise. We know of several cases of servants having been brought here by their owners from the South, enticed a way and not recovered.
We understand that the Churchman is to be edited hereafter by Rev. H. N. HUDSON well known by his Lectures on SHAKSPERE and other literary productions. It has been purchased by Mr. JOHN HECKER.

On Saturday morning, 20th inst., MARY ANN, wife of Alfred Colvill The friends of the family and those of her brother, John McKeon, are invited to attend her funeral on Tuesday. the 23d inst., at 3 o'clock. P.M., from her late residence, 5th av., 4th house above 27th st. t.

INQUEST.--On Thursday last, Coroner Donly of Gravesend, at Fort Hamilton, held an Inquest on the body of a man found drowned at that place, supposed to be Weliam Z, Culbertson, of Ohio. The deceased was clothed with black cloth pants, black silk vest, black silk cravat, bottle green coat, and dark brown overcoat. In height about four feet five inches. A gold watch was found upon his person, also $55 in bank bills.

From the New-Orleans Picayune, Nov. 12. The steamship Yacht, Cant. AULD, arrived at this port on Wednesday night, from Brazos Santiago. We received by her a copy of the Brownsville Flag, of the 30th ult., which contains not a line of news of any kind.

On Friday night, Mr. THACKERAY delivered the first, in his course of six lectures upon the Humorous Writers of the last century. In compliance with a request made on his behalf that his lectures might not be reported, we confined ourselves on Saturday morning to an editorial notice of its general character.

We doubt if twenty men could be found in all Gotham to regret the announcement which appeared in the Times of Thursday, that the price of tickets to the popular lectures which are in course of delivery at the Tabernacle was reduced from 25 to 12. cts. each.

SOUTHERN RIGHTS AND PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES.--Close upon Election Day, we published a correction of Gov. TROUP'S letter of acceptance of the Presidential nomination, tendered him by the Southern Rights party. The ex-Governor was earnest in remonstrance against unwarranted liberties which, he claimed, had been taken with his first published epistle;

TAKING IT COOLLY.-Next day after election, a Whig wrote the editor of the Detroit Free Press as follows: DETROIT, Wednesday, Nov. 3. S. M. JOHNSON, Esq.: DEAR SIR: Having now discovered " Who Franklin Pierce is," I hasten to enclose you my check for fifty dollars in payment for the information. and at the same time to wipe out a small bet I made with you on the State of Pennsylvania.

FUNERAL OF CAPT. J. R. VAN RANST.-The funeral of Mr. VAN RANST, who died suddenly on Wednesday night last, took place from his late residence in North Second-street. at one o'clock yesterday afternoon. The procession, as it moved through Grand-street, was very imposing. The procession came in the following order:

Mr. SLEEPER: Sir,-I send you for publication the remarks made by me at a late medical dinner. I am not confident that it is in the precise terms which I then used, but it is a correct account of the incidents to which I referred on that occasion. Your obedient servant, JOHN JEFFRIES.

A WEDDING IN A JAIL.-JOHN LOFTIS and ELLEN McCLUSKY were united in the bonds of wedlock, on Saturday last, in Bergen Jail; the ceremonies being performed by a priest of the Roman Catholic Church. The jaw had decided that the bridegroom was under obligations to the bride, which warranted his imprisonment until he should summon his courage for a change of relations, by way of experiment.

Having published an article from the Philadelphia Bulletin, signed by one of the Presenters of Bishop DOANE, we of course give place to the following in reply: A WORD OR TWO WITH " ONE OF THE PRESENTERS."

The Northampton Gazette says: "Oliver Graves, aged 92; Justin Morton; aged 91; and Consider Morton, brother to Justin. aged 94, of Whately. were born in the same house, voted for Gen. Washington and have voted at every Presidential election. We doubt whether another such remarkable trio can be found in the Commonwealth. Col. Samuel Thompson, of Amherst, a revolutionary pensioner, over 99 years old voted for Scott.

The Sardinian Government has transported the remains of the exiled GIOBERTI back to Turin. Another instance to the many of popular debts paid with posthumous honors. GIOBERTI, the Scholar, Christian, and Patriot, is only welcome to his native Italy, dead!

Last week was twice performed at the Bowery Theatre, BARIMOOR'S drama of "WILLIAM WALLACE." The scenery was beautiful; the company, especially EDDY and DAWES, did that in which SHAKESPEARE says, "all the honor lies;" and, consequently, although the play is a very poor one, on both evenings the house was crowded.

" Old Boreas" has been in a dreadful rage over and around the environs of Lake Erie for the last few days, and has scattered the relicts of his devastating power all along the shore. Between this point and Buffalo, numerous vessels are laid up on the beach or, in other words, pretty permanently located on terr-firma.

Fromn the San Francisco Whig. The accident occurring to the clipper-ship Gazelle, [at Cape Horn, on her late voyage from New-York to San Francisco,] was one of those narrow escapes to which sea faring life is incident and which is often the fatal termination of the voyage commenced with so many proud and happy auspices.

It may not be generally known to the' people of the United States, that comprised within the limits of the good State of New-York, there are two Southports. One sufficiently well known lies in Connecticut, the other and more retiring Dromio is obscurely nestled upon a creek in Long Island.

THE RUMORED OUTBREAK AT BUENOS AYRES.--We stated, yesterday, on the authority of letters from Rio Grande, that an attempt had been made at Buenos Ayres to overthrow Gen. UEQUIZA, the conqueror of ROSAS, and the present temporary head of the Buenos Ayrean Republic. Whether there was a general rising of the people of the city, or whether it was one of those periodical outbreaks so common in that region, we are not informed.

The Nationat Intelligencer states that M r Richard Cole, some twenty years ago engaged as a compositor in that office, but now employed by the London Missionary Society, in China, has made a most successful attempt in casting type by which books can be printed in Chinese characters. The extensive paper mill belonging to A. H. Todd Brother, of Cooperstown, was destroyed by fire, Nov. 17.

By the arrival of the bark D. Godfrey, of Boston, TREADWELL, master, we have dates from Rio Janeiro to the 3d ultimo. Our files contain nothing of interest. Much interest was felt at Rio on account of an agreement entered into by the largest importing houses, regulating the transactions between the importers and the jobbers.

JUBILEE COLLEGE--LETTER FROM BISHOP WHITEHOUSE.--Bishop WHITEHOUSE, of Illinois, late Rector of St. Thomas's, in this city, has written an interest letter to Dr. DAVID RUTEN; of Chicago, which we find in the Chicago Tribune. It says of Jubilee College and the services of the late Bishop CHASE:

The Governors of the New-York Hospital have addressed a statement to the public, in which they call attention to the magnitude and extended usefulness of the Institutions under their care. These Institutions are the City Hospital proper, located in Broadway opposite Pearl-street, and the Bloomingdale Asylum for the Insane.

The opinions of the Bench of Judges of the Superior Court, of New Hampshire, respecting the constitutionality of the Liquor Bill, were read in the Senate on the 19th inst. TRAGICAL AFFAIR IN MISSISSIPPI.--An affray occurred a few days since, on the steamer C. F. Watkins, while lying opposite the residence of Judge JAMES, of Washington County, which resulted in the death of THOMAS CARNEAL, Jr., and probably of Judge JAMES also.

ANOTHER BOGUS OPERATION.--CHARLES TONER, Captain, and CHARLES BOSSHEIMER, of the canal boat J. Lovett, were arrested on Friday night, at 12 o'clock, about a mile this side or New-Hope, by JOHN JENKINS and SAMUEL HALZELL, Deputios of the U.S. Marshal, on a charge of counterfeiting and passing counterfeit half-dollars.

DEDICATION OF THE ALBANY CATHEDRAL.--The imposing ceremony of dedicating the Albany Cathedral--the second Cathedral dedicated in this State--according to the rites and usages of the Roman Catholic Church. were performed yesterday in the presence of the largest congregation ever before collected in this city, on any occasion of a similar character. Most Rev. Archbishop Hughes, of New-York;

We have returns from about 60 towns for the election of Representatives, on which depends the political complexion of the State. In Boston, owing to the Anti-Maine Law men refusing to support all the regular Whig ticket, 7 representatives only were elected, the other 5 being defeated.

Wilcox, wrecked on the west shore of Lake Michigan. Three men lost. November l0-Schooner-D. Newhall. lost 13 barrels of beef and damaged 900 bushels of wheat.

The Board of Education have purchased four lots of ground on South Fourth-street, near Eighth, for the purpose of erecting a Primary School house. The Union Avenue Washingtonian Total Abstinence Society are to have another or their interesting meetings this evening, at the First Mission M. E. Church, in Union-avenue.

The People vs. Aaron Diamond, indicted with one Joshua Fensher, for Arson in the First Degree, in selling fire to the dwelling house of John Nally, situate No. 25 Roosevelt-street, was put to the bar. If a man only knew beforehand that he was going to be born, how many little arrangements he would like to make preparatory to his birth. He would doubtless have a choice whether he should be born into the Empire of France, or of Quashee-land, which lies a hundred leagues to windward of the unexplored portions of Ethiopia, or under the refreshing shadow of the American flag.

The Twenty-ninth Anniversary meeting of the New-York Bible Society was held, in the Tabernacle, last evening. The attendance was thinner than on previous occasions, but larger than could have been hoped from the inclemency of the weather.- The -proceedings opened with an anthem, sung by a full choir.

WARREN, in relation to a death by chloroform, accidentally administered at the Massachuselts General Hospital. The U. S. Mail steamer Crescent City, Lieut. HENRY K. DAVENPORT, U. S. N., commanding, arrived at her wharfearly yesterday morning, from New Orleans vid Havana, leaving the latter port on the afternoon of the 16th. A succession of heavy northerly gales, which she has encountered, accounts for the unusual length of the trip.

THE MUSKINGUM DISASTER.--Hon. C. C. COVEY, Member of the Senate from Marietta, who had his leg broken was otherwise injured by the explosion of the Buckeye Belle, is dead: His loss will be severely felt in Southern Ohio. His talents were of a high order and he was universally esteemed. He died on the 17th.

Two men were taken about 11 o'clock last night, while in the act of robbing a grave in the Catholic burying ground, near this city. They confessed that they had already taken up one body, and that it was in a vacant lot near the burying ground. The officers proceeded to the spot and found the body, which proved to be that of a female lately deceased at the Hospital.

The mail to-night brings nothing south of Mobile. The Virginia Legislature met at Richmond to-day. It being an adjourned session no message was received from the Governor, and both Houses organized under the officers previously chosen. The Baltimore Patriot says it learns on reliable authority,

WINTER LECTURES.--Much interest in Public Lectures is manifested at present in Jersey City. A Lecture Association has been formed which contemplate a series of Winter Lectures. We understand that they will be delivered each week, alternately by those from abroad and those residing in Jersey City.

The British mail steamship Dec left Vera Craz on Thursday, the 4th, touched at Tampico on the 5th, and arrived at Havana on the 12th inst. She brings three days later news from the city of Mexico. Owing to a severe norther at Tampico, the Dec was compelled to leave that port without the mails or specie intended for her.

AGRICULTURE IN ALBAMA.--Extract of a letter from a friend in Alabama: "I have been most industriously engaged since the 9th August, more than two months of the time absent from home, and in thirty or more countries. In all, I observed an increased and increasing moral improvement, and in most a rapid progress in agricultural improvements, means of transportation, inter-communication.

THE NEW-ENGLAND COURSE OF LECTURES.--The Fourth Lecture of the New-England course will be delivered at the Brooklyn Institute this evening by H. N. HUDSON, Esq., who has chosen for his subject "Falstaff." The next lecture of the course will be delivered by HORACE MANN.

THE CANALS OF THE STATE.--The Canal Commissioners have determined not to designate any day for closing the canals of the State--being desirous that navigation should continue as long as the weather will permit. Although this determination is not in accordance with the general usage, it will, no doubt, be more in conformity to the wishes and interest of most commercial men and of all doing business upon the canal, or interested in canal navigation.

On the 10th inst. the bark Byron, PINKHAM, master, bound from Laguna for New-York, arrived here in a leaking condition. The Surveyors appointed have ordered her cargo, which consists of logwood, to be discharged, when another survey will be held to estimate repairs, should they be deemed necessary.

The Galveston News says in is in contemplation by the New School portion of the Presbyterian church to affect a regular organization of their denomination in the State sometime soon. The body embraces about 150,000 communicants, and a large number of clergymen eminent for their piety and talents.

THE LEMMON INDEMNITY.--The amount subscribed to the fund designed to indemnify Mr. LEMMON for the loss of his eight slaves, has reached $5,280 This is $280 more than was asked for. THE LAST WEEK'S MORTALITY.-The City Inspector reports that for the week ending Nov. 20, there were in this City 282 deaths, viz: 55 men, 60 women, 92

The steamship Crescent City arrived at this part yesterday morning, from Havana on the 16th inst. Her arrival was delayed by a succession of heavy northerly gales. Her reception at Havana was peaceable, but the old tone of menace was still employed. The steamer arrived off the Moro on the evening of the 15th, and remained outside until the next morning.

WALLACK'S--The comedietta of "Two Can Play at that Game," with LESTER and Miss KEENE; the comedy of the "Soldier's Daughter," and the laughable farce of "High Life Below Stairs," are all to he played this evening. NIBLO'S--KNOWLES'S comedy of the "Love Chase," is to be performed this evening--BROWNE playing Wildrake, and Miss FITZPATRICK, Constance.

UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA.-On Monday evening, the 15th inst., the Rev. GEORGE POTTS, D. D., New-York, delivered the annual oration before the alumni of the University of Pennsylvania, at their hall in Philadelphia. The oration occupied two hours in the delivery, and was listened to with unflagging attention.

One of our exchanges reports the following as the gist of an exhortation by a colored preacher to his congregation. Taking the Bible in his hands, he said: " What I see in dis book, dat I do. If dis book tells me to go troo a stone wall, I run al it-dat's my part. Going troo it belongs to de Lord. I do my share when I run at it." Now,

THE "NORTHERN LIBERTIES, "PHILADELPHIA.--The new registry of the various properties in the incorporated District of the Northern Liberties, gives the annexed statistical information: There are 6.432 dwelling houses in this District. Of this number 2,358 are three storied brick houses, with two rooms on each floor; 1,347 with one room on cash floor; 110 are four-storied dwellings.

"The vital principal of Austria is so strong," said Prussia's greatest monarch, "that even long-continued misgovernment has not succeeded in extinguishing it." The Austrians themselves, (writes the Times correspondent.) who take a less philosophicat view of the matter, attribute the extraordinary success which has hitherto attended this country to "luck," and the events of the last lew years have not a little confirmed them in this.

Yonder white cottage opposite the church, and half hidden among those beautiful maples, is our country parsonage. Its occupant is Rev. Mr. JOHNSON, who, for twenty--five years past--quite a long time, by the way, in this day of frequent changes--has been our beloved pastor.

The Students of the university of vermont, feeling anxious to show to the world that the death of DANIEL WEBSTER had made a deep impression upon their hearts, held a meeting a few deys age, and appointed Rev. J. WHEELER, D.D., former President of the University, to deliver an eulogy upon the character and services of the great New England statesman and orator.

Our accounts from Madrid are of the 3d inst. It was rumored that M. BRAVO MURILLO intended to resign the direction of the Finance Department, and to retain only the Presidency of the Council. According to a return, published by the Gazette, the receipts of the Treasury, during the month of Sept., were 102.034,100 reals. They had amounted, during the corresponding month of 1851, to 105,376,000 reals.

OVER AND TERMINEER.--Refore Judge EDWARDS, Aldermen WAID and DUDLEY HALEY. The People vs. William Sant and -- Johnson, indicted for the murder of the Watchman Baxier.--These prisoners, both youths under twenty, were put to the bar to take their trial for the same offence that Hewlett was convicted of. Mr. Wheaton, of Albay, who defended Hewlett, had been assigned by the Court to defend these prisoners, but he did not appear.

By the arrival of the steamer Hermann at this port, we have received dates from Europe fourdays later than our previous advices. The news turns upon the course of events in France. The Empire in France is finally recstablished, and the Prince-President assumes the title of NAPOLEON III.

King OTHO was expected in Athens on the 28th ult., and great preparations were being made for his reception. The Ministry hope to protest by the manifestations of loyalty against the rumor which had arisen, that the King would be induced to abdicate immediately in favor of his brother; as well as other intrigues, which are supposed to be at the bottom of the question of the succession.

A SUGGESTION.--A lady makes the following suggestion: "It may be well, as Thanksgiving is near at hand, to remind our benevolent eltizens, that there is a new institution just commenced, which consists of a family of twenty-two old ladies, who have all seen better days.
The Picayune has received letters from the City of Mexico, which state that ARISTA has demanded to head the troups himself against the revolutionists.

Harrowing.--In conducting this operation, the harrows pass over the ridge either longitudinally or across. At the end of the ridge they are turned, and generally pass again over the same ground. This is called a double turn of the har rows. When they do not return over the same ground, but pass to another space, they are said to give a single turn.

King OSCAR is still seriously ill of nervous fever, the sickness which was fatal to his son. A regency has just been appointed, composed of Sweedish and Norwegian members, to govern the two kingdoms until his Majesty's recovery.

The Board of Trade, in this city, has called a convention of the various merchants, planters, farmers, and business men, generally, of the Southern and Western States, to meet at Baltimore on the 19th of December next, to consider the progress of the Southern and Western States in their direct interest with Europe, regarding internal trade, and also with a view to stimulate commercial affairs.

HOUSE OF REFUGE, RANDALLL'S ISLAND.--The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of the House of Refuge, in Randall's Island, for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents in this City, was postponed until to day, in consequence of the unfavorable state of the weather.

New-York Historical Society--COURSE OF LECTURES: 1852--1853--FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE FIRE PROOF BUILDING FUND.--The Committee on Lectures have to annunce that the Course of Lectures for the benefit of the Fire Proof Building Fund will be opened at Metropolitan Hall, on THURSDAY EVENING, Dec. 2, 1852.
Nearly all the Towns in which elections took place yesterday have been heard from, and show the choice of 37 Whigs, 32 Coalition, and 2 National Democrats.

**** At Pittsheld, Mr. FRANCIS GRAN??GER came into the cars as a passenger, and he too, was most rapturously cheered. Thus we came and arried here, at 8 1/2 o'clock. At the depot the crowd was immense.

The actual session of Parliament commenced on the 11th inst. The speech from the throue was read by the Queen in person, and is more lengthy than usual, extending to over one thousand words. The following embraces the main features.
The Kolner Zcitung has a telegraphic dispatch from St. Petersburg, announcing the death of the Duke MAX of Leuchtenberg. His Imperial Highness died on the 5th inst.

Many persons who, in days gone by, have taken a lively interest in the welfare of Messrs. ENG and CHANG BUNKERS, the celebrated Siamese Twins, may be glad to learn that these gentlemen are well, and live at Mount Airy.

The Senate met on the 4th of Nov., in accordance with the summons of the President of the Republic, and was opened by Prince JEROME BONA PARTE in a brief speech, stating the object of the meeting. The following message from the President was then read:

On Sunday, 21st inst., by Rev. Mr. Henson, AUGUSTUS H. SMITIH, of Sing Sing, to MISS ELIZA J. KEYES. daugh'er of John S. Keyes, Esq. of East Brooklyn. At Stamford. Conn. 23d inst.. by Rev E. D. Bryant, Mr. JOHN ABENDRUOTH of this City, to MISS AMANDA W., daughter of Isaac B. Redneld, of the former place.
An attempt will be made by cliques, local and political, of the universal Democratic party, to obtain exclusive possession of General PIERCE's confidence and to control his Admistration.

The New-York Historical Society promises an attractive course of Lectures for this Winter. Among the gentlemen whose services have been engaged, are Hon. RUFUS CHOATE, Hon. GEO. BANCROFT, Hon. EDWARD EVERETT, Hon. PIERRE SOULE, Hon. JOHN A. DIX, Rev. Dr. Hawks and CHAS. O'CONOR, Esq.

The Whig states that Mr. ASHMEAD, Clerk of the steamship Richmond, has been removed from that ??easel for practicing deception towards Mr. LEMMON, the owner of the slaves recently set free in New-York.

The Mail is through from Now-Orleans. Governor JOHNSON, of Virginia, has called the attention of the Legislature to the recent Slave Case in New York. He does not recommend any specific action, but says when he obtains a certified copy of the proceedings in the case, he will make it the subject of a communication.

We publish this morning a very interesting collection of public documents relating to the efforts of the United States to purchase the island of Cuba from Spain. It seems that this subject has engaged the attention of our government at intervals for the last thirty years; and that among the official papers recently transmitted to Congress upon the subject are letters from Mr. CLAY, Mr. WEBSTER other distinguished men.

The Customs' Conferences were opened on the 30th, when Count BUOL SCHAUNSTEIN delivered a long speech in which it is distinetly said that if the existing Zoloverein should be dissolved, a new one, including a population of 18,000.000, will be formed. The Austrian Minister concluded by solemaly declaring that, far from wishing to bring about the rain of the present Union.

One of the slaves belonging to JOHN JONAS, of Montgomery County, Mid., has been sentenced to death or committing a rape on a white woman. A heavy rain and snow storm prevailed here last evening. The mail has failed this morning beyond Raleigh.

* The Newburyport Herald says the manufactories in that city are gradually recovering from their severe depression, though much more slowly than they would do if they had a sufficiency of working capital.

After much delay, opposition, protest, and general contention, in the Provinces, the great railways proposed for some time past in the North are beginning to be distinguishable; and we see the outlines of what will he soon accomplished facts.

Passed Midshipman DAVENPORT'S recent course at Havana is severely censured by the Government, and he has been removed from the Crescent Cite and ordered to the Vincennes, now fitting for a three years' cruize in the Pacific.

CRYSTALOTYPES.--We have received from Mr. J. A. WHIPPLE, of Boston, some speciments of this recent discovery in the Photographic Art. It would seem that the uses of the daguerreotye, like those of steam, are yet far from being fully revealed. The Crystalotype was discovered in France. A daguerreotype is taken on a thick plate of glass, from which any number of impressions can be transferred to paper, after the manner of ordinary copper-plate engraving.

On Saturday morning last, a man was found upon the track of the railway at Mansfield. Mass., entirely dead. He appeared to have been killed by the steamboat train of the last evening, from Boston to Providence. The right arm was severed from the body above the elbow, and the skull was also wounded severely.

More than one hundred of the friends of a direct line of railroad from this city, north to Plattsburg, in Clinton County, assembled in convention at the Hall of the Young Men's Association this afternoon.

Dispatches had been received from St. Peters burg, announcing that the Emperor had selected to attend the funeral of the late Duke of WELLINGTON three officers of most distinguished service and high rank, namely, General of Infantry Prince CORTZAKOW: Major-General Count BENKENDORF, Imperial Military Commissioner at Vienna; and a Colonel.

Accounts from Constantinople to the 21st ?? have been received via Vienna. The remainder of the funds intended for the reimbursement of the first payment of the loan was sent off by the English packet of the 19th. It could not be sent by the French packet in consequence of the difficulty in procuring gold, and particularly foreign gold.

Cleared. Ships Living Age. Holmes, San Francisco. Carey Co.; John Wood. (Br.) Archer, Charleston. Stett Brothers Co.; Probus, Weeks. Antwerp. E. D. Hurlbut Co. Barks Franklin. Mitchell, Matramoros, J. W. Ellwell Co.; Montezuma. Hausen, Demerara

The new Lord Mayor of London was sworn in on the 9th, before the Barons of the Exchequer. The foreign refugees in London, celebrated on the 9th inst., the anniversary of the death of ROBERT BLUM, an event which is recalled to mind by a banqulet at Freemasons' Hall.

The Governor's Message was delivered to the legislature to-day, and is a long and able document. It represents the Bank of the State to be in a highly prosperous condition, the profits of the year being 9 per scent.
