The Moniteur has confirmed with the least possible delay the statement which we published yesterday as to the formal reestablishment of the French Empire, and, with one remarkable exception, this change will doubtless be effected in the manner proposed by LOUIS NAPOLEON himself to the Senate.

THE COURSE OF TEN LECTURES ON MUSIC to be delivered at Metropolitan Hall by Mr. WM. H. FRY, gives promise of unusual attraction and interest. Mr. FRY is a fine scholar, as well as a musical critic, and is well qualified to judge of Music from the Stand-point of a Literary connoisseur, as well as by personal experience of the style and quality of tones and inflections.

We met an odd but intelligent old gentleman last night, who seized our arm, and with marks of much emotion said, "My young friend, I am in trouble; I do a small business, you know, a very small business, but it is intended to be a cash business in every item.

The Postmaster--General of Canada has made his report for the year ending the 5th of April, 1852. It shows the favorable working of the system under the reduced rates of postage. On 6th April, 1851, the management of the Canada Post Office was given up by the Imperial authorities to the Provincial. Under the Queen's officers, the gross revenue at the high tariff of rates was [Pound]93,802 currency, including the British packet postage--about [Pound].f10,000.

OUR HAVANA CORRESPONDENCE.--Our Havana correspondent "R," in is letter published in yesterday's Times, referred to the brutal whipping of many free persons for the purpose of extorting from them confessions or accusations implicating themselves and others in insurrectionary movements.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Commercial credit now threading the wide world, and connecting its trading points witll their mercantile centre of operation, has, of late, to a great extent, superseded the use of currency in effecting its heavy mercantile exchanges.
At a Boys' mesting, one of the speakers was insisting on the rewards of virtue in this life. "Be steady, honest and industrious," said he, "and you will be rich, respected and honored.

On Tuesday 23d inst., at No. 73 warren-st.. HENRY C. ADAMIS, son of Ebenezer Adams, Rondout, Ulster Co., in his 27th year. On Monday evening, 22d inst., Mrs. JANE LABIBEBT. relict of Capt. W. Lanbert, in the 74th year of her age. Her friends and those of her son, Edward A. Lambert, and of the family generally, are invited to attend her funeral, this Wednesday) afternoon.

The French Empire has come at last. The phantom Republic has vanished, and in place of a President sits NAPOLEON III, Emporor of France. We are glas of it. Republicanism was shamed and degraded while he were its livery.

THE EXPENSE OF THE NEW-YORK ALMS-HOUSE DEPARTMENT.--The report of the expenditures of the Governors of the Alms-House for the last month, has just been printed. From the document it appears hat the net expenditure during the month of October amounted to $41,923.75.

The London Corn market was without much alteration from the previous week's prices. Floating cargoes of Mediterranean Wheat were held for 15. per quarter advance. American Flour met with a tolerably free sale.

It was observed by TRANQUILLUS SEUTONIUS that the Emperor AUGUSTUS found Rome built of wood, and left it adorned with marble. It is not to imperial power, except in few lands, that we look now for the most splendid and imposing illus trations of metropolitan taste and opulence as displayed in architecture.

The election of the Second Chamber took place on the 3d thronghout the kingdom. In Herlin the Electoral College assembled in the four districts into which the city is divided at an early hour this morning. In two districts a second voting and scrutiny were necessary; but the following is the final result:--In the first district, M. VON MANTEUFFEL, President of the Cabinet, M. Kuhne, retired General Director of Texas, and M. Bock were elected.
COTTON.--The sales of the week foot up only 32.000 bales, of which speculators have taken 12.000, and exporters 2,750. The brokers quote fair Orleand at 6 1/2.

M. METAXA the Greek Ambassador at Constantinople, has just given in his resignation, alleging that Turkey having by her last Ministerial changes entered on a retrograde path, which is announced by hatred and persecution against all Christians, and above all, against her Greek subjects, it is no longer according to the dignity of Greece to have an ambassador there, and that her interests ought to be left to a Charged Affaires.

The English political news by this packet is unimportant. Parliament has been merely occupied with the customary forms of taking the oaths. The Queen's speech was to be delivered on the 11th, when the real business of the session would commence. Great interest continued to be excited in reference to the Presidential election.

PORTUGUESE CLAIMS.--The Department of State has issued a notification to claimants under the convention with Portugal, that the second instalment has been received and is ready to be distributed. All claimants are accordingly requested to forward to this Department such evidence as will enable the distribution to be made to the proper parties respectively.

We notice among the arrivals at Willard's Hotel the following:--Hon. D.A. Bockee, of New York, Captain Du Pont, U.S.N.. Major Merchant, U.S. A., Captain Merchant, U. S. A., Commodere Perry. Commanding East India Squadron, Captain Sands.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Hermann, Captain HIGGINS, arrived last evening, from Bremen on 5th inst., and Southampton on the 10th. Her news is important, conveying intelligence of the official acceptances of the Empire by LOUIS NAPOLEON.

The Piedmontese Gazette of the 5th inst. an nounces that the King had definitively composed his Cabinet as follows: Messrs. CAMILLUS CAVOUR, President of the Council and Minister of Finance; General DABORMIDA, Minister of Foreign Affairs; PONZA DI SAN MARTINO, of the Interior; CIBBARIO, of Public Instruction; General LA MARMORA, of War and Marine; BONCOMPANY, of Grace and Justice; and PALEOCCAPA, of Public Works.

To the remarkable deaths which will hereafter signalize the obituary of 1852, we may now add that of the man who by common consent was reputed the greatest among the statement of the New World. The knowledge generally possessed by Englishmen respecting the life and services of DANIEL WEBSTER will, perhaps, hardly prepare them for the sensation which his decease has created in the country of his birth.

Almost irresistably the conviction of the great growth. exhaustiess resources, and rapid progress of our country, forces itself upon the mind of the most casual observer, wherever he may turn. When American glass presented itself in market, people could neither very readily see through the glass, nor through the supposed fully of the Yankee maker.

METROPOLITAN ACADEMY.--A new enterprise in education has been commenced in this City, under the title of the Metropolitan Academy. The object is to combine the Academic and Collegiate departments of study in a regular course. The Academy is a handsome Freestone structure, five stories in height, covering two lots at Nos. 93 and 95 Sixth-Avenue.

Private dispatches, received here, announce a collision between two engines on the Erie Railroad. Messrs. BOOKHAMER and DULL (Engineer and Fireman) were killed or mortally wounded. The accident is said to have occurred between Tioga and Corning.

The "Society for Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents" laid the corner-stone of their new "House of Refuge," on Randall's Island, yesterday. The steamboat Ravenswood left Peck-slip at 11 A.M. The morning was fine, and several gentlemen attended on the invitation of the Committee. Besides the officers of the Society.

The Rev. H. N. HUDSON delivered his second, and fourth of the course, of the New-England Lectures last evening at the Brooklyn Institute, to a not very large, but an appreciative audience. Previous to the introduction of the speaker for the evening, SETH LORD, Esq, announced that the next lecture of the course would be delivered on Tuesday evening next by Hon. HORACE MANN. Subject--" Woman."

A dwelling-house occupied by two Irish families, in North Adams, was consumed by fire on Tuesday night, and on Wednesday morning, the body of a woman with her skull badly broken, and nearly consumed, was found in the rains. Her husband and child are missing, and it is supposed that he first murdered her, and then fired the house, as they were heard quarreling in the night. The man's name is MARTIN HEATH.

The Governor of this State having recommended the observance of THURSDAY, the 25th inst, as a day of Thanksgiving to Almighty God for the mereles which have crowned the year, I would urge upon the inhabitants of this city the observance of that recommendation, by suspending their ordinary avocations and closing, their places of business.

Suddenly, on the 24th inst., HENRY H. MYERS, in the 41st year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral from his late residence No. 110 4th-st., corner of South 3d, Williamsburg, this (Thursday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock.

THE RESULT OF RECKLESSNESS.--On Saturday afternoon last, as Mr. OLIVER CORNELL, Of Glenville, was proceeding homeward on the Sacandaga turnpike, in a wagon drawn by a span of horses, he came in contact with a train of cars going West, by which he was so dangerously injured that he died during the night. One of the horses was killed and the other rendered valueless.

OVER AND TERMINER--Before Judge EDWARDS, Ald. WARD and DUPLEY HALEY. The People vs. William Saul., indicted along with Hevelett and Johnson.--The prisoners were put to the bar. Messrs. John Cochrane and James B. Phillips appeared as their counsel. The District Attorney said the prisoners had exercised their right of demanding separate trials, and he should proceed with the case of Sail this morning, and postponed Johnson's until Friday.

Issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending Nov. 23, 1852, and bearing date Nov. 23, 1852. Joseph J. Couch, of Philadelphia, Pa.--For improvement in machines for drilling stone. William F. and Nathan Davis, of Castleton, Vermont For improvement in swinging churus. Augustus Faulkner, of Walpolo, New Hampshire For improvement in pincers for operating pile wires. E. C. Harmon, of New-York--For improvement in spaces for setting type.

The sixth Lecture of this course was delivered last evening in the Tabernacle, by Rev. Dr. SEARS of Boston, Secretary of the Massachusetts Board of Education. The attendance, at the reduced rate of admittance, was larger than usual. The Doctor took for his subject. "Imagination--its culture and use." He would, he said, call it an "Intellectual" imagination, in contradistinction to "lawless" imagination.

ELECTION FOR MASSACUSETTS MEMBERS OF CONGRESS.--The Governor and Council have directed that elections be held on the second Monday of December, to fill the vacancies in all the Congressional Districts where they have failed to elect. As a Plurality elects on this trial, all the vacancies will then be filled.

WEDNESDAY, Nov. 24.--The Board met, pursuant to adjournment, RICHARD T. COMPTON, President of the Board, presiding. The minutes of the last meeting being read and approved, the next business in order was the Presentation of Petitions--Engine Company No. 24 asked for an appropriation to pay for repairing their engine.
Lovers of Literature and Art will find a collection of Books, and also one of Paintings at the rooms of H. H. LEEDS Co., in Wall-street, which are of unusual merit and interest.

The Washington Intelligencer announces that the sloop-of-war Cyane has been ordered to the harbor of Havana, and the Albany to Pensacola. The reported failure of the machinery of the steamship Princeton is confirmed by the Norfolk papers--only fifteen inches of steam can be kept on her, and usually not more than six or seven.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--The BATEMAN children appear at the Broadway Theatre to-night in two pieces, viz.: "Her Royal Highness," and "The Young Couple." The farce of " Married and Settled," is also to be added to the entertainment of the evening. BURTON's--The Farce of " One Thousand Milliners Wanted," "Woman I Adore," "Bagone Dull Care," and several interludes, are on BURTON's bill for to-night.

The Jury in the case of FELIX BURNS, charged with the murder of CHARLES BURD, (a jeweler,) two two years since, went out this afternoon, under a charge by Judge THOMPSON. They returned into Court this evening, and inquired whether they could bring him in guilty of a lower grade than murder, and were told they could. They then returned again.

From the Evening Mirror. On the 7th of October last, the Evening Mirror entered upon the ninth year of its existence. Absence from the city prevented us from "improving the occasion," by having a few words with our readers touching our own affairs--a subject we are not in the habit of saying much about.

Hon. WALTER FORWARD died at 5 o'clock this morning, of bilions colic, in the 65th year of his age. He was ill three days only. He has filled many important stations--represented this County in Congress for many years--was Secretary of the Treasury under President TYLER--was Minister to Denmark--and up to his death a Judge of the District Court. He will be much lamented in this community.

If President FILLMORE had sought to render impossible all further negotiations for the peaceful acquisition of Cuba by the United States, he could scarcely have chosen a more effectual method of accomplishing that object, than by publishing the documents which were given at length in yesterday's Times. The negotiation was, and still is, one of the utmost delicacy.

BARBOUR'S REPORTS OF THE SUPREME COURT, VOL. XI.--NO text can be more uppermost in the mind of our worthy reporter than the often quoted one," there is nothing new under the sun." For every four months there appears in the shape now before us a collection of judicial platitudes, axioms, and idiosyncrasies, which to read are less instructive but more amusing. than the pages of Punch.

PROCBRDINGS of THE Board OF ALDERMEN- November 24. New colors for the New York Volunteers. The Committee of Arts and Sciences reported in favor of presenting the returned members of the First Regiment of New-York Volunteers with a new stand of colors, but the "mount having been left blank, Aldermon STURTEVANT moved that the report be referred back to be filled up.

He who yesterday gave something else than thanks, slept last night with sounder digestion and brighter dreams than others. His turkey, however juicily and greasily sauced, exhibited no propensity to post-prandial rebellion.
The Postmaster General has established, discontinued, and changed the names of the following Post-Offices, during the week ending Nov. 20, 1852.

The much admired patriot and orator, THOMAS F. MFAGHER, delivered his first lecture in Metropolitan Hall, last evening, by invitation of the citizens or New York. The Hall was densely crowded, long before the hour announced, and numbers had to return disappointed from want of accommodation.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The undersigned address you this communication as the Executive Committee of the Broadway Railroad Association, in whose favor a resolution has passed the Board of Aldermen, granting, on specified conditions, the privilege of laying and working, on specified conditions, in Broadway.

The Thanksgiving discourse at the Broadway Tabernacle was preached yesterday morning by Rev. SAMUEL D. COCHRAN, of Paterson, N. J. Although this gentleman is not so widely known in our community as others whose sermons we notice this morning, we feel satisfied that the interesting sketch we give of his appropriate and practical effort upon this occasion, will lead our readers to desire to hear and know more of him.

The frenzied course of the Governor-General of Cuba and his subordinates, in regard to the "individual named WILLIAM SMITH," justifies the presumption that the gods have decreed the destruction of the Spanish tyranny in that Island. A clearer case of official insanity it would be impossible to make out.

THANKSGIVING ON THE FIVE POINTS.-At an early hour yesterday morning, the vieinity of the Five Points was unusually active. Respectable looking men, and well dressed women were seen threading their way through the streets usually monopolized by hrawling ruffians unwashed bawds.

The following documents, in continuation of the series already published in the Times, relate to rumored designs of Great Britain upon Cuba in the year 1843, and will be read with interest: Mr. Webster to Mr. Irving.--[Extract.]

" Our aristocracy," said a divine in his Thanksgiving sermon, "is a matter of dollars and cents. It goes up with cotton and down with stocks." We have seen a man labor and sweat to attain it, all the way up from "a dollar a day and found," till none but the lobbyman at Washington could tell his price.

Public worship was had in nearly all our City Churches yesterday, and in most of them discourses were delivered, having reference more or less direct, to various phases of the public affairs of our country and the world at large.

A Saucy PETITION.--Considerable confusion was caused in the Canadian Parliament upon reading the following petition from the townships of Daunes and Burloigh, in reference to the clergy reserves: "Your memorialists neither ask nor desire that any threats towards the crown of England should be employed.

Every available seat in Calvary Church was occupied at morning service, yesterday, by a most respectable auditory, anxious to hear Rev. Dr. HAWKS deliver his discourse on this occasion of National Thanksgiving. The old veterans of 1812 attended, and were seated in front of the Chancel.

A SAD STORY.--About eight months ago a ship master sailed out of Boston, bound for the port of Rio; he was accompanied by his wife and child, and his brother. Since the sailing of the vessel nothing has been heard of her, and it is almost certain that she is lost.

Good lady, your kindness of heart is apparent to all; you do good to the poor at all sea sons; none are turned away hungry from your door; you seek out employment for the idle, and your benevolence is a noble example to all who, like you, are blessed with the means of giving liberally.

-The members and patrons of the praiseworthy Institution, known as the Hebrew Benevolent Society, assembled last evening at the Chinese Assembly Rooms Broadway, and celebrated their thirty-first anniversary.

Helifax and Pictou dates to-the- 20th state that the railway almost absorbs the attention of the newspapers. Messrs. Sykes Co. have offered to build the road in Nova Scotia for [Pound] 4,000 sterling per mile, which is [Pound] 1,500 per mile less than Jackson's contract in New-Brunswick.

Rev. Dr. BURCHARD preached from the text, Mathew xvi. 3: "Can you not discover the signs of the times ?" He said that the familiar adage- that" coming events cast their shadows before"- involves two important principles: 1. That no great event stands alone, but is the effect of previously-operating causes.

RUNAWAY SLAVES.--The slaves in Kentucky are daily escaping to Ohio, and by the underground Railroad, to Canada. So serious is becoming the evil, that the Slaveholders have formed a Society for their assistance and protection.

On Saturday night last, one of the Boston watchmen found wandering about in a state of intoxication, a man somewhat celebrated as a ventriloquist, and who has often performed at theatres. He was taken in charge, and placed in the cell of the watchhouse.

THANKSGIVING IN BROOKLYN--Thanksgiving in this city passed off with more than usual eclat. At an early hour in the morning, those who had neglected to provide themselves with a turkey or a substitute, could be seen in scores wending their way homewards. with the chief dish for the Thanksgiving dinner.

THE PRINCETON.--The failure of the new vessel bearing this name, and her consequent withdrawal from the squadron, composing the Japan expedition, is the subject of regret to Pailadelphians, who have always had a pride in the reputation justly earned by the original Princeton. which was entirely the product of our own ship wrights and machinists.

Our recent intelligence from Brazil indicates increased energy on the part of the Imperial Government for the suppression of the slave trade. Brazil has been one of the two great slave markets, whose incessant demands have baffled the utmost vigilance of the Christianpowers.

DEATH OF DOCTOR COWDERY.--Dr. JONATHAN COWDERY, the Senior Surgeon in the United States Navy, died at his residence in Norfolk, Va., on Saturday night last. The Norfolk Beacon, referring to the event, says: "Few men have borne a more unblemished character, or been held in such high and universal esteem for all the qualities of head and heart that constitute the efficient officer and worthy citizen.
Gov. Foo'e, of Mississipi, has published an address to the people of that State on the subject of the next Senatorship.

THE NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES.- The newest newspaper in New-york city, is the beat. We speak of the Times as it is since its enlargement. No daily Journal in this country exhibits, or ever did exhibit, so much labor, so great ability, or a comprehension and purview so general and vast.

On Wednesday, Nov. 24, DANIEL P. LYON, in the 20th year of his age The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral this afternoon, at 1 o'clock, from St. Thomas Church, without further invitation.

The keen observer of passing events and of human nature, has remarked that great attention has been devoted for the last few years to the raising of fowls, especially the large breeds. Many persons have related to the ample ear of the public the history of their experience and successes in this department of business. My own has not been recorded to this day. The hiatus shall not longer be unfilled.

FATAL ACCIDENT WITH HOT WATER.--The Coroner held an inquest yesterday, at No. 40 Cherry street, on the body of a child named WM. O'GORMAN, aged 3 years and 4 months, who came to his death from being scalded with hot water.

The State of Arkansas is in debt to the depth of Two Millions, and has nothing to show for it. Not a mile of railroad; no great public works; no useful financial institution. The half-million acres of land bestowed on the State by the Federal Government have all been wasted, without leaving any permanent advantage to represent them.

We have received no news of interest from New-Mexico or Utah since I last wrote you. From Fort Pierre, one of the chief posts of the fur-traders, high up on the Missouri. I received a letter yesterday. It was brought down by a gentleman who has been spending the Summer upon the Plains.

TELEGRAPHIC.--We are gratified to learn that Mr. JAMES BAILEY, for the past year Assistant Operator at the New-York office of the Washington and New-Orleans line, has been promoted, and will hereafter per form the duties of Chief Operator--an office which he is eminently qualified to fill in an acceptable manner.

ALPINE TRIBUTE.--The Federal Council of Switzerland have presented to the Washington Monument Association, a block of granite cut from the Alps, and bearing the following inscription: To the Memory OF WASHINGTON. The Free Swiss Confederation. MDCCCLII.

The result of the election in Massachusetts has surprised everybody. The game was apparently in the hands of the coalition, who had used their strength to so good purpose in the preceding struggles and considering the value of the present contest, the use of the most desperate means was anticipated to secure victory.

The violent storm of yesterday and last evening cut off the usual supplies of news from every quarter. Mails failed to arrive, and telegraphing lines were crippled in their operation, so that little could be obtained from either direction.

Rev. Dr. CUTLER, of St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn, preached from 1 Samuel, ch. ii., v. 30. Them that honor me, I will honor." The subject of the sermon was the thankfulness we ought to feel to God for the leading lights of such men as WASHINGTON and WEBSTER.

Mr. THACKERAY read his third lecture last evening, to an audience less crowded than on either of the two previous evenings, but far larger than the driving storm of the day and night led any one to suppose could possibly be collected.

We observe that the enterprising firm of BARTHOLOMEW WEED, No. 551 Broadway, are driving a much heavier business this season than ever, and ladies now seldom think of purchasing mourning goods at any other place than the New Mourning Store.

Dr. SPRING addressed his congregation in the Brick Church, on Thursday morning. He selected as his text: JAMES I., 17--"Every good and every perfect gift cometh from above." It is, said the reverend gentleman, a beautiful thought that represents the Infinite God as the Father of light.

CAMILLE URSO-PLEASING INCIDENT.-M'lle CAMILLE URSO's farewell concert, on Thursday evening, was attended by a highly respectable audience, who manifested their approbation of the little artiste in the most enthusiastic manner. This, as yet, new candidate for popular favor is not a mere youthful prodigy--a musician whose only claim to attention is that which curiosity lends because of her tender age.

NICHOLAS RADZIVIL in his Hierosolymitana Peregrinatio, gives a curious account of the manner in which a certain Arabian Caliph selected his Vizier. A plate of transparent crystal was suspended by a silken cord from the ceiling, and the rival candidates passed in turn before it.

A DISGRACEFUL SCENE AT THE LOWER POLICE COURT.--Yesterday forenoon, between the hours of 10 and 11 o'clock, a most disgraceful scene was enacted at the Lower Police Court, Halls of Justice, in presence of the sitting Magistrate.

THE JAPAN EXPEDITION.--We learn from the Norfolk Beacon, of 24th inst., that the Mississippi was to sail on that day for Japan vid Madeira. The Powhatan, according to the same authority, will take place of the Princeton, disqualified by the imperfections of her boilers.

A LECTURE-BY THOMAS DARCY X GEE. The third lecture of the series before the Catholic Institute, was delivered by THOMAS DARCY McGEE, of Buffalo, last evening. The Lecture-room of Stuyvesant Institute was filled, notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather. Archbishop HUGHES, and several of the Roman Catholic Clergy, attended.

The Cherokee is to sail to-day for Havana in place of the Crescent City, which is detained for repairs. We have been informed,--and we presume on reliable authority,--that orders have been received at the Post office from Washington, that if Purser SMITH goes out in the Steamer no mails are to be sent by her.

Several of the Officers, Agents and Colporteurs of the American Tract Society, and Delegates from the Branch Societies at Boaton and Baltimore, met in Convention at Richmond, Va., on the 10th inst., and continued their session six days.

The mail from El Paso arrived at San Antonio on the 29th ult. The Texan has the following items of intelligence: The Indians continue as troublesome as ever. But a short time since they stole seventeen Government animals from Fort Webster, at the copper mides.

A brilliant affair came off last evening, at the Astor House, on the occasion of the presentation of a magnificent Service of Silver Plate to JUNIUS T. STAGG, Esq., Treasurer of the Light Guard, commanded by Capt. EDWARD VINCENT; and also a dinner given in honor of the birth-day of Mr. STAGG.

The Thirty-ninth Annual Meeting of this Society was held at the Asylum in Twentieth-street, yesterday; 12 o'clock was the appointed hour, but the weather being unpleasant the opening of business was postponed to one; even then the attendance was thin. This Asylum was founded in the year 1838. The demands on the Society have of late so increased, that they find accommodation for 200 persons would be required.

[Concluded.] Mr. A. H. Everett to the Secretary of State. [CONFIDENTIAL.] MADRID, Aug. 17, 1827. SIR: The enclosed copy of a confidential dispatch addressed to the Minister of State by the Conde de la ALCUDIA, Spanish Minister at London, was handed to me to-day by a private friend, and may be depended on as authentic.

"MESSIEURS LES SENATEURS: France, attentive and excited, now demands from you a great political act. You are called upon to put an end to her anxieties, and to secure her future. But this act, however important, does not meet with any of those great difficulties which obstruct the wisdom of legislators.

INGRATITUDE.--On Thanksgiving night, a young man of quite aristocratic feeling, named JAMES ATCHINSON, lost his way, owing to having imbibed too freely of strong beverage during the day, and while endeavoring to find his home, he wandered down Fourth-street, and walked off the Pier into the East river.

Poetry.--The Mother's Dirge. Literary.--Dr. Franklin, John Adams and Lord Howe. Incidents of Rural Life. Better Done than Said. Cossip about Children--A Familiar Epistle, by L. Gaylord Clark. Sketches of Mr. Thackeray's Lectures--L. Dean Swift; H. Congreve and Addison.

We beg to state in reply to the communication from Mr. CHARLES S. TAPPAN, Agent N. Y. Erie Railroad, that we received the dispatch published on Thursday, relative to a fatal collision on the Erie Road, near Corning, from a reliable correspondent at Philadelphia.

BURTON's.--The comedy of the "Patrician and Parvenu," is to be performed again this evening, together with the farce of 'Fortunes Frolie," and the comedy of" One Thousand Milliners." NIBLO's.--The performances this evening, consist of fifteen different pieces, including singing, dancing, the drama and pantomime.

Yesterday the session commenced in earnest. The proceedings of Parliament were inauguarated by her Majesty, who proceeded from Buckingham Palace to the new houses amidst a drizzling shower of rain, and delivered the Royal Speech.

It suits some unrevealed purpose of the Tribune to represent the Times as advocating the forcible seizure of Cuba, unless Spain will sell it. We are so slightly affected by its misrepresentations, and so little impressed by its epithets, that we shall take no pains to expose the one or repel the other.

MONTAGUE FERRY.--What we can learn about the establishing of this Ferry, leads us to believe that the boats will not commence running before about the first of April. The work is said to be going forward with all possible dispatch. Boats are building, and an architect is now drawing plans for the Ferry-houses, which are to be similar, we learn, to the new arrangements at the Catherine Ferry.

We have more than the usual number of Steamer arrivals to record this morning. Three from Aspinwall and San Juan, including the mail steamer Georgia, with the California mails, fifteen days' later, and treasure of 1st November, and the Baltic from Liverpool, with four days' later news from Europe.

In April 1849, Mr. LAW opened a correspondence with Mr. CRAWFORD, then Secretary of War, for the purchase of muskets and appendages, belonging to the U. S., and advertised for public sale. The negotiation for the purchase of said arms was successful, and a Bond for compliance with the terms of sale, dated April 23d, 1849, was duly executed, signed by M. O. ROBERTS, and PROSPER M. WETMORE,--the amount of liability being $160,000.

THE STORM.--During Friday night, a frame building in course of construction in North Seventh street, and belonging to THOS. MONROE, was prostrated by the wind. A portion of the building fell upon a stable adjoining, demolishing it, and injuring a horse which was in the stable at the time.

The builders of the boilers of the steamship Princeton predict that the condemnation will be found premature, as she acted well on her trial trip, and only failed on account of using Anthracite instead of Cumberland coal on her trip to Norfolk.

INDIA.--A telegraphic despatch announcing the arrival of the Indian Mall was transmitted, per steamer America. Since then we have had advices from Bombay to October 16th. Intelligence from Burmah comes down to September 26th.

THE ENLARGEMENT OF THE BATTERY.--It seems that the Battery is to be enlarged after all. The project was broached some years ago, but caused so much dissatisfaction in the First Ward, and with many residents in other parts of the City, that the work was abandoned, although the line of the proposed outside wall had been run and marked by buoys.

The Memphis Whig is indebted to a gentleman who came passenger on the steamer Julia Dean, direct from the neighborhood where the deed was committed, for the following particulars of an awful murder, committed by a boy eleven or twelve years of age, near Augusta, Ark., on the morning of the 9th inst.:

By the Chilian bark Alexandra, 45 days from Tahita, we learn that the three British men-to-war, which met at Raistea, had not quitted that place, with the exception of the frigate Didon, which, having damaged its false ?? had sailed for England to repair damages.

A brilliant affair came off last evening, at the Astor House, on the occasion of the presentation of a magnificent Service of Silver Plate to JUNIUS T. STAGG, Esq., Treasurer of the Light Guard, commanded by Capt. EDWARD VINCENT; and also a dinner given in honor of the birth-day of Mr. STAGG.

The New-Orleans mails arrived here to-day, paving the latest still due. Mr. JOHN S. THRASHER's new paper, the Beacou of Cuba, had made its appearance at New-Orleans. MAURICE W. HOFFMAN, a distinguished lawyer o New-Orleans, died in that City recently.

The United States Mail steamship Baltic, Capt. GOMSTOCK, arrived at her wharf at an early hour yesterday morning. She was off the Hook on Saturday evening, and the passage, for this season of the year, is an excellent one.

A meeting of the American citizens in London, was convened at the Legation, 13th, by Mr. INGERSOLL, for the purpose of uniting in a tribute of respect to the memory of DANIEL WEBSTER. Suitable resolutions were passed, and it was resolved that the usual badge of mourning be worn for thirty days.

ACCIDENTAL KILLING.--A sad accident attended the bear hunt on the mountain east of us, in the killing of Mr. CHARLES ADAMS, of Ripton, by the accidental discharge of his own gun. The turn out, we understand, was not general, but many from this town, Ripton, Gosben and Salisbury, wore out on Thursday.

THANKSGIVING PRESENT.--The occupants of house No. 70 Front-street had a young baby left upon their door-step Thanksgiving-eve, but having a plenty of the kind of their own, they turned it over to the fatherly care of officer BABCOCK of the Second District police, who in turn delivered it to officer PHILLIPS, of the same district, in whose family the young one found "distinguished consideration."

In the Evening Times of Saturday was published the following letter, received by telegraph from Washington. It will he observed that it is a private letter, addressed by President FILLMORE to HUGH MAXWELL, Esq., Collector at this Port, in reply to a letter from Mr. MAXWELL, purporting to repeat conversations he had had with Mr. GEORGE LAW, in regard to the future course of the Crescent City:

OYER AND TERMINER--Before Judge EDWARDS, Aldermen WARD and CORNELL. The People vs. Michael Shpifer allas Shipser.--The evidence for the defence was resumed by Mr. Sickles calling Jacob Weitzell, but he could only prove that he had known the prisoner since last Monday, and though the had seen him on the Monday.

We have to notice a greater degree of interest in our market than has been apparent for some time. Up to the 20th inst, the various clippers and other vessels from the Atlantic ports had been so much retarded in their arrival as to occasion a scarcity of most articles of general merchandise.

The steamers Prometheus, Northern Light and Georgia arrived at this port on Saturday after noon and yesterday, bringing dates from California to the 10th November, and later advices from San Juan, Aspinwall, and Kingston, Jam.

After having spent a week at Marshfield in fishing, sailing, driving on the beach, shooting, and in all the delights of that charming resort, we changed the scene. Lady EMIDY STUART WORTLEY, a daughter of the Duke of RUTLAND, who is a warm friend of Mr. WEBSTER; Governor EVERETT, Mr. GRAY, of Boston, and a number of others, whom Mr. WEBSTER esteemed highly, had been with us, and the time passed gaily.

The provincial journals are filled with proclamations and addresses from the prefects stimulating the zeal of the voters. In Paris all is quiet--apparently no enthusiasm for the Empire, although no show of opposition.

On Saturday afternoon Nov. 27, 1852. WILLIAM BOCK. Esq. in the 67th year of his age. His relatives and friends are respectfully invited to at tend his funeral on Monday, 29th inst. at 2 1/2 o'clock P M., from the residence of his son-in-law, Thos F. Devoe, No. 80 Wrs 13th-st, near 6th-av.

The Coxsackie Union of the 10th inst. has the following: Our village, on Friday evening last, was the scene of a terrible casualty. A wooden building near the pier of Hunt and Nelson occupied by the families of William Aiken and George Vanvalkenburgh, was destroyed by fire occasioned by the negligent use of "burning fluid."

In the House of Commons, Nov. 12, Mr. S. HERBERT observed, that the paragraph in the Queen's speech referring to the difficulties which arose during the last Summer respecting our Colonial Fisheries, left an impression as to the origin of those difficulties, as to the course taken with respect to them, and also as to the result likely to ensue from the negotiation, at variance with the public impression on the subject.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Can there be a doubt but that the great novelist had his friend JEFFREY in view, when in drawing one of his most striking characters he has invested him with those remarkable qualities, that of unlimited conversational powers, and the most finished eloquence, which so conspicuously shine in the Scottish Advocate.

Hanover and Brunswick have just concluded a convention subject, to the approbation of their respective Chambers, for the laying out of a railway which will connect both States more directly with the north.

The disposition manifested at the present time by France to claim the exclusive guardianship of the Holy Sepulchre at Jerusalem, and the determination on the part of the Greeks and Russians to resist any change in favor of the Latins, makes it an interesting matter of Inquiry to know who has had possession of it since the ascension of Him who was first laid therein.

EMIGRANTS TO LIBERIA.--Another vessel has left North Carolina for Liberia, with free blacks for the Colony. On the 22d the steamer Fayetteville was chartered at Wilmington, to take 150 emigrants to the bark Joseph Maxwell, then lying at Smithville.

PARLIAMENT.--On Monday the House of Lords transacted little business, except passing a bill to make Thursday 18th, on which day the funeral of the late Duke of WELLINGTON takes place, a legal holiday. And Lord BROUGHAM presented a petition from Jamaica, praying that more stringent measures may be adopted for the suppression of the Slave trade.

From the London Sun. The taxes on knowledge must be repealed ere long; no one doubts it. Argument has settled the question in every mind acquainted with the subject, and it only remains for an adequate number of minds to give their attention to it, and the thing is done forever.

The obsequies of the Duke of WELLINGTON excite the largest share of public attention. To-morrow, the day of funeral, will be observed throughout the country as a holiday. All the stores are to be closed and business suspended.

TARGET EXCURSION.--On Thursday, the "Neptune Guards" composed principally of the members of Engine Co. No. 7, and commanded by Capt. KELLEY, proceeded to Bushwick for the purpose of contending for the prizes.

The Baltic brings, with very late accounts from British India and China, a few items from Australia, down to the 31st Aug. They show a wonderful condition of affairs at the Gold Mines, and in the principal ports connected with their trade.

COUNTERFEIT BILLS ON THE DUTCHES COUNTY BANK.--There has recently been put into circulation in this City, well-executed counterfeit $2 notes, purporting to be the genuine issues of the Dutchess County Bank, at Armenia, N. Y., and are principally palmed off by females in payment for trifling articles at dry-goods and grocery stores.

LOSS OF LIFE IN THE CROWD.--The universality of the public interest in the funeral solemnities, which properly commenced on Saturday last, 13th inst., was evinced by the unprecedented crowds that thronged to Chelsea from the early hour of seven in the morning, continuing without intermission throughout the greater part of the day.

PROVINCIAL RAILROADS--The length of some of the railroads projected in the provinces and already under charter for construction, will rival that of any yet existing in any part of the world. The length of the Grand Line will exhibit thus:

On Saturday a meeting of citizens of the United States of America, now resident in England, was held at the American Legation, No. 45 Portland-place, for the purpose of agreeing upon some tribute of respect to be paid to the memory of this lamented and distinguished statesman.

Both houses of the Convocation of Canterbury were in session at London, 12th. There was a large attendance of Bishops end clergy, but their proceedings offer nothing of interest to the American readers. The ill-disguised scope of the present agitation is to the authority of Convocation above that of the Crown.

COMPLIMENTARY VISIT TO HON. ABBOTT LAWRENCE.--The Mayor and the two branches of the City Government made an official call on Hon. ABBOTT LAWRENCE, this morning, at his residence, to welcome him on his return from diplomatic service.

NUMBER SIX. For a week past, and more, my partner and myself have so arranged our hours that his "turn on" has closed at dusk. I had noticed all this time a self-satisfied smirk on his countenance, when I made my appearance to relieve him, which convinced me that he had been playing some trick that gratified him hugely.

Dr. Gooch editor of the Tethoscope, a medical journal published at Richmond, Va, given the following, in his account of the North Carolina Twins: "These two children were born in July, 1851. The mother is a Stout negroes, aged 31, very fat, and of large frame.

We cannot too warmly commend to public favor the series of weekly Lectures on Music, by WM. H. FRY, which commence to-morrow, Tuesday evening. Each Lecture, besides being an able and well arranged treatise on this interesting art, by one who has made it his close and enthusiastic study for many years, will embrace in its practical illustrations, a Grand Vocal and Instrumental Concert.
At the Grand Rande, while prosecuting his journey across the plains to Oregon, JOSEPH CLARK MOORE, M. D., late of Carlisle, Illinois, son of Robert Moore, Esq., of Linn City, aged 47 years.

On Monday, Earl DERBY called a meeting of the Members of Parliament who will support his measures. About 220 members were present. The meeting was understood to be in relation to Mr. VILLIERS'S intended Free Trade motion.

The proposals for executing the brick work of the Capitol Extension were opened at the office of the Secretary of the Interior to-day. There were twenty-one bids, ranging from $2 49 to $7 50 per thousand. The decision will be given on Monday.

ARRIVAL OF MORMON MISSIONARIES.--In the steamer El Paso, from the Missouri River, yesterday, were a number of citizens of the Territory of Utah, being a portion of a company of about eighty Mormon Elders, who left the Salt Lake City on the 15th September, as missionaries to various nations of the earth.

Three Steamships and nearly Three Millions of Dollars in gold dust, reached the City yesterday. The event is the more remarkable, because the prognostics from the Mines have not latterly been so encouraging.

The handsome stores erected on the site of the old Hampden Hotel have been almost undermined by a stream of water flowing from the town brook, owing to an obstruction. The water is rushing from one cellar to the other, and has carried away so much of the centre foundation that fears were at one time entertained of a complete cave in.

The work of enlarging the Albany Penitentiary is completed, and the additions are such as to render that building a model in its construction. Some 40 new cells or sleeping apartments have been added to the female wing; the male department has been extended, taking in 80 new cells, and water has been introduced throughout the building.

We cannot call Mdme. SONTAG'S beautiful entertainment of Saturday morning a mere rehearsal, though as such it was given out. It was one of the most pleasing concerts, taken as a whole, we have attended during the present season.

Certain remarks in a recent number of the Daily Times, in reference to the Slave Trade in Cuba, appear to be justified by our latest English news. On the 12th inst., Lord PALHERSTON, who will unquestionably return to the Foreign office when the present moribund Ministry shall expire, broached the subject in the House of Commons, by moving a return of the number of slaves landed in the island since 1851.

I presume neither you nor your readers will be unwilling to hear how matters are going on in this delightful place, where, I do not doubt, many of them have revelled among the varied manifestations of beauty, which nature here vouchsafes to her worshippers, and where you have passed some of the brightest years, and formed some of the strongest ties, of your, life.

The most extraordinary revolution that has yet occurred in South America, took place at Buenos Ayres on the 11th of September.--It was bloodless. General URQUIZA, who, since the great victory of February over ROSAS, had controlled public affairs, for various reasons became extremely distasteful to the Buenos Ayreans.

Mr. EDITOR: The excitement of our great quadrennial canvass has passed over, and your columns are not hereafter to be burdened with political matter. The national wailings for the loss of the great Massachusetts Statesman are begining to die away upon the breeze. The country is now once more at rest.

We stopped at the Melrose station, and, taking a carriage, drove over to Abbotsford, some three miles. The country, though exceedingly pleasant, did not strike us as remarkably picturesque, and before we dreamed of such a thing we were at Abbotsford, which lies low, on the banks of the Tweed, hidden from the road by a thick plantation.

The speech of Horace Binney on the death of John Sergeant, in the Federal Court Room at Philadelphia, is described as an eloquent and solemnly impressive scele. An eye witness writing to the Trenton state Gazette, says, that he looked bale and strong, for a man so near four score. His dress was scrupulously plain, and his enunciation very distinct and clear.

The following is a list of the bids for the Brick work of the Extension of the Capitol, opened at the Department of the Interior on Saturday: S. J. Driggs, at $4 85 per thousand; Frederick A. Burche, at $2 49; Joseph Fowler, $3 85; David Hepburn, $3 9??; Stephen Costar, $3; Francis E. Parker, $3 80; Geo. H. Plant, $4 32 ; Wm. J. McCullom, $7 50:

Why it is thus: The upper ten, to enjoy the pleasant air of yesterday, threw open the tea-room window, and, in its draught, did, what it seems by a late revelation, even BEN FRANKLIN, in spite of his theory of its impossibtlity, once did--"took a bad cold."

The sales of COTTON in the market on Saturday were 850 bales, at prices ranging from 8c.@9 1/4c. The market is depressed. CHARLESTON, Monday, Nov. 29. COTTON--Sales today 1,500 bales at 8c.@9 1/2c., the bulk at 9 1/4c @9 1/4c. The market is depressed, and shows a decline of ??c. @1/4c. CINCINNATI, Monday, Nov. 29. HOGS and PROVISIONS are less firm, but prices are unchanged. New-York sight EXCHANGE has declined to 1/2@1/4 discount.

"VILLAGE LIFE IN EGYPT," by Mr. BAYLE ST. JOHN, is a highly interesting phase of that much traveled land, which has escaped the annual caravan of observers. Mr. ST. JOHN is a narrow examiner of men and things, and an uncommonly pleasant writer.

MASSACHUSETTS TEACHERS ASSOCIATION.-- The Annual meeting of this Association at New Bedford, on Monday and Tuesday of this week, was a rich treat to the friends of Education who had the pleasure of being present. Very able and interesting lectures were delivered by Mr. GOLDTHWAIT of Westfield, Mr. HOVT of Dover, N. H. and Prof. FELTON of Harvard College.

A small building, No. 251 Pine street, owned and occupied by G. W. PARKER Co., as a grocery stores, was destroyed by fire with its contents, about 3 o'clock yesterday morning. The building and stock were valued at $2,300, and were insured at the Pawtucket Mutual office for $1,300. The house adjoining on the vist, occupied by WM. CLARKE, was considerably damaged--insured at the Concord office.

OYER AND TER??INER.-- Before Judge EDWARDS, Aldormen WARD and OAKLEY. The People vs. William Johnson, indicated for the murder of Charles Baxter in Conjunction with Hewlett and Saul heretofore convicted.--The panel of jurors was called by the Clerk. Messrs. John Cochran and Jonas B. Phillips appeared for the prisoner, and challenged several jurors for favor, and some peremptory.

Our news columns this morning present quite a contrast to the stirring accounts from various quarters published yesterday morning. We have no steamship arrival from abroad of which to make record, and the Telegraph brings little from the interior of our country of very general interest.

The Secretary of the Interior, to-day, awarded the contract for executing the brick-work on the Capitol Extension to FREDERICK A. BURSHE, at $2-19 per 1,000, being the lowest bid--the requisite guarantee and evidences having been given.
We have a pleasant touch of Winter--a clear, bright, blue sky, with just a sufficient frostiness in the atmosphere to make one feel nimble and frisky. It is a most charming day with us.

THE MEETING OF CONGRESS.--The hall of the House of Representatives and the Senate chamber are now in proper condition for their respective occupants; the Summer trimmings having been superseded by those in accordance with the season of Winter.
Heavy rains have fallen, and a great freshet ensued in various parts of Georgia, obstructing both mail and telegraphic communication. No mail from New-Orleans has reached us since Friday last.

The Corning (N. Y.) Journal of Friday, gives the particulars of the accident on the Tioga and Corning Railroad, six miles above that village, of which we had a partial account by telegraph Mr. Peter P. Guernsey, the Superintendent of the road, was instantly killed.

Some two years since, the jewelry store of H. D. Brackett, of Brattleboro', Vt., was broken open and robbed of a large amount of watches and miscellaneous jewelry. At the time, the value was estimated at about $3,000. From that day, no trace of the stolen property has been discovered.

The New-York Historical Society's Lectures have already been announced. The Committee in charge of the arrangements have deemed it advisable to effect a slight alteration in the programme. Instead of the issue of free tickets to the members of the Society, the rate of admission will be lowered to a uniform standard of five dollars for the Course.

The publication of the correspondence on Cuba is a very remarkable instance of both Executive and Legislative indiscretion. In the first place, the call for the correspondence was very irregularly made. The House of Representatives has nothing to do with the negotiations in their present state.

For several years, we have had an active agitatation against the exorbitant and unjust duty on Tea, which article may now be ranked among one of the first necessaries of life. This year, little has been said on the subject; but the Government must not suppose, from the absence of all expression of public opinion, that the merchants engaged in this trade, and the public generally, are indifferent to the importance of the subject.

Few of our readers can forget the sage ad vice of SAM. WELLER, on a certain occasion, "not to witness nothing." It would seem that this advice should be current coin in the metropolis. An emigrant arrives from Ireland en route to Iowa, to join his family. He has just money enough to reach them.

We now await the result of no less than three issues that have been made in regard to the Cuban flurry. The first and most important is that now pending between the Governments of the United States and of Old Spain; the next is between Mr. LAW and the Cuban officials; and the third is between this Government and Mr LAW.

The British mail steamer Severn, at Southampton, from Rio, Oct. 15, brings dates from Buenos Ayres of Oct. 2, and from Montevideo of Oct. 5. A revolution has broken out at Buenos Ayres, and MANUEL G. PINTO has been named Governor. without opposition or bloodshed. URQUIZA left Buenos Ayres on the 9th Sept., with the English, French, and American ministers, for Santa Fe.

MY DEAR FRIEND: I love children, I used to think when I was a bachelor, (it is a good many years ago now,) that there was something rather presuming in the manner in which doating fathers and mothers would bring their "wee things" around them, and, for the especial edification of us single fellows, cause them to " mis-speak half-uttered words," and to go through with divers little lessons in manners and elocution.

On Monday morning, Nov. 29, of inflammation of the chest, GEORGE POLE, a native of England, in the 28th year of his age. His friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 38 Beach-st.; St. Johns Park, at 2 o'clock, on Wednesday afternoon, Dec. 1.

"Remember the poor," says the preacher on Thanksgiving Day, and as he goes home from church, he must frown upon the poor who extend their hands for charity, or call on his trustees for a new remittance, on account of salary, before he can hire a carriage to ride to Madame SONTAG'S rehearsal.
A large and imposing concourse of people, comprising the City Councils, members of the Bar and Clergy, attended the funeral of Hon. JOHN SERGEANT this morning.

Hon. JOHN WHIPPLE, in a eulogy upon Mr. WEBSTER, delivered at Providence on the 23d, gave the following interesting account of some remarks by Mr. WEBSTER upon his method of intellectual culture: Perhaps I may not improperly here introduce what may by possibility be useful to the rising generation, the little I know of Mr. WEBSTER'S system of mental culture.

We have no mail south of Savannah. She storm has been severely felt in Georgia; rain fell during two days in succession, and much damage was apprehended from the flood. All travel had been suspended on account of the damage done to the railroad lines.

ANOTHER FINANCIAL OPERATION IN WALL STREET--CHARGE OF FRAUD IN GIVING A CHECK ON THE OCEAN BANK.--Within the past ten days another alleged fraudulent financial operation in Wall-street has been developed, and brought to the notice of the Police authorities at the Tombs.

Senator DODGE, of Iowa, recently addressed Mr. BENTON in regard to the bill passed by the House of Representatives at the late session, but defeated in the Senate, for the distribution among the States of FIFTY-EIGHT MILLIONS acres of the Public Lands.

Prior, Gay, and Pope. Mr. THACKERAY delivered his Fourth Lecture, last evening, before a larger audience than has been gathered since the opening of the Course. His subjects were PRIOR, GAY and POPE--a trio to which Mr. THACKERAY did full justice, and of whom he treated with an evident liking.

Indianapolis has 11,800 inhabitants, and is a city legally, and will soon be one actually, if it continues to increase to-day and to-morrow with the miraculous rapidity of yesterday. Seven several lines of railroads either centre here now or will do so within the ensuing six months.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--Some weeks since a convention, consisting of delegates from the different companies composing the Fire Department, was held at Fire man's Hall, for the purpose of nominating two candidates for the office of Chief Engineer of the Department, to be voted for on the 14th December, which resulted in the nomination of JOHN C. ROACH and JOHN J. GREEN.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR--In your paper of Friday last was a card signed by the Executive Committee of the grantees of the Beard of Aldermen for the Railroad in Broadway, which contained the following points and charges, viz: First. That the Times and the public accused the members of the Board of Aldermen with bribery and corruption in making the grant.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--An Irishman, name known, was killed on the Morris and Essex Railroad, at Orange, yesterday morning. He attempted to get on the platform of a freight car from the platform of the depot, after the train started, but in some way missed his footing.

By reference to an advertisement in another column, it will be seen that, in consequence of Mr. THACKERAY'S engagements else where, the arrangements for his second course of Lectures have been altered. The first course will be continued on Monday and Friday evenings, as first announced.

BROADWAY.--Mrs. MOWATT had a good audience last evening to witness her personation of the character of Rosalind. To-night she plays Mrs. Haller, in "The Stranger," CONWAY the Stranger, and Mrs. ABBOTT the Countess. The afterpiece is the petite force of "Petticoat Government."

IN TWO CHAPTERS--CHAPTER ONE. Capt. THIRFTY was born of poor but honest parents; and indeed it was their unbending honesty that was near ruining the financial prospects of the lad, for they taught him that it was better to be poor than to get riches after the fashion of Aldermen, and to be honest than to be President.
A new and most important subject has been presented to the American people within a few years, namely, the creation of a private steam marine, which should be available by Government in time of war.

The Eulogy upon Mr. WEBSTER, pronounced yesterday, at Boston, by GEORGE S. HILLARD, Esq., which will be found at length in our columns this morning, is one of the most eloquent and admirable tributes yet paid to the memory and character of that great man.

The great statesman who so long and so ably represented South Carolina in the council of the nation, once observed to us in conversation relating to this Island, that "Cuba was forbid to the United States."

THE EXTRAORDINARY COUNTERFEITING CASE.--THE FEXUERS COMMITTED BY THE UNITED STATES AUTHORITIES.--The important case of the persons arrested for counterfeiting the coin of the United states, as reported in the Daily Times of Tuesday, has been transferred to the jurisdiction of the officers of the General Government.

The latest intelligence from Southern California states that the office of the Land Commissioners at Los Angelos is still kept open for the reception of claims, al though it appears that the Board will not be in session again at that place, as Judge THORNTON did not intend to return thither. About one hundred claims have been filed since the Commissioners left San Francisco for the South. The Sacramento Times of the 30th October says:--

MISSISSIPPI CONGRESSMEN.--The Picayune calls attention to curious state of political affairs in Mississippi. The Legislature having adjourned without districting the State in view of the next Congressional election, a grave question arises whether there is any law in force for electing Representatives at all. The existing law, passed in 1846, makes four districts; but the State is entitled, under the new apportionment, to five members. There appear to be three opinions.

The Democratic portion of Congress--Senators and Members--are coming in fast, and together with their attendants and friends, present a very handsome appearance. They are, since the late Presidential election. decidedly the best dressed party of the two, and what is most remarkable on the score of reciprocity, they are dressed by the Whigs, in return for the dressing they have given them.

There is a very gruft old fellow going the rounds of the City, Unto whom, in humbleness of mind, we would by some means attract the attention of all loving citizens, both men and women. The police, probably, have not an eye on his ways.

To the Editor to the New-York Daily Times. That you get up the best daily paper our City has ever seen, is admitting are firmly persuaded that, out of ten so admitting are firmly persuaded that, "if you would just be guided by them, and give their views (only a little more so)," on matters in general, your paper would be "better as good."

TRIBUTE TO DANIEL WEBSTER.--On Monday evening last the citizens or Jamaica, L. I, assembled at the Union Hall Academy, to testify their appreciation of the late Mr. WEBSTER. The meeting was organized by calling Dr. NATHAN SHELTON to the chair, and appointing MARTIN I. JOHNSON Secretary.

In another column is published an article from the Journal of Commerce, which has been awaiting opportunity for several days. We give it as an epitome of the whole anti-annexation argument, and not for any intrinsic merits.

COLES, deceased. The following Resolutions, among others, were adopted:

IMMIGRATION, ETC., FOR THE MONTH OF NOVEMBER.--During the month of November, there arrived at this port 17,635 immigrants, in 229 vessels, the aggregate tonnage of which amounted to 106,079 tons. The following Table shows the countries whence the emigrants started, with the number and burden of the vessels employed in transporting them hither:

Yesterday, the citizens of Boston gave formal expression to their sorrow at the death of MR. WEBSTER. The day was most happily propitious; the weather serene and Indian Summer-like in its mildness; the gathering large and swollen by contributions from all the New-England and Middle States. Altogether, the various elements of weather, popular feeling, and the fulfillment of the programme were in satisfactory attendance.

The President's Message is in type, and special messengers for New-Orleans, and other distant points, will start with it tomorrow morning at 6 o'clock. The New-Orleans messenger expects to reach his destination at 8 o'clock on Tuesday morning, stopping at nine intermediate places.

OYER AND TERMNER.--Before Judge EDWARDS, Aldermen WARD and OAKLEY. The People vs. William Johnson, indicted for the Murder of Charles Baxter in conjunction with Hewlett and Saul, heretofore convicted.--The jurors having appeared and answered to their names, the Counsel for the prisoner called.

FROM SOUTH AMERICA.--The following letter will show that earthquakes and civil wars are not all the calamities they have to provide against in that quarter of the world. Diseases incidental to our own climate, also find their way there, as will be seen by the remedy they seek for protection.

From the London sun. THOMAS HOOD--the gay, the gentle, the bright eyed, and large-hearted THOMAS HOOD--is at last to have raised over his mouldering dust some token of the popular gratitude. NERO, monster as he was, had flowers scattered over his grave by some unknown hand as the sign of affectionate remembrance.

Boston has Literally appeared to-day in a dress of mourning. The obsequies of DANIEL WEBSTER were upon a scale of selemn grandeur, and imposing show, such as has been seldom, if ever, before witnessed here.

On Monday evening, 29th inst., JOHN, son of Alexander and Mary E Knight, aged 7 months and 23 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to at tend the funeral on Wednesday afternoon at 2 o'clock, from No. 25 Market-street. On Saturday, 27th inst., the infant son of John and Maria P. Thompson aged 3 weeks and 4 days. His remains were taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

COMMON COUNCIL.--A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen, was held at the City Hall on Monday evening, the President, Mr. Mansser, in the Chair. A communication was received from Win. H. Gulechard, tendering his resignation as Captain of Police, and Second Ward Policeman, to take effect on 1st Dec.--Adopted.

WM. DELANY, a native of Ireland, is the inventor of a very ingenious piece of ordnance, on the Revolving, or Repeating principle. A very complete and handsome model, made by himself, is an exhibition at the Montgomery Hall, Prince-street, where Mr. D. has given illustrations of its power and adaptability to several military men and others.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Bishop WAINWRIGHT, for the first time, administered the rite of confirmation yesterday morning at the Church of the Holy Cross, in this city, and in the evening administered the same solemn rite at St. Paul's.

We are surprised to see how many papers there are in the United States with two names. The country is now full of newspapers with double names, to write and print which is rather troublesome. These names have their origin in the union of two or more papers, generally in order, by assembling their divided and dispersed patronage, to make one which will pay a profit.

The London Morning Chronicle, in one of a series of articles describing the Industrial condition of Italy, has the following in regard to Venice. The account is by a reliable correspondent: The reversed circumstances of Venice are even more strongly impressed upon the visitor by the desecration of palaces to the purposes of trade, than by the dilapidation of neglect.

THE BRITISH PATENT LAW AMENDMENT--NEW RULES AND REGULATIONS.--The first set of rules and regulations under the new act for the passing of letters patent for inventions, and which come into operation on the 1st October, have just been issued under the authority of the Lord Chancellor, Master of the Rolls, and Attorney and Solicitor Generals, the four commissioners under the act.

The admirable programme of Monday evening is announced by Madam SONTAG for this evening, with all the Choral accompaniments. The chief exception which we have heard taken to this entertainment is that it embraces too many sweets.

The reference in the Queen's recent speech to the subject of transportation to Van Die man's Land will be likely to revive the old discussion about the propriety of that practice. Lord DERBY is prepared to recommend the disuse of the island for its present purpose; and either the entire suppression of criminal establishments, or the selection of some other location.

RUNAWAY SLAVES.--It is stated that a Convention was recently held by slaveholders of the towns of Kentucky bordering on Ohio, to devise means for preventing the lose of their "property" by elopement to Canada. They were alarmed at the number of escapes.

Mr. FRY commenced his Lecture on Music last evening, under very favorable anspices. A pleasant night and a full house were flattering indications. In these days of great feasts, it is something novel to effect a combination of choice harmony with expositions of the way in which it is brought about, and the plan is likely to receive a large share of the public favor.

The telegraph brings us a Sketch of the imposing ceremonial at Boston, yesterday, in honor of the memory of Mr. WEBSTER. The procession was very long, and the obsequies imposing and touching in the highest degree.
