The late Westminster Review has a very clever paper about style--which the gens de plume should read, mark, learn, and inwardly digest. BUFFON says, le style, c'est l'homme, and with a great deal of truth. Unless in treating of the exact sciences, in these days, when we must say over again what has been said many times already, the way of saying or stating a thing may be considered its chief charm.

It is in contemplation to erect a monument to the memory of Mr. COOPER on the summit of "Mount Vision," a bold peak, which overlooks his late residence at Cooperstown. The project has found many helpers in Otsego County, and is a worthy tribute to the great novelist, to whose name the pleasant village at the foot of Otsego Lake owes its past and present celebrity.

The imposing funeral obsequies to the memory of Mr. WEBSTER at Boston, yesterday, is the leading topic of interest in our news report this morning. The Legislature of New-Hampshire attended in a body, and the entire procession, when formed, was nearly a mile in length, and occupied over one hour in passing.

PATRONAGE OF THE CHURCH.--In the Church of England there are 2 archbishops, 25 bishops, 29 deans, 58 archdeacons, 355 prebends, 291 canons, 10,784 in cumbents. 4,837 curates, in some instances these dignities being held by one individual.

There is a scattering mail through from Mobile. Three New-Orleans malle are now due. The freshet did considerable damage at Augusta, Geo., the water coming down so suddenly that it carried off 200 bales of Cotton from the wharves, and damaged a considerable amount.

In the Massachusetts Supreme Court, on Saturday. Attorney General Clifford stated that he was ready to argue several Government cases which had come up on questions of law, the most important of which was a case under the new Liquor law, which came before the Court on the question of the constitutionality of the law,

The Democrats of this city had a second celebration last evening. The company was large and enthusiastic. Messrs. FOLLETT and STANTON were present, and made stirring speeches. Letters were also read from Messrs. DIX, DICKINSON, EDWIN CROSWELL and JOHN VAN BUREN, and toasts given complimentary too PIERCE, SEYMOUR, STANTON, Gen. SCOTT, and in memory of WEBSTER and JACKSON. Many speeches were given, in some of which Cuban annexation formed a prominent idea.
The First Annual Meeting of this Association was held last evening, at Hope Chapel. Every pew and aisle was densely crowded to excess. The attendance of the fair sex was very large.

The December issue of Harper's Magazine presents a rich treat. Filled with readable articles--of which many are original, profusely illustrated, and capped with the usual spice of the Editor's Table--it has a series of attractions that the public will appreciate very highly.

The Democratic festivities last night continued until a late hour. The principal speakers were Mayor MAURY, Senators DOUGLAS, WELLER, BROADHEAD, Gen. LANE, Dr. OLDS, Judge BROCCHCS, etc. DOUGLAS's was one of his ablest speeches, and was warmly applauded. He congratulated friends on the result of the election and the harmony which prevailed--was sure every Democrat felt proud of the bearing of their candidate before and since the election. It promised well for his administration.

LUNCH ROOM IN THE CAPITOL.--The best lunch to be had in the "city of magnificent distances," is in the lunch room at the Capitol. The readers of the universal Cotton Plant must not be surprised to hear that, within the walls of the Capitol of this great Republic, is just as snug and cozy a restaurant as is to be found anywhere in the world.
The Presidential canvass being over, a tolerably active canvass respecting the partition of the blushing honors, has succeeded. The stress lies between Young America and the Antique school.

Or rather what is he,--for everbody knows that he is Mr. SMITH, and that his name is WILLIAM. We have taken some pains to in quire, and from the information we have collected, we are confident in asserting that Purser SMITH is a human being.

OYER AND TERMINER.--Before Judge EDWARDS, Aldermen WARD and OAKLEY. The People vs. John Dolan, indicted for the murder of High Duffy, by stabbing him with a knife, or some sharp instrument, in the abdomen, on the 8th of June. 1852.

The Electoral College of the State of New York assembled this morning. At 11 o'clock the College was called to order by the President, and Rev. Dr. POHLMAN addressed the Throne of Divine Grace, in a patriotic and fervent prayer. The roll was then called, and, all the Electors having answered to their names, the minutes of the College for Tuesday were read by the Secretary, and approved.
We find in the American Law Register, an account of some recent trials in France, which touch upon the rights and duties of authors and editors.
Dec. 1. after a short illness, LEWIS ANDREW WATKIS, second son of Charles L. and the late Helen M. Watkis aged 5 years and 8 months.

A BRAVE OLD REGIMENT.--The celebrated 12d Regiment of the British Infantry, known as the Royal Highlanders, has completed the 112th year of its organization as a regiment, from May, 1740. it was embodied in Perthshire, Scotland. in 1730. as a local corps, and was widely known as the "Black Watch," the privates, even, being gentlemen by birth and fortune.

The City, in the contract for the enlargement of the Battery, "reserves to itself the right to dump dirt, , there, for three years." It was certainly wise in the City to take time enough to dump its dirt.

THE DANGER OF BEING ACCOSTED BY THE CZAR.--On one occasion the Emperor met VER NET, the favorite actor at the French theatre, in the street, and stopped to speak to him A group of persons quickly formed itself, and no sooner had the Emperor walked on again, than the police came up and took VERNET to the nearest guard-house, for having spoken to the Emperor.

A NEW INSURANCE CASE.--During one of the recent heavy gales on our Lake, the imminent danger of the foundering of a brig laden with railroad iron, drove the crew to the long boat for safety. In their efforts to get into the boat, several of the men fell into the Lake; but, finally, all but one were safely stowed in the boat.

A ROYAL, BOTANIST.--There is one King in Europe who is a good practical botanist, and who must look back upon the hours spent in the arrangement of his fine herbarium with far more pleasure than upon those wasted in a vain and retrograde course of politics.
YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--A Special Meeting of this Association was held last evening at its rooms, No. 659 Broadway.
The Electoral Colleges of the several States, assembled yesterday, and chose the President and Vice-President of the United States.

THE EXCHANGE AT HAMBURGH.--The building itself is one of moderate antiquity and respectable appearance, larger in its internal area, much more commonious, and somewhat lighter than our more splendid Tite-an structure in the city.

The following article, from the pen of Mr. WEBSTER, is sent to the Home Journal, by Mr. N. P. WILLIS, who says: "It was given to me, with much kind counsel voluntarily and generously offered, to aid my first literary project, after leaving college--the American Monthly Magazine. I published it, as I received his kind counsel then and at other periods, with grateful admiration of the author."

DEAR MR. EDITOR:--In the advertisement of the Historical Society's Lectures, which appears in the Times, it is said that "each member will be entitled to one ticket to the Course." Now, what I want to know is, whether that ticket will allow a member to take his wife.
This is the anniversary of the day when the French Republic foundered on the rock of Bonapartism. One year ago Louis NAPOLEON coined his blank Presidency into embossed, showy current Empire.

We have no mail south of Charleston--making four now due from New-Orleans. The Charleston papers of Monday state that the freshet was subsiding, and a large force had been sent out to repair the damages to the railroads.

The following extract from Dr. GUTZLAFF'S work exhibits the Chinese in a somewhat new light: Foreigners, who know nothing about the internal state of the country, are apt to imagine that there reigns lasting peace.

THE CRIMES OF COTTON.--Now that scarcely a civilized individual exists in any part of the world who does not wear cotton in some form or other, we may well wonder when we are told of the inveterate opposition with which its first introduction and use in this country was met. Under pretence of encouraging our woolen manufactures, laws were enacted to forbid cotton being worn by gentle or simple upon pain of fine or imprisonment.

BEHIND THE SCENES.--We clip the following clever sketch from the St. Louis Republican: A few years ago a danseuse of considerable note, who was serving an engagement at the "Old St. Louis," nightly turned every head with pirouettes and other deadly tricks of the art--to say nothing of her magnificent charius physique that wont straight to the heart.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT--As the 9 A. M. Philadelphia train from New York was proceeding about a mile beyond Rahway, on Wednesday morning, a horse, driven by Dr. ELIHU B. SILVERS. on the road alongside, be came entirely unmanageable, and was drawn by the Doctor to the side of the fence.

The National Intelligencer publishes letters from the United States Consuls at Tripoli and Malta, giving a description of a terrific hurricane in the Mediterranean, about 20th Oct. From twenty to thirty sail were stranded at Tripoli. and several at Malta.

The Baltimore Sun describes the Territory of Nebraska as extending from the fortieth degree of North latitude to the forty-third and from the Missouri River to the Rocky Mountains, and includes an area of 180,000 square miles.

COTTON has been active to-day--the sales reaching 5,000 bales, at previous prices. RIO COFFEE has been very active; the day's sales have been 7,000 bags, at 8??c@91/4c BACON has advanced. Sides sell at 8 3/4c.@3c-FREIGHTS have improved Four ships have been chartered for Liverpool, at ?? lb. for Cotton.

The Second Concert of Madame SONTAG was again largely attended last night. It was an improvement, in the spirit and celat of the performance, on the Concert of Monday evening. though the programme was substantially the same. The Madame was in capital voice, and so was the young Tenor, who certainly grows in popular favor.

Mr. THACKERAY's Lecture, last evening-initial to the Second Course--was surprisingly attended, and listened to devoutly. We have already expressed our gratification with all his qualities as a lecturer.

Miss BACON delivered an introductory Lecture on the subject of History generally, (intended to precede a course of Historical Lessons.) in the Lecture-room of the Stuyvesant Institute, Tuesday evening. There was a large and respectable attendance, principally gentlemen and their daughters.

The Bowery is looking up--at least the upper end of it. To say nothing of several imposing buildings that are progressing on other parts, the great improvements that are being made between the Third and Fourth-avenues, entitle the Bowery to hold its head as high as some other more frequently flattered streets.

TRICKS OF NECROMANCY.--The Chicago Journal lets the public into the secrets of the " Wizards." A conjuror's implements were lately seized in Chicago, and hence this exposition; In the hurry of departure he unluckily left at the depot a couple of large boxes, which the creditors of his wizardship immediately pounced upon, and which were found to contain the implements of his trade.

BURSTING OF A CAMPHENE LAMP.--On Tues day evening, about 7 o'clock, a camphene lamp in the shoe store of a Mr. SESANS, in Myrtle, near Nostrand-avenue, exploded, scattering the burning camphene in every direction. Fortunately, there was no one burnt.

In the year 1605, in the city of London, and parish of St. Michael's Cheap, was born Sir THOMAS BROWNE, M.D., author of Religio Medici, Pscudodoxia Epidemica, and other celebrated works, all remarkable for majesty of diction, originality of thought, and variety of learning.
"Father, I really hope we shall have another house, next Spring; this is so dreadfully cramped. Sarah and I have but one room for us both, and you know how bad it was when we had so much company.

Miss CATHARINE BEECHER makes an appeal in behalf of Poor Women, through the columns of the Erangelist. Her suggestions are timely: Has Woman a profession! Certainly she has; and its duties, in dignity and importance, yield to those of none of the professions of man.

We have the proceedings, by Telegraph, of six of the Electoral Colleges on yesterday, all which, with the exception of the New-York College, dispatched their business with the utmost promptness and unanimity At Albany there was something of a tiff between Barn burner and Hunker, in which the latter came off second best by the defeat of Mr. O'CONOR for the Presidency of the College.

The Miami, it may be known, is one of the principal tributaries that the Ohio River receives from the north. It takes its rise in the flat, marshy land covered with beech and poplar timber, which forms the central portion of the great State of Ohio, and flowing in a southwesterly direction discharges its waters into the "beautiful river" near the southwest corner of the State.
Not only is Washington convulsed with preparation for the approaching session, but the remotest extremes of the land share in the perturbation.

And who does not know how ruthlessly women will tyrannize when they are let to domineer? and who does not know how useless advice is? I could give good counsel to my descendants, but I know they'll follow their own way, for all their grandfather's sermon. A man gets his own experience about women, and will take nobody's here-say; nor, indeed, is the young fellow worth a fig that would.

The letter of Mr. FAULKNER, of Virginia, upon whose call the Cuban correspondence was furnished to the House of Representatives, shows one fact, as to which some doubt existed-to wit. that the papers were attentively examined by the President, personally, before he sent them to the House.

Friend HEMPHREY, in one of his excellent Essays, reminds us to be thankful for the blessings that cost us nothing; and in the list of such blessings, he Enumerates Air, Water, and several other very popular sources of daily comfort.

The Williamsburg Gas Company enlarge their works early next Spring, by building an addition to the present building, extending 112 feet on North Eighth-street, and 65 feet on Sixth-street. They also intend. during the next season. to build a large Gas holder on Tenth-street. which will be capable of holding about 300,000 feet of Gas.

FARMERS' CLUB.--Pursuant to adjournment, another meeting of the Farmers' Club was hold on Tuesday afternoon, when several subjects of interest were presented for consideration; that of the "Vitality of Seeds" elicited a lively discussion.

The following article is from the pen of a young lady of Alabama, whose reminiscence will be read with all the more pleasure for the scarcity of personal anecdotes of the great Southerner--Ed. Daily Times.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As many are contributing their mite to form a perfect biography of that great man whose death the nation bewails, permit me a place in your colomns for a vivid recollection of his first entrance into political life, which I give the more readily as I have not seen it, in all that has been written, much alluded to. It was in the Summer of 1812.

England, alter leaving her hero in limbo for an unconscionable space, has at last laid him to rest. The ceremonies, to which we have given a liberal space, were extremely imposing, representing worthily the sorrow that should follow the departure of a guardian genius, the loss of the champion of the sorest struggle through which England was ever called to pass.

UNCLE TOM'S CABIN IN FRANCE.--AN American gentleman, just arrived from Paris, writes concerning Uncle Tom's Cabin as follows: When I left Paris, five translations of Uncle Tom's Cabin were in progress: one by ALFRED MICHIELS, the well-known historian of Flenish Art; one by the accomplished daughter of the author, EMILE SUTVERTRE; one by M. LEROY, a contributor to the progressley Reviews; and two others, by persons whose names I leave forgotten.

CINCINNATI.--In 1788, Mr. MATHIAS DENMAN, of New-Jersey, purchased 800 acres of land at the specie price of fifteen pence per acre, in Hamilton County, Ohio. On that purchase now stands Cincinnati, the "Queen City of the West!" In the Fall of 1789, a survey of the town was commenced. The lower table land was covered with sycamores and maples, and the upper with beech and oak.

A parliamentary paper, just published, states that the surplus of income over expenditure, during the year to 10th Oct., was [pound]1,904,341 9s. 7d. The prospectus of the new "London, Liverpool and North American Steamship Company" is published, and appears to meet with favor from the business public.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your extract in to-day's paper, you omit the names of ten Scotch Regiments from your list. They are the First Royals or Royal Scotch, the oldest regiment in the world; raised in the reign of JAMES the Fourth, were at the battle of Flodden Field; and the history of there military services was written fifty years ago, in their volumes, and is a standard work.

LECTURE.--The lecture on the "Philosophy of Reform," was given last night to the entire satisfaction of all parties concerned. It came off in the First Presbyterian Lecture Room, and HIRAM P. CROSIER was the lecturer.

Here we are fast nearing the end of another year! We have traveled past the beginning of December already. There remain to us, for the performance of all the good intentions with which we were to signalize this year of our history, only twenty-eight days more.

SINGULAR CASE OF MURDER.--The British ship Fitzjames, Capt. HOYT, arrived at the Quarantine on Wednesday night, having on board among other passengers one wounded man, a Jew, named DRESTNER, a native of Poland, and also a German named AUGUSTINE BEHR. It appeared that these men, when the ship was about thirty miles from Sandy Hook, had a discussion on religion, and that in the excitement BEHR stabbed the other with dirk-knife.

Lord BROUGHAM has recently addressed a long and very sensible letter to Lord DENMAN, upon the Law Reforms which are to be urged during the present session of Parliament. His Lordship especially encourages the idea of a better and more extended system of Arbitration.

Throughout the country there are hundreds of young men, well qualified by the possession of health, and many years of practice to labor upon the farm, who, for various reasons, leave agricultural employments for the business of teaching.

We have no mail south of Raleigh, N. C. The North Carolina House of Delegates has passed a resolution, claiming for that State a fair and equitable portion of the public lands or proceeds of the same.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A writer on Art, in your able paper, has, in an article signed F. J. O'B., given expression to several very inadvertent errors, which I have no doubt he will very gladly see corrected in relation to the Pre-Raphaelite brethren. Will he permit an old friend of that able brotherhood, to set him right, the more especially as the matter may have some historical interest.

We have no mail south of Augusta, Ga. The Savannah papers of Tuesday state that portions of the Central Railroad were still submerged to the depth of four to six feet, and the water still rising. It would probably be several days before travel could be resumed. The storm extended as far south as Mobile.

ANTIQUARIAN DISCOVERY.--A few weeks ago, in clearing out the ruins of an old chanel in Nunaham Regis, in Warwickshire, which had been pulled down, all but the belfry tower, about forty years since, we thought it necessary to trench the whole space, that we might more certainly mark out the boundaries of the building, as we wished to restore it, in some measure, to the former state.

The British steamer Europa arrived at this port last evening, and brought three days later news from all parts of Europe. The leading feature in her accounts, is the funeral pageant of the late Duke of WELLINGTON, which took place in London on Thursday, 18th November.

Our good Queen has said her say,--whatever the Cabinet chose to write down for her; and that too, with "a firm voice, and in a clear and distinct tone." And her "loyal and faithful Commons" are debating the "loyal and dutiful address," they will return to "Her Majesty's gracious speech,"--which, in like manner, is the production of the same heads and pen that concocted the "speech."

The expression of the public grief in the observance of the obsequies to DANIEL WEBSTER in Boston, was very general and sincere. Through out the line of the Funeral Procession the streets were decked with the emblems of mourning, and the decorations and mottoes were very appropriate to the occasion.

Suppose that your very gentlemanly neighbor has possession of the only key that fits your door. The key is not yours, for you did not buy it when you took the house, nor is it absolutely necessary that you should have it, since, if you will be careful to leave your door "on the latch," your family has no difficulty in passing out and in.

A home in the West is quite a different thing from this "institution" in New England. There, the hallowed memories of nearly two centuries cluster around the hearth-stone. Here, the hearth-stone is but of yesterday; and the pioneer has only an unwritten history of struggles with disease, of triumphs over the prairie soil, and the rank growth of the forest.

A writer, who disguises himself beneath the malaprop name of "Young America," communicates the following information and private opinion to the National Intelligencer: "To correct a misapprehension under which "many of your readers are laboring in relation "to the innocent but ??obnoxious Purser "SMITH'--for the question is frequently asked, "why is he not 'Japanned' as well as Capt. "DAVENPORT?--permit me to say, he does not "belong to the Navy.

Accounts from Germany remind us that the modifications in the new Austrian tariff, will take effect in January next. At the same time will cease the ??. additional duty levied during the first year of the tariff on textile geads, millinery, and haberdashery, clothing, wrought metals, jewelry, and mixed labrics. In January likewise, the new duty upon cotton will come into effect.

A serious accident occurred last evening to the passenger train of cars that left Philadelphia at 5 o'clock P. M., and was due at the Jersey City depot at 9 o'clock P. M. The train consisted of a heavy locomotive, tender, baggage car, and five passenger cars, with a large number of passengers on board.
Recently, the Flibustier press has permitted no opportunity to pass of arraigning the authorities of Cuba on account of alleged hostility to Mr. LAW's steamers.

From the Boston Journal of last evening. At about 11 o'clock last night a fire broke out in the case-room of the third story of the extensive Piano forte establishment of Joans Chickering, No. 334 Washington-street. The flames spread with great rapidity, and in a short time the upper part of the back building was in flames.

The news of the reestablishment of the French Empire has caused little feeling in Madrid. Reports, were current, lately, that changes in the Diplomatic service were to be made, by which Senor Rt-QEELME, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, would be sent to Washington, but they are now contiadicted.

From Tast's Edinburg Magazine. Two very dissimilar scenes at one time contrasted in our mind, moved us to certain anxieties, inducing the present reflections. In the Parisian field of Mars, a multitude of admiring gazers saw the magnificent array of military France. Acclaiming shouts and thunder of cannon announced the possessor of that splendor and force, to whose name an idolatrous nation had again devoted itself.

Odd enough is the march of events in the world; some moving in one direction, while others counter march; and others again traverse the rest. While LOUIS NAPOLEON is making himself conqueror, on the strength of another's imperial qualities, England buries the man whose same chiefly rests on the extinction of the first NAPOLEON; and at Moscow they are celebrating the anniversary of their deliverance from the Frenchman's luckless invasion.

On Thursday morning, Dec. 2, SARAH LAVINA WARRIN, daughter of Thomas and Elizabeth Warrin, aged 4 ears and 11 months. The funeral will take place this day, (Friday,) at 4 o'clock precisely, from No. 12 Varick-place, (Sullivan-st., between Houston and Breecker-sts.) The relatives and friends of the family are particularly requested to attend the funeral without a further invitation.

It is well known to the religious community that this missionary was condemned by the criminal court of Athens to fifteen days' imprisonment and banishment. The former of these sentences is regarded by all the orthodox Greeks as executed.

BROADWAY.--Mrs. MOWATT played Blanche, last evening, in the drama of "Armand," written by herself. The play is full of passages designed to please the popalace, but it is not very novel in its incidents. The mock death reminds you of "Romeo and Juliet," and the plot same what too closely resembles that of the "Lady of Lions.
CANNING was not original in his facetious criticism of The Queen of Hearts, She lost some tarts, All on a Summer's day,

The Ministerial Lithographic sheet of Vienna examines at length the reestablishment of the Empire in France. The tone of the article is quite friendly to LOUIS NAPOLEON. Austria, it states, without repudiating the principle of legitimate succession, will not refuse to accept the new Sovereign of France, who is supported on the triple basis of popular election, imperial succession, and necessity.

HOTEL LIVING IN NEW-YORK--The Messrs. LELAND of the Metropolitan Hotel, are quite intimate with BARNUM. Indeed, it was said before they started that the millionaire of Iranistan had loaned them a plum or so wherewith to furnish the house. It would seem from certain signs that reach us through the provincial papers, that he has loaned them also something of his Psychology, indifferently known to the vulgar as Humbug.

CAPE COAST CASTLE COTLON FIELDS.--The Manchester Commercial Association has received intelligence of the successful result of some experiments in cotton cultivation at Cape Coast Castle, in Africa. A year and a half ago some of the members of this association subscribed upwards of [pound]1,500 towards an experiment of this kind. The money was sent to agents (merchants generally) at Cape Coast Castle.
The Electoral Colleges of Tennessee and Kentucky met yesterday, and cast their votes for SCOTT and GRAHAM. Hon. JOHN W. CROCKETT, son of the celebrated DAVY CROCKETT, died at Memphis on the 24th uit.

SARDINIA.-The company formed at Genoa, a month since, under the name of the "Transationtic Company," for the establishment of regular steam communication between Genoa and North and South America, has been authorized by the King.

The following brief account of India finance will be a sufficient answer to this question. The entire net revenue of 100,000,000 of Indians is rather short of [pound]20,000,000 a year. In the last year of the last Indian charter the Indian debt was [pound]35,463,483, bearing an interest of [pound]1,754,515. On the 30th April, 1850, or in sixteen years' time, the debt had accumulated to [pound]l6,908,064, and the interest to [pound]2,236,140.

AN UNFORTUNATE WOMAN.--A young woman, who some weeks since we noticed as having attempted to commit suicide by drowning, was, at an early hour on Monday morning, rescued from the water by some sailors, near the Hamilton avenue Ferry, where she again attempted to drown herself.

All Paris has been taken by surprise at the publication in the Moniteur of the Count DE CHAMBORD'S Protest, and the documents emanating from the Revolutionary Committees in London and Jersey. The Moniteur appends this notice to the Protests: "All these documents are now known to country; its good sense and its patriotism will judge of them as they deserve."
In Williamsburg, on the 1st inst. by Rev. John D Wells. WILLIAM WENDELL, of Albany, to Miss FRANCES EMILY, daughter of E. H. Roberts, DM of the former place

The event of the week has been the funeral of the Duke of WELLINGTON. It is impossible to convey an idea of the excitement that prevailed throughout the metropolia, the general holiday having liberated all classes, and every one belt, anxious to "asoist" at all the ceremonies.
Among the latest arrivals are Senators FISH, SUMNER, BROOKE and MERRIWETHER,--also, Hon.

The third, and last but One of the present series, of Madame SONTAG'S Grand Concerts, is given to-night at Metropolitan Hall. The selection of music, as noticed yesterday, is a very beautiful one, and the entertainment, we do not doubt, will prove every way delightful.

The funeral ceremonies of yesterday were impressive enough--though, in the opinion of some, not so much so as they might have been. The Fire Department, it seems, was not cordial, and a few other local discontents were talked of. But the demonstration was creditable, and the keen, sunny weather favored it, bringing the population a good deal out of doors, and crowding the thoroughfares.

The result of the Presidential election in the United States has been anticipated from various signs of dissolution in the Whig party of that country, and especially from the proceedings of the Convention at Baltimore, which served only to nominate a candidate whom the party never cordially adopted, and to increase the dissensions which it ought to have terminated.

As the hurricane is preceded by an hour of significant quiet and repose, so Washington, during the few days just before the meeting of Congress, is excessively dull and stupid, so far as relates to the discussion or development of political affairs. The present is the hour of preparation; the storm breaks on Monday next--and a considerable of a shower is generally anticipated, for the three months to come.

Winter is certainly putting this best foot foremost. December has thus far been as mild and pleasant as an Autumn day of the Poets. But Winter cannot be far off. As they say of the steamer, he is already over-due. Not long hence he will bolt in upon us suddenly, shaking the snow-flakes from his locks.

CANAL BOAT BUILDING.--This business is largely carried on at Rochester. The whole pumber of boats built in that city since the close of navigation last year, was 130, by fourteen firms. The average capacity of these boats was about one hundred tons, making the total new tonnage added the past season from that city, 13,000 tons.

The march of Free Trade through the month of November, has elicited several phenomena bearing seriously upon its future fate. The meeting of the Imperial Parliament has brought the subject to a crisis in England.

The steamship Isabel, Captain ROLLINS, arrived here to-day, with dates from Havana and Key West to the 30th ultimo. She brings the intelligence that the Captain General of Cuba had expressed his en tire satisfaction with the affidavit of Purser SMITH, in the Crescent City affair, and Mr. SMITH has now permission to enter Havana.

The south half of the three-story brick block on South Water street, owned by SETH ADAMS, Jr., and occupied by SPELMAN METCALF, fell with a tremendous crash, last night about 11 o'clock. The building was heavily loaded on all the floors with corn, flour, shorts and oil meal. The street was filled with the ruins.

The news from the United States is that FRANKLIN PIERCE is elected President. The event has been considered certain for some time past; yet is the question still heard on both sides the Atlantic, "Who is FRANKLIN PIERCE?" It is a continuation of the joke which told so well at the time of the same question being asked about Mr. POLK, on the same occasion.

GAME BEEF AND AN INDIAN'S APPETITE.--The flesh of a fat buffalo-cow is perhaps the best beef that can be eaten; wholly free from the rank flavor which marks the fat of the male; it is at once juicy, tender, nutritious, and very digestible added to which it has a game flavor which renders it far superior to the very best beef of the States.

The undersigned, Secretary of State of the United States, has been instructed by the President to direct the following communication to his Excellency, Mr. JOAQUIN J. D. OSMA, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of Peru.

"The poison of our time is a spirit of adventure." [ Tribune. Under the shadow of an old tree, hundreds of young ones start up, that never come to anything, which, if transplanted to some other spot, where the rain and sun could freely visit them, might attain to the full growth of the old one.

On Friday morning. Dec. 3, D. J. THORBURN GIBBS, in the 26th year or his age. The friends of the family, also those of his uncles, J. R., Wm. M and Jos. T. Thornburn. are respectfully invited to attend his funeral on Saturday at P. M., front the residence of J. R. Thornburn, No. 1,067 Broadway, without further invitation

BOARD OF EDUCATION.--The regular meeting of his Board was held on Thursday evening. Present, D. D. WINANT in the Chair, and a quorum of members. The Committee on School Books made a lengthy report relative to the books now in use in the public schools of Williamsburg, and recommended that uniformity in reference to the school books be hereafter observed in this city.

A LECTURE, BY REV. AMBROSE MANAHAN, D.D. The fourth Lecture of the series before the Catholic Institute, was delivered by Rev. AMBROSE MANAHAN, D. D., of Penn., in the Stuyvesaat Institute, Thursday evening.

There is talk of starting a Joint Stock Breast Pin Association among certain of the excellent ladies in the prouder walks of life. The movers in the matter are worthy persons living on the border between up town and down-town, who do a great deal better business than they are willing to confess.

It has already been said that we will not permit ourselves either to be frowned down or frightened. The knowledge of Cuban events, like those of any other country, we hold to be property of the world, and the world shall have them We have hitherto, and shall continue strictly to confine ourselves to such facts as come to our knowledge, and of which we are certain with regard to their truth.

It is with feelings of profound regret that we perform the duty of announcing the death of Hon. WALTER FORWARD, who died at his residence in this city, on Wednesday morning, Nov. 24, in the 66th year of his age.
MELANCHOLY SUICIDE.--Yesterday Coroner IVES held an inquest on the body of a young German named PHILLIP ANDREWS, who committed self-destruction by hanging himself with a silk cravat.

BUILDING MATERIAL.--In the present prospect of a rapid increase in the price of lumber, brick, , the following from the Scientific American will be read with interest. That paper, in an article on the cost of materials for building houses, says that a house near Fishkill has been constructed, the walls of which are prepared gravel.

We find the following communication addressed to the Editor of the London Standard, in that paper of the 19th ult: SIR,--As American corn growers have full liberty to compete with our farmers in the article corn, is it not a great injustice to prevent our farmers from competing with the Americans in the article tobacco?

QUARTZ CRUSHING MACHINE.--The mechanics of this City have their part in the golden harvests of California. Mills and machinery for breaking up the quartz and refining the gold into ingots is called for to an extent of not less than one million of dollars, and nearly all this goes to New-York workmen, for the raw material is almost nothing in comparison to the labor.

ROBBERY OF BANK BILLS BY A BOY.--Yesterday a boy by the name of George W. McCalvey, was arrested in Avenue B, by officer Bumstead, of the Third District Police Court, upon a warrant issued by Justice James II. Walsh, wherein he stands charged with stealing upwards of $500 in bank bills, checks and drafts.

Well, the grand funeral pageant is over! Our great Duke is not only dead, but buried! and well it is that it is so. The excitement for several days previous to the solemnity of yesterday, was most extraordinary and intense, allowing hardly of any other business to be thought of.

The Dalton (Ga.) Times thus speaks of a copper mine in Polk County, Tenn. Every few days our streets present a lively appearance from the influx of wagons, loaded with copper ore, on its way to New-York. This ore, we understand, comes from the Hiwasse mines, located in Polk County, Tenn., about five miles from the State lines of North Carolina and Georgia.
The Evening Post of yesterday, gives an account of the flare-up in the General Committee, thus getting ahead of the "National Democrat," which paper was promised a full account of the transaction.

The event of the week is the publication, in the official Monitcur, of three Manifestoes, emanating respectively from the Revolutionary Committee, and the Society of Revolution, at London; and from the Democratic Socialists, French exiles now resident in Jersey.

JERSEY CITY BIBLE SOCIETY.--This Society held its annual meeting in the First Presbyterian Church yesterday, and was addressed in an able manner by COURTLAND PARKER, Esq., of Newark. A large number of persons were present and evinced deep interest in the remarks of the speaker.

From Dickens's Household Words. Having received permission from the Tuscan Secretary of State to visit the MADIAI in the prisons where they are severally expiating their enormous crime of possessing a Bible, we determined to take the husband first in order, for, by a refinement of cruelty, they are confined in separable prisons, in different parts of the country.

COLLECTION OF SEEDS.--The American Farmer says that the present Secretary of the Navy, Hon. JOHN P. KENNEDY, soon after coming into office, renewed the order to our naval officers, commanding ou foreign stations, to be vigilant in the collection of such seeds, roots, and plants as were calculated to be introduced advantageously into the agriculture of the country.

THE VICE-PRESIDENT ELECT.--A meeting of the personal friends and neighbors of Hon. WILLIAM R KING, was held in the town of Selina, Ala., for the purpose of tendering to him some public expression of their feelings of regard and confidence. A letter was accordingly sent to him, inviting him to a public dinner, to which he returned the following reply: PINE HILLS, Dallas Co., NOV. 19, 1852.

The commencement of the month brings us fresh tidings from the various missionary stations. Mr. PEOR writes from Ceylon that he has of late been directing his efforts to secure houses of worship in the different villages of his parish.

COBBETT said that the way to make children "take to their books," was to leave books, such as were likely to interest them, in their way. The American father does the same thing for his children, in a cheaper way, by taking the daily paper.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You have taken pains to publish some of my letters and extracts, written concerning Mr. WEBSTER within the last ten years. Some of them, as you have stated, have been before published, but many of them, though written a long time ago, have never been in print till you placed them there.

BAD MADE WORSE.--A large reservoir, some ten or twelve feet square, and six or seven feet deep. has been dug in Eleventh-street, for the purpose of draining the large pond of water in the street at the corner of South Fourth and Eleventh-streets.

The Earl of DERBY rose, and, in a voice which was occasionally broken by emotion, spoke as follows: My lords, I wish by moving the adjournment of the House to put myself strictly in order in addressing a few observations to your lordships on a subject to which I am anxious to call your lordships' attention.

Poetry.--Stanzas by a Bereaved One. Literary.--Literary Odds and Ends; Style--A Mediterranean Poem--Screw ships-Bacon--Prohibiting the Bible--Irish Progress, , The Private Life and Domestic Experiences of Captain Thrifty. A Royal Botanist. A Brave Old Regiment.

BROADWAY.--Mrs. MOWAT played Ion last evening, in TALFOURD'S tragedy. Her voice was much improved since Thursday evening, and her performance was far more satisfactory than when she played Blanche, in her drama of "Armand. The last act was excellent, and we have seldom seen the interview with Clemanthe more correctly given. To-night she appears again in the character of Blanche, with the same cast as on Thursday evening.

THE CALORIC ENGINE.--It will be seen by the following paragraph from the London Mining Journal, of Nov. 6, that preparations are already in progress to contest the claim to this invention if it shall prove successful.

The death of Capt. GEO. P. UPSHUR, of the U. S. Corvette Levant, belonging to the Mediterranean Squadron now at Spezzia, though not unexpected, will be received by numerous friends at home with sadness. He had been ill a long time, and death was not unwelcome to the sufferer. The affecting event was noticed in the most becoming manner in the squadron.

The Boston Times, in its editoral notice of the WEBSTER obsequies, says: "General PIERCE was not present, the invitation being extended in such a form that he could not accept it without sacrificing a common feeling of self respect."

The House, in Committee of the Whole, have reported to extend the Charter of the Bank of the State to 1871. A collision on the South Carolina Railroad occurred this morning, between the night express and the up freight trains, about 14 miles from Charleston.

We have no mail south of Washington. The boiler at HAMMILL'S Steam Grist Mill, on Long Dock, exploded this morning, dangerously scalding an Engineer, named JOHN NORTH. Two conductors of freight trains on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, named JOSIAH RAY and ELIAS BEVINS, were caught between the cars to-day, and badly crushed.

JOHN TARR has been arrested in this city for selling two counterfeit Tens on the Marine Bank, Buffalo, and committed by the Mayor. One of the notes is dated June 3d, 1843. SAMUEL COWPERTHWAITE, convicted of the murder of a watchman named MILLER, has been sentenced by Judge KELLY to eight years' imprisonment.

EARLY WINTER IN THE NORTHERN SEAS.--The following report from the log of Captain DOLLE, commanding the steam vessel Amsterdam, which arrived at Dunkirk on the 9th instant, shows that although the weather in France has been like that of Spring, the Winter has begun to set in severely on the Baltic.

A distinguished lawyer of your city remarked to to me, not long since, that if Mr. WEBSTER made any mistake in the Lobos Island affair, it was in not maintaining to the last the proposition that the guano deposits there were free to the world.

The following official documents on this subject, which have just been published, will be read with interest: Message from the President of the United States, communicating, in compliance with a Resolution of the Senate, information in relation to Foreign Postal Arrangements, and especially Cheap Ocean Postage. To the Senate of the United States:

There are two very promising signs of the times visible in the following telegraphic dispatch from Philadelphia, which appeared in the Times of Thursday: "The Whig who obliged himself to saw half a cord of wood if PIERCE and KING were elected, fulfilled his task this afternoon, in Arch-street, having a large crowd of spectators."

FIRE DEPARTMENT FUND.--On Wednesday evening last, a meeting of the Representatives of the Brooklyn Department, assembled at Firemens' Hall, on Henry-street, and elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President--A. F. CAMPBELL, of Hose Company, No. 2. (reelected.) Vice President--William E Johnson, of Hose Company, No. 3. Secretary--E. E. Morehouse, of Hook and Ladder Company, No. 2. Treasurer--E. B. Morrill, of Hook and Ladder Company, No. 1. Collector--James Young.

From the National Intelligencer of Thursday. Among the visitors to this City at present is Captain HENRY SKILLMAN, a partisan officer, whose valuable services in Texas and New-Mexico are well known to a 1 who are acquainted with the hardships and adventures of those wild regions of the far South and West.

Some persons, seeing how large are the demands of the poor and needy, and how many Societies and associations operate for their relief without supplying the demand, are disposed to be discouraged, and drawing them selves within their shell, determine to take care of themselves and let others do the same. The hand is always extended for Charity.

St. John (N. B.) papers to the 1st inst. are to hand. They state that during the 30th ult., the schooner from Annapolis for St. John, with produce, was driven ashore and wrecked, and all hands were lost. Several other small craft are missing.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The German Refugees, you may have observed, recently held an interesting meeting in London, at which about three hundred attended. The meeting was held to commemorate the martyrdom of ROBERT BLUM, who was publicly shot after the taking of Vienna, by the Imperialists.

It will be seen from the letter of our Special Correspondent at Washington, that the particulars of the Guano Indemnity have been made out by Mr. A. G. BENSON and his associates, with a view to preferring a claim before Congress at the approaching session to the large amount of TWO-AND-A-HALF MILLIONS-DOLLARS!

O. F. N. N. Y.--These initials appear in the end of the new building recently erected at the corner of Court and Joralemon-streets, The letters are the largest size block letters; and during yesterday were made the subject of many remarks as to their meaning.

A description of Antioch College, of which Institution Hon. HORACE MANN has been Chair President, is given by a correspondent of the National Era: Antioch College is the name of an Institution established in Yellow Springs. Greene Co.. Ohio, by the religious body called the "Christian Connection."

THE IRON TRADE IN SCOTLAND.--In Glasgow and its suburbs there are no less than thirty-eight iron foundries, all in full operation, besides two now building, and three old ones not at work. The extensive mallcaole iron works of the West of Scotland Iron Company, at Motherwell, near Glasgow were lately exposed to sale at the upset price of [pound]23,000, and sold, after a keen competition, for [pound]42,050 to the Glasgow Iron Company.

SIR:--I have had the honor to address you on several occasions on the subject of our postal arrangements, and to transmit my correspondence with this Government relative to the rate charged for the transit of postal matter in closed bags through England to France.

A new five-act drama, entitled "Civilization," has lately been produced at the City of London Theatre and very well received. M. CLAPASSIN'S new opera, "The Mysteries of Udolpho," has been lately produced at the Opera Comique, Paris, and very well received.

THE FIVE POINTS HOUSE OF INDUSTRY.--It will be seen from the following correspondent, that a festival in aid of the Five Points House of Industry, is to be given at Metropolitan Hall about the 20th inst.

We have nothing south of Richmond this morning. One week's papers are now due from New-Orleans. More outrages were committed by the rowdies in this city last night, and no steps have been taken by the authorities to arrest the lawlessness.

THE PALM TREE OF SCRIPTURE.--Palm tree, ?? tree remarkable for loftiness, straightness, and productiveness, and hence made an emblem in Scripture of uprightness, fruitfulness, and victory. Its fruit is the date, very sweet and nourishing, and a large portion of the inhabitants of Egypt, Arabia, and Persia, subsist almost entirely upon it. Camels are fond of the stone.

The Cuba quarrel is at an end. Purser SMITH is again to have free ingress and egress at Havana. The steamer Isabel, at Charleston, brings news that the affidavit of Mr. SMITH is entirely satisfactory to the Captain General. The probability therefore, is, that the Cherokee will be permitted to land and depart in peace on the voyage she is now making, to New-Orleans via Havana.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times I observed a day or two ago, in your columns, an editorial speculation on the choice of a Senator to fill the seat now held by Mr. DAVIS, in which you suggest the name of Mr. CHOATE as probably a successful candidate.

HOMOEOPATHIC CONVENTION.--A number of physicians residing in Yates, Steuben and adjacent counties, assembled at Dundee, N. Y., on Friday last, and organized " The Union Homoeopathic Medical Academy of the State of New-York," under the general law of 1848.

The Montreal Telegraph Company are extending their operations, having just opened offices at Gananoque and Napauce....Two first class express freight steamers are to run at regular intervals between Hamilton and Ogdensburg....The body of Mr. C. CHRISTIE was found dreadfully mutillated, lying on the road to Milton, a few days since.

THE PROPER BANK-CHECK CASE.--The alleged charge of fraud pending against SAMUEL I. PROPER, on the complaint or EDWIN F. POST, broker, at No. 23 Wall-street. of whom he obtained $250 on his own check, drawn upon the Ocean Bank, where there was no funds to his credit, was brought to a close on Saturday afternoon.

CULPABLE CARELESSNESS.--A gentleman residing in Washington-terrace sent to an apothecary's shop for a potion of castor oil, and evening or two since, that was to he administered to a sick child. Observing

Our isoles are crowded with newspaper and pamphiet copies of Orations and Discourses delivered in all parts of the country upon the occasion of the decease of Mr WEBSTER, for no portion of which, no more than for the many columns of similar discourses pronounced in honor of Mr. CLAY, can we possibly find room at large in our columns.

BOOTH, THE TRAGEDIAN.--"Old BOOTH," as he is familiarly termed by theatre goers, is dead. Through good and evil report, through good and evil fortune, and through good and evil habits, he has maintained a long and strong hold upon the American stage.

BROADWAY THETRE.--"Armand, or the Peer and the Peasant," is the principal piece at the Broadway this evening. "Married and Settled" is the afterpiece. BURTON's.--" David Copperfield," "One Thousand Milliners Wanted," are on the bills at Barton's.

A vacant clerkship in the State Department was yesterday supplied by the elevation of Mr. G. BARTLE, who has for several years filled the position of a Messenger in that Department. This is carrying out the just and salutary principle of promotion by merit, for which Mr. Secretary EVERETT deserve credit.--National Intelligencer, Dec. 4.

GROWTH OF THE UNITED STATES.--In a letter to the National Intelligencer, Mr. WILLIAM DARBY. who has devoted much attention to the subject of the statistical history of the United States, makes the following remarks on the growth of the country.

We are at a loss to conceive of any excuse for the toleration by the authorities, for the rowdyism with which Baltimore seems latterly to be cursed. What is the trouble? The elections are over, are they not!

BUSINESS SEASON CLOSING.-- The Oswego Times says the business season is about closed there. There has been a large increase over any previous season in tonnage of property sent forward, and also in that received by canal, yet, owing to the reduction in the rates of tolls. there is a falling off in the amount collected at that place of over $7,000 as compared with last year.

A London letter in the Boston Journal says of Rev. Baptist W. Noel: Curiosity led me a few evenings since to a little Baptist chapel, in a somewhat remote part of the city. The evening was very stormy, but yet the crowd which early filled the chapel showed at once that some distinguished man--some man who had made his work upon the age--was expected to preach.

The schooner Mary Ellen, from Tampico 26th ult., has arrived at this port. She brings information that great excitement existed in consequence of a formidable revolution which had broken out in the State of Tamaulipas.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Recently a friend of mine took the occasion of my father's visiting Europe to present his brother, who resided in Ireland, with a copy of the works of Lord BYRON; which copy was, on arriving at Liverpool, seized by the British Custom-House officers, and condemned as a "piratical print:" duty was tendered them, upon it but they refused.

DIVIDEND.--The Citizens' Fire Insurance Company have declared a semi-annual dividend of 8 per cent. ROBBERY.--Two boys entered the grocery store of Mr. A. Wicks, on corner of South First and Second streets, on Friday afternoon, and called for some coal.

From the Mercantile Gazette. Our readers, in common with ourselves, no doubt have always believed, until the late notices by our co temporaries appeared, that the Labrador coast was as nearly a wilderness, and as entirely barren and desolate, as any place might be, which was from time to time visited by a few Esquimaux and fur traders.

GREAT OYSTER TRADE.--In illustration of the extent to which one item of the trade between Baltimore and the West has advanced, and that item, too, which has not been considered of commanding importance, we may mention that one of the largest and most enterprising concerns in the oyster trade is now forwarding daily to the West, by way of the Baltimore and Susquehanna Railroad and the Pennsylvania improvements eight tons of oysters in cans.

A young man by the name of F. J. E. WORDEN, engaged on the Rochester and Syracuse Railroad, as a brakeman on the emigrant train, was run over by the cars, and killed, about 11 o'clock on Saturday night.

The great want of New-York now, in a moral respect, is--Education for vagrant children. We are wont to think, because we have such a grand system of public schools, that the whole population of the young is well attended to.

A great Democratic Festival was held at Richmond, Va., on the 1st inst., in honor of the election of General PIERCE to the Presidency. At the dinner, the following letters were read from invited guests who were unable to attend; we copy them as indicative of the views entertained in influential quarters, concerning the character of the contest just closed:

Mrs. Doleful was what the world calls a fine lady. She resided in yon magnificent and most costly furnished four-story freestone dwelling; and was supposed to be favored far beyond most people of her acquaintance, with this world's goods ;--indeed, people did say that they knew of no one who made a more dashing appearance with their fine horses and carriage, costly equipage and livery servants, than did Mrs. Doleful.

After a short illness, on Friday, Dec. 3, CHARLES P. FREEMAN. in the 44th year of his age. The funeral will take place from the house of his brother. Dr. A. Freeman No 73 Union place, corner of 19th-st. and 4th-av on Monday, 6th inst, at 2 o'clock, P. M. His Friends and those of his brothers, are invited to attend without further notice. His remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery.

At the last advices from Persia, the Turkish Ambassador had not et had his audience of the Shah. The Shah having appointed an hour to receive him, and the Ambassador having delayed to come for four hours after the time named, the Shah indignantly refused to receive him both then and since.

ANECDOTE OF BUCKLAND.--This distinguished Geologist one day gave a dinner, after dissecting a Mississippi alligator, having asked a good many of the most distinguished of his classes to dine with him.

MR. BROWNSON ON LOUIS NAPOLEON.--We find in the Boston Pilot a sketch of a lecture by Mr. ORESTES A. BROWNSON on the politics of Europe, in which he speaks as follows of the President Emperor of France:
The Keokuk packet Geneva burst her boiler, twenty miles above here, last night while wooding. The boat is a total loss.

Congress meets to-day. As there is reason to believe that a quorum in each House will be in attendance, and as the officers in both are already elected, the President's Message will probably be sent in to-day, and we shall be able to lay it before our readers in our Evening Edition.

We published the intelligence on Saturday, brought from Havana by the steamer Isabel to Charleston, and thence to this City by Telegraph, that the Cuban authorities had recoked their interdict against Purser SMITH; and that American vessels were hereafter to be admitted to that port, whether he should be on board or not.

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--The total number of transient passengers over this road for the month of November, 1852, was sixteen thousand and eleven. Total number of transient passengers for the corresponding period of time in 1851, fourteen thousand one hundred and fifty-one.

A London Correspondent of the Boston Journal, describes an interview which he has recently obtained with KOSSUTH in London: A few days since, matters of business, of course totally unconnected with European politics, led me to seek an Interview with KOSSUTH.

The rumored resignation of the Mayor is unfounded. There have been no disturbances for the last few days, and the alarm is subsiding. The Mayor and Police are determined to check rowdyism by the most efficient action.

CINCINNATI CRIES--A NEW THING ON THE OHIO.--Our citizens were yesterday greeted by a street cry hitherto unheard on this side of the Alleghenies--nothing less than "Shell Oys-ter-s--Shell Oys-ter-s--Fresh from New-York yesterday."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: At a time-when deaths are frequently occurring from the use of Chloroform, it is the duty of every one to cultivate, as far as may be, toward the consummation of so desirable an object, in rendering such results less frequent.

Upon all the leading topics of international and maritime rights, the State papers of Mr. WEBSTER, elicited by the Treaty of Washington, are the highest American authority. It was the faculty and the characteristic of that analytic mind, to throw and to leave a flash of light upon every subject it glanced upon.

The Chicago Democrat utters a complaint at the high prices of provisions. Eggs, it says, are selling at 23 cents by wholesale, which is the highest we have heard of these articles selling for a number of years.

A MOONLIGHT STORM AT SEA--NARROW Es CAPE OF THE U. S. SHIP ST. LOUIS -- The Delaware Journal publishes a letter, written on board the U. S. ship St. Louis, off the coast of Tripoli, in which is described a remarkable storm encountered by that vessel on the 20th of October last, when about 70 miles from Tripoli, on her passage from Tanis.

The Concert of Madame SONTAG, on Friday evening, appears to have given very general satisfaction and she presents another delightful bill for this evening, freed entirely of the monster chorus, which, though kindly meant by the management, has proved rather a bore to the public.

AN IMPORTANT SURGICAL OPERATION.--We were invited yesterday to be present at the performance of a surgical operation on the person of a young girl of some fourteen years. The disease was a cancer of the jaw bone--?? surconia, in technical language--which had proceeded so far that a removal of a portion of the bone became indispensable to the prolongation of the sufferer's life.

The magnificent ball at the Palace, in honor of St. Isabel of Hungary, came off with great prestige on the night of the 21st. A great crowd was present, but I did not observe either the English or American Consul.

LECTURES ON THE CONLITION OF THE JEWS.--The Committee appointed to make arrangements to continue the lectures of Mr. MATTHEW A. BERK, have resolved to commence them this week. Admission free. Collection to be taken for the support of the lectures.

INGENIOUS MODE OF SWINDLING--IMPORTANT ARREST.--For several months past, a graduate of the Sing Sing State Prison, named CHARLES LIVINGSTON, has been practicing an ingenious and successful game of swindling, on a low scale, by which he has defrauded various Germans in the upper part of the City.
The bark Rebecca, with advices from Rio Janeiro to Oct. 24th, arrived at this port to-day. Her captain reports that at the date of his departure all was comparatively quiet.

Married ladies are doomed, in American life, to an early exclusion from all active participation in society. The fact is so obvious as to be the subject of frequent notice and criticism both by intelligent Americans and observant foreigners.

DEATH OF CHARLES V.--Towards eight in the evening, CHARLES asked if the consecrated tapers were ready; and he was evidently sinking rapidly. The physicians acknowledged that the case was past their skill, and that hope was over.
The value of the laud in the Kingdom, with the number of proprietors and of population, necessarily vary in the several commnues. The following are examples of some of the highest and lowest figures.
A severe rain storm has prevailed here to-day, and the weather is very thick. The indications are that our municipal election will be warmly contested.

THE LATE FIRE AT CHICKERING'S.--Workmen were busily engaged yesterday afternoon, and are also at work to day, demolishing the walls at the scene of the late disastrous fire on Washington-street. The street is stopped so that all vehicles are obliged to take an outside route.

The funeral of Watchman FOSTER, killed by the falling of CHICKERING'S building, was attended to day, by the Mayor and Aldermen of the City, the Watchmen in a body, Police Department, Odd Fellows, and many sympathising citizens.

LEGAL SKETCHES.--The Bar must occasionally allow that they know how to make the best of a bargain as well as the sharpest. A fat suit is apt to move rather sluggishly through a Court. Many a solicitor is apt to keep a Chancery case on its legs through two or three generations of litigants, when in fact the original parties to the suit have died and become rotten.

Governor MEANS, in his late Message to the Legislature of South Carolina, has the following paragraphs relative to the imprisonment of colored persons arriving at Charleston from other States or countries.

The Fall River line to Boston is in great favor now, owing to low prices. Among the crowd in the cars, as we came up from Fall River, was an old man, an original. I must tell you something of him, for he is of a type which you would find nowhere expect in America.

To the Editor of the London Daily News: SIR--Efforts are now making in England, Scotland and Ireland to raise a sum for the ransom of the family of JOHN WEIMS,--a free negro with a slave wife and children.

This has been a lively day in Washington. Members and officers of the two Houses of Congress Judges of the Supreme Court, newspaper reporters, letter writers, and strangers, have been coming in from every direction.

The suit of Gerhart Valton and Amos Adams, vs. The National Loan Fund Life Insurance Society of London, which has occupied the Circuit Court, now in session here, terminated yesterday in a verdict of $11,337 for plaintiffs.

It is quite common with a certain class of our Cuba annexationists to scorn the idea which is sometimes suggested to them that England or France would step in to prevent the carrying out of any of their plans of annexation.

The U. S. mail steamship Empire City, Capt. WINDLE, arrived yesterday from New-Orleans and Havana, with dates from the latter port to the 29th ult. The Empire City left New-Orleans on the 26th, and arrived at Havana on the 29th, leaving that port at 1 P. M. of the same day.

An important meeting of the Church Society has lately been held in Toronto, with regard to the manner of carrying out the provisions of the 14 and 15 Via., vesting the patronage of the rectories, formerly in the hands of the Crown, in the Church Society.
