We have no mail south of Wilmington this evening. The North Carolina Senate rejected the free suffrage bill, but afterwards reconsidered the vote.

It was a very arbitrary thing, the division of mankind into tribes, according to the color of their skin, the parallelism of their hair, or the height of their cheek-bones. For all these distinctions are variable, and constantly vanishing under the influence of estimate, habit and accident.

HAYTI.--We are requested by Capt. R C. DENNIS, who has recently returned from Port-au-Prince, to state, for the information of those who have lost friends there the present season, that in no foreign port do foreigners receive more kindness and attention in sickness, from the natives, than at Port-au-Prince.

OLD PAINTINGS AND THEIR PURCHASERS.--A citizen of Washington, writing from Rome to the National Intelligencer, makes the following reference to the picture shops, where sham paintings "by the great masters" are manufactured and sold: The Italians have a way of smoking bad copies of oil paintings, and making them a great deal older than the originals.

THE EARTHQUAKE OF 1814.--The most severe shock of an earthquake experienced in this section with in our recollection, was on the evening of Nov. 28, 1814, at 20 minutes past 7 o'clock. It gave a heavy and majestic noise and tremor in Portsmouth; the shaking of the largest blocks of brick buildings was apparent, and persons on the ground were much agitated.

There have been but few marine disasters since my last letter; our harbor is filled with vessels, but no wrecks. Provisions are plenty and can be had at moderate prices. The Brig Anita, DAMON, came near being wrecked on Friday evening, the 26th inst, she struck on the outer edge of Pickles reef, but succeeded in forcing her way over without receiving assistance from the wreckers.
Mr. WARREN STAGG, of Cincinnati, O., has opened a correspondence with royalty through a dozen sugar-cured hams, and Hon. ABBOTT LAWRENCE, Envoy to the Court of St. James.

The Free-Soil Convention this afternoon nominated J. HERON FOSTER, Editor of the Dispatch for Mayor. The trial of the naturalization frauds has commenced in the Quarter Sessions. Coroner SOWAY is the defendant.

FIRE.--Last evening, between 10 and 11 o'clock, a fire broke out in the stable of PATRICK KELLY, corner of Raymond and Bolivar streets, which was totally destroyed, together with a valuable horse. Officer SHAW, of the Fourth Police, rescued one horse from the flames. The total damage amounts to about $500 ; no insurance.
The Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions held their monthly meeting yesterday at 31/2 P. M. The proceedings opened with a Prayer, by Rev. Dr. BURCHARD.

The Second Session of the Thirty-second Congress organized yesterday, and both Houses immediately proceeded to business. The President's Message was delivered at an early hour, and is given in full in our columns this morning.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--Alderman COMPTON, President, in the Chair. The Minutes of the preceding meeting were read and approved. Petitions Referred-Nineteenth Ward.--Petition of Lawrence Odell and others, for a division of the Nineteenth Ward. (The reading of the Petition was called for.

The Senate was called to order at 12 1/2 o'clock by the Hon. W.R. KING. The following Senators were present: Messrs. Adams, Atchison, Bayard, Borland, Bradbury, Bright, Brodhead, Brooke, Cass, Chase, Clarke, Clemens, Cooper, Davis, Dawson, Dodge (Iowa), Dodge (Wisconsin), Douglas, Downs, Feleh, Fish, Foote, Geyer, Gwin, Hamlin, James, Jones (Tenn.), King, Mangum, Mason, Meriwether, Miller, Morton, Pratt, Rusk, Seward, Shields. Smith, Spruance, Stockton, Summer, Toucy, Upham, Wade, Weller.
There is a great excitement here--ALBONI gives a Concert on Friday, and Madame SONTAG on Tuesday and Thursday. next week. Preparations are making to give a splendid reception to Madame SONTAG.

Yesterday was set apart by the Governor of this State as a day of Thanksgiving, in accordance with which, all the public offices, the courts, and the banks were closed. The day previous was warm and sultry, and a drizzling rain prevailed; but yesterday the wind came out from the cold N. E., and the rain fell in "water spouts" without cessation during the twenty-four hours.

I have been requested by a friend, deeply interested in passing events, to give you this interval letter, although I have not time for arrangement of thronging matter upon my mind, and in this case I comply, not so much from the importance of the facts I have to convey, as from the spirit of encouraged vindictiveness which seems to be springing to aid the little intelligence holding the destiny of Cuba at the moment.

COTTON is in active demand. Already 9,000 bales sold at still lower prices. Strict middling is at 8 1/2 c. NEW ORLEANS, Monday, Dec. 6. The market for Western produce is heavy, owing to the rate of freights FLOUR has declined 25c The sales to-day have been 3,000 abis. Ohio at $4 40 CORN is ?ull at 50c Of prime BACON sides there is none in market.

LOSS OF THE PILOT-BOAT YANKEE, No. 7.--The pilot-boat Yankee, No. 7, was lost on Friday night last, while lying to under a double-reefed mainsail, 35 miles east of Sandy nook. The pilots, who were saved, suppose she struck a sunken wreck, and almost instantly she settled by the head and went down.

The new Catalogue of the Officers and Students of Williams College, gives the names of eight officers of instruction and government, viz.: the President, five Professors, one Tutor, and a Teacher of French and German. Of Students, there are 30 members of the Senior Class, 66 in the Junior, 57 in the Sophomore, and 41 in the Freshman Class, making a total of 203.

DANIEL STREET and wife, father and mother of four children, and deck passengers on board the steamer James Millinger, from St. Louis to Louisville, recently committed suicide under the following circumstances: When near Evansville, the wife seized the youngest child, an infant, and jumped into the river.

We have advices from Texas to the 19th of Nov. The news is to important. From the Galveston Journal we learn that the sale of San Antonio city lands commenced on the 8th ult., and so far the lots had sold considerably above the appraisement.

COURT CALENDAR--Tuesday--SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM --" The Million Trust Case" still on, and likely to occupy the year out. COMMON PLEAS--Part I.--Nos. 491, 495, 499, 503 to 511, 515 to 521, 527 to 531, all odd numbers. Part II.--Nos. 150. 578, 580, 582 to 604, all even numbers.

The booksellers cannot get rid of one edition of the works of Mr. CALHOUN, a fact which moves the press generally to lamentation at the decay of patriotism and taste. All those grave discussions of Constitutional law; all those acute hermeneutics of the Declaration of Independence and of the Federal compact, all those masterly speeches and letters appealing to the South, against Federal aggression; they all slumber in uncut sheets, and unopened boards.

The Steamship Black Warrior has arrived at Mobile with Havana dates to the 2d inst. The reports that Captain GRAY and the mates and crew of the American Ship Lany Suffolk had been imprisoned on the charge of selling the ship for the Slave trade, and equipping her accordingly The arrest was based on information given by the British Consul.

Sterne and Goldsmith. Mr. THACKERAY closed his series of Lectures last evening. The attendance was large, and the interest manifested still greater than that which has usually been evinced. He began his notice of STERNE by referring to his father, ROGER STERNE, who was a Lieutenant in MARLBOROUGH'S war, married the daughter of a sutler, and was severely wounded in a duel which grew out of a dispute about a goose.

All's well that ends well. I forgive JOHN for appropriating the tickets intended for me. Had I net, however, received tickets for Mr. THACKERAY's Second Course, I doubt whether I should have found the practice of that Christian virtue quite so easy.

The brief space which has elapsed since the close of your last session has been marked by no extraordinary political event. The quadrennial election of Chief Magistrate has passed off with less than the usual excitement.

FACTS FOR THE NEXT EDITION OF UNCLE TOM'S CABIN.--There died lately, in a lower county of Virginia, a mulaon man who was manumitted by his master, and was under our law permitted to remain in Virginia. His master had with his liberty, left him a respectable property, and this man by industry accumulated an estate of $25,000.

The first exhibition of the Poultry Society took place in this city a few days ago. Such spectacles are as yet rare in this or any other country, and it is, perhaps, less the novelty than the utility of them that attracts public attention.

The President's Message is a clearly written, unpretending and satisfactory document. It gives, with reasonable fullness, information concerning the condition of the Country in its various relations and interests, and evinces throughout an earnest anxiety for the public peace and prosperity.

A fire broke out in this city about 12 o'clock last evening. consuming the Franklin House, situated in Franklin-square, with several other dwellings and stores. The freight depot of the Hudson River Railroad was in imminent danger, but was fortunately saved.
Three men, named COLEMAN, CUTTING and BUTTERWORTH, have been arrested at New-Orleans for a large robbery committed at the house of DELANO SONS.

From the National Intelligencer. The letter of the Secretary of State to the Peruvian Minister of Nov. 16 (relative to the Laboes Island affair) has appeared in some journals. It is not, however, the original letter as written by Mr. EVERETT, but a translation into English from some translation into a foreign language, probably the Spanish.

The Valedictory Message of President FILLMORE, is given in full in our columns this morning. It is a temperate document, of moderate length, and takes a comprehensive view of all questions of national interest.

The strength acquired by rumor "eundo" is finely illustrated by the reputed illness of Hon. WILLIAM R. KING. It started from Alabama, a feeble bantling, a mere gossiping report that Mr. KING had a cold in the head, a cough, a touch of lumbago, or a twinge of rheumatism in the left shoulder.

Patriotism is too often talked of as a virtue that belongs especially to Statesmen, and men of official standing. It is indeed essential to the character of a good Statesman, but it is not his exclusively. The true patriot remembers, that to have his country loved, it must be made lovely.

GAS WORKS.--The Gas Company are prepared to supply the City with gas, but the Common Council have not passed resolutions with regard to its use in the streets. COMMON COUNCIL.--The Council meet to-night at the Common Council Chamber, Grand-street.

The latest accounts from the interior of Georgia represent the fre-hers as having been far more destructive than was anticipated. In the vicinity of Columbus, the Chatahoo?? river is reported to have swollen to the extent of thirty-feet. Buildings were undermined, bridges washed away and various factories and other property were materially damaged.

The importance of the copper trade to Michigan can scarcely be over-estimated, any more than the extent and value of her copper mines. We have more than once referred to a single section bought on speculation, not long since, for about $2.600, that is now valued at more than $100,000, and is probably worth more than tour times that sum.

GEOGRAPHICAL DEPARTMENT OF THE MERCANTILE LIBRARY.--The Mercantile Library Association have added a new and excellent feature to their Institution. viz : a Geographical Room, for the deposit of maps, charts, astronomical and nautical surveys, and statistical and other tables connected with geography and navigation.

Hear what the New-York correspondent of the London Times says of the ultimate consequences of the election of General PIERCE: "One of the not distant results, probably, will be the withdrawal, or banishment of the whole tribe of fanatics from the Democratic ranks--1, the Abolitionists; 2, the Fillibusters and Pirates: 3, the Women's Rights Dreamers; 4, the Bloomers, et id genus omnc.

The second of Mr. FRY'S Lectures on the History of Music, drew together a still larger audience, and entertained them quite agree ably. The proportions of the Lectures are to be curtailed hereafter so as to come within the ordinary compass, the only amendment needed to complete the pleasure of the auditors.

There seems to be a growing disposition at Washington, to override and set at nought the checks and balances provided by the Constitution and the laws, to guard the public Treasury, and conserve the public monies to legitimate use. There is a strong necessity for some immediate; earnest, and decisive action in the premises by Congress.

To the Editor of the New--York Daily Times: There is no longer any policy in sneering at Woman's Rights. The long nights are upon us; grim old Winter stands shivering at our threshold, occasionally even favoring us with a visit up stairs, and Mrs. OAKES SMITH is delivering her lectures at the Tabernacle.

By the steamship Yacht, Captain LAWLESS, from Brazos St. Jago, via Galveston, we have our Texas papers. The steamship United States, Capt. G. F. MARTIN, arrived off the bar at Galveston on Saturday night, the 20th inst., about 9 o'clock; but, as the wind was then blowing heavily from the east, she could not come over, and had to put out to sea for safety.

From the Boston Atlas. It is not a mere Piano-Forte Factory which has been destroyed, but a familiar temple of music, to which not only our own worshippers have paid daily devotion, but into which the pilgrims from many a foreign land have come; very many of whom have obtained comfort and support.

FROM VENEZUELA.--The bark Venezuela, Captain WILSON, arrived at this port last night, having sailed from Laguayra Nov. 13th, and from Porto Cabello, Nov. 18th. We have received by her the following letter:

We learn by the Lake Superior Journal that the Iron Mountain and Lake Superior Railroad has been pushed forward with energy under the superintendence of Mr. ELY, and the hardest part to the work has been done. The route has been cut out from the Lake to the Mountain, considerable grading and grubbing has been done, and the Road is to be finished early next Summer.

The milkmen of the city of Providence, as has already been announced in our courans, have determined hereafter to sell by wine measure, instead of bear measure, which makes a reduction of one-fifth in the Quantity delivered.

There or four weeks ago, a person calling himself HOUGHTON, and who gave out that he was a wealthy English gentleman, arrived in the town of Bloomington, Illinois. Possessing a favorable exterior, and having a pleasing, plausible address, he soon gained the confidence of several of the principal citizens, to whom he communicated his intention of investing some capital in their place.

BROADWAY.--Mrs. MOWATT played Ion last evening, to a large audience. The performance was far better than on its first representation. Mrs. M. is fast recovering her natural voice, and the difference in her acting is plainly observable. She does not appear to labor so much, and their is less of the ranting, which we have heretofore noticed as so objectionable in an actress. She was warmly applauded and is certainly growing in public favor.

On Monday, the 6th inst., WILLIAM E. COLEMAN, aged 27. His remains will be taker to Bridgeport for interment. At Hastings, Westchester County. on the 4th inst, SARAH, daughter of Robert B. and Anna Many Minturn, in the 7th wear of her age.

The Churches in the Atlantic States are by no means unmindful of the spiritual welfare of the emigrants to California. We have within a few weeks noticed the departure of several bands of Miseionaries, sent out by various denominations. Indeed, they seem to go out by almost every departure.

A LECTURE--BY E P. WHIPPLE, ESQ. The first lecture of the course before the Me chauies' Soceity was delivered Monday evening by EDWARD P. WHIPPLE, Esq, of Boston, to a large and respectable audience, in the Lecture-room of the Society, No. 472 Broadway.

FOSSIL ELEPHANT EXHUMED.--A highly interesting discovery of what is termed the "Fossil Elephant," was made Yesterday, on the line of the Central Ohio Railroad, on the river bank, near the residence of B. VANHORNE, Esq., in the eastern portion of our city.

From the Florida (Tallarace) Sentinel. Before the establishment of this Government. and before or about the time that the territory which now conistitutes the State of Tennessee was ceded to Congress, the inhabitants of the Eastern part of that territory established a Government for themselves, and called it the State of Franklin. They adopted a very goor Constitution, divided into the usual branches of legislative, executive and judicial power.

Our readers, (says the Armaugh Gnaradian.) know as a matter of history that several ships belenging to the Spanish Armada, destined for the conquest of England, were driven away by storm to the West coast of Ireland and wrecked. We find from Mr. WoonHouse Mr. Ireland and Rescked that two of these vessels are lying off the coast of Donegal, one of these at Mullaghderg, in the Rossas, and the other some miles further northward.

The Southern mail has arrived with New-Or leans dates of the 1st inst. The Democratic Convention of Louisiana nominated PAUL HERBERT, of Iberville, for Governor. A fire at Barnesville, Georgia, on the 27th ult., destroyed HIGHTOWER'S hotel and Mr. NULLING'S store, entailing a loss of $18,000. The property was insured for $12,500.

SIXTH ANNUAL DINNER OF THE ST. NICHOLAS SOCIETY OF NASSAU ISLAND.--On Monday evening, the members of this Society, and invited guests from all parts of Long Island assembled at the Hotel of JOHN I. SNEDIKER'S, on the Brooklyn and Jamaica Plank-road to partake of their Annual dinner, and on this occasion also to elect a President in place of General JEREMIAH JOHNSON, deceased.

THE CONFESSION OF BLAISE SKUPINGKI.--The following statement is made by the Rev. CELESTIN WILLIM, in relation to the interview with Mr. Ro MERTZE, referred to in the Ledger of yesterday: -- "A communication appeared in the Ledger of to-day, calculated to produce a false impression of an interview between Mr. HENRY ROMERTZE, the interpreter, and myself, in relation to BLAISE SKUPINSKI, the unfortunate man who was executed on Friday last.

CONFIRMATION.-- Yesterday morning, Arch Bisshop HUGHES administered confirmation in the Church of St. Charles Borromeo, to a large number of boys and girls, all of whom first received communion; the Bishop then made a short address to them from the 8th Chapter of Acts of the Apostles, 14th Verse, giving them to understand that no worldly fear or shame should dater them from profesing their religion, and to live as becomes the Church of Christ.

This may truly be called an Iron Age. Virgin ore, dug from the bowels of the earth, is shaped by science and skill to meet a hundred uses to which man kind have applied it. Implements of husbandry, of war fare, and of household utility, have improved under the teachings of experience, until we have now a complete and general collection of the best appliances of industry.

A series of articles on the Amazon and tributaries, which has recently enlivened the columns of the Washington Union, is understood to be from the pen of Lieut. MAURY. The author has obviously studied the topic with con amore fondness, assisting it with a knowledge of winds and currents, and meteorological phenomena, which very few men possess with the same thoroughness as the accomplished lieutenant.

LAYING THE CORNER STONE OF A NEW CHURCH.--The ceremony of laying a corner stone of a new Methodist Episcopal Church in Seventeenth-street, between the First and Second avenues, took place on Monday afternoon. The building will be a substantial brick edifice, with stone front, 55 feet by 85 deep. Its probable cost, including grounds, building and properties, is estimated at $23,000.

Mr. FRY, on opening, stated that in obedience to the dictates of the musical critics of the City, he had determined to abbreviate somewhat his lecture for this evening; after which introduction he said:

A telegraphic dispatch, dated New-Bedford, Dec. 7, says: "The bark Avola, HUMPHREY, from Charleston for Boston, with a cargo of middling cotton, struck on the Sow and Pigs at 4 o'clock this morning, and after thumping a while, came off with 5 feet of water in her hold, and leaking badly, when the crew abandoned her. She fell on her beam ends, and shortly after capsized.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: These women are always grumbling. We unfortunate men have to abide the infliction of mental three-legged stools and hide our diminished heads,--all because there is so much talk about Woman's Rights and her Wrongs. Heaven knows the men have wrongs too, only they are so modest they do not blazon them forth like the "fair" sex. Woman's prerogative is to govern mankind.

The first organized meeting ot the Shipwrights and Caulkers of the City and County of New-York was held Monday evening at Chatham Hall, Chathana-square. There are upwards of 1,000 men in the City who are employed in this trade, and although the movers in this benevolent object have only held three preliminary meet ings prior to the one last night, they have already about 275 members.

ANOTHER DREADFUL CALAMITY--FALLING OF A FIVE STORY BUILDING--THE CONTRACTOR AND TWO JOURNEYMEN MASONS INSTANTLY KILLED--SEVERAL MECHANICS INJURED.--It becomes our painful duty to record the details of another dreadful calamity, which occurred in the upper part of the city, yesterday, and resulted in the loss of several human lives, and a number of workmen being injured to such an extent that it is feared they cannot survive.

The Senate commenced proceedings at 121/2 o'clock. Messrs. BADGER, BUTLER, CHARLTON, PEARCE, and HUNTER appeared to-day. The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Navy Department, calling for a plan of classification of Clerks, which was laid on the table and printed. A message was received from the House, with a resolution, providing for the election of Chaplains, which was taken up, and concurred in by the Senate.

We have no mail south of Wilmington. The Virginia House of Delegates has passed a bill authorizing the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad Company to increase its Capital Stock $1,500,000. Also, authorizing the Manassas Cap Railroad to increase its Stock $l80.000. The bill to establish a line of Steamers between Norfolk and Antwerp, has been postponed to the 14th inst.

THE CITY OF BOSTON AT ISSUE WITH THE OLD COLONY RAILROYD CO.--A few weeks since an order was passed in Board of Aldermen that all the sidewalks on Turapike street, South Boston, be forth with paved with brick. The Old Colony Railroad Company have in the line of this street their Freight Depot, extending from First-street to Broadway.

The Farmers' Club held their usual monthly meeting in the rooms of the Institute. General TALMADGE in the chair. The subjects under consideration at the meeting were New Plants, New Uses of Old Plants, and American Madder.

Professor OLMSTED of Yale College, delivered his first Lecture on Astronomy Monday evening in the Tabernacle. He was introduced to an intelligent audience, as about to commence a series of four Lectures to follow each successive Monday evening, an undertaking projected by a few gentlemen in this City, and one which every person saw was much to their credit.

From the Hudson Daily Star of the 4th. We are called upon to record the melancholy result of a most disgraceful proceeding, which occurred in the village of Claverack, in this County, on Thursday night, among a party of resident Irish and a large gang of rowdies from this City, in which one of the latter, MICHAEL MCCARTHY, about 18 years of age, was brutally killed.

It is strange that no one has ever yet made a determined onslaught upon certain peculiarities of speech that prevail in Yankeedom, in defiance of good taste, and of the practice of the best speak ers of the language. Dr. HOLMES, indeed, in his "Urania." (a poem whose beauties and felicities are not half enough appreciated,) has dealt some hard hits at some of them, as, for instance, speaking of the Muse:

Rev. Dr. NEAL, of the First Baptist Church in Boston, made Mr. WEBSTER the theme of his Thanks-giving discourse. Referring to the great anxiety entertained by Mr. WEBSTER'S friends, when it was known that he was to reply to HAYNE, during the "great debate," Mr. NEAL remarked that" Mrs. WEBSTER shared in the general anxiety, and was present in the gallery of the Senate on that eventgual morning, filled with nervous trepidation.

Mr. DEMPSTER gives a ballad entertainment at the Tabernacle, this evening. "The Indian's Complaint," "John Anderson," " Duncan Gray," and "The May Queen," are in the programme. This is the last Concert which Mr. D. will give in this City the present season, and to give all an opportunity of hearing him he has reduced the price of admission to twenty-fivecents.
The sloop-of-war St. Mary's brings Cape Town papers to the 26th October. The steamship Great Britain, from Liverpool, for Australia, arrived at Table Bay on the 10th October.

The only topic of general interest here is the contest in the Senate relative to the right of Mr. DIXON to a seat in that body, which continues to attract universal attention, the debate upon it only serving. to increase the interest. No new developments in relation thereto occurred to-day.

By the Halifax papers we notice that heavy falls of snow have taken place there and in various parts of the Province. So violent was the storm on the 24th ult, that the Telegraph line between Amherst and Sackville, a distance of only 9 miles, was broken in 60 places. Snow has fallen to the depth of 4 feet on a level in Picton, seriously retarding the mails.

The regular monthly meeting of the Society, held in the lecture room of the University, on Tuesday, was largely attended. Gov. BRADISH, President, in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read by Mr. GEO. H. MOORE, Librarian, in the absence of the Recording Secretary.

LATER FROM SANTA FE.--The Santa Fe mail reached Independence on the 27th ult. It was delayed somewhat below its usual time. This delay has been in consequence of frequent storms of rain, sleet and snow. At Fort Union, the snow had fallen to the depth of eighteen or twenty inches. On the Journada, but little was to be seen Nearer the States, the ground was covered, more or less, according to locality.

The Report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office is a document of a good deal of interest, and likely to give the reader a large idea of scope of the duties and labors that pertain to that office.

CHARLES WHITNEY, Esq., delivered his second lecture to an intelligent audience last evening, in the Stuyvesant Institute. He commenced with the Indian Chief so well known as RED JACKET, whose original name was "Always Ready;" he was considered a great warrior by his people, nor was he devoid of great oratorical powers in their imagination.

The entire collection of Pictures of the American Art Union is to be sold at auction on the 15th, 16th, and 17th days of the present month. Our readers are already aware of the circumstances which render this proceeding on the part of the Managers necessary for the interests of the subscribers.

The bark Avola, from Charleston, before reported, lost on the Sow and Pigs, is insured in this city on the vessel and cargo for $21,000. At last accounts there was a fair prospect that she would be towed into port. A part of her deck load of cotton had been picked up by lighters.

ARRIVAL OF THE U. S. SLOOP-OF-WAR ST. MARY's--The United States sloop-of-war St. Mary's, Commander MAGRUDER, arrived at the Delaware Break water last evening, and reached the Philadelphia Navy Yard this morning, after a very rapid passage from the Pacific via the Cape of Good Hope.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDANT.--Tuesday evening, at 6 o'clock, near Elizabethtown, a man named STEVENSON was run down by the Philadelphia train and killed instantly. A Coroner's inquest was held and a verdict given in accordance with the facts. Another man, name unknown, was killed about the same time, on the New-Jersey Central Railroad. The bodies of the dead were brought to Elizabethtown in the same train.

On the evening of the 7th inst.. of consumption. WALTER LIBBEY, in the 26th year of his age. His friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend his tunerai on this Thursday.) 9th inst..at 2) o'clock. P.M., from the residence of his father, No. 124 Prince-at., Brooklyn. In Brooklyn. on Monday, the 5th inst., of consumption, WILLIAM M. ROYCE. aged 45 years.

The Senate commenced business at 12 1/4 o'clock. Mr. HALE appeared to-day and took his seat. The CHAIR laid before the Senate the report of the Land Office on private claims in Louisiana. Tabled, and ordered to be printed.

MADAME SONTAG IN OPERAR.--On the conclusion of Madame SONTAG'S Concerts here, she will visit Baltimore and Washington, and having delighted our friends at the South, will return to New-York and appear in Opera. Many of her ardent admirers will awaitherrelurn with inpatience.

The mail from New-Orleans, as late as due, is to hand. Gen. PILLOW met with a public reception at East Fellciana, La. Governor MARCY and Son arrived at Savannah, on Monday, on their way to Florida and Havana.

The Annual Report of the Postmaster General for 1852, which will be found at length in another part of this day's Times, states that the whole number of post offices in the United States, at the close of the fiscal year ended June 30,1852, was 20,910.

Congress held a short session yesterday. The debate in the Senate on the Kentucky contested seat was postponed until Monday next. Mr. CLEMENS introduced his promised resolution to confer the rank of Brevet Lieutenant-General upon General SCOTT. Mr. GWIN gave notice of a bill granting Public Lands for the construction of a Railroad from the Father of Waters to the Pacific--the particular starting-point not named.

This document is quite lengthy and full of matter of public interest. The vessels of the navy now in commission are distributed into six squadrons, each of which is required to serve on a cruise of three years, except the one allotted to the coast of Africa, which is limited to two years.

The Eighth Lecture of the Popular Course was delivered, in the Tabernacle, last evening, by JOHN THOMPION, ESQ., of Poughkeepsie. Subject: "The Life, Character and Genius of Milton." The attendance was not so numerous as on previous occasions.

From the New-Orleans Picayune, 2d inst. By the arrival of the steamship Louisiana, Capt. SMITH, We have received dates from Galveston to the 30th ult. We have only room for the following items. The Western Texan has the following intelligence from Eagle Pass:

The Course of Lectures before the New-York Historical Society commences this evening. The opening discourse will be delivered by Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT. The Lectures will be given on successive Thursday evenings, until the Course is completed, and we are glad to learn that the prospects of liberal encouragement and pecuniary profit are very flattering.

Mr. SEWARD said: Mr. President--Before the question is taken, I have a word more to say upon it. The Hon. Senator from Virginia, (Mr. MASON) sceems to me to have conceded the whole case upon the hypothesis which he has presented. He concedes to the Hon.

The U. S. steamer Fulton brings dispatches from Consul SHARKEY, in regard to the imprisonment of Capt. GRAY and the officers and crew or the ship Lady Suffolk. The contents we have not yet ascertained.

A friend hands us, fresh from the package, a copy of "Dod's Parliamentary Companion." A small book is Dod: it might be stowed away in a vest pocket if need be: a snug sixteen-mo; and yet absolutely over-brimming with facts, and possessing immense authority all over England.

The Report of the Superintendent of the Census presents a great many very valuable facts, concerning the progress of the United States, the extent of their various productions, , The document, however, is so long and is so filled with important and irrelevant matter that it will probably not be read by one in twenty of those for whose use it ought to have been prepared.
THE SESSIONS.--The third days session of the Court of General Sessions was held yesterday, at the Halls of Justice, with Hon. Recorder TILLOD, Alderman COMPTON and HALEY, presiding as the Judges.

The publication of the long Annual Reports of the various Secretaries at Washington is an affliction which newspaper readers are compelled to endure. They are not compelled, fortunately, to read them, but only to regret the lack of more various and interesting matter Which they crowd out.

MANHATTANVILLE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH.- The corner-stone of the first Presbyterian Church was laid in Manhattanville, yesterday, by Rev. Dr. PARKER, of this City, in presence of a number of persons, assembled to witness the ceremony. Among the clergy men present were Rev. Dr. PARKER, Rev. F. s. Howe, Rev. Mr. LORD, Rev. Mr. AMBLER, and Rev. C. S.BRIGGS, of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES.--Tuesday, Dec. 7. 1852.--S. S. Baxter. Esq., of Virginia: Ebenezer Allen, Esq., of Texas; J. Glaney Jones, Esq., of Pennsylvania; Charles Edwards, and James T. Brady, Esqs., of New-York, were admitted Attorneys and Counsellors of this Court....No. 1. Richard Eels, Executor, plaintiff in error, vs. the people of Illinois.

THE CATHEDRAL--THE REDEMPTORISTS.--The crowds that have gathered to the Catholic, Cathederal, daily and nightly, for the last week, have exceeded even that which attended its dedication. At an early hour in the evening, the crowds begin to set in, in direction or the noble church, which is filled to the utmost long before the appointed time of the exercises. Hundreds have to turn away.

A meeting of the friends of Land Reform was held yesterday evening at Military Hall, Bowery, pursuant to an advertisement in the morning papers. The meeting was called for 7 1/2 o'clock, but up to 8 1/4 there were not more than a dozen people in the room. They then began to arrive, but the meeting was slim in point of numbers.

The following is an extract from a letter in the Salem Register, written by an intelligent American, long resident in Russia: "ST. PETERSBURG, Tuesday Nov. 16, 1852. "The Emperor has started an expedition for Japan consisting of the frigate Pallas, a tender, and a screw steamer bought in England,--to be under the command of Vice-Admiral POATATINE, a very efficient officer and a worthy man.

The present number of the Scientific American contains a superb representation of the "American Crystal Palace," now in progress of erection in the City of New-York. The design was taken from the original drawings accepted by the Committee, and is therefore accurate in every respect, and has been so pronounced by THEODORE SEDAWICK, Esq., Secretary of the Association.

SIR: I have have the honor to submit herewith a report of the various operations of this branch of the Department, since the annual report of Nov. 1851. The tabular statement marked A, presents the number of pensioners on the rolls of the United States and the District of Columbia, exclusive of navy pensioners, of whom a separate report will be made.

ST. DOMINOO COFFEE.--The Island of Hayti possesses many advantages for the growth of Coffee, but heretofore the capabilities of the island in this respect have not been half tested, owing to the social disorder which has prevailed.

The Commissioner opens his report with a lengthy refutation of the common sentiment, that our course towards the-Indians has been marked with injustice and inhumanity. The report speaks generally, in encouraging terms, of the condition of the Indian tribes in the North and West.

ELLEN CAPPERILLA, a ballet girl at the Frontstreet Theatre, fell from the flies to-night about 6 1/2 o'clock, on to the stage and was instantly killed. She went up to dress for the performances. The remaine of BOOTH arrived here this morning in a metallic sarcophagus, and the funeral takes place tomorrow. They were brought on by a Masonic Committee.

The steamship Philadelphia arrived at this port this morning, from Aspinwall, on the 2d inst. She brings the California mails and San Francisco dates to the 16th of November, and 200 passengers. The Philadelphia sailed in company with the steamship Illinois for New-York, which vessel has two and a quarter millions of Gold dust on freight and 200 passengers. The news is important.

A correspondent of the Times calls the attention of the public to a new project for the prevention of crime, and one which, if it could be carried into effect, would, without a doubt, prove of very great services His proposition is to provide schools for vagrant children, at which meals and clothing if necessary would be furnished to the attendants.

The absorbing avocation of great numbers of our leading business men in the West is the Pork Trade. It is a pursuit in which more is hazarded, larger fortunes are lost and won, than in any other respectable calling. It is not only a greasy, but a slippery business.

The mail train by the Pilot Line, ran off the track near Princeton. last evening, and did not arrive here till three o'clock this morning. A coal boat from Bristol sunk at Pine-street wharf, this morning, and two men who were asleep in the cabin were drowned.

Extract from a Private Letter from Cuba. "The wild, uncivilized look of the negroes herestrikes one very forcibly. Constantly one sees teeth filed like those of a saw, which gives a most shark like look to a large mouth, and nearly every darkey one meets, has the long cicatrices on his cheeks or forehead, that in Africa mark the tribe or the people to which he belongs.

A Rio Janeiro letter, under date of Oct. 12, says: We are now having much rainy weather, but with it little or no sickness. On Sunday last, the American flags in the harbor were at half mast, caused by news of the wreck of brig Emily Jane, and the death of Captain FOXWELL, her commander, well known and much respected as an old trader to this port.

The natural scenery of this island, in the parts I have visited, is very picturesque, variegated and beautiful. At some points you behold nothing but high hills and deep valleys, reminding you strongly of the wild and rugged scenery to be found in many parts of New-England.

THE BROADWAY.--The new play of "Anne Blake," was repeated last evening. The plot is very slight, but the incidents are striking, and the interest in the characters is well sustained throughout the five short acts. Anne, the heroine, is left a dependent upon a sordid Uncle, who seeks by marrying her to a rich heir to a peerage, to release the mortgages upon his estate, held by the proposed husband.

The fifth Lecture of the Course before the Catholic Institute, was delivered last evening, by JOHN G. SHEA, Esq., who selected for his subject, "The Early Catholic Missions among the Indian tribes in the United States and the Canadas."
What everybody does, Is generally supposed to be about right, and everybody encores an artist when her execution of a favorite air is particularly agreeable to his sense of correctness and propriety.

The sons of Scotia celebrated the festival of their Patron Saint at Albany, with the accustomed ceremonies. Letters in reply to invitations to attend were received from Hon. HORATIO SEYMOUR, THURLOW WEED, Esq., and others. The President of the Society, Dr. JAMES McNAUGHTON, gave a brief narrative of his recent visit to his native land, and remarked upon the rapid growth of the Scottish cities.

The danger, real or imaginary, to which the Spanish interests in Cuba are supposed to be obnoxious, is exciting the attention of the Government to every possible remedy. The Diario de la Marino, in one of its latest numbers, ascribes all the existing evils indirectly to this one source. It says:

Our city is now fixed and "made up" for the season. We are all ready to receive visitors, and are at home to friends and strangers. Our principal streets are newly paved with the Russ pavement; our new and elegant stores are all finished; the opera and theatres are in full blast; our hotels are all full, and the St. Charles is being "rushed on" to completion.

The President recognizes JOSE MITCHEL, as Consul for Guatemala and Porto Rico, at New-Orleans. H. V. BUTLER, Co., who received contracts for supplying the printing paper, were not the lowest aggregate bidders; their prices being 14 cents per pound for first clase, 15 cents for second, and 17 cents for third; but were accepted as the lowest bidders, samples considered.

A SEARCHING INVESTIGATION TO BE INSTITUTED.--The falling of the building in Thirty-second-street, between Lexington and Third-avenues, on Tuesday last, has, as usual, created considerable stir in the community, and the authorities having taken hold of the matter, in the right spirit, we may now look for a rigid and searching investigation, and the punishment of the guilty parties, should any of them be traced.

SIR: Among the errors that abound respecting our Indian relations there is one so injurious to our national reputation, that it should not be disregarded. The opinion is extensively entertained, that our whole course of conduct towards the red men of this country has been marked by injustice and inhumanity. An enlightened consideration of the subject will lead to a different conclusion.

SLAVE MURDER.--The Concordia (La.) Intelligencer has the following: Murder among slaves seems to be quite rife among our neighbors on the Natchez side of the river. It was but two weeks since one negro slave was sentenced by the District Court in Natchez to have the letter " M," for murderer, burned into the palm of his right band, for killing a fellow slave in a brick yard.

WAR DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON, Dec. 4, 1852. SIR: I beg leave to submit a brief account of the operations of this Department during the year. The efforts of the Department have been principally directed to the defence of our frontiers and those of Mexico from the Indian tribes within our borders.

The first of the series of Lectures before the New-York Historical Society, for the benefit of the Fire-Proof Building Fund, was delivered last evening at Metropolitan Hall by Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT. The audience was large and comprised the most intelligent and respectable of our citizens.

The Columbus Ga, Enquirer of Tuesday, contains the following additional facts in regard to the freshet in the Chatahouchee river: "We hear of great quantities of Cotton carried off from plantations on the river below, and in some instances the gin houses, with considerable amount of Cotton. both in bates and in the seed.

THE SKUPINSKI EXECUTION.--Mr. ROMERTZE, Interpreter, makes the following reply through the Philadelphia Ledger to the asseverations of the Rev. CELESTIN WILLIM. "In yesterday's Ledger, the Rev. CELESTIN WILLIM denies saying to me that BLAISE SKUPINSKI Was worse than his brother MATTIHIAS, and that the reason for his not taking charge of the body of BLAISE, was because that he bad to bear alone the funeral expenses of MATTHIAS. To substitute the truth of my assertion.

Messrs. SPAULDING ROGERS have commenced a suit at Baton Rouge, against the Corporation of that place, for illegal seizure and detention of the Floating Palace, for exhibiting without a city license. They refuse to give security to await the result, and have abandoned the boat to the authorities, by advice of counsel, and will institute a new suit every day while the detention continues.

NEW CATHOLIC CHURCH AT FORT HAMILTON.--A new and beautiful Roman Catholic Church has just been completed at Fort Hamilton, Long Island, for the congregation who worship under the instruction of Rev. Mr. LOUGHLAN. The building is of the Grecian style of architecture, 40 feet wide and a depth of 75 feet, and contains eighty pews, which will comfortably seat five hundred persons.

BEEF PACKING IN CHICAGO.--The Chicago Tribune publishes an elaborate exposition of the extent of the Beerpacking business in that city. The following recapitulation shows the total number of pounds of beef, and the average weight of the battle slaughtered during the season just closed:

The Southern Mail has failed beyond Raliegh, N. C., and the New-York mail has also again failed this morning. A bill has been introduced, in the North Carolina Legislature, providing for the appropriation of $3,500,000 for purposes of Internal Improvement--$2,000,000 to be applied to the extension of the North Carolina Railroad to some point in Tennessee--the money to be raised on loan, payable in 30 years.

Mr. WALKER took his seat to-day. The CHAIR laid before the Senate an Executive document, containing the accounts of the United States Treasurer. Also, from the Interior Department, showing the balances of appropriations for that Department remaining unexpected. Laid on the table and ordered to be printed.

WHIG MEETING IN JACKSON, MISS.--A meeting of the Whigs of Jackson, Miss., was recently held at the City Hall, for the purpose of reorganizing the Whig party in Mississippi. Hon. J. J YEAGER, and D. W. ADAMS, Esq. addressed the meeting, after which the following resolutions, reported by a committee appointed for the purpose were unanimously adopted.

It is soft, mild weather in the country, and the ground is not frozen. It is just the weaother for pulling turnips. The boys are not over fond of the business, for they cannot learn to love this turning out before breakfast, and with mittenless hands grasping the turniptops all sparkling with hoar frost.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT.--About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, as Mr. George Shores, foreman of the mason-work now in progress on Trinity Building, corner of Broadway and Thames street, was standing on the lower floor, an iron column, weighing between 600 and 700 pounds, which had been put up in the fifth story to support the rafters around the skylight, by some means fell from its position, and struck one of Mr. Shore's feet,...

Mr. WM. HOWARD VAN DOREN, Pastor of the Second Dutch Church, Piermont, publishes a volume of essays on Mercantile Morals, the spirit of which is generally good, and the teaching not without practical worth. Such disquisitions usually disgust those they are delivered to, by the obvious ignorance of the authors upon the code they are discussing.

THIRD LECTURE.--The Third Lecture of the Course--"The Love of Truth "-was given last evening in the Lecture Room of the First Presbyterian Church, to an attentive audience. Dr. MCCLINTOCK commenced his remarks by alluding to the Bible as the groat source of all truth ; everything else containing but a particle of this first great principle acknowledged by unmistakeable indications the greatness, the glory, the beauty of this sublime foundation of truth.

CLOSING OF THE MISSISSIPPI.--The Minnesota Pioneer says, the Mississippi closed his eyes at 12, and 5 1/2 minutes, M., Thursday, the 18th inst. Peace to his slumbers. Last year this event occurred on the 28th, at 7 1/2 A. M.

MAN OVERBOARD.--On Wednesday night, a passenger on one of the South Ferry boats, being drunk at the time, managed to get over the side of the vessel into the slip, and after shouting most lustily for help, was rescued by Messrs. VAN HOUTTEN and DE ANGELIS, of the Revenue Department. This is the fifth person, this year, that Mr. DE ANGELIS has been instrumental in saving from drowning.

The following are the deaths, resignations, and dismissals of commissioned and warrant officers in the United States Navy since the Ist of Dec., 1851, so far as they have been ascertained: DEATHS. Commanders--William Pearson and George P. Vpshur. Lieutenants--William Preston Griffin; Benjamin S. Gantt. Nathaniel W. Duke. and John H. Little.

We see it stated that the Cherokee Council have appointed Dr. ROBERT ROSS, THOMAS PEG, and JAMES KNELL delegates to this city to effect a sale of certain "neutral land." We understand that this tribe of Indians consists in all of about 20,000, as follows:

VALUE OF BAGGAGE.--A case of some interest to transportation companies, was decided in the Supreme Court of Cleveland on Friday last. HUGH McFADDEN brought suit against the steamboat Niagara for the loss of a trunk. On the trial before the Sury, McFADDEN proved that on the 1st of May last, he embarked on the Niagara with his family at Detroit, taking passage and paying fare, for Cleveland.

At our latest from Texas all was quiet throughout the length and breadth of its extensive frontier, and the measures adopted by Gen. SMITH to insure tranquility can hardly fail of success. Small maransing bands of Camanches may slip through the chain of posts at times, but their depredations must be of minor consequence, and ample punishment will almost certainly follow the commission of any overtact on the part of the savages.

THE HUDSON FIRE.--In addition to the Franklin House, destroyed by fire Sunday night last, were the two adjoining buildings, one owned by HENRY HILLER, and occupied by him as a grocery and provision store. Mr. CHAMBERLAIN and Mr. SCOTT occupied the upper part as a dwelling. The next adjoining was owned and occupied by AMOS CARPENTER, both as a store and dwelling.

DISPENSARY REPORT.--The following is the report of the resident physician, Dr. HARDCASTLE, of the doings at the Dispensary for the month of November: The whole number of patients treated was 280; patients treated at their houses, 12. Of these 108 were males, and 172 females. Nativity--Born in Ireland, 196; in the United States, 72; England, 4: Germany, 8. Whole number of prescriptions, 594.

Private Havana letters received here by the Cherokee, state that the Captain and crew of the ship Lady Suffolk had been released, causing much excitement among the British residents at Havana. Seven or eight slave ships are expected on the coast, and all the British vessels of war are cruising off the Island awaiting them.

Yesterday evening, a serious and probably fatal accident occurred on the Harlem Railroad, the particulars of which are as follows: A heavy freight train was proceeding up the road, and when reaching Forty secondstreet, the switch was misplaced, but the engineer did not discover the disarrangement of the rails until too late, and the entire train swiftly glided along upon a branch track, where were standing several empty cars.

NEW CHURCH.--The proprietor of Wellwood's Hall has permitted the Germans of Jersey City to bold meetings therein on Sundays, free of all expense. From statistics in possession of their temporary pastor, Rev. Mr. SANTER, it appears there are two hundred German families who, hitherto, have been deprived of religious advantages.

By the Pension Office Report, it appears that the whole number of Pensions in the United States is 18,868, which is less by 743 than one year ago. About $1,500,000 have been expended on account of pensions during the year.
It has been proposed to erect in the City of Washington the Marble Group to COLUMBUS, designed by COSTOLI. The height of the Group and Pedestal is to be about forty feet, and of Italian marble.

By this document which is commendably brief and pertinent, it seems that the efforts of the Department have been principally directed to the defence of our and the Mexican frontiers, from-the Indian tribes within our borders. For which purpose, eight out of the eleven thousand officers and men on the Army rolls have been employed. And their success has been unusually good, peace having been secured in almost every quarter.

On Wednesday, Dec. 8, JOHN CYRUS, youngest son of Peter L. and Emeline M. Neal, aged 3 years, 7 months and 8 days. The relatives anti friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral on Friday the 10th inst , at 2 o'clock, P. M., from the residence ot his parents, No. 5 Hudson-av., Brooklyn.
The Express is a newspaper for which we are not in the habit of professing more respect than we feel :--our readers are, therefore, seldom troubled by the mention of it in any connection.

We have received later advices from California, by the arrival of the Philadelphia at New-Orleans from Aspinwall. The latest dates are to the 16th November. The Illinois left Aspinwall in company with the Philadelpia, with $2,500,000 in gold, consigned to this port. She may be expected here before the close of the week. The news from California is of some importance, though briefly reported by the telegraph.

Loafers. When I reflect on the dismal condition to which our side-walks would be reduced, were there no Loafers, I confess I am filled with a conscientious spirit of thankfulness towards that ubiquitous body. There is, I am aware, a violent prejudice existing against them.

Dates from the City of Mexico to the 20th November, being ten days later-are published in the Delta. The Committee in Congress on the Tehuantepec propositions, had reported a bill granting the contract for constructing the route to Senor BELANGE.
The Ninth Lecture of the Popular Course was delivered to a very large audience, in the Tabernacle, last evening, by Mr. JOHN KEESE, of this city.

The Cunard steamship Niagara arrived at Haifex yesterday, with dates from Liverpool to the 27th November. She has made a long passage of thirteen days. The Washington, from this port, arrived out on the 21st alt., and the Arctic on the 24th. The news from England is important, conveying intelligence of the final triumph of Free Trace.

Extract from a Discourse delivered by Rev. J. O. Choules, D. D., before the Baptist Church in Newport. An acquaintance of more than twenty-five years has enabled me to form some just idea of the departed. I have always regarded him as a Christian man, and the fact is singular though melancholy, that many who were his malignant revilers in life, acknowledged his excellence at death.

THURSDAY, Dec. 9, 1852.--Ex parte: In rc. Thomas Kaine, an alleged fugitive from justice from Great Britain. The Court granted leave to the counsel to be heard on the first Monday of January next on the following questions:

Over seven Millions of Votes for the Emperor. The Vote for the Empire was cast on the 21st and 22d November. Both public and private accounts agree that the ceremony was conducted decorously, but without any show of enthusiasm. From the pains taken to bring up the voters the returns will exhibit a large majority--greater probably than on any previous appeal to the people.

The Report of the Secretary of the Interior, which will be found at length in another part of this morning's paper, estimates the appropriations needed for the next fiscal year, at $14,921,022- which is $774,302 less than that for the present year. The quantity of land sold during the last fiscal Year was 1,553,071 acres. being 293,776 less than the preceding.

DEDICATION.--To-morrow, (Sunday,) the 12th inst., the new Catholic Church recently erected at Fort Hamilton, L. I., will be dedicated to the worship of God, with appropriate exercises. The Right Rev. Archbishop HUGHES will officiate.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--This limb of the City Government met yesterday evening at the usual hour. During the day several groups of outsiders were observed hanging round the purlieus of the City Hall, whose long and anxious faces and twinkling eyes detokened the fact that they had interest at stake in the action of the Board.

AN OLD ACCOUNT SETTLED.--The executor of the estate of a late well-known citizen of Albany, received an anonymous letter yesterday, post-marked in Massachusetts, containing forty dollars, to liquidate the principal and interest of a debt due the estate. As there was nothing on the books to indicate that any such debt was due, it was probably a liability only known to the person by whom it has been honorably liquidated.

BOARD OF ASSISTANTS--Mr. WOODWARD in the Chair.--The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Petitions Referred--Of Capt. U. P. Long, to have a nuisance in First-avenue removed. Of Russ Reid, for a contract to pave Chatham-street and the Bowery. Of Orison Blunt and others, for the purchase of the property at the foot of Gansevoort-street.

We very much fancy these Exploring Expeditions, on which our Government so much felicitates itself. They gratify a healthful curiosity. They cater to our intellectual palates. They nourish our love for useful knowledge.

The whole-bearing of Mr. DISRAELI, and his distinctive features as a speaker, are so peculiar. as to render the task of description very difficult. at least in order to convey to the mind of the reader any clear and tangible idea of the man. If he have already seen some of the admirable sketches made of Mr. DISRAELI by H B., it will much facilitate his comprehension.

ELECTION DAY WITH THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--Next Tuesday, the 14th inst., the Brooklyn Fire Department will hold an election for Chief Engineer and Assistant Engineers. The following are the candidates: For Chief Engineer--JOHN C. ROACH, Foreman Engine No. 13; JOHN J. GREEN, Assistant Engineer, and ISRAEL D. VELSOR.
If any doubt existed after Mr. DISRAELI's motion, that the DERBY Government would throw Protection overboard, it was set at rest by Lord DERBY, in the House of Lords, on the 22d inst.

ARRIVAL AND DEPARTURE OF NOTED CRIMINALS--Among the vast number of rogues who constantly infest the City, one of the most shrewd and cunning individuals, known to the police authorities, by the name of JAMES WALKER, alias "English Jim," recently arrived at this port from California, and was "spotted" by the Police of the Fifth Ward.

BROADWAY.--We were pleased to see a crowded house, last night, on the occasion of Mrs. MOWATT'S benefit. The audience was highly respectable; every seat was filled, and all the available standing room was appropriated. The first piece was "Anne Blake," in which Mrs. MOWATT'S excellent performance elicited the hearty, and, in many instances, the enthusiastic cheers of the audience.
In the suit for damages by Railroad collision, decided in the Superior Court yesterday, the law as laid down by Judge PAINE, and we believe correctly, seems strangely at variance with common sense.

The fire in Sacramento City broke out on J-street, and spread over Third, R, L and M-streets, laying completely bare the whole space between N-street on the south, and J-street north, and all between Front and Tenth-streets, comprising no less than forty blocks, and leaving ninetenths of the population of the city houseless.

When a railroad is first projected, the people along the proposed line are fully apprised of the advantages that are likely to accrue to them through its aid. The facilities that rail roads afford for cheap and swift transportation are set forth in the strongest light they will bear.
HALIFAX, N. S., Friday, Nov. 10. The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, Captain STONE, arrived at this port at 5 1/2 this morning, having left Liverpool at-1l 1/4 A. M. on Saturday, the 27th Nov.
On motion of Mr. HOUSTON, the House went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union, and took up the annual message of the President of the United States.

FATAL ACCIDENT AT SEA.--The following is an extract of a letter received in Boston from Mr. JOHN KUHN, mate of bark Lyman, on a voyage from Cronstadt to Boston. ELSINORE, Nov. 12, 1852. It is my painful duty to inform you of a fatal accident which occurred on board of the bark Lyman, (of Boston,) on the 2d day of November, in the North See about 40 miles from the coast of Norway.
We have intelligence of the total destruction of the steamer Cleopatra by fire on Monday night last whilst on her passage down the Black River. She had a cargo of nine hundred bales of cotton.
The majority of the Yankee Nation have certainly common sense. And yet, when we are lumped as a mass, we do some things that are not remarkably characteristic of men commonly sensible.

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERMS. Assignment of Courts and Judges in the City of New-York, for the year 1853. 1st Monday of Feb..Judges Edwards, Mitchell. Roosevelt. 1st Monday of May..Judges Edmonds, Edwards, Mitchell. 1st Monday of Oct..Judges Edmonds, Morris, Roosevelt. 1st Monday of Dec..Judges Edmonds, Edwards, Morris.

A telegraphic dispatch in another column contains the sad news that GREENOUGH, the sculptor, is a confirmed lunatic. The thought that any fellow-being is crazed, is a painful one; that a great man has become so isdoubly sorrowful.

The New-Orleans Picayune has seen a giant, whose name is Augus McKaskell. He was 19 years of age, seven feet nine inches high, robust, weighed 400 pounds, and was still growing. He was a native of Nova Scotia.

A ball at Tammany! We took seats near the door, and surveyed the dancers at our leisure. There were polkas, waltzes, quadrilles and gallopades, all in a hurry to be done, and the music hurrying to get done also. The world flies through Space at the rate of how many miles an hour? Follow the world.

The telegraph brings us intelligence that a revolution in the Mexican department of Sonora, has proved successful, under the leadership of a French Count, who has pro claimed its independence of Mexico and its annexation to France.

Mr. EMORY, granite-cutter, while standing at the entrance to the Senate gallery, yesterday, had his pocket picked of a port-monnale containing $130 in bank bills, $5,000 in promissory notes, and $200 in Baltimore stock certificates.

Our Special Correspondent at Washington has sent us a statement of the facts and arguments in a highly interesting case now pending in the Supreme Court of the United States, which presents a very important point of controversy, relative to the power to enact laws for the arrest and delivery of fugitive slaves.

Mr. JOHN G. SHEA has devoted several years of research and study to the Jesuit discoveries in America in the seventeenth century. Some of the fruits of his labors are embraced in a work, published by J. C. REDFIELD, containing a History of the Discovery of the Mississippi River, and its exploration by the Missionaries; a volume in which all the records of the pious fathers are analysed and presented in chronological order.
DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR, Dec. 4, 1852. SIR: In anticipation of the approaching session of Congress, I respectfully submit the following report of the operations of the Department of the Interior.

FATAL ACCIDENT.-On Friday afternoon, a boy named ANDREW RAZOR, whose parents reside in Johnson-street, was almost instantly killed while engaged at work in the ropewalk of Messrs. BANKER SONS, in Second-street. It seems that he was standing in front

SUPREME COURT--Special Term--Before Judge ROOSEVELT--Opinion of His Honor in re the Application of Townshend vs. The Register of Deeds.--This is an application for mandamus, against the Register of Deeds, to compel him to "search the records in his office and certify the title, as there appearing, of one Edward T. Wigfall" to certain lots of land, fully described, in Eighty-fifth and Eighty-eighth-streets, in the City of New-York.

It will be seen by an advertisement in another column that the sale of the pictures of the American Art Union is to commence on Wednesday next. The notice mentions some of the principal pictures on the list, but they constitute but a very small proportion of the whole. Among so many there must of course

The news from California occupies a large share of or columns this morning. We are indebted to the Express messengers of Messrs. ADAMS Co., and WELLS, FARGO Co., for the early delivery of papers, and to Mr. ELLIOTT, of ELLIOTT Co's. California Express, who came passenger in the Illinois, for a number of interesting additions to our summary.

The course of lectures just finished by Mr. THACKERAY, have certainly formed the best literary treat enjoyed by our citizens, these many years. His style, in point, terseness and energy, has not been equaled by any of our lecturers. His descriptions-as we would expect from a true dramatist-are the most simple, yet effective possible.

WESTERN TOBACCO TRADE.--The following interesting letter from a citizen of Baltimore, now in the West, bears date, LOUISVILLE, Friday, No. 26, 1852. Of tobacco there are now inspected in this place 24,000 hhds. per annum, and its reception is increasing every year. It is chiefly the growth of this State and of Tennessee-a large portion coming up the river.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--At tho Broadway Theatre, this evening, a new piece is to be produced which promises to take well. It is entitled " The Perj; or, the Enchanted Fountain." The scenery is prepared with great care, and presents many tableaux of exceeding beauty. The plot is taken from a fairy tale, and, after a series of difficulties, happily. The after piece will be "Married and Single."

We have received by the Illinois at this port the details of the accounts to Nov. 15 from California, of which we had a brief summary by Telegraph from New-Orleans. They are unusually interesting, and in respect to the loss of property and life by the great fire at Sacramento, painfully so.

The present condition of the British Empire should be carefully studied by all who feel any interest in the welfare of humanity. For it is the largest, the most populous, and most powerful which the world hitherto has seen. It embraces one-eighth of the habitable globe, and contains one-seventh of the human race; and every part of it is agitated by the hope or by the fear of an approaching dissolution.

We have no mail to-night South of Augusta. The Legilature of South Carolina, on the 9th, elected J. L. MANNING Governor, and J. H. IRBY Lieatenant Governor of the State. The Charleston papers announce the death of JAMES ROBERTS, an old and eminent merehant of that city.

Our readers will recollect that we have published from the Hudson papers accounts of the burning of the Franklin House in that city, and of the arrest of GEORGE W. SYMONDS, by whom the house was kept. Receiving yesterday such information from the Mayor of Hudson as led us to believe that we might be personally interested in the investigations that were progressing there, we visited that city yesterday afternoon.

By the mail steamship Illinois, arrived at this port early yesterday morning, from Aspinwall, we have the mails and treasure from the San Francisco semi-monthly packet of 16th Nov., previously announced, by telegraph from New-Orleans, as on the way to New-York.

The extensive wholesale grocery warehouses of DAVID HAYS and JAMES GEORGE, corner of Commercestreet and Exchange-place, were totally destroyed by fire, together with a large stock. Loss, about $60,000, which is fully covered by insurance.

The late vote of the people of Mississippi against paying, by taxation, the old Planters' Bank Bonds, has created some surprise, although there was little hope that the Union Bank Bonds of that State would ever be paid at all. Those Mississippi Bonds are of a class of financial operations which universally have failed, but which may revive again during the speculative season which is approaching.
