This is getting to be rather lively business, in this region, and, from rcent developments, it would appear that a large number are engaged in it. We do not know where the spurious money originates, but that there is an extensive association for its circulation throughout this part of the State is very evident. We rejoice that it stands so good a chance of being broken up.

SUFFOLK COUNT[Yen] TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION.At the late meeting of this Association, held at Huntington, the Committee on Text Books reported upon Arithmetics, mental and Written, to be used as standard works in the schools--Thomson's "Practical," and Higher upon Written Arithmetic, and Stoddard's Juvenile and American Intellectual,upon Mental Arithmetic. No formal action was had upon the report.

UNION MEETING.--Last week the members of St. Paul's Church, South-sixth-street, extended an invitation to the various churches in the City, to attend a Union meeting at that church on last evening. Agreeable to this request a number of persons from different churches assembled,and listened to a series of short addresses made by those who have lately signified their intention of connecting themselves with the church.

When Lord DERBY got up, the other day, in the House of Lords, and humbly recanted his economical heresies, it is hardly likely that he realized the full value of the act. For it had profound as well as superficial significance. It was not merely a vanquished Minister doing homage to the victors; and it was something more than the " obsequious" eulogy of a deceased principle.

Seven prisoners escaped from the Baltimore Jail, last evening, at an early hour. They were EDWARD HUDDEN and THOMAS CONNER, both awaiting trial, one for the murder of ZIMMERMAN, the other for the murder of Capt. HUTCHINSON; FREDERICK BLOOMER, awaiting sentence for obtaining goods on false pretences; JOHN B. HASKELL, awaiting trial on a charge of fraud; GEORGE SPROUL and LEWIS R. KING,

MEETING OF PIANO FORTE MAKERS--Last evening an adjourned meeting of Piano-Forte makers was held at the rooms of Messrs. HALLETT ALLEN, No. 339 Washington street, for the laudable purpose of devising, nearly one hundred in number. Whose tools were destroyed last week, by the burning of CHICKERING'S Piano-Forte Manufactory, where they were employed.

On Saturday, Dec 11, in her 85th year, HANNAH DIXON, relict of Jonath in Dixon The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at St. Luke's Church, Hudson-st., on Tuesday, Dec. 14, at 3 o'clock. On Saturday evening. Dec 11, after a long and painful illness, Capt. ROBERT P. GAY in the 47th year of his age.

The bark Morgan Dix arrived at this port last night with Buenos Ayres dates of Oct. 6. URQUIZA had disbended his forces, and disclaimed all hostile intentions towards Buenos Ayres, but says he will defend his province from any attack.

The order is at last published rescinding all previous instructions to the " Captain of the Port," and other guardians of our quiet waters, "to admit" the U. S. mail steamer Crescent City " to the port-of Havana," with almost the same privileges" as the most favored nations."

LATER FROM BUENOS AYRES.--The bark Morgan Dias, Captain CLAYPOLE, arrived at this port yesterday, from Buenes Ayres, having left that port on the 6th of October, and Point India on the 13th. She came into the Chesapeake on the 6th inst. We are indebted to Captain CLAYPOLE for copies of the British packet newspapers.

Last evening Chief of Police MORGAN. accompanied by five officers, made a descent upon a house in West Troy, long suspected of being the head quarters of a notorious counterfeiter and his accomplices, and after a desperate struggle arrested ROBERT MORRISON, proprietor of the house.

STARTLING INCREASE OF CRIME IN NEW-YORK.--Two men were murdered with the knife, in the Fourth Ward, on Saturday night, and on the same night, a man's head was cut open with an ax, in Cross-street; and another man probably murdered in Mulberry street.

FROM THE CAPE OF GOOD HOOPE.-We have received Cape Town papers to Oct. 26, brought by the United States sloop of-war St. Mary's, at Philadelphia. They contain a variety of details of the frontier war, where no regular hostilities were attempted by the Kaffirs and rebel Hottentots, except for the purpose of plunder. Considerable numbers in their predatory expeditions had been encountered and routed and shot. They were, however, occasionally successful.

The Express replies to our comments upon HUMPHREY MARSHALL'S appointment as Minister to China, by a three-fold argument. In the first place, it alleges that the Times and the Albany Atlas "coincide charmingly" in their views upon this subject.

The Mexican troops in all parts of the country are daily deserting the Government and joining the insurgents. Gen. URAGA's pronunciamento in favor of the insurgents had the effect of bringing over a considerablo number.

Messrs. NORRIS, SOULE, and UNDERWOOD, appeared and took their seats. The Secretary read a letter from President KING, (who is ill,) suggesting Senator ATCHISON to take the Chair. Agreed to. Mr. BRIGHT gave notice that to-morrow he would move the reference of the President's message to the several Committees.

The rumor that LOUIS NAPOLEON has invited JEROME NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, of Baltimore, to go to France, is pronounced by the Sun as wholly unfounded. JOHN SINOTT, who was convicted of enticing a slave to run away, was sentenced, in the Baltimore County Court, to six years and five months' imprisonment.

Advices have been received in England from Australia, that the ship Dido is on her way, and soon to arrive in London, from that country, having-on board the extraordinary amount of 280,000 ounces, or 23,333 pounds, troy weight, equal (at 2,000 pounds to the ton,) to nearly TWELVE TONS Gold Dust.

Aunt Deborah was a good philosopher, as the world goes ; that is, she had a theory, according to which she practiced, never worrying herself much about its truth. Her doctrine was that everybody has got to commit a thousand blunders in this world, and so, every time she committed one, she rejoiced at being rid of one more source of vexation and trouble.

ENTERPRISE.--The Herald yesterday announced to its startled readers that the Empire had been reestablished in France, and published the Report of the Senate Committee, in favor of the changethe Senatus Consultum--the speech of the Vice. President on offering the Empire to LOUIS NAPOLEON, his reply, the Count of CHAMBORD'S protest,

It is rot a little remarkable that, with all the vast arrivals of Gold Dust from Australia, Gold Coin from the United States, and Silver from the West Coast, reported of late in London, that the accumulations are apparently thus far inconsiderable, not only in the Bank, but throughout the Kingdom.

COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED.--Four men residing in the neighborhood of Chicopec Falls, Mass., were arrested late on Wednesday night, at Holyoke, by Col. R. M. ABBE, of Thompsonville, and lodged in the Springfield jail on Thursday, on the charge of having passed counterfeit notes on tile City Bank of Hartford. The proof against them is conclusive, as they have passed counterfeit bills (mostly $3 notes) on several different people in Thompsonville.

In the Ist District, SCUDDER, Whig, is elected. The opposition abandoned their candidates, and voted for ABRAHAM H. HOWLAND, of New-Bedford, a Whig. New-Bedford voted SCUDDER 838, HOWLAND 775, Scattering 74. In the Hd District the election of WESTON, FreeSoiler, is claimed, but the returns received are not decisive.

The mails by the steamer Niagara arrived in this City, from Boston, at an early hour yesterday morning. The foreign files give some' interesting details of the news previously reported by the telegraph. Sundry ship owners in Liverpool remonstrated loudly against the desertion of British vessels in the ports of Australia. A correspondent of the Times

Last evening, at 4 o'clock, the stern-wheel steamer Geneva, a two boiler boat, left St Louis for the Illinois river, with a barge in low. Four miles below Alton, at HAYNES' wood-yard, she landed to wood. When the boat had just been landed and fastened to the shore, and the deck hands were at the wood pile, the boilers exploded with terrific force, destroying all the forward part of the boat.

There are at this time but six quartz mills in successful operation in Mariposa County, all of which are paying daily a very liberal percentage on the investments made. Several other quartz mills ofa large and extensive construction are now in process of being erected upon veins that have been prospected and are known to be rich.

AN IMPORTANT INVENTION--Gen. CROSBY, of Chautanque, is well known to the lumber World, as the inventor of several useful improvements, in the sawing departments. His last invention is a long-sought desideratum-a circular saw for sawing clap-boards and panel stuff; or, in other words, for splitting plank or boards to any desired thinness. The process, now in general use.

About 3 o'clock this morning, in Allegheny City, the watchmen arrested two German shoemakers, named JULIUS and FRANCIS OPPEL, under suspicious circumstances, and upon searching their premises a large amount of stolen property, some coining utensils, , were discovered.

AN EXCITING RACE.--On Wednesday afternoon East Utica was the scene of an exciting race. The Sheriff, with five other officers, was engaged in removing the prisoners, twenty-two in number, to the new jail just completed in that vicinity, and had reached within about twenty rods of their new quarters, when fourteen of them, who were chained together two and two, made a concerted and desperate effort to escape,

LECTURE ASSOCIATION. -- J. W. SCUDDER, Esq., of Jersey City, delivers the next lecture before the Association, to night. Subject: "The connection of Mechanics, Arts, and Civilization." This year the price of admission to these lectures has been lessened considerably--a project which, thus far, appears to operate successfully.

The electoral proceedings which were terminated throughout France last Monday evening have accomplished another revolution, extinguished the Republican form of Government, restored Monarchy in its most absolute form, and proclaimed that Louis NAPOLEON and his family are now and for ever the chosen representatives of the Imperial dynasty of France.

The case of the MADIAIS has excited great attention in the religious and diplomatic circles of Europe, and the embassage from England and Switzerland to petition the Grand Duke of Tuscany has already been mentioned. The work of sympathy, and, if possible, of aid, to be taken up in this country.

" I am Miss Catherine's book," (the Album speaks); " I've lain among your tomes these many weeks; I'm tired of their old coats and yellow cheeks. Quick, Pen! and write a line with a good grace; Come! draw me off a funny little face; And, prithee, send me back to Chesham Place."

THE KENNEBUNKPORT ROBBERY.--W. F. BANCROFT, alias BATES, and JOHN CALHOUN, alias JOHN ROGERS, were examined the first three days of this week, before Justice SETH SCAMMON, in Saco, Me, charged with forcing the store of W. F. MOODY, at Kennebunkport, and robbing it, and the Post office boxes, on the night of 2d inst.

Several musical publications have appeared of late, as if to meet the extraordinary furor of public taste without direction. "CHURCH MUSIC IN AMERICA," by Mr. NATHANIEL D. GOULD, is a highly interesting publication, and of some value as preserving records of the art, which would otherwise be lost. Mr. GOULD consults his own

" PI APS!' THEY GO"--Yesterday morning, a horse attached to a wagon loaded with apples, became frightened on the corner of Seventh and South Sixth-streets, and dashed off down Division-avenue, at locomotive speed, and the load of apples were strewn along the street, to the infinite delight of the smuttyfaced urchins, who made themselves handy in helping themselves to the "pi aps," while the owner was after his horse.

The Express says, that" the Times continues to suppress the fact in the case of Mr. MARSHALL, (Minister to China,) that he was confirmed by and with the advice and consent of the Senate." If any reader of the Times needs this information, or feels aggrieved by our having "suppresed" it, he will confer a favor on us, and probably promote his own welfare, by transferring his subscription to the Express.

BURTON'S.--Mr. PLACIDE played Col. Hardy, in "Paul Pry," last evening, as we seldom see it given. He is by far the best genteel comedian now in this country, and his characters are all living pictures. To-night he plays Dr. Ollapod in the "Poor Gentleman," and BURTON, Sir Robert Bramble. The afterpiece is the comedy of the "Breach of Promise," with BURTON as Ebenezer Sudden.

FUNERAL.--The funeral of the Rev. Mr. REGAN late Assistant Pastor of St. Paul's Church, in this City' took place yesterday at the above church. The Rev. Dr. PISE, Pastor of the Church of St. Charles Borromeo. officiated, assisted by others. An immense concourse of friends followed the body to its final resting place, St. Patrick's Church, New-York City.

To-day, the Santa Fe mail arrived, somewhat after its usual time of reaching here, and yet a few days before contract time. From the quantity or snow the carriers found upon the plains, together with the rain and sleet they had upon them all along the route, it is a wonder they reached here as soon as they did.

DEATH OF EDWARD SEGUIN.--Mr. EDWARD SEGUIN, well known as a vocalist, died at his residence in White-street, this City, yesterday morning. His complaint was disease of the heart. The deceased was the son of the former assistant manager of the Italian Opera House, London, and was born about 1810. His father, still living, is probably the oldest actor or manager now on the London Stage.

CRYSTALOTYPES.--This latest discovery in Daguerreotyping is creating much excitement in the sciontific and artistic world. What will artists and engravers say to a process which promises to supersede their labors, the Sun himself being both artist, engraver and printer ? In another column will be found an advertisement from Mr. RooT, the Daguerreotypist, of Broadway, which is worthy our readers' attention,

One who is sklilful at sketching, might make a pleasant series of pictures for us, by taking down the attitudes and conditions of Benevolence as he is seen in New-York. The old gentleman is careful to look after the poor, whether they are of his own kin or from another land and clime.

ANOTHER BLOODY TRAGEDY--ONE MAN MURDERED AND SEVEN MEN DANGEROUSLY STABBED.--Between 8 and 9 o'clock Sunday night, a bloody affray took place on the corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street and Fifth-avenue, which resulted in the murder of one man, and others being mortally wounded with knives.

A PAPER BY DR. E. K. KANE, LIEUT. U. S N. The usual Monthly Meeting of the New-York Geographical and Statistical Society, last evening, was held in the Chapel of the University, for the purpose of accommodating a numerous and most respectable attendance of our citizens, who were attracted to hear Dr. KANE read a paper on the above interesting subject.

Prof. OLMSTED delivered his second Lecture on Astronomy, on Monday evening, before an intelligent audience, at the Broadway Tabernacle. There was a decided increase in the attendance, compared with the former Lecture. The Lecturer remarked that it was Lord BACON who said that some discourses were so high that they were like the stars.

In the Supreme Court, at the present term, a case of some importance has been argued-entitled, Konnell et al. vs. T. Jeff. Chambers-an appeal from the U. S. District Court of Texas, The bill on this cause was filed in May, 1848, to enforce a specific performance of a contract to convey lands in Texas, entered into the 16th of Sept., 1836, at Cincinnati, between CHAMBERS and the complainants or their assignors.

LATER FROM NASSAU.--By the arrival at Charleston, on Thursday, of the Spanish brig Copernico, the Savannah Courier has advices from Nassau to the 29th ult. Spanish vessels are arriving here from Cuba, to get clearances for the United States, to avoid the American tunnage duties. Cholera has almost entirely disappeared from tile town, but at some of the outposts it has broken out with great severity.

WATER WORKS.--The Water Commissioners have determined upon the quantity of work necessary to construct the Receiving Reservoir at Belleville, which is as follows: 24,000 cubic yards of embankment; 20,000 cubic yards of puddle bank; 1,140,147 brick laid in cement, and 6,170 square yards of sodding.

LAUNCH.--A schooner rating 260 tons was launched, on Wednesday last, from the ship-yard of Mr. SINEX, in this Borough. She was christened Maria Pickup, that being the name of the lady of one of the owners. She is much the largest vessel ever built here, and in point of model and workmanship reflects credit on those who constructed her. She is intended for the Southern trade.--Chester (Pa.) Republican.

I am happy to be able to state, that Capt. GRAY, his son, and the crew of the late Lady Suffolk, were released last evening from the " Carcel Tacon," the Captain remaining here under the personal security given by Mr. ANTONIO CABARGO, until the cause is closed, which would not have been accepted had there been any appearance of criminality attaching to the Captain or any of his officers or crew.

The weather has been very much the same with our neighbors as with us. But out West they have not been blessed in similar manner. An Iowa paper (the Bellevue Press) says: "We have never seen a Winter set in so early in the season, here in Iowa, during twelve years' residence. Snow has covered the ground since the 10th of November, and the weather since has been characterized by the rigorous cold of Winter."

ENGINE COMPANY No. 18.--The resolution offered by Alderman SPINOLA, on the 6th of Sept., based upon a petition of Engine Company No. 18, asking for an appropriation of $250--balance due on their Engine, was lost. COMMON COUNCIL--A regular meeting of this body was held on Monday evening at the City Hall--Ald. HARTEAU in the Chair.

The Second Lecture of the Series before the Mechanics ' Society, was delivered by Rev. SAMUEL OSGOOD last evening. Subject: " The Poetry of Mechanism, or the Future of the Useful Arts." The room was crowded by a respectable and intelligent audience. Mr. OSGOOD was received with loud applause. His discourse was marked with much ability.

Hon. C. M. CONRAD, Secretary of War. SIR: The following returns from the Adjutant General's Office accompany this Annual Report: 1. Organization of the Army as established by law, marked A. 2. General return of the Army, showing the actual numbers borne on the rolls. B. 3. Distribution of the troops in the Eastern Division. C.

The Elections are past. The Compromise has put to rest all the questions that whilom agitated the States. The Guano matter is settled. The Fisheries lie over by common consent, aud the only question we can possibly worry ourselves about now, is, What shall we do for small change ? This is coming to be the all-prevalent study.

Yesterday morning, the Schooner Gazette, Capt. BASSETT, reached Cleveland harbor in distress, having suffered much in the gales of last week on the Lake. The crew had been nearly 24 hours without a mouthful of food, and were worn out with fatigue. As she entered the harbor, the Gazette was cast against the cast pier and a hole was knocked in her bow. She then drifted into the Lake, and was capsized.

NIBLO'S.--The opera of " La Fille du Regiment," with ANNA THILLON and HUDSON in the principal characters. BURTON'S.--The comedietta of " Uncle John," with PLACIDE, " The Milliners," and the drama of " The Miller's Maid." BROADWAY.--The new Spectacle is to be repeated again this evening, together with the farce of "Petticoat Government."

The recent intelligence of the defeat of the Mexican authorities of Sonora by a party of Frenchmen under one Count BOULBON, and of his having proclaimed its annexation to France, has directed public attention to the general subject. The Courrier des Etats Unis, in an article copied in the Times yesterday morning, intimates that the affair is without importance,

The Arctic steamer, of the Collins line, arrived fast night. She was delayed over two days beyond the usual prompt time made by these packets, from heavy weather. Her news is interesting from France, where the preliminaries to the crowning of the Emperor on the first anniversary of the eventful Second of December, were going forward on a scale of great splendor.

Mr. FRY delivered his Third Lecture on Music last evening. The lecture was an interesting exposition of early Oriental, Egyptian, Jewish and Greek Music, with illustrations of medieval melodies, battle-songs and love-plaints. Madame ROSE DE VRIES,

HOOPER C. HICKS, Collector of Customs at Vionna, Dorchester County, Md., while passing along Loilbard-street, near South, at 5 1/2 o'clock this evening, had a rope thrown round his neck, and was dragged into an alley by 3 men, who there robbed him of $3,000, ($500 of which was in gold, $1,200 in Baltimore notes, and a draft for $1,400 on New-York,) and his watch.

Further returns of the Congressional election yesterday show that CROCKER, Whig, is probably elected in the Second District, by a small plurality over WESTON, Free-soil. Third District--EDMUNDS, Whig, elected by from 800 to 1,000 plurality. Sixth District--URHAM, Whit, elected by over 500 plurality. Seventh District--BANKS is elected by several hundred plurality.

The following gentlemen were elected officers of Protection Engine Company No. 2, for the ensuing year, at a meeting of the Company for that purpose, on Monday evening; Foreman--J. W. PILLOIS ; Assistant Foreman--J. C. TRAVIS; Treasurer--J. WOOD ; Trustee--J. W. PILLOIS ; Representatives--R. R. MOORE, B. COSGROVE, and P. LAPP.

LOUIS NAPOLEAN sees fulfilled, at last, the dreams of Empire which haunted him from his cradle, following him wherever his destiny led him--whether amidst the quiet valleys of Switzerland, through the streets and courts of London anti New-York, or to his solitary apartments at Ham.

I subjoin a few short extracts from the French papers upon your Presidential election. The Constitutional says: "The triumph of the Democratic party is of a nature to inspire England with disquiet for Canada, Spain for Cuba, and Mexico for the Isthmus of Tehuantepec. Happily, however, Gen. PIERCE is abetter man than the average of the party whose candidate he was."

The Senate was called to order at 25 minutes past 12 o'clock. A letter from Mr. KING, requesting Mr. ATCHISON to preside, was read, and no objection being made, Mr. A. took the Chair. Mr. NORBIS, of N.H., appeared to-day and took his seat. Mr. UNDERWOOD presented numerous petitions against the employment of Chaplains.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It was my misfortune to be a passenger in the train of cars on the Syracuse and Rochester Rail road yesterday morning, when a collision occurred about sunrise a little east of Canandaigua, by which three persons lost their lives and others were severely injured.

The superserviceable zeal of the Member from New-York in the House of Representatives, on the Surplus Revenue and the Tariff, is ill-timed and in exceeding bad taste. The reproof of Mr. BAYLY was gentle in terms, but caustic in meaning. Mr. BROOKS was out of place in leading off on this question, at this particular juncture.

The United States steamship Arctic, Captain LUCE. arrived at this part at 8 o'clock last evening, after a passage of 13 days and 5 hours. She left Liverpool on Wednesday, Dec. 1. She brings the following passengers and the English and Continental mails:

By the steamship Cherokee we have received files of the Diario de la Marino, Gaceta, Prensa, Diario de la Habano to the 3d inst. The news had been in a great measure anticipated. The Diario de la Marino of the 2d says, that "the affair of the Crescent City being terminated in a manner highly satisfactory, we hardly wish to recur to it again," and then goes on with two columns and a-half,

The receipts to the Washington Monument last week were $2,279, more than two-thirds of which was from Maryland. The President officially recognizes DANIEL WOOLF as Consul for Ecuador at California. The contract for supplying timber for gun carriages for the army has been awarded to Messrs. FULLER, CHAFFE Co., of Springfield, Mass. Tile required quantity is 872,000 feet, and the contract is at $28@@43 per 1,000 board measure, amounting to about $35,000.

The heaviest robbery that has occurred in Cincinnati for many years was perpetrated Tuesday evening on board the steamer Editor. lying at the wharf, on her way from Pittsburg to St. Louis. While the passengers were at supper, about 5 o'clock, the state room of Mr. Robert Butcher was pried open with a chisel--the hurglars forcing open the outside door--and $5,321 abstracted from a valise in the room;...

Coming down Broadway last evening, wondering what some rowdy would knock us down for--for every man's turn has to come sooner or later, to be maltreated by rowdies and rioters in New-York,--before we knew it, we had run into a stout fellow whose presence obstructed the side-walk, and knocked ourselves as far out of balance as we knocked him. With our blandest smile, we asked his pardon, and hoped we had not hurt him.

The Editors' Table in Harper's Monthly for December, gives as its first course, an able article upon " Crime and its Increase"--abler, however, in philosophy than in exact accuracy of facts and knowledge of the practical points of the discussion. With the single exception of homicides, the offences of highest grade in this City have not increased within the past five years.

We publish on our Third Page this morning some interesting documents relating to the extent and the objects of the French Colonization in Northern Mexico. Extracts are there given from works of authority, showing that the public men in France are vigilantly jealous of the growing power and preponderance of the United States--that our influence on the Pacific Coast is feared:

A CAPITAL CITY IMPROVEMENT.--The Sixth and Eighth-avenue Railroads are improvements which were much needed, and are fully appreciated by the traveling community, who use them in their short journeyings to and from business. The day cars have run full from the time they first started till the present day, and the night line is well patronized.

ANNIVERSARY OF THE BIBLE SOCIETY.--The Anniversary of the Williamburg Bible Society was held at the Presbyterian Church, corner of South Third and Fifth-streets, on Tuesday evening--Rov. Mr. McLEON, President of the Society, presiding. The exercises of the evening were commenced by the reading of a pealm, and prayer.

EXPLOSION OF STEAM BOILERS AND INSURANCE.--A case was recently tried at Montreal involving the insurance on the steamer Comet, which blew up at Oswego some two years ago The Montreal Herald gives the following report of the case: "This action was tried last week, the verdict being given on Saturday night, in favor of the defendants.

A MONUMENT TO THE MEMORY OF GENERAL LINCOLN.--A correspondent of the Advertiser gives the following description of a monument recently erected in Hingham to the memory of one of the heroes of the Revolution: GENERAL LINCOLN -- A tribute to the memory of this honored patriot has recently been placed in the Hingham Cemetery.

FROM THE CHOCTAW NATION.--The following letter from the Rev. JOHN HAREELL, Principal of the Academy at Fort Coffee, in the Choctaw Nation, is published in the Fort Smith (Ark) Herold, of the 27th ult: FORT COFFEE, Nov. 20, 1852.

The nomination of Hon. E. A. BRADFORD for Judge of the Supreme Court of the United States, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of Judge McKINLEY, still lies upon the Executive table of the ex-Senate, awaiting action of the body thereon.

The danger to which the Democratic party is likely to be exposed, from and after the advent of the new Administration, in consequence of its "Swollen condition" and immense weight, and the absence of any extraneous force adequate to the work of keeping its integral parts from resolving into chaos, are already painfully apparent.

The body of PETER LAIR, a German laborer, was taken from the ruins of CUMMING'S grain store this afternoon. He was caught between two girders, and about twelve feet of grain was above him. J. OSLER, while intoxicated, fell down a flight of stairs at the Circus last evening, and died in the hospital this
At Kirkcudbright, Scotland, Nov. 30, Mr. ROBERT HORNELL, late of this city.

A must daring highway robbery was committed In this city about 9 1/2 o'clock last evening. It appears that Mr. J. A. BILLS, a grocer, was going to his dwelling house, in the upper part of the city, when he was assaulted by two ruffians, who knocked him senseless to the earth; and upon returning to consciousness, he found that his pockets had been rifled of their contents.

The legal penalty of death, which was abolished many years ago by the great LEOPOLD, grand father of the present reigning Duke, has just been revived in Tuscany by a Ducal decree, to the full extent of its application in olden times.

HOMES OF AMERICAN AUTHORS; COMPRISING AN-ECLOTICAL. PERSONAL AND DESCRIPTIVE SKETCH ES, BY VARIOUS WRITERS. Illustrated with views of their residences from original drawings, and a facsimile of the manuscript of each author. G. P. PUTNAM Co., No. 10 Park-place. We greatly misjudge the public taste if this elegant volume stand not foremost among Holiday favorites.

From the London Spectator. Occasionally the Police make vigorous attacks on the squalid parts of great towns, drag forth the wretched abiders in such places, and arraign them under some sanitary act of Parliament for offences against health or decency. In a raid of that sort, several Irish people were summoned before Mr. YARDLEY, from Slater's Court.

The evidences of improvement in the condition of the country are daily becoming more decided; and the agricultural classes are beginning to participate in the general prosperity, after the exhausting effects of the famine. In the Western counties. in particular, the change for the better is quite remarkable; and farmers find them selves in a far better position under free trade than they were during protection.

The Directors of the Association for the Industrial Exhibition have issued a circular, urging on native manufacturers the urgent necessity of representing completely the natural and artificial products of our country in the forthcoming exhibition.

The Twenty-Sixth Anniversary of the New-York City Tract Society, and Thirtieth of the Female Branch, was held in the Reformed Dutch Church, Lafayette-place, last evening. The attendance was numerous. At 7 P.M., the President, Rev. THOS. DEWITT, D.D., took the Chair, and a hymn was sung by a full choir.

To KILL BEDRUGS.--The following is certain destruction to these troublesome visitors: Alcohol, half-pint; spirits of turpentine, half-pint; sal ammoniac, one ounce; corrosive sublimate, one ounce; camphor, one ounce.

FIRE AT NEW-HAVEN.--On Tuesday morning, the store of Messrs. SCOTT ALLIS, in Church-street, took fire and the flames spread to the adjoining store of Mr. P. A. BUELL, tailor, in the same building, the goods in which, together with most of those belonging to SCOTT ALLIS, were destroyed by fire and water.
THE EXPLOSION OF THE STEAMER GENEVA.--The St. Louis papers recount sundry causes which conduced to the explosion of the steamer Geneva, on the Mississippi.

U. S. STEAM FRIGATE SARANAC.--By the late arrival at Salem from Para, we have received a news paper, O Gran Para, of the 8th ult., which contains intelligence of the safe arrival at that port of the frigate Saranac, Captain J. COLLINS LONG, with the Brazilian Minister on board, on her way to Rio Janeiro.

The Moniteur has the following article, which may be taken as a sort of programme of the Empire: "France is giving to the world a magnificent spectacle. It is a noble sight to behold the whole of a great people, animated by the same sentiment, assemble peace fully at every point of the country and declare its will, with that dignity and that resolution which befit its sovereign independence.

A considerable portion of Gov. BROWN'S Message to the Legislature, now in session in Florida, is devoted to the subject of Internal Improvements. That body at its last session chartered the "Atlantic and Gulf Central Railroad Company," with a view to the construction of a road from Pensacola to St. Mary's.

A young man named Thomas Brannan, was admitted into the Pennsylvania Hospital on Saturday, with a wound of the hand, callced by a slug from a pistol. He said that he was at a private dance when a muss was raised, the fiddler and a young man named "Hopps" Fleming, attached to the Franklin Hose, had a collision.

There is hardly any other product of the farm which uniformly brings so quick and remunerative a price as good butter. The excellent quality of this article produced in English dairies is well known to all those who have visited that country.--is. indeed, proverbial, particularly that of Epping and Cambridge.

From the Washington Union. The recent extraordinary intelligence of the revolt of a French Colony in the Mexican province of Sonora, of the defeat of the Federal troops by the insurgent forces under command of Court RAOUSSET BOULHON, and the annexation of the Department to the Empire of France, by the proclamation of the victorious adventurer, excited throughout the country a mingled sensation of doubt and astonishment.

We see it announced that Rev. Dr. HAWKS is to deliver the second of the series of Lectures before the Historical Society, this evening, at Metropolitan Hall. Nothing more than this announcement is needed to insure a large audience.

We publishhd yesterday morning a some-what detailed report of another case now pending in the Supreme Court of the United States, which possesses much importance, and will be found especially interesting to members of the legal profession--because of the points involved--while the general reader will find it of value for its historical incidents.

Mr. ATCHISON again took the Chair, at the written request of Mr. KING. The Chair laid before the Senate the report of the Secretary of War on the classification of clerks in that Department. Peticions, etc., were presented.

Governor SEYMOUR, it will be seen by a paragraph in another column, has made the appointments of his military staff. As the first of January is close at hand, we presume his Message is also ready. There is a good deal of curiosity in political circles concerning the ground it will take in regard to the completion of the State Canals.

Thanks to the manly firmness and characteristic American dignity of GEORGE LAW, this Government has failed in its purpose to coerce the Steamship Company into the humiliating and degrading compliance with the will and decree of the Captain General of Cuba.

Says the Boston Times, the "Spirit Rappings" in this city are doing an immense deal of mischief at this time, and we hear of several cases of instantly produced by belief in this delusion. A very popular actress attached to one of our theatres, has been rendered partially insane on this subject. She imagines that she hears the manifestations when at home and alone.

The Sixteenth Anniversary of the Association for the Benefit of Colored Orphans was held in the Asylum, corner of Forty-third-street and Fifth-avenue, on Monday morning. This Institution, which now exercises a wide and beneficent influence, originated in the philanthropic efforts of two ladies, members of the Society of Friends--the present Secretary and Treasurer--who, visiting the haunts of the miserable colored outcasts, felt strongly that justice, humanity and safety demanded something should be done for them.

From the New-York Abion. Cuba--Cuba--Cuba--In the Message, and out of it: and something new thereupon served up every morning in the daily journal. In our own, last week, it was the departure of Mr. Purser SMITH in the steamer Cherokee, and the chance of that vessel being refused admission at Havana.

INDIAN CONCERT.--a large number of gentlemen and ladies were present at the Odeon last evening, to hear the Sacred Concert of the Oneida Indians. Mr. Z. M. CLARK, the vocalist, together with several young gentlemen, volunteered to sing on this occasion.

BROADWAY--The operatic Spectacle is to be repeated every evening this week, together with a laughable farce. NIBLO's.--The ROUSSET Sisters appear in the new ballet of" La Vivandiere," and BROWNE plays in afterpiece.

THE HEAD OF LAKE SUPERIOR.--The Saint Paul's (Minnesota) Pioneer, gives an account of survey of the lands around the south-west end of Lake Superior, by Mr. STUNTZ, under the direction of the general Land Surveyor.

ALEXANDER DRAKE, a distinguished comic actor of the West, often sang the popular song of "Love and Sausages," and on such occasions he never failed to secure crowded houses. One evening, when this song was proposed, the curtain rose, and DRAKE stood on the stage with his arm up raised ready to begin the song, but not a word issued from his lips.

BLACKS AND MULATTOES.--Mr. Senator CUSHING, from Gallia County, introduced into the Senate of Ohio a bill "to prevent the further settlement of blacks and mulatto persons in this State "This bill provides-- That after the 1st of Jan, 1854, no black or mulatto person shall settle in this State.

TURNING CORNERS AT TOO RAPID A PACE.--The practice the drivers of all sorts of vehicles, at the present day, is to turn the corners of the streets at a break-neck pace. The cartman, the backman, the bus drivers, the liveried apes of upper-tendom, and the sporting "whips" of the road, all seem pertinaciously deter mined to contemn the law relative to turning coners at a walk.

A "STRIKE" AT THE BROOKLYN NAVY YARD.--In consequence of an order from Washington requiring the employees in the Navy Yard to commence work at Sunrise, instead of one hour after as has been the custom during the winter months, not more than fifteen or twenty men, out of about eleven hundred, were at work yesterday-those that did work were old men who are by circumstances compelled to succumb to the new order.

Ex-Senator BENTON said recently in conversation with a gentleman who spoke of his being the last of the group, "CLAY, WEBSTER and CALHOUN are gone; years ago Dr.---told me, 'When these men are dead, you will be fresh and vigorous as ever.' My habits of living do it; until I was thirty, I drank nothing, Sir! Since then I have drank only what circumstances made it fit I; should drink.

PLUTARCH, in his Cheroncan retirement, was a "head of department," and discharged the duties of Commissioner of Sewers and Public Buildings.

FERRY BOAT.--A new ferry boat is soon to be put on the Passaic, to be worked upon the chain principle. The New-York and Newark line of omnibuses have hitherto had considerable difficulty in crossing the river, all of which will be obviated by the new boat.
THE GREAT SUSPENSION BRIDGE OVER THE NIAGARA.--The Lockport Journal says that laborers are busily employed in pushing the Niagara suspension bridge to completion.

AN ADVENTURE ON THE PLAINS.--The St. Louis Republican tells this story: "A Mr. M. L. CHAPIN, of Pawpaw, DeKalb County, was at Rock Island the other day, and informed the editor of the Rock Island Advertiser that he left Sacramento City September 28th, and arrived at the Council House, Salt Lake, in fifteen days, six hours, where he remained three days.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Our citizens have never been more gratilied and delighted than on Friday evening, when listening to the superb and eloquent lecture of E. P. WHIRPLE, on the English Mind,--although Mr. W. was wearied with his long journey.

From the National Intelligencer. There can be nothing more distressing to the mind of a noble people, than a consciousness of having neglected distinguished merit. By his labers and genius this individual has conferred upon his country imperishable renown. But he lived neglected and dies under the pressure of poverty.

CAPTURE OF AN EXTENSIVE GANG OF COUNTERFEITERS.--RECOVERY OF COUNTERFEIT $1, $2, $3, $5, $10, AND $20 NOTES ON VARIOUS CITY AND STATE BANKS.--At a late hour Tuesday night, a very Important arrest of an extensive gang of counterfeiters, was effected in the upper part of the City, by sergeant MARTIN, and officer GLEASON, of the Sixth District Police.

Berryman, Austin S. Cushman, Thomas L. Gott, Johnson De Laguelle, Win. D. Kennon, Wilson McGuanigle, Albert Morsell, Charles H. Wheeler. S. W. Gillett, John E. Wilson, Thomas Osborn John G. Nonegs, D. C. Fonstable, Edwin Halbert.
The Board of Aldermen met Tuesday evening at the appointed hour, (5 o'clock.) The members were called to order by the President; a quorum being present, they proceeded to business.

The Providence Journal has received advices from Mr. BARTLETT, Commissioner of the Mexican Boundary Survey, dated Chihuahua, Oct. 23d, where he arrived, with his party the day before, in 15 days from El Paso with a small Mexican escort.

If he did not fill his sheet with news of importance, whether there be any or not, it is condemned for not being what it purports to be--a newspaper. If he does not fill at least one column every week with something laughable, his folio is pronounced uninteresting.

During the last Cholera season, a friend of ours preached a most pertinent sermon on the necessity of continual preparation to meet death, and insisted that it was the part of every mall of business to keep his house always in order.
The following are the estimates of appropriation required for the service of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1853: TREASURY DEPARTMENT. Dec. 7. 1852.

An event occurred last Saturday night week which makes us ask ourselves whether we have really passed the middle of our century. In the course of Saturday night, Nov. 20, one died who could and did tell so much of what happened early in the reign of GEORGE III., that her hearers felt as it they were in personal relations with the men of that time.

Mr. ATCHINSON, pursuant to a written request from Mr. KING, took the Chair. Mr. SEWARD presented a petition from citizens of Rochester, N. Y., praying remedies against foreign piracy on American patents.
The Cincinnati Evening Atlas gives an abstract of a bill recently introduced in that State, by Mr. CUSHING, Senator from the counties or Laurence, Gallia, Meigs and Vinton.

From the London Times. Dispatches and private letters have just arrived at the Foreign Office and the Prussian Embassy from the expedition is the interior of Africa, conducted by BARTH and OVERWEG At the request of his Excellency Chevalier BUNSEN, I beg to submit to you a few particulars of the progress of that expedition, which may interest some of your readers.

On Thursday evening, about 11 o'clock, a respectable appearing lady, of respectable family, who resides in New-York, applied to officer HUNT, Acting Captain of Police, of the Second Ward Station-House, for his aid to rescue her daughter, a young girl about 15 years of age, who had been enticed from her home.

THE FIRST LOCOMOTIVE WEST OF THE MISSISSIPPI--The people of St. Louis were delighted on the 2d inst., at having started, on the Pacific Railroad the first locomotive engine west of the Mississippi River.

STEAM NAVY.--The Mediterranean, the Black Sea, the Channels, the Indian Ocean and seas, our coasts, the West Indies, the Frozen Ocean, the Red Sea-are all constantly traversed by British, French or Russian steamers, either in national service or in that of the commercial marine.

Poetry.--The Pen and the Album, by W. M. THACKERAY. Literary. --Homes of American Authors--DANA BRYANT-BANCROFT, GOETHE and BRYANT, Knickknacks--Ground mice--MONROE EDWARDS--Old Knick in Sleepy Hollow--The Dog and the Lobster--Remeinhered Childhood.

The Boston Young Men's Total Abstinenco Society had their Anniversary Festival on Tuesday evening. Speeches were delivered by Dr. J. C. Warren, Dr. Lyman Beecher, Dr. Garnett. and others: and letters were read from Hon. R. C. Winthrop and Dr. J. V. C. Smith.

NEW ENGINE House.--Arrangements are being made for the construction of an Engine House, on Mercer-street. There is a general complaint among the firemen, in consequence of the poor accommodations of the engine houses, and the Common Council have resolved to removed the difficulty, by erecting several, with all the late improvements.

CAUTION to TOBACCONISTS.--INDECENT EMBELLISEMENTS.--On Monday last, WILLIAM GOODE, tobacconist, of No. 199, Strand and Ludgate-hill, London, appeared at Bow-street Police Court, to a summons charging him with having exhibited for sale, in his shop window, a meerschaum pipe indecently illustrated.

A correspondent of the St. Louis Republican gives the following account, dated at Fort Laramie, Oct. 20. Yesterday and to day have been busy and exciting days at Laramie, especially to the Indian population concentrated in this vicinity.

The packet-ship B. R. Milam, Capt. ELLIS, arrived last night from Havana, after a passage of nine days, with a very full cargo of sugars, segars, Capt. E. reports having had very pleasant weather, with moderate breezes. He brings no papers.

Within the last two weeks some twenty loco motives have been shipped from Buffalo for the different Western railroads. The Buffalo Courier says it noticed two beautiful machines for the Rock Island, and also two very heavy ones for the Great Western (Canada) road.

INDIAN NAMES--Squamscot River empties into the Piscataqua in New-Hampshire, and is sometimes written Swamsoot. A writer in the Exeter News Letter says: "The original Indian word was Wonneasquamsauke, derived from three Indian words--Wonne, (beautiful,) Acquam, (water,) and Sauke, (a place)-meaning 'The Beautiful Place of Water.'

THE STRIKE AT THE NAVY YARD.--Yesterday, as on the day before, the workmen at the Brooklyn Navy Yard refused to go to work under the nine hour order, and positively declare they will not, unless they are allowed to work the eight hours per day, as formerly.

We heard yesterday that ALBONI'S manager had arranged with the Broadway manager for a short Italian Opera Season this Winter. It is stated by the Evening Mirror that MARETZEK is on his way home from Mexico, and may possibly organize with ALBONI.

THE NOTORIOUS COUNTERFEITERS, SEIZURE OF TUE COUNTERFEITING APPARATUS-ADDITIONAL ARRESTS.--The Police authorities continued their exertions during Wednesday night ferreting out other parties connected with the gang of dangerous Bank Note Counterfeiters, an account of the arrest of some of whom was published in the Times yesterday morning.

NEW HAMPSHIRE LIQUOR BILL.--A Concord correspondent of the Boston Journal gives the following abstract of the bill offered in the House yesterday by Mr. WIGGINS, of Dover. Such a bill would satisfy many people of Massachusetts much better than our present law: It constitutes it the duties of Mayors, , and Selectmen, to license annually in April a suitable number of persons of good moral reputation to sell wines and liquors.

On Wednesday, Dec. 13, HANNAH, wife of Henry Nelson, aged 51 years and 7 months. Her friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this day. (Friday.) at 2 o'clock, P. M., from her late residence. No. 210 Third-avenue.

From the Evening Post. We alluded yesterday, briefly, to another evidence of the profligate mode in which the property of this city is squandered, and that too, apparently without awakening a murmur or a sigh among the tax-payers, who bear their municipal burdens as patiently as if they were specifically imposed by Providence. MARYLAND STATISTICS.--The whole number of paupers who received support in Maryland during the year ending June 1, 1850, was 4,491, of whom 2,591 were native born, and 1,903 foreign born.

THE REMOVAL OF THE MENOMINEES.--We learn front a friend, who has just returned from the upper Wolf River, that this tribe of Indians, numbering 2,200, has lately been removed to the land selected for them on the Wolf River, in this State.

MILTON'S RIB-BONE.--Mention is made of CROMWELL's skull ; so it may not be out of place to tell you that I have handled one of MILTON'S ribs. COWPER speaks indignantly of the desecration of our divine poet's grave, on which shameful occurrence some of the bones were clandestinely distributed.

SEIZURE OF COUNTERFEITING APPARATUS BY THE POLICE AUTHORITIES.--MORE ARRESTS--We learn that the police officers continued their exertions in the counterfeit cases during all of Wednesday night and yesterday ; and their efforts have not been unavailing.
