Do? Why, it will talk an "everlasting wishy-washy flood." It will utter an abundance of small talk, and by that time the session will be half through. We had forgotten the holidays--but they will not forget them, and, coming out of them, what an accumulated force the stream of talk will exhibit.

The condition of New-Mexico is rather a better one than it has been for some time. The new Governor, Mr. LANE, has thus far proved popular, and, if I may judge by the knowledge I have acquired of his character since he has been among us, I should say he is likely to continue so.

SECOND DAY'S SALE. The sale of this valuable collection of Works of Art was continued yesterday, and the finest pictures in the Society's possession were disposed of. Purchasers attended in large numbers from the cities of Washington, Albany, , and the biddings were made with considerable spirit.

A paper recently submitted to the Common Council from the City Controller, informs that honorable body that the snug sum of five millions of dollars will be required for the government of the City next year,-- which is not quite tire millions MORE than was required last year.

In the Board of Aldermen, on Tuesday evening, a communication was received from the Controller, with a detailed estimate of the receipts and expenditures of the City Government, for the year 1853, and also an estimate of the probable amount of tax that may be required for the said year.

BROADWAY.--"The Peri," with its magnificent scenery, is to be presented again this evening, together with a laughable farce. BURTON's.--The popular drama of "Grandfather Whitehead," and the Comedy of "Begone Dull Care." An original farce is announced as in rehearsal at this house.

We see that it has been proposed in the Ohio Legislature to appropriate a part of the earnings of convicts in the State prisons to the support of the families of such convicts. Why should it not be so ? Every family has a right to expect a support, in part, at least, from its head.

The annual installment of gratitude due from juveniles to the publishing gentry, is this year even larger than ordinary. Of the books of the season, the moiety at least is theirs; ornamented so profusely, and gilded and silvered so prettity--to say nothing of the variegated contents, stories, facts, and fables, between covers,--that children of larger growth have reason to complain of partiality.

The Sixth and last Lecture of the Course be fore the Catholic Institute, was delivered yesterday evening, by Rev. JOHN BOYCE, of Worcester, Mass. Subject: Mary Stuart. There was a full and respectable attendance. The lecture was attended by several of the Roman Catholic clergy, and was received with applause.

Dates from Turks Island to Nov. 30 have been received. 250,000 bushels of Salt remained there unsold. The price was llc.@12c. per bushel. Yellow fever had entirely disappeared. The deaths were mostly confined to strangers.

THE TREASURER CASE.--The case of the People vs. James M. Cook is set down for argument before the Court of Appeals at its session on the first Tuesday of January. It is a preferred cause, and will be taken up immediately upon the meeting of the Court. But this is not satisfactory to those who have exhibited so much anxiety to oust Mr. Cook.

DISORDERLY CITIES.--We notice in a washington paper. that a clergyman in Baltimore had suspended the regular night services in his church. in onedience to the request of a large portion of the lady members of his congregation, who, in view of the numerous outrages recently perpetrated in that city, had become alarmed at going out after dark.

The Ohio papers complain that rowdyism is tampant in Newark, in that State. Two of their Judges were knocked down on Thursday night though no provo cation had been given. The ringleader was fined $ 10 for the outrage. Many of their oldest and best citizenshave armed themselves, as the law is powerless.

SAVED THE COURT THE RESPONSIBILITY.--A barrel of liquor in a wagon, near Gorham's Corner, with a driver who seemed to be somewhat pubzied what to do with it, attracted the attention of a policeman, on Saturday. Finally, the driver called at a house near Cobb's Court, and after some parley, unloaded his charge at the door.

THE EFFECT OF CLIMATE ON CONSUMPTION.--Latterly some English physicians have come out against a change of climate-especially a mere change from a warm to a cold region--asserting that some warm regions were more dangerous to invalids than their own cold native hills and valleys.

There is some excitement at the Charlestown Navy Yard, in consequence of the order from Washing ton, requiring the men to commence work at ten minutes before sunrise. Eight hundred men are now employed in the Yard. and a public meeting is called to consider the order. A strike is anticipated.

The Cleveland papers contain thrilling accounts of the shipwreck of a schooner at the mouth of the harbor on Monday last, and the daring rescue of the crew. One of the most exciting incidents of the season occurred on the lake in sight of this city, this morning, The night had been black and towards morning, stormy and howling.

The Boston Bcc says that the Truant Law appears to work quietly in that city One of the officers reports, as the result of his labors during the past two months, that he had found 130 traunt children, of whom all but 20 had been induced to attend school regularly 60 of whom were habitual trauants; 70 Were absentees; many of them had never been to school before.
We have no mail this morning south of Raleigh. The North Carolina Legislature had resolved to adjourn on the 22d inst. No further ballotings for a U. S. Senator have taken place.

I have just returned from a visit to the Seminary edifice, where three of the brightest years of my life were passed, and which I have not seen before for years. Thus it happened: The previous Sabbath evening I was passing through Bleecker-street, where I saw the Church where I had been wont to worship, during my student years, lighted up for evening service.

THE NAVY YARD WORKMEN.--We alluded, briefly, yesterday, to the fact that workmen in the Navy Yard had determined not to resume work under the new order said to have been issued by the Bureau on Naval Affairs at Washington.

"HONESTY IS THE BEST POLICY."-- A man named MARTIN BARTON, Of Foxborough, undertook the other day to defraud the Boston and Providence Railroad Company, by buying a ticket to Canton, and going to Foxborough, seven miles beyond, without paying.

__STICK T0 YOUR OWN BUSINESS.-Let specula tors make their thousands in a year or a day, mind your own regular trade; never turning from it to the right hand or the left. If you are a merchant, a professional man, or a mechanic, never buy lots or stock, unless you have surplus money whichyou wish to invest. Your own business you un-

The Lecture of Rev. Dr. HAWKS, the second in the series of Lectures before the Historical Society, delivered last evening before a large audience at Metropolitan Hall, was an exceedingly able and interesting discourse on the Ante-Revolutionary History of NORTH CAROLINA, and especially the famous Mecklenberg Declaration of Independence.

In Congress, nothing was done, yesterday, that is likely to immortalize the Members. In the Senato, Mr. CHASE introduced a bill ceding to Ohio the public lands in that State remaining unsold and unappropriated. Mr. CLEMENS's bill, authorizing the President to confer the rank of Lieutenant-General by Brevet for meritorious services, after sundry verbal amendments, was postponed till Monday.

Two propositions are before the United States Senate to correct the bogus Banking at the Seat of Government: one by Mr. FISH, to regulate the subject by a General Banking Law; the other by Mr. ADAMS, of Mississippi, to make the issue of unauthorized small notes a penal offence.

STATE APPOINTMENTS.--The Albany correspondent of the Evening Post announces the following appointments by Governor SEYMOUR: The rumor is authenticated which assigns to Col. ROBT. E. TEMPLE the post of Adjutant-General, in the new administration.
The North Carolina Legislature adjourns to night The appropriation of $1,250,000 for the Blue Ridge Railroad has passed both Houses.

We have no mail this evening beyond Mobile. A Company has been started in Savannah to build a first class steamer for running between that port and Havana. Evacuation Day was celebrated at Charleston on Tuesday last.
They have one parish in Louisiana-the parish of Winn--which gave not a single vote for Scott and Graham, but 264 for Pierce and King. The Democrats call it a "barren" pariah. Altogether likely!

Our files of the Diario de la Marina, received by the Black Warrior, supply us with later dates from Vera Cruz and the Capitol. The revolution has thrown everything into disorder. On the 5th ult., D. RAMON ARCHCUNDIA pronounced at Ixtapan with two hundred men. The whole population joined him, declaringg in favor of the plan of JALISCO, and for the abolition of direct contributions.

The citizens of Williamsburg will make application to the Legielature, atits next session, to alter the bounds of the city so as to include Bushwick; to alter and increase the number of wards; to establish a City Court of Records, and to make the office of cells' keeper elective.

BROADWAY--A grand operatic spectacle of "The Peri," and the farce of "Ladies Beware." BURTON'S.--The popular drama of "David Copperfield," and the still attractive farce of "The Milliners." WALLACK'S.--The comedietta of "The Morning Call," and the comedy of "She Stoops to Conquer."

The precarious condition of Mr. KING'S health is a topic of anxious interest with his friends. The fact that the Senate went into Executive Session for the purpose of talking over the steps necessary to be taken in view of his inability to attend its sittings, shows the studious efforts which were made to keep from the public a knowledge of his true condition. Of course, all such attempts are futile.

The sale of the pictures of the Ameri can Art Union closed yesterday. In another part of this morning's paper we publish a complete list of all the pictures sold, with the name of the artist and purchaser, and the price paid by the latter, as well as the original cost of each picture to the Art Union.

A meeting of the Clergy and Laity of the Protestant Episcopal Church was held in the vestryroom of Trisity Church, for the purpose of hearing the report of the Committee on the Mission at the Five Points. Right Rev. Dr. WAINWRIGHT presided.

WILLIAM A. WHEELER and Co., of New-York have been awarded the contract for the fourth class of paper for the public printing as the lowest bidders, samples considered. Secretary CONRAD gave a brilliant entertainment, the first of the season, last night, about 30 members of Congress were in attendance.

On motion of Mr. FULLER, of Maine, the House took up the Senate bill, authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to issue registers or enrolments to wrecked vessels, foreign built, when purchased and repaired by American citizens, and when the repairs equal three-fourths of original cost of vessel. This bill is general, and saves the time of Congress in passing special acts. It was passed.

Madame FRANCES WRIGHT D'ARUSMONT, or to call her by the name which she made famous, FANNY WRIGHT, died on the 14th inst. at Cincinnati, aged 57 years. She was born in Scotland, but visited America at the age of 23, and published her opinion of our people on her return, under the name of "Views of Society and Manners in America."

He is a bad man who is ashamed of an honest parentage, because it was poor and humble. He is no better who is ashamed of his country, because its history records few or none of the bloody triumphs of ambition, but tells the simple story of a people's unobtrusive progress in civilization and homely comfort. I am sorry for the man who,

Two mails arrived to-night from New-Orleans, leaving one still due. The papers contain the details of the Mexican news to the 20th ultimo, the important points of which have been already telegraphed. A conductor with $1,200,000 had left the City of Mexico for Vera Cruz.

It was very kind in the Mayor of Baltimore to tender the hospitalities of that city to the President Elect while on his way to Washington. Such things are apt to be regarded as mere compliments-empty honors, showing good will, and nothing more.

The remaining pictures, and other works of art in the collection of the Art Union, were disposed of yesterday. Good prices were obtained for the best paintings. A celebrated piece by CHURCH--New England Scenery--was brought by Mr. G. DANIELS at $1,360. WH. H. WEBB was the purchaser of "Marion crossing the Pedee," a fine historical composition by RANNEY, at $900, and a View of Mount Washington, by KENSETT, at $570.

THE FIVE POINTS MISSION--FESTIVAL AT METROPOLITAN HALL.--The ladies who conduct this Mission, gave a grand Festival, consisting of a Concert and Oration, on yesterday, at Metropolitan Hall, for the benefit of the children and all the destitute under their charge. The afternoon's entertainment commenced at 2 o'clock. It comprised Overtures, Bailads, Solos. , by distinguished individuals.

The steamer Black Warrior, R. W. SHUFELDT, U.S.N., commander, arrived yesterday afternoon at half-past 3 o'clock, from Mobile from Havana, Left Mobile Bar at 8 P.M., on the 9th inst., and Havana on the 12th at 5 P.M.

The British and North American Mail steamship Africa, from Liverpool, at noon, on Saturday, 4th inst., arrived at this port at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M., yesterday . The new screw steamer Andes, the first of the Cunard Company's steamships between Liverpool and Chagres. via United States ports, was to sail from Liverpool, Wednesday, Dec. 8, for NewYork, and is expected to anticipate the mail usually received via Southampton.

The proceedings of the First and Second of December in Paris constitute the most interesting feature in the political news by this arrival next to which are the Budget and Speech of Mr. DISRAELI in the House of Commons, on 3d December, the day previous to the sailing of the steamer.

Another event in the present eventful annual of France. The Empire is formally declared. One annual revolution of the sun has embraced both extremes of that political revolution, by which France is once more laid at the feet of the Bonapartes. It gives us little pleasure to note the stages as they occur.

VISIT OF THE SUPERVISORS TO THE COUNTY JAIL.--Yesterday afternoon, on invitation of Sheriff HODGES, whose term of office is about to expire, the Kings County Board of Supervisors proceeded to inspect the interior of the prison, accompanied by ENGLEBERT LOTT, Esq., Sheriff elect, E. W. HINMAN, Esq., Alderman elect from the Tenth Ward, and several members of the Press.

It is manifestly the American destiny to be the scape-goat of national sins. Inevitable faults and trifling foibles--we have some of both--are magnified into capital offences; and we are lectured remorselessly by fine old English ladies, Duchesses, Countesses, and the Earl of SHAFTESBURY, on the evils of Slavery. It is easy and stale enough...

In the Dublin Tablet, of the 27th ult., we find it announced that the Right Rev. LEVI SILLIMAN IVES, Bishop of North Carolina, has abandoned the Protestant faith, and attached himself to that of Rome.

The season for holiday presents last approaches. The mouths of the little folks already water at the thought of the good things so nearly due, and what their presents will be, is matter of daily and nightly speculation.

In one point there is a very general agreement among the nations of the earth. They all believe that they understand their own difficulties better than their neighbors do for them. We have had, and still have, many social problems, which events, and the spontaneous changes of society, rather than legislation, are solving in one way or another.

Some changes of importance have recently taken place in the Board of Commissioners of Emigration. Mr. HICKS has resigned, on account of ill health, and the Governor has appointed CALER BARSTOW, Esq., to fill his place. JAMES L. MORRIS, Esq., has also resigned his position as Vice-President.

LAYING THE CORNER STONE.--On Thursday at Bergon the corner stone of the African Methodist Episcopal Church was laid with appropriate solemnity. The exercises commenced at 2 o'clock, and were con ducted by one of the Bishops of the Church. A hand some collection was taken at the close of the meeting, in aid of the enterprise.

The Commercial Convention met at 11 o'clock. A large number of Congressmen are present, among them Messrs. BRECKENRIDGE, STANTON, PRESTON, and UNDERWOOD, of Kentucky, Senator JONES and F. P. STANTON, of Tennessee, Senators DAWSON, CLEMENS, DOWNS, PRATT, The Convention was called to order by JOHN C. BRUNE, Chairman of the Board of Trade.

The allusion in our last Foreign summary, to the remarks of Sir CHARLES Fox, on the practicability of the Darien Canal across the Isthmus, is interesting to the friends and shareholders of the Panama Railroad. Whether found practicable and built, or deemed impracticable from the nature of the country, or the immense cost, the Canal project works to the advantage of the Railroad Company.

To the Editor of The N. Y Tribune: SIR: In your paper of the lOth inst., there is an extended editorial on the resignation or removal of Mr. EWBANK, in which the President and the undersigned are associated in language somewhat charseteristic of the Tribune. You ask: "Why was he removed;" and answer, "Because he would not consent to lavisk the public money on a favorite of the President, in violation of law."

Last Spring MR. DISRAELI condescended to make some mention of the taxes upon knowledge in an obscure paragraph of the Budget. This year all allusions have disappeared. The Chancellor of the Exchequer has nothing more to offer on the subject, and certain budding hopes of the Liberalists have thus been summarily cut off.

Our Government, a few months since, issued a circular dispatch to several of our Ministers in Europe, asking of them information as to the expenses they were severally obliged to incur. To that circular, the following replies, which we copy from the Post, have been returned: Letter from Abbott Lawrence.

WESTERN RESERVE COLLEGE.--The friends of this institution, in this vicinity, will be glad to learn that the difficulties which a few months ago seemed so embarrassing and threatening to its interests are passing away. The College is again to resume its hold on the public confidence. It has always held a high place in the regards if the friends of Christian education.

The division on the VILLIERS' motion was recorded too late last Saturday morning to enable me to announce it in my last dispatch. The motives of that division, which gave a majority of 80 to ministers, together with the no less important one on Lord PALMERSTON'S resolution which followed, have, by this time, been tolerably well sifted and ventilated, as well as the anticipated results.

It is not a little amusing to read the speculations of the newspapers in relation to the Cabinet of General PIERCE. Some of the opposition papers are so very obliging as not only to establish the principles upon which the members of his Cabinet are to be selected, but even to name the individuals who are to compose it.

A SCENE AT A FUNERAL.--Quite an excitement occurred yesterday morning, in Lombard, near Front-street, on the occasion of the funeral of WILLIAM JOHNSON, a colored man, who died possessed of considerable properly, accumulated while proprietor of a sailor boarding house located there. The deceased left children by a former wife, who died some years since, and had, while on his death bed, married her daughter by a previous marriage.

The steamships United States, Capt. BERRT, from Aspinwall Dec. 9: and the Star of the West, Capt. TINKLEPAUGH, from San Juan Dec. 10, arrived at this port yesterday. By them we have received two days' later advices from California, eight days later from Panama, and nearly a month later from South America, beside further accounts from Oregon. The news is quite interesting.

A dispatch from Memphis states that the steamer Western World was run into and sunk by the H. R. W. Hills near Hurricane Island, and was turned bottom up, proving a total loss. Several lives were lost.

THE NAVY-YARD STRIKERS.--Some years ago, when DAVID HENSHAW was Secretary of the Navy, there was a movement in the Charlestown Navy-Yard similar to that which occurred a few days since, and he met it by a letter the workman, giving to them most excellent and practical advice, and taking the proper ground which belonged to the head of a national Department in such a controversy.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS--A regular meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held Friday evening at the old Court room in the Kings County Jail. Present, presiding, A. J. BERRY, Esq., President of the Board The following bills were referred to Committee: Thomas Dacrey, $35; John A Lavender, $19 50; J. Van Anden, $190 74; Alexander McCue, $83 33; J. O. Whitehouse, $100 50: and of John Friend.

TERRIBLE INCREASE OF CRIME IN BOSTON.- No one, not himself a great sinner, can deny but that there is a fearful increase of crime in this city. There were contined in one watch house, last evening, twelve persons, all of whom had been arrested before 10 o'clock. These wicked individuals were charged with no less than twelve distinct breaches of the law and dignity of the Common wealth.

ARRIVAL OF THE CHERUKES.--The U. S. M. steamship Cherokee, Capt. Baxter, arrived at this port last evening from New-Orleans, vid Havana, with dates from the latter port to the 14th inst. No further difficulties were experienced by the Cherokee in entering Havana. Full and free communication with the shore was permitted, and the mails and passengers were received and landed quietly.

A boy named HENRY GILMORE, was drowned in Tuckawana Creek yesterday. As his mother was taking him to school he tell from a log, while crossing the creek. His mother leaped in after him, and was with difficulty rescued.

The Boston Transcript informs us that Horatio Greenough, one of the first American Sculptors, died at Somerville, Mass., on Saturday morning. His illness had been brief, terminating in a violent attack of brain fever, bidding defiance to medical skill. No event could fall more painfully on the car of the art-lover than this.

The Coperhagen Navigation schools are about to be improved and enlarged; a separate building will be created on the quay, provided with an observatory and instruments. Presents of money from the Danish Minister and Baron HAMBRO, in London, and from other individuals, as well as of books, instruments, , have been annonnced. It is to be hoped that the State will give this valuable institution its assistance.

A southern newspaper mentions as worthy of remark, that since the passage of the President through St. Jean d' Angely, not a single crime or offence has been committed in that commune. The editor attributes this fact to the general mollification of the hearts of the citizens, produced by the presence of their Sovereign; repentance sank deep into their hearts, and a determination to improve was established in their bosoms.

By the arrival of the steamship Texas, Captain LAWLESS, we have received dates from Galveston to the 7th inst. There was a fire in the town of Washington, on the Brazos, on the 24th ult., by which the printing office of the Texas Ranger, and other property were destroyed. The Lone Star says the flames were discovered in the Ranger office about 2 o'clock A. M., and spread very rapidly.

His unfortunate Holiness, Pro NONO, must contemplate the procession of events in France with peculiar interest. It brings the day of his deliverance nigh. The Imperial crown, we are told, has been in course of manufacture for some months past. The "crowner," too, has been kept in equal readiness for some years, and is now near enough to the end to see the consummation in of his keeping.

Mayor KINGSLAND, it will be seen, has vetoed the Ordinance granting to a private Company the right of building a Railroad in Broadway. The reasons he gives for his action are cogent, and to very many minds will be convincing. The Common Council, how ever, will undoubtedly pass the bill in spite of the veto, and without any regard to the considerations it presents.

The great Southern and Western Trade Convention assembled at Baltimore on Saturday, and the Telegraph brings full details of the interesting proceedings. The Convention was held in the New Assembly Rooms, and was very numerously attended; Its members meeting and separating with the utmost good feeling.

THE NEW WORK-HOUSE ON BLACKWELL'S ISLAND.--On Saturday last the Aldermen, Governors of the Alms-House, and quite a number of invited guests, visited Blackwell's Island for the purpose of locking at the new Work House, which has just been completed After an inspection of the premises had been made, the company were invited to a sumptuous dinner which had been prepared for the occasion.

General PIERCE attended Rev. Mr. KIRK'S Church this forenoon. JOHN F. PLUMMER. while drawing some burning fluid from a cask on Saturday evening, at his grocery glore in Garden-street, accidentally ignited it with a lamp, and an emplosion followed, which burned him so that he died at 8 o'clock this morning.

The London Standard, announcing the death of Rev. M. MARCUS, formerly Rector of the Church of St. George the Martyr, in this City adds: He came to this country about four years since, for the purpose of procuring means for the establishment of an Emigrants' Home in New-York, in which the poorer class of British emigrants should enjoy the advantages of shelter and religions instruction on their arrival in the United States.

We are in the receipt of later advices from Mexico. Private letters say that Gen. CARAVAJAL has crossed the Rio Grande with 100 Texan Rangers, and is marching on Monterey. It is said he has been invited by the citizens of Tamaulipas, and that Gen CRUZ, the military commandant at Camargo, is indirectly aiding the movement.

ROBBERY.--About 4 o'clock yesterday after noon, a woman named SUSAN WELSH, who keeps a drinking and eating saloon in the basement story of the Commercial Buildings, on the career of Lombard and Gay-streets, was arrested by officers McKENLEY and GOODRICH on the charge of having robbed GEORGE W. MAYNLAND, Captain of the English ship Constitution, of money to the amount 89'0. and several valuable papers.

Loud complaints are made from time to time of the utter inadequacy of the salaries paid to our Ministers abroad; and the President, some months since, addressed a circular letter to at least a portion of our representatives in Europe asking for accurate information upon this subject. Replies from several of them will be found in another part of the Times this morning.

From a private letter in the London Times, July 2, 1852, during a recent solitary tour in search of stray horses, I was forced to visit the celebrated "Bendigo" diggings, and as events of a prodigious nature follow each other so quickly in this go a head colony, it's just as well to jot down memoranda of them while they are yet fresh.

The people vs. Clark. The people vs. Sulivan.--Judge MITCHELL.--The prisioners in both these cases were tried at the Oyer and Terminer, and found guilty of murder. The Judge who presided at the trial charged the jury as to the meaning of the statute defining murder; the prisoners, by their counsel excepted to the charge, and a writ of error was brought to this Court.

Mr. KING clings to the hope of again attending the Senate, to resign his office of President in person. Should he be convinced, however, of his inability to attend, he will send in his written resignation.

During the four weeks ending the 24th ult., 158 deaths from cholera, and 105 from yellow fever, occurred at New Orleans. Brig Mechanic, bound to New York with a cargo of mahogany, has been totally lost.

FROM YUEATAN.--While from many of the States of Republican Mexico, we hear accounts of anarchy and revolution, from the State of Yueatan we have a more favorable story, contained in a letter received in this city, dated Sieal. Nov. 21, which says: "Matters are quiet here. BARBACHAINO, (Spaniard.)has been elected Governor.

LIQUOR DOINGS.--In an attempt to arrest an Irishman on Exchange-street for violation of the liquor law, a desperate encounter took place between some fifty Irish citizens and officers PHILLIPS, FARNHAM and WALKER, of this city, C. D. GILMORE, of Newburg, and NATHANIEL BARKER. of Exetcr. The defender was captured, but PHILLIPS, WALKER and GILMORE were somewhat injured.

A WOMAN KILLED ON THE NEW-HAVEN RAILROAD.--At 8 o'clock Saturday morning, a woman named ELIZAA CULLEN, residing in Fifty-second-street, was run over and Instantly killed by the New-Haven accommodation train, near Fifty-first-street. It appears the unfortunate woman was endeavoring to cross the track, when the train came along at rapid speed, the cowcatcher struck her feet and tossed her into the air.

You are already apprised by telegraph, that Mr. KING will probably be unable to visit the Senate to-day. as he hoped on Friday last. He is extremely desirous of standing once more in his place in that body, and laying off the harness there, where he has worn it so many years. He desires also to address his brother Senators a few words of counsel, and farewell.

Interesting intelligence from Mexico has reached us through New-Orleans. The Revolution was progressing rapidly. URAGA has entered fully into the movement in Guadalajara, and the Provinces on the Pacific espouse the cause of SANTA ANNA. Reports of the movements of the French in Sonora are contradictory. The engagement between the troops of DE RAOUSSET and Gen. BLANCO, was severe, and heavy losses were sustained on both sides.

The service up-town was not held last evening, owing to Rev. Mr. CANFIELD's illness. In the North Dutch Church, Rev. JOHN B. HAGANY , of the Methodist Church, delivered a very able and argumentative discourse on Faith. His text was St. Mark, ch. II, v. 22. " Have faith in God."

SIR: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of Nov. 4, 1851, (No. 17,) communicating a resolution adopted by the Senate on the 31st of Jan. last, and asking specific and accurate information respecting the expenses incident to my residence in my official character at Constantinople.

The steamship Isabel arrived at Charleston on Saturday, with Havana dates of the 15th inst. Everything was quiet at Havana, and the excitement in reference to crescent City affair had entirely subsided. The Cyane was still at Havana. From Key West we learn that the brig Florida, bound from Charleston to Boston, formerly reported to have put in there, and been condemned--has been sold.

As the prison van was coming up from the county prison this morning, with a number of noted offenders to receive their sentences, an English burglar named SMITH, and another convict known as "Jack Shepherd." alias Hughes, managed to escape by slipping off the lock of the van. Efforts have been made to recapture the in but thus for they have proved unavailing.

With great respect for the opinions uttered with the gravity proper in a message of the Chief Magistrate of the Union, permit me to make a few side remarks, not particularly touching the general merit of the document, which we have had the pleasure of reading, although interdicted under the " misconception" of the Captain-Genoral of Cuba-General CANEDO.

At the Anniversary dinner of the Scottish Hospital Society, held in London on the last day of November, Lord JOHN RUSSELL toasted "The President of the United States," and Mr. INGERSOLL replied--his first appearance on any public occasion in England. The News of Dec. 1. thus speaks of the effort:

The Journal of Commerce publishes the following correspondence concerning a matter which has been for some years a subject of public comment: BOSTON, March 21, 1846. DEAR SIR: I have the honor to inform you that there is now deposited in the Massachusetts Hospital Life Insurance Company, on special contract, the sum of THIRTY-SEVEN THOUSAND DOLLARS.

ENFORCING AN ORDINANCE.--We have an old ordinance prohibiting all shopkeepers from making storehouses of the sidewalks. This law has been almost a dead letter and the walks have been used and blocked up in every direction with perfect impunity--if one may except a case here and there where some of the public functionaries were incommoded. But recently a new leaf has been turned over.

By the arrival at this port of the ship Margaret Eliza, Capt. ADAMS, we have dates from Buenos Ayres to Nov. 1. The news relates chiefly to the commercial policy of the Government. The British Packet is taken up with public documents, one of which recognizes as a principle the advantages of a free navigation of the river Parana.

Saturday Evening.-The Board met at 5 o'clock on Saturday, having first refreshed in the keeper's room It seems the meeting was for the special purpose of reeiving the Mayor's veto on the Broadway Railroad. A quorum being present they proceeded to business. PETITIONS REFERRED.-Of James F. Chamberlain, to be appointed a Commissioner of Deeds.

The Secretary read a letter from Mr. KING, in closing his resignation as presiding officer. Mr. BUTLER said his colleague, DE SAUSSURE, was present. On the journals it appeared that when Mr. KING appeared in the Senate for the first time, there was no presiding officer. On motion a Senator was authorized to administer the oath of office.

While the contest between Mr. Secretary KENNEDY and the workmen in the several Navy-Yards was pending, we held our peace, in deference to the dictates of fair play. Now that it is over, we see good reasons for putting the case clearly on record, and pointing its moral, in order that other Secretaries of the Navy and Government functionaries generally may profit by the lesson.

In the Board of Aldermen, on Saturday evening, the following Veto Message on the Broad way Railroad was received from Mayer KINGSLAND: MAYOR'S OFFICER, Dec. 19, 1852. To the Hon. the Board of Alderman of the City of New York: GENTLEMEN: I return herewith, without my approval, the report and resolutions granting to the parties therein named the privilege of laying down a railroad track in Broadway.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: An article having been reprinted from the London Tablet of Nov. 27, asserting that the Right Rev. Bishop IVES, of North Carolina, in an interview with Cardinal WISEMAN, had renounced the communion of the Reformed Church and submitted himself to the Church of Rome,

EXPLOSION OF THE MAGNET.--We learn from the officers of the Royal Arch. some particulars of the explosion on the Magnet, not furnished by the telegraphic dispatch published on Wednesday. The Magnet was on her way up to this port, and when at the head of Grand View Island, landed for the purpose of fixing some part of here machinery; and it was while lying to that here boilers burst.

Says the Richmond Republican, on Wednesday the 16th inst., Augustus Kumblin, a German citizen, aged 32 years, ended his existence by blowing out his brains with a musket, loaded with powder and ball., Mr. Kumblin was a shoemaker by trade, but had been engaged for several months in selling German books about the streets. He was a very king hearted, humane man.

PEDICATION.--The Dedicatory Ceremonies of the Order of Odd Fellowship, were performed last Friday evening, in Wellwood's Hall. Mechanic's Lodge was dedicated, and a very large representation of the Lodges in the District were present, and participated in the solutions of the occasion. At the conclusion of the service they repaired to the saloon of VAN DURAIN. Where a sumptuous repast was served, and to which fall justice ??. .

Mr. PUTNAM inserts in his Semi-monthly Library, A Story of Life on the Isthmus, an extremely readable and chatty book. Mr. FABBNS, the author, is already known as the hero of The Camel Hunt, a book which amused many readers in its time. His humor, unlike his camels, when transferred to American soil, does not appear to flag in the least.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On Monday evening, the Broadway Theatre presented us with a new grand opera anti spectacle, called "The Peri, or the Enchanted Fountain." Mr. MAEDAR's talents as a musician, and the estimation in which he is held by all who know him, would have insured an overflowing house;

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: The address of the Ladies' Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church, as read at Metropolitan Hall, Friday evening, Dec. 17, 1852, has the statement, at least, which in justice to myself and others, I feel called upon kindly to correct. It is found in the following paragraph:

LOSS OF THE STEAMER CLEOPATRA BY FIRE.--The steamer Cleopatra, Capt. Rose, from Black River, with a cargo of 914 bales Cotton, bound down, took fire on Monday night, 6th inst. about six miles below the Trinity river, and was totally destroyed, a small portion of the Cotton will be saved. The fire originated in the wood-racks, alongside the border, and then communicated with the Cotton.

The condition of affairs in Mexico reminds one of the breaking up of the ice of an Arctic bay. The first sunshine of prosperity in that hapless Republic, after a momentary calm has permitted the perturbed political waters to become congealed, thaws the ice, and once again we have the thunderous sounds, and surfaceheaving and purposeless commotion betokening another terrible convulsion.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE.--About 2 o'clock on Monday morning a fire broke out in the grocery store of Mr. E. L. SAMUEL, (PADDY BURNS' old stand.) and before it could be extinguished, the entire building, with three others, were consumed, viz : those occupied by J O HARA'S shoe and leaher store, Dr. CRUTCHER's drug store, and the dwelling house adjoining the last, and occupied by the family of Mr. WM H. KENDALL, deceased.

The Buffalo Courier, a leading Democratic paper in Western New York, speaks thus of Gov. SEYMOUR's course in regard to the enlargement and speedy completion of our State Canals: "Governor SEYMOUR need have no embarrassment upon the Canal Question, and, we presume, has none. He voluntarily took a position previously to the election--he boldly advocated everywhere the speedy completion of the enlargement.

It is a terrible trial to Yankees to let so fine a water-power be wasted at Niagara; and every few months, we hear of some new plan for erecting mills in the vicinity, to be driven by its head. But against anything of the sort, the taste, the poetic sense of the world revolts.

By the arrival of the United States, we have received dates from Kingston to the 12th inst. The earthquake, which occurred at Kingston, on the morning of the 26th ult., was not confined to the Island, but produced sad alarm in St. Jago. The Standard publishes a detailed account of the sensations produced by the shock.

We have received, by way of New-Orleans, later intelligence from the City of Mexico,--the dates from that City being to the l6th of Nov. The revolution was making progress in every quarter, and Government was unable to check it in any quarter. Gen. URAGA had entered fully into the movement in Guadalajara, and was endeavoring to enlist the population of Guadalajara and Michoacan in the same cause.

By the bark Kate Lincoln, we have received files of Georgetown (Demarara) papers to the 18th, and accounts from the island of St. Lucia to the 5th Nov. The Georgetown papers are mainly taken up with a trial for forgery, which has been going on for some time in the Supreme Court of that colony, which, however, possesses only a local interest:

MARINE DISASTERS.--The schooner Brewster, loaded with lumber, which sailed for Cleveland, front Long Point, C. W., capsized in the Lake, and all hands on board were drowned. The vessel ?? ashore, bottom up, near Fairport. The Brewster and cargo were owned by Mr. PETER FRANCISCO, of Ohio City, who took passage for Cleveland, gether with Messrs. WM.

We are this morning called upon to record another sad accident on the Hudson River Railroad. It appears that about thirty three laborers employed on the road. and closing their work soon after 6 o'clock last evening. started on their return to the City on a gravel train. On approaching Spuyten Tuyvil Creek, the Station Agent hoisted a signal of danger, (the draw of the bridge being then up,)

They are from the pen of one than whom the young merchant has no truer well wisher, JOHN GRIGG, the retired bookseller of Philadelphia, whose large wealth is the result of the practical observance of the maxims which he here places on record for the consideration of his successors :

The snow is very heavy, and now a foot deep. It is said to be a foot and a half in the woods. We learn that it is from two and a half to three feet deep in the Rum River pinery, about 100 miles above St Paul. The river which had been closed by the cold weather of the previous week, has been opened in many places by the subsequent weather.

The generality of people, in their ideas of England's dependencies, do not perhaps always realize the fact that she has three military Colonies, of a powerful order, on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea, and another post in the North Sea-not to mention the stations that lie, as it were, within hail of her own cliffs.

PEASE is Superintendent, called together a large and respectable audience. The Programme for the evening promised the performance of the popular Cantata, "Eleutheria."

One mail from New-Orleans arrived this morning leaving the latest still due. The APPLETONS have just published in two neat volumes of their Popular Library, the "LIFE AND MEMORIALS OF DANIEL WEBSTER, from the New-York Daily Times." The volumes contain (1) the biographical sketch of Mr. WEBSTER published in the Times the day after his death, which occupies over 150 pages in this book,--with its leading articles upon the subject:--(2) the MEMORIALS,

Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from the American Peace Society, in favor of the arbitration of national disputes. On motion, a Committee of Conference was reappointed, on the disagreeing votes of the two Houses on the bill granting a pension to the widow of Gen. WORTH. Mr. DODGE, of Iowa, gave notice that at an early day he would move to take up the homestead bill.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The regular meeting of this body was held on Monday evening. After various unimportant business was transacted, the Board adjourned to Thursday evening, for the purpose of taking up the Charter amendments. The Treasurer reported the amount of moneys received, $84,474; paid out $95,000; overpaid, $10,530.

On the 24th June the Colonial Secretary laid upon the table of the Legislative Council the reports of the Chief Commissioner for the gold districts. on the present state and future prospect of the western and southern gold fields. The report opens by stating the places at which a sufficient number of diggers have been at work to render it desirable to form an establishment, Viz:

LARGE FIRE.--At an early hour yesterday morning, a Police Officer discovered flames arising from a building at the corner of Tillary-street and Hudsonavenue, formerly occupied as a grocery by PATRICK CARBERRY, but at the present time untenanted. The flames spread with great rapidity, and wore only chocked after burning three wooden buildings and a part of a fourth, all on Tillary-street.

The obsequies, yesterday, passed off to the entire satisfaction of our citizens and the numerous strangers in the city. Truly, it was mournfully brilliant; and although it rained the night previous, the day was clear and cold, and the sun and wild soon dried the streets.

FIRE.--Monday evening, about 10 o'clock, a firewas discovered breaking out of the boot and shoe store of Mr. PEARCE, No. 270 Fulton-street. Engine Company No. 3 was promptly upon the ground, and extinguished the flumes before they had made much progress. The damage sustained by fire and water amounts to about $400 or $500, covered by insurance.

The Mercantile Library Association of this City has started a project which bids fair to be an excellent commencement of a very worthy plan. The preparation and preservation of maps and charts of noted places, currents of the ocean, winds and tides, are objects that will commend themselves to the attention of persons who desire to spread important knowledge among the masses.

The $2,500,000 before reported as about to be expended by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, in laying down a double track and in purchasing locomotives and cars. is intended to accommodate the coal trade. The President of the Company has called a meeting of representatives of all the Cumberland Coal

We have already given the leading items of intelligence from Buenos Ayres by the latest arrival, The following statements of the present condition of affairs, with the official documents appended, are interesting:

Prof. OLMSTED delivered his third Lecture and last but one, on Monday evening, in the Tabernaale. Though the evening was not as pleasant as one could wish, yet the audience was large and intelligent as usual.

On Tuesday, Dec. 21, at Hackensack, R. P. CAMPBELL, aged 40 years. His friends and the friends of his father-in law. Andrew Brown are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at Hackensack, on Thursday, the 23d, at the house of Mrs. Van Tilburgh. Cars leave Jersey City at 9 A. M. On Tuesday morning, Dec. 21. in the 74th year of her age, SUSAN, relict of John Aspinwall.

The Baltimore Sun has a letter from Petersburg, Va., stating that BENJAMIN SADLER (charged with kidnapping,) and another prisoner named JONES, had assailed their keeper and locked him in a cell. They then crossed the prison yard, when JOEL STURDIVANT and a negro man attempted to stop them, and were both shot dead by SADLER.

Three men named CHAPIN, (of the late firm of FILLEY CHAPIN, shoe dealers.) WILLIAM KISSANE, (of the firm of SMITH KISSANE, park merchants,) and ---- CHANDLER, were arrested in this city yesterday by the U.S. Marshal, charged with swindling, murder and arson--in obtaining Insurance Policies by false bills of lading, signed by the officers of the steamer Martha Washington, which was burned about the 1st of Feb. last, on the Mississippi river.

And we utterly deny that New-York or its press-Boston and her press can speak for themselves-has ever attempted to "ignore the existence of any commercial capitals" but our own.

The New Orleans mail, as late as due, came through this morning. The Pacayune has advices from Texas to the 10th inst. DIXON H. LEWIS'S widow, his brother, and brother-in-Law who removed to Texas from Alabama.

The proceedings in the Senate yesterday turned upon the question of the Lieutenant-Generalship to be conferred upon Gen. SCOTT. The creation of the office was commended by Mr. SHIELDS, discussed by Mr. CASS, who reviewed his former action in the Senate on the same subject; and the subject was finally merged into a debate on the merits of the Mexican War and the platforms of the parties, including a consideration of the

The Milwaukee Sentinel complains that we do not represent the Banking law of Wisconsin fairly. We can promptly reply that no injustice has been intended; none can be drawn from the objections which we have repeatedly stated to the use of railway bonds, for the reason that the Scntincl concedes that this provision is in the law.

The observer who traces on the map of the world the movement of Nations, is struck with three great facts :-the stagnant condition of the Latin race, which advances slowly in Africa under the French flag, and recedes at all other points:--the maritime progress of the Anglo Saxon race, which invades the East by India and America, and takes its stand at Gibraltar and in the Mediter.

ADDITIONAL PARTICULARS.--In yesterday morning's issue of the Times, we published exclusively an account of the accident that occurred on Monday evening at Spuyten Tuyvil Creek. Yesterday, our Special Reporter revisited the scene of the accident, but found it utterly impossible to obtain reliable information as regards the extent of the loss of life that ensued.

The regular meeting of the Farmer's Club was held in the room of the American Insitute, yesterday, at 12 o'clock M., R. T. UNDERHILL, Esq., of Croton Point, in the Chair. On motion of Mr. DICKEY, the Club, proceeded to consider the fruit produced and preserved by Mr. W. R. SMITH, of Macedon, Wayne County.

Some transactions have come to our notice within a few days, which illustrate the temper-fever heat we may call it-of speculation in this branch of business. The movement extends equally to purchases in fee and to new leases.

A great experiment in Navigation is now on the eve of trial. The Caloric Ship is undergoing the final preparations for her experimental trip, and will soon be before the public for praise or censure. Our own port is destined to reap the honor or suffer the reproach of its ultimate success or failure.

The Senate having disposed of the disputed election case by admitting Mr. DIXON to his seat, will probably take up the proposition to confer the rank of Lieut.General on General SCOTT tomorrow or at some early day. General CASS will make quite a speech on the proposition.

Prof. R. O. DOREMIUS, of the New-York Medical College, delivered the first of two lectures before the Mechanics' Society last evening. The lecture-room was filled to excess. The matter of the Professor's discourse was rendered highly interesting by various experiments, the apparatus for which were very complete. A powerful galvanic battery was brought to work, by which many beautiful results were obtained. The subject for last evening

MEXICAN BOUNDARY COMMISSION.--Extract of a letter from a member of the Boundary Commission to a friend in this city, dated CHIHUAHUA. (Mexico,) Oct. 29, 1852. We were compelled to come this side of the Rio Grande, down through the Mexican States, for want of an escort, and had to rely upon an escort of Mexican soldiers.

On Wednesday, Dec. 22, ELIZABETH ANN BROAD-BRIDGE. The friends and relatives are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this day, at 1 o'clock, from No 94 St. Mark's place without further invitation. Last evening, in the 47th year of his age, MARK H NEWMAN, for many years a publisher and bookseller in this City.

The Committee on the part of the City Government of Boston, consisting of Messrs. HOBART, SPIN NEY and KIMBALL, of the Council, and Messrs. OBER and REED, of tile Board or Aldermen, commissioned to tender the hospitality of the City to General PIERCE, on his way to Washington, waited on the General this morning, and he accepted the invitation.

THE WHIG PRIMARY ELECTIONS FOR GENERAL AND WARD COMMITTEES --The Whig Primary Elections in each of the twenty Wards came off yesterday morning between the hours of 7 and 10 o'clock, and, as far as we could ascertain, everything was conducted in a harmonious and quiet manner. The Whigs appeared united, and in nearly every Ward but one ticket was run, and those elected for tire ensuing year are men of good standing.

FLORIDA LEGISLATURE AND INDIANS.--Dr. MAGBEE, of Hillsborough, in the Florida Legislature, now in session, has given notice of his latention to bring in a oill to extend the laws of the State over the Territory now in the occupation of the Indians. The Floridian Journal says that the General Government has failed to perform its duty in the removal of the Seminoles, according to repeated treaty stipulation,

The second Lecture of this Course was delivered last evening, in the Tabernacle, by Rev. SAMUEL ??GOOD. On no previous occasion, during the season, did we see so large and respectable an auditory in the Tabernacle; nor has there been any on which the subject was more interesting, or handled with greater ability.

It may he of some interest to your readers who are friends of the " Maine Law," to hear of its operation in our city. This is, perhaps, the temperance city of the Common wealth; at least, I believe there is no other place where the law has been so rigorously executed as in this, and, consequently, none where its salutary effect can so clearly be seen.

Sweet languishing Spring has thrown her arms around hoary, stern, old Winter, and has coinpletely captivated him with her bewitching loveliness. I really think that Winter has " given in," or rather given it up, for we have rarely witnessed such charming weather here in the month of December. Our City is crowded with strangers, more so than I have seen it for years at this period,

A letter from Berlin, Maryland, dated the 2Oth inst., says that the brig Atlantic remains tight; most of her cargo is landed, and a vessel has been chartered to convey it to Philadelphia. The Atlantic was expected to float next tide. The schooner November, from New-Bedford, for Norfolk, ran ashore on the 17th, half a mile above where the Atlantic lies. She is an old vessel, and will go to pieces.

THE RECENT ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD--THE BODY OF THE FIREMAN BROUGHT TO THE CITY.--THE CORONER'S INVESTIGATION.--The remains of the unfortunate fireman named PATRICK CASEY, who was killed by the late accident on the Hudson River Railroad, at Spuyten Tuyvil Creek, was brought to the Thirty-First-st. depot yesterday,...

The Bark Leo, Capt. MILLS, from Malaga in 41 days and 38 days from Gibraltar, with Fruit and Wine to AGUIRE GALWAY. Passed Gibraltar in company with some American barks, one of which was painted black, showing a French flag for a signal--the Leo has experienced very severe weather during the whole passage--split several sails.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I might naturally, in the mere chronological order of my own recollections, pass from RANDOLPH of Roanoke, the abortive child of talent and of notoriety, to JOHN MARSHALL, the least specious of men, the most inartificial that ever was; to whom Nature had given the strongest abilities and the solidest virtues:

FRIENDSHIP AND ENMITY.--He who is a friend to himself has seldom any lack of enemies; but he who is his own enemy, is generally considered a clever fellow, and has a plenty of friends and well wishers. "And hitherto doth love on fortune tend, And who not needs, shall never lack a friend; But who in want, a hollow friend doth try, Directly seasons him his enemy."

THE UNIVERSITY OF ALABAMA.--The Independent Monitor, published at Tusealoosa, contains the catalogue of the University for 1852-3, from which it appears that the institution is tolerably patronized. The number of pupils is as follows: Seniors 14: Juniors 24: Sophomores 11: Freshmen 22; total 101. Of these, Mobile furnishes four.

NEW-ENGLAND SOCIETY--STATUE TO WEBSTER--The New-England Society of the City of New-York held their annual meeting for the transaction of business in the Astor House, at 5 P. M., yesterday. The Chair was taken by LUTHER B. HUBUART. The minutes of the last annual meeting were read and approved. The Treasurer's Report showed a balance remaining in hands of $673.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Your editorial on the topic of Free Banking, in the Times of the 17th inst., introduces to your readers the whole subject of Banking and currency, and induces the following questions: What are the principles which govern the subject, and what is the preciso evil against which we are to guard, and which, at the present time, secens to agitate the public?

The steamer Cherokee. which left yesterday for New-York, was fined fifteen dollars, for having on the previous trip discharged a conciliation gun when opposite the palace, as she was leaving port for New-Orleans, without having obtained permits sion from the supreme authority, in violation of the regulations of the port,

THE AZTEC CHILDREN LAW SUIT SETTLED.--We learn that the comroversy about the possession of the Aztec children has been finally settled, by compromise, and that Mr. MORRIS, who has them in charge, has paid to RAYMOND O SELVA, the claimant for possession of them, the sum of thirteen thousand dollars for his interest in them. The documents were prepared by CONSTANT GUILLON, Esq. attorney for Mr. MORRIS, and acknowledged nature air WILCOX Notary Public.

The British schooner Time arrived here to-day, in five days from Nassau, reports that the bark Ovando arrived in distress at Nassau, on Dec. 3, fifty-five days from Havre-was burned on the 6th to the water's edge. A1l her cargo was not burned,

SHAMEFUL.--J. O. WILLIAMS was found dead in a house on Main-street, Utica, on Friday last, and a verdict of death from "exhaustion and want of proper care," rendered concerning him, The Utica Herald finds on further inquiry, that if he did not die from positive starvation, his end was hastened by neglect and desertion. He had been for some time unwell and had depended for his subsistence upon the charity of friends.

ATTEMPT TO TAKE LIFE WITH FIRE ARMS.--Yesterday morning, the Police of the First Ward brought a man named HENRY L. PETESCH before Justice OSBORN, at the Lower Police Court, charged with attempting to take the life of JAMES DOOLEY, residing at No. 67 Greewich-street.

AN ALTERED BILL.--One of the most successful cases of altering hills from a small to a large denomination, was discovered in the Suffolk Bank this morning. The bill in question was altered from a $1 to a five hundred, and so perfectly was the thing done that the foreign money-teller of the Suffolk Bank took it without suspicion, and the cheat was only discovered by the scrutiny of the accountant.

The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Treasury Department, relative to the classification of clerks. Mr. RUSK said the appointment of Mr. ATCHISON as President of the Senate, made a vacancy in the Committee on Indian Affairs. He moved the Chair fill that vacancy.

The Two Hundred and Thirty-Second Anniversary of the Pilgrins' Landing was celebrated by the New-England Society of the City of NewYork, in their forty-seventh annual meeting at the Tabernacle, last evening. A free invitation was given to the public, and at all early hour every available seat in the building was occupied by an attentive and respectable auditory.

THE WATER REPORT.--The report of Mr. MCALPINE, the Engineer, who has been making the necessary examinations relative to the supplying of the City of Brooklyn with water, has been printed, and we presume is now ready for distribution at head-quarters. The report makes a book of 140 pages, and contains a large amount of information which every citizen of Brooklyn is interested in, water or no water.

STREET COMMISSIONER.--The Common Council, after a great many ineffectual attempts to elect a Street Commissioner, elected JAMES FLEMMING, at their last meeting They also resolved to advertise for proposals for printing the proceedings of the Board. Bills, amounting to the sum of $154, were received from the Board of Education, and disposed of in the usual manner, and the Board adjourned to Tuesday evening next.

The "Odd Fellows Offering" for 1853, is published this year somewhat behind time; but the loss of time has probably been the gain of the work. It is got up with the usual care and taste, the selections made with fair judgment, and the bindings in Mr. EDWARD WALKER'S most elaborate style.

The serious illness of Hon. Wm. R. KING, Vice President elect of the United States, has suggested a very general consideration of several questions which would arise in the event of his decease. It is asked: " Suppose Mr. KING dies before he is qualified as Vice President--who, in that event, would discharge the duties of Vice President after the 4th of March next?--and would not the people...

On the 2d of December, tile subscribers to the IIoon Memorial Fund had a public meeting in London, to consider tile prospects of their design. The Secretary reported that over [Pound]312 had been subscribed, of which ?250 had been actually received. [Pound]500 is the sum sought, and it was resolved to close the list on the 1st of February 1853.

AN ACT authorizing the construction of a Railroad and branches; for establishing a certain postal communication between the shores of the Pacific and Atlantic, within the United States, for the protection and facilities of travel and commerce, and for the necessary defences of the country.

The brig Halifax has arrived here with Halifax, N. S, papers of the 18th inst. The British North American announces the sudden and unexpected failure of the firm of JOHN McDOUGALL Co., with liabilities between $50,000 and $60,000; and it is feared other firms may be involved. An investigation into the cause of the failure was going on.

The Union, of this morning, says that Hon. W R. KING has so much improved in health as no longer to need the attendance of a physician, and he will probably be able to take his seat in the Senate in a few days. The President recognizes FRANCISCO SALVADOR ALOAREZ as Consul for the Republic of Chili at California.

WATCH HOUSE--The Watch Department have hitherto labored under considerable disadvantage in consequence of the want of a suitable building as hendquarters. The subject has been repeatedly presented to the consideration of the authorities, who at their last meeting, adopted the following resolution: Resolved. That the Committee on Watch be and hereby are authorized and empowered to cause such repairs to be made to the new Watch-house as they may deem necessary.

The new Light House Board. W. B. Shubrick, Chairman, at Washington City, has issued a circular requesting mariners and others interested in commerce, and the preservation of life and property from loss by shipwreck, to give prompt information of cases in which lights are not lighted punctually at sunset. and extinguished at sunrise, or in which they are not properly attended to during the night.
