Now, the tables are turned, and the political majority bring forward and support a proposition,

Richard Eells Plaintiff in Error vs. The People of the State of Illinois--In Supreme Court of the United States.-Writ of Error to the Supreme Court of Illinois. Mr. CHASE and Mr. DixoN, for plaintiffs; Mr. McDOUGALL, for defendant in Error. Mr. Justice GRIER delivered the opinion of the Court. The plaintiff in error was indicted and convicted under the criminal code of Illinois for " harboring and secreting a negro slave."

It is rumored that Hon. R. M. T. HUNTER has gone to Concord, by invitation from Gen. PIERCE. The article in the Concord Patriot is not considered official. Our statement of the Sccretary of the Interior's contracts, though contradicted, came from high authority; and it is till believed that he will leave it with the CongrEssional Coninittecs to consider and report who shall furnish bricks for the capitol extension.

The affairs of Cuba were discussed yesterday in the Senate, and Messrs. MASON and CASS made extended speeches on the general questions growing out of that fruitful theme. Mr. MASON introduced and supported a resolution calling upon the President for the correspondence of the French and English Ministers, proposing a Tripartite Convention, to disclaim all intentions against Cuba.

A work of much beauty, and of profound interest to the religious world, is the "American Missionary Memorial," published by the Messrs HARFERS. It contains historical sketches of American Missions, with biographies of all those self-sacrificing servants of the cause whose heroism does higher honor to the nation than the noblest displays of patriotism.

The following communication from Governor JOHNSON, relative to the discharge of the slaves of JONATHAN LEMMON, has been sent to the Legislature of Virginia. We find it in the Richmond Enquirer. EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, Dec. 17, 1852. To the General Assembly of Virginia:

The third lecture before the Historical Society at Metropolitan Hall, was, owing to the severity of the weather, but thinly attended. At 8. P. M., the President, lion. LUTHER BRADISH, introduced Rev. Wm. ALLEN, D. D., of Bowdoin College, Me., who, he said, hid kindly come, at considerable inconvenience, to deliver a lecture on their invitation.

The St. Paul (Minnesota) Pioneer says: The snow is very heavy, and now a foot deep. It is said to be a foot and a half deep in the woods. We learn that it is from two and a half to three feet deep in the Rum River pinery, about 109 miles above St. Paul This Winter will be one of the busiest seasons for teamsters that they have seen for many a day.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The columns of the Daily Times, of Wednesday, contained an extraordinary opinion of Mr. Justice ROOSEVELT. in the cases of The People vs. Clark and Suilivan. No lawyer or layman can have read that opinion without astonishment. If not extra-judicial, the tone of the opinion was certainly unjudicial. It finds fault with the Court of Appeals for reversing the learned Judge.

Hon. DUDLEY S. GREGORY of Jersey City, has been appointed by the President, as Commissioner of Customs in place of Mr. ROCKWELL, resigned. There is a great flare up among the Southern Democratic Senators, because Messrs. CASS and MASON sprung question on them in to-day's discussion on Cuba. SOULE and other fillibusters seem afraid of treachery.

The Richmond (Va.,) Dispatch has the following items of local news: A negro boy named THOMAS, slave to MAYO ArKINSON, was arrested Saturday evening last with an irregular pass, and on yesterday ordered five lashes. JAMES ALLEN, slave to ALLEN CORDON, was caught wish his sign hanging out in the same manner, contrary to law, and was ordered ten lashes.

The 935,000 robbery, reported last night, is believed to have been a humbug. The lost pocket-book has been found, and contained $28, instead of $35,000. It is believed that several reported robberies, of late, were similar humbugs. We have no mail to night south of Ricbmond.

From the Detroit Daily Advertiser. We have received this letter form Mackinaw, with the assurance that it is a true copy of one lately found in the streets of that village. It is unanswerable. MACKINAW, Dec. 4, 1852. To Hon. LEWIS CASS and Hon. DAVID STUART:

On Thursday evening, Dec. 23, in the 43d year of her age, SUSAN, wife of John Clark, a native of Dumfrieshire, Scotland. The friends of the family are respectfully invited in attend her funeral on Saturday. (to-morrow) morning, at 11 o"clock from No. 163 Lexington avenue, between 31st and 32d sts . Wednesday evening. Dec. 22, PHILIP L. VAN TAMBACHT, aged 20 years and 6 months.

FAIR FOR THE RELIEF OF THE AGED POOR.--We dropped in, for a short time last evening, upon the Fair of the Ladies Union Aid Society, at Metropolitan Hall, and were pleased to see that in spite of the very hardest kind of weather, there was a goodly gathering of purchasers. The object which the Society has in view, makes its success particularly gratifying.

Senator SEWARD is engaged in the Supreme Court of the United States, in the argument of an apparently intricate case, which comes up from Alabama, in which State both the parties to the suit reside. Our Washington correspondent, a day or two since, suggested as a little singular that Mr. SEWARD should have been hunted out and selected by a client in that Southern latitude.

In another part of this morning's paper, will be found a card from the District Attorney, explaining the circumstances under which the law complained of by Judge ROOSEVELT, in his opinion a day or two since, was passed by the Legislature We have already expressed our conviction of the mischievous tendency of such a course as that pursued by Judge ROOSEVELT in regard to this case.

The pictorial SHIPPING in BARNUM's Illustrated News, is thus criticised by a correspondent who both understands ships, and appreciates, proper pictorial representations of them: "Here's BARNUM's Illustrated News," bawled in our cars by a ragged newsboy, informed us of the advent of this long looked for pictorial. Scarce though sixpences be in sailors' pockets, we ventured to invest.

We publish this morning a second portion of the interesting and important Memoir of M. DUPASQUIER, urging the Colonization of Northern Mexico by France and other European powers, as the only means of checking the dangerous and overshadowing growth of the United States.

USING THE KNIFE.--At a late hour on Wednesday night, a man by the name of JOHN WALKER was attacked by a desperado named JOHN DONNELLY, while quietly walking through Cutharine-street. The assailant was pushed away by Mr. WALKER, who made an effort to escape. but was seized and stabbed three times with a knife in the hands of DONNELLY, indicting dangerous wounds.

We publish in another part of this morning's Times a very important Bill, introduced into the Senate of the United States on Wednesday last, by Senator GWIN of California, providing for the construction within ten years, of a Railroad from the Mississippi River to the Pacific Occan. We publish the bill entire, in order that its details may be examined, and thoroughly understood:

When Maine separated from Massachusetts. the latter State retained in its possession near four and a hall millions of acres, exclusive of the territory afterwards ceded by the Treaty of Washington, which lay within the bounds of Maine. At the opening of the present year, the title to about two and a half millions of acres, Massachusetts had parted with.

Our attention was arrested by the proceedings of a meeting lately held at Newburg, for the purpose of considering the evils of our present pauper system, as reported in the Newburg Gazetic. It would seem, from the tenor of the resolutions there passed, that in some portions of Orange County, the tax-payers are subjected to an oppression, and the poor to some inflictions. which are not true of the State at large.

MEDAL PRESENTATION--A very large and hand-some gold medal was yesterday presented on the part of the workmen employed on the Capital extension. to SAMUEL STRONG, Esq., late superintendent of the work. This beantiful acknowledgment had for one of its faces a corret bkeness of the Capitol as extesded, beautifully executed; on the other a tribute to Mr. STRONG.

WALLACK'S.-BULWER'S comedy Of " Money" is to be repeated, with the force of "Born to Good Luck." BROADWAY.--"The Peri," is to be performed this evening, and the first and second acts of "Tae Postilion of Lonjumeau," for the benefit of Miss C. RICHINGS.

THE COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.--THE DOTY PERJURY TRIAL--TELEGRAPHIC DISPATCH FROM Mas. FORREST--MOTION TO POSTPONE DENIED.--At the opening of the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning, at the Halls of Justice, Hon. RECORDER TILLOU, Alderman HALEY (2d Ward) and Alderman BARR (6th Ward) presided as the Judges.

[Continued from the Times of Monday] The protective system is the order of the day in the Union. It will be remembered that the acting President, MILLARD FILLMORE, through THOMAS CORWIN, Secretary of the Triasury, has demanded an increase of the tariff on foreign produce which is similar to that in the United States.

An Albany paper mentions the case of a young lady of that city, who, having frequent occasion, in the prosecution of benevolent objects, to visit the residences of the extremely destitute, was often pained with the slovenly appearance of their dwellings and children, and determined to make the experiment, on a small scale, of teaching the female children of a particular locality not only to read but to work.

The Royal Mail Steamship Canada, Captain LANG, reached her wharf in this city, at 11 1/2 o'clock this morning, having left Liverpool, at 10 A. M. on the 11th instant. The Canada has experienced a succession of very violent gales. She brings [pound]2,500 in specie. On the 11th inst., signalized the Cunard steamer Asia for Liverpool, and within six hours sail of that port.

The debate in the Senate to-day with reference to the acquisition of Cuba, brought up the entire subject for a discussion, which probably will be the most interesting of the session. During the ten days to come no important business will be taken up in either House, and gentlemen will have leisure to arrange their views, and be prepared to give them proper expression when the consideration of Mr. MASON's resolution is resumed.

SHIP ON FIRE.--The alarm about 5 o'clock last evening was caused by the discovery of fire on board the ship Affghan, of New-York, Capt. BASMUSEN, which had just arrived from New-Orleans. She had a cargo of 1,693 bales cotton, I do wool, and 1,169 bags lard--all of which must have been badly damaged, either from fire or the flood of water thrown by the city firemen.

The steamship Canada arrived at Halifax on Wednesday morning, but her news reached us only at a late hour last night. The dates from Liverpool are to the 11th inst. The new screw-steamer Andes loft 'Liverpool for this port on the 8;h, and is now seventeen days out. The City of Manchester also left on the 8th for Philadelphia.

All our places of public amusement offer attractive bills for Christmas night. At the BROADWAY--The new romantic Opera of " The Peri" is to be performed for the last time. The scenery of this piece has never been surpassed on any stage in this city. The panorama of the sea voyage is very fine, and the closing scene surpasses anything we have ever seen attempted.

Mr. SOULE, on Monday next. will introduce into the Senate, a resolution to place five millions of dollars at the disposal of President PIERCE, as a provision for any exigence in our foreign relations during the recess. The vote will be a test of confidence in the incoming Administrotion. The discussion upon the matter will open the whole subject of our foreign relations.--Tribune.

Dr. JOSEPH PARISH of Burlington, publishes a card in the Gazette of that place, stating that his evidence before the Committee of Investigation on the case of Bishop DOANE, has been wrongly reported in the papers, in which it is said that he advised the Bishop to drink more stimulating liquors, and that the Bishop's cellars were open to all people.

The Monroe doctrine has some real existence (in Congressional papers); the existence of a conspiracy amongst the European powers to check the rapid growth of this Republic may well be doubted, although it is occassionally assumed by writers for the press. At any rate, both the one and the other, the reality and the shadow, are practically inconvenient and unmanageable.
Christiaas is here; Winds whistle shrill, Icy and chill; Little care weLittle we-- Little we fear Weather without, Sheltered about The Mahogany Tree.

COUNTY JAIL.--This building, which, under the superintendence of Mr. JAMES FLEMMING, is undergoing a thorough alteration and enlargement, will be completed in about a month. The rear of the building has been raised two stories, in order to allow of the construction of two tiers of extra cells, 7 feet by 4 feet 10 inches, which will increase the whole number to 92.

THE BOUNDARY COMMISSION.--The following letter to the New-Orleans Picayune is dated Fort Duncan, Western Texas, Nov. 29: I have the pleasure to announce to you the safe arrival of the party of the Boundary Commission under Mr. MARINE CHANDLER. They came through Santa Rosa and San Fernando. having been compelled to abandon the work on the Rio Grande, owing to want of provisions consequent on the loss of the boats in the rapids.

" Now Hospitality, to cheer the gloom Of Winter, invitation sends abroad; The rural housewife lays the annual block Of Christmas on the hearth, and bids a blaze Of tenfold brightness glad its sable spot; Then sprucely decks the windows with fresh sprigs Of evergreen, triumphant o'er the storms Of fading time, while ever social mirth And rival kindness load the smoking board; And boisterous sport and heavy dance resound." [The Year.

Governor HEMPSTEAD, of Iowa, has sent his Annual Message to the Legislature. It is brief and sufficiently explicit. It opens by stating, tha, the country has had occasion to mourn the loss of some of its most eminent statesmen-CALHOUN, WOODBURY, CLAY, and WEBSTER, since the close of the last session of the General Assembly.

Capt. W. W. Williams, aged about 62 one of the earliest settlers of this section, says the Cleveland Herald, committed suicide at his residence in Newburg, on Sunday night by hanging himself. It is supposed by his neighbors that grief for the loss of his wife some two years ago, has preyed upon his mind until it overcame his reason, and that the act was the result of temporary insanity.

MASSACHUSETTS CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION.--The Commonwealth gives the following as the official count of the vote of the people of Massachusetts on the question: "Is it expedient that delegates be chosen to meet in Convention to revise the Constitution of this Commonwealth," on the 8th of Nov. last:

The bark Reindeer has arrived at this port with Rio Janeiro dates to the 17th November. She brings 3,500 bags of Coffee. The ship Sophia Walker, for New-York, was to sail on 18th, and the bark E. Corning, for New-York, during the week. The ship Dakotah, from New-York for San Francisco, was at Rio repairing. We have no mail to-day south of Petersburg, making three now due from New-Orleans.

No. 2. John Hager, appellant, vs. L. P. Walker et al. On appeal from the District Court of the United States for the Northern District of Alabama. Mr. Justice Curtis delivered the opinion of this Court, reversing the decree of the said District Court, with costs, and remanding this cause, with directions to overrule the demurrer, and order the defendants, other than the representatives of the United States, to answer the bills.

THE ANNUAL HIRING OF NEGROES.--The time for hiring negroes for the year 1853 will soon arrive Main-street will be converted into one vast unroofed intelligence office, and the owners, masters and hirers, in accordance with the usual custom, will briefly dance attendance upon their black attendants.

GREENHOUSES IN WINTER.--Very few persons appear to know the value of the sponge in a greenhouse-I mean for the purpose of washing the leaves of all those plants with leaves broad enough to admit of it. I took the hint some five years ago from a neighbor, the most successful plant-grower I have ever had the good fortune to know.

RESIGNATION OF THE PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE.--The following is tile letter of Hon. WILLIAM R. KING, resigning the office of President pro tern. of the Senate-read in that body on the 20th instant: WASHINGTON CITY, Dec. 20, 1852. SENATORS : The feeble state of my health renders me unable to discharge the duties of President pro tem.

It is reported that Governor BOUTWELL is dissatisfied with the proceedings of the sale of Massachusetts land in Maine, and will refuse to ratify the sale. An objection, it is said, has been discovered, which renders the proceedings void. The commission, to be appointed under the resolution for the division of lands with the State of Maine, has not yet been filled up,

TEMPERANGE.--The Union avenue Washington Total Abstinence Society held a regular weekly meeting at the First Mission M. E. Church, on Wednesday evening. Addresses were made by Rev Mr. HINESON, Messrs. LANDOWER, McDONOUGH, Aid. BARKER and Mr. BROWN, of Yonkers. Several temperance odes were also sung by Messrs. BROWN McDONOGH, and others.

We published yesterday the commencement of what will doubtless prove to be a very important debate in the Senate of the United States, upon our Foreign Relations,--and especially upon the movements of European Powers designed and calculated seriously to affect our interests and our rights.

A SHAM DOCTOR.--The police authorities are at present engaged in the investigation of a case of some interest to emigrants and others who may be necessitated to entrust their health and lives to the care of a medical man during a lengthened sea voyage.

The existence of an open sea at the North Pole, is proved by an amount of testimony known to but few persons. In 1751, Capt. McCULLUM sailed from Hackluyt's Headland, to lat. 83 1/2[degrees] North, where he found an open sea, and the weather being fine, nothing prevented his proceeding farther North but his responsibility to his owners for the safety of their ship.
It is an editor's duty always to tell the truth. Wash. Union. Ah, but that's a specific duty, and you know that the Democrats are all opposed to specific duties.

Intelligence having reached this Department of gross frauds upon persons going abroad by parties claiming the right to issue Passports to citizens of the United States, the following notice in regard to Passports is republished from the Washington Republic, of the 21st of March: Citizens of the United States, visiting foreign countries, are liable to serious inconvenience, if unprovided with authemic proof of their national character.

The leaves of pine trees have been made useful, by producing from them a species of vegetable wool! This need not alarm the cotton men. Cotton proper may continue to rule the States for the present, and England too, as it seems of late to be doing, in spite of all of our pine wool.

Mary and Catharine Galvin were arraigned before the Maor of Cincinnati, on Monday morning, on care of abusing and beating their aged mother in a cruel and in human manner. It was shown that these girls were constantly using abusive language and striking her over the head--many of the marks of the various wounds she received. are still retailed.

On Thursday, Dec. 23. JOHN HAMMAN CATTNACH, son of John and Elizabeth Cattnach, aged 4 years and 23 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from their residence, No. 26 Bargen-st., South Brooklyn, on Saturday, the 25th, at 2 1/2 o'clock.

It is high time the Railroad Companies between this City and the Capital should place themselves on the defensive. There is a fearful gathering of foes. The Postmaster-General, in his late Report, declares undying hostility to their disobliging uncertainty. He refuses to recognize any reason why the mails shall spend so much of their time in transitu:

The public meeting in this City, to express sympaty for the imprisoned MADIAIS, is announced to take place at Metropolitan Hall on Friday evening, Jan. 7. The cooperation of the friends of religious liberty is invited. The call for the meeting bears the signature of Hon. LUTHER BRADISH, Hon. JAMES HARPER, HUGH MAXWELL, ANSON G. PHELPS, and other prominent citizens.

The United States Senate has made a call upon the Secretary of the Interior for information as to the manner in which $100,000, so generously granted by Congress for the purchase of a site and the erection of a Lunatic Asylum in the District of Columbia, has been expended.

The Broadway engagement of ALBONI and her troupe, begins on Monday evening. She has judiciously chosen ROSSINI'S Opera of Cinderella, with one or two of the gems of which the public of New-York have identified some of her most charming notes, as the introductory Opera. She will be efficiently sustained in the tenor and buffo parts, and also by the old and well-trained Astor Place Chorus.

HOW TO MAKE A READER.--Mr. CORDEN, in a late speech, said: "If you put into the hands of the rural peasant treatises on science, or extracts from history, or hooks of travel, they will afford no stimulus or excitement to such people, and they either will not read them at all or they will very soon fall asleep over them.

NAVAL ASSISTANT-SURGEONS.--Connected with disease on the west coast of Africa, the services of the Assistant Surgeons must ever hold a conspicuous position On no station hare there been so many assistant-surgeons employed, with so much exclusive responsibility entrusted to them; nowhere have their labors been more arduous, or more ably performed; and no class of officers in the naval service has offered up an equal proportion of victims at the shrine of public duty.

PRESENT FROM SCHOLARS TO THEIR TEACHER.--Yesterday, JOHN J. DOANE, Esq , Principal of Ward School No. 20, received from his pupils a chins dinnerset, silver spoons, forks and butter-knives, as a Christmas present. Mr. DOANE has a fine school, numbering five hundred scholars. A suitable address was delivered by Musier JAMES, and replied to hy Mr. DOANE, who seemed much affected by this spontaneous expression of esteem from a grateful school.

A Canadian girl born blind, named SARAH HAWLEY,twenty-one years ot age, has lately been gifted with the power of seeing by Dr. CALDWELL. All her ideas of objects had been derived entirely from touch. She was almost instantaneously endowed with the power of sight. What must have been her new sensation on such a remarkable event!

MILITARY SCHOOL.--Several of our prominent citizens are endeavoring to create interest enough in this city to establish a Military School, where physical training and mental cultivation will be combined-as a branch of an Institution established (or about being established) at Brandywine Springs, under the superintendence of tile well known Capt. ALDEN PATRIDGE, of Norwich and Middletown.

A SCENE IN THE CITY HALL.--(Dennis and Patrick looking over the voting list.) Patrick--is it all right now, Dennis? Dennis.--Shure, Patrick, you are a vother. Patrick.--Which way will I vote, Dinnis? Dennis.--Do you mind them Iron Works at South Boston; they are not going at all?

Mr. KING continues to improve. The statement that Senator HUNTER has gone to have an interview with Gen. PIERCE, is fully confirmed. It is rumored that a large number of Clerks are to be removed from the Census Bureau on the 1st of Jan. In the Supreme Court, to-day, the Telegraph Case has been continued.

EX-ALDERMAN CLAYTON DANGEROUSLY INJURED--A an early hour last evening an explosion of one of the Manhattan gas pipes took place in front of ex-Alderman EDWIN B. CLAYTON'S residence, No. 419 Broome street which created great excitement, and drew a large con course of people together around the premises.

CHRISTMAS DAY ! What a world of pleasant thoughts and remembrances lie nestled in those dear old words. How they recall the fading past, and with it the joyous times that have gone forever, leaving only their cheerful outline on the serene horizon of memory.

ECLIPSE OF THE MOON.--On the morning of Sunday next, the 26th inst., there will be a partial eclipse of the moon. the beginning of which will be visible in New-England, the greatest obscuration; also, In the valley of the Mississippi, and the whole eclipse in California and the Territories of Oregon and Utah. In the course of 1853, the only eclipse visible in Boston will be a small one of the Moon, on June 21.

CRITICISMS ON THACKERAY IN BOSTON.--The opinions of the Boston press, upon the merits of Mr. THACKERAY's style, are quite various--e.g.: The Courier says: Mr. THACKERAY is not an agreeable lecturer. He lacks grace and elocutionary accomplishment. He seems to have studied Dr. JOHNSON's manners, and speaks in the same dogmatical style.

The Superintendent of the Census has prepared a report on the telegraphs of tile United States, based on returns furnished to the Census Office in reply to special circulars. From it we learn that Morse's first line was commenced in 1844, when an appropriation was made by Congress to test the practical operation of the invention.

The hills round about our meridian throw a wrong g reflection of the moon's light in upon our tnwn. showing its every feature, rendered more charming in the softness of the Light.

The contract for the edifice of the "Christian University" has been concluded with Mr. Solomen Jelaris, of St. Louis, at the Sum of $24,900. The building will be sufficiently large to accommodate from three to five hundred students, and will be located at Canton, on the Mississipi river--a point proverbial for its unprecedented health. Owned and controlled by the Christian Church.

A genteelly dressed individual, having paid his fare, and presented his ticket to the steward, received the key of his state room. Searching out its whereabouts, he found it decorated with three life preservers, inflated, ready

FESTIVAL.--The members of the York-street M. E. Church, held a Festival on Christmas in their Church, for the purpose of "raising money sufficient to support a Missionary among the German population of the City." The exercises commenced at 2 o'clock, with singing by the Sabbath School scholars; banner and bible presentations followed, and the whole concluded with addresses from three Indians of the Oneida tribe, and Prof. MATTISON of New-York.

Philosophers, milliners, and medical men have given much attention to the dress of women; but the little philosophers know about the operations of the human mind, does not qualify them to give an opinion upon dress; and as dress makers have not given themselves the trouble to study the form of the object given them to fit, medical men are alone competent to understand and to decide upon this matter.

An inquest was held on Friday, in view of the body of a white woman found dead at Washington, in a small grocery occupied by the deceased and her husband. It was in evidence that her husband, Daniel II. Woodward, bad many altercations during the previous evening with her, and threats had been heard by the neighbors made by him to kill her if power enough could be found.

Herald says: It was chancery suit instituted by the heirs of HENRY FAIRFAX, deceased, of Prince William, against his devisers; averring that his will was procured by the under induence of his wife Mr. FAIRFAX left a very heavy estate, of some $150,000 or $200,000.

It seems by the following Circular Letter, that the Ballston Law School goes to Poughkeepsie on New-Year's Day: The State and National Law School, hitherto located at Ballston Spa, Saratoga County, N. Y., is now removed from that place to Poughkeepsie, Dutchess County, N. Y. with all its Professors, Library,. , and will commence its next term on the first of January, 1853.

The passenger train from Cumberland ran off the track this afternoon. near Martinsburg. All the cars were broken, and one was turned over. Several passengers were all slightly, but none fatally injured, and all have arrived here this evening on the burthen train.

The conflicting nature of the various " reliable" predictions relative to the Cabinet of General PPIERCE, is the best evidence that they are nothing more than the expressions of personal preference by the prophets themselves, or the vague speculations of curious busy-bodies. It is quite certain that Mr. PIERCE has given no indication of what is lo be his policy in. this respect.

We well remember, some fourteen or fifteen years ago, the ?? mania in New-York City, Hundreds of well grown, stately horse-chesbuts, lindens, and other good old fashioned trees of that sort, were torn from the sidewalks in the "uptown" districts, in the most unceremonious manner. No back woodsman was ever more merciless than were those New-Yorkers.

OPPRESSION OF THE POOR.-A worthy young weman who earns her living by hard work, visited one of our Savings Banks on Thursday, to deposit the siIall accuniulutlios of a few months service, Having with her. as she entered, an umbrella, she 'was directed by some one connected with the Banlk to leave. it ,utiide the door, as they could nrt allow the door to be wetted with its dripping.

The steamer Massachusetts, on entering the harbor at stonington, Conn., this morning, ran into a schooner, the bowsprit of which entered the boiler, and one or two of the does passengers were slightly scalded. The Massachusetts will be repaired in season the leave Stonington for New-York this evening, at the usual hour.

TELEGRAPHIC WIRES.-In the lines of the electro magrictic telegraph, recently erected in British Ildia, ani improvement has been introduced which, it is suggested, might be advantageously copied ia this country. In a line recently established between Calcutta and Kedgereo, instead ot a wire, a thick iron rod Is used, which is three-eighths of an inch in diameter, and weighs,one ton to a mile.

At a meeting of the Common Council of Boston, on Thursday evening Mr. Jewell, from the Committee on Finance, reported that they had negotiated with Baring, Brothers Co, to the amount of ??100,000 sterling, beating interest at st 41/2 per cent. per annum, payable in twenty years from 1st October last. Amount to be realized estimated at $1,950,000. Amount previously received on issues of water scrip $3.471,000. Making a total of $5,421,000.

Sir ARHIBALD ALISON iS about to pulblish another volume of what lie sarcastically denominates " History." It is in continuation of that large work by which, a few years since, he earned at once his knight-hood and the distinction of being, as an author, the most voluminous and profound liar living.

CHRISIMAS DAY IN BROIKLYN.-Christmas day in this city was observed in the usual manner by the Roman Catholics and Episcopalians. The most attractive feature of the day was the Missionary Festival of the Sands-st. Methodist Episcopal Church Sabbath School. At this place Rev. HENBY REQUA,

He says: "There is not a school-girl in Boston over the age of twelve years who does not know that the work Theirs is pronounced tea-air,

An article in this paper of Saturday last, did material injustice to the New Jersey Railroad, or so much of the line hence to Philadelphia, as extends to New Brunswck, N. J. -a distance of thirty-five miles. The utmost, we believe, is accomplished on this road to expedite the mails and passengers.

BRODWAY.-The Opera of La Cencrentola,' with the strong cast heretofore noticed. The rehcesrsal, on Saturday. was very pertec:: the Chorus and Orches. tra much more effective than we anticipated. After the Opera, the French Ballet Trnupe appear in the new ballet of " Rosita."

FLOOD IN THE SCIOTA--The hogs belonging to the Penitentiary met with a narrow escape from the flood. The Warden had just slaughtered all but 30, Which have been driven into the prison yard for slaughter on Wednesday--consequently all the pork is safe.

AN OLD INHABITANT.--Col. COFFIN, formerly City Inspector, and said to be the oldest inhabitant--lies at his residence, in Read-street, in a hopeless condition. He is supposed to be near ninety years of age, and has resided in one house over half a century. Until the last week the has borne his years frosty but kindly, and was in the City Hall to see his old friends within the past fortnight. His disease is erysipelas.

The following dispatch, dated London, Saturday morning, Dec. 11, was received just previous to the departure of the Canada: ENGLAND. The steamer Adelaide, for Australia, will take three hundred thousand sovereigns.

Two of the most adventurous chamois hunters in Switzerland have just lost their lives at the glacier of Argentieres, under circumstances peculiarly distressing. M. CARRIER, long resident at this place, went out, a few mornings ago, with his son, a lad of 19, to hunt mormots.

A famous chief of bandits, named RANDOM CROTENTGUE, in 1847 began committing extensive depredations in the Government of Wilna, in Russia, near the Prussian frontiers; and although he was frequently pursued by Prussian and Russian detachments, all attempts to seize him failed until a short time ago, when he was recognized, in spite of a disguise, by some peasants; and, being arrested and bound, was given up by them to the authorities.

The London Chronicle of Dec. 3rd, reports the proceedings of a meeting for the promotion of emigration to New-Zealand, when some interesting statements were made concerning that Colony, which were new to us, at least.

"I think that I may unhesitatingly say that never, in the political history history of this country, has there been an epoch more critical, more delicate, involving more responsibility and risk, and requiring at one and energy, than that which sagacity, foresight, and energy, than that, which we are at present traveling.

In the Telegraph Case of "O'REILLY et al vs. MORSE," in the Supreme Court, Mr. GILETTE finished his opening argument this morning in behalf of appellants. and Mr. HARDING. of Philadelphia, commenced the opening argument in behalf of the appeliecs.

Mr. Roberdeau Annan died very suddenly at his residence in St. Louis, on Wednesday, the 15th. In the performance of his duty as Special Mail Agent on the Upper Mississippi river, he went down to the mail boat at the usual hour.

On Saturday morning the Police of the middle district, Baltimore, arrested, on various charges of rowdyism, riot, , a very large number of belligerent characters, seven or when, for want of better accommodation, were locked up in one of the first story rooms of the Station-house, an apartment provided by the city for the safe keeping of sach characters.

THE DERBY DISRAELI BUDGET. The most stirring subject of discussion, both in and out of Parliament, since my last week's lucubrations, has been the BUDGET. Our clever Chan cellor of the Exchequer has, by this time, found out that he has brought a test of hornets about his ears, who for some weeks to come are likely to disturb his official repose.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a communication from the War Department, inclosing a statement of unexpected balances of appropriations. Also, from the Interior Department, with a statement of the Navy Fund Petitions.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: I perceive in the Times of this morning an advertisement for a nursery governese, which I am confident you will admit reflects shame and discredit upon the person who inserted it.

We are indebted to a friend in this City for the following interesting extracts from a private letter from a lady who went out as passenger in the last trip of the steamship Pacific: STEAMSHIP PACIFIC-IN THE CHANNELL, Friday, Dec. 10, 1852.

By the brigs Adams Gray and Millaudon, which arrived yesterday from Havana, we have received files of the Diario de la Marina to the 8th inst. In that paper of the 7th, we find the following, copied from an extra published by the Redactor, dated St. Jago, 26th Nov., 1852: "In the midst of the terror inspired by the horrible earthquake which was felt at twenty-fire minutes past 3 o'clock this morning.
I cannot leave Rome without giving some account of the monument of WASHINGTON, which is being executed by orders of the United States Government by Mr. CRAWFORD, an American sculptor of much merit.
When that promising craft, the Whig party, went to the bottom, the other day, it left a spar or two floating. Party wrecks, like those of nations, are seldom total.
R. M. SAUNDERS, Democrat, has been elected Circuit Judge in the North Carolina Legislature, the Whigs voting for him. The Legislature adjourned today. No Senator will be chosen.

The ceremony of inauguration as Chancellor of the Michigan University, the Rev. H. P. TAPPAN, D.D, took place at Ann Arbor yesterday, Dec. 21. The exercises of the occasion were held in the First Prosbyterinn Church of that city, in the presence of the Regents, the Faculty, and Students of the University, and a large number of ladies and gentlement, amongst whom was a fair representation from Detroit.
THE LEAD TRADE.--We derive from the Gale na Jeffersontan some interesting facts in regard to the Lead Frade of that section of the country for the yearinst closed.

Judge EMMETT gave an important decision in the Superior Court yesterday, enjoining the sale of the wharves and piers of the city. It will be remembered that Mayor KINGS-LAND has once or twice recommended this sale on the ground that the city derived no adequate revenue from this property, and that in the hands of private owners it could be made to yield a large income from taxation.

TO TUTTLE'S MAMMOTH MUSEUM OF OURIOSITIES, No. 315 BRADWAY, NEW-YORK. AIR: Yanhee Doodle. I went to York, a while ago, To stay a week, or more, sir, With Uncle Jabe, who lives you know, Not far from TUTTLE'S store, sir.

There is an undertow in the drift of French opinion that may trip the new Emperor up at the shortest notice. We have seen something of it in the popularity of a book strictly prohibited by the Police-the Napoleon le Petil of VICTOR HUGO.

A LADY MISSING.--A young woman named MARY ANN LANE, took a stage at Williamsburg on Friday afternoon, for the purpose of proceeding to Brooklyn to deliver some shirts which she had been making, since which time she has not been heard from. Her friends are very much alarmed about her, and fears are entertained that she has been louly dealt with. She is of prepossessing appearance, small stature, and 26 years of age.

The Annual Festival in celebration of St. John's Day was held by the Free and Accepted Masons of St. John's Lodge No. 1, Independent Royal Arch Lodge No. 2, and Holland Lodge No. 8, in the Stayvesant Institute, last evening. The attendance was limited. The stage was handsomely decorated with the grand banners of the Lodges, and smaller ones representing Faith, Hope, Charity,
We have no mail south of Mobile to-night. A fire at Charleston, on Friday, destroyed the grocery establishment of VALENTINE HEIDT. Loss, $15,000 on stock, and $6,000 on building.

Little, business was done in the Senate yesterday, for lack of a quorum. The bill was passed for the relief of THOMAL B. PARSONS, who saved the lives of seven persons at the expense of his own health, in the year 1808.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your Washington correspondent "S" writes, of its being generally understood in the Capitol, that Senator DOWNS, of Louisiana, opposes Mr. BRADFORD'S nomination to the Supreme Bench, with a view to obtaining it himself; and that Senator SOULE is opposing Senator DOWNS in such a way, that being a powerful man for friend of foe, to the incoming Administration, his opposition is to be feared, ,

The public were very recently surprises by the appearance in a few papers of an advertisement offering for sale, at twenty days' notice, all the public lands of the Commonwealth, situated in the State of Maine, amounting to about eighteen hundred thousand acres, comprising tracts of territory. most of which are covered by their native forests. exceeding in extent a third part of the entire area of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Extract from a letter of an officer on board the United States ship Susquehanna, dated Cumsingmoon, China, Sept 22, 1852:-- For some months past the chief subject of interest in the squadron has been the contemplated expedition to Japan.

SIR: Some friends of mine have been reading with great interest, in your Times of the 15th inst., the very womanly Address of the noble and gentle Ladies of England to those of this Republic, on the subject of negro Slavery; and we have argued the matter, and agreed that the feelings which prompted such an Address were highly laudable, and worthy of all consideration.

From the N. O. Beacon of Cuba. The Nerthern papers come to us daily with speculations as to the nature of the dispatches carried to Washington by the steamer Fulton from Havana. The general supposition is that they relate to the case of Capt. ADAMS GRAY, who was arrested in Havana by the Captain General, on charge of having abetted in the slave trade now so extensively carried on in Cuba.

Very destructive floods have occurred in both the Great and Little Miami Rivers. The "Little Miami" and "Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton" Railroads have been considerably damaged--on the latter several bridges have been washed away, and on both of them the trains are unable to run through.

LOBSTER FISHING ON THE COAST OF NORWAY.--Some time age, a number of individuals in Berwick formed themselves into a company for the purpose of prosecuting the lobster fishing on the coart of Norway, and engaged two Yarmouth fishing vessels for the purpose.

BRIDGET SCAMLIN, a beautiful young girl, aged about 16 years, attempted to commit suicide on Sunday evening, by leaping into the river from one of the Ferryboats which ply between this city and West Troy.

WILLIAM BURKE KIRWAN, a man in respectable position, has been convicted of having murdered his wife. The circumstances are detailed in the following testimony given by the principal witness, a boatman named PATRICK MANGLU.

On Tuesday, an inquest was held by Mr. HERFORD, at Manchester, on the body of man named GEORGE WILSON, commonly known as "Hammer" WILSON, of Birmingham, who was killed in o fight with another man named THOMAS WELSH, of Manchester.

MR. FRY's FIFTH LECTURE ON MUSIC.--Mr. WM. H. FRY' will deliver his fifth Lecture on Music, at Metropolitan Hall, this evening. The special topic of this Lecture will be "Voice." Madame DE VRIES, Signora PICO VIETTI, Signor VIETTI, and a grand chorus, will give the illustrations.

IN JAIL FOR THE CRIME OF BEING OLD.--We have made acquainted authoritatively with the following circumstance: JOSEPH HIDE, at present an inmate of the County Jail, was horn at sea between England and the United States, on the 10th of June, 1753, and was consequently ninety-nine years of age last June. He has resided in Cincinnati, except some trifling absences, for more than fifty-six years.

TEMPERANCE MOVEMENT AT THE SOUTH.--The Senate of the Florida Legislature has passed a bill, leaving it to the people in each county in the State to determine for themselves whether they will grant licenses for the sale of intoxicating liquors within their jurisdiction.

In the United States Supreme Court the appeal from a decision by the United States Circuit Court in the suit of "Professor MORSE vs HENRY O'REILLY" made in 1849, and involving the right to use what was called the Columbian Telegraph--is under argument.

GENTLEMEN:--I read with great satisfaction in the national Inteiligencer of this morning an interesting correspondence relative to the WEBSTER Annuity. There was no subject on which this eminently great and good man was more sensitive; and with your permission, I propose to add one incident illustrative of the refinement of feeling which characterized him.

The illumination which I announced in my last Thursday's letter as the closing ceremony of the birthday of the Empire, was more general than I had anticipated. Quite a number of private buildings displayed colored lamps and gay Chinese lanterns.

The London Times, commenting upon a lecture delivered by Lord JOHN RUSSELL before a Mechanics' Institute, makes the following admirable remarks on the desirableness of politicians and public man knowing also something of letters: It is rather a new feature in British statesmanship. that the political chief is obliged to let the people see now and then that he is something else than a politician.

MR. WEBSTER'S POETRY.--An old, brown piece of paper has been handed to us, containing a scrap of Mr. WEBSTER'S poetry, written in the Album of a lady at the time of LAFAYETTE'S visit to this country. The lady had requested Mr. WEBSTER to write his name by the side of LAFAYETTE'S autograph. The lines were originally published in the Boston Sun.

A good memory has always been appreciated, but Congress seems particularly impressed with its value. Several memorials have been presented of late which, should they be favorably considered, may be regarded as so many premiums offered to a retentive memory.

The New Orleans Picayune of the 19th, says that the one brig Zebra has by on chartered by the Colonization Society, to convey its emigrants to Sinora and Monrovia, and will have immediate dispatch. There are already here some eighty emigrants, and others are daily arriving.

Congress will do nothing this week. The Senate will probably meet to-day and adjourn until Thursday, and then adjourn again to Monday. If either House continues in session, it will be to attend to business in which no discussion arises, and in which no general interest is felt.

LATER FROM ST DOMINGO.--The Picayune of the 18th says. By brig Eagle, Capt. EVANS, we have received papers from St. Domingo to 30th of November. The Electoral College was to meet on the first Monday in December, for the purpose of electing the President of the Republic.

Professor DOREMUS delivered his Second Lecture on Chemistry, to a large and respectable audience, in the Mechanics' Society Lecture Room, last evening.

Prof. OLMSTED delivered his fourth and concluding lecture last evening at the Tabernacle. His audience, as usual, was intelligent, but not as large as on former evenings. The rain evidently prevented many from enjoying an interesting fire well lecture.
The repetition of Cinderella at the Broadway, last evening, was witnessed by another full and fashionable, as well as highly gratified audience.

Last evening, Rev. WM. W. PATTON, of Hartford, delivered a Lecture in the Tahernacle, being the third of the "People's" Course. The attendance was large as usual. The subject was: "The Martyrs of
The British Almanac and Companion for 1853 contains a highly interesting table, showing the number of lives lost in the British service from 1793 to 1815.

The following appointments have been made by the Secretary of the Treasury, under the act of Congress approved Aug. 30, 1852, entitled "An act to provide for the better security of the lives of passengers on board of vessels propelled in whole or in part by steam; and for other purposes."

We have received a number of the Bermuda Herald for Dec. 20. The steamer Ospray, from Halifax, entered Hamilton Harbor on the 16th. She experienced heavy weather on her passage, and was supposed to be in danger of foundering. She lost seven out of eighteen head of cattle that she had taken onboard. The brig Swan, PIERCE, of New-York, had hard weather, and lost six of her cattle. She entered Dec. 17.

The Society known as the Union Missionary Society, hose field is the Five Points, will hold an anniversary meeting this evening at the Oliver-street Baptist Church. This Society has existed for quite a number of years, having been In active operation for a long time prior to the starting of the modern enterprises, which promise to effect so much good in the way of refrom in the blighted and condemned region of the Five Points.

It is the business of a Daily Journal to furnish the materials for history rather than to write it. It is, indeed, impossible to write an accurate and reliable history of any period, one which shall not only record events, but trace their causes and results with clearness and intelligence, while its shadow rests upon its incidents and actors.

The Postmaster-General, on the application of Mr. RUSK, has given permission for a Mail steamer from New-York to touch at Norfolk, to take on board Hon. W. R. RING and convey him to Havana, where he proposes to spend the Winter. The Telegraph Case closed in the Supreme Court today--Mr. GIFFORD concluding for MORSE, and Hon. S. P. CHASE following in an able argument for O'REILLY.

THE PARDONING POWER.--An example not to be disdained has been set by the Executive of the State of South Carolina, in issuing and promulgating the following rule, which it has made for its guidance in regard to the exercise of the pardoning power: EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT, CLARENDON, Dec. 21, 1852

The Board met yesterday evening, pursuant to adjournment, and a quorum being present, the minutes of the preceding meeting were read and approved. REPORTS ADOPTED--of Committee on Salaries and Offices, in favor of concurring to pay C. T. McCienchan as official reporter for the Board of Assistants, during the last year. Of Committee on Public Health, in favor of concurring with the Board of Assistants to fill in low and sunken lets and removing nuisance.

Mr. DAVIS reported a joint resolution, allowing in certain cases to the owners of steamers, further time to make the necessary preparations to bring their vessels within the provisions of an act entitled "An act to amend an act entitled an act to provide for the better security of the lives of passengers on board of vessels propelled in whole or in part by steam."

The Pacific Mail Steamship Columbia, Capt. L. DALL, arrived here yesterday evening, after a passage of three days from Astoria. Coal has been discovered at several places north of the Columbia river. Several veins have been opened along the Cowhtz river, which promise to yield an abundant supply The most important discovery is on Skookum Creek, a branch of the Chickolecs.

A young man named Charles Dupuy was arrested on Monday, at Newark, and committed for stealing $35, with other articles, from a pocket-book of the late S. E. Canfield. When Mr. Canfield died so suddenly a few days since, Dupuy, who had been working for him some time, assisted in carrying him home, and saw the pocket-book containing the money, , laid away by Mrs C in a drawer.

CAUSES OF INCREASE OF CRIME.--The Baltimore Clipper and the National Intelligencer think that the great increase of crime in Baltimore is owing to the election of Judges, and all other officers of the State Courts, by the people. The Clipper says:

We commend the report of last night's proceedings in the Board of Aldermen to the careful perusal of every citizen who supposes that lie is living in a community where the LAW, as administered by our Courts of Justice, is binding alike upon all classes of our people.

On Wednesday morning, Dec. 29, FREDERICK LEAVENWORTH, aged 7 months, son of John C and Margaret J. Booth. The funeral will take place this morning at 10 o'clock, at No. 134 East 19th-st. The friends of the family are requested to attend without further notice. The remains will be taken to Stratford Conn. for interment

Mr. William Williams, a planter living on Richland Creek, as we understand, had recovered the possession of a negro named George that had for some time been run away.

The resolution of Gen. CASS, relative to British aggressions in Central America is very well as far as it goes. It is quite certain that the CLAYTON Treaty has been to all intents and purposes a dead letter, in its bearing upon the conduct of British officials in that quarter.

The City of Brooklyn is blessed with a rapid growth-of important feeling, particularly. We have often wondered that the Common Council of that nice place never have adopted a resolution forbidding Long Island to come any further west than Brooklyn's western border.

PROSPERITY OF NOVA SCOTIA.--Never in the most palmy days of the Province could it have boasted of an amount of general prosperity equal to that enjoyed at the present moment. Among merchants and manufacturers we hear no ground of complaint, while the farmers command a ready sale and high prices for their stock and produce. In one short and emphatic sentence,

NEGROES IN CANADA.--The Canadian papers are taking ground against the influx of negroes in to the Province, viewing it as a present injury to their property, a drawback to their social progress, and a source of much future trouble. The Scoder treats the matter after this fashion:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: If the publication of exparte reports of sectarian discussions in papers devoted to the noble cause of Literature, is at least censurable--how much more so when truth is sacrificed to prejudice, and charity trampled upon to sustain antiquated creeds?

DREADFUL ACCIDENT.--Mrs. NEW COMB, wife 0. H. N. NEW COMB, well known in this quarter as the head of one of the principal houses in Louisville, in a fit of derangement during he absence of her husband, threw their four children from an attic window. Two of them fell upon the pavement,

IOWA COLLEGE.--We have received a Catalogue of the Officers and Students of IOWA COLLNGE, Havenport, Iowa. The whole number of students in attendance during the year ending July 13th, 1852, were 93: to wit:--Juniors 3; Sophomores 2: Freshman 3: making in the Collegiate Department, 8. In the Preparatory and English Departments, in all 85.
The Senate to-day confirmed WILLIAM HENRY TREECOTT, a young South Carolinian, of respectable literary attainments as Secretary of Legation at the

We continue this morning our Historiical Summary for 1852. The importance of the events of the year in ENGLAND and FRANCE, and the fulness with which they have been sketched. compel us to omit the similar history of Germany, Austria, Italy, Russia, the British Colonies, Mexico, the South American States, , , which we have in type. They will be given hereafter.

MR. CALHOUN AND CUBA.--The National Intelligencer repeats the declaration imputed to Mr. CALHOUN, that "Cuba was forbidden fruit" to this country, for the purpose of arraying the authority of his eminent name against the policy of the acquisition of Cuba. Now, we have reason to know that the declaration attributed to Mr. CALHOUN does not express the conclusions of his judgment,

We are wont to judge of the intellectual condition of a community by the number of persons in it who can or cannot read and write. If it should be announced that in some county of the State there existed not one person, over five years of age, who had not an acquaintance with the mystic arts of reading and writing it would be told of, far and near, as highly complimentary to the locality.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Franklin, Captain WOTTEN, from Southampton, for New-York, put in here this afternoon, short of coal. She brings 24 passengers, and a very large cargo of continental merchandise from Havre. Her dates are from London, Southampton and Havre to Dec. 13. and from Paris. by telegraph, up to Dec. 12.

The new arrangement of the Congressional Districts in South Carolina is likely to produce some contest for the honor of serving the State at Washington. Messrs. Orr and Wallace were thrown into the same District, and therefore one of them must take a beating and stay at home. In Mr. Burt's old District, Messrs. J. F. Marshall, Brooks and Pickens have been announced before the District was marked out;

MORE ABOUT THE BURGLARs.-The Chief of Police and his aids are making every effort to find out the secrets of the suspicions characters arrested in this City on Thursday night last and yesterday; in addition to what has been heretofore published-quite a number of overcoats, silk dresses, broad cloths, , , were found at different places in New-York, which had been stolen from houses in this City.
The favorite amusement now-a-days seems to be speculating about Gen. PIERCE'S Cabinet and general policy. Every day brings new rumors-all equally positive, and probably equally authentic.

We do not consider the power of the Supreme Court to enjoin the Common Council from passing particular ordinances to be by any means free from doubt. We understand that several of the ablest lawyers in the City have given opinions that it has no such power.
I hear that a number of deaths from cholera have occurred in Charleston. Mr. TRESCOTT, of South Carolina, has been confirmed Secretary of Legation to England, vice DAVIS, resigned.

On Wednesday, Dec, 29. at Newark, N. J., by Rev. J. F. Steam. DD. Mr. MARTIN R. PORTER of New-York, to Miss LIZZIE FRANCES BACON, of the former place, all formerly of Masst chusetts On Wednesday evening. Dec 23 by Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Burchard.. JAMES H PEFFE'S to MARIA W. youngest daughter of J. M. Dexter all of this City.

With the exception of the Imperial movement in France, the history of the past year has been singularly destitute of striking events. It has, like that of the previous year, been marked by the steady development of those systems which have taken the place of the revolutionary projects of 1848 and 1849.

We have no mail this morning South of Savannah. Fabricated news by the Canada was sent South from Baltimore, announcing that cotton was firm and unchanged, causing heavy losses among merchants in Macon, Montgomery and Columbia. The Charleston Courier exposes the imposition, and cautions editors and factors against relying on any reports except those emanating from agents of the New-York Associated Press.

The Board met yesterday evening pursuant to adjournment, a quorum being present the minutes of the preceding meeting were approved, and they proceeded to business. PETITIONS REFERRED--Of John S. Tensdale of the Fifteenth Ward Police, for donation to pay doctor's bills, ??. Of Captain L. C. Heime in relation to the funeral expenses of the late Henry Gibson. Of J. Raywood for relief from erroneous assessment.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate an invitation to attend the inauguration of the JACKSON Equestrian Statue on the 8th January. Also, the Report of the Secretary of the Interior, communicating the progress made in regard to the Senate Asylum in the District of Columbia.

BOARD OF EDUCATION--SPECIAL MEETING--Wednesday--Present: ERASTUS C. BENEDICT, Esq., President, and Commissioners Stuart, Savage, Jones, O'Donnell, Hilton, Meeks, T. E. Smith, Murphy, Pinckney, Fell, Wright, Stout, Dodge, Williams, Tappen, Field, Beadle, DeLamater, Cary, Hibbard, Carter, C. H. Smith, Aldis, Waterbury and Montelth.

SAILING OF MISSIONARIES.--A large Missionary company (nine adults and three children.) sailed from New-York on board the Martha Clark for Sierra Leone, West Africa, on Monday, the 27th inst. The company consisted of Rev, George Thompson and wife, with their two children; D. W. Burton and wife, with one child; Rev Morris Officers,

On Monday a discussion took place in the New Hampshire Regislature, upon the subject of paying the newspapers for the publican of the Liquor Bill. One member went against the resolution to pay, and said parties had recourse at law against the parties ordering the advertisement. That is cool, surely. Pay up gentlemen; honesty is the best policy.

The New-Orleans Commercial Bulletin indorses a writer for that paper, who contends against the acquisition of Cuba, upon constitutional grounds. The position is an exceedingly broad one. All acquisition of territory, whether by conquest or purchase, he pronounces to be in direct conflict with the Constitution; and the title, therefore, by which our acquired territories are held, is to be taken as utterly worthless.

The third representation of Cinderella, last eve ning, was rather a bright commentary on the carping of a morning paper against its frequent repetition. The house was the fullest of the week. It will be full again to-night, on the fourth and last representation. The reason is palpable-tho popularity of the piece grows with the completeness of its performanee, and the familiarity of the public with the music.

The case of William H. Green vs. the City of Providence, for the seizure of certain liquers, brought before the Court by writ of replevin, to recover said liquore, which were condemned by the Court of Magistrates, was decided by Judge CURTIS, giving his opinion that the law of this State, under which the property in the case was condemned, is unconstitutional, because

We are eager for something new from Baltimore. The Convention of last week was wonderfully refreshing as a change. We read the musical criticisms, the cabinet speculations, the weather items, in their dailies, as a grateful relief to the monotony of their police reports. There is no lack of murders,

The Tenth Lecture of the Popular Course, was Delivered in the Tahernacle, last evening, by (GEORGE WM. CURTIS, Esq., author of "Nile Notes," and other works of interest. The attendance was numerous, and comprised many gentlemen of literary attainments. The audience repeatedly applauded the more eloquent passages in the lecturer's treatment of the subject--The Age of Steam.

The steamship Falcon (reported to have arrived at the Belize on Sunday, in error,) reached this port to-day, having left Aspinwall on the 21st inst. She brings the California mail of the 1st Dec. $100,000 in gold dust, and 150 passengers.

FIRE IN HAMILTON AVENUE.--Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in a block of buildings owned by Dr. TOWNSEND, located at the junction of Van Brunt and Summit streets with Hamilton, which destroyed three three-story brick buildings before the flames could be subdued. One was occupied by JOHN CUNNINGHAM as a stone store, another by GRIFFIN, DANFORD, and GADING, coopers, and the third by WILLIAM HUNT, marble maker.

A Convention of believers in Spiritual Manifestations commenced at the Masonic Temple Wednesday forenoon. There were some two hundred persons in attendance, including those draws thither by curiosity. The Convention was called at 10 o'clock, but nothing was done until about 10 1/2 o'clock, when one gentleman alone and said he felt impressed to any a few words. object of the spirits in bringing this Convention together.

The house of JOHN WILSON, shoemaker, on Fayette street, was destroyed by fire last night. While the Drintnell Block was burning the other day, a woman resident in West-street, left two children in charge of a servant girl and went to see the fire.

The New England Farmer says if the weather should continue moderate until the 1st January, we think there will be as much fodder on hand at that time as there was on the 1st of last January. The Granite Farmer of the 15th states that "young cattle and sheep have not required any feeding, and a good portion of the sustenance of other stock has been obtained from the fields to the present time.
Alderman STURTRVANT publishes a Card in the Commercial Advertiser, in reference to the report in that paper, of his remarks on Wednesday night, concerning Mayor KINGSLAND, in which he says:

SUDDEN DEATH.--We regret to announce the very sudden decease of Mr ?? P. BANOS, one of our most respected merchants and highly esteemed fellow-citizens. Mr. BANOS left the city at 8 o'clock this morning, in the cars for Newtown, for the purpose of visiting a son. . Jost as the care reached Newton Cop.

The bark Miquelon arrived at Salem yesterday with dates from Buenos Ayres to the 10th ultimo. The Chamber of Representative had, by a decree, appointed Dr. DON VALENTINE ALBINA, as Governor and Captain Genera of the Province. A decree of Nov. 4th, revokes the ban of expatriation passed against a number of persons shortly after the revolution of Sept. 11th.

Our City Columns note rather a stirring scene between the MAYOR and President COMPTON of the Board of Aldermen. The latter, it seems, so far forgot personal propriety as to insult the Mayor, which the latter very warmly resented;

The cholera has diminished considerable in the city of St. Jago, The deaths which had at one time increased to 110 daily, now number from 8 to 10. In the surrounding country the epidemic still prevails, making fearful ravages. At the mine of Colve and in the village of the same name, also at the village of Caney itl violence has been unprecedented.

Nothing has been heard as yet of the steamer pacific, She was to have left Liverpool on Wednesday, the 15th of Dec, ; and if she sailed on that day she has now been out over sixteen days. So long absence of course oreates a good deal of anxiety.

Two or three days since, Mr. John Sherburn, his wife and son Alonzo, eight years old, of East Boston, went to Maiden to spend the Holidays with some friends, and yesterday afternoon Alonze, in company with other leds, went upon a pond of ice and commenced cutting holes for the purpose of seeing the water bubble up.

Yesterday morning, (Dec. 30) CAROLINE, daughter of the late Jirch Bull, of Milford. Her remains have been conveyed to Norwich for interment. At Brooklyn, on the 30th ult., ANNA LEFFERTS, relict of Samuel Lefferts, late of the city of New-York, aged 73 years. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 262 Hickseat, Brooklyn, on the 3d instant, at 1 o'clock, P. M.

REV. JOHN SCOBLE.--This gentleman, so long distinguished as one of the leaders of the British and Foreign Anti Slavery Society, has lately arrived in New York, with his family, on this way, we believe, to Canada, where he proposes to settle, The British and Foreign Anti Slavery Committee signified their high appreciation of his services by the passage of the following resolution:

We have received dates from the City of Mexico to the 14th inst., one week later than previous advices. Congress had approved by a majority of the report of the Committee on the Tehuantopec Route, which was in favor of the Guanajuata proposition.

We have received a circular signed by Gens. SANDFORD, MORRIS, SWAN, LEE, BROWN and SHEARMEN, announcing a convention of Commissioned Officers of the State militia, to be held at Syracuse on the 11th of January next.

Jan. 1. Freshele in the Hudson River, in Vermont, New-Hampshire, etc.; much damage to property. 1. Oath of office administered to State Officers of New-York. 2. The National Democratic Committee meet at Washington, and agree upon June 1 as the time of meeting of the National Convention.

Senator Houston arrived to-day, direct from Texas, in good health. The Hon. GRAHAM N. FITCH has gone to Indiana, to be about at the meeting of the Legislature next week, and will be returned Senator for the unexpired term of the late Mr. WHITECOMB.

The U.S. Mail Steamship Georgia from Aspinwall, Dec. 20, arrived at this port yesterday morning with the mails and treasure brought down to the ?? by the mail steamer Panama, from San Francisco, December. She spoke the Steamer Illinois, outward bound, Dec. 26, all well. She reports orig Myra at Kingston.

JOHN W. WEEKE has been appointed Inspector of Hulle, and H. RENWICK Inspector of Bollers in New-York, by the Secretary of the Treasury. The following have been confirmed in the Senate: WM. R. SMITH, Collector, Galveston, vice JOHN B. ASHS, whose commission was revoked. FREDRICK L. HENNUP, appraiser for Philadelphia, Vice JOHN H. WITHERS removed.

The commercial or business year of 1852, is ono of the most remarkable in the history of this country. In many respects it has no parallel. The strides of Ocean Stoam navigation in extending our Foreign intercourse and facilitating intercomnminication with the now and distant State of California, on the Pacific, have been immense,

As completing the history of the year 1852, we publish, among other materials, this morning, a catalogue of notable deaths. A regard to the exigencies of space forbids this necrology to be anything more than a catalogue.

From full statistics before us, of the deaths that have occurred in the city of New-York during the year, with their causes, and attendant circumstances, we have prepared the following summary:--The number of deaths for the year was about 21,070,

Another year has "gone ever to the majority." The skill; in which it started so gally fifty-two weeks ago, grated on the sands of the shore of Eternity last night, at twelve o'clock. Its freight of good deeds and misdeeds, of benevolences and inalevolenees, of pleasant greetings and cross words, has reached its consignment.

Interesting and important Intelligence from Mexico will be found in another part of our paper this morning. Our Acapulco correspondent confirms the report received by telegraph from New-Orleans, that Count BOULBON'S expedition in Sonora is at an end.

TO ALL WHOM IT MAY CONCERN. Satisfactory evidence having been exhibited to one that OLIVER O'DONNELL has been appointed Consul of Nicaragua for the port of Baltimore, in the State of Maryland, I do hereby recognize him as such, and declare him free to exercise and enjoy such functions, powers and privileges as are allowed to the Consuls of the most favored nations in the United States.

We continue our HISTORY OF 1852 in this morning's Times, We suspend the regular continuation of our political sketches of the several nations, in order to present a complete chronological summary of the events of the year,--including a list of the deaths of distinguished persons which have occurred within that period.

TEMPERANCE DEMONSTRATION.--The Public Temperance Societies of the First and Second Ward, and Third and Fourth Wards, together with the several Divisions of the Sons of Temperance, have concluded their arrangements for a grand demonstration in Jersey City. It is to take place on the 11th instant.

We find in our California papers received by the Georgia, yesterday, interesting intelligence from Mazatlan, later than had before reached this City. It seems that Gen. VALDEZ, Governor and Commander in Chief of the State of Sinalon, was determined to resist the authority of Gen. VEGO, who had been appointed his successor, and to retain his office in spite of him.
BROADWAY.--There will be no performance of Opera at this house, this evening, in order to give time for the rehearsal of "La Figlia del Reggimento," which will be played to-morrow.

SHOCKING MURDER OF TWO CHILDREN NEAR HOBOKEN.--We are again called to record an atrocious murder perpetrated, on New-Year eve, some miles distant from Hoboken, New-Jersey. The facts of the tragical affair are annexed, as given by Mr. WM. KIPP, residing at Washington Township, Bergen County. Some years since a man named WILLIAM CATON came to this country from Ireland in search of a distant relative named TIMOTHY O'BRIEN.

We copy from the London Times this morning a very sharp dissection of the correspondence concerning the purchase of Cuba, recently published, with such lamentable lack of discretion, by the President.

The U. S. Mail steamer Franklin, Capt. WOTTON, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having been detained outside overnight by the fog. Some particulars of her tedious voyage and its causes, were given in our telegraphic account from Halifax. The Franklin brings 400 tons French goods, and 30 passengers.

On Saturday evening, Jan. 1, ROBERT BULOID, in the 78th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of his son, Robert W. Buloid, are respectfully invited to attend his unerul, on Tuesday, 4th instant, at 3 1/2 P. M., from his late residence, No. 12 West 14th. at., without further invitation.
The new City Government is to be inaugurated to-day. The new Board of Assistant Aldermen comes into office,--the Aldermen remaining in office.

On Thursday last, numerous petitions were presented by Mr. DAVIS, of the Senate, for the repeal of the tax of twenty cents on seamen's wages, as Hospital Money; and we hope these petitions have not been presented in vain. Why the sailor should be taxed to furnish a hospital for himself, whether sick or well, poor or rich, needy or not, has always been to us a mystery.

J. A. McMASTER, Esq., is to deliver a lecture this evening at Metropolitan Hall, upon the bearings of State Schools on the religious education of the people. Mr. McMASTER is Editor of the Freeman's Journal, and is well known as the earnest opponent, through that paper and elsewhere, of the Free School system, and of the principles upon which it rests.

From the London Times. The speech addressed by LOUIS NAPOLEON to the Senate and the Legislative body of France, upon the announcement of the suffrages which have just raised him to the throne, may not be regarded as the most significant and important of the state papers which that event is likely to call forth.

We regret to be called on to announce the death of one of our most valued and respected citizens, AMOS LAWRENCE, Esq., of the firm of A. A. LAWRENCE Co This event took place at 12 1/4 o'clock last night. He retired in his usual health last evening, and about midnight he experienced one of those spasmodic affections in the stomach to which, for many years, he had been subject.

From the London Times, Dec. 14. We have read with interest, not unmingled with surprise, the very prolix correspondence published by the journals of the United States with reference to the policy of the American Government towards Spain in relation to Cuba.
The mail is through from New Orleans, but there is nothing of interest in the papers. The U. S. Sloop. of war Albany has arrived at Pensacola, from Boston.

At the sitting of the French Society of Encouragement for National Industry, on the 1st of December, the Baron SEGUIER stated, on behalf of M. NIEPOR DE SAINT VICTOR, that the problem of natural colors in Photographs had been solved, and that he was prepared with a series of plates to demonstrate the fact to the Society.

By the return of the Amphitrite to her station in the Pacific, from Behring Strait, despatches and letters have been received from the Plover depot ship. An exchange of officers has also taken place, and Commander MAGUIRE has entered upon the command, vice Captain MOORE, who took the Plover out.

By the arrival of the screw steamer Queen of the South, at Plymouth, on the 13th ult, we receive ad vices from the Cape to the 6th of Nov. The war had not been brought to a close. Operations continued against the Caffres, who, although dispersed and pursued, were neither reduced nor driven beyond the Kei.

The American Mail Steamer Pacific, Captain NYE, arrived at her wharf in this city on Saturday noon, having sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday the 15th inst., at 5 o'clock in the afternoon. She arrived off Sandy Hook at 8 o'clock on Friday night, but was detained by the fog.

We present below an accurate tabular statement of the number of trials, cases argued, motions heard, and applications of a minor character, which have been before the civil and criminal tribunals of this City and County within the past year.

The question of the reimbursement of the sums advanced on the loan in Paris and London is regarded as definitively settled. The Porte has offered to pay capita and interest, and France and England have accepted this arrangement.

The following is a chapter of Incidents and Casualties which have marked the history of New York during the year 1852: JAN. 20. Ship fever prevalent at the Marine Hospital, State Island. Dr. Duane attacked on the 19th and died 27th.

Later dates from the RIO Grande have been received. We learn from Brownsville 18th ultimo, that she civil war was raging in the State of Tamaulipas. Governor CARDENAS with nine members of the Legislature, his adherents, had been made prisoners by the insurgents, and carried to Tampico, while the State had declared acquiescence in the new Provisional Government of Mexico.

THE GERMANIC CONFEDERATION. The political history of Central Europe for the last two years hinges entirely upon the rivalry between Austria and Prussia for the supremacy in Germany. Two years ago the question seemed about to be decided by arms, and some trifling hostilities took place which appeared to be the inevitable precursors of a general war.

The Paris Charivari amuses itself with laughing at the policy of the Spanish Government in behalf of Catholicity, and the Protestant rigors in Germany against the Jews. But neither is a laughing matter.
The U. S. Mail Steamship Isabel, arrived here last night, having left Havana on the morning, and Key West the evening of the 30th ult. The Small Pox was raging frightfully at Havana.

Mr. WILLIAM LYON MACKENSIE has issued the first, or "precursory" number of a new paper at Toronto-The Weekly Messenger. Like most of Mr. MACKENSIE's productions, it is remarkable in its way; autobiographical, historical, pathetic, tragic, humorous, poetic, sensible; along tissue of all the figures and elements of rhetoric, passion and eloquence.

The U. S. mail steamship Empire City, Capt. H. WINDLE, commander, arrived at this port yesterday, from New-York via Havana, having left the latter port on the 19th inst. The Empire City reports that the English fleet had taken three slavers--one bark and two schoonera-just fitted out for the African coast.

The recognition of the Empire by the British Government created general satisfaction when announced in Paris. Funds became firmer, and in public securities generally, a more animated tone was observed.

By and with the advice and consent of the Senate. JOHN WILSON, to the Commissioner of the General Land Office, vice JUSTIN BUTTERFIELD, resigned. EDWARD A CABELL, to be principal clerk of public lands in said office, vice JOHN WILSON appointed Commissioner.

We understand that quite a number of our merchants gave their clerks, as the most useful New-Year's present they could make them, a certificate of Membership in the Mercantile Library Association. This is an example worthy of imitation;--and as it is quite possible that some merchants have not yet made their clerks any present, who still intend to do so, we present the suggestion for their consideration.

BURNING OF THE BROOKLYN FEMALE ACADEMY. --About 5 o'clock on Saturday morning, the Brooklyn Female Academy, located in Joralemon-Sreet, between Court and Clinton-streets, was discovered to be on fire in the basement by the Janitor and his wife, who slept in the building, and who had barely time to escape with their lives.

If a man commits suicide at any time, he is either crazy or foolish. It is always a losing game to play. It is running into a burning house and locking the door behind one. It is the perfection of nonsense always. But just now there are added several new and potent reasons against the practice.

The Annual Report of the Trustees of the Benevolent Fire Department Fund for the first year, has just been issued, and we are pleased to find that the receipts of JOHN S. GILES, Esq., the Treasurer, from various sources, have largely increased since the close of their financial year in 1851.
