Another Railroad Accident-Conductor and Brakeman Killed-Several Persons Seriously Injured--Cars and Locomotives Destroyed by Fire. At an early hour on Saturday morning another sad accident occurred on the Harlem Railroad, in the immediate vicinity of Morrisania village, about 8 miles beyond the City, which was attended with a serious loss of life and limb.

The adjournment of the North Carolina Legislature without electing a United States Senator to succeed Mr. MANGUM, whose term expires on the 4th of next March, leaves that State with but one Representative in the Senate for the next two years.

The new Constitution proclaimed by the Queen, making the Senate hereditary, and restricting the franchise to a very small body of the electors, determined only by high property qualification, has caused great excitement. The Queen has accepted ROSA? resignation as Vice President of the Council.

New Year's evening was characterized by three rows--two of which occured on Hudson street and the other on Sussex; the former were between sailors just landed and drunk, the latter with landsmen and sailors, who were driven to their vessols with clubs and brick bats. The difficulty arose out of charges of theft made in a greg shop.
The steamers bring us very little foreign news. Indeed the Pacific sailed only one day after the Franklin, whose intelligence reached us from Halifax some day last year.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Since writing the note which you did me the favor to publish on Wednesday last, a meeting of the Directors of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company has been held, at which the following resolution was adopted, which will for the present obviate the necessity of publishing the documents to which I referred in my note of the 28th.

A Convention of the Spiritualists began yesterday, at the Masonic Temple, in this city, JONATHAN BUFFUM, of Lynn, was Chairman; Mr. HAY-WOOD of Milford, ALFRED BINGHAM, of this city, and Rev. Mr. LOVELAND, of Charlestown, were Vice President; and Messrs. C. H. WHITE and S. C. HEWETT, Secretaries.

The Syracuse Star understands that the Directors of the Syracuse and Binghamton Railroad contemplate putting berths in their night cars, which, it says, can readily be done if the six foot guage is adopted.

By the arrival of the Glasgow we have advices from Europe one day later. There is no news of importance save the details of the Overland Mail. The chiefs in India have proceeded to fresh extremities, and he country was in a sad state at last accounts.

Smith, for lease of Piers Nos. 20 and 21, and north half of Pier No. 13, North River, and Exchange-slip. Of Joseph Pine and others, to have Thirty-seventh-street lighted with gas.

Capt. COFFIN, of the brig Suticitf, arrived this morning from St., Domingo City, reports that the black vomit was still committing ravages there, and many of the crews of foreign vessels had died. The disease was also quite fatal on shore, Among others whe had died, was the French Consul.

They have some trouble with the School System in Upper Canada. The last Annual Report of the Normal, Model, and Common Schools of that Province shows an aggregate of 3,340 School Sections, so called,--which is 67 less than the number reported for 1850.

UNLUCKY MARRIAGE.-Mrs FARNHAM,the former Matron of Sing Sing Prison. seems to have bad luck in her second marriage In Calilbrnia, if we may judga by the following paragraph from the San Frnncisco Herald of Nov. 27. From the Boston times, 3d. By the arrival yesterday at this port of the fast sailing clipper bark Springbox, Capt MAYO, We have received Cape Town papers of the 20th Nov., being twenty days later than previous advices from tile PacificAmong the passengers in the Springbox are the Rev. E. B. CUess and family. The William Frothingham, from New.Ynrk for Australia, put into Cape Town for water, and called again on the I4th Nov.

The two islands of Malta and Gozo, lying to the south of Sicily, form a fortress and military colony of England, scarce less impregnable and important than the Rock of Gibraltar. Malta has been for over half a century an English garrison. About 700 years B. C. the Greeks drove the Phoenicians out of the island, settled on it, and called it Melitas.

On Thursday last, the following letter addressed by the Secretary of State to Mr. MAROOLETA, Minster from Nicaragua to this Government: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, Dec, $0, 1852, " SIR: Some months ago Mr. KERR was instructed to request appointed us representative from Nicaragua to this Government.

BANKs.-Measures are in progress with a view to the establishment of another bank, to be styled "The Farmers and Meebanies' Bank,!' with a capital of $250,COO--tbe amount to which Hudson County Bank proposes to extend its capital.

To the truth that "all men are born free and equal," we must assent, because the Declaration of Independence says so, and we would not be the traitors so early in the year's morning, to doubt the assertions of that venerated document.

A LECTURE, BY J. A. MCHASTER, ESq. J. A. McMASTER, Eeq., editor of the Freeman's sturnal, delivered a lecture in Metropolitan IIall, last eveuiDg. Subject-" The Bearings of State Schools on Qhe Religious Education of the People." There was a good attendance. Mr. Mc IAsTEn was accompanied by several l of the loman Catholic Clergy, and was received with continued applause.

The caucus of the Democratic members of the Assembly was called to order to day, by Hon. ARPHOXED LOOMIS, of Herkimer, and on his motion Hon. HENRY SHAW, of New-York, was called to the Chair, and Mr. CHAMPLIN, of Allegany, appointed Secretary. The list of members having been called, all the members elect, except Mr. HUTCHINGS, of Kings, answered to their names.

Information has been received from an authentic source that the Chippe was are so well contented with recent arrangements on the part of the Government officers, that they propose, of themselves, to remove to the Mississippi.

Messrs. JONES of Iowa, and HOUSTON, appeared in their seats. The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Interior, enclosing the annual reports of the Surveyor Generals of California and Oregon.

From the London Sun. It was a curious coincidence, that America should have been mourning for WENSTER precieoly at about the same period when England was mouthing for WELLINGTON, During the same month of November--(1852)--the old Monarchy consigned to the tomb with public obsequies the greatest of her warriors, and the young Republic offerred a somewhat similar funeral homage to the memory of the greatest of her statesmen.

We publish in another part of this morning's Times the ablest and most sensible analysis of the character and political position of LOUIS NATOLEON we have ever seen. It is from the London Economist, and is well worhty of careful perusal.

On Wednesday last, the 22d December, his Excellency DAVID S. REID, was inauguarated in presence of both Houses of the General Assembly as Governor of the State for the next two years. The British propeller Glasgow, Capt. R. CRAIG, arrived at this port yesterday from Glasgow, with dates from that port to the 16th Dec., and London to the 15th-one day later than the advices per Pacific, The news by the overland Mail is important as regards the condition of affairs in India ,and China.

The Broadway Opera, for this evening, is the "Daughter of the Regiment," with ALBONI as the prima donna, of course. To perfect the rehearsals, Monday evening was omitted as an opera night. The same opera is to open the lyric scene to Madame SONTAG, at NIBLO'S, on Monday of next week.

THE LAKES.-The Buffalo Express contains a detailed statement of marine disasters on the Lakes during the past year, together with the loss of life and property thereby occasioned, prepared by Capt. G. W. RouaDs. Agent of the North Western Insurance Company. The lose of property is some S260,000 greater than in any previous year.

Through the politeness of Mr. GEORGE COACHMAN, the efficient Clerk of the City Prison, our reporter was enabled to procure from his books Ihe following statistics, which exhibits the number of criminals received and discharged at that institution during the year 1652, and also the balance now remaining in custody of Mr. EDMONDS. the Warden:

The Steamship Washington, Capt. FITON, from Bremen, Dec. 3, and Southampton, 18th, for New-York, put into this port this morning, short of coal, and with the lose of foretopsail-yard, having experienced very heavy weather. She will take in a supply of coal, and probably proceed to New-York early tomorrow morning.

Gen. CASS yesterday made an interesting speech, on presenting a petition asking our Government to Solicit religious freedom for American citizens in Europe. He took strong ground in favor of the petition. There was also in the House a debate of considerable interest on the Cuban question.

TEN DAYS LATER FROM BUENOS AYRES.-By the arrival of the bark Minguela at Salem, we have advices from Buenos Ayres to Nov. 10-ton days later. An official decree of the Chamber of Representatives, Oct. 30, announces Dr. VON VALEINTINE ALSINA as Governor and Captain. General of the Province. His installation took place on the succeeding Sunday.

The anniversary of tile birth of our Savlour was duly celebrated by our good people yesterday, with prayers, feasting and rejoicing. All the churches were well attended, and appropriate ser. mons delivered, At midday, Obartros and Royal. streets swarmed with beautifully dressed children, accompanied by their nurses, and groups of lovely young girle, from the budding rose to the bloom. Ing flower, Everybody wae in holiday attire.

The election is over. Once more a Protestant is just as good as a Catholic, and a native-born citizen as a foreigner. Not having any imported blood in our veins, we have not felt upon an equality with mankind for a few months past. Now, till the commencement of another Presidential campaign, "All men are free and equal."--Minnesota paper.

We have been favored with an extract of a private letter from HENRY W. COWLES, Esq. who has started on an European tour, before commencing the practice of law in our City, giving an interesting account of the thrilling incident that happened to the Pacific on her outward voyage, a graphic account of which, from the pen of a lady passenger, we published some time since.

We have no mail south of Richmond this morning, The Norfolk Herald states that orders have been received there to fit the U. S. steamer Fulton for the purpose of conveying the Hon. W. R. KING to Havana, and the steamer Engineer was to be immediately dispatched to Washington to convey him to Norfolk.

A vendor of turkeys was yesterday, as is usual in these days of approaching Christmas, driving his flock of birds through Main street, New-Orleans, apposite the residence of Mr. GUSTAVE CLAUDE. Now, Mr, CLAUDE has been fattening a turkey in his yard for his own table on Christmas, but yesterday his turkey was missing.

We learn that at the recent meeting of the Board or Trustees of Webster College, Missouri,MCessrs. S. R. Curtis, S. T. Glover, anti Rev. A. Bullard, were appointed a committee to draft an set of' incorporation, which is to lhe forwarded to the Lcgislaturo during the precnt week.

WALLACK'S.--The new farce of "My Christmas Dinner," the fairy tale of "Mysterious Rappings," the comedietia of "Faint Heart Never Won Fair Lady," and the Irish farce of "Born to Good Luck," In these LESTER, WALCOT, BLAKE, and Miss ?? appear. The fine old comedy of "Speed the Plough" was given last evening in a style far better than we have seen it performed for the last fifteen years.

Mr. McMASTER delivered his promised lecture last evening, upon State Schools, to a fair sized audience, at Metropolitan Hall; and a sketch of it will be found in another column applause with which it was received indicated that the listeners were of his faith

The Treasurer of the Essex (Mass.) Savings Bank, in his last report says "Gentlemen--I communicate the information, that your have it in your power to declare the usual dividend of two per cent, for the six months last past, and an extra dividend of twenty-five per cent, or five per cent per annum, for the first five year's business.

TO EX-MAYOR AMBROsE C. KINOSLAND.--On Now Ycar's day, a magnificent clock, of the value of 9500 or $600, was presented to lIon. AMBROSE C. KIRNOsLAND, then Mayor of the City of Now-York, on behalf of the omnibus proprietors of this City, as a testimonial of their esteem and appreciation of Mayor KINOLAND'S official conduct. We here annex the correspondence that passed on the occasion:

A bill drawn by A. B. CLITHERALL, Esq., and adopted at a recent Temperance Convention in Alabama, will be urged upon the Legislature of that State for passage, Its features are as folLOWS: It makes it lawful for the inhabitants of any town, village or city, to increase the amount to be paid for a license to sell intoxicating liquors within its limits, or to suppress such sale entirely.

COMMON COUNCIL -- The first meeting of the new City Government was held at the City Hall Monday evening. The meeting was organized by appointing Alderman HARTEAU President pro tern. On motion of Alderman HAWXHURST, the Board went into Executive session. The question of whether the Board of Aldermen was a continuous body or not was brought up on the approval of the minutes of the last meeting

To the Senate and Assembly: FALLOW CITIZENS: Charged with administering the affairs of a State unequalled by any in the Union in its population, wealth and commercial interests, we have reason to distrust our own ability in the performance of the duties imposed upon as, and to implore the continued direction of that Providence which has hitherto guided and blessed the people of this State and Nation.

NEW-HAMPSHIRE CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS -- The bill to divide New. Hampshire into three Congressional Districts, has passed the House. The Patriot says no county is divided, and the Districts are as follows: Ist District, the Counties of Rockingham, Siraffurd, Carroll and Belanap; IId District, the Counties of Hillsborough and Merrimack;

Governor SEYMOUR opens his first Message with a recognition of that kind Providence which has guided and blessed the people of this State and Nation. He bespeaks a liberal support and endowment forth numerous charitable and benevolent institutions, which are designed to relieve the subjects of bodily and mental affliction.

The President to-day nominated Senator BADGER for Judge of the Supreme Court. Some think he will be confirmed, More think not. The Democrats in the Senate will holdacaucus in relation to the nomination.

A FEMALE KILLED ON THE SIXTH-AVENUE RAILROAD--CORONER'S INQUEST AND VERDICT.--On Monday afternoon a young woman named ANNA McGAVARAN met with an accident, that resulted in the loss of herlife. It seems the deceased was going on an errand, and while crossing the Sixth and Eighth avenue railtracks in West Broadway, a car of the former company came along.
The report of the State Controller, which will be found in another part of this morning's Times, sets forth at great length the condition of the various funds belonging to the State.

WILLIAM P. SCHELL, Democrat, was elected Speaker of the House, by 25 majority, ever C. W. KELSO, the Whig candidate. The Sena e failed to organize this afternoon. Several unsuccessful ballots being had for Speaker.

On Tuesday evening, Jan 4, LILLIAN ELDREDGE, infant daughter of Major Charles H. and Mary Elizabeth Larnard. Funeral services this (Wednesday) morning, at No. 153 Prince-st., at 11 o'clock. The remains will be taken to Greenwood. Providence, R. I., Detroit and Chicago papers please copy.

The "BANKS GUARD" commanded by Capt. JOHN P. HOPKINS, celebrated their first Annual Target Excursion on Monday last, presenting the appearance of an exceedingly well drilled corps of 50 rank and file. Previously to setting out, DAVID BANKS, Jr., presented the company with a beautiful standard, together with a set of beautiful guide colors. After having gone through the usual parade, the company repaired to the shooting grounds of the Pollock Mansion House, Hoboken.

The Third Lecture of the Mechanics Institute course was delivered last evening, at the rooms of the Institute, corner of Bowery and Division-street, by JOHN H. GRISCON, Esq., M. D. Making due allowance for the severity of the evening, the audience was respectable, both as to numbers and intelligence. There was a pretty fair sprinkling of the rising generation, consisting of males and females ranging from 12 to 18 years of age, among the audience.

The Whig Legislative Caucus this evening nominated GEORGE BLISS, of Springfield, for Speaker o the House; he had 61 votes to 55 for O. P. LORD, o Salem. WM. SCHOULER, of the Boston Atlas, was nom inated for Clerk of the House; he had 66 votes, GEO W. MINNS, 40; J. R. CIIILDS, of Chicopce, 9.

From the Nantucket Inquirer we have the particular of the resouing of the crew of the brig Isabel, of whose disaster we gave an account nine days since by telegraph: She went ashore at Great Point, after riding at anchor some time, during a severe storm. The crew suffered greatly on Tuesday night from cold, there being so much water in the brig as to prevent them from going below.

The Governors of Virginia and Maryland, have consented to attend the railroad opening on the 10th, at Wheeling. The petition for freedom by RACHEL PARKER, who is alleged to have been kidnapped in Choster County, Pennsylvania, and claimed as a slave, was commenced in the County Court to-day. Seventy witnesses from Pennsylvania are present.

The Worcester Transcript says that five seizures of liquor have been made in Gardiner, Mass., recently. Three of the cases have been tried, the defendants convicted, and the liquor ordered to be destroyed. A bonfire was made on Thursday evening, and the contraband spirits committed to the flames.

The affairs of the EMPIRE STATE claim a large portion of our space. The Governor's Message and the Controller's Report,--both ponderous papers, sent into the Legislature yesterday,--will be found in our columns this morning. They are interesting documents, and deserve a far more careful perusal than they are, likely to receive.

CIL.--City Clerk--Joseph Hegeman. Health Officer--Mathew Wendell, M.D., old incumbent. City Treasurer --A. S. Malford. Messenger and Keeper of the City Hall Robert Howard, old incumbent. Keeper of City Parks--George Doherty, Whig. Sealer of Weighs and Measures--Thomas Petit. Bell-Ringers--James Dillon, William Krily; latter Whig.

ARRIVAL OF THE STEAMAT WASHINGTON AT THIS PORT.--The U. S. mail steamer Washington, Capt. FITCH, from Bremen via. Southampton, Dec. 13, for New-York, put into this port yesterday forenoon. short of coal. She has experienced a succession of heavy westerly gales, and stormy weather, which has protracted her voyage beyond the usual time, and compelled her to put in for a supply of fuel, which was about exhausted.

BALTIMORE POLICE REPORT.--From the Annual Report of High Constable HERRING to the Mayor, we lake the following statistics, showing the number of arrests for all causes during the year 1852: For aseault and battery, 908 ; assault with intent to kill, 74 ; assault with intent to commit rape, 4; assault with intent to rob, 28; assault on officers, 73; assaulting and stabbing, 43; assaulting and beating wives, 115;

BROADWAY.--The is one of the "regular" nights, when the old cast of entertainments and old prices are on the bill. For the first time for many years, KENNEY'S comedy, "Love, Law and Physic," is to be played, with a ballet a farce, and a pantomime-surely variety enough for one night's entertainment. To-morrow, Madame ALBONI appears again in Opera.

THE MURDER IN WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP.--The murderer of the children of Mr. O'BRIEN has been found In the woods adjoining the house where the deed was committed. He lay secreted in the brush as the funeral procession of his victims passed along, which excited him so much that he made an unsuccessful attempt to cut his throat, which at the time of his discovery was festered and materiated in a shocking manner.

LOSS OF SHIP AMULET. OF BOSTON, AND FIFTEEN LIVES,--Captain SETZER, of the ship Annawan, which arrived at this port yesterday afternoon from New-Orleans, reports having picked up, on the 31st ult., at 4 o'clock P. M., latitude 40[degrees] 25', longitude 71[degrees], a boat containing Captain PAUL HOWES, THOMAS S. HOWES, first mate; ROBERT B. FOLK, second mate, and JOHN WILLIAMS, third mate of the ship Amulet, from Cette, of and for Boston,with salt.

The following letter, which we received last evening from our distinguished Senator in Congress, will be read with interest, and by a vast many of his constituents, with profound regret: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. 1852. SIR--My object in addressing you, as the conductor of a public press, is to make known a purpose, which has long been avowed by me, of withdrawing from public life.

The occupation of Samana, in St. Domingo, by the French, seems very likely to prove unfounded after all. The fact was originally stated on the authority of a private letter received by Le Phare, a French paper published in this City. Two or three vessels have since arrived from that region without bringing any confirmation of the rumor.

The business of Slaver-eatching grows on the hands of England. The letters of our regular Havana correspondent apprize us of the liveliest state of feeling in that department of industry; a wholesome competition having grown up between the Captain General and the British agents, appointed for the suppress ion of negro-dealing.

In the Supreme Court this morning the KAINE Extradition case was again called up. Attorney-General CRITTENDEN stated that he had examined the law applicable to the case, and had come to the conclusion to take no active part in it, considering that the duty of the Executive only commenced when the criminality of the accused was legally established and the warrant issued.

In obedience to chapter eight, title three, article one, of the first part of the Revised Statutes; and also of chapter 350, of the Laws of 1847, the Controller has the honor to submit the following ANNUAL REPORT. The several Funds belonging to the State, which are referred to and considered in this Report, are the following, viz.:

Mr. MALLORY appeared to day. Mr. BADGER offered a resolution continuing the employment of a Clerk to the President of the Senate. He said the adoption of the resolution would be gratifying to the late president of the Senate (Mr. KING), who was now on account of ill health leaving our shores. The resolution was adopted. pted.

The President today sent to the Senate the nomination of lion. GEO E. BADGER, of North Carolina, to the vacant Judgeship of the Supreme Court. The Secretary of the Treasury has appointed WILLIAM MILLER, Inspector of Steamboat hulls, and S. C. WARD, Inspector of Boilers at New-London, Conn.; NATIIANIEL NASH, Inspector of Hulls, and GARRETT B. DAVIES, Inspector of Boilers at Norfolk, Va., at salaries of $300 each.

Strikes for higher wages seem to be generally more questionable as to policy than as to right. Without a doubt, a man who is hired by the day, has a perfect right to stop working when he concludes that his work is not properly remunerated. And if several workmen chance to agree in the matter, the right of one is the right of all,

HORACE HAWES, formerly Prefect of the District of San Francisco, California, throws some new light on the sale made by the Mexican authorities at Acapulco, of the steamer Commodore Stockton. Judge HAWES is well known as an eminent lawyer,

After every extraordinary occurrence in our City, in which rowdyism holds up its head above the law, and takes an undisputed preference before it, the question passes from mouth to mouth, "What shall be done to prevent a repetition of such outrages?" It is seriously considered whether or not our laws are sufficiently stringent.

ALBONI as the "Daughter of the Regiment, drew a very crowded audience to the Broadway Opera last night. The character, we believe, was entirely new to her. In personal appearance she seemed at first blush, not exactly in place, but to this the audience soon became more than reconciled. She carried through the performance with so much spirit and genuine vivacity,

Paris paper give an account of a new motive power, as applied experimentally in that capital. With true French passion for the romantic, they describe two porters bearing a mysterious burden, concealed in multitudinous envelopes, and behind it eight or ten persons marching evenly and eagerly onward,

THREATENED RUPTURE BETWEEN PERU AND NEW-GRENADA.--The latest dates from Panama, per steamer Winfield Scott, refer to an insult perpetrated upon a foreign official by a native functionary. The difficulty is substantially this. Sener I. LOUSTOUNAN, Consul for Peru, at the port of Panama, was basely insulted by the Chief of Police, a few days prior to the sailing of the Winfield Scott.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held Monday evening, and after transacting some business, adjourned sine die, when the newly elected members took the oath of office. The following are the names: First Ward-Messrs. BARKER, Van Sant, Sparks, and Willmarth Second Ward.--Messrs. Comstock, Hobley, Baker, and Smith.

The Parliamentary Committee appointed to inquire into the charges of bribery and corruption practised by the Tory Party at the recent election for Derby, and as to the share which Major BERESFORD, the Secretary-at-War, had in such transactions, reported to the house on Thursday night.

FUNERAL OF AMOS LAWRENCE, ESQ.--The funeral services over the remains of the late AMOS LAWRENCE, Esq, were solemnized this day at 12 M., in the church in Brattle-square, where he had for so many years worshipped, and for a long period was one of its most beloved and honored church members.

EXPLOSION OF GAR. WORKS -- A terrible explosion occurred at about 3 o'clock on the morning of Dec. 31, at the new gas works in Woonsocket, by which two men were shockingly burnt, and a portion of the works completely destroyed.

DEAR SIR: A transaction occurred here to day which I feel myself called upon to notice, with the view of expressing my own reprobation of such acts as are occasionally committed here by individuals connected with the press, which unfortunately reflect upon the profession unjustly and injuriously.

From the Boston Courier. In consequence of the wish expressed by our correspondent, S. M. S., in Saturday's Courier, a wish in which we need not say the public heartily concur, we have procured a copy of Mr. WEBSTER's Last Will and Testament for publication.
Commodore MORGAN died at the Navy Yard in this city this morning. His funeral will take place to-morrow.
The meeting of the Cumberland region Coal Companies, to confer with the President of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, this morning, was largely attended.
THINGS IN NORTH CAROLINA.--The business of the last session of the North Carolina Legislature related mainly to works of Internal Improvement on State and individual account.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Before Hon. Judge BEEBE, Aldermen FRANCIS and BRISLEY.--The Grand Inquest.--At the opening of the Court of General Sessions this forenoon, they proceeded to empanol the Grand Inquest for the Term, the Jurors of which areas follows:

SIR: I beg leave to inclose the copy of the dispatch and the project for a Convention which formed the subject of the conversation which Mons. DE SARTIGE and myself had the honor of holding with you this morning.
The Legislature met at 11 o'clock this morning. The Senate was organized by the choice of CHARLES H. WARREN, of Boston, as President, and CHARLES CALHOUN as Clerk--both Whigs.

TRAGEDY IN LIMA.--The Commmercio de Lima, of Nov. 25, gives the details of an affray which has placed the whole city in excitement. A young Frenchman, named EMANUEL GIROUX, being mistaken for another person, JOSE TORIBIO MARSILLA, was waylaid, and stabbed in two places with a dirk, by Mr. THORNE, the husband of the prima donna, CLOTILDE BARILI.

A new Cotton Mill in Burrillville, belonging to ANTHONY STEERE, and operated by S. B. MORY, the owners of the machinery, was destroyed by fire last night. It was valued at $35,000; insured in this city for $24,800.
The Marina Washington conspiracy case is still in course of investigation at Columbus. The testimony, as far as it has been given before the Court, is very strong against the defendants.

COMMODORE GREGORY AND THE WORKMEN OF THE CHARLESTOWN NAVY YARD.--Commodore GREGORY invited the master workmen if the various gangs employed in the Charlestown Navy Yard, to visit him at his residence at 12 o'clock, and the mechanics and workmen, to about seven hundred in number, to assemble at one of the ship houses.

From the London Times. At a time when Parliamentary Government would seem to have lost much of the ground it had won upon the Continent of Europe, we are suddenly roused from the indifference with which we had for some years past regarded the internal affairs of Spain by a struggle of unusual vehemence and a coalition of unprecedented extent in that country between men of every shade of political opinion.
RENTING PEWS IN THE PLYMOUTH CHURCH.--On Tuesday evening the Pews in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, (Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, Pastor,) were rented for the coming year.

The Senatus Consultum, fixing the amount of the civil list and the dotation of the crown, has been promulgated. The civil list is 25,000,000 francs. The dolation is composed of the same royal palaces, forests and manufactories, the furniture, museums and crown jewels which belonged to the crown under the Monarchy and Empire NAPOLEON'S right of property in and administration of these possessions, are qualified by restrictions similar to those of the Monarchy.

At the Broadway Opera, this evening, ALBONI repeats the character of Maria in the Child of the Regiment, which, by common consent, was so decided a success on Tuesday. Our neighbor of the Mirror, posted in the Green Room, says the character is not new to ALBONI.
The steamship Washington sailed for New-York, at 9 o'clock this morning. In turning round in the harbor she got foul of the bark Arctic, ready to sail for San Francisco.
On Wednesday morning, Jan. 5. of scarlet lever, FRANK GILBERT, youngest child of James and Louisa Price, aged 1 year, 1 months and 21 days.

In the Albany Register of the 1st we find the following: By an arrangement with the proprietors of the State Register, I have become its editor, and hold myself responsible for whatever appears in its columns.

London Markets. Per Steamer Asia LONDON, Friday, Dec. 17, 1852-5 P.M. We have had rather more activity in the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets this week, and COFFEE and SUGAR have been in improved demand COTTON rather firmer. METALS keep up.

The New-Orleans mail has again failed, and we have nothing this evening South of Richmond. The Maryland Legislature met at Annapolis to-day, but did not organize, and adjourned till to morrow, when an organization will probably take place, and the Governor's Message will be read.

Theories of what may follow this division are of course numerous enough. Various names are mentioned as those of statesmen likely to be called upon to assist the deliberations of those on whom the decision of the House of Commons last night throws new responsibilities.
At Cincinnati they opened a bale of Cotton and found the body of a negro pressed into it. So great was the pressure that the body of the man was not more than three inches thick.--Exchange.
THE CALORIC SHIP.--The Caloric Ship Ericsson returned, yesterday afternoon, from her trial trip down the Bay, having exceeded the anticipations of those interested in her.
There is a state within the bounds of Christendom, where the crime of a man is visited upon his harmless wife and dependent children.
The ministry was defeated on Thursday night upon the question of the house tax, which it was generally understood was to decide the fate of the Budget and of the administration.
Commodore CHARLES MORGAN, whose death at Washington is to-day announced, was a Virginian by birth, and the tenth Captain on the Navy list.

To the President of the United States: The Secretary of State, to whom was referred by the, President the resolution of the House of Representatives of the 24th of January last, in regard to Central America, has the honor to report she facts disclosed by the accompanying correspondence, which is respectfully submitted in response to the resolution.
Prince NAPOLEON, son of the ex-King of Westphalia, who is to have the place and title of Lieutenant of the Emperor in Algeria, is already occupied in forming the personnel of his administration.

MURDER BY POISON AT CINCINNATI.--A woman named FANNY MAHONEY, and an Irish girl named ELIZABETH BRAY, and a blind man, well known here as a begger and wood-sawyer, named EDWARD BRESLIN, left St. Louis some ten days since as deck passengers on the steamboat Herald.

By way of Singapore, advices have been received from Bangkok to Oct. 12. Not only the city, but the nation have been thrown into deep mourning by the death of the Queen, which event took place on the night of Oct. 10.

Spain still continues on the verge of revolution. Our accounts from Madrid are of the 11th inst. The Duke of VALENTIA returned from Aranjuez the evening before, and left in the night for Bayonne, accompanied by his former aide-de-camp, M. ENRIQUEZ.

Mr. SEWARD presented the memorial of CHRISTIAN HANSELM, of Brooklyn, praying that Government would contract with him for carrying the mails in war steamers between that City and Gluchstadt, in Germany, to connect with mail steamers connecting St. Petersburg the Baltic Sea, Copenhagen, and all parts of Germany with New-York.

The Inaugual Message of Gov. BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, was delivered to the Legislature yesterday. The following is a synopsis of its leading points: The Governor commences by congratulating his follow-citizens upon the general prosperity of the country its freedom from famine, ware and internal strife.

WATER COMMISSION.--The Water Commissioners deem the present to be a favorable time for obtaining the remainder of the loan authorized for the construction of the water-works to and in Jersey City, and have accordingly invited proposals for the sum of $300,000, which will be opened on the 19th instant.
After a very protracted debate, the House of Commons last night, or rather at a late hour this morning, rejected the first resolution of Mr. DISRAELI'S Budget by a division of 305 to 286.

Substance and Show--By Rev. T. S. King. The Fourth lecture of the People's course, was delivered in the Tabernacle last evening, by Rev. THOS. STARR KING, of Boston, to a more than usually large audience. Mr. KING was received with prolonged applause.
THE LIQUOR LAW DECISION.--Much misapprehension has arisen in the public mind regarding the late decision of Judge CURTIS, in reference to the Rhode Island liquor law.

The Executive response to Mr. CASS'S resolution of inquiry elicited two insignificant documents and nothing more. One of them is the following memorandum of the Secretary of State, in reference to the treaty of Washington of April, 1850: The within declaration of Sir H. BULWER was received by me on the 29th day of June, 1850.

A SHREWD CONFIDENCE OPERATION.--A few nights ago, a gentlemen residing on the corner of Eldridge and Broome streets, familiarly known as SAM KELLINGER, WAS "done" by the shrewd operations of a genuine "confidence" man.

We sometimes see in the prints announcements that HERR, X. Y. or Z. will take flight from the top of some lofty spire, and alight safely at a spot a considerable distance away,--or that a famous magician will undertake to walk across a sheet of water, in the presence of any number of spectators.

Mayor SEAVER, of Boston, delivered his loaugural message to the City Council on the 3d. He recommends the establishment of a Board of commissioners, for the management of the public lands, and insists that a liberal policy be adopted in disposing of them, and encouragement given to purchasers to build immediately, would increase the taxable property of the city, and stay the Exodus of her citizens.
When the news of his certain election as President of the United States was carried to FRANKLIN PIERCE, it is said his countenance scarcely underwent any change.

The following is the Correspondence sent to the Senate yesterday on the Cass resolution: To the Senate of the United States: In answer to the resolution of the Senate of the 30th ult, requesting information in regard to the establishment of a new British Colony in Central America, I transmit a report from the Secretary of State and the documents by which it was accompanied.
The Royal Mail steamer Asia, Capt. LOTT, arrvied at her wharf yesterday morning, via Halifax, having left Liverpool on the afternoon of the l8th December, and Halifax on the 2d inst.
An important decision upon the limitation of the responsibility by contract of common carriers, was lately given in the English Court of Common Pioss, Easter Term.

The river, says the Cincinnati Atlas, on the 31st, had fallen in all nearly two feet, and gradually receding. The packet from Pittsburg reports the water rising at Pittsburg, but falling from Marietta to this place.

Our space is largely given to the publication of the documents laid before Congress in relation to Central America and Cuba, including the correspondence respecting the attempted Tripartite Treaty. These documents will be read with interest.

THE MINISTRY. The London Times says, in a leading article, that at the Cabinet Council, held yesterday, the collective resignation of Ministers was doubtless resolved on, and before night it was probably in Her Majesty's hands.

A letter from Neufchatel of the 8th, in the Frankfort Post Journal, states that on the evening of Sunday, the 5th inst., a Frenchman named FLANE, formerly cook to Queen HORTENSE, who keeps a cafe at Neufchatel, thought proper to illuminate his windows in honor of the reestablishment of the Empire in France, and exhibited a transparency with an imperial crown.

The Special Telegraphic Dispatch from Washington which we publish this morning, giving full copies of the CLAYTON Treaty correspondence, was sent over a single wire by Mr. A. B. TALCOTT, of HOUSE's New-York and Washington Printing Line, in forty-eight minutes.

There is little to add to the news contained in the official market lists. Our markets generally are dull, which I attribute to a desire on the part of merchants to restrict their business until the New-Year.

The accounts from the whaling fleet on the North-West coast, by the last California mail, are of the most favorable character, and we hope it will affect the price of oil. Consumers are not only obliged to pay exorbitant prices for this useful article, but they find as the price goes up the quality of the oil goes down.

ANNUAL REPORT OF THE BROOKLYN DISPENSARY FOR THE YEAR 1852.--This charitable Institution, situated near the corner of Fulton and Pineapple-streets, has Benevolence stamped upon its very organization. The Physicians, six of whom are in daily attendance, contribute their services gratuitously, and have done so faithfully, in the face of embarrassments and difficulties, since the Institution was founded, some six years since.

The Maryland Legislature fully organized today, and the message from the Governor was received. He states the finances of the State to he in a prosperens condition, the surplus revenue of the year being $543,000, after paying $677,000 for current interest on the Dublic debt. The following bills were introduced. To distribute standard works of American authors among Common School Libraries. Relatives to the organization of the militia. Authorizing certain Railway companies to consolidate their stock.

WHO HAS LOST A LITTLE GIRL ?-One day last week a man calling himself JAMES WALTERS, came to this place, having in his charge a little girl about five years of age. For two or three days and nights the fellow gave gratuitous feats of legerdemain, swallowing a sword, etc., in the bar-room of HEDRICK's tavern.

The funeral of Commodore MORGAN took place from his official residence at the Navy Yard, this after noon, and was attended by a numerous assemblage, including General SCOTT, Commodore MORRIS, and many other officers or the Army and Navy, and also the Secretary of the Navy and other distinguished citizens. Rev. Mr. HODGES, Episcopalian, delivered an appropriate discourse. Rev. Dr. BUTLER assisted, and read the Episcopal service for the dead.

It will be seen, by a correspondences in another part of this morning's Times, that Miss BACON is about to commence a series f of twelve Evening Lessons upon the "Origin of the Oriental Elements in our Civilization," to be delivered on Tuesday and Friday evenings of each week, at the Stuyvesant Institute.

The Court commenced its January Term at the Capitol this morning at 10 o'clock. Wallace, respondent, against Latsmon, appellant; No. 212 on Calendar. Motion by appellant to set aside a former order dismissing the appeal in this case, denied with costs. A Benedict for motion; N. Hill, Jr., opposed.

IMPORTANT ARREST.--The Cincinnati Nonpareil, of the 3d, has the following: "We made mention on Saturday, of the arrest of a female on charge of having in her possession, and passing a quantity of spurious coin of different denominations. After her arrest, Officers ZEHRER and DRAGER went to the house of her husband on Mulberry, between Locust and Poplar-sts., to arrest him, but receiving information of their approach he made good his escape.

There is one thought in the report of the Common School Superintendent which challenges our hearty assent. It is that our School System requires permanency to adapt it to the circumstances of society, and to give facility and vigor to its operations.

DARING BURGLARY AT JAMAICA PLAINS--COURAGEOUS ATTACK UPON THE ROBBERS.--At about 2 o'clock on Tuesday morning, the dwelling of Col FESSENDEN, the well known Railroad Engineer, was the scene of a burglary of a most unexampled character. The house of Mr. FESBENDEN is situated in a secluded lane, Green-st., Jamaica Plains, at a considerable distance from any other house, and in the vicinity of woods.

The Cincinnati Gazette states that a shocking assault was made upon Mrs. Ridge, by one Isaac Ablett, on the 29h ult., under the following circumstances. Owing to the rise in the river, Mrs. R. who occupied the lower portion of the house on Hunt-street, between Harriet and Horn-street, was forced to move into the upper portion of the house occupied by Ablett.

The President elect had a very narrow escape, and met a very sad bereavement yesterday, upon the Railroad near Andover, Mass. Returning with his family from Boston, whither they had been in attendance upon the funeral of Mr. LAWRENCE, the car in which they were seated was thrown down a steep bank some twenty feet high, rolling over and over in its progress, and seriously injuring a number of the passengers. Gen.

The Maine Legislature met at Augusta yesterday. LEWIS C. TALBOTT,wild-cat Democrat, was elected Speaker of the House by 25 majority. In the Senate LEWIS COWAN, Whig, was elected. For President no election was made-the Democrats refusing to vote and thereby preventing a quorum--their object being to stave off the election of a permanent President until vacancies are filled when they will have a majority.

Mr. D. B. TAYLOR of this city has given notice of his intention to introduce a bill allowing the owners of slaves to pass through this State, or reside temporarily therein, with their property;--in other words reestablishing slavery in this State, under certain restrictions and for certain purposes. His principal object in this is undoubtedly political.

THE OLDEST MEMBER.--Hampshire County has again, probably, the honor of furnishing the oldest member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives: GILES C. KELLOGG, Esq., Representative elect from Hadey, was a member of the House in 1809, and we doubt whether any member elect held a seat in that body prior to that date.

The Cairo correspondent of the Evansville, (Ind.) Journal, writes :-Thirty-two Indians, from the State of Arkansas. passed up the Mississippi, not long since, in canoes. They wore dressed mostly in fure, and painted only as an Indian knows how to paint.

Mr. EVERETT'S reply to the proposition that the United States should join France and England in guaranteeing to Spain possession of Cuba forever,-published at length in the Times of yesterday morning, is one of the most admirable papers ever issued from the State Department. It is in the highest degree creditable to the Secretary and to the President under whose direction it was prepared.

A LECTURE-BY WILIAM ROSS WALLACE Mr. WM. ROSS WALLACE delivered his promised lecture on Peter The Great," in the Stuyvesant Institute, last evening. The attendance was large, and Mr. WALLACE was received with flattering applause.

CITY FINANCEBS.--Thirty eight thousand dollars have been assessed this year for city uses; about thirty thousand of this has been collected, leaving a balance unpaid the Collector of about eight thousand dollars. Of the thirty thousand dollars collected, two-thirds has been expended, and on the 1st of January there was in the Treasury ten thousand five hundred and seventy-one dollars and twenty-four cents.

Capt. McKay, of the clipper Sovereing of the Seas, previous to sailing from New-York for San Francisco, in August last. addressed a letter to Lieut. Maury, of the National Observatory at Washington, requesting a copy of the fourth edition of his "Sailing Directions," for the use of the voyage. Lieut.

This magnificent establishment, which in extent of accommodation, completeness of arrangement, costliness and chaste elegance of decoration, and combination of all modern improvements, takes place as the Hotel par excellence of our day,--opened yesterday morning for business, and already a groat portion of the apartments have been engaged.

Four mails from, New Orleans arrived to-night, bringing dates as late as due. Texas dates to Dec. 24 are received, but the news is of little importance. Gen. HARNEY had arrived at Austin, and taken command of the Eighth Military Department during the absence of Gen. SMITH.

FROM BERMUDA.--We have received Hamilton papers and extract the following: From the Bermuda Gazette of Dec. 21. We are happy to learn that His Excellency Captain ELLIOT, is likely to resume the Government of Bermuda, at the desire of H. M. Government.

ANTI-RENT.--In our article, day before yesterday, we stated that "One case had been decided in favor of The People, and the defendant had carried that to the Court of Appeals." We should have added that, in that case His Honor, Judge HARRIS, in a very able and elaborate opinion, decided that the landlord's title to the occupied lands, or leasehold farms, was perfect.

THE MAINE LANDS.--The Governor and Council have, for several days, had under consideration the proposition of the Commissioners relative to a sale of the lands belonging to Massachusetts in the State of Maine. The Commissioners unanimously accepted the proposition of Messrs. McCRELLIS CLARK for $60,000, and so reported to the Governor and Council. Yesterday,

SHOCKING MURDER.--We learn from the Baltimore Sun that a wanton and deliberate murder was committed between 8 and 9 o'clock Monday night, on a led named THOMAS MILLER, about 15 years old. It appears that there is a considerable feud existing between two rival games of youths, rallying under the names of "Bloats" and "Sheep Boys," and which has led to numerous collisions and riots in Southwest Baltimore.

WILLIAMSBURG WATER WORKS.--The recent extensive surveys on Long Island, to ascertain the sources whence a sufficient quantity of pure and wholesome water can be obtained, has been satisfactorily terminated, and the Company are now actively engaged in making arrangements to proceed with the work.

A Correspondent of the New Pork Sun has been traveling in Ireland.--Exchange paper. That is a new name for Cincinnati, any how. But how truthful ! how suggestive ! how it makes a body think of " killing hogs time," and sausagemaking, and head-cheese and souse and so forth ! and how much more republican it sounds than "the Queen City !"

There is now exhibited in Leeds a young lady aged eightee, whose beard measures between four and five inches in length. As an inducement to persona to attend the exhibition, it is announced that "visitors will be permitted to touch the beard."

Some excitement was caused in the New-Hampshire Legislature yesterday by a charge preferred against Judge BUTLER, not a member, of attempting to bribe Mr. PIERCE, the member front Northwood, to uso his influence in favor of uniting the Concord and Claremont and the New-Hampshire Central Railroads. The subject was referred to a Special Committee.

ROXBURY (MASS.) CITY GOVERNMENT.--Mayor WALKER'S Inaugural Address shows that the City debt is $176,087,05, which could be nearly met by selling the public property not immediately required for City uses. An English High School has been established on the same footing as that in Boston, and the condition of the public Schools is flattering.

News has just been received here of a terrible accident on the Boston and Maine Railroad, one mile north of Andover. Several persons were severely injured, and the only child of Gen. PIERCE was killed. The train left Boston at 124 o'clock.

The Lecture of Gen. DIX before the Historical Society last evening, which will be found at length in this morning's Times, was commended to the intelligent audience which heard it by the direct simplicity of its style, the practical character of its sentiments, and its close connection with the daily duties and life of our people.

From the Washington Union. Extract of a letter from on board the ship Superior, lost off Cape Prince of Wales, Behring's Straits, August 11, 1852: MY DEAR PARENTS The bark Black Eagle will leave the whaling ground immediately on the taking of one more whale, and I thought it would be a good opportunity to let you hear from me.

Letters have been received at the War Department from Colonel SUMNER, representing a lamentable condition of affairs in the Territory of New-Moxico. The people are depicted as immoral, ignorant, and ungovernable. Mr. WEIGHTMAN, the Delegate from New-Mexico, is said to be awaiting an opportunity to demonstrate, upon the floor of the House, the incorrectness of those reports.

We should be sorry to think that the death of Commodore MORGAN was in any way resultant from the debate in the Senate on the same day. There was, certainly, nothing said or done on that occasion to shock the sharpest sensibilities; for all was compliment, sympathy and professions of ardent friendship, such as Damon and Pythias might have properly exchanged.

A NEW MEDICAL WORK.--The Houston papers publish a correspondence between some of the medical men of Houston and the interior, and Dr. J. C. MASSIE, in which the latter gentleman is solicited to write a book on the diseases of Texas. Dr. M.consents, and from the reputation which he enjoys as a physician and medical correspondent, we predict he will produce a work of eminent value and interest.

General PIERCE and lady are still at Audover. It is thought the funeral ot their son will take place at Concord to-morrow. The axletree of the car was broken in the middle. The car broke in pieces like a cigar-box. It contained sixty passengers.

The St. Paul Minnesotian thns plainly meets ihe charge of corruption made by the Minnesota Democrat against Governor Ramsay in regard to the payments of the Sioux Indians. We have taken pains to investigate the whole affair from beginning to end, and would be willing to stake our lives upon the result of the issue here made up between his revilers and ourselves.

We find the following notice of proceeding in the Supreme Court at San Francisco, on receiving intelligence of Mr. WEBSTER's death,--in the Times and Transcript of that city: Remarks of Judge Anderson. I cannot refrain, on this occasion, from adding the expression of my respect and admiration of the character of the great man, who has just passed from amongst us.

In the U.S. Senate on the 5th, some little debate was had upon a resolution offered by Mr. BADGER to print for distribution 10,000 of HICKEY'S edition of the Constitution of the United States, with WASHINGTON'S Farewell Address, and some other matter.

Twelve months after date, we are favored with the report of the Patent Office for 1851. Two bulky volumes are required to contain the vast mass of matters, which custom thrusts into the document. They are well enough printed and quite smartly bound, improving greatly in both particulars on previous issues. Mr EWBANKS has done what was possible to bring order out of the ordinary chaos.

Senator TABER has given notice of a bill in the State Senate, to regulate the granting of Charters for the Construction of Railroads in the City of New-York;--and Senator BEEKMAN promises a bill to amend the Charter of this City. We welcome these indications of a purpose, on the part of the State Legislature, to come to the relief of our citizens, and to remedy some of the evils under which we are suffering.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In my last, I painted Chief Justice MARSHALL; not at the full length of his public character, but in the miniature of private life; for such is the whole scope which I propose to myself, in these limnings of remarkable individuals. Were I to aim at more, each of these sketches would swell, in spite of me, to a biography.

ORIGINAL ANECDOTE OF MR. WEBSTER.--A few years since we passed a night with a farmer who resided within six miles of Mr. WEBSTER'S home in Marshfield. In speaking of Mr. WEBSTER the farmer said that he had made his acquaintance and found him a most agreeable neighbor. The acquaintance was in this wise. "I was out in my door-yard one morning before breakfast last summer, and saw a gentleman in my cow-yard.

A large and influential meeting was held last evening in Metropolitan Hall, to express the Christian sympathy of the citizens of New-York, in behalf of the persecuted family of the MADIAIS, now suffering imprisonment in the Grand Duchy of Tuscany, by the Government thereof, for "possessing and reading the Holy Scriptures."

The citizens of Ponghkeepsie are abont applying to the Legislature for a City Charter. The Eagle says in regard to it: We believe the day has come when the change from a village to a City has become indispensable for the common welfare, a village government being no longer suited to our wants, or calculated to preserve either our interests or our safety.

We hear that an important Railroad consolidation has been consummated between the different Companies owning the Great Central line of this Slate, from Albany to Rochester. Our information is not sufficiently definite to say whether the old Buffalo Co., are included or not.

SEIZURE OF COUNTERFRIT DIES. COIN AND BANK PLATES--ARREST OF WILSON.--For some time past a number of new counterfeits, which have been issued and circulated about the country, have been traced to this city. In consequence, the police have been at work to solve the question as to where they were manufactured.

Nos. 29 and 30. The United States vs. J. Gusman and V. Rillieux's heirs.--Appeals from the District Court of the United States for Louisiana. Mr. Justice Catron delivered the opinion of this Court, reversing the decrees of the said District Court, and remanding these causes, with directions to dismiss the petitions of the claimants.

On motion of Mr. ORR, resolved, when the House adjourn it adjourn till Monday, in order to afford members an opportunity to attend the ceremonies of the Jackson Equestrien Statue. Mr. HOUSTON asked leave to report from the Committee of Ways and Means, the last of the General Appropriation Bills.

TEMPERANCE MOVEMENTS.--The Temperance people in New-Jersey have been making energetic efforts throughout the State to advance the cause, by circulating petitions to be presented to the Legislature at its next session, praying the enactment of a prohibitory law. One petition is for legal voters, and the other for ladies and youths. The number of signatures obtained to these petitions is not far from 50,000, men, women and children.

It sounds like fiction to say that in one of the enlightened states of Christendom, within the present year, men, women and children are thrown into dungeons, or driven into banishment, like the most degraded criminals, for no other offence than having and reading the HOLY BIBLE.
It can scarcely be necessary for us to call the attention of our readers to the sketch of the Home, Person, Habits, and Conversation of THOMAS JEFFERSON, on the second page of this morning's Times.

A Cincinnati papers says: most of printing offices keep a dictionary, and it would be well if some of them would add a gramnmar, at least we judge so when we see in some of the city papers such expressions as: "he done it," "The Pike lays at the Levee," yesterday it one paper we saw: "The Supreme Court sets at Columbus;" and "The kettle with the metal in was setting in the stove."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The extract which you made from a foreign paper (the London Economist) on the character of NAPOLEON III., and its probable effects upon the political world, is entitled to all the commendation you have bestowed upon it; but there are two circumstances, capable of modifying these effects, which the writer has not noticed, but which I consider ought to present themselves to every reflecting mind.

The following is from the New-Orleans Picayune. The substance of it was published as telegraphic in the Times of January 1: By the arrival of the schooner Esther Burr, Captain RYAN, we have received files of papers from the City of Mexico to the 14th, and Vera Cruz to the 10th ult.

Governor SEYMOUR, in his Message, recommends the establishment of an Agricultural College. This recommendation has so often been made, and parties interested for the matter have so often attempted to obtain an Agricultural Charter without success, we wonder that the project has not before nowbeen abandoned utterly.

In the Daily Times of the 24th ult., we published a highly interesting and important opinion of the Supreme Court of the United States in the fugitive slave case of EELLS as. The State of Illinois, a full statement of which had previously been furnished us by our special correspondent at Washington.

The brig Planet, from Port Praya, Dec. 4, arrived at Salem yesterday. She left at Fort Praya U.S. ship Germantown, waiting orders. The John Adams, for Goree Gambia and a cruise down the coast, on the 6th Dec.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--A meeting of the King's County Board of Supervisors was held Thursday afternoon at the County Jail. His Honor, Mayor BERRY, of Williamsburg, presiding, and a quorum of members present. His Honor, Mayor LAMBERT, of Brooklyn, was present for the first time, and participated in the business of the meeting.

We have received a few of our Texan papers the latest to the 24th ult. From the New-Orleans Picayune of the 28th ult., we extract the following items: The Houston Telegraph says the late rains have raised all the principal streams so that they are again navigable, and It is quite probable that they will remain in a navigable condition until late in the Spring.

The Annual message or LOWE, delivered to the Legislature of Maryland on Thursday, was briefly sketched by Telegraph. We give a more complete summary of its leading points: The Message makes appropriate allusion to the blessings conferred on the State by a merciful Providence, and touches upon the triumph of Reason and Justice over the agitions of Fanaticism.

The Board met last evening. After waiting a considerable time, a quorum could not be mustered, and Mr. Sergeant SEAGRIST was dispatched to drum up the missing members. A rigid search in all the purlieus of the City Hall, the Tea-room included, was made by the indefatigable official, and in about 15 minutes he returned with a sufficient number to form a quorum; the business was then proceeded with.

COTTON--Sales to day 3,000 bales at firm prices. Middling ?? ??. NEW-ORLEANS, Friday, Jan. 7. COTTON has been quiet to-day, the sales barely reaching 1,500 bales, operators awaiting the America's news. Prices are so newhat easier.

NEW CITY TREASURER.--Mr. ALFRED MULFORD, the newly-elected City Treasurer of Brooklyn, is Cashier of the Mechanics' Bank. Under the old Treasurer, WM. S. DOUGHTY, (who has held the office since the incorporation of Brooklyn as a city,) the funds have been kept in the Atlantic Bank, and a question now arises whether the city funds can be transferred from the Atlantic Bank at once, or until drawn out in the regular course of business.

Among the many eminent persons whose death has distinguished the present year, Gov. VAN NESS is one, whose character and career deserve more than a mere passing and cursory memorial. For upwards of thirty-five years he was, with scarcely an interruption, in public life--enjoying positions of the highest trust and importance in the State of his adoption, and under the General Government during the whole period.

Our special dispatch from Washington, under date of last evening, reports the rumored explanation given by Mr. KING--whose extreme low health renders the controversy at this time much to be regretted-of the discrepaney between his note to Mr. CLAYTON, in 1850, and his verbal statement to Mr. C.ss last week.

Tile opening of the Mllwaukie and Mississippi Railroad to Janesville was celebrated yesterday at this place. A train of fifteen cars arrived here at 3 o'clock P. M. A large crowd had gathered at the dept, and great enthusiasm prevailed. CHARLES S. GORDON, on

FIRE.--Between 7 and 8 on Saturday evening, afire broke out in Central Hall, corner of South First and Fillh-streets, and in consequence of the building materially being of wood, was soon leveled to the ground. The building was owned by Mr. LEVI UFFORD, and was used as a Concert Hall and for Sunday services. Loss, $5,000--insured for $3,000 in the Citizens Insurance Company, at Williamsburg.

The procession has just moved from the City Hall for Lafayette-square in order of programme. The military escort is composed of the following companies: Ringgold Flying Artillery, Col. In addition to the California news which will be found on third page, we find in our exchanges the following items of interest. The steamer Sea Bird, at San Francisco, from San Diego, brought 27 passenger, and dates from Los Angeles to Dec. 4th,--two weeks later.

Messrs EDITORS: I send you the following subject to your own good will and pleasure in the premises. The subject to which I would call the attention of your readers, is the existence of a mountain of Marble in the Great Salt Lake Valley, situated on or near the road leading from said Lake to the intersection of the Fort Hall road, at Steeple Rocks. I find, by reference to my journal.

THOMAS F. MEAGHER repeats this evening at the Tabernacle, before the Mercantile Library Association, the brilliant lecture he delivered here some weeks since on Australia. He is sure of as large an audience as the building will hold. To-morrow evening, Lieut.

The Governor and seventy members of the Virginia Legislature, and the members of the Maryland Legislature, have arrived in this city, to join in the opening celebration of the Ohio Railroad to-morrow.

DARING ROBBERY.-Last Saturday night, at about 11 o'clock, two men (it is supposed) entered tho house of Mr. SOLEN, on the Plank road, some distance from Jersey City, and stole therefrom, a watch valued at $50, and two new coats worth $35, with which they, made their escape. The entrance was effected through: a back window, by cutting a hole in a pane of glass, with a diamond, and unfastening the sash from the inside.

The movements of the past week afford a pretty striking commentary on the progress of luxury-and may we not add questionable extravagancc--in this city and country. We do not remember when so many tall values and tinsel appliances have been recorded in the progress of importation and luxurious living in a single week.

We conclude this morning the translation of the political memoir prepared by M. DUPASQUIER DU DOMMARTIN, for the purpose of urging upon France the importance of Colonizing Northern Mexico, as a means of interposing a barrier to the ambitious designs of the United States.

FROM PORT AU-PLATTE.-BY the arrival of the brig Gipay, we have advices from Port-au-Platte of Dec.' 22, and Turks island Dec. 24. We have received the following information from Capt. BOYD, of the above vessel. Business was dull. Market stocked; the To. bacco season over. Gen. SANTA ANNA had been elected President. Several seamen from St. Thomas have died ofBlack vomit.

The Cleveland Herald has the following: " Pleasant, when the flagging is only six feet wide and the mud deep on either side, to meet a brace of individuals with thirty-six inch umbrellas spread, and who persist in walking abreast. We would suggest the establishment in all medical colleges of a chair for the express purpose of teaching students how to walk alone, single file, when occasion or courtesy demand it.

SEIZURE OF GUNPOWDER BY THE BROOKLYN FIRE WARDENS.--On Thursday last, Officer McNAMARA, of the Third District Police, arrested a man at the Hamilton-avenue Ferry, having in his possession two boxes of powder open. This was taken to the station-house of the Third District, when Assistant Captain McKINNEY, of that District, immediately transmitted a note to Mr. JOHN C. ROACH, one of the Fire Wardens, stating the facts.

The scheme of irritation and agitation which was concocted by the clique just expelled from Tammany Hall, and which they commissioned Mr. TAYLOR to execute, has just been renewed in the Assembly. A member from Broome County, impatient of the tardy progress of the bill proposed by Mr. TAYLOR, has introduced a series of resolutions denouncing the laws which forbld the holding of slaves by persona passing through the State. or sojourning within the State.

The brig Two Ladies, from Port-au-Platte, Dec. 20., arrived here this morning. Port. au-Platte is only about 25 miles from Samans, and the Captain reports that the story of its occupation by the French is without a shadow of foundation.

Senator BEEKMAN proposes to amend the Charter of this City, so as to give the MAYOR the absolute veto power. Probably nine out of ten of the intelligent portion of our citizens, who have given any special thought to the present condition of our City affairs, would welcome such a provision as a desirable barrier against the sweeping tide of corruption by which we are threatened.

TRIAL TRIP OF THE ERICSSON.--The pilot of the caloric ship Ericsson has filed in the office of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company the following certificate of the circumstances attending the recent experimental trip of the vessel: "This is to certify that on the 4th day of January, '53, I piloted the caloric ship Ericsson from Williamsburg. leaving there between 9 and 10 o'clock,

By the Nerthern Light we have news from Oregon as late as Dec. 4. THE IMMIGRATION.-The immigrants it is said are all, or neatly all, at the Dalles, and have entered the valley. A letter from Mr. WILLIAM B. AFFLECK, who went out with the Yamhill county relief expedition, gives the fullest information concernirng the immigrants that we have lately found.

The Ex-Governor, previous to returning to his old home in Niagara County, will spend the remainder of the winter in this city. He has apartments at present at the St. Nicholas Hotel; not the " Governor's Room," however, which is one of the prerogatives of his democratic successor.

Mr. FULLER, of Manchester, who was in the car at the time of the accident.

The R. M. Steamship America, with one week's later intelligence from all parts of Europe, arrived at this port at 12 o'clock to-day, having sailed from Liverpool at 10 A. M., on the 25th ult.

On Sunday morning, Jan. 9, EDWIN B. CLAYTON, in the 62 year of his age. The funeral will take place from his late residence, No, 419 Broome-st., on Tuesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock precisely. The relatives and friends are invited to attend without further in invitation.

Senator SEWARD, it is understood, will speak to-morrow on the Nicaragua Treaty, and in vindication of President TAYLOR'S administration, and Secretary CLAYTON from the attacks of Senator CASS and others.

The sad bereavement in the family of the President elect, reported the other day, brings to recollection a similar painful incident which occurred, with almost equal suddenness, amidst the congratulations that surrounded General JACKSON, as President elect, in the winter of 1828. Mrs. JACKSON was taken suddenly ill about the close of December, on the eve of her preparations for removing to Washington, and in a very few days was numbered among the dead.

EXPLOSION IN SOUTH ACTON, MASS.--The powder mill in South Acton, was destroyed by an explosion, about 10 o'clock on Friday morning. The following particulars we learn from a correspondent: The sound of the explosion was heard for several miles.

DANIEL WEBTER'S POSTHUMOUS PRESENT TO PETER HARVEY.-Just before Mr. WEBSTER'S death, he called his son FLETCHER to his bedside, and said, " My dear son, I wish you to procure a handsome and sub. stantial piece of silver plate, and present it to my valued friend, PETER HARVEY, with a suitable inscription, as a testimonial of my dying love for him."

The semi-monthly budget of news from CALIFORNIA is promptly to hand by the Nicaragua route. The treasure on the mail packet by the Isthmus will probably follow in a day or two. The amount on freight leaving San Francisco on the 16th Dec., is reported at two millions dollars.

The steamer Northern Light, Capt. THOS MINES, arrived at this port with passengers, to D. B. ALLEN, on Sunday, (yesterday morning.) The Northern Light left San Juan del Norte January 1, at 6 A. M., and arrived off Sandy Hook at 6 A. M, on 9th inst., with 247 passengers.

THE CASE OF WILLIAM W. WILSON. --Agreeably to postponement, the case of WILLIAM W. WILSON, charged with having in his possession certain bank-note plates, , for unlawful purposes, as already stated, came before the Police Court at 12 1/2 o'clock this after-noon, Judge RUSSELL on the Bench.

Multiply him by four, and the seat will hold no more. Multiply him by eight, and the omnibus is " full inside." He is wont to get the further corner seat, where, with his eyes turned upon something ahead, and that is only visible through the front window, he is quite sure not to see how much the woman with the baby in her arms is perplexed to find a sitting place.

BROADWAY.--BELLINI's beautiful opera of "La Sonnambula," in which two artistes make their first appearance in this country. Of course Madame ALBONI plays Amina, BARILI Count Rodolfo, Signor PELLIGRINI Elvino, and Madame SEIDENBERG Lisa. After the opera, the French troupe appear in the ballet of "Une Fete a Constantinople."

Last week was devoted at the Broadway to the Child of the Regiment, in which Madame ALBONI is admitted on all sides to have won a success of no equivocal character. The closing performance of this sprightly Opera was witnessed by another of the very full houses which have complimented and warmly and enthusiastically appreciated this ]ady's singing and acting, Her triumph has been, if not single handed, against, at least, one serious draw back.

Another ease of suicide has just occurred in this City, traceable directly to the influence of the spiritual rapping jugglery. A man named MATTHEY LANGDON, in respectable position and comfortable circumstances, lost a daughter, and was induced, through his grief at her death, to attend meetings of these persons who pretend to hold communication with the spiritual world.

By a tabular statement in the Whaleman's Shipping Last, we learn that near 79,000 barrels of sperm oil and over 84,000 barrels of whale oil have been brought into the United States during the year. Of this, 2,517 barrels of sperm came into the port of New-York, (most of it Suffolk County,) and about 7,700 of the whale.
The funeral of Master BENJAMIN PIERCE will take place here on Monday. We learn that Gen. PIERCE and his wife still remain at Andover. The Legislature adjourned this morning.

WRECK OF THE ERIE--SUBMARINE OPERATIONS.--In a recent conversation with Mr. QUIGLY, of Portland, In this county, who is associated with Mr. GREEN, the weli known diver, in the work of raising vessels by the sub-marine armor, we gathered some interesting particulars concerning the wreck of the Eric and the sub-marine operations.

The Montreal Gazette talks freely of the growth of that city. It says that even the dreadful conflagration of last July has only furnished occasion for fresh improvements. The poor wooden shanties which disfigured our older suburbs, have been destroyed, never to re-appear, and in their place have arisen neat brick houses, covered with metal,

We may now safely announce the complete success of the project of a united Administration. From the following arrangements it will be seen at once that all the supposed difficulties of the design have been met in such a way that the country does not lose the services of any considerable statesman, and that no sacrifice of dignity has been imposed on any statesman or any party.

The mail this evening brings New-Orleans papers as late as due. The High Court of Errors of Mississippi, has given orders to the Auditor of the State to pay the coupons of interest on the Planters' Bank Bonds, amounting to $45,000.

Satisfactory evidence having been exhibited to me that HERMAN ARNOLD HEINRICH RUNGE has been appointed Consul of Bremen at Indianoia, in the State of Texas, I do hereby recognise him as such, and declare him free be exercise and enjoy such functions, powers, and privileges as are allowed to the Consuls of the most favored nations in the United States.

The Court of Cassation has confirmed the sentences passed upon the thirty-two persons convicted of disarming and imprisoning two gendarmes, as related a short time since. The burgomaster and parish priest of the place are condemned to imprisenment for two years, and the others for shorter periods.

The trains conveying the excursionists to Wheeling for the opening celebration of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad left this morning at 9 o'clock. Bands of music were in the cars, which were handsomely decorated with flags, 'c.

The Piedmontese Gazette of the 16th contains the following notice: "Experience having shown that the commercial relations of Sardinia with Tunis were not sufficiently important to permit the continuation of the heavy sacrifices which the Treasury had imposed upon itself to establish a regular line of correspondence between the two countries by means of royal steamers, the Government has decided that, after the 1st January next, that correspondence shall cease.

The Moniteur contains a series of correspondence from Cayenne, addressed to the Government by the chiefs of the penitentiary establishment formed in that colony. The greater part of the dispatches is filled up with details of the arrangements made for the management of the prisoners.

From the Daily News. In foreign relations, there are indications of impending changes that will require in a Ministry adequate to the occasion far more than an average share of sagacious foresight and provident precautions for the future.

The city of Troy, one of the handsomest towns in the Union, is located at the head of navigation on the Hudson, and built upon a level plain, in the rear of which rises a continuous and commanding summit, known by the classic name of Mount lda.

The funeral services on the son of Gen. FRANK LIN PIERCE took place this morning at the house of Mr. AIKEN, in Andover. The attendance was large, embracing many of the citizens of Andover, the professors, and students of the seminary, and quite a number of the family relatives of Gen. PIERCE from this city.

People here are determined to believe that the recent regulation concerning the navigation of the Bosphorus refers only to the intermediate stations in the Straits. As the new law will not come into force until the 26th Feb., 1853, there will be time enough for learning its meaning.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I have read with much attention the Times report of the "Religious Freedom" meeting held on Friday evening, at Metropolitan Hall, and presided over by Mayor WESTERVELT, at which the case of the MADIAIS, said to be imprisoned for reading the Bible, was the topic of discussion and action.
COMMON COUNCIL --The regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening at the City Hall. the President of the Board, Alderman COMSTOCK, in the Chair.

The Valedictory Message of Gov. FRENCH, of Illinois is a document of fair length. The Governor opens by declaring that the meeting of the- General Assembly usually carries with it associations connected with the leading and most important interests of the State.
The Pacific Insurance Company of this city, having sunk 20 per cent. of its capital with all of its receipts for premiums, has resolved to close business and pay its debts.

The last degree of satisfaction appears to exist in England, with the balcyon promise of the coalition. Lord ABERDEEN, the Premier, notwithstanding the rancor of his earlier Toryism, answers perfectly to the British idea of a man for the time, his advocacy of the PEEL reformatory measures in 1846, having cured all previous delinquencies, and guaranteed his liberality for the future.

TEMPERANCE DEMONSTRATION.--Metropolitan Hall was filled last evening, by the friends of the Temperance cause, to listen to an address from JOHN B GOUGH. DODWORTH'S Band was in attendance, and discoursed excellent music.
We give this morning, in full, the exceedingly lucid argument of Mr. SEWARD, delivered in the Senate yesterday, upon the conduct of Mr. CLAYTON, in regard to the Nicaraguan Treaty.

It is composed of General RONCALI, President of the Council of Ministers and Minister of Foreign Affairs; General LARA. Minister of War; General MIRASOL, Minister of Marine; M. VAHEY, Minister of Justice; M. ARISTAZABAL, Minister of Finance; and M. LLORENTE, Minister of the Interior.

In its sitting of the 15th, the municipal council of Genoa unanimously adopted the proposal of the Chamber of Commerce, to contribute six millions of francs towards a railway going from the Sardinian frontier to the Lake of Constance, along the valley of the Rhine.
