We have a bright and beautiful day for the commemoration of the battle of New-Orleans; and it has been improved by the people here in masse. For the last three hours the Hotels and the Avenue have been quite deserted.

WILLIAM P. NEWTON and JOHN ROGERS were arrested in the State of Maine last week, and committed to jail in this city to-day, on suspicion of robbing several mails in this State recently. They will be exaimined on Wednesday.
The Board met pursuant to adjournment. On the call of the roll, a quorum having answered to their names, the proceedings of the preceding meeting were read and approved.

No sooner had His Imperial Majesty, the Emperor of the French, attained the summit of human power and felicity than a few incidents occurred to remind him that he is mortal, and that in all human greatness some alloy of our original infirmities will work its way.

A Berlin letter to the Times, under date of Dec. 17, says: The Emperor of Austria arrived here to-day, on a visit to this Court, accompanied by the King, who had gone nearly to the Saxon frontier to meet his youthful and Imperial guest.

NEW MEXICO, SANTA FE, Friday, May 27, 1852. SIR :--It may be well to promise that I consider it certain that some radical change must and will be made in the Government of this Territory sooner or later: that the people of the United States will not consent to bear this heavy burden, endlessly, without receiving the slightest return, and without even the possibility of bettering the condition of this people.

The first appearance of Madame SONTAG in Opera, in this country, was made last evening under the most favorable auspices. The established European fame of the prima donna, her success and popularity in the United States as a Concert singer, and the novelty of a debut in a favorite and fashionable amusement, drew together an audience before which any artist might have been proud to appear.

The Senate in secret session this afternoon, debated the question of removing the injunction of secrecy relative to the CLAYTON treaty, but came to no decision. The subject will probably be resumed tomorrow with closed doors.

The U. S. Mail steamship Humboldt, Capt. LINES, arrived of the Bar at midnight, and reached her wharf at an early hour yesterday morning. She left Havre on the 24th, and Cowes on the 25th ult., bringing the same dates as the America at Halifax.

From the London Daily News. English travelers in America-those of them who have had acquaintance with the statesmen of that country--have, for these five-and-twenty years past, been subject to a strange perplexity, whenever the foreign policy of either Great Britain or the United States was freely discussed.

The Message of the American President, though partially deprived of its importance by the period of its delivery, is invested, from the nature of its topics, with even unusual interest for English readers, and exhibits, if we may be allowed the criticism, a considerable improvement upon the traditional character of these documents in condensation and style.

We publish copious extracts from our foreign files by the Humboldt this morning, as they will be found of more than ordinary interest.

My correspondence, says a writer in the Times, has so long led you to believe that Austria had resolved to effect a compromise with Prussia, that the sudden journey of the Emperor to Berlin can hardly have taken you much by surprise. What has hitherto been obstinately denied here is at length tacitly acknowledged.

The Moniteur publishes a decree, instituting a committee for the purpose of examining the petitions addressed to the Emperor. It is to be composed of two masters of requests and six auditors, and presided over by a Counsellor of State Every week the President is to repair to the Tuilleries, and submit to the Chief of the State the result of the labors of that Committee, which is to be renewed every three months.

The White Water Valley (Ind.) Times says that William H. Oliphant was murdered on the morning of Wednesday, the 22d inst, on the White Water Canal, about four miles below the town of Harrison, in Hamilton County, Ohio. Capt. Oliphant commanded the Canal boat Enterprise, and on his way up, was met by the canal boat Metamora, Capt. Armstrong.

The Roman Journal of the 12th states that the Pope had appointed Monsignor ANTONIO MATENCRI to the vacant post of Director-General of the Police, with a right to participate in the deliberations of the Council of Ministers.

The steamship Humboldt arrived at this port early yesterday morning. She left Havre on the 24th, and Cowes on the 25th ult., bringing no later dates than the America. By her we receive full files in advance of the Boston steamer. We make copious extracts, which will be found to possess unusual interest.

Texas advices to the 30th ult. are received. Judge GAYLE died at Liberty, on the 19th. Hon. J. C. WILSON was a candidate for Congress in the Western District. The Brazos and Trinity rivers were very low.

In the House of Lords, on Monday, Dec. 20, the Earl of DERBY made the following explanation of the circumstances which had led to the resignation of the Government: It is unnecessary for me, my lords, to advert to the circumstances under which the Government advised the dissolution of Parliament, and to the declarations made previous to that dissolution with regard to the policy it was to pursue.

The Senate met on the 21st; M. MESNARD, First Vice-President, in the chair. The number of Senators was smaller than on the previous occasion, owing, it was thought, either to the unfavorable weather, or to the fites and hunts which are now making the old forest of Compiegne ring again.

The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania yesterday denied the injunction against the Franklin Canal Company, under whose charter the Pennsylvania section-from the town of Erie to the Ohio State line-of the Lake Shore Road was recently built, and is now being operated.
The steamer America arrived at this port from Cleveland, last evening, with a large load of live and dead hogs and left again at 4, this. P M., for Cleveland with freight and passengers.

The following vessels put in here yesterday. The brig Azalia, from Bonaire, with salt from New York, leaky, and with loss of sails, spars, The Panama, from St. Domingo for Boston, with a cargo of mahogany; lost sails, deck load, provisions,

DEMONSTRATION BY THE TEMPERANCE PEOPLE.--This evening the public demonstration takes place at: the Second Reformed Dutch Church, Wayne-street JOHN B. GOUGH, Dr. REX, of Hunterdon, and Rev. J. M. JOHNSON, of Morristown, N. J., will be present and address the meeting.
With the exception of two vessels, the Erzherzog Johann and the Hansa, the whole of the German fleet has passed out of the possession of the Bund.
Another State Educational Convention was held on the 28th ult., at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. Not much business was transacted, but the interchange of views cannot prove useless.

ALLEN, of Salem, for Secretary; FRANCIS MULFORD, of Camden, Engrossing Clerk; Mr. SMITH, of Sussex, Sergeant-at-Arms. House.--J. W. FENNIMORE, of Burlington, Speaker; Mr. DELIKER. of Somerset, Clerk;

Senator SOULE is expected to speak to morrow, or very soon, on the Cuban question. I am satisfied that he will take a position that is calculated greatly to surprise the country, which has looked upon him as the leading representative in Congress of the Cuban revolutionary movement. He will probably oppose all propositions by the United States to purchase Cuba,

The completion of the British Ministry presents us with an array of talent, such as the Queen has seldom enjoyed in her Councils. Halifax papers of the 9th inst., have come to hand by the America. The steamer Merlin from St. Johns, Newfoundland, had arrived, bringing the agent of the New York Crystal Palace Exhibition--who reports that Newfoundland will be well represented. It is thought that the inhabitants and the legislature together will raise o500 for the purpose.

We are neither surprised nor disappointed by this first complete novel from the skillful pen of the author of Vanity Fair. We knew the level below which the genius of Mr. THACKERAY would not fall, and above which its wings are not solicitous to soar.

The Charleston Standard traces the prevalence of Cholera in that city to the oysters which are brought to market from out of brackish instead of salt water; and a short time since a Florida paper was persecuting the harmless bivalves as the authors of the Cholera at Apalachicola.

Changes of dynasties,--the transformation of civil governments,--the rearing or the razing of Empires,

On Monday, 27th, Liverpool was visited with the most violent gale that had been felt for years. The gale commenced on Sunday night, from the south-west, and reached its height Monday morning Considerable damage was done to the shipping, and it is feared that further disasters will be reported.

The "Meagher Club" gave a ball and supper at Niblo's Garden on Monday night, which THOS. F. MEAGHER attended, Immediately after delivering his lecture on Australia before the Mercantile Library Association. A magnificent supper was provided at 1 o'clock.

General PIERCE left the Eagle Hotel, for Andover, in the 10 o'clock train this morning. He obtained a comfortable night's rest at Mr. WILLIAMS'S, his old boarding house-resting more quietly than during any night since the accident. He was greatly prostrated by the melancholy duties of yesterday, and suffered considerably also from the strains and bruises which he sustained. .

A little daughter of Webster Clark, of Six Mile Falls, Me., aged five years, was so shockingly burn by her clothes, which were of cotton. taking fire as she was passing the fire-place, on the 6th inst., that she lived but nine hours after the accident.

Governor STERLING PRICE, of Missouri, delivered his Inaugural Address to the Missouri Legislature on the 27th of Dec. He said that the Convention that nominated him laid down its platform with great distinctness, and by his election, the people endorsed that platform.

The success of the new Motor invented by Capt. ERICSSON was yesterday exhibited for the first time in presence of a select company of invited guests. NATHAN TROTTER, a merchant of this City, died this morning. A large quantity of stolen jewelry, recently recovered by the Police of this City, has been identified as a part of that plundered from the store of D. B. CASTLE, watchmaker, Buffalo, in August last. t.

The Broadway management, on very short notice, last evening substituted the Child of the Regiment, with the popular cast of last week, for the Sonnambula given over on account of the failure of the new tenor on Monday night.

In Williamsburg, of consumption, on Monday, Jan 10, Mrs. MARY ANN, wife of Asa S. Crosby, aged 39 years. The Funeral will take place from St. Mark's Church, South at 2 o'clock. P.M. The friend's of the family are invited to attend without further invitation.

A large number of petitions were presented. Mr SUMNER presented memorials of steamboat owners in Boston, asking compensation for services rendered during the storm in that harbor last year. Mr. JONES presented joint resolutions of the Iowa Legislature asking for land for Railroads in that State.

We conclude this morning the publication of the Report from the Bank Department. We have drawn largely upon the tables of the report, with the purpose to present at one view the ten years progress in Bank expansion in the State of New-York,

The Baltic arrived yesterday morning bringing interesting news to the 29th ult....We have the complete list of the new British Ministry, and the nominating heir to the Imperial throne of France; a revolution in Albania ; intelligence from the Cape of Good Hope, saying that the war is at an end; advices, only 75 days old, brought by the colonial built ship Marco Polo from Australia,

New-York and Washington. An announcement appears in the Republic, with the signatures of the managing officers of the several railroads between this city and Washington, appended, stating that provision has been made against further delays

The Massachusetts Legislature in convention today, filled the twenty-two vacancies in the Senate with Whigs, which makes that body stand thirty two Whigs and eight Opposition, and gives the Whigs a majority of forty-three on joint ballot. Mr. CLIFFORD will probably be chosen Governor tomorrow.

The Baltic arrived at this port yesterday morning. She left Liverpool at noon on Wednesday, the 20th ult. In running down channel encountered thick weather. with a very severe south west gale. She was twenty-six hours reaching Tuskar, and forty-two to Cape Clear.

KING, and the latter's letter to Mr. CLAYTON. The amount of it is, that Mr. KING never having seen the declaration attached to the treaty in point, understood that it acknowledged the right of England to British Honduras,

There was a large and respectable audience in the Meehanies' Hall, last evening, to hear the last lecture of the Course, by Rev. E. H. CHAPIN. Mr. BUNTING, the Chairman, announced that arrangements had been made for a second Course, to be continued on Monday evenings. .

We see by the Buffalo Courier that it is in contemplation to found an Agricultural Department for the University of Buffalo. The thought is to endow seven Professorships through Scholarships at $150 each. The interest of these Scholarships only to he used, while the interest is to remain in perpetuity.

PARMELE HARVEY, situated in East Thirty-third-street, between Second and Third-ave., consisting of three large brick buildings.

The two Houses of the New-Jersey Legislature organized this afternoon. In the Senate, Col. WILLIAM C. ALEXANDER, Dem., of Mercer, was appointed President, L. A. ALLEN, Dem., of Salem, Secretary, GEORGE T. SMITH, Dem., of Sussex, Sergeant-at-Arms , and FRANCIS D. MULFORD, Dem., of Camden, Engrossing Clerk.

The Military Convention met in Market Hall, at 11 o'clock this morning. Gen. SWAN, of Rochester, was chosen President, and made an appropriate speech. Two Vice-Presidents and three Secretaries were chosen. After prayer by Rev. Mr. SUNDERLAND, Chaplain of the Fifty-first Regiment, it was resolved to organize the Convention into a State Society, and a Committee of seven was appointed to draft a Constitution. .

A cask of gunpowder was lately shipped from Boston in a small sailing craft, to be carried to one of the Islands for use in blasting. The crew of the vessel supposing it to be a cask of crackers, placed it close to a hot stove, where it remained for the entire passage without accident.

THE RISING GENERATION.--Though not tenacious of antiquated customs, on looking around and comparing the present with the past, we are not surprised at the ludicrous expression of a worthy old lady when she thought of the spanning-wheel which had given place to the plane--"Times is not as they used to was." The fact is, juvenile progress has been so astonishing for a few years.

MR. EDITOR: I am one of those unfortunate individuals, who, without knowing the character, disposition, and habits of coolies, have engaged their services for five years. It is now fully ascertained and admitted, that they are very generally, if not universally, a troublesome set of fellows.

THE WEATHER YESTERDAY.-At an early hour yesterday morning, Winter, which had deferred his visit so long, made his appearance. At first, a hail storm rattled over the City; then came a little snow and a great deal of wind, which state of things continued till the middle of the afternoon, when the snow began to fall in large quantities. THE LOSS OF WHALING SHIP SUPERIOR.--A letter from Cape Prince Wales, Behring's Straits, dated Aug. 11, 1852, gives an account of the loss of ship superior, on a small island (six miles long, and about twenty rods wide) in the Anadir Sea. at the month of the Gulf of the Holy Cross, and about half a mile from the coast of Siberia, on the 11th July.

The Military Convention reassembled at 9 o'clock this morning. Col. SCROGGS asked, Was it a Convention or an Association? The PRESIDENT decided it was a Convention until another organization was effected. Col. SCROGGS stated that the compensation to soldiers was insufficient.

Notice has been already taken of the shock of an earthquake, and a singular phenomenon which took place a little before midnight of Wednesday last, at Lake Merced. Before this phenomenon occurred, the lake was a beautiful sheet surrounded mostly by a fine amphitheatre of hills. It is located about seven miles from this city in a southwesterly direction, and covers a surface of about thirty acres.

LATER FROM TEXAS.--We have received Texas dates to the 30th ult.: The Western Texan says the Assistant Quartermaster at San Antonio, has received orders to hold himself in readiness to remove his depot to Indianola. Columbia, Dec. 8 -- All through Brazoria County, sugar making is progressing rapidly, and the yield of cane is abundant.

MERCANTILE LIBRARY ASSOCIATION.-THEIR REMOVAL UP-TOWN.-It has been reported that the Mercantile Library Association had purchased the Astorplace Opera House for $150,000, for the use of the Society's Library. This is not exactly so.

NATIVE TREES.-There is many a good, honest farmer, whose dwelling stands bare as a lighthouse upon an ocean rock, exposed to every wind that blows, and every ray of sun that a merciless mid summer day pours down on its devoted walls and windows. The very chickens cannot find a shrub to shelter them, without making a journey of half a mile.

The Washington people are in ecstacles with the Equestrian Statue of Gen. JACKSON. Mr. MILLS, the young artist whose genius and industry have produced it, is named in the same sentence with classical names and though put last, he is definitely said not to be the least.

Besides a large train of courtiers that went out with hin, we hear every day of some minister, prince, or senator, who snatches a vacation from his official duties or city pleasures and rides out there for a few days shooting in the country. A letter from Bermuda, dated December 27, from Capt. DENNIS, of the schooner Sarah and Lucy, of Boston, reports that he put into that port after a succession of gales, which rendered the vessel a wreck, and she was abandoned to the underwriters, both vessel and cargo. She was nearly a new vessel, with a fall cargo, and was bound to Port-au-Prince.

FEMALE ACADEMY.-The stockholders of this Academy (destroyed by fire on the 1st inst.,) held a meeting at the Brooklyn Institute, Tuesday evening, to coneider the erection of a new building. Mrs. PACKER,, who owns a large property on the Heights, made a prop. position to endow an Institution with $65,000--$30,000 in money and the balance In property, and the meeting adjourned to consider, relative to the matter.

Pursuant to notice given by private circulars, to some five or six hundred of the most influential gentlemen, residing in various parts of the city, a large and respectable meeting was held last evening at the Stuyvesant Institute, for the purpose of taking action to remedy the corruption of the present City Council.

PENSYLVANIA COMMON SCHOOLs.-The Superintelsoent of the Common schools of Pennsuivania, reports that the number of pupils at the schools in the State is 491.G679; number of dis. tries 1,498: schools 9,699.

governor MOCLELLAND, of Michigan, sent his Annual Message to the Legislature last week. He reminds them that during the present session it will be their duty to elect a United States Senator. He speaks with encouragement of the financial condition of the State. With economy, the public debt will be liquidated in a few yearn.

The U. S. Mail steamrship Illinois, HARTSTEINE, from Aspinwall, with the mails and passengers from San, Francisco, the 16th nilt., is at anchor at the S. W. Spit, disabled of her larboard engine. Capt. YATES, of the steam tug Achilles, went to her assistance yesterday, and while in the act of towing her up to her anchor parted her steering gear, which accident was remedied by shipping a tiller in her rudder head.

The Consulate rendered vacant by the demise of the late T. B. LIVINGSTON, Esq, has been filled by B. HAMMATT NORTON, Esq., U. S. Consul at Pictou, N. S., who has been directed by the State Department to extend his jurisdiction over the whole Province.

Mr. Saxe, the able and very agreeable editor of the Burlington, Vt., Sentinel. holds a free and good natured talk with his readers, which be concludes thus: "Some are indebted to us for two, three, and even four years' subscription Pray, look up your receipts, ascertain the amount and send it along. Do your duty, and we will do ours, and do it with a zeal and cheerful heart.

Mr. VANDERBILT presented a memorial from the Atlantic Dock Company, for a grant of land under water. Also, of the Brooklyn Savings Bank, for authority to purchase stock. Mr. BARTLETT made a report on the subject of causes and the statistics of railway accidents. Referred to the Railway Committee.
Mr. NEWALL, of West Cambridge, who was injured by the late accident on the Boston and Maine Railroad, died at the residence of his son, in Lawrence, yesterday.

The number of deaths during the year 1851 was 18,934. which is 15 per cent, over the mortality of 1850; the latter, however, was a year of unusual health. The average of deaths was one to fifty-one and ninety-eight hundreths (51 98) of the population, or less than two per cent.

"How shall we manage to get small change?" is the inquiry that comes out of all mouths, about as frequently as bread and butter enters the mouth of the lad on the holiday when he has "the run" of the milk-room.

A Relief Association has been for some time under way in the City of Cleveland, its object being the succor of the Poor during the inclement season. The Executive Committee, in announcing this plan for the present Winter, adduce some startling facts, equaled only by the misery and destitution of New-York.

UNCLE TOM'S CABIN.--The sale of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," is prodigious. Five of the journals are now publishing it as a feuilleton. The future French opinions on American Slavery will be based on Mrs. STOWE's book.--Paris Cor. of the Pieayune.

SLEIGHING IN NEW-YORK.--The streets of New - York were all alive yesterday with merry sleigh riders. The omnibus proprietors, who had began to think that their yearly sleighing harvest would fail, got out their gaily painted and mammoth sized sledges; the hack-men betook themselves to runners, as did also the milkmen, cartmen, and grocers.

Several appointments by the new ABERDEEN Ministry are published. Among them Villiers for Judge Advocate; Hayter, Secretary of the Treasury; Sir W. Page Wood, Vice Chancellor; Admiral Berkley, one of the Lords of the Admiralty; Lord Drumlanrig, Controller of the Household; Monsell, Clerk of the Ordinance.

By comparing the Massachusetts Report of Births, , for 1851, with the United States Census for 1840, the increase of population during the last decade is ascertained to be 256,814, equal to 34.81 per cent. The County of Middlesex shows the largest Increase, which is near 51 1/2 per cent. Next follows Suffolk, with an increase of near 51 per cent.

The mischief that a work is capable of doing, when it is suffered to become the vehicle of unexposed errors, is proportioned to the reputation it may have attained for accuracy in matters of fact.

The operations of the French under the Count RAGUSSET in Sonora, have not only affected the interests of that particular State, but in consequence of the disastrous appearance of political affairs in that unhappy country, is really an object of interest to us as well as to Mexico, and particularly to California.

THE MARRIAGE OF MISS GOODENOW, THE ALLEGHANIAN.--MISS GOODENOW was married to Mr. ROBB of Sacramento, at Sonora, about the 1st of December. The Sonora Correspondent of the Republican says: "This marriage was kept a profound secret for a while, on account of engagements having already been made by the troupe for several concerts, in which she, as Miss GOODENOW, was advertised to appear.

Dr. Bethune's Reply to P. Lynch, Esq. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The very courteous tone of the remarks made by Mr. LYNCH, (of The Irish American,) on my speech of last Friday evening, compels me to answer so gentlemanly an inquirer; nor can I refuse acknowledgment of my regret that any language I felt myself obliged to hold, has given him pain.

Boss.--English writers say that the republicans of this country have such an aversion to the word master, that they say boss instead of it. Out West, we learn that a "Master in Chancery" is called a "Boss in Chancery." The above extract shows how much one is influenced by a mere name.

STEAMBOAT DISASTER ON THE MISSISSIPPI -- The St. Louis Intelligencer has the particulars of the disaster of which we had an announcement by telegraph: Yesterday afternoon the mammoth steamer John Simonds, while in the act of rounding out from the Portland wharf, collapsed the flues of one or two of her boilers, and created the greatest consternation among the crew, several of whom jumped overboard and were drowned.

MR. WEBSTER ON PSALMS.-DANIEL WEBSTER was particularly pleased with those Psalms and Hymns by Dr. WATTS, which dwelt upon the atonement and salvation by faith in CHRIST. He regretted the modern alteration in some of them, by which, he said, their classic beauty, not less than their devotional character, has suffered.

It is understood that the nomination of Mr. BADGER will be called up in Executive Session to-morrow. Whig Senators, to day, express the hope of confirming the appointment. Meanwhile the following dispatches have been received by a member of Congress from reliable parties in Mobile.

A GANG OF BURGLARS BROKEN UP.--FIVE PERSONS ARRESTED--PROPERTY RECOVERED, the 3d of Nov. last, the dry goods store of Messrs. DRLAND SONS, No. 196 Fulton street, and on the 5th of Dec. the dry goods store of Mr. CROCHERON, No. 156 Atlantic street, were entered by burglars, and robbed-- the former of about $800 worth of goods, and the latter of about $500 worth.

The mail is through from New-Orleans. The papers contain the details of the news received from Tampico to the 27th ultimo. Among the leading officers of the regular Army who had pronounced in favor o the revolution, were COLS, CASANOVA, CRUZ and TENORIO.

ENOUGH TO BREAK ON.--Mr. HINE, in writing to the Nonpareil, from Zanesville, tells the following of a rich father and son: "Zanesville is rapidly growing in the corruptible--in wealth and all its concomitants.

Liverpool Cotton Market. The Cotton market had been dull all the week, and prices favored buyers, but quotations were only partially lowered to the extent of 1-16d. on American descriptions. The sales of Friday were 4 000 bales; and for the week they footed up 36 700, including 1,400 on speculation, and 450 bales for export.

INSANITY AND ATTEMPTED SUICIDE.--On Wednesday, at about 11 P.M. a German morocco dresser, residing at No 36 James street, made a desperate attempt to commit suicide by leaping out of the attic window of his house and striking his head upon a stick of timber, causing severe Injuries.

BOARD OF CHOSEN FREEHOLDERS.--This body held a meeting at Bergen Court House on the 12th inst. Various bills of various amounts were ordered paid, and the following, among other resolutions, were offered, discussed and adopted: That twenty two new cells be constructed in Bergen Jail, over the three tiers lately raised, under the direction of a Committee--which was appointed.

DISPENSARY.--At a meeting of the Board of of Trustees of the Williamsburg Dispensary, held last evening; Dr. HARDCASTLE made the following report of the number of cases treated for the month ending December: Whole number of patients treated, 337.

About 10 o'clock on Monday night, a colored man, named Summerfield Young, was found a dying condition, on the Davement in Haltimore. On discovering him, the watchman recognized him as a slave belonging to Mr. Morris, and he accordingly informed his master of the circumstances, and had him conveyed into the house.

Appeal from the District Court of the United States for the District of Texas. L. Sherwood, of New-York, and W. G. Snethen, of Washington, D. C., for Appellants; Hon. Volley E. Howard, of Texas, for Appellee.

Gen. FLORES has undertaken another expedition against Ecuador, if the telegraph may be believed. Say not, careless reader, What of that! You will find there will be a great deal of that before we are through with it. Firstly, the statement will be contradicted. Secondly, it will be reaffirmed with a circumstance.

We do not know whether the name of ROBERT F. STOCKTON is upon any conjectural list of the PIERCE Cabinet, as Secretary of the Navy. If not, let it be put there forthwith. The Captain has sensible views of that institution, He is a young fogy. He is one of the very few who sport an epaulet on either shoulder, who listen to the word reform without asphyxia.
Mr. GWIN'S speech to-day on the Pacific Railroad was forcible and interesting. The bill will not pass in its present shape, but there is every indication that some measure to build the road will.

The case of RACHEL PARKER, the petitioner for her freedom. she having been kidnapped in Pennsylvania, was decided in her favor yesterday, the respondent abandoning the case. The citizens of Chester County, Penn., offered a reward of $1,000 for the apprehension of the murderers of JOSEPH C. MILLER, who assisted in the capture of RACHEL, and was shortly afterwards found dead in the woods near Stemmer's Run.

The Coroner is engaged this morning investigating the murder of JOSEPH RINK. A number of persons were examined who saw the man running from the store; and a man answering the description given was arrested last evening, but discharged, not being identified.
NIBLO'S.--Madame SONTAG has entirely re-covered from her indisposition, and appears this evening in "The Child of the Regiment," the last time it will be performed by the NIBLO troupe.

A POOR CRITTER.--"Long time ago" in New England, dwelt a lady equally renowned for piety, credulity, and courage. As she was in the habit of returning from meeting unattended, some wild fellows formed a project for frightening her, and furnishing themselves with a little pleasant amusement.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a communication from the War Department, with a statement of the expenditure of that department for 1852. Mr. SMITH presented a memorial of 1,000 citizens of Connecticut, setting forth the claims of Doctor WELLS, as the discoverer of the anesthetic agent.
A MODEL LETTER.--The Postmaster at Nacogdoches, Texas, has received a letter of which the following is a literal copy. The Chronicle publishes it for the benefit of the party concerned.

COLTS.--The breaking of a colt should be commenced before he is twenty four hours old. Handle him frequently--make a pet of him. Bridle him when young, and the Winter when he is two years old, place a wagon-saddle on his back, and buckle the girth loosely.

One day last week, a serious accident occurred in the family of one of our citizens, from the burning fluid within a lamp taking fire, when the lighted match touched the wick. The top of the lamp was tightly screwed on, and all proper precautions taken to prevent harm, except that the wick was rather too small for the tube.

From a Private Correspondent at Panama. The steamship Columbus arrived at Panama on the 19th, in 19 days from San Francisco. She reports the United States sloop-of-war Portsmouth at San Diego. Spoke and was boarded by the whale-ship Marengo, of New-Bedford, off Cape St Lucas--one year out, with 1,400 barrels of oil. Passed a clipper-ship, bound up, in latitude 12[degrees] 22', longitude 89[degrees] 52'.

THE NEW STEAMBOAT LAW.--The St. Louis Intelligencer says that the new law appears to meet with but little favor anywhere, and its usefulness or practicability, as we have heretofore stated, is very much doubted.

MISSISSIPPI BONDS--HIGHLY IMPORTANT DECISION.--We understand that the High Court of Errors and Appeals has just made a decision which virtually sets at rest the question of the legality of the Planter's Bank bonds.

The meeting held on Wednesday evening, the proceedings of which were reported in the Times of yesterday, promises to be of essential service to the cause of City Reform. It was well attended, and the gentlemen prominent in its deliberations are among our most influential and intelligent citizens.

Snow fell here for twenty-four hours, and is now about twenty inches deep. The train on the Erie Railroad have been greatly delayed, and the freight trains are scattered along the road wherever the storm overtook them.

At the hour of going to press, the storm continues. Not much snow is falling, but the sky is stil overcast. The mails are all behind--the Railroads, to a considerable extent, being blocked up with snow. No Philadelphia trains arrived in Jersey City from 51/2 o'clock P. M. on Wednesday, until noon yesterday.

The following is a full and corrected report of the remarks of Judge VANDERPOOL, at the City Reform meeting, on Wednesday evening. Judge VANDERPOOL said he did not come here to cast imputations upon any man or body of men.

DEATH OF HORACE B. WALLACE.--W laarn, with deep regret, by a private letter from a friend in Philadelphia, that HORACE BINNEY WALLACE, Esq., a young lawyer of that city, and nephew of the eminent jurier and statesman, the Hon. HORACE BINNEY lately died very suddenly at Paris.

The Editor of the Chicago Tribune discourseth pleasantly of a New Year present he has received: We found in our Sanctum on New Year's day, standing on our new carpet, (that generous gift,) Rear a shelf of new books. (holiday presents,) a New Arm-Chair. Evidently designed for the Editor of a Newspaper.

The Hon RICHARD YATES, of Illinois, de clines to be a candidate for relation to Congress, in 1853. He a sensible man, and here is his card: To my fellow-citizens of the Sixth Congressional District: I avail myself of this early opportunity to announce to my fellow citizens that I shall not be a candidate for reelection to Congress in 1854.

A very interesting and important decision of a legal question in the Supreme Court of the United States will be found given at length in another part of this morning's Times. The facts of the case out of which it grew have been already stated in this paper.

From the London Spectator. A fortnight since, we drew attention to various indications in the declarations of leading politicians, in special measures of acknowledged importance, and in physical and social phenomena not of man's contrivance and beyond his control, of a possible and probable union of the Liberal party in England on the question of Representative Reform.

MARRIAGES IN AUSTRALIA.--It appears that the male and female convicts obtain certain privileges, which wonderfully promote matrimony. A correspondent writes to the Alta California from Van Diemans Land!

The letter from the "Editor of the Irish American," published in our columns on Tuesday, seems every way manly and sensible; and it finds a reply, equally manly and equally sensible, in the letter from Rev. Dr. BETHUNE, published in another column of this morning's Times.

THE SNOW STORM IN NEW-YORK.--Yesterday, everything continued to wear the happy, half-holiday appearance which the fall of the snowy flake brings along; nor wasthe "good time" less keenly enjoyed, because it had been so long "coming." The frosted snow that crusted and shrouded up the face of Nature, expanded the heart and made rubicund the countenance of her "lord."

Horse-shoe nails, kicked about the world by horses innumerable, are not the useless frag ments we might naturally deem them. Military men may discuss the relative merits of Minie rifles and needle guns, but we all agree that the material of which the barrels are made should be sound and tough; gun-makers tell us no iron is so well fitted for this purpose as that which is derived from horse-shoe nails and similarly worn fragments.

From the Alta California. If the Isthmus were nothing more than a sterile Waste; studded here and there with lofty hills shorn of all verdure, it would still be an object of great commercial value. But its physical character is precisely the reverse. From the time of its discovery, it has always been believed and asserted that it contains a large amount of mineral wealth.

The CHAIR presented the credentials of Hon. JOHN M. CLAYTON, Senator elect from Delaware, for six years from the 4th of March next. Mr. WALKER presented a memorial of Clerks in the Treasury, praying that the additional allowance of 20 per cent. be continued them next year.

THE RAILROADS.--ARRIVALS OF TRAINS YESTERDAY.--On the New-Jersey roads, the trains experienced but little detention. One train from Newburg and Ramapo came in on the Eric Railroad, reaching here about 11 o'clock A. M.; but at a late hour last evening no through train (as it was stated at the depot,) had arrived during the day. On the Hudson River

EXPLOSION AND LOSS OF LIFE.--The steam packet Fusilier, Capt DENSLOW, which left New-Orleans on Sunday, Jan. 2, bound to Attakapas, burst her boilers yesterday morning, at 5 o'clock, when off Ship Island, killing outright JOSEPH SOLE, first mate, J. MCCULLOUGH, the second engineer, and five of the hands, Capt. DENSLOW is badly wounded, having received a compound fracture in his left thign, his shoulder dislocated, and otherwise injured.

FRUIT AND SHADE TREES--The following sensible article is from the Stockton Journal: "It is to be regretted that so little attention is being paid to the planting of permanent shade and fruit trees in this State, where such things are so absolutely necessary.

With Gibraltar and Malta in her hands, England did not consider her ocean influence sufficiently extensive in the Mediterranean. The possession of these only prepared her for a further assertion of her predominance in that quarter--the taking possession of the seven Ionian Islands.

The snow storm ceased this morning, and about noon indications of sunshine were manifest. A foot of snow fell on the level, and in some places it has badly drifted. The steamboat train, via Stonington, arrived at 9 o'clock this morning, the boat having reached Stonington at 6 o'clock last evening.

Senator UPHAM died at his lodgings in the Irving House at 11 o'clock, this morning, of varioloid, after about ten days sickness, aged 58 years. He died easily and calmly. His wife arrived from Vermont a few days since, and was with him when ho died.

From the London Spectator. The estimable ladies who have hold a species of public meeting on American affairs in an exclusive and carpeted saloon of Stafford House, have suffered Lord SHAFTESBURY to lead them into a false position. In the name of benevolence he appealed

From the Boston Journal, 13th. A very severe northeast gale commenced last evening, and it continued to blow very hard during the night. Towards morning snow began to fall, and it has continued through the day, but is greatly drifted. The vessels on the coast must have had an unpleasant and perilous time.

Governor CLIFFORD was sworn into office before both branches of the Legislature, at noon to day, after which he delivered his Annual Message. He begins by alluding to the deaths of distinguished men during the past year: FOWLER, THOMPSON and RANTOUL, of Massachusetts, and WEBSTER and CLAY of the Nation.

We would possess our souls in patience, -- but the little rascals ought to be tutored. We would not lose our temper, but the men that engage in it, ought to be dealt with. Yesterday was a great day among the boys. Every sleigh that passed a company of them, received a volley of snow-balls.

ATTEMPTED MURDER OF A WHOLESALE MERCHANT, BY A NEGRO--ESCAPE OF THE VILLAIN.--Yesterday evening, at about 6 1/2 O'clock, a daring attempt was made to take the life of HENRY HAYDOCK, Esq., of the firm of HAYDOCK, CLAY EVANS, extensive importers of drugs and chemicals, at No. 218 Pearl-street.

PROJECTED RAILROAD FROM ST. LOUIS TO MINNESOTA.--This Railroad projected by the citizens of St. Louis to run through Iowa to Minnesota, with the design of rendering the vast territory embraced between the Missouri and Mississippi rivers as well as the portion of Minnesota lying East of the latter river, tributary to that city, meets with but little sympathy in this State.

Issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending Jan. 11, 1853, and bearing date Jan. 11, 1853. Thomas Baylis and Daniel Williams, of Tecumseh, Michigan.--For improvements in rakes to harvesters. Nathan Chapin, of New-York, N. Y.--For improvement in lathes for turning interior and exterior surfaces.

Hon. HENRY BARNARD, of Conn., is delivering a course of Lectures here before the Smithsonian Institue on Education. As they relate to a topic of universal interest and importance, and embody the views of a gentleman of more than ordinary ability and experience, the readers of the Times may be glad to receive such general outlines of them as shall indicate the sentiments they present.

THE CHILDREN OF OUR GREAT POETS.--It is impossible to contemplate the early death of Byron's only chill without reflecting sadly on the fates of other families of our greatest poets. Shakspere and Milton each died without a son, but both left daughters, and both names are now extinct. Shakspere's was soon so.

The municipal authorities of Paris, says a correspondent, are actively engaged in directing the levelling of the different streers which run into the new Rue de Rivoli. Workmen are employed in demolishing the houses on each side of the Rue St. Martin, in order that from the Quai to the Rue des Lombards it shall have a uniform width of 20 metres, and be on a level with the Rue de Rivoli.

There is a jail down East so "shabby," that the prisoners are ashamed of it. One day a great rogue told the keeper that if he didn't get it fixed, he would break out and "thrash" him. Fine place that for the encouragement of honesty.

THE LIQUOR TRADE IN BANGOR.--The Bangor Democrat publishes the report of the Committee of the Bangor City Council on the business of the City Agency for selling liquor, and adds: "It appears to be a large, prosperous, and profitable business.
Mr. BAILEY, who was injured by the Railroad disaster at Andover, died this morning at Lawrence. This is the third death. Mr. KITTRIDGE is said to be improving.

The Legislature commenced its session on Tuesday, and notice was given that a substitute to the Maine Law would be presented on Thursday, by Mayor BRASTOW. Much anxiety is felt in the community in relation to the proposed measure, and the Hall of the House was crowded at an early hour.

The religious societies have recently been aided to a remarkabir extent by the liberal bequests and donations of their friends, The late MARK II. NEWMAN, Esq, of this city, by his will left twenty-five thousand dollars in trust to the American Home Missionary Society, ten thousand dollars to the American Board, and has made the former his residuary legatee.

Hon. WILLIAM UPHAM, one of the United States Senators from the State of Vermont, died at Washington yesterday. He had been lil for some weeks of erysipelas. He was a man of fair abilities, and previous to his entering upon political life, he had a large law practice, and enjoyed a high reputation in his own State, especially as a jury lawyer.

LIQUID GLUE--A strong liquid glue, that will keep for years without changing, may be made by placing in a glazed vessel a quart of water and about three pounds of harp glue. This is to be melted over a gentle fire in a glue-pot, and stirred up occasionally.

DEATH FROM RAILROAD INJURIES.--Thursday afternoon Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest at the New York Hospital, on the body of a young man, by the name of CORNELIUS GRIMBY, who died from injuries received Christmas day on the Paterson Railroad, near Bergen Hill The Jury rendered a verdict "That the deceased came to his death by a concussion of the brain, from injuries accidentally received on the Paterson Railroad, 25th ult."

Since the feverish excitement arising from the rejection of the loan made in Europe for the government, men look about themselves with more calm, and find the ship of state sailing along in tolerably smooth water, just as if there had been no storm.

We have had much fine music this week. Two Opera houses in full operation, and both crowded with a population rapidly growing fastidiously musical in their tastes. It is almost a source of general regret--it should be we think--that we have two great favorites at the same time. The conflicts of interest, and the templation to popular comparison is unpleasant.

SPASMS BEFORE BRANDY.--The following anecdote was told of a very clever fellow, who has been somewhat frolicksome, but who had recently joined the Sons of Temperance. After becoming a "Son," he went to Mohile on business, and was taken sick there.

A MAN OF ENERGY.--At the Cambridge Cattle Market, last week, there was seen a forcible illustration of the capability of man to overcome physical disabilities. A Vermonter, who, from his birth, has been deprived of the use of his lower limbs, came down with a car load of cattle to sell.

" Marriage is honorable," saith the Scripture, "and profitable for the state," say all wise men who eschew Malthus and his atrocities. A married man has motives to honorable exertions and for living wisely, that bachelors cannot find.

THEOLOGICAL PROFESSOR IN ROCHESTER UNIVERSITY.--We understand that Rev. E. G. ROBINSON, of Cincinnati, has accepted the Theological Chair at the University of Rochester, tendered him by a Committee appointed at the late session of the "Board of the Ministerial Union."

RAILROAD ACCIDENTS.--The past week has been fruitful in railroad accidents,--hardly a day having passed that we were not called upon to notice some loss of life, either from carelessness of passengers, mismanagement on the part of the operators, or some defect in the iron works.

THE LIFE OF SIR WALTER SCOTT. By DONALD MACLROD. 1 vol. CHAS. SCRIBNER. What! we think we hear the critic exclaim. What! a new life of Sir WALTER! Pooh! isn't there LOCKHART? To this question we feel bound to reply in the affirmative.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE.--A young lady named JANE PECK, residing in York street, near Gold, attempted to commit suicide on Thursday evening, by taking an overdose of laudanum. She retired to her sleeping apartment at an early hour in the evening, and locked the door, and from some of her actions previous, the lady of the house was induced to visit the room.

From persons who have recently visited the other islands, we learn with pleasure that the crops are looking well, and will be ready for grinding in about six weeks. The amount of canes to grind this year is small, compared with what it will be next. Hundreds of acres having been recently planted, which will require a twelvemonth to come to maturity. TEXAS ITEMS.--by the arrival of the steamship Texas, Capt. LAWRENCE, we have received Galveston papers to the 31st ult., one day later than those brought by the Mexico. The following is from the News: On Tuesday evening last Dr. GRANT, whose residence is near Washington, on the Brazos, was shot in Houston by Mr. ANSELEM HUDSON, who was acting as barkeeper in the Houston House.

RELIGIOUS MEETINGS--During the past month meetings have been held every evening on the York street and South Sixth street M. E. Churches, and the attendance has been unusually large. Clergymen of various denominations, and from this and adjoining States, have addressed large audiences in these Churches. Over one hundred new members have joined the Church.

In the Daily Times of yesterday morning was published the very able charge of Mr. Justice ROOSEVELT, in relation to the disputed will case of the late JOHN MASON. Mr. MASON, who was generally known in this City as an enterprizing and successful merchant, died on the 26th of September, 1839.

From the London Times. The literary world and a wide circle of affectionate friends have sustained a serious loss by the death of Professor EMPSON, which took place at Hayleybury on Friday last. Few men of our time have discharged educational duties with greater zeal and conscientiousness. He consider-

From the Philadelphia Ledger. Readers have noticed the reported success of this novel power, by most of the commercial papers of New-York. The Scientific American plainly denounces the whole as deception; exactly as it stood alone in exposing the Paine Water Gas Imposition.

Our mails are very light yet, and no news of importance from abroad greets our readers this morning ... The Eric Railroad is clear of snow, and the cars are running....There was snow again in Boston yesterday, but it seemed likely to turn to rain....The Arabia left Halifax for Boston, having replenished her coal-room Friday morning.

In consequence of the recent snow storm the interment of ELIAS HICKS, did not take place on 5th day morning last, as previously notified. His remains will he taken from his late residence, No. 175 East Broadway. at 8 1/2 o'clock, this morning, and thence to Jericho by railroad, to leave the South Berry in Brooklyn at 10 o'clock. A special train will be procured to return in the afternoon

DR. FRANKLIN AND THE DOCTORS.--In a recent lecture on Female Medical Education, Mr. GREGORY related the following incident, communicated to him by an elderly gentleman who remembers when it was comparatively fresh, and of interest to the public, from the fact that male physicians were just beginning their encroachments upon the province of the good women whom Dr. FRANKLIN so honorably mentions, by their familiar titles in those days.

A young man, named BENJAMIN BENJAMIN, committed suicide to day, by hanging himself, on his house, on Pine street. He was married on Wednesday last, in New-York, to DEBORAH MARKS, a young lady of eighteen, who has proved to be a lunatic, which is supposed to have been the cause of sad act.

Rev. Prof. MATTISION delivered the second and last of his lectures on Spirit Rappings in the Tabernacle, last evening, to a large and intelligent audience. The Professor's discourse was an able exposition of the humbug, tanaticism and infidelity of the system.

The Message of Governor FORT, of New-Jersey, is of fair length and ability. We give a summary of its leading parts: In the enactment and modifications of the law the Governor deems it proper to suggest the necessity of caution, and thinks it possible to legislate too much, believing that frequent changes in the laws create difficulties in reference to their proper construction and due observance by the people

A Yankee speculator who had immense tracts of land for sale in the Far West, used frequently to say, that a gentleman who was traveling there, saw a very old man sitting at the door of a log cabin, weeping bitterly.

THE OBSERVATORY AT DARTMOUTH COLLEGE. --The Trustees held a meeting week before last, and voted to accept the donation of Dr. SHATTUCK, of Boston, with its conditions, and to erect the Observatory next summer. It is to be set on the eminenee a little north east of Wentworth Hall. The telescope now in the temporary observatory works well.

The Mail is through from New-Orleans. The papers contain one day later from Mexico. No determination has been arrived at in regard to the Tehuantepac question. The Siglio contains a communication from the associates of Col SLOO, dcaying the accusation that their propositions require the cession by the Government of transit dues, and asserting that these will always remain a source of revenue to the Government.

COURT SCENE.--" Sir! " said a fierce lawyer, "do you on your solemn oath, swear that this is not your hand writing?" " 1 reckon not," was the cool reply. " Does it resemble your writing?" " Yes sir. I think it don't."

In Executive Session to-day, the Senate had finished the discussion, and were just about taking a vote on Mr. BADGER'S nomination when the death of Mr. UPHAM was announced. They adjourned immediately. This is rather unfortunate for Mr. BADGER; his case stood well to-day, and may not be as well on Monday.

Gov. FOOTE, of Mississippi, has published a card vindicating his right to appoint a Senator in Congress, after the 4th of March next, when the term of Mr. BROOKE will expire. Gov. FOOTS was, himself; the predecessor of Mr. BROOKE, and resigned his seat to canvass the State for Governor The Legislature, by a combination of Union Waigs and Democrats chose Mr. BROOKE for the unexpired term.

THE SMALL TRADE OF NORFOLK.--It appears by a statement in the Norfolk News that last year about eighteen hundred barrels of eggs, each containing about one hundred dozen, were shipped from that port. The return, including the price of the cars in which they were packed, is estimated at $20 per barrel, making a total of thirty-six thousand dollars received for eggs.

If you want to see the pertest little dignitary on earth, look up and see him on his throne there at the head of this little regiment of words. He is not only pert, but powerful, as any petite belle be fore whom all hearts bow.
The Hon. HENRY BARNARD, of Connecticut, is delivering a course of lectures before the Smithsonian Institution, at Washington, on Popular Education.

At the Annual meeting of the Williamsburg Medical Society, held on Thursday evening, the following gentlemen were elected its officers for the present year: President, Dr. COOK; Vice President, Dr. SOHAPPS; second Vice President, Dr. KRACKOWIZEN; Corresponding Secretary, Dr. MCFARLAN; Recording Secretary, Dr. BLOUVELT; Treasurer, Dr. PERRY.
ABD-EL KADER seems to be having various sorts of fun since he has been turned loose in Paris, and withal he is evidently something of a wag at times. The Paris papers abound in anecdotes of him.

THE BURNING OF ILLINOIS COLLEGE.--The Morgan Journal gives the following particulars of the burning of the College at Jacksonville, a short time since: A season of vacation had closed, and the ordinary exercises had been resumed on that evening. In the southern half of the building, a large proportion of the property of the students was destroyed--some losing all.
The steamer just to hand brings ample accounts, through the London papers, of the extraordinary progress of Gold digging in Australia. The accounts are down to October last.
The following Senatus Consultum is promulgated in the Monilcur, and has become the law of France.
The Arabia's mails reached the City yesterday. Full details of the news from Europe are given in our columns this morning. The new British Ministry has taken possession of its official quarters.

The Israelites in the desert scarce booked with more eager anticipation for a fall of manna, than some of our citizens for a fall of snow. From the first day that cold weather has fairly set in, sleighs of most tempting and gaudy hues, are displayed on the pavement by speculative coach-builders.
The chivalric blood of South Carolina has been newly stirred by a dispute with her neighboring State of Georgia, regarding their respective boundaries.

The annual Message of Gov. FORT, of New-Jersey, presents gratifying evidences of prosperity in the affairs of that State. The several institutions, including those for knaves and madmen, belonging to the State Government, are in the most desirable condition.

This affair, which has excited so much interest from the peculiar circumstances connected with the various persons concerned in it, came on yesterday before the Court of Assizes of the Seine, M. Bresson being the presiding Judge.

On this day thirty-eight years ago, "two hours before daylight," according to the orders of Gen. PAKENHAM, the British troops were under arms, and went forth to battle for their lost honor, in the defeat which they had sustained on the 23d December, 1814.
The Porte is reported to have Intermed the Powers that it will not grant any further concessions respecting the navigation of the Bosphorus.
It is showu by the facts of the Massachusetts Registry, for 1851, of Births, Deaths and Marriages, that agriculturists stand much the highest chance of long life.

TAKE IT EASY.--Don't allow the pebbles on your path to become stones of stumbling. Even if they do, take it easy. The ladder of patience is at hand, and the smooth path of success lies beyond. If life bring a sorrow, take it easy.
From the Republic. It is so currently reported that we are inclined to give some credit to the rumor, that Mr. HUNTER'S Objection to going into the Cabinet is the fact that Mr. DIX is to be a member.

BROADWAY.--The Opera of "II Barbiere di Siviglia" is to be brought out this evening for the first time. Madame ALBONI plays Rosina, ROVERE, Figaro, SANGIOVANI, Almaviva. The afterpiece is the ballet of "La Maja de Sevila."

UNION OF THE SOCIETIES FOR RELIEVING THE POOR.--A meeting of the Societies (female) for improving the condition of the Poor in Jersey City, was held last week in the First Presbyterian Church, Washington street, for the purpose of uniting and forming a new Society.

A painful event has been made known at Lloyd's in relation to an alleged mutiny among a body of Chinese emigrants, on board the English ship Gertrude, when the master ordered his crew to fire on the people, of whom about seventeen were killed and wounded.

We have received dates from the City of Mexico to Dec. 23. The Congress was still in session. The Senate had not yet acted upon the bill sent up by the Chamber of Deputies, granting the Tehuantepec contract to the Guanajuato Company.
Papers are to hand, bringing details of the news, of which a telegraphic summary has already been sent. Dates from Rangoon are to the 18th November, but bring no news.
The hurricane which broke forth on Sunday night has not been equalled, in point of severity and for extent of havoc, since that which occasioned so much destruction to life and property in 1839.

Hon. BENJAMIN FITZPATRICK has been appointed United States Senator from Alabama, to succeed Mr. KING. Mr. FITZPATRICK is expected to arrive here on Tuesday. Senator COOPER has returned, in better health. Mr. CLEMENS will be in his seat to-morrow.

Dickinson College, Pa., is now in a flourishing condition. From the catalogue just issued we learn that there are now in attendance in the Under-graduate department 13 Seniors, 24 Juniors, 39 Sophomores and 39 Freshmen; in the Preparatory Department, 40--total, 155.
Wall-street is considered a brisk street, in its way--the money and stock-jobbing way--but it bears no hand, at present, with the French Bourse.

THE WEATHER.--The sudden and extreme changes of temperature experienced within the week have scarcely a parallel in this avowedly variable climate. The mercury, which on Monday stood at 44[degrees],was yesterday afternoon down to 10[degrees].

RECOVERY OF GOODS STOLEN BY BURGLARS--EXAMINATION OF SUSPICIOUS PARTIES.--A large number of houses have been entered in this City during the past three months, and clothing and housekeeping articles in considerable quantities stolen at different times.

The Saratoga Whig says that there has been quite an excitement in Cohoes and Waterford recently, on the subject of rabid dogs. The son of Mr. John Sullivan, of Cohoes, was bitten about three weeks since, and on Thursday of last week he began to exhibit signs of hydrophobia.

The Broadway Railroad. SUPERIOR COURT--General Term.--The BROADWAY RAILROAD--Present Chief Justice OAKLY, Judges DUER, CAMPBELL, PAYNE, BOSWORTH, and EMMET.--Thomas E. Davis and C. Palmer vs. The Mayor and Commonalty.--This case came up before a crowded Court room and a strong array of Counsel.

Orders were to-day introduced In the Legislature of Massachusetts, to consider the expediency of repealing so much of the Secret Ballot Law as makes it obligatory upon voters to deposit their ballots.

MR. UPHAM'S DEATH--EULOGISTIC SPEECHES, ETC Mr. FOOT, of Vt., said: Mr. President--I rise to perform a melancholy duty this morning, in formally announcing to the Senate, the sad intelligence of the decease of one of the oldest members of this body.

After proper references to the prosperous condition of the State and the nation, and to the Almighty Disposer of events, Governor WRIGHT proceeds at once with his survey of public affairs, and his suggestions to the assembled wisdom of the State.

The Emperor returned from Compiegne to Paris, on the 28th. He was respectfully received, but no enthusiasm of any kind was manifested. Various absurd rumors had been in circulation during his sojourn at Compiegne, to the effect that an attempt had been made on his life; that he had been killed by a fall from his horse; that his hand was shattered by the bursting of a fowling-piece-all of which tales were unfounded.
DEATH OF REV. MORGAN J. RHEES, D. D.--Rev. MORGAN J. RHEES, D. D., late pastor of the First Baptist Church, Williamsburg, died on Saturday morning. The deceased was much beloved by his people.

The mail from New-Nexico arrived yesterday, bringing us papers of the 27th November. At that date, news had just been received of the election of General PIERCE to the Presidency, so that by the aid of a dispatch sent to Independence, and the mail, they were only twenty-five days in ascertaining this important result of the election.

"DEAR FRIEND: I come on duty; not a single meeting of your Society must take place without my signifying by my presence how grateful we Italians are to you all for your noble efforts. But I know that I shall not be able to speak a single word; I feel unwell, absolutely unequal to the task, and most likely doomed to leave before the meeting is over.

It is often the province of a journalist to relate the discovery of statues and other valuable works that have been hidden in the earth for centuries; and, but for such incident, they would, in all probability, never have been preserved, or descended to us.
From the New-Orleans Picayune, 7th. The number of vessels which arrived at Havana during the year 1852 was two hundered less than that of the previous year.

we have advices from Auckland, New-Zealand, by way of London, to Sept. 14. The attractions of the Victoria gold fields were beginning to be felt in an extended degree, many of the small storekeepers and tradesmen being about to sail to Australia.

VENTILATION OF CHURCHES.--" Churches are surely the worst ventilated places in the world," said a lady to us lately. How often have we silently made the same reflection, while sitting among the auditory in a crowded house of worship, preparatory to the opening of the services.

The world is a little improved in its festal tastes since the days of DOMITIAN and CALIGULA. If a fight between a lion and a gladiator were advertised in the Daily Times as coming off on such a day at a New-York amphithcatre, it is more than probable that, before the appointed time, the lion would be in BARNUM's and the exhibitor in prison.
The new Cunard steamship Arabia from Liver pool, about 11 1/4 o'clock, Jan. 1, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

Daniel Mace, Esq., of Indiana, was admitted an Attorney and Counsellor of this Court. No. 36. Samuel S. Downey vs. J. T. Hick's executrix. In error to the Circuit Court of the United States for Mississippi.
In addition to the names already published, the following have accepted office under the now ad ministration: Secretary to the Treasury--Mr. HAVTER.
Mr. BARTLETT, the Mexican Boundary Commissioner, arrived at New-Orleans on the 11th, and was to leave for Washington next day, by the river route.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the schooner J. Truman, from Tampico, we have received files of the Siglo Diez i Nueve to the 15th ult., being one day later than previous advices from the city of Mexico.

The above highly respected lady departed this life about 9 o'clock this morning in her temporary residence in this capital. She had been seriously ill for some weeks, but yesterday some strong hopes of her recovery were entertained by her medical attendants, one of whom was Dr. PERKINS, a long established English resident, and who is distinguished by his kind attentions to the various political exiles in this city.

MINNESOTA MATTERS.--The young Territory got chilled early this season. The Minnesotian of November 20, notices that the navigation of the Mississippi closed at St. Paul on the 10th of November, and says, during that week, " the mercury has ranged from zero to 30[degrees] above," and very philosophically adds: "Our Winter commences right for an old-fashioned Minnesota Winter, such as they used to have before white folks came here."

The new Railway undertakings in this Country, now in actual progress, were computed on 1st January at twelve thousand miles. It was then estimated that of these, at least five thousand miles would be opened to traffic by the close of the year, making the total of revenue yielding work eighteen thousand miles.

Captain HAZZARD, of the steam-tug Titan, who returned of Saturday from the packet-ship Cornelius Grinnell, ashore on Squam Beach, informs us that the ship lies head on the beach, or nearly so. She is full of water; the masts are gone, excepting the mizzen mast; the main mast his broken off about 10 feet above the deck.

From the Washington Republic. We devote a considerable space in our columns this morning to an article abridged from the New-York Times, giving a detailed account of the second trial trip of the Caloric ship Ericsson.
Messrs. TICKNOR, REED and FIELDS have recently added two other volumes to their collection of DE QUINCEY'S writings. They embrace some of the author's most successful papers.

There is no State in the Union that has a greater variety of climate than Ohio. The northern part is subject to all the influences of the great chain of lakes on the North--while the southern part has a climate controlled to a great extent by the influences of the Gulf of Mexico and the Mississippi Valley.

Yesterday was a right cold wintry day. We don't know how the mercury stood, for it never conveys half so definite an impression of he state of the weather to us, as a turn around a block, or a moment's listening to the wind whistling around a corner.

The New Ministry. Lord STANLEY, of Alderley, in addition to his office as Vice President of the Board of Trade, will hold that of Paymaster-General of the Forces. Viscount CANNING is Postmaster-General.

A BOY KILLED BY TWO OF HIS COMPANIONS ON RANDALL'S ISLAND.--Yesterday morning Coroner GAMBLE held an inqueet on Randall's Island on the body of JOHN McCAFFRAY, a boy about six years of age. From the testimony of the nurses and two or three boys, we extract the following facts: Mrs. JANE LEY, the matron, testified that the boys (and amongst them the deceased) went to bed at 7 o'clock in the evening all well.
The Picayune finds in a recent number of the Siglo, published in the Mexican capital, an article upon the Tehuantepec grants: an article remarkable for the courageous moderation of its tone.

Questions relating to the encouragement of the Fine Arts, engaged the attention of the House yesterday. Many wise and weighty comments were made upon the size, quality, cost and location of a proposed statue to WASHINGTON.

A writer in the Rochester Advertiser, in allusion to the temperature of last month, gives the following particulars which may be found of interest: "The mean heat of December for the ten preceding years, is 28.15 degrees, and the warmest December in those years is 24.10, in 1848. The mean of this December is still higher, 34.30 degrees, and more than six degrees above that of the ten.

The ministerial arrangements of the new Premier are at last finally settled--and the "Cabinet work" being completed, the State machine may be said to be once more in working order.

On Monday last, says the Corning Journal, Mr. James C. Davis, of this village, committed suicide, by hanging himself from a cross-board in a shanty-barn on his premises. About 10 o'clock A M. he went out, which was the last seen of him, until he was found about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, suspended by his neck, nearly dead.

FIRE ALARMS.--The alarm rung for the Fifth District on Sunday evening, was occasioned by a fire in Williemsburg. The alarm about 2 P. M., Sunday, proceeded from the burning out of a chimney at No. 6O Fulton-street; no damage done.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--A regular meeting of this excellent organization was held at their rooms at Stuyvesant Institute last evening--O. P. WOODFORD, President, in the Chair. The exercises were commenced by reading the fifth chapter of Matthew. Prayer was offered by Mr. BUCKLAND.

Our paper yesterday announced the death of one of the most distinguished citizens of Virginia--Judge WM. H. CABELL, late President of the Court of Appeals of the State.

The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLINS, arrived at Charleston on Friday, with Havana and Key West dates of the 11th inst. Among her passengers were the Commissioners sent out by Congress to investigate the GARDINER Claim--with witnesses to prove the claim a humbug.

BROADWAY.--At this house there will be a repetition of the "Barber of Seville," the cast as before. The ballet of "Giralda" will conclude the performances. BURTON'S.--The annual benefit of Mr. DYOTT takes place this evening, and an attractive bill is offered in consequence.

ANOTHER HORRIBLE MURDER IN THE FOURTH WARD.--Coroner HILTON was notified yesterday morning to hold an inquest at the Fourth Ward Station-House, on the body of a man named JOHN HINES, who died at 3 o'clock, A. M., from the effects of injuries received at the hands of a gang of rowdies.
