THE BUSINESS HABITS OF THE QUEEN.--A few days ago her Majesty had ordered a piano-forte for one of the royal children to be sent from a London maker's to Windsor, and it not arriving as speedily as she expected, she summoned the Controller of the Household to "know the reason why."

On Monday, Jan. 17, ADRIAN B. HOLMES, Esq., in the 79th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family, also those of his sons Charles M. and Adrian B., are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from the residence of the latter, No. 10 West 22d-st., this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 1 o'clock, without further invitation.

The resolutions on Cuba are upon the carpet for to-day's discussion in the Senate. Mr. CASS will make an elaborate argument in support of the Monroe doctrine, and is to occupy two days for the delivery of his speech.

Spain, they assure us, is on the verge of revolution. Why, and the modus, we are unable to see; only that the recent retro-active measures proved to be as thoroughly unpopular as they ought to be, and one ministry has had to give way to another.

SEWERS.--Besides the opening of Montgomery-street, which will probably be commenced soon, a sewer is to be constructed, commencing 75 feet cast of Barrow-street, and running thence to the present sewer in Montgomery-street; being about 200 feet in length.

IMPORT.--The total Import of COTTON into Great Britain this year has been unprecedentedly great, amounting to 2,357,000 bales, against 1,905,000 last year--thus showing an increase of 452,000 bales over the greatest import ever previously known.
The following is a complete list derived from authentic sources, of the officers and clerks in the Custom House at San Francisco, California, together with the salaries of each.

The foreign department of the Crystal Palace is being actively attended to. Letters from agents in Europe and Asia communicate daily the fact of contributions of a most interesting nature being got in readiness by various nations for the exposition.
The one hundred and forty-seventh anniversary of FRANKLIN'S birth-day was celebrated by the Typographical Society of New-York, with a grand ball and supper at NIBLO'S Saloon, last evening.

New Orleans papers of the 10th inst. are to hand. They contain Galveston dates to the 6th inst. The Santa Fe mail has arrived at San Antonio, with dates to the 1st December. Matamoros still held out, and the Commandant was preparing for a sturdy resistance.

Mr. SEWARD presented a memorial of THOMAS EWBANK, praying an appropriation to enable him to make experiments with his recently discovered plan for paddle wheels. Mr. BRODHEAD presented a memorial of 1,400 citizens of New-York, in favor of granting 160 acres of land to all who were engaged in the war of 1812.

The name of Terra del Fuego should certainly be transferred from the Southern to the Northern extremity of the American Continent. If ever a country deserved to be called the Land of Fire, it is that region in which all other incidents of life, are regarded as subsidiary to the collection of gold.

STOCK FOR CALIFORNIA.--A letter is published in the last Independence Messenger, from Rev B. H. RUSSELL to Dr. BELT, of Missouri, dated Valejo, California, Oct. 13, which says: The stock that has been driven across the plains this year will not reduce the price one cent on the pound. There is now scarcely any American beef in market, and the Spanish cattle are being very much reduced in number.

The Governor of Massachusetts delivered his inaugural address, on the 14th inst. It is not of excessive length; is able, and lucid. Touching the long-pending controversy between Massachusetts and Rhode Island, he congratulates them that the matter has been brought before the U. S. Supreme Court for a final determination and adjustment.
The Congressional proceedings are not particularly edifying. The bill to establish a Railroad from the Mississippi to the Pacific was taken up in the Senate, discussed, and postponed.

LECTURE ON ORIENTAL COUNTRIES AND TRAVELS.--The first of three Lectures, forming part of a course of seven, on literary subjects, to be delivered in the Hall of the Church of the Ascension, corner of Sackett and Court-streets, South Brooklyn, was delivered last evening by J. WOOD JOHNS, Professor of Architecture, S. R. A., of London.

The failure of Mr. MARSHALL to introduce his resolution to place Ten Millions at the disposal of Gen. PIERCE, for purposes heretofore stated, is significant of the fate of the entire proposition. It will not pass Congress. The Virginia delegation and nearly the whole South voted against it. The DOUGLAS men voted in the affirmative.

We find in our Havana files dates from the City of Mexico to the 30th Dec., and from Vera Cruz to Jan. 4. The revolution continues to have full headway in Guadalajara. Gen. MINON is entrenching his camp, and making preparations for an active campaign, but there have been no decided rencontres.

TUNNEL SECTION OF THE PACIFIC RAILROAD.--The seventeenth section of the Pacific Railroad, known as the tunnel section, we believe, exhibits the heaviest work along the whole of the first division. To say nothing of the various stupendous cuts at different points, its two tunnels through adjacent ridges, near the beginning of the section, are evidences of the vastness of the whole work.

FIRE.--On Sunday evening, between 7 and 8 o'clock, a fire broke out in a Carpenter's shop on the rear of the lot corner of North First and Tenth-streets, owned by Mr. J. HEUSTIS, and occupied by Mr. MARTIN as a carpenter shop, and PATRICK CARR as a staircase manufactory.
ROSSEAU says: " There are but two things that are positive goods--health of body and health of mind; and but two things that are positive evils--pain of body and pain of mind."

Both the Opera troupes have now been heard in "The Barber of Seville." The popular verdict as to the relative attractions of the two principal voices will probably soon be made up. The public were partially satisfied on this point after the first contrast in "The Child of the Regiment."

FIRE IN LANSING, MICH.--The Governor of Michigan, in his late Message, remarked that there was no fire engine in the capital city. His urgent request for a fire department was seconded by a disastrous fire there on the 11th. The Lansing Journal says that It broke out in the office of the State Sentinel.

The Pacific Railroad discussion was resumed to-day with some spirit. No long speeches were made, and several participated. It is a mistake, however, to suppose that the subject is to be disposed of without a long debate. There will be a number of set speeches from prominent Senators; and the counter projects will excite a long-continued cross-fire discussion.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Permit me to ask the attention of your readers to the editorial article in the Freeman's Journal, of Saturday, relating to the meeting in be half of the persecuted people in Tuscany, held at Metropolitan Hall. The chief object of that article seems to be--1. To excite the gentlemen who signed the "Call" for that meeting to disclaim its proceedings; and--2.

I am a quist, orderly citizen a little over forty, and rather inclined to be stout--indeed. I weigh about two handred pounds; but that is not on account of fat--it is muscle--all muscle. I am a quiet man as I said, and rather a little nervous. I don't like to be hurried--not by any means. I have a horror of haste, and all that kind of thing. Like Cave Johnson, I am a slow man.

Twenty millions of gallons of wine are annually consumed in this country. Six millions of gallons are Imported; three hundred thousand gallons are manufactured from American grapes; and the remainder from eider, turnips, logwood, whiskey, rain water, and sugar.

It is very clear that difficulties are gathering about General PIERCE in his endeavors to form a Cabinet. The Democratic journals generally preserve a discreet and prudential silence upon the subject; which renders the language of those which do speak the more significant.

The State Temperance Convention assembled at the Baptist Church, on State-street, this morning. H. CAMP, President, in the Chair. Rev. R. S. CRAMPTON and H. McALLISTER were appointed Secretaries pro tem. Messrs. W. H. BURLEIGH and J. C. CROCKER, of Albany; S. P. TOWNSEND and C. G. WARREN, of New-York, and seven others, were appointed a business Committee.

Hon. GEORGE W. MORRISON, of Manchester, was to-day nominated at the Democratic Congressional Convention, held In Manchester, to be supported in March, as the democratic candidate in this (the Second) District, under the new revision. He received 145 votes, the while number. There was a majority of between 100 and 200 against the democrats last year, in this District.

Professor KOEPPEN will deliver his Lecture on MOHAMMED and the Saracen Empire, at the Tabernacle, this evening. In this lecture, the Professor intends to give a picture of Arabia during the seventh century, the character and life of the great Reformer, and the influence which Islamism and the empire of the Caliphs exercised on the European natives during the middle ages.

The steamship Perseverance arrived yesterday from Texas, with dates from Galveston to the 7th Inst., and Indianola 3d. Major W. W. CHAPMAN, and Dr. JARVIS, of the U. S. Army, took passage on the Perseverance from Indianola, having left Corpus Chrlsti on the 2d. Col. BAETLETT, Major EMORY and others, of the U. S. Mexican Boundary Commission, arrived at Corpus on the 1st inst. from El Paso.

The lamentable loss of life on board the steamboat Reindeer at Bristol Landing, on the Hudson River, in the early part of September last, must be fresh in the recollection of our readers. By the lamentable accident thirty-six lives were sacrificed.

New Orleans papers to the 10th, give us the following Texas items: Col, COE, who was lately shot in an affray at Gonzales, is dead. A gentleman of Indianola gathered a dish of green peas from his garden on Christmas day. In another garden in town there are fig trees full of fruit now in a ripening state.

On Tuesday evening, of consumption, in the 51st year of his age, Mr. GEORGE RAYMOND, formerly of Tralee, County Kerry, Ireland. His friends, and those of the family, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence. No. 80 Ann-st.. at 2 o'clock, P. M., on Thursday, the 20th instant. Hisremains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

The Thirty-sixth Anniversary of the American Colonization Society, was held in the First Presbyterian Church, this evening. The edifice was densely thronged with ladies and gentlemen, including Members of Congress, Judges of the Supreme Court, Heads of Departments and other dignitaries.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen on Monday evening, there were six petitions presented from various parties, asking grants to lay rail-tracks through the main streets of the city, all of which were referred to a special committee. Remonstrances were received from property owners on South Sixth and South Seventh-streets against rail-tracks being laid down in those streets, which were also referred to the special committee.

We noticed yesterday morning in our report of the Printer's Festival, on the Anniversary of FRANKLIN'S birth-day, Mr. R. A. WEST'S remarks in reference to the toast complimentary to Woman. We find them given at length in last evening's Post, and copy them as follows: Mr. PRESIDENT: I suspect that the introduction of that toast at this stage of the proceedings will take many by surprise.

LATER FROM PORTO RICO--We find in the Havana papers received by the Cherokee, dates to the 25th of December from Porto Rico, brought to that port by the Spanish mail steamship. In several parts of the island the small-pox, which appears to be raging with unexampled violence throughout the whole West Indian group, was carrying off large numbers of the inhabitants.

The steamer Black Warrior, R. W. SHUFELDT, U. S. N., Commander, arrived Tuesday noon, from Mobile and Havana. She left Mobile Bar on the 10th inst., at 3 o'clock, P. M., and Havana at noon on the 13th.

Mr. RUSK moved, and the Chair was authorized to fill the vacancy in the Committee of Post-Offices and Post Roads, in place of Mr. UPHAM. Several petitions were presented. Mr. BADGER introduced a bill changing the law relative to bail in civil cases in the District of Columbia. It abolishes all right to demand bail in any civil case.

The Thirty-sixth Anniversary of the American Colonization Society, was held at Washington yesterday. President FILLMORE was on the platform. The attendance of delegates from auxiliary societies was unusually large. The Annual Address was delivered by Hon. EDWARD EVERETT. It is published in full in our columns this morning.

Our dispatches of yesterday morning informed us of a great event. The first Caloric Ship was loosened from her meoriags at New-York, on the 4th day of January, 1853, and driven over the bosom of the waters by an agent hitherto unknown, except in some very dissimilar capacity. If experiment is worth anything to sustain prediction, the reign of steam must date its decline, if not its downfall, from that day.

RAILROADS.--The railroad mania appears to be still alive. Petitions were presented for permission to lay railway tracks in Montague-street and Myrtle-avenue by E. B. LITCHFIELD; also by same parties, from Fulton and Montague Ferries to Third-avenue. One from JOHNSON, HUDSON Co., through Flushing avenue and other streets.

When Capt. KEPPEL'S ship was lately near one of the islands in the Pacific, which are still inhabited by savages, the crew were for some time puzzled, in looking at the canoes of the natives, to make out the use of a curiously formed piece of wood, from a hole in the centre of which descended a strong cord of twisted rattan, forming a running noose, like a hangman's knot.

EXTRAORDINARY WEALTH OF A SOUTHERN PLANTER.--The following is from a German paper: "A rich planter, a Mr. DELABITZSCHER, descended from an ancient French family, recently died in New Orleans. He was a young man at the time of the first French Revolution, and fled from the guillotine to become a merchant's clerk in the Crescent City.

Mr. BRIGGS has determined to secure a test-vote on the New-York Mint bill to-morrow. If the Speaker does not reverse his decision of to day, the Yeas and Nays will be called on an appeal from it. If the supporters of the project are defeated, then the bill is gone for this session.
With the close of the Extra Session of the Missouri Legislature, on the 25th ult., was consummated the work of inaugurating the future Railroad system of Missouri.

The Reindeer Homicides--Trial of Charles W. Farnham, Master of the Reindeer, for Man slaughter. U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Judge BETTS. SECOND DAY. The Jurors having answered to their names, Mr. Hall, U. S. District Attorney inquired if the defendant had pleaded in this Court, as the indictment was found in the District Court, and had been remitted to this Court.

The Address of Mr. EVERETT before the American Colonization Society, published in this morning's Times, will repay an attentive reading. It bears the marks of care and elaborate finish which characterize the productions of its author, and is useful as affording a condensed history of the efforts of the Colonization Society for the abolition of the Slave Trade, and their objects in the foundation of the Republic of Liberia.

The St. Louis Republican, of the 6th inst., gives a detailed account of the very serious riots and disturbances that have occurred on the line of the Pacific Rail road. It seems from its account that the eighteenth section of the road has been for a long time badly managed, the contractors having left it and gone to another section, and the hands being allowed, contrary to the ordinary discipline, to elect their own foreman.

President PIERCE is evidently beginning to feel the embarrassments of his position. He has been trying to frame a Cabinet; and, unless rumor be utterly unreliable, he finds it a task of no little difficulty. Two paths are open to him--as they have been to other men, under similar circumstances, at various periods of political history.

The Whig Caucus last evening, on the twentieth ballot nominated SAMUEL G ARNOLD for U. S. Senator, and it was intended for the two Houses to join in Grand Committee this morning, to make the election; but the Senate adjourned, by a party vote, after a session of a few minutes. The House will probably vote to join to-morrow, but the concurrence of the Senate is doubtful.

From the London Athenaum. This small volume is a valuable addition to our scientific literature. A few years since, much interest was excited by the publication of certain experiments by M. DU BOIS REYMOND, which appeared to prove an intimate connection between the phenomena of vitality and those of electricity.

We have a Green Bag. Readers, who know nothing of an editorial sanctum, you would be astonished if you could become familiarized with ours. Take, for instance, the letters we receive every morning. You don't suppose they can all be read at one sitting--do you? Why, only yesterday we perused three hundred and thirteen with our own spectacles, till the glasses grew obstinately dull, and refused to assist us to another letter.

A DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT BALDWINSVILLE.--A most destructive fire occurred in Baldwinsville, on Saturday evening--the largest, it is said, that ever visited that village. It broke out in the Rod Mill, about 10 1/2 o clock, and before it could be subdued, destroyed that building and the woolen factory. The loss is estimated at $5O,000.

AFTERNOON SESSION--No. 47, (a reserved case) Lyon, respondent against Clark and another, appellants, Argued. N. Hill, Jr., for appellants; Samnuel Beardsley for respondent. MONDAY, Jan. 17. The following motions were decided-Lallietie, respondent, against Van Keuren, appellant. Motion to dismiss appeal denied with $10 costs, without prejudice. N. Hill, Jr. for motion; Warren T. Worden opposed.

The mail is through from New Orleans. A correspondent of the Nueces Valley Gazette dating from Brownsville, 23d ult., says: The Revolution has been proclaimed in Mon??erey, and it is rumored that CARVAJAL was there. Colonel MONTERO, of the Regular Mexican army, was captured by him.

The complete internal Railroad system of this State, as recently adopted, embraces five trunk lines, which four terminate in St. Louis. The Hannibal of and St. Joseph road, as was stated in my last, crosses the State from a point (Hannibal) about 150 miles above St. Louis, on the Mississippi, running nearly west some 200 miles to St. Joseph.

MORAL INSANITY.--Some thirty years ago, a Young lady, the only daughter of a noble house in the north of Germany, from having been one of the most cheerful girls, became subject to fits of the deepest melancholy. All the entreaties of her parents were insufficient to draw from her the reason of it.

A BIG TRANSACTION.--A bill is before the Iowa Legislature, authorizing the Commissioners of the Des Moines Improvements to contract with PAGE BACON, of St. Louis, for the completion of the works on the Des Moines River. By the terms of this contract, the State conveys absolutely to PAGE BACON the remaining lands belonging to the improvement, amounting to nearly 900,000 acres.

We have obtained from Washington the subjoined statement of the circumstances attending the seizure and recovery of the negro man SOLOMON NORTHROP, whose case has excited so high a degree of interest.

The Annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury, delayed since the opening of the Session, will be presented to Congress to day. We are enabled, by special dispatches from Washington, to lay before our readers the leading points of the Report in advance.

PARTICULARS OF THE LOSS OF THE SHIP BRAMIN OF NEW-BEDFORD.--A letter from Mr. GILBERT B. BADEN, late first officer of the ship Bramin, of this port, gives some particulars of the loss of that vessel. Mr. B.'s letter is dated Ship Adeline, Oct. 17, 1852. On the 7th of Sept., the Bramin was driven on the south- west shore of the Arctic Ocean in a gale of wind, about 100 miles from East Cape.

In the motions of European politics, we are glad to perceive in the Madrid locale some evidence that the Concha policy in relation to Cuba will be sustained, and this island be relieved of the administrative incubus that now presses it to the very death.

We copy from the Washington Republic the following abstract of the Annual Report of the American Colonization Society, presented at the meeting on Tuesday evening. Its statements are interesting: Since our last anniversary, Hon. HENRY CLAY, President, end Hon. DANIEL WEBSTER, one of the oldest Vice Presidents of this Society, have departed this life.

The Riot at Tammany Hall In December last--Joint Trial of the Six Rioters--Verdict of, Guilty. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS-Wednesday--Before Hon. City Judge BEEBE, Alderman BRISLEY, (Ninth Ward,) and Alderman FRANCIS, (Tenth Ward.)--At the opening of the Court of General Sessions this forenoon, A. Oakey Hall, Esq., the Assistant District Attorney, arose, and called up the joint indictment for riot pending against

The Washington Globe makes the following important correction: We said in the Globe of Saturday evening last, that Queen VICTORIA was in a fair way to add another prince or princess to the Royal family, which would be, we believed, the seventh. We have since learned from a London journal that it will be the eighth, should there be but one. There are now three princes and four princesses.

It would seem that the Kentuckians are seriously agitating the question of a prohibitory liquor law--similar to that now in force in Maine. From an exchange paper we take the following synopsis of its leading provisions: 1. The manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors, except for medicinal, sacramental and mechanical purposes, shall be entirely prohibited.

Oregon, as a field of labor for the farmer, mechanic and scholar, or the Christian, has become conspicuous, and will continue to attract more and more the attention of the virtuous and industrious who shall emigrate from the Atlantic States.

Alexander Hamilton, Jr. Esq; of New York, was admitted an Attorney and Counsellor of this Court. No. 140 John Perkins, appellant, vs. E. P. Fourniquet et ux., appeal from Circuit Court of the United States for Mississippi

The population of Texas was increased two hundred thousand last year, thinks the Houston Telegraph. The editor says: "The roads through the eastern counties are literally lined with emigrants. The ferries on Red River are constantly employed in transporting emigrants from the eastern the western shore.

In this City, on Wednesday morning. Jan. 19. of congestion, FREDERICK EGERTON, second son of Henry M. and Lophelia Beneciet, aged 2 years and 6 months. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral services, at New-York Hotel, on Thursday, the 20th inst, at 9 o'clock. A.M. His remains will be taken to Greenwich, Conn., for interme??t.

The speech of Gen. CASS upon the MONROE doctrine is sure to make a profound impression. It bears the marks of thorough reflection and conviction; a competent knowledge of the matter discussed, and a frequent strain of vigorous eloquence, quite worthy of the General's exalted reputation for oratory.

Prof. TAYLER LEWIS delivered his first lecture on the Six Days of Creation, before the Young Men's Christian Association, on Tuesday evening There was a large and intelligent audience assembled in the rooms of the Society, Stuyvesant Institute. The discourse showed profound erudition and deep study of the subject treated.

PROPOSED NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.--It is proposed to hold three public meetings in Albany during the present winter to discuss the subject of a National University. The first meeting is to be held on the 26th and 27th of the present month, and the others on the 23d and 24th days of February and March.

In the State Senate, on Monday, Mr. CONGER reported favorably on the bill to abolish Teacher's Institutes. So they go, one after another. We have not seen Mr. CONGER'S bill, but doubtless it is all right. Teacher's Institutes were established a few years since, under the most favorable auspices for success, and immediately commenced a career of usefulness.

SWORD PRESENTATION TO THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER BY THE NAPPER TANDY LIGHT ARTILLERY OF BROOKLYN.--On Tuesday evening the members of this corps of adopted Irish citizens under the command our much-esteemed fellow citizen WILLIAM H. HOGAN, Esq., assembled at the armory for the purpose of presenting a sword to M. MEAGHER, as a taken of their respect and esteem.

Mr. CHARLES WOODBURY a son of LEVI, is here, supposed to be an agent of Gen. PIERCE, to ascertain the feeling of the public pulse. Virginia seems to be losing her chance of a Cabinet appointment. The war-steamer Fulton, with the Vice President elect and suite, left Cape Henry on Sunday evening.
The industry with which Congress addicts itself to the patronage of the Fine Arts, is an indication of improved feeling in that regard. The time and money appropriated to Statuary are surprising.

TEMPERANCE MEETING--Wednesday afternoon, about one hundred youths held a festival in Franklin Hall. They are attached to a Society styling itself the Jersey City Temperance Sunday School. After a liberal indulgence in the nicetios set before them, several addresses were made.

Last Tuesday being the anniversary of the birth of DANIEL WEBSTER, the day was honored in Boston by appropriate ceremonies. At noon, a national salute was fired on the Common, by the Webster Artillery. In the evening, a large number of citizens assembled at the Revere House, to commemorate the occasion by a supper and the interchange of civic and patriotic sentiments. The company sat down to table at 6 1/2 o'clock.

The Cincinnati Gazette, of the 17th, has the following: COLUMBUS, Saturday Evening, Jan. 15, 1852. On the opening of the Court this morning, Judge WALKER rose and said that a proposition had been submitted on the part of the counsel for the prosecution, to submit the case without argument; and upon a full consideration, the counsel for the defence have agreed to the proposition.

THE WISCONSIN GOVERNOR'S MESSAGE.--This document, which is most commendably brief and business-like, was sent to the Assembly on the 13th. It appears by the returns of the last general census, that the ratio of increase in population has been greater, and the health of the people better, in Wisconsin, than in any other State in the Union.

WRECK OF THE ERIE--SUBMARINE OPERATIONS--In a recent conversation with Mr. QUIGLEY, of Portland, in this county, who is associated with Mr. GREEN, the well-known diver, in the work of raising vessels by the submarine armor, we gathered some interesting particulars concerning the wreck of the Erie, and submarine operations.

PAY IN THE NAVY.--The new Naval Reform bill proposes the following, as the pay of the personnel of the Navy: The pay of midshipmen as now allowed by law. Boatswaine, gunners, carpenters, and sailmakers, newly appointed, and before having a warrant, on duty, per annum seven hundred dollars.

We publish this morning a condensed statement of the points in the Annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury. The Report itself will be presented to Congress today; our dispatches from Washington anticipating its general features.

There has not been a customer inside the door to-day. Our letter orders were shipped by 11 o'clock this forenoon; and two of the partners have gone home. The remaining one sits behind the railing smoking a cigar. He is thinking of a certain charming young lady, whom he has engaged for SONTAG'S, this evening.

BURGLARIES AND ROBBERIES FRIDAY NIGHT. --It would be an occurrence, in this city, unusual, if we were not called upon to note some burglary or robbery during the twenty-four hours preceding each issue of our paper, so great is the preponderance towards crime, and the avaricious thirst for the mammon of this world.

The Supreme Court have decided the McDONOUGH Will Case in favor of the Cities of New-Orleans and Baltimore, and adverse to the States of Louisiana and Maryland The Legislature of Louisiana was organized at Baten Rouge on Thursday.

The difference of opinion existing between Mr. CASS, on one side, and Messrs. MASON and HUNTER, on the other, as to the proper interpretation of the MONROE doctrine, has caused considerable talk here, and various speculations are afloat, as to the effect it will have in arranging the foreign questions and the forming of the new Cabinet.

A general Mass Convention of the friends of Temperance, including the State Society, the Sons of Temperance, , assembled at the State-street Baptist Church this forenoon. The Cour??h was deasely crowded. The meeting was organized by the appointment of A. C. FLANAGAN, of New-York, as President; S. P. TOWNBEND and WESLEY BAILY, Vice President, and two Secretaries.

The untimely fate of Mr. MARSHALL'S proposition to put ten millions of dollars in the empty pockets of President PIERCE, ought, perhaps, to relieve it from any further discussion. The rule nisi bonum is however less true of measures than of men.
THE CASE OF WILSON, THE ENGRAVER.--In the Police Court yesterday, the case of WILLIAM W. WILSON, the engraver, was brought up for examination, Justice RUSSELL on the bench.
WATER LOAN.--The proposals for the 6 per cent Water Loan of $300,000 have been opened. They amounted to $976,000, and have been awarded as follows;

It was very edifying and instructive to witness the conduct of pedestrians in the street yesterday, especially if the observer could look through the exterior of things and perceive that interior meaning, of which the higher philosophers tell us that outward acts are only the types.

On Tuesday, Jan 18, after a short illness, JENNET, daughter of the late William McDougall, aged 23 years. Her friends and relatives are respectively invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her mother, No. 113 Charlton-st., on Friday, (this day,) the 21st inst., at 1 o'clock P.M., without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

We gave yesterday, in a special dispatch from Washington, a summary of the leading figures in Mr. CORWIN'S Annual Report, and now submit, in another part of this morning's paper, the Report at length, which, by the courtesy of Mr. HODGE, the Assistant Secretary, was furnished to the New-York press at an early hour yesterday forenoon.

A seasonable day is this. Citizens draw nearer to their office or sitting-room fires, or ride out on the avenues, as their business or their fancy inclines them. But what are the country people at, this weather? We mean the people who live so far into the country that they cannot take a daily paper and have the news of the whole world's morning poured into their ears after breakfast.

The State Register has the following interesting paragraphs: Quite a volcano was discovered here on Tuesday night. It seems that the friends of DANIEL S. DICKINSON have, for some time, been quietly, but effectualty at work, fortifying him for the Cabinet of General PIERCE.

THE EMPEROR OF AUSTRIA.--A letter from Vienna gives the following account of the Emperor of Austria: "The Emperor, although the youngest sovereign in Europe, is one of the most remarkable for cool judgment and application to business. He rises every morning at 6 o'clock, even in Winter; and is never in bed more than four or five hours.

The following notice is posted up in a tavern in Maine: "Notice to the public the Subscriber will keep Liquors of all kind untill the Select men of Passadumkeag a point a man to sell a cording to Law."

The following Message from the President in reference to the affairs of the Seminoles in Florida, has been already sketched by telegraph. It is an interesting document: WASHINGTON, January 18, 1853. To the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States:

The Inaugural Message of Gov. MATTESON, of Illinois, was delivered to the Legislature on the 10th inst. It is a document of greater length than usual on the occasion of a Gubernatorial inauguration, but gives a clear idea of the condition of the State.

A female teacher of a school that stood on the banks of a quiet English stream, once wished to communicate to her pupils an idea of faith. While she was trying to explain the meaning of the word, a small covered boat glided in sight along the stream. Seizing upon the incident for an illustration, she exclaimed:

Prof. LEWIS delivered his second lecture on the subject of "The Six Days of Creation," last evening. The position taken by the Professor in his discourse of the former evening was well and ably maintained. He takes a liberal and natural view--receiving without question the sacred narration, where any fact is expressly declared, but rejecting all forced and narrow conclusions.

The Chair laid before the Senate the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury. Referred, and 10,000 copies ordered to be printed. Also the Report of the Light-House Board. Mr. SEWARD presented resolutions of the New-York Legislature, concerning the distribution of the Public Lands to the several States for internal improvements.

Hon. WM. A. GRAHAM delivered the Sixth Lecture of the Historical Course to a large and intelligent audience, in Metropolitan Hall, last evening. Mr. GRAHAM was accompanied on the stage by Gov. BRADISH, Rev. Drs. HAWKS, DE WITT, FRANCIS, and some others.

Mr. Ewing, the present incumbent of the office of Secretary of State of Missouri, refuses to leave his office till March next, upon the plea that his time of appointment does not expire till that period.

DOMESTIC LIFE IN GERMANY.--The following letter originally appeared in the Boston Commonwealth, It is from GEO. P. FISHER, Esq., formerly Clerk in the State Department, under JOHN M. CLAYTON: I have become pretty much accustomed to the German style of living, and like it.

The annual report of the Boston Chief of Police shows the following facts when compared with the reports for the years 1851 and 1852. In 1851, the whole number of robberies and larcenies reported at the office, was 562, and the whole number last year, within the city, 626.

So little is ever done in Congress, that when anything is completed there, it is well worth while to make a fuss about it. We have not given the news from Washington a double head, in capitals of extra size, because it is not the custom; but we must not refrain from calling attention to the fact that something was done in Congress the other day.

In his speech delivered at the Railroad celebration at Wheeling, the President of the Baltimore and Ohio road said: "As to the power of overcoming high grades, Mr. Mayor, we claim to have taught a lesson to the world.

THE BROADWAY.--The ALBONI troupe repeated the opera of "La Sonnambula" last evening, to one of the most crowded houses we have ever seen in this City. The opera was admirably performed, and the audience evidently appreciated it, for the applause was hearty and prolonged. After the first act, Madame was called before the curtain. This was again done at the close of the play, and the brilliant finale was repeated before the audience would disperse.

The Regents of the University held their annual meeting, at Albany, on the 13th inst. The Secretary of State presented a draft of the annual report on the condition of the State Cabinet of Natural History, and the Historical and Antiquarian Collection annexed thereto, which was read and adopted, and ordered to be transmitted to the Legislature.

"To Science and Art," is dedicated the noble structure in course of erection on Astor Place, by Mr. PETER COOPER; and in such a living monument, the name of the benevolent founder will be worthily perpetuated with the "undying arts." While seeking "the moral, mental and physical improvement" of his race, he will have secured a posthumous fame more noble and enduring than the powerful, but self-idolizing founders of useless pyramids.
The Postmaster General has established, discontinued, and changed the names of the following Post Offices during the week ending Saturday, January 15, 1853:

Several of us who wanted to see how the newsboys, dock-loafers, and whole class of vagrant children amuse themselves, paid a visit lately to the "National Theatre" in Chatham-street. We took gallery tickets, and finding some seats, placed ourselves so as to get a view of the whole, without being much in sight ourselves.

The examination of W. W. Wilson on the charge of having in his possession coining and counter-felting materials with intent, was continued in the Police Court at Boston, on Wednesday. Mr. Wilson was held for trial on this complaint in $3,000.

When butter is to be made from cream alone, the milk is, in Winter, usually skimmed as often as four, and in Summer two or three times, or until it will afford no more cream; and this should be first separated from the edge of the pan, to which it firmly adheres, by means of an ivory or silver bladed knife, run closely around it.

The members of the United States Commission, for the survey of the boundary between the United States and Mexico, arrived here on Tuesday evening, in the steamer Louisiana, from Indianola. Among them are Mr. J. B. BARTLETT, Commissioner; Major W. H. EMORY, Chief Astronomer and Surveyor; Dr. T. H. WEBB, Secretary; Messrs. RADZIMINSKI, JACOBS, GARDNER, FORCE, CLARK, and HOUSTON.

THE SOUTH AND THE NORTH. Mr. H. B. NORTHRUP, of Washington County, New-York, arrived at the Carolina Hotel. In this town, on Saturday morning, on route from Red River, via New-Orleans. Mobile and Charleston, for New-York.

WASHINGTON IRVING.--Our distinguished countryman WASHINGTON IRVING, is passing a few days in Baltimore, on his way to the National Capital, where he designs remaining some weeks. We are happy to see that the intellectual labor in which his life has been employed has not impaired his bodily vigor, nor diminished that mental viva city which, for the last forty years, has diffused so great a charm over English literature.

There is much transpiring of late which is calculated to infuse into the public a doubt as to the value of the reputedly great discovery of JENNER. If the doctrine he first promulgated is true, small-pox ought to be, if not an unknown disease, at least an uncommon one in our midst.

A HOLIDAY INCIDENT.--The butchers of Cincinnati are proverbial for their whole souled genorosity. No class of our citizens are so frequently called upon to sympathize with the suffering poor, and none so liberally extend the open hand, and by their acts, not words, show their noble nature. A pleasant incident came under our observation yesterday morning.

A BOLD FELLOW.--Mr. CHARLES ELLIOTT, who boards at WM. BREDELL'S, on Fifth street, between Elm and Plum, was awakened on Sunday night by a noise in his room, and on looking about him discovered a man in the act of examining his clothing, and who afterwards came to his bed and felt under his pillow.

UNIVERSITY FUNDS.--The Regents of the University of the State have certified to the Controller a list of the Academies entitled to moneys for the instruction of Common School teachers. Among them are the following, with the number of students taught and the amount they are entitled to therefor:

FIRE IN THE U. S. BONDED WAREHOUSE.--At about 10 3/4 o'clock, last night, a fire broke out in the store keepers room of the large U. S. Bended Warehouse, in Broadway, corner of Exchange Place, which was fortunately extinguished before the flames had time to spread through the extensive building.

We entertain sincere respect for Hon JOSEPH R. CHANDLER. We have had faith in his vigorous sense and unvarying honesty He was a useful and highly successful pedagogue. His ability to communicate knowledge to infant minds was of a high order.

The Jackson Mississippian announces the death of Judge Anderson Hutchinson, at his residence in that city, on the night of the 31st Dec. Judge H. was well known as the compiler of those valuable works, Hutchinson's Code, Manual of Forms, He was born in Virginia-removed to Alabama in early life, and thence to Mississippi, where he soon took a high position at the bar.

COMMON COUNCIL.--A special meeting of the Board of Aldermen convened last evening at the City Hall, Alderman COMSTOCK in the Chair. Mayor BERRY announced the decease of ANDREW C. JOHNSON, a member of this Board from the Third Ward, and also made a brief eulogy upon the character of deceased, and the loss which this Board, and also the City, of which he was an honorable and estimable member, has sustained.

Gov. CROSBY, in commencing, alludes to the peculiar circumstances by which he was called to the Executive Chair, and hopes they may tend to the promotion of harmony in the doings of the Legislature. The Maine Law he alludes to as an event in the history of the State and the Union.

Lieutenant Governor SANDFORD E. CHURCH, S. C. W. WRIGHT, PETER CAGGER, and BENJAMIN WELCH, Jr., arrived from Albany this afternoon, and diped at the Eagle Hotel. The following arrived yesterday: From New-York City--J. E. NEWTON, J. H. HART T. H. HART, and JOHN L. PRUYN; from Cleveland, Ohio--General WILSON and J. W. FITCH, Judge BEARDSLEE, of Utica, and PEARSON, of Troy.

We wish the Democratic papers would call Mrs. PIERCE the wife of the President elect, in stead of his lady. They are legally married, and she is entitled to the name of wife. Besides, it shocks all our ideas of morality to hear it said that the President elect of the United States is travel ling around so much with any other woman than his wife.

Presenting popular novels in a dramatic form to the public, has been long a favorite stratagem with managers to secure the usual favor. It has many advantages. People are acquainted with the dramatis personce long before they take their place on the red lined benches.

The Winnebago Indians have been presented as a nuisance by the Grand Jury of Benton County, Minnesota. The presentment represents that the Indians are constantly depredating on the lands of the whites, and proceeds to say:

LECTURE IN SOUTH BROOKLYN.--Mr. J. WOOD JOHNS, who lectured in South Brooklyn a few evenings since, corrects our reporter as follows: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your report of my lecture in Brooklyn, on Monday evening, it is stated that the Latin Church opposed the road between Jaffa and Jerusalem.
COGNAC BRANDY.--We were much amused, on yesterday, by the appearance of a large lot of this celebrated French liquor, that was relling on board one of our New-Orleans boats.

ROMAN CATHOLIC'S ORPHAN ASYLUM.--The ladies of the Catholic Churches in this City, assembled a few evenings since, and determined to hold a Fair for the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum of the City of Brooklyn. The Fair will be held at Montague Hall, during Easter week, commencing on Easter Monday.

A correspondent of the Nueces Valley, writing from Brownsville on the 23d ult., says that intelligence has been received from Monterey that the revolution had been proclaimed at that place, and rumor has it that CARVAJAL is there, although one of his officers must be near the frontier, as news had been received that Col. MONTERO, of the regular Mexican army, had been captured by him.

The mail is through from New-Orleans. A letter from an officer of the army in Florida says, that BILLY BOWLEGS has been deposed from the command of his tribe, on account of his consenting to their removal from Florida.

The State Temperance Alliance reassembled at 3 o'clock this afternoon. A Committee of eight, one from each Judicial District, was appointed to nominate officers of the Alliance for the ensuing year. The Executive Committee reported some amendments, enlarging said Committee, , which were adopted.

We are likely to have a singularly interesting contested election case from Louisiana. Hon. J. P. BENJAMIN, who was elected by the late Legislature, to succeed Mr. DAVIES. Since that time the new Constitution has gone into operation, and its provisions cause all public offices to be immediately vacated.

The Senate devoted another hour to day in secret session, to the nomination of Mr. BADGER. Mr. FITZPATRICK, the newly-elected Senator from Alabama. arrived in the Southern boat this afternoon, and was immediately sent for. He reached the Senate while BADGER'S case was up--was sworn in, and took his seat--but as Mr. DAWSON, of Georgia, arrived with him, it did not change the state of the vote, and the nomination was again laid over.

American Literature has neglected our Pulpit. Among its omissions--its national omissions--this has been one of its capital faults, and it is the more remarkable from the fact, that our countrymen seem to have an instinctive veneration for pulpit effort. No where are the churches better attended than in the United States.

No. 52. The General Mutual Insurance Company, plaintiff in error, vs. Ebenezer Sherwood. The argument of this cause was concluded by Mr. Hamilton for the plaintiff in error. No. 58, Elijah Peale, Trustee, , plaintiff in error, vs. Martha Phippe et al. This cause was argued by Mr. Lawrence for the plaintiff in error, and submitted on a printed argument by Mr. Taylor in behalf of the defendants in error.

From the Milwaukee (Wis) Sentinel. In consequence of a letter from a traveler in Norway, which has been published in most of the American newspapers, relating to a certain disease in a small part of Norway, to which is given the alarming name of Leprosy, several of the Norwegians of the city of Milwaukee assembled together for the purpose of discussing the matter.

TEMPERANCE.--The tenth regular meeting of the Washingtonian Temperance Society took place on Wednesday evening. The meeting, which was unusually large and interesting, was addressed by Messrs. PRICE, HUTCHINS, STAYLOR, EVANS and LITTLEDALE, of New-York.
The Reindeer Homicides--Trial of Charles W. Farnhem, Master of the Reindeer, for Manslaughter. U.S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Judge BETTS. FOURTH DAY.

In the Senate, on Wednesday, Mr. BERKMAN introduced the following resolutions respecting the MADIAI'S: Resolved, (if the Assembly concur,) That the Legislature of the State of New York have regarded with deep solicitude and regret the recent persecutions to which FRANCISCO MADIAI and his wife ROSA MADIAI, have been subjected in the kingdom of Tuscany, for the alleged crime of reading the Holy Scriptures.

The 18th day of January, a day henceforth to be enrolled among the "dies fasts" of our country, as the anniversary of the birth of WEBSTER, was appropriately observed in this city by a eulogy upon the great statesman, pronounced before the faculty and students of Yale College, by Hon. HIRAM KETCHUM, of your City.
The Secretary of the Treasury reports RECEIPTS AND EXPENDITURES. The receipts for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1852, Were:

WHISPERING.--We copy the following sensible remarks from the Berlin Messenger:--"Those young gentlemen in the habit of whispering in church or public meeting must quit it--it won't do. Ladies may be excusable, but gentlemen cannot.

To say that Mesdames SONTAG and ALBONI are two of the most distinguished artists, not only of the day, but of the musical annals of the world, may seem like using a truism to let off a double-barrelled puff; yet we more than question whether the public has that constant appreciation of the fact which it is but just that it should have.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In your notice of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S "Life of Moore," you represent MOORE'S father as keeping a potty grocery store in Dublin, similar to those groggeries kept by Germans at the corner of every street in this city.

The Ministers of Austria, Prussia and Russia have at length presented their credential letters to the Emperor. The Emperor of Russia remained firm in his refusal to use the term "Brother," and compromised by writing "Mon ami."
Of the sum of $100,000, to be raised for the Union Theological Seminary, the Rev. Mr. GALLAGHER has succeeded in getting subscriptions to the amount of $75,000.

The clerks down town have got a grand topic of talk. For three or four days past it has been constantly introduced in their business hours, in their waiting at the Post Office, in their knots at the dining saloons, in their homeward walks, and in their evening recreations.

On Monday evening, the 3d inst., a superb banquet was given, at Liverpool, to Hon. J. B. INGERSOLL, the American Minister, by the American Chamber of Commerce. Sixty gentlemen were present--among them, the Earls of DERBY and SEFTON.
OUTRAGEOUS ASSAULT.--A young man named WILLIAM R. WILLIS was yesterday arraigned be fore the Mayor, charged with the commission of two grave offences.

A novel scene was witnessed yesterday in the Assembly Chamber at Albany. On motion of Mr. BURROUGHS, leave was granted that a deputation of ladies there present offer in person the petition of 28,000 ladies for the Maine Law.
YANKEE GIRLS.--The independence of the Yankee girl begins at the early stage of boarding school life--with the choice of her books, her dancing-master, of her congregation, of her minister.

By the arrival of the Europa, at Halifax, we have Liverpool dates to the 8th inst. The Niagara arrived out on the 3d, and the Arctic, on the 5th. The Hermann sailed on the 5th, but was obliged to put back to Cowes. The commercial intelligence is unfavorable;

MR. EDITOR.--A friend of mine is chasing those ignes fatui, Land Titles, in the swamps and wild lands of Michigan. He writes to me from time to time describing his progress and adventures. I enclose a few extracts from some of his letters, which are at your service if they possess interest.
Some severe skirmishing has taken place between the Turks and Montenegrines at Kirbancar, on the Lake of Scutarl. The Turks lost 600 killed and the loss of the Montenegrines was also great.

The royal mail steamship Europa, Capt SHANNON, from Liverpool on the 8th instant, arrived 7 o'clock this morning, and sailed again at 9 1/2 for Boston, where she will be due about 5 o'clock P.M. on Saturday.

Our streets are never cleaned. Our police force is inefficient, and our thoroughfares are obstructed by a thousand disagreeable obstacles. We walk in mire, sleep in fear, and run the risk daily of being trampled to death by infuriated oxen in our principal highways.

THE MEETING OF THE DEMOCRATIC GENERAL COMMITTEE (SOFT SHELL,) AT TAMMANY HALL.- PEOPOSITION OF THE HARD SHELLS TO BUILD A NEW HALL.--In pursuance of the call of the Tammany Hall Sachems as reported in the Daily Times of yesterday, a meeting was held last night by the "Soft Shell" portion of the Democratic Committee for 1853, in the "coal hole" adjoining the restaurant, in the basement of Tammany Hall.

ATLANTIC DOCK PROPERTY.--We are gratified to state, as we do on reliable authority, that the property on the Atlantic Dock, taken in 1851, by the late FRANCIS GRIFFIN, Esq., from Mr. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, as security for endorsements for $80,000, has proved to be fully adequate to that object.

NEW PROJECT FOR CLEANING THE STREETS.--His Honor Mayor LAMBERT, last evening sent a communication to the Common Council, In which he suggests the following plan: The division of the City into three Districts, as follows--First District composing the First, Second, Third, Fourth and Fifth Wards; Second District, Sixth and Tenth; Third District, Seventh and Eleventh.

From the New-Orleans ??, Jan. 13. We have received files of papers from the City of Mexico to the 23d, and Vera Cruz to the 27th ult. They contain some very interesting intelligence. The Chamber of Deputies had passed the bill granting the privilege of opening a communication across the Isthmus of Tehuantepec to the Guanajuato Company, and it had gone to the Senate for the concurrence of that body.

For several days past we have had very fine weather for sleighing, and it has been enjoyed with infinite zest and animation. All the outlets of our City are covered with racers, powdering to and fro, for the bare life; but the finest exhibition of the sport of the season is on our Corso--the Neck--connecting the head of the State with the broad shoulders of Dorchester and Roxbury.

A MAN STABBED--PROBABLE MURDER.--Yesterday morning, at about 1 o'clock, a serious affray occurred in Seventh avenue, near Seventeenth street, originating from a dispute hetween four Germans named HENRY ECKHART AND GEORGE KOHLER, and NICHOLAS GOODMAN and WILLIAM MALCOLM.

BANKS.--The new Bank is to be opened in the Sentinel Buildings, and will commence operation at an early day, under the General Banking Law. The report relative to the subject of Banking, before the Legislature, states that four Banks have been established during the year 1851-2, with approved securities of publie stocks as their basis, and Of bonds and mortgages upon real estatte, according to law.

PLANK ROADS.--A Plank Road is about to be laid from the easterly termination of Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, and running thence easterly, nearly a straight line, to the Brooklyn and Jamaica Plank Road, at a point near the dwelling-house of Mr. E. BERGEN, Jamaica, ?? County. The books for subscription for stock will be opened in a few days.

The new steamer J. Wilaon, as she was leaving the landing at Columbla on the 6th Inst. burst two of her boilers, carrying off the forecastle and nearly one-third of hurricane roof One of the boilers was blown ashore, a distance of more than fifty yards. In its passage it struck the upper story of the Phoenix Exchange Coffee House, belonging to Captain PETER ROWLETT, which it completely demolished.

The news of the morning is not particularly full refreshing. From Mexico, we have news from the capital to the 23d ult. The Government had intercepted letters from Gen. URAGA to partisans in the City of Mexico.

The exchange of courtesies between British merchants and manufacturers, and Mr. JOSEPH R. INGERSOLL, our Minister at the Court of St. James, marks quite a millennial condition of political affairs. The lion and the lamb lie down together.

The Treasurer of Columbia County, Ohio, having called, on the 30th upon upon the Salem Bank for taxes assessed several times, and being refused, on the ground that the taxes were levied on the capital instead of the profits, entered the Bank with a posse, armed with guns, revolvers and sledges, for the purpose of breaking open the vaults and securing the requisite funds.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE.--On Sunday, BRIDGET McGOWAN attempted to commit suicide by drowning herself in the East River, near Catherine Ferry, she was rescued by Officer BURNS, of the Second District Police, with much difficulty. Cause alleged--brutal treatment by her husband while intoxicated.

BROADWAY.--The opera of "La Cenerentola," with the original cast. This is the last night but two of the present Opera season, Madame ALBONI being announced to appear in Boston on Monday evening. Between the acts of the opera, Madame ALBONI and the Chorus will sing the Drinking Song from "Lucrezia Borgia." --On Thursday evening the opera of "Norma" is to be produced.

Mr. Frederick Leopold, a naturalized citizen of the United States, who last summer was seized in Hanover, for military services due to the King thereof, has returned to his home in Charleston. S. C. He states that he was seized at night, and immediately taken to prison.

Two back New-Orleans mails have seen received. The papers contain City of Mexico dates to the 23d ult. The Mexican Government had intercepted several letters to Gen. URAGA to partisans in the City of Mexico, in which he informed them he awaited Government in the capital, where he would attack under Gen. MINON, and hinder Guadalajara from again acknowledging Centrall Government.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Jan. 23, 1853.

Our readers Wilt remember that the Hon. J. P. BENJAMIN was elected to the United States Senate by the Legislature of Louisiana a year ago, sitting under the old Constitution. By that Constitution the State Legislature assembled only one in two years, and at the time of Mr. BENJAMIN'S election it was, supposed that the next Legislature would not assemble in time to anticipate the vacancy which occurs on the 4th of March next.
