FRANKLIN LECTURES.--Professor Yeomans delivered the introductory lecture to a series on Chemistry, on Monday evening, January 24th, at Broadway Taberncle. Subject for the evening--" The Chemical Relations of the Atmosphere of the Living World."

DARING BURGLARY AND THEFT.--During Sunday night the grocery store of Mr. A PETERSON, at tho corner of Grand-street and Graham-avenue, was broken into by some daring thieves, who carried away two jars of butter worth 826; two kege of lard, each weighing 56 Ibs.; amounting in all to $40.

The Emperor has re regulated the three bodies of State, Council, Senate and nominal Legislature, by a new decree, which repeats, with slight additional restrictions, the decree of March 22. The Moniteur gives notice that, if the bodies show any signs of restiveness, the Emperor will regulate them still more severely, as by article six of the late "modifications" he has the Constitutional right to do. Thirty-eight new Senators

In these days, if we fail to receive a steamer from across the Atlantic, an arrival from California, or something a little later from Mexico, we put it down as a dull day, and pronounce the newspapers particularlyt stupid.

THE CONDEMNED--INTERVIEW BETWEEN THE CONVICTS SAUL AND HOWLETT AND THEIR FRIENDS.-- The Confession lately made by WILLIAM SAUL and NICHOLAS HOWLETT, relative to the murder of CHARLES BAXTER--published exclusively in the Daily Times of yesterday-has excited the sympathies of a large number of persons who take an interest in the prisoners fate.

In pursuance of a call, published yesterday morning, and signed by Mayor WESTERVELT and several distinguished citizens, a meeting was held in the Astor House, last evening, to take measures for the relief of the unfortunate sufferers in Madeira, who had been rendered destitute by the failure of the Vine and Potato.

ARREST.--Yesterday, officer POLLARD received a telegraph dispatch from Philadelphia, stating that a party who had committed a robbery in that city, was on his way to New-York, per the Philadelphia train. A description of his dress, height, age and general appearance was also communicated.

The following letters of Mr. F. W. Rice, the late Consul of the United States at Acapulco, are referred to in the regular letter of our correspondent at Washington. They will be read with profound interest as throwing light on a question which has often engaged the attention of readers of the Daily Times.

A NEW EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION.--The Protestant Episcopal Church of this City have, for some time past, been considering the propriety of establishing an institution for the education of females, upon a different plan from any now established, where pupils are educated under the influence of the Episcopal Faith.

I drop you a line just as the mail is closing. Last Saturday was a miserable cold and rainy day, and all its horrors continued yesterday, except that the rain turned into a drizzle, and the cold increased its intensity. There must have been a heavy fall of snow North and West.

A correspondent writes us plaintively about the quality of the grammar used by the daily press. As he makes the Daily Times an exception to his censures, we are not obliged to regard them as at all personal. But we must say, there is much to be said on both sides of this business.

On Tuesday, Jan. 25, of consumption, NELSON J. PECK, in the 23d seat of his age. His friends, and those of his brothers, Wm T. and D. C. Pick, and of his brother in law, Nelson J. Eillott, are invited to attend his funeral, from the residence of his brother-in-law, T. D. Smith. No. 191 Pearl-st., Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, without further invitation. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

THOMAS F. MEAGHER met with a cordial reception in Boston to-day. He was received at the Depot by a Committee of Arrangements, and conveyed to the Revere House, in an elegant carriage and\four horses, where he was formally welcomed in a speech by J. B. HARVEY, Esq.: to which Mr. M. responded.

Mr. SEWARD expects to speak to morrow in the Senate. It is said that he will express approval of the principles of the MONROE doctrine, and vote for Mr. CASS'S resolutions on that ground, if they are brought to a vote; but that, at the same time, he will insist that no such resolutions ought to have been introduced--that there was no necessity or occasion for them in the existing state of affairs.

The Galena Advertiser, of the 17th, says: "We are unacquainted with the writer of the following letter, and have no means of judging of the reliability of the statements made; but, under the circumstances, we have no right or disposition to deny the request made, and withhold them from the public."

TO MANAGE A REARING HORSE.--In the British Sportsman we find the following hint respecting the management of a rearing horse, which strikes us as being worthy, as it is easy, of a trial; When-ever you perceive a horse's inclination to rear, separate your reins and prepare for him.

CLEVELAND.--The Forest City grows rapidly in business and importance, and it is not to be wondered at that she should, now and then, as she moves on ward with railway speed, "takes airs upon themselves." But our thriving neighbor of "the Lakes far away," says, as does The Forest City of the 19th inst., that Cleveland must eventually become the great Park Depot of Ohio."

CHAMPAGNE AND THE GOVERNMENT LANDS.--"Our government lands cost one dollar an acre, on an average, and champagne two dollars a bottle. How many a man dies in the poor-house, who, during his life-time, has drank a fertile township, trees and all!" We could not help these reflections yesterday, as we sat at the Weddel House table and saw the Heidsick, and sparkling Catawba going the rounds, free as water.

IMPORTANT TO MARINERS.--It is not unfrequently the case that vessels on our coast, wishing to make Portland harbor, are compelled to put to sea, on account of strong head winds, while, if they understood the directions, they could enter Richmond's Island harbor, and thus in a short time find a safe retreat.

The Pennsylvanian contains the following: "There were eleven prisoners before the May of yesterday morning, one of whom came up vol intarily and confessed vagrancy, requesting that he might be sent to the County Prison. "Have you tried the Alms House?" asked the Mayor.

News has been received to-day, by way of New-Orleans, of a very important character. The latest date from the City of Mexico was to the 12th inst, which is twenty days later than previously received. President ARISTE had resigned the Presidency of the Republic, and fled from the City.
The Court of Quarter Sessions in Allegheny County, commenced on the 27th ult., and we find in the Pittsburg Gazette the very plain, pointed and sensible charge of Judge McCLURE to the Grand Jury.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A paragraph which appeared in some newspaper a short time since, relative to the disposal, after death, of the remains of the late Senator UPHAM, has been republished in your paper, with comments of a nature to do me great injury, if the facts had been stated correctly; but such is not the case.

Schooner Henrietta, from Wilmington, N. C., for New-York, sprung aleak, 16th inst., and run ashore at Currituck Beach, near Baums. The vessel is a total loss. Cargo saved, and will be sold on Thursday next. The crew reached here safely to-day.

THE FIVE POINTS MISSION BUILDINGS--LAYING OF THE CORNER STONE--The corner stone of the new Mission Building, which is to be erected on the site of the old Brewery at the Five Points, is to be laid on Thursday afternoon at 2 o'clock.

The Tallahassee Sentinel publishes the following important documents in relation to the Seminoles in Florida. Governor BROWN having returned the bill for the removal of the Indians, as passed by the Legislature, it was reconsidered by both Houses, on the 14th inst., and passed by the constitutional majority, over the Governor's veto. Its provisions are stringent.

The Anniversary meeting of the Methodist Episcopal Church Society was held yesterday--Bishop JANES, of New-York, in the Chair. The principal speakers were Dr. DURBIN, the Corresponding Secretary of the Society in New-York; ABEL STEVENS, Editor of the National Magazine; and Bishop JAMES. The affairs of the Society were reported to be in a flattering condition.

The Annual Message of the Governor of Louisiana was read on the 17th inst. The Governor commences by congratulating the Logislature on the prosperous condition of this State and of the nation. Then referring, in appropriate terms. to the death of CALHOUN, CLAY, WEBSTER and WOODBURY, he proceeds to speak of the result of the late Presidential election as the overthrow of sectional legislation.

TROUT FISHING IN WINTER.--The following account of a singular incident by which a fine trout was captured, was originally published in a New-Hampshire paper in 1792, whence it was copied into the Massachusetts Magazine, for the same year.

BROADWAY.--Madame ALBONI appeared for the last time as Cenerentola last evening. She was in excellent voice, and sang with even more grace and spirit, than she did on the opening night. Between the acts of the Opera, she gave the Drinking Song from "Lucrezia Borgia," which was encored.

The steamship Empire City has arrived at this port with Havana dates of the 20th inst. The news generally is unimportant. MARTIN GALLIANO, the Secretary of the Captain-General, had been removed, and his successor was expected from Spain by the next steamer.

THE ZEBRA AGAIN.--We are pleased to learn from the consigness, Messrs. KINCHLEY, LOCKETT Co., that Dr. DEMERE returned from the above vessel last night, and reports the health of the emigrants greatly improved. No new cases have occurred for two days, and the general appearance of the sufferers greatly improved.

NERVES.--The most agreeable friends in the world, may, by a judicious and persevering use of the facilities they enjoy, become eminently trouble-some and unpleasant. Of all these friends we know of, none more desirable in friendship, more terrible in enmity, than the one whose name we have prefixed to this article.

"A hand of whistlers are organizing in the New-England States, who design the execution of National and Operatic airs in plain English. This is an unique feature, and we should think such performances would prove attractive. The Columbian whistlers, as they are called, are said, using a hackneyed Shaksperianism, to 'discuss most eloquent music.' "--Exchange.

A LONDON EDITOR FIFTY YEARS AGO.--Our editor was originally intended for the kirk, and was a well-informed person; but to see him at or after midnight in his official chair, a Writing his" leader." was a treat for a philosopher.

A correspondent of the Bangor Mercury walks into peripatetic pill pedlers thus: "With regard to itinerant physicians, the people of this goodly city have abundant reason to let them alone most severely; they are, as a usual thing, nothing more or less than medical vagrants; and when a physician gets to this pass, it may be laid down, as an infallible rule, that he is more knave than fool.

WHAT SOMEBODY SAYS OF THE YANKEE GIRL.--"She very early acquires the calculating habits of the country. She is her own duenna and chaperon. She learns to value her admirers according to their worth. Her fancy and heart always under the control of reason. Romance is all very well in books, but marriage is a matter of prose.

An excited Irishman thus contrasts the Celtic and Saxon races, in one of the London papers: "The Celt has a long cranium, high and expressive features, dark, or warm complexion, square and muscular frame," such as we find in the SPAKSPERES, NEWTONS, NELSONS, and WELLINGTONS, in the STEVENSONS, and men of enterprise, in great statesmen, authors, artists,

MURDOCK first used gas to light his offices at Redruth in 1792. "It would," says LIEBIG, " he one of the greatest discoveries of the age, if any one could succeed in condensing coal gas into a white, dry, solid, odorless subtance, portable, and capable of being placed on a candlestick or burnt in a lamp."

MY DEAR FRIEND: You have been often in my thoughts, since I received your affectionate letter of the 16th inst. It was one of the earliest of the kind from my personal friends; soothing and grateful to me at the time. And it has been pleasant since, to think of you as among those who have truly sympathized with us in this dark hour of overpowering affliction.

SPANISH FRITTERS.--Cut the soft part of baker's bread in slices of a quarter of an inch thick, and of any form you choose. Take a pint of milk or cream, three well-beaten eggs, half a teaspoonful of nutmeg and cinnamon mixed, three drops of the essence of lemmon, and sugar to the taste, stir well together and pour over the slices.

The Broadway Railroad Bill was up in the Senate again yesterday. Mr. McMURRAY was in favor of it, but thought it would fall short of working out the great reform. The bill necessary to do that should grapple with the City Charter itself.

FATAL ACCIDENT IN A STEAM TOBACCO FACTORY--THE INQUEST.--Yesterday morning, Coroner O'DONNELL held an inquest on the body of a lad named EDWARD McLOUGHLIN, who was killed in the tobacco factory of Messrs. HOYT Co., corner of Dover and Front-streets.

We have the outlines of very remarkable news from Mexico this morning, through an arrival at New-Orleans. The latest date from the City of Mexico was to the 12th inst. President ARISTA had resigned and fled the City, and his troops were scattered by the Revolutionists. CEVALLOS, the President of the Supreme Court, had been called to the head of the temporary Government. We shall doubtless have full accounts soon.

Whither has political principle fled? Whether are cabinets or patriots most skillful and successful in tergiversation? And who will go down to posterity most deeply branded with political profligacy--Governments or Agitators, when--after the bitterest, sworn mutual hostility, they have become locked in closest, fraternal alliance? We had a Government-rogarded as strong in party-stronger still in principle.

A SNAKE STORY.--In the south-eastern Part of the town of Harwinton, (says the Hartford Times,) on land owned by Mr. B. ALFRED, it was surmised that a burrow of black snakes lived in an old cellar, from the heads of several being occasionally seen projecting from the wall.

We are gratified to announce the liberation of Captain GRAY, of the Lady Suffolk, whose confinement at Havana has been the subject of repeated notice in the Daily Times. The statement of our Baltimore correspondent is entirely reliable.

A fatal malady broke out a short time since at Galena, which defies all the effort of physicians. It is a new type of disease, and with symptoms entirely peculiar, so much so that the physicians fear its attacks more than that of any epidemic which has raged through the country for years.

A large building on India-street, near Fox Point, was set on fire about noon to-day, and nearly destroyed, together with a large portion of its contents. It was owned by MOWRY STEERE, lumber dealers, and occupied as a storehouse for shingles and other lumber, oil,

The United States ship Raritan. Commodore McAULEY, ninety-eight days from Callao has arrived. Lieut. BENHAM died on the passage. His remains were preserved and brought home. She spoke, Nov. 23d, ship Danube from New-York for San Francisco--Dec. 26th, steamship Sierra Nevada, from New-York for Rio Janeiro--Jan. 18th, fell in with the wreck of a brigatine, waterlogged and abandoned.

Captain GRAY, of this city, who sold the Lady Suffolk to some of your New-Yorkers, who it is alleged, with certain parties in Cuba, have put her into the slave trade, has been fully discharged, and is now on his way home in the steamer Isabel, via Charleston.

LADIES' HOME MISSION OF THE METHODIST EPISCOPAL CHURCH.--Mr. WM. ROSH WALLACE will deliver a lecture at the Odeon, this (Wednesday) evening, for the benefit of the Williamsburg Ladies' Home Mission of the Methodist Episcopal Church. The subject of the lecture will be "Peter the Great, the Barbarian, Emperor, and Self-Civilized.

EXCELLENT ADVICE.--Watch and fortify your-selves against the temptation of sending any poetry to the Editor. To heed this caution, with many, will require great self-denial, yet we trust some will "reck the redo." The world is already full of poetry, and will not, in reality, need any new creations of this sort for at least ten years to come.

OREGON.--We have already referred to the fact, that a College has already been projected in this distant region, with a view of affording the sons of the emigrants, the means of obtaining a classical education on the Pacific coast. The undertaking is one which cannot be too highly commended.

CURRENTS OF THE GULF.--The Nueces Valley of the 1st inst., publishes the following, which was found enclosed in a bottle, eight miles southwest of Arkansas Pass, on Mustang Island. It is signed by Capt. NEWENHAM, of the British West India mail packet Dee: This makes the fourth bottle which I have thrown overboard from the packet to ascertain when picked up. If ever, the currents of the Gulf, and any other existing stream.

Long before the hour of meeting, the Senate galleries and passages leading thereto, were crowded with men and women, expecting to hear Mr. SOULE. The Chair laid before the Senate, the annual report of the expenses of the National Armory for 1852.

IMPROVEMENTS IN OMNIBUSES.--The regulation adopted by most of the omnibuses on the 2d inst., requiring the fare to be paid in advance, appears to work well. The coach is no longer detained, as formerly, while passengers fumble for their change, which ought to be forthcoming before the strap was pulled.

GOLD MINES IN NEW-YORK.--The Dansville Herald says, great excitement exists at Canisteo, in the county of Steuben, in consequence of an alleged discovery of a gold mine. A boy who made the discovery, it is stated, took out $500 worth of the precious metal.

While at Augusta, recently, we visited the Insane Hospital. It was just at the time when the Democratic Senators had trigged the wheels of Government, and the business of legislation had come to a stand. One of the patients--probably a retired politician--seemed to feel a great interest in the matter, and questioned us very closely as to the causes of the delay and the circumstances attending it.

Two New-Orleans mails reached here this morning, bringing papers of the 18th and 19th inst. The following account of the pronunciation of the City of Vera Cruz, and the Castle of San Juan d'Ulloa, is copied from La Union of the 29th ultimo: The City of Vera Cruz has seconded the plan of Guadainja.

FALL OF A HOUSE.--On Monday afternoon, a two-story wooden house, worth about $1,000, owned by Mr. THOMAS BURROUGHS, and located In Skillman-street, between Willoughby-street and Myrtle-avenue, fell over, and was broken in pieces.

The Secretary of the Treasury has directed the Collector of the Port of New-York, to institute a thorough investigation into the cause of the recent fire in the Government Warehouse in that City, and to make a speedy report to the Department. There were THREE MILLIONS DOLLARS' worth of property in the Warehouse at the time of the fire.

In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SEWARD presented petitions in favor of CHRISTIAN HANSON'S proposed line of Mail Steamers between Brooklyn and Giuokstadt, and all parts of Germany. Mr. SHIELDS offered a resolution, directing inquiry by the Secretary of War, to report the most eligible sites for necessary arsenals on the Pacific, Gulf and Atlantic Coasts; and it passed.

Inventors, discoverers and all men who make a mark in the world, are sure to receive the marks of many blows before they get through with it. When a bachelor reads that the course of true love never runs smooth, he thinks that he developes great shrewdness if he steers altogether clear of true love's currents.

TELEGRAPH LINES IN CUBA.--The Government of Cuba recently advertised for proposals for laying down six hundred miles of subtorranean telegraph wires, and also for building three hundred miles upon posts, after the manner of the lines in the United States.

REPORTS OF COMMITTEE. Mr. COOLEY, from commerce and navigation, by bill, giving the Staten Island. Railroad Company ferry privileges between New-York and Staten Island. Mr. PIERCE, from the committee on printing, favorably on the bill relative to printing the Colonial History. Mr. MONROE gave notice of a bill amending the act for the preservation of the public health.

GREAT WIRE BRIDGE.--It is known that there is no regular bridge communication across the Potomac between the District and Alexandria. A proposition for the erection of an immense wire suspension bridge has just been submitted to the Corporation of Georgetown, by CHARLES ELLET, Esq., Civil Engineer.

While Col. SPOONER printed a paper at Sag Harbor, he was much encouraged by a liberal merchant, who advertised his wares in two long columns specifying every item of wet and dry goods, shovels, stationery and mouse traps.

THE CAMANCHE INDIANS.--A friend of ours, an officer in the army, who has for several years been stationed at a port in Western Texas, represents the condition of the Camanche Indians in that country as extremely deplorable. Confined to their territory by a hedge of mititary posts, and unable to pursue their game beyond the frontier, they are almost in a state of starvation.

MASTER BENJAMIN PIERCE.--This bright and manly little fellow, whose melancholy death has awakened so deep and universal a sympathy for the desolate parents, was worthy of all the affection with which they cherished him, and of all the hopes they entertained of him.

HYDROPHOBIA AMONG DOGS--Mr. A. ERMAN, in his "Travels of Siberia," remarks on this subject, that madness is unknown among dogs.--"Madness," says he "among the dogs would be, in this country, a most formidable scourge, and would infallibly cause the destruction of whole races of men; but every one here assured us that the disease is wholly unknown to them.

If the let of January, 1853, will be famous for nothing else, it will be eternally celebrated as the day on which the largest sale of sugar-plums was ever effected in Paris since the year one. The quantity disposed of was really fabulous, during the week preceding, and the forty-eight hours following New Year's day.

From the Cleveland Herald. An outrage occurred in Salem, Ohio, yesterday, of an extraordinary character, growing out of a difficulty between the Farmers' Branch Bank of that Town, and the Treasurer of Columbiana County. Some time ago the Treasurer demanded payment from the Blank of a State Tax of $3,397 38, which the bank refused to pay.

The negotiations for the purchase of the Republic, by DUFF GREEN and other parties, has collapsed. It is said that some of those engaged in the movement became a little afraid of Mr. GREEN, and accordingly took advantage of the difference with Mr. GIDEON, relative to the price demanded by him for a transfer of the establishment, to let the scheme die out.

ALLEN THOMAS has presented a petition to the Maryland Legislature, relative to a fugitive slave convicted of felony in New-York, and pardoned by Governor HUNT, three days before the expiration of his term of imprisonment.

We have received late and important intelligence from Mexico. President ARISTA resigned office, and left the City of Mexico on the 6th inst. Sen. CAEVALLAR, Judge of the Supreme Court of Justice, becomes President ad interim.

SUICIDE BY AN ENGLISH SURGEON--POVERTY AND DESPAIR--Yesterday morning, Coroner GAMBLE was called to hold an inquest at the Sixth Ward Station-house, on the body of WALTER JARDINE, an English Surgeon, aged 35 years, who committed suicide in the rear of No. 135 Walker-street.

The Court opened at 11 o'clock. The term is especially held for the trial of the JERRY Rescue cases. Present of Counsel for Government, Hon. JAMES R. LAWRENCE, U. S. District Attorney. D. D. HILLS, Esq., of Syracuse, and GERRIT SMITH, of Peterporo. After some motions In civil causes were disposed of, the District-Attorney moved the trial of ENOCH REED, (colored.)

MOTIONS DECIDED.--Livingston and another, Appellants against Fitch and others, Respondents. Motion by Appellants to vacate a judgment of afflemance entered at this term, and fur leave to apply to the court below to amend the bill of exceptions--denied with $10 costs. C. L. Benedict for motion. N. Hill, Jr., opposed.

We have no tidings of the safety of the pilot boat Commerce. She was seen on the 12th inst. off Egg Harbor, and was in company with the pilot boat Nettle, No. 2, at that time and place, with the wind from E.N E. and blowing a gale.

The Convention to take into consideration the establishment of a National University, assembled in the Capitol, Wednesday morning at 11 o'clock. The Convention was called to order by T. W. OLCOTT, of Albany, on whose motion Dr. T. ROMEYN BECK of Albany, was called to the Chair, and Rev. Dr. KENNEDY, was appointed Secretary.
The debate in the Senate to-day created much excitement. Mr. SEWARD angered Mr. CASS seriously. Mr. MASON'S remark about the British Colony at Belize was startling, and it was considered ominous.

By reference to our news from the West Indies, there will be found an item of interest to farmers. It seems that the Island of St. Vincent abounds in a kind of earth of very peculiar properties, and withal so valuable, that it is likely to become, at no distant day, an important and regular article of exportation.

From Spain, we have nothing of interest. The expenses of the Treasury for the present month are fixed at 115,244,618 reals. There is no political news, except contentions between the various parties in the Cabinet.

COTTON--The very quiet tone with which our market closed on Friday last, was again fully manifested on Saturday, when holders becoming anxious sellers; and the demand being very small, buyers were enabled to purchase on rather lower terms.

By the arrival of the steamship Mexico, Capt. PLACE, we have received dates from Galveston to the 14th inst. The News says that a letter has been received in Galveston, giving information that there was a rise in the Trinity at Pine Bluff, on the 3d inst., of three feet.
The speech of Senator SEWARD-it will be found on our first page-upon the MONROE principle, is, as usual with that gentleman's efforts, clear, condensed and satisfactory.

Senator CLEMENS has received a dispatch, stating that Mr. KING arrived at Key West on the 22d instant--his health being no better than when he left- that he has himself lost all hope of his recovery, and will remain at Key West.

JOHN CAPSIDY, Captain of Philadelphia oyster sloop Hero, is likely to die at Annapolis, from wounds received while resisting the officers who seized his vessel. The Virginia House of Delegates have passed a bill appropriating a million dollars for the construction of a Railroad from Covington to the Ohio River, near the month of the Big Sandy River--also a bill increasing the stock of the Manassas Gap Railroad.

The mail is through from Now-Orleans. The steamer Fashion, Captain BAKER, arrived at New-Orleans on the 18th, having left Tampa bay on the 16th inst. General CHILDS was at that port; also, Capt. GRAHAM, Commanding the Engineer party surveying the route for a ship canal. General BLAKE left Tampico for Fort Myers on the 17th.
Beautiful nights these,-pleasant, mild, and moon-shiny. Capital nights for sliding down hill-capital for getting up a sleighride to distant singing schools.

The CHAIR land before the Senate the communication from the Treasury Department, concerning the classification of Clerks. Mr. SUMNER presented petitions from Boston, praying the establishment of uniform rates of ocean postage of two cents per half-ounce.

On the 7th inst. the Second Chamber proceeded to the election of its President for the remainder of the session. The extreme right, or Tory party, put forward Herr von KLEIST RETZOW; the Catholic party Herr von WALDBOTT; and the left, or Moderate Constitutional party, Graf SCHWEREIN.
Our special correspondent at Washington, with his usual industry, has supplied us with a verbatim report of Senator SOULE'S speech upon the Cuban Question.

After a long debate the Whig Legislative Caucus, this P. M., nominated Hon. EDWARD EVERETT for United States Senator on the first ballot. The vote was --Everett 98; ASHMAN 54; BRIGGS 4 ; ROCKWELL 3 ; GRINNELL 1. The vote was then made unanimous.
The Seventh Lecture of the People's Course was delivered at Broadway Tabernacle, on Tuesday evening, Jan. 25, by Rev. THEODORE PARKER, of Boston. Subject- The Progress of Mankind.

The steamer Isabel has arrived at this port, having left Havana and Key West on the 22d inst. Small pox had disappeared from Havana. The steam ship Futon arrived at Key West on the 22d. Mr. KING'S health was better than when he left Norfolk he would remain several days at Key West if the climate proved agreeable.

The Fifth Lecture of the course before the Mechanics' Institute was delivered last evening by Hon. GEO. BANCROFT. The lecture-room was in sufficient to accommodate all who attended, and several were obliged to stand at the door leading from the Library.
The U. S. steamship Arctic arrived at this port at 5 o'clock last evening, having sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 12th inst., with news four days later than by the Europa.
To the Legislature: The Commissioners of the Canal Fund respect fully submit to the Legislature the annual report required of them by law.

From the London Daily News. The following piquant sketch of Count Raoussent-Boulbon and his adventures in Sonor? given in the feuilleton of the Constitutionnel, is from the pen of M. Amedee Achard: Count Raousset-Boulbon is a young man of from thirty-two to thirty-three.
From France we have little beyond the details of the Imperial appointments. It takes some time for every one to find his place under the new regime.
By the arrival of the brig American, Capt. MALONEY, from Vera Cruz, we have received dates from the City of Mexico to the 28th ult., and Vera Cruz to the 2d inst.
From the London Times. All Englishmen, and Londoners in particular, may draw, we think, a satisfactory kind of moral from certain remarkable documents which we published on Wednesday.

The Indianola Bulletin says that Capt. PLACE, of the steamship Mexico, on his last trip, reported that in coming over Pass Cavallo Bar, he sounded a channel nine feet large, which he supposed was washed out by the severe norther which preceded his arrival.
THE NEW OHIO CAPITOL.--The first appropriation for this building was made in 1838, of $10,000. From 1846 to 1848 no appropriations were made, and the work was suspended.

From the London Daily News. It is not often that we are treated with a morsel of amusing and innocent gossip in direct connection with political affairs; but such a treat is furnished to us now in the replies of the American Foreign Ministers to inquiries from their own State Department, about the sufficiency or insufficiency of their salaries to maintain them at foreign courts.

THE THREE CONDEMNED CRIMINALS--THE APPROACHING EXECUTIONS--APPEARANCE OF THE PRISONERS -AFFLICTING SCENES, , our Reporter again visited the cells of the three unfortunate condemned criminals-SAUL, HOWLETT and JOHNSON-who are to suffer the penalty of death, under the gallows, tomorrow morning. for the murder of CHARLES BAXTER, the night watchman of the packet ship Thomas Watson, in August last.

From the Waterford News. About half-past seven o'clock on Wednesday morning, Dec. 29th, a polacca rigged brig was seen running through Bannow Bay, right before the wind, which was blowing hurricane at the time.
LATER FROM NASSAU, N. P.--By the arrival of the schooner Azorian, Capt. INGRUM, we have received full illes of the Nassau Guardian, Bahama Herald, and Royal Gazette, to the 8th inst, inclusive.

Beside the Present House, of which Capt DE GROOT is to be the lesseo, and which is now nearly finished, another new hotel is rapidly progressing in Broadway. The building is going up in front of Metropolitan Hall. which superb saloon is, we learn, to be incorporated into the new establishment, and the whole will be styled the Lafarge House.
The U. S. mail Steamship Arctic, Capt. LUCE, arrived at this port at 5 o'clock last evening, having sailed from Liverpool on the afternoon of Wednesday, the 12th inst.

SIR: In my last annual report to you I explained the measures which had been adopted by this Department to effect the peaceable removal of the Seminole Indiana from Florida, and expressed the opinion that they would shortly be crowned with success.

Yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, as the mail train, consisting of three cars, on the Ohio and Pennsylvania Railroad was passing New-Brighton Bridge, an axle of the middle car broke, and the car was precipitated down an embankment a distance of forty feet.

The Mexican News, announcing President ARISTA'S resignation was received here by the Empire City from Havana. Vera Cruz dates are to the 12th inst. ARISTA'S resignation was caused by the refusal of Congress to grant him extraordinary power.
By telegraph from Charleston, we learn that Mr. KING had arrived at Key West by the steamship Fulton, on the 22d inst. He was intending to remain there a few days, perhaps for a longer time.

Three hundred and sixty-five days are a long while for this fast age. The world and all its matters ought to make wonderful progress towards perfection, if they really move at the rapid rate that we generally think they do.

AFFRAY AT A MEDICAL COLLEGE--ENCOUNTER BETWEEN TWO SOUTHERN STUDENTS--ONE STABBED WITH A BOWIE KNIFE.--Tuesday afternoon an affray occurred at the Medical College, situated in Fourteenth street, near Third-avenue, between two medical students from the State of Virginia, by the names of DAVID E. BASS and WILLIAM IRVIN.

ILLNESS OF JUDGE CALEB CUSHING.--The Supreme Judicial Court was adjourned by Chief Justice SHAW on Monday morning, until this morning, on ac count of the illness of Judge CUSHING, who is holding the present Term of the Court. His disease is said to be scarlet fever.--Botlon Times.
Sir FRANCIS HEAD went into Ireland last Summer, stayed there a fortnight, and after wards wrote a book. It forms one of Mr. PUTNAM'S semi-monthly library.

The accounts supplied us by the Arctic, of the four days in Europe preceding the 12th inst., are without notable feature. The death Of FRANCESCO MADIAI in his Florentine prison, reported though not confirmed, has excited much interest in England, and will be no less painfully welcome here.
A petition was presented from C. SWACKHAMEN for the extension of the provision of the bill regulating railways in New-York, to Williamsburg.
SECOND DAY. The Court met at 9 o'clock, A. M., pursuant to adjournment. Present-Hon. JAMES R. LAWRENCE, U. S. District Attorney, and Hon. HENRY G. WHEATON, of Counsel for Government.

FRANCIS W. RICE, late Consul at Acapulco, arrived here this evening. He will seek a searohing investigation at the hands of the Senate. The Montgomery Guards have appointed a Committee to invite THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER to visit this city, and deliver an address on the occasion of their first parade and banquet, on or about the 14th February.
On the 22d inst. at Gracs Church, Brooklyn, by Rev. Dr Vinton, E. A ROBERTSON to EMILY, daughter of Charles C. Walden. Esq On Sunday, Jan 23, by Rev. Dr. Neville, Rector of St.

We had a tremendous gale last night, accompanied with heavy snow squalls. It is clear to-night, and very cold. Thermometer, 16. Dr. KANE'S lecture here last night, before the Maryland Institute, was attended by a brilliant audience.

PROPOSED AMENDMENT OF THE LIBEL LAW.- Senator BEEKMAN introduced a bill in the following terms, in the Senate this morning. The intention of it is to place the reporter and publisher of a legislative de bate upon the same footing as the legislator who makes the remarks which are reported.-Albany Evening Journal, 24th.

FRANCIS MADIAI, whose case has excited so much attention in the religious world, is dead in prison at Florence. Mr. WILBRAHAM TAYLOR, writing in the Times, expresses his "firm conviction," that MADIAI was poisoned, and says that the unfortunate man himself complained that some slow poison was mixed with his food.

The Auditor of the Canal Department at Albany gives a very full account (in the document which we publish at length this morning) of the progress of the Canal Debt since the adoption of the new Constitution in 1846.

The Gazette contains a notice from Lord JOHN RUSSELL that the British Government has received from the Ottoman Porte an official announcement of the blockade of the Adriatic coast from Dulcigno to the extreme Turkish frontier, by the Turkish fleet.

No. 40. The Board of Trustees for the Vincennes University vs. The State of Indiana. Error to the Supreme Court of Indiana. Mr. Justice McLean delivered the opinion of the Court, reversing, with costs, the decree of said Supreme Court and remanding the cause for further proceedings, in conformity to the opinion of this Court.

The discussion of the MONROE doctrine in the Senate calls out some of the old spirit of debate. The veterans, as if piqued at the every-day lament over the decay of that body, brace themselves up to renewed energy; and at least prove a willingness to be great, if the ability be still questionable. General CASS

The Grand Division of the Sons of Temperance met to-day. Very large delegations were present from all parts of the State. NEAL Dow was presented, this evening, with a splendid silver pitcher. Speeches ware made by Messrs.
In the political world there is nothing astir, if we except the contested election between Mr. GLADSTONE and Mr. PERCEVAL, for the representation in Parliament of Oxford University.

From the London Times. The same impression of the Times which presented to the public a report of the menacing de bate in the American Senate on the relations between Great Britain and the United States, brought to this bane an ample antidote in the report of the speeches made at the dinner given by the American Chamber of Commerce as Liverpool to the new American Minister, Mr. INGERSOLL.
The Turkish squadron, on its way to blockade the Coast of Montenegre, consists of one sailing and one steam frigate, three schooners and two brigs.

The deliberations of the Senate rapidly assume a practical shape. For a while they seem disposed to lose themselves in questions savoring rather of biography and history than of current politics; and the issue narrowed into a doubt whether the MONROE Doctrine was the MONROE doctrine, or the doctrine of CALHOUN, JEFFERSON or ADAMS.

Among the arrivals at the Eagle Hotel, this forenoon, were Gov. THOMAS, of Maryland, Hons. JOHN WHEELER and MIKE WALSH, Members of Congress elect from New-York City; Mr. VOSBURGH, of Albany, a Presidential Elector; Editor of the Troy Budget, and FRANK FOLLET, New-York Canal Commissioner, Room is left for a few more.

COUNTERFEITERS--ASTOUNDING DISCLOSURES. --A correspondent of the Cynthiana (Ky.,) News, in a letter from Harrison County, of the 6th inst., gives the following information of the discovery of a clan of counterletters, horse thieves and robbers. A man named NEIL BALLINGAL, of Nicholas County, was arrested for uttering spurious money, by officer JAMES KENTON, who upon searching the premises, found the sum of $4.118 counter?? bills, of the denominations of $100.

LAND COMMISSIONERS' MEETING.--The Commissioners appointed by the Executives of Massachusetts and Maine, under the act of 1819, for the purpose of dividing the public lands in Maine, met at the State House, in Boston, on Saturday last, organized their Board, and filled up the Commission, in pursuance of the provisions of said act, by appointing CHAS. B. HALL, Esq., of Haverhill, and ELDRIDGE GERRY, of Waterford, Maine

SHIFTING FLAGS IN ACTION.--This naval manoeuvre did not originate as supposed by many, with Commodore 0. H. PERRY; although he de serves great credit for the manner in which he executed it after his own ship was desabled, and thus achieve the victory on Lake Erie, Sept. 10, 1813.

MASSACHUSETTS.--The Free Soil State Committee, comprising most of the leading men of that party, have issued a circular relative to the Convention called to revise the Constitution of Massachusetts, which is to assemble in May. After defending the measure, they allude to some of the changes which the friends of the measure propose to advocate: such as an alteration of the representative system; a division of the Commonwealth into forty single Senatorial Districts;

HENRY S. RANDALL was called to the Chair, and Prof. PERKINS was appointed Secretary. Mr. RANDALL said: He had no doubt that a properly organized National University was a great dosideratum. He desired to see one established. But he must be distinctly understood that, in taking the place assigned him upon the Committee, he pledged himself to no particular plan, or even class of views, on the subject.

A NORTHAMPTON BOY ABROAD--An exchange says:--" We learn that Mr. WILLIAM D. WHITNEY, of Northampton, Mass., now in Berlin--a brother of the excellent chemist and geologist, J.D. WHITNEY, Esq., of the U. S. Geological Survey--is engaged, in connection with Prof. ROTH, of the University at Tubingen, in a preparation of a new edition of one of the sacred books of the Hindoos--the "Atharva Veda."

[The following sketch of a lecture delivered before the Smithsonian Institute, upon PATRICK HENRY, by JOHN S. TYSON, a distinguished lawyer of Maryland, cannot fail to be read with interest, though upon a subject with which every American is more or less familiar.--Ed. Times.]

Several valuable improved. properties were sold at auction yesterday, situate in the lower Wards of the City. The store No. 82 Cedar-street, 21 by 84 feet, brought $29,000; and No. 72 Gold-street, 37 by 78, $25,000. The old American Bible House, No. 117 Nassau- street, adjoining Clinton Hall, brought $105,000. The Bible Society soon remove to their new building in Astor-place.

On Wednesday, the Whigs of the Massachusetts Legislature, nominated the Hon. EDWARD EVERETT, for United States Senator. Mr. EVERETT's most formidable competitor in the canvass, was the Hon. GEORGE ASHMUN, of Springfield.

One of the strong points made by Senator SOULE in his remarkable speech--which we give at length this morning, because no one else has enterprize enough to save us the trouble,--was the fact that Spain and England were engaged only a half-dozen years ago in the most flagrant of flibustiering.

Suddenly, on Wednesday evening, SAMUEL D. DAKIN. aged 50 years. His friends and those of his brothers in-law, George H. Mumford, of Rochester, and of Charles Gould, are invited to attend the funeral, front the house of the latter. No. 5 Madison-square, (North) on Saturday morning, at 10 o'clock. No special invitation will be given.

PETITIONS TO THE LEGISLATURE.--A return to the Legislature, praying the enactment of a prohibitory law against the sale of intoxicating liquors, and subscribed with 2,549 names of persons residing in Hudson County, was forwarded to Trenton Wednesday The County having been but partially canvassed, arrangements have been made to present a similar petition to every inhabitant, and the number of petitions will probably swell to upwards of 3,000.

FROZE TO DEATH.--At a late hour Wednesday a man, named NICHOLAS BOARDMAN, was found lying insenaible, from the effects of the cold, in a yard In Marshall-street, between Graham-avenue and Smith-street. He was immediately taken into a house, and every effort was made to restore him, but he expired in about an hour after he was found.

GREAT RAILWAY SPEED-236 MILES IN 305 MINUTES.--The train that left this city at 4 o'clock, P. M., on Sunday, reached Worcester, 45 miles, in 54 minutes; from Worcester to Springfield, 53 miles, in 78 minutes, (a ?? of this distance was run exceeding a mile a minute;) from Springfield to Hartford, 26 miles, in 34 minutes; from Hartford to New-Haven, 36 miles, in 56 minutes; from New-Haven to Twenty-seventh-street, New-York, 76 miles, in 105 minutes.

In a recent article on the spread of Small 'Pox and Varioloid, you spoke of the desirableness of some plan by which the benefits of vaccination might be more widely diffused. Can this be me a readily and effectually done than by legal requirement that all children entering our Public Schools, or in anywise enjoying the benefits of the Common School Fund, shall be vaccinated?

The Arctic's news was received before 8 o'clock this evening by the Delta, having left New-York at 6 o'clock. The sales of COTTON to day were 13,000 bales, at unchanged prices. Strict middling is quoted at 9 1/4c. Rio COFFEE is in active demand, 12,000 bugs sold to-day at 9c @ ?? Prime MOLASSES is at 24c @24 1/2c. The stock of COTTON now on hand, amounts to 320.000 bales.

The proceedings of the Anti-Slavery Convention have been quite tame and uninteresting. In the afternoon a colored man, representing himself as a fugitive with a wife and two children in slavery, requested a collection might be taken to purchase their freedom. PARKER PILLSBURY denounced the application as made in the wrong place.

FIRE.--About noon yesterday, the carpenter's shop of FRANCIS D. NORRIS, in State-street, near Bond, was, with its contents, consisting of tools, lumber, and 160 house doors, destroyed by fire. Mr. NORRIS'S loss is about $1,400, upon which there was no Insurance; The men In his employ lose nearly $800 worth of tools, not Insured.

Who will be elected to-day to the United States Senate from New-Jersey? WILLIAM WRIGHT was ahead by the last accounts, Gov. VUROOM was crowding him, and not far behind either was Gen. E. V. R. WRIGHT. Neither of the three was asleep.

Hudson River Railroad -STOP THAT ENGlNE.--Pursuant to public notice, a meeting of property owners and residents of the XIXth and XXth Wards, in the vicinity of llth-ave, was held on Wednesday evening, at the house of Mr. DONNELLY, at the corner of 11th ave and 17th st, for the purpose of taking measures to secure a prohibition of the use of steam on the Hudson River Railroad in the City below 61st st.

ADMINISTRATION OF CITY GOVERNMENT AND ITS ABUSES.--S. K. SWEETMAN, Esq., last evening de livered the Introductory lecture of a proposed course, relative to the affairs of the City. Mr. S gave a very interesting explanation of the organization of the City Government, and the working of the Heads of the several Departments, which he deemed necessary, in order to render his subsequent lectures more readily understood and appreciated.

There are various rumors in regard to the whereabouts of Mr. IDELL, the abscanding Trenton merchant; one report stating that he has sailed for Australia; another that he was seen on board a steamer for California. It is supposed there are about $20,000 of his notes in the hands of bill brokers of Trenton, who assert the endorsements and signatures are not forgeries.

The grand Temperance demonstration took place to-day. A procession numbering about 700 marched to the State Capitol, and presented a petition containing 50,000 signers, for a prohibitory Liquor Law-20,000 of them legal voters.

DR. ANTISELL delivered his second and last lecture at the Stuyvesant Institute last evening. Subject: The Origin and Distribution of Coal. The Lecturer commenced by saying it is at all times interesting to consider the origin of anything that ministers to the wealth and comfort of man; hence the interest of the subject under consideration,

HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--The citizens of the Nineteenth and Twentieth Wards, and particularly owners of property along the Eleventh-avenue, who are opposed to the use of steam as a motive power on the Hudson River Railroad, below Sixtieth-street, assembled on masse, on Wednesday evening, at the house of Mr. DONNELLY, corner of Eleventh-avenue and Forty-Seventh-street, to take into consideration the best means of attaining that object.

A sad accident, which will probably prove fatal, occurred at the Chesnut-street Depot about 12 1/2 o'clock this afternoon. A man aged 23 or 24, who appears to be a laborer, was walking upon the platform between the Railroad tracks and stepped off upon one of them just as the train from Philadelphia approached. He was struck by the cow-catcher of the Engine which fractured his skull, and it is foared, injured him internally.

WALLACK'S.--The Comedy of the "Heir at Law," with the original cast. BLAKE as Daniel Dowlas WALCOT as Dick, BROUGHAM as De Pangolss, and Miss LAURA KEENE as Cicely Homespun, a character in which she far surpasses any whom we have ever seen play it. The Comedietta of "A Handsome Husband," is also to be given.

The bringing into closer connection our Atlantic and Pacific domain--now remote in distance and in time--is, unquestionably, the task for the present generation to accomplish; and the best mode of doing it, one of the greatest problems of the time.

ISLAND OF MADEIRA SUFFERS.--Yesterday efforts were made in the business circles down town for the relief of the destitute poor on the Island of Madeira, who are now suffering from the failure of the grape crop and scarcity of provisions.

Every reader will be surprised that Mr. STANLEY'S amendment to the Deficiency Bill was adopted in committee and concurred in by the House. The drift of it was that hereafter no books shall be distributed to members except such as are ordered to be printed as public documents by the Congress of which they are members.

A thriving trader in Wisconsin, claiming the paternity of eleven daughters, greatly to the astonishment of his neighbors, succeeded in marrying them all off in six months. A neighbor of his, who had likewise several single daughters called upon him to obtain the secret of his husband.

BECOMING A MEDIUM,--The fascinating spiritual rappings is without a doubt gaining strength among us, and some very ludicrous incidents often grow out of it at times, as well as more serious and deplorable ones.

Mr. PIERCE deserves well of his country for giving so many men the opportunity of being announced as candidates for Cabinet berths. To see the list of those who have been declared eligible, one would get, an impression that we abound in "capable men."

TEMPERANCE MEETING--The Third and Fourth Ward Temperance Society, held a meeting last night, in Wellwood's Hall, and were addressed by Rev. R. GIVEN, formerly of Jersey City. A good audience was in attendance.

A rumor prevails here to-day, that Gen. PIERCE has offered the State Department to JAMES BUCHANAN. The Northern and Southern Democrats in Congress are apparently delighted in consequence. The President sent a message to-day to the Senate, in answer to Mr. CASS' resolution of the 12th inst., calling for the correspondence between the British Minister and other parties, respecting the trenty with Nicuragua, negotiated by Mr. SQUIER, in 1850,

THOMAS F. MEAGHER, the Irish exile, arrived in this city yesterday noon. A large number of people, chiefly his countrymen, assembled at the Providence Depot to welcome him. Mr. MEAGHER was received by the Committee of Arrangements, and was addressed, on their behalf, by Mr. J. B. HARVEY.

Before the commencement of the proceedings, the Aztec Children were brought in the Senate Chamber, and placed on the Secretary's table. The exhibitor of them addressed the crowd of Senators and others, explaining their history, , and putting them through their evolutions.
Thomas S. Alexander, Esq., of Maryland, Case J. Hull, Esq., of Illinois, and Thomas Shankand, Esq., of New-York, were admitted Attorneys and Counsellors of this Court.

The New-Orleans Delta of the 18th, gives the following particulars of the recent decision in the Supreme Court of Louisiana in the McDONOGH case: "This important case was decided yesterday by the Supreme Court against the States of Maryland and Louisiana, and in favor of the cities of New-Orleans and Baltimore.

The Senate had under consideration the following Resolutions, heretofore submitted by the Hon. Senator from Michigan, Mr. CASS: Resolved by the Senate and House of Representative, of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That the United States do hereby declare that "the American Continents, by the free and independent position which they have assumed and maintain, are hence forth not to be considered as subjects for future colonization by any European power;"

The Senate, after having given the Aztec Children a capital advertisement, took up the BULWER and CLAYTON resolution of Mr. CASS, and adopted it, Messrs. CASS, BELL, MASON, HALE, and others having discussed it at considerable length. Mr. CASS' joint resolution, reaffirming the MONROE doctrine, was postponed till next Thursday.

A supplemental volume to COLLIER'S eight volume edition of the Works of Shakspere has just been published, of which we find the following interesting notice in the London Athenaum. " Early in 1849, Mr. COLLIER bought, at Mr. RODD's, a dirty copy of the second folio edition of the' Works of Shakspere,' printed in 1632.

These gentlemen have, of late, fallen out among themselves. They are now classified as Wild Cat Bankers and Shinplaster Bankers. The Western Governors are after the former for their malpractices, and the Grand Jury of Chicago in pursuit of the latter.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR - In the communication which you did me the favor to insert in your paper of the 10th inst., I fear that, in consequence of the omission by me of some words which should have been in the concluding paragraph, the meaning of the passage has been misapprehended.

Parties interested in the French Spoliation bill, have had a meeting, and are making strong efforts to carry their bill. Success is doubtful. Mr. CASS was sharp on Mr. SEWARD to day, but the latter maintained a dignified silence, Mr. SEWARD dined with the President to-day. ALBERT S. GELSTRAP has been nominated to the Senate, as receiver of public land monies in Missouri.

A great thaw came yesterday and the day be fore and melted our sleighing all away. There was a frost last night and this morning is beautiful but the sleigh bells must sleep till the next fall of snow.

Poetry.--Nightfall; by T. BUCHANAN READ. Literary.--The Great Conversationists--No. V: JOHN C. CALHOUN; by II Segretarco. Yankee Girls. The Emperor of Austria. Editorial.--Our Minister at Liverpool. Fireside Education. Domestic Slavery.

From different portions of the State, we hear of the great scarcity of beef cattle. The large ranches in the lower portion of the State, that have long boasted of their large herds of stock, are daily being reduced, and instead of the large droves that formerly blackened the plains, there are to be seen a few small herds here and there, with two or three Mexican boys to corral them.

Friday morning, WILLET COLES. infant son of Win. H and Abby M. Phelos, aged six weeks. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from No 818 Greenwich-st., on Saturday, the 29th inst. at 12 o'clock M.

The stories of the rapid progress or luxury and extravagance, in this metropolis, which go out to the world in the various shapes of public lectures, hotel puffs, newspaper comments and otherwise, of course, attract much attention from the neighboring cities.

The joint meeting was held this morning--Hon. WM. C. ALEXANDER, President of the Senate, in the Chair. The following officers, nominated by the Democratic Caucus last night, were elected, viz: U.S. Senator--Hon. WILLIAM WRIGHT, to succeed Hon. J. W. MILLER, whose term expires March 4. Mr. WRIGHT was nominated by the Democrats, and Hon. JACOB W. MILLER by the Whigs.

MOSES C. CRYPSRY, of Lockport, give the particulars of raising twenty acres of corn, which yielded seventy seven busnels to the acre. The expense of the crop was $23 97, and he realized from it $573 80. His land was clear of stumps and stones, and all obstructions to the cultivator.

THE MURDER OF MR. RINK.--A man Was yesterday arrested on a charge or committing an assault and battery on a man named DAVID WILSON, a chaise driver. It appears that the defendant engaged WILSON to take him to Jones's Exchange Hotel, on, the 10th instant; after reaching there he refused to pay his fare, and a squabble ensued, in which the defendant drew a knife and threatened to stab WILSON.

MEETING OF THE NOVA SCOTIA LEGISLATURE--THE FISHERIES.--We received, by the last steamer arrived at Boston, the opening speech of the Governorf Nova Scotia, at the meeting of the Legislature, from which we extract that portion which relates to the fishery question, and the pending negotiations on that subject, and reciprocity.

The Sacramento Union, of Dec. 31, has the following: The warm and unprecedently heavy rains of the last forty-eight hours have brought down upon us an avalanche of water from the snowy regions skirting the forks of the American River, and swollen the latter stream to a greater height than at any former period of the present season.

Dec. 15, at the Tehama House, in San Francisco, by Rev. A Williams, Mr. T. B. Robb, member of the Common Council, of Sacramento, to Miss Miriam G. Goodenow, the distinguished vocalist.
