The following decision of the Supreme Court of Louisiana, at its recent term, as reported in the New-Orleans Picayune, recognizes the constitutionality and propriety of the legislation of the North, on the question of slaves in transitu, or temporary residence: Lucy Brown, vs. Persifer F. Smith--S. B. Taylor, warrantor.
The late heavy rains and southeast winds have wrought injury on bridges, fences, farms, mining works and almost every perishable species of stock throughout the San Joaquin county.

The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer Columbia, had arrived at San Francisco with Oregon dates to the 27th ult. At the mouth of the Willamette River the hark Ocean Bird and the brig Hodgdou were frozen in.

One of the cases which, perhaps, illustrates as forcibly as any other the justice with which Mr. GALIANO may claim the violation of the laws of hospitality, by those who sojourn temporarily in this land, appears in the case of CUNNINGHAM, who was employed as an engineer upon the rail road between this city and Matanzas; and the route particularly, making the connection with the last city.
A grand New-England festival had taken place at San Francisco. The dinner was laid at WILSON's Exchange, and the tables groaned under the weight of good things.

DESERTION.--Among the most frequent cases, which come under our notice at the Police and Poor Master's offices, is that of husbands deserting their wives. There is no offence against the law that cries so loud for further and more effectual punishment, as the one we have alluded to.
The steamship Star of the West, Capt. TINKLE PAUGH, arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday from San Juan de Nicaragua, bringing dates from California to January 1.

OYSTER PIRATES CAPTURED.--An Annapolis correspondent communicates the following facts: Information having been communicated to the Sheriff of this county, that several vessels were violating the oyster laws of this State, Deputy Sheriff BRYAN, of this county, with a posse, proceeded down the Bay to the neighborhood of South River, this morning, and succeeded in capturing the sloop Hero, and schooner Perseverance and Susan, of Philadelphia.
The Convention called for the purpose of consulting on the propriety of establishing a National University at Albany, is still in session, and very much interest attaches to its proceedings.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers)...No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART CO., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade.st.
A dispatch from Bangor states that WM. PITT FESSENDEN has been nominated by the Whigs for United States Senator in place of Mr. BRADBURY. HAMLIN'S friends will support him, and he may be elected.

EXPLOSION OF A VESSEL BY GUNPOWDER--THIRTY-TWO PERSONS KILLED.--We find in the last foreign mails the particulars of the stranding and subsequent explosion, by gunpowder, on the English coast, of the brig Lily, of 180 tons.

The Boston Journal, of Thursday, announces the death of the Rev. SYLVANUS JUDD, as having occurred at Augusta, Me., the day previous. Mr. JUDD was the pastor of the Unitarian congregation in that city. His novels, " Margaret, a Tale of the Real and Ideal," Richard Edney," and "Philo," have secured for him the highest repute as a writer of philosophical romance.
David Quinn, Esq., of Ohio, Was admitted an attorney and counsellor of this Court. No. 48. Stephen W. Dose vs. William Tyack et al. Appeal from the District Court of the United States for Texas.

The Union Prayer-meetings which were largely attended in this City, a few months since, have been resumed at Hope Chapel. A service of half an hour is held every morning at 8 1/2 o'clock. The different Evangelical denominations combine in the work.

The Legislature has appointed Wednesday next, Feb. 2, for the election of U. S. Senator, in place of Hon JOHN DAVIS. The debate upon the Liquor Law has resulted in the adoption of an order referring the Law to a Special Committee of one from each County, to report upon the expediency of amending the same, without infringing upon the fundamental principles of the Act.

ANOTHER STEAMBOAT DISASTER.--A letter from Columbia, Ark., states that the now steamer J. Wilson, as she was leaving the landing on the 6th inst. burs two of her boilers, carrying off the forecastle and nearly one-third of the hurricane roof. One of the boilers was blown ashere, and struck the upper story of PETER ROWLERTT's coffee-house, from which a party of gentlemen had just retired.

ARANAMA COLLEGE.--We desire the attention of our readers to the advertisement of this institution. It has closed its first session under the most encouraging auspices. Its location, at Go-had, is one of the most pleasing and healthy in Western Texas.

HON. J. M. CLAYTON.--This distinguished gentlemen, recently elected to the U. S. Senate from Delaware, on Wednesday of last week, entertained the members of both branches of the Legislature of Delaware and a number or gentlemen from different parts of the State with a dinner at BENSON'S Hotel, in Dover.

It is understood that Mr. HOUSTON, Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means in the House, is about to report an important bill regulating the Coinage. The testimony, before the Commissioner of Patents, on the application for an extension of the Rubber and Sulphur Combination Patent, established the fact that it was in common use by the trade ten years before the patent was granted.

The California steamer brings little news, and that which she has is freighted with evil tidings. The unlucky city of Sacramento, again flooded, has suffered anew the penalties of low situations and proximity to a rapid stream.

Mr. MANGUM moved that when the Senate adjourn it be till Monday. Mr. ADAMS opposed the motion. A vote resulted. Ayes 11-Noes 5; no quorum. Mr. BRIGHT said to morrow was understood to be set for the Texas debt bill.
In July last the schooner Caroline sailed from Honolulu with a number of missionarios for Strong's Island, Ascension Island, , in the Caroline group, or, Micronesian Archepelago.

It has been raining steadily at Nevada for a week, and all the ravines and gulches are surfeited with water. The Calaveras Chronicle says: "As we go to press, a frightful tempest prevails. Thunder, lighting, and hail and rain are simultaneously heard, seen and felt.
The well-known Indian chief, PACHATTA, was killed near Jackson a short time since, by some Chinamen. No particulars heard. An atrocious murder was committed at Sonora by a couple of Mexicans.
At Washington, Yolo County, on the 18th inst, Andrew Gray, of Newark, N. J. On the 4th inst., at Jamestown, Tuolumne County, after a long and severe illness, Ezra Cooper, in the 34th year of his age.

From the San Francuco Price Current. Since our issue for the steamer Tennessee, on the 15th inst., we have nothing of particular interest to record; the continued rainy weather effectually interrupting communication between the river towns and mining distrists, there is but little change in a business point of view worth mentioning.

Some of us who are not "the oldest inhabitants," can remember the time when half a dozen coaches carried all the people, who left our pavement on a winter morning for Albany and the various parts of New-England. The fare to Albany was ten dollars, and two days time and board.

Within a week or two past, the Bounty Land Warrants of the General Government have rapidly advanced in price, under a speculative demand from the West, and the 40 acre script sold yesterday as high as $43 50; the 80 acres at $83; and 160 acres at $158.

It has been asserted that the decision of Judge CURTIS. Of the U. S. Circuit Court, against the constitutionality of the "Maine Law" in Rhode Island, only affected certain provisions peculiar to the law in that State, and which could be avoided elsewhere.

AFFECTING BEREAVEMENT.--An Industrious Irishman, residing in Boston, had accumulated an saved money enough from his earnings, to secure an, furnish a snug little tenement, and to send for his family to come over and occupy it. They took passage in the ship Moses Wheeler, which arrived last week, after stormy and tedious voyage, having been long and anxiously expected.

WILLIAM SAUL and NICHOLAS HOWLETT, convicted of murder, in killing CHARLES BAXTER, a watchman on board the ship Thomas Watson, on the 25th of August last, were executed yesterday at the Tombs, in accordance with the terms of their sentence.

The leading features of the news are given in the following Summary from the Alta California. The only important intelligence is the recurrence of the flood in Sacramento and its vicinity, and the consequent suffering among the miners.
STATE NORMAL SCHOOL.--The following are the vacancies in each County, at the close of the present term of the school. They are to be filled by the Town Superintendents, in county convention.

HARVARD COLLEGE.--The Board of Overseers of Harvard College held a meeting in the Senate Chamber, Thursday afternoon, Gov. CLIFFORD in the Chair. Prayer by Rev. WM. A STEARNS, of Cambridge. President SPARKS communicated that the Corporation had appointed REGINALD HEBER CHASE, Tutor in Latin vice THOMAS CHASE resigned.

COMMERCE OF THE PORT OF NEWARK.--The following statement presents a view of that part of the commerce of Newark represented by the sailing and steam vessels belonging to this port, and those trading to this port from other districts: "The whole number of arrivals from the commencement of navigation, on the 9th of March, to the 31st of December, 1852, is 2,681--as follows: 16 brigs.

The other day our musical notice contained, by typographical oversight, the little word as in stead of or, making a palpable blunder in the sense of the remark. The Herald was especially merry on the occasion.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Sometime since I read in your paper, with a great deal of interest and satisfaction, the general outline of a new theory of storms, advanced by Dr. W. BLASIUS; but last week, the citizens of Trenton, New Jersey, enjoyed the pleasure of a personal explanation of his views, by the Doctor himself, in a course of lectures, assisted by a number of Diagrams.

It is always pleasant to witness an honorable fullfilment of engagements, although the substance thereof be not of the creditable sort' Mr. WILLIAM WRIGHT, of Newark, N. J., at one time Whig Representative in Congress, and Whig candidate for Governor, is elected United States Senator from New-Jersey.
He bore three volumes, bound In faded vellum, And in his hand he carried a green bag, Filled to the top, as it would burst its sides, Like a goose stuffed with grain for Martinmas. Old Play.

BROOKLYN ATHENAEUM.-The project of an Athenaeum for South Brooklyn is about being consummated in the completion of the splendid building erected for that purpose at the corner of Atlantic and Clinton streets. The idea of such a building originated with a few citizens, who wished to relieve the young men of Brooklyn of their dependency on New-York for mental entertainment.

POLICE COURT.--Before Justice BOSWELL.- Mary Ann Kinney was sent to the Penitentiary for 90 days, for being drunk and assaulting an officer. She had that morning been discharged from the penitentiary, having been in for six months....The five Germans, arrested on a change of burglary, were sent to the County Jail to await their trial at the Court of sessions.

The appeal of Mr. CATLIN to the American Congress to purchase, and thus preserve, his collection of material that illustrates the condition, life, character and history of the aborigines of this country, will not fall, we hope, upon dull or unwilling ears.

SURGEON BOYER.--At a recent meeting of the Imperial Academy of Medicine, held in Paris, the Secretary pronounced a eulogy on the celebrated Surgeon BOYER, who was at the head of the Medical Staff under the first NAPOLEON.

A CALORIC ENGINE ON THE OHIO.--The Cincinnati Gazette is informed that a responsible business house in that city has contracted for the building of a first-class packet boat, to run thence to St. Louis or New-Orleans, which is to be propelled by a caloric engine.

The steamship Star of the West arrived at this port at an early hour Friday morning, from San Juan de Nicaragua, bringing dates from California to January 1. The passengers by the Star of the West report the transit across the Isthmus as in excellent condition. Traveling was easy, and the roads were in good order.

By the Falcon we have Panama dates to the 15th inst. Mr. MILES had arrived there, en routs for Washington, bringing important dispatches from Lima; also, Col. TOTTEN and the Engineers of the Panama Railroad, who were about to commence operations.

ALLEGED FALSE PRETENCES.--Three young men, by the names of PHILLIP and HERMAN DAHL and FERDINAND LEHO, were arrested In the Seventeenth Ward yesterday, by officer ELDER and Captain HICKS, upon a warrant issued by Justice STUART, wherein they stand charged with obtaining some $700 worth of clothing, from JACOB WOLF, in Sixth-avenue, by false and fraudulent operations.

By the Falcon we have Panama dates to the 15th inst. Mr. MILES had arrived there, en routs for Washington, bringing important dispatches from Lima; also, Col. TOTTEN and the Engineers of the Panama Railroad, who were about to commence operations.

THE MAN WHO SMOKES IN THE CAR.--The man who smokes in the railroad car was a passenger in the Sixth avenue car that left the Chambers street depot at 12 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday night. The flavor of the piece of tobacco which he puffed industriously was not good, and the other passengers endeavored to raise the windows to let the smoke escape.

This morning a fire broke out in a block of buildings on College-street, which consumed the-store occupied by A. B. RORERTSON, shoe dealer; EWIN BROTHERS, druggists ; R. LUSK, broker; T. KENT, jeweller; WATERFIELD WALKER, hatters; R. J. O FITE, dry goods merchants, On College-street.

We have been permitted to make the following extracts from an exceedingly neatly written original letter, from the late JOHN QUINCY ADAMS. GHENT, 14th November, 1814. GEORGE BOYD, Esq,, Paris: DEAR SIR--I received last evening only, your favor of the 4th, and am at some loss to account for its having lingered so long on the way.

LAW AND FARMING IN MINNESOTA.--We extract the following from a private letter received from St. Paul, Minnesota, dated the 30th ultimo. The writer is a well known legal gentleman: "I have just returned from attending a term of the District Court, held in Benton County, a region that two years since was a wilderness. It is some 90 or 100 miles north of this.

M. RIVES, Minister of the United States, presented his credentials on Monday, at the Tuileries, to the Emperor. The presentation took place with the same ceremonial as on late similar occasions. The Ottoman as well as the Prussian and Austrian Ministers also presented themselves officially near the Emperor.

The third anniversary of this Society, was celebrated in the Church of St. Barnabas, which was given for the occasion by Rev. Dr. Cook, last evening. There was a numerous and respectable attendance. The Right Rev. Dr. WAINWRIGHT, Provisional Bishop, presided, and was assisted in the services of the evening by Rev. J. HAIGHT, D. D., -- PRICE, D. D., Mr. HALSEY and HOPKINS.

By the steamship Australian dates are from Sydney, Sept. 8th; Port Philip, Sept. 28th; Adelaide, Oct. 5th. The news was mostly anticipated by the arrival at Liverpool of the ship Marco Polo, already announced.

From the St. Louis Republican. Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a broke out on board the steamer New-England, lying at the upper end of the wharf, and before its progress could be stayed, the entire boat was enveloped in flames, and finally burnt to the water's edge.

The steamship United States, Capt. BERRY, arrived at 4 o'clock Saturday morning from Aspin wall on the 19th inst., and Kingston on the 22d. The health of Aspinwall was very good. The Isthmus continued in good traveling order.

The British and North American steamship Africa, which ought to have sailed from Liverpool on Saturday, 15th inst., was detained till Sunday, 16th inst., by an order from the Foreign Office. The order to delay the steamer gave rise to many surmises, some of them absurd enough.

The Albany Medical College held its Graduating Exercises last Tuesday. Judge HARRIS conferred the degree of M. D. on nineteen young men. A pleasant reunion was held at Professor BECK'S after the close of the Exercises.

On Saturday, the 22d, a young man named William Layton, son of Allen Layton, of Marlboro', N J, was instantly killed while engaged in the marl-pits of Chaf. H. Conover, Esq., of that place, pitting out a marl-pit. There were at the time five or six hands engaged at the pit, several of them in it.
CENTRAL PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH. -- The changes which have recently taken place in the Central and Pearl-street Presbyterian Churches, have involved some important enterprises.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--The Chinese Troupe of Magicians, Acrobats, , made their first appearance at the Broadway, on Saturday evening, and attracted a crowded house; and, judging from the very general satisfaction that was manifested by the audience, the engagement of the "Celestials" by Mr. MARSHALL is likely to prove a decided card.

Accounts from Riga of 3d January mention that, in consequence of the mild weather, the port still remained open, and that a ship had just been chartered for London, a circumstance wholly unprecedented at this period of the year.

THE BURNING OF THE STEAMER MARTHA WASHINGTON--IMPORTANT ARREST OF AN ACCESSORY AFTER THE FACT.--A full account of the destruction of the steamer Martha Washington by fire, on the Mississippi River, on the 14th of January, 1852, was published in the Times a year since.

A French journal publishes from the Augsburg Gazette an interesting account of the rapid progress which has been made within the last few years in the prosecution of Railroads in Russia. From this article we gather the following facts:

From the Shootsburg Gazette. By an examination of any authentic map, it will be found that the "air-line" is three miles and nine-thirteenths shorter from Quattlebum to Squashtown, than the present traveled route by the Conger Creek Railroad.

HORRIBLE.--On Thursday morning last. JAMES CLARK, a well known citizen of Clark County, made an assault upon his negro woman for a cause which we have not heard stated. He then ordered her into the corner, and commenced pitching his knife at her, point foremost.

IN PETTENGILL Co.'s ADVERTISING AGENCY, much time, trouble, and expense are raved the advertiser: First By selecting papers of the largest circulation, and: best adapted to the business of the advertiser. Second By making out the price of the advertisement for any length of time before sending it, so that the advertiser will know the exact amount of his bill when due.

In the United States Circuit, the Jury in the case of ENOCH REED were last evening charged by Judge HALL, and on the opening of the Court, at 8 3/4 o'clock this morning, the jury had not yet agreed. At a later hour the balance of the panel was called.

Postmaster GORDON of Boston is now authorized by the Government to submit such a proposition as will probably ensure a Sunday evening mail between New-York and Boston. It is rumored that an officer connected with the Custom House in New York, is about to be favored with a contract for filling in the Navy Yard at Brooklyn.

The Commercial Advertiser, only a year ago, lifted up its voice and bewailed the violence of the Kossuth excitement. Political intervention, we have been lectured into believing, is not the doctrine for the times.

From the Paris Journal des Debets. Now that the American expedition sent against Japan is making its way across the Atlantic in this direction, let us cast a rapid glance at the singular and difficult relations which the Japanese hold with the commerce of Europe, or rather with that of Holland, for no other power than this last has been permitted by the Government of Jeddo to trade with Japan.

The correspondent of the Times, from Vienna, 7th and 8th inst., refers to the Montenegrin insurrection, but throws little or no additional light on the events that have taken place. The Pacha of Scutari has assumed the Offensive, and OMAR PACHA, the Turkish Commander-in-Chief, was advancing towards the mountains to hem in the enemy.

LOMBARDY.--The Opinions has the following singular paragraph from Milan, 3d inst. "The report of the increase of the Austrian troops in Italy is confirmed. Military quarters are being prepared at different points particularly in the Provinces of Milan and Como. Strange rumors have circulated for some time past.

By the arrival of the bark Flash at this port, from Vera Cruz, we have confirmatory accounts of the resignation of President ARISTA. The dates are the same as before received by telegraph; Vera Cruz to the 12th inst. and the City of Mexico to the 7th.

APAROPRIATION OF $500,000 FOR PUBLIC PARKS.--Mr. LEBEAUME, of the Board of Aldermen, offered an important bill at the session of the Board, last evening. It authorized the Mayor to issue bonds of $1,000 each, to the amount of $500,000, having twenty-five years to run, with six per cent, interest, payable semi-annually in New-York City.

The Legislature of Indiana meets biennially on the first Thursday in January, and continues in session sixty working days. As this is one of the years of their meeting, Indianapolis is now enjoying the presence of as various a collection of men as can well be imagined.

The steamship Africa arrived at this port last evening, bringing dates from Liverpool to Jan. 16. She was detained one day, by an order from the Foreign Office, for the purpose of forwarding dispatches to the British Minister.

Foreigners of distinction on arriving in New-York, are apt to inquire for the Clarendon; and the Union Place is known as the favorite resort of eminent vocalists, and travelers of wealth and leisure. At the Astor you find "leading politicians,"--each the "most remarkable man in the country.

We have received dates from Costa Rica to the 8th of January. The San Jose Gaceta publishes the constitution of the State. The 29th article provides that "Naturalized persons are the natives of the States of Central America, and of other sections of America who shall navigate in the State, or have a capital, in real estate, of not less than $1,000."

From the Boston Journal. The report of the Joint Standing Committee on Education, authorized and instructed by a joint order of the two branches of the Legislature of 1852 to visit the State Normal Schools during the recess, has been published.

We referred in our last to the magnitude and competing character of the Railway interests of the State of New-York. We learn, from private letters from Albany, that the continued multiplication of new schemes, and the rapid issue of new credits based on these schemes, are exciting the serious attention of good men to the consequences which are to grow out of what is viewed as ill-advised competition.
The confidence of speculators and the rates of money values both in London and Paris have been seriously disturbed by the recent change in the rate of interest by the Bank of England.

The Government have directed that the Cunard Mail Steamer--advertised to sail this day--shall be delayed at Liverpool till to-morrow, in order that she may bear across the Atlantic dispatches from the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Lord JOHN RUSSELL.

A telegraphic dispatch from Trieste announces the arrival there of the Overland Indian Mail. The dispatch says, under date of Jan. 12: "The steamer Adria arrived this morning, with the Calcutta mail of Dec. 8. Pegu was taken on the 21st of November, and will be annexed.

We have received Tampico dates to Jan. 19. Great excitement existed in consequence of a rumor that two thousand Texans were marching on Tamaulipas. Col. RUFFIN RODERIGUEZ and twenty-three men belonging to the National Guard have been shot.

By the Steamship Isabel, via. Charleston, we have advices from Havana to the evening of the 22d inst. They indicate the germs of a possible serious disagreement between Spain and Great Britain arising from the expulsion of a British subject from St. Jago de Cuba, by General MEDINVILLA, without any assigned reason, and without form of trial as demanded by him.

A special general meeting of this Society was held yesterday at Flummery Hall, and the proceedings were somewhat stormy and angry, if such harsh terms can be applied to a parterre of sweet roses agitated in a breeze. The President, Mrs. CLEOPATRA LOVELACE, briefly explained the object of the meeting:

FIRES--Yesterday afternoon, a fire broke out in a dwelling-house at No. 440 Second-avenue, owned and occupied by WM. CONNER, but was extinguished with trifling damage....At about 2 1/4 o'clock this morning, a fire was discovered in the house No. 268 West Sixteenth-street, which was put out before any material damage was sustained.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers)...No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART CO., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

From the Manchester Guardian. We have already stated that his Excellency the Hon. J. R. INGERSOLL, the American Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to this country, arrived in Manchester from Liverpool, about 12 3/4 o'clock, on Friday week; being accompanied by the Mayors of Liverpool and Manchester, and by W. BROWN, Esq., M.P., whose guest he had been during his stay in Liverpool.

The only event of political import this week, is the statement made by Lord JOHN RUSSELL to the Corps Diplomatique, that he holds office only ad interim, and will soon resign his office to the Earl of CLARENDON. The Earl of DALHOUSIE is appointed Constable of Dover and Warden of the Cinque Ports.

THE DUKE OF WELLINGTON'S BEDCHAMBER.-- A narrow passage to the east leads to the Duke's bed-room; a small, shapeless, ill-lighted room, with a rather common mahogany young person's bedstead, surmounted by a tent-like curtain of green silk.

Mr. J. K. HARVEY, the Washington correspondent of the North American, is lying very low from the affection of paralysis. He had been speechless, but is rather better this morning. The Steamship State of Georgia has arrived here from Savannah.

From the great scandal that Gen. ST. ARMAND'S alleged speculations have given rise to, the Emperor has ordered a Commission to be appointed to inspect and check every part of the public service. As yet the marine is the only department yet put under this wholesome surveillance.

"Either that press of New-York is wielded by a set of the most abandoned, mendacious libellers the world ever witnessed, or the Aldermen are among the most shamelessly corrupt and profligate scoundrels that ever held a public trust to abuse.--St. Louis Republican."

HEAVY DAMAGES.--In the case of ROSWELL HOOD vs. the New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company, on trial in the Superior Court, the jury yesterday brought in a verdict for the plaintiff to recover $6,000 damages and costs.

A fugitive slave was arrested in Madison County a few days since, and after a hearing of the case before the Commissioner, it was ordered that she be given up to the claimant. The owner of the woman offered to release all title to his property provided the sum of $1200 was paid him.

Manchester is the centre, we an know, of an enormous manufacturing industry. It may be considered the founder of free trade, and the metropolis of political liberality. No other town or city in England exercises an influence so well calculated to speak as the organ of British industry and commercial progress.

The Cortes assembled on the 2d inst. The Duke DR. SALDANHA informed the House that the dispute respecting the General Armstrong claims--which was referred to the Arbitrator of the French Republic, has been decided in favor of Portugal.

The steamship Australian, from Sydney, whose arrival was announced by telegraph per Arctic, has dates from the Cape of Good Hope to December 1, eleven days later than previous advices. The general scope of the news appears to be that the war is drawing to a termination, but whenever the troops are temporarily withdrawn, predatory bands of the enemy spring up and make successfully inroads into the colony proper.

SELECT BRITISH ELOQUENCE, embracing the best speeches entire, of the most eminent orators of Great Britain for the last two centuries: with sketches of their lives, an estimate of their genius, and notes critical and explanatory -- By CHAUNCEY A. GOODRICH, D.D., Professor in Yale College.

On Saturday morning, Jan 29, WILLIAM SHANNON, son of the late John Shannon, aged 43 years. His friends, and those of the family, are invited to attend his funeral on Wednesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 56 Monroe-st.

By way of England, we have news from Madeira to the 7th inst. January 5th, the brig Richard Cobden arrived, forty days from Newport for St. Thomas; the Hamburgh bark Aleda, sixty-three days from Hamburgh for New-York; the American ship Europe, thirty days from Liverpool, for Philadelphia-short of water.

The Madrid Gazette, of the 5th inst. publishes the new law regulating the Press. It is less stringent than some of its predecessors. The following paragraph is going the round of the English Press, under the heading of "Important from Havana:"

The House, by unanimous consent, introduced a bill to enable Brevet Major-General RILEY to settle his accounts growing out of military contributions in Mexico, and allow him for monies advanced in California, and for assisting overland emigrants.

Owing to the "Festival of the three Kings," (Epiphany,) the news from Vienna is rather limited. FAUSTIN of Hayti, says a letter from Trieste in the Augsburg Gazette, has appointed a merchant in that City his Consul, and an exequatur is to be demanded by him, though the Austrian Government has not yet recognised the Emperor.

An accident occurred to the train from Pittsburg, at 8 o'clock this morning, when near Christiana. The rail broke, throwing the last car off the track, and upsetting it down an embankment. There were ten persons in the car, all of whom were injured.

Last evening the Lecture Room of the Smithsonian Institution was unusually crowded by a highly intelligent and appreciative audience to hear the intrepid and scientific traveller, Dr. E. K. KANE, on "The Physical Aspects of the Arctic Regions, in connection with the Search after Sir John Franklin, and the Discovery of an open Polar Sea."

NIBLO's.-- Madame SANTAG, plays Amina in the Opera of "La Sonnambula." BURTON's.--The comedy of "The Serious Family," with BURTON as Sleek, and the drama of " Nicholas Nickleby." Squeers, Mr. BURTON; Mons Mantalinl, FISHER, Newman Noggs, JOHNSTON; Smike Miss WESTON.

The steamer Petrel, which arrived at this port from St. Thomas, W. I., on Saturday, brings the sad intelligence of the death at that place, of Prof. C. B. ADAMS, of Amherst College. Prof. ADAMS had become widely known in the scientific world, by his labors in the departments of Geology; and in his unexpected demise, Science has to mourn the loss of a most indefatigable and accurate investigator.

INDICTMENTS FOUND.--A recent Grand Jury at Buffalo found Indictments against JUDAH LEVY, of No. 43 York-street, Brooklyn, and -- KELLY, of Rosevelt street, New-York, for participating in the robbery of Messrs. CASTLES Co.'s store, Buffalo, some time last Summer. Officer TYLER, of Buffalo, came on yesterday and arrested the parties, and took them on to Buffalo to answer.

The annual commencement of the Female Medical College at Philadelphia, took place on Thursday, before a crowded audience. The lady graduates some nine or ten in number, occupied seats on the platform and their appearance was greeted with loud applause. The degrees were conferred by Prof. Cleveland, the President of the College, and the valedictory address delivered by Prof. Cornell.

The St. John New Brunswicker, of the 28th inst., announces the arrival there of JAMES WHITMAN, Colonial Agent of the New-York Industrial Exhibition. Mr. WHITMAN will immediately communicate with the Government, the New-Brunswick Society, the Mechanics' Institute and all others who feel interested in the matter, in order to insure a proper and sufficient display of the products of New-Brunswick, and its workmen, of every description, at the forthcoming Exhibition.

The new Ministry having been duty completed and reelected, have been comfortably enjoying their Christmas holidays, not in the metropolis, but in the provinces. Downing-street is a desert, and politics for the present in abeyance. Not a mouse is stirring behind the Ministerial arras, and we should hardly have a scintilla of excitement but for the Oxford University election, on which I shall have something to say anon.

The St. Louis Republican announces that two of the private Banking Houses in that city, LUCAS SIMONDS and E. W. CLARK Co., have determined to withdraw their unauthorized circulating checks and certificates of deposit, from a sense of respect due to the popular feeling against such operations.

In the U. S. Supreme Court, yesterday, Mr. Justice NELSON delivered an important Opinion respecting the case of KAINE. The Court affirms the power of habeas corpus, and declares the action of the Circuit Court irregular, so far as remanding the prisoner into custody was concerned. The effect of this decision will be to bring up the case anew before the Lower Court in a proper and legal shape.

This morning the Santa Fe mail reached here, bringing but little additional news from that of last month. The Legislature of New- Mexico was in session, following out the recommendations of the Governor, and apparently doing some good for the country. Governor LANE's course is becoming very popular, and he will do much for that country, if not removed by the in coming Administration.

By an arrival from Brazos, St. Jago, we have received Brownsville papers to the 12th inst. inclusive. According to the latest advices, CARAVAJAL was at or near the little town of China, with some one hundred followers, levying black mail upon the in habitants and contributions from every merchant's pack mule or wagon.

"BRING ME NO MORE REPORTS."--A Boston paper says: "Editors in this vicinity may well make this exclamation upon receiving telegraphic dispatches from Washington, pretending to give authentic reports of the movements of the President elect, in regard to his Cabinet.

"TUGABOOS."--The Boston Journal gives the following definition of this new and remarkably euphonious political appellation: TUGABOOS.--This is a new distinguishing appellation given to a political party of the South, which is composed of those politicians who deserted the two old parties, and united against the" States Rights" men, or "Secessionists."

AMERICANS IN PRUSSIA.--A letter from May once of a recent date says that a Mr. RHEINHEIMER, of Baltimore, who had gone to Germany for two of his children, whom he had left there to be educated, was, on his arrival at Minden, a frontier railway town in Prussia, arrested by the police for having among his baggage four numbers of a German Democratic magazine, printed in Baltimore in 1848--49.

JONAH TITUS, Democrat, has been elected to the State House of Representatives, from Scituate, vice ROBERTS, deceased--the Maine Law men and the Democrats forming a coalition. The Moderator told the voters to bring in their votes for JONAH TITUS, and they did so. A farm-house in Cranston was burned on Saturday afternoon. The flames spread so rapidly that scarcely anything was saved.

The U. S. Circuit Court is engaged empannelling a Jury for the trial of WILLIAM L. SALMON. Twenty five persons were on the panel. The District Attorney moved the trial of WILLIAM L; SALMON, of Granby, Oswego County.

Good, honest people cannot endure to find the yellow sunshine on the walls of their dormitories when they rise, and Society will not tolerate early retiring, for night is the time for pleasure-seeking--the season for social and festive gatherings, and the hour of inspiration for poets. So, between the two, Sleep, who is but a modest, easily-frightened spirit, has very narrow quarters appointed for her accommodation.

Senator DIXON, of Kentucky, is in bad health. He leaves for Charleston to-morrow, and will not return this session, having paired off with Mr. BORLAND on the confirmation of BADGER. SAMUEL MEDARY is violently opposed by a portion of the Ohio Democracy in the Cabinet war fare, A strong remonstrance against the bestowal of Executive favor in that direction, has been forwarded from Ohio to Concord.

Sir E. B. LYTTON'S play of the Lady of Lyons continues to hold the stage with undiminished popularity, after a run in this country of fifteen or eighteen years. Its announcement, with anything like a strong cast, is almost sure to draw. Like BELLINI'S Norma and Sonnambula on the lyric stage, it often attracts a crowded house when least looked for. Such was the case last evening, at the Lyceum.

Prof. YOUMANS delivered his Second Lecture on Chemisty to a large and attentive auditory in the Tabernacle last evening After recapitulating some points in his first lecture, Mr. YOUMANS proceeded to remark: As the atmosphere when reduced to a uniform density, extends upwards but five miles, we shall form the best idea of the proportion of its elements by sup posing them to be separated in successive layers or strata.

The National Intelligencer quiets a re port which created speculations and surmises without number on its first appearance--viz, the occupation of Samana by the French. It appears that official intelligence from Mr. RIVES declares the story destitute of foundation, and that the French Government denies any knowledge of the supposed transaction which had taken place in its name and by its authority.

From the London Times: The Stafford house address to the ladies of the United States has provoked an effective reply, in the shape of an " Affectionate and Christian Ad" dress of many Thousands of the Women of the "United States of America to their Sisters the" Women of England."

Suddenly, on Monday, Jan. 31, of disease of the heart, EMILY, wife of John Fowler, and daughter of the late Samuel Marks, of Peekskill, in her 39th year. Her remains will be taken to Peekskill this morning. On Sunday morning Jan. 30, Mr. NIEL GRAY, in the 63d year of his age.

BRIDGE ACROSS THE MISSISSIPPI.-- Jan. 12, in the Missouri Legislature, " a Senate bill passed the House without comment---ayes 68. nays 1, absent 6--granting to JOSEPH A. MATTESON and others, the right to build a railroad bridge across the Mississippi at Rock Island, to be completed within six years. But afterwards the bill was re considered, and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary."

Mr. THACKERAY last evening delivered one of his characteristic, sparkling and picas ant discourses, at the Church of the Messiah, in behalf of the Society for the Employment and Relief of the Poor. His subject was Humor and Charity, and the lecture was a portraiture of the humorous school of STEELE, ADDISON, GOLDSMITH, and DICKENS; the aim being the demonstration of a kindly element in such literature.

Mr. THACKERAY delivered a lecture for the benefit of the Society for Employment and Relief for the poor, in the church of the Messiah last evening. A large and respectable attendance was attracted to hear the humorous and learned Lecturer, whose course on the writers of Queen ANNE'S reign, left so favorable an impression on our citizens. Mr. T. made his appearance at 8 1/4, o'clock and was warmly greeted.

The Military Ball last evening, at NIBLO'S, Was the cause of a change of the first Opera night of the week to TUESDAY (this) evening. Sonnambula is announced for repetition, Other engagements prevented us from seeing and hearing the first representation of Amina by Madame SONTAG, but report generally speaks highly of it, and this success, in connection with the never tiring poplarity of the opera itself, will no doubt draw a full house.

To the Editor of the Savannah Morning News: On Saturday, the 15th inst., Lieuts, BURROWE and BELL. of the revenue cutter Hamilton, in company with Mr. A. C. DAVENPORT, called upon the Mayor, and stated to him the situation of the Zebra. The Health Officer was immediately ordered down to ascertain, the condition of the passengers and crew on board said vessel.

The Springfield Republican says, (and no body says these things better,) of the Convention of Milkmen: "With a smart sprinkling of farmers interested in the milk trade, who held a meeting in Boston, on Wednesday, that its discussions were particularly interesting to those outsiders who have never been able to account for the milk in the cocoanut.

From the London Daily News: Within the last few days we have had English and American speakers-in public meeting assembled--criticising the institutions of their two countries, and thus bringing John Bull and Brother Jonathan into comparison the one with the other. The Earl of DERBY began this by his elaborate oration on the House of Peers.

Mr. CLEMENS appeared in the Senate for the first time this month. The Chair laid before the Senate official copies of the Army and Navy Register. The Deficiency Bill was received from the House, and referred to the Finance Committee.

In the Supreme Court of the United States to day, three opinions on the KAINE Extradition Case were delivered. Justice CATRON delivered the opening one, and held that the arguments of Counsels BUSTEED and BRADY, denying the right or power of Consul BARCLAY to usurp the functions of the accredited British Minister, upon a question of broad international law-was not tenable; but that the British Government might delegate that power.

THOMAS DE QUINCEY.--In a few days, says the Boston Courier, Messrs. HOGG Co., of Edinburgh," Selections--grave and gay--from the writings, published and unpublished, of Mr. De Quincey, revised and enlarged by himself."

The first of February is usually the time for notifications between landlord and tenant in regard to new rent engagements on the first of May. There appears to be little regularity--and we might almost add neither rhyme nor reason--in Store, Warehouse, Hotel and Shop Rents, and to pretend to report anything like the probable general or average advance, would be a pretty serious job, and not likely to prove very reliable at last.

The editors of the London Times and of the British Statesman seem to be sorely exercised in relation to the policy of our Government to wards Cuba, and in a late number of the great journal they ask upon what principle of policy or public justice do the United States claim a right to determine what institutions and alliances are best adapted to the other States in this hemisphere.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT.--On Saturday forenoon, a man named EDWARD DONNELLY, residing in Hammersley-street, New-York, had both of his legs broken below the knee, by the caving in of a bank of frozen earth, while engaged excavating in a cellar in South Seventh street, between Second and Third-streets. The injured man was conveyed to the office of Dr. ROTTON, who adjusted the fractured limbs, after which he was taken to the City Hospital, in New-York.

The clipper ship Surprise, Capt. RANLETT, from London, arrived last night, having left Portsmouth, Dec. 20th, which, under the circumstances, is an excellent passage, having beat the ship all the way across the Atlantic, and encountered continual heavy westerly gates, some of them of the most terrific violence. Capt. R. did not lay his ship to during the passage, and has seen but two vessels since leaving Portsmouth.

We have had an opportunity of examining Col. P. W. PORTER'S patent rifle, a fire-arm of very great and obvious merit. It is remarkable for the simplicity and compactness of its structure; its extended range, and the faculty of loading and discharging it. Forty balls may readily be thrown in a minute, and with such force as to penetrate, at twenty yards, a plank eight inches thick.

The second lecture of this series was delivered by Rev. Dr. TYNG, of St. George's Church, in the Tabernacle, last evening. Owing to the disagreeable weather, the attendance was not so full as had been anticipated. The "Spiritual Nature of Man," which he had chosen for his discourse, was, the lecturer said, a subject always important for man's consideration, particularly so when there was a tendency to deny it.

Row.--A Dutchman, a resident of Jersey City, ?? dangerously ill in consequence of the bruises he received last Monday evening, near Thatched Cottage Garden. It is stated he entered a liquor shop near the place above named, and after drinking considerably, got into a quarrel with a party, who struck him on the nose and split it from top to bottom.

By the arrival of the Empire City, Captain WINDLE, at this port from New-Orleans and Havana, and the Black Warrior at Mobile, we have received dates from Havana to the 31st January. The Purser of the Empire City has placed us under obligations for favors.

Mrs. JOHN GOUGH NICHOLS sends to the London Gentleman's Magazine two original letters of Doctor FRANKLIN. Both have escaped the diligent search of Mr. JARED SPARKS; at least, we find neither of them in the Correspondence of Franklin; and the latter is missing from the Diplomatic Correspondence of the Revolution, leaving a hiatus very much to be bewept in that important work.

ATTEMPTED VIOLENCE BY 'LONG-SHORE MEN--Wednesday afternoon the police of the Twentieth Ward were called up to quell a disturbance among a gang of 'long shore men. It appears the packet-ship Roscoe and bark Amelia were being loaded with a cargo of lumber at the foot of Thirtieth-street, N.R.

A SUGGESTION.--While learned Senators are discussing the "Monroe doctrine" in its application to Cuba, Central America, , we bog leave humbly to submit to Members of both Houses, the propriety of using letter paper which does not contain the "Crown" stamp. Let the "Monroe doctrine" have practical force with reference to Congressional paper.

There is rather a hard war now being waged upon this great highway, and one not altogether as generous as it might be, considering the trials and difficulties through which the Company have struggled to give us a direct, cheap, and expeditious route to Albany.

I have been laid up for the last few days with a terrible cold, all owing to the dogmatical weather we have had for the past week, and which has set, every one to barking. We had all been looking for snow, and I felt confident that you were get ting a sprinkle of it. I have remarked of late that our weather here, is a very good indication of what sort you are having.

Mr. RICHARD, BRODHEAD, who happened into the United States Senate, a few years ago, from Pennsylvania, is opposed to the Pacific Railroad. He quarrels with none of its re commendations. He does not deny that there is a popular call for it. It may be necessary, it must be built; but not now, quoth Mr. BRODHEAD, not now.

The magnitude of the current operations now going on in City improved property and vacant lots was again illustrated yesterday by the auction sales at the Merchants' Exchange. The lists of sales by three of the leading auctioneers embrace 103 different properties, and the proceeds amount to about $725,000--the largest single sale being $27,000.

A cold, dreary morning, and a touch of rheumatism in my back. I shall not go to the City to-day. I shall not even go to the village; but stay at home, toasting myself, and listening, between whiles, to the creaking of the vane. I do not know how the world is getting along this morning; and I begin to think I do not much care.

A bill has been proposed in the Maryland Legislature, to incorporate a Company to contract a ship Canal from Chesapeake to Delaware Bay, with a capital of $2,000,000. A Committee of the Legislature have reported against the repeal of the law, prohibiting the Issue of notes under $5 by the Bank of the State after 1st March.

The shooting affair at the National Hotel to night, has created great excitement. SCHAUMBERG delivered himself up voluntarily to the authorities, and was committed to jail by Justice MORSELL, His counsel are Senators HALE, COOPER, SOULE, and RICHARD S. COXE, Esq. COOPER, and other friends visited him at jail to-night.

The Lady of Lyons continues to "run" at WALLACK's Lyceum. It is announced to be played every evening of the week. There is very much in the getting up of the piece to add to the attraction. The costumes are beautifully rich and appropriate, and the scenery in fine taste.

The Diario de la Marino has advices from Merida to the 19th of January. A movement had taken place in that city, on the previous evening, designed to second the revolutionary plan of GUADALAJARA, and to displace the authorities of the State. Don MIGUEL BARBACHANO was to yield the post of Governor to Don ROMULO DIAZ DE LA VEGA.

When the Duchess of SUTHERLAND and the ladies of England addressed their sisters, the women of the United States, on the subject of Domestic Slavery, no one supposed that their address would not find a reply in the course of a season. And no has been disappointed.

SUDDEN DEATHS AND SUICIDES IN PARIS.--Under the influence of the singular temperature which now reigns, says the Presse, cases of sudden death have become very frequent. Two or three days ago a young man from Bordeaux, who had sustained heavy losses at the Bourse, died in in a cofe, while playing a game of chess.

New-Orleans papers of Friday, 28th, have been received, and those from all points as late as due. The Maryland House of Delegates have passed an exemption bill, exempting property to the amount of $150 from seizure for debt.

THE BEQUEST OF MR. APPOLD.--We mentioned, yesterday, that the late GEORGE APPOLD had made a bequest of $10,000 to be divided among several institutions of this city.

The Agricultural Society met at 9. Nineteen States were represented by about 100 members. The various Committees reported. An amendment to the Constitution, changing the time of holding the annual meeting to the last Wednesday of February, was adopted.

There seems to be some little doubt as to the effect of the recent decision of the Supreme Court of the United States in the case of KANE, the alleged fugitive from British justice, whose extradition is sought by the British Consul at this port.

By the arrival of the Empire City at this port, and the Black Warrior at Mobile, we have received later news from Havana. The most important intelligence brings information of a destructive conflagration at Cardenas on the morning of the 29th ult. The loss is estimated at Half a Million of Dollars.

In the proceedings of the New-York Legislature for Tuesday, we find the following: "Mr. RICE, on notice, introduced a bill to reprint the Birth, Marriage and Death Registering Act. A corrected edition made it read re peal instead of reprint. We care very little which word is the one really used.

About six o'clock last evening, EDWARD H. FULLER, who in company with his father, was part proprietor of the City Hotel and Irving House, but more recently a clerk in the Census Office, was shot at the National Hotel by JAMES W. SCHAUMBERG, formerly of the U. S. Dragoons.

YALE MEDICAL COLLEGE.--The Examining Committee met on Jan. 26, and on their recommendations the degree of Doctor of Medicine was conferred by President WOOLSEY on fifteen gentle men. Professor SILLIMAN gave notice that he had resigned his Professorship, and terminated his official connection with the Committee, and accordingly took leave of the Board.

At our races "Jefferson Davis" won the purse in two heats, four miles each. Time, 7m. 45s. and 7 m. 46 s. THOMAS PARYCAR'S Glencoe Colt won the HUTCHINSON stakes in two heats of two miles each. Time, 3 m.44 s. and 3 m. 46s.

The Utica Herald has the following ac count of the late affray in that city, wherein one man was killed, and two others seriously wounded: "The most heart rending catastrophe ever witnessed in Utica occurred in the upper part of the city about half past ten on Monday evening, between a party of watchmen and people residing in Eaton, Madison County.

We were shown a letter yesterday just received from St. Louis, to the effect that PAGE BACON had directed their correspondents through the West to retire their small notes as rapidly as they come in. The house will do the same at St. Louis.

It was a humiliating spectacle for Spanish pride, when the Spanish brig Aroganti Amelio was brought into the port of Havana, in tow of a British war-steamer, as a pirate prize, with the Spanish banner flying at her mainpeak--and kept there until sunset, when it was lowered away.

Another sad accident occurred last evening In this City, from the use of camphene. A daughter of Mrs. ADAMS, a widow woman, residing at No 61 Academy-street, had been reading by a lamp filled with that fluid and fell asleep. On awaking, she probably hit her head against it, or in some other way upset it into her lap.

IMPORTANT LEGAL DECISION.--On the 1st of October, 1849, the agent of the Berkshire Woolen Company went to Boston, to attend a lawsuit in which that Company was a party, putting up at the Marlboro Hotel. On the 2d or 3d of November, his room at the Marlboro was entered, and his trunk broken open and robbed of $500.

The steamship Black Warrior, Captain SHUFELDT, arrived at Mobile at noon to-day, from New York via Havana. She brings dates from the latter port to the 31st January. The U. S. sloop-of-war Cyane was in port, all well. A great conflagration has occurred at Cardenas. The loss is estimated at over half a million of dollars.

Having received our exchanges from the Interior of Texas, we append the following Items: The Legislature of Texas assembled at Austin on the l0th inst., but there being no quorum, it met on the following day and organized. Gov. BELL sent in his message on the 12th.

An effort is being made to induce the Postmaster General, to extend the mail service by a new route from New-Orleans to Vera Cruz, across the country, via Acapulco, to San Francisco. The contractors demand $500,000 per annum for the service, and say it will require only 17 days. The Postmaster General hesitates, as Congress has not yet authorised this new mail service to California.

On Wednesday Feb. 2, by Rev. Dr. Burchard, Mr. CHARLES E MILES to Miss HARRIETA. COLEMAN only daughter of Hiram Coleman Esq. all of this City. At Riverhead, L I., by Rev C. Lock wood, Mr. DANIEL W CORWIN of this '?? to Miss MARY E. JAGGER, daughter of David Jagger, Esq. of the former place.

Hon. JOHN P. SANDERSON, of Philadelphia, was to-day nominated as Judge for Oregon. Mr. BARTLETT, Mexican Boundary Commissioner, appeared to day before the Senate Committee, for the investigation of the charges against him. The ex parte evidence tends to corroborate the charges.

FIRE.--Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning a two story and basement frame house, located at the corner of Nostrand-avenue and Van Buren-street, was destroyed by fire. It was owned by an Italian named CHARLES SWEETZER, and valued with contents, furniture, , all of which was destroyed, at $2,000, and insured for $800, in what office we could not learn.

It was expected that the vote upon the main question of the Anti-Liquor Law would be taken this morning, but, upon motion, the bill was ordered to be engrossed, and made the order of the day for Tuesday next.

From the Albany Argus. By the resolution of the Canal Board of August 25, 1852, before referred to, all the old locks between Montezuma and Rochester, will be rebuilt of the enlarged size and brought into use next Spring; and on the first day of June there will be enlarged locks through the whole line from Buffalo to Albany.
As a general thing farmers do not provide themselves with good gardens; at least, so far as the writer has traveled, he has seldom seen what he would call a good garden on farms.

MARRIAGE.--Dr. FORBES WINSLOW, speaking of marriage, says: "Nothing delights me more than to enter the neat little tenement of the young couple, who within perhaps two or three years, without any resources but their own knowledge of industry, have joined heart and hand, and engaged to share together the responsibilities, duties, interests, trials, and pleasures of life.

THE ASTOR LIBRARY.--Many inquiries have been made of late concerning the Astor Library. The time at which it will be opened, the arrangements, rules which will govern it, etc. According to our information, the Library Building is rapidly progressing towards completing.

"It is expected that the shipments of specie, now sometime intermitted, will soon begin. We can spare five or six millions of dollars within the next six weeks, much to the health, and ultimate security of sound business affairs.
TRICK UPON LEGISLATORS.--A base trick has been played upon the Iowa House of Representatives, in the manufacture of a petition for country subscriptions to railroad stock.

With the election of Mr. WILLIAM WRIGHT to the United States Senate, New-Jersey may be said to have touched the lowest deep of degradation. Not that the latter fact of itself is half so disgraceful as a half dozen others, which preceded and led to it.

SILVER COINAGE.--Complaints begin to come to us, from various quarters, of the scarcity of silver change, and the inattention of Congress to the petitions for relief. Serious inconvenience is daily experienced from this cause; and considering the present relative values of gold and silver, the prospect is that the evil will go on increasing.

Sir ISAAC NEWTON, the great, the learned, and the good; who followed in the track of his illustrious predecessor, Sir FRANCIS BACON, styled by WALPOLE "the prophet of arts, which Newton was afterwards to reveal," was indebted to inaternal solicitude for the development of that genius which has never been surpassed nor ever equalled.

An overladen book-table! Specimens of all manner of literature crowd upon us, and--shall we own it?--the business of the day bids the craft of authorship seek the wall and leave the pave to the stirring world.

May-day is the time for moving, but the day to determine whither to move precedes it by some three months. It is not so for all the people of Gotham. They who rent rooms by the month, postpone their trouble ill "all fools day."

Coroner LEMUEL, GAY, Esq., of Stoughton, was called on Tuesday, Feb. 1, to hold an inquest on the body of MARY ELIZABETH HUMPHREY, daughter of THOMAS and MARY HUMPHREY, found dead, with her throat cut, on said Tuesday morning, in a bed room in her father's house in Stoughton.

SALES OF REAL ESTATE.--The Portuguese Consul, Mr. DAVID SEARLEY, sold his place few days since, containing five acres, a dewlling-house buildings, for $10,000. Mr. JOHN DREW sold the ELDERT farm, containing thirty-six acres, (which he purchased last Spring for $4,000,) for $18,000. Mr. J. Y. WHITSON, disposed of twenty seven acres of poor land, and without buildings, for $7.000

The details of the Indian news add little interest to the telegraphic intelligence already published. Great complaints are made of the inactivity of Gen. GODWIN in Burmah. Pegu was captured by 1,200 men, under GODWIN, while five months since Major COTTON took the place, and would have kept it had his instructions permitted.

FIRES--Yesterday morning at an early hour, a fire broke out in a wooden building, corner Fifty-seventh street and Eighth-avenue, but was extinguished before any material damage was sustained to the building or contents....At about 7 o'clock Thursday evening, while a child was in the upper story of a dwelling-house, No. 160 West Sixteenth-street, with a lighted lamp, he set fire to the covering of a bed.

HARD TO DIGEST.--The Concord (N.H.) Democrat states that a cow belonging to Mr. MOODY GILLINGHAM, of Newbury, N.H., in eating some garden vegetables, accidentally swallowed a very sharp butcher knife, about eleven inches in length, including the handle, with a blade more than an inch and a quarter wide.

The news from Europe is interesting to-day. The affairs of France take a new shape and assume definiteness. The Emperor has finally accomplished the undertaking to which his energies have been so assiduously devoted since his crowning act, and an Empress is finally to sit upon the throne.

INQUEST.--An inquest was held company after noon before Coroner DICKINSON, at Mayor BERRY'S office in the City Hall, for the purpose of investigating into the cause of the death of CATHARINE ROSINA KIEL, mentioned in the fore part of the week.

Society, like nature, is always equal to new wants, and supplies itself by adjusting, or creating, just as is most convenient. When wars distract it, it produces heroes, who preside over battles, and organize peace.

Mr. CUSHING'S prospects for the State Department appear to be on the rise again. It is confidently asserted by some that certain others, usually well informed, offer wagers that either BUCHANAN or LOUIS MCLANE will be Premier.

HIT OR MISS.--Here is a capital story told of a couple of Western hunters. Their names were HOFFMAN and COWAN; and both were excellent shots, and not a little given to boasting of their skill. One day they went on a deer-hunting expeduion and after getting into the woods where they expected to find deer, they separated.

The Opera was suddenly changed last evening, owing to POZZOLIN's illness. ARNOLDI took the Tenor's role in Lucrezia Borgia, which was substituted for Sonnambula. This Opera can scarcely be termed one of Madame SONTAG's successes.
The steamship Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing dates from Liverpool to Jan. 23. The news is important, conveying tidings of the marriage of the French Emperor.

Israel Garrard and George, W. Thompson Esq., of Ohio, and Nimrod H. Johnson, Esq., of Indiana, were admitted Attorneys and Counsellors of this Court. No. 57 Wm. H. Winder, plaintiff in error vs. A. D. Caldwell. The argument of this cause was continued by Messrs. Lawrence and Bradley for the defendant error, and concluded by Mr. Davidge for the plaintiff in error.

BROADWAY.--This the last night of the Chinese Performers, and they perform both of their great acts, the "Impalement," and the "Decapitation." The comedietia of "The Two Bonnycastles," and the farce of "Married and Settled," will be played, in addition to the Chinese entertainment.

This Society commenced its annual meeting in Court of Appeals Room, at Albany, on Tuesday morning, at 11 o'clock. Dr JENKS S SPRAGUE in the chair. The Secretary read the minutes of the semi-annual meeting, which was held in New York. The minutes were approved.

"The Emperor NICHOLAS breakfasts on a cup of tea, and a rush; dines on a little fish, a cutlet or a chop, with a biscuit and a glass of sherry and water. In the evening he takes a cup of tea. He suffers from an internal disease, and is obliged to be abstentious."

The overland mail brings Sydney dates to Oct. 15, Melbourne 25th, and Adelaide Nov. 6. Flour at Melbourne was worth [pound]40 to [pound]47 per ton, and four pound loaves brought 2a. 6d. Gold was valued at [pound]3 7s. 5d. to [pound]3 10s. 6d. per ounce.

Almost every newspaper that we take in hand contains some "valuable recipe" for the cure of some inveterate disease or other. May be it is a cranberry poultice for erysipelas, the fat rind of a pork ham for scarlet fever, or Scotch snuff spread on a belarded linen for the croup.

Mr. SEWARD presented memorials from Lewistown, Buffalo, and New-York City, praying a suspension of the Steamboat law. Messrs. COOPER and BRODHEAD presented petitions for giving all who were engaged in the War of 1812, 160 acres of land.

A late English paper remarks that there is something imposing in the fact that 366,192 ounces, or $7,323,860 were the produce of the Mount Alexander and Ballarat mines, in twenty working days in September, though 100,000 people were directly or indirectly employed in the job.

Some over-wise people have an idea that when a tree gets mossy and bark bound--the latter but another term for want of growth, and weakness consequent upon neglected cultivation--it is only necessary to slit the bark up and down the stem with a jack-knife, and it will at once spread out and grow. This is sheer nonsense.

It will be seen that the senate yesterday passed the bill extending the time of warehousing foreign goods, with an amendment restricting the time for goods intended for consumption to twelve months.

BLAGOROVE, NO. 115 Atlantic-street, and demanded of the boy--the only person In, belonging to the place at the time--a drink of brandy.

The Paris Siecle has the following on the proposed establishment of a line of Transatlantic packet-ships from a French port on the Atlantic: "The ports which now contend for selection as the place of departure are--in the Channel, Havre and Cherbourg; in the Atlantic, Nantes and Bordeaux; and in the Mediterranean, Marseilles, which is already in possession of the Levant line.

I resume the consideration of the various proposed schemes for the construction of a Pacific Railroad. Mr. BRODHEAD, of Pa., has introduced an amendment, substituting for all present propositions to construct the road forthwith, a simple authority for the survey and location of the road, leaving to a future Congress the duty of authorizing the construction.

Liverpool Cotton Market. From Brown. Shipley Co.'s Circular. There has been a steady and good demand for COTTON throughout the past week ending last (Friday) evening. The sales reached 58.390 bales, with 11,100 on speculation, and 6,740 bales for export at an advance of fully 1/2 d. in ordinary and middling qualities, and of 1/2d.@1/4d. ??. lb. in the better descriptions.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The writer of the enclosed hopes the Daily Times will find an appropriate corner for it. The object is entirely disinterested, and the end to be obtained one which commends itself to every liberal mind.

Four weeks only remain of the present Congress, and the great measure of the Session still hangs undisposed of, in the Senate. The whole country is looking earnestly towards the National Capitol, hoping and expecting that the present winter will not have passed, ere some measures have been adopted, to secure the immediate commencement, and early completion of a Railroad from the valley of the Mississippi, to the Pacific Ocean.

The American Tract Society have appropriated twenty thousand dollars for the distribution of Tracts in foreign lands during the ensuing year: $3,000 to Continental Europe; $1,800 to the Armenians in Turkey; $3,800 for Southern India; $3,000 for the Old School Missions in Northern India; $4,300 for Burmah, Assam, Siam and China; and $3,200 for our own aborigines and the Sandwich Islands.

After the Criminal Court adjourned in Cincinnati, on the 31st ult., Henry Mankin, who was on trial during the day for the murder of William Oliphant, supposed the Sheriff was behind him and went down into the street with his attorney where they parted.

CONTEMPLATED IMPROVEMENT.--The common Council have appointed a Special Committee to consider the prayer of petitioners in relation to laying out and filling in a street in Hudson River, below Hudson-street, to run parallel therewith.

The open question with the owners in Gotham now,--the question which like an interrogation point made of steel, hooks itself into the thoughts of them all, is; Shall we move in May, and to what place? Good reader, perhaps you find this crooked inquiry standing in your path--asking to be straightened before you can proceed. Lend us your eyes and your ears awhile, and let us talk of house hunting.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--On Saturday afternoon last while several boys were playing in the vicinity of an excavation in a sand-bank in Little-street, adjoining the Navy Yard wall, between John and Plymouth-streets, the bank suddenly caved in and buried a boy named EDWARD CARREL, aged 11 years, whose parents reside at the corner of Hudson-avenue and John-street; also a companion named WILLIAM H. CLARK, aged 10 years.

The able decision of Judge, DUER of the Supreme Court, in reference to an alleged contempt on the part of the City Council, cannot fail to give thorough satisfaction. Beside being an eminently necessary vindication f the bench and its dignity from the contemptuous neglect of recusants, it establishes a valuable legal principle, and pronounces upon the extraordinary conduct of the Board in terms as explicit as they are authoritative

MARINE DISASTERS.--The brig Celestial Empire, arrived yesterday from Liverpool, reports having had very heavy weather-carried away fore and main-top-gallant masts, head rails, knees, bowsprit, shrouds. split sails, sprung aleak, a few days out from Liverpool, and has had one pump going nearly all the time since.

The February number of the New-York Medical Gazette, edited by Dr. REEGE, and published monthly, has the following about the mysterious and spiritual humbugs: "In several papers the movement of tables has been alleged as capable of being effected by a circle sitting around them and touching them with their hands; thus giving color to the wildest of the ghostly stories, while disclaiming these, and alleging electricity as the cause.

The telegraphic announcement from Halifax or the sudden marriage of the French Emperor is suggestive of much entertaining gossip concerning the bride. As she is soon to wear the imperial crown and share the imperial fortunes of France, the curiosity of the public and its free indulgence may well be pardoned, albeit there is" a lady in the case."

Suddenly, on Friday evening, Feb. 4, ANNA WALTON, wife of Andrew Lockwood deceased, aged 54 years. The friends of the family and of her brother Elisha L. Walton, and of her sons. Roswell] E, and Andrew Lock wood, are requested to attend the funeral service on Tues day morning the 8th inst. at 10 1/2 o'clock, from No 259 12th st.. without for her invitation. The remains will be interred at Norwalk, Conn.

Dr. SPENCER offered the following, which was unanimously adopted: Resolved, That the thanks of the Society be presented to Dr. CLARK for his very able and interesting Address, and that a copy be requested for publication.

GALES SEATON-My Dear Sirs: I inclose you a venerable letter, written to me by Mr. JEFFERSON, third President of the United States, when the subject of a bridge across the Potomac, at the seat of the National Government was first agitated-just fifty years ago.

In the India Rubber case yesterday, N. RICHARDSON concluded his argument. He contended the invention was not novel; that DAY and others had in vented it long before HAYWAYD or GOODYEAR, and that even were it HAYWARD's discovery, his sale of the invention before the issue of the patent to GOODYER, and GOODYEAR's conveyance to others rendered the extension unlawful.

To the Editor of the New - York Daily Times. I see by your paper that Louis NAPOLEON has married my own sister's daughter, Mrs. FITZPATRICK. Good luck to ould Ireland! Sure I always said it was in the family, that we should be Quains and Impresses, and sich like. And did n't the ould fortune-teller, MOLLY MAGUIRE, say as much, when we gave her the Thirteener to look at the scores in our hands?

Ireland was always the English difficulty: and the successors of NICHOLAS BREAKSPEARE always appeared to have a better and more manageable bargain of it than the successors of the first PLANTAGENET. Many have been the schemes set on foot for the right management of the isle; but no one has ever yet hit upon the true one.

"BLUNDERE BEGET BLUNDERS.--We were led into an error the other day by a statement in the Times in regard to the accident at Croton Falls, on the Harlem Railroad. BROADWAY.--The Chinese troupe conclude their engagement at this Theatre on Saturday night, and open to-night at Philadelphia. Their stay in this City, though limited to one week, was quite long enough. Such exhibitions, in our opinion, serve no good and.

Senator CLEMENS speaks to-morrow. He will answer Senators SOULE, CASS and MALLORY. The President elect leaves Concord on the 16th, and expects to make Vice-President KING's residence his head-quarters.

New-Orleans papers of Monday are received.. Schooner Wild Pigeon, from Tampico, at New-Orleans, brings dates of 17th ult. The correspondent of the Picayune states that a detachment of the National Guards under RUFINO RODRIGUEZ, had formed a plan to take possession of the city, and depose the regular authorities.

The Steuerverein. A neighboring and rival Union to the Prussian Zollverein has been the Import Union of Hanover. This association-the Steuerverein-dates from a Treaty in 1831 with Brunswick, by which portions of that State are included under the Hanoverian Tariff system. During the succeeding ten years, various small States were added.

FUNERAL or MR. BUELL.--The remains of Mr. BUELL, the late member of Congress from Herkimer and Montgomery, reached Little Falls on Wednesday noon, where they were received by a large concourse of people, who accompanied them to Fairfield, the residence of deceased. The signs of mourning were general, the shops were closed, the political flags at half-mast, and the belle of all the churches were tolled.
