THE POWDER SEIZURE.--The powder seized several weeks ago by the Brooklyn Fire Wardens, nearly forty thousand pounds, is to be sold at auction, for the benefit of the Widows' and Orphans' Fund of the Fire Department, in a few days.
The U. S. Mail steamship Atlantic, Capt. WEST, arrived at this port yesterday morning, after a short passage of eleven days from Liverpool, whence she brings dates to the 26th January.

A letter from Rome, 14th inst., states that an extraordinary congregation of twenty Cardinals was held five days before, at the Vatican. Al though it was endeavored to keep the subject of discussion a secret, it is generally thought that the question under consideration was the cession of the Legation of Benevento to the King of Naples for 8,000,000 ducats.

London Markets. Per Canada.] LONDON, Friday, Jan. 21, 1853--5 P. M. The Colonial Foreign Produce markets have been dull this week. COFFEE 1d. lower. COTTON firm, SUGAR and Tea dull. BREADSTUFFS quiet.

From the Washington Union. This important bill--unquestionably one of the most important now before Congress--has been ordered to engrossment by the Senate, almost without opposition, and will doubtless pass that body.

Prof. YOUMANS delivered the Third Lecture of his course on Chemistry, at the Tabernacle, last evening, to an attentive audience. By means of admirable illustrations, Prof. Y. throws much interest into this highly instructive course.

The following inscription is to be found upon a grave-stone at New London, Conn: "On the 30th of October, 1782, 4 000 English fell upon this town by fire and sword; 700 Americans de fended the fort for a whole day, but in the evening about 4 o'clock, the commander of the besieged delivered up his sword to an Englishman, who immediately stabbed him.
Last evening, a meeting was convened in Metropolitan Hall, nominally to promote the cause of Temperance, but virtually to propagate all the wild extravagances of Woman's Rights.

From the London Times. History supplies but few instances of many States, politically distinct, yet linked together by a perfect community of race, of language, of customs, and of social institutions.

A telegraphic dispatch announces the death of WILLIAM PETER in Philadelphia. Mr. PETER was widely known in the ranks of Literature as a genial and easy writer and translator of verse, and as such had acquired a permanent name among the poets of modern days.

This Department of the City Government met yesterday evening after a recess of three weeks. There was a large concourse of persons outside the bar, no doubt in expectation that some violent speeches would be made in reference to the proceeding of the Superior Court on Saturday last, but if that was their business, they were greatly disappointed.

" In the autumn of 1835, having been cheated out of the previous summer's earnings by the captain of the steamer on which I had been employed, running away with the money, I was, like the real of the men, left without any means of support during the winter, and therefore had to seek employment in the neighboring towns.

From the London Times. The speech delivered by LOUIS NAPOLEON on Saturday last to the principal political bodies of the Empire, and, in fact, to the French nation, for the purpose of announcing his resolution on the subject of his marriage, has rather strengthened than altered the favorable opinion we have already expressed of his choice.

WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS.--The weekly report of the City Inspector shows that during the week ending on the 5th instant, there occurred in this city 393 deaths, viz. : Of men, 73; women, 85; boys, 124; girls, 111. Of the deceased, 138 were infants under two years of age.

PRESENTATION.--On Sunday afternoon the teachers and scholars connected with the Sunday School of St. Peter's and St. Paul's Catholic Church, in Second-street, presented the pastor, Mr. MALONE, with a splendid gold watch, as a token of their esteem for his assiduity to this department.

Saturday the Bourse opened with remarkable firmness under the influence of a report extensively circulated that M. FOULD, the Minister of State, had received the support of the greatest banking houses in Paris to maintain the price of Government Securities against any attempt to depress them.

The declaration of LOUIS NAPOLEON'S scribe, M. GRANIER DE CASSAGNAC, that his master is going to make new conquests by steam navigation in America, is met by the resolution which General CASS has moved before the American Senate, protesting against any European Colonization of America, and by the published correspondence in which the American Government rejected the tri partite treaty for guaranteeing the possession of Cuba to Spain.

On Sunday, Feb 6, of construction, HARRIET WARD, wife of James H Townev, and daughter of Mrs. Margaret H. Ward, of Scandale, Westchester Co. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at 11 o'clock this morning at No,. 116 1st-st. The remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.
The Intelligencer of Feb. 7, contains the decision of the Board of Land Commissioners for California, on Col. FREMONT'S Mariposa Claim, which was delivered by Commissioner HILAND HALL, Dec. 27, 1852.

The Southern Mail brings us New-Orleans papers of the 1st inst. The Delta contains a letter from British Honduras, which confirms the report that the State of Honduras has taken possession of the English settlement at Limas.
Advices from the Dalmatian coast state that the Porte had sent orders to press forward the war against the Montenegrins, being anxious not to give opportunity to the intervention of diplomatists.
Mr. BADGER'S nomination came up in Executive session today, but was postponed till Saturday, when it will certainly be disposed of. Senator SEWARD speaks on the Tehuantopce question to-morrow.

Madame SONTAG gave her large audience last evening one of the most pleasing entertainments, thus far, of her Opera Season. She was quite in her element in the light and comic Opera of Don Pasqvale, enchanting in voice and naivete in acting.

The Emperor has shifted the drama and appeared in the character of Othello. With what edifying artlessness he tells his loves to the most impotent, grave and reverend Seigneurs of the Senate; how he lost his young and inexperienced heart to the cunning Andalusian; that the union was one of affection; and how candidly he tells off the arguments with which he originally persuaded himself to take the step.

In Britain it is difficult to find anything of interest to report. There is an impression that soon after the reassembling of Parliament, Lord PALMERSTON will bring forward a motion for an increase of the Army.

From the Commercial Advertiser. We are favored with a letter from which the following is an extract: "BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 8. "We are in the midst of another revolution. A few restless and dissatisfied chieftains raised forces in the country, and has surrounded the city.

The coffer dam, erected between Kingston and Now-Brunswick, on the Delaware and Raritan Canal, for the purpose of facilitating the work, broke loose a few nights ago, and destroyed all the work that had been done, putting back their operations for some weeks.
From the Birmingham Journal. On Friday night, 21st ult., Birmingham offered its hospitalities to the Hon. J. R. INGERSOLL, the representative of the United States.

ADVICE OF AN OLD LADY--Now, John, listen to me, for I am older than you, or I couldn't be your mother. Never do you marry a young we man, John, before you have contrived to happen at the house where she lives at least four or five times before breakfast.
The great India Rubber case, which has excited so large a share of public attention for several years past, has been brought up again in this city,in a somewhat novel manner.
DEAR BRETHREN: Some of you, at least, are aware that for years, doubts of the validity of my office as Bishop, have at times harrassed my mind and greatly enfeebled my action.
On Saturday, 22d, the various functionaries of state presented themselves at the Tuilleries to receive from the Emperor an announcement of his intended marriage.

The bill for the construction of a railroad to the Pacific Ocean, which is now more immediately under consideration of the United States Senate, is that reported by Mr. RUSK from a Select Committee, to whom the whole subject had been referred. This bill deserves careful consideration.

In his Charge to the Grand Jury yesterday, Recorder TILLOU said to the members of that body: "You are authorized to inquire into any wilful neglect or violation of duty by public officers or magistrates ;" and further on in his Address, his Honor alluded to the charges which "have of late been made to the disparagement of many of the late and present public officers."

The mail steamer Lady Jocelyn, from Calcutta, Nov. 15, brings Cape of Good Hope advices to December 20. The Cape Town Mail, of the 18th December, says: Few events have occurred since the departure of the last steamer, which can be regarded as indicative of the prospects of the war.

The steamship Atlantic arrived at this port yesterday morning,--before we had fairly got through with the mails of the Canada. She sailed from Liverpool on the 26th ult. Her news is interesting, and four days later.
The following account of the method of catching mackerel will probably be new to many of our readers: "The method of taking the mackerel is very simple.

FRANCE. PARIS, Tuesday.--The civil marriage of the Emperor will take place on Saturday next. At the Source a steadier feeling. Three per cents closed f 80 15. Four and half per cents closed f 104 70. In Bank Stock a rise of 20 francs.

The rain and warm weather has caused several freshets in the Merrimac and Contoocook Rivers in New Hampshire; and the vicinity of Concordimmense masses of ice have been thrown up, and the rivers in some places diverted from their channels.

From the London Times. We published yesterday a correspondence of remarkable interest between the Government of the United States and certain European powers on the subject of Cuba, and the communications in question became the more instructive from the illustration which they received by a cotemporary debate in the American Senate.
Since the adjournment of the United States Agricultural Society, their Executive Committee have met once or twice, and transacted a variety of important business.
MORTALITY OF PHILADELPHIA IN 1852.--In the February number of the Medical Examiner, is an interesting paper on the records of mortality in Philadelphia.

SOUTHWEST PASS, Jan. 29, 11 A. M.--By an arrival from Tampico to the 19th inst., we are informed that great excitement prevailed there in consequence of a report that 2,500 Texans were marching on Tamaulipas.
Petitions were presented. PREEMPTION RIGHTS. The bill extending the preemption rights to settlers upon lands not surveyed, to a variety of cases, was taken up and passed, after debate.

Our Minister has again distinguished himself in England. He has been at Brummagem. He has manufactured a sort of diplomatic Brummagem article for the people of that interesting town, wherein American sentiment, American policy, and his own political consistency, only partake as a very trifling alloy.

BUTTER.--The speculators in butter have fairly overdone the matter, and are likely to pay dearly for their folly. Money is so easy to be had, in these times, that the entire region from the Hudson to the western shore of Lake Michigan was literally overrun, last Summer, by butter speculators.

BROADWAY.--Miss FITZPATRICK, who formerly appeared at Niblo's, made her debut at this house last evening, as Letitia, in the play of "The Belle's Strata gem." The play is not one we like, but Miss F. played the heroine with much spirit, and dressed with admirable taste and judgment, and wastes much skill and art in endeavoring to make Letitia endurable.

FIRES.--Yesterday morning about 7 o'clock, a fire brake out in the baking establishment of Mr. JOHN HARPER, situated on the Northwest corner of Eighth-avenue and Jane-street, which originated from a basket of shavings being carelessly left near the furnace of the oven.

We have been favored with the particulars of the interesting Council before referred to in our columns, held in Nov. last, at Albiquin, one of the most westerly pueblos of New Mexico, between Acting Indian Agent GREINER and a large portion of the Utah tribe of Indians, in which, a considerable number of friendly Jicarila Apaches being present, it was thought best to allow them to parcipate.

The track of the Hudson River Railroad has been so far cleared as to permit the trains to connect by passengers walking about 100 reds over the damaged bridge and track, at Schodac. The Eastern and Southern mails are all in, and the water is slowly subsiding.

CHARGE OF OBTAINING MONEY BY SWIND LING OPERATIONS--ARREST OF THE ACCUSED PARTIES--AN ATTEMPT TO COMPROMISE THE FELONY.--On Monday morning a commission merchant by the name of GURDEN BRADLEY, doing business at No. 124 Water-street, appeared at the Lower Police Office, and preferred a charge of false pretences against a young man named CHARLES LEWIS, alias GARRY.

Our Washington correspondent in a series of letters has discussed with some minuteness, the several propositions pending in the United States Senate, for the construction of a Railroad to the Pacific.

At Red Hook, On Thursday, Feb. 3, after a Long illness, JACOB P. LEWIS, in the 52d year of his age. In Savannah, Ga, on Sunday the 30th ult, CHARLES J. WALLACE, of this City, in the 32d year of his age.
From the New-Hampers Statesmen. The 19th of January, 1810, was a day the intense coldness of which will long be remembered by those who experienced its rigor.

DONATIONS.--The following donations have been made the Ladies' Benevolent Society for the relief of the poor: From the First Presbyterian Church, $75 34; Second Presbyterian, $24 12; St. Mathews, $96 85; First Reformed Dutch, $60; St. Peters, $77 03. Total $333 34.
Surely the wise saws on the value of a good reputation never were more fully justified than by the illustrious modern instance that at present occupies the French throne.
BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening. Ald. BARKER was chosen Chairman Proten.

The following is from a correspondent of the Alabama Journal: "In Murray County, Georgia, and near its south-eastern boundary, at the summit of a mural precipise 1,700 feet in perpendicular hight, there stands the remains of an ancient fortification, constructed of solid mason work, covering five acres of ground.

A DESERVED COMPLIMENT.--When the Supreme Court had got through the business of the term, WM. L. HIRST said, that he observed the Court was about to rise, and that the intense devotion to the public business which enabled the Court to make such an announcement, had made a deep impression on the Bar, and the members present bad desired MR. MEREDITH to express their views on the subject.

POLICEMEN RELIEVED.--In the Board of Aldermen on Monday evening last, a report of the Police Committee was adopted, recommending the payment of Police Officer PATRICK H. TOOLE for time lost by sickness, occassioned from severe and dangerous injuries received while in the active discharge of his duties as policeman.
CHARLES BONAPANTE had a good many sons, one of whom was named NAPOLEAN BONAPARTE and another JEROME BONAPARTE.

We have no mail south or Washington this evening. A slip from Norfolk gives us the particulars of the awful mortality on board of the ship Antarctic. Small pox, ship fever, measles and dysentery were prevailing among the passengers, numbering 500 to 600.

EX-GOVERNOR HUNT WAITED UPON BY THE TWO WHIG GENERAL COMMITTEES, AT THE ST. NICHOLAS HOTEL.--A joint special meeting of the Old and Young Men's Whig General Committee, was held last evening at the Broadway House and arrangements made to wait upon Ex-Governor HUNT, at the St. Nicholas Hotel.

In old fields and by the road-side, as the snow melts away and shows a carpet on the earth that is yet green, the gatherer of herbs often finds, on attempting to pull up by the root a small broad-crowned plant which he supposes to be dandelion, that he has made a mistake.

I Inclose two letters from Postmasters HALL ad HUBBARD, which were communicated to the Senate a few days since, in answer to a resolution, calling for information in regard to the execution of the Postal Treaty with Great Britain.
BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--The President in the Chair. A quorum being present the Board proceeded to business.

When people are making love, everything is so fair and so bright that they are disposed to think each other something more than human, and scarcely liable to the ?? of human nature.

SENATOR SEWARD's transcendent speech to-day will increase his fame as a profound stateman. The telegraphic report is very meagre. A full report will reach you in time for Thursday's issue. The Tohuantepec operators are taken all aback.
BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.-A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening at the City Hall. JOHN RICE, Esq., President of the Board, in the Chair, and a quorum of members present.
By the arrival of the steamship Yacht, we have highly important intelligence from the Rio Grande.
From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the arrival of the steamship James L. Day, we have received dates from Galveston to the 28th ult.
A friend said to us yesterday that a word of serious reproof was due to the Woman's Rights affair at Metropolitan Hall on Monday night.

Those cabalistic words, "The Empire is peace," had hardly been pronounced at Bordeaux, when LOUIS NAPOLEON, in order to act conformably to his promise, reduced the French army to the extent of thirty thousand men--a measure of doubtful policy with those crowned heads of Europe, with whom he had hitherto entertained the most peaceful international relations.

The main topic of interest at the present moment is the revolution in MOntenegro. The revolutions of the last few years in Bosnia and Albania have had but a local importance, for they were simply local rebellions of separated Mussulman nationalities against the Sultan, and they could hope for aid or sympathy from other bodies of their co-religionists, or from European nations.

Highly important intelligence reaches us from Mexico, by way of New Orleans. Matamoros pronounced in favor of the Revolution on the 28th, and, in a battle which ensued, the insurgents were successful. Gen. AVALOS resigned on the 1st, in favor of Col. BASAVE. All Tamaulipas has declared for the Revolution.
One of the most interesting items of news from Germany, is the indictment of Prof. GERVINUS on a charge of treason.

The Courier overhauls the Times and Tribune for the abuse of Messrs. INGERSOLL and EVERETT, and the cause of it is traced to the fact that the Secretary of State and American Minister are gentlemen, Conservatives as well as Whigs.

Continues from the London Times, of Feb. 4. When ISAAC WALTON apologized to the reader for his life of DONNE, he sought to disarm criticism by frankly avowing that, having once commenced to take notes for his undertaking, he "be came like those men that enter easily into a lawsuit or a quariel, and, having begun.

No. 50. Benjamin T. Reed, appellant, vs. Wm' M. Peck and others. The argument of this cause was commenced by Mr. Davis for the appellant, and continued by Mr. Woodbury for the appellees. Adjourned until to morrow at 11 o'clock. A. M. WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Feb. 8, 1853.

The following letter explains the manner in which the President of the United States was recently constituted a Director of the American Colonization Society. It is from the Washington Republic: WASHINGTON CITY, Monday, Jan. 31, 1853.

Much rumor is afloat about the ultimate composition of the Cabinet-it would not be well to take all that is said for granted. There is little doubt that President PIERCE's mind is made up, or nearly so, and yet I have it from what I deem good authority, that the formation of the Cabinet will not be closed before the end of the week.

IMPROVEMENTS.--Ordinances have been passed to fence vacant lots on Monroe-place; ditto to flag the side walks on the northerly side of Livingston, between Smith and Bocrum-streets; ditto to fill up and grade lots on the blocks between Flushing and Park-avenues and Adelphi street and Vanderbilt-avenue.

The elaborate speech of Hon. WM. H. SEWARD, upon the Tehuantepec question, is published at full length this morning, in our columns. As usual with that gentleman's efforts, it is marked by close logical accuracy and condensation; and if we are obliged to dissent from his statement of the premises, or from the conclusions he links them with, we cannot deny the ability with which they are managed.

Nature is a clever old lady certainly. How considerate she has been in furnishing topics of conversation, that constantly vary and are forever new. So soon as one grows threadbare another is brought in: they change as rapidly as the fashion of ladies' bonnets, or the covers at a fashionable dinner when the hour for the leaving of the cars rapidly approaches.
The schooner Aquilta, from Vera Cruz, brings us highly Interesting news from the City of Mexico to the 20th January. The City of Mexico had finally pronounced in favor of the revolution.

The Senate resumed the consideration of the resolutions submitted by Mr. MASON. Mr. SEWARD--Mr. President, history will elucidate this subject, If we can adjust the lens so as to concentrate its rays. The great occupation of the nations of Western Europe, from the beginning of the fifteenth century to near the close of the eighteenth century, was the colonisation and the establishment of empire upon the American continent.

The steamship Philadelphia, from Aspinwall 2nd inst., has arrived at the Southwest Pass. She brings 180 passengers, and dates from San Francisco to the 15th January. Left at Aspinwall steamships Uncle Sam and Ohio, for New-York ; the latter with 500 passengers and $1,500,000 of gold dust on freight.

Messrs. Lowell Senter, Jewelers, of Portland, Me., have a little round piece of metal, the 625th part of an inch, on which is engraved in clear, round, hold text, the following:" Lowell Senter, Watchmakers, 64 Exchange street, Portland. Written by Froment at Paris. 1852." There is sufficient space between the words and lines. It is road through a microscope of great power.

The Senate met at 25 minutes past 12 o'clock. A Message was received from the House, announcing their readiness to proceed with the order for counting the votes for President and Vice-President of the United States.

The Course of Lectures on Music undertaken by Mr. WM. H. Fax was concluded on Tuesday evening by an extra performance at Metropolitan Hall, given in consequence of the impossibility of obtaining the Opera chorus at the Tenth Lecture. A crowded house testified to the public appreciation of Mr. FRY's enterprise.

The California news, brought over the wires from New-Orleans, is nothing very encouraging. The miners are still suffering sadly. Provisions were up to an enormous price, and the roads, many of them, impassable. An other Convention of miners had been proposed.

My last letter was from Anjer, a small town situated on the western extremity of the island of Java. We left that place on the afternoon of the 23d of August, with an abundance of fruit and vegetables on board, and six sheep and one bullock as an addition to our complement of living creatures.

A NEW VILLAGE.--A German Association of New-York have purchased the "Mercer Farm," situated about one mile above Astoria, on the Flushing road. This farm contains twenty acres, and has been divided into 250 building lots, which have been distributed among the members at an average price of $115. Streets are being laid out and graded, and the property will be rapidly improved.

Quite Cromwellian is the appearance of the last tidings from Mexico. The President entered the Hall where Congress was assembled, and with his soldiers' bayonets, pushed them out of their stubborn ways. Ordering a Constitutional Convention to make a supreme law to suit present emergencies, is after the Gallic fashion.

LOST CHILD.--A boy, JOHN THOMAS, residing formerly on Railroad-avenue, left his home on Sunday last, and has not been seen since, by his parents. He started off in the morning to see his cousin who lives in the lower part of the City: but upon inquiry being made, it was ascertained that he had not visited the house of his cousin.

The project of converting the falling torrents of Niagara to prosaic and practical purposes seems to be taken hold of with earnestness and zeal. The glorious old cataract has hitherto remained unharnessed. No one has dared to insert curb or snaffle between her massive jaws.

A physician of Washington City is recommending, in one of the medical journals, a resort, to a freezing mixture, as a preliminary to the removal of nails of the toes and fingers, when such operations are necessary.

The Philadelphia, from Aspinwall, reached the Southwest Pass yesterday, bringing San Francisco dates to Jan. 15, and 180 passengers. The Ohio she left at Aspinwall, with one and a half millions of gold dust on freight for New-York.

THE CONDEMNED CRIMINALS.-We learned last evening, from a reliable source, that his Excellency Gov. SEYMOUR, has consented to commute the sentence of JAMES SULLIVAN, who is sentenced to be hung tomorrow; but that, in all human probability, he will not interfere with the unfortunate seaman, JOSEPH CLARK, who is also under sentence of death.

The London Lancer gives the following summary of the results obtained from a chemical examination of thirty-five samples of preserves of different kinds:- That the raspberry jam analyzed contained a very considerable quantity of copper.

WORLD'S FAIR IN NEW-YORK.-The Committee appointed, on behalf of the State of Michigan, to take into consideration the objects of the coming Exhibition of the Industry of all Nations, have reported to the Senate and House of Representatives of that State.

It was decided by one of the courts at Cincinnati last week, that if a passenger in a railroad oar purchase a ticket, but accidentally lose it, the company have no right either to make him pay the fare the second time, or turn him out of the cars, provided he can bring proof hat he actually paid for the lost ticket.

We have no mail south of Richmond to-night. R. B. SEMPLE, Editor of the Fredericksburg News, and Mayor of Fredericksburg, died suddenly at Richmond last night. The receipts of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for the past month have been $129,000, an Increase of $40,000 over the same month last year.

Buy a ticket for a dollar or two, and ride with yonder train that is just starting from the depot for three hours or four at the most, and you may disembark into the very heart of a country most quietly rural, and utterly innocent of the factitious life of the town.

We publish elsewhere another attempt at the solution of the City Railroad problem. Our correspondent may be regarded by some as "running the subject into the ground," but we are not sure but that he has pitched upon the only plan capable of meeting the difficulty at all points.

BROADWAY.--At this house to-night CIBBER'S Comedy of "She Would and She Would Not," will be played. This is really an attractive play--at least, our recollectlions so impress us. The only time we saw it was at Covent Garden Theatre, London, with Mrs. NISBETT, Madame VESTRIS, CHARLES MATTHEWS and WILLIAM FABREN in the principal parts.

The subscription is already completed for the new steamship Union, to run between this city and New-York. Capt. BERRY of the Marion is to superintend the building of it. CHARLES B. SCULLY, a merchant of Savannah, but a native of New-York, died on Saturday last on board the steamer returning from Florida.

From the Republic, of the 8th. A meeting of the officers and members of the Coast Survey in Washington, was held at the Coast Survey Office on the 2d inst.; and, on motion of Lieut. Commanding J. J. ALMY, U. S. Navy, Prof. A. D. BACHE, Superintent of the Survey, was called to the Chair.

M. PROUDHON has written a rather amusing letter to the Presse, in reference to the refusal of M. D. MAUPAS to allow him to publish his review and to the curious law-suit he recently lost. PARIS, Jan. 14, 1853.

SUPPOSED MURDER.--THE COR??NER's INQUISITION.--On Tuesday night, between 10 and 11 o'clock while Officers WALKER, WHITE, KINNEY and SHERWOOD were patroling through the Seventeenth Ward, they found a man lying on the side walk in Avenue A, quite insensible and utterly unable to speak.

Controller FLAGG will not resign. His good friends, who have his interest so near al heart that you would really think the money he dispenses their own, will scarcely be able to transfer him from a City to a Federal post. His affections do not that way tend.

The asserted identity of Rev. ELEAZAR WILLIAMS with the son of MARIE, ANTOINETTE, excites much interest among Frenchmen. The editor of the Courrier des Etats-Unis, has been paying some attention to the subject since the number of Putnam, in Usum Delphini, appeared; and availing himself of the presence of the royal missionary in this City, has obtained an interview, and made his own observations.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The Common Council have passed an ordinance establishing, regulating and controling the Fire Department, and for the prevention of fires. It is the old ordinance altered and amended to suit the requirements of the city charter.
NAVAL.--Business at the Navy Yard at Charles-town is by no means brisk at present. There are 350 mechanics employed in the various departments of labor in the yard.
THE GARDINER CASES.--On Monday last the District Attorney moved the Court to fix the 17th inst. for the trials of the Indictments against GEORGE A. GARDINER and JOHN C. GARDINER.
The steamship Philadelphia has arrived at her wharf in this city. The valley of Sacramento and San Joaquin were still flooded. Major DEAL, U. S. Indian Agent, had returned.
A delightful repetition of Don Pasquale, was given at NIBLO'S on Wednesday. We have certainly never heard Madame SONTAG to such pleasing advantage in Opera.

We were misinformed relative to the sale of Dr. BERRY's properly at the foot of South Eleventh-street. It is thought that this statement was circulated for the purpose of Injuring the new Ferry Company, which has recently been formed; a bill for an act of incorporation, being now before the Legislature.
THE SHIP ANTARCTIC.--We had accounts by telegraph that this ship, from Liverpool, bound to New-York, had put into Hampton Roads in distress, having lost sixty persons during the passage.

A gentleman of Burlington, N. J., has contrived a plan for forming artificial ice. The operation is effected by means of leaden water pipes pierced in small holes so as to throw out a considerable quantity or water in minute streams of spray.

It is said that International Copyright has taken shape as a treaty between Messrs. CRAMPTON and EVERETT. It is moreover said that it will be sent to the Senate in a day or two for ratification. We believe neither story.

WILLIAMSBURG DISPENSARY.--At a meeting of the Trustees of the Williamsburg Dispensary, held last evening, for the purpose of electing officers for the present year, the following named gentlemen were duly elected: President-SAMUEL GROVES. Vice Presidents-John J. Hicks, Timothy Collia.
The rule of Vicegerent CANEDO in Cuba, relaxes not of its energy because of ministerial changes at Madrid. The fear of displacement may perhaps stimulate him to increased displays of devotion.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I am informed by my cousin, Mr. GEORGE CLINTON GENET, son of the former French Minister to this country, that he has heard his father state that the Dauphin (LOUIS XVII.) had a remarkable birth-mark upon his person, and that this mark was known to Madame CAMPAN (GENET'S sister) and one other lady besides the Queen.

From the Philadelphia Ledger, 10th inst. Yesterday afternoon, a meeting, afternoon, of citizens was held at the City Hall, to take measure to pay a proper tribute of respect to the memory of WILLIAM PETER, Esq., British Consul; at this part. Mayor GILPIN Was called in the chair.

The St. Paul Pioneer, of the 13th, says: "The snow is two feet deep. We have no rain, and sleighing is abundant. Some of our people are traveling to Traverse des Sloux, preparing for opening their claims on the Sioux purchase. Wood is worth from $3 to $3 50.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The family of KIRKPATRICK, from whom, on the mother's side, the bride of LOUIS NAPOLEON is descended, is both ancient and honorable, and not without distinction in the annals of the Scottish monarchy.

THE HOMEOPATHIC MEDICAL SOCIETY OF the State of New-York held its annual session, according to appointment, in this city, on Tuesday. The Society met in the City Hall at 10 o'clock A. M, Dr. CLARY, of Syracuse, the President, in the Chair.

From the Albany Argus, 10th. The State Agricultural Society held its annual meeting in the Assembly Chamber yesterday. The Secretary, B. P. JOHNSON, Esq., called to order, and stated that the President of the Society.

The Daniel Webster has arrived at New-Orleans, bringing 300 passengers from San Juan, Nicaragua' and $90,000 in gold dust on freight, besides a considerable amount in the hands or passengers. No later California dates than we had in yesterday's paper.

GOVERNORS OF NEW-MEXICO.--What sort of a sinecure the berth of Governor of Mexico is, may be guessed at from the following statement in a letter from Santa Fe: "By the way, for fear that any of your friends in Ohio might become ambitious, and wish to fill Governor LANE's shoes, let me give them a little information that might be useful to them.

JOSEPH CLARK is to be executed to-day for the murder of Police Officer GILLESPIE in the Fourth Ward, in the month of July, 1851. The judgment of the Court will be carried into effect this morning, between the hours of 10 and 11 o'clock.
The subject of a change in the system of management of the national armories is now before the legislature of the country. Misrepresentations in regard to it have been extensively circulated.

BOARD OF CHOSEN FREEHOLDERS.--This Board have received proposals for furnishing medicines and attending the sick, and for holding post mortem examinations. Dr. Cook of Jersey City, is elected County Physician for the year ensuring.
If all the responses to the Stafford-House protocol, which have been sent for publication to the Daily Times, were published, we, if not the British ladies, would be overwhelmed.

A man named Edward Charles, has been arrested on suspicion of knowing something of the origin of the fire at Brockport, He was the lessee of a bowling saloon in Mr. Holmes' building near which he was first seen.
THE PLUNDERERS PLUNDERED.--On the morning of the 22d, the field of battle, and the roads for some miles in the rear. exhibited an appearance it seldom falls within human fortune to witness.
THE LIQUOR LAW IN RHODE ISLAND.--The new liquor bill, designed to obviate the constitutional objections to the law of 1852, has passed the Rhode Island House of Representatives by a vote of 39 to 27.

Not far to the east of the Adriatic and contiguous to Dalmatia, lies a region scarcely one hundred miles in circumference, which incloses high mountains that are black with the pines and rocks covering their sides.
Edward F. Hodges, Esq., of Massachusetts, was admitted an Attorney and Counsellor of this Court. No. 61. The Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, plaintiff in error, vs. Elias H. Derby.
There is an immense deal of character in a hat. It is to our other articles of apparel what the nose is to the rest of our features. It distinguishes and individualises.

I witnessed, this afternoon, an attempt at self-destruction, which seemed likely to prove fatal ere this. Mr. HENRY T. WEIGHTMAN, aged nearly 60 years, cut his throat with a razor and took prussic acid, at his residence.
Commodore STOCKTON has resigned his seat in the United States Senate. The Legislature of New Jersey has accepted his resignation with the same docility with which it always registers his decrees.
DEMOCRATIC GENERAL COMMITTEE.--This Committee met at Colgan's Eagle Hotel, Fulton-street, on Wednesday evening last, for the purpose of electing officers for the ensuing term.

From the Syracuse Journal. Since the occurrence of the circumstance which induced the mob and consequent excitement at Fulton, on the 30th of last month, we have made considerable effort to procure a full and true statement of the facts in the case.
The Fitchburg (Mass.) papers chronicle the arrest and examination of W. W Griswold, of that town, on a complaint of disturbing a school kept by A. O. Leavitt, contrary to the statute.

From the Household Words. It was late and quite dark when we once reached the town of Falaise, the birthplace of WILLIAM the Conqueror. As we drove to the inn, we passed a lady walking home, attended by a female servant, who carried a lantern of such vast dimensions, and such antique fashion, that it might have helped to illuminate the castle the night WILLIAM was born there.

The genius and arts of modern Italy will, there is reason to believe, be well represented at the exposition of the Industry of all Nations in New-York. An effort is now making to secure a full exhibition of the products of this kingdom.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a copy of the laws and resolutions passed in the Territory of Oregon. Messrs, CASE and UNDERWOOD presented memorials in favor of securing to American citizens abroad religious worship.

Mr. LOOMIS, of Herkimer, the Chairman of the Finance Committee in the Assembly, opened his budget yesterday, and the Ways and Means by which he would replenish the General Fund and provide for the Canals are set forth in his remarks copied under the Assembly head.

New Orleans papers, of the 3d inst., are to hand, but they contain nothing of interest. The Maryland Legislature to-day elected JAMES S. OWENS State Treasurer. The Susquehanna Bridge Bill is still under consideration in the House of Delegates.
CONVENTION OF COLORED CITIZENS.--The Colored Citizens of Ohio held a State Convention at Columbus, Jan. 19 and 20. About 200 were in attendance. Mr. GORDON, of Cleveland, presided.

GAS IN NEW-BEDFORD.--What is the most valuable of modern improvements may well be a subject of debate, but there can be no question that them most impudent movement connected with them is the introduction of gas into the city of oil! Nantucket, we suppose, will fall next; whale ships will sail with patent gas apparatus to make their own light while they explore the seas in search of the means of illuminating others.
LEGISLATIVE AGRICULTURAL MEETINGS.--The fourth agricultural meeting of the season was held at the State House last evening, Hon. SETH SPRAGUS, of Duxbury, presiding.

From the London Afternoon. Our publication this week falls on the first day of a New Year--and the first day of a New Year presents a sort of 'vantage ground on which men are apt to pause and take a look around;--backward along the road which, they have traveled--all whose landmarks and sinuosities they now khow,--and forward into a limited future lying unexplored and indistinct in the first young light of a New Year's morning.
ARREST OF A MURDERER.--A man named JOSEPH SIMMONS was arrested at Louisville on Friday night, charged with the murder of Messrs. COFFMAN and PARK, on a trading boat below Natchez last Summer.
FROM LAKE SUPERIOR.--We had the pleasure of a visit this morning from T. JACKSON, Esq., Agent of the Marquette Iron Company, at Carp River, Lake Superior.
APPLICATION OF HEATED AIR TO THE MANUFACTURING OF SALT.--We were shown yesterday, a model of the hot air application to the manufacturing of salt, got up by Mr. S. B. HOWD.

We have never grown the thousandth part of an inch out of Robinson Crusoe. He fits us just as well, and in exactly the same way, as when we were among the smallest of the small. We have never grown out of his parrot, or his dog, or his fowling-piece, or the horrible old staring goat he came upon in the cave, or his rusty money, or his cap, or umbrella.

To be a Fogy Merchant, it is not absolutely necessary that we should be a subscriber to the Courier and Enquirer, or should, in defiance of the up-town tide of progress, reside in one's paternal mansion in the lower part of Greenwich-street, or should occupy a store in the silent sinuosity of Pearl.
The following Appointments by the President have been confirmed: JOHN L. BERNARD, Register of the Land Office, Lebanon, Ala. OBADIAH W. WARD, Receiver at Lebanon, Ala.

Of the two persons who were to be executed yesterday, one received his doom, and the other was left in the enjoyment of life-long imprisonment. For what reason this discrimination was indulged by Gov. SEYMOUR we do not know.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a communication from the State Department, giving the number of Clerks in that Department. Mr. SEWARD presented petitions from C. VANDERBILT, from the owners of the COLLINS's line of steamors, and from others engaged in steamship business, praying for a suspension of the steamboat law of last session. Petitions or a like nature were also presented from Lake Huron, Hartford, and other places.

SHORT HORN CATTLE FOR OREGON.--Col. J. M. SHERWOOD of Auburn, informs us that he has just sold several of his fine young short Horn Cattle to go to Oregon. They will be driven there over the plains and mountains.

A prize of two hundred dollars, for the best essay on the "Means to be used by the Churches for making the Pastoral Office a more inviting and productive field of Christian labor," is offered by " A Layman," through the columns of this week's Independent.

The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLIN, from Havana the 8th inst., and Key West the morning of the 9th, has arrived at this port. The U. S. steamship Fulton, with Hon. W. R. KING on board, arrived at Havana on the 6th inst. Mr. KING was in improved health.

We have received the prospectus of the Spiritual Beacon, which is to be "edited on the broad platform of toleration and free inquiry," located, it seems, at Cincinnati. "The size of the paper will be double medium."

COLLISION.--Yesterday morning, the ferry boat Niagara came in collision with the New-York and New-Haven steamboat Champion. No damage was done further than carrying away the figure-head of the Champion, and somewhat disconcerting the nerves of the ladies on the ferry boat.

A bill has been introduced in the Now Jersey Senate, which, if it becomes a law, will effect a material alteration in the structure of the social system. SEC. 1. Gives married women the power of devising and conveying their property without the consent of their husbands.

BANKRIS' ASSOCIATION.--There was a large meeting of delegates from many of the New-England Banks, held in the room over the Tremont Bank yesterday, for the purpose of organizing a Bankers' Association, for the detection and prevention of counterfeiting.
America's Ericssons. The success among us of Mr. ERICSSON's achievement of Scientific Mechanism, gives him an American name and renown which the world will not willingly let die.

M. GOTTSCHALK'S reception by a New-York audience, last evening, was exceedingly flattering. The young artist was evidently embarrassed by the warmth earnestness of the welcome that was extended to him.

One thousand workmen, from the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad workshops, with all of the conductors, breakmen and engineers of the transportation trains, struck for higher wages this morning, and marched to Monument-equare, where they were addressed by FRANK GALLAGHER, and where they were subsequently joined by a large number of machinists and workmen from all the other shops in the city.

This Texas of ours is an astonishing prolific country. Every field stands luxuriant, crowded, so that it can scarce wave under the breeze, with corn or sugar, or wheat or cotton. Every cabin is full and overflowing, through all its doors and windows, with white haired children.

To every one there is his pleasure, but the frivolous alone seek for it frivolously. Happy are they who, taught by trials, sufferings, disappointments, and vicissitudes, have learned to find their pleasure where so many miss it, in duty, and in privation, and who experience more delight and satisfaction in hardihood than in easyhood.
One Gen. J. A. BETHUNE, of Columbus, Ga., is unhappy about the Union. The slim possibility of a dissolution breaks his rest o' nights. He is not fond of the Union. It is not after his own heart.

This City is pretty well cared for in the article of Medical Schools, Three large and good ones, each enjoying the extraordinary facilities for instruction that properly and of necessity pertain to the metropolis, are on the full tide of successful experiment.

The Electric, for February, abounds with very excellent matters. The leading article drawn from the British Eclectic Review, upon PASCAL, is a fine specimen of scholarly and elegant writing. An article from Tait, upon the Turkish Empire, is well timed and satisfactory.

There was a story as old as the Rocky Mountains, to the effect that a man being once asked if he could sing, replied in the negative, but added that he had a cousin who played on the German flute. There are a great many men like this musician by connection.

The Committee of the New-Jersey Rail road Company, appointed to confer with the Common Council relative to the increase of railroad and ferry accommodations, propose fixing the rate of the speed of their locomotives through the city at twelve miles per hour, which agrees with the law regulating the speed of railroad trains in the city of Newark, N. J.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I observed a few days since, on a scrap of the Daily Times for some day in December last, some comments upon a report upon the mortality of the British armies,--embracing the period between the years 1790 and 1815.

REV. ALBERT BARNES.--We learn from the New-York Evangelist, that a most touching and interesting scene occurred at the First Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia, a few evenings since, in the congregation over which Rev. Dr. BARNES has exercised his pastoral care for more than twenty years.

The Secretary of the Treasury has appointed JOSEPH WOODS Inspector of the Hulls of Steamers at Wheeling, on a salary of $500. Mr. BADGER's nomination, in the executive session to-day, was postponed to the 4th of March, by a majority of one.
STATE NORMAL SCHOOL.--The Concluding exercises at the State Normal School took place at Albany on Thursday.

A curious case recently occurred in England. Two young women attempted to starve themselves to death, rather than apply to the parochial authorities for relief.

From the London Times. The question of capital punishment can hardly be said to be mooted in this country, a few sentimental ejaculations being all that one ever hears on the side of the opponents. But there is another question, not less important, and much more practical.

Not long ago MONTALEMBERT, the head of French Jesuitism, wrote an essay upon the reviving glories of Catholicism. The world in 1800, and the world in 1852, were brought together in order to demonstrate the recuperative tendencies of the Church, throughout the ended half of the nineteenth century.
MELANCHOLY SUICIDE OF AN INSANE EMIGRANT AT WARD'S ISLAND--Yesterday morning Coroner GAMBLE was called upon to hold an inquest at Ward's Island, on the body of an unknown emigrant.

PRIZE MEDAL TO MR. McCORMICK -- The following is a copy of a letter sent to Mr. G. H. McCORMICK, the inventor of the American Reaper, by the President, as Chairman of the Central Committee of the United States, informing Mr. McCORMICK of the award made to him by a jury of Royal Commissioners at the World's Fair, held in London in 1851, as the inventor of this celebrated agricultural implement.

Strikes are again the order of the day. We are getting to be a well-stricken people. The samples of human nature now in the market are so bad that it is fair to presume that there is a sad fault in somebody.

The Committee of Investigation on the charges against parties connected with the Capitol Extension, are busily engaged in taking evidence. From the testimony taken so far, it would appear that the charges of gross corruption are fully substantiated.

From the Lansing Journal We give up our editorial column to-day, to the following letter, from the editor of the Michigan Farmer, on the subject of the Agricultural school and its proposed connection with the University, written in reply to our call for such information relative to foreign schools of that character, as Mr. ISHAM might have acquired during his late visit to Europe.

Trial for Smuggling. THIRD DAY. U. S. DISTRICT COURT--Before Judge BETTS.--The United States vs. Elisha M. Fitch. Peter Cook examined by District Attorney--I am a Marshal's officer; I have been to summon Mr. Asster, this morning--the clerk told me Mr. Asster had left town ; I also summoned Bartlett.

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--The Railroad Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council held a Committee meeting at the City Hall on Thursday evening and had before them the subject of the Ordinance ordering the withdrawal of locomotives from the Long Island Railroad In Atlantic street, on the 15th inst.

The atmosphere, as is well known, contains oxygen gas, in the proportion of one-fifth part, by measure. It is also well known that if hydrogen gas be mingled with atmospheric air, it becomes explosive when flame is applied.

INTERESTING LAW SUIT--OPERATION OF THE CODE OF PRACTICE.--The Louisville papers mention the trial in the Jefferson Circuit Court of an action brought by ALLEN Son, extensive print manufacturers of Providence, R. I., against A GOWDY Co., of Louisville. upon the allegation that the defendants had counterfeited the plaintiffs' labels and used them upon inferior goods, to the injury of the plaintiffs' reputation and business. The damages were laid at $10,000.

Mr. DOTY, of Wisconsin, is about to introduce in the House, under the rule, a petition accompanied by a bill appropriating $500,000 for the immediate constraction, under the direction of the Postmaster General and Typographical Engineers, an air line Post Route Railroad from Washington, via Baltimore and Philadelphia, to New-York.
Poetry.--A Song for the Season; by G. B. NEW COMB. Literary.--The Great Conversationists--No. VII; by "II Segrotario"--Dr. THOMAS COOPER. Miscellany.
About fifty vessels, delayed by head winds, arrived at this port this morning. Among them, the ships Bowdich and John M. Mayo, from Calcutta; and bark Suliotte, from Fayal, Jan. 23.

WALLACK's.--"The Lady of Lyons" and "The Review." --By the way, a change of performance is announced for Monday, when the comedy of "Old Heads and Young Hearts" and the farce of "A Practical Man" are to be played.

REPORT OF THE MASSACHUSETTS BOARD OF EDUCATION.--We have received the sixteenth annual report of the Board, including the usual annual report of the Secretary. The report recommends the establishment of two new Normal schools--one in Berkshire, and the other in Essex.

From the Tribune. Sundry City journals have indulged their dull wits with amazing facetiousness over the appearance of three or four ladies on the platform of Metropolitan Hall the other evening, to commend the cause of Total Abstinence, advocate the Maine Law, and defend the right of Women thus to set forth and commend their earnest convictions.

EXTRAORDINARY CASE--REMARKABLE DEVOTION OF A MISTRESS TO HER SLAVE--We have recently learned the particulars of a very Strange history--one of the Strangest which the working of the "peculiar institution" has yet brought to light.

The following sketch, from a statement of M. BROWNIEWSKI, formerly an officer in the Russian fleet, will be found interesting at the present time: "A Montenegrin is always armed, and carries about, during his most peaceful occupation, a rifle(a gun), pistols, a yatagan, and a cartouch-box.

WARREN, MERCER, GREENE.--A movement is making in Virginia and Rhode Island, to induce Congress to carry out the early votes of that body, which on the 12th of April, 1777, adopted the re port of a Committee, to whom it was referred, to consider what honors should be paid to the memories of Generals WARREN and MERCER.

From the Esculapian. We, the inditers, members of the Infant Society, being fully determined on our own account and in behalf of the rising generation, cry aloud for reform in the system of management to which we are subjected, both parental and professional, which is often un-civil and un-medical.

In St Louis. Mo., Dec. 28 JAMES KENNADAY, Esq., of Vandalia, Fayette Co., III.. aged 47. Mr Kennaday was the brother of Rev. Dr. Kennaday, of Brooklyn, and was formerly the proprietor of a printing office in New-York, but for several years past has been engaged as Editor of the Free Press, published at Vandalia.

The annual report of the Adjutant General of Massachusetts states that orders have been Issued during the year for disbanding eleven light infantry and one rule company. 421 commissions for various grades have been issued, and 203 commissioned officers discharged. There have been sixteen encampments in various parts of the state, which have been attended by the Adjutant General and Governor, and the appearance and character of each one of then is briefly noticed.

NEW-ENGLAND POULTRY SOCIETY.--At a meeting of the "New-England Society for the Improvement of Domestic Poultry," hold Tuesday night in the State House, the following officers were chosen for the forthcoming year: President--Moses Kimball, of Boston.

At a late meeting of the New-Hampshire Agricultural Society, a gentleman made his name odorous of good sense and taste, by offering a premium of twenty-five dollars for the best specimens of patching and darning that should be exhibited, being actuated thereto by seeing how many specimens of useless needlework were presented.

From the national Intelligencer. Messrs. EDITORS: Mr. CHASS has moved, in the Senate, for the purchase by Government of the statue of "America," by POWERS. It is hoped that his effort will be successful. Mr. POWERS is an American born, and has won an eminence in his art which is overtopped by no sculptor of time past or present.

The Coroner's Jury, in the case of the murdered German girl, ays the Newark Daily Advertiser, are still in session at the Court-house, with closed doors. The public will be glad to learn that they are determined to push their Investigations to the utmost, and to spare no measures to ferret out the abominable scoundrels who perpetrated the horrid crime.

The progress of the Mexican Revolution is not tardy. The General CEVALLOS understands his business. Whether he has derived his skill from long practice, in a school where examples are supplies in the most liberal spirit, we have no means of knowing. His name has not been uppermost in any previous revolutionary demonstration.

BROADWAY.--DOUGLAS JERROLD'S Comedy, that was "set before the Queen" at Windsor Castle, less than three weeks since, and is now playing nightly at the Princess's Theatre, London, is to be produced here this evening. It is called "St. Cupid, or Dorothy's Fortune." The action occurs in the reign of GEORGE I. of England, and has reference to the struggle of the Pretender.

A letter from Trieste, 18th ult., states that apprehensions are again expressed of the failure of this year's crop of Currants Owing to the continued mildness of the weather, the vegetation of the trees had so far advanced that the leaves and even the blossom had appeared, but covered with the white blight which last season was the unfailing forerunner of disease.

The proceedings on Saturday were quite interesting, and somewhat stirring withal. In the Senate, the Consolidation Railroad bill passed its final reading with much case--the negative vote being only six Senators.

St. Valentine; His History and Mystery. It is one of those mysterious historical or antiquarian problems which are doomed never to be solved, as to what the unhappy Saint VALENTINE had to do with the 14th of February, and all its symbols and paraphernalia of Cupids, hearts and love-letters.
Mr. SEYMOUR, Chairman of the U. S. House Committee on Commerce, has reported on Reciprocal Trade with the British North American Colonies, accompanied by a bill. The bill is here copied at length.

General BLAKE has returned from Florida. It is understood that he anticipates no serious difficulties with the Indians. Mr. DOUGLAS expects to speak to-morrow on the MONROE Doctrine. He will thoroughly sustain the position assumed by Mr. CASS.

The Times has received a telegraphic dispatch from Trieste, Jan. 27, 1 o'clock, A M., in anticipation of the Overland Indian mall per steamer Germania. The dispatch says: Gen. GODWIN having imprudently stutioned an advance post of only 400 men at Pegu, 60 miles from Rangoon, and with is a short distance of the main body of the Burmeso army.

Accounts from Madrid of the 21st inst., state that the Electoral Committee of the Moderado Opposition was on the point of dissolving itself, in consequence of the two last Ministerial Circulars They intended, however, previously, to address a manifesto to the electors or Madrid and of the provinces, to apprise them of their intention to prosecute, before the competent tribunals, the Government agents who should commit excesses or violence during the elections.

The CHAIR, had before the Senate a Message from the President, inclosing the Report of the Directors of the Mint. Referred. MOUR OF MEETING. Mr. GWIN moved to take up the Resolution providing that. after Monday next, the hour of meeting shall be 11 o'clock, on which motion two divisions took place, and no quorum voted.

The fifteenth section of the Act of Congress, entitled "An act to amend an act entitled' An act for the better security of the lives of passengers on board of vessels propelled in whole or in part by steam, and for other purposes.'" approved 30th August, 1852, provides: "That all plates of boiler iron shut he distinctly and permanently stamped in such manner as the Secretary of the Treasury shall prescribe, and if practicable.

The steamships Ohio, Northern Light and Uncle Sam, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing the California mails and specie of the 15th January with dates from Panama and Aspinwall to the 3d inst., San Juan del Norte to the 4th, and Kingston to the 7th.

The news from California this morning is painfully interesting. It turns, not upon the immense yield of Gold, for the receipts are only Two Millions, but on the destitution which prevails universally in the mining districts in consequence of the disastrous floods that have laid the country waste.

The political world is altogether quiet. Almost the only rumor we hear of is one circulated on the authority of the Morning Advertiser, that dissensions have already broken out in the Ministry. Mr. GLADSTONE, Chancellor of the Exchequer, is reported to he at variance with some of the members of the Administration on the subject of the Income Tax, and the misunderstanding will probably end in his retirement.
The R. M. steamship Niagara, Capt. LEITCH, arrived at this port yesterday in the afternoon, having sailed from Liverpool on Saturday, the 29th ultimo, at 11 o'clock A. M.
The bark Linwood, arrived below from Rio Janeiro, January 2d, reports the fever raging there very badly.

The week in Europe has been unusually void of incident. The prominent topics of editorial and out-door discussion in England, have been the Peace Society's demonstration at Manchester, and the probable retirement of Mr. GLADSTONE from the New Ministry.

VALENTINE'S DAY.--With morning's earliest dawn, and while yet drowsy newsboys are waiting for consignments of the Daily Times, the amatory campaign of 1853 has fairly commenced; that season when "All nature seems in love, And birds draw forth their Valentines."

FIRE--Yesterday morning, between land 2 o'clock, a fire broke out in a three story brick building, in Seventh-street between Fourth and Fifth-streets, which, together with the contents, was entirely destroy ed. The building was owned and occupied by Mr. W. HUNT, as a stair and bannister manufactory. The building was valued at $2,000, and was insured for $1,000 in the Stuyvesant Insurance Company.

By the arrival of the brig Lucy at this port, we are in possession of dates from the City of Mexico to the 25th January. The news is of an important character. After the ejection of the members of Congress, fifty eight of them assembled at a private house on the 25th January, impeached CEVALLOS, and elected OSORIO, the Governor of Peubia, as President ad-interim, but the latter declined to accept the office.

According to our foreign papers, the Montenegrine war is being pushed on with a good deal of vigor. Rumors were current that the Turkish army had been repulsed, and that many of the surrounding districts had declared for the mountaineers.
The Cunard steamship Niagara arrived at this port yesterday, after a long passage of fourteen days from Liverpool, whence she brings dates to the 29th January.

HARVARD UNIVERSITY.--The adjourned meeting of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University was holden at the Senate Chamber on Thursday afternoon, Governor CLIFFORD presiding. He read a letter from Rev. Dr. YOUNG, announcing his resignation as Secretary, whereupon Dr. LOTHEOP moved the accentance of the resignation, with a vote of thanks for the services of Dr. YOUNG, which were both adopted.

The Emperor's marriage, though taking people by surprise, has not been exactly a nine days wonder; and the public has for the last two or three days looked upon it almost as a matter of course, and have ceased to be surprised. From the present state of public feeling, always of course excepting the political circles, there is reason to anticipate that the future Empress will be generally popular.

Samuel Blatchford, Esq., of New York, was admitted an Attorney and Counsellor of the Court. No 63. H. Webster, plaintiff in error, vs. P. Cooper.--The argument of this cause was concluded by Mr. Davies for the plaintiff in error. No 64. Passaic and Hackensack Bridges vs. The State of Jersey.--This case, from the Court of Appeals of New-Jersey, was dismissed with costs, pursuant to the 59th rule of this Court.

WALLACK'S.--The old story of "The Lady of Lyons," and "The Wags of Windsor" --The new comedy of "St. Cupid" is in rehearsal, and will probably be brought out on Thursday evening. A new "Musical Drama" is also in preparation.

BE CAREFUL, HOW YOU TELL A GHOST STORY.--The following anecdote of the mishaps that may afflict the teller of ghost and other stories, is given on the authority of the Courier des Etats Unit: It seems there is at present a sort of Club in Paris called "The Dinner of Parvenus."

To the Common Council: The 21st section of the Act of 1849, to amend the Charter of the City of New-York, provides that " every head of Department shall report in writing to the Common Council, at the commencement of each stated session, the state of his Department, with such suggestions in relation to the improvement thereof, and to the public business connected therewith, as he may deem advisable."

The Senate commenced business at 11 o'clock and 20 minutes. Several Executive communications were received. Mr. SEWARD presented petitions for the repeal of the Steamboat law, and others in favor of a line of steamers from Brooklyn to Germany.

Professor YOUMANS delivered a lecture at the Broadway Tabernacle last evening on the "Chemical Relations of the Atmosphere to the Living World." Mr. YOUMANS opened his lecture by remarking, that we last week attempted to show how it was that dead mineral matter is organized or transformed into living compounds in the mechanism of the plant.
