DEATH FROM VIOLENCE.--The Second District Police reported yesterday morning that a woman named HAGAN, wife of BERNARD HAGAN, had been found dead in her bed that morning, at her residence, corner of Charles and Tallman-streets.

Metropolitan Hall was filled last evening by an audience as numerous and enthusiastic as greeted Mr. MEAGHER on his first appearance there, to hear his promised lecture on "HENRY GRATTAN and the Irish Volunteers of '82."

The New-England Farmer says, very truly: The Chesnut, both on account of its timber and the fruit it produces, deserves more attention than it receives. The nuts intended for planting should not be allowed to become thoroughly dry.

Gen. PIERCE has just taken his departure for Boston, en route for Washington, accompanied by his Private Secretary--SIDNEY WEBSTER. A large number of our citizens took leave of him at the Eagle Hotel, and at the Depot, but at his re quest, no public demonstration was made. He will stay in Boston to-night, and perhaps reach New-York to-morrow night, or Wednesday morning.

The postponement of the question on Senator BADGER'S nomination to the Supreme Court, has greatly disappointed his friends here of all par ties. There are none who do not condemn this action as unworthy the Senate, except those whose devotion to party as an avenue of spoils rather than the representative of principles, is not superior to every other influence.

ANOTHER ACCIDENT FROM BURNING FLUID.--On Sunday evening, about 9 1/2 o'clock, Mrs. BUCKNELL, boarding house keeper, No. 546 Houston street, was badly burned in the face and hands by the explosion of a fluid lamp.

From an Italian Paper. Pietro Carnesecchi, a name celebrated in and beyond Italy, born of a noble Floreutine family, in the beginning of the sixteenth century, was a friend of Cosmo de Medici, beloved by Clement VIL, a Pontiff of that family, and to whom he was Secretary, as also Prothonotary to the Apostolic See.

THE CHARGE AGAINST AN ASSISTANT ALDER MAN FOR AIDING AND ASSISTING A PRISONER TO ESCAPE--DECISION OF JUSTICE WELSH.--The serious charge of aiding and assisting in the escape of a prisoner from the Fourteenth Ward Station House, pending against Assistant Alderman THOMAS WHEELAN, has been thoroughly investigated before Justice WELSH, at the Second District Police Court.
From Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine. In the street, opposite the meadow, was a long, low show, made of canvass, with an ornamental front and stage, whereon a merry-Andrew was delighting the populace.

ALLEGED PERJURY AND ARREST.--Yesterday morning Officers RUE and MANSFIELD, of the Lower Police Office, proceeded to the Quarantine, at Staten Island, and arrested a young man by the name of THOMAS McCANN, (not the Fifth Ward McCANN,) upon a warrant issued by Justice OSBORNE, wherein he stands charged with the crime of perjury.

WEST-POINT FERRY.--Among the various retreats to which many of our citizens resort during the Summer months, there are few that compare with those situated near the Highlands of West Point, whether as regards scenery or healthiness, and the overflowing hotels of COZZENS and RYDER the last season, gave evidence how these places are appreciated, and since the Railroad has been finished, they are much more accessible.

FIRE DEPARTMENT--Under the act entitled "An act concerning the Firemen of Jersey City," a new organization of the Fire Department has been effected, a new Constitution and By-Laws adopted, and officers of the Board of Trustees elected.

Monument-square is again thronged this morning with mechanics from all sections of the City, music, banners, The Strikers have been joined by the workmen from the Federal Hill Establishment to the number of 700 or 800. The meeting was attended by about 4,000 men. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad workmen, having pledged themselves to stand by the others, still refuse to go to work, notwithstanding the Company give the prices demanded.

From Colburn's New Monthly Magazine an Humorist. In a conspicuous part of the house, placed there for the edification of his guests--for he knew it by heart himself--and fairly copied out and framed, was the oath, administered to the claimants of the flitch, which had always hitherto appeared so formidable to him, but which he now hoped to be able to pronounce, without any omission, or the slightest mental reservation.

In Brooklyn, On Monday morning, Feb 14, WILLIAM H, son of Win H Bean, aged 2 years and 6 months. On Sunday night, at 12 o'clock, Feb 13, of hemorrhage, at College Hotel, in this City, after a short illucas, MISS MARY MATHER, of the City of Albany, aged 25 years.

The Secretary of the Treasury has made the following appointments, viz: JOHN GREATON, Inspector of Steamboat Halls, and E ELLICOTT HEWES, Inspector of Steamboat Boilers, Charleston, S. C., salary $400 each. JAMES E. WITHRINGTON, Inspector of Hulls, and WILLIAM KINE, Inspector of Boilers, Savannah, Ga., salary $400 each. LIGHT-HOUSE KEEPERS. SANL., WILLOUGHBY, Braodywine Shoal, Del., salary $500 Per annum.

The Mechanics' Institute was thronged again this morning by the strikers. A proposition was introduced to allow the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad hands, and of all other shops that give the prices, to go to work, and bind themselves to contribute 25 per cent. of their salaries to support their brethren of those shops that refuse to give the price.

FROM CUBA--THE CARDENAS FIRE.--By way of Charleston, we have details of the telegraphic news from Havana, per Isabel. Advices from Santiago state that several slight earth quakes had been felt there from the 11th to the 26th Jan, The consternation was at one time great, but no injury was done.

The rejection by the United States Senate of Mr. BADGER'S nomination for Judge of the Supreme Court, is one of those purely party operations which the country will not sustain. There was no possible objection to the Senator from North Carolina, except that lie is a Whig.

The figures of the City Controller on the progress of real estate may not probably arrest the attention of sanguine speculators in town property, but, we humbly submit, they should bring to a pause the prevailing eagerness of tenants to secure long leases.

LETTER FROM THE BARL OF SHAFTKOBURY. To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: I have just read in your paper a letter purporting to be the reply of the American ladies to the address of the " Women of England," on the subject of Slavery in the United States.

Four New-Orleans mails, bringing dates as late as due, are to hand. The following are the particulars of the dismissal of Congress by President CEVALLOS: A bill was under discussion providing for convoking a Convention,

The revival, under distinguished auspices, of the claim made public a few years ago on behalf of Rev. E. WILLIAMS to recognition as the son of LOUIS XVI., generally supposed to have died in prison during the Revolution, has created a general interest in the details of that melancholy tragedy.

FUNERAL OF LIEUTENANT CHARLES B. BROWES, OF THE NEW-YORK VOLUNTEERS.-Tne remains of this gallant officer, who served with so much credit to himself in the late war with Mexico, were yesterday consigned to their last resting place, at Greenwood Cemetery.
The State Legislature adjourned yesterday. The Maumeo Charter amendments were not passed. The Ann Arbor Bank amendments were vetoed by the Governor.

The Opera at NIBLO's continues to attract very large audiences. Lucia was brought out on Monday, and will be repeated this evening. The first performance appears to have given very general pleasure, so far as the singing of Madamo SONTAG and Signor BADIALI has been discussed.

The following letter, addressed by Mr. COBDEN to a clergyman who had sent him a copy of his sermon on the Duke of WELLINGTON'S death, has excited a good deal of attention in England, and will be read with interest here: DECEMBER, 1852.
The steamer Osprey has arrived here in four days and twenty-four hours from Havana, being the quickest passage on record. Her dates are to the 10th instant.

On Tuesday, Feb. 15. in the 88th year of her age, Mrs MARGARET MORGANS, widow of the late Morgan Morgans. The friends of the family, and of her sons, Josiah and Morgan Morgans, and son-in-in-law, David Jones, are requested to attend her funeral on Thursday afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock, from No. 9 Monroe-st.

Mr. DOUGLAS'S speech to day attracted a great deal of attention. He sustained all that General CASS claims for the MONROE doctrine, but put it to his colleague very tightly for urging mere abstractions. He was quite severe, and Mr. CASS felt himself called upon to reply.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate communications from the War Department. Mr. BADGER said he noticed that in the proceedings of the Criminal Court of the District of Columbia, the District Attorney had moved to fix a day for the trial of the GARDINER and other cases of frauds.

MATTERS IN HAVANA.--From a gentleman just arrived from Havana, we learn that the Captain General has sent a special messenger to Key West inviting Mr. KING, Vice-President elect, in case he visited Havana, to take up his quarters in the Captain General's palace.

THE ANTICIPATED DUELS.--The expected dual between two members of the Virginia Legislature, we learn has been avoided, and the affair honorably adjusted. It was Mr. LEWIS, Democrat, who challenged Mr. CRANE, Whig. The challenge was accepted, and the adjustment by subsequently brought about through mutual friends, by Mr. C. disclaiming any intention to insult Mr. I, during a discussion in the House of Delegates of Virginia, a few days ago.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the arrival of the steamship Mexico, from Indianola and Galveston, we have received files of Texas papers. A gentleman who left Swartwout on the 23d ult., In. forms the editor of the Galveston News, that the Trinity was then slowly rising, and that the expectation was general that the navigation would continue good for several months.

Yesterday some twenty members of the City Government assembled at the Tremont House, where a room and dinner had been ordered in anticipation of the arrival of General PIERCE, and his presence as a guest. The General, however, did not come, and the gentlemen consoled themselves with the solids and liquids spread before them.

There have been numerous wrecks and marine disasters since my last was written; the wreckers are doing a good business, and everything is in a prosperous state. Provisions, however, are scarce, and a cargo of flour, potatoes, butter, onions, c., would find a ready sale.

KINGS COUNTY CIRCUIT COURT--Before Judge BARCULO--Monday.--Amasa Aery and others vs. James Heker.--The parties agreed to share the profits and loss in a quantity of pine-apples to be brought from Matanzas. Aery was to purchase the fruit and bring it to Now York, and own one-third; Heker was to sell them after their arrival, and he was to own one-third; the remaining one-third belonged to the firm of Dickinson Co., the other plaintiffs.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Tuesday.--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Alderman BRINSLEY and BARD.--The case of Wm. M. Doty, indicted for Perjury in the Forrest Divorce Trial.--Very great interest prevailed concerning this case, and the Court-room and gallery were filled, while numbers, anxious to obtain admittance, were denied entrance from the want of accommodation.

Schooner Clara has arrived at this port from Rio Janeiro, Jan. 5. She reports that the steamship Sierra Nevada, from New York for Panama, arrived at Rio on the 3d January. Bark St. James, from Philadelphia, sailed Dec. 29 for Montevideo.

From the Boston Times, Tuesday. Gen. PIERCE arrived in this city in the Northern train last evening. He was expected by the City Government in the noon train, and arrangements were made to give him a private official reception at that time, but his non-arrival prevented that ceremony.

FRIEDRICH BULAN is a most diligent explorer of the byways of history. In a recent book entitled Geheime Geschichlen and Rathselhafte Menschen, ("Secret Histories and Enigmatical personages,") he has presented a portion of the results of his researches.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers)...No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART CO., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st,

EXPECTED ARRIVAL OF THE PRESIDENT-ELECT OF THE UNITED STATES--SPECIAL MEETING OF THE "SOFT-SHELL" DEMOCRATIC GENERAL COMMITTEE--In pursuance of the following call, a special meeting of the "Shepard" or "Soft Shell" General Committee was held last evening at the "coal hole" of Tammany Hall Subjoined is the call as issued in the little organ of the "Soft-Shells:"

There was quite a scene between Hon. GEROGE BRIGGS and the Postmaster-General, at the Department, on Saturday. Mr. BRIGGS called to present a petition, signed by the merchants and brokers of New-York, representing many millions of dollars, praying for the employment of swift steamers to bring the mails of the ocean steamships from Sandy Hook to the city.

SUICIDE.--A man apparently about 40 years of age deliberately threw himself overboard from the Hoboken ferry-boat James Rumsey, when about half way between Canal-street and Hoboken, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He appeared to act in the most deter mined manner, as he was observed by some persons to take hold of the ring of the rudder-bolt and lower himself off.

The Keepsake for 1853 contains a very amusing letter from Malle. RACHEL to Madame SAMSON, dated from Interlaken in 1843. It seems that the great tragedian was encountered in the auberge on the Montanvert by a party of French badauds, who disputed with each other about her identity--one among them considering it impossible that Phedre could have wandered so far from the boards of the Theatre Francais.

Henry Dampior Lapaugh, Esq., of New-York, and M. Hale Smith, Esq., of Massachusetts, were admitted attorneys and counsellors of this Court. No. 67--Marsh et al., plaintiff in error vs. E Brooks et al The argument of this cause was concluded by Mr. Butler, for the plaintiff in error.

Dates from Havana are received, via Philadelphia, to the 10th inst. The health of Vice-President KING was improving, at last accounts. Ho was taking daily exercise, on foot, and hoped to be able to return by the 1st of April.

The great Library Hall of ---- College, at the time I was an under-graduate of that celebrated institution, possessed, in addition to the usual furniture of alcove and gallery, a long velvet covered table, which extended nearly from window to window of the apartment, and was at all times covered with the periodicals of the month or quarter.

Some of the papers facetiously talk of a liquor law which should allow the free and unlicensed sale of liquors, but require that every drinker should procure a license before he can legally purchase. That would not be bad.

Introduction--From New-York to Washington-Agriculture in the District and Neighboring Country--New-England Emigration to Fairfax--Good Effects of it--From Washington to Richmond, Va.--Aspect of the Country--A Prairie Farmer's View of it--Appearance of the People--Style of Planter's Houses-Social Position of Slaves.

CRAVATS.--Professor HAMILTON'S remarks at the Buffalo Medical College on asphyxia, and particularly that form caused by wearing tight cravats, may be of interest to the general reader. Cravats were first worn by the Croats in the sixteenth country, as a part of their military dress.

From the National Intelligencer. The following extract of a letter, addressed to the officer in our Post-Office Department having, under the supervision of the Postmaster-General, the charge of our foreign mail arrangements, will be recognized as in answer to a letter, the larger part of which was published in the Intelligencer of Dec. 27:

COMMON COUNCIL.--At the meeting of the members of the Council on Monday evening, a petition was received from David S. Mills, for permission to lay a rail track on Division avenue. Alderman WILMARTH moved that the petitioner have leave to withdraw his petition, as the Common Council have already granted the right to another party, Adopted.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--The Board met Tuesday evening at the Common Council Chamber, Grand street, approved the minutes of the last meeting, and transacted the following business: A communication was received relative to the improvement of Prospect-street.

The State Assembly at Albany has been engaged for a day or two in discussing a question of personal privilege. One of the rules of the House requires every member to vote. Mr. RUSSELL SMITH asked to be excused on one occasion.

The Holmes County (Ohio) Farmer states that a wonderful natural curiosity has been discovered in that County, in the shape of natural gas. The discovery was made on the farm of a Mr. Purdy, some eight or ten rod south of the house, in a curious kind of earth, resembling sawdust.

From the Journal of Commerce. We publish below a bill entitled " An Act in relation to the taxation of Real Estate, and of Mortgages thereon." This is an important bill, and should be published in full in the Journal of Commerce Remonstrances against this bill have been signed and forwarded to Albany.

PIRACY ON THE COAST OF MOROCCO.--In reference to the recent acts of piracy on the North Coast of Morocco', the Gibraltar Chronicle of the 1st inst. contains the following: "It appears that the coast of Riff is as insecure as ever.

On Wednesday, Feb. 16, after a short illness, CHARLES H LORD, in the 28th year of his age The friends of his father, Joseph N. Lord, and of his brothers-in-law, O. B Tweedy, F. W Edmonds, and Archibald Hilton, are invited to attend his funeral on Friday next, at 3 1/2 o'clock, from No. 69 Irving-place. At Jacksonville, Florida, on the 8th just, JOHN M. SATTERELEE, aged 36 years.

SENTENCE OF THE CARPET SWINDLER.--In the Municipal Court, this morning, Capt. CHARLES BLANCHARD, alias ROBERT McGINNITY, plead guilty to an indictment which charges him with fraudulently obtaining $1,000 worth of carpeting from JEROME B. JUDKINS.
Mr. R. W. LATHAM invites, through the Washington papers, poetical competition for certain five hundred dollars he happens to have about him. Mr. LATHAM is a votary of the fine arts.

The Nantucket Inquirer is particularly exercised lest our Government should be led into doing something unpleasant towards the crowned heads of Europe. A misunderstanding with Russia, it thinks, would be especially disastrous.

SENT UP.--A brute, in the shape of a man, named Patrick McKinney, was brought before Justice KING on Tuesday by assistant Captain Oswold, or the Third District Police, charged with repeatedly beating and abusing his wife, who is in a delicate situation. He was furnished with quarters at the Penitentiary for the ensuing three months.

We received yesterday (too late to give the news in the Evening Picayune) the Brownsville Flag of the 31st ult, containing an account of a successful pronunciamento at Matamoros, and other interesting Intelligence from Northern Mexico.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate the report of the board of officers appointed to survey for a canal around the falls of the Ohio. DEFICIENCY BILL. Mr. HUNTER moved to take up the Deficiency bill. Mr. BRIGHT said he hoped a half hour would be given to other business. He supposed the Senator made the motion as a matter of duty, and would take its being voted down, kindly.

The telegraph has notified us of a fact too important to wait the tardy motions of railroads or steamboats. General PIERCE has, at last, broken from the impenetrable cloud of mystification and doubt by which he has been so long surrounded, and has made his first appointment.

Gen. PIERCE will not announce his Cabinet probably until immediately after the Inauguration, in order to hear a that is to be said on the subject here by the leaders, and to change if it be deemed necessary. The now budget announced to night with much positiveness, gives CUSHING the State Department; FLAGG the Treasury; JEFFERSON DAVIS, War; DORBIN, Navy; BUTLER, Attorney-General; McCLELLAND, Postmaster-General.

A grand Sacred Concert, consisting of sixty performers, members of the New York Sacred Harmonic Society, was given last evening at the Odeon, under the direction of Messrs GEO. F. BRISTOW, and GEO. H; CURTIS, Mr. WM. H. FRY, and others, were also present, and added to the entertainment.

We publish in another column a strong and interesting paper from the Cuban Junta, in reply to an article upon Cuban Affairs which we recently copied from the London Times. It is written with ability, and sets forth cogent and conclusive reasons vindicating the friends of Cuban independence from the censures of the London press.

Governor RAMSAY, of Minnesota, delivered his Annual Message to the Council and House of Representatives of that Territory, on the 26th of January. Notwithstanding the hue and cry which has been raised about the Governor by some of the local papers, he writes in good spirits and relieves the tedium of territorial politics with figures of speech and the adornments of rhetoric.

A MURDER CASE--INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSES OF THE DEATH OF MRS. BRIDGET HAGAN--VERDICT OF THE CORONER's JURY.--Yesterday after noon, Coroner BALL proceeded to investigate the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. Bridget Hagan, wife of Bernard Hagan, who resides at the corner of Charles and Tallman-streets, Brooklyn.

On Saturday morning last a fire broke out in the old building in Water-street, near Orange, Albany, long occupied by Mr. H. NEWMAN as a wool depot. The building was seriously damaged, as well as the bulk of the contents. We have not heard the amount of the loss.

THE RIPLEY TRAGEDY.--ROBERT PETERS, who was shot on Wednesday by CHARLES BAIRD, whose sister be had seduced and refused to marry, was still living when the Kenton passed Ripley yesterday, but there was little probability of his recovery. BAIRD was in California when the news of his sister's ruin reached him, he immediately left his business, and scarcely took rest or food till he reached Ripley.

The Message of Gov. LANE to the Legislature of New-Mexico is a document which comes to the point about matters in that Territory. The Governor says: "We are very distant from the States difficult of access, and surrounded by barbarians of doubtful faith.

Rev. RICHARD S. STORRS, of Brooklyn, delivered a Lecture, (one of the Popular Course,) in the Tabernacle, last evening, to a small but appreciative audience. His subject was--"The Past our Benefactor." He was, he said, to speak on one of the most trite subjects, and one on which a brilliant speaker had but a short time preceded him.

The success of Mr EVERSTT'S filibustering and colonization pronunciamentos has been signal. Messrs. CASS and MASON are entitled to his most distinguished consideration for giving him the first chance; the second be made for himself. To two of the most potent passions in the Northern mind be has appealed--and successfully. One is the progressive spirit which Mr. FILLMORE's cold-blooded Caution and retrogression had exasperated; the other the sentiment of Negrophilism.

A few years since we had occasion to make a visit to Hon. -- --, Secretary of the Treasury; and, while waiting his return from dinner, our eyes chanced to fall upon a small volume lying in the centre of the book-table. Curiosity moved our fingers towards it, and on taking it up we found it to be Emerson's Essays.

The editor of the Albany Transcript having had a sight of the identical time keeper worn by WASHINGTON, thus remarks concerning it: "It was in the possession of HENRY E RIELL, Esq, of No. 64 Lispenard street. New-York City, who has boon near two twenty-five years in getting possession of it.

The Portland Advertiser says the business of putting up provisions in hermetically-sealed cans, has become an important one in that city. There are five large establishments engaged in it. Beef, mutton, lamb, lobster, clams, neate' and sheepe' tongues, with green beans, in their season, , are put up in immense quantities.

Trial of Wm. M. Doty for Perjury, SECOND DAY. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Wednesday--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Aldermen BARD and WESLEY SMITH.--The People against Wm. M. Doty The trial of Doty, for alleged perjury in the Forres Divorce Case, was continued yesterday.

It is my painful duty to inform you of the awful conflagration with which our town was visited on the night of the 28th ult., and which has destroyed a great number of stores and dwellings, together with a very heavy amount of property therein contained estimated in all, at a moderate calculation, at least $1,000,000.

Whether Paris be the gay metropolis of the world, or London the great maelstrom of dissipation, may well be doubted in the present day. The ample gaiety furnished to the inhabitants of Manhattan, seems to contradict either assumption. New-York, like a robust inheritor of wealth, is enjoying itself in right royal style; neither sparing expense or submitting to mediocrity.

Webster Kelley, Esq., of Massachusetts, and S. W. A. Beach, Esq., of New-York, were admitted attorneys and counsellors at this Court. No, 57--Wm. H Winder vs A. D Caldwell. In error to the Circuit Court of the United States of Washington.

This morning, at about 12 1/2 o'clock, General FRANKLIN PIERCE, President Elect of the United States, arrived at the Astor House, accompanied by his Excellency, Gov. SEYMOUR, of Conn., and his Private Secretary, SIDNEY WEBSTER, Esq.

DISCHARGE OF MR. WILSON.--In the Municipal Court this morning, WM. W. WILSON, who was arrested several weeks since on a charge of having in his possession counterfeit apparatus, , was discharged, the Grand Jury having found no bills against him. Five charges were sent up from the Police Court.

CHARGE OF CONSPIRACY TO DEFRAUD--AR REST OF THE ACCUSED PARTIES.--STARTLING DISCLOSURES.--During the last few months, the police authorities have been busily engaged in effecting the arrests of persons charged with defrauding the community out of monies and other property, by alleged false-pretence operations, whereby various business men have been victimized to the tune of hundreds and thousands of dollars.

MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE--SUSPICION OF FOUL PLAY.--There was considerable excitement in our sister city of Charlestown yesterday, in consequence of the mysterious disappearance of a very pretty, intelligent girl, of Irish parentage (16 years old) named HONORA COCHRAN, and sowing as a domestic in the family of MARCELLUS CARPENTER, of No. 75 Green-street, in that city.

The Baltimore and Ohio R. R. Mechanics still refuse to go to work--the Directors having only conceded $1 per week additional pay to each, whilst their demand is 15 per cent, advance on their former salaries. The President of the line has called another meeting of the Board to-morrow to endeavor to settle difficulties.-- The Engineer and Brakeman threaten to stop again if the Mechanics do not get their demands.

Messrs, CAPERS HEYWARD sold at auction yesterday, a gang of negroes, belonging to the estate of JOHN H. MCINTOSH, of Duval County, Fla., 209 in number, for $97,425, averaging $466 per head. They were sold in families, and there was an unsual proportion of young children. One family of ten averaged $505 each, and another of ten averaged S610 each.

Again we must raise our feeble voice in reply to the remarks of the Times on our article of November 17. The mission with which we are charged will not permit us to pass, without notice, the arguments put forth by the leading periodical of the most free and enlightened nation of Europe, to discourage and retard our revolution.

Letters received here from Rio to the 3d Jan-state that heavy rains and the prevalence of fevers had kept the coffee from coming to market. The bark Ottawa, of New York, is reported to have been sunk at the bar of the Rio Grando, the crew being saved.

The House of Representatives at Washing ton seems inclined to inquire into the reasons of its imbecility. Mr. VENABLE asserts that the rules of the House are in fault. He charges upon them the "public contempt" into which Congress has fallen.

THE CONSOLIDATION BILL.--The passage by the Senate on Saturday of the Railroad Consolidation bill, gives general satisfaction to our citizens. When it shall become a law, as we do not doubt it will, the conveniences and comforts of a journey between this City and Buffalo will be greatly enhanced.

The following letter from Mrs. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE to Dr. WARDLAW, dated Dec 4. 1852. was read at the Second Annual Meeting of the Glasgow Female New Association for the Abolition of Slavery: DEAR SIR: I Was most deeply and gratefully touched by your kind letter, and by its certainly very unexpected contents.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the columns of your valuable paper of Saturday, 12th inst., I noticed an exhibit of contributions to benevolent objects, of a large amount, as also for liquidating the existing Indebtedness of the Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn. All this is surely laudable and praiseworthy in this congregation, and is conclusive that God is prospering the work of their hands.
Although the accounts are contradictory, enough transpires through the Dalmatian papers to show that fighting is going on, and with the atrocity of Turkish warfare.
We learn from the Madison County Journal that the total number of students in Madison University is 201. Of these there are 11 Theological 93 Undergraduates, and 91 members of the Grammar School.
Liverpool Cotton Market. (From Dennistown Co's Circular.) Our market continued active and buoyant in the early part of the week, with daily stiffening prices.
The following is a list of the deaths among the passengers per ship Antarctic, from Liverpool. We believe this list to be correct or as near so as it is possible to get at the present time.
The acquisition of Cuba was first urged upon the attention of the country, by public men who were known to be identified with the South and its institutions.
At an early hour on Sunday, 30th., ult., all Paris was astir for the celebration of the marriage of the Emperor NAPOLEON III.
Accounts from Europe to the early days of the month, indicate a tranquil and comfort able condition of affairs, which is truly pleasant to behold.

The Persian screw steamer brings Lisbon news of the 27th ult. The Cortes had not been constituted for regular business, but most of the preliminary forms, approval of elections. , had been gone through.
THIRD DAY. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.--Thursday. Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Alderman WESLEV SMITH, and BARD.--The People agt.

The House of Representatives yesterday passed the bill, which passed the Senate at the last session, amendatory of the existing laws regulating the coinage of the half dollar, quarter dollar, dime, and half dime, and providing for the coinage of three-dollar gold pieces.
Providence (R. I.) gave birth last week to three new papers. Uncle Tom's Cabin, at a cent a number; the first number is out, and the second will come if, and when, that sells.

The last news from the seat of war is, that on the 15th neither party made any great progress. "In the evening," says the Trieste Zeitung, "OSMAN PASHA, of Scutari, (who entered by Szabljak.) retired into the open country and took up a position at the foot of a hill.
The following is the communication presented by Mr. VANDERBILT to the State Senate on the 16th, relative to amending the Constitution with reference to the completion of the Canals:

BRITISH NORTH AMERICAN COLONIES-The Report of Mr. ISRAEL D. ANDREWS to the Secretary of the Treasury, on the subject of the Fisheries and other products of the British North American Colonies, is nearly ready for distribution.

The 21th ult., being the day fixed for the question to be addressed to the Piedmontese Cabinet by M. BROSSERIO leader of the Left, on the subject of the condemnation of Dr. MAZZINGHI at Genor, for Protestant propagandism, the galleries of the Chamber of Deputies at Turn were thronged to suffocation.
A fire occurred at Cumberland, on Monday last, destroying an entire block of buildings on Baltimore street. A number of storekeepers lost their entire stocks.

An effort will be made to-morrow, to dispose of the Tehuantepec resolutions in the Senate. I can count only ten votes in their favor, and some of those will be given under a sectional pressure that cannot well be resisted.

A MONUMENT TO THE PATRIOTS OF THE VOLUTION.--It is said that the Vestry of Trinity Church have it in contemplation to erect a monument to the memory of the American Officers and Soldiers who died in British prisons in this City, during the War of the Revolution.

It is nearly or quite a year since we first had occasion to comment upon the neglect of our Government to take the necessary steps for the protection of American rights and interests in the Pacific Mexican ports.
The sensation created at Vienna by the the Emperor NAPOLEON'S allusion in his speech to the Senate, to MARIA LOUISE, does not appear to have abated.
BOARD OF EDUCATION.-The annual meeting of this Board was held Wednesday afternoon at the City Hall. Ex-Mayor COPLAND occupied the Chair.

Agreeably to previous resolution, the working men on a strike reassembled yesterday morning in the hall of the Maryland Institute, and were called to order at 10 o'clock by the President, JOHN M. CLARK, at which hour JOHN H. WATERS, a moulder at the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad depot, and a most excellent and sensible man, addressed the meeting in a manner which seemed to give general satisfaction, as he was much applauded.

From the Chicago Journal. The operations of the Bank of Chicago, which its proprietors have conducted in this city for some time post, affecting to have communications in regard to it from spirits of the departed, were summarily closed yesterday by the interposition of the law.

The Benton (Ala.) Ledger says that no invention since the advent of the "Iron horse," has proved more beneticial to the prairie roads of Alabama than the construction of plank roads, so recently carried into such successful operation.
We have received the Madrid journals of the 27th, but their contents are without importance. The Diario Espanol states that its first edition of the 23d had been seized.

The effort for City Reform has resulted in the introduction into the Legislature of two bills for amendments to the City Charter, the provisions of which are stated in another column of this morning's Time's.
Mr. MARCY arrived at Richmond to day from the South. He has stated positively that he has received the notification there of a Cabinet appointment, but the department is not specified.
Paris has resumed its wonted quietness. The Emperor and Empress remained at St. Cloud, but took every opportunity of showing hemselves abroad.

INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSES OF THE DEATH OF MR. ENGLISH.--About 10 o'clock on the night of the 30th January last, three men entered the bar room of the Livingston House, corner of Atlantic and Columbia-streets, Brooklyn, and while there are said to have assaulted the proprietor, Mr. ENGLISH, and Injured him in such a manner, that he died on Sunday last, the 13th inst.

In the steamship Roanoke from Norfolk and ?? Ex Gov. John B. Floyd, of Va J. Dupuy, W. Harrison, J. M. Smith. H C Watkins, J White. S. S. Griggs, W. W. Joyce, Gibson, J B. Read and lady. S. Fancher R. D. McChesney, Miss Beck with, E. Tower, Thomas Cousin and lady.

The alarming rumors respecting the appearance of Asiatic Cholera in Paris, are contradicted. The new Agricultural consultation Chamber of Paris met on Friday at the Hotel de Ville, for the purpose of effecting an organization.

The following documents, relating to the proceedings and treatment of FRANCIS W. RICE, Esq., late U. S. Consul at Acapulco, Mexico, are among those recently transmitted to the Senate by the President:
On Thursday morning. Feb. 17, JACOB MOORE, in the 53d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funera services at 4 o'clock this afternoon.
Excepting a few miscellaneous items we have nothing of interest to report, politics and general news being alike dull.

The negotiations pending between five Greek merchants and the Porte, regarding the liquidation of the Bank of Constantinople, having now ended, the former have issued a circular, bearing the date of 10th Inst., by which they inform the public that the Government has placed the books and funds of the Bank at their disposal, and that they will do their best to merit its confidence.
The following list of Business Firms aye among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers)...No. 112 Broadway.
The arrival of two Cunard steamships, the Alps and America, places us in possession of dates from Liverpool to the 5th inst.
RECEIVED AT THE OFFICE OF THE NEW YORK DAILY TIMES.
The following is an abstract of a bill which has been introduced into the State Legislature, as an amendment to the City Charter:

The new Cunard screw-steamship Alps, Capt. WICKMAN, arrived at this port last evening from Liverpool, whence she sailed on the 2d inst., thus making her first ocean passage in a little more than fourteen days.

The merchants, underwriters and shipmasters of this port, appreciating the unremitted labors of Lieut. MATTHEW F. MAURY, Superintendent of the National Observatory, in aid of the science of Navigation, have resolved upon tendering to him a suitable testimonial of their esteem.
An immense meeting of the friends of religious freedom was hold at twilight, relative to the Imprisonment of the MADIAL. Speeches were made by Rev. Messrs. BERG, ROBINSON, and JOHNS.
The Viceroy still continues absent from the capital. He was last heard of at Slout, and his return was looked for early in Feb.
The U. S. mail steam Ohio arrived at this port at 3 o'clock this morning. Some fears for her safety had begun to be entertained, but the slip arrives safely.

CITY BUSINESS--HENRY SOUTHMAYED and others have notified the City Authorities that they shall apply to the supreme Court, "to set aside the proceedings of the Assessors in relation to the assessments on Morgan and Washington-streets," in consequence of informality in the proceedings.
THE ERICSSON.--The Pilot who brought up the British steamship Alps reports having seen the caloric ship Ericsson, yesterday morning, lying to, about forty miles south-east of the Highlands.
To the Editor of the N. Y. Freeman's Journal: The heading of this communication suggests the matter which it proposes to discuss.
The Montenegro Question occupies the attention of Austrian politicians, and of the intelligent public generally, to the exclusion of every other topic.

The sentence of Dr. NEWMAN, in the case of Achilli vs Newman, had been pronounced. Mr. Justice COLERIDGE delivered the judgment, remarking that the great controversy between the two Churches might continue to go on for years yet, and if the defendant engaged in it for the future, he entreated he would employ his great abilities in a spirit of kindness to individuals, for the sake of his ardent, holy life, and our common Christianity.
President PIERCE has engaged an elegant suite of rooms at WILLARD's, for himself, lady, and Secretary. President FILLMORE has engaged the same apartments on and after the 4th of March.

As I informed you yesterday, the announcement of the marriage of LOUIS NAPOLEON would have been regarded with a feeling skin to indifference, but for the accompanying speech, which is considered as a gauntlet thrown at the feet of the legitimist Sovereigns of Europe, who will find it hard to swallow the new theory of "glorious parrenus."
The Moniteur thus describes the way in which the French Ambassador at St. Petersburg, was received by the Emperor, on the occasion of his presenting his new letters of credence.
GEN. McNEILL.--The late General WM. GIBBS McNEILL, who died at Brooklyn on Wednesday, was a native of Rhode Island.

[Entered According to Act Congress.] From the Sunday Dispatch. TO THE EDITOR OF THE SUNDAY DISPATCH: SIR: Noticing in the last number of the Sunday Dispatch a paragraph copied from a Huntingtonshire (England) newspaper, ?? a "Mysterious Affairs," in which two Americans, brother and sister, are spoken of as playing a preminent part.
Various petitions were presented. Mr. BRODHEAD presented a memorial in favor of a suspension of the Steamboat Law.
Mr. L. M. GOTTSCHALK gave his second grand concert last evening at Niblo's Garden. A house liberally filled to the ceiling received the young pianist with flattering demonstrations of favor.
WARD SCHOOL NO. 1--The examination of the Primary Department of Ward School No. 1, by the Committee, Messrs. DEMAREST, TUTTLE and ??, took place on Wednesday afternoon.

Notwithstanding the earnest request of Gen' PIERCE, President elect, as published in the Times yesterday morning, desiring to be kept in seclusion and retirement, his apartments were be sieged at an early hour by various leading politicians of the Democracy and office-seekers.
An extraordinary express, in anticipation of the Overland Mail, has brought correspondence and journals from Bombay to the 3d January, Calcutta 22d December.

At Lanark. Canada West, Feb. 8, at the residence of her Uncle, Rev Thos Fraser. after 6 months of patient and enduring suffering, the well.-known and much admired Scottish vocalist, Miss J A NE FRASER, daughter of John Fraser, Esq., of Nowfiold House. Johnslone, near Glassgow, Scotland English and scotch papers will please copy.

A New-York correspondent of the Boston Transcript notes a few items of our domestic extravagance, as follows: Allusion was made in a former letter to the lavish prodigality with which money was expended in this city upon hotels and stores.

A negro lad, some nine or ten years old, belonging to Col Simeen Christie of South Carolina, was instantly killed on Monday last by the running gear of a gen. He had climbed upon the cog wheel, and in attempting to get down was caught by the evolution of the trundle head. His head was awfully crushed.
When the Democratic party entered upon power in this State last Fall, it inherited the duty of providing for the Completion of the State Canals.

Messrs. GUTHRIE, DOBBIN, and MARCY, have reached the City. The Cabinet rumors to day settle upon MARCY for the Treasury, DOBBIN for the Navy, and CAMPBELL for Attorney General. The War, Post Office, and Interior Departments, stand as reported last night.

We have received a note from Senator UNDERWOOD, of Kentucky, asserting that he " made no speech, either long or short, on the " subject of Mr. BADGER'S nomination on the" day Mr. UPHAM died." This declaration is

GREAT EASTERN RAILROAD PROJECT.--The citizens, of Belfast, Me., have held a public meeting to forward the plan of a railroad from that place to Moosehead Lake 80 miles, at a presumed cost of 82000,000. Col. ROWLAND CARLTON presided.
The British mail steamer Lima arrived at Panama on the 19th ult., with dates from Caliao to the 11th January. On the 3d January two fatal cases of yellow fever were reported at Caliao.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times, The public appears to be receiving amusement from a silly story now going the rounds of the newspapers, which, for its folly alone, might be allowed to pass unnoticed-but as it concerns other people, and may be commented upon by them, and subject us to ridicule, it had better, it may be thought, be arrested in its first commencement.
How HE TOOK It.--A physician thus addressed the surgeon while in his patient's chamber: ' You must not fail to plebotomize the old gentleman to-morrow morning."

THE CODE REFORM.-- The Huron Reflector has received a copy of the Code Report, a volume of 260 pages. The Editor says; The forms of pleading are cut down in regular Spar tan style to the utmost point or brevity, and are doubt less an improvement on may of the long, uncouth and absurd formulas used in Courts.

The eleventh lecture of the People's Course was given by Rev. E. H. CHAPIN, last evening, in the Tabernacle. The attendance was unusually large, Mr. CHAPIN's known eloquence and ability always attracting a crowded audience.

Florists will be pleased to learn that what was hitherto a floral impossibility, is said to have been as complished at last. The " August Rose," a new aspirant to their favor, claims to be a double, yellow fragrant climber.

Poetry.--True Freedom, and How to Gain it; by CHARLES MACKAY. Literary.--Literary Miscellany; Bashfulness- New-England in Old Times--America's Ericasons--The Sea Serpent--Rules for Persons about to Marry. Cravats.

We have received from our Washington correspondent, copies of the voluminous correspondence between our Government and that of Great Britain, concerning the claims of the latter to dominion in Central America, and especially concerning the Convention for opening communication between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, by canal across the Isthmus.

Public attention is turned in Piedmont at present to the case of a person named DANIEL MAZZINGHl, who was condemned on the 18th inst., by the Tribunal of Appeal of Genoa, to three years exile on an accusation of Protestant propagandism.

To the Honorable Cornelius W. Lawrence, late Mayor of the City of New-York: SIR: It is well ordered that the men who administer or municipal affairs enact their several parts in the presence of their official seniors, who now repose from successful aspirations and conflicts of political life.

We learn that in the "Deficiency Bill," passed by the Senate on Wednesday, a clause was inserted virtually repealing one of the most important provisions of the Senate's "Coinage and Seigniorage Bill," which passed the house of Representatives on Tuesday.

EDITORIAL CONVENTION.--Our friends of the Mississippi press contemplate calling a Convention of Editors to arrange a system by which their rights as publishers may he secured. The Mississipian thus notices the proposition: " A proposition has been made by the Vicksburg Sentinel, and assented to by the Port Gibson Reveille, Carrollton Democrat and Holly Spring Guard, for holding an early Convention of the conductors of the press of this State.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church having recommended the observance of the last Thursday of February as a day of Prayer for Colleges, the Presbytery of New-York accordingly designate that day, falling on Thursday of next week, as a proper occasion for the manifestation of Christian sympathy.

The National Intelligencer, of this morning, states that the Senate has passed a section in the Deficiency bill, which renders null one of the most import ant provisions of the New Coinage, Seignorage bill. It provides that the Seignorage on bare and ingots of gold shall not exceed the cost of assay and casting

The Legislature of New-Jersey has nominated as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of that State, PETER D. VROOM in the stead of HENRY W. GREEN, whose term is about to expire. It is pleasant to signalize one act of that extraordinary body, which maybe approved without conscientious scruple.

SIR: The perusal of your interesting article on the soi disant Dauphin of France, in your journal of yesterday, induces me to observe that in the summer of 1844, I met that individual at Camberwell, near London, where he was then residing.

The two latest publications of M. GUIZOT are by no means his latest works. The Shakspere and his Times, embraces an essay, with introductory remarks to several of the plays, illustrating a French trauelation of the great dramatist, that appeared at Paris in 1821.

GOTTECHALK'S second concert at NIBLO'S Theatre last evening was attended by a full and enthusiastic audience. * * He was assisted by Madame SONTAG and the artists of her troupe. who sang with all that perfection which the public so well know how to appreciate. -Tribune.

We have received, via Panama, the Valparaiso Mercurio to the 30th Dec., from which we translate the following: "Since the departure of the last steamer no events of great importance have transpired. The country goes on well in the path of conciliation of parties, by uniting all interests in the great works of internal improvement, as railways, canals, , and the crops in the southern portion of the State have been abundaut."

We hear from what we believe to be good authority, that no Convention between Eng land and the United States for an International Copyright has yet been laid before the Senate for confirmation ; and that no treaty, containing such provisions as are said to be embodied in the project now engaging attention, if submitted, would stand the slightest chance of being ratified.

The Senate was called to order at 20 minutes past 11 o'clock. Mr. GWIN moved to take up the Pacific Railroad bill, which was agreed to. Mr. HAMLIN gave notice that on Monday he would move to take up the bill (Miss DIX's) for the benefit of the indigent insane.

Trial of Wm. M. Doty, for Perjury. FOURTH DAY. EXAMINATION OF MR. FORREST. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.--Friday.- Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Alderman WESLEY SMITH, and BARD.--The People agt. Wm. M. Doty.- The trial of Wm. M. Doty for alleged perjury in the Forrest Divorce Case was resumed at the sitting of the Court.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Time: A letter appears in the Times of to-day, advocating the claims of NAUNDORF, the pretended Dauphin. It states that the mark said by Mr. FIELD to be on the body of the Dauphin was on that of NAUNDORF, because the authorities of Dolft registered certain marks as being on the corpse.

PLANK ROADS--More wagons have passed through Wadesboro', on their way to Cheraw, the past week, than during the same time in the last five years. We suppose this has been caused partly by the bad roads which we had in the fore part of the season, when wagons could not travel, and partly by the building of the plank road, which is now being constructed.

There is quite a scarcity of news this morning. The affairs of Central America occupied the attention of Congress. The President sent a Message to the House, transmitting a letter from the Secretary of State in relation to the communications recently made to the State Department by the British Minister, concerning the claims of England upon Central America, and with reference especially to the Interoceanic Ship-Canal.

Some highly interesting documents concerning Central American affairs, will be found in this morning's Times. It seems from the communication made to Congress yesterday by the President, that Great Britain desires to relinquish her Protectorate of the Mosquito King, and to make some new arrangement for the adjustment of affairs in that quarter and to secure the construction of a ship Canal across the Isthmus.
Albert W. Paine and Hiram O. Alden, Esqs., of Matne, were admitted attorneys and counsellors of this Court.

By the arrival of the steamship Texas, Captain LAWLESS, we have dated from Galveston to the 7th inst., and Indianola to the 3d. There is no news in the Galveston papers. The roads from Indianola to the interior are in good order.

DEFRAUDED BY THE OPERATIONS OF " SPIRIT. UAL RAPPERS."--We learn that the Police authorities are engaged in ferreting out certain parties, who have defrauded a man named RICHARD DOUGHERTY out of $13,000, by the operation of "Spiritual Rappings," or "Manifestations," concocted and carried out success fully by various persons, who practice these humbug '"rappings " upon the weak minded portion of the community.

UNION COLLEGE.--Dr. HIOKOCK says the productive capital of this College is $150,000, besides buildings, books, apparatus, and three hundred acres of land on which the buildings stand. Recently a deed of trust has been made over to the College, from which it will realize over $500,000. This puts the institution beyond the fear of embarrassment.

General PIERCE is Still at the Merchants Hotel. He received about a thousand visitors this morning, and became so fatigued that he was compelled to retire. He will, however, receive visitors again this afternoon, and will leave by the night train for Baltimore.

Feb. 4, Edward Hirst, aged 20, of Reading, Yorkshire, England, of disease of the heart; buried at sea. Feb. 6, Charles Fisher, aged 24, of Cincinatis. Cortlandt County, N. Y., of bilious remittent fever; buried on shore at Kingston, Ja.

The following facts are interesting. They give us a glimpse within the veil of Parisian life, and tell a short story of the morals of the fashionable metropolis. The births in Paris during the year 1951, amounted to 32,324.

THE DOCTOR AND THE SEXTON.-A good story is told of a doctor in Beverly, who was somewhat of a wag. He met one day in the street, the sexton with whom he was acquainted. As the usual salutations were passed, the doctor happened to cough.

We have received Jamaica papers to Feb. 7. The Port Maria Westermost River overflowed its banks on Wednesday, the 3d, a quarter of a mile above the town, and in about ten minutes the water rushed through the houses and stores to some extent. In the Post Office, the water rose fully twenty inches, and in the streets it was at least three or four feet in depth.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday have been received. The ship Susan L. Fitzgerald, cleared at this port by FITZGERALD, BOOTH CO., for South America, takes out a cargo, mostly of domestics, valued at over $150,000.

From the N. O. Picayune By the brig Lucy, Capt. WEEKS, we have received files from the City of Mexico to the 27th ult. We give the following summary of events: Don MIGOUEL ARROJO had sent notes to several mer chants and proprietors slating that the Government asked from them a loan of $4,000 each. It was said that President CEDALLOS thought of raising a forced loan of $2,000,000.

The friends of the Pacific Railroad bill will rally tomorrow, to consider Mr. SHIELD's amendment. Mr. WELLER will submit sundry new amendments, asserting throughout the bill, the principle of no money appropriations to build the road, except in the territories. If these fail, he

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a message from the President on the subject of Nicaraguan Affairs the same as communicated to the House yesterday. Referred and ordered to be printed. Mr RUSK moved to take up the Pacific Railroad bill Agreed to.

The following letter from the Secretary of State settles one of the questions of the day on which all have been exercised. The new Empress's grandfather was retained some eighteen years as American Consul at Malaga: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, Feb. 16, 1853.

The Union is severe upon the Whig clerks who sold out to Democrats, and says the purchasers can't keep the offices. Prices of clerkships may interest applicants: a $1,200 clerk, an active Whig, sold out recently for $200--a $1,600 clerk holds at $500 a year. The market is well stocked and sales are quick.

The mechanics' strike will probably be all arranged to-night. The employers solicited the appointment of a committee of journeymen to meet them to night, to close the matter. Accordingly, the committee was appointed and instructed not to yield a particle in the demand of fifteen percent. advance. The employers that are giving the advance are overrun with business. Two thousand men are now at work, and two thousand nine hundred still on the strike.

The America's mails arrived yesterday noon We give the details of the foreign news that they furnish. The "COBDEN wager" is dilated upon by the London Times, and the " Signs of Prosperity " by the News. The rumored modifications of the French ministry are expanded. Gen. CHANGARNIER'S letter circulating in the Legitimist circles of Parts--if authentic--shows that the probabilities of war are not so very far distant as Mr. COBDEN seems to suppose. The

The Celebrated Father GAVAZZI, being about to visit the United States, is giving his farewell orations, the last of which will be delivered in Liver pool on the 22d inst., the eve of his departure. The congregation of Rev. Dr. WARDLAW have invited him to a festival in the City Hall, Glasgow, on the 16th Feb., on the occasion of his completion of the 50th year of his pastoral office among them.

On the 28th ult. Professor GERVINUS presented himself, according to summons. before the penal tribunal at Heidelberg, to answer the charges, preferred against him by the public prosecutor. The proceedings were merely formal, and consisted in the drawing up of certain acten or documents, which may serve as the ground-work of the proceedings before the Hofgericht, at Maunheim, where the decision of the case will he. No 71. Elisha Bloomer, appellant, vs. John McQuewan et al.--The argument of this cause was concluded by Mr. Kelier for the appellant. No. 72. J. B. Doolittle's lessee et al., plaintiffs, vs. Levi Bryan et al-This cause was argued by Mr. Stan berry for plaintiffs, and submitted on a printed argument by Mr. Corwin for defendants.

The Expana announces that the Duke of VALENCIA bad replied to the last communication of the Minister of War, ordering him to proceed to Vienna that the pains from which he usually suffered had become so acute that it was impossible for him to undertake the journey for the present, but that he would set out the moment he was able to travel.

On Saturday morning, Feb. 19 HOWARD CALHOUN, son of Harriet M. and Michael Allision, Jr., aged 10 months and 15 days. The connections and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his pa rents. No. 134 Waverly-place, on Monday morning at 9o'clock.

FIRES.--About 7 o'clock Saturday evening, a fire broke out in a small, unoccupied frame building, in the rear of No. 292 Hudson-avenue, near Fieat Street, Which was destroyed--as also was the two story building fronting on the avenue, No. 282. The buildings were old and unoccupied. Loss estimated at $900, and were an insured. The property belonged to the McDOWELL estates. The Fire Department turned out promptly, and prevented the further spread of the fire.

Mr. C. EDWARDS LESTER delivered a Lecture on Saturday evening, before the Mechanics' Institute of this City, on the " Elements which make up an Independent Workingman." Mr. LESTER spoke as follows: The blasts of Winter have been on us, carrying chilling cold into many a habitation of the poor. One would think, in a walk through Broad.

INDIAN TROUBLES IN FLORIDA.--A few days since it was stated that Governor BROWN, of Florida, had vetoed the bill "to provide for the final removal of the Indians of Florida, end for other purposes." It appears that the bill was reconsidered by both Houses and passed again, notwithstanding the Governor's veto, by the requisite constitutional majority, and has accordingly become a law. New-Orleans papers of Sunday and Monday have been received. They contain Galveston dates of the 19th inst. The first locomotive in Texas had been put in operation on the Harrisburg Railroad. Indian outrages were still occurring. An attack had been made on the town of San Ignacio in which several white inhabitants were killed, A party of troops had been dispatched in pursuit.

CORNER'S INQUEST.--The Corner's Jury were in session on Friday, investigation the causes of the death of THOMAS ENGLISH, proprietor of the Livingston House. The evidence of to-day exhibits an astonishing state of affairs in connection with the notorious rowdy ganga of that part of the City, and the Coroner is determined to give the whole affair a thorough investigations

The Preasure-seeking folks of this merry City of Gotham may hold high holiday during the present week. A reference to our amusement column will convice them that their requirements--simple or compound--are responded to in a liberal spirit. Our managers are deserving of success.

DEATH OF MISS MARY MATHER.--Yesterday the telegraph communicated to her relatives in this City the painful intelligence of the sudden deaths of Miss MARY MATHER, who left home for New-York, in her usual state of health, on Friday.
A large crowd of politicians have assembled at the Merchants Hotel, to great General PIERCE, whose levee commences at 12 1/2 o'clock. GEORGE M. DALLAS had an interview with the General this morning.

There probably has been no time for many years, when the great mass of our citizens were so throughly convinced of the necessity of a radial reform in our City Government, and so ready to unite in support of any plan promising to effect it, as at the present moment. The official returns from Vermont show that the New Liquor Law has been adopted by 1,121 majority The total number of votes thrown were 43.509, being 4,089 less than at the last Guhernatorial election. Eight Counties give majorities for the Law and six against it.

INTERFERING WITH THE POLICE.--Sunday evening a quarrel occurred in a house on South Eighth street, and the persons engaged in it cried out "murder," which caused the night police to enter the dwelling and attempt to arrest the parties implicated.

From the Boston Atlas. It has been announced in several of the news papers of New-York, with apparent confidence in its correctness, that a treaty netween this country and Great Britain on the subject of an international copyright, is now before the Senate of the United States. It is stated also, with equal confidence, that it will be acted upon before the 4th of March next.

The United States mail steamship Pacific, Capt. NYE, arrived at this port early yesterday morning, from Liverpool on the 9th inst. She has made the passage in a little over eleven days. Her news is four days later. The Arabia arrived out, off the Mersey at 3:20 o'clock, afternoon of Sunday, 6th, but did not come up until Monday morning.
FIRE.--About 7 o'clock on Sunday evening, a temporary carpenter shop in South Sixth street, between Seventh and Eighth-streets, together with its contents, was destroyed by fire.

BERLIN, Feb. 1.--The inventors of gun-cotton, Professor SCHUNREIN. of Basle, and Professor BOTTGEH. of Frankfort, have made over their process of preparation to the Austrian Government for 30 000 florins, two-tha??ds of which fall to the share of the former, as having the propriety of in vention. The money has already been paid in Frankfort.

The prophecies of the sanguine are rushing up to their fulfilment far faster than their authors dreamed of. When some folks said that within a year from Jan. 1, 1853, we should have news from San Francisco not more than fifteen days old,--they hardly thought that we should come within three days of the mark so soon in the year.

The town of Milford, in Massachusetts, is a great boot-making place, and must be a happy one; for a correspondent says it has neither a dandy nor a loafer, and adds this pleasant picture: "Indeed, there is work for everybody and everybody appears to be at work.

TORTUG, ISLAND -- The Island of Tortuga is situated six miles from the main land of St. Domungo: it is a low island covered with trees and vegetation, but uninhabited, and having dangerous reefs on its north-ra shore. Although it many not be in the direct trade of vessels hound from Turk's Island Passage through the wildward channel, it lies very near the southern part of that passage.

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are to hand. The Delta has a late letter from Tampico, giving an awful picture of the state of affairs there. CARAVAJAL, it was rumored, was going there, and it was thought the National Guard would join him.

The Delta has received California dates of the 2d February--only 18 days from San Francisco to this port. They were brought from Acapulco to Vera Cruz In five and a half days, and there by steamship Albatross to New-Orleans--being the shortest time on record. Only a few scattering San Francisco papers have been received, including the Herald of the 1st inst.

THE McDONOGH WILL--Quite an interesting discursion took place in the Second Branch of the City Council, yesterday evening, on a resolution of inquiry offered by Mr. SUTER. in relation to all information which the Mayer and Counselor of the city may have received in relation to the "McDONOGH WILL."

However necessary it may be for politician, it is of far more importance to a nation the it be able to define its own position. The fossil arts and sciences in China, have as yet only enabled that ingenious people to see themselves; and accordingly, on their map the Central flowery nation obscures all others.

The two remaining ships of the German fleet are to be sold at auction on 16th March, at Bremen. They are the Hansa, 750 hose power and 1,800 tons, and the Erzhirzog Ja??ana, 416 horse power and 1,135 ?one, both are at present entirely dismantied. A further term will be appointed for the sale of the 26 gunboats and the stores.

We invite the attention of our readers to the advertisement of Ayer's Cherry Pectoral, in the columns of our paper, as a remedy of the first importance to the community. The certificates published in its favor are not from unknown names, but from eminent and widely celebrated men.

In the Yankee theory of the sublime, the sublimest spectacle is claimed to be the quadrennial election of a President. A bloodless revolution ; millions of freemen snowing their ballots into the box, by way of emphasizing their opinions upon political affairs; the rule of one of earth's widest empires transferred from one hand to another, without shock, and almost silently, indeed; the simple citizen converted into the chief of potentates.

The Chair laid before the Senate a Message from the President, in reply to a resolution calling for copies of applications by British fishermen for leave to fish off the coast of Florida. Referred and ordered to be printed. Also a reply by the Secretary of the Navy to the resolution calling for the copy of the report on the quality of coal mines and coal fields on the Western waters.

OPENING OF THE GREAT SILVER MINES.--In formation of the increasing demand for silver having been generally diffused, extensive preparations have been entered into, in various quarters, to augment the annual yield from the different silver mines, in almost all quarters of the world.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Two new pleces attracted a fashionable audience to this establishment last evening. The first was a petite comedy, in two acts, by the author of "Paul Pry," called "'Twould puzzle a Conjurer;" the other an operetta, also in two acts, by ADRIAN BOILDIEU, called "First come, first served."

Trial of Wm. M. Doty for Perjury. SIXTH DAY. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.--Monday.--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Aldermen WESLEY SMITH and BARD.--The People agt. Win. M. Doty.--The trial of WM. M. DOTY, for alleged perjury in the FORREST divorce case, was resumed at the sitting of the Court. Judging from the large attendance, the interest in the case continues unabated.

A fire broke out on the northeast corner of King and Mary-streets, this morning, consuming Cook's grocery store, HEFRNSCHIEL'S bar-room, (in the same building) and HUMMEL'S apothecary store; also, damaging Mr. Cook's dwelling.

From the London Morning Advertiser. At the Anti Slavery Breakfast at Manchester. on Saturday, Mr. JOSIAS BROWNE expressed his satisfaction at learning," that the demand for his labor goods is on the merease, and that as much tree labor cotton can be had from America and the West Indies as would suffice for all present requirements, and to spare."

Rev. Dr. TAPPAN, Chancellor of the University of Michigan, sails on Saturday for Europe, on a special mission, in behalf of the Legislature of that State, to examine and report upon the Prussian school system. Dr. T. is deputed by the University to obtain apparatus for the new Observatory, which has been handsomely endowed by the citizens of that State--principally of Detroit.

INTERESTING RELICS.--JAMES BROWN, Esq., of New-York City, (of the house of BROWN, BROTHERS Co.,) has deposited in the rooms of the Historical Society of this city one of the original Stamps, which was affixed to deeds, notes, , by order of the British Government, the resistance to which brought on the independence of this country.

A correspondent of the St. Louis Republican writes thus from California, in answer to the question, "Who ought to come to California?": "Farmers, especially Western farmers, who know how it goes to settle a new country--farmers who have boys and girls to help carry on business--to all such, the country holds out the surest prospects of prosperity and wealth.

FERRY IMPROVEMENTS.--The contemplated improvements at the Peck slip Ferry in Williamsburg are being vigorously pushed forward by the Company. The old ferry houses are being torn down to make room for one of the most commodious ferry-houses in the vicinity of New-York.

NEW-YORK BIBLE SOCIETY.--The Twenty ninth Annual Report of the New-York Bible Society, the labors of which are confined to this city and its suburbs, has just been published, and contains many interesting facts.

The Pacific United States mail steamship reached this port early yesterday morning, from Liverpool on the 9th instant. She has made the passage in a little over eleven days Her news is four days later, but there is very little of it. From France we have little of interest: from England nothing. Belgium is on the point of entering into closer relations with Russia.

The Exhibition of the Metropolitan Mechanics Institute opens on Thursday evening next, and remains open for three weeks. It will be held in the new wing of the Patent Office building, the Hall of which is one of the most magnificent rooms in the country, being 275 feet in length by 70 in width, and beautifully decorated.
A fight broke out late last night, among the members of an Irish family named SCANLAN, living in Oliver street, which Messrs. YOUNG, RICHARDSON and WRIGHT, of the City Watch, attempted to suppress.

Reported for the New-York Daily Times. For BEAVES, at the WASHINGTON DROVE YARD Corner of Fourth avenue and thirty-fourth-street, and at CHAMBERLAIN'S HUDSON RIVES BULL's HARD, foot of Robinson-street. For Cows and CALVES, SHEEP and LAM??S, at BROWNING'S, in Sixth-street, near Third-avenue and also at CHAMEBRLAIN'S.

THE LUDLOW SLAVES.--We noticed a day or two since, that the twenty-eight slaved belonging to the estate of ISEARL LUDLOW, of this city, had sailed for Liberia. These slaves, except two or three, were all imported from Africa to Texas; during its independence and were then young in years; they are now in the full vigor of manhood.

The Augsburg Gazetic. of the 5th. quotes from the Gazette of Vienna, of the 4th, an article on the affairs of Turkey, in which it states that Austria has not taken any aggresave attitude towards Turkey. This Resurance had tended to reassure both the Bourec and the public.

General PIERCE came through in the Express train from Philadelphia this afternoon. He kept as quiet as possible at Baltimore, and there entered the rear car in company with SIDNEY WEDSTER and PIERSON BUTTLER, reaching Washington at 8 1/2 o'clock. Major MAURY was at the Depot. but did not discover him.

Mr. MEAGHER delivered his lecture on GRATTAN, at the Musical Fund Hall, to-night, to a densely crowded audience, among whom the greatest enthusiasum prevailed. Nearly three thousand people were present, and many were obliged to go away, in consequence of being unable to goin admittance.

There is little of political Interest from Vienna, public attention being absorbed by the amusements of the Carnival. It is not exactly known what led to the numerous arrests which took place some time since in Ha??aly. That a widely extended and cunningly devised conspiracy was discovered, is certain, out what its ex act object and what its chances of success it is impossible to say.

INTERESTING To WHALERS.--A report of no little interest to Whalers has recently been made to the French Government by Caot. REQUEMAUBEL, commanding the French squadrou in the China seas. It gives a variety of information collected on board the Capricieuse, state corvette, in a voyage from Shanghae to Guam, across the Sea of Japan and the Strait of Matsinai, during the months of July, August and September, 1852.
