At a recent meeting of the South Carolina Rail road, a committee of the South Carolina Annual Methodist Conference presented a memorial touching the desecration of the Lord's Day by the operations of the South Carolina Railroad Company. The memorial, as published in the Charleston papers, is a very able and conclusive argument against the secularization of the Sannath by that railroad, or any other company.

UNITED STATES MAIL BAS FOUND.--Sergeant CUNLAN of the Third District Police, on Sunday evening found a United States Newspaper Mail bag in a lot, between Henry and Hicks, near Warren-street. It was filled with newspapers which had apparently never been unfolded. The mouth of the bag was tied with a single cord, and on one side was the United States stamp.

FIRE--THREE BUILDINGS AND TWO HORSES BURNED.--Last evening between 5 and 6 o'clock, a stable belonging to WILLIAM K. HOGGET, adjoining his carpenter shop, in the rear of the porter house No. 73 Grand-street, was set on fire and was soon demolished, together with two valuable horses and a quantity of bay.

FRER COLORED PERSONS.--A Memorial to the Maryland Legislature is in circulation in Kent County, making for a law to compel tres persons of color, hiring by the year or otherwise, to refil their contracts by retaining during the period for which they may have agreed to serve.

In Brooklyn, on Monday, Feb. 21. SUSAN E., the only child of Susan and J. M. Morse aged 7 months and 7 days. Her funeral will take place from the residence of her parents in Wednesday, Feb 23, at 2 o'clock. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment 123 2?*

The wedding of the French Emperor is as costly, as the wooing was cheap. A million and a half of francs expended in cadeaux and pin-money, are but a drop in the ocean of the Imperial profusion. New palaces, without number, are talked of.

The President has recognised HENRY AMBROSIE as Vice-Consul of Sardinia at New-York. The Republic publishes a long communication from the Superintendent of the Census, in which he vindicates his right to a salary of $3.000 per annum.

The New-Orleans papers announce the death of JOHN FRERET. Esq, of that city, on the 7th inst. Mr. FRERET was a well-known, enterprising citizen, of the firm of the Brothers FRERET. In all public enterprises, this house has been foremost. Mr. FRERET'S age is not stated.

We learn from the Atlanta (Ga.) Intelligencer that Mr. Fields passed through that way last week on his way to the Dahlonega Mint, having in charge $19,000 worth of gold from the mine of Mr. Dorne, in Abbeville and Edgefield Districts.

The Massachusetts Legislature passed a Truant act at their last session, which con ferred upon the public authorities of the towns and cities in the State, power to compel the attendance upon school of all boys who wil-fully absent themselves therefrom. The law seemed arbitrary, but the good people were moved thereto by such facts as they found in the report for 1851 of the City Marshal.
I arrived here in the steamship Albatross from Vera Cruz, having left Mexico on the 11th inst. with dispatches for Washington, also with the Tehuantepec contract for A. G. SLOO in my pocket.

We have Galveston dates to the l1th, bringing Some news and some further details of our last diapatches. The Brazes was reported as falling. There had been a rise in the Trinity of fifteen feet, but a fall was last reported as taking place.

The copyright treaties are being negotiated with both England and France. Information received to-day satisfies me that Mr. FILLMORE favors both, but that some difficulties exist relative to the details. They cannot be ratified this session, and there is little probability that they will be during the extra session.

SOMNAMBULIST.--Sunday night, about 11 o'clock, officer THOMPSON, of the Third Ward, while on duty, discovered a very strange looking being attired in white, moving along the street in a mysterious manner, On going up to him, he discovered him to be a German clothing merchant who does business in Ewen-street.

DOGS.--Ir?Quebec, dogs draw the carts of the milkmen around the City. In New-York, they have herenofore, as well as in constantinople, been treated as gentlemen of leisure, otherwise called drones, having no particular employment.

The Hartford Times, of the 17th, gives the following account of that hypocritical thief who has been sentenced to the Connecticut States Prison, for a term of four years: "His career of crime for the past three years has been remarkable, and is worthy of something more than a passing notice.

We learn from the Providence Journal that a bill has passed the Senate, and is now before the House of Representatives of Rhode Island, to establish a Commission of Pilorage Mr Narragansett Bay It is a subject of much importance, and seriously affects the commercial interests of the State.

The country papers are congratulating the city on the novelty which is said to have been introduced into sundry of our newly bail houses, in the shape of a room in the upper story, devoted to gymnastic exercise and recreation. The thought is, that now the son, or wealth need not look pale any longer-need not be thin, emaciated and dyspeptic.

GEN. PIRICK'S CARRIAGE.--We have seen the carriage, now about finished at Pittsfield, intended as a present to Gen. PIERCE, from some Bostoniens. It is really a superb thing, of superior workmanship, and beautiful style and perfect great credit upon the manufacturers MEFFRS JASON CLAPP Son.

MAIN LANDS.--It appears from the report of the Land Agent of Maire, that of the lands owned by that State in severalty, there have been select during the past year 125,087 acres, for the sum of $27,508 18. Of the lands owned in common with Massachusatts there have been sold 185 715 acres, for the sum of $117,205 82.

The papers teem with congratulatory addresses to the Emperor and Empress. We read that their Maj?lies appeared on borsenack, in the Bois de Boutogne the other day, and were received with enthusiasm The round of official felts in honor of their marriage is new pretty nearly exhausted. On Monday evening, 7th, the great late at Luxemburg case off.

At the time of Mr. PIERCE'S triumphant nomination to the reversion of the American Presidency. we remarked that any danger watch menaced the peace of the world from the Dum?crats of the United States would be found to have its origin. not in the personal characteristics of the chief whom they had elected, not in any mischievious object which the party itself kept in view, but in the obsolutely colorless complexion of Democratic opinions.

Per Stamer Pacific] LIVERPOOL. Feb. 8, 185. Our cotton marset since Friday has lost mach of the buoyant tone noted on that day. The transactions on Saturday were large being awelled up by extensive purchases?? ?? ??

DEATH OF CAPT. GEO. C. WESTCOTT.--Intelligence has been received here of the death, at Acapulco, Mexico, on the 8th of January, of Capt GEO, C. WESTCOTT, of the Second Regiment of U.S. Infantry. Capt. WESTCOTT was a son of Hon. J. D. WESTCOTT, late Secretary of State of New-Jersey, and a brother of G. G. WESTCOTT, Esq., of this City.

MAD DOGS.--As the "wild cats" are disappearing. "mad dogs" seem about to rule the hour. There is a very great alarm felt in one or two adjoining counties contiguous to our own and in different parts of that A considerable number of cattle and hogs have died at Bridgeport supposed to have been bitten by mad dogs Mr PETER GARLAND, of New-Trier, was bitten by a rabid dog a few case since.

It is understood that the Chairman of the House Committee on Naval Affairs will to-day report favorably on the proposition of A. W. THOMPSON to establish a line of steamers between the Western coast of our country and Eastern Asia. The line is to consist of six steamers, of 3.000 tons, and armed with heavy batteries, for war purposes.

AGRICULTURAL PROSPECTS OF GEORGIA.--The Savannah Republican says: We had the pleasure, some days ago, of meeting an intelligent agriculturist from the North, now on a tour through the Southern States. He comes for the purpose of informing himself of the Condition and prospects of Southern agriculture, and not to meddle in any way with our institutions.

SPIRITUAL MEDIUMS AGAIN.--On Wednesday evening, after the hearing before Justice TUCKER, on the Complaint of Mr EZRA SHERMAN, the following persons were arrested on the charge of riot: JOHN DRYSDALE, CHARLES HERRICK, AMBROSE SMITH, HENRY PILGRIM, and JOSH. M. ARNOLD Yesterday they were brought before Judge SKINNER for nearing, and during the morning the court was crowded, and waited with much impatience in the case came on.

From the Boston Journal. Few who are in the habit of either using or seeing the beautiful black Japan Varnish which is so much admired for the elegant gloss it imparts, know whence it is obtained, or are familiar with the manner in which it is procured, and the unpleasant exposure attending the operation. It is the product of a tree which grows wild both in China and Japan.

Celebration of Washington's Birth Day--Parade of the Vetoran Corps--Oration by N. Bow ditch Blunt. The one hundred and twenty-first birth day of WASHINGTON was celebrated in this City yesterday, by military parades, processions of civic societies,

How MURAT MET HIS FATE.--The sentence of the military commission was read to him with due solemnity. He listened to it as he would have listened to the cannon of another battle during his military life, equally without emotion or bravado. He neither asked for pardon, for delay, nor for appeal. He advanced of his own accord toward the door, as if to accelerate the catastrophe.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE. (Importers)...No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART CO., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

THE AMERICAN OFFICERS AND THEIR SOLDIERS.--A very objectionable part of the duties required from the general police, and the source of a good deal of discontent, is a practice which exists of causing them to do a considerable portion of work for officers, which ought to be done by their own domestic servants.
A locomotive, baggage and one passenger car of the evening train from Washington ran down an embankment near the relay house. Some of the passengers were slightly bruised, but none seriously.

Another musical prodigy is to be added to out list of stars. Mademoiselle MARIETTA SERATO, a young artist, aged twelve years, and reported to be a consummate mistress of the violin, is announced to take her departure from Venice in season to reach New-York in April.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Baron VON HUMBOLDT was the pioneer in the attempt to popularize science by means of lectures to the people.

Five or six hundred people from all parts of New- England gathered at the Vermont Central House, corner of Causeway and Canal streets, this morning, to draw prizes in the New-England Joint Stock Art-Union Levee Association.

An edifying scene that, which occurred between the Postmaster-General and a Member of Congress, yesterday, in Washington. Opinions will differ as to the taste exhibited in the quiet submission of one of the parties, according to the education of different readers, and the several standards of taste.

The Character and Influence of the Angle-Saxons. A LECTURE--BY REV. THEODORE PARKER. A very large and attentive audience assembled in the Tabernacle last evening, to hear a lecture from Rev. THEODORE PARKER, on the "Character and Influence of the Angle-Saxons."

Trial of Wm. M. Doty for Perjury. SEVENTH DAY. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.--Tuesday.--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Aldermen WESLEY SMITH and BARD.--The People agt. Wm. M. Doty.-On calling the names of the Jurors empaneled in this case, it was found that one of their number, Mr. JOHN OWENS, was unable to attend, from illness. A physician's certificate to that effect was handed in.

Ex-Governor CHARLES LYNCH, of Mississippi, died at his residence near Jackson, Miss., on the 9th inst., at a very advanced age. Gov. LYNCH had filled several stations of public trust, and was Governor of the State of Mississippi from 1836 to 1838.

FATAL ACCIDENT BY A RUNAWAY HORSE.- Monday night about 11 o'clock, a gentleman by the name of JOHN F BAKER, residing at No 224 West Fourteenth. Street, met with a shocking accident which will probably result in his death.
The term of the grant of the Tehuantepec route to Col. SLOO is for 50 years--(the road to be finished within seven years)--with the exclusive navigation of the Huasacule River.

The Albatross brought a letter mail for New York from California, which is in charge of Mr. J. C. FARNUM (the associate of Col. RAMSEY, in this mall contract via Vera Cruz and Acapulco....Mr. ALBERT SPEYER, from whom we gave a dispatch yesterday, came passenger by her, bearing dispatches from the City of Mexico to our Government....
The Tehuantepec Treaty has been settled, as far as Mexico is concerned, by the cession of the contract to Colonel A. G. SLOO. A copy of the grant is said to be on its way to Washington.

The current of the Danube is very strong, and in some places, especially between Vilshofen and Aschach, and in the neighborhood of the Strudel and Wirbel, very turbulent; and in the broader parts, when the wind is high, the waves rise to a considerable height, breaking into white horses at the top like the sea.

NUMBER THREE. The Austrian Union. AUSTRIA has always been a constant friend to high Protective Tariffs. In MARIA THERESA'S time, the importation of all goods, which could possibly be manufactured in the country, was forbidden.

There is Mexican news to the effect that the Tehuantepes grant has been signed, and delivered to A. G. SLOO Co. Gen. URAGA and Col. ROBBES had arrived in the City of Mexico. President CEVALLOS, not being able to agree with them, had resigned.
It is generally understood that the Grand Jury is busily engaged in taking testimony concerning the corruptions of the Common Council.
We are glad to learn that Dr. KANE has finally completed his preparations for the renewed exploration of the Arctic Seas, upon which he designs to enter as early as possible in the coming season.

To Rev. Archbishop HUGHES: SIR: As one of the Committee engaged in making arrangements for the "Madial Meeting" in Metropolitan Hall, I beg leave to call attention to a statement in your letter, that the occasion was made use of " to denounce our Catholic fellow-citizens in this country;" " to inaugurate a Protestant crusade against our Catholic fellow-citizens."

SOCIAL LIFE IN KENTUCKY.--We find the following paragraph in the Louisville Journal: The Feud in Garrard County, Kentucky--The Hills and Evans.--From a private letter to a citizen of this place we learn that the trial of the parties surviving the last fray (at a tobacco barn, in which some half dozen on each side were engaged, and several killed and others wounded) has resulted in their acquittal.

The epigrams upon the Empress, and her sup posed frailty, are innumerable. There could certainly be nothing more melancholy than this spectacle of a whole population amusing themselves at the expense of a woman, if her character were really damaged by it.

Letter from Rev. Dr. Durbin in Review of Archbishop Hughes's Communication. The communication or Archbishop HUGHES'S, published in the New-York Daily Times of Feb. 18, discusses a very grave subject, and ought to be carefully examined.

Mr. C. EDWARDS LESTER has long been known to us as a literary gentleman of much more than ordinary enterprise and assiduity. From the day when he startled the world with his fearful revelations concerning the " Glory and the Shame of England," he has kept his name before the public in connection with a great variety of important interests.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate several Executive communications. Several petitions were presented. Mr. WELLER introduced a bill for the Settlement of the accounts of the late Collector of California. Mr. SUMNER Introduced a bill providing for the reciprocal international probatory letters. Referred.

REMOVAL.--The Episcopal Church situated on Grove-street, near Newark avenue, is to be sold. The Congregation who have worshipped there propose to remove to the new church erected on Erie and South Seventh streets. This edifice is nearly finished, and will be ready for occupancy by the first of May next.

The Mechanics and Artizans Club celebrated WASHINGTON'S birthday last evening by a very handsome dinner at the Astor House. About seventy-five members and guests sat down to the table,--among the latter being Ex-Gov. HUNT, Judges BOSWORTH, EDWARDS, and WOODRUFF, Ex-Mayor BRADY, SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., and several others.

The Caloric ship Ericsson, it will be seen by a dispatch in another column, has fully justified the expectations of her most sanguine friends, in her voyage South. It will be remembered that she left the Hook in one of the severest gales of the season, and the weather during the whole trip was such as to put her capabilities to the hardest and most conclusive test.

WISCONSIN.--This State will be represented in the next Congress by DANIEL WELLS, Jr., B. C. EAST MAN and JOHN B. MACY. Wisconsin is growing rapidly. We copy the following from the Sheboygan Journal: The official vote for members of Congress in this State at the last election affords a striking evidence of the rapid growth of the northern or third district.

WASHINGTON's BIRTH-DAY IN BROOKLYN.--This day, in Brooklyn, was celebrated with more than usual eclat. At sunrise the stars and stripes were run up in every part of the city, and flaunted gaily to the balmy breeze of a morning more like Spring than Winter.

To show the good-natured unselfishness of the New-York press, it is only necessary to point to their columns of yesterday. The arrival of the Albatross at New-Orleans was received with a chorus of congratulations. Not one help back, at the prompting of selfish considerations.

General PIERCE kept his room the entire day, declining to see company-not admitting even the Mayor. In the afternoon, Mr. MARCY was closeted with him for a considerable time. Various Volunteer Companies of the city paraded the streets, with stirring music, in commemoration of the day, and on passing WILLARD'S, saluted the President elect, but he did not appear.

Advices from Mexico announce the death of General ANASTASIUS BUSTAMENTE, one of the leading patriots of the emancipation. Gen. BUSTAMENTE was one of those who rallied about ITURBIDE during the war. BRAVO, VITTORIO, GUERRERO, SANTA ANNA, were others.
The Caloric ship Ericsson arrived at Alexandria yesterday afternoon, from the mouth of the Potomac, where she had laid at anchor for 27 hours during the late snow and thick weather.

The Pacific Railroad Bill is probably dead for this session. There is a clear majority for it in either House of Congress, in almost any form in which it can be presented. But experimenting upon its vitality has been indulged in a little too long, and with fatal effect.
It is gratifying to know that a full house--literally full to the ceiling--was never better merited than on the occasion of PAUL JULLIEN'S Farewell Concert last evening at Metropolitan Hall.

AN INDIAN CAPTIVE RESTORED.--The Adrian (Mich.) Watchman gives an account of the kidnapping of a son of Mr. CHUBBS, living at that time in Blissfield, in that State, and formerly of Barrington, Yates County, some fourteen years since. The boy was six years of age at the time be was stolen by a party of Chippewa Indians, who kept him concealed, and afterwards sold him to a Western tribe.

On Saturday morning, one of the boilers in the rolling mill of Lewis Dalzell Co., In Sharpsburg, Pa., exploded, throwing the other four boilers to a considerable distance, Lewis Lapsley, one of the hands, was dreadfully bruised and scalded, but it is thought that he will recover.
The steamship Albatross brought a California letter mail for New-York in charge of J. C. FARNUM, the associate of Col. RAMSEY, in the new mail contract via Vera Cruz and Acapulco.

WASHINGTON'S BIRTH DAY.--The following named six German Military Companies from Williams burg, took part with the New-York procession in the Anniversary of the Birthday of WASHINGTON:--City Horse Guard, under command of Capt. GAUS; Jefferson Horse Guard, Capt. JOHN MILLS; Washington Guard, Capt. JOHN MAEEZ; Jefferson Blues, Capt. CHARLES KEHL; Long Island Riflemen, Capt. WALTER; andthe Black Riflemen, Capt. H. WILLS.

From Nassau, N. P., we have the Guardian, to Feb. 2. The crow of the ship Haidce, Capt. CHRISTIANSON, arrived here on Thursday evening, Jan. 27. She was from New-York for Mobile, in ballast, and got ashore on the 18th ult., at 5 o'clock, A. M., on the north side of Eleuthera, the reef near Pierce's Island.

On Tuesday, Feb. 22, HERBERT, son of Edward W. and Susan P. Leggett, aged 11 months and 22 days. Funeral to morrow (Wednesday,) from the residence of his parents at 1 o'clock. On Tuesday, Feb 22, suddenly, JOHN F. BAKER, aged 32 years.

The impression prevails to-night that MARCY takes the State Department, that CUSHING goes abroad, and HUNTER takes the Treasury. If this latter is true, HUNTER falsifies his well-known determination not to take a Cabinet appointment.

The Pacific Railroad bill was buried in the Senate to-day, "with the honors of war." The vote on adjournment was considered a test on the question whether it could be resuscitated or not. The decision was decidedly in the negative. This

Mr. A. Brackett, teacher of a Select School in Orange, attempted suicide on Friday night or Saturday morning, by cutting his throat. The wound did not prove immediately fatal, but was dressed by the physicians, who express some doubts as to his ultimate recovery.
The Customs League between Austria, Parma and Modena, came into force on the 1st inst. Nevertheless a few provisional restrictions are still observed for the repression of smuggling.
On Wednesday, Feb 23, in St James Church, Danbury, Coun. by Rev W. W. Broneon. WILLI. M WILLIAMS, of New-York. to ELIZABETH, eldest daughter of Horaco Marsmall, Esq, of the former place.

The Free Democratic State Convention assembled at the Congregational Church to day. S. TAPCOTT was chosen President. ANTOINETTE BROWN and Miss PELLETT were present. GERRITT SMITH reported an address with twelve resolutions, re affirming the old principles of the party, and he expressed the hope that the Free Democracy would take the same ground.

The Arabia, making a remarkably good passage, brought us yesterday highly interesting information from Italy: though closer scrutiny deprives it of much of the importance which, at the first glance, it seemed to possess.

The steamship Arabia arrived yesterday at 2 1/2 P. M. She left Liverpool on the 12th. An insurrection broke out at Milan on the 6th, and it was said that 300 of the insurgents had been slain by the soldiers. By the latest dispatches it appeared that the fighting had recommenced after the first suppression of it.

COSTUME OF THE HINDOO WOMEN.--The costume of the Hindoo women is peculiarly becoming. It consists of a long piece of silk or cotton tied round the waist, and hanging in a graceful manner to the feet; it is afterwards brought over the body in negligent folds; under this they cover the bosom with a short waistcoat of satin, but wear no linen.

Just two days before Christmas it was our painful duty to record how the Austrians were treating the Italian Liberals in Lombardy. At Shrewsbury, N J., suddenly, on Tuesday, Feb. 22, JOHN CORLIES in the 77th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to at tend the funeral from his late residence, on Sixth day afternoon. 25th Inst , at 2 o'clock.

THE ALLEGED SEIZURE OF LETTERS AT THE BROADWAY POST OFFICE--EXAMINATION OF PETER COOPER, ESQ.--There was considerable excitement and some anxiety, and a few elongated countenances, in and around the Tombs yesterday afternoon, in consequence of a rumor to the effect that the seizure of letters at the Broadway Post Office was to be the subject of investigation before Justice OSBORNE.

From Berlin it is stated, of date 7th, that all the Prussian Ambassadors have been officially informed that a treaty of commerce had been concluded between Austria and Prussia. It is to M. MANTEUFFEL that this result is attributed.
From the Providence Journal. Oxford and Cambridge Universities are represented in Parliament. We believe that New-Jersey is the only State which reserves this distinction for a railroad corporation.

THE HINDOOS--AN INTERESTING FACT.--One of the odious features of the paganism of India is its opposition to the re-marriage of Hindoo widows. The polygamy system renders this class of females very large; and, shut out by absurd custom from forming again the marriage relation, they are driven from want and other causes, into most debasing courses of life, Henco a prolific source of licentiousness.
The Hunkers continue to threaten PIERCE for the appointment of MARCY. PECKHAM (Huaker member from Albany) is here, striving to kill MARCY off. There is no evidence that the President elect wavers.

Mr. HUNTER, from the Committee appointed to wait on the President elect, made a report that the President had accepted the office to which he had been chosen. [The President's reply will be found at length in the House report.]

DEATH OF GEORGE DUMMER, ESQ.--Monday last, died GEORGE DUMMER, Esq., of Jersey City, in the 71st year of his age. He was born in Connecticut, from whence he removed to Jersey City, and entered into the flint glass manufacturing business, which he carried on successfully through all the panic that so seriously affected the business in other parts of the country.

Don JOSE DE ARRILLAGA, Governor of the State of Vera Cruz, died on the 20th ultimo, of Asiatic cholera. Judge H. G. O. COLBY, of New-Bedford, formerly one of the Justices of the Court of Common Pleas, died at New-Bedford, Mass., on the morning of the 22d inst.

Senators HOUSTON, DAWSON, CASS, JAMES, Secretary CONRAD, Speaker BOYD, and F. P. BLAIR had an interview with General PIERCE, at his lodgings this morning. This afternoon he walked out for the first time since his arrival, appearing in good health.

Letters from Hungary show, especially when considered with the Italian news, that Austria is in no condition to menace Turkey or any other State with war. A correspondent writing from the Hungarian frontier at the close of January, states that while the Government has deceived and alienated its most constant supporters in that kingdom, the masses are as well disposed to insurrection as in 1848.

SCIENTIFIC HINTS TO ISLANDERS UPON MATRIMONY.--Long and extensive observation has brought physiologists to the conclusion, that first cousins should never be married together. The facts, which they have collected to sustain this opinion, are the most unequivocal and important.

Berlin correspondence reasserts that there is every reason to believe that the commercial negotiations between Prussia and Austria are upon the eve of a satisfactory solution. Another account in the Morning Herald states that the commercial negotiations are terminated, and that M. DEBRUCK only waits at Berlin for the authority of the Austrian Government to sign a treaty of commerce concluded for twelve years.

FIRE IN LITTLE ROCK--The Little Rock (Ark) Gazette and Deinocrat gives the details of the destructive fire at that place, already noticed in our telegraphic news: About 3 o'clock on the morning of the 4th inst., a fire broke out in the Post Office building in Little Rock, Ark., on East Main-street, which for more than an hour threatened the destruction of the principal business houses of the city.

The Minister of Finance announces in his report that the Revenue receipts for the present year, will meet the expenditures without the imposition of any new taxes. This announcement was favorably received on the Bourse.

To the Editor of the London Express: SIR: However unprepared the rest of Europe may now appear for revolution, if the insurrection be victorious at Milan, it will immediately spread like wildfire throughout Italy, and not only Hun gary and Germany, but perhaps France itself cannot avoid following the generous example.

BLACKSMITH's MEETING.--The Master Black smiths of Chicago, held a meeting at the Chicago House, on Randolph-st., on Monday, Feb. 14, 1853. LOUIS HAAS was called to the Chair, and MICHAEL PIERCE appointed Secretary.

The lecture before the Historical Society, this evening, is to be delivered by Mr. GEORGE SUMNER, of Boston. The weather here is bright and frosty-clear, but rather cold. On Saturday night, however, the temperature of the Massachusetts House of Re presentatives was rather unseasonable, being extremely hot, or, as the Whig journals intimate, flagrant outright.

Both Houses of Parliament met, on Thursday, the 10th inst., after the recess. LORDS.--The business before the House of Lords referred to Criminal Law Proceedings, Law Reform, Suitors in Chancery Relief bill, Lunacy bills, Bankruptcy, and Criminal Law Procedure; thereafter the Earl of DERBY urged Lord ABERDEEN to lose no time in laying before the House a statement of the measures which the Government intended to introduce.

CRIME IN WILLIAMSBURG.--The following is from a report made by Justice BOSWELL, showing a not very flattering account of the number of crimes committed in the City of Williamsburg, during the past year: The whole number of persons arrested, brought before him and contined in the cells, is 2,000, who were charged with the following crimes and offences: Intoxication, 415; assault and battery, 225; petit laroeny, 110; disorderly conduct, 170; peace warrant, 60; grand laroeny.

The Port Huron Commercial thinks that the people of Michigan too lightly prize their University. It says: "It is clear that as heretofore conducted, it has been an institution more costly than useful; we mean that the number of graduates bears no proportion to the aggregate expenses of sustaining it.

The steamship Black Warrior, R. W. SHUFELDT, U. S. N., Commander, arrived at 3 o'clock this morning from Mobile and Havana. She left the former port on the 14th, and the latter on the 18th inst.

The American Barque, Martha Ann, BABCOCK, of Newport, was fired into on the 16th inst., by H. B. M. Corvette, Vestal, Capt. HAMILTON. On being signalized to show her colors, she delayed responding, until she received other notice.

The Democratic State Convention this after. noon nominated For Governor.--PHILIP ALLEN, of Providence. For Lieutenant. Governor.-FRANCIS M. DIMAN, of Bristol. For Attorney-General.-WALTER M. BURGESS, of Providence.

THE SAUT CANAL.--The act passed by the Legislature in Michigan, providing for the construction of the Saut Ste Marie Canal, vests the absolute control and supervision of the work in five commissioners and one engineer, who are to prepare a plan for the construction, the Commissioners to receive proposals, and the contract to be approved by the Governor and Engineer.

The Musical profession and the friends of Musical culture, in this City, are about to give Mr. FRY a complimentary Concert, which, from the preparations on foot, we are led to hope, will prove to the worthy beneficiary a substantial, as well as gratifying token of appreciation.

BRIDGING THE MISSISSIPPI.--Engineers, with the view of bridging the Mississippi, have taken surveys of every feasible point, and have decided that a bridge can be constructed with less expense at Rock Island than at any other place on the river.

THE New BIBLE HOUSE--The splendid edifice lately erected on the Fourth avenue, Astor-place, Third avenue and Ninth-street, is so nearly completed that there is no doubt of its being ready for occupancy on the 1st of May next.
The Whig Convention to nominate candidates for State officers, assembled in this city to day, and was organised by the appointment of JAMES F. BABCOOK, of New. Haven, as President.

The Senate in Executive Session confirmed the nominations of a number of Army officers for pro. motion. The nomination of GARDNER for Captain of Dragoons, the position claimed by Captain SCHAUMBERG, was discussed but not decided.

IMPROVEMENT IN STEAM POWER.--The St. Louis News learns that Mr. SAMUEL CABLE, of that city, has lately discovered an improvement in the application of steam as a motive power. The principle upon which Mr. CABLE is operating is this: He proposes a no less important change in steam power than discarding boilers entirely from use.

A lecture is to be delivered this evening at the Tabernacle on behalf of two French gentlemen, sent to Cayenne as State prisoners by LOUIS NAPOLEON after the usurpation of December 2d, but who escaped on the passage.

THE LOTTERY DEALERS.--ASA D. PATTEE and HIRAM N. PATTEE, were brought before the Police Court yesterday afternoon, upon a complaint charging them with having in their possession one hundred and fifteen lottery tickets, with intent to sell the same, and also with getting up and promoting a lottery.

The Legislature of Maryland have had under consideration a bill Imposing a tax of fifteen cents on every passenger passing over the proposed bridge across the Susquehannah. The Baltimore Sun remarks, that "of all tariffs, a tariff upon travelers is most obnoxious."

ACCIDENT AT BERGEN HILL.--Two laboring men named BARNEY REILLY and EDWIN MARTIN, employed in removing Bergen Hill, were Wednesday severely injured by the falling upon them of a heavy bank of earth. They were removed from their perilous position as quick as circumstances would permit, but more dead than alive.

What news we have this morning is fresh and good, but it is very scare....In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. DAVIS reported a bill amending existing laws for granting registers to yachts, which was passed. When the Army Appropriation Bill was taken up, Mr. CHASE moved additional sections appropriating $150,000 for survey of routes to the Pacific, with a view to the selection of one for a Railroad.

We have had frequent occasion, within a week or two past, to notice in our Money column the attempt about to be made by a Wall-street Bank to give credit to the issues of the so-called Wild Cat Banks of the West, which certain Brokers have nominally located in Illinois and Indiana, under the new and ill-secured General Banking Laws of these States.

Doty.--Doty was accompanied into Court by his mother, a respectable elderly lady, his sister and other ladies, in all nine, who were seated near Counsel.

SLYLY OFF FOR CALIFORNIA.--During the latter part of last week, several gentlemen, all married men, some of whom have recently filled offices of trust and responsibility in this city, quietly and slyly took leave of their families and proceeded to New York, from whence some of the number sailed on Saturday, in the steamer Prometheus, for San Juan, en route for Sun Francisco.

The Albany (Ga.) Patriot learns that a project is in agitation at Tallahassee for dividing the State or Florida. It is proposed by the advocates of the plan to unite that portion of the State lying west of the Cnattahoochee and Suwannee rivers to Georgia, the balance to constitute the future State of Florida.

FIRE.--About 12 o'clock yesterday forenoon, a fire broke out in the resin oil factory of Wm. LEECH, at the foot of North Sixth-street. The fire is supposed to have originated in consequence of an imperfection of one of the "stills," by which means the resin escaped and caught fire.

An Irishman named John Martin, a laborer on the cement Train of the Camden Amboy Railroad was seriously and probably fatally injured at New Brunswick Tuesday morning, He was caught by the engine of the 9 A. M. line for Philadelphia, as it was backing down slowly from the water-station.

SWAMP LANDS IN THE EIGHTH WARD.--A few weeks since, JOHN D. LAWRENCE, Esq, Street Commissioner, sent in a communication to the Common Council, calling the attention of that body to the swamp lands in the Eighth Ward, and recommending them to be filled up.

The Eighth Lecture of the Historical Society's Course, was delivered in the Metropolitan Hall last evening, by Hon. GEORGE SUMMER, of Boston, Mass. The attendance was more than usually numerous, and very respectable.

WILLIAM LESTER, mate of ship Italy, reported to be floating about at sea with a cargo valued at $10,000, writes to his father as follows: NASSAU, BAHAMAS, Monday, Jan. 31. We sailed from New-Orleans with every prospect of a pleasant voyage. We had fair wind and weather all.

Mr. GENTRY, of Tennessee, is entitled to the public thanks for calling public attention, and invoking public action, to certain gross abuses which seem to have been long practiced in the Executive Departments at Washington.
At this period the pulpit of New-York was supplied with a ministry of eminent talent and great worth of character. Almost every Protestant denomination had its share.

Ruth, a Novel.--TICKNOR CO., BOSTON; EVANS BRITTAN, New-York. The authoress of Mary Barton, secured by that publication a name hardly less notable than CHARLES KINGS LEY'S, as compassionate fried of the working classes.

We presume that the public shared the surprise which we certainly felt, on reading in yesterday's Times, the assertion of Mr. SHAW in the State Assembly, that the charges of bribery and corruption brought against members of the Common Council of this City, were absolutely false; that errors of Judgment might have been committed by them, but that the integrity of each individual member of that body was above suspicion or reproach.

A SEAMAN STABBED ON SHIP-BOARD.--At about 6 o'clock on Thursday evening a quarrel took place on board the packet ship Liverpool, lying at the foot of Burling-slip, East River, between a party of sailors, during which one of them named JAMES COURLEY was dangerously stabbed in three places with a knife or other sharp instrument, in the hand of one of the hands named RICHARD HALL.

The charges made to-day against Secretary STUART, in the House of Representatives, have created a great excitement, and already the community has drawn the line between those who sustain, and they who condemn the accused.

Mr. HAMLIN reported a bill granting a register to the bark Mary, of Baltimore, which was taken up and passed. Mr. MORTON submitted a resolution to pay DANIEL L. YULEE an amount equal to his per diem allowance and mileage while contesting a seat in the Senate from Florda. Laid over.

A WINDFALL FOR A JOURNEYMAN PRINTER.-A letter received yesterday by AUGUSTUS B. McDONALD, a journeyman printer in this office, informed him that his great uncle, Marshal McDONALD, who recently died in Paris, at the Hotel de Ville, aged 82, had left him by his will a snug little fortune.

A letter from Berlin, Md., States that the brig Champion, of Portland, Me., went ashore an Chincoteague Shoals in the storm of Saturday night, and all hands were drowned. Schooner Mary E. Batch, from Wilmington, N. C., for Boston, is also ashore on the same Shoals.

The Portland Advertiser remarks that manufacturing in Maine is coming up, and other places be sides Lewiston are reaping the advantages of it. The factory in Brunswick has been sold recently, but it is to be put into operation forthwith. The Hallowell Factory is driving, with full force, and coining money. The cloth which is printing brings 5 1/4 cents. The Augusta factory is in full operation.

A BEAUTIFUL PRESENTATION.-Within a few weeks past, the friends of JAMES L. WAUGH, Esq., ex-Captain of the Tompkins Blues, Procured a magnificent testimonial of their esteem for the gallant soldier, which they presented to him, on Thursday evening, at WRIGHT'S Fifth Ward Hotel. The Presentation was witnessed by a number of persons.
The following is a portion of a paper real before the Academy of Medicine, by Dr. A. K. GARDNER, of this city. We find it in the last number of the New-York Journal of Medicine.

Trial of Wm. M. Doty for Perjury. TENTH DAY. COURT OR GENERAL SESSIONS.--Friday.--Before Hon Recorder TILLOU, Aid. WESLEY SMITH and BARD.--The People against William M. Doty.-- At the sitting of the Court, the Recorder announced that in reference to the question reserved from previous day.

Gen. PIERCE spent an hour to-day with his sick friend, Senator CLEMENS. I have the best of reasons for saying that the Cabinet is made, and will not be altered, but the position of each person is not determined.

SIR: In the absence probably of a more attractive theme, you chose in your paper of the 231 inst., to bestow nearly two columns of a leader upon myself; and furnished the public with some very flattering allusions to my former history and pursuits.

Issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending Feb. 22, 1852. Hezekiah Bradford and Elisha Fitzgerald, of New-York, N. Y., for improved Apparatus for Separating Ores or other specific gravities. Dated Feb. 22. 1853. Alexander A. Croll, of London, England, for Improvement in Gas Meters. Dated Feb. 22, 1853.

Hon. CALEB CUSRING and A. O. P. NICHOLSON have arrived. President FILLMORE's last leave took place this evening. The east room and the various anterooms were so crowded as to render it extremely difficult to promenade.

The return of MAX MARETZEK from the Mexican tour is very heartily welcomed by the friends of the Opera. Negotiations are already on foot, if indeed they are not already concluded, to install him Impresario and Conductor at NIBLO's.

The series of Papers entitled "Leaves from the Journal of a New-York Clergyman during the first half of the Present Century," of which the first number appears in our columns this morning, will, we are confident, command and repay the perusal of all our readers.

The Religious Press this week teems with accounts of interesting revivals, particularly at the West. Many Churches in the Eastern States have also been favored. Large accessions are making in the evangelical denominations.
We need not direct attention to yesterday's proceedings in the Court of Sessions, reported in another part of this morning's Times. They are not likely to be overlooked,--or speedily forgotten.

An INCIDENT OF LIFE IN BOSTON--One morning, a week or two since, when frost and ice laid heavy upon the sidewalk, a young boy passed along Washington-st, with a basket half filled with old coal, picked up from various ash-heaps, upon his arm.

L'Empire--c'est la paix.--[Napoleon Ill. It is the Empire that pays.--[Free Translation. The young couple who have just gone to house-keeping in the Place at St. Could, appear to have commenced a style of extravagant expenditure that can only be accounted for by the fact that it comes out of other people's pockets.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Permit me to say a few words in reply to the letter from a "Catholic Layman" which you gave in the Times of Thursday, the 24th inst., which I read with great satisfaction.
OVERBOARD.--Yesterday afternoon a man fell into the river and was nearly drowned. He was employed on a raft near the farry, and in attempting to reach the wharf fell.

Major D. H. McPHAIL, formerly of Baltimore, and distinguished in the Florida and Mexican wars, is strongly urged for the Marshalship of the Southern District of New-York. He was one of Gen. JACKSON's citizen soldiers, and received a brevet for his gallantry and Maryland voted him a sword.

Mr. C. EDWARDS LESTER has Written us a long letter, which will be found in another column, His object is principally to proclaim to the knowledge of the world at large his own abilities and achievements; and in this complacent endeavor, long and laborious practice has given him considerable skill. His letter is cleverly written and well worth reading.
Green Bags, it would seem, are of great antiquity. According to PLAUTUS, they were used by the Romans as a beggar employs his wallet, to hold orts and broken scraps of food.

The Bribery Investigation Respecting the Common Council--The Refractory Witness who Refused to Answer Before the Grand Jury--The Argument Postponed--Judge Beebe Overruled by the two Aldermen. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Friday--Before Hon. Judge BEEBE, Alderman BRISLEY, (Ninth Ward) Alderman DOHERTY, (Nineteenth Ward.)

The General Assembly adjourned to-day. The ten-hour bill was passed by the concurrence of the Son-ate in the House amendment. LEFFINGWELL the actor, formerly of the Bowery Theatre, in an affray last night, knocked down a man named WILLIAM BOWMAN, who, in his fall, fractured his skull in such a manner as to render his death extremely probable. LEFFINGWELL has ?? from the city.

Congress beat about a good deal yesterday, but they did not get out of sight of any of their old landmarks....The Senate passed a bill granting a register to the bark Mary, of Baltimore, also a bill for the relief of the widow, of Lieut; COCHRAN of the United States Army....A resolution giving DANIEL L. YULEE his per diem and mileage while contesting a seat in the Senate from Florida, was laid over....

CULTURE OF POTATOES.--Mr. PHINEAS PRATT, of Deep River, Ct., informs us that, after some thirty years experience and close observation, he has come to the conclusion that the potato rot is caused by an undue absorption of moisture by the balls, before they are fully ripe.

A RETURNED CALIFORNIA--Mr. A. TINK-HAM, one of our old citizens, reached this place on Saturday last, on his return from California. Few of his intimate friends could recognize in the erect form, the keen black eye, the energetic man, as he was when be left here some two years ago.

Last week, says the San Antonia Texan, a company of the Rifles brought in some nineteen or twenty Indian prisoners, a portion of a party they had pursued and captured, after killing eight of their number. They also captured a large number of horses.

Gen. PIERCE attended the Presbyterian Church an Ninth-street, Rev. J. C. SMITH pastor, this morning. There was a crowded attendance. Attorney General CRITTENDEN was married to the widow of the late Gen. ASHLEY, at Dr. PYNE'S Church, at 6 o'clock, this evening.
A meeting of the managers of the Allegheny Valley Railroad, took place last night, at which a resolution was unanimously adopted, locating the road on the eastern side of the Alleagheny River.

The Court of General Sessions were in session at the Halls of Justice, during Saturday forenoon. The prosiding Judge was Hon. Recorder TILLOU, and his associates were Alderman WESLEY SMITH, (Eleventh Ward,) and Alderman JAMES M. BARD, (Fourteenth Ward.) The Court opened at 10 o'clock, when the Grand Jury came into the room, and having answered to their names.

The Police Committee of the Common Council, In connection with Mayor BERRY and Assistant Captain HUNT, met in the Mayor's office, on Friday evening, to consider the propriety of re organizing the Police Department of Williamsburg. The Committee will probably submit a report at the meeting of the Common Council this evening.

LECTURES ON GEOLOGY.--Dr. JOHN F. BOYNTON commences on Thursday evening, a series of lectures at Metropolitan Hall, upon "Geology, or the Natural History of Creation," of which a notice will be found in our advertising columns. Dr. B. has acquired a high reputation as a popular lecturer on scientific subjects, and has been successful in attracting and satisfying very large audiences wherever he has lectured.

NUMBER THREE. To Hon. Cernelius W. Lawrence, late Mayor of the City of New-York: SIR: The opposers of the original petitioners had effectually pleaded the cause of the Omnibus men, and obtained a verdict in their favor.

We publish this morning a second letter of JOHN JAY, Esq., upon the subject of an International Copyright. Mr. JAY'S special object is to define more precisely than before, his opinions upon the Author's right of property in his books; and to guard against inferences drawn from language used upon this point in his former letter.

DEATH OF AN OLD SLAVE.--A few days since JENNY CADE MOORE, formerly known as "Aunt JENNY," died at Greenport, L. I., at the advanced age of 97 years and some months. She was born a slave, and was owned at the time by JONATHAN TERRY, at Orient, L. I., then called Oyster-ponds. She was a pure African, but was endowed with a more than ordinary capacity of mind.

...."Books Are a substantial world." The degree of intellectual vigor in any community must depend in great measure upon the literary opportunity that is afforded. The abundance of books, the prevalence of newspapers, the speedy processes of the Press, go to indicate the culture enjoyed by the mass of the people, and serve very cleverly to place the society in its proper rank for intelligence and enterprise.

ASSAILING A DEAD MAN.--Mr. COGGSWELL says: "It is to me matter of deep regret that we cannot have the advice of woman in our legislative deliberations--especially on a subject in which she is so deeply interested (temperance.) Woman has been constantly wronged by man; and that wrong commenced in Eden, where our grandfather Adam cast the blame wholly upon Eve, instead of bearing it himself like a man.

The Southern Churchman publishes the following letter from Rt. Rev. Bishop WHITTINGHAM, Of the Episcopal Diocese of Maryland, defining his position in regard to the ordinances and belief of the Church.

The Chair laid before the Senate several executive communications, all of which were laid on the table and ordered to be printed. Also a communication from Mr. KENNEDY, Superintending Clerk of the Census, asking an investigation of his conduct.

COMMON COUNCIL.--At the last meeting of the Common Council, after considering the report of their Committee, relative to granting certain privileges to the Railroad Company, the report was referred back to the Committee, with certain information which they will report upon soon.

President FILLMORE gives an elegant entertainment to-morrow to the President-elect. Messrs. ATCHISON, SOULE and HUNTER, of the Senate, and other distinguished Senators, a like number of Representatives, and the prospective Cabinet, will be in attendance. On the part of the President, this is a graceful finality of his Administration.

No. 76 Henry D. Huff et al., plaintiffs in error, vs. C. J. Hutchinson et al. The argument of this cause was continued by Gov. Seward for the defendants in error. No. 77. John G. Goesele et al., appeliants, vs. Joseph M. Bimeler et. al. The argument or this cause was commenced by Mr. Quinn for the appeliants.

The following are likely to compose Gen. PRERCE's Cabinet, with a different arrangement of their positions, according to later and better authority: Hon. WM. L. MARCY, N. Y., Secretary of State. Hon. JAMES GUTHRIE, Ky., Secretary of the Treasury.

When will the Senators at Albany have done with trying to convert the Superintendent of Schools' Department into a bibliopolitical establishment! The same old question of books for the Schools was up yesterday, and bore off floods of talk.

The Aldermanic Contempt. SUPREME COURT--Special Term--Present Judges DUER, CAMPBELL, BOSWORTH and EMMETT.--In re the Broadway Railroad--The People vs. Richard T. Compton.--There was a large crowd in attendance on Saturday, in addition to all the defendants, and their legal advisers.
An amendment to the Army bill, moved by direction of the Military Committee, was passed in the U. S. Senate, on Friday, appropriating $100,000 to the discoverer of the anaesthetics in use.
TOLLING THE RAILROADS.--Sendator PIERCE introduced a bill in the Senate Yesterday, with the sanction of the Canal Committee, or a majority of them, imposing telis on all Railroads in the State.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers)...No. 112 Broadway, A. T. STEWART CO., (do.)..Broadway, cor, Reade-st.
On Sunday morning, Feb. 27, RACHAEL U. TALMAN, eldest daughter of John and Elizabeth Talman, aged 3 years, 8 months and 26 days.
Three hundred passengers left here to-day in the steamship Daniel Webster, bound for San Francisco vid the Nicaragua route. Steam Communication between the United States and China.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Crescent City, Capt. BAXTER, arrived on Saturday, from New-Orleans and Havana, bringing dates from the latter port to the 21st inst. She has encountered strong gales during the entire passage.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have this evening finished my first trip over the Harlem Railroad, and I wish to inform the public of one peculiarity of its management not specified in its advertisement.

A Lecture on the "Coup d'Etat of LOUIS NAPALEON, and treatment of French political prisoners," was delivered at the Tabernacle, on Friday evening, by JOSEPH WARREN FABEUS, Esq, late U. S. Consul at Cayenne, for the benefit of Messieurs QUESNE and CHAMBONIERE, French political prisoners, with whose escape from Cayenne our readers are familiar.

Matters here are too easy and times too dull for the fabrication of news. It is hard to get items of greater importance then the decline in pork and the rise in Eastern exchange. You will not, therefore, expect much "thrilling interest" in my humble letter.

The American Colonization Society is making preparations to start a vessel from Norfolk, Virginia, the first of May, with emigrants for Liberia. One hundred and seventy-eight persons have already applied for a passage; of whom one hundred and fourteen are from Virginia, fifty-two from North Carolina, six from Kentucky, three from Massachusotts, one from Ohio, one from Pennsylvania, and one from New-York.

New Orleans papers of the 21st are received. They contain full particulars of the SLOO grant. The road will begin where the navigation of the Coatzacoalcos River ceases. A plank road will be built from that point to the Pacific, to be begun in the year of the contract, and to be finished within three years.

As it may be a matter of some curiosity to know how the special organs of the Common Council receive the presentment of the Grand Jury, we copy the following from the Herald, which is the largest recipient of Corporation favors: It is needless to commend of the document to-day.

Gov. VROOM has rejected the Chief Justiceship of the New-Jersey Supreme Court. His reason probably was that be was unprepared to sell himself with the rest to the Monopoly, preferring to stand by those independent sentiments, which have long made him obnoxious to its managers.

Our Court of Sessions presented a scene on Saturday unparalleled, so far as we are aware, in judicial history. Two of the Judges upon the Bench, constituting a majority of the Court, were compelled to listen to their own indictment by the Grand Jury, for demanding and receiving bribes in the discharge of their official duties.

The correspondence which has recently passed between the Postmaster General and the British Post Office Department, in regard to the rates of Pamphlet and Magazine Postage between the United States and Great Britain, has been published.

The Captain-General of Cuba in his courtesy to Mr. KING, has been somewhat unfortunate, as a gentleman, in consequence of which, when he called to see him he was not admitted, not having complied with his own arrangements for that purpose, made for a previous day.
THE UNIVERSITY OF THE CITY OF NEW-YORK.--A movement is on foot to rolieve the University of a debt of $40,000 which hangs over it, greatly to the detriment of the Institution.
LAKE ONTARIO STEAM NAVIGATION.--The directors of the steam navigation interest on Lake Ontario had a meeting last week. We learn a few facts in regard to the season arrangements then determined upon.

A very barren budget of fresh news this morning. There were no arrivals yesterday from abroad, and the details of the latest intelligence from California fall to reach us. The proceedings of Congress are unenlivened by anything remarkable.

THE BOSTON PRESENT TO GEN. PIERCE.--The Democrats of Boston have done the handsome thing in their present to the President elect of a superb carriage, and horses to match. The gift was prompted by feeling of respect to the man who is shout to assume the reigns of Government.

SAD EVENT.--A daughter of Mr. BERNARD HASTINGS, about six years of age, was burned to death at Mill Valley, in Amherst, on Friday afternoon last, under the following circumstances: Boys who were skating had built a fire on the ice. This little girl and a daughter of Mr. FREDERICK JOY. aged ten years, were playing around the fire, when the clothes of the former were caught by the flames.

The steamship United States, Capt. WM. C. BERRY, from Aspinwall, arrived at 3 o'clock this morning, with passengers and treasure to JONES JOHNSON. The United States left Aspinwall Feb. 18, at 5.30 P.M., and Kingston Feb. 21, at 3 P.M., connecting with steamship Cortez, (of New-York and San Francisco Steamship Line,) which ship arrived at Panama Feb. 15, at 6 A.M., from San Francisco Feb. 1.

CUBIC MEASURE.--Few persons have correct notions in regard to this measure, hence make most erroneous estimates in their computations of size and capacity, Some three years since we ordered from the cabinet maker a bureau for our little girl. It was to contain one half as much as one of the ordinary size, and we agreed to pay him $6 50 for it.

The Oregon dates are brought down to Jan 15. The Oregonian, of the 8th inst., says: The upper Willametto River, and its tributaries, have never been known to be as high as they have been for the last week, and the loss of property has undoubtedly been very great; we have been almost entirely cut off from communication with any part of the upper country.

The late Rt. Hen DAVID BOYLE, President of the Scottish Court of Session, whose death was briefly announced in our last foreign intelligence, was a man of considerable note. He was born at Irvine, in July, 1772, was called to the Bar in 1793, and was appointed Solicitor-General for Scotland In 1807.

New Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. The Picayune has Tampico dates of the 9th inst., from which it learns that Ex-President ARISTA had arrived there in disguise, and after a atay of two days left for Matamoras.

LYNCHING,--On Saturday last, Mr. WILLIAMS. of Jackson, was informed that a quantity of carpenter's tools which had been stolen from him several months ago, were secreted in a certain cabin on Murphy's Guich. He procured a search warrant, and on Sunday, examined the cabin, and found the tools and the thief, whose name was CHRISTOPHER FERRILL, and is supposed to be a "Sydney duck."

The remarkable assertion of Mr. SHAW of this City, made in the State Assembly some days since, called out some observations upon that gentleman's unqualified endorsement of Aldermanic integrity. It was clear that Mr. SHAW was either unaware of the extent to which bribery and corruption had been carried in our Common Council, or that he was seeking to uphold that which he knew to be unsound and dishonest.

We publish this morning the communication of Mr. Secretary KENNEDY to the Commit tee of the House of Representatives, in reference to the Caloric ship. It will be seen, that a contract with Capt. ERICSSON for a vessel of 2,000 tons burthen is recommended.

It is to be lamented that popular indignation is evanescent. It seldom holds out from the commission of an offence through the tedious interval required by law for the trial and sentence. The prosecuting agents require all the stimulus of a concentrated and interested public opinion to support them against the influences industriously exerted by parties interested in eluding the requisitions of justice.

ST. LUXE's HOSPITAL.--Ninety thousand dollars have been subscribed to this noble Charity, twenty-four lots of ground have been secured, and only ten thousand dollars more are needed to ensure the success and immediate prosecution of the work.

The Panama Star of Feb 15, has the following: By the British bark Larne from Liverpool, via Callao, some seventeen passengers arrived in our port yesterday from Australia. These passengers came from Melbourne to Callao, in company with about three hundred others, in the ship Miltiades, which sailed from, the former port on the 27th Nov., and made a fifty days' passage to Callao. The Miltiades is bound for Liverpool.

Mr. HUNTER moved to take up the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation bill. Mr. UNDERWOOD opposed the motion. He said, if the Senate intends to grant any land to the old States or to the new ones for Railroad and Educational purposes, the BENNETT Land Bill must be taken up and passed. There would be no debate.

The International Copyright Treaty is creating a warm discussion between neglected authors, on one side, and wealthy book publishers, flourishing on men's brains, on the other. That such a law will restrict the sales of books by making them dearer, is very probable; that it will compel American readers to read the productions of native authors, is not at all likely.

JAMAICA.-The Jamaica Dispatch gives the following summary of local news: Since the compilation of our last resume of local intelligence, nothing or striking importance has transpired in our political world, and, except the few items we have here strung together, there is no intelligence which would be found interesting to our trans-admtic roaders.

Mr. MOORE, of Louisiana, is a sensible man. Thursday, he asked and obtained leave to print a speech in defence of the Sugar Planters of that State, rather than occupy the time of the House so near the close of the session.

The steamship Pampero, from San Juan de Nicaragua, arrived at this port to-day; she reports the route as healthy. The steamer Columbus was at Panama from San Francisco, wih passengers from on board the Winfield Scott, that vessel having sprung a leak in the Bay of Tehuantepec, causing great distress among the passengers.

FIRES.--On Sunday evening about 11 o'clock, a fire was discovered in a building used for storing lumber, and connected with Mr. AFFLICK'S Cooperage, in Afflick's alley, near First and North Second-streets. It was extinguished before much damage had been sustained.

The Eighth Anniversary of the Prison Association was held, on Monday night, at Metropolitan Hall in consequence of the unpleasant state of the weather, the attendance was not so large as expected. On the platform, seated with W. T. McCOUN, the President, were LUCRETIA MOTT, the celebrated Quakeress, Mrs. MABY GREW, R. N. HAVENS, JOHN COCHRANE, and others.

The proceedings of Congress, and the Legislature of New-York, have some interesting facts. The United States Senate agreed to a number of amendments in the Appropriation bills, among which was one naming $8,000 as the salary of the Vice-President and the Cabinet officers.

A certain enterprising butcher in Baltimore killed a fatted beef the other day, and sent portions thereof to President FILLMORE and Secretary KENNEDY. Each gentleman returning a highly complimentary acknowledgement, it makes altogether a capital advertisement.

There is great apprehension of the defeat of some of the Appropriation bills, in consequence of the numerous amendments. The proposition pending in the Senate to repeal the duties on Railroad iron will very likely pass that body if it comes to a vote.

LONG PASTORATES.--in noticing the retirement of Rev. WM. Jan from a pastorate of sixty-three years in Bath, England, the Boston Watchman mentions several English Baptist pastors who have enjoyed remarkably long pastoral relations.

Immediately after the departure of the last steamer the weather greatly improved, and for several days an active business was carried on, chiefly for country account. Prices of provisions and staple commodities (FLOUR excepted) advanced with the demand, and the improvement has been maintained, although for the past few days there has been comparatively little doing.

The days of the old English Comedy are not yet numbered. The various successes during the present season at WALLACK'S and BURTON'S prove this. The starring system is not essential to its prolonged popularity.

The Secretary of the Navy has recommended the Naval Committee of the House to report a resolution directing the Department to contract with Capt. ERICSSON for a caloric frigate of 2,000 tons. The Common Council of Washington have passed resolutions highly complimentary to President FILLMORE, asking him to appoint a day for a public leave-taking.

THE MOOSE.--Prof. Baird, of the Smithsonian Institute, recommends the domestication of this animal, as they combine the qualities of the horse and ox. He says, "harnessed to a sled, a pair of them in Canada are reported to have travelled two hundred miles in one day," which may be regarded as a long story.

Some people are cursed with congenital laziness. It cannot be called inbred, for it seems to be independent of all training, and to remain in spite of the stoutest efforts of their well-wishers to rid them of the incubus. Others are lazy rather from the force of their connections, and for lack of a motive to action.

The following is a more complete synopsis of the contract between the Mexican Government and the SLOO Company, for the construction of the Tehuantepec road: First article provides that the communication is to be by water as far as the Guaizocaulcos River is navigable.

New USE OF MILK.--A novel discovery has recently been made, which is likely to effect a revolution in the milk trade. In consequence of the advance in the price of olive oil, from [Pound]40 per ton to [pound]70, the manufacturers of woolen cloths, who use this oil in large quantities, have found out that necessity is the mother of invention.

Few men touch human life at more intellectual points than EMERSON. Few trace its familiar facts to remoter causes and spiritualize in so peculiar a manner, the incidents of common experience. A careless reader will not discern every-day existence in his volumes.

AQASSIZ AND HUMBOLDT.--Dr. GIBBES, of Charleston, at a dinner of the Medical Society, recently given, concluded a speech with this anecdote: When AQASSIZ first came to this country, he was under the direction of Baron HUMBOLDT, to whom he was largely indebted for aid in his pursuits, and, though desirous of remaining here, he felt bound to return to Europe.

Under ordinary circumstances some Austrian paper is the vehicle by means of which the opinions of this Government are conveyed to the public, but in a case of more than usual importance recourse is had to some foreign journal enjoying an extensive circulation. The first article in the Augburg Gazette, of February 2, which has evividently been forwarded from Vienna, professes to be one of a set of documents relating to the Oriental question.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have read the communication of " A Protestant " with attention. Though courteous in tone, at least to me, he is evidently, to my apprehension, tinctured, though unconsciously perhaps to him self, with the one sided spirit which controls the MADIAI intervention and public meetings.

Trial of Wm. M. Duty for Perjury. ELEVENTH DAY COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.--Monday.--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Aid. WESLEY SMITH and BARD.--The People agt. William M. Doty-At the-sitting of the Court, yesterday morning, Aid. SMITH and BARD took their seats as Associate Judges with the Recorder. Doty was accompanied into Court by several ladies of respectable appearance.
The steamship United States, whose arrival was briefly noticed yesterday morning, reached her wharf at 3 o'clock, and her news was received at an early hour of the day.
UNCLE TOMITUDES.--The last English Unelo Tomitude is an advertisement in the Birmingham Journal, of the following list of songs, written by CHARLES JEFFRBY, and suggested by " Uncle Tom's Cabin."

We have dates from Panama to the 15th ult. Our files contain a few interesting items: The season is certainly now sufficiently settled to warrant the expectation of profitable working. we should think, (if profitable working le to be had.) at the Chepo mines.

FRY'S CONCERT.--Our readers will bear in mind that Mr. W. H. FRY's Grand Complimentary Concert takes place this evening at Metropolitan Hall. Considering the good service that Mr. FRY has done to the cause of music in New-York, the least that he can expect is a bumper.

SPOTS ON THE SUN AND MAGNETIC VARIATIONS.--We find the following statement in the National Intelligencer, from its London correspondent: Mr. FARADAY, in a late lecture before the Royal Institution upon the Magnetic Forces, made the following important announcement:

In steamship Georgia, from Aspinwall.--Mrs Shony and children, Mrs. H. Morris, Col T. Johnson, S D. King, W. Ro?ke and lady. A M. Dupun. lady and sen: G. F. Tan hair, Mrs. W. Fanchilds, Paner Schell. J. M. Freeman, P. Harvew, C H. Ames. A Ranhael, W. Dayton. J. M. Goggin, Special agent Post-Office Department: Mrs. Hunter J. H. Bailey.

THOMAS FITCH, 2nd., the Whig nominee for Lieut. Governor of Connecticut, having declined the nomination, the Whig State Central Committee have empowered the Convention of the Fourth Congressional District, which assembles in Norwich on the 9th of March, in connection with any delegates from the recent State Convention, who may be present, to make a new nomination.

The steamer Humboldt arrived yesterday, bringing later dates from Europe. Our London flies reach to the 15th ult. Among the passengers by the Humboldt are FRANCIS PULZSKY, the intimate companion of KOSSUTH, and Mr. J. R. COWDREY, United States Consul at Southampton.

The New-Orleans papers give further items and detail some portions of the news we have already given by telegraph. From Tampico, the Comercio to Feb. 9; had been received. On the 5th, it said: "From several sources we have learned that during last week Don MARIANO ARISTA arrived incognito at San Luis Potosi, and after staying two days in that city left for Matamoras, where he probably is at present.

STRIKE.--The Masons' Laborers Society of Jersey City have publicly notified boss masons, and other parties with whom they are interested in matters of labor, that after the 1st of May next they shall demand ten shillings per day.

THE BENEDICTINES IN AMERICA.--Among the glorious footsteps of Catholic progress in the United States, it is far from the least that the noble Order of St. Benedict has planted itself deep and firm on the hills of Western Pennsylvania.

NAVAL SURGEONS.--The Naval Medical Board of Examination which was convened at Philadelphia on the 15th of Dec. last, has reported the following Assistant surgeons as qualified for promotion, to wit: No. 1, WM. LOWBER; No. 2, P. J. HORTWITZ; No. 3, B. RUSH MITCHELL; No. 4, D. B. PHILLIPS; No. 5, JAMES HAMILTON; No. 6, J. L. BURTT.
