The construction of a Magnetic Telegraph line to the Pacific Ocean is only second in importance to the project of a railroad across the continent to its western shore. The subject is before Congress; and even at this eleventh hour, a united, determined effort of its friends, and a few minutes of the time now so valuable, will be sufficient to secure the immediate initiative and early consummation of the work.

Mr. GIBSON, the American gentleman, who, in his yacht, the Flirt, it will be remembered, was arrested by the Dutch authorities at Palembang, Java, on a charge of high treason, in exciting the Rajah of Djambi to wage war with the Dutch, and imprisoned at Bata via now nearly twelve months, still remains incarcerated.

BURNED TO DEATH.--On Friday last, a girl about two years old, daughter of Michael Tracy, residing in First-street, was so severely burned, in consequence of her clothes catching fire from the stove, that she died in two hours afterward, and was buried the day following without an inquest being held.

The Milan insurrection proves to have been little else than a momentary and unsuccessful riot. The Austrian organs, correspondents of London journals, and private letter writers combine in giving the affair no more formidable aspect; and as the friends of Italian unity have nothing to say per contra, we may assume the melancholy fact to be as stated.
The mail steamer Georgia sailed from Aspinwall on the 19th inst., at 9 P. M., for New York direct. The California dates are the same as brought by the United States. She arrived at noon of yesterday.

CHURCH CHARITY FOUNDATION.--On Sunday evening last the first annual report of this society was made, at a meeting held at Grace Church. This association was formed in February, 1851, under the auspices of the Episcopal Church of this city.
Our accounts from Madrid are of the 9th inst. The Minister Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Venezuela, M. FRANCISCO DE MICCHELENA Y ROSAS, presented his credentials to the Queen on that day.

The Tahiti Messenger of the 5th of Dec., contains the following items of intelligence. At that date everything was tranquil in that Archipelago. The American ship Fides. Capt. BECKNAM, had arrived at Tahiti, after a remarkable passage of twenty seven days.

By way of San Francisco we have dates from Hong Kong to Dec. 8. The most important item in the news refers to a difficulty between the American and British Vice-Consuls at Whampoa. It appears that a great number of desertions had taken place from British ships at Whampoa, and that the British Vice-Consul had been exerting himself to put a stop to them.
The Secretary of the Treasury has made the following appointments: SAMUEL VAUGHAN, Inspector of Steamboat Boilers, and THOMAS MURPHY, Inspector of Hulls at Philadelphia. Salary $1,000 each per year.

We have received Texas papers to the 16th of February, inclusive. The Legislature has adjourned sine die. The Apportionment Bill has become a law without the signature of the Governor. The Internal Improvement Bill was indefinitely postponed.

We give in another part of to-day's paper the opinion of Judge DUER in relation to the Aldermanic contempt. In accordance with this decision, Mr. FIELD, on the part of the deponents, put in the following answer: The answer of Oscar W. Sturtevant and others to the fifth interrogatory filed against them in this proceeding.

The following is from Hong Kong papers of Dec. 27: It is stated that SU, upward of a month ago, (Nov. 18,) routed a hand of the insurgents at Seung-tam, in Hu-nan, and took upward of four hundred prisoners, among them the leader of the band and his counsellors.

Of Montenegro there is little to be said. At the end of January the Turkish corps were quiet in their respective positions. Prince DANIEL, PETER PETROVICH, and GEORGE PETROVICH (from Vienna) were in Cetigne. The Austrian frigates Novara and Bellona and the war steamer St. Lucia were in the Bay of Topla.

On Tuesday, the 1st inst, of consumption, ANN, wife of Abel Smith, and daughter of the late John Mather, in the 31st year of her age The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Thursday, at 1 o'clock, from her late residence, corner of North 2d and Lonmer sts, Williamsburg.

ST. DAVID's--FESTIVITIES.--Yesterday being the anniversary of their Patron Saint, the sons of Cambria held holiday, and celebrated the occasion by festive gatherings at the Florence Hotel and Tammany Hall. At the former were the old "St. David's Society ;" at the latter the more recent organization called the "Cambrian."

FINED.--A driver on the Bedford Omnibus Line named Francis McGillen, was fined $10 yesterday morning for assaulting a person named Charles Wilson. It appears Wilson took passage in the omnibus of which the accused was driver.

We have received papers from Bermuda, to the 10th ult., and from them we learn that the revenue of the colony for the year ending 31st Dec., 1852, has greatly exceeded the most favorable anticipations that were formed concerning it.

The address from Stafford house to the ladies of America has met with just the response that we anticipated for it. The highborn dames of Virginia, who, with their mothers before them, have held slaves now for more than two hundred years have risen as one woman to resent this interference with their immemorial privilege.

Feb. 28, at St Patrick's Cathedral, by the very Rev. John Loughlin, JAMES R DEL VECCHIO to JULIA, daughter of J. P. Berard, Esq, of the City of Brooklyn. On the 27th Sept. last, by his Honor the Mayor and afterwards by his Grace.

VICE-PRESIDENT KING.--We are enabled to announce, on a perfectly reliable authority, a great improvement in the health of Hon. WILLIAM R. KING since his sojourn in the Island of Cuba GEORGE H. JONES, Esq., the gentleman commissioned to notify Col. KING of his election as Vice-President of the United States parted with him on Monday evening last.

The Triest Zeitung contains various interesting morsels of news from the Turkish capital. The arrival of the Greek Patriarch from Jerusalem had created a great sensation. " Two mighty elements, Catholicism and Schism, have cast their gauntiets at each other's feet and that on neutral around."

The ship Versailles, from London for Boston, struck on Cohasset Rocks last night, but got off with five feet of water in her hold. She lies at anchor near the rocks, waiting the assistance of a steamer. She has a valuable cargo on board.

At the Mark lane Corn Market, trade was not very active, but a fair extent of business was done at previous prices. FLOUR was in improved request, and fresh American brands were held with increasing firmness. English BARLEY was in small supply.

"The Madial and the Proceedings in the United States." To Rev. John Hughes, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New-York: DEAR SIR--In your remarkable letter of the 18th inst., upon the subject of "The MADIAI meeting" held in Metropolitan Hall, in this City, in January last, and "the proceedings in the United States," you say:
Secretary EVERETT answers the resolution of the Senate, that all the information relative to the Mosquito question, was transmitted to Congress in his communication of the 16th February.

Our accounts from Paris are to the 15th ult. The Moniteur publishes an official disavowal of the recent pamphlet called "Letters Franques," in which the destruction of England by France was coolly recommended.

The Opinion of Judge DUER, in regard to the case of Aldermanic contempt in which Mr. OSCAR W. STURTEVANT so conspicuously figures, is published in full in this morning's Times. It will effectually put a damper upon any transient hopes of leniency which may have been excited by the former action of the Court.
The U. S. Mail steamship Humboldt, Capt. LINES, arrived at this port yesterday, having sailed from Cowes on the 16th Feb. at 4 P. M. Her news is highly interesting.

We have the papers of Honolulu to Jan. 1st., containing, however, no news of consequence. A large number of vessels that had cleared and were ready for sea, were detained in the harbor some days by heavy westerly winds. The Polynesian says:
A Call for a public meeting in favor of City Reform, is published in our columns this morning. It will meet with a ready and most hearty response.

Although the Captain General of Cuba feels very sensitive upon the subject of the serious allegagations implicating him, and tarnishing his fame, as being interested in the prosecution of the Slave trade, by encouraging the direct importation of Africans, which has been so openly conducted, that he could not but have knowledge, no matter how well sealed his perceptive powers by the Felix Auspice of seventeen dollars each.
This Society has taken its origin in the deeply settled feeling of our citizens, that something must be done to meet the increasing crime and poverty among the destitute children of New-York.

Considerable excitement was produced yesterday "on 'Change," among our capitalists and those of our citizens interested in the New-Orleans and Tehuantepec Railroad Company, by the news brought: by the steamship. Albalross from Vera Cruz, with dates from the city of Mexico to the 11th inst.

Mr. HUNTER moved to take up the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation bill. Messrs. DAVIS and COOPER desired time to make reports. The CHAIR, by consent, laid before the Senate the Annual Report of the Regents of he Smithsonian Institution, and the report of the Coast Survey Bureau.

The circular of the Children's Aid Society will be found in another column, and we de sire to call especial attention to it. Large numbers of the destitute children who swarm our streets, escaping the charities of our existing Asylums, are left to vagrancy and the miserable influences which, sooner or later, are almost sure to betray them into dishonorable courses of life.
The following letter from Gen. PIERCE was received to-day by the President of the State Senate. It is in reply to the resolutions of condolence recently passed by the two branches of the Legislature:

Accounts from Milan represent the recent outbreak there as a contemptible affair. The ringleaders had been hanged. The Austrian Government had placed a military cordon on the frontier of Switzerland. Martial law in its most vigorous shape had been proclaimed and enforced at Milan.

Madame SONTAG and her associate artists repeated Linda on Monday evening with very charming effect. The slight drawbacks noticed to the first representation on Friday, were entirely absent from the stage, while the Orchestra showed signs of a more careful rehearsal.

In both Houses of Parliament, on the 14th ult, interpellations were addressed to the British Government in the Lords by Lord CLANRICARDE, and in the Commons by Mr. DISRAELI, in reference to the incautious speech made by Sir CHARLES WOOD at Halifax, in which the conduct of the Emperor LOUIS NAPOLEON was attacked, and his despotism held up to public execration.

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--The ordinance adopted in December, by the Brooklyn Common Council, to take effect on the 15th of February, requiring the withdrawal of locomotives from the Long Island Railroad in Atlantic-street, was last evening in that body resoinded by a vote of 12 Ayes to 5 Nays.

The Boston riding equipage was presented to Gen. PIERCE at Willard's this morning, by EDWARD RIDDLE, of Boston, in the presence of a few invited friends. Mr. RIDDLE handed the General a letter, with the names of the doners attached, and briefly explained their sentiments, to which Gen. PIEACE responded as as follows: "I accept with much dieasure, Sir, the handsome gift which you and the gentlemen associated with you have presented me.
The passage of the amendment making an appropriation of $100,000 for the establishment of an ASSAY OFFICE in this City, is the most gratifying piece of intelligence that we have to announce to-day.
The reading of the journal was dispensed with. APPROPRIATION DILLS. Mr. HUNTER reported back the Indian Appropriation Bill, with amendments. Also the Navy Appropriation Bill, without amendment.

Our Charter Election was held to-day--WILLIAMS, (Dem.) was elected Mayor by over 1,000 majority. 10 Democratic Alderman and 10 Democratic Supervisors were also elected. The County generally is Democratic.

The surprise of business men at the defiance thrown out by the American Exchange Bank at the newspaper press and public opinion, is increased, and reasonably so, by the known vulnerable position of that concern, when contrasted with what creditable Banking ought to be at the money centre of this great country.

In another column will be found a letter from an estimable clergyman of North Carolina, in reference to the apostacy of Bishop IVES. As placing the antecedents Of the Bishop's secession in a proper light, it will be read with interest.

The Whig party have issued their ticket for the Convention Delegates--containing, among others, the names of RUFUS CHOATE and E. EVERETT. It is reported that people in the country parts will choose distinguished men belonging to other places, should the latter not be elected where they reside.
KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--A regular meeting of this Board was held Tuesday afternoon at the County Jail. His Honor Mayor Berry, of Williamsburg, in the Chair.

The following is the Speech of Mr. SEWARD in relation to the Debt of Texas, delivered in the United States Senate on Tuesday night, and briefly announced in our telegraphic dispatches yesterday morning: Mr. President: At the epoch of Annexation, 1845, the Republic of Texas possessed some property in public defences, a large domain of unappropriated land, and revenues derived from customs.

On Monday, Feb. 28, after a short illness, MARY BLAZBY daughter of the late Capt. James Taylor, aged 44 years, 9 months and 26 days. The relatives of the family and friends generally are respectfully invited to attend the funeral to-day.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The earliest account which we have of Japan is that recorded by the celebrated oriental traveler, MARCO POLO. A spirit of adventurous enterprise having early led him abroad, MARCO POLO, in the thirteenth century, visited Tartary, and resided at the Court of KUBLAI, the great Khan of that country.

Our California exchanges make hitter complaints of the inaccuracy of their census returns. The figures show no increase of population within the last two years, and make Sacramento less than one-fourth the size of San Francisco, while the vote of the former at the late election was three-fifths that of the latter city.

Mrs. General PIERCE is stopping at the Eutaw House, where she will remain until after the Inauguration. An immense concourse of Baltimoreans, with several Military Companies, are preparing to attend the Inauguration.

From the National Intelligencer, 2d. In accordance with a resolution of the City Council of Washington, and agreeably to appointment, the members of the Board of Aldermen and Board of Common Council, with the Mayor and other executive officers of the Corporation, waited on President FILLMORE yesterday, to tender their respects and good wishes in taking leave of him on his retirement from office and from the seat of Government.

There was another late session of Congress yesterday; the House adjourning at midnight. The Appropriation bills are still under discussion. The Senate rejected a number of amendments; and among them one offered by Mr. WELLER for a Subterranean Telegraph to San Francisco.

The Baltimore Board of Trade to day passed a resolution requesting the Legislature to abolish all Inspection Laws. The Philadelphia train to-night brought on nearly 2,000 passengers, all bound to Washington.

BROOKLYN CITY DISPENSARY.--A distinguished physician of Brooklyn calls the attention of the citizens of this City to the paucity of the funds supplied the Dispensary. Owing to this they have not been able to attend upon only those patients who apply at the Dispensary.

Mr. BREKMAN reported favorable on the bill relative to Rural Cemetries. Mr. CORNELL, of a bill to amend the charter of the Junction Canal. Also, of a bill regulating the practice before justices of the Peace.

Of the several documents laid before the Senate in reference to the Fishery question, we this morning publish the most important. The letter of Mr. EVERETT to our Minister at St. James, accords with the high estimate of the Secretary's fine diplomatic abilities, which his short career in office has justified.
ARRIVAL OF THE STAR OF THE WEST.--The steamship Star of the West, S. L. TINKLEPAUGH, Esq., Commander, from San Juan de Nicaragua via Havana, arrived yesterday morning.

As usual, during the last few days of the session, Congress has gone to work in earnest, and more work will be accomplished in any single day of the present week than in seven fold that time during the first two months of the Winter.

A party of members of Congress visited the Ericsson this morning, by special invitation. They carefully examined the machinery, took a ride upon the pistons, listened to lucid explanations by Captain ERICSSON, breakfasted, and returned to Washington in season for Congress, expressing the highest satisfaction with the vessel.

In the prosecution of some recent literary labors, I had frequent occasion for authentic information touching the present condition of our domestic manufactures, and in almost every instance, found it impossible to obtain what I desired.

Some weeks since an Irish girl, about 17 years old, named HONORA COCHRAN--educated in the Catholic faith--but recently converted to Protestantism--mysteriously disappeared from her home in Charlestown. Her disappearance caused much anxiety to her Protestant friends, and her guardian--a wealthy and respectable merchant--has spared no efforts to learn her whereabouts.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As there can now be no doubt of the apostacy of Dr. IVES to the Church of Rome, I send you, as I proposed, some account of the difficulties which have existed between the Bishop and his Diocese in North Carolina till his final secession.

The "spicy East," "the perfumed gales of Araby," "redolent of odors as an oriental bride," these common phrases indicate our usual associations with the East. It is true that the Orientals love perfumes, and perhaps have a religious regard for them, because MOHAMMED loved them excessively, and praised the use of them.

Murder of a Seaman in Water-street--Capture of the Murderers--The Coroner's Inquisition. We are called upon to record the details of another horrible murder that was perpetrated in the Fourth Ward, on Thursday evening, at about 6 o'clock.

The New-York Historical Society held its regular monthly meeting Tuesday evening at the University. The President of the Society being prevented by illness from attending, FREDERICK DE PEYSTER, Esq., took the chair.

Charles D. Mead, Esq., of New-York; Nelson Dewey, Esq., of Wisconsin; Elijah P. Brooks, Esq., of New-York; H. J. Jewett, Esq., of Ohio; Elias F. Terry and James W. Borden, Esqs., of Indiana; and John W. Howe, Esq., of Pennsylvania, were admitted Attorneys and Counsellors of this Court.

Trial of Wm. M. Doty for Perjury. TWELFTH DAY--EVIDENCE CLOSED. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Wednesday.--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, Aid. WESLEY SMITH and BARD.--The People agt. William M. Doty.--The evidence on both sides was brought to a conclusion. The Attorney-General called evidence of a rebutting nature.

THE DAUPHIN QUESTION.--The Boston Transcript gives a sketch of the recent Lecture of Rev. Dr. LOTHROP, of Boston, before the Mercantile Library Association of that City, in reference to the disputed question of the Dauphin Louis.
SCHOOL EXAMINATION.--Several classes belonging to the Female Department of Ward School No. 2. in Fifth-street, were examined by the Trustees on Tuesday afternoon, in the various common branches.
On Wednesday, March 2, at the Central Presbyterian Church, by Rev. A. A. Wood Mr ADOLPHUS J. HALSEY to Miss HARRIETT C., daughter of the late James Miller, Esq., all of this City.

Alderman STURTEVANT has published a card in which he attempts to relieve himself from the serious Charge of bribery presented by the Grand Jury. The Aldermen just now are in contempt, and if any one of them is able to show cause why honest men and good citizens should not regard them as contemptible, it is eminently due to such an one, that his showing be published far and wide.
There are thirty Railroad lines embraced in the Anual Report of the State Engineer of New-York, with an aggregate length, in main stem, of 1,901 3/4 miles.

The ship Forest Queen, from London, reported yesterday ashore at Soituate, has bilged, is full of water, and is breaking to pieces. Her cargo has mostly washed out; a portion has some ashore, and some has floated to sea with the ebb tide.

It may be that portions of the testimony before the Grand Jury were false. The cause of truth and justice may have suffered from the excessive readiness of witnesses to make a case against parties, from whose extortion they may have fancied themselves sufferers.

The negotiations between the SONTAG management and MARETZEK are for the present cut short. The ALBONI troupe have secured the popular conductor after the 1st of April, when Manager LE GRAND SMITH is to have NIBLO'S.
Whether the Protestant case, founded upon the MADIAI prosecution, be sound or not, the subject has its lessons. At Charlestown fierce riots have occurred.

WITCHCRAFT IN PENNSYLVANIA.--The Chambersburg (Pa.) Whig of 17th inst., relates the following singular instance of superstition, which proves that the belief in witchcraft is not yet done away with: A correspondent, writing from Fulton County, informs us of a singular case of supposed witchcraft that occurred near Sideling Hill.

The Professional Writer. It is customary with naturalists, in classifying the objects which form their study, to place at the bead of each species, whether of the animal, vegetable, or mineral kingdom, that individual which comprises in itself the greatest number of the distinguishing characteristics-of its order, and to arrange its followers according as they share such traits.

Liverpool Cotton Market. The sales of COTTON for the week ending 18th Feb., inclusive. were 39 810 hales--7,280 being to speculators, and 4,170 to exporters. The Europa's advices checked business, but a moderate demand subsequently sprung up, and prices partially recovered; still they close 1-16d@1/6d. below last Friday's quotations.
The reading of the journal was dispensed with. Mr. MILLER presented the credentials of WILLIAM WRIGHT, Senator-elect from New-Jersey, for six years from the 4th March next.

The ship yesterday reported ashore on Pollock Rip is the Mary Ann from Liverpool for Boston. She got off last evening at high water, with assistance from the shore, leaking, and proceeded on her way to Boston, but at 4 o'clock this morning, was but four miles from Chatham, becalmed.

The last dying speeches of the Thirty-Second Congress occupy no small share of our available space this morning. The proceedings are hardly so interesting as in the times of the Compromise troubles, and no very remarkable scenes transpired in either House.

Verdict of Acquittal. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Thursday.- Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU, and Aldermen WESLEY SMITH and BARD -- The People against Wm. M. Doty.- At the sitting of the Court this morning, Mr. Clarke addressed the 'Jury for the defence.

The number of strangers in this City exceed all previous inaugurations, The hotels are unable to accomodate; the boarding-houses are overrun and many hundreds must sleep in chairs. The reading rooms and the parlors of the hotels filled with cots. The Capitol is thronged with people and the Avenue is swarming with pedestrians.

Milan is now reported quiet, but the theatres and public assemblages are prohibited. No outbreak had occurred in the Tuscan or Roman States, except some rioting at Orvieto, where one man was stabbed and some windows broken.
The Alexandria Gazette has perused the correspondence touching the interesting subject of the engraving of a fuc simile of WASHINGTON'S Autograph Will.

The New-York Medical School had its Annual Commencement last evening. Prof. BARKER delivered an able Valedictory to the retiring Class, on the secret of success in the Medical profession, which, he told them, was" to cure their patients."

The following is the speech of Mr. MILLER, in favor of the recognition of the independence of Liberia, and the establishment of commercial intercourse with Africa, delivered yesterday in the United States Senate, and referred to in our Congressional report:

The following is a list of the acts and resolutions passed during the present session of congress: PUBLIC ACTS. An Act making further appropriations for the construetion of roads in the Territory of Minnesota. Approved Jan. 7.
The Royal mail steamer Cambria arrived at this port at 10 1/2 o'clock, this morning, having left Liverpool, and Saturday the 19th ultimo. She brings 56 through passengers.

We regret to hear that BARNABAS BATES, Esq., the venerable champion and untiring advocate of cheap postage, is seriously ill in Boston, whither he went, some months since, for the par pose of securing the influence of the merchants of that city in favor of cheap Ocean Postage.

STEAMBOAT EXPLOSION IN FRANCE.--A steam boat, plying upon the Rhine, recently burst a boiler just as she was leaving Andance, where she had stopped to discharge freight and land passengers. No person was killed 'immediately by the explosion; but some thirteen or fourteen were drowned, in consequence of the breaking up of the vessel.

A most remarkable occurrence, says the Doylestown Democrat, took place a few days since in the village of Lahaska, Buckingham township, Bucks County, Pa., where a small party were assembled around a light table for the purpose of testing their power in causing it to move round.

The Royal Mail steamship Cambria arrived at Halifax, yesterday. She brings dates from Liverpool to the 19th ult. The commercial intelligence Indicates a fall of 1/2d. in Cotton, and an unchanged market for Breadstuffs. The political news presents few features of interest.
The reports that have reached us touching the health of Col. KING, who to-day be comes Vice President of the United States, have been quite contradictory. The last is the worst, however.

HEMPSTEAD AND JERUSALEM PLANK ROAD.--At a recent meeting held at Hempstead, Long Island, it was shown that there was considerable difficulty in making any amicable arrangement with several holders of property on the route of this proposed road, and an adjournment was had, and in the meantime to select, if possible, some other route.
The Foreign news possesses no more exciting features than the customary budget of rumors from the dominions of NAPOLEON III., and the confirmation of the suppression of the Milan revolt.

The following resolution has been passed by the Legislature of Maine, relating to the lands in that State owned by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts: Resolved, That the Land Agent of this State proceed without delay to Boston, for the purpose of ascertaining from the authorities of Massachusetts the terms on which that State will sell or surrender to Maine all her interest in the lands in this State.

Both Houses of Congress are in full blast at the present time--10 o'clock at night. I write from the Senate gallery, suspended half way between the blaze of a thousand jets of flame that issue from the brilliant chandelier overhead, and a scene of confused disorder on the floor below. These night sittings are rather unique "institutions."

On the 14th inst. Mr. George Sharp, of Burnsville, Dallas County, Ala, was murdered by a man named Notes. Notes had been guilty of the infamous crime of incest with two of his daughters, and a warrant had been issued for his apprehension. Sharp had been deputized to serve the warrant, and in the performance of this duty he, on the 14th inst., with a posse of men, Burnsville, for the purpose of arresting him.

COST AND PROFITS OF GUANO.--A correspondent of the Edinburgh Quarterly Journal of Agriculture, in allusion to the fact that the fixed price of guano has settled to $45 per ton, states that it is a curious coincidence that the returns of the crops manured with it amount to just about the cost of its application.

The Eleventh Ward. This Ward, extending from Rivington-street on the south, to Fourteenth-street, on the north, and from East River to Avenue B, contains probably 350 acres. Its population in 1850 was 43,772; at present, it is estimated at about 45,000, Of this, the foreigners amount to about 25.000.

Our readers probably remember that some weeks since, T. F. MEAGHER, Esq., the Irish patriot, made a speech at a dinner of the Meagher Guards, in which he referred to certain attempts that had been made to silence him in regard to Governor KOSSUTH and the principles of civil and religious liberty; and that he repelled with a good deal of indignation such attempts to restrict his freedom of opinion and of speech.

MURDER.--A horrible murder was committed on Thursday morning last on the person of HANNAH FRAZIER, a free colored woman residing about one mile from town on the Charlotte road. The body was discovered by a teamster, who traced it up from the blood which was sprinkled over the ground.

The high festival of a Presidential Inauguration is solemnly observed to-day. Washington was brimful of life last night, and all in eager expectation of the event, some from mere curious interest in stage effects, and others from anxiety to catch the first glimpse of the policy which the inauguration is to prelude.

From the Agriculture. Many instances have been cited of meanness, and several persons have been held up as examples, possessing that quality in the superlative degree. One of the most "eminent men" of this class that we ever knew was a "boss carpenter," who lived not far from Massachusetts.

AN EDITOR'S LIFE.--Some one published, about five years ago, in a New-York paper, the following description of the life an Editor leads: "As a general thing, the habits of the journalist are very regular; he being regularly employed till 2 o'clock in the morning, and rising at 10 o'clock the next day to breakfast on hard eggs and cold biscuit.

By the steamship Severn, Buenos Ayres dates of the 2d January had reached England. On New Year's day a revolution broke out, headed by the Minister of War. Governor ALEIM had resigned, and MANUEL PINTO had been elected Governor.

INVENTOR'S ASSOCIATION.--A meeting of the friends of the " Inventor's Association," was held on Wednesday evening, at No. 413 Broadway. Mr. WEN DELL WRIGHT was called to the Chair. Mr. CLINTON ROOSEVELT reported a Constitution and By-Laws for the government of the Association, which were adopted, with Flight modifications.

EXANDER DICKERSON, an old and experienced iron manufacturer, who has been several years in maturing this process, for which great advantages are claimed over the old methods;

The New-York Assay Office is a fixed fact, unless the General Appropriation bill fails entirely, of which there is at this hour much danger. The House is ruthlessly rejecting the Senate amendments, and the Senate insists that it will not yield its right to make important and necessary amendments, simply because it is so late in the session-the House having kept the Appropriation bills back for so long a period.

An acquaintance of ours, and, by-the-by, a very clever fellow, who has much oftener visited the theatre and concert room than the church, was persuaded by his wife last Sunday, the first time since their marriage, which occurred several years ago, to accompany her to St. John's Church.

The Albany Evening Journal publishes the following particulars of the State Charter Elections, more fully given than in our telegraphic summary: Buffalo--ELI COOK. Democratic Mayor, 700 majority. Rockester-JOAN WILLIAMS, Democratic Mayor, 1,200 majority.

The Democratic State Convention of Pennsylvania assembled at Harrisburg on Wednesday. The meetings were held in the Hall of the House of Representatives. Mr. JAMES, or Warren, moved that the President of the Convention be authorized to appoint a State Central Committee.

It is said that while the Legislature will support the Government, they have determined to act more independently in checking expenditures. Much speculation exists concerning a private audience given by the Emperor to the Russian Minister.

A THRIVING TOWN OF ST. CRISPIN.--A correspondent sends us the statistics of the boot making business in the town of Abington, Mass., which, he thinks, is fully equal to that of Milford, in the same State, lately referred to. He is unable to state, however, that his town is free from dandies and loafers, which is Milford's cardinal recommendation.

A TOUCH OF NATURE.--A car, full of passengers, recently passed over the Western Railroad, in which occurred a simple but touching scene, worthy of record. One of the passengers was a woman, carrying in her arms a child who annoyed every one by its petulance and cries. Mile after mile the passengers bore the infliction of its noise, which rather increased than diminished, until, at last, it became furious, and the passengers nearly so.

The riotous proceedings at Charlestown, caused by the alleged abduction of Miss COCHRAN, kept that city in a state of alarm nearly the whole of last night At 11 o'clock the mob gathered again to the number of some 200 or 300, forced the door of the Unitarian Church on Main-street, and rang an alarm of fire.

HUMAN FAT CANDLES AND SOAP,-When the Cemetery of the Innocents at Paris was removed to the outside of the barriers the buried corpses, which had accumulated to the depth of sixty feet, were found, to a great extent, apparently converted into fat.

In the House of Commons on Friday night, a discussion on the state of the rotations with France, was brought on by M. D'ISRAELI, and elicited strong assurances of peaceable intentions. The Navy Estimates, amounting to ?7,000,0 sterling were voted.
FEMALE PHYSICIANS.-- The number of female followers of ESCULAPIUS that have sprung up recently, is both astonishing and gratifying:

PRINTERS RISING IN THE WORLD.--It is gratifying to learn that our brother type of the For Smith Herald, JOHN F. WHEELER, Esq., has been elected Judge of the Probate Court of Sebastian County. We hope Judge WHEELER will bear his honors with meek ness, and discharge the duties of his distinguished station to the satisfaction and benefit of his constituents.
The Southern train which arrived at midday brought New-Orleans papers of Thursday, and two Charleston and Savannah malls. Col. SLOO, grantee of the new Tehuantepec contract, was at New Orleans.

Great crowds assembled at the depot this morning to see General PIERCE and his lady depart for Washington. Baltimore is thronged with strangers and military companies. Upwards of fifty car loads left for Washington this morning, and the trains will be crowded all day.

Domestic Items. The South Carolina Medical Association met lately and had a capital time of it. The toast to JOHN HEART, Esq., Editor of the Charleston Mercury, was not bad: "He compounds in his laboratory, the only preparation of Mercury which even Thompsonians are willing to take."

SUPREME COURT-- General Term--Before Judges EDWARDS, ROOSEVELT and MORRIS.--The In junction against the Section Avenue Railroad--Gerard Stuyvesant VS. Denton Pearsall and others, and the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the City of New-York.

That noisy, riotous, quarrelsome, industrious, good-humored mob, the Thirty-second Congress, is gathered to its thirty-one for bears. Are not its acts recited elsewhere in the Times ? A very few of them are of undoubted utility.

MY COUNTRYMEN: It is a relief to feel that no heart but my own can know the personal regret and bitter sorrow, over which I have been borne to a position, so suitable for others, rather than desirable to myself.

We are three students. We live together, and are fast friends. Thus, even with all our little care and annoyances, we lead the happiest life in the world. Our abode is in Patnam-square. You have probably never heard of the place--nevertheless we reside there--No. 19, five flights from the ground. It is rather high up, certainly, but attics have their advantages.

The following is a list of the acts and resolutions passed during the Second Session of the Thirty-second Congress : PUBLIC ACTS. An Act making further appropriations for the construction of roads in the Territory of Minnesota. Approved Jan. 7.

The lovers of universal peace are, just now, unusually active. Availing themselves of a brief Parliamentary recess in England, they have been urging the movement along by dint of speech and pamphlet, insisting chiefly upon the wisdom of international references and arbitrations, as conditions precedent to a declaration of hostilities.

THE "BALL" GAME.--Yesterday morning, a man called NED HAGGERTY was arrested by officers BEAM and SEAS, of the Third Ward Police, charged with obtaining $75 from a resident of the Buckeye State, named JAMES M. FLEMMING, by the "ball" game.

AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY.--The monthly meeting of the Board of Managers was held on Thursday, at 4 1/2 P. M., WILLIAM FORREST, Esq., presiding. Twelve new societies were recognised, of which three were in Ohio, three in Illinois, and in North Carolina, Alabama, Tennessee, Mississippi, Indiana, and Iowa, one each.

The five years passed have demonstrated the possibility of improving the physical, mental, and moral condition of idiots. Longer ago than that, there existed in France, Switzerland, Wurtemberg, Prussia, and Saxony, institutions devoted to their relief, which were abundantly successful.

At his residence, in Greenwich, Conn., on Friday morning, Blarch 4, Mr. EDMUND BANKS, in the 79th year of his age. The funeral will take place on Sunday, the 6th inst., at 3 1/2 o'clock P. M. On Thursday, March 3, EDWARD, youngest chill of Alfred A and Harrial W. Arment, aged 2 years and 10 months.

No class of the unfortunate claims a warmer sympathy than the Blind. Efforts for their relief have not been wanting, and with the increase of the class comes an addition to the means f imparting to them instruction and guidance.
One of the shrewdest stratagems of the late Cabinet campaign was that managed by the Southern "States' Rights" men, and resulting in the selection of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS for the War Department.

LADIES' STOCKINGS.--At a camp meeting a number of ladies continued standing on the benches, notwithstanding frequent hints from the minister to sit down. A reverend old gentleman noted for his good humor, rose and said: "I think if those ladies standing on the benches knew they had holes in their stockings they would sit down!" This address had the desired effect--there Was an immediate sinking into the seats.

HARD AND SOFT HANDS.--The Lily has the following: " LUCY STONE related an incident when here last Fall, which it will not be amiss to relate in this connexion: She entered a cabinet shop somewhere in Massachusetts, not long previous, and was surprised to see two women at work there,

The Muscatine Journal says :-- " Last evening, two responsible trustees of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, called on us and requested us to state that a certain sable divine, known as Rev. BAKER BROWN absconded yesterday morning, with about $120, belonging to the society in this place ; moreover, that there is evidence to prove him to be a drunkard, liar, adulturer, and vile imposter.

The meeting at Metropolitan Hall this evening, to take steps for an immediate and effectual Reform of the City Government,--one which shall give us permanent and reliable security against the evils from which we have hitherto suffered so much,--will, we trust, be largely attended.

Col. GEORGE NEWCOMB, the last of the original settlers of Dayton, O., died at that place on the 25th ult. He was the first Sheriff of the Country after its organization, afterward State Senator and Representative, and a man of probity and intelligence. He was a native of Ireland, and came to America in 1775, settling first in Delaware. He died at the advanced age of 82.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Last evening, ROSSINI'S opera, "The Barber of Seville," was repeated for the last time. The house was not so well filled as usual, in consequence, we imagine, of the severe snow storm. Mad. SONTAG was suffering from a slight hoarseness, but succeeded in rendering her role satisfactorily.

Another gathering in behalf of the multitudes of children in this City who are still destitute of the means of moral training, will be held tomorrow evening in the Mercer-street Presbyterian Church. Among the speakers who are expected to address the meeting, are Rev. Mr. STORRS, of Brooklyn, and Rev. Mr. WILLETS, of Philadelphia.

The following is the amendment establishing a United States Assay Office in this City. It was attached to the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation bill, which become law during the latter hours of Congress.

In addition to the items furnished by the telegraph concerning this riot, the following, from the Boston Journal of Thursday, will be found interesting: In consequence of the numerous rumors relative to the "missing girl," HANNAH CORCORAN, and by reason of placards calling a public meeting, to beheld in Richmond-street, Charlestown, at 7 o'clock last evening, considerable excitement had been created among a portion of the citizens both of Charlestown and this city.

A POP-CORN STORY.--Many of our lady readers have undoubtedly been called to the door by a corn doctor, who goes from house to house, about once a year, proferring his services, and exhibiting a large number of corns strung on a string and hung over his shoulder, as evidences of his skill.

The Times for California will be issued THIS MORNING at 9 o'clock, in ample season for the mails per steamship Georgia. It will contain a complete Summary of Domestic and Foreign Intelligence during the past fortnight; the Proceedings of Congress; Public Documents; Editorial Articles on current topics ; short News Items of interest from all parts of the United States; full Commercial Summaries,

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--The receipts on this road for the month of February, amounted to $13,547 28. The whole number of passengers for the same period of time, 14,181. For the corresponding month of last year, there were, total receipts, $11,946 14. Whole number of passengers during the same time were- 12,140; showing an increase in favor of February, 1853, over that of 1852, in receipts, $1,602 14, and in passengers, 2,041.

THE SICK MINISTER.--A venerable divine, who, in his time and generation, was remarkable for his primitive and abstinent mode of life, at length tell sick, and was visited by a kind hearted lady from a neighboring parish. On her proposing to make some beef tea, he inquired what it was; and being informed, he promised to drink it at his usual dinner hour.

The above is the title of a bill introduced into the Assembly, on notice, by Mr. RUSSELL SMITH, of this City. It has been read twice and referred to the Committee on Banks and Insurance Companies, reported favorable from said Committee, and committed to the Committee of the Whole.

An act of tardy and only partial justice this, obtained by the faithful pertinacity of Mr. FISH, and his colleagues in both Houses; and to them alone is the credit due. AN INGENIOUS REBUKE.--A general officer, who was in early life much addicted to profane oaths, dated his reformation from the memorable check he received from a Scotch clergyman. When be was lieutenant, and settled at Newcastle, he got involved in a brawl with some of the lowest class in the public street; and the altercation was carried on by both parties with abundance of impious language.

POLITENESS BETWEEN BROTHERS AND SISTERS.--By endeavoring to acquire a habit of politeness, it will soon become familiar, and sit on you with ease, if not with elegance. Let it never be forgotten that genuine politeness is a great fosterer of family love; it allays accidental irritation, by preventing harsh retorts and rude contradictions; it softens the boisterous, stimulates the indolent, suppresses selfishness, and by forming a habit of consideration for others, harmonises the whole.

SABBATH OBSERVANCE CONVENTION --A, meeting of this body was held on Thursday evening, in the, lecture room of Rev. Mr. WELLS' Church. The object of the meeting, was for the purpose of embodying an ad dress to His Honor 'Mayor BERRY, and his reply thereto.

The President's Inaugural is the exclusive topic of conversation. The opinion is almost universal, that it will make a favorable impression on the masses; although in some points it is not unobjectionable to careful criticism. Its chief merit is considered to be its distinct enunciation of the general policy of the Administration, so far as it goes.

THE MURDER OP JOHN McCARE IN WATER STREET-VERDICT OF THE JURY.--The investigation concerning the murder of JOHN McCABE, corner of Water and Oliver-streets, was resumed yesterday at the Fourth Ward Station House, before Coroner O'DONNELL and Jury.

LIQUOR LAW IN SWEDEN.--In Sweden, who-over is found drunk fined, for the first offence, $3; for the second, $6; for the third or fourth, imprisonment is added to the fine, and deprived of the right of voting at the elections, or holding office, and exposure to the church on Sunday.

THIRD POLICE DISTRICT.--ANDREW VAN OR DEN was elected, on Wednesday evening, Assistant Captain of the Third District Police, by the Board of Aldermen. Two weeks ago, JAMES McKINNEY was elected by the same body, to fill the same office, and he has never been removed by any action of the Board. There are, accordingly, three Assistant-Captains in this District, Instead of two-the number designated in the Charter.

A CHICKASAW NEWSPAPER.--We lean from the Fort Smith Herald, that an association of Chickasaw Indians intend to publish a weekly newspaper at Post Oak Grove, Chickasaw nation. The following is from the Prospectus: "It will be devoted to Science, Literature, Agriculture, Education, and the advancement of the Arts and Manufactures among the Chickasaws and other civilized tribes of the red race. As well as the news of the day.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT--WARNING TO PERSORS WALKING ON A RAILROAD TRACK.--On Thursday evening, while the New-Haven four o'clock passenger train of cars was coming over the Harlem Rail track, near upper Mott, Morrisanla, the engineer discovered a man walking on the track, with his back towards the train.

GENERAL REMARKS.--LEONARD MASCAL has commonly had the honor accorded him of having been the first to introduce the common or cultivated apple into England, about the year 1525; and such is the universal estimation in which t is not held, and such the degree of care bestowed upon its cultivation, wherever it is known, that it would be difficult to say whether its varieties should be numbered by hundreds or thousands.

The city is literally swarming to-day; and the railroad cars and steamboats are continually ad ding to the throng of people who desire office for themselves and friends, or who wish to be present at the Inauguration of General PIERCE.

The charges against him, involving a most extraordinary amount of moral turpitude, are as follows: 1. of receiving a bribe in the case of suit against COMSTOCK SANDENSON,

Measures have been taken in Philadelphia for the establishment of the Industrial Schools. An Industrial Union for the State of Pennsylvania has been formed; Prof. W. H. Allen, Girard College, President. It is proposed to institute a series of ragged schools, on week days and Sunday.

THE WRECK OF THE CHAMPION.--We had an interview, yesterday, with Mr. GRAVES, the only survivor of the crew of brig Champion, of the wreck of which vessel we have already published some particulars. We are informed by Mr. GRAVES, that she sprang aleak early Saturday morning, the 19th ult., Cape Henlopen bearing north, distance about forty miles, during a severe blow and thick snow storm.

The Inaugural of President PIERCE, in our columns this morning, will be read with interest and, we think, with general satisfaction. Its tone is manly, its style fresh, and its spirit eminently earnest and sincere.

ECONOMY.--At a late temperance meeting some where, Mr. KELLOGG, the Buckeye Orator, said, when the people of Bangor turned into the street several casks of wine and brandy, many stood and gazed upon the stream as it ran down and mingled with the waters of the Penobscot; some saying what a waste, and others rejoicing in its destruction.

By Col. A. C. Ramsey, Formerly of the United States Army. Communicated by Edward Ludlow, M. D., of this City, to the Medical Times for March. Interspersed among the native population of certain parts of Mexico, are to be found a class of Indians, in greater or less numbers, presenting characteristics so marked as at once to arrest the attention of the observer.

An amusing story is told of a recent interview between Col. BENTON and President PIERCE. The Colonel expressed himself heartily gratified at the result of the election, and very desirous to support the new Administration; but he told the President that he had one man in his Cabinet who would make him ridiculous-a " perfect nondescript, Sir," said he--" a perfect nondescript--neither one thing nor the other."

Gen. FRANKLIN PIERCE was yesterday inaugurated President of the United States. The ceremonies were attended by the usual display, and passed off satisfactorily. WHAT Is IT ?--The Toledo Blade says: Our friend JOHN G. KLINCK, Esq., of Richfield, exhibited to us on Saturday last a piece of tallow, moulded into the most perfect resemblance of the hand of an infant, with the wrist attached. It was covered with the usual skin that coats all untried or leaf tallow.

The Inauguration of President PIERCE took place at noon yesterday, with the appropriate ceremonies. The following dispatches were published in our Evening Editions of yesterday, and are given in the order in which-they were received Both Houses of Congress remained in session until 12 o'clock, when, by its own limitation, the Session terminated.

Never have we seen within the spacious walls of the Metropolitan, a more numerous and orderly meeting than assembled on Saturday evening, according to requisition, to adopt measures for securing an amendment in the Charter and effectually reforming our City Government.

The Royal Mail steamer Cambria reached Boston on Saturday morning, and her mails arrived at this City on Saturday night. A summary of her intelligence was received from Halifax and published in the Daily Times, of Friday morning last.

Ex-Gov. VROOM, of New-Jersey, has still further manifested his indisposition to share in the present degradation of his party. A commission had to be named the other day to draft amendments to the Constitution. As the head of the New-Jersey bar, Mr. VROOM, could hardly be omitted from the list.
The Royal Mail steamer Cambria reached Boston on Saturday morning, and her mails arrived at this City on Saturday night. A summary of her intelligence was published in the Daily Times on Friday last.

THE CRIMINAL COURT--MARCH TERM--PLENTY OF WORK FOR THE GRANC JURY.--The March Term of the Court of General Sessions commences this morning, at the Halls of Justice. The presiding Judge will be Hon. City Judge BEEBE, and his associates are to be Alderman JAMES M. BARD (Fourteenth Ward,) and Alderman DOHERTY, (Nineteenth Ward.)

FROM BATAVIA.--A letter dated Batavia, Dec. 29, states that there had been no less that nine failures during the month, among the Chinese merchants in that place. Two of the failures were considered the wealthiest and most substantial Chinese houses.

Among our foreign extracts this morning will be found a very interesting debate in the British House of Commons on the case of the MADIAI. We have copied those portions of the speeches which throw most light upon the facts involved; for the lack of authentic information has been seriously felt throughout the discussions to which the subject has given rise in this country.

LATE FROM HAYTI.--The bark Charles E. Lex, Captain HARPER, arrived at this port this morning, from Port-au-Prince, whence she sailed Feb. 15th. The country was very healthy, and except among the shipping, where the epidemic still raged fear fully, there was no prevalent sickness. The Emperor and his family were at the Southern Spring, where they were to remain three months, accompanied by the Imperial Court.

DISASTER TO THE CLIPPER-SHIP FLYING ARROW.--By the steamer Petrel, from St. Thomas, we have received intelligence that the clipper-ship Flying Arrow had put into St. Thomas, after a boisterous passage of twenty-five days from Boston.

Rumors have been in circulation in Paris, for some days past, of the probability of an alliance by treaty between France, England, and two or three minor States, with it vew to counterbalance the power of the North of Europe.

The London Advertiser announces the discovery of a very extensive and well organized conspiracy in Hungary against the Austrian rule. Italian letters say that there now circulates in Hungary a proclamation signed by, KOSSUTH, granting a general amnesty to all those persons who were formerly opposed to Hungarian independence. It appears that regular guerilla bands are forming all over the country, and that "things do not look well."

London Markets. Per Combria.] LONDON, Friday, Feb. 18--5 P. M. We have to notice great firmness in the Colonial at Foreign Produce markets, with continued good demand for INDIGO and WOOL, the public sales of which are proceeding with much animation.

On Sunday morning, March 6, ELIZABETH SHERWOOD, widow of the late Isaac Sherwood, aged 67 years. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral on Third day (Tuesday) afternoon, 8th inst., at 2 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 49, South 8th-st., Williamsburg.

A SERIOUS AFFRAY--ONE MAN STABBED.--On Saturday afternoon, officers ZIGLER and SHERWOOD, of the Seventeenth Ward, arrested two men, named THOMAS LARKIN and JOHN LARKIN, on a charge of violently assaulting MICHAEL RYAN, residing in Thirteenth-street, near First-avenue, inflicting a dangerous stab in his side.

The meeting at Metropolitan Hall on Saturday night, for the promotion of City Reform was without exception the largest, the most intelligent and the most influential demonstration of the kind we have ever seen.

The selection of Mr. GUTHRIE for this important post is not to be regarded with disfavor because he comes from the interior instead of the commercial seaboard. The rumor, noticed in some of the newspapers, that he was never before in Washington, is little or nothing against his qualifications.

ARRIVAL OF THE BRITISH STEAMSHIP CONWAY AT SAVANNAH.--The British steamship Conway arrived at Savannah on the 1st inst. from Navy Bay vid Jamaica, Inagua and Nassan, bringing eighteen passengers and the West India mails.

From Milan, under date 13th, we learn that Marshal RADETSKY had published a second proclamation in which he orders the Judicial authorities to sequestrate the property of those persons who shall render themselves directly or indirectly, accomplices in treasonable practices.

Nature is playing alternatives finely here--one day, sunshine--another, showers; but considering that it is Winter, we can submit cheerfully. Wet and dry form our chief inheritance down South--a sort of compromise between the two regions of the heavens, the upper and lower sky.

NAPOLEON'S address, announcing his marriage, is published in the Russian journals; but, in translation, is very ingeniously deprived of its sarcasm. The word parvenu, for instance, is translated "non-hereditary position," so that one of the most telling points in the speech reads, "I acknowledge my non-hereditary position before the whole of Europe!"--a very different meaning from that which NAPOLEON expressed.
The MONTAGUES and CAPULETS, while the truce lasted, were sore bested for an excuse to justify a recommencement of hostilities. France and Britain are in a similar category. There is no actual war.

The Baltimore Sun, of Saturday, gives some further particulars of the progress of the strike in that city: A very large meeting of the workingmen took Place last evening at the Temperance Temple. Among the contributions, was one of $250 from the Mechanics of the Washington Navy Yard.

Liverpool Markets. LIVERPOOL, Thursday, Feb. 22, 1853. PROVISIONS--Bacon keeps in steady request; but the expectation of imports from America makes curers more disposed to sell, and prices are, therefore, easier. Cheese brisk. In Beef or Pork no change--no arrival.

The London Morning Chronicle announces from its German correspondence, that hostilities had been resumed between the Turks and Montenegrins, and that a serious difficulty, if not a collision, has occurred between Austria and the Porte.
