The American mail steamer Baltic, Capt. COMSTOCK, arrived last night at about 10 o'clock, having left Liverpool on Wednesday, the 23d ult., at noon, and thus bringing news four days latter than that by the Cambria.

By way of New-Orleans, Galveston dates to the 25th and Indianola to the 24th February have been received. A tremendous gale took place at Galveston on the 22d inst., commencing about 3 A. M., from the northwest, moderating towards the evening. The Galveston News says: The large new store of Messrs. ST. CYR Co. had its metal roof partially blown off.

Not less than ten thousand strangers have left the city since the Inaugural ceremonies, and still our streets are thronged, and the hotels compelled to continue the colonizing system. Probably never in many years were there so many applicants for office at the Capitol as now.
In the resolutions read by you at the Reform meeting, held on Saturday last at Metropolitan Hall, were many valuable suggestions, and some may meet the end intended.

MR. MARCY.--The Premier is from our own City, He is a capable and experienced Statesman. His appointment was strenuously resisted, however, by the friends of the Hon. D. S. DICKINSON, who claim to have had majorities of all the representative organizations of the Democracy of the State in his fovor. He was opposed, also, by the VAN BURENS, who, after Gen. DIX, are said to have preferred even Mr. DICKINSON to Governor MARCY.

THREATENED DISTURBANCES AT SAN JUAN.--The New-Orleans Crescent of the 28th ult. has the following: We learn through private letters received by the house of W. L. CUSHING Co., of this city, that at the time the Pampero left San Juan, disturbances of a serious nature were threatened between the citizens of San Juan or Greytown, and the Vanderbilt Nicaragua Transit Company.

The trials are proceeding slowly, but surely, to the end proposed by Government. The name of the Conde MACURIGES given in my last, was in error by my informant, as that gentleman has not been implicated, as far as I can ascertain, by suspicion, in any movement.

The Senate met at 12 1/2 o'clock. The Journal was read, when Mr. FITCH corrected that part of it wherein it was stated that his colleague was present on Friday. His colleague had been called away by illness in his family.

The speech from the throne has been favorably received by the nation--minus the zealous opposition of the Republicans, Orleanists and Legitimists. It was posted at the Bourse immediately after its oral delivery at the Tuileries.

The Northampton Courier has a correspondent in Minnesota, a reverend and, if he is the man we suppose, a man of unimpeachable veracity, but what prodigious stories he tells of onions and squashes! "Cranberries, blackberries, strawberries, raspberries, whortleberries, plums, cherries, grapes, crab apples, gooseberries, black currants, black haws, rice and beans, all grow wild, and some of them in the greatest abundance.

MEETING FOR THE MAINE LAW.--A large meeting of the friends of Temperance is called, to be held this week in Wellwood Hall, for the purpose of determining upon measures to establish a Liquor Law in Jersey City, similar to that in the State of Maine, and to make such arrangements as may appear necessary to cause its full execution.

MR. PRESIDENT: I regard the propositions submitted by the Senators from Illinois (Mr. DOUGLAS) and Virginia (Mr. MASON) as synonymous. I think it requires no prophet to foresee that to suspend the duty on Railroad iron for three years, will be virtually to suspend it indefinitely--that is, to repeal it altogether.

GAMBLING.--A few weeks since we noticed the breaking up of a gambling crib for boys, by the First District Police, on the Heights. On Sunday night last, officers Fox, THOMPSON, CAIN and TOOLE, of the Third District, made a similar descent upon a house in which games of chance are played, in Hamilton-avenue near Columbia-street, kept by one O'NEIL.

The schooners Emeline Caroline from New York, for Philadelphia, and the Abby for the East ward in ballast, came ashore near Cape May on Friday night in a snow storm. The former vessel had on board the crew of the schooner Patriot which came in collision with the E. C. off Barnegat on Thursday night and sunk. The Abby has bilged and will be a total loss.

NORTH SIDE RAILROAD.--On the 4th inst., a large meeting was held at Huntington, Long Island, to lake into consideration the construction of a Railroad to pass from the terminus of the Flushing Road, at Flushing, through the principal towns on the northern side of the Island. ZOPHAR B. OAKLEY was called to the chair, and GEORGE H. SHEPARD, appointed Secretary.

The Milwaukee News says our Janesville friends have taken the railroad fever to such an extent that they have a railroad running through every man's farm in Rock County. A gentleman inquired the other day of one of the citizens if he knew of a farm for sale. "Yes," he replied, there's one yonder;" adding the customary recommendation, "only ten dollars an acre and railroad running right through it."

A journal in this City which enjoys a well-earned reputation for supplying news to order, and always with sovereign disregard to truth, has informed its readers that a fresh expedition to Cuba is a-foot.

The last English papers announce the decease of a number of distinguished personages. On the 11th ult., Major General ALLAN, C. B., died at his residence in Lansdown. Gon. ALLAN was first commissioned on the 31st December, 1794, and received the rank of Major General, Nov. 9, 1846.

I desire to call the attention of your readers to the approaching sale of this collection of works of the Old Masters, to take place at the Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia, on the 18th of March. RICHARD W. MEADE, to whose estate these paintings belong, was well known in Philadelphia, the place of his birth, and throughout the United States, from his commercial connections, and his residence abroad.

SUDDEN DEATH.--A young man residing in North Fourth-street, died suddenly about 4 o'clock on Sunday morning. It seems that he had been intoxicated on Wednesday morning, and although apparently in the enjoyment of good health, had been unable to sleep up to the time of his death. This should serve as another warning to drinkers.

The Telegraphic Convention were in session the greater part of to-day and transacted a variety of business. It adjourned finally this evening, to meet annually hereafter. During the day the members of the Convention waited on President PIERCE, and were respectfully and cordially received.

It has been announced as upon authority that copies of the Inaugural. Address of President PIERCE were entrusted to FRANCIS B. CUTTING, Esq., instead of the Postmaster, as hitherto, for simultaneous delivery to the several members of the New-York Press.

To Hon. Cornelius W. Lawrence, late Mayor of the City of New-York: SIR: Freedom of movement for persons and property, over sea and land, is the one economical doctrine in the development of social philosophy, and is forcing its way into the policy of civilized nations. Facility of movement is the prominent and successful aim of associated enterprise.

The extended details of South American news, given elsewhere in the Times, need explanation. The expulsion of General URQUIZA from Buenos Ayres, which occurred in September, was a victory of the Democratic party.

The Empire City, Capt. WINDLE, arrived at this port on Sunday from New-Orleans and Havana, bringing dates from the latter port to the 1st instant. We are indebted to Mr. CRAIG, Purser, for memoranda. The propellor Albatross was left in port at Havana, destitute of coal, and unable to procure a supply, very little being in port.

Mr. BEEKMAN reported favorably on the bill for the relief of real estate owners in New-York, on account of assessments. Mr. BEEKMAN gave notice of a bill relative to Commissioners of Deeds and Notaries in New York.

Now that the ministerial programme has under gone more rigid scrutiny, it has not gained ground in public favor; and the absence of the reform element, in regard to the representative system, is viewed with marked disapprobation by the "progressive" liberals.

In noticing the new Finance Minister of the Government, yesterday, incidental allusion was made to the condition of money affairs at the time of his accession, as being not altogether different from another eventful period in the financial history of the country. Perhaps it is as well to speak to this point with a little more plainness.

A few days ago we thought we had seen the skirts of the departing Winter. But this morning--the first day of General PIERCE'S administration--absit omen--we wake to a howling storm of wind and snow; the most terrible we have had yet. The gale comes from a Western quarter, sweeping the ground in the most brumal fashion, and the atmosphere is all one dreary flurry of snow-flakes.

The election of members of the Convention for revising the State constitution is now coming off. Considerable spirit prevails. There are five tickets in the field--the Whig, Democrat, Free-Soil, Citizens', and Union; the latter contains but one name.

Each branch of the Common Council last night appointed a special committee, to investigate the charges of bribery and corruption, which have been brought against members of that body. We cannot help thinking that this action on their part comes too late to be either grateful or useful.

ASSAULT AND MURDER AT HOLYOKE.--Last Sunday evening four men in the employ of the Glasgow Mills, at Hadley Falls, opposite Holyoke, were returning home from Holyoke, when they were brutally assaulted by seven unknown men, who were lying in wait for them by the way. The scene of the affray was on the Holyoke side of the river, above the village.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--On Saturday evening last a new farce was produced at this establishment. With unusual modesty the author describes his bantling as "an unaccountable mystery in two mistakes," entitled the "Dolphin of France, or have we a Bourbon among us."

News from Texas to the 24th of February, except the details of a great gale at Galveston, and a strange mortality in Polk County, is pleasant. Business lively, trade active, and the Supreme Court rid of that old-standing and tedious DELEON Claim, by an adverse decision.

Not a word of objection was made to the Cabinet confirmations to-day. It has been reported, for the last day or two, that DAVIS would decline, because of the strong language of the Inaugural, sustaining the Compromise.

NEW STEAMERS.--There are at present two Steamships fitting out at this port, for Australia. The City of Norfolk, late of the Richmond line, is preparing to leave soon, and, it is said, will go out under sails. The Golden Age, (known formerly as the San Francisco,) is receiving her Machinery at the Morgan Iron Works. She is expected to sail in May, stopping at Cape Town to take in coal.

Anarchy in Buenos Ayres. By way of England, we have received later dates from South America. The dates are from Rio Janeiro to the 13th January, Montevideo to the 5th, and Buenos Ayres to the 15th of the same month. The news has already been sketched in our foreign news per Cambria.

We are very glad to learn that Recorder TILLOU has determined to continue the investigation begun by the late Grand Jury, into the alleged corruption and misconduct of various members of the City Government.

The most prominent feature in the proceedings of the Board of Aldermen, last evening, was a vehement desire to establish a high tone of morals among the several members; to so conduct themselves as to appear blameless before all men, and to secure a character for integrity and honesty of purpose, which neither Judges nor Juries--Petty or Grand--should even dream of impeaching.

In Potsdon, March 1, MIRANDA R., daughter of Samuel Partridge, Esq., and wife of William L. Knowles, aged 33 years. On Monday, March 7, SANFORD C. BROWN, aged 29 years. Notice of the funeral will be given in the papers of tomorrow.

Mr. S. Campbell was returning to his home in Buffalo, about 10 o'clock Tuesday evening, when he was accosted by some six or seven rowdies, and after some words, he was seized by the collar of his coat from behind, and at the same moment one of the ruffians struck him two severe blows, one on the breast and the other on the arm.

The following letter may lead some who are obliged to minister to the necessities of persons afflicted with this loathsome disease, to perform the offices of humanity with less absurd fears for their own safety. Of course no one will be so fool-hardy as to venture into the midst of small-pox without all the advantages that come of the sufficient protection afforded by thorough vaccination.

HARVARD COLLEGE.--An adjourned meeting of the Board of Overseers of Harvard College, was held in the Senate Chamber, Thursday afternoon Gov. CLIFFORD in the Chair. The nomination of Rev. GEO. PUTNAM, D.D., of Roxbury, was then confirmed as a member of the corporation by a vote of 17 yeas to 5 nays.

The schooner Splendid went ashore about 7 o'clock, on the morning of the 4th inst., one mile South of Glades House, Cohasset, and must have struck on the Ledges, South of Minots Ledge, during the night, and hands are supposed to have perished, as two bodies were found on the beach next day. The schooner's log-book was found on

STEAMSHIP CASE.--The New-Orleans Delta of 25th ult, says: Suite was yesterday instituted in the Fifth district Court, by LEWIS U. NEAL, against the Vanderbilt line of steamers, for the recovery of $1,000 damages for breach of contract.

[Report concluded from the Times of Monday morning.] After the resolutions had been read, a gentleman near the platform offered an amendment to one of them, "that the police be elected by the people, for a term of three years--one-third of the force to be elected annually."

COLUMBIA COLLEGE.--The stated semi-an meal distribution of honors, accompanied by exercises in declamation, took place in the College Chapel yesterday. At an early hour the somewhat limited accommodations of the Chapel were taxed to their utmost, and when, at 10 1/2 o'clock, the appointed time, the President and Faculty, accompanied by the Trustees of the College, took their seats, little unoccupied space remained.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I notice, in a late number of your paper a few remarks relative to Hospital Tax imposed on seamen in the Merchant Service by the Government of the United States, in which you say, " Why the sailor

The Democrats have carried their nominee for Governor--NOAH MARTIN--by more than double the last year's majority. They have also elected all three of their candidates for Congress, defeating AMOS TUCK in the First District by a handsome majority. He was supported by the Whigs and Free Soilers.

Under this somewhat pompous title the NEW YORK TIMES of the 16th inst., proceeds to make the following remarks: We commence on our second page this morning the publication of a series of letters from the Southern States, which we commend to public attention. They to public attention. They are written by an intelligent

A correspondent, whose letter will be found on another page, takes exceptions to a brief notice we made, a while since, of the petitions presented to the United States Senate for the abolition of the tax of twenty cents on seamen's wages as Hospital money.

The people of Tampico and the military have pronounced for SANTA ANNA. The citizens resist the Government's proposition to restore the old tariff of duties....By an arrival at Providence, we have news from South Africa to the 4th of January. The British, in a severe fight had, with 1,000 men, routed 6,000 armed Basuto horsemen. The British loss was 38 killed, and near half as many wounded.

Dr. Allison has said that there is hardly an instance of a mason regularly employed in hewing stones in Edinburgh living free from phthisical symptons to the age of fifty. By way of prevention, it is recommended to work the stone damp, and ventilate the work sheds. Dr. Allison, too, recommends the Edinburgh hewers seriously to wear mustaches and beards, which are said to have been found in practice abroad, to act as respirators.

Mr. HENRY A. SCHOOLCRAFT is a good friend to the Aborigines. Their interests are the care of his life. He omits no opportunity to advance their claims, and especially to press forward his favorite scheme of Indian Colonization. In a letter lately addressed to the Editor of the Washington Union, based upon the bill passed by the House of Representative for the organization of Nebraska Territory, Mr. SCHOOLCRAFT renews his appeals.

The following list of Business Firms arc among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BROWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouses. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co,) 189 191 Water.

The oath of office having been administered to the members of the new Cabinet, they took charge of their several Departments at 11 o'clock this morning. The Democratic Senators caucused an hour this morning. They agreed upon an arrangement temporarily filling the vacancies in the Standing Committees, with a view to a thorough reorganization of the Committees at the commencement of the next session of Congress.

NIBLO'S GARDEN..--Madame SONTAG will appear this evening, in the Opera of "Maria diRohan." It has been some time in preparation, and will, we hope, be produced in a creditable manner. The season is drawing to a close, and it may be desirable to leave as favorable an impression behind as possible.

COLLEGE STUDIES.--The overseers of Cambridge University, (Harvard,) in their last report threw cold water on the scheme for which many modern educators are so zealous, of introducing elective studies into the academic course.

The Convention met, pursuant to adjournment, on Monday morning. The Committee on Resolutions reported on the following points, which were adopted in detail by the Convention. 1. All words in the body of a message should be count ed. Proper names, such as the names of persons, steamers, cities, , shall be counted as many words as there are capitals used in them.

By all means, gentlemen, when you advertise a house to let, or put a bill on its door post, be sure to name the price. Uncle Job wanted a little house for $250, and he travel $ Six days round about Brooklyn to find the prices of houses which he hoped might be furnished at that figure.

The President refers all applications for office to the Representative Departments, positively declining personal interviews on the subject. His rule is imperative, even when from such men as BUCHANAN they come with the strongest recommendations.

We have complained of the growth among us of luxurious tastes and habits. Gold-bearing countries yield so lavishly that it has required the entire devotion of our energies to expend the influx. We have seen, and accordingly said, that the extravagance of the times must tell banefully on the character of those who fall into the current of indulgence; and banefully on their fortunes, in the probable event of reaction.

The Virginia Legislature visited the caloric ship Ericsson, yesterday, at Acquia Oreek, sixty miles below Washington, pursuant to invitation. A handsome collation was provided them. Captain ERICSSON explained the principle and working of the engines. There was speech-making, and toasting, in which Captains ERICSSON and LOWBER, and Mr. KITCHING, were enthusiastically remembered. They acknowledged the compliment in suitable terms.

The Board of Aldermen have become thoroughly awakened to the necessity of making a gigantic effort toward steming the heavy tide of public opinion which now threatens-if it has not already succeeded-to sweep them from the standard and society of honest, upright men. It is to be regretted, as we have before said, that they should have delayed so important work for so long a time.

BRILLIANT RECEPTION OF MANHATTAN ENGINE COMPANY No. 8-TORCH-LIGHT PROCESSION.--The several Fire Companies turned out in large force, last evening, to receive the Manhattan Engine Company, on their return from Washington, where they represented the Fire-Department at the Inauguration.

Another session of the friends of the National University was held in Albany the last week. of February. The meeting was unanimous in sentiment and confident of success. The Committee appointed for the purpose re ported a Constitution for the Association, which document announces the object of the Association to be the promotion of the design to establish as early as practicable a great National University.

Thomas Connor, a very young man was on the first inst. sentenced to be hung in Baltimore, for the murder of Capt. William Hutchinson, on the 31st of October last. The Baltimore Sun gives the following account of the effect the sentence produced upon the prisoner: During the pronouncing of the sentence.
Last evening the train on the Buffalo and Rochester Road going out, ran into the rear car of the New-York City train coming in. The rear car was smashed, and several persons slightly injured.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE BY JUMPING OUT OF A WINDOW.--Yesterday morning, between 12 and 12 o'clock, a young man named WILLIAM LOVE, jumped out of the third story window of a house at the corner of Canal-street and Broadway, occupied by a woman named Mrs. FORRISTER.

The steamship Black Warrior, Capt. SHUFELDT, arrived at Mobile at 7 o'clock on Sunday morning, having left Havana on the evening of the 3d inst. A dispatch from Matanzas says that Mr. KING'S health has slightly improved-the climate being more congenial to him. His situation is nevertheless still considered very precarious.

We copy in another column an article from the Savannah Republican, concerning the series of Letters from the Southern States written by a special correspondent of the DAILY TIMES, and published in its columns from time to time.

By the bark Corsair, at this port from Mozambique, we have Cape Town papers to the 4th of January. The Cape Town mail to the 4th contains aacounts of a severe fight, in which 6,000 Basutos armed horsemen were routed by about 1,000 British.

Massachusetts is casting about to rid herself of a lot of lazy, shiftless fellows, who grow fat in her poor-houses, though perfectly able to earn a good living without State aid. She is about to adopt a new system of supporting her paupers.

Mr. CLARK introduced a bill to repeal the law relative to the recovery of debts against corporations. Mr. TABER] introduced a bill repealing the law authorizing Albany to loan its credit to the Susquehanna Railroad Co. The bill was passed relative to certain annuities due Indians residing west of Mississippi.

Mr. BENNETT reported, by bill, in relation to the abondonment of certain parts of the Great Western Turnpike Company. Mr. BRISTOL, by bill, favorably on the law to amend the act concerning the preservation of health. Mr. BEEKMAN, complete, the Union Cemetery bill.

The confirmation of General PIERCE's Cabinet to-day has solved many doubts which have been expressed within the last few days relative to the complexion it would assume at last. By the way, it is really amusing to the initiated to witness the erratic gambols of a Washington correspondent of one of your cotemporaries.

The Portsmouth Journal has seen a biscuit which was baked in May, 1793, and is consequently about 60 years old. It was one of the first batch prepared for the oven by Mr. Benjamin Carter, when an apprentice at Newburyport. It is nearly the size of the crackers now made, and they were sold at the time for half a copper each.

BOARD OF FOREIGN MISSIONS.--At the meeting of the Foreign Mission Society, on Monday, JASPER CORNING, Esq., took the Chair, Rev. W. WOOD opened the meeting with prayer. An account of the prevent condition of religion in Turkey was given at some length by Rev. WM. GOODELL, from which it appeared that professors of the Christian religion there suffered a great deal of persecution.

ALISON'S History has a great name; it covers a great deal of ground, and has a world-wide interest. It is a book you cannot read listlessly, or to kill an idle moment. ALISON is a High Conservative, with the ideas of one. Hence, you sit all alive over his work-full of that attention which a disposition to question and contradict usually excites.

SIR: In requesting you to publish the accompanying letter from JOHN MITCHEL, I do not intend to commit you to any one of its Sentiments. To the greater part of your readers these will probably appear altogether extravagant; yet I doubt if any of your readers will quarrel with you for presenting them with such a curious treat.

We have no mail south of Augusta, Ga, The National Intelligencer publishes a correspondence between Ex-President FILLMORE and his late Cabinet. The members of the Cabinet express their admiration of the untiring assiduity and devotion to the duties of his office exhibited by Mr. FILLMORE, and acknowledge the personal courtesy with which they were ever treated and the harmony that ever prevailed.

THE COMMITTEES. The following is a list of the Committees appointed. On Foreign Relations--Messrs. Mason, (Chairman, Douglas, Clayton, Norris, Everett. On Finance--Messrs. Hunter, (Chairman,) Bright, Pearce, Gwin, Badger. On Military Affairs--Messrs. Shields, (Chairman,) Borland, Dawson, Fitzpatrick, Jones of Tennossce. On Commerce--Messrs. Hamlin, (Chairman,) Soule, Seward, Dodge of Wisconsin, Benjamin. On Naval Affairs--Messrs. Gwin, (Chairman,) Mallory, Fish, Thomson of New-Jersey, Toombs.

From the St. Augustine Ancient City. We learn that the last season has been our of unexampled prosperity to the planters of our State. The great staple of East Florida is' Sea. Island, or Long Staple Cotton. The producing regions of this species of Cotton are confined to the Sea Islands, along the coast of Carolina, Georgia, and the Peninsula of Florida.

By the kindness of a friend we shall be enabled to publish three valuable letters written by JOHN ADAMS to his old friend and classmate, Judge DAVID SEWALL, Esq., of Maine. These latters have never been made public. They relate to legal and scientific matters and contain many facts of permanent interest. We give them in chronological order:

We understand that the present Grand Jury are in very great haste to get control of the investigation into the charges of corruption against the Common Council. Their object can be quite as easily imagined as described. The composition of this Grand Jury is a matter of general, and by no means complimentary discussion.

GENTLEMEN: Your kind note, which was handed me last evening, was as unexpected as it was gratifying. While I cannot flatter my self which the idea that I am justly entitled to all the praise which your friendship has s generously bestowed, I am frank to confess that I do feel a consciousness that I have spared no pains to merit it. Of this, however, you are the best judges.

From Christmas to New-Years' Day, the Slaves (except the house servants,) enjoy a freedom of labor; and Christmas is especially holiday, or Saturnalia, with them. The young ones began last night firing crackers, and I do not observe that they are engaged in any other amusement to-day; the older ones are generally getting drunk, and making business for the police.

The thirteenth lecture of the Peoples' Course was fully attended Tuesday evening. Hon. HORACE MANN was introduced, and warmly greeted by the audience. His subject was, "Great Britain--its Power, Resources, Talent ; its Poverty, Crime, Suffering; Causes, Admonitions," It was with no unkind feelings, he said, that he proposed to par-sue this subject.

THE NEW ARMORY.--We noticed last week that efforts were being made to have a new Armory for the military, erected in place of the old dilapidated building at the corner of Henry and Middaghstreets, now used for that purpose.

DEAR SIR: I have received your favor of the 21st, transmitting a copy of the resolutions of the Common Council of Buffalo of the l4th. I cordially concur with the resolutions in all that is said of the character of President FILLMORE, who has administered the Government,--for a part of the time under circumstances of extreme embarrassment and anxiety,--with unsurpassed discretion, ability and success.

None of the appointments referred to yesterday, except Mr. WASHINGTON'S, have yet been made. The report originated with a well-known Member of Congress. The Senate have confirmed SIDNEY WEBSTER, the President's Secretary, as a Commissioner for signing Land Patents. They have also confirmed several minor Consuls.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT AT THE SOUTH FERRY.--Last evening about 8 o'clock, a lady in attempting to leave one of the South Ferry boats, Brooklyn side, before properly secured to the bridge, made a misstep and fell between the boat and draw and was caught between the two, just below the arms, and crushed in a shocking manner, breaking her ribs and receiving such other injuries that it is thought impossible for her to recover.

CHILD CLAIMED BY TWO MOTHERS.--The infant left at Mr. AUGUSTUS'S house on Friday evening last, as mentioned in the Journal of Saturday, has been claimed by two mothers! It seems that a Mrs. DRAKE put her child to nurse in Stone ham, and on going for it some days afterwards, she was told that it had been sent into Boston, to betaken care of by a person who was to adopt it.

The attendance last evening at NIBLO'S Garden was by no means extraordinary. "Maria di Rohan," is an opera only tolerable when executed by a perfect company. It is not malicious to say, that the SONTAG troupe is scarcely up to the estimate. Excepting Madame herself, and BADIALI, (neither of them infallible,) the Company, Orchestra and Chorus, are of very moderate excellence.

Mr. BADGER read an article from a news paper printed in Wilmington, N. C., reflecting upon the conduct of himself and Mr. MANGUM for failing to obtain, or endeavoring to obtain an appropriation for the removal of an obstruction in Cape Fear River.

The bark Lady Suffolk reports that the ship Rocksburgh Castle, from Melbourne, Australia, for London, put into Cape Town on the 6th of January. She has on freight 8 tons of gold, valued at over Five Millions of Dollars, being the largest lot ever shipped from Australia

In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, March 9, JAMES AUGUSTUS, only son of James A. and Colin H. Requa, aged 1 year, 7 months and 16 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, from the residence of his parents, No. 206 Court-st., South Brooklyn, on Thursday. March 10, at 3 o'clock.

SIR: As our connection with you is about to terminate, we cannot forbear to give utterance to the feelings of unmingled satisfaction with which we look upon our official and personal intercourse. We have witnessed with admiration, your untiring devotion to the public service, and your patience and assiduity in the discharge of the incessant and laborious duties of your office.

ALLEGED FRAUDULENT OPERATION IN MERCER-STREET, IN THE FURNITURE LINE.-Yesterday forenoon, a female by the name of Miss BERTHA JURATZIK, appeared at the Second District Police Court, and preferred before Judge STUART a charge of false pretences against a real estate agent and furnisher of houses, whom she alleged has defrauded her out of several hundred dollars.

ASAEL HUNTINGTON, Whig, and a Whig Board of Aldermen, were elected in Salem yesterday. Two hundred and seventy-two towns have elected 140 Whigs and 223 Oppositionists as Delegates to the State Constitutional Convention.

Monday noon, while the workmen in Mr. RUSSEL'S Carpenter Shop, in South Seventh street, were absent to dinner, an attempt was made to fire the building, by igniting a pile of shavings in the rear part of the shop. Some persons in the vicinity discovered the smoke issuing from the building, and succeeded in extinguishing the flames.

By the arrival of the steamship Perseverance, at New-Orleans, we have received Galveston dates to the 1st inst. Mr. Tankersley is out in the Houston Telegraph of the 25th inst., in answer to Mr. BUCKNER H. PAYNE and the editor of the Austin State Gazette, who very plainly hinted that it was through Mr. TANKERSLEY'S intentional errors that the Opelousas and Texas Railroad bill was lost.

BAPTIST EDUCATIONAL CONVENTION.--A Convention of the Baptists of New-England is now in session in this city for the purpose of considering the question of advancing the standard of education in the denomination, and promoting the usefulness and capabilities of its educational institutions.

It is gratifying to know that Miss HANNAH of HONORA COCHRAN or CORCORAN, is again in the bosom of her family. The public solicitude is allayed. It is no longer necessary to burn down churches, and riot, and rave madly about the streets, by way of enforcing production of the absent maid.

A problem of singular difficulty, and every day growing more and more portentous--than which, if we except African Slavery, none is more difficult of solution--is rising in the distant West, before the American Government and people. Ere long they will have to grapple with it. Whether it can be peacefully solved, the future alone can tell.

FROM THE BRITISH PROVINCES.--We have files of New-Brunswick papers, but they contain little of interest. One of the St. John papers publish a dispatch from England, requesting, the Assembly to stay railway proceedings, as the British Government is going to take up the matter. Its authenticity is doubted.

The Lecture of Dr. MARSHALL HALL in the early afternoon of yesterday, at the Smithsonian Institution, gave great satisfaction to his intelligent audience, in which was included nearly the whole of the medical profession of our District cities.

We learn from the Montreal Herald that a public meeting has been held at Sorel, at which resolutions were passed expressing an opinion concerning the Harbor Bill opposed to the views of the Montreal Board of Trade, and more particularly to that part of their projected Harflor Bill which imposes a tonnage due upon vessels drawing less than 10 feet of water.

Mr. THACKERAY has written a preface to one of the volumes of his works, recently reprinted by the APPLETONS, in which the speaks of his visit to this country, his reception, the popularity of his books, , in terms which lead us to copy it--as follows:

WILLIAM L. MARCY, of New-York, to be Secretary of State of the United States. JAMES GUTHRIE, of Kentucky, to be Secretary of the Treasury of the United States. ROBERT McCLELLAND, of Michigan, to be Secretary of the Interior. JEFFERSON DAVIS, of Mississippi, to be Secretary of War.

Hon. NATHANIEL O. KELLOGG, of Vernon, is nominated for Lieutenant-Governor, by the Third Congressional District Convention, in place of THOMAS FITCH, who has declined. Hon. DANIEL O. TYLER, of Brooklyn, nominated as the Whig candidate for Congress.

SCHOOL BOARD.--The Board of Education have discharged the Committee appointed to consider and report the expediency of establishing Night Schools. At a meeting, held on Tuesday, the following resolution was adopted:

The Ball at this house last evening proved the crowning feature of the season. Although an impromptu affair, it was carried through with a decision, skill and good taste combined, entitled to much praise. The committee found themselves embarrassed, in an unexpected manner, by an attendance at least four times as great as they had, at outset, calculated upon.

FORTUNE-TELLER ARRESTED.--Mrs. T. A. FOWLER, residing at No, 160 West Eighteenth street, preferred a complaint against a Mrs. MONROE, as a fortune-teller, in the Second Police Court on Tuesday. On the 4th inst., Mrs. FOWLER had $115 stolen from her room, and went to the place of She accused, No. 251 Hudson-street, to consult her in relation to her loss, and was told that by paying $1 she could find out who stole the money.

LITERARY INTELLIGENCE.--JARED SPARKS IS about to bring out his "Revolutionary Correspondence" in three volumes. Mr. IRVING has been occupying himself with researches in the public offices in Washington for his "Personal Memoirs of the Father of his Country." FLETCHER WEBSTER is occupied with "Recollections of the Private Life and Conversations" of his illustrious father.

From the Southern Literary Messenger. The NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES has just commenced the publication of a series of Letters on the "Productions, Industry and Resources of the Slave States," which, we are told by the editor, are from the pen of "an intelligent gentleman," who is now travelling in the South for the purpose of informing himself as to the "character and condition" of the people.

ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD. --As the freight train of eighteen cars, and one passenger car, was passing about four miles north of Cold Spring, on the Hudson River Road, on yesterday morning, it came in contact with a large rock, three feet by two feet in size, which had tumbled on the track.

FROM NASSAU, N. P.--The Bahama Legislature met at Nassau on the 22d ult. The Message of the Governor presented a rather favorable view of the Colony. The Governor says he has entertained, and frequently expressed to the legislative bodies, an earnest desire to promote the advent to that Colony of valetudinarians, and their families, from Canada and the United States.

FROM VENEZUELA.-PUERTO CABELLO, FEB. 10, 1853.-Our Coffee market shows high figures, which is owing not only to the shortness of the crop, which will fall far short of the one of last year, but is also owing to the very heavy rains of late preventing the growers from drying the same

Senator JAMES has introduced a resolution into the Senate, authorizing inquiry into the fate of a citizen of Rhode Island imprisoned in Cuba. This is very well, though somewhat tardy. We wish some Senator would make the inquiry general, and ascertain the facts concerning various American citizens said to have been outraged in their rights and their persons by the Colonial Government Cuba.

Mr. CLAYTON' Speech to-day was generally admitted to be a perfect vindication, exposing the geographical blunders of his assailants and making his own action clear as noon-day. He speaks with as much fervor, ease and freshness as he did ten years ago.

Sometime since, the foreign papers brought us accounts of a new mode of shipbuilding, in which the timbers were dispensed with, and the whole vessel build of plank. The Peninsular and Oriental Company and launched a steamship at Gowes, constructed by Messrs.

Almost every morning, when the Editor of the-Magazine goes down town to his desk to read the papers and his letters, and correct his proofs, he funds, among the various epistles directed to his address, one rather more bulky than the rest carefully mailed in a while envelope, and superscribed in small and delicate handwriting. The Editor of the-Magazine that this is not a love-letter.

An arrival from Cape Town, Southern Africa, six days later news than we published Yesterday, reports that the war is quite as likely to continue for years, as to come to a speedy conclusion....In the Senate, Mr. CLAYTON concluded his remarks on the Central American treaties.

RESTORATION OF COM. AP C. JONES.--Among the on dits of the past week, was one that President FILLMORE had remitted the sentence of suspension passed by a Naval Court-Martial, about two years ago, on Commodore THOMAS AP C. JONES, of the Navy.

In the State Senate Mr. VANDERBILT, from the Select Committee on the subject of amending the Constitution's relations to the Canals, yesterday reported in behalf of the majority--Senators PIERCE and DAVENPORT not concurring.

Last week closed without any further exciting or pregnant events than those of the Tehuantepoc Treaty, and the firing into the steamer Black Warrior, which has afforded ample food for discourse among politicians and flibustiers. Since the arrival here of Col. SLOO, from Washington, he has been besieged by all sorts and conditions of men, eager to obtain contracts of every nature, or employment of some kind on the road.

The Albany Journal says the fall of snow which occurred at Syracuse on the morning of the 3d instant, deserves special notice. It commenced at 3 o'clock in the morning, and at 7 o'clock, two feet of snow had accumulated, being at the rate of six inches per hour! We do not believe the records of meteorology will furnish any parallel to this.

M. AMPERE, the learned and distinguished French Traveler, has commenced in the Revue des deux Mondes a series of articles upon the United States, giving the result of his travels and observations in this country. His position and ability will render his remarks specially interesting and influential: and our readers will probably be glad to see a notice of some of the most prominent points in his first article. He begins his narrative thus :

REPORTS. Mr. CONGER, by bill, to amend the School act so as to provide for the establishment of union free schools. Mr. PLATT, favorably, on the bill to incorporate the Albany and New-Baltimore Ship Canal Company. Mr. WARD, by bill, to provide for the location of the Court House in Queens Co.

Mr. VANDERBILT, from the Committee to which the said resolution was referred, reports: Inasmuch as said resolution was referred to a Committee, in order that the same might be in the first instance considered by them, a better and more ample opportunity has been afforded freely and calmly to consider the principles involved in the plan submitted, and to decide on the details embraced therein.

There are hosts of doctors in the world,- once in a while we hear of a spot where they are needed. The Australians sent over a Macedonian cry for physicians to come over and medicate them, and the young meds, have flocked out nobly in response to the call.

MY DEAR SIR: I received on yesterday your favor of the 1st inst., advising me that a final judgment had been perfected in my favor, on the whole of the Fire Suits, commenced and carried on against me during the last six years.

Literary,--Review of Sir ARCHIBALD ADISON'S History of Europe. Student Chronicles: No. 1--Our Menage. The South,--Letters on the Productions, Indus try and Resources of the Slave States: No. IV. By the Special Correspondent of the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES.
The mechanics at BENSON'S and REEDER'S establishments have gone to work at fifteen per cent...advance. Ross WINANS, MURRAY and HAZLEHURST, and DENMEAD still hold out.

A State Temperance Convention of the friends of the. liquor law of 1852 is now in session at the Melodeon. JULIUS A. PALMER was chosen President, assisted by thirteen Vice-Presidents. Among the latter is Capt. F. JONES, of the U. S. Navy. who appeared in behalf of seamen.

The Ohio House of Representatives on Saturday was the scene of ruffianism on the part of one of its officers. Mr. Barnum, one of the members from the Cleveland District, and a member of the same political party with the Medarys, had charge of a bill which was ordered to be engrossed some weeks ago.
The returns from New-Hampshire are sufficient to indicate the reelection of Gov. MARTIN by a largely increased majority, and the choice of a Democrat to Congress from each district.

The Mobile Advertiser says, at a recent playing of "Romeo and Juliet," in that place, Tybalt, after being stabbed, fell in such an awkward position as to be compelled, after death, to turn, twist, and roll over, in order to get out of the way of the shifting scenes.

On Wednesday, March 9 GEORGE COLYER, eldest son of George and Rebecca Colyer, aged 9 years, 6 months and 20 days. He had just returned from school and was Playing in a timber yard near his father's residence, While

There is no opposition half so effectual as that which takes the shape of professed friend ship. It allays suspicion and under cover of good intentions, does infinitely more mischief than an open, manly hostility.
Our special dispatch from Washington notices a rumor that Mr. CHARLES EAMES is to be Assistant Secretary of State. Mr. E. is now engaged on the Washington Union.

Our County Circuit is being held this week by Judge STRONG. The trial of JOHN F: DE WICK, for the murder of his father, at Comac, occupied two days. The competency of one of the jurors in that case was tried by the two jurors first called as triers; after the counsel and Court had addressed the triers, the triers could not agree on their verdict.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I send you the Report of the New-York Juvenile Asylum, by which you will be pleased to learn that the $50,000 required by the act of incorporation has been contributed, and the Board of Supervisors have appropriated a like sum, making $100,000, to be expended on a location and buildings.

Buried in hidden depths of greenery.-Leigh Hunt. Will our friends have some consideration ? Our Green Bag, we acknowledge it, is large. There must be, at least, twenty-three yards of baize (ell width) in it.
Our private advices from Albany look to the passage of the Railroad Consolidation, and the probable defeat of the new Banking basis, as proposed in the Assembly.

By the arrival of the Lady Suffolk from Cape Good Hope, we have received dates from Port Philip to the 15th November, which though not so late as those recently received by the way of South America, bring some news of interest.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,).No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

THE FIRE AT SOUTH WORCESTER.--The Worcester Transcript gives the following additional particulars of the fire at South Worcester on Monday night: "The factory buildings and boarding house were the property of Messrs. JONAS BARTLETT and JOHN WARDEN.

MY DEAR SIR: Your letter is strictly correct as to details, in reference to the particular proceedings in the New-York fire causes, in which you were engaged. It falls very far short of conveying any adequate impression of the importance of the professional services performed by you, or of the value of those services.
Very little news to detain you with this morning, good reader. You may finish what we have to say in this department and take an extra cup of coffee without being at all belated at your business.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Foreign advices have twice mentioned the surrender of the above articles by the late Bishop IVES to the Bishop of Rome. Before the matter is for gotten permit me to show the fancifulness of the proceeding.

The Annual Report of the State Prison Inspectors, shows that the whole number of convicts in our State prisons on December 1, 1852, was 1,843; 129 more than one year ago. Of these, 924 were at Sing Sing, 752 at Auburn, and 167 at Clinton.
We have dates from Bathurst, West Coast of Africa, to the 3d ult. The U. S. ship John Adams sailed from Bathurst on the afternoon of Jan. 15, 1853, for Sierra Leone, having visited Goree.

The ship Banshee, from Rio, Jan. 22, arrived here this morning, bringing 6,000 bags of coffee. Sailed in company with the bark Neptune, for Salem. Left at Rio, steamship John L. Stephens, Capt. PEARSON, from New-York for California, to leave soon; ships Golden Eagle, from Boston for California, put in, in distress; Narragansett, from New-York for California, to sail in a few days.

The Select Committee of the House of Delegates of Maryland, to whom was referred a memorial from the descendants of the Nanticoke Indians, one of the aboriginal tribes of Maryland, have, through their Chairman, Mr. William A. Stewart, submitted an interesting report, exhibiting consider able research into the history of this once numerous but now almost extinct tribe.

COAL FOR THE JAPAN SQUADRON. Mr. COOPER offered a resolution calling for the contract entered into with HOWLAND ASPINWALL for supplying the Japan squadron with coal, the price per ton when delivered in the Chineseseas, the commissions, , with all the particulars.

DEAR SIR: I have received your favor of the 24th, and it revived or restored many of the sensations of my youth. The last trial before a Special Court of Vice Admiralty in Boston, before the Revolution, was of ANSEL NICHOLSON, for Piracy and Murder on the high seas.

THE DIFFERENCE.--The Fitchburg Reveille has an anecdote of Judge MERRICK, in a case some years since, growing out of the Fifteen Gallon Law. A lawyer was arguing against the constitutionality and expediency of the law, when the Judge intimated that he could not hear an argument so absurd.

MEETING OF EXEMPT FIREMEN.--The exempt Firemen of this City held a meeting at Firemen's Hall, in Henry-street, last Wednesday evening, to take the preliminary steps towards organizing them selves into a Society similar to others now in existence in some of the principal cities of the United States-for benevolent purposes.

GEOLOGY OF MASSACHUSETTS.--A report from President EDWARD HITCHCOCK, under the resolve of the last Legislature authorizing him to make some new surveys, has been laid before the Legislature of Massachusetts.

FROM RIO JANEIRO.--By the arrival of the bark Hazard at New-Orleans, from Rio de Janeiro, the New-Orleans Bulletin learns that the ship Augusta, from New-York for Australia, arrived in December, with 120 passengers, in a leaky condition.

We know no sight more pitiable than that of a great public interest, like our State Canals, made the foot-ball of political parties. And yet the State of New-York has furnished this disgraceful spectacle for the past ten years.

LAUNCH OF THE STEAM YACHT NORTH STAR. -The announcement that VANDERBILT'S mammoth steam yacht North Star would be launched from Mr. SIMONSON'S yard, yesterday morning, drew together a large number of persons, who had an opportunity of viewing her on the stocks for about one hour and a half after the time she was to have moved off.
Europe seems reposing in a state of profoundest peace. The muttered discontent of the nations is smothered by the power of the oppressors, and scarce a murmur is to be heard.
Ex-Governor WILLIAMS, of Maine, was found dead in his bed at Portland on Thursday morning. Mr. AMOS CRANDALL, for several years a shipbuilder in Bristol, expired suddenly on Thursday week.

The report noticed in a Washington letter, in the Express, that Collector MAXWELL has been sued by the Surveyor and Naval Officer for a large sum on a claim to one-half the penalties recovered on irregular importations for the past four years, may be true, but nothing is known on the subject at the Trust Company, where the Collector is said to have deposited $60,000, to await the issue of the suit.

PETITIONS PRESENTED AND REFERRED. Mr. COOLEY presented a petition of three citizens of New-York against the law relating to ecclesiastical devises. Mr. McMURRAY, of the Common Council of New-York for an increase in the number of Commissioners of Deeds.

This morning about three hundred and fifty hands, employed in the machine shop, struck for "ten hours." Last week several meetings were held and resolutions passed expressive of their de termination to cease work unless their employers should accede to their proposition of reducing the hours of labor to ten.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: My computation of interest was published without explanatory remarks. I did not deem them necessary,--supposing a ready perception on the part of those acquainted with such matters, by reason of its simplicity.

A large delegation from the Maryland Institute, Baltimore, visited the Mechanics' Exhibition to-day by invitation. They were received by a Committee of the Metropolitan Institute, and hospitably entertained.

In the new code of Alabama, soon to go into use, occur the following paragraphs in relation to slaves: 1. No master, owner or everseer must allow any slaves of which he has charge, to hire his own time or go at large, under a penalty of not less than twenty nor more than one hundred dollars.

A meeting of a number of our wealthy and influential merchants, was held at the Revere House this evening, to consider the expediency of aiding in the building of the Prescott and Baytown Rail road, to connect with the line of the Ogdensburg Road. Mayor SEAVER presided.

The Aldermanic Contempt. SUPERIOR COURT.--Before Judge DUER.- Sitting at Special Term.--In re The Broadway Rail road--The People ex rel. Davis and Palmer vs. Oscar W. Sturtevant and others.--After considerable delay, Mr. Hilton, attorney for the relators, produced the report of the Referee, Hon. William Kent, and read it to the Judge.

DAVID CROCKETT.--An anecdote is related of this remarkable man which does him infinitely more honor than any office he ever hold. Before he was a candidate for Congress, or expected to be, there was a season of scarcity in the Western District, where he lived.

The manner in which I executed the important trusts of Counsel to the Corporation, confided to me by your suffrages, has been made the subject of several articles; first published in the Journal of Commerce, and subsequently reissued in a pamphlet form under the imposing title of "A Series of Unanswered and Unanswerable Editorials."

It was rumored yesterday that Mr. SCHUYLER LIVINGSTON had been appointed Collector of this Port. There has been as yet no confirmation of the report from Washing ton, though it is stated that the offer of the place was received by Mr. L., in a letter from the President.
FROM THE CAPE OF GOOD HOPE.--The bark Lady Suffolk arrived at this port this morning, from Cape Town, with dates to Jan. 10, being five days later than the advices received at Providence.
From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. The following letter, addressed by Mr. FILL MORE to Mr. BARTON, late Mayor of the City, has been handed us for publication: WASHINGTON, Friday, March 4, 1853.
Issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending March 8, 1853, and bearing date March 8, 1853. Seth Adams, of Boston, Mass.--For improvent in printing presses.
CLAYTON will reply to DOUGLAS'S speech of to-day. Democratic Senators admit that C.'s de fence is complete. The Senate will sit two weeks yet at least, unless it throws over the pending treaties.

We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a statement of the expenses in detail of the City Government during the last year,--not giving by any means the whole of those details, but enough of them to show the reckless lack of economy by which our financial Administration has been distinguished.

A horrible murder was discovered this morning, in a house in Federal above Seventh-street. Two women, named HANNAH SHAW and ELLEN LYNCH were found lying weltering in their blood, in the front parlor; the latter in her night clothes.

DISPENSARY.--At a meeting of the Trustees of the Williamsburg Dispensary, Thursday evening, the following report was submitted by Dr. HARDCASTLE: The whole number of patients treated during the month of February was 328, viz.: Patients treated at the Dispensary, 294; at their houses, 23; vaccinated, 11, Of these there 124 males, and 204 females.

The first decision under the new Steamboat law, has been made at Cincinnati, in the case of the collision between the steamers Falls City and the Pittsburg. The regulations requiring the "ringing of the bells and blowing the whistles at intervals of two minutes, when running in a fog," were not complied with. The pilots of both boats have been suspended for ten days.

Notice is hereby given that the 5 per cent. stock created under the provisions of the act of 3d March 1843, will, in pursuance of the terms of its issue, be redeemed at the Treasury of the United States on the 1st day of July next, at which date interest thereon will cease.

SERIOUS DISTURBANCE.--Yesterday, soon after the packet ship Queen of the West arrived at her wharf, East River, with several hundred emigrant passengers, a serious disturbance commenced among cartmen, runners, and others.

A letter from Rio Janeiro says that the bark Alabama, of and from Baltimore, had sunk at sea, and the Captain and crew had arrived at St. Catharines. Rain at Rio was incessant, retarding the arrival of coffee.

The Eclectic has a capital translation of an article from the Revue de Deux Mondes, on the "Press in the Nineteenth Century." As giving a scholarly and philosophic estimate of English literature, as viewed through French spectacles, it will gratify the reader.

Literary.--Review of Sir ARCHIBALD ALISON'S History of Europe. Student Chronicles: No. 1--Our Menage. The South.--Letters on the Productions, Industry and Resources of the Slave States: No. IV. By the Special Correspondent of the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES.
Mr. ZENAS WELLS, formerly keeper of the Verandah House in Philadelphia, and of the Mount Vernon House at Cape May, was found dead in a chaise, on the 6th, which he had engaged to take him home.

The American Bible Society has commenced issuing the new edition of the Scriptures, as revised by the Committee on Versions. Many misprints have occurred in the former issues, and the revision of these errors was some time since confided to a Committee, whose labors here begin to show fruits.
The general principles upon which appointments are to be made have been definitely settled from the commencement of the Administration.

DEATH OF A PHILANTHROPIST.--The sudden death of JOHN B. GRAHAM, announced yesterday, cast a general gloom over the city. Of late he had been enjoying his usual health, with the exception of one day (Wednesday) of this week. He was advised to remain within his house, and not expose himself to the inclement weather.

About six o'clock in the forenoon of yesterday the fire bells commenced ringing, and a great blaze lit up the horizon. Our eager firemen immediately rushed up Tchoupitoules-street, and in a short time it was announced that an important cotton press was on fire.

"Let him who thinketh he standeth take heed lest he fall." As I heard this pregnant text read by my Rector last Sunday, I little thought that before another week should roll away, myself would stand an example of its sublime truth.

An interesting Archaelogical item is found in the discovery of antique monuments in that part of Naples known as Paglia,--the ancient Magna Graecia. A subterranean necropolis, nearly entire, has been opened by the Cavalier CARLO BORUCOI, who has been for twenty-five years the Director-General of antiquities and excavations in the kingdom.

If Senator PEARCE will visit these whereabouts we will show him "the man who has read three volumes of the 'Natural History of the State,'" and will engage to read the set whenever he can get hold of them. The Documentary History, too, has had several readers in this latitude, and would have more if the copies were plentier.

The result of observations made at Charleston, during the sinking of the Artesian Well, now in course of construction in that city, is in accordance with that of similar undertakings in Europe; proving that there is a very obvious increase of temperature in the crust of the earth, the deeper we descend.

The outstanding Canal Certificates, about $1,460,000 of which are held by the Bank Department in trust for the Free Bankers, will virtually pass into the permanent Canal Enlargement Loan, should Mr. VANDERBILT'S proposition go before the People as an amendment to the Constitution.

Secretary MARCY has communicated the pleasing intelligence to the clerks of the State Department, that none of them will be removed who have discharged faithfully their duties. The office seekers complain bitterly of this.

COLLEGE OF PHYSICIANS AND SURGEONS--ANNUAL COMMENCEMENT.--The Annual Commencement of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of the University of the State of New-York was held Thursday evening in the College Hall, Crosby-street.

Dr. NORWOOD has made his first Report to the General Assembly of Illinois upon the Geological Survey of that State. Two thousand copies of the document were ordered to be printed, but we rely. for our items upon the newspaper accounts.

According to the Report of the Land Agent of Maine, the sales which have been made in prosecution of the policy resolved on by the last Legislature, consist of the undivided half of forty townships, held jointly with Massachusetts.

MY LIFE AND ACTS IN HUNGARY IN THE YEARS 1848 AND 1849.--By ARTHUR GORGEI: Harper Brothers. This book deserves a careful consideration. It is by far the most important contribution which has been made to the history of the Hungarian struggle, and we can look for no other of equal value.

The Tax Bill urged by the Barnburners in the Assembly is not called for by the wants of the General Fund of the State Treasury. This is made clear by official and semi-official figures published by the Evening Journal. The current wants are $811,835.

Prof. BOND, of Cambridge University, states that a comet was discovered on the evening of the 8th, at the Observatory of Harvard College, by Charles W. Tuttle, assistant at the Observatory. It was situated about 5 deg. South, preceding the bright star Rigel.

New-Orleans contests with New-York the palm for supremacy as a miserably ruled city. The Courier says: " This is now, and long has been, the worst governed city in the world. Officials, and their confidants and satellites, thrive. The property holder grows poorer.

In a discussion which arose in the Board of Aldermen, last evening, relative to several resolutions presented for the removal of nuisances, Alderman DENMAN said, "If the nuisances are simply heaps of dirt, we have nothing to do with them."

A distinct class among themselves are these boys. They eat and sleep, and make their living, and amuse themselves, in their own way, perfectly independent of the world, so long as the world will buy their papers.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your article of the 9th inst., under the above caption, deserves the hearty Amen of the wealth and energy of this great City. In common with thousands, I thank you for it. The taxpayers of New-York, waking up to a sense of corruption of their municipal Government, have done some things well.

The average daily consumption of Cochituate Water in Boston for the past week has been 3,125,060 gallons, or nearly 60 gallons to each inhabitant, which shows a great waste. The number of water-takers is 16,862, an increase of 786 over last year. The total receipts of all kinds for the year, including the sale of about $8,000 worth of property, will be about $200,000. Last year $179,486.

From the Boston Atlas. We have already called attention to the rumors, with regard to the correctness of which no doubt is entertained, that the Senate of the United States have now under their consideration an International Copyright Treaty.

The Lily, dilating on the prospects of the "dress reform," says that "there is hope for our faint-hearted, fashion-led women; for we see it stated that the new French Emperor has directed a change in court costume, and that the ladies are to wear short skirts, coats and vests, but no pantaloons.

The Royal Society was lately entertained by Capt. DENHAM, R. N. of H. B. M. ship Herald, with an account of his experiences in Deep-Sea Soundings. The expedition under Capt. DENHAM was particularly directed to observe soundings, and it was very successful.

In the Criminal Court, the case of the United States versus GEO. A. GARDINER, indicted for false swearing, in order to obtain an award from the late Mexican Board of Commissioners, was taken up to-day. District-Attorney FENDALL, and HENRY MAY, of Baltimore, appeared for the United States, and Jos. H. BRADLEY and JAMES M. CARLISLE, of this City, and B. F. PERRY, of South Carolina, for defendant.
The Union publishes an official notice by the Secretary of the Treasury, that the 5 per cent. stock of 1853 will be redeemed on the 1st of July, and interest will cease after that day.

Suddenly, on Friday morning, of congestion of the Jungs, H. M. HAYES, Esq., for many years a merchant in this city. His remains will be taken to Boston for interment. On Thursday afternoon, ARTHUR MONTGOMERY, youngest Child of W. R. Vermilye, aged 4 years.
Mr. COOLEY reported for the consideration of the Senate a bill enlarging the basis of Bank circulation. Mr. MORGAN reported favorably on the bill to supply Brooklyn with water.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR--Being attracted by the advertisement of Hon. HORACE MANN'S lecture, as announced in your columns yesterday, I was, on several accounts, induced to attend, not the least being my desire, as an Englishman, to hear what such a popular lecturer would say of a country he must be conversant with from travel, and knowledge acquired from an extended residence there.

The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLINS, from Havana and Key West, 8th inst., has arrived at this port. Private letters dated Havana, March 7, say that up to the present it is not known what will be the fate of the political prisoners, as the Government is either undecided or desirous to keep its intentions a profound secret up to the last. Much anxiety is felt by the Cubans, and the worst is feared.

The following items from the Appendix to Controller FLAGG'S excellent Report just published, will enable our citizens to understand how the City Government manage to get rid of so large an amount of the public money.

The steamship Africa, now in her fifteenth day out, has not yet arrived. A dispatch dated 10 1/2 last evening, says no signs of her had appeared at the Highlands of the Nevisink up to that hour. Four days later intelligence from Cuba.

A Banker residing in one of the interior cities of the State, hearing of the sudden change in and pressure for money in New-York, writes as follows: "I don't believe the real time for everything to be knocked over has come yet.

These are great times for the goldsmiths. Almost every gentleman who has had the honor of serving the public for a few years past, and who is now constrained to vacate, receives a service of plate, either from his admiring fellow-citizens or from the sub-ordinates who have been blessed with the privilege of serving under him.
An anonymous correspondent writes in deprecation of the censure and distrust we have expressed of the Court of Sessions and the Grand Jury, in regard to the charges alleged against the Aldermen.

FORGERY ON THE NASSAU BANK.--Yesterday evening, a man was arrested by officers KEEFE and WATLING, of the Chief's Office, charged with forging a check, on the Nassau Bank, for the sum of $200, It appears the prisoner was formerly employed at MENDELL'S Exchange Office, under the Howard House, Broadway, as clerk.

The Hamburg Borsenhalle, learns from Athens, 28th ult., that the house of ROTHSCHILD has offered, under certain conditions, to advance the Government a sum, at 9 per cent., to establish a Mortgage Bank. A Commissioner is appointed to consider the proposal.

From the London Times. Among the indirect consequences of the repeal of he Corn Laws, must be reckoned the rapid augmentation of our commercial intercourse with countries which had, before that event, comparatively little produce to send to our markets, and the increased political interest with which we naturally regard States and territories that are henceforth to supply a large portion of the food of the English people.

The Aldermen for Contempt-Sentence of Fine and Imprisonment. SUPERIOR COURT--Special Term--Before Judges DUER, BOSWORTH, PAYNE and EMMETT.--There was a large crowd in attendance on Saturday morning, long before the hour (11 o'clock) appointed for the delivery of the sentence of the Court.

Since 1 o'clock to-day, the city has been in a state of great excitement, and it would be difficult to say whether the attempt upon the life of the Emperor has caused greater consternation or disgust. The electric wire has already made known to your readers, that FRANCIS JOSEPH of Austria has providentially escaped the assassin's knife.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday last, are to hand, but contain no news of interest. Mrs. PIERCE is still in Baltimore, tolerably well in health, but her spirits are still much depressed. The President returned to Washington yesterday afternoon.

DEATH ON SHIP-BOARD BY INHALING CHAR COAL GAS.-Yesterday forenoon, information was received at the Coroner's office that a man was found lying dead in the cabin of the Bremen ship F. J. Wichelhausen, lying at Pier No. 10, East River.

From the Washington Union. Some of the western and eastern papers contained not long ago the intelligence: "Governor UJHAZY having abandoned his former residence at New Buda, Iowa, himself and family and some of his countrymen set out for Texas, as the place of their future habitation."

To the Editor of the London Times. SIR: I notice in the Times of this morning that four Hon. members have been unseated on the plea of "bribery and corruption." That is indeed a melancholy notice. I do not take time to inquire whether they are Whigs or Radicals, or Tories, as politics have very little to do with the few words I have to say.

The schooner Charles Pearson, arrived this morning, from Honduras. She reports that great excitement prevailed on the Island, in consequence of her British Majesty's war steamer Devastation, having anchored off Toupillo, and demanded the surrender of the place in the name of the Mosquito King.

The numerously signed petitions from this City for the suppression of banking on Wild Cat money have been promptly responded to by the Bank Committee of the Assembly. The bill reported by Mr. RUSSEL SMITH, their Chairman, will be found in another column.

The following resolutions were passed at the meeting of Boston merchants, at the Revere House, on Wednesday evening: Resolved, As the sense of this meeting, that the Canada trade is of great commercial importance to Boston, and no locality in that extensive rich country is more so than the great Ottawa Valley; and that the merchants of this city ought therefore to use all honorable efforts to increase their connection therewith.

The proceedings in Parliament have not possessed much interest. On Tuesday, Sir J. PAKINGTON gave notice of his intention to move on the motion for the second reading of the Clergy Reserve (Canada) Bill, that it be-read that day six months.
