The ship Atalanta is still on Romer shoals. She has changed her position once or twice during the day. She now heads to the south and lies easy. Lighters and a steam tug are in the vicinity, to render assistance the moment, an opportunity presents itself; and should the weather continue favorable, she will soon be got off.

The Exodus from Ireland to America. The Western Star gives a melancholy sketch of the sufferings of the poor for the last two months, owing to the want of employment consequent upon the impossibility of proceeding with out-door labor, during the late severe weather.

Cotton and Corn. LIVERPOOL, Friday, Feb. 25, 1853. here is no change whatever to notice in the state of general trade or of the Money market during the week. Trade continues very active, and Money in demand at 3 ?? cent. ?/ annum. Consols remain at 99??.

THE EFFECTS OF THE STRIKE.--Under the head of "Outrageous Proceedings," the Baltimore Patriot publishes the following: We stated yesterday that an attack had been made on Wednesday evening, on some of the workmen who had resumed labor in the machine shops of Messrs. WINANS.
On Saturday, March 12, after a short illness, Mrs. SOPHIA ANN, wife of Gorham P. Taylor, aged 30 years. Her remains will be taken this morning to Guilford, Conn., for interment.

Iron forms so many articles of universal utility, and is withal so economical and substantial a material, that it is next to an impossibility to enumerate the styles of its application. We use it in our stores and dwellings, in houses and on railroads, in-doors and out-of-doors. Its uses are illimitable.

The combination of vocal talents, under the conduct of MAX MARETZEK and the management of LE GRAND SMITH, will be eminently strong. Many of the favorites of the old Havana and Astor-place Troupes have, as previously announced, returned to New-York, from Mexico and the South.

I learn on excellent authority, that Hon. GEORGE M. DALLAS will be tendered the District Attorneyship of Philadelphia. It is a lucrative position. GEORGE HARRINGTON, Chief Clerk in the Treasury Department, was removed yesterday.

NEW BOAT.-A new boat called the Atlantic, was launched for the Fulton Ferry, Company last Friday, from the yard of Messrs. BURTIS YATES, Red Hook Point, and on Saturday was towed to the South Ferry, there to be fitted up. It will be when completed, one of the best boats in these waters--similar, somewhat, to the splendid boat Fulton, recently placed on the Fulton Ferry, but a handsomer model.

FROM BRAZIL.--A Price Current of Feb. 21, from Rio Janeiro, contained in a circular, alludes to the favorable prospects of commerce, and adds the following: The Empire has not, since its independence, presented a more flourishing aspect than the events of the past year have demonstrated, chiefly from its internal tranquility.

REDUCTION ON FERRIES.-The proprietors of the Jersey City Ferry commence a reduction in their charges to-day, from 4 cents to 3 cents for passengers, and 25 per cent. on vehicles, The law passed for reduction of ferriage on Hoboken and Jersey City Ferries, takes effect on the 1st of May.

The propeller Glasgow, Capt. CRAIG, from Glasgow on the 24th ult., arrived at this port on Saturday afternoon; and the Cunard steamship Africa reached port yesterday, after a passage of fifteen days from Liverpool, whence she brings dates to the 27th ult.

The Cincinnati Life and Trust Bank refused to receive all New-England bank paper today, except Boston City banks. The private banks, however, received it at one per cent. discount. There is an immense amount of Eastern money in circulation here.

We publish to-day the third section of the civil and diplomatic appropriation bill, which is the substance of the bill framed by Senator HUNTER, of Virginia, for the re-organization of the Executive Departments. It passed both houses of Congress and goes into operation on the first of July, the first day of the next fiscal year.

In noticing the stranding of the clippership Atlanta, 84 days from Canton, outside the Bay, the morning papers of Saturday notice the trip as the shortest ever made from that port to New-York. This is a mistake. We know it is not the first within 84 days, by at least eight days, and we are not sure that it is the second best run.

From the Albany Atlas. Mr. MELLEN BATTEL, of this city, machinist and engineer, has communicated to the papers a plan for the improvement of the channel of the Hudson, so as to increase its capacity to the purposes of ship navigation.

A recent English decision gave a verdict for $1,000 against a Railway Company, for personal injuries to a passenger, who got out of the last carriage but one of the train, at the Station where he was to stop, in the dark, and in the absence of a platform, strained his ankle.

The bill which passed the Assembly on Friday, as already stated, imposes upon the property of the State a tax of seven-tenths of a mill, and tolls upon all railroads carrying freight. The money thus raised, amounting to $1,600,000, is to be added to the Canal Fund, and to be appropriated to the completion of the State Canals.

The vicinity of the late murder has been thronged the whole day. The house has been closed, and the bodies removed by the Coroner. The funeral has been delayed, awaiting the return of Mr. LYNCH from New-York, who is anxiously expected, to ascertain the amount of money carried off.

The March number of Mr. PUTNAM'S new Monthly, which we find was promptly sent to us, though misplaced at the time the other Magazines were noticed, gives evidence of continued interest and increased success. The papers on BANCROFT, on Life in Havana, and Family Portraits, are in the best style of Magazine writing.

By this arrival, we have news of one of the most violent storms of wind which has visited the neighborhood of Liverpool for some time back. During Friday night and Saturday morning, the wind blew a moderate gale from the north-west, increasing in violence until about noon on Saturday, when it blew a complete hurricane.

Vienna letters are still full of the recent at tempt on the life of the Emperor. The assassin's name is now spelled JANOS LIBENY, a journeyman tailor, from Stuhlweissenburg, in Hungary. His age is 23. He maintains with vehemence that he had no accomplices, and that his intention was not to kill the Emperor, but to give him "a mark."

A Bill is before the Assembly, submitted by Mr. GILLMORE, for the reorganization of our City into Wards. Under its operation, there would be no changes in the Wards now numbered from One to Eight, nor in the Tenth and Twentieth.

M. ARPIN retires from the Courrier des Elats Unis, after a five years faithful service in its editor ship. Mr. LASALLE, the proprietor, retains his services, however, in the department of American politics, literature and news. M. MASSERAS, late of the Phare, which paper has been merged in the Courrier, is to be the new editor.

The board of Managers of the Kentucky Colonization Society are now sending to every precinot in every County of the State, blank petitions, calling upon the Legislature for an appropriation of $5,000 per year to hid, in sending to Liberia Such colored persons as may apply to the Colenization Society for that purpose.

The oath of office was not administered to the Vice-President on the 4th inst. Mr. RODNEY, our Vice-Consul, visited Mr. KING on the 3d for the purpose; but Mr. K. considered the ceremony unnecessary, fearing that he should never be able to reach Washington to assume the duties of the office, and if he should, the oath could be administered at Washington.

Milan letters of Feb. 19, say that the Austrian authorities, believing that MAZZINI was still in the city, had taken the most vigorous measures to prevent his escape. They even opened the coffins which were carried to the burial ground, to assure themselves that he was not concealed in one of them.

It is not often the newspaper press is bothered for an opinion of some sort or other on questions of public moment. It will have its say, and where discussion is left free to combat error, (as Mr. JEFFERSON did not remark,) there is little danger that the liberties of the people will be upset and broken into fragments, by its tyranny or corruption.

Condition of Trade and Manufactures in Paris. From the London Times. Trade in Paris remains nearly as it was a week since. Some American houses have made purchases of fashion and luxury, to be exhibited at the exposition which is being prepared at New-York for the month of May next.
A rumor, scarcely amounting to an assertion, had found its way into circulation, that an at tempt had been made on the life of the King of Berlin. Advices proved the rumor to be wholly unfounded.

MARYLAND STATE AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.--At a meeting of this Society, held on Wednesday evening, a long report was presented by WILSON M. CARY, Esq., Chairman of the Committee on the Inspection Laws. This report recommends the abolishment of all existing inspection laws of this State, and the introduction of a system for licensing Inspectors, and puts forth the reasons for the proposed change.

We hear that the PRINCE DE JOINVILLE has written a letter to the publisher of PUTNAM'S Magazine, acknowledging the receipt of the article concerning the "Bourbon among us,"--adding that he remembers meeting Reverend ELEAZER WILLIAMS during his western travels and having a very interesting conversation with him about the Indians,--but giving the Dauphin story a very flat denial indeed.

The Keokuk Dispatch, of the 1st, speaks of a murderous affray which occurred in Scotland County, Missouri, about twelve miles south of Bonaparte, in which two men--one named Circle, and the other Dulin or some similar name--were killed by a man named Carter.

On a motion by CHARLES WALLACH to admit Lieut. SCHAMBURG to bail, Dr. BOYLE testified that Mr. FULLER had greatly improved, had been removed to his residence without difficulty, was able to sit up and walk a little, and he had reason to believe would recover. Drs. HOLMEAD and MILLER concurred.

By Electric Telegraph from Trieste we learn that the steamship Adrin arrived from Alexandria at Trieste 24th, after a passage of 140 hours. She left Alexandria on the 18th, and brings the following news from India: The Burmese occupy the Aeng Pass with a large force. Pegu (the province we suppose) has been again occupied by a large force of Burmese.

Mr. Collector MAXWELL publishes a letter stating that out of one hundred and four persons employed as Clerks in the Collector's Office, only twenty-eight Democrats have been removed during his official term. What proportion of removals have been made in the other departments of the Custom House service, he does not state.

The reported attack of a British ship-of-war upon one or two ports claimed by the State of Honduras, derives some degree of probability from the previous rumors from the same quarter. Early in February news reached here that Honduras had seized the English settlement at Limas, appointed a Commandant and declared her purpose to retain possession at all hazards.

According to the Navy Register for the current year, the following is the naval force of the United States: Eleven ships of the line, carrying eight hundred and sixty guns. Of these, three are in commission as receiving ships, three in ordinary, four on the stocks, and one preparing for sea.

In consequence of the late decision of the United States Court, reversing the decision of Judge Woodbury in the case of Henry Webster vs. Peter Cooper, the titles of a large number of citizens in Maine to their lands and homes are jeopardized.

The exertions that have been made to save some of the prisoners under trial, from the extreme penalty by the garote, may be the means of bringing all those most seriously implicated within the commutation to ten years' in presidio, which will be of undoubted advantage to the Government as well as relief to the parties.

PLASTER CASTS OF LEAVES AND FLOWERS.--The following is the process recommended by the ingenious Mr. DEEBLE, the engraver, at Islington, by which that gentleman succeeds in taking the most accurate and beautiful casts from the leaves and other parts of plants.

POWERS AND HAYNAU.--The Florentines have just started a story in regard to our sculptor, POWERS, and HAYNAU the Austrian General, which has sufficient foundation in fact to be extremely piquant and illustrative of the national tone towards their respective countries.

Four members of the British House of Commons leave been unseated, upon the ground that they obtained their elections by bribery. The fact is one of considerable interest and importance in connection with the general question of suffrage.

The GARDINER trial was resumed this morning. Mr. BRADLEY referred to several decisions relevant to the objection raised on Saturday. The District Attorney proceeded to produce further evidence on the point.

The Emperor of Austria is recovering from the effects of the wound inflicted on him last week. He was struck with a poignard, and not shot, as the first telegraphic dispatch announced. The author of the attack is a young Hungarian, LADISLAS LEBENYI, formerly a servant to Count NICOLAS ESTERHAZY, who commanded in the Hussars, but Intterly working at his trade of tailor in Vienna. On his way to prison, he repentedly shouted Eljen KOSSUTH.

BOARD OF ASSISTANTS.--The President, J. TROTTER, Esq., in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Petitions referred--Of Patrick Smith, for indemnification for the loss of a grey horse which ran away on the Eighth-avenue in February last, fell off the bank near Sixty-sixth street and broke his neck, so the petitioners asks for $150 from the Treasury.

At a very late hour last night, the Aspinwall steamer Uncle Sam reached port, bringing two weeks later intelligence from California. Our dates are from San Francisco to the l6th February, Aspinwall to the 5th instant, and Kingston to the 9th. The news is not important, but cheerful.

Two of the new Cabinet Ministers are warmly commended for personal worth and ability by the leading organs of the Whig opposition in their respective vicinities and States. The Albany Evening Journal pays a high compliment to the integrity and ability of Governor MARCY, and the Louisville Journal says of Mr. GUTHRIE that

We have received three articles from the "Catholic Layman," whose papers on the MDIAI case will be remembered by our readers, upon will relations of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States to the great question of Religious Freedom.

SINGULAR CAUSE OF FIRE.--The Boston Atlas says the following fact may be useful, not only in guarding against a similar occurrence, but in suggesting one among many causes of fires, which are, undoubtedly, often wrongly attributed to incendiarism: A few days since, a gentleman, in the vicinity of Boston, observed that the tassel to the shade of his window was badly burned, and in a manner which gave no indication of the cause.

When Senator HOUSTON stood up and defended the little handful of Seminoles--weak, miserable, and half-starved--who threaten to exterminate the warlike Floridians, he won the good opinion of the humane of all parties and from all quarters. But Virtue is not wont to be rewarded too liberally.

The Cabinet have found it quite impossible to agree upon the number of new appointments, and the removals which would be rendered necessary. Accordingly the list of nominations, which it was expected would be sent to the Senate to-day, was not received by that body.

An enterprizing Toronto paper deprecates the passage of a bill now before the Legislature, on the ground that it would reduce the Canadian Universities to a level with American Colleges and Academies.

In Washington City, D.C., March 9, at the Unitarian Church, by Rev. Dr. Dewey, EDWARD JONES and MARY REBECCA MOORE, daughter of Jacob B. Moore, all of San Francisco, Cal. On the evening of the 9th inst., by Rev. Dr. Van Arsdale, Mr., JAMES H. STEPHENS and IDA ELIZABETH IRISH, all of this City.

How good the Bostonian digestion must be! When a man writes so complacently as this, he must needs sleep sound o' nights and enjoy pleasant dreams. The Boston Traveller thus felicitates itself and the mechanics of that city: THE JOHN HANCOCK.-The John Hancock steamer, which was launched form the Charlestown Navy Yard a few days since, was not a new vessel, but on old-steamer lengthened and remodelled.

The Indian Appropriation bill, lately passed by Congress, makes provision for the expenditure of a large amount on account of our financial obligations to the Indians, for lands purchased of them by treaty, and for meeting the usual expenditures of the Indian Department.

To the Editor of the N. Y. Daily Times: It is not a matter of surprise that an active discussion of the question of religious liberty should spring out of the imprisonment of the MADIAI in Tuscany. A large portion of the Christian world is at present agitated by this discussion.

The Board of Aldermen commenced last evening's session under the most favorable auspices. There were a sufficient number present at the calling of the roll to constitute a quorum and the lobby was not so crowded as on former occasions.

LOOKING OUT IN TIME.--A few days ago, a decent married woman, in whose husband's name a small sum was deposited in the savings-bank here, called upon the actuary, and intimated that she wished to have the whole amount withdrawn. It happened to be after banking hours, and she was requested to call again that day se'nnight.

SPINGLER INSTITUTE.--By invitation of the young ladies of the first music class at this establishment, we attended the performance of a Cantata called the "Flower Queen, or the Coronation of the Rose." The libretto is by Miss FRANCES JANH CROSBY, (a graduate of the New-York Institution for the Blind,) and displays a considerable amount of talent.

The Tax and Toll Bill, as passed by the Assembly, will not pass the Senate, writes a well-posted, and on this point, confident correspondent at Albany. Senator VANDERBILT's plan is the favorite. If that fails to become a law, nothing will be done with the Canals.

DAGUERREOTYPES.--W. LAWRENCE has the pleasure to inform his friends and the public that he will open to-day at No, 381 Broadway, corner of White-street, one of the most extensive and splendid Daguerrian Galleries in the world.
DEATHS.--From the Health Officer's Report for the week ending March 12, we learn that there were but 48 deaths; 30 of this number were males, and 18 females; 18 of these were adults, and 30 children.

TAKE CARE OF YOUR HEALTH.--To a young man who asked of HORACE MANN counsel to guide him towards success in the legal profession, that extraordinary Mann replied tersely, promptly, and definitely. He opens with the following very common-sensical and important suggestions touching the necessity of Health: "First, you need health. An earnest student is prone to ruin his helath.

In New Hartford, Conn., on Sunday, March 13, at the house of his father, Rev. Cyrus Yale, JOSEPH BRADLEY YALE, aged 30. In Brooklyn, on Monday morning March 14, at 1 o'clock, WILLIAM, eldest son of Capt. Wm. C. and Eliza, Berry.

The parliamentary piece de resistance on Monday and Wednesday evenings in St. Stephen's, was the Maynooth grant. This bone of contention between rival religions and parties, is regularly flung down once a year on the floor of the House, and in variably the subject of fierce debate for several evenings.

A CENTENARIAN.--An instance of very remarkable longevity came under the notice of Mr. MELVIN, during his recent flying tour in quest of a runaway slave through Madison county, Ill, While, in the negro settlement on Wood river, he chanced to call at a house whose door was opened to him by the owner, a tottering negro, with a head whitened--as the writers have stereotyped it--by the frosts of 90 winters.

The late shocking murders of Mrs. Shaw and Mrs. Lynch, at Philadelphia, of which we have given accounts, are creating much excitement in that vicinity. The Philadelphia papers are full of the details. According to the Bulletin: "On the body of Mrs. Lynch was found a gold ring on the pubis, and a leather sheath of a dirk knife under her left arm. The wounds were in all forty-six.

The old silver and lead mine at Middletown, Conn., is about to be worked vigorously. The report of the State Geologist concerning it is very favorable. The vein in the shaft is three feet wide and carries, it is believed, thirty or forty ounces of silver to the ton, About 1500 feet of old drifts have-been cleared out, and present very promising appearances.

THINGS AT KEY WEST.--The cargo of the ship Lucy has been appraised at $1,46,769 21; the vessel, $13,000--total, $159,769 21. No decision has been made by the Judge of the Admiralty Court. It will be given soon. The affairs of the ship N. Kimball, have been settled, the salvage adjudicated and the dry cargo reshipped.

The political horizon of Europe, which has been tranquil for so many months, has be come suddenly obscured by the stand Austria seems maliciously to be taking against Turkey. The cause of the sudden appearance of Col. LEININGEN, in an estafette steamer of the Austrians, was soon revealed.

The hail storm at Charleston, Ga., commenced at 21 o'clock on Thursday afternoon, and in ten minutes time did immense damage--almost every house in the city being injured. The ware-houses of Mr. RANNIN and Messrs. GUNBY, DANIEL Co., were all partially blown down and unroofed.

The steamship Uncle Sam, WM. A. MILLS, Commander, arrived quite unexpectedly at this port about 1 o'clock this morning, from Aspinwall and Kingston, with dates from California to the 16th ult. The news is two weeks later than our previous advices.

LECTURE ON CAYENNE.--Mr. FABENS, for many years Consul at Cayenne, delivered a Lecture; last evening at the Tabernacle. He had a very fair?? audience and the Lecture was listened to with uncommon interest. He gave a complete and vivid picture of Cayenne, which was very interesting, as but little is known of it by our people.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The question of International Copyright has recently occupied your attention, and that of the public; and you have conclusively shown that it is one of expediency and not of right. In that view there are great practical considerations to be pondered by the people, whose interests are closely involved in the subject.

SUPPOSED ATTEMPT TO MURDER.--About 12 o'clock on Saturday night, as a gentleman and lady were passing near the German Church, corner of South First and Ninth-streets, they were startled by the cry of "Murder," and on going to the rear of the Church, found an aged female in a pond, which was so deep that she was but just able to keep her head above the water.

An improved passenger car has been placed on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the body being placed on swinging trucks, with eight springs at each end, so arranged on the second axles as to give the utmost ease and comfort to those inside. A man may read with perfect case.

The striking workmen of the Lowell machine shop, held a meeting on Friday evening, chose officers, and effected a permanent organization. The "strike" comes particularly hard on the locomotive department of the shop, there being a large number of orders for locomotives, which it will be unable to fulfill in time.

As I have not seen any of my letters in the TIMES lately, I have come to the conclusion that they have miscarried or that they have met with an ill-timed fate in that editorial barrel of hades, which is concealed in the sanctum of journalists, and on the brink of which so many aspiring writers have trembled with fear and terror, for the arduous efforts of their simple noddles.

The Union gives the testimony in the case of the Dutchman Sacksin: After the lapse of more than an hour in listening to the different addresses and suggestions from various gentlemen, the propositions were reduced to two, viz: hanging or whipping.
There is good reason to believe that you are not mistaken in supposing Gen. PIERCE ready to do all he can justly, in aid of European freedom in its contest with despotic power.
"Punch" says that the heirs of Robinson Crusoe have instituted a suit for the recovery of the island of Juan Fernandez, on the ground that their great ancestor was monarch of all he surveyed.

A man named HARVEY BURNS, was murdered at Cow Creek on the 17th inst. Two Pitt River Indians, captured by some of the soldiers belonging to Fort Reading, are supposed to have committed the act, and were pointed out to the captors as such by a chief of the Cow Creek tribe.
The Pacific Mail Steamship Company's steamer Columbia, Capt. DALL., arrived, bringing news to the 29th of January. The brig Vandalia was lost on Columbia Bar, with captain and crew.
We have Kingston papers to the 9th of March, but the news is unimportant. The papers discuss sanitary reform--the treatment of the cholera--the Cooley immigration, and the Australian emigration,
The body of a man was washed ashore on Scituate Beach, on Sunday, and was taken charge of by JOHN BEAL, Coroner. The deceased had on a light colored pea-jacket, and dark pantaloons.

A hearing in the murder Case took place this afternoon at the County Prison before Alderman ISARD--JOSEPH DORAN appearing as Counsel for the prisoner, ARTHUR SPRING ; and AARON THOMPSON for young SPRING.

We have no mail south of Savannah to night. New-Orleans papers of Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, are now due. ROSS WINANS has addressed a letter to REVERDY JOHNSON, JOHN NELSON, J. V. L. McMAHON, and J. H. B. LATROBE, inquiring their opinion as to the legality of the strike of the workmen, and the protection they are entitled to from the City.

CARACCAS.--The late Caraccas papers have some items of political interest. The message of the President of the Republic of Venezuela to the Legislature, congratulates the State on the general tranquility which has followed the policy of the Administration.

Dec. 25--In Yamhill County, Mr. Warwick Hely Ton kin Tidd, to Miss Mary Woodland, of Ohio. In Portland, Oregon, Jan. 27, Mr. Nehemiah James Owen, formerly of Trenton, Oneida Co., N. Y., to Miss Louisa Jane Manor, of Chicago, III.

WATER FOR BROOKLYN.--A Communications from JAMES J. MURDOCK, of Brooklyn was presented to the Common Council on Monday, and referred to the Water Committee, suggesting an entire new plan for, supplying Brooklyn with water.
The Green Bay Advocate says that it has been informed that there will be I4,000,000 15,000,000 feet more lumber shipped from that place during the coming season, than during the previous one.

The memorial of GEORGE GRISWOLD and others relative to abuses in the assessment for opening the Fourth-avenue, was presented. Mr. WRIGHT gave notice of a bill for the incorporation of Roman Catholic Bishops for the State of New-York.

A DOG IN CHURCH.--An amusing incident occurred at one of the churches in a neighboring village last Sunday afternoon. Just as the services were about to commence, a good sized dog was observed to be sauntering about the aisles, probablyin search of his master.

Our readers, probably remember the legal controversy which has been waged now for several years between Captain, VANDERDIILT and the People, in regard to the ownership of certain dock privileges on Staten Island.

The State Tamperance Convention met at 10 o'clock this morning, Mayor BRISTOW presiding. The attendance is very large, and the proceedings spirited and interesting. The Convention holds sessions this afternoon and evening.

The Board of Aldermen met again last evening, not withstanding the high winds that prevailed during the entire day. The weather seems to have but little effect upon the present Board. They were as much inclined for business last evening as if all had been calm and pleasant both without and within.
On Monday, March 14, CHARLES H., Son of Thomas W Ogden, aged 10 months. On Monday evening, March 14, CLARENCE RATT, youngest son of Rev. M. L. and Sarah Ann Scudder, aged 11 months.

The news from Valparaiso is but a day or two later than that received by the Sierra Nevada, and does not comprise much of interest. Business seems to have been, according to the Commercial Report of the Reporter, at a stand-still, "between the two seasons."

The late receipt of the papers per steamship Uncle Sam precluded us from giving extended extracts yesterday morning. We add below a number of interesting items, with details of the intelligence from, Oregon, the Sandwich Islands and South America.

The Senate on meeting went immediately into Executive Session. After two hours thus spent, the doors were opened, when Mr. CLAYTON concluded his remarks on the resolution calling on the President for certain documents connected with the CLAYTON and BULWER Treaty.

The Constitution of the United States requires that all legislative powers granted by it shall be exercised by Congress; and so careful has it been to secure popular rights that in another section it is provided, that all bills to raise revenue must originate in the popular branch of that body.
In San Francisco, Feb. 13. of chronic dysentery, Elliot Torrey, of Boston. At Auburn, on the 7th ult., John Gambrill, late of Maryland, aged 33 years.

Feb. 14, 1853.--Owing to the continuance of fine weather, we have had an active business, and a large amount of merchandize has been forwarded to the interior. The demand for provisions has been very great, and prices generally have tended upward.
The Indicted Aldermen--Arguments on the Motion to Quash the Indictment against Alderman Bard. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Tuesday- Before Hon. City Judge BEEDE, Aldermen TIEMAN and CORNELL.

CHURCH FOR THE DEAF MUTES.--Considerable interest is, we learn, felt in the proposed erection of a church for the Deaf Mute parish of St. Ann, under the benevolent fosterage and pastorship of Rev. Mr. GALLAUDET.

Last night, the store in State-street owned by the Misses LEWIS, and occupied by JOSEPH DAVIS SON, (as a paint store,) and others, was destroyed by fire. DAVIS's loss is covered by an insurance for $4,000, in the Merchant's Insurance Company, of New-York.

The Panama papers announce the death of Capt. JOHN D. WILSON, Commander of the Sierra Nevada. Capt. WILSON was born in the State of Maine, and having at early age gone to sea-faring, had run out of the port of New-York, as commander of a ship, for some twenty-years.

What becomes of all the Gold brought in from California and not sent abroad, is a very frequent inquiry. "That it passes into the interior, without sticking long by the Banks in this City we have frequent official reports to show.

FROM NEW-BRUNSWICK AND NOVA SCOTIA.- We have received St. John papers to the 9th inst. The Morning News gives an account in the riot at Halifax, in consequence of rumors which had been circulated of outrages committed by some of the crew of the American ship Winchester, which had arrived there, on the women passengers in the ship, of which we have already had a telegraphic report.
The steamship Prometheus, Capt. CHURCHILL, arrived here yesterday morning from San Juan on the 6th inst. She brings the passengers of the Brother Jonathan, from San Francisco.

Anything that promises to protect the property and lives of our citizens from the ravages of fire is matter of interest. In Philadelphia, where they continue to agitate the question of establishing a "paid Fire Department," the Committee appointed some time since to report, gave the following account of the way fires are managed in London and Paris:

A letter from El Paso, of the 23d of January, has the following: The two parties in the State of Chihuahua, headed by CORDERO, the Governor, and General TRIAS, the former Governor of Chihuahua, have at last had a collision in the Town of El Paso. Colonel LANBERG, of the Mexican army,

PAINT FOR BRICK HOUSES.--A correspondent of the Ohio Farmer has used a cheap and very durable paint for the exterior of brick dwellings, which has already stood several years, and is now quite as fresh as when first applied.

The Senate, in Executive Session to-day, received a large number of nominations from the President. The following were confirmed: Ex Senator FELCH of Michigan, ROBERT THOMPSON of Virginia, and THOMPSON CAMPBELL of Illinois -Land Commissioners for California; salary $8,000 each.

The Temperance people of Jersey City have resolved to support no man to office in the Charter election of April, unless he is unqualifiedly identified with them. A Committee of four has been appointed for the purpose of selecting a candidate for Mayor.

The Polynesian gives the following account of the burning of the whaleship Warren: The ship Warren, of Holmes' Hole, Capt. R. N. SMITH, returned to this port on the 7th Jan. to re pair damages sustained by fire at sea since leaving this port in November last.

ATTEMPT TO KILL.--Officer JAMES McKINNEY, of the Second District Police, arrested a man yesterday named GEORGE DERRICKSON, charged with entering the sugar refinery of Mr. BENSON, in Water-street, the day before, and attempting to kill GEORGE C. OLIVER.

By reference to our Legislative report. it will be seen that the subject of Municipal Reform obtained a lengthened hearing in the Assembly yesterday. The Memorial of citizens for an amendment of the Charter of New York was presented by the Speaker, and elicited a general discussion.

Rt. Rev. Dr. WILLIAM GRANT BROUGHTON, Bishop of Sydney, and Metropolitan of Australia, died on Sunday, Feb. 20, in the 64th year of his age. His lordship arrived in England from South America a few weeks since, by the La Plata, having previously by letter announced to the Rev. ER NEST HAWKINS, the Secretary to the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts, his intention of visiting his native land.
Mr. GEORGE PEABOD, formerly of Boson, but now of London, is likely to be in good repute with the reading men of the next generation in that pretty New-England village, Danvers.

NAVIGATION OF THE OUACHITA.--The Arkansas Traveler states that there seems to be less, reason than ever to question that the regular navigation of the Ouchita to Arkadelphia is practicable and complains that there has been no boat there this season.

The following list of Business Firms are among best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,).No. 112 Broadway.A.T. STEWART Co., (do).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

Prayer by Rev. Mr. REED. PETITIONS PRESENTED AND REFERRED. Mr. CONGER, for the repeal of the law relative to taking oysters in the Harlem River; Mr. WRIGHT, two, on the exercise question; Mr. BEEKMAN, of JOHN F. RODMAN and others for a ferry-boat from New-York to Fort Hamilton.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--The revival of Shakspere's Comedy of the "Merry Wives of Windsor," is certainly an event in the theatrical world, especially when as at BURTON's, it is reproduced with all the adjuncts of new scenery and correct costumes.

The Boston Traveller says that the body of a man was washed ashore on Scituate Beach yesterday, (Sunday,) and was taken charge of by John Beal, Esq., the Coroner. The deceased had on alight-colored pea-jacket and dark pantaloons.

THE WINCHESTER RIOT AT HALLIFACX--The HALIFAX.--By telegraph we Wlad. the outlines of an excitement at Halifax, originating in the alleged outrages of the crew, upon some of the female passengers of the Winchester, an American ship which put into port in distress. The Halifax Recorder says:

The proceedings of the New-York Legislature were interesting. The Assembly discussed Municipal Reform in New-York, at great length The Speaker presented the Memorial of citizens, praying for an amendment of the City Charter.

PLINY MILES, Esq., delivered last evening, before the Geographical and Statistical Society, a very pleasant and instructive lecture on Iceland. That frozen island, which lies so near to the frigid zone, that nine-tenths of the good people who read geography and study maps are quite sure it is with in it, is said to enjoy brief seasons of the year when the atmosphere is really warm and genial.

We have dates from the City of Mexico to the 22d ult., conveying little news in addition to what has already been received. Mexican Plenipotentiaries have been appointed to treat with the American Minister for the settlement of the terms of neutrality on the Tehuantepec treaty.

TRIAL FOR MURDER.--The Suffolk County City Court, sitting at Riverhead, L. I., have for some days past been engaged in trying JOHN F. DEWICK, on a charge of murdering his father at that place some time since.
Under the above head the Lagrange Missourian makes the following statement: A very daring outrage was recently committed at Chambersburg, Clark County, Mo. The facts areas follows:

MEETING OF ROMAN CATHOLIC CLERGY AND LAITY--SYMPATHY WITH DR. NEWMAN AND THE ARCHBISHOP OF SANTA FE DE BOGOTA.--A large number of the Roman Catholic Clergy, and few of the Laity, assembled in the Church of the Transfiguration, Chambers-street, Tuesday, for the purpose of expressing their admiration and sympathy toward the Archbishop of Santa Fe de Bogota, lately qanished from New-Granada, and Dr. NEWMAN, convicted of libel in the Queen's Bench, London.

Under this title, an exhibition of paintings, principally of the American School, has opened at the American Art Union Gallery, with the praiseworthy object of aiding the New-York Gallery of Fine Arts. It is managed by an efficient committee of gentlemen known for their encouragement of the arts, and the selection with which they have presented us does them infinite credit.

Among the letters found in the possession of Clark, arrested at Pond's Exchange Hotel a short time since, as a counterfeiter, were several, says the Albany Journal, signed Robert Harkness, Delhi, Delaware County. Officer Mack proceeded to Delhi to arrest Harkness, but found he had gone to Unadilla, where he was practicing law.

In the United States Senate, on the 17th ult., Senator SMITH, of Connecticut, made a speech in support of the bill reported by Mr. RUSK, from a Select Committee, for the construction of a Railroad and Telegraph line from the Mississippi Valley to the Pacific.
THINGS AT KEY WEST-March 8.--The following is the report of the Surveyors on the wrecked schooner Montauk, of New-York, PENDLETON, master.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: There is no class of Americans from principle more attached to, and ready to maintain, the fullest liberty of conscience, than our Catholic citizens. This proposition was advanced in my first communication to the -TIMES.

CENTRAL AMERICAN STEAM NAVIGATION COMPANY.--Contracts have lately been concluded by Captain THOMAS WRIGHT, with the Governments of Central America, for the establishment of a new line of Mail steamers on the Pacific, between the Central American Republics and Panama, commencing at the port of Iztampam, in Guatemala, and touching at the intermediate ports of Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica.

One of the most honorable of the peculiar institutions of East Boston, is the Ornamental Tree Association, which, during the past year, set out two hundred and twenty-five trees, and expect, during the present one, to setout from eight hundred to a thousand.

During the past week, a State Temperance Convention has been held in our city, for the purpose of arousing the public on the subject of Temperance, and deciding upon what course of action to adopt at the coming election, in order to secure the passage of a stringent liquor law at the next session of the Legislature in May.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: In your paper of last week was a letter pro posing a plan for the better government of this City. On examination it will be found to contain elements which, if successfully developed, would reform great abuses.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--An excellent house highly appreciated and cordially greeted Madame SONTAO last night, in the Fille du Regimento. The Opera was well rendered. Madame SONTAG sang the music lesson with unusual gusto, and was warmly applauded.

CHILI.--News has been received from Valparaiso to Feb. 14. The silver and copper mines of the North were being successfully worked, They have introduced gas into Valparaiso, and are highly pleased with the improvement.

It is said that there is a lady at Frostville, France, 101 years of age, who has not been out of mourning once during the last 70 years. She has successively lost her father, mother, two husbands, seven uncles, eight aunts, four brothers, five sisters, six brothers-in-law, three sisters-in-law, three sons, four daughters and thirty-two grandchildren.

SEDUCTION AND PROBABLE MURDER.--A revolting murder transpired on Monday evening last, in our city, which can be traced to the artifices of a villain who had been guilty of a base seduction. It is no less than the murder of an infant newly-born by its mother.
The witness TOGRE was recalled at his own request, and explained some points in his evidence given yesterday. He now distinctly recollected having seen Dr. GARDINER in the City of Mexico in 1845.

March 7, on board the ship Nestorian, Rev. JOHN BYERS, late of the Presbyterian Mission, at Shanghae, China. Funeral services in the First Presbyterian Church, 5th av., Rev. Dr. Phillips, this afternoon, (Thursday) at 5 o'clock. On Wednesday morning, March 16, at 3 o'clock, EZEKIEL PETTY, aged 64 years, 1 month and 12 days.

HEMPSTEAD AND JAMAICA PLANK ROAD.--On the 14th inst., the following gentleman were elected Directors of this Company: Laurens Reeve, G. N. Searing, D. F. Manico, S. C. Snediker, J. H. Seaman, David Willets, Richard Carman, Henry Story and John Skidmore. At the same time, LAUENS REEVE was elected President; G. N. Searing, Vice-President; S. C. Snediker, Treasurer; and John Harrold, Secretary.

At Albany, yesterday, the Assembly passed the New-York Pilot Bill, and the bill to increase the number of Notaries Public. The amendments to the Emigration Law were further debated. In the Senate, the Tax Bill from the other House was made the order after Mr. VANDERBILT'S Canal Measure.

They did a large business in the way of confirmations yesterday, at Washington. The dispatches say a hundred men were secured in office. Among them were Ministers to Pnru and Switzerland,-Mr. J. RANDOLPH CLAY to the former, and THEO. S. FAY the latter; Consul to Tunis and sundry others.

"JOHN BROWN'S TRACT."--The Albany Evening Journal has an article, in connection with the "Racket River Improvement," in relation to the wilderness of Northern New-York. It observes that the most desolate, deserted wilderness west of the Rocky Mountains, has had its locality in Northern New-York.
New-Orleans papers of Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday were received to-night. Thursday's are still due. The main points of the news in the papers have been anticipated by telegraph.

A rich harvest of jobs and contracts is annually gathered by the favorites of the Common Council under the various powers, most liberally construed of course, of regulating, grading, paving and sewering the streets and avenues of the City.

SPRING, THE PHILADELPHIA MURDERER.--The North American says of the carriage of the murderer ARTHUR SPRING, during the examination of his son, that his demeanor was cool, indifferent, and reckless to a shocking degree. A fiendish smile played about his mouth all the while.

Yellow fever was raging at St. Vincent at our last receipts, and among its victims has been Sir JOHN CAMPBELL, late Lieutenant-Governor, who has been buried with great solemnity. At Tabago there has been a misunderstanding between the President and the Legislature.

The Chicago Tribune. "puts it" pretty strongly to that flourishing city. It professes to have heard on good authority" that the basement of their new Court-house holds in its iron embrace a citizen for a debt of $2. It will cost him $6 to swear out, therefore we have the proportion as 2 is to 6, so is the opening in to the opening out.

The Senate confirmed a number of nominations to-day. Among the confirmations were J. RANDOLPH CLAY as Minister to Peru; THEODORE S. FAY as Minister Resident in Switzerland; Dr. HEAP, as Consul at Tunis, and all the other nominations reported from the Committees, with the exception of the Territorial Judges.

The remarks of Hon. TRUMAN SMITH, which we publish this morning, in favor of the construction of a Railroad from the Mississippi Valley to the Pacific, clearly set forth the advantages to be derived from the fulfilment of that enterprise.

BOARD OF ASSISTANTS.--On motion Mr. KING took the Chair, and the minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Petitions Referred--From Levi Adams and others, to have sunken lots between Second and Third avenues and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-streets filled up. Of Win. M. Baxter and others, to have a pier constructed at foot of Twenty-second-street, East River.

Carmelich, the Spaniard, who lately in Jack son County, Miss., walked away from the Sheriff, a few months before his neck was to have ornamented a noose, and whose modesty prevented his consenting to a public exhibition of himself, has sailed for Spain. So it will probably happen that the hanging will have to be indefinitely postponed.

PATRICK'S DAY IN THE MORNING.--Early, very early, this morning, thousands of our Irish-American citizens are awakened by the lively strains of their national air, to "do honor to the day that's in it; and quickly come the recollections, and warmly beats the heart, of the expatriated Celt, for friends of his youth, the "Beautiful City," and "Green fields of Ould Ireland."

In consequence of the lateness of the hour al which the Board, of Supervisors adjourned, the Board of Aldermen did not meet until 51/2 o'clock, when, after the reading of the minutes, presentation of numerous petitions, communications, , an invitation was received and accepted from Colonel FERRIS and others, to review the troops on parade on St. Patrick's Day.

The Senate to-day confirmed all the nominations which had been reported upon--upwards of a hundred in number. The nomination of Lieut. GARDENER, promoted to Captain in the 1st Regiment of Dragoons, was laid on the table by a large majority, the post being claimed by Lieut.

The Commercial Advertiser, alluding to the Meeting for City Reform at Metropolitan Hall and its proceedings, says that "there is a "very common suspicion that the whole "movement is but a shrewd attempt to divert "attention from the notorious corruption of "the present Common Council, and to acquire "power to sway future elections."

The Randolph (Cattaraugus) Whig, of Friday last, says that Michael Bond, of Randolph, died very suddenly on the 28th ult., from the effects of chewing aconite, or what is commonly called wolf's bane, supposing it to be a root of altogether a different nature. The occurrence took place at the drug store of C. L. Fitch, in Randolph, where the root, it seems, was exposed on the counter.
THE SAN JUAN NICARAGUA TROUBLES.--The trouble between the Nicaragua Transit Company and the San Juan authorities, has two sides to it, like most other questions in dispute.

COMMON COUNCIL.--A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held at the City Hall on Monday evening, the President, Alderman COM STOCK, in the chair. The following was received; To the Hon. the Common Council:

The Randolph (Cattaraugus) Whig, of Friday last, says that Michael Bond, of Randolph, died very suddenly on the 28th ult., from the effects of chewing aconite, or what is commonly called wolf's bane, supposing it to be a root of altogether a different nature. The occurrence took place at the drug store of C. L. Fitch, in Randolph, where the root, it seems, was exposed on the counter.

SEDUCTION AND DESERTION.--A cruel case of seduction ard desertion has just come under our notice. Some time last summer or full, a man calling himself HARLY HADLY, took up his residence in one of the towns of this county, and figured conspicuously among the young people, making himself particularly agreeable to the young ladies.

Mr. SHAW moved a suspension of the rules to have the bill in relation to the New-York Police referred to the New-York delegation. Carried and the bill was referred. A communication was received from the Superintendent of Common Schools, announcing that the City of New York refuses to pay its share of the school tax of 1852.

We ventured a few days ago to say in reference to the re-opening of the question of Banking basis, that the attempt to foist upon the Department the stocks of certain States South, was probably "a job," though the fact might not be known to the Assembly.

In our Brownsville dates we find a few returns of news. The Flag of Feb. 18 says: "We learn from good authority that the plans of CARAVAJAL have been abandoned, at least for the present, and that his followers, many of whom are farmers, have turned their attention to planting their fields. Order is, therefore, completely restored on the frontier."

Semi-Annual Report of the Chief of Police. The following is the Chief's Report for the six months between July 1 and Dec. 31, 1852. Hon. JACOB A. WESTERVELT, Mayor, The statistical tables accompanying this report will exhibit to your Honor the operations and condition of the Police Department from the 1st day of July to the 31st day of Dec., 1852.

DETERMINED ATTEMPT AT SUICIDE.--A young and well-dressed man attempted to destroy himself yesterday morning, about ten or half past ten o'clock, on the steamer Prairie State, lying at the wharf between Morgan and Green-streets, to be repainted. His first effort was to cut his throat with the large blade of his pen-knife, which inflicted a wound about an inch in length, but as far as we could see, was not a fatal one.

They had a heavy gale on Lake Ontario on Monday night. The wind was very high at Rochester, and a large building was blown down at Brighton, near that city. The Rochester Union says: "We saw a large sign taken from the upper story of STONE'S Block on Main-street, and shivered into fragments by the wind. A horse that was hitched in the street came near being killed by the falling sign.

The news by the New-Orleans papers which failed to reach us for several days, has been for the most part anticipated by the telegraph. We subjoin, however, the following in addition, from the Picayune of the 9th: The brig Tehuantepec, Capt. BROWN, arrived last evening from Vera Cruz, which port she left on the 26th ult.

We give below the tariff in force under the present Mexican Government: The most excellent Senor President ad interim of the Republic has addressed me the following decree: The President ad interim of the United Mexican States, to the inhabitants of the Republic: Know Ye: That, desirous of carrying into effect the known will of the nation, by the adoption of all those reforms in favor of which it has pronounced.

The anniversary of St. Patrick was celebrated yesterday, with a spirit and display superior to any previous observance of the occasion. The day, though somewhat gloomy and threatening, held up until after the procession. About 10 o'clock, the military organizations, under command of Col. B. C. FERRIS, formed in East Broadway, where they awaited the arrival of the several Civic Societies, marshaled under Mr. THOS, MCKIERNAN.

The GARDINER case was resumed this morning by recalling JAMES WRIGHT, whose cross-examination occupied nearly all day. He gave his own history, with the time and date of his various occupations in Mexico, since 1839, showing he was at different periods a stage-driver, stage-owner, manager of a menagerie and circus, proprietor of balloon ascensions, and a miner at three different mines.

The changes announced for the new Ad ministration in the Diplomatic Corps, some of them at least, commend themselves to general favor. The Mission to PERU was raised by the late Congress to the first grade. Mr. RANDOLPH CLAY is very properly retained by the President, at Lima, to fill it. Mr. C. is no partizan.

We said, the other day, on the judgment of our Albany correspondent, that nothing will be done with the Canals, unless VANDERBILT'S plan be adopted. The Atlas affects to treat this as a threat against any attempted legislation on other Canal measures. This sort of smartness will not avail the hypocritical, and at heart, as well as in purpose, Anti-Canal clique, who give tone to the Atlas.

New-Orleans papers of Friday are at hand. Those of Thursday are missing. The True Delta publishes correspondence from Belize, Honduras, dated Feb. 24, which confirms the statement that the British war steamer Devastation had taken possession of the town of Truxillo by force, compelling the Governor to give up the town, or submit to a bombardment.

STEWART Co., (do,).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouses. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Water.

At Fort Leavenworth, Missouri, Feb. 21, ELIHU WHITNEY BLAKE, aged 19 years and 8 months, son of Elihu and Adeline N. Blake, of this City. In Brooklyn, on Monday, March 17, JAMES BARR, aged 65 years, 7 months and 3 years. His friends and acquaintances, and those of his son, Geo. II., are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Friday, the 18th inst., at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 114 Sands-st., Brooklyn.

It Jeffersonville, Sullivan Co., N. Y., March 10, by Rev. Edward K. Fowler, FRANK L. BOGARDUS, of New York, to HELEN C., youngest daughter of Hon. Sidney Tuttle. On Tuesday morning, March 15, at the residence of Richard Taylor, Esq., by Rev. J. W. Shaw, of Caldingham, Mr. THOMAS BECK, late of Bunbridge, to Miss MARTHA JANE SHAW, eldest daughter of James Shaw, Esq., of Newry.

The following report of a recent trial in the Court of Queen's Bench on a charge of libel in a report of proceedings in a Court of Justice, shows that in some very important respects the Press enjoys greater freedom under English law than under that of the United States. The charge of Lord CAMPBELL sets forth principles of interest and importance to the public as well as to the Press:

At 5 1/4 o'clock last evening, there were a few Aldermen in the Council Chamber, and, in the absence of the President, Alderman WARD was called to the Chair, and the Clerk proceeded to call the roll. Alderman TIEMANN requested that the result should not be announced for a few minutes, as, if it was announced immediately, the Board would have to adjourn--a quorum not being present.

Mr. VANDERBILT made a very able speech this morning, in support of his proposition to amend the Constitution so as to facilitate the completion of the public works. Mr. V. is a chaste and eloquent speaker. His review of Mr. PIERCE'S report was a fine specimen of Legislative criticism. Neither Mr. VANDERBILT COOLY, BRISTON, KIRBY, or OTIS, can be shaken from their Canal attachment, and several others are like them.

In relation to the Maspeth-Avenue Railway. To incorporate the Parker Female Institute of Brooklyn. To extend the time for the Albany and Susquehannah Railway Company, to comply with the general Railway Law. To regulate the fees of searchers at the Clerk's office, New-York.

DEATH FROM BURNS.--A young child residing with its parents, corner of Court-street and Hamilton-avenue, named Falcher, died on Thursday, from the effects of burns received a few days previous. The clothes of the child caught on fire from a stove, during the temporary absence of the family from the room. ACCIDENT.--Late on Tuesday evening, a man named Ebenezer Ferguson fell upon the side-walk, in Myrtle-avenue, whereby he received a severe fracture of the skull.

A meeting of the clergy and laity of the Roman Catholic Church was recently held, to express sympathy with the Archbishop of Santa Fe de Bogota, now an exile in the United Status in consequence of persecutions experienced from the Government of New Grenada. Archbishop HUGHES presided and expressed his sentiments upon the subject in oral remarks and in a formal address, both of which will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES.

Affairs at Washington lack pungency. The usual quantum of confirmations took place yesterday, and among them the following: Wm. F. Colcock, Collector at Charleston; Evans as District Attorney at Boston, and Col. Jack Hays as Survey-or-General of California. Nominations were sent in for the new officers of the recently established Territory of Washington, as follows: Major Stevens of the Topographical Engineers as Governor, and Capt. Clendennon of Louisiana as District Attorney.

Mr. McMURRAY presented the majority report of the Committee on Finance in favor of the Assembly bill imposing tolls on Railways, Mr. MORGAN dissents--on the ground of no public necessity for the bill. Mr. McMURRAY moved to make it the special order for Saturday. Mr. VANDERBILT suggested that it should be taken up after the disposition of his amendments to the Constitution.

The Hudson River and Robert Fulton. In the-Spring of 1810, my health was found to have suffered from close application to study and other duties of my profession. Relaxation, change of air and change of scene became indispensable; and my fondness for the Hudson River and the fine regions of country which line both its banks soon determined me where to go.

Exile of the Archbishop of Santa Fe De Begotn--A Meeting of the Catholic Clergy. A meeting of the clergy, and laity of New York, for the purpose of expressing their admiration and sympathy towards the Archbishop of Santa Fe de Bogota, lately banished from New-Grenada, and now a resident of this City, was held Monday morning, at the Church of the Transfiguration, Chambers-street.

SUPPOSED MURDER.--Some four weeks since, a German woman named MARGARETTA DENNER, who keeps a fancy store at No. 160 Ewen-street, was seen to wrap her infant up in cloths and leave the house, and afterwards to return again without it. Since that time she maintained the appearance of still being enceinte, by artificial means.

From the Washington Union, 16th. In conformity with established usage, the members of the Diplomatic body were, on yesterday, received by the President, at the Executive Mansion, in their official capacity. The President was attended by the Secretary of State and the other members of the Cabinet.

SUICIDE OF MR. SNYDER.--This gentleman, who committed self-destruction, on Friday night, at the St. Charles House, Keokuk, Mo., was of the firm of SNYDER TURNER, of Galena, engaged in large lead mining operations there. The particulars of the dreadful act were in the highest degree tragical and determined.

A number of confirmations were sent to the Senate to-day. Among them COLLOCK for Collector, EVANS for District Attorney of Boston, and Col JACK HAYS for Surveyor-General of California. Also a number of nominations, among which were Major STEVENS, (Topographical Engineer,) for Governor, and Captain CLENDENEN of Louisiana, for District Attorney of the new territory of Washington, together with several registers and receivers for the Western States.

Texas papers have been received--Galveston to the 4th inst. and Austin to the 26th ult. The subscriptions to the capital stock of the Texas Central Railroad already amount to nearly $600,000. The favorable terms of subscription are sufficient to induce every one interested in property which the road will benefit to subscribe to the extent of their means.

The first Minister Resident from the United States to Switzerland is to be Mr. THEODORE S. FAY, for many years Secretary of Legation at Berlin, first under the late HENRY WHEATON, and subsequently under Mr. DONELSON and Mr. BARNARD. This is another of the new President's arrangements abroad, which will give satisfaction.

ARKANSAS ITEMS.--The Fort Smith (Ark.) Herald of the 26th ult., says: "Lieut WITTER, of the 5th Infantry, U. S. A., arrived last Saturday, on his way to the Brazos. He was thrown from a horse a few days ago and received several severe bruises, and was otherwise injured. Lieut. STEVENSON, 7th Infantry, arrived from Fort Arbuckle, on Wednesday.

A trifle of benevolent ingenuity might be spent in relieving the President and Washington from the horde of office-craving barbarians. A plan for the relief of the capital is wanted; some SOBIESKI, who shall raise the leaguer and scatter the foe, may pluck bright honor from the achievement.

THE EMPIRE JEWELRY COMPANY.--This Company have just opened a splendid salesroom at No. 210 Broadway, corner of John-street, where they make a most glittering display of valuable articles for use and ornament, consisting of a great variety of valuable gold watches, bracelets, guard, fob and vest chains, diamonds, finger and ear rings, and breast-pins, together with all the variety usually to be found in such establishments.

The Union of this morning says: We have reason to believe that the statements which appeared some time since in the public journals, to the effect that Col. KING had been inhospitably treated at Havana by the Captain-General of Cuba, were, quite unfounded.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Some lots are now offered for sale near this City, which I have personally examined, and which are so beautifully situated that I would recommend persons wishing to purchase property of that kind to visit them.

A STARTLING DISCOVERY.--During the late trial of ARCHIBALD, SEAMAN, and WALTER BARNES, on a charge of Burglary, in the Lorain County Common Pleas, the existence of a Secret Society was disclosed, the designs and tendency of which one or two extracts from its preamble and constitution will sufficiently explain.

Two stores on Main-street, occupied by J. SMITH, as a Stove store, and OSCAR SEVERANCE, tobacconnist--were destroyed by fire this morning. The buildings were of wood, and were insured for $2,000. SMITH'S stock was insured for $3,500,--and SEVERANCE'S for $2,000.

BOWERY SAVINGS BANK.--The Bowery Savings Bank people have got into their new and very commodious building, on their old site, a few doors above Grand-street. We were particularly pleased to see that they have arranged to enforce the en queue system, which will save much time to persons dealing with the Bank, besides getting them into good habits.

The question arises some time or other in the mind of every man as to the best means of disposing of that corporeal skin which falls like a cerement when the chrysalis bursts and the Psyche soars into the sunshine of the eternal.

A public meeting at the Broadway Tabernacle is called for Wednesday evening next, to receive Father GAVAZZI, the converted Italian priest, whose efforts against the Catholic Church, in England, have been attended by so much sympathy. The addresses delivered by GAVAZZI in England and Scotland have placed his name prominently before the world in the ranks of theological debaters. A large meeting is anticipated at the Tabernacle.

The process of manufacturing Woven Iron is exceedingly simple and rapid. Rods are selected of the required length, size, and quality, and are to be made of the finest style of wrought-iron, which, by repeated experiments, is found to possess many advantages over cast-iron. The tenuity of wrought-iron so far surpasses that of cast, that it is coming into general use, and meets with universal favor, in the construction of Wire Fences.

A step has been taken toward City Reform for New-York. Mr. RUSSELL SMITH reported a bill in the Assembly to-day, which is satisfactory; and also introduced a bill to limit and define the powers of the Supervisors. These two bills are in tended to cover the entire ground, and I think will effect the desired end. It is a piece of compulsory honesty on the part of your City servants.

The following is the conclusion of the proceedings in the Legislature on Thursday. The consideration of the Canal plan of Mr. VANDERBILT was set down, on motion of Mr. UPHAM, for to-day (Friday) at 4 P.M. The bill concerning the enlargement of the Champlain Canal Locks, was ordered to a Select Committee to report complete.

THE TRIAL TRIP OF THE STEAMSHIP AUGUSTA. --Contrary to general expectation--the river being covered by a dense fog during the morning hours--the steamship Augusta, the third in the line of the New-York and Savannah Steam Navigation Company, made her trial trip yesterday.

We are indebted to the politeness of the City Inspector for a copy of his Annual Report of the number of deaths and interments in the City of New-York during the year 1852. It is a document of more than 300 pages, and, of course, is not destitute of valuable statistical information.

FIRE IN CHELSEA.--BY a slip from the Chelsea Advertiser, we learn that the most disastrous fire that has occurred in that town for fifteen years, broke out in the spirit-level factory of Mr. YOUNG, corner of Broadway and Fourth-street, about 1 o'clock on Wednesday morning, when the whole block consisting of wooden buildings, was destroyed.

Must he not be a bold man who would dare may a word in favor of an article so much used and so much condemned ? So much condemned, indeed, that if precept could only serve instead of practice, the weed would be unknown. " My son," says a sage father, " hand me a light for this cigar." He lights and begins smoking. " I hope you will never acquire the habit.

The U. S. Mail steamship Ohio, Capt. HART STEINE, arrived yesterday from Aspinwall and Havana, bringing the California mails and the shipment of gold dust, amounting to $2,445,000. Her news from the Isthmus and California is anticipated.

There has been a wonderful thinning-out of office-seekers during the last twenty-four hours. The hotels are comparatively deserted and the town is quiet. Scarcely any news of interest is stirring. Mr. J. G. C. KENNEDY, Superintendent of the Census, was removed to-day.

ST. PATRICK'S DAY IN BROOKLYN.-The Anniversary of Ireland's Patron Saint, was celebrated with more than usual honors Thursday. The different Irish military and civic organizations, were out in full force, and made a very fine appearance. The Laborers' Society attracted general observation; they numbered over a thousand strong, and carried a beautiful original Irish harp.

HOBOKEN BIBLE SOCIETY.--At a meeting held in the Methodist Church on Tuesday, a Society was formed under the title of the Hoboken Bible Society, for the purpose of promoting the circulation of the Holy Scriptures throughout the township of Hoboken and County of Hudson.

EARTHQUAKE.--The shock of an earthquake was felt in this vicinity at about 2 o'clock on the morning of Saturday. The announcement may appear strange, but it is nevertheless true. A considerable number of our citizens, who were awake at the time, describe the vibrations, which were very distinct.

SUICIDE OF AN INMATE AT THE BLACKWELL'S ISLAND LUNATIC ASYLUM.--Yesterday morning Coroner GAMBLE proceeded to the Lunatic Asylum at Blackwell's Island, and held an inquest on the body of an inmate named JOHN FIET, who committed suicide by hanging himself, with a piece of muslin torn from the bed sheet. Mr. SAMUEL O. GRIFFIN, physician, and A. C. PINCKNEY, one of the keepers, were examined.

Whoever has visited the American coal-mining districts can hardly have failed to notice the unpromising condition of the houses provided for the accommodation of the miners. Mere shanties, loosely constructed, are generally deemed sufficient to supply their wants.

The Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer are now in session at this place--Justice JOHN W. BROWN, of Newburgh, presiding. The criminal business is not very large this term--there has been but one criminal trial, that of ERNST F. HANBOLD for assault and battery, with intent to kill one HENRY SCHARLOCK, a workman in the employ of the prisoner, who keeps a powder factory.

CANVAS BACKS IN THE CONNECTICUT.--Five canvas back ducks were shot in the Connecticut river, near Lyme, one day last week. A large flock of them came into the river, and Capt. E. S. OLMSTEAD, of the "Bacon House," in Lyme, with some friends, went out after them. They secured five.

A man by the name of Charles Kingsbury, who resided at Dedham, Mass., was found on Tuesday morning in the road leading to his residence, frozen to death. He was a single man, 40 years of age, and of intemperate habits.

The Baltimore mechanics held an immense mass meeting this afternoon. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad operatives threaten to stop work again, if the Company grants an extension of time to Ross WINANS and ADAM DENMEAD, on their contracts, which would enable them to further resist the demand of the workmen.

MR. RICHARD COLE.--Among the recent arrivals from Hong Kong, is the gentleman whose name heads this paragraph, who has been employed for a series of years in the manufacture of movable metalic Chinese type, and in the superintendence of Chinese printing.

MAPLE SUGAR.--It must be evident to every one that liquid filtrated through solid maple timber cannot be otherwise than pure. It also must be evident that sap caught in old, half-decayed wooden troughs with a liberal infusion of leaves and dirt, impart a great impurity to the sap.

Mr. RUSSELL SMITH, on behalf of the Select Committee of five in the Assembly, to which were referred the petitions for amendments to the Charter of the City of New-York, yesterday reported the following bill: The People of the State of New-York, represented in Senate and Assembly, do enact as follows:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: May I ask room in your columns for the letter of CHAS. H. MARSHALL, Esq., as the subject is, in my judgment, of great public importance. The bill before the Legislature proposes to create an office beyond the control of the Commissioners of Emigration, to whom the public look for the responsibility.

Two hundred years ago, the interesting locality in the midst of which I am now seated, to record the glories of civilization and the triumph of art, was a rude wilderness, in the sole possession, of the brave and chivalric Pawtuckets, once the most powerful tribe of Indians in Northern Massachusetts.

BITE OF MAD DOGS.--An English journal says that an old Saxon has been using for fifty years, and with perfect success, a remedy for the bite of mad dogs, by the agency of which "he has rescued many fellow-beings and cattle from the fearful death of hydrophobia."

New-Orleans papers of Saturday have been received. During the week ending the 12th inst., the sales of Cotton at New-Orleans amounted to 80,000 bales, valued at $3,000,000. Gen. PERSIFER F. SMITH had recovered from his recent sickness, and would leave New-Orleans for Washington shortly.

DISCOVERY OF LEAD ORE NEAR MILWAUKEE, WIS.--The Sentinel of Thursday last has the following: "One of our correspondents informs us that a discovery of lead ore has been made in the town of Ottawa, Waukesha County, a few days since.

The Diario de la Marino supplies us with dates from Vera Cruz to the 2d inst., and from the city of Mexico to the 26th of February. The Provinces of Hascala and of Durango have voted for SANTA ANNA as President.

The Cunard steamship Canada reached Hal-fax yesterday afternoon. A brief synopsis of her news is published elsewhere. The Commercial advices by this arrival are not encouraging. Cotton and Breadstuffs were both dull and declining. The latest date from Liverpool is the 5th inst., but the failure of the wires leaves us without an intimation as to the importance of the news.

REVOLT ON SHIPBOARD.--The examination of the crew--twenty-six in number--of the American ship Washington, Captain PAGE, came on yesterday at the United States Court-room, before Commissioner B. B. BREEDIN. The revolt, according to the testimony, commenced in the Bay of Mobile on or about the 3d January--the men refusing to work and manifesting a very turbulent disposition, soon after which they were put into irons.

On motion of Mr. MORGAN, Monday next was set apart specially for the third reading of bills. Mr. VANDERBILT presented the memorial of the President and Trustees of Union College, in relation to the affairs of said College. Mr. V. moved the printing. Mr. BEEKMAN consented to it, as fair, and it was adopted.

At San Francisco, Jan. 20, of consumption, CHARLES A. KNOX, in the 31st year of his age. On Friday morning, March 18, JOHN GRAY, youngest child of Charles F. and Julia M. W. Hunter, aged 9 months and 24 days. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral this (Saturday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from No. 695 Houston-st. No special invitations given.

The War of Ormuzd and Ahriman, by HENRY WINTER DAVIS.--The most objectionable feature of this work is its title; which not only fails to give a correct idea of the subject, but repels the reader, who may hastily look no further, from giving the writer the attention he really merits. Mr. DAVIS regards the antagonistic principles of absolutism and liberalism as typified by the two contending deities of the Persian pantheon.

MUTINY ON BOARD THE WHALER WM. PENN. --The Alta California gives an account of a mutiny on board the Wm. Penn, which left Strong's Island, 23d of July last. for a whaling voyage, under Command of I. P. HUSSEY, with CHRISTIAN NELSON as first officer, JOHN HALSEY as second officer, and five white men and fifteen natives.

We publish in this morning's TIMES a bill for the reorganization of our City Government, reported yesterday in the Assembly, from the Select Committee of five to which the various memorials on this subject have been referred. It will be found eminently worthy of perusal.

ALPHEUS FELCH of Michigan, ROBERT A. THOMPSON of Virginia, and THOMPSON CAMPBELL of Illinois, to be Commissioners, under the act of Congress approved March 3, 1851, to ascertain and settle the private land claims in California, Vice JOHN L. HELM, of Kentucky, whose nomination was not acted on by the Senate, and HILAND HALL of Vermont, and HARRY J. THOMSON of Alabama, removed.

Mr. DE Bow, Editor of the Commercial Review, has been appointed Superintendent of the Census Department, vice KENNEDY,--and took the oath of office to-day. The GARDINER trial was resumed this morning. The witness LEWIS was recalled, and further cross-examined.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"Lucia" was repeated last night. The house was well filled, and the audience appreciated the performance in a very flattering manner. We do not consider the Lucia of Madame SONTAG equal to some other characters in which she has appeared.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Captain STONE, from Liverpool 5th March, arrived here at 5 o'clock this evening. [We can get nothing further to-night. The Eastern lines have been working with the greatest difficulty, repeating at numerous stations.

BROOKLYN, WILLIAMSBURG AND BUSHWICK.-- In the Brooklyn Common Council on Monday evening last Alderman HAWXHURST, of the Third Ward, offered a resolution to the effect that a Committee of three be appointed to consult with a like Committee of the Williamsburg Common Council, when appointed, and the authorities of Bushwick, relative to uniting the three places under one Corporation. The resolution was tabled.

Liverpool Cotton Market. The week's business in COTTON has been limited--the sales reaching only 35,550 bales, of which speculators took 3,250, and exporters 4,500 bales. The imports of the week have been 87,000 bales. The stock at Liverpool now amounts to 650,000 bales.

The temporary arrest of speculation by the money turn in this City, is extending its influence to the country. The Free Bank circulation returns more rapidly in such seasons, for redemption. This is first felt by the Bankers in the neighborhood of the metropolis.

A meeting of the School Board of Finance was held at the City Hall, on Thursday evening, but adjourned to next Thursday evening in consequence of the City Clerk refusing to act as Clerk of said Board without remuneration for previous services.

MRS. SIGOURNEY AND COLONIZATION.--Rev. J. MORRIS PEASE, Corresponding Secretary of the Pennsylvania Colonization Society acknowledges the following letter and its enclosure, from the estimable lady and distinguished poetess of New England, Mrs. SIGOURNEY, an act worthy of the imitation of other ladies: HARTFORD, Tuesday, March 8, 1853.

CLERKS IN THE DEPARTMENTS.--One reason why two of the Secretaries have announced that they will make no changes in the Clerks of their departments, except for cause, may be that the Clerks are nearly all Democrats. Such, we think, is the case in the State Department, where neither Mr. CLAYTON nor Mr. WEBSTER were at all proscriptive.

The New-Orleans Picayune makes the following suggestion in relation to fires in the holds of vessels, which at the present time is apropos: "To, extinguish a fire in the hold of a slip, nothing more is needed than the following simple apparatus.

On Thursday last, says the Watertown Union, a man by the name of Wm. Stuart died in this village very suddenly, from the effects of in temperance. He had been stopping at the "Centre" of the town lately, and before that at Ellis Village, and was known to be a man of very intemperate habits.

SILKS, SILKS, SHAWLS.-HEARD, CLAPP Co. No. 301 Grand-st., (late BARKER'S) has just received 10 cases rich Brocade and Figured Silks, also Glace. and Chameleon Silks, only 4s. 6d. per yard; 5 cases rich India Foulards, yard wide and heavy, from 5s.6d; 10 cases Embroidered and Plain Crape Shawls, from $3 to $5 less than the Importer's Prices; also, Broche long and square do.; Printed Cashmere do. in every variety, very cheap.

A correspondent of the Boston Advertiser states that a gentleman of this city, whose name is withheld, has donated to the Boston Athenaeum a large number of books, unequalled in value by any gift of books to the library since its foundation.

It is said the Cabinet discussions of Foreign Policy, during the last four days, resulted from the necessity of deciding on some general platform, with reference to which the appointments of Ministers and Charges abroad shall be made.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No, 112 Broadway, A.T.STEWART Co., (do.)..Broadway, Cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouses. R.L.ALLEN, (late A.B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Water.

Messrs. DANIEL ??, MORAM BROTHERS, STRACHAN SCOTT, Gev. POST, and others. GENTLEMEN: I am in receipt of yours of a recent date, calling my attention to a late publication, in which you say, "The undersigned Stockholders and Bondholders of your Company respectfully ask your attention to an article in the American Railroad Journal, of the 19th ins., in which the character of your Company is most unfavorably, and, we believe, most unjustly represented."

A CHANCE FOR THE TASTY.--As many a quiet citizen is looking out, at this time, for a hand some, cozy, comfortable dwelling, we may as well mention that LUDLOW sells, to-morrow, at public auction, the admirable three-storied dwelling, No. 175 East Fifteenth street, a most enviable property. It has all the modern convenience.; is three rooms deep on each floor, and has both basement and sub cellar.

SERIOUS STABBING AFFAIR.--About 1 o'clock yesterday morning, a man named THOMAS KEATLEY, a baker by trade, employed in Thirteenth-street, New-York, proceeded to the residence of JAMES STEPHENSON, in Jackson-court, leading from Front-street, between Gold-street and Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn, where he asked for admittance to see a female acquaintance.
