To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You desired me to write to you if I met anything worthy of being communicated. You see that I think I have. Yet, thus far, I can only report what I gather from the well-informed or well-judging; I have had no time for personal observation, such as I shall be able presently to employ.
The Lloyds says that in consequence of the unsettled state of affairs, Russia is taking great precautions to prevent an outbreak in Poland.

TRINIDAD.--A fatal case of typhus fever occurred at this Island, attributed entirely to the filthy, pestilential state of the premises on which it appeared. Two hundred and four men, forty-one women, and six children had arrived from Calcutta, by the first emigrant vessel this year.

INDIAN FORAY.--The Van Buren Intelligencer publishes the following extract from a letter dated North Fork, Cherokee Nation, Feb. 19: " A Post Chaplain was sent out some few weeks since to Camp, Belknap, on the Brazos--Rev. DA VID EAKIN, who for some time resided as a missionary near the Creek Agency.

EXCITEMENT--DISINTERRING THE REMAINS OF PROF. WINKLE.--The Trustees of the St. Peter's (Catholic) Cemetery, on Lick Run, a few days since, removed the remains of Professor NEPOMUK WINKLE, which were interred in that ground, to a corner spot of the Cemetery which was not consecrated ground.

EXTENSION OF PIERS.--The Common Council are fast extending piers into the river on either side our City, thus decreasing the surface of harbor accommodation. Pier No. 15, foot of Wall-street, now reaches four hundred and twenty-eight feet beyond low water mark, which is twenty-eight feet beyond the point to which the utmost claim of the Corporation extends.
Mrs. Hall, wife of John Hall, residing in the alley between Third and Fourth-sts., South Troy, died very suddenly last night, says the Troy Budget of Thursday.

The programme of a giant-looking Railway scheme in the West appeared in the London Times some months since, with an array of American notabilities as Managers, Counsellors, and Bankers, the exact object of which we could not divine at the moment our attention was called to it, but the progress of which we have not been unmindful of.

Mr. WALDO took charge of the pension bureau this morning. SAMUEL COLE, of New-York, late clerk in that office, was commissioned chief clerk, vice JOHNSON removed. W. W. DEXNISON, at present a Democratic clerk in the census office, was offered the chief clerkship of that office to-day.

We have no mail beyond Richmond this morning. The Washington Union publishes the Bolivian decree, opening to commerce the tributaries of the Amazon and La Plata rivers. Nearly twenty ports or points are declared free.

By the arrival of the brig Tornado, we have Bermuda dates to March 9. The transport ship Edward had arrived from London with 244 convicts. No appointment to the Governor ship of these Islands had taken place at the latest dates from England; but it is generally supposed that Captain EL LIOTT will be continued in the office for a further period.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I regretted to learn from your paper that Uncle Job had suffered from rheumatism and fatigue while seeking a house; and entirely agree with you that an explicit advertisement of all facts in relation to the domicil is most desirable, as saving time and trouble.

The Canada arrived at Boston yesterday at 9 o'clock, P. M. Her mails are not yet received in this City. Her news found its way slowly over the wires from Halifax, the whole of it not reaching this City until Saturday night.
A well-inflated bladder is a very substantial looking object :--but the prick of a pin renders it very contemptible. The Tribune affords a case in point, by its course on Copyright.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.---Madame SONTAG appears to-night as Amina, in "La Sonnambula." And with this opera and this representation, will terminate the season of the SONTAG troupe. No other performance is announced.

The Collins steamship Atlantic, from New York, Feb. 19, arrived at Liverpool at 6:25 A. M., 2d inst. The screw steamship City of Manchester, (probably City of Glasgow,) sailed from Liverpool at 5:30P. M., of the 2d inst., for Philadelphia.

We are not surprised at the general unanimity of sentiment and expression in our mercantile community, and among all classes of business men, in favor of the speedy pas sage of the bill now pending in the Legislature, to prohibit the circulation, in this State, of foreign bank notes, at greater rates of discount than those fixed by law for there demption of the bills of our own banks.

We have further intelligence by Telegraph from Halifax. The difficulty between Austria and Turkey seems to have been adjusted, and all danger of disturbance in that quarter has, for the time at least, passed away.

The war between Turkey and Montenegro is over. A telegraphic dispatch of the 1st inst., says: OMER PASHA is ordered to cease hostilities, and the march of the Austrians to the Croatian frontier is countermanded.

Some arrests are yet taking place in Milan. The church bells are still mute, and all the belfries are guarded. The dissemination of false news is punishable by court-martial, and it is under consideration to prosecute writers to foreign papers.

The demand for Money continues unabated, rates tending upward. Large arrivals of gold are expected daily. The Bullion in the Bank of England shows a decrease of [Pound]87,00O. Consols closed steady at 991@991. The precious metals remain as last quoted, excepting American Eagles, which sold in London, on the 4th, at 76s. 4d. ?? ounce.

Through telegraphic dispatches you have already been informed--and have given the in formation to the public--of the destruction by fire of the buildings, fixtures and library of the Wyoming Seminary.

The New-Haven Register is indebted to David Scranton, Esq., for a mess of new potatoes, dug on his premises a few days since. We ought, perhaps, to state, that while digging a cellar, the workmen came upon several full hills of potatoes; two feet under ground, from which those sent us were taken.

MARINE AFFAIRS.--The U. S. M. steamship Pacific, Capt. NYF, sailed from the foot of Canal street, at 12 o'clock, on Saturday, for Liverpool, with 102 passengers. GORHAM D. ABBOTT, Esq., bearer of dispatches, and JACOB ABBOTT, Esq., author of various educational works, are among the passengers.

To PREVENT JUMPING.--The many fatal accidents recorded, seems to have no effect in deterring boys, men, and even ladies, from the dangerous practice of jumping from and to the ferryboats before they are made fast.
The Foreign Goods entered at the New York Custom House, last week, were of the large aggregate value of FIVE MILLIONS, FOUR HUNDRED AND SEVENTY-SIX THOUSAND DOLLARS.
Captain MATTER was recalled, and having refreshed his memory by reference to papers, gave further testimony as to dates,
Mr. EVERETT addresses the Senate to-morrow on CLAYTON'S resolutions. His special object is to explain his letter transmitting England's proposition for a new treaty relative to Central America.

The Pope's journey to Paris is confidently looked for. His Holiness will stay in France two months, at Compeigne. M. BUSHBECK had an audience with the Emperor, who assured him that the Imperial manufactories should be worthily represented at the New-York Exhibition.

The sad condition of the Frank or European residents of Smyrna, for the last three or four years, has hardly its parallel in any port of commerce in the World. Bands of ruffian's have devised a scheme of torturing violence towards them, by means of which nearly every month they obtain black mail from some one to an enormous amount.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: The City Inspector recommends to the Common Council a prohibition of the sale of swill milk. That might do if a certain white liquid had not the power of being swill or milk with so great case to the owner.

Our readers may recollect an article in the DAILY TIMES, of a recent date, asking from the Legislature careful scrutiny of a pending bill, confirming the title of Capt. VANDERBILT to a certain water-right on Staten Island, and urging sundry reasons why the bill should not become a law.

On Saturday, March 19, after a brief illness, SARAH ELIZABETH, wife of J. Otis Averill. Her funeral will take place from the residence of her father. John H. Jones, at Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., this day, (Monday) at 1 o'clock, and her friends are rospecifully invited to attend.

The Governor-General of Cuba lately communicated to the American Consul a copy of the annexed directions, which he had issued to the Postmaster-General of the Island respecting newspapers, , for Cuba.

The Eco del Comercio of Vera Cruz, of which files to the 4th have been received, has the following extract from a Mexican paper: " Senor MUNOZ LEDO, one of the present Cabinet, has certainly determined to be the evil genius of our country, since his great desire is to place obstacles in the way of everything.

SAD MISTAKE.--During Saturday night, a young gentleman residing in First-street near south Fourth, while waiting upon his wife and sister--who are both laying sick in the same room,- gave six spoonsful of Elixir of Vitrol to his sister by mistake.

The British ship Shand, Capt. CHRISTIE, from Calcutta, Dec. 5th, arrived at this port yesterday. She brought the passengers and part of the crew of the clipper ship Golden Light, which sailed from this port Feb. 12th, for San Francisco.

This Committee, in reporting on the new basis for Banking, suggested the Stocks of the State of Virginia, as among the best to be introduced to the Department. This was done under the impression, as stated at the time, that the total Debt of Virginia was only $14,500,000.

The customs conferences between the Governments of the South Germanic were closed on the 22d ult., at Vienna. Saxony and Hesse, with all the minor Governments have signified their adhesion to the treaty just concluded between Austria and Prussia, and will assent to the renewal of the Zollverein, with Hanover included.
LEBENEY, the attempted assassin, was executed at Vienna on the 20th ult. The Emperor has not quite recovered from the wound, which is more serious than was at first supposed.

The schooner S. Morris Waln, from Pernambuco 17th ult., arrived this afternoon. The captain reports that on the 10th January, lat. 30[degrees] north, long. 29[degrees] west, on the outward passage, he was brought to by a black, topsail schooner, and boarded by a boat's crew, armed with pistols and dirks.

The East India mail had arrived in England, but brought no letters from Manila or Batavia. The Northwest was reported tranquil. From Burmah the ordinary channels of communication say nothing of consequence has occurred.

SHORE-FRONT IMPROVEMENTS.--The Morris Canal and Banking Company have signified their willingness to vacate that portion of their Canal and Basin lying within the limits of the city, provided an arrangement can be made with the Common Council by which they may build suitable piers and basins south of South-street.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday and Sun day were received this morning. To-night we have nothing from beyond Wilmington. Galveston papers to the 8th had been received, but they contain no news of interest.

The Sussex (N. J.) Register notices the decease of a venerable citizen of that County in the person of BENJAMIN HALSEY, Esq. He was a native of Morris County, born in April, 1764. For some ten years, he had a place in the local magistracy; and for the last thirty years was a ruling elder in the First Presbyterian Church at Newton.

Mr. PERRY, the operator of the Morse telegraphic line at Meriden, Conn., was instantly killed by the accommodation train from Springfield this afternoon. He was standing on the platform at the depot, and was in the act of handing a letter to sonic person on the cars while they were in motion, when he fell on the track, and the wheels of a passenger car passed over his neck.

The March Term of the Court of Appeals will commence on Tuesday, March 22, 1853, at the Capitol, in this city. There are 221 causes on the Calendar, the first 40 of which we give below: 1. Daniel Wood, respondent, against Alfred Hubbell and others appellants.

The Albany Evening Journal notices a rumor, current for some days past, that Mr. BELMONT, the New-York representative of the house of ROTHSCHILD, and the Consul General for Austria, is " a candidate for a diplomatic appointment," to Naples or Turin.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: Of the Premier of the new Administration, there can be little need of giving a very particular description to New-Yorkers. And yet, in the very different situations which Governor MARCY has occupied here and at home, he may well have aspects to us totally unlike hose he has borne to you.

The Canada's mails arrived from Boston at an early hour yesterday morning. A summary of the intelligence by this arrival has already been received by Telegraph from Halifax;--but our foreign correspondence and European files contain so many matters of interest and importance, that we surrender to them a large part of our space in this morning's TIMES.

The President of the United States assumes, this day, the supreme power of that great common wealth, and enters upon the duties of the office to which he was elected in December last by a large majority of his fellow citizens in almost every State of the Union. No man has ever commenced his high political career under circumstances more favorable than Gen. PIERCE.

Government has recently received two such strong proofs of what may be expected should a European war break out, that it is nearly akin to madness to push matters to an extremity with any foreign Power just now. We well know what may be expected in Italy should an opportunity present itself, and, if appearances are not very deceptive, things are just as bad in Hungary.

The Kreuz Zeitung states, apparently on good authority, that the chief features of the commercial treaty, negotiated by M. VON BRUCK between Austria and Prussia, are as follows: Both nations reciprocally put each other's shipping on the same footing as its own, and mutually admit each other's commerce to all advantages of the most favored nations.

The creek and canal are clear of ice, which moved down the river yesterday, and last night all was clear as far as Point Albino, where it is thought boats can easily get through. Steamers are preparing fast to go out.

We have no change to notice in the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets this week. The CORN trade is dull, and COTTON ?1/3d. lower; but most other articles are firmly held, and stocks decreasing, the long prevalence of easterly winds keeping vessels out.

NEW-GRENADA.--One of the late Panama, papers contains a letter from Medellin, in the interior of New-Granada, which speaks of the Provinces of Antioquia as another California. The Post-Office of Medellin has within the last ten months forwarded 6,400 pounds of gold dust, the product of the numerous mines which have been recently discovered in that region of country.

Progress and development are the two great, active principles which are now spurring the world on in its mighty strides. New forces, that former ages did not dream of, are descending for our use, the old ones are developing new capabilities, and some, which have industriously toiled in the service of man, are passing away, resting from their labors and quietly submitting to the reign of newer forms of power.

It is said, with what amount of foundation we are at present unable to state, that the Austrian Government has resolved to demand the extradition or, at least, the es?pulsion of KOSSUTH, MAZZINI, and the other refugees now fomenting revolution abroad under the shelter of British hospitality; and that, on the anticipated failure of this demand, the Governments of Prussia and of France are prepared to address a joint note to the same effect.

By the arrival of the Hibernia at Madras, and the Severn at Colombo, letters and papers from Melbourne and Port Phillip have been received to the 6th Dec. last. Their contents are important, but require confirmation.

It would appear, by the following statement from the New-Orleans Picayune, that Vice-President KING was duly sworn in on the 4th of March, notwithstanding the telegraphic reports to the contrary. The Picayune says: We have been favored with the following extract from a private letter from Matanzas, received in this city by the Crescent City:

THE RIO GRANDE.--A letter from Eagle Pass or Fort Duncan, dated Feb. 14, has the following: "On last Friday, the 12th of this month, about two hundred Rio Grandians from Presidio, Rio Grande, came up to attack the town of Peidras Negras, just opposite to us, in Mexico.

Mr. EVERETT'S speech to-day was well calculated to allay all excitement that may have grown out of the apprehension that England is disposed to violate the CLAYTON BULWER Treaty, It was beautiful in style and greatly admired.

The U. S. Mail steamship Crescent City, Capt. RODNEY BAXTER, arrived yesterday morning from New-Orleans and Havana, having left the latter port on the 10th inst. She brings three days later news, but there is little of importance.

There has been variety, if nothing else, the Parliamentary sayings and doings of the week. In the Lords the Canada Clergy Reserves bill produced a grand Episcopal" field day" on Monday evening, and a strong developement of opposition to the bill. The truth is, the clergy scent danger afar off, and if the principle of allowing the Canadian Legislature to deal with church property be conceded, the precedent might be dangerous nearer home.

Dr. DAVIS, Hon. GEO. EVANS, and Col. PAYNE were recalled and identified a paper in Spanish, purporting to be the title deed of GEORGE A. GARDINER to his mine in San Luis Potesi. Also a translation of the same as having been before the Board of Commissioners.

The death of Judge ANDREW T. JUDSON in Connecticut, has been before announced. The following incidents in his life are interesting. He was a native of Ashford, Windham Co., Ct., and at an early age attached himself to the Democratic party, in which he gained considerable notoriety.

MISSING.--CHARLES E. DAVIS, Esq., Deputy Clerk of the Supreme Court, , in this city, suddenly disappeared last Friday morning, and has not since been heard of by his friends. Fears are entertained for his safety.

In the House of Commons, on the 3d of March, Lord DUDLEY STUART, in moving for certain papers, called the attention of the house to the affairs of Turkey, as affected by the contest now proceeding in Montenegro.

The trial of ARTHUR SPRING was commenced in the Criminal Court at 10 o'clock this morning, before Judges ALLISON and KELLY. By 11 o'clock the Jury was sworn, and the trial is now progressing. There is a great crowd in and around the Court-House.

Through our files of the Diario de la Marina, we are placed in possession of intelligence from the City of Mexico, to the 3d inst., and from Vera Cruz to the 6th inst. Of the twenty-three States of the confederation, sixteen have declared for SANTA ANNA. The Government in the meantime remains in the hands of Gen. LOMBARDINI, who is prepared to surrender it into the hands of the President elect whenever he presents himself.

BOOKS.--The Trade Sale of Messrs. BANGS BROTHER Co., is largely attended, and the bidding is conducted with unusual spirit. The invoices of Messrs. A. S. BARNES Co. were despatched yesterday. To-morrow the sale of Messrs. HARPER BROTHER will probably occupy the day.

The Vienna Lloyd, a semi-official organ of the Austrian Government, publishes in very conspicuous type the telegraphic dispatch from Trieste, announcing that the Ottoman Porte had complied with all the demands of Austria.

The Senate resumed the consideration of Mr. CLAYTON'S resolutions, calling on the President for certain information relative to Central American affairs. Mr. EVERETT addressed the Senate. MR. EVERETT'S SPEECH.

Much curiosity exists as to the nature of the instructions to be given to M. DE LA COUR, on proceeding to his new post at Constantinople, and the line of policy France purposes to follow on the Turkish question in its present complicated state.

In the House of Lords on the night of the 4th, Lord LYNDHURST called attention to the irritation that prevailed in Austria towards the Government and people of England, in consequence of the conduct of certain political refugees in that country. He expressed the opinion that the British laws already provided sufficiently for punishing any conspiracy, on the part either of British subjects or of foreign refugees, against the peace of neighboring States.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Madame SONTAG made her farewell appearance last evening, in "the Sonnambula." Decidedly the most crowded house of the season greeted her; throughout she was received with cordial applause, and on the termination of the second act, was thrice called before the curtain.
The operations against Montenegro are vigorously carried on by the Turks, whose great object at present is to pass the Obostizza in the north, and the Zetta and Sitnizza in the east.

The U. S. Mail steamship Crescent City, from New-Orleans and Havana, arrived yesterday morning, in four days and sixteen hours from Havana. The officers of the steamer report that there were a large number of European vessels in the harbor of Havana, awaiting cargoes.

The Santa Fe Mail has arrived at Independence. There is, however, no news of interest. Trade was still depressed. Gov. LANE was on a tour of observation at El Paso, and was to return, by the copper mines, through the Nauvoo country.

To the Editor of the Daily News: SIR: I have no opportunity, from the place where I am, of reading papers or receiving correct information; but a report reaches me of LOUIS KOSSUTH having publicly protested on account of the proclamation to the Hungarians which appeared during the last insurrectionary attempt at Milan.

The details of the foreign news which we publish this morning, will be read with interest. No event, has occurred of striking importance: but all the movements of Europe are significant of contending interests and popular discontents, which cannot fail? ere long to give rise to great changes or great endeavors after change.

SPRING WEATHER.--Particularly bright and pleasant have been the past two days, and the old fable of the traveler and the Sun has been well illustrated in the laying aside of top coats and mufflers under the May-day warmth of his beams.

Dates from Galveston to March 8 have been received by telegraph, and the following details arrive rid New-Orleans: A letter from San Antonio to the Galveston News says: The removal of the headquarters of the army has undoubtedly been a drawback to San Antonio. The Quartermaster's Department is still here, but that is expected also to be removed shortly, which will be a great loss to the place.

The Code was reported this morning, and a warm debate ensued on a motion to postpone the matter indefinitely. The ground taken in support of this motion was, that there was not time properly to consider the report during the present session. Some make this objection in good faith, others because they don't want the Code passed, and others still, because they want to ensure an extra sessession; but there will be no extra session.

MURDER IN BOSTON.--The Boston Journal of Friday has the following account of a horrible murder: The corner of North (formerly Ann) and Richmond-streets, was last night the scene of a tragedy which adds one more to the catalogue of murders which have occurred in that locality within the remembrance of many of our citizens.

Three wise men of Baltimore have declared their hostility to the base mechanical privilege of setting a price upon one's own labor. A late Attorney-General is one of them; a noted and eloquent champion of Colonization is another.

A correspondent of the Boston Traveller, writing from Florence, February 10, says: "Our Minister to Turkey still remains here, awaiting instructions from Washington in regard to the case of Mr. KING, the missionary at Athens.
MARINE AFFAIRS--At noon, yesterday, the steamboat Fairy was launched from the yard of Mr. ISAAC C. SMITH, at Hoboken. She is 90 feet in length; breadth of beam, 19 feet; depth of hold, 51 1/2 feet.

NEW FRENCH AND ENGLISH ENGRAVINGS.--Assassination of the Duke of Guise, $16; Le Temeraire, Oberwesel, after Turner, each $3; Christmas Eve, a beautiful print, $5; Sermon on Temperance, a comical print, $3; Portrait of Sir Robert Peel, $5; Genevieve de Brabant, and parlor prints, each $8--besides a splendid assortment of engravings, suitable for the parlor, the portfolio, landscape and figure studies.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: "The discussion of the question is healthful, and will lead to good results if conducted without offensive personalities, and without drawing into the controversy the peculiar doctrines and ceremonies of either Catholicsm or Protestantism."

NAVAL.--The U. S. steamer Massachusetts, whose arrival we before noticed, went up to the Yard, on Thursday afternooon, in tow of the U. S. steamer Engineer. It is said she is to have immediate and extensive repairs.

To the Editor of the N. Y. Daily Times: SIR: You will not object, I think, to receive an endorsement from a Southern man of the statements contained in number seven of "Letters on the productions, industry and resources of the Southern States," published in your issue on Thursday last.

The Moniteur has been unusually fertile in decrees lately, but they possess no interest, being mostly individual appointments to office. A batch of new Senators is created, and several members are added to the Council of State.

French political affairs still move on quietly, as at my last date. Those so often-quoted entities, " political circles," would be reduced to silence for lack of argument, were their range of topics limited to domestic affairs.

From the London Times. It is impossible to reconcile the proelamations and assertions of the Austrian authorities in Lombardy, on the breaking out of the late insurrection, with the unexampled and indiscriminating rigor of the measures they have taken since the termination of it.

The report made in the New-Brunswick Legislature, on the subject of the Fisheries and Reciprocal trade with the United States, takes strong grounds in defence of maintaining the Provincial claim to the fisheries.

The Boston Journal learns, from Capt. WINSOR, of ship Golden Light, which was destroyed by fire, that the passengers were all saved in the boats that were picked up, and brought to this port, as before stated.

We have further accounts of the arrangement come to between Austria and Turkey. On 12th ult., a Divan was held at Constantinople, at which all the high dignitaries of the land,--both in and out of office,--were assembled.

MOVEMENT WITH THE BROOKLYN BUTCHERS.--On Monday evening last, the regular Butchers of Brooklyn held a meeting for the purpose of devising means to protect themselves against the evils arising from the sale of impure meats, by persons now in the business, who scarcely know whether they are selling meat that died by sickness, or by the Butcher's knife.

The brig Montague, from the city of St. Domingo, March 1, reports that the yellow fever had disappeared from that place. The schooner Champion, from Aux Cayes, March 1. reports that the fever had disappeared there also.
The Intelligencer says that on account of the continued severe indisposition of Mrs. FILLMORE, the ex-President's Southern tour will be postponed till next month. Perhaps abandoned altogether.

In the House of Lords, on Monday, 8th inst., the Earl of ABERDEEN replied, in answer to a question by the Earl of MALMESIURY, that the Government had no information as to MAZZINI having escaped on board the British frigate Retribution.
The Tribune gives the public the benefit of a somewhat elaborate exposition of the principles on which its editorial department is conducted.

There is a terrible German refugee, named and titled MAX, Count GORITZ, established in London. There is also a French lady residing there named JAVENOT. The refugee has run off with the daughter of the lady, and pretends to have married her.

By arrival of the steamship Texas at New Orleans, we have Galveston papers to the 11th inst. The Galveston News, of the 11th, has the following paragraphs: "A general attendance of delegates from all the lodges of I. O. O. F. of the interior counties is expected at the next session of the Grand Lodge, when the removal of its location will be proposed to some convenient point of the interior."

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway, A. T. STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, Cor. Reade-st.

The Spring is slowly coming up this way. She has made her appearance among us on two or three soft, moist days; but "the lion March," before going to Labrador, has been making cold snaps at her, and driving her back.

Letters from Berne, of the 27th ult., state that the Federal Council has determined to address a note to all the European powers, showing that the accusations brought against it by Austria are unfounded.

On Tuesday, March 22, at Jersey City, COURTLAND, second son of Wm. H. and Lydia Scott, aged 10 years, 8 months and 6 days. Oh! what a shadow o'er the heart is flung, When peals the requiem of the lov'd and young.

FROM LIBERIA.--Letters have been received from Rev. Bishop SCOTT, who left Baltimore last Fall, to visit the Methodist Missions in Liberia. The Bishop arrived at Monrovia on the 6th of Jan. in good health, which continued up to the 12th of that month, when the Bishop was about to leave Monrovia for Cape Palmas ; and he would probably be absent one month on that tour.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate several communications from the Department of the Interior. Mr. WELLER submitted a resolution that the Select Committee on the Mexican Boundary Commission, be allowed until next session to make their report.

The last of the People's Course of Lectures was delivered by Rev. THOMAS K. BEECHER, of Williamsburg, at the Tabernacle, last evening. The house was well filled, and nobody was disappointed who went to hear a pleasant, peculiar, instructive, eloquent and rich exposition of the way" to manufacture American Citizens."

A bill before the Maryland Senate pro vides that an annual tax shall be "levied upon all free negroes between the ages of twenty-one and fifty-five, that is on every male five dollars, and on every female one dollar."

THE MASSACHUSETTS POOR.--Of the 27,737 State paupers in Massachusetts, more than 11,000 are foreigners; nearly 10,000 of them British subjects. More than 1,500 foreign paupers arrived during the last year.
The West India Mail steamer Orinoeo with the West India mails, arrived at Southampton, free of fever, at 6:40 P. M., of the 8th. At Plymouth, 8th, arrived steamer Forerunner, with the African mails.
The Emperor has so far recovered from his wound that no further bulletins will be issued. On the 5th inst., he was able to go out for a drive. It would seem that he made a narrow escape.

JAMMED.--Yesterday a man named JAMES TONSOLE fell between the wharf and the side of a schooner, and was dangerously jammed. Medical assistance was immediately provided, and in an hour, with great difficulty, he was restored to consciousness. Several of his ribs were broken.

SPRING was brought up from Prison about 8 o'clock, though the Court did not open till 10. There was a great crowd in and about the Court House. The examination of witnesses was continued, the whole chain of evidence being of the most complete character, only requiring that of young SPRING to fasten the guilt upon the accused.
The press is commenting widely and freely upon a verdict recently rendered against the Proprietor of the Mirror of $250 damages for a libel published in that paper upon Mr. FORREST, the actor.

SWINDLE ON CALIFORNIA PASSENGERS.--Last evening Justice MCGRATH proceeded with the investigation of charges preferred against a Mr. GEO. E. HAMILTON, who has absconded, for defrauding several parties by the sale of tickets purporting to be genuine, and authorizing a passage to California in the steamship Uncle Sam.

The Senate, in secret session, confirmed CAMPBELL, for the Supreme Court, and RICHARD P. HAMMOND, Collector, and 0. P. SUTTON, Appraiser, at San Francisco. S. R. HOBBIE was nominated First Assistant Postmaster-General--the office he held for several years formerly.

DIOCESE OF NEW-JERSEY.--On Palm Sunday, March 20, in St. Mary's Church, Burlington, Rev. Professor DOANE read morning prayer, and the Bishop preached, and confirmed twenty-two per sons, making forty-three in this parish since the last Convention.

Trial of Gervinns. The two processes against Prof. GERVINUS have just been brought before the courts of Baden. The appeal of the Professor against the confiscation of his book, " Introduction to the History of the Nineteenth Century," was heard by the Hofyericht at Mannheim, on the 20th ult., and rejected-GERVINUS being condemned in the costs.

SCHOOL EXAMINATION.--The closing examination of Ward School No. 4, took place on Monday evening. The class under examination was the senior one of the male department, which is under the immediate supervision of the Principal, Mr. BUCKLEY.
In the Chamber of Representatives, on the 4th, a bill was presented, asking for an annual dotation of 200,000 francs for the Duke DE BRABANT, as heir presumptive to the throne.

NAVAL.--The report that about two hundred mechanics were discharged from the Navy Yard at Charlestown, on the 12th inst., proves to be incorrect, as only about one-fourth part of that number were discharged at that time.

It is a pity that Col. BENTON postponed his second general epistle upon the Pacific Railroad until too late for Congressional discussion. There was much in it calculated to throw more effectual light on the project than all that had been previously said.

Receiving yesterday from friends in the South a request to be informed of the probable time of Ex-President FILLMORE'S departure from Washington, we have made inquiry on the subject, and answer thus publicly, for the information of our readers in the South generally, to all of whom it will be of interest.

The bill to consolidate certain Railroads will pass. This is a fixed fact, and an exceedingly important one. There was a sort of test vote today, on a motion to postpone. It stood 28 to 63, with a dozen more members in the city, but not in the House, in favor of the bill.

ROM OREGON.--A letter received at the Methodist Mission Rooms, in this city, from Rev. T. H. PEARNE, reports that at Salem a new Methdist Episcopal Church has been erected at a cost of $9,000. It was opened free of debt, the Revs. Messrs. PEARNE and WALLER having collected a balance of $300 within a week of the opening.

The point pending at the adjournment yesterday--the objection by the defence to Capt. BARRY testifying to the boundaries of Laguinillas County, where GARDINER'S mines were located, from the hearsay definitions of these boundaries. by people residing there--was argued till nearly 4 o'clock, and the Court sustained the objection.
Reports continue to circulate regarding a contemplated Spanish loan with the negotiation of which M. SALAMANCA, who is now in Paris, is said to be charged.

The vacancy on the Bench of the Supreme Court of the United States, caused by the de cease, last year, of Justice McKINLEY, of the South-Western Circuit, is at length filled by the nomination of Mr. J. A. CAMPBELL, of Mobile.

MAZZINI has published two letters, which have produced disunion in the Democratic camp--so it is reported, at least. The Democracy were in consequence already arranged into two parties, the poor, calling them " Barrabas," who approved of the attempt of MAZZINI against Lombardy, and the nobles, who, apprehensive of the confiscation of their property, loudly condemned it in their conversations and journals.
It seems as if about one day out of every seven the telegraphic wires are down, and news has to wait for hours, sometimes for days, before it can reach its destination.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The old time honored stage route from Troy to Burlington, Vt., so familiar to Northern travelers, has given way to the rail track and locomotive; so that now on arriving at Troy, instead of the anxious inquiry, " Is there room in the stage," the query is, which of three routes by railroad is it best

By the arrival of the Atlantic we are enabled to give a few days later news from Europe. It is not at all startling however. The Parliamentary de bates are somewhat interesting. The coming of Mazzini, the New Grenada affairs, the Darien Ship Canal, and mints in the gold-producing colonies, have passed in their review.

The Albany Journal says: Emma Snodgrass, the lady of newspaper notoriety--the wanderer in man's apparel--who some time since created a great deal of talk in Boston, and was finally brought before the Police Magistrate of that city, has at last paid us a visit.

LARGE FIRE--NEARLY ONE WHOLE SQUARE DESTROYED.--Last evening about 5 o'clock, a fire broke out in a stable occupied by Messrs. POWEL VINING, in a small alley leading from York-street, between Pearl and Adams-streets.

From the London Times. We have this day to announce a step which, simple and unpretending as it may seem, is really a greater move towards a complete unity of our independent Empire than the most splendid conquest or the largest annexation.

PETITIONS. By Mr. MORGAN for a law relative to emigrants; also, two remonstrances on same subject; Mr. BABCOCK for a bridge at Black Rock, Erie County; Mr. BEEKMAN for incorporation of National Guard Institute.

Lisbon dates of the 1st inst. say that the Chambers, in this the second month of their session, were still discussing their reply to the speech from the throne. No business of importance in political affairs.
We believe the readers of the TIMES will bear us witness that we have, from the beginning, tried very hard to mind our own business, and to trouble them with it as little as possible.

The U. S. mail steamship Atlantic, Capt. WEST, arrived yesterday afternoon, from Liverpool, whence she brings dates to March 9. The Niagara, hence on the 24th ult., arrived in the Mersey on the morning of the 8th inst.

Liverpool Grain and Cotton Markets. Per Atlantic.] LIVERPOOL, March 8, 1853. COTTON--Our market for this staple on Saturday and yesterday was quiet but steady, with a fair amount of business doing at the full prices of Tuesday.
There are several large Churches along the street known as University-place,--and morning service on Sunday is over in all of them at just about the same time,--a little after noon.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: A paragraph in your paper of the 22d, headed "Charge of Robbing Letters," conveys the erroneous idea that messengers in our employ had been guilty of robbery upon letters intrusted to our Express. This is not the case.
I have seldom witnessed a more exciting legislative contest than that which closed with the passage of the Railroad Consolidation bill.

TEMPERANCE CELEBRATION AT METROPOLITAN HALL.--The Seventh Anniversary of E. L. SNOW Social Union No. 1, was held last evening in Me tropolitan Hall. The ladies of the Society caused to be prepared a suitable testimonial to Col. E. L. SNOW, which was presented on their behalf by Rev. N. B. BALDWIN, Pastor of Bethesda Church.

The National Intelligencer a few days ago, in reviewing CHARLES B. STUART'S Publication on the Naval and Mail Steamers of the United States, stated that the establishment of our lines of Atlantic Mail Steamers, is mainly due to E. K. COLLINS, Esq., of New-York.

THE FIRE IN BROOKLYN.--ACCIDENTS.--FIREMAN OF ENGIRE CO. NO. 12 KILLED.--The Firemen exerted themselves with a perseverance and promptitude deserving of the highest praise, at the extensive fire in Brooklyn Tuesday. They experienced great difficulty from want of water.
We published yesterday morning a very concise correspondence between Mr. WEBSTER while Secretary of State, and Mr. RIVES, the American Minister at Paris.

Most of this morning's news is of domestic matters. A single item from Mexico ends the chapter of Foreign intelligence. Eleven of the States of Mexico have cast their votes for. Santa Anna. He was expected to make his appearance in the British steamer on the 1st of April.

In pursuance of a numerously signed public notice addressed to "The Friends of Civil and Religious Liberty," a large assemblage convened in the Tabernacle, last evening, for the purpose of welcoming to the United States Father GAVAZZI, the celebrated Roman patriot and orator.

The Delta has later dates from the City of Mexico, by the brig Brownsville, from Vera Cruz 5th inst. The news, however, is of little importance. The State of Durango had cast its vote in favor of SANTA ANNA, making eleven States which had voted for him.

The proposed General Law for organizing Life and Health Companies is not called for by sound policy. At least such a bill as the one now before the Assembly is not. It is wholly inadequate to any safe purpose.

ELECTION BY THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--The annual election of Assistant Engineers for the Fire. Department was commenced on Tuesday evening at the Fireman's Hall in Wooster-street, and as usual, was continued over to last evening.
In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found,--reported specially for its columns, and revised by the author,--the speech delivered in the Senate on Monday last by Mr. EVERETT.

The Senate to-day confirmed Hon. HUGH J. ANDERSON, of Maine, Commissioner of Customs; RICHARD P. HAMMOND, Collector; and PHILIP A. ROACH, Appraiser, at San Francisco; HENRY WILTON, Marshal of Illinois.
The trial of ARTHUR SPRING for the murder of ELLEN LYNCH and HONORA SHAW, was commenced at Philadelphia on Monday, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer--Judges ALLISON and KELLY on the Bench.

On Tuesday evening a special meeting of the above Society was held at their rooms in the University, Washington-square. After transacting some more routine business, the Society proceeded to the Chapel of the University, for the purpose of hearing Captain MARCY read a paper descriptive of his recent explorations amongst the Camanche Indian tribes of the western plains.

The Susquehanna Bridge bill has been again under discussion in the Legislature to-day, on a proposed amendment restricting the Company from discriminating against way travel. Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Stock sold here today at 76.

SUPERIOR COURT AT NISI PRIUS.--Before Judge BOSWORTH.--Richard G. Fowles vs. Henry C. Bowen.--This case has been before alluded to, and we now present a concise report of the facts and the charge of the Judge.

SENATE... WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 23. The Senate proceeded to the consideration of Mr. HAMLIN'S resolution that the same extra compensation be allowed to the Superintendent of Printing and Clerk and Messengers under him, as is paid by the resolution of the Senate to the Clerks and Messengers of a similar grade.

ROBBERY OF GOLD PENS BY AN APPRENTICE.--Yesterday morning Captain LOVETT and Officer McPHERSON, of the Ninth Ward police, arrested a young lad named CHAS. W. BERRY, upon a charge of stealing one hundred gold pens, valued at $50, from the manufactury of Messrs. W. J. RICHARDSON, No. 4 Liberty-street, where he was an apprentice.

A petition was presented from the Mechanics of New-York against the Emigration Bill. The Maspeth Avenue Bill was ordered to a third reading. Also, the bill relative to the conveyance made by the Dutch Church, corner of Green and Houston-streets.

We have just received the particulars of a murderous attempt upon the life of Major PEMBERTON, which occurred at Fort Hamilton on Tuesday. Some time since, Major P. had occasion to prefer charges against a Corporal, named WHITE, which charges, through the Major's clemency, were afterwards withdrawn, and WHITE released.

The examination of Capt. EDWARD BARRY was resumed this morning. He described, from personal explorations the whole region of Lagunillas, where GARDINER locates his mine. It is an extremely mountainous wild country; roads leading to it very bad, principally mule paths, and utterly impassable for wheel carriages.

The Court to-day decided not to discharge the attachment against HORACE H. DAY, and required him to give $5,000 security to appear before the Master and abide by the decision of the Court. This he did and was discharged from custody.

Last evening we attended; by invitation, a private Concert, at the Apollo Rooms, given by a new aspirant for fame, Mr. GOCKEL. This gentle man is a pianist, and contemplates, we presume, giving a series of Concerts--himself the principal attraction.

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT.--Before Judge BETTS.--The Grand Jury came into Court with true bills against Cramer Varnum, of the firm of Farnham Co., of Cohoes, Troy, for making fraudulent entries at the Customs of threads of the alleged value of $6,800, when the real value was $15,000. The Court ordered the defendant to find bail in $5,000, and in the civil suit to recover the penalties to find bail in $20,000,

At St. Cro?? on Sunday, Feb. 20, EDWARD J., son of Wood Gibson, in the 33d year of his age. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral at St. Johns Church, on Friday afternoon, at 3 1/2 o'clock, without further invitation.

DAYS OF GRACE.--The House of Representatives consumed a large part of the session yesterday in the consideration of a motion to reconsider the vote whereby they ordered to a third reading on Friday, the bill fixing the payment of notes and drafts due on Sunday and holidays for the succeeding legal day instead of the preceding, as now required by law.

FIRE IN BROADWAY.--Between 12 and 1 o'clock Tuesday night, a fire broke out in the upper story of the brown stone building No. 598 Broad way, next door to the Club House. The apartment where it originated was occupied by the " Island City Lodge."

WILLIAM B. MANN sunmmed up the evidence against the prisoner this morning, and was followed by JOSEPH M. DORAN, counsel for the prisoner, who, in opening, stated he had, in the most solemn manner, appealed to his client to confess the crime if guilty, but met with protestations of innocence, and instructed by SPRING, he repeated the asseverations.

"Hans Yorkel" writes to the N.O. Bulletin of the heterogeneousness of the Telegraphs, as follows: Is the printing Telegraph used in your city? If so, step into the confidential office some day, (as you are a disereet man, it will be permitted I dare say,) and look over the cross readings which come out of the wheel to be clipped out by subjects from the long and narrow slip of electric paper.

The Philadelphia Bulletin relates the following incident: John Aspdep, Whose sudden death on Monday was noticed, Is to be buried this afternoon, from Swanson-street, Southwark. Mr. Aspden was one of the English claimants of the immense estate left by Matthias Aspden.

The President nominated to-day, JOHN SLIDELL, of Louisiana, as Minister to Central America. He is an able man; a friend to the Compromise; and was an advocate for BUCHANAN'S nomination. The announcement in the Senate greatly surprised Senators,--especially Mr. SOULE, who does not at all like the nominee.

Fall Part-cutars may be found in our Advertising Columns. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--She Stoops to Conquer--The Pet of the Petticoats. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Merry Wives of Windsor--Two Queens. BROADWAY THEATRE--Gladiator--Twas 1. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--A Phenomenon in a Smock Frock--Bluebeard. ST. CHARLES THEATRE.--A New Way to Pay Old Debts--To Paris and Back for [pound]5.

GOV. RAMSAY AND HIS INDIAN TROUBLES. The Senate proceeded to the consideration of Mr. WALKER'S resolution authorizing the Committee on Indian Affairs to delegate one of their number to proceed, during the recess of Congress, to take testimony in the matter now on reference to said Committee, touching certain frauds alleged to have been committed by ALEXANDER RAMSAY and others, in making payment of money to certain bands of Sioux Indians.

Several of the Paris papers have republished within the past fortnight, an article taken from the Courier des Etats Unis, on the Rev. ELEAZER WILLIAMS, alias CHIARLES LOUIS CAPET, the last Dauphin-" positively the last," as the advertisements say. He is the fifth in order of pretenders to the name of the unfortunate child who died at the Temple, June 8, 1795.

Our Legislators at Albany worked like men yesterday and earned their wages, books, pocket-knives, stationery and all. The Senate passed several bills, among which was one of a good deal of importance, authorizing the construction of a Ship Canal from Albany to New Baltimore; and another especially gratifying to those who believe that the morality of our City depends upon the healthy condition of our Schools, the bill consolidating the Public Schools of New-York.

We have no mail beyond Charleston to night. The Maryland House of Delegates to-day passed--by Yeas 38, Nays 14--the bill authorizing the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad Company to bridge the Susquehanna River at Have de Grace.

On Thursday, Alarch 24, at St. Paul's Church, Brooklyb by Rev. Mr. Labagh, Mr. WILLIAM THOMPSON, of this City, to Miss FANNY, youngest daughter of the late Joseph Brereton, Esq., of Manchester, England. On Wednesday evening, March 23, at the Reformed Dutch Churwh, Lafayette Place, by Rev. Dr. T. E. Vermilye, THEO. B. TAYLOR to KATE, daughter of James II. Brundage, Esq., all of this City.

Hon. GEORGE EVANS, wishing to return home, was recalled, and identified several papers as having been filed with the Board by Dr. GARDINER, in evidence. The Counsel for the defence proposed to interrogate him as to the mode of proceeding upon the claim, and the reasons by which the Board were governed in making the award.

RIOT.--On Tuesday evening, about 10 o'clock, a mob attacked a Church in North Second street, near Union-avenue, while the congregation (colored) were holding a meeting, and endangered the lives of the inmates by throwing stones through the windows. Officer CUNNINGHAM attempted to quell the riot, when the assailants turned upon and drove him off.

We were disposed to regard the appointment of Prof. DEBOW to the Census Office, as among the most judicious nominations of the new administration. Mr. DEBOW has de voted himself ardently to the perplexing study of statistics. As editor of the Review which

-- There is a very loud outcry raised in sundry quarters against elementary education be. cause it does not always prevent crime. That it has some influence in diminishing it may fairly be inferred from certain facts stated by an English barrister, Mr. FREDERICK HILL, who has also been Inspector of Prisons,-in a work recently published upon "Crimc,--its amount, causes and remedies."
A Whig ticket for State Officers is announced this morning, by the Committee appointed at the late Whig Convention. The nominations are as follows:

Goodyear vs. Day--March term U. S. Circuit Court.--It seems that in October last the District Judge ordered the defendant, DAY, in contempt, and issued an attachment against him, returnable at this term of the Court. Mr. DAY was not served with the attachment, and on the first day of the term voluntarily appeared in Court with his Counsel, and moved to discharge the attachment on the ground that it was irregularly issued by the Court.

Considering the particular animal sale especially to delight in that pastime, it is a little startling to observe how nearly universal, is the taste for kicking a dead lion. Much of the current braying against KOSSUTH prompts instinctively Betsey Trotwood's exclamation --"donkeys!"

The Telegraph announces the death of Dr. ALEXANDER DUNCAN, of Cincinnati. His name is identified with the eventful Congressional events which followed the accession of Mr. VANBUREN to the Presidency in 1837. He entered the House, we believe, two years previous to this date.

The Buffalo Express publishes a list of all the vessels and steamers now in process of construction on the different lakes. The total number amounts to 8 steamers, 20 propellers, and 77 said vessels--making a total of 105, and a tonnage of 39,700.

"OPENING OF ASSESSMENTS."--Several par ties have complained to the Common Council lately in relation to assessments on their property, which they themselves caused to be improved. A Committee was appointed to investigate the subject and report. The following is an extract:

The Washington Union of Thursday last, pronounces the statement of Count LEININ-GEN having failed in his mission to the Porte, and of his return, to be unfounded; and there upon--in connection with the other news from that distant point-bases some observations by no means calculated to encourage those brave men in the Old World, who hold their lives in their hands, ready to purchase with their blood the freedom of their native lands.

The merchants of Baltimore have held a public meeting on the subject of Southern steam shilps--HENRY MANKIN, Esq., presiding. Two Committees were appointed to obtain reliable data respecting coastwise steamers to Southern ports, and to open negotiations for a Liverpool line. One

MAINE LANDS.--The following is the concluding paragraph of the Report made on Saturday last by the Massachusetts Land Agent: "There are now something over one million of acres of land in the State of Maine belonging to Massachusetts, not included in this sale.

We will be obliged to the oldest inhabitaht of this town to point to a morning when less news was stirring. Notwithstanding, our paper will be found very interesting, of course,--particularly so to conservative people, who like to take a long breath, once in a while, and he sure that no sudden revolution has occurred during that refreshing operation.

MOVEMENT FOR INCREASED WAGES.--The movement for an advance of wages continues to spread among journeymen in every department of labor. On Wednesday evening a meeting of the coach-painters of New-York was held, for the purpose of taking immediate measures to get an, advance of wages of two shillings a day.

The Colonization Society of Maryland has elected CHARLESS HOWARD, Esq., as President for the ensuing year, vice J. H. B. LATROBE, elected Prespident of the American (Colonization Society. Mr. HOWARD has been a Director of the Maryland Association ever since 1826.

Mr. VANDERBILT closed his elaborate and very able Canal speech this morning. It will be prepared for publication and will be found to be the most triumphant vindication of the Canal policy of the State that has been written in many years.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Delineations of character, such as I am drawing, are, for their effect, helped by parallel, provided it be not too formal or too forced. A real and well-managed contrast of trait with trait, serves, like well-distributed light and shade in a picture, to make the figures set off' each other.

THE COMBINATION OPERA TROUPE.--Our readers will by this time be familiar with the programme of the ALBONI and MARETZEK troupes. The repertoire is published in another column, and cannot, we think fail to give satisfaction to the most insatiate of operatic epicures. The management appears to be determined to appeal to all tastes, and offers to each a dish of rare excellence.

MR. FILLMORE.--EX-Secretaries STUART and CONRAD, and Postmaster HUBBARD, following the example of the Ex-President and Mr. EVERETT, have severally addressed to the Mayor of Buffalo letters of thanks, for invitations extended to the late Cabinet to visit that City. They all speak in high praise of Mr. FILLMORE. Mr. STUART'S letter is a specimen:

The late Professor ANTHONY DUMOND STAN LEY-not WALKER, as erroneously announced a few days ago-Professor of Mathematics in Yale College, was a native of East Hartford, Conn., and was born on the al of April, 1810. In 1832, he was elected Tutor in Yale College, and in 1836 was ap pointed Professor of Mathematics.

This Court commenced its March Term at the Capitol this morning. Present--Ruggles, Chief Judge; Gardiner, Jewett, Johnson, Morse, Willard, Mason and Taggert, Judges. Motions were first heard. Several motions to correct the Calendar were first disposed of.

BANCOR THELOGICAL SEMINARY.-- By a catalogue of the Bangor (Me.) Theological Semi nary, we see that there are in that Institution 43 students. Most of them are graduates of some of the New-England College; 10 from Amherst, 9 from Bowdoin, 2 from Harvard, The Anniversary is on the last Wednesday in August.

ENFORCING ORDINANCES.--His Honor Mayor LAMBERT has gone to work in good earnest to en force all the ordinances of the City, particularly those affecting in any way the health of the City. He is very well supported by the police in this effort for the general good, and every day numerous arrests are made of parties violating ordinances which have heretofore been but partially, if at all, enforced.

During the whole of yesterday, the excitement within and around the Court-House was intense. Everybody seemed anxious to obtain a glimpse of the prisoner, and, as far as it could be done with propriety, the officers gratified the crowd, after they had secured the prisoner within the Court Room.

We published yesterday morning a full report of the speech made by Father GAVAZZI at the Tabernacle, to an audience of some thousands of persons, assembled to give him a welcome to the United States, and we publish this morning a letter from Mr. LYNCH, the intelligent and liberal-minded Editor of the Irish American in reply to some of the sentiments which were then expressed.

The severe storm of Thursday, the 17th inst., has proved very disastrous to roads, bridges, , in Alabama. The Tallapoosa rose higher than had been known for years, and the Alabama also attained to a great height--consequently planting in the low lands and river bottoms has been greatly retarded.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I have read in your paper of this morning, (Thursday, March 24,) Father GAVAZZI'S "opening speech" before a New-York audience. With Its general bearing, tone, and object, I have nothing particularly to do. Those details of difference and disputation I leave to other and abler hands.

At Brooklyn, on Wednesday, March 23, at his late residence, No. 273 Bridge, at., THOMAS P. TEALE, in the 38th year of his age. On Thursday, March 24, Col. JAMES L. HEWITT, aged 48 years and 6 months. His relatives and the friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral from St. Thomas Church, corner of Broadway and Houston-st., to-morrow.

The five examiners appointed to investigate the affairs of the Census Office, have reported work enough yet to employ fifty clerks until the next session of Congress, at least. We hear of several removals of clerks in the different Departments.

We heard yesterday that Mr. W. J. McALPINE, the present efficient State Engineer, is about to be transferred from the service of the State, at Albany, to the employ of the New York and Erie Railroad, as Engineer-in-Chief and Assistant President of the Company.

The Senate immediately resolved itself into committee on the Constitutional amendments of Mr. VANDERBILT. Mr, VANDERBILT resumed his speech. He said he would define his position. He was opposed to taxation, direct or indirect, for the purpose of completing the canals.
We have had an opportunity to examine a new REPEATING PISTOL, invented by Mr. E. WHITNEY, of New Haven, Conn.; a weapon meriting more than ordinary attention.

The Austrian mission of Count LEINENGEN to the Porte is no sooner terminated than the Russian mission of Prince MENSCHIKOFF is announced to have arrived in Constantinople. The character of the Austrian Envoy was military, and his instructions peremptory. His demands were not to be evaded, and were known to be backed by a powerful army.
LOMBARDY.--At Milan there is no relaxation of the Austrian oppression. Citizens are forbidden to approach the sentries, and M. BERNARDI, having failed to observe the regulation, was bayonetted.
THE STRIKE MOVEMENT.--A meeting of the Ship-Joiners was held Thursday evening, for the purpose of hearing report of Committees appointed to wait on the employers.

In the warm days and nights of the approaching season, no luxury will be more commended to the approval of the tried citizen, than a light, airy, but substantial Bedstead; and, for such, no material is so well adapted as Iron.

The 3 1/4 o'clock train from Phillipsburg, opposite this place, for New-York, came in collision, on the New-Jersey Central Railroad, with a locomotive coming from Elizabethtown, and MATHIAS JOHNSON, baggage-master, was instantly killed, and three other persons severely injured--one, it is thought, fatally.

The Assistant Secretaryship of the Senate, contemplated by Mr. ADAMS' resolution to-day, is designed for B. R. FRENCH. The clerks in the Census Office have been increased to thirty-six, principally by reinstatements.

The Emperor has quite recovered. His wound, indeed, was at no time dangerous to life; but the shock seemed to have affected his brain, and it being notorious that "his bosom's lord does not sit firmly on his throne," fears were entertained that his intellect would be unsettled.
The British and North American steamship Asia, Capt. HARRISON, which sailed from Liverpool, Saturday, the 12th inst., at about 10 A. M., arrived at this port, at 7 o'clock last evening.
The mails this morning bring nothing of interest. It is scarcely fair to repeat the very delicate inuendoes respecting the position of the Empress EUGENIE.

The Executive Committee of the American Tract Society has completed the appropriation of $20,000 for operations in foreign countries. The receipts of the Society during the last month were $35,139, and for eleven months to March 1, $316,204.

The London Daily News quotes Lord ABERDEEN'S suggestion that the Government will keep its eye on KOSSUTH and the other political refugees sheltered by the British flag, and treats it in a strain of well deserved and effective ridicule.

Gossip says, perhaps prematurely, that the Empress EUGENIE will not suffer the direct line of the BONAPARTES to fail. We are without political news. Three new Senators have been added to the list-Gen. AUPICK, the French Ambassador at Madrid, M. LEBRUN, ex-Peer of France and Baron THIEULLEN, member of the Corps Legislatif.

Suddenly, on Friday, March 25, WILLIAM T. BLAGROVE, in the 45th year of his age. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral on Saturday, at 2 o'clock, P. M., from No. 115 Atlantic-st., Brooklyn.

The missing New-Orleans mail, of the 10th inst., has been received, having been 15 days on the way. The Intelligencer has a long letter from J. R. BARTLETT, Mexican Boundary Commissioner, defending himself from the attack of the Union.

From Pesth, 1st. inst., it was stated that NOSLOPY, chief of guerillas, and three of his accomplices, one of whom was tutor to KOSSUTH's children, were to be executed on the 3d. Accounts via 5th say that the execution took place at Pesth on the day specified, the victims being JUHBAL, ex-tutor to KOSSUTH's family, CHARLES ANDRASFFY

The New-York Hardshells presented to the President to-day their ultimatum, to wit: SCHELL or war. It is stated on apparently good authority, that the Cabinet stands tied between SCHELL and KELLY, DAVIS and PIERCE not voting. Another well-received rumor is, that both are slaughtered, and CORNELIUS W. LAWRENCE decided upon. It is difficult to get at the truth.

There has been very little of general interest perfected to-day in either House. Mr. BEEKMAN reported a bill relative to assessments in the City of New-York, intended to secure greater equality with more economy. The only feature of the day was Mr. R. SMITH'S report on the subject of the circulation of the bills of expiring Safety Fund Banks.
In the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets, great firmness has been shown this week, and SUGAR has experienced a very active demand. COFFEE keeps steady, COTTON heavy at 1/4d decline.
Prince MENCHIKOFF, Russian Minister of Marine, and Spicial Ambassador to Turkey, had arrived at Constantinople, and immediately put himself in communication with the Government.

Mr. VANDERBILT, favorably on the Assembly bill relative to mock auctions. Also, favorably on the Assembly bill relative to trusts held by T. R. BECK. Third reading. The same, favorably on the bill relative to disputed wills. Mr. CONGER, favorably on the Assembly bill authorizing school districts to raise money to pay librarians.
FUNERAL OF MAJOR TEALE.--The funeral of Maj. THOMAS P. TEALE, of the 13th Regiment, took place yesterday afternoon, and was attended by a large concourse of citizens.

The foreign news is not very important, yet it is quite interesting. Englishmen were poring over some old South American news which we had a fortnight ago, and over some Australian advices, for which they had to thank Brother Jonathan.

The U. S. mail steamship Isabel, with Havana and Keyport dates to the 22d inst., arrived at this port to-day. Mr. KING'S health was no better. It was rumored that serious disturbances has taken place among the troops at Santiago de Cuba, or some other port in the Eastern Department of the Island.

FROM LIBERIA.--Late advices from Liberia have been received, via England, by the Colonization Society in this City. We are favored with extracts from sundry letters from parties settled at Monrovia, Buchanan, etc., all expressing high hopes and pointing to cheerful indications.

Leaves from the Journal of a New-York Clergyman: During the first Half of the Present Century: Written for the DAILY TIMES--No. II.--The Hudson River and ROBERT FULTON. Incident of Revolutionary History, Maple-Sugar, Railway Maxims. Domestic Manufactures--No. III.--The City of Lowell as it was; Written for the DAILY TIMES.
SIR: A rambling letter from an old correspondent, while journeying westward, may not be unacceptable to you, and I shall take the liberty of sending one now and then.
We give on another page of this morning's paper, a communication, from a party interested, in regard to our remarks the other day, on the Life and Health bill now before the Assembly.
NOMINATIONS.--The following persons are candidates for Aldermen in the Third Ward:--John Low, Henry Gorham, Selah Hill, Edward P. Torrey.
In steamship Asia, from Liverpool--J. S. Wright, M. M. Whiting, Mr. Barringer, L. Sisson, John H. Adams, Jos. Beandry, Mr. Dean, Lieut. Harrison, Lieut. Shackerly, Lieut.
The Asia arrived at 7 o'clock last night from Liverpool, bringing news three days later. Cotton and Breadstuffs are reported dull; Money in great demand yet.
The annual Bishop prize debate in the Linonian Society of Yale College took place on the afternoon and evening of March 16. The competitors were from the Freshman and Sophomore Classes.
SCHOOL BOARD OF FINANCE.--An adjourned meeting of the members of this Board was held at the City Hall, on Thursday evening. The President of the Board, Mayor BERRY, in the Chair.
The weekly Import tables for the four calendar weeks of the present month, show the following results in Foreign Dry Goods at this port, as compared with the corresponding month of last year.

"STEP INTO MY PARLOR, LITTLE FLY."--The Special Committee appointed by the Board of Assistants, to investigate that which could no longer be concealed, announce that they will meet at 4 P. M. on Monday, "to receive voluntary evidence, tending to sustain the charges of fraud against members of the Common Council."
The Journal of Commerce refers to the " exaggerated and improbable stories" that have been circulated concerning the Caloric ship Ericsson, since her return from Alexandria.

BROMA AND COCOA.--Everybody in this country, of course, is quite familiar with those two excellent articles of diet for invalids, Broma and Cocoa, manufactured by WALTER BAKER Co., of Dorchester, Mass.

Great Military precautions are being taken at Nuremberg, also at Bamberg and Munich, as if in anticipation of an outbreak. Several political arrests have been made at Furth. GERVINUS' sentence is two months' imprisonment. An appeal has been taken from the Court at Mannheim.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found a letter copied from PUTNAM'S Monthly for April, from Prince de JOINVILLE, in which he denies most emphatically the statement, that he informed Rev. ELEAZER WILLIAMS that he was the Dauphin, and endeavored to induce him to abdicate his right to the throne of France.

A Gazetteer of the United States of America, by JOHN HAYWARD. A work of much labor. After every census such compilations become necessary, in order to embody the latest facts, as the population and multifarious interests of the country. Previous publications of the same kind are at once antiquated and of very little practical use.
FIRE.--Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, a fire occurred in the Second Fire District, in the block bounded by Henry, Harrison, Degraw-streets-and Cheever-place.

Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Heir at Law-Pauline. BURTON'S THEATRE--David Copperfield--Old Dutch Governor. BROADWAY THEATRE--Broker of Bogota--Twas I. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--A Phenomenon in a Smock Frock--Bluebeard.

At a funeral of an aged and faithful slave, which recently took place at Lynchburg, Va., five hundred colored persons attended. Nearly all of those were slaves who had been released from labor by their masters in order that they might pay the last tribute of respect to fidelity, honesty, and duty well discharged.

On Wednesday, the 9th instant, the proceedings were of no interest in either House of Parliament. On the 10th, in the Commons, Mr. DRUMMOND asked whether the Government had considered the effects of the reduced value of gold, and its consequences, and whether it was not advisable to appoint a Committee to inquire into the altered value of the standard.

Reserving the Secretary next in rank, but perhaps first in official influence (him of the Treasury,) for a little further investigation, I will proceed to describe those other members of the PIERCE Cabinet whom I personally know.

The Senate resumed the consideration of the resolution authorrising the Committee on Indian Affairs to delegate one of their number to proceed, during the recess, to take testimony in the matter now pending in reference to certain frauds alleged to have been committed by ALAXAN- DER RAMSEY and others, in making payment of money to certain Sioux Indians.

No. 14--Emmet, Receiver, , appellant against Reed respondent. Argued. Anthony L. Robertson, counsel for appellant, Samuel Sherwood, counsel for respondent. No. 141--The People ex rel. Scott, defendants in error, against The Board of Supervisors of Chenango County, plaintiff's in error.

The Count DE CAMERATA, second cousin of the Emperor, shot himself last Friday morning. He was maitre des requetes at the Council of State. No one knows the cause of this suicide. Every one guesses and surmises.

BOWERY AND THIRD-AVENUE RAILROAD. A petition was presented in reference to the opening of the Bowery and Third-avenue Railroad. Mr. BEEKMAN presented a petition in relation to the opening of Sixth-avenue.

EASTER SUNDAY.--Yesterday being Easter Sunday, the Roman Catholic Churches in the City were the resort of hundreds of persons, outside of the regular congregations, anxious to witness the imposing ceremonies with which the anniversary of the Resurrection is celebrated in those places of worship.

A correspondent of the St. Louis Republican writes from Santa F6 under date of Jan. 31. The Commissioners of Public Buildings are busy in taking the preliminary steps to commence the new building and spend the $20,000, and have advertised for the quarrying of a part of the stone.

Major MAKALL, Acting Inspector-General, came in yesterday from Tampa and the Indian country, and in an interview with him, we lean that BOWLEGS still keeps to the bush, but has offered no hostilities; in fact, the country was very quiet.

AMATEUR SPARRING AND A FATAL RESULT.--On Saturday afternoon Coroner HILTON held an inquest at No. 292 Walker-street, upon the body of a young man named RIVINGTON DUYCKINCK, who died on Friday evening, under the following circumstances:--The deceased was about twenty-one years of age, and had been employed in the book binding establishment of Mr. CHARLES JENKINS, No. 144 Nassau-street.

A discussion of a somewhat personal nature sprang up at the close of last week, between Mr. BURTON, of the Chambers-street Theatre, and WILLIAM YOUNG, Esq., Editor of the Albion. The Manager has, it seems, taken offence at the strictures of our cotemporary upon some of his performances, and retorted, by asserting that the criticisms were induced by his rejection of two plays of Mr. YOUNG.

To P. LYNCH, ESQ., Editor of the Irish American: SIR: In your letter published in the TIMES on the 25th inst., you remark: "Father GAVAZZI, the Destroyer, assumes the mission of inciting our Protestant brothers to that war with us, poor benighted Irish Papists, to form no union with us, to drive us out of the land; to destroy us root and branch."

The Count DE CAMERATA, second cousin of the Emperor, shot himself last Friday morning. He was maitre des requetes at the Council of State. No one knows the cause of this suicide. Every one guesses and surmises.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: To my purpose of giving you a history of nearly all the PIERCE Ministry whom I have not yet described, there exists a very serious impediment, upon which I have somewhat unthinkingly rushed; I strangely forgot that the men had none.

ATTACK UPON A WIFE BY HER HUSBAND--PROBABLE MURDER.--Early on Saturday morning, a man named WILLIAM GEEREY, quarreled with his wife, at their residence, corner of Twenty-seventh-street and First-avenue.

With the present week will begin a new era in the musical history of New-York, According to the success of the inauguration will be our future progress in the "divine art." If, as we anticipate, it should be brilliant, we may calculate with tolerable certainty on a still higher range of entertainment hereafter.

The callous indifference of this monster in human shape, is a subject of general remark among the officers who have been brought in connection with him. Nothing can soften his feelings, or allay his bitter resentment against several of the officers of the law, as well as his only son.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Thank you, Mr. Editor, for your article of to-day on KOSSUTH. Its words are true and generous, spoken at a fitting time. Remorse less hatred and slander have, in ever flowing abundance, been poured into the cup of the illustrious Hungarian.

GENERAL REMARKS.--This fruit is esteemed far more highly by the English than by us. In its wild state, the apricot is a small, round, pale, waxy, yellow fruit, rosy on one side, and of an agreeable subacid flavor.

FROM BUENOS AYRES.--The bark Ottawa, Capt. BROOKS, from the Rio Grande, reports that produce was scarce and commanding high prices; hides scarce. A vessel from Buenos Ayres had arrived at the Rio Grande, bringing dates to the 20th January, which state that Buenos Ayres was closely besieged by URQUIZA.

Amusements this Evening. F?? Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera--Don Pasquale. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Money--High Life Below Stairs. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Merry Wives of Windsor--Two Queens; BROADWAY THEATRE.--Metamora--To Paris and Back for ?5. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--Money. In the Afternoon--The Miller of Whetstone--Songs, Dancer, as a Post.

The determination of the Senate against delegating its functions to a Commission during recess, will meet with general approval. The Commission, it will be remembered, was evoked by certain alleged defalcations of GOV. RAMSEY, of Minnesota.

COMMON COUNCIL.--A special meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held Friday evening, Alder man COMSTOCK in the Chair. A communication was received and placed on file, from Mayor Berry, relative to the granting of a charter to David S. Mills, to lay a Railroad track in Division-avenue--asking their immediate action upon the same and to remonstrate against the enactment of said law.

The following confirmations are officially announced in the Union of this morning: Registers in Illinois--Daniel Roberts, Kaskaskia; Richard S. Molony, Danville; John Conolly, Springfield; John M. Cunningham, Shawneetown; Harmon Alexander, Palestine; Augustus C. Marsh, Quincy.

Here's to the "Board of Aldermen!" long may its Members stand; A shining light of honor bright--a beacon to the land! Long may their sterling qualities employ the honest pen In heralding the virtues of our "Honorable Men!" 'Tis true, they bribe the voters--the truth we must not blink-- And steal away their consciences, when laid asleep by drink:

A NEW BANK.--The stock for a new institution in this City, to be called the Central Bank, with $200,000 capital, with privilege to increase to $1,000,000, has nearly all been subscribed for, and the Bank will go into operation on the first of August next.

The Grand Jury, after a long session, closed its labors and made its presentment in the Court of General Sessions on Saturday last. That document will be found in another column of this morning's TIMES.

The object of the resolution introduced yesterday by Mr. SEWARD, is understood to be the publication of the dispatches received from our Minister in Brazil, Mr. SCHENCK, relative to the African Slave Trade.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,).No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Roade-st.

The Cabinet held a protracted meeting on Saturday, continuing together until 3 o'clock. The New-York nominations are under discussion. MARCY fought to the last, and all along against the Hard-Shells; but despite all, it is said that SCHELL will be Collector.

In steamship Southerner, from Charleston--B. Bellamyer, Miss M. Bellamyer, A. J. Day, A. H. Boykin and lady, Miss Boykin, Capt. Hamilton, L. S. Wood, A. Jones, B. Brown and servant, M. C. Gove, Joseph Lakeman, W. B. Oliver, Lieut. A. Burrows, W. H. Levy, H. M. Smith--and 45 in the steerage.

From the Norfolk Beacon of Thursday. WM. HINCKLE, Captain of the schooner Rachel P. Brown, was examided on Tuesday, before J. T. FRANCIS, Esq., U.S. Commissioner, upon the charge of being concerned in the slave trade on the coast of Africa. From the evidence of WILLIAM RILLEY, mate of the schooner, we get the following particulars: He shipped at New-York on the 7th of December last, for a voyage to the west coast of Africa.

A quiet day was yesterday. It came and went, and brought little news. An arrival from California, however, may be hourly looked for.
