By special dispatch from Washington, we have received a digest of the dispatches lately forwarded to the State Department by the American Minister in Brazil, in reference to the Slave Trade, and the utter inefficiency of our cruisers to put a stop to the desecration of the American flag.
Presentment of the March Term Grand Jury--Important Movement Respecting the Empaneiling of Grand Juries. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS-Saturday.--Before Hon. Judge BEEBE, Aldermen CORNELL and TIEMAN.

Report of the Committee on Banks and Insurance Companies on certain Resolutions of Inquiry, adopted by the Assembly, January 12 and 22, 1853, respectively, which said Resolutions are in the words following, to wit: Resolved, That the Committee on Banks and Insurance Companies ascertain and report to this House, at as early a day as may be convenient.

After a short illness, on Sunday morning, March 27, ELIZA MOTT, daughter of A.M. and Margaret Cameron, aged 6 months and 41 days. Funeral will be from the house of her grandfather, John G. Mott, No. 83 Franklin-st. Notice of time will be given on Wednesday. On Saturday, March 26, N. SMITH PRENTISS, aged 63 years.

The "Coalition Cabinet" is progressing as smoothly as can be desired. They experience just enough opposition in both Houses to supply a certain degree of pleasant excitement, with now and then a little contretemps or two, without which, place would be too much of a paradise.

THE PARK.--If the Park be the lungs of the City, as the phrase goes, then the City has got the consumption, for its lungs are in bad case. Not to speak it profanely, the Park, in its present state, is a disgrace to the City.

The latest date from San Francisco is the 18th of March. The news is quite unimportant, though it possesses some interesting features. The first intelligence received through the new Mexican route via Vera Cruz and Acapulco, reached San Francisco on the 16th, thirty-eight days from New-York.
The argument in No, 13, commenced yesterday, concluded. No. 15. Reserved to March 31. No. 16. Reserved generally. No. 17. Reserved to March 29.

At an early hour this morning, a fire broke out in the carriage shop of Mr. WELTSON, 0n Sycamore-street, below Third, and before it could be subdued, fifteen houses, mostly frame, were destroved, rendering thirty families houseless.

RUMORED CONFESSION.--Since Saturday last, it has been currently reported that CARSON EMMOS, one of the persons convicted of the murder of CHRISTOPHER SOOHAN, had made a fill confession of the terrible deed.

From the Detroit Advertiser. We have been permitted to look over the correspondence of Col. S. McKNIGHT, from the Saut, brought down by Capt. JONES, who arrived here last night, having made the journey in ten days.

Our receipts of general merchandise have been large, and present quotations indicate important fluctuations in the value of several of the leading articles. The effect of the high prices that have ruled for so long is now being seen.

Our advices from Puget Sound are to the 12th February. The Hudson Bay Company's ship Vancouver recently arrived at Victoria, Vancouver's Island, with two steam engines for grist and saw mills, which are in process of erection on the Island.

While Pennsylvania is legislating to relieve her great Railway from all the weights which are likely to Impede or embarass the trade between her commercial metropolis and the West, a bill is passed through our Assembly, with caucus force, to impose tolls upon the thorough fares to New-York commerce, and at the same time to tax the people directly, in order to avoid the real issue of Canal Enlargement.

From the Californian we take the following ex citing intelligence respecting this noted guerrilla, the particulars of which were gathered by that paper from Mr. JOHN FLOYD, Who left lone Valley on Wednesday morning: On Wednesday last, a man who was traveling from Jackson to Sutter, was attacked, near the chaparral where JOAQUIN and some of his companions were seen and shot a few days since, by several Mexicans, and robbed of over $600.

It will be seen by a correspondence in another column, that the old war upon Col. BENTON has been renewed at Washington, and that two of his associates in Congress, who have hitherto been BENTON men, have gone over to the enemy, and decline to unite with him in recommending appointments for office to the President.

LECTURE I.--THE BIBLE AND THE PAPAL SYSTEM. The first of Father GAVAZZI's course of Controversial Lectures came off at the Tabernacle last evening. The house was well filled, and the lecturer was warmly applauded upon making his appearance.

M. DE LACOUR, the new French Ambassador at Constantinople, has left Paris for his post. The Moniteur announces the re-imposition of the penalties pronounced by the mixed commissions against thirty-eight persons compromised in the events of December, 1851.

From the mines reports are, with respect to the diggings, sufficiently favorable, but we regret that we have to chronicle a series of atrocities unexampled for villany and cruelty, and which have in a great measure been perpetrated with impunity.
ACCIDENT.--On Sunday, a party of three young men started from the foot of Henderson street in a small yawl, for the purpose of fishing off the Island.

MORTALITY OF THE CITY.-The deaths in tile City, for the week ending Saturday, 26th inst., were 387, being an increase of 16 from the previous week. Of these 106 were men, 77 Women, 118 boys, and 86 girls.

Rio Grande letters to Jan. 29, received here, corroborate the Buenos Ayres news received vid New-York. It is stated that Judge HERRICK is likely to receive the appointment to the vacancy in the Supreme Court, occasioned by the resignation of Judge CUSHING.
A SMART THIEF.--A singular robbery was committed yesterday. A gentleman named BARRY, transacting business in Broadway, New-York, and residing in Clinton-street, Brooklyn, was on a visit to this city.
The Havre steamship Franklin and the California packet Georgia arrived last evening. Our dates from London reach to the 16th inst., and from San Francisco to the 1st.
NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The combination troupes commenced in earnest last evening. It was an occasion of warm welcomes. BENEVENTANO, MARINI, SALVE and ALBONI were separately greeted with rounds of applause.

INTERVIEWS: MEMORABLE AND USEFUL; from Diary and Memory Reproduced. BY SAMUEL HANSON Cox, D. D. HARPER BROTHERS. Under this characteristic title, Dr. Cox puts forth his reminiscences of a number of interviews and discussions between himself and various persons of note.

On Sunday, March 27, in the 70th year of her age, Mrs. MARTHA M., the wife of Jacob B. Taylor, Esq. The friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend her funeral without further notice, on Tuesday,

In regard to the general aspect of affairs, there is nothing to report materially different from the accounts I have before given you. The same astonishing amount of immigration continues; the same commercial activity prevails.
The intelligence from California this morning, though devoid of the striking peculiarities of that from Australia, received at the same moment, is not uninteresting.

At' Augusta on Saturday, the senate passed the Liquor bill with its amendment, by Yeas 20 to Nays 10 The Green-street House in this city, kept by Mr. SHAW, with its stables, and a cooper's shop in the rear, were destroyed by fire last night.

A train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad ran off the track about 2 o'clock this morning, seventy miles west of Cumberland. Five persons are known to have been killed, viz: DANIEL, HOLT, Of the firm of HOLT MALTY, oyster dealers; a young woman and child, and two strangers.

DUTIES ON IRON. Mr. HUNTER submitted the following resolution: Resolved, That the Secretary of the Treasury be directed to report to the Senate at its next annual session, the average prices annually of bar iron merchantable manufactured by rolling, bar iron merchantable manufactured otherwise than by rolling, and pig iron, for the Just ten years preceding 1853, in the foreign markets of production or shipment.
We have no mail beyond Richmond. Seven are now due from New-Orleans. The great Broad Free Tunnel on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is completed.

The latest dates from Oregon, received via San Francisco, are to the 18th February. The gold mines were yielding fair returns. The Portland Times has intelligence from the mines of Yreka, Jacksonville, and Winchester.

General PIERCE has done well in selecting such men as MANN, CLAY and FAY, to important positions under the Government. It was a bold stroke that floored the expectations of a thousand and one aspirants for these places, whose chief recommendations were partizan services and their claims for reward; but it is proving to have been an eminently successful one.

If that great body of our citizens who desire to secure some speedy and effectual reform in our 'City Government, are not completely balked in their expectations, it will not be for lack of ingenious and persevering efforts in various quarters, to bring about that result.

The Peach crop is reported highly promising for the coming season in West Jersey, and the Albany Journal adds that the prospect of an abundant crop from the orchards and gardens of Western New-York is good.
Intelligence from Hong Kong has been received to Jan. 28. Hon. HUMPHREY MARSHALL, U. S. Minister, had arrived.

A correspondence has Just been published in Missouri betwen Col. BENTON and two of his colleagues, which explains the current rumors concerning the Colonel's recommending nobody for office from Missouri.

The only New-York nominations sent in to day were widow BERRAND, Postmistress at West Point, which was confirmed immediately, and Mr. BIRDSALL, Navy Agent at New-York, vice LEROY, which was referred. No nominations were made for Philadelphia or Baltimore.

Mr. VANDERBILT, on the petition of the New-York Mutual Life Insurance Company, reported a bill to amend the General Insurance law. Mr. BEEKMAN reported bills to incorporate the American Society of Natural History, and the American Geographical and Statistical Society.

Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera--Monday, Wednesday and Friday. WALLACK'S THEATRE,--Lady of Lyons--Good for Nothing. BURTON'S THEATRE.-Merry Wives of Windsor-Two Queens.
The political condition of Europe is in the highest degree satisfactory. The propensity of Frenchmen for revolution is at present swallowed up in curiosity.

In the report of a paper on the History of Iceland, read before the New-York Historical Society, on the 2d of March, your reporter makes me say that Iceland, with its 60,000 people, has three newspapers, and that the Island of Sicily, with a population of 2,000,000, has none.
The U. S. Mail steamer Franklin, J. A. WOTTON, Commander, arrived at this port last evening, having left Havre on the 15th, and Cowes on the 16th inst. She has a good freight from the former fort.
The U. S. Mail steamship Georgia, Capt. PORTER, arrived at an early hour last evening, from Aspinwall, bringing the California mails and specie to the 1st inst.
There was a long discussion in the Senate, to-day, upon the Consular Treaty with France. No decision was reached. SLIDELL'S nomination was not touched.
A decision of some importance, respecting the wages of steamboat hands, was made at Pittsburgh last week by Judge IRWIN, in the U. S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania.

From the London Times. Several weeks have elapsed since we had occasion to advert to the state of affairs now established in France, for the monotony of universal silence and submission has succeeded to the animated and excited scenes that country has so often presented to us, and the Imperial Government seems perfectly satisfied to enjoy the results of the measures which have called it into existence.

Mr. W. F. ANDERSON, of Newberry, S. C,, left Charleston, on Wednesday, the 16th, apparently in his usual health, was seized on the road with a violent attack of cholera morbus, under which, in the absence of all remedial agents, he continued to Suffer throughout the journey, sank rapidly and died.
Sure we are, that we can write no article more agreeable to the citizens of New-York, than one which shall give the dust its due. There is no doubt about the fact that dust is the bane of New-York.
The Circuit Court met to-day, and after a short sitting adjourned for three weeks, in order to allow the Criminal Court to occupy the room for the GARDINER trial.

Our dates front Panama reach to the 18th inst. There is no news of the least consequence. The U. S. sloop-of-war Portsmouth, Capt. DORWIN, has returned to Panama, after an absence of nearly seven months, having visited during that period the ports of San Francisco, Monterey, Santa Barbara and, Sari Diego, in California.
There was an unusual commotion in the Barnburners ranks this morning, at the rumored appointment of SCHELL us Collector of your Port. The leaders of that faction were in Caucus.
The Bank Basis will come up in the Assembly in the course of the present week probably on Thursday. The chances of the bill rest upon the amendments.
In San Francisco, Robert Jessup, of Philadelphia, aged 4 years. At, Quartzville, Butte County, Feb. 12, Jas. Yount, of Weston, Platt Co., Mo., aged 28 years.

One department, at least, of the World's Fair, will not be devoid of interest or value. Measures have been taken for the establishment of a Class in the Exhibition which shall comprise a perfect collection of the Mineral and Metallic productions of this country, arranged under the eye of experienced scientific man, and classified in such a manner as to be a daguerreotype of the resources of every State in the Union.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--Last evening about 6 o'clock, a boy named JOSEPH CARRIGAN was run over in Atlantic street, near Columbia, by a horse attached to a cart, and injured so severely that he died a few minutes after in an apothecary's store, to which he was conveyed.
WATER FOR BROOKLYN.--Late on Friday afternoon last, a special meeting of the Common Council was called for the same evening, to consider the Water question.
Intelligence from Sydney to December 28, and from Port Sydney to January 3, has been received. The previous reports concerning the falling off in the supply of gold, were wholly refuted.
On Saturday, County Treasurer DODGE opened the vaults of our City Banks and seized the amount of taxes due by them. The keys were purposely left where he could get them.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,) No. 112 Broadway, A. T. STEWART Co., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

We have had the preasure of presenting to our readers some interesting papers relating to the Amazon, the last of which were of the above title, over the signature of "Inca." These papers attracted attention not only in this country, but in the countries immediately interested in the free navigation of the Amazon.

Our neighbor of the Tribune is in sore distress. He deluges his readers with the outpourings of his grief. And if there were not in it a decided infusion of ill-natured malice, the overflow of his wretchedness would be more deeply affecting than anything more manly than the Sorrows of Werter, or more modern than the spectacle of Niobe--all tears.

The Select Committee appointed to present to the Legislature the memorial for CITY REFORM, adopted at Metropolitan Hall, have made a report of their action in the matter, which will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES.
ECCLESIASTICAL TROUBLES.-We clip the following from the Post of last evening; "A pamphlet has been issued by certain members of St. Thomas' Church, Brooklyn, affecting the interests of that church.

AMERICAN COMMERCE WITH CHINA.--The Boston Journal says: We are indebted to a friend for the Shanghai (North-China) Herald, of January 1. The most interesting item of news which it contains, is a report of the Harbor Master of Shanghai, NICHOLAS BAYLIES, (who, by the way, is a Massachusetts man.)
The New-York nominations have at last been made. DANIEL S. DICKINSON is to dispense the political patronage and wield the political power of the New-York Custom House.

On motion of Mr. BADGER, Resolved, That the Sergant-at-Arms be authorized to continue the messengers in the employment of the Senate for two months after the termination of the present session, for the purpose of folding and transmitting documents.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A correspondent of the New-York Tribune, dating BOSTON, March 24, 1853, among other things, passes sonic severe strictures upon the American Company, and also upon the United States, of New-York, regarding their statements to Massachusetts, under their late law.

There is very little news stirring this morning. From Washington, however, we have fresh tidings, with very interesting particulars respecting the New-York appointments, which are at last made, and create a great sensation.

History, like Madame TUSSAUD'S wax-works, has its chamber of horrors. There we find RAVAILLAC, the regicide, BRINVILLIERS, the poisoner; and, no doubt, in the twentieth century, students will read of ARCULARIUS, the suffocator.

The President to-day nominated ex-Senator DICKINSON for Collector of New-York; ex-Senator Dix, Sub-Treasurer; CHARLES O'CONOR, District Attorney; and other New-York appointments. The nominations took the Senate by surprise, were received with a laugh all round, and confirmed immediately.

From the National Intelligencer. Among the few acts of positive legislation consummated at the Session of Congress just concluded, that organizing the new Territory of Washington is one of the most important and interesting.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--To-night, "Don Pasquale." Unless we are mistaken, the house will be crowded. The first performance was entirely delightful, and if there is any virtue in practice, its repetitition this evening will be, if possible, still more so.

To the Editor of the New-York Times: In my last, it was made to appear that the cost of employing Slave labor in Virginia over free labor in New-York, was equal to an addition of one dollar to every dollar now expended for labor.

The following New-York Nominations were sent to the Senate to-day: DANIEL S. DICKINSON for Collector. JOHN COCHRAN for Surveyor. HEMAN J. REDFIELD for Naval Officer. CONRAD SWACKHAMER for Navy, Agent, in place of BIRDSALL, declined. ISAAC V. FOWLER for Postmaster.
A gentleman and his wife, on their way to Church, found a small package, and upon examination on their return home, found it to contain a twenty dollar bill and four dollars in small bills.

The ancient town of Names, in France, was lately the scene of an incident which is the more singular, from its being the counterpart of one which took place in the same city in 1840. In that year, a poor woman was visited by a seeming lady, who said she had been employed by the Dutchess DE BERRI, to look into the affairs of the needy, and to administer relief.

CULPABLE CARELESSNESS WITH FIRE, ARMS.--Yesterday, a man named SCHAFF, residing at No. 183 South-Fourth-street, appeared before Justice BOSWELL to prefer a complaint against an individual for discharging a pistol in front of his window, the ball shattering the glass and lodging in the opposite wall of the room.

THE MURDER OF CHRISTOPHER SOOHAN-A CONFESSION.--Our readers are fully aware of all the circumstances attending the murder of the unfortunate CHRISTOPHER SOOHAN, in Swanson-street, below Queen; and also of the fact that JOHN CAPIE and CARSON EMMOS, both young men, residents of Southwark, having been tried and convicted of that awful crime.

THE CASE OF AITCHINSON.--This culprit, tried and convicted of the crime of murder, in the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer last week, was recommended to the mercy of the Court by the Jury, in consideration of his long incarceration and the state of his and the state of his health. The Judge, in passing sentence, stated that he could not unite in that recommendation.

A SINGLE OBJECT. Nature has provided but one great luminary daily to enlighten the world. Numerous lights are feebler ones. In like manner, many objects destroy unity of action, but an individual one of magnitude consolidates it and gives it effect. We need attention to learn--concentration to act.

We briefly stated in our City news Monday, that a frightful assault had been committed by a husband on his wife, at their residence, corner Twenty-seventh-street and First avenue. The name of the family was NEARY, and not GEERY, as we were then informed.

THE MURDERER SPRING.--THIS miserable man, finding that his deception of yesterday morning could not avail him against the keen and prying examination of the Marshal's officers, whose business it is to convey him from the prison to the Court-room, arose from his bed by the dawn of day this morning, and paced his cell to procure that quiet which can never again find a place in his mind.

Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera--Don Pasquale, WALLACK'S THEATRE.--For the Benefit of Brougham--Irish Henres--The Review. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Merry Wives of Windsor--Novel Expedient. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Hamlet--Diamond Cut Diamond. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--Paul Pry. In the Afternoon--Lady of Lyone.
The Detroit Free Press says, the importance of Wool as a staple, is but just beginning to be realized among the farmers of Michigan and other States of the West.
At Lyuchburg, Va., on the 20th inst., ANDREW R. JONES, formerly of Ilempstead, L. L, after a short illness. His remains will arrive in this City, on Thursday, per steamer Roanoke, 31st inst.

At a meeting of the Committee appointed by the meeting of citizens held at Metropolitan Hall, on the evening of March 5, 1853, to solicit from the State Legislature, amendments of the City Charter, held on the 29th of March, 1853; PETER COOPER, Esq., was called to the Chair, and THOS. R. WHITNEY, appointed Secretary.

LECTURE II.-THE TWO-FOLD SUPREMACY OF THE POPE. The Second Lecture of Father GAVAZZI'S Course was delivered at the Tabarnacle last evening, before a numerous audience. As on former occasions, the Reverend Father met with a very favorable reception from his assembled admirers.

In our City news this morning will be found the details of a cruel murder, perpetrated on Friday night. We have seldom had to record a deed of a more fiendish nature. The victim was a woman who had been married twenty-two years to her husband, and the murderer was that husband.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Before recurring to Catholic affairs in our own country, permit me, Sir, to offer some comments upon the recent political convulsions in Europe, and their influence upon ecclesiastical affairs abroad.

In the GARDINER case, the argument upon the inadmissibility of evidence, proving that the signatures and seals to papers filed by GARDINER in his claim, were all forgeries--was continued until 2 o'clock.

The political track of Mr. BENTON is no primrose path. Some men with talent less decided, walk quietly over the course, and bear away the prizes, without effort, and often without unfriendly competition. But their trick lies in dodging difficulties rather than in meeting them.
A petition was presented from the Medical Board of the Brooklyn Hospital, for a physician at the Marine Hospital. Also a remonstrance of Consuls, resident at New-York, against the emigrant law.
Speaking of NATHANIEL HAWTHORNE, and his snug provision in the Liverpool Consulship, the Post says:

Liverpool Cotton Market. COTTON advanced under the advices received per Arctic to the extent of 1-16d.@ld. ? lb., the fair and middling qualities experiencing the most of the advance. The sales of the week were 58,250 bales, of which speculators took 10,250, and exporters 750 bales.

PROSPECTS FOR THE FUTURE.--The City Will be built by-and-bye. We are in a fair way to complete it by the year 1953. Alterations there will be, of course, after that. Streets to be pulled down and rebuilt, as is being done to Liberty-street at this present time.
Mr. RODMAN, chief clerk in the Treasury Department has been temporarily appointed Solicitor of the Treasury. The public offices closed to-day, at 12 o'clock, as a mark of respect to Mrs. FILLMORE.

The following is the official list of appointments of Cadets to the Military Academy-the appointments to take effect on the 1st day of June next: Maine-George H. Weeks, Augustus G. Robin. son. New-Hampshire-Edward J. Connor, Haddeman l S. Putnam . Massachuusetts-Arthur F. Devereux, John C. Palfrey, George E._Strong.

REPORTS OF COMMITTEES. Mr. McELWAIN, favorably on the bill relating to the New-York Live Stock Insurance Co. Mr. BARTLETT, favorably on the bill for the con solidation of the Oswego and Syracuse and Syracuse and Binghamton Railroads. On motion of Mr. PLATT, said bill was ordered to a third reading.

Thus far I have confined my letters--not intended to be many, and still less to news mongering ones, the usual political gabble of this place-to one main subject, as yet the most important that admits of any certainty: the Cabinet. Of the composition and character of that, I have given you all that can yet be said.

GREENWOOD CEMETERY COMPANY.-At a meeting of the Board of Supervisors, held on Tuesday, Super visor KENT presented a remonstrance from sundry of the inhabitants of New-Utrecht and Flat bush, against the action of the Board at the last meeting, which concurs with the Greenwood Cemetery Company, in the matter of extending the limits of their ground.

Unless signs fail miserably, the tide of travel will flow through the coming Summer, with much more than common violence. Much of that superabundant wealth which now depletes itself in Fifth-avenue mansions and Broadway hotels, will take to the road-not after the manner, perhaps of TURPIN and PACL CLIFFORD.

BOSTON RELIEF TO THE MADEIRA SUFFERERS.-The Boston Advertiser says; It may gratify those who contributed to pay for the cargo of pro visions sent to Madeira by the bark Nautilus, to read the following letter just received from our Consul, J. HOWARD MARCH, Esq., under date of the 28th February: "It is with infinite satisfaction I announce to you the arrival of the Nautilus, and the delivery of her cargo in good condition.

By the arrival of the Niagara at Halifax, we have at 1 1/2 o'clock this morning, three days later news from Europe. Cotton has advanced under the advices received by the Arctic. Parliamentary business is very unimportant. Canadian affairs, the Milan insurrection and the gratifying intelligence that the Grand Duke of Tuscany has liberated the MADIAI, and allowed them to leave Tuscany, were the leading topics under discussion.

The Governor will sign the Consolidation bill. The Democratic members of the Senate were in Caucus last evening. It is understood that Senators VANDERBILT, COOLEY, BRISTOL. KIRBY and SNOW, are determined to do something in carnest for the Canals; and it is by no means certain that, instead of being driven out of the party, they will not drive their party into these measures.

The bill for the regulation of the issues of the Banks of mere circulation, which passed the Assembly by a large majority, is still before the Senate, but it can hardly fail to become a law. The interests of the people are directly involved in this question, as well as the interests of all of our sound State banks, and both alike call for the measure under consideration.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR--In your brief review of Dr. Cox's " Interviews Memorable and Useful," referring to the Doctor's interview with Hon. J. Q. ADAMS, you intimate your belief that Mr. ADAMS "entered into the discussion as a pleasant intellectual exercise," although "Dr. Coxtook the whole affair seriously."

HIGH PRICE OF PROVISIONS.--BOARDING HOUSE STRIKE.--We learn that a movement is being made by the hotel keepers to raise the prices, both of transient custom and permanent boarders. The first class hotels will probably raise 50 cents, and the second class 25 cents per day, and from 50 cents to $2 per week on regular boarders. Our first class hotels now charge $2 per day, and second class $1 25 and $1 50.

LEOPOLD VON BUCH died at Berlin on the 4th March, aged 76 years. He was the associate of HUMBOLDT. ENCKE and RITTER, to each of whom an active scientific career of more than half a century has been allotted. VON BUCH was born in 1777, and was a pupil of WERNER, the great founder of geological science, at the School of Mines in Freiberg, Saxony.

It is not positively known whether DICKINSON accepts or not. The whole matter is kept from New-York outsiders. BIRDSALL came here on DICKINSON'S behalf to urge SCHELL for the Collectorship, and to ask nothing for himself.

In my last, my chapter of Miscellanies was but begun. I will proceed with it. The Senate, you know, still sits. It grows wearisome: for nobody knows what it is sit ting for, unless to bring into play the fag-ends of speeches, the subjects of which (these wise orators fear) will, to the utter loss of their eloquence, be dead and gone, before they shall again meet in council.

The City delegation in the Assembly late on Tuesday afternoon pretended to report a bill amending the City Charter-but neither handed any such document to the Clerk, nor put it within reach of the reporters for the Press.

NOMINATION FOR MAYOR.-The Democracy have drawn party lines in the present canvass, and have made the following nominations in City Convention: For Mayor, CHARLES FINK; for Collector, P. MARTIN; for Superintendent of Schools, JOHN M. CORNELISON; for Assessors, S. BRIDGART, First and Second Wards, and J. PLATT, Third and Fourth Wards. The Whigs have made no nominations, and the proposition for a Union ticketmetts with no favor in respectable quarters.

Our telegraphic dispatches speak of large public meetings held in Cincinnati upon the subject of PUBLIC SCHOOLS. The controversy there, as here, grows out of the demand of the Roman Catholics that a portion of the public money shall be set apart in aid of the schools under their special charge.

The Niagara has arrived at Halifax, bringing late news from Europe, but the report is given meagerly. The commercial advices are satisfactory. The political news is quite unimportant. The British Government has announced in Parliament the gratifying fact of the liberation of the MAIDAI by the GrandDuke of Tuscany.

On Wednesday morning, March 30, ANN MATILDA, wife of Win. H. Day, in the 24th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral on Thursday, March 31, at 12 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 146 Wooster-st. The re mains will be taken to Tarry town for interment. On Wednesday, March 30, LAVINA FISTER, wife of Rev. Isaac Fisler.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Another delightful evening. We confess to a greater amount of satisfaction last night than we have experienced for some time. Madame ALBONI sang more deliciously, the orchestra performed more precisely, and everything went more together than on Monday night. It wasindeed a pleasure of no ordinary kind.

HARPER'S MAGAZINE FOR APRIL.--This number of Harper is of a more popular character than even most of its precursors. With none of the sparkling brilliancy which dazzles the eyes of the multitude in our more flashy periodicals, it has an abundance of pleasing articles, on topics of general interest written so as to be read with ease-some of them seasoned and spiced sufficiently to stimulate the most dainty palate.

The President has decided upon the following Baltimore nominations. They would probably have been sent in to-day, but the Senate adjourned immediately, giving no opportunity to receive them: P. T. THOMAS, for Collector; J. G. DAVIES, Postmaster ;. J. 0. WHARTON, Surveyor; J. H. BRISCOE, Navy Agent; JAMES POLK, Naval Officer; J. W. WATKINS, Marshal; J. G. LEGRAND, Solicitor.

The Vermont Liquor Law provides among other things, for the arrest of a person found intoxicated, and his detention until he will disclose where he obtained the liquor. A case under this provision has already arisen in Woodstock, where a man was arrested for intoxication, and lodged in jail. On examination he refused to give a definite answer as to where he obtained his liquor, and was re-committed to jail.

A serious accident occurred on Monday afternoon, about three miles from this city. While Mrs. BRENT, widow of Col. WM. BRENT, her daughter EMILY and son EDWARD, were riding over the narrow bridge at Piney Branch, on the line of the plank road, the body of the carriage became detached from the fastenings, and turned over into the shallow water below, a distance of twelve or fifteen feet. leaving the horses standing above.
