FATAL SUPERSTITION.--We are credibly in formed that Mrs. RICH, of Kirtland, was taken suddenly in what appeared to the a fit, about 4 o'clock on Monday morning, Feb. 18. Her family supposed her to be in a mesmeric trance, and consulted a couple of the spirit mediums to ascertain what was the matter. The mediums wrote that she was in a mesmeric state, and would not come out until two weeks from that day.

The Albion is responsible for this "hit from Louis NAROLEON :" No one will accuse us of flattering his Imperial Majesty; but we have, from private and undoubted source, a neat little ?? of his, that has not appeared in print, and is too good to be lost.
The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, Capt. LEITCH, arrived here at 5 o'clock this evening, having left Liverpool on Saturday, the 19th inst. The Niagara brings 96 through passengers, and a full freight.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: A more palpable error than the sub joined extract, taken from your paper of the 29th inst., and which appears to be going the rounds, could not well be penned, as will be seen by ex tracts from reliable authorities which follow: "HONDURAS.--There are two countries called Honduras, in the same region of territory.

The U. S. ship Germantown, from Port Praya, Cape de Verds, March 1, arrived here to-day. She sailed in company with the U. S. sloop-of-war Dale, for Boston. The U. S. sloop-of-war Marion arrived at Port Praya on the 22nd February.

MEETING OF EXEMPT FIREMEN.--The exempt Firemen of Brooklyn met last evening, at Firemen's Hall, to complete the organization of an Association for the relief of such exempt Firemen as may be in need. The following officers were elected: DANIEL VANVOORHES, President; Francis B. Stryker, Jeremiah Wells, Michael Trappall, Sr., Morris Simonson, Peter B. Anderson, Vice Presidents; Thomas R. Mercein, Recording Secretary; William A. Walker, Corresponding Secretary; WalterBane, Treasurer.
The Emperor's policy at the present moment being to preserve a quiet aspect towards all Governments until after the coronation, political news is scarce.

" MAINE LAW" IN CANADA.--A bill has been introduced into the Legislative Assembly of Canada by Mr. MALCOLM CAMERON, whose principles are set forth in the following preamble: " Whereas, The common traffic in intoxicating liquors, and their use as a beverage, is a fruitful cause of crime, poverty, disease and demoralization:

There was a larger attendance at the Tabernacle last evening than on the two previous occasions. The reverend lecturer was greeted with loud applause upon his appearing before the large audience assembled to listen to his third lecture. The reverend gentleman announced the subject of his discourse for that evening to be "Monks and Nuns," which he proposed to show were both useless and dangerous to society.

Mr. GEORGE W. NEWELL, the Auditor of the Canal Department has been using the surplus revenues of the Canals, which are made applicable under the Constitution, to Enlargement, for the payment of certain claims dating back to 1842-46, previous to the adoption of the Constitution, and which claims were part of the Canal debt then otherwise provided for from another fund. The Senate called upon

Parliamentary business is very unimportant. Lord JOHN RUSSELL stated in the House that the Mexican Government had reduced the duty on printed calicos and paper, and measures referring thereto would soon be submitted.

The Young Men's Democratic Union Club of Chicago met on the 17th inst., and resolved that their members of Congress were transcending their legitimate powers in staying at Washington to dictate to Gen. PIERCE and his Cabinet the appointments for Illinois.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Captain STONE, sailed at noon to-day, with 38 passengers for Liverpool, and 14 for Halifax. Among the for mer are Mrs. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE, Professor C. E. STOWE, and Rev. CHAS. BEECHER, No specie is registered at the Custom-house.

MASSACHUSETTS COAL.--Prof. HITCHCOCK'S late Geological Report on the Coal fields of Bristol, Mass., we have before alluded to. But it states some other interesting facts which we do not like to leave unnoted. It has long been known, he says, that coal exists in Rhode Island and the southern part of Massachusetts. Geologists have been slow to settle its exact position in the geological scale.

THE KOSCIUSCO WILL CASE.--Mr. G. TOCK MAN writes to the Union, in explanation of some current errors respecting the decision of KOSCIUSKO'S Will. He says: "The controversy recently decided upon by the Supreme Court of the United States, was not between the Russian Government and the heirs of KOSCIUSKO.

From the Herald. THE GRAND JURY AND THE PRESS.-We hope the Grand Jury, when they shall have occasion again to make a presentment against the press, will specify their victims, and not fire their broadside at random into the crowd.

PROF. YOUMAN'S LECTURE IN BROOKLYN. On Monday evening last, Prof. YOUMANS gave the first of a series of three lectures on Chemistry, as applicable to organic life-the nature of Alcohol, and its effects upon the human system, at the lecture-room of Rev. Mr. BEECHER'S Church, Brooklyn. The lecture was well attended by many of the most intelligent citizens, who listened to the able lecturer with the most profound attention.
THE NEW-YORK ASSEMBLY.--It seems, by the classification of the Members of the Assembly that we published yesterday, that farmers are more frequently chosen than members of any other profession.

Controller WRIGUT, it is known, has advertised for proposals for a State Loan of $467,000, to reimburse one of the General Fund Loans due July 1, 1852. Bids will be received and considered to the 9th April, at Albany, on the basis of FOUR or FIVE percent. interest, the Loan to run to 1868.
The following is the Bill to Amend the Charter of New-York City, reported complete, by the New-York delegation, in the Assembly, and ordered to a third reading:

Antioch College is going on, The Xenia (0.) Torchlight says that the work on the new College buildings is progressing rapidly. Two and a half millions of brick have been laid, and much progress has been made in other departments.
Hon. JOHN SLIDELL has been appointed and confirmed as Minister to Central America. We are inclined to consider this decidedly the worst appointment President PIERCE has yet made.

On Thursday, March 31, Mrs. ELIZABETH SHERWOOD, widow of the late David Sherwood, deceased, in the 80th year of her age. The friends and relatives of the family, and also those of her sons, William, David, and Samuel J. Sherwood, and also those of her son-in-law, Lewis R. Knapp, are re spectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence, No. 84 Spring-st., on Sunday, April 3, at 1 o'clock, P.M.
THE FIREWORK EXPLOSION.--The funeral of the boy, THOMAS DUNCAN, took place yesterday, at 11 o'clock, A. M., from the residence of his parents, in North Second-street.

District Attorney BLUNT has written a letter to the Express, containing a practical suggestion to wards street cleaning, which we would be very glad to see some enterprising and public spirited citizen put into practice. Here is the letter:

THE MECHANICS.--A large meeting of the mechanics of the city was held at the Temperanne Temple last night. It was organized by calling JNO. M. CLARK to the Chair, web stated that the object of the meeting was the formation of a Union among the several. classes of mechanics. After

Two of our morning neighbors join issue on the Debt and Canal policy of the State. One is opposed to enlargement by State loans, because with enlargement will come mammoth contracts, and with an increase of Debt used in the Bank Department, will come increased paper issues.
THE WILL OF J. P. DEWITT.--The will of J. P. DEWITT, which was contested in Warren County, on the ground of the testator's unsound mind, has been confirmed.
For the other City News of this morning, see Third Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIDLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera--La Favorita.

COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED.--On Monday evening last, two men, one calling himself JOHN MORGAN, the other a Mr. BENSON, were arrested at Cape Vincent on the application of J. C. HAVEN, of Kingston, C. W., by Constable SPININGS, for passing counterfeit money.

As I sit down to my letter, the sun comes gently through the window, mildly demanding an apology for the hard words I have had to say this Winter of Paris weather. I make it willingly. For the last few days we have enjoyed a temperature and atmosphere, that we might he thankful for in May.

The Niagara left Halifax at 7 o'clock Wednesday evening, and will consequently be due in Boston early on Friday morning. FRANCE. It is very doubtful, too, if NAPOLEON will concede anything in spiritual affairs to the Pope, if he does come to Paris.

MAINE.--The Maine House of Representatives, on Monday, passed a vote to adjourn sine die on Wednesday. The two branches passed the following Railroad bills on Monday: To establish the Dexter and Newport Railroad; the Belfast and Moosehead Railroad ; the Vassal boro' and China Railroad; to provide for certain Railroad connections for the European and North American Railway company; to authorize the lease of the Atlantic and St. Lawrence Railroad.

CONVICTION OF POST-OFFICE ROBBERS.--The United States District Court in this city, Judge SPRAGUE presiding, has been occupied the two past days in the trial of WILLIAM F. NEWTON and JOHN ROGERS, for the robbery of the Post-Office in Stoneham, Mass.. in October last.

The following is the letter of condolence addressed by the President to Mr. FILLMORE, on receiving intelligence of Mrs. F.'s death: EXECUTIVE MANSION, March 30, 1853. MY DEAR SIR: Information has just reached me of the death of Mrs. FILLMORE.

MARINE HOSPITAL.--On the 19th ult., in the House of Representatives, the Civil and Diplomatic Appropriation hill being under consideration, Mr. BROWN, of Alississippi, moved to amend by inserting the following appropriation for Marine Hospitals: Cleveland, Ohio, $15,000; Pittsburg, Penn., $5,000 ; St. Louis, Mo., $20,000; Louisville, Ky., $3,000; Paducah, Ky., $3,000; Napolcon, Ark., $4,000; Natchez, Miss., $4,000;--to be expended in finishing, repairing, heating and fencing the buildings.

William H. Seward in his Writings. THE WORKS OF WM. H. SEWARD; With Biography by GEORGE E. BAKER--Vols. 1, 2, 3. Published by Subscription.-REDFIELD, Nassau-st. "ELIA" needed to have written one more essay to make his classical and sparkling collection perfect in design and complete in execution.
After a very long nap, the Broadway Rail road bill was awakened this evening. A majority of the Railroad Committee are opposed to the bill, and have made an elaborate report against it.

The New-York appointments at Washington are very gingerly treated by the organ of the Barnburners at the State Capital. The Atlas says they occasion "surprise;" were "arbitrarily" made, without regard to the presentation of the candidates; and though this is not regarded as an " objection," the doubt is expressed by an "if" whether or not the end will justify the means.

The Tabernacle was very well filled last evening, on the occasion of the fourth lecture of Father GAVAZZI's course. As on previous occasions, the eloquent lecturer was warmly received by his numerous auditory, upon his appearing before them.

HORRIBLE.-On the 15th inst., a mulatto girl named SARAH SMITH, aged thirteen years, in the service of Mr. PENNOCK, of Upper Oxford, Penn., took his little daughter, EVA ANN, aged five years, into the barn, with the intention of murdering her.

The consideration of the nominations of Dix and FOWLER, have been postponed. Very strong remonstrances have come in against FOWLER from New-York. About both of these the Senate will have a desperate conflict.

The failure of the Senate Post-Office Committee to report Mr. FOWLER'S nomination, resulted from the fact that its Chairman, Mr. RUSK, was presiding in Executive Session when the reports were made, and not from any design to withhold it.

PARIS, Friday evening.-The reported entrace of the English fleet into the Dardanelles, had caused a sort of panic on the Bourse. Towards the close all sorts of securities recovered. The 3 per cents finished at 60f.30; the 4 1/2's at 103f.60.
ACADEMY FOR BOYS.--A meeting of the subscribers to the stock for a Boys' Academy, was held last evening at the Brooklyn Institute. CYRUS P. SMITH, Esq., occupied the Chair; WM. M. HARRIS, Secretary.

No. 17. (A reserved cause.) Van Densen and wife, respondents, agt. Rowley and another, adm'rs, appellants. Argued. John Van Buren, of New-York, counsel for appellants; Killian Miller, counsel for respondents.

The Tribune puts itself to very needless trouble in its elaborate vindication of its general course upon Spirit Rappings, Social Re form, Abolitionism, the Maine Law and other points upon which, as it whiningly complains, the TIMES has not seen fit to follow its lead.

ST. THOMAS' CHURCH--IMPORTANT PROCEEDINGS.--Difficulties of an unpleasant nature have recently arisen in this Church and Society, which threaten to terminate only by resort to the Courts. Through these misunderstandings, at the election of Vestrymen last Monday, almost an entire new body of men were elected.

FROM, SOUTH AMERICA.--By way of Panama we have advices from Valparaiso to the 19th, and from Callao and Lima to the 27th of Feb. The Panama papers say: "Everything was quiet at Lima. It was expected that the affairs of Ecuador would be definitely settled in a few days.
The Leon Pioneer, of the 23d ult., has the following paragraphs: The new County of Madison includes about six hundred miles of territory, the greater part of which is cut off the territory of Grimes.

The Venezuelean Congress continues in session, but we learn of no important measures adopted by that body beneficial to the country. The President has forwarded a batch of names, (all military ones,) for promotion in the army.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,).No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

The officers of the Germantown report that when they left Port Praya the John Adams was employed in carrying out the views of the Navy Department relative to the exploration of the coast of Africa by Commander LYNCH.

Liverpool Cotton Market. HALIFAX, Wednesday, March 30. The COTTON Market during the early part of the week was very dull, but the advice of the America partly revived the demand, which was further improved by the Arclic, making altogether an advance of about 1/2d, ?? lb on fair and middling American.

A RAILROAD TO WEEHAWKEN,--We noticed on Tuesday a new enterprise of our Hoboken friends, which seemed to us most satisfactory, being a line of omnibuse from the ferry at Hoboken to Weehawken, and the adjacent places.
The steamship Star of the West, TINKLEPAUGH, Commander, arrived yesterday morning from San Juan de Nicaragua, making the passage in 7 days and twenty-one hours. Her California news is not later.

AMERICAN DIPLOMACY,--We have seen an extract of a letter from one of our most experienced diplomatic representatives on the, Continent of Europe, to the following effect: "Mr. EVERITT'S Cuban letter has excited attention here. I read it with pride and admiration.
We have our additional news by the Niagara at length, which will be found under that head. To those who are in special haste this morning we may add, that it is not at all important.

POLITICAL WAR.-The following is the political creed of the Union party, who are to hold a meeting on the 1st of April: "A wise and sound administration of our city affairs. The preservation of our Free Public Schools, as now organized.
It is a fortunate thing for the honor of our country, and we may well congratulate ourselves, that Hon. JOHN M. CLAYTON has been sent back to the Senate of the United States.

Yesterday morning, between the hours of 9 and 10 o'clock, another tragedy was enacted in our City. A young Frenchman, named EUGENE MELVILLE, aged 26 years, went into the wine packing vault of Messrs. A. GERAUD Co., on the northwest corner of Greenwich and Reade-streets, under Harris's Hotel.

John Skin O'Brien, an Indian Chief, 100 years old, recently visited the Philadelphia House of Industry, with his wife and five of his youngest children. He was born in Massachusetts, in the Oneida tribe of Indians.

SCULLIONS.--A correspondent of the Cultivator says the undoubted cause of the growth of scullions is late sowing. A very good way of checking the inordinate growth of onion tops at the expense of the bulb, is to roll any empty barrel over the bed after the bottoms begin to form.

The Senate to-day were in Executive Session two hours and a half. They confirmed all the Philadelphia nominations as reported-also all the New-York nominations except DIX and FOWLER, which were postponed.

All the back New-Orleans mails were received at Washington last night, but none have yet been received here. The Western mail car, last night, on the way to this city, caught fire, and one letter-bag was burned.

The Young Men's Democratic Union Club called a meeting of the Democracy at Tammany Hall, last evening, to consider what amendments should be made to the City Charter, and the manner of making them, and to take such measures as might be deemed advisable towards City reform.

ROUTE FROM SANTA FE TO CALIFORNIA.--A trip from Santa Fe to California in mid-winter, cannot be supposed to possess many charms, particularly if the person making it is encumbered with the charge of some five thousand head of sheep.

We have nothing brought south of Augusta, Ga. New-Orleans mails from the 16th to the 25th, inclusive, are now due here. The Augusta papers of Tuesday say that letter mails of the 2lst], 22d, and 23d, had come to hand, but the newspapers are still missing.

The Senate immediately upon assembling proceeded to the consideration of Executive business. When the doors were opened, Mr. HOUSTON submitted a resolution, which lies over, calling for the report of an examination of the Patent Office building.
METROPOLITAN HALL.--The "Black Swan" gave a concert last evening. The hall was crowded, and as the free list was entirely suspended, we presume the lady realized a handsome return.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Doubtless, Sir, you participate in the general self-complacency enjoyed by all who by the accidents of either birth or fortune are identified with the interests and the future of this prosperous City.

PROCESSION OF THE HOUSE CARPENTERS.--STRIKE FOR SEVENTEEN SHILLINGS PER DAY.--Pursuant to resolutions passed Wednesday evening, there was a general strike among the House Carpenters of the City yesterday morning for 17s. per day.

From 1811 to 1813 a warm controversy pervaded the Associate Reformed Church on the subject of Free and Open Communion,?? as it is generally termed. Dr. MASON'S conspicuous position, being at the head of their Theological Seminary, and the example he had set in admitting to the Commission Table Christians of other denominations, drew upon him animadversations from many of his brethren, which at times lay heavily on his spirits.
The Canal Board has selected the following depositories for their revenues; first deciding that Individual Banks were not elegible under the law:

The Senate were in executive session until 4 1/2 o'clock. The delay in the confirmation of DIX and FOWLER, and some say COCHRANE also, had caused intense excitement, and a renewal of the struggle outside, pro and con, and a protracted discussion arose thereon in the Senate, Mr. BRIGHT leading off in opposition.

The debate in Executive Session to-day, on the nomination of DIx, lasted four hours, and was superbly rich. Senators DOUGLAS, SOULE, WELLER, CHASE, SEWARD, HUNTER and PETTIT, took ground in favor of confirmation; and Messrs. RUSK, BRIGHT, BUTLER and MASON against it.

List of Patents issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending March 29, 1853. Luther Atwood, of Boston, Mass.--For improvement in preparing lubricating oils. Schuyler Briggs and John G. Talbot, of Sloansville, N.Y.--For improvement in winnowers of grain.

The suggestions I telegraphed you relative to MARCY's position with reference to the New-York nominations, are taken very generally now to be the true solution of this perplexing affair. Gov. MARCY is an old stager.
During last Fall, some thirty wild ducks were ensnared and captured alive in Maine. Their wings were clipped to prevent their escape, and thus they gradually became domesticated.

CANAL DEPAULTERS.--The defalcation of W. SUMNER, late Canal Collector at Oswego, is for the sum of $2,300. That of J. WESLEY SMITH, at Havana, is for about $160. That of -- CARLIN, in New-York, $1,000.

A correspondent of the Morning Post, whose letter is dated Naples, March 12, says: "I have just received letters from Sicily, dated Palermo, March 8. The police authorities declare that a wide spread Mazzinian conspiracy exists throughout the Island.

To Messrs. DE WITT DAVENPORT: Gentlemen: I have received with much pleasure the valuable work by Miss SINCLAIR. I had already seen it, but it is a work which can never be too often read, or too highly appreciated.

The sloop-of-war Germantown, Commodore E. A. F. LAVELLETTE, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon from Port Praya, Cape Verd Islands, which place she left March 1. She sailed in company with the U. S. sloop-of-war Dale, Commander LARDNER, bound to this port.

EX-PRESIDENT FILLMORE.--Among the news items crowded out of our columns yesterday morning was an account of the arrival of Mr. FILLMORE in our City on Thursday, by the Camden and Amboy Railroad. The ex-President was accompanied by his son and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. HEMENWAY, and Mr. POWERS, who was in charge of the remains of Mrs. FILLMORE.

We have received late and highly important intelligence from San Juan de Nicaragua. Our dates are to the 16th of March. On the morning of the 12th, the flag of the city was lowered, amid a salute of twenty-one guns, and the Government came to an end.

Mr. MORGAN reported complete the bill to confirm the conveyances of land sold by the New-York Institution for the Deaf and Dumb. Mr. PIERCE reported a bill to reconstruct the locks on the Champlain Canal.

Professor GERVINUS will leave Heidelberg on the expiry of his imprisonment, and reside at Bonn. An American lady has been arrested at Heidelberg, who came direct from the United States, for having a number of pamphlets, declared by the police to be of a revolutionary character.

By the arrival of the British Mall Steamer at Vera Cruz, on the 4th of March, late and authentic intelligence is received of the movements and intentions of Gen. SANTA ANNA. He has decided to accept the Presidency of Mexico, and proposed to return to that country in the steamer of 1st April.

Our local columns show that there is a very general demand, on the part of the trades and laborers of the City, for higher wages. The Carpenters, who have been getting fifteen to sixteen shillings, ask seventeen per day.

Whatever doubts may have oppressed the minds of the worthy but suffering citizens of New-York as to the existence of one HENRY ARCULARIUS, they have been forever dispelled by the unexpected appearance of that individual at the Municipal Reform Meeting, held in Tammany Hall on last Thursday evening.

For the other City News of this morning, see Third Page. THE STRIKE MOVEMENT--MEETING OF JOURNEYMEN COOPERS.--The Coopers' Protective Society, held a public meeting in Chatham Hall, last evening, to receive new members and consider the propriety of making a strike far an advance of wages.
The Agricultural College bill was referred to report complete. Mr. McELWAIN reported the Militia Code. Mr. BARTLETT reported a bill to equalize and regulate the assessment of Railway Companies.

Our regular files of the Correo de Caracas, to the 26th February, have reached us. They contain no important news. Congress is still in session, and the Chamber of Representatives has had under discussion the treaty indemnifying citizens of the United States for commercial losses sustained during the political convulsions of the State.

Let us have a National Gallery. Let us in part cease to be the mechanics of the world, and rend the iron veil which seems to hang between us and Art. It is not enough that we of all people should stand forth as the Genii of Industry, while others and more cultivated nations play the Aladdins, and look on while we work wonders for them.

New disturbances have arisen at Denizli, at Anatolia--it is supposed in consequence of the heavy taxes. Conflicts took place in the streets, many lives were lost--100, it is said; and the bazaar remained closed for some days.

The semi-official returns of the Foreign Imports at the Port of New-York for the month of March, have just been made up, and present a total aggregate larger in value than any previous month in our statistical record, viz.: $19,166,106, exclusive of $247,722 Foreign Specie and Bullion.

REESE's Medical Gazette, for April, contains two successful cases of double amputation of the inferior extremity in each case, performed while the patient was under the influence of chloroform, and in immediate succession.
We have no mail south of Richmond tonight. The Committee of the Maryland Senate have reported favorably on the Susquehanna Bridge bill.

Some of the Kaffir chiefs are again giving evidence of insubordination. KRELI'S adherence is equivocal, and the Governor is making arrangements to visit this chief, who, however, has, by the last accounts, sent in a friendly message.

The accounts from Buenos Ayres, by the English steamer, represent that the beleaguered Government of that city is in a critical situation. The hopes which they had in the raising of an army in the south to march to the aid of Buenos Ayres have been completely shattered.

Mr. MASON asked leave to withdraw the papers of FRANCIS W. RICE, American Consul at Acapulco. He said the Committee on Foreign Relations, at the late session, found it impossible to act upon them, together with the communication of the President upon the subject,--and they show great and cruel oppression there exercised by the Mexican authorities.

The Democratic meeting of Thursday evening, in favor of City Reform,--reported in our columns yesterday morning,--was in the main calculated to do good. It was to some extent a party gathering,--called for the promotion of party purposes, and somewhat absurdly abusive towards party opponents.

It is essential to the beauty of a well regulated country house that its gates and windows and fences be in good repair. The security of houses in town demands a careful regard to the windows and the doors, while the moonlit balcony is not less inviting or of greater utility than the breezy verandah.

NIBLO's GARDEN.--In consequence of the sudden indisposition of Signor SALVI, the Opera of last night was unavoidably postponed. We regret exceedingly the unfortunate circumstance which has disappointed so many of Madame ALBONI'S admirers, and trust that illness with which Signor SALVI is afflicted, may not prove of a serious nature.

SABBATH OBSERVANCE.--At a meeting of the Sabbath Observance Convention, held on Thursday evening, a memorial was presented and adopted, requesting the Common Council to enforce the laws and ordinances which forbid the desecrating the Sabbath by trafticing, liquor dealing,
We gave, in our paper of last Saturday, the aggregate value of Foreign Dry Goods imported through the New-York Custom-House for the four calendar weeks ending with Thursday, 24th inst.

The Niagara on the morning of the 20th, passed the Cunard steamer Arabia, bound for Liverpool, which port she would probably reach in the afternoon; her trip having occupied about eighteen hours longer than that of the Collins steamer Arctic.

Mr. VANDERBILT'S reply to McMURRAY'S anti Canal Speech to-day, as short and sweet. Nothing could have bee more telling and effective than his citations from the Atlas of two years ago, in favor of the very plan which he (Mr. VANDERBILT) is now advocating.

The Albany Register is under the impression that the Banking Law will not authorize the use of a Four per cent. Loan for a basis of circulation over 67 cents in the dollar, to make it equal to a six per cent. Stock at par, instead of five.

We publish in another part of this morning' TIMES, the two reports made by the majority and minority, respectively, of the Assembly Committee, upon the Senate bill intended to prevent the construction of the Broadway Railroad.

In the State Assembly yesterday Mr. D. GILMORE, from the Committee on Railroads, to whom was referred the Senate's bill entitled "an act to prevent injustice in the construction of Railways in the cities of this State."

The Niagara's mails reached the City at midnight, from Boston. We give elsewhere the leading items of intelligence. The comments of the London Times on President PIERCE's Inaugural Address, will be read with attention.

The Bourbon Fusion, A great number of rumors have been afloat for some time past with respect to the progress making by the long-talked-of fusion between the two branches of the House of Bourbon. There is reason to believe that these reports are without any good foundation.

ARRIVAL OF THE NIAGARA'S MAILS. Reception of President Pierce's Inaugural Address. The English mails, per steamship Niagara at Boston, reached this City at 12 1/2 o'clock this morning, having left Boston in the 3 1/2 afternoon train.

The History of the State of New-York: by JOHN ROMEYN BRODHEAD.--Mr. BRODHEAD has not been willing to permit the history of his Dutch progenitors to continue any longer under the deliberate misrepresentations of Mr. Diedrich Knickerbocker.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: ST. THOMAS CHURCH, BROOKLYN.--In the TIMES, of yesterday, under the general head, "Brooklyn City," in a notice of St. Thomas' Church, it is stated that I burst in the doors and directed the taking away of the property there, under my $400 chattel mortgage.

Church and Missionary Intelligence. The removal of several of our more prominent benevolent societies to the new building of the Bible Society near Astor-place, will, it is said, have the effect of removing from the Broadway Tabernacle those anniversary meetings which have for many years made that place known.

The outsiders are all on the qui vive for the publication of the proceedings and debates in Executive Session, on the question of confirming Hon. JOHN A. DIX's nomination for Sub-Treasurer. It is understood that their curiosity will soon be gratified.
NEW-YORK TAX BILL. Mr. MORGAN reported complete a bill to amend the Tax bill of New-York. OTHER BILLS REPORTED. Mr. McELWAINE reported complete the New York State Agricultural College bill.

Baring Brothers Co.'s Circular. LONDON, Friday, March 18, 1853--5 o'clock P. M. In the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets, the business this week has been on an increased scale, with a continued active demand for SUGAR, and more inquiry for COFFEE and TEA.

The Arctic has not yet arrived. Santa Anna touched at Havana on his way to Mexico on the 26th ult. A telegraphic dispatch from Boston, whose truth, however, is not confirmed by our papers from the South, says that war has been openly declared between Honduras and Guatemala.

What a fluctuating climate ours is getting to be! Until the end of last week we had charming weather, with a balmy atmosphere perfumed by opening flowers, and peach trees had already blossomed, and contrasted with the golden fruit which hung in clusters on the trees of orange groves birds caroled sweetly, and the country wore that happy smiling appearance when it receives the first kiss of Spring.

BRIDGE-STREET FERRIES.--There are two ferries about to be established to run from the foot of Bridge street, Brooklyn to New-York. One under the management of Messrs. SMITH and BULKLEY, is to terminate at the foot of Goveneur-street, and the other at Rosevelt-street.

THE POLICE DISBANDED.--On Friday morning, Mayor BERRY issued orders to the Policemen of the several Wards to deliver up their stars. Most of the Police men refused to comply with his request, and contended that the police force was not disbanded by the action of the Common Council, at their last meeting.

Here at length is April. The month was called April or Aprilis, that is Aperilis from the verb Aperio, "since, then it is that Spring opens." Never mind what the Almanaes say. March may be the beginning of Spring in the books, but the Seasons are very independent of the books.

For the other City News of this morning, see Third Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera--II Barbiere de Siviglia. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Faint Heart never won fair Lady--Rivals.
The U. S. M. steamship Empire City, Capt. WENDEE, arrived at this port on Sunday afternoon from New-Orleans, having touched at Havana, and sailed thence at 8 o'clock, on the 29th ult.

In a letter of three columns in Saturday's Tribune, under his own signature, the editor settles his accounts with the DAILY TIMES, and that small portion of the public which has taken any interest in the business thus finished will not, perhaps, be surprised to find that the net result is a profound disgust, on Mr. GREELEY'S part, for personal controversy with the TIMES, and a determination diligently to eschew it, henceforth and evermore.

By and win the advice and consent of the Senate. CUSTOM-HOUSE OFFICERS. Collectors.--R. B. WILLIS, district of Oxford, Maryland, vice J. H. ALLEN, removed. J. G. DELL, district of St. John's, Florida, vice I. D. HART, removed.

We find in our files of the Diario de la Marina, received by the Empire City, news from Izabal, to the 5th of March. It will be observed that the telegraphic dispatch from Boston, printed else where, lacks confirmation; the state of hostilities between Guatemala and Honduras having assumed no more violent type than it has borne for four years past.

The Tribune, of Saturday, contains the following remarks upon the debate in Congress touching Mr. GREELEY'S vote on a resolution to pay for certain books for the individual members, which we copied on Friday from the Congressional Globe.

The Select Committee of the Assembly to which was referred the Preamble and Resolutions, charging HENRY FITZHUGH with perverting his authority as Canal Commissioner to his individual benefit, as the proprietor f certain flouring mills, and part owner of the Oswego line of boats respectfully

UNKNOWN MAN DROWNED.--About 11 o'clock on Friday morning, the body of a man was found floating in the river, opposite Castle Point, and was brought ashore by some laborers. A jury was shortly empanneled and an inquest held by F. B. CARPENTER, Esq, Justice of the Peace.
In the Court of Oyer and Terminer this morning Judge THOMPSON pronounced the decision of the Court, granting SPRING a new trial on account of MCQUILLAN'S serving on the Jury instead of CORR.

The addresses offered by the towns and villages of France to the Emperor, on the occasion of his marriage, are published not only by the Moniteur, but also, very many of them, by the Opposition and disaffected journals.
THE BROADWAY RAILROAD. Important Decision in the Supreme Court. SUPREME COURT--General Term--Before Judges EDWARDS, ROOSVELT and MORRIS.--In re Mithan and others vs. Jacob Sharp and others.

In the DAILY TIMES of this day, I notice an article, taken from the Albany Evening Journal, headed, "Canal Defaulters," in which I am announced a defaulter to the amount of about $1,000. This I pronounce a base and malicious calumny.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--A very much better attendance than could have been expected assembled in this elegant establishment on Saturday night, to witness "La Figlia del Reggimento." When a change of Opera takes place abruptly, as on this occasion, the audience is generally effected in a serious degree.

The Supreme Court on Saturday granted an injunction against the Broadway Railroad Company, forbidding them to lay down their track in that street, or to avail themselves in any way of the rights granted by the Common Council.

CITY POLITICS.--The Whigs of the First and Second Wards have appointed Committees to nominate Aldermen and report at a future meeting, and they have also appointed delegates to attend the Mayoraltv Convention to he held on Tuesday, 5th inst.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.). Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

In this City, on Thursday, March 31, AGNES, only daughter of Allen N. Wilson, late of Somerville, N. J., aged 3 years. On Friday, April 1, at his residence, Ramapo, New-Jersey, Judge HENRY BRASHER HAGERMAN, in the 65th year of his age.

The debate on the TARBOX case was continued at length by several members. Amendments offered by Mr. HENDEE to terminate the imprisonment on the 13th inst., and by Mr. BURNETT to recommit with instructions, were rejected.

Half a house on a lot scarcely thirty feet in front, by just enough deep to allow sun and air to visit one brief clothes-line and its pendents, between the rear line of the house and the partition wall of the neighbor opposite!

It is pleasant to note the very excellent understanding springing up among the European "crowned heads." It is a pity the Phenomenon is not in as well as among them. There is an evident eagerness of every one to look out for the security of the others.

In the GARDINER case the day was principally occupied in an argument upon admitting the testimony of Mr PARTRIDGE, respecting the genuine ness of the signatures upon the mining title and accompanying deposition. The evidence was mostly ruled out.

By the British steamship Conway, which arrived here yesterday, we have dates from Navy Bay to the 18th, Jamaica 24th, Inagua 26th, and Nassau to the 28th ult. The steamship Union, which left Navy Bay on the 18th for New-York, via Jamaica, had not reached the latter port on the 24th and apprehensions were entertained for the safety of the vessel.

The session has glided on pleasantly enough to its half-way house, the Easter holidays, which from time immemorial have supplied an excuse for relaxing from the severity of legislative labor, and on that account are ever acceptable to "both Houses."

A friend writes us from the South in complimentary terms of JOHN A. CAMPBELL, Esq., who has recently been elevated to the bench of our Federal Court. He is yet a young man, considering the legal distinction he has acquired; and, among the great lawyers of the country, is probably unsurpassed since the death of WEBSTER.

A bill- to erect a Monument to Gen. WORTH, in Greenwood Cemetery, at an expense of $5,000 to the State, was ordered to a third reading in the House today; but it will not pass. Mr. LOOMIS made another unsuccessful effort to get his bill through to secure greater economy in Canal expenditures.
THE HISTORICAL SOCIETY.--JOHN C. DEVEREUX, Esq., will this evening read a paper before the Society, upon "The Disputed Historic Claims of WILLIAM PENN."

Their hand against every man, and every man's hand against them, is a proverb which applies almost as literally to the street-children of our large cities as to the Ishmaelites of antiquity. Side by side with the strides of civilization advances its monitory spectre.

The Binghamton Republican states that ex-Senator DICKINSON is at his residence in that place, and that it is understood he will accept the Collectorship of New-York. There has been no doubt upon that point, we presume, since his nomination was made.

We have papers from Santa Fe to the 26th of February. The Gazette has the following items: Gov. LANE will leave on the 28th, on a visit of exploration and observation down the country. One or two gentlemen of this city will accompany him.

The Senate to-day confirmed Col. POLK as Surveyor of Baltimore, but he declined, and the President afterwards nominated Dr. J. O. WHARTON for that office. Among the nominations are ex-Senator Sturgeon for Sub-Treasurer, Philadelphia, vice Ewing, declined; Robert white, Collector at the port of Galveston, and J. W. Pomeroy and J. T. Emerson, Appraisers, Baltimore.

BOARD OF ASSISTANTS.--The President, JONATHAN TROTTER, Esq., in the Chair. The Board met at the usual hour, when the minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Petitions Referred.--From Stephen Whitney and others for widening and regarding Chatham-street.
In the bill now before the Legislature amending the City Charter, is a clause making the MAYOR ex-officio one of the Board of Alms House Governors. The reason for this is not quite clear.

GREAT SWINDLE.--ARREST AND RECOVERY OF THE MONEY.--On the 17th inst., C. H. SMITH, who has figured as President of the Buckeye Health Association, received through the Post-office, a letter directed to C. H. SMITH, woolbuyer, announcing that a package of $3,000 had been forwarded by express from Troy, to the office in this city.

The standing topic of political talk is the coming of the Pope to crown the Emperor. It is the standing topic for want of a better, rather than from any lively interest that it excites. When conversation turns on this theme, it is made up suppositions as to the present, and abundant historical reminiscences regarding the Coronation of the first NAPOLEON.

One of the witnesses relied on by the Rev. Mr. HANSON, it will be remembered, to prove that the Prince DE JOINVILLE sought an interview with Rev. ELEAZAR WILLIAMS, was Mr. JAMES 0. BRAYMAN, one of the Editors of the Buffalo Courner, who states that he heard the Prince make inquiries concerning Mr. WILLIAMS and express a desire to see him.
Mr. McMURRAY reported adversely to in creasing the Harbor Masters of New-York. Laid on the table. Mr. MORGAN reported favorably on the Caulkers and Shipwrights' Benevolent Association bill.

NEW MARKETS.--A new market was not long since erected in Grove-street near Newark-avenue. It is considered the handsomest market in the city; but it will have to yield the palm to the new Market located in Greene, near Montgomery-street, and now nearly completed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the last communication, it was my intention to show the benign motive and wholesome tendency of the liberal movement of 1846-7, in Catholic Italy particularly, under the auspices of the present Pope.

COLLECTORS.--Daniel S. Dickinson. District of New-York, N. Y., vice Hugh Maxwell, removed; Charles Brown, District of Philadelphia, Penn., vice Wm. D. Lewis, removed; Edward T. Hillyer, District of Newark, N. J., vice Frederick S. Thomas, removed; William E. Bowen, District of Bridgetown, N. J., vice Ephraim Buck, removed; Alexander Somerville, District of Saluria, Texas, vice Levi Jones, removed.

The Lavaca (Texas) Commercial says that Capt. MITCHELL, while out hunting a few days ago, on the opposite side of the bay, was accident tally killed by the discharge of his gun in his own hands. At the time of the accident he was endeavoring to get up to a flock of wild turkeys, pulling his gun after him.

The Select Committee to whom was referred so much of the Governor's Message as related to juvenile delinquents, and also the pettions relating to "Street Children," having had the, 'same under consideration, beg leave to present the following

Our City, at this present writing, is "dull, stale, flat, and unprofitable." We have had no news from beyond Stockton, Ala., for a week past, the everlasting point which the mails fail to reach. Our Legislature is taking its time, and the members seem determined to spin out the session until June.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"11 Barbiere di Seviglia" was never performed more enjoyably than last night. Not that it was faultless, but that the excellencies far out numbered the blemishes. Indeed, so trifling were the latter, that the audience was almost unanimous in its applause.
FROM BRITISH GUIANA.--We have from Georgetown, advices to the 10th of March. The weather had been dry, but the crops have not yet suffered much. The rats have troubled them prodigiously.

STEAMBOAT DISASTER.--The steamer Shreveport, Capt. TARBELL, hence for Upper Red River, on Sunday last, the 20th inst., when eight miles below Gordon's Landing, on Red River, collapsed a flue of her starboard boiler, by which Mr. E. S. ELLENGHAMcar, penter, JACOB BURGET, second engineer, and JOSEPH COOKHART, fireman, were severely, but it is thought not dangerously scalded.

FROM BERMUDA.--We have received dates from Hamilton, Bermuda, to the 22d March. The brig Swan had arrived from New-York with a deck load of cattle. The American brigatine Triad, which was brought into Hamilton some days ago in a sinking state, had been examined and found on survey to be past repairing.

The Galveston News, of the 25th ult., gives the following account of an explosion on board the steamboat Farmer, about 11 o'clock on the night of the 23d, when she was about ten miles from Galveston, in the bay, on her way from Houston, by which calamity a large number of lives were lost, and many persons were more or less injured.
Imports (other than Dry Goods) at the port of New. York, for the week ending and including Friday, April 1, 1853.

The Grand Jury for the April Term--Charge of Hon. Judge Beebe--Neary Indicted for Murder. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Monday, April 4.--Before Hon Judge BEEBE, Aldermen DENMAN and WOOD.--At the usual hour, this morning, the Court of General Sessions met at the Halls of Justice for the commencement of the April Term.

The late Mrs. CASS, says the Detroit Advertiser, was a daughter of Dr. JOSEPH SPENCER, of Connecticut, who removed to Lansingburg, New York, in 1786, at which place she was born Sept. 27, 1788. Five years afterwards she removed with, her father's family to Wood County, Virginia, where she resided until she was married to General CASS in 1806.

For the other City News of this morning, see Third Page. Amusements this Evening, Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera. Friday, WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A cure for the Heart ache--A Practical Man.

On Sunday morning, April 3, JAMES FERGUSON, aged 21 years, 9 months and 1 day. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, this (Tuesday) afternoon, at I o'clock, from the Central Presbyterian Church, Broome-st., between Elin and Marion-sts.

On the 24th inst., at 12 o'clock, the ceremony of administration of the oath to Mr. KING as Vice-President of the United States, took place at the estate of Ariadne, by WM. L. SHARKEY, Consul of the United States at the Havana, assisted by Hon. GEORGE W. JONES, M. H. R. from Tennessee, and several American citizens who went down from Havana for the purpose of being present.

Mr. GWIS made a brief statement in allusion to a statement of Mr. HALE, late Senator, and denied that any outside influence had operated on the Naval Committee, to induce an extra appropriation for officers, seamen, and marines serving on the Pacific coast.

WE WISH TO KNOW--Whether, now the Ferry Company have been compelled by the Legislature of New Jersey to reduce the rate of ferriage to three cents, they intend to issue any more quarterly commutation tickets, or to cut their own throats by only issuing their yearly ?

The exercises here for the last two days have been of a very interesting character. They took place in the following order: On Tuesday morning a public examination of the applicants for the degree of M. D., was held at the Medical College, and several theses also were read.

SPRING was brought up for trial again this morning. There was a great crowd in and about the court-room. Judge KELLY charged the jurors upon the opening of the April term, after which the calling of jurors for the SPRING case was commenced.

GAS REGULATOR.--Gas is so universally burned in this City, that everything tending to promote economy in its use is of public interest. We have examined and tested with some care KIDDER's Gas Regulator, an invention designed to regulate the pressure at which gas shall be burned by each consumer.

This gentleman is not dead. The telegraphic dispatch was clearly wrong in his place of residence, and we distrusted the correctness of his reported death at the hands of his tenant. Mr. MARSHALL resides at Versailles, south of Lexington--not Maysville.

The Journeymen Printers have raised their prices for composition about 20 per cent.; possibly, on the average, something less. The principal newspaper proprietors will probably not object. The House Carpenters will generally obtain their demands of $2 121/2 the day.

ST. ANN's CHURCH FOR DEAF MUTES.--On Thursday evening next, a public exhibition of the pupils of the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb will take place at NIBLO's, in behalf of the new organization known as "St. Ann's Church for Deaf Mutes."

ROWDYISM ON SUNDAY--A MAN STABBED.--The filth of society floated on the surface on Sunday. The pestilent rowdies, comprising the thieves and black guards of Brooklyn, with a considerable importation of New-York scoundrels, were active in misdeeds.

THE IRISH SOCIETIES AND THE TEN HOURS' BILL.--A report of the proceedings of this body, at a meeting held on Friday night, at No. 76 Prince-street, has been crowded from our columns. The proceedings were of great interest, but we can only give a brief sketch of them.

Elsewhere in this paper we have translated from the columns of the Courrier des Etats Unis, a letter from San Juan de Nicaragua, giving a third distinct statement of the recent difficulty at that place.

ACCIDENTS.--On Sunday night, a man named THOMAS TREMDLE, while walking through Water-street, was severely injured in his breast by falling upon an iron spike. A little girl about 5 years of age, named ANN CARL, whose parents reside in South Ninth-street, had one of her hands crushed on Saturday afternoon, by a window sash falling upon it.

JAS. D. TAYLOR, Esq., Editor of the Cincinnati Times thus announces his intentions. The course is quite as honest certainly as giving Bob a dollar to treat Bill and Jim with, often enough to secure their assistance in getting Joe appointed delegate to a primary meeting, and bully the rest into the nomination of delegates favorable to the candidate at the approaching district meeting:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: With such influences upon them, with such a character, with such education, with such associations, as I described in my last letter, it is not surprising that Southerners say that the condition of the slave who is subject to some wholesome restraint, and not withstanding his improvidence is systematically provided for, is preferable to that of the free black.
The result of the election to-day, as far as heard from, is decidedly favorable to the Democrats. In this District, INGERSOLL is elected to Congress by an increased majority.

The Senate did nothing in open session yesterday but adopt Mr. Brodhead's resolution requesting the Secretary of the Treasury to furnish the Senate at the commencement of the next session, a statement, showing the entire amount of United States Stocks and Bonds held abroad.

LECTURE V.--THE POPE'S TEMPORAL POWER. Father GAVAZZI delivered his fifth lecture at the Tabernacle, last evening, and considering the inclemency of the weather, the attendance was very good. The subject of the lecture was "The Pope's Temporal Supremacy as peculiar to the Roman States."

The investigation by the Grand Jury into City abuses was greatly embarrassed, it will be remembered, by the refusal of a witness to answer questions, and by the delay of the Court of Sessions, two Aldermen sitting as Judges, to decide whether he could be compelled to answer or not.

A private correspondent of the Courrier des Etats Unis sends from Greytown, under date of March 15, an account of the recent transactions there, which differs materially from what we have already had.

TAKING THE VEIL.--On Monday morning last, the ceremony of taking the veil took place at the Chapel of the Sisters of Mercy, of this city. The ladies who made profession of the Order, were Euphrasia, Alphonsa, Victoria, and Jane Frances de Chantal, previously known as Mary Kinsella, Josephine Butler, Celine Bosset and Catharine Grogan.

The New-York Historal Society held their regular Monthly Meeting at their rooms in the University, last evening. The attendance of members was very full. The President -of the Society, (Hon. LUTHER BRADISH,) occupied the Chair, supported by Rev. Dr. DE WITT, and FREDERICK DEPEYSTER, Esq., first and second Vice Presidents.
LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.-The whole number of passengers (other than those who commute) conveyed over this Road during the month of March last, was 18,512 Total receipts for the same month, $17,116 76.

For the other City News of this morning, see Second Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particular, may be found in our Advertising Columns, NIBLO'S GARDEN.-Combination Italian Opera. Friday. WALLACK'S THEATRE.-Two can Play at that Game--Money.
Alderman STURTEVANT introduced in the Board of Aldermen, on Monday night, an important resolution in regard to re-building Washington Market. It was referred to the Committee on Markets, for inquiry.

By and with the advice and consent of the Senate. CUSTOM-HOUSE OFFICERS. Collectors-Adams Treat, District of Belfast Me., vice Maurice C. Blake, removed; George P. Sewall, District of Bangor, Me, vice William C. Hammatt, removed; John Cousons, District of Kennebunk, Me., vice Daniel Remick, removed ; Bion Bradbury, District of Passamuquoddy, Me., vice Daniel Kilby, removed; John Babson, District of Wiscasset, Me., vice Jeremiah Baily, remove; Charles N. Bodfish, District of Bath.

A letter received in this city dated Buenos Ayres, Feb. 18, says that URQUIZA has crossed the Parana on his march to Buenos Ayres, at the head of 600 men, which would be largely increased at Santa Fe.

From the London Morning Chronicle, March 22. The recent crisis in the affairs of Turkey, which was terminated only by the submission of the Porte to nearly all the demands of Austria, has been succeeded by one of a still more momentous character.
The threatening aspect of Russia towards Turkey has caused the highest degree of excitement not only at Constantinople, but in France, and in a lesser degree in England.

The U. S. Mail steamship Arctic, Capt. LUCE, arrived at her wharf at 4 1/2 o'clock yesterday, in the afternoon. She sailed from Liverpool at 9 o'clock A. M. upon the 23d of March, and brings us, therefore, four days' later intelligence.
A HEARTLESS MURDERER.-We learn from a letter, under date of Mackinac, March 2, that Mr. O. T. HOUSON, of Grand Traverse, Michigan, has murdered one of his sister's children.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.)., Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

The bark Gay Head, from Cape Town Feb. 11, arrived this morning. She reports that the steam propeller West Wind, from New-York via Ascension for Australia, put in to Cape Town Feb. 7, with trouble among her passengers.

The Arctic has arrived with four days' later news. Very ample details, and copious extracts will be found elsewhere in this morning's issue. There is nothing of special interest, but some very significant indications observable.

Owing to the Easter holidays, Parliament is not in session, and home politics are consequently dull. The Ottoman difficulties that have excited considerable attention, are referred to more at length under the caption " Turkey " in another part of this dispatch.

On Monday, April 4, PETER LISPENESSE, of consumption of the throat, in the 32d year of his age. His friends and relatives, and the patriarchs and brethren of Mount Pisgah Encampment and Evening Star Lodge. I. 0. of 0. F., are invited, without further notice, to his funeral, which takes place this (Wednesday,) day, at 2 o'clock, P. M., from his late residence, No. 286 Division-av., Williamsburg, L. I.
From the circumstance that the Mayor of Rheims has been summoned to wait on the Emperor, there are some who say that the coronation will take place in that' ancient city.
The stone contributed by Switzerland, in scribed "The Free Swiss Confederation to the memory of WASHINGTON," was presented this noon at the City Hall with appropriate ceremonies.

Advices from Berne of 18th ult., state that the Federal Council was to meet on the following day to discuss the Austrian vote. This vote repeats the former accusations against Switzerland of inciting revolt, but proposes to restore the former footing between Austria and Switzerland, so soon as justice shall have been done to the complaints of Austria, and Switzerland shall have given guarantees for the future.

The question of the power of the President to remove Judges in the Territories, after considerable debate, was decided in the Executive Session of the Senate yesterday, in favor of the power, by a vote of 25 to 9.

NAVAL.--The U. S. steamer Engineer, Master OLMSTEAD, commanding, arrived here yesterday, from Washington and Baltimore, with 69 naval recruits for general service, and a portion of the guns from the U. S. ship Ontario.

LOMBARDY.--In Paris it is stated by those who claim to be well informed, that the revolutionary chiefs were never more active than at the present moment, and that an outbreak somewhere may be looked for towards the end of May.

The New-York Police bill coming up, was referred to the Senators from the City of New-York. The special order being the Constitutioal amendment of Mr. VANDERBILT'S was considered--Mr. BARTLETT in the Chair.
A well-dressed man was found in the river near the steamboat landing at Newark, Monday It is thought his name is George W. Hamill, of New-York.

COMMON COUNCIL.--A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held at the City Hall on Monday evening. The Street Committee reported favorably on the petition for opening South Tenth-street east of Fourth-street.

SIR--In your journal of this morning I find the following obituary notice: BENJAMIN BIRDSALL, Esq., died at his residence, in Madison, N. J., on the 30th ult., at the advanced ago of 78 years. He was for a long time a prominent politician.

The Winter is on its last legs. We have had several days of fine, genial weather, whose influence on the 'accumulations of the past season is quite satisfactory. The quantity of snow which fell during the Winter was greater than for several years past.

From the London Daily News, 21st. The news of the sailing of an English fleet for Constantinople is scarcely confirmed before we are told that our ships of war have been followed by a fleet from France, bound to the same Quarter.

The extreme efficacy of a sea voyage in producing, a total and complete change of system, is well known to physicians. It is at times beneficial to a gratifying extent, and in many instances, completely restorative.

Hamburg letters of the 18th state that the navigation of the Elbe had been again interrupted by frost, which had set in, accompanied by sharp easterly winds. Several steamers were obliged to leave the port, and proceed to Gluckstadt or Caxhaven.
The University of Vermont has taken measures to establish a Medical Department in connection with its course of study. Four Professorhips have already been filled, and three are still to be supplied.

It is understood that the Treaty recently negotiated by the American Secretary of State and the British Minister, giving to the Authors and Publishers of each country a monopoly of their books in both, will not be acted upon at the present extra session of the Senate.

The "Uncle Tom" Anti-Slavery movement has ended as it began at Stafford-house, all the messengers, missives, circulars, and other harmless projectiles launched from that mansion in November having been duly returned last Saturday.
The Arctic arrived last evening after a tedious passage, such as the season usually inflicts upon us. The advices are more than ordinarily interesting.

THE REPORTED SUICIDE OF A WOMAN WITH OIL OF TANSY-THE CORONER'S INQUEST.-Yesterday, Coroner O'DoNNELL proceeded to the residence of Mrs. MARY, ANN CUDDY, at No. 245 Eighth-avenue, and summoned a Jury to investigate the cause of her death.

The Senate succeeded in getting into Executive session and out again to-day. The nominations unbudgeted were not very important. The feature of the day was the Governor's rehash of his regular Message on the subject of the Canals.

From Berlin it is stated that the new Four per Cent loan of [Pound]750,000 sterling is to be issued in a few days, and the demand for it was great. The Plenipotentiaries of the various States comprising the Zollverein, hold their meetings daily, their main point being for the present to increase all facilities for commercial intercommunication between the members of Steuerverein, the Zollverein, Austria, and her Italian States.
THE OTSEGO BANK ROBBERY.-It is not improbable that the individual or individuals who were really engaged in robbing the Otsego Bank, will soon be discovered.

The Prussian Gazette states that the British Ambassador, Lord WESTMORELAND, has presented an official note to the Austrian Ministry from the English Cabinet, containing a formal expression of their intention rigorously to suppress any conspiracy planned by foreign refugees in England against the Continental powers.

During the latter part of Mayor KINGSLAND'S official career, a rumor obtained currency that the members of the Police force were to make their appearance in uniform; that they were to be dressed in a distinctive and perhaps slightly conspicuous costume, so that they might be easily distinguished.

The New-Orleans papers of Tuesday and Wednesday last, as late as due, are received. The authorities of Vera Cruz have decreed that the day of SANTA ANNA'S landing shall be celebrated as a public festival.
The steamers Southerner and America arrived here this morning, from Dunkirk, fully laden with goods. The navigation between this port and Dunkirk is unobstructed.

The North is right glad to acknowledge it, and acknowledge it she will-the South is doing some wonders in the way of improving girls. For years past, the land that a great Gulf stops from reaching into the Tropics, has been stretching its arms towards another equator, and the " imaginary great circle " is fast becoming more than a line among the divisions of the social sphere.

The perplexity thrown over the present state of affairs in the East by the confused and exaggerated statements of several foreign journals is now partly dispelled ; and when the occurrences which have actually taken place are reduced to their real dimensions, they will be found to have lost much of the imposing and alarming character ascribed to them.

Liverpool Markets. LIVERPOOL, Wednesday, March 23. COTTON-Since the sailing of the Niagara, on the l0th, the market has been irregular, and the improvement quoted by last advices has been lost. Holders being still apprehensive of a continuance of large receipts at the American ports, are willing to sell, and partial concessions of one-sixteenth (1-16d.) ??lb., have been made to effect sales on current qualities of American.

The returns are still very imperfect. PRATT (Dem.) is elected to Congress in the First District by about 1,200 plurality. The First, Second, Third, Twentieth and Twenty-first Senatorial Districts have elected Democratic Senators.
The line of telegraph from this City to Dunkirk is singularly affected; a case in point to support the theory of the mysterious spirit rappers.

The West India mail steamer Parana, arrived at Southampton on Monday, 21st ult., bringing $916,368 specie on freight, and' a large cargo. Advices by the Parana report great discontent at San Juan (Greytown) and Navy Bay, from an attempt of the authorities to lay new and heavy taxes; but amicable arrangements were expected.
The steamship El Dorado, Capt. J. F. SCHENCK, arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Aspinwall, on the 26th March, and Havana on the 1st April.

LECTURE VI.--MARIOLATRY--ST. PATRICK. The Sixth lecture in the course was delivered by Father GAVAZZI, at the Tabernacle, last evening. Judging from the attendance, the public interest in those lectures does not at all abate as they progress.
The Ohio Statesman passed, on the 1st inst., from the editorial charge of Col. SAMUEL MEDARY, to that of Messrs. JAMES H. SMITH and SAMUEL S. COX.
By the schooner Edward Bernard, we have received full files of papers from Vera Cruz to the 19th, and from the City of Mexico to the 15th inst. The news contained in them is of little interest.
Mr. MORGAN presented the memorial of the Chamber of Commerce in relation to the proposed amendments to the Constitution--as to the Canals, Taxes and Toll Law.

By and with the advice and consent of the Senate. POSTMASTERS.--Twyam Wauyt, at Charlottesville, Va.; Wm. McNulty, at Georgetown, S. C.; G. H. Rundlett, at Portsmouth, N. H.; P. Allen, jr., at Pittsfield, Mass.; Douglas A. Danforth, at Burlington, Vt.; Thornton F. Brodhend, at Detroit, Mich.; Josiah A. Noonan, at Milwaukee, Wis.; John J. Heister at Easton, Penn.; Henry M. Raigart, at Lancaster, Penn.

KINGS COUNTY TOWN ELECTION.--On Tuesday, the country towns in Kings County held their annual election for Town Officers for the ensuing year, which resulted as follows, as far as we are able to learn: BUSHWICK.--Supervisor--Martin Kalbfleisch. Town Clerk--Norman Andrews. Assessor--John Garrison.

The Legislature of Michigan has just adopted a new system of taxation. The system so much abused by the Locofocos of Ohio, when it was proposed by the Whigs some years since, is the basis of the law. The Detroit Advertiser says:

THE CHARGES AGAINST GOV. RAMSEY. On motion of Mr. SEBASTIAN, the President of the United States, was requested to cause to be investigated the charges of fraud and misconduct in office alleged against ALEXANDER RAMSEY, Superintendent of Indian affairs in Minnesota.
We have no mail south of Richmond tonight. The Maryland Senate to day passed a bill incorporating the Pittsburg and Connellsville Railroad.

ELECTIONS.--The election for town officers for, the town of Bushwick took place on Tuesday. The Democratic ticket was successful by a majority, ranging from 70 to 400. MARTIN KALBFLEISCH, was elected Supervisor by about 70 majority.
A letter from Lt. Col. MILES, stationed at Fort Fillmore, New-Mexico, gives an account of a new Pass across the Rocky Mountains, recently discovered on the route from Albuquerque to San Francisco.

The Boston Journal of Monday says: Officer At well Richardson, of this city, and Joseph Keefe, of New-York, arrived here this morning, having in their custody William O. Bicknell and Nathaniel Atkins, fugitives from justice, whom they arrested in New-York on Saturday at French's Hotel, charged with swindling Anson: Peck, of this city, of a considerable amount of jewelry.

We improve in trifles but slowly. In great things our attention is at once absorbed and our energies enlisted, while many minor matters quite as conducive to personal comfort as great inventions, seem to be most unaccountably overlooked.
There must always be a certain class of thinkers, who will want to know how things in general, or in particular, are going. Facts are no facts for them unless figures show the certificates.

The bill fixing the general budget of receipts and expenditures for 1854, was communicated to the Legislative, body on Friday. The summary of the eighth and ninth articles, of this bill, as printed in the London journals from telegraphic dispatches transmitted Friday evening, is erroneous.
Mr. KING will leave Matanzas for Mobile, on or before the 6th of this month. A very comfortable room has been built for him to occupy during the voyage on the deck of the steamer Fulton.
Mr. PULSZKY and his accomplished wife have produced an eminently candid and judicious book, which will be read with pleasure and profit on both sides of the Atlantic.
THE WESTCHESTER ELECTION--ALL DEMOCRATS RETURNED.--We have received the return of the elections in Westchester County, which are as follows: Town of Rye--NEWBERRY D. HALSTED, (Dem.,) for Supervisor.

By the arrival of the steamship Texas, yesterday, we have Galveston papers to the 25th inst. The News states that the amount subscribed to the Texas Central Railroad by the citizens of Galveston exceeds $850,000.

OYER AND TERMINER--Wednesday. Before Chief Justice EDWARDS and Aldermen STURTEVANT and PECK.--Court met at 10 o'clock, but the District Attorney having other business to attend to, the Court took a recess until 11 1/2 o'clock.

The cause of Justice is again thwarted by the Supreme Court. Judge MORRIS delivered an opinion yesterday, which foreibly illustrates and fortifies the theory, that technical Law is far more efficient in protecting than in punishing crime.
The Austrians allowed the thunder cloud they had created to pass over Constantinople with out discharging upon poor Turkey any blasting thunderbolts.

Discharge of John J. Hicks. SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS.--Before the Hon. ROBERT H. MORRIS.--HABEAS CORPUS--In re the People Ex Rel. John J. Hicks.--In this case, his Honor gave quite a lengthy opinion, as follows: The prisoner, John J. Hicks, is before me upon the return of a habeas corpus issued to the Sheriff of the City and County of New-York.

NOMINATION FOR MAYOR.--DAVID S. MANNERS, the incumbent, has been re-nominated for Mayor of Jersey City, by the Whigs in City Convention. The First, Second and Third Wards have made a Whig nomination for Aldermen.
A note from Messrs. G. P. PUTNAM Co. directs our attention to an erroneous impression which an article in yesterday's TIMES might convey, concerning LAYARD'S second book on Nineveh.

THE LATE EXPLOSION OF THE STEAMER FARMER.--We are indebted to a friend for the following additional particulars in relation to the explosion of the steamboat Farmer, at Pelican Island, near Galveston, noticed by us yesterday: The number of the passengers on the Farmer was about thirty-two to thirty-five.

Suddenly, on Tuesday, April 5, Mrs. MARGARET DUBUAR, in the 64th year of her age. Her friends and connections are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her nephew, Mr. David Robins, on Thursday, at 2 P. M., precisely.

It is a melancholy consolation to know that New-York City does not stand alone in being governed by corrupt legislation. We publish elsewhere the report of a Committee of the State Assembly, embodying testimony convicting a subordinate officer of that body of trying to bribe one of its members.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have read with deep interest the series of letters from the South published in your columns. Circumstances have made me quite familiar with the field of your correspondent's investigation, much more familiar than he is at present, and yet I am happy to say, that his letters are more satisfactory than any I have ever seen relating to the South.
In consequence of Major STEVENS' appointment as Governer of the Territory of Washington, the Coast Survey Office in this City has been placed under the immediate direction of Captain BENHAM.

To the Senate and Assembly: I deem it my duty to call the attention of the Legislature to the necessity of making immediate appropriations to secure some essential Improvement of the Erie and Oswego Canals.

The Connecticut Legislature just chosen is divided thus--as far as heard from: House.--Democrats 126; Whigs 75; Free Soilers 4; no choice 1, and 17 to hear from.

The Jury, in the case of ARTHUR SPRING, came into Court this morning with a verdict of murder in the first degree. After the polling of the Jury, the prisoner asked permission to make statement, which was granted. Judge KELLY rebuked the prisoner for his hardihood in persisting in such improbable statements when his moments on earth were numbered.

By the arrival of the steamship Daniel Webster at this port from San Juan, we have dates from San Francisco to March 15. The Daniel Webster brings the passengers and specie brought down by the steamer Pacific, which left San Francisco on the 15th of March.

ELOPEMENT EXTRAORDINARY.--The Philadelphia Arugs of yesterday, tells the following extraordinary story: "At a late hour last night, a black fellow as found in company with a white woman, by stone members of the City Police, under circumstances which led to their being taken to the station-house.

If the interview between SANTA ANNA and CANEDO the other day, were a solitary fact, speculations about it might pass without notice. There would be no difficulty in accounting for the conjunction of two such stars.

HEROIC CONDUCT OF A BOSTON WOMAN--We are informed that on the 19th ult., Mr. JOHN F. SNOW, formerly of the Boston Police, but now County Jailor at Marysville, Cal., upon entering a cll in that Prison, occupied by two stalwart men named FARROW, was attacked by therm, and his revolver taken from him, and himself hurled violently to the rear part of the cell.

At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen Wednesday, although a vast number of communications, reports; were disposed of, there was but little business of special interest transacted. The following is a sketch of what was done: A communication was received from Comptroller Flag, in answer to a resolution calling for a report concerning the amount of moneys paid to the late Corporation Council.

RUNAWAY OMNIBUS.--On Wednesday afternoon four horses attached to one of the Jamaica omnibusses became frightened and ran through Division-avenue at a furious rate. The omnibus came in contact with a lamp, when the driver was thrown between the horses and one of the wheels, which passed over his head, injuring him severely.

Mr. BRIGHT offered a resolution, which was adopted, requiring an amendment of the thirty-fourth rule, so as to refer to the Committee to audit and control the contingent expenses of the Senate, all resolutions directing the payment of money out of the contingent fund, or creating a charge on the same.

The London Correspondent of the Tribune, states that MAZZINI had returned to London from the Continent, having eluded the utmost vigilance of the Governments at every point. If this be so, it shows that he is possessed in a remarkable degree of the very valuable faculty of moving incognito.

We have already announced the death, at his residence in Rutland, of Hon. CHARLES K. WILLIAMS, late Governor of Vermont. The close of a life so illustrious is deserving of a wider notice than has been bestowed upon it by the public press. The circumstances attending his death were somewhat remarkable.

A very important demonstration has been made in the State Senate, upon the Canal policy of the State. Mr. VANDERBILT'S proposition to amend the Constitution, so as to authorize a loan for the completion of the Canals, has been adopted by a vote of 19 to 6 !

JAIL BURNED--EIGHT LIVES LOST.--The Cherau (S. C.) Gazette of the 30th ult., gives the particulars of the destruction of the Chesterfield Jail, before noticed by telegraph: "The Chesterfield Jail was consumed by fire about 3 oclock yesterday, destroying the lives of eight persons.

New-Orleans papers of Thursday have been received. The bark Rainbow, from Rio Janeiro, Feb. 27, arrived last evening, with a cargo of 4,000 bags of coffee. She spoke, March 10, bark Indian Queen, for New-York; 12th, bark Emily Banning, from Philadelphia, all well.

One of those events which occur at intervals, to teach us how much in death we are in life, took place with singular impressiveness a few weeks since at Paris. A new piece, called the Decameron, was produced at the Vaudeville Theatre. When the curtain fell, the author was demanded.

No nomination of Minister to England has been made. BUCHANAN has been prominently spoken of hitherto, but Col. BENTON moved in high circles to day in connection with that mission. The Minister to France is yet undeterminedR. J. WALKER is talked of.

J. WATSON WEBB entertains the private circle of subscribers to the Courier and Enquirer, about once a month, with a repetition of the personal abuse of me, with which he has been in the habit of consoling himself since the Winter of 1851, for my refusal to aid his enHeavors then to be nominated by the Whigs of the Legislature of this State, as their Candidate for United States Senator.

FIRES IN CINCINNATI--A HEROINE.--One of the most destructive confiagrations with which our city has been visited, occurred Saturday morning. The fire broke out in WILL'S carriage shop, and is supposed to have been the work of an incendiary.

The steamship Promethcus arrived of the bar last night, short of coal, in six days and five hours from San Juan, which port she left at 5 P.M. on the 31st ult., with 221 passengers, and the specie brought down by the steamer Pacific, which left San Francisco on the morning of the 15th.

We have seen no collection of pictures which gives us so good an idea as this of what should form the ground-work of an American public gallery. We believe there are few persons who visit it who do not lament that it is not a permanent affair--the property of the State or of the City-to be increased from time to time, and opened freely for the delight and instruction of all.

No. 76. Fitch respondent, against The New-York and Erie Railroad Company, appellants. Submitted. N. Howard, Jr. , counsel. No. 35. (Reserved.) McDernnott, respondent, against Palmer, appellant. Argued. William Curtis Noyes, counsel for appellant; James B. Sheys, counsel for respondent.

FIRE.--Last evening about 7 1/2 o'clock, the store No. 285 Fulton-street, occupied by Messrs. LWEIS WILLIAMS as a dry-good store, caught fire from one of the gas-lights located in a show window. The fire was extinguished after burning a portion of the goods in the window, and before any general alarm was given. Loss about $200.
By the way of New-Orleans we have news from California of varied complexion. The discovery of rich mines of gold in Oregon, and the favorable accounts from the California mines are pleasant.

The Kentucky Mechanics' Institute was regularly organized at Louisville, on the 25th ult., P. M. Jones, President. Among the Committees appointed, was one on Manufactures, which was charged-ith the duty of ascertaining and reporting at as early a period as convenient what branches of mechanical industry, not now pursued here, might be advantageously introduced, and what is the condition generally of the small manufactures carried on in the city at this time.

AMERICAN COMMERCE WITH CHINA.--The report of the harbor master of Shanghai, (Mr. NICH(OLAS BAVLIES,) shows that from Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 1852, the American tonnage exceeded that of any other nation. The number of British vessels was one hundred and two, with a tonnage of 32,700; of American vessels seventy one, with a tonnage of 40,365. The whole amount of tonnage was 76,900,

I for one,
