Babcock, Beckman, Bennett, Bristol, Clark, Cooley, Huntington, Kirby, McElwain, Morgan, Monroe, Otis, Platt, Smith, Snow, Taber, Upham, Vanderbilt. Williams--19 NAVS--Messrs. Bartlett, Conger, Cornell, Davenport, Jones, McMurray--6. Adjourned.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR--Yesterday I had the inexpressible joy of receiving a letter from Mr. BARRINGER, U. S. Minister at Madrid, announcing the pardon and release of my beloved brother, and of all the other Hungarian prisoners, from the Spanish Presidio at Ceuta, in Africa.

A correspondent is respectfully inforned that when the " trunk full of documents," said to be in possession of " a lady " in NewOrleans, touching the Dauphin question, shall have been received, we will give due attention to their disclosures.

REMOVAL.--The Reformed Dutch Church on Grand-street, yesterday, was removed from its old site, to make room for the erection of a new and more commodious building. WHIG NOMINATIONS.--The following nominations have been made by the Whigs in City Convention: DAVID S. MANNERS, Mayor; LORENZO JAQUINS and STEPHEN QUAIFE, Assessors; P. C. DUMMER, Collector.

SUICIDE.--On Wednesday afternoon an unknown man, who from papers found in his possession, is supposed to he a German, committed suicide at New Lotts, on the farm of Mr STORTHOFF. It appears that he held a loaded pistol to his mouth, and discharged it; the charge mutilating his face and head in a horrible manner. When found, the pistol was clenched tightly in his hand.

Senator SOULE was nominated today as Minister to Spain, and confirmed unanimously, without reference to a committee. All the Louisiana nominations were confirnmed except JOHN M. BELL, Sub-Treasurer. The Finance Committee were not ready to report on it.

NEW-MEXICO.--Fort Union the depot of the army supplies for the Territory of New-Mexico, has, it appears, been infested by a gang of wretches who sold liquor to the soldiers, and induced some of them to commit depredations on the public property to the amount of thousands of dollars.

MUSICAL WNDOWS.--We are sometimes guilty of stopping to look in for a few moments at the windows of the principal music-stores. The feeling that prompts this proceeding is wholly inexplicable. It is not curiosity, for we rarely see anything new or striking. Nor have we the slightest hope of informing our minds upon any earthly subject front the literature we meet there. It may,

THE OVERLAND EMIGRATION THIS SPRING.--We notice by St. Joseph and Council Bluff papers, that preparations have been made to equip and help forward a large emigration this Spring, and already considerable numbers are arriving on the frontier preparatory to the long journey.

The Delta has dates from the City of Mexico to the 19th ult. President LOMDARDINI, the Secretary, (or Secretaries) and Gen. UNAGA, and MARTIN CARRARA, assembled on the 17th, opened the hallot-boxes, and counted the votes for President of the Republic. The result was eighteen for SANTA ANNA, and five for all others.

FROM AUSTRALIA.--We have been favored with the perusal of a private letter from Mr. DAVID DONALDSON, who went from this City to Australia by the ship Magnolia which sailed on the 26th of July, and anchored at Port Philip on the 22d of Nov. The letter contains of course no news, having been anticipated in this respect by intelligence received by way to England.

REV. MR. FINNEY, OF OHIO.--The telegraph reports that this well known gentleman is attending a Spiritualist Convention at Springfield, with Rev. J. M. SPEAK and others, and yesterday in his ad. dress "boldly broached the broadest doctrines of infidelity." Alas, if this is true.-Commercial.

By an arrival at New-Orleans, we are possesed of 15 days' later intelligence from California. The great feature of the news is the total loss of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company's Steamer Tennessee, on the 12th ult. She ran ashore in a fog, near San Francisco, but her 600 passengers and mails wore saved.

General View of the Physical Character and Agricultural History of Eastern Virginia and Region adjoining... Aristocracy and Slavery... NIBLO's GARDEN.--We are glad to announce that the opera of the " Favorita " will be produced positively this evening. Signor SALVI is perfectly restored to health. At the rehearsal yesterday he sang with more vigor and brilliancy than ever.

A Mrs. Sanderson, of Lancaster, Mass., a few days since, while engaged in her domestics duties, had occasion to pour into a a pail or tub, ?? quantity of boiling water, Being called to leave the room immediately after, she left the vessel uncovered.

Admiral Sir THOMAS BLADEN CAPEL, G. C. B., who died lately, at the advanced age of 77 years, was in active service for thirty-one years. He was the youngest son of WILLIAM, fourth Earl of Essex. He entered the Navy March 22,1782.

In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, April 6, of convulsions, DANIEL RusseLL, son of Dr. Daniel and Augusta C. Ayres, aged 3 years and 9 months. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral on Friday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of his father, Montague-place, near Court-st.

GEORGE THOMPSON, M. P., is somewhat notorious for the free expression of opinions concerning slavery in the United States, in the highest degree obnoxious to our people and dangerous to our peace. If he were to be sent by the British Government to Washington, as Minister Plenipotentiary, we hazard very little in the opinion that he would not be received in that capacity.

At. St. Croix, W. I., Feb. 22, STEPHEN BOGARDUS, in the 35th year of his age. His remains have been brought on by steamer Merlin, for internment. His funeral will take place at Aquackacnock Church, on Monday, April 11, at 2 o'clock. His friends and acquaintances are invited without further notice. A Paterson train leaves foot of Cortlandt-st. at 12 3/4 o'clock P. M., and a return train leaves Paterson at 4 P M.

That a City should be properly lighted, is most important to civic safety and convenience. That it should be economically lighted is highly desirable, but is secondary to the first consideration. A prospect of combining both is held out to us in the " Report of the Committee on Lamps and Gas in favor of permitting the New-York Mutual Saving Gaslight Company to lay pipes through the streets and avenues of the City."

The congregation worshipping in the Reformed Dutch Church, Franklin-street (Rev. Dr. HARDENBERGH, pastor,) held their last service in that place on Sunday last. The Hall of the Metropolltan Academy, situated on the Sixth-avenue, near Eighth-street, has been hired for their use until the opening of their new church on Twentythird street.

LECTURE VII.--SLAVERY OF ROMANISM. The Tabernacle was agan crowded last evening, on the occasion of Father GAVAZZI'S Seventh Lecture. The lecturer, as usual met with an enthusiastic reception from the large audience which filled the House. He said the subject of the Lecture would be the " Intolerence of the Papal System of the Court of Rome, and specially its intolerant despotism as seen in the operations of the Inquisition."

In May, 181-, I met with a painful occurrence. I was going down Broadway near the Battery, and observed a man before me leaning against a lamp-post, whose clothes showed that he had been taken out of the gutter. Our eyes met as I approached him, and I saw it was my former classmate in College.

Mr. DICKINSON has declined the Collectorship thrust on him. Judge GREENE C. BRONSON has been nominated and confirmed as Collector of New-York. Mr. DICKINSON and others urged the President to appoint SCHELL.

AN ELOPEMENT.--A young couple, says the Cincinnati Gazette, anxious to assume the responsibilities of conjugal life, left Cleveland on Friday evening, and arrived at Columbus on Saturday morning, where they spent the day. On Sunday morning, they took the morning train for Cincinnati, destined for Aberdeen, the Gretna Green of the State. In the meantime, the papas of both the lovers discovering their absence, had set out in pursuit of the runaways.

We understand that the managers of the coming World's Exhibition confidently expect to have the Crystal Palace ready by the first of June. Everything connected with it is making good progress, though it has involved much more labor than was foreseen at the outset.

WHOLESALE DESTRUCTION OF LETTERS.--On Wednesday last, seven hundred bushels, or about one million, of dead letters were destroyed. in accordance with the usage of the Post-Office Department. They were carted to Monument square, and spread over a line of two or three hundred feet, when the match was applied.

The Poetical Works of Thomas Gray; edited by Prof. HENRY REED. Every craft knows its own difficulties. That which has most seriously perplexed book-makers is the expansion of the writings of GRAY into the dimensions of a decent volume: a problem which for a hundred years has defied ingenuity. BNTLEY tried his hand at it first, in 1753.

By and with the advice and consent of the Senate. MISCELLANEOUS.--William H. Wlech, to be Chief Justice of the United States, for the Territory of Minnesota, in place of Henry Z. Haynerk, removed. An drew G. Chatfield, to be an Associate Justice of the United States for the Territory of Minnesota, in place of David Cooper, whose commission has expired.

The resolution adopted by the United States Senate, on the motion of Mr. BRODHEAD, of Pennsylvania, directing the Treasury Department to report on the indebtedness of the country to Europe on Federal, State, City, Railroad and other public obligations, will probably elicit some very useful statistics.

THE FERRY COMMUTATION.--The excitement respecting the " Ferry Commutation" is on the increase. A public meeting, to remonstrate with the Cqmpany, is to be held at BAUMER'S Hotel, this evening. It will, no doubt, be well attended, as a very active Committee has the affair in hand.

Ex-Senator DICKINSON declines the NewYork Collectorship, and Ex-Judge GREENE C. BRONSON has been nominated and confirmed in his stead. This makes short work of the matter. Judge BRONSON is a far abler man than DICKINSON, and has been a less conspicuous partizan, although he belongs very decidedly to the same section of the Democratic party.

My DEAR SIR: I promised that I would furnish you with an occasional sketch of current literature, and as my promise has had time to cool itself in mid-winter, I take it to be important for my honor and veracity that I should redeem my word. I sometimes fancy that nature or circumstances have a peculiar hostility to promises. They never promise;

A new edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica is in course of publication in Edinburg. The progress of science and discovery renders necessary Frequent new editions of this great work. It was first published in three quarto volumes in 1771; in 1778 appeared a second edition in ten volumes; in 1797 tile third edition swelled to eighteen volumes, to which a supplement of two volumes wits added in 1801.

The Senate met at 2 o'clock, and immediately went into Executive Session, and remained therein more than half an hour. Mr. HOUSTON'S resolution appropriating $1,500 to enable HENRY JOHNSON to crect his loachine in the Chamber, for taking the years and Nays, was reported back for the action of the Senate.

The Evangelist, noticing, a recent Convention held at Charleston, S. C., for promoting the better observance of the Sabbath, says it was "particularly noticeable for the reap"pearance, after years of silence, of the once "celebrated Col. HAYNE., immortally associ"ated with the fame of Mr. WEBSTER'S great "speech in the U. S. Senate, who took a " prominent and decided part in the meeting."

TENNESSEE DEAF AND DUMB ASYLUM.--We have received the fourth biennial report of the Board of Trustees of the Tennessee Institution for the Deaf and Dumb. The location is a pleasant one at Knoxville, and the system of instruction is the same generally adopted in American institutions. Pupils are taught written language as well as the language of signs, and mechanical and other employments. They number 44, the first admission being in 1845.

NIBLO'S GARDEN. --A very excellent attendance last night, Parqutte and Dress-circle filled, Lobbies reserved for the especial accommodation of the crowd--press included. There is no opera of DONIZETTI'S so unpleasantly reminiscent as the "Favorite."

Mr. DICKINSON has declined the New-York Collectorship, and the Hon. GREENE C. BRONSON has been nominated and confirmed in his stead. Hon. SOLON BORLAND, of Arkansas, has been nominated and confirmed as Governor of New-Mexico.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the TIMES of this morning, speaking about " the Street Children," you mournfully, and in a style somewhat poetical, say, " Never have their steps by bells been knolled to Church." I recollect the time, my dear Sir, when the utterance of that SHAKSPEREAN sentiment would have elicited my rapturous applause.

FIRE.--On Thursday night, about 12 o'clock, a fire occurred in a carpenters' shop situated in a vacant lot off Hudson-avenue, near Plymouth-street. The building and contents, consisting of carpenters' tools, were entirely destroyed. Total loss estimates at $400. The building was owned by Dr. FREDERICK MORRIS, and was occupied by a Mr. HENNESSEY. It was supposed to be the work of an incendiary.

The bill authorizing the State Railway Companies to subscribe to the stock of the Plattsburg and Whitehall Railway. The New-York Tax bill was reconsidered and recommitted for amendment. Mr. VANDERBILT introduced a bill providing for means to pay the State debt, and for the support of Government. It imposes a tax of six-tenths of a mill.

For on no less an authority than that of " Our own correspondent," we find it stated that:

MOVING CAUTIOUSLY.--The Boston Post tells a story concerning the doings in a certain town in Vermont, some years ago, during a religious excitement. A large number of hard cases came to the confessional, and pretty hard characters they gave themselves. But confession was not deemed enough, and the restoration of gains wrongfully obtained was proposed.

No wise man ever yet expected to get everything desirable in the way of Reform Half a loaf, however, is so much better than no bread-and the present condition of our City Government is so hopelessly and desperately deplorable-that any change in its present constitution will be heartily welcomed.

NAVAL.--The U. S. Frigate Columbia, Commander PENDERGRAST, bearing the broad pennant of Commodore JOHN THOMAS NEWTON, arrived at this port on Sunday last, twenty-nine days from Norfolk. She came through the Mona passage and along the South side of the Island of St. Domingo. She pursued this safest course, we presume, in consequence of being short-handed, as seafarers observe,-officers, seamen and mariners, numbering in all about three hundred men.

Complaint is made that the balance in the Sub-Treasury at this port is suffered to accumulate. A morning paper says that the importations are likely to continue large, and serious mischief might follow if the balance, already $7,000,000, should go up to eight or nine millions. Mr. GUTHRIE is therefore called upon to deplete.

NIRLO'S GARDEN.--The "Favorita" will be repeated to-night. The success of its first representation will doubtless attract another large and fashionable audience. We anticipate a pleasant evening. There is a laudable desire to be perfect in the rendition of operas displayed by the present management which should not be overlooked.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Captain LOTT, arrived at this port on Saturday, from Liverpool, whence she brings dates to the 26th March; having made the passage in a little better than fourteen days. The 25th being Good Friday was kept as a strict holiday in England. Our market reports from Liverpool, London, and elsewhere are therefore no later than to the evening of Thursday, 24th.

ARREST OF A NOTORIOUS BURGLAR.--On Saturday night last, Officer FROST, of the First District Police, arrested a ?? burglar named CHARLES MILLS BURG. ?? a bench warrant issued from the Court of Sessions. The accused is charged with committing several offences in Brooklyn.

Looking over the newspaper sketches of departed persons of wealth and note in our country, one can hardly fail to notice the characteristics of our better nature that appear in their bequests. Nearly all of them leave large sums to benevolent objects.

We learn by a letter received from a passenger on board the ship Glance, hence for Australia, on the 29th December last, that an attempted mutiny on that vessel was frustrated in the early part of February. As the ship was crossing the line, Capt. TAYLOR gave orders that no liquor should he furnished to the sailors.

Our California Exchanges contain a long letter from Count RAOUSSET-BOULBON, the leader of the Military Expedition in Sonora which excited attention some months ago. The object of the letter is mainly to deny that either he or his band were in that expedition the agents of any foreign power whatever.

The Madrid correspondents of the Lonlon press state that a treaty for the partial emancipation of Cuban slaves has been concurred in by her Catholic majesty. The treaty only affects the class known as emancipados, answering to the Roman freedmen. It is determined that these negroes shall be absolutely discharged at the ehd of a five years' apprenticeship.

THE FERRY GRIEVANCES. -- A large and respectable meeting of the citizens of this village, convened in the large room of Baumoer's Hotel, on Saturday evening to take action in regard to the new regulations of Ferry commutation, H. WALKLEY, Esq., was called to the Chair, and J. M. BOARD was appointed Secretary.

On Sunday, April 10, ENOCH E. CAMP, aged 42 years, 10 months and 10 days. The members of Tammany Society, Darcy Lodge, No. 187, and the Masonic fraternity in general, and the relatives and friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend his funeral from his late residence, No. 639 8th-av., hear 48th-st., on Tuesday, the 12th ??st., at 2 o'clock, P. M.

FIRE AND LOSS OF LIFE.--A fire broke out about 7 o'clock on Saturday night, in a carpenter shop in South Fifth, near First-street, owned and occupied by JOSEPH ELLIOTT, which was entirely destroyed, together with its contents and a stable in the rear. A large three-story wooden dwelling adjoining the shop, owned by DAVID KEESE, and occupied by five or six families, was damaged to the amount of $1,200 or $1,400.

Passion-week may be always safely predicted and described as the most dismal of the entire fifty-two; and the present, as far as it has gone, does not shame those which have preceded. Somehow few stirring events ever happen during Passionweek; even railway smashes, which have been plentiful as blackberries for some time past, have suddenly grown scarce and not more than two or three are recorded in the papers of the week;

The hundred days, allowed under pay of the members, by the Costitlution, for the Legislative Session, expire on Wednesday. The House of Assembly have resolved to adjourn on that day at 4 P.M. The Senate may he held over by request of the Governor on Executive business.

The Telegraph has been giving us, piecemeal, from New-Orleans and Charleston, for several days past, the news from the Pacific Coast brought to Panama and Nicaragua by the San Francisco Steamers of March 16. The corresponding packets on this side, have now arrived at this port, with the mails and gold, and the accounts will be found on another page of this paper.

In the TIMES of Friday last I made certain statements concerning my management of the Courier Enquirer, while that paper was under my direction during Col. WEBB'S absence in 1849 and 1850. Those statements threw upon Col. WEBB very distinctly the charge of having stated what he knew to be untrue in the assertion he has repeatedly made, that during that time I made the paper the organ and advocate of Aholitionism;

Each steamer brings us a thrifty rumor of general European convulsions, together with an obituary notice of the previous reports. The same vessel that notified us of the adjustment of the Austro-Russian involvement, set curiosity agog with stories of a prodigious embassy from St. Petersburgh, bearing the horrid front of war, and paling the Crescent with its terrible portents.
It is now confidently reported that the Cabinet is to break up. The crisis, it is believed, has been reached, MARCY is said to have actually withdrawn, and report makes CUSHING Premier.

Mr. EDITOR: A murder in the country is not an every-day occurrence. When such an onormity transpires, it necessarily, creates a great excitement, filling all minds with horror and alarm. I gave your readers some account of the murder of LOUIS REESE, a Jew, on the Kingston Flats, in open day, at the distance of less than one mile from this borough, on the first of October.

Self-preservation is the first law of Nature, and a contemporaryy print, being naturally interested in the conservation of nuisances, has taken upon itself the task of defending ARCULARIUS. The arguments adduced in support of the Thunderer of Tammany Hall are not of sufficient importance to demand any notice.

CASE OF KATING.--The case of WM. KATING, indicated on the charge of murdering MARY O'BRIEN, one of the two murdered children of TIMOTHY O'BRIEN, in Washington Township, was brought up Fryday morning, in the Bergen County Court of Oyer and Terminer, Judge GREEN presiding. Counsel for the prisoner,

On Monday, April 11, of inflammation on the brain, GEORGE FREDERICK TOWNSEND, infant son of samuel and Jane Eliza Townsend, aged 4 months and 21 days. The funeral will take place from No. 46 East 16th-st., Wednesday next, 15t inst, at 2 o'clock, P.M. a12-21 In Jersey City, Saturday, April 9, EMILY, only months and 4 days.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund have made the following Report in favor of granting permission to the Trustees of the Brick Presbyterian Church (Rev. Dr. SPRING'S) to sell that property. The minimum amount which would be received from its sale is estimated at $250,000, while the addition of a like value in the buildings to be erected upon its eight lots would produce an additional City assessment of $500,000.

THE NEW CLOCK FOR TIIE CITY HALL.--A large number of citizens visited the Exchange yesterday, to inspect the new Clock now on exhibition there, and intended for the turret of the City Hall. This clock is the workmanship of Messrs. SHERRY BYRAM, of Sag Harhor, Long Island. Our readers may be interested in the following description:

WHIG NOMINATIONS RATIFIED.--On Friday evening there was a meeting at Franklin Hall, to ratify the nominations of the Whig party for Charter Officers. GEORGE FORD, Esq., in behalf of the Delegates to the City Convention, reported the nominations made by the Convention-each of which were reported as follows: For Mayor, DAVID S. MANNERS; Assessors, LORENZO JAQUINS, STEPHEN QUAIFE; Collector, PHIINEAS C.

An announcement from the Mint at Philadelphia states that no more three cent pieces will be issued. What a delightful reflection. Any time during the past twelve months we have been afflicted with a plethora of three cent pieces. Individually and collectively there has been complaint of their superabundance.

We find in our English papers an elaborate Report, drawn up by a Board of Delegates from all the principal English Railways, appointed to devise a plan for establishing a mode of communication between the passenger cars of a Railway and the engine.

This is Sunday. It is a charming day. The light broke over the far eastern lakes and prairies of our State this morning, with that beauty and melting tenderness of Spring blushing into Summer. The coast looks beautiful with its green fields, shrubbery, and forest trees, dotted here and there with pretty villas and mansions, while the air is laden with the grateful perfumes of the orange blossom. The Mississippi is very high,

Reader, have you ever suffered martyrdom, on the five bars of a musical staff? No. Give thanks then, and rejoice exceedingly. You have escaped a painful and soul-vexing infliction. The man who has no music in his soul is notoriously a rapscallion ; fit for treason, and Heaven only knows what else beside.

The late Minister of the Marine at St. Petersburg, Prince NEWZIKOFF, atually arrived here last Monday, in a Government steamer, from Russia. The Charged Affaires of Russia went twelve miles up the Bosphorus to meet him on his arrival, in another steamer, and hundreds and thousands, both of Russian subjects in Turkey, and of Chris. tian subjects of the Porte, assembled to see him land.

Nothing in the world requires more prudence, tact and good management than an effort on the part of working men to force Employers to increase their wages. As long as they ask nothing glaringly unjust,-abstain from meddling with the business arrangements of Employers, and confine themselves to strictly proper methods of urging their claims, they will meet with sympathy and good chances of success. But over-doing the thing,

In the past week I have noticed considerable movement among the troops, which I presume is owing to the rule of service, which does not permit any corps to be stationed over one or two years at the same point, in order to avoid those social relations and attachments which might overrule the effect of discipline in case of any civil rupture.

Hon. JAMES BUCHANAN is the American Minister to England He has many qualifications for that honorable and important post. He is a man of decided ability, of large public experience and familiar with the merits of all the great questions likely to demand his action. As Secretary of State under Mr. POLK,

MY DEAR SIR: Has Hippolylus and his Age by BUNSEN; been reprinted in this country I am desirous to get it, as the good Chevalier holds a prominent position among my Library men. His Life of Nicbuhrinterested me, but in that work it is more NIEBUHR than BUNSEN that gives attraction.

The English press has more to say at present about the Old Lady of Leadenhall-street, than upon any other topic. In April, 1854, the charter of the Company will expire. It will be necessary for Parliament to take early action providing for that event; and there has been much excitement among politicians in consequence of a declaration of Lord JHON RUSSELL that Government proposes to renew the charter, without essential modifications.

The Board of Supervisors continued to sit last evening until 5 1/2 P.M., and the Aldermen in consequence were unable to commence at the appointed hour. On calling the roll, eleven members answered. A member proposed that the reading of the minutes be dispensed with, lost before they got through there would not be a quorum.

A Paris letter states that the library of the late Prof. BRUNCK, advertised for sale, contains a mass of curious books. Among them are several which were printed very shortly after the invention of Printing, many copies of first editions, and ELZEVIR editions innumerable.

We were flooded yesterday with rumors of the disruption of the Cabinet. It was announced confidentially that Secretary MARCY had resigned his seat as Secretary of State, to be succeeded by CISHING: and that he was himself to go as Minister to England. We have, however, no confirmation of the report, and do not believe it.

The following from the N. O. Picayune was referred to in our telegraphic dispatch on Monday: BROWNSVILLE, Wednesday, March 30, 1853. GENTLEMEN--Presuming that an account, although a hasty one, of the filibustering operations along the Rio Grande will not be unexceptable, I send you a few lines in relation thereto.

Two MEN KILLED AND TWO WOUNDED.-The boiler of a dredging machine, used at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, exploded yesterday morning at 81/2 o'clock, instantly killing we men-the engineer, named PATRICK MCNALLY, aged 45 years, and JAMES SMITH, fireman, aged 30 years. SMITH leaves a wife and one child. MCNALLY Was a Fingle man.

On the 16th of February I reached this place--forty-one days from New-York, having been detained three days at Panama and five days at San Francisco. From San Francisco to Portland we came on the steamship Columbia, a vessel of about eight hundred tons burden, owned by the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and employed upon this route in carrying the mails and passengers.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--Between 6 and 7 o'clock last evening, a serious accident occurred by the falling of the two story dwelling house, No. 177 Grand-street, which had been raised up some twelve feet, and stood on a temporary underpinning, for the purpose of building a store, by which a boy named -IVES, about 11 years of age, in the employ of Mr. MAARKs, tailor, at No. 104 Grand-street, was instantly killed; Mr. GIRSON, who resided in,

THE SCHOOL QUESTION.--Application was made to the Common Council of Jersey City, by the Roman Catholies, during the past year, for a share of the public school money, to be devoted to the support of a school conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholie, Church, which is now connected with St. Peter's Church, Their petition was not granted, and this question is now the prominent issue of the Charter Election.

REFUGEES IN CANADA.--The asylum of negroes in the neighboring and convenient territory of the Canadas, grows turbulent. From late accounts of a meeting of refugees, held at Sandwich, March 26, under the auspices of HENRY BIBB, J. P. HALLY, and others, it would appear that dissensions of a serious character have taken place.

The Philadelphia Bulletin. speaking of the appointment of Mr. SOULE as Minister to Spain, says it is generally believed that before accepting the mission he " obtained an assurance from the Executive that he should have unlimited powers for the purchats of Cuba."

BUCHANAN was confirmed this morning as Minister to England, notwithstanding some strong opposition from without. An unimportant Postmaster in Maryland and the correction of sundry errors in the names of former appointees, completed the business of the Senate. The Senate then adjourned, at 1 o'clock, sine die. S.

The Dramatic Fund Association of New-York celebrated its Fifth Anniversary by a Festival at the Astor House last evening. The dinner was served at 7 o'clock, in the best style of the veteran hosts of the Astor, in the long room of the establishment, so widely and justly celebrated for the elegance and completeness of its public festivities.

LECTURE VIII.--AURICULAR CONFESSION. By far the largest audience which has hitherto waited upon Father GAVAZZI'S Lectures, filled the Tabernacle last evening to hear the eloquent padre's discourse on Aricular Confession. There could not have been less than three thousand people present. The Reverend Lecturer was received with great enthusiasm, and the utmost feeling was manifested throughout the course of his observations,...

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--A careful performance of the "Favorite" last evening was received by another overflowing house. Excepting Signor SALVI, the vocalists are deserving of little additional commendation to what we have already bestowed on them. Indeed, neither MARINI nor HENEVENTANO were equal to what they were on Friday night; the former being frequently out of tune, and the latter, except in concerted pieces, too gusty.

DEATHS IN BROOKLYN--From the Health Physician's report for the week ending April 9, we lear that there were, during the weeK, 64 deaths; 31 of them were males and 33 females. Of the whole number, 26 were adults and 38 children.

The National Intelligencer publishes a card, signed CHARLES LANMAN, B. PERLEY POORE, and GEORGE J. ABBOTT, announcing the receipt by subscription, of $800, for the purchase and emancipation of "DAPHNE" and child, the wife and daughter of the slave belonging to the late Hon. DANIEL WEBSTER, known as "WILLIAM," and who was emancipated by him before his death.

Irregularities in the administration of the Sub-Treasury Department are rumored from Washington. They are said to have occurred both in New York and Boston, and grew in part, at least, out of the authority of the Treasury to purchase United States Stocks.

The expenditures of the Corporation of Cincinnati, during 1852, were $643,713; receipts., $504,970. Excess of expenditures, $128,743. The City Property is valued at $5,001,200 34; the City Debt is $2,520,000, Mr. H. Richten, of Bremen, the inventor of the process of killing whales by electricity, arrived at New-Bedford last week, from the Northwest Coast, where his apparatus has been successfully tested.

No. 162. Smith, supervisor, , respondent, against Leviness, appellant. Submitted. W. Howard, Jr., Counsel. No. 61. The People, ex rel. Silas Babcock And others, defendan s in error, against the Commiessiners of Highways of the Town of Cherry Valley, plaintiffs in error. Argued James E. Dewey, fur plaintiffs in error; Amos Dean, for defendants in error.

The Tribune yesterday signalized its entry upon tho thirteenth year of its existence by a very considerable enlargement of its dimensions, and by various changes in its typographical appearance. It is now very nearly as large as the London Times, and is much the largest daily newspaper ever published at the price for which it is sold.

SUNDAY SCHOOL UNION ANNIVERSARY.--At a meeting of the Sunday School visitors and Superintendents held a few evenings since, at the residence of Mr. J. M. STEARNS, it was decided that the Sunday School Union Anniversary should take place on the 10th of May next. The celebration is to take place at the First Baptist and First Presbyterian Churches.

CRICKET MATCHES.--Great preparations are making among the cricket clubs. The New-York and the St. George's Cricket Clubs are particularly active. Among the matches spoken of is one between the NewYork and Ncwark clubs, which is to take place at Fox Hill about the 1st of May.

MURDER OF A WIFE.--At Fall River, yesterday morning, as we learn from Kinsley's Express, an Irishwoman named NELLY MURPHY, was found dead in bed with her feet firmly tied. From the appearances about the mouth it is supposed that she was murdered by pouring oil of Vitriol down her throat. There were four or five children in the room at the time.

The Legislature was in session till a late hour last night. The pressure of business at the conclusion of the session, occupies the attention of both Houses pretty thoroughly. The Sectional Canal Enlargement was discussed in the Assembly, both the majority and minority reports being under consideration.

THE STRIKE MOVEMENT.--Men's Boot and Shoemaker's.--This body held a meeting on Monday night at Keen's, corner of; Grand and Elizabeth-sts. The Chair was taken by Mr. GAMBLE, President of the Society, and Mr. O'KEEFE acted as Secretary. The Chairman stated the objects of the meeting. It was desirable to organize a movement of the whole trade in the City. in order to secure a just remuneration for their labor.

NAUTICAL INVESTIGATIONS.--A letter from Licut. MAURY, of the Coast Survey, communicates the results of the cruise of Lieut. BERRYMAN, of the U. S. brig Dolphin, in search for certain dangers which have been reported to exist in the Atlantic Ocean. Among these are the " Eight Stones," said to exist in latitude 34degrees 22' north longitude 16degrees 40' West; and Jean Hammond's Rock, latitude 36degrees 56' North, longitude 19degrees 50' West.

We do not know that the People of NewYork have cause to complain of the change of Constitution in favor of an elective Judiciary. The dignity of the Bench may here and there suffer, but the advantages, on the whole, we incline to place to the credit of the present system.

No. 63, Burrows, receiver, , appellant, against Herrick and wife, respondents. Argued. Henry R. Selden for appellant; N. Hill, Jr., and N. Davis, Jr., for respondents. No. 64, Burrows, receiver, , against Swift and wife, respondents, Argued. Henry R. Selden, for appellant; N. Hill, Jr., and N. Davis, Jr., for respondents.

The letter of our special Southern Correspondent, which we publish this morning, contains observations likely to be interesting and useful to those farmers who may be tempted to emigrate, either from England or New-England, to Virginia. He has a very high opinion of the capabilities of the soil in Virginia, and gives some practical and valuable directions as to the mode of making it most productive.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: With the low prices for tobacco consequent upon the war of 1812, the distress and poverty resulting from the previous universal extravagance and pride, reached its climax.

We learn from the Detroit Times that the Sheriff of Kent County in Canada recently arrested a man accused of having stolen $2,000 from a colored woman in Chatham. On searching him they found $1,800 of the money secreted about his person. He was taken across the river and delivered to Her Majesty's officers, to be sent to Chatham.

WASHINGTON NATIONAL MONUMENT.--We learn that the town of Durham, N. H., has presented a fine block of native granite, bearing the simple inscription, "Durham, New-Hampshire." From the City of Frederic, Md., a beautiful block of marble; and from the Washington Erina Guard, Newark, N. J., a fine block of New-Jersey brown stone, with suitable inscriptions.

INCENDIARY FIRE.--THREE BUILDINGS DESTROYED.-Last night. about 12 o'clock, a fire broke out in a three story frame building in the rear of Little-street, opposite Plymouth. The fire spread from this to the one adjoining, fronting on the street; both of these, together with one other, next building on little-street, were nearly destroyed before the flames could be checked.

ANOTHER MURDER CHARGED UPON SPRING.--The Philadelphia Bulletin says it has now been clearly ascertained that ARTHUR SPRING was the murderer of JosEPH RINK. The umbrella which was found in the store of Mr. RINK after it had been ascertained that he had been stabbed to death, has been recognized by Mr. and Mrs. RAGAN, as the one which had been loaned to SPRING;

AN AMERICAN IN MILAN.--A correspondent of the Newark Advertiser writes from Milan, March 14: There are constant cases of spoliation and robbery by police agents and soldiers, who enter houses at will, on the slightest suspicion, and rob and maltreat the families, under the cry of "imperial orders."

THE FISHERIES.--The Fishery bill introduced in the New-Brunswick Legislature is very stringent: Authorized officers may go on hoard any vessel or boat within any harbor in this Province, or hovering within three marine miles of any coasts or harbors thereof, and stay on board so long as she may remain within such place or distance.

AGRICULTURAL INSTRUCTION IN AMHERST COLLEGE.--Mr. SAMUEL APPLETON has added to his many generous acts, that of giving $500 for the establishment of instruction in Agriculture in Amherst College. We understand, also, that Mr. JONATHAN PHILLIPS has contributed a like sum for the same purpose. The object is a good one.

The Sectional Canal Enlargement projects occupied the House until the hour of evening .recess. On reassembling, the business then before the House was laid aside, and the Supply bill was taken up, by a vote which is not considered a test, on VERPLANK'S constitutional amendment. It is not unlikely that the two Houses will differ, and a Compromise Committee be appointed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: My DEAR SIR: I am in trouble. Exactly thirty years of consciousness and memory have been mine. I am older somewhat than this numerical computation, but I apply the internal measurement. I find, that my friends insist on calling me an old man, and this disturbs me.

Y., in place of Danicl S. Dickinson, who declines the appointment; William S. Bowen, District of Bridgetown, N. J., in place of William E. CORONER'S INQUEST.--The following is the verdict rendered at 11 o'clock last evening, by the jury, relative to the cause of the death of WALTRR TUITE: "The jury find that deceased (Walter Tuite) came to his death in consequence of injuries received by the falling of the house No. 177 Grand-street, on the evening of the 11th of April, inst.

From statements in the London Examiner and other English papers it would appear that the crime of child murder is greatly on the increase in that country. In some cases it seems to be perpetrated in the indulgence ot fiendish malignity, though more generally for the sake of escaping the labor and expense of supporting the children.

A FRENCH CASSIUS.--A singular sort of fantasy has been lately exhibited by a young Frenchman named BELLEMAR, a native of Rouen. He went voluntarily to the Parisian authorities and desired to be placed under arrest. He stated that he had been employed as a clerk in various commercial establishments,-but was at heart devoted to the enfranchisement of his country.

RAILROAD CASUALTIES.--On Tuesday last, as the Express, going east, on the Erie Railroad, approached Port Jcrvis, the engine struck a rock and was dashed to pieces. The engineer and fireman were almost instantly killed, but the passengers escaped unhurt. The stone which caused this accident had but just fallen on the track--a watchman having passed over the spot eight minutes pre. viously, when all was clear.

Alderman PECK is a man of benevolence. He has taken up the cudgels in behalf of an oppressed and well-nigh suffocated class of the community. He declares against all congestions of city railroad cars, and proposes to have a law setting forth distinctly that the adjective full, as applied to that interesting and popular description of vehicles, admits of no comparative or superlative degree!

IMPROVEMENTS CONTEMPLATED.--The primary steps to accomplish the following improvements have been taken: To grade Clinton-street from Hamilton-avenue to Leonard-street; to open Baltie-street from Flatbush road to Grand-avenue; to have Underhill-avenue opened the whole length of the Ninth Ward; to have lots on the south side of Flushing-avenue between Throop and Tompkins-avenues filled.

THE ELECTION.--The Annual Charter Election in Jersey City, came off yesterday. It was quite spirited and perfectly peaceable. Many of the Whigs did not exert themselves or vote, because they considered the victory certain. The Catholic vote was opposed to them on, account of the school question, by which the mass of their votes were secured to the opposite party.

The situation of the London General PostOffice in Lombard-street, having been found inconvenient for the daily increasing business, the precinct of St. Martin's-le-Grand was selected for the site bf a new and more appropriate building. An act of Parliament was passed in 1815, making all necessary provisions for clearing the area formerly occupied by the Church and sanctuary, and the dis. trict became to all intents and purposes a part of the city.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT NEWARK.--A destructive fire broke out between 12 and 1 o'clock to-day, in the buildings of the Rosendale Lime and Cement Co.'s Works, on the Passaic River. The main building, of three stories high, and a long wing, were entirely consumed. The engines saved the numerous adjoining sheds and buildings.

We briefly alluded yesterday morning to an accident which occurred Monday night at No. 177 Grand-street, Williamsburg, occasioned by the falling of a building in process of erection, instantly killing a lad of twelve years of age, by the name of WALTER TUITS, who resided with his mother, a widow lady, in North Seventh-street, and seriously injuring Mr. and Mrs. GIBSON, and two of their children.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.-The "Favorita," will be repeated to night for the last time. There will in all probability be a crowded house. BROADWAY THEATRE.--A new farce, called the "Obstinate Family," translated and adapted from the German of RODERIC BENEDIX, was produced at this theatre last evening. It is the same version as the one now being performed on the London boards.

When I last wrote you, the examination of the testimony in the murder case before our Court, on the part of the prosecution, had just been concluded. On the day following, the testimony for the defence occupied two or three hours, consisting mostly in evidence of character, with scarcely a particle of evidence bearing upon the main circumstances of the case.

MORMON IMMIGRANTS.--From time to time for nearly a month past, the New-Orleans steamers have landed at our port companies of Mormons recently arrived from England, and on their way to join their brethren at Salt Lake. The emigration from Europe is setting fairly in, and we may expect a large accession of these strangers from week to week.

NAVAL MATTER S.--On Friday last, Hon. JoHN P. HALE, the father of the law abolishing flogging in the U. S. Navy, by invitation of Commander NICHOLOAS, visited the U. S. sloop-of-war Germantown. The crew was mustered, and the ex-Scnator made a brief speech to them, complimenting them for the high character which had been paid them by their commander and other officers.

It is a startling fact, not perhaps very generally known, but more credible on mature reflection, that of all those minor crimes which are so terrible in their social effects, because of their supposed insignificance, there is none so prevalent as that of ill treatment of wives by their husbands.
RESULT OF THE ELECTION.--The result of the Charter Election in Jersey City, on Tuesday, was as follows on Mayor and Aldermen: VOTE FOR MAYOR.

Modern eyes are the most significant things n the world. All the senses have given us words that apply to the mind, but terms borrowed from the laws of sight are the most numerous and expressive. Eyes command the world.

A few days before the adjournment of Congress, Lieut. BEALE, Superintendent of Indian Affairs in California, sent in his yearly report to the Department of the Interior. The document has just come to light. Some of its developments are so extraordinary as to deserve a better fate than the common oblivion to which State papers go.

Our correspondent, "IL SEGRETARIO," in his recent sketch of LEGARE alluded to a letter which he wrote while Attorney-General in reply to the inquiries of a young friend concerning the course of study best fitted to qualify him for taking an active, honorable and useful part in Public Life.

Tile large derrick of Messrs. BUTTERFIELD CO. was towed to the Navy Yard yesterday, for the purpose of raising the dredging machine, but up to a late hour last evening it was employed without success. Some of the tackling broke after it had been partially raised, and one or two men were thrown into the water, but immediately rescued. There is no trace of the missing bodies, as yet.

ACCIDENTALLY KILLED.-Tuesday morning all Irishman named PATRICK FLOOD, employed in the Cement Works at North Point, Jelsey City, was caught in the machinery and killed almost instantly. He was 22 years of age. The circumstances were investigated by Justice CUTLER, and found to be entirely accidental.

James Buchanan, of Pennsylvania, to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States of America at the Court of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, in place of Joseph R. Ingersoll, resigned. George S. Walden, to be District Attorney of the Uuited States for the Northern District of Alabama.

WROUGHT IRON CAR WHEELS.--Since the sad accident which resulted in the death of the son of President PIERCE, the managers of the NewEngland Railroads have endeavored, if possible, to remove the constant danger of the breakage of carwheels, and the disasters incident on such breakages.

ACCIDENT TO STEAMER EMPIRE STATE.--This boat left New-York last evening, with about 400 passengers, for Fall River. When off Huntington Light, at 8 1/4 o'clock, one of the flues of the larboard boiler gave out, and blew fire from the furnace. A scene of consternation occurred; but as the steamer Commodore, of the Stenington line, was in sight, the passengers did not fear for their lives.

The Providence Journal says that the attempt to raise money enough, by subscription, to retain Mr. WEBSTER'S Marshfield estate in the possession of his family, is likely to fail, and that the place will necessarily be sold. It infers that the people of Boston are a good deal more apt at making speeches in honor of Mr. WEBSTER'S memory, than in acting in compliance with his expressed desires. The Boston Courier,

The New-Orleans Della of tile 6th, contains details of Mexican City news to the 19th March, previously reported by Telegraph: The President ad interim, LOMBARDINI, and the Secretaries of Foreign Affairs, of Justice, of Agriculture and of War; the Commanders of Divisions.

The predictions of a fortnight since, of the calling of an Extra Session of the Legislature, immediately after the adjournment, have been fulfilled. The pro damation of the Governor was issued in printed letter-form, showing conclusively that it was no sudden movement of the Barnburners, but one of mature deliberation.

The following are the essential provisions of the very important bill regarding the Schools of this City, which has lately passed the Legislature: SECTION I--Says tile Public School Society shall make over all their property by the first of September, 1853, to the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City, to belong to them precisely as do the other School property.

URER SUSPENDED.--A special session of this body was held last evening at the City Hall. The particular business of the meeting, had reference to the refusal of the Treasnrer of the City, to obey the orders of the Common Council in the management of the City Funds. At the meeting on Monday last, the Board adjourned during the consideration of a resolution to suspend the Treasurer.

The April term of the County Court and Court of Sessions, for Westchester County, commenced at the Court-House of this place yesterday, before hon. JOHN W. MILLS, Country Judge, presiding, and Justices LOCK WOOD and MERRITT. JOHN VANCE was placed on trial on an indictment for selling liquor without license and keeping a disorderly house in the Village of Sing Sing.

An interesting point has recently been decided by the Supreme Court of Vermont, conneeted with the Anti-Liquor law. One of the sections of that law authorizes any sheriff, justice of the peace, grand juror, constable, or selectman, to arrest, without warrant, any person found so drunk as to disturb the peace, and to detain him in jail until, in the opinion of such officer, he shall be capable of testifying in a court or justice;

The Junior Exhibition connected with Yale Collge took place to-day. It would take more space than a daily paper would allow, to give a detailed statement of the several orations. The exercises were interesting.

TWO CHILDREN BURNED TO DEATH.--Yesterday afternoon. Coroner HILTON was called to hold an inquest at No. 140 East Sixteenth-Street, on the body of a girl named ELIZABETH FREATH, aged fire years, The poor child was playing in an open dot, it Sixteen--street, on Monday lost, when some of her companions built up a fire, and scattered the burnings embers over the ground.

CONFIRMATION.--At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, Archbishop HUGHES administered the sacrament of confirmation, according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church, to 20 adults and 310 children, in St. Peter's and St. Paul's Churches in Second-street. Before administering the sacrament, the Rev. Gentleman delivered an able appeal to those about to be confirmed.

Let not the office-seekers yet despair. The man of the White House may be slow in giving, but there are gifts enough left yet. Seven full missions, at $9,000, are said yet to remain undisposed of, a berth for one Commissioner at $9,000, and for another at $3,000. one for a Minister resident, at $6,000, fourteen for Charges at $4,500 each, and for Consuls, Postmasters, , enough to stock a colony.

The Sunday Liquor Prohibition is to be enforced in Albany, by the surveillance of the Police. The Register claims that the law was quite generally obeyed last Sunday. The Sons of New-Hampshire in Bangor and vicinity, held a grand Festival at the Bangor House, on Thursday evening.

The following Acts, relating to the affairs of this City, and matters of public interest, have been passed by the Legislature: 1. To extend the time for the collection of taxes of 1852. 2. To authorize the Metropolitan Fire Insurance Company, in the City of New-York, to increase the number of their directors.

We have received several communications concerning the proceedings in the Court of Sessions, upon the recent death of a member of the bar whose practice had been chiefly in that Court. The enlogies of the Presiding Judge, and the adjournment of the Court, and other indications of special respect for the character of the deceased, are sharply censured as tending to mislead the public judgment, and to lower the dignity of our judicial tribunals.

The Southern Commercial Convention held last winter at Baltimore, adjourned to meet at Memphis in June. We have been favored with a copy of the circular of invitation of the Memphis Committee, which briefly refers to the object of meeting and the subjects likely to conic under discussion.

We have already more than once alluded to the concerted and resolute effort, just commenced by the bishops and clergy of the Roman Catholic church, to brcak down the Free School System, which is so general and so pupular in the several States of this Union.

The U. S. Mail steamship Union, Capt. J. D. PHILLIPS, arrived at this port last evening, from Aspinwall and Kingston. Her dates from the later port are to the 6th inst., with corresponding advices from the various West India Islands. The dates from Aspinwall are no later than were received by the Illinois on Saturday.

Governor SEYMOUR has summoned the Legislature to meet in Extra Session to-day, at 10 o'clock. What special business requires this renewed convocation the Governor does not state. We can hardly believe that its object is simply to secure the confirmation of his appointments to office, which has been thwarted during the regular Session by the refusal of the Senate to stay in Executive Session;

The Royal Mail steamship America, Capt. LEITCH, arrived at Halifax at 8 o'clock last evening, having left Liverpool on the 2d inst. She brought 92 passengers for Boston, and a full freight.

We have advices to the 8th inst. from Havana, by the steamer Isabel. The intelligence is of considerable interest. Our public and private correspondence reports a good deal of feeling in con sequence of recent proceedings of the Government.

The Board of Aldermen met Wednesday evening, RICHAD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Second-avenue Reilroad.--A petition was read from the residents of Pearl-street, to have that thoroughfare put in immediate repair, between Chatham and Peck-slip. Its condition at present (having been torn up for the purpose of laying a railroad) was almost impassable, being a great inconvenience, and very detrimental to business.
Those who have studied the Topography of their country with devotion will be aware of the fact that there is, in the immediate vicinity of New-York, a city called Brooklyn.

The Wild Cat lobby at Albany was ultimately routed. The American Exchange Bank could not defeat just legislation. The bill to restrain that and all other Banking concerns in this State from dealing in the vicious Free Currency nominally dating from the Th West, but really originating for shaving purposes in Wall-street, passed both Houses of the Legislature, and has already been enrolled and signed by the Governor.
There has been rumor in circulation that an English Opera is again seriously contemplated. The gentlemen who are (we hear) connected with it are striving assiduously to effect their object.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The "Favorita" was repeated to a crowded house on Wednesday night, and received with much applause. MARINI sang better and more in tune than on the previous occasion of its performance. Madame ALBONI in the last act was perfectly electrical.

TESTIMONIAL.--Hon. DUDLEY S. GREGORY, having determined to change his residence to the City of New-York, has been addressed by Mayor MANNERS, exMayor GILCHRIST, and about 150 other citizens, irrespective of party or creed, inviting him to meet them at a public dinner.

The Extra Session of the Legislature commenced with storms yesterday. Gov. SEYMOUR'S Message refers to the failure to pass a Supply bill, bills paying interest on the Canal debts and the New-York Tax bill as the cause for his convening the Legislature in Extra Session.

We copy, in another column, an article from this week's Freeman's Journal, vehemently assailing the TIMES for what it has said upon the subject of our Free School system, and the relation to it of our Catholic fellow-citizens.

THE LABORER WORTHY OFHIS HIRE--.In a late English case, Mason vs. Parker, a jury awarded justice with praise-worthy promptitude. The defendant was a publisher, and had employed the plaintiff, a clergyman, to translate a celebrated German work on Roman Civilization.

A correspondent calls our attention to an item in the City Comptroller's Report, (page 71) under the head of Expenditures, " Reception of Thomas F. Meager, $2,126 75," and desires to know what it means, inasmuch as Mr. MEAGHER positively declined a public reception, and the only one given him was by the Irish Regiments, at Castle Garden, at their own expense.

VIROINIA SECESSION.--The people of Brooke County, Va., had a meeting on the 5th inst., at Wellsburg. They preambled and resolved to the effect, that the Virginia Legislature, in denying them authority to construct a railroad over their own lands, and by refusing to extend them any protection from the encroachments of the city of Wheeling, give no indications of any relief for them in the future.

The immediate effect of the new Silver Coinage is to direct large amounts of the old coin to the Mints at Philadelphia and NewOrleans. The Government is made the only buyer, by the provisions of the act.

Both branches of the Legislature met at Albany yesterday, in Extra Session, in conformity with the proclamation of the Governor, published in yesterday's TIMES. A great deal of excitement prevailed, and it is evident that the Session will be Marked by great bitterness of political feeling.

By reference to our Special Telegraphic Dispatch from Washington, it will be seen that Dr. E. R. KANE, having just completed his arrangements and received his final instructions from the Navy Department, expects to sail for the Arctic Ocean again, on or before the 1st May, in search of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN, and his company of long lost navigators.

Dr. KANE is here, arid has just received his instructions for his Arctic Expedition from the Navy Department. He expects to sail by the 1st of May. He goes first to the head of Baffin's Bay, and thence to the Polar Sea.

STATE LANDS OF MICIIIOAN.--The Deputy Superintendent of the State Land Office of Michigan, states some interesting facts relative to the sales of the lands during the quarter ending March 23, 1853, as compared with the like period in 1852. A great increase is indicated.

On Thursday, April 14, SUSAN, B., window of the late John Morrison, aged 13 years. The friends of the family, and of her late son-in-law, Dr. A. T. Hunter, are invited to attend her funeral this (Friday) afternoon, at 5 o'clock, from the First Precbyterian Church, corner of 5th-av. and 11th-st., without further invitation.

DEAR SIR: As Union Democrats, we are called upon to choose between the re-union of the Demooratic Party, and the re-organization of the Union Party. Having fully expressed myself favorable to the first proposilion, I will give the reasons which have influenced my own decision, and which I think should control the course of every Union man who intends to identify himself with the National Democratic Party.

We have Galveston news to the 4th inst. JAMESW. SIMMONS, Jr., the Clerk in the Galveston Post Office, who was arrested on suspicion of being concerned in the mail robberies alleged to have been committed in that. office, has been admitted by the United States Commissioner to bail in the sum of $2,500.

IMPORTANT ARREST OF AN-ACCOMPLISHED SWINDLER-HIS ATTEMPT TO KILL A POLICEMAN.-For three days past the Police of this City have been in eager quest of a shrewd individual who, for the past ten years, has traveled extensively in various parts of the world under the assumed names of Col. Polk, Captain Sumner, Col. C. P. Williams, Lieut. Charles Chapman, and latterly as Col. Merrian C. Fillmore.

On Thursday evening, April 14, GEORGE SANDERSON, late of Rottendam, after a prolonged and painful illness of consumption, aged 21 years, 1 month and 10 days. His friends and acquainttaces are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from the house of ?? Y. Van Tuyl, No. 173 Hudson-st., thin (Saturday) afternoon. at 3 1/4 P.M., without further notice. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

Judge BRONSON has accepted the berth of Collector at New-York, and Mr. O'CONDR accepts the post of District Attorney. The troubles are, therefore, ended. The Administration, the "Hards" and "Softs," and all, breathe freer, and the anxious crowds who are dependant upon Custom-House favors will have their opportunity.

It is stated, with many expressions of sorrow, by a South Carolina religious paper, that there is no legal obligation for the marriage ceremony in that State. If a citizen buy a piece of land, he must take a deed; a negro changes hands by a bill of sale; payments of money involve the necessity of receipts and obligations;...

This is no every day occurrence. It is one of the works not to be accomplished by Washington gossip or petty personal jealousies. Cabinets often bend, but seldom break. No sensible President is fond of re-organizing his Council Board. He goes into office not for the love of change, or the glory of arbitrary rule, but to signalize his administration by good works and smooth sailing.

CONSECRATION.--Calvary Church, in North Fifth-street, is to be consecrated this morning at 11 o'clock, by Rev. Bishop WAINWRIGHT. A disgraceful fight occurred on Thursday evening in Seventh-street, near South Fourteenth-street, in which some twenty-five or thirty boys were engaged, and stones were freely used.

THE NEW BOARD OF ALDERMEN.-The Board of Aldermen for the ensuing year will be composed as follows: First Ward-Narine and Betts holding over; and James and Cardner, newly elected-all Whigs. Second Ward-Lyon and Edge, Whigs, holding over; aid Sleter, Whig, and Cleveland Democrat, newly elected.

The steamship America reached her wharf at Boston at noon yesterday, and her malls were dispatched to this City by the afternoon train. They reached the City at midnight. The London Times, of April 2, contains a telegraphic dispatch, dated Paris, April 1, 6 o'clock, P. M. A which states that the American Government had consented to indemnify the owners of French vessels which had been seized in California.

THE AUTHOR OF "THE SKETCH BOOK."--Idly sauntering down Broadway, a few weeks since, we chanced to meet WASHINGTON IRVING rambling as listlessly up that noisy, dusty thoroughfare. His eye undimmed, and his step unfaltering, he seemed to be enjoying the busy, hustling crowd that rushed by him, quite unconscious that a man of genius, whose fame began so many years ago, was that day abroad.

This is no season for Tariff discussions. We have preferred, since the popular decision last November, to let them pass. But it is not so with our neighbors, who represent the Foreign Commercial Interest in this City. The Quarterly Import Tables have evidently disturbed their confidence.

LAUNCH.--The steamer Anglo Celt will be launched from the yard of Mr. ISAAC C. SMITH, at Hoboken, N. J., this day at 1 o'clock, P. M. Her dimensions are, length 170 feet, beam 26 feet, hold 9 feet, measuring 410 tons. She is owned by parties in New-Orleans, and is designed for towing vessels in the harbor of that city.

One small seed has been incidentally dropped by the recent strikes, out of which we hope good may grow. One of our City papers, unable to pay the increased prices demanded by printers, has employed girls in setting its type;-and so far, we understand, with a very fair chance of success.

THE POOR IN CITIEs.--The Earl Of SHAFTSBURY states an instructive fact of those thirty-three thousand women, earning hardly nine cents a day, by fourteen hours' work, in London. His Lordship offered two hundred and fifty odd of them a dollar and a half a week, besides lodging, in the north of England; but his formal offer was not accepted.

MUTINOUS CONDUCT.--Seven men who shipin Baltimore to join the bark Swan, laying in Hampton Roads, were pult on board that vessel on Saturday. The mate allowed them the day and night to themselves, blut on Sunday, ordered them to do certain necessary duty.

GOOD BUTTER AND BAD.--The Boston Journal has tried and found worthless the two modes of making rancid butter sweet, which have for a long time been going the rounds of the papers. Neither working it over with cloride of lime and water, nor subjecting it anew to the action of the churn-dasher with fresh milk, proved of use.

Will discover from our commercial column that the Wild Cat money, against which the press has faithfully warned them, for months past, but which, unfortunately, found its way into circulation through the conduct of one of our Wall-street Banks, acting in concert with the Wild Cat Brokers, is now at a heavy discount, and that shaves varying from two to five per cent. are demanded, since the Legislature applied the knife to the evil.

The State Scnate yesterday resumed the Bill received from the Assembly previous to the close of the regular session, to extend the Basis of Bank Note Circulation to the Stocks of the incorporated cities of this State--If not issued for over 10 per cent. of real taxables--and passed it, with amendments, by a large majority.

The people of Oglethorpe, Ga., have held a public meeting, at which the Mayor presided, to take measures to justify in the eyes of the world, Drs. HEAD and COLZEY, the only physicians of the town who would consent to visit the sufferers from the late malady, which shut off Oglethorpe from communication with its neighbors.

We have no doubt that many suppose that all which editors say upon the benefits of advertising is attributable rather to their own self-interest than to the honest convictions of their minds. Do such persons ever reflect that the conduct of printers--actions, which speak louder than words--completely refute this uncharitable inference!

The Twelfth Ward Shade Tree Society of Boston is vigorously engaged in its most honorable labor. They not only ask aid of the Common Council, but work heartily for themselves. They have leased a lot of land, plowed, fenced; and prepared it for the reception of trees from the forest--a depot where they remain until called: for by purchasers or the orders of the Society.

The Cincinnati people turned out en masse on Saturday night to consult how the was of seamstresses might be advanced. We extract from the report presented to the meeting: It is estimated that there are in Cincinnati about four thousand women who support themselves by sewing.

RUSSIAN PLAN OF STOPPING A RUNAWAY HORSE.--Around the horse's neck, near the neck strap, is placed a running knot. To this slip noose is attached a pair of reins--on gentlemen's horses generally of silk cord, about the size of a pipe-stem--which always lie thrown over the dash-board, ready to be seized at once.

Mrs. MATILDA HITZFIELD, an American lady, has been seized in Germany as a propagator of American democracy. Mrs. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE is undergoing glorification in England, as an oblique assailant and impugner of that same.

LECTURE X--ITALY Father GAVAZZI delivered the concluding Lecture of the Series at Metropolitan Hall last evening. As soon on the doors were opened the Hall commenced to fill rapidly, and by the time the reverend father appeared upon the restrum, the building was densely thronged--numbers do doubt postponing the gratification of hearing the eloquent Italian exile even to the last moment.

SINGULAR ABANDONMENT.-Late on Thursday night, Officer WILLIAMS, of the Third District, found a boy about eight years of age, who, upon being questioned, stated that, about three weeks ago, his father and mother left their home in Hamilton-avenue, since which time he had not heard or seen anything of them. He stated that he had slept in an unoccupied building in Columbia-street.

ARRIVAL OF A WILALER.--On the 12th inst., the ship Splendid, Captain RICHARD SMITH, arrived at Cold Spring from an eighteen months waling voyage in the South Pacific Ocean. The vessel brings home as proceeds of the voyage 2,500 barrels of oil and 60,000 pounds of bone. The Splendid spoke the Monmouth in November last, with 800 barrels of oil.

COMMERCE OF THE ADRIATIC.--The terms of tile recent settlement between Austria and the Ottoman Porte have been but imperfectly, and not very authentically, made public. The most intelligible fact-taking the settlement for granted-is that of the cession of Kleck and Sutorina to Austria. These names the reader will seek in vain on any ordinary map.

The Albany Argus is surprised to find in the published schedule of high crimes and misdcmeanors charged to Canal Commissioner MATHER, an important item which it understands is embodied in the report of the inquisitorial Committee.

Dr. J. V. C. SMITH, of Boston, says that immense crops of poppies are raised in Switzerland, not for the opium but for the oil extracted from their seeds. This oil is beautifully transparent, extensively used in house painting, colorless as water, and when mixed with white lead leaves a beautiful surface that never becomes yellow.

STREET NUISANCES AND NO REMEDIES.--It was the remark of an ex-Mayor of this City, that there were quite enough laws to make a good civic Government if (how much virtue in that if 1) any careful officer would but enforce them. This remark carried profundity in to the heart of the Aldermen when it was read to them at their opening day;

The Repository for April, has a letter from Rev. J. T. BOWEN, who is settled in Yoruba, Central Africa. The country called by this name, Yoruba, begins about forty miles from the sea, and stretches nearly to the Niger. A million of people speak the language of the country.

The Rural New-Yorker has a correspondent who commends red cedar for farm hedges, for the following qualities" It bears pruning well. It is not subject to any disease. Thin poor land is as good for its growth, as belter. Drought does not hurt it nor the coldest weather.

D., Moderator of the last Assembly. On the same day, the New School Assemlibly meets at Buffalo, in the North Presbyterian Church. Sermon by Rev. Dr. ADAMS of this City.

It may he safely affirmed, that the progress of every Science, Art, Business, has been in proportion to the clearness with which its general principles have been seen, and the vigorous hold they have consequently taken on the administrative faculties of our nature. Independent facts are indeed facts, so far as mere truth is concerned, but truth is one thing and power another.

The Right Honorable Lord SKELMERSDALE died on the 3d inst., at Olmskirk. He was 82 years of age. The anniversay of his birthday was celebrated on 7th ult., when he appeared to be in good health and seemed highly pleased with the amusements in which his servants engaged. Since that time his health has gradually deelined.

COAL HEAVERS STRIKE AND PROCESSION.--The workmen employed in the Coal Yards of Brooklyn struck on Friday for an increase of wages. They have hitherto received $1 per day, which, they deem insufficient to support themselves and families.
THE VAGRANCY ACT.--The new Vagrancy act obliges the Police Justice who commits a vagrant to the Alms-House, Workhouse, or Penitentiary, to file a record of such conviction;

Tile Mobile papers narrate a distressing tale of a woman, apparently respectable, who was prevented from committing suicide, by drowning berself, and whose history is as follows: She stated that she is of a respectable family in South Carolina-that she went to Mobile, with her husband, who subsequently died-that she was left penniless, and that she went to work to earn a subsistence, and that site received encouragement from some of our best people.

Hon. GEORE BRIGGS, Of New-York, left here yesterday morning for home; having made a trip to the Capitol for the purpose of facilitating the establishment of the U. S. Assay Office in NewYork, in pursuance of the recent act of Congress making provision therefore.

The London papers received yesterday, by the Pacific steamer, announces the arrival of the long expected steam propeller Great Britain, from Australia, at Liverpool. As she sailed from Melbourne on January 4, her market and emigration news is no later, indeed not quite so late, as heretofore received. Her passage was 86 days.

May it please the Court to grant us no more injunctions. Not that we want Railroads particularly, but we want Roads more. There was Pearl a passable street onceChatham navigable, after its fashion--and Second--avenue a beautiful highway.

The Aldermen were dilatory in assembling on Friday evening. At 5.20 P.M., Alderman STURTEVANT moved to have the roll called, but, by request, withdrew his mo-. tion for a few minutcs when the Sergeant-at-Arms was dispatched to hunt up any members who might be loitering in the halls. A quorum was thus procured, and the hoard proceeded to business.

THE MURDERER SPRING.--INTERVIEW WITH HIS SON.--The Bulletin of Friday evening gives a further account of the particupation of ARTHUR SPRING in the RINK murder, showing circumstances with fasten that deed upon the convicted cluprit.

An Act relating to Incorporated Banks, Banking Associations, and Individual Bankers, located and doing business in the City of New-York. The People of the State of New-York represented in Scnate and Assembly, do cnact as follows: SECTION 1. In addition to the quarterly statements now required by law to be made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department, by Incorporated Banks, Banking Associations and Individual Bankers in this State.

The Church Review, which represents the average of Episcopal sentiment in the United States, has in its April issue an article demonstrating the tendency of tile age toward barbarism. The proofs are found in every fact and phase of our belief. Riots in New-York, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Charlestown declare it.

From the St. Louis Republican. We understand that a project is now on foot to commence as early as practicable. a series of reconnoisances, from in the South Pass across the different ranges of mountains to the Pacific slope of the continent, which, we think, should meet with prompt attention and eacouragercient from our citizens.
