UNSAFE BUILDINGS.--A new brick buildig sit-uated on Fillmore-street, between Fifth and Sixth-streets, is in a very unsafe condition. The side wall fronting towards Sixth-street is bulged out several inches, thus leaving the stone lintels over the second and third story windows without the required support.
A correspondent, among whose up-strokes and down-strokes and pot-hooks the superseription of DIVES is plainly legible, reproves us for what it suits him to call our advocacy of strikes.

The usual City Tax bill, which lately passed the Legislature, empowered the Board of Supervisors to raise $2,414,925 by tax for the following purposes: Aqueduct repairs, $18 000; Asylum for Javenile Delinquents, building, $50,000: Almshouse, $385,000; Battery Enlargement, $52,000; Board of Health, $10,000;

The U. S. Steamship Pacific, Capt. NYE, left Liverpool at 9 A. M., of Wednesday, the 6th, and arrived at this port Sunday afternoon, The Pacific has had very fine weather; has been delayed thirty hours on the passage by taking new kind of coal, which proved to be the worst ever used on board the shin.

SATISFACTORY ARRANGEMENT OF THE COMMUTATION DIFFICULTY.--The adjourned meating of the citizens of Hoboken, to consider the subject of their commutation grivances, was held on Saturday evening, at Baumer's Hotel, pursuant to appointment. The Chairman of the previous meeting, Mr. WALKER, was again appointed. Mr. VAN BOSKERM,

The Banking Basis Extension Bill underwent several important amendments in the Senate on Friday, and as finally passed, authorizes the use of the Stocks of the Cities of this State, already issued, or authorized to be issued; and it restricts Cities in all future issues of Stock, to five per cent.

The steamer Black Warrior, Captain SCHUFELDT, arrived at this port Sunday morning, at 10 o'clock, from Mobile vid Havana. She left the latter port on the 12th instant, and brings files to that date inclusive. With the exception of some Mcxican news, the papers contain nothing of importance.

The diffenities attending the dispatch of the Japan Expedition have hitherto rendered the departure of the squadron as problematical as its results. The lack of seamen is represented as the chief obstacle. The utmost assiduity at the chief Naval depots has failed to enlist in the national service a force equal to the manning of a half-dozen ships.

The Advertisements of the DAILY TIMES have increased so rapidly of late, and have come to engross so large a share of its space, that we have been compelled somewhat to enlarge its size. We have lengthened each of its forty-eight columns about an inch and a half:-so that we have in fact added four columns to its daily dimensions.
An interesting case, involving the action of the Slave Laws of South Carolina, was to come before the United States District Court at Charleston, on the 13th inst.

The German movements in Newark have attracted some attention. From considerable inquiry, the Newark Daily is led to three conclusions, viz.: that the Germans imagined, without reason, that they were subject to greater restrictions than other citizens; 2d.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of the 15th inst., I find an article on "Catholics and Godless Schools,: which you have honored with a brief editorial notice. It emanates from a source which can claim but little respect from many of the "Catholics" of this City--the Freeman's Journal.

Certainly, no man of the age has graduated in such a course of preparatory discipline as he to whom is now entrusted the search for the long lost navigator. He has taken his diploma in the College of Dangers.

NEW MILL.--The two four story new brick buildings, No. 8 and 10 South Seventh-street, near the Peck-slip Ferry, have recently been purchased by the Messrs. SMITHS Co., proprietors of the Genesee Flour Mills at Rochester, New-York, and are being converted into an extensive Steam Flour Mill, to be called " Branch of the Genesee Flour Mills of the City of Williamsburg."

Hope Chapel was crowded last evening to hear Mr. HUNTINGTON, the author of Albans, Lady Alice, , on English Society as painted by THACKERAY. Beside the lecturer, on the platform, were the Bishop of Pittsburg and Archbishop HUGHES. The lecturer apologised for disappoint.

A notice, signed byANDREW JACKSON DAVIS, WILLIAM GREEN, Jr., and WM. P. DONALDSON, "on behalf of a large number of persons," appears in some of the papers, bidding mankind to a Bible Convention at Hartford on the 2d of June next. "Clergymen and Laymen.

One hundred and sixty-four individuals and firms in Boston now pay taxes on an assessment of upwards of $100,000 and less than $200,000; 46 on $200,000 and over; 16 on $300,000 and over; 10 on $400,000; 20 on upwards of half a million; Abbott Lawrence's property is taxed for $1,092,000.

Easter, as far as London is concerned, is the signal of an annual explosion of gaiety ; it is the season when the smoke dried denizens of the Metropolis deem it right to relax a little of their habitual sombreness, and, as old FROISSART says, " amuse themselves sadly after their fashion."

Hon. EDWARD EVERETT is advertised to deliver the lecture before the New-York Historical Society this evening, at Metropolitan Hall. His name will attract such an audience as is seldom gathered in this City.

Let us buy canvass and tent out. Rents rise with every rising sun. They rise, not here alone, but in the West as well--witness the complaints of the Memphis papers, which say that rents were never so absurdly high before. They rise in the East, too.

From the Charleston (S. C.) Mercury. The institution of African slavery is every day becoming more and more isolated; and, by consequence, the section in which it exists, and to which it gives prosperity and peculiar characteristics, is being gradually removed from the pale of sympathy and social intimacy with the rest of the world.

At the residence of her uncle, R. H. Hopkins, Brooklyn, on Saturday, the 16th inst., after a short illness, FRANCES S. HOPKINS, aged 18 years. The remains have been taken to Onondaga County for interment. On Monday, April 18, EMILY M. ROLFE, wife of Jacob Relfe, aged 39 years.

From the London Examiner. In the Philosophical Transactions there is a reference to an Earthquake, which "had the honor" of being reported in the papers of the learned Society. This is an honor which it seems has not been accorded to an Earthquake at Hereford with sufficient promptitude in the London journals, and the consequence of this slight to a highly respectable Earthquake, has been some incredulity as to its very existence.

From the London Examiner. In three letters addressed to the Times, Mr. ANSTED, the Professor of Geology in King's College, states the opinions he has been led to form after a visit to the Slave States which included an inquiry into the condition of the laborers.

LAUNCH AT SAG HARBOR.--A splendid schooner of 211 tons burthen, was launched last Friday. from the ship-yard of Messrs. H. HARRIS CO., at Sag Harbor. She is 90 feet keel, 26 feet 8 inches beam, 8 feet 6 inches hold. She was built for Capt. MARCUS B. BROWN,

THE BERGEN CLASSIS.--At 10 o'clock this morning the annual meeting of the Bergen classics wil commence, in the Reformed Dutch Church, Waynestreet, and continue two days. The public will be admitted to hear the proceedings. In the evening, Rev. A. W. MCCLURE, will preach the opening sermon,--services to commence at 8 1/4 o'clock.

Tile Eighth Ward is not, by any means, one of the poorest districts of the City. Its population, numbering some 36,000, are none of them very wealthy; yet, there are many substantial, well-todo people among them. There has not been as much open vice there as in other quarters.

The extraordinary embassy of Russia is still the main topic of conversation. On account of the insult he received from the Ambassadors' not paying him a visit when he was waiting for it in official costume, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, FUAD EFFENDI, has not only resigned, but insisted that he would not accept the office on any terms.

The Cabinet held long sessions again today. Its action is understood to have had reference to the remaining Foreign appointments. The following appointments in Rhode Island have been made by the President: At Providence, WELCOME B. SAYLES, Postmaster; GIDEON BRADFORD, Collector; SILAS A COMSTOCK, Naval Officer.

The Grand Jury of the U. S. Circuit Court at St. Louis have returned true bills against John Shawney, Joseph V. Dodge, and John H. Holland, who murdered a Delaware Indian and squaw, and plundered their property, last year, on the plains. The indictments are three in number, two of which are for murder, and one for robbery.

SIR JOHN FRANKLIN.--An interesting incident in the life of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN is narrated by a correspondent of the National Intelligencer, writing from Ravenswood, L. I. In the year 1834, it appears a dispute arose between Mr. JASPER CHASSEAUD, U. S. Consul at Beirout, and the Syrian Government, concerning the ill-treatment experienced about that time by Mr. BIRD, an American Missionary then residing in Beirout.

The Senate and General Assembly of the State of New-Jersey have just passed rather a stringent Act, having for its object the deprivation of habitual drunkards of certain social and legal rights, and operating to the same extent as the Act entitled " An Act concerning Idiots and Lunatics."

After all, the Ursulines of Charlestown are not going to get anything for the burnt Convent(as yet) and the failure of 1853 must be added to all the rest of the failures in this business. The parties concerned in the claim must live a little longer in suspense-a disagreeable condition;

In my last I anticipated poor EVANS sentence on Monday. He was brought before the Court on that day, and was remanded until Thursday, when he was sentenced by CUNNIGHAM to suffer the extreme penalty of the law. The sentence was couched in most affecting language, and was pronounced with becoming dignity and solemnity.

This Rock Island region of the Upper Mississippi River country, is one of the most beautiful and inviting portions of Uncle Sam's domains, and the progressive movements of enterprise and business is in some respects almost without a parallel.

There are 484 prisoners in the two Penitentiaries of Pennsylvania. In the Western Institution, the labor of the convicts has covered the cost of their subsistence during the year, and has paid. four-fifths of the salaries of the officers.

BURTON'S THEATORE.--A new piece, in five acts, called "Civilization," was produced at this establishment last evening. It is, we believe, a portion of Mr. J. W. WALLACK'S, Jr., private repertoire, and was produced on the present occasion for his first appearance since his trip to Europe.

On the 2d inst., the following Proclamation was issued from Vera Cruz by General SANTA ANNA: GENERAL ANTONIO LOPEZ DE SANTA ANNA TO HIS COMPATRIOTS. MEXICANS: On placing my foot on the shores of my country, 1 salute them with the liveliest emotion.

A severe gale occurred on Lake Michigan on the 5th. At Chicago, considerable dust was raised, and some damage done to buildings. At Janesville, injury was sustained to buildings, and during the gale the principal hotel at Janesville took fire and was consumed.

LATER FROM VENEZUELA.--The bark Venezuela, Capt. WILSON, arrived at this port on Saturday, from Puerto Cabello, 1st inst. Left no American vessels in port, and the only American vessel at Laguayra was the schooner New Republic, loading for Philadelphia.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: Permit me to correct several errors contained in a paragraph relative to the melancholy and fatal accident which occurred upon the Hudson River Railroad opposite my residence, on the 11th inst., of which an account was published in your issue of the 12th, not wholly correct in some particulars.

A report from Albany was current yesterday that Governor SEYMOUR is about to withhold his approval from the Bill to extend the Basis of Banking to City Stocks. It is certain that it was not returned to the Legislature up to a late hour on Saturday.

The correspondent of the TIMES writing on the subject of the South, , in a recent letter, mentions facts which should lead to the emigration of enterprising farmers from the Empire State to the shores of the Old Dominion. It occurred to me that a letter from this section of country might be of interest to the readers of your widely-circulating journal.

The following correspondence has been handed to us for publication: NEW-YORK April 10, 1853. To the Hon. George Briggs, late Member of Congress from Eighth, Ninth, and Fourteenth Wards: DEAR SIR--The undersigned, members of your late constituency, cannot allow to pass the occasion of your return to private life without tendering to you some expression of their respect and regard.

A Centenarian Negro, familiarly known as "Old JACOD," died near Augusta, Geo., on the 5th inst. He was purchased by Mr. THOS. WALKER, one of the earliest settlers of the county, in 1768, as the bill of sale declares for [Pound]800, being then 20 years of age, making him at the time of his death 105 years old.
The enterprising American correspondent of the London Daily News sent word some months since to that journal, that the International Copyright Treaty with the United States had been concluded ;-

Our Caraccas files extend to the 26th of March. Among other particulars we have the announcement that JOAQUIN HERRERA has been chosen Vice-President of the Republic. The Bishop of Pamplona, exiled from NewGranada, in consequence of a sentence of the Supreme Court of that State, has been allowed to reside in Venezuela, by a decree of the Executive.
DEATHS.--The Health Physician reports the whole number of deaths, for the week ending April 16, to be 55. Of this number, there were 33 males, and 22 females; 20 adults, and 35 children.

We noticed on the levee, last evening, directly in front of the steamer James Robb, two or three huge piles of trunks, chests, boxes, bedding, cooking utensils, , surrounded by a crowd of English emigrants who had arrived from New-Orleans but a few hours previous.

" I reiterate," said Lord ABERDEEN the other day, in reply to a conservative query, "that "the present Government will sustain the "foreign policy consecrated by settled, and indeed immemorial usage." And the iteration excited no remark.

BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.--A regular meeting of this body was held last evening at the City Hall, JOHN RICE, Esq., President of the Board, in the Chair, and twenty members present. After reading of the minutes and presenting petitions, Alderman GRAHAM, of the Seventh Ward, Chairman of the Special Committee on the Armory, moved that the rules be suspended, to afford him an opportunity to present a report of that Committee. Permission was grunted.

Tuesday, April 12, the birth-day of HENRY CLAY, was celebrated by the citizens of Lexington. The Observer gives the following account of the celebration: The day was ushered in by the firing of cannon and the ringing of bells, and at 10 o'clock a procession was formed under the direction of General LESLIE COMBS, as Chief Marshal.

It was known at an early day after the Presidential election, last November, that a pulmonary disease had made such inroads upon the constitution of Mr. KING, that the chances were against his surviving through the term for which he was elected. At Columbus, Ohio, HARRIET NEWEL, wife of I. C. Van Epps, Esq., and daughter of the late Capt. Dobbin, of Waterloo, N. Y. Her remains were taken to Geneva for interment. She has left unquestionable evidence that she still lives. Religious papers please copy.

OVER AND TERMINER--Tuesday--Before Chief-Justice EDWARDS, Aldermen PECK and DOHERTY. The Case of Patrick Fitzgerald, tried Monday.--The Jurors were kept together all night, and, on the reassembling of the Court, yesterday, the Jury were kept in deliberation, without any sign of coming to a conclusion as to a verdict. It was understood, on Monday, that the Jurors stood--ten for a conviction for Murder, and two for a verdict of Manslaughter.

The citizens of Cleveland, Ohio, have, by a majority of more than six hundred, authorized the construction of water-works, at a cost of $4,000,000 or over. A new Temperance paper, the Standard, is about to be started at Woodstock, Vt., under the auspices of the State Temperance Committee.

The fever seems to be working in the community of St. Jago de Cuba, affecting the military and civil departments, and moving the people of that district. The subordinate officials of all branches of the Government have remonstrated against the illegal acts of their Governor with such strength and ability, that it amounts almost to deposition of the obnoxious functionary.

BERGEN CLASSIS.--The Bergen Classis of the Reformed Dutch Church. commenced its Annual Session in the Wayne-street Reformed Dutch Church, Jersey City, (of which Rev. A. W. McCLURE is Pastor,) at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. This body of clergy includes the ministers of that Church in Hudson, and a part of Essex and Bergen Counties,

The Raleigh Register of Saturday announces the death of an eminent citizen of North Carolina-Hon. JAMES IREDELL-who died at Edenton on the 13th inst. The high esteem in which this gentleman was held in his native State is evinced by the various high trusts with which he was honored by it.

A fourth death in the same cell of the City Prison, confirms a suspicion we have elsewhere expressed, that the mortality is due to foul and fatal atmosphere of the place. CHARLES MILLER died there yesterday. A Coroner's verdict decided that his death was the result of congestion of the brain;

The Cleveland Herald gives information of the murder of a man named William Beatson, who stated to persons, while living, that he came from England last February, bought a farm near this city, and sold it for $125 more than he gave for it. He was on his way west; at Cleveland got intoxicated, and was induced, by a man into whose corn pany he fell, to go with him to Alliance.

The Mobile papers of the 12th inst. contain details concerning the landing there of Hon. WILLIAM R. KINO, Vice-President of the United States, on his return from Cuba.

In an editorial in your paper of this morning, in which you discuss the question, "Do we tend to Barbarism?" you refer to the Church Review as having "in its April issue an article demonstrating the tendency of the age toward barbarism."

Says the Philadelphia Bulletin, since our account of the murder of GEORGE W. SOLLY, on Sunday afternoon, was published, the result of the Coroner's inquest has been made known, and additional facts have transpired, which are calculated to induce the belief that the crime was premeditated by O'NEIL.

Passed at the Seventy-sixth Session (1853) of the Legislature of New-York. (COUCLUDED.) 217. An act further to amend the Charter of the City of New-York. 218. For the protection of Emigrant passengers arriving at the City of New-York.

The Pittsburgh Visitor says that last Monday, a passenger in the accommodation train on the Pennsylvania Railroad told the conductor he had no money to pay his passage, but wished him to permit him to come to Pittsburg. This the conductor Refused, when the poor man made no further remark. The cars were stopped, and he expelled.

Mr. EVERETT did not lecture last eveningbefore the Historical Society. Late in the afternoon yesterday, he received a message by telegraph, summoning. him immediately home on account of the dangerous illness of Mrs. EVERETT: and he left for Boston accordingly in the 3 o'clock railroad train.

There has been for the last two years a considerable rebellion in this country, which until lately has been looked upon by the most intelligent, as merely the outbreak of a band of desperate men, who were disposed to pillage rather than work for a living.
ARRIVAL OF SOUTHERN STEAMERS.--The steamship Florida, Capt.WOODHULL, arrived yesterday morning from Savannah, which port she left or Saturday. She brings 38 cabin passengers, and 79 in the steerage.

By invitation of Mr. SAMUEL, BRANNAN, a large assemblage of Californians was had last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel, where they were entertained most sumptuously, and enjoyed a convivial repast worthy to be regarded as a biennial observance of the grand festival of 1851.

The Washington Union makes a very desperate attempt, not to defend the appointment of Mr. SOULE as Minister to Spain, but to malign the TIMES for venturing to pronounce it an unwise and unaccountable procedure.

The Evening Post could not resist the impulse to accompany its announcement that Hon. EDWARD EVERETT was to lecture before the Historical Society, by characteristic remarks upon his political position and character. It announces, among other revelations, that Mr. EVERETT is fixed upon by the Whigs as the competitor of Mr. SEWARD for the Presidency in 1856.

FALLING OF AN EMBANKMENT.--Two men named PATRICK O'FLAHERTY and TERRENCE DONNELLY, both residing in Eleventh-street, New-York, were seriously injured last evening by the falling of a large embankment of earth, under which they were at work excavating for a celler in Division-avenue.

LOLA MONTEZ IN NEW-ORLEANS.--The Crescent gives a sketch of tile performances of LOLA MONTEZ at the Varieties Theatre in New-Orlcans, a few days ago. The fracas has been briefly mentioned. The Crescent says: It appears that LOLA, on the night in question, presuming on the privileges of the buskin craft, as well as on tile blazonry of her distinguisthed title as Countess of LANDSFELDT, had insinuated herself behind the scenes of the theatre.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The "Gazza Ladra" was produced last evening, and received with much applause. Madame ALBONI was in excellent voice, and gave " Di Piacer " in a style truly beautiful. A burst of hearty and genuine applause rewarded the fair cantatrice. What little SANGIOVANNI had to do was executed with care.

I return again to the affair of the arrests that excited so much interest last February. You will remember that some thirty or forty persons were arrested on the first Sunday of that month on suspicion, it was said, of conspiracy against the State and of propagating false news,

Parliament has recommended its labors, and Monday evening saw Lord JOHN RUSSELL hard at work in an endeavor to present the "education question " in a shape likely to be acceptable to the legislature and the public.

Sir FRANCIS B. HEAD, of Canadian celebrity,--he who had blown bubbles at the Brunnen of Nassau, and more latterly, twisted up a faggot of French sticks after his own high Tory fashion,--made a short journey through Ireland, last August, and printed an account of it.

About tuo thousand public Waiters have made arrangements for a general strike this morning at 8 o'clock. Out of all the hotels, restaurants, etc., in the City only half a dozen or so, we believe, have agreed to pay the scale of wages demanded by the waiters. Upon all the others the virtue of a strike is to be tried.

LIARILITIES OF RAILROAD COMPANIES TO EMPLOYEES.--We have already mentioned the decision of the Supreme Court of Ohio, in the case of A. KEARY vs. The Cleveland, Columbus and Cincinnati Railroad Company, that the Company is bound to pay damages to an employee, who has been injured through the carelessness of another employee to whom the party injured is subordinate.

The City of Glasgow arrived at Glasgow 8th inst., from New-York in 12 days 20 hours. M. KENTSHEEFER is named Minister of Finance of Austria, and GEHRUIGER Minister of Trade. The Archbishop of Rouen and Bishop of Versailles have received the appointments of Assistants to the Pontifical Throne.

The steamer P. H. White was seized, about three weeks ago, near Fort Gibson, Ark., by a detachment of the troops there, for violating the "intercourse law between the United States and the Indian tribes." The boat was loaded with whisky, designed for sale to the Indians. The cargo was seized, and the officers arrested and placed in the guard-house at Fort Gibson.

The President will issue the following Proclamation to-morrow: THE PRESIDENT hats with deep sorrow received inforplation that the Vice-Presideut of the United States, WILLIAM R. KING, died on the 18th inst., at his residence in Alabama.

On Wednesday morning, April 20, BENJAMIN BRUNDRED, aged 63 years, I month and 10 days. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at 1 1/2 o'clock, P. M.. from from his late residence, Oldham, near Paterson, N. J., on Thursday, the 21st inst.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The Boston papers have been lately giving publicity to what they term a newly-invented mode of transmitting the mails by atmospheric pressure. The inventor is a Mr. RICHARDSON, of Boston, who has constructed a model of his machine, which is exhibited at the Exchange of that City.

Are there any great causes, charged with all the elements of efficient force, that are now getting into active play to stimulate American Literature ? Are the laws of their prospective operation so clear and satisfactory as to warrant reliance ? These are questions of much moment to thinkers; and as general attention is now turning towards the subject, a fewjournalized thoughts may not be lost.

The extent of the benefit conferred upon the negroes of Cuba by the late Anglo-Spanish treaty, can scarcely be ascertained. The emancipados, its subjects, embrace all those who have-been seized in transit from Africa, by the cruisers of Great Britain and Spain, since the Anti-Slave Trade Treaty of 1817; and, of course, their natural increase is, upon every civil and international law, entitled to its freedom.

The death of Mr. Justice SULLIVAN, in Toronto, is announced. He was born in Ireland, and emigrated at an early age to Toronto, where he commenced the study of law. Engaging in politics, he soon gained eminence, was Mayor of Toronto in 1835, afterward in the Cabinets of Sir F. B. HEAD, Sir GEO. ARTHUR, Lord SUYDENHAM, and Sir CHAS. METCALFE.

THREE CENT RUM.--A colored woman, named MARGARET WILSON, was yesterday sent to the County Penitentiary, as a vagrant, for thirty days. On the previous evening, she entered a porter-house on Grand-street in a state of intoxication, bearing a child about 2 months old in her arms.

We noticed several weeks ago, upon authority which we deemed good, but without using the name of the Railroad Corporation implicated in the transaction, that an ugly looking business had been going on in this market, in English Rails, supposed to have been taken in barter for certain Western bonds negotiated in London, without proper guaranties of regularity or security.

FRELERICK J. BETTS, Esq., of Orange County, has addressed the following " Protest" to the State Comptroller or Auditor: NEWBURG, April, 11, 1853. GENTLEMEN-Permit me to call your attention to the last clause of the 5th section of the 7th Article of the Constitution of the State of New-York, which is in these words: " Every contribution or advance to the Canals,

From the Albany Argus, 20th. The State Canals, under the direction of the Canal Commissioners, are to be opened for navigation to-day. So far as we are able to learn, they are in complete order throughout the entire line. On the Eastern Division, the water was in part let in yesterday; and is no doubt in complete order today. The drain at Utica, we learn, is completed.

FIRE.--About 11 o'clock last night a fire broke out in the lumber yard of J. M. CAUTINE, at the foot of Amity-street, South Brooklyn, and before the progress of the flames could be checked, about $5,000 worth of lumber was destroyed, together with a small stable, two valu-able horses, wagon, harness,

ARTHUR SPRING, the Philadelphia murderer, has attempted to commit suicide. The Bullelin of yesterday says: "From the time of his sentence on Saturday, until yesterday, he refused to eat and drink, and had reduced himself to a very feeble condition by his course of abstinence.

WALL-STREET FERRY.--This new connecting link between New-York and its sister city is wEll nigh completed, and it is expected the Company will be able to run their boats by let of May. The Ferr houses on either side are built on an improved plan--having, in facility of ingress and egress, protection to passengers, and general accommodation, decided advantages over the other Ferries.

A letter, signed by a number of the most respectable citizens, was addressed to Lieut. Murray, commanding U. S. steamer Fulton, and officers of his command, inviting them to partake of a public dinner, in consideration of their kind attentions to Vice President King while on board the Fulton.

A report has been going the rounds of the Press, that it is in contemplation to establish a Literary Institution of a somewhat similar nature to the Dramatic Fund Association, having for its object the relief of indigent authors, editors and other members of the press.

In the vicinity of Springfield, Ill., they have finished the Spring plowing, and it is well advanced in Northern Illinois. The excellent prices of agricultural produce for the past three or four years, have given a great stimulus to agricultural industry.

A letter from a medical gentleman cognizant of the circumstances of the case, published in another column, contends that the four men, whose sudden deaths in the City Prison we have already announced, died solely from causes in no way connected with the condition of the cell in which they were confined, or the treatment to which they were subjected.

There is a bill now pending in the Legislature of Louisiana, which will cause taxpaying people to look sharp. It is intended "to provide a revenue for the support of the Government of the State,"--and it does it in this wise: A poll-tax of $1 is to be levied on every free white male citizen over 21 years of age;

The Royal Mail Steamship Arabia, Captain JUDKINS, arrived at her wharf in Jersey City, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, having sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday, the 9th inst., at 10 1/4 o'clock, A. M. The trip will, no doubt, prove a serious disapointment to the proprietors, as extraordinary efforts had been made to have it a trial of speed.

READING ROOM.--The dedication of this noble structure of which we have heretofore given a detailed description, took place on Tuesday. At an early hour people flocked from all parts of the city to examine the building, and witness the proceedings of the occasion. In the large Hall or Lecture Room, at 8 o'clock, one of the largest and most brilliant assemblages ever gathered together in this city, had assembled.

Another obstacle has been thrown in the way of a final settlement of the affairs of the American Art-Union, by the appointment of a Committee on the part of the State Assembly to investigate its affairs.

We learn from a credible source that three Portuguese Captains and one Catalan merchant, arrived from Cuba by the Cherokee and Black Warrior steamers, and are now in this City making arrangements for despatching vessels to the Coast of Africa to engage in the Slave Trade, between that Coast and Cuba.

Mr. ALEXANDER BAIN, whom many of our readers will recollect as having introduced into this country what is extensively used and known as the Bain Telegraph, has recently failed, and a report of his case, on application for discharge in the Bankruptcy Court, is given in the London Daily News, of the 4th. The amount of his debts is thus stated.

ENGLISH RAILROAD MANAGEMENT.--This subject is attracting general attention in England at present. We have already alluded to the report of a Committee appointed by the several Companies to devise some mode of establishing communication between the passenger cars and the engineer.

Dates from Galveston are received to the 8th instant--four days later. Lieut. WHITING, of the Topographical Engineers, is now making a survey of the Colorado river from Austin to its mouth, but for what purpose is not known.

STORM ON THE MISSISSIPPI.--A letter is published in the Louisville Evening Bulletin, giving an account of a tremendous storm which occurred at Grand Lake, Ark., on the night of the 3d inst. It is dated on board the steamer Belle Key, and says: We were compelled to law yo for several hours.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have been, and am still, unable to conclude the series of papers you were good enough to find place for in the TIMES, in consequence of what I hope may prove a parting visitation from a last year's fever.

An effort was made in 1777 to unite the two States of South Carolina and Georgia, so as to form of them only one State. Two Commissioners were appointed by South Carolina to proceed to Savannah, and lay the proposition before the State Convenition.
A week's sojourn in this hospitable city, at this season of the year, is a real luxury to one who has endured the changeable weather and dusty streets of New-York during a long Winter.

The French Government recently employed M. EUGENE RENDU to investigate the methods of popular education in Germany, with a view to sundry improvements in her own educational system. His report upon the subject has recently been published.

Dr. JOSEPH T. PITNAY, of Auburn, died on the 20th inst. aged 66. He was born in Mendham, Morris County, N. J., on the 18th November, 1786. In June, 1804, he commenced the study of physic and surgery, and in November, 1807, came to New-York, where he attended upon lectures and hospital practice until March, 1808.

PEOPLES' COLLEUE ASOCIATION.--A meeting of this Association was held in Brooklyn, Wednesday, at No. 166 Fulton-street. A Committee of five was appointed, who, by public meetings and otherwise, are to make known to the public the object sought by the Association,--which is, in a word, to establish in this State a Manual Labor College.

The death of Mr. King is not the first instance of a vacancy in the Vice-Presidency. George Clinton and Elbridge Gerry died while-they were Vice-Presidents, in 1812 and 1814. George Clinton, of New-York, the fourth Vice-President of the United States, died in office, April, 1812, in the last year of his second term, William H. It is worth the time and money it costs, to see the Falls under a new aspect. Wen I arrived here three days ago, the somewhat rare phenomena of an ice-bridge below the Cataract was visible. It is not formed by the freezing of the water there, but by the ice from the lake above becoming wedged together and cemented by freezing of the descending spray.

POPERY AND PAGANISM THE SAME. Father GAVAZZI delivered the first Lecture of his Second Series, at Metropolitan Hall last evening. Owing to the inclemency of the weather, the attendance was not very numerous. The reverend lecturer was warmly received upon making his appearance, and said he proposed to demonstrate the similarity which existed between Romanism and Paganism. He would set out with the asser.

Our special Washington correspondent announces that Mr. BORLAND, of Arkansas, has certainly been selected as Minister to Central America. He declines the Governorship of New-Mexico, as too remote from the line of promotion.

Although probably known to quite a number of persons, the details have not yet been spread before the public. If we are correctly informed,

Our papers of late present a terrible calendar of crime. Murder follows fast upon murder, and the City seethes with a brew of vice that is continually boiling over. It is scarcely safe to walk an unfrequented street after nightfall, and if the passenger, through many districts, is so fortunate as to reach his home without molestation,

Nothing wrong can ever be expedient. If Slavery is a malum in se, it ought to be so regarded, and no considerations of utility should be suffered to blind our eyes to its sinfulness. No man is permitted to weigh the advantages or disadvantages of anything until the law of right is acknowledged.

The reduction effected a day or two since, in the Revenue Service, was not as has been charged--a mere ruse to turn out a certain number of Whigs in order to fill their vacancies bye-and-bye with Democrats. Whatever may be Mr. GUTHRIE'S proscriptive tendencies, his action in this case, I cannot doubt, is an honest construction of the law.

The signs of the day point to renewed excitement this Spring and Summer in Railway enterprises. The money interest at home and the news of fresh bond negotions abroad favor speculation; already at fever heat in this State from the profits and prospects of Central Consolidation. The Spring traffic on all the roads in the country is already largely in advance of last season.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A book which, within nine or ten months of its issuing, has realized a sale of one million of copies or upwards, must needs be an extraordinary book. Pointing to its laurels, it may laugh at the pains-taking criticism which seeks to parade before the public a few minor defects of plot, character, incident, or style.

The National Intelligencer publishes an extract of a letter from New-Mexico, which sheds some light upon the reported attempt of Gov. LANE to annex to New-Mexico the Valley of Messilla, a few leagues southwest of Dona Ana. The letter is dated Santa Fe, Feb. 28:

GOV. LANE, of New-Mexico, has attempted to seize a portion of Mexican territory. We announced, the other day, the fact, and the Washington Intelligencer just announces the intention. So that the statement appears to be pretty well authenticated. But what has GOV. LANE to do with Mexican territory? If undeniably Mexican, he certainly is a trespasser, and should be punished accordingly.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--The 2 o'clock train from Philadelphia, on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, met with an accident on Saturday afternoon at Rancocus Creek, twelve miles from Philadelphia. On reaching the Creek, the train found the draw bridge turned, and the engine, tender, baggage-car and crates were precipitated into the water; leaving the second-class car half out of the water, and broken in pieces.

The steamship United States, Capt. BERRY, arrived here to-day, in five and a half days from Aspinwall. She brings but a few straggling passengers. The steamship Uncle Sam left Aspinwall for New-York, on the 18th, with the passengers by the steamship Cortes, which arrived at Panama, in fourteen days from San Francisco.

The following luminous paragraph, is from the Bath, (Eng.) Chronicle: "A friend of ours, whose avocations compel him to travel much in the dark, astonished us, a few nights ago, by exhibiting a capital weapon of attack and defence.

The application of apparently useless materials to some serviceable purpose, is a striking evidence of the utilitarian spirit of these days. The Orientals, however, surpass the Christians, in finding employment for waste affairs. A late number of the (English) Pharmaceutical Journal calls attention to the fact that the Sumatrans have long used the leaves of the Coffee-plant for tea, and late Indian newspapers devote considerable attention to the nature of this beverage.

New-Orleans papers of Monday have been received. They contain Galveston dates to the 15th. The Attorney General of the State had commenced suits against the Commercial and Agricultural Bank and the firm of R. D. G. MILLS, for violation of the banking laws.

We learn from Capt. OTIS, of the ship Harriet, arrived yesterday from Havana, that on his passage out from Savannah to Havana, on the 31st March, when about thirty miles to the westward of the Double Headed Shot Keys, at 7 o'clock, A.M., he discovered a steamer some five or six miles to the leeward, and near a hermaphrodite brig.

From the Washington Union. We have been furnished by the Post-Office Department with the following list of countries, the postage on newspapers to which, when sent from the United States in the British or open mail to Great Britain for transmission, is two cents each, to be prepaid, (instead of four cents, as stated in the postage tables last published,) being the United States postage only.

It might not be impolitic for her Britannic Majesty to look after her Britannic Matesty's steamship Devastation, which is committing something resembling its name in Southern waters. The ship Harriet, Capt. OTIS, we learn from New-Orleans papers, was twice fired at by that cruiser on the 31st of March.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway, A. T. STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reade.-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Water. Architects.

DANGEROUS CURIOSITY.--A Belgian flax spinner and his manager, together with the overseer of a Leeds Manufacturing Company, have recently become involved in quite an unpleasant affair at Leeds, in England, in consequence of seeking information by unworthy methods.

The steamship City of Manchester, Captain LEITCH, sailed to-day for Liverpool, with fifty cabin passengers, $7,000 in specie, and a full freight. The steamship State of Georgia, arrived this morning from Savannah, bringing one hundred and five passengers.

NEW-YORK AND NEW-HAVEN RAILROAD--WINTER ARRANGEMENT--NOV. 1, 1852. TRAINS OUT OF NEW-YORK. Accommodation and Special Trains leave at 7 and 11:36 A. M.; 4 and 5 P.M.; through to New-Haven. At 9:10 A. M., and 6:30 P. M., for Port Chester. The 11:30 A. M. train runs in Connection with train from New-Haven to Hartford and Springfield, and with train over the Canal Road.

Father GAVAZZI delivered the second of his new series of lectures before a somewhat numerous audience on Saturday evening. The reverend lecturer said: The subject of this evening's lecture will be the Jesuits, considered in regard to themselves--to the church, and in-relation to society.

Senator BORLAND had no disposition to govern New Mexico, the Barataria of our Union, and so the President has sent him to the Isthmus. At first sight, no appointment would seem more injudicious. Senator BORLAND is a hasty man; hot-headed; rather overweening in his national pride and prejudices; and not easily induced to abate a tittle of the highest pretension our Government has ever been induced to make.

CLARKSON, WILDERFORCE and PITT advocated the abolition of the slave-trade, upon the supposition that the abolition of slavery would follow as the necessary result. It was the prevalent error of that time. The idea prevailed in the Convention which framed the Constitution of the United States.

The ship Parana, Capt. LANGSTON, arrived at this port on Saturday, in forty-five days from Buenos Ayres. We have received files of the Packet to the 19th February. A great mass of official documents occupies space in this journal, but there is very little of interest in them.
To CORRESPONDENCE.--We cannot undertake, as a general rule, to return rejected manuscripts.

Melancholy confirmation of the loss of the Pacific Mail steamship Independence reaches us, by way of New Orleans, this morning. Previous accounts from California expressed the feeling of anxiety entertained at San Francisco for the safety of this vessel, many days overdue at our last dates.

Important Presentment by the Grand Jury--The Tombs Presented as a Nuisance. COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Saturday, April 23--Before Hon. Recorder TILLOU and Aldermen WARD and BARR.--The Court met on Saturday morning at the Halls of Justice, for the last day of the term, and received the Grand Jury. The foreman; James G. Moffat, Esq., handed in the following PRESENTMENT.

The Sixty-Seventh Anniversary of St. George's Society, of New-York, was celebrated on Saturday evening, by a sumptuous banquet at the Astor-House. At the head of the large dining hall was a full length portrait of Queen VICTORIA, copied from VANDERHOFFER'S celebrated painting.
On Thursday, 21st inst., by Rev. Dr. Knox, at the Reformed Dutch Church in Lafayette-place, HENRY R. BARKER to MARY E. CHAMBERLAIN, both of this City.
Cleared. Steamships--Roanoke, Cavendy. Norfolk and Richmond, Ludlam Plessants; James Adger, Dickinson, Charleston, Spofford. Tileston Co.; Florida, Woodhull, Savannah, S. L. Mitchell.

Major ITERBIDE, the son of the Emperor, has arrived in this City from the City of Mexico, as bearer of dispatches to the Mexican Minister, and bringing from our Minister, Judge CONKLING, to the State Department, a copy of the Treaty negotiated by him with Commissioners TORNELL and LONSAS, guaranteeing and protecting the SLOOgrant for the Tehuantepec Railroad.

The evidence at Boston in the case of John Nelson's. Alexander Richardson, master, and John Patten, mate, of brig Ellis, shows a degree of brutality hardly to be believed. The plaintiff was engaged by Richardson at Rochelle; Nelson told him that he was no seaman, but only a cook and steward. The captain, however, concluded to ship him as a seaman.

The Feeling towards Santa Anna--The Revolution. By way of New-Orleans, we have dates from the City of Mexico to the 2d inst. The news of SANTA ANNA'S landing on the shores of Mexico was received in the Capital with salvos of artillery and a general ringing of the bells. Yesterday evening, (says the Trait d'Union of the 2d,) the roaring of artillery and musketry announced the advent of some great occasion.
We published a few days since from the London Examiner, a statement of the substance of a series of Letters by Prof. ANSTED, the distinguished English geologist, upon American Slavery.

It has come at last. The sky is very red in the East,--no stars are to be seen from the win dows, but whetherit is because it is too light for them to show, or whether there are clouds to obstruct their appearance, the little folks cannot agree.

ROBBERY ON SHIP-B0ARD.--On Saturday, Officer CURLEY, of the Sixth Ward, arrested for men named PATRICK DOUGHERTY, THOMAS MURPHY, DAVID ROSTER, and JOHN RYAN, charged with stealing a carpet bag from on board the packet-ship Rialto, from Liverpool, containing four ten pound Bank of England notes, valued at $200; also some shirts, and a portable writing-desk, valued at $7-in all $207, the property of THOMAS CULEY.
MORTALITY.--The return of deaths by the Health officer for the week ending April 23, gives the total number as 55-29 maldes and 20 females; of these, 24 were adults and 31 children.
Col. PICKETT testified he had known GEO. A.GARDINER four years; had seen him write; the signature on the mining papers resembled his; was better acquainted with the writing of J. CARLOS GARDNER.

The steamship Star of the IVest, Capt. TNKI. rAuGl!, arrived at this port at 83 o'clock last even ing, from San Juan de Nicaragua, whence she brings dates to the 17th inst. By this arrival, we receive our files of California papers to the 1st of April, in the remarkable shortspace of twenty.five days.

New-York is leaping forward in the race for wealth and greatness, more rapidly than at any other period of her history. She intimately sympathizes with the general prosperity ofthe country, and advances with it.

The nondescript Herald is out upon the coming "season" at Newport, because the Maine Law will curtail the use of liquor, and the aristocratic Post is against Saratoga because not so exclusive as that beautifil Summer resort used to be to "people of position and fortune" or "quality."
Some transcendent genius has been enlightening the British public, through the pages of the Dublin University Magazine, upon the character, condition and prospects of the United States.

FATHER GAVAZZI AND THE TEMPERANCE CAUSE. --Padre GAVAZZI is a famous man. The Roman Catholics, it is true; are acquainted with orators more to their liking; nevertheless they are ready to allow that the worthy Padre is famous.

It having been decided to restrict the employment of the officers of the revenue marine to the number and grades allowed by law, to the vessels now in commission and in the course of construction, the following changes have taken place in that branch of the public service.

WM. H. GARRETT, of Alabama, has been appointed Creek Agent, Ex-Senator CLEMENS had recommended another person, an intimate personal friend, but the JEFFERSON DAVIS influence in this, as in nearly every other point he has pressed, has overruled him.

MY DEAR SIR: 1 am debtor to Chloroform for some of the happiest moments of my life. Once' only have I taken it, but "once" con tains:mtnore meaning than minutes, and in rela tion to experience is far more significant thanin relation: to time.
By the late arrivals from Europe;' we learn that there is a great deal of tallk of what the Government ought to do, on the approaching termination of the East India Complnlany'scharter.
Miss LUCY STONE declaimed last evening upon the wrongs and rights of Woman. Miss STONE is an agreeable orator, with an agreeable manner, an agreeable person, and a disagreeable subject.

The arrival of the San Juan steamer last evening, places us in possession of the California advices of the 1st inst., and the full details of tile loss of the steamship Independence. A large portion of our space is devoted to the narrative of the terrible calamity.

FIVE CASES OF COWARDLY ROWDYISM.--MICHAEL and CONRAD MAHNING were arrosted by officer HAINES, of the Third Ward, on Sunday night, charged with assaulting a man named JOHN GARLING, on the corner of Montrose-avenue and Leonard-street.

The steamer Star of the West, belonging to VANDERBILT's line, arrived from San Juan last night, bringing intelligence from San Francisco to the Ist of April. The general summary of her intelligence will be found on the first page of this morning's TIMES.

The U. S. Mail steamer Isabel, Capt. ROLLINS, arrived at this port this morning with later advices from Havana and Key West. From Havana there is no news of importance. The brig Moncure, bound from Cubn for New York, was at Key West in a leaky condition, discharging cargo.

My DEAR SIR: Our papers and public men, are getting earnestly engaged in the discussion of legal interference, to prevent the sale of all intoxicating liquors. A Convention was held last Fall in Selma, Ala., to take this subject into consideration.

The Ohio and Lake Shore Roads and Lake line of Steamers between Sandusky and Cleveland, and Buffalo and Dunkirk, have settled their through fares from Cincinnati at the uniform rate of $7 50. The Consolidated Central line from Albany to Buffalo announces $6 as the through fare between those cities.

An ordinance has been reported to the City Council of Boston, to establish the office of a superintendent of the Internal Health Department, who shall have the care and superintendence of the city carts and stables, and shall make all necessary arrangements for cleaning the streets, disposing of manure, and removing house dirt and house offal.

A commission de lunatico inquirendo was lately held on the case of Mr. FEARGUS O'CONNOR, the celebrated Chartist leader, whose visit to this country a few months since excited so much attention. He was declared insane almost immediately after his return, and has ever since been in the Lunatic Asylum, under the care of Dr. TUKE, at Turnham-Green.

In the New-York Herald of the 1st inst., I notice a communication signed "H," professing to give a true and accurate account of the late disturbance at this port. The object of that letter, it is easy to perceive, was to place the Commander of the Cyane before the public in a false position.
NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"Lucrezia Borgia" attracted another large audience on Monday night. Mad. ROSE DE VRIES was in better voice and conserved much of her power for the last act.

The day was occupied in a cross-examination of JOHN CHARLES GARDINER, by Mr. MAY. A letter in Spanish, signed "J. Charles Gardiner," and addressed to the Alcalde of Rio Verde, being shown, he said the signature resembled his, but thought the body of the letter was not in his hand.

THE GREATEST DISCOVERY OF THE AGE.--No remedy can be purchased equal to Dr. TOBIAS' Venetian Liniment, for the cure of dysentery, colic, sea-sickness, croup, chronic rheumatism, toothache, sore throat, coughs, cuts, burns, old sores, pains in the limbs, chest, hack,
CALL ACCEPTED.--Rev. JAMES DERMAREST has received and accepted a call to the Dutch Reformed Church of Manhasset.

We have dates from Galveston to the 15th inst. The Mayor of Galveston has authorized a vote of the citizens to be taken respecting the propriety of allowing a railroad to pass through the suburbs of that city.

The ownership of this ill-fated vessel is not exactly fixed. The responsibility of her employment on the Pacific belongs to the owners of the VANDBIBILT line, although it is alleged, in extenuation that her charter had expired, and this was to have been "her last trip" in the service of the Nicaragua Company.

Accounts of importance had been received from Constantinople to the 25th March. At that date Prince MENSCHIKOFF had not made any official communication to the Divan, and the intentions of Russia continued to be involved in complete mystery.
COMMISSIONER OF PILOTAGE.--Captain JAMES ROGERS has been appointed by Governor FOOT, as a Commissioner of Pilotage, in the place of the late JOHN F. ELLIS, whose death occured a short time since.

WILLIAM HOWITT, the celebrated English author, in a letter published in the London Times, gives the following graphic, though not very encouraging picture of his experience and observation in Australia:

WILLIAM HOWITT, the author of that pleasant book "Homes and Haunts of English Poets," and perhaps more widely known as the husband of MARY HOWITT, went to Australia soon after the first discovery of gold in that country.

In the Common Council on Monday evening, a resolution was adopted granting to the Flushing Railroad Company the privilege of constructing their railroad from the Bushwick line to the Brooklyn line, through First and Second-streets.

An ordination of Nature insists that the ornamental rather than the useful shall run to seed. Thus we find that beds of immovable granite are flourishing in perfection, while beds of ornamental poppies get seedy and dilapidated.
The U. S. Mail steamship Humboldt, Capt. J. D. LINES, arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning.

The Superintendent of Common Schools in this State complains that the sum of $4,100 due from Rensselaer County towards its share of the School tax is withheld, by the Collector of the County, although he has collected it,--on account of some dispute concerning the valuation of property between the City of Troy and the country towns.

The Austrian Government has published a further ordinance relative to the future administration of Hungary. For the purposes of Government the kingdom is to be divided into three districts, with Deputy Governors, subject to the Governor-in-Chief at Pesth.

At the Mark Lane Corn Market on the 11th inst. English WHEAT declined 1s. ? quarter. Foreign WHEAT was from 1s. to 2s. ? quarter lower. The demand for all descriptions of grain was of a strictly retail character, and the market was heavy.

In the House of Commons, on the 11th inst., the third reading of the Canadian Clergy Reserves Bill was carried by a majority of 80 in favor of the Ministry. In the House of Lords, on that day, nothing of importance was transacted.

Our European advices indicate a much calmer feeling respecting the Turkish question. It is by no means founded on a sound conviction that the crisis is past. The attitude of the Russian envoy at the Porte is as menacing as ever.

Judge NELSON pronounced a very important decision yesterday, in the case of KANE, which has occupied the attention of our Courts for some months past. The decision will be found at length in another part of this morning's TIMEs.

A telegraphic dispatch from Trieste, dated April 10, anticipates the overland Calcutta mail to 5th March, due in London on 16th April. There was no further intelligence from Burmah. Trade in Calcutta was dull and the weather hot. Two of the Sudder judges have been dismissed by Lord FALKLAND.
The new patent arrangement, put in force by the President to-day, for receiving office-seekers in open session, has done the work of a week. The scene is described as a very amusing one.

On the 26th of May, 1852, the British schooner Clyde, Capt. BETHEL, arrived at Charleston, S. C., from some Cuban port. On board was one REUBRN ROBERTS, a colored man and a cook; a stranger whose presence was no sooner made known to the Sheriff of Charleston District, than REUBEN was waited upon by that distinguished functionary, and tendered, in the name of the Commonwealth, the hospitality of the city.

SECOND UNITARIAN CHURCH.--Rev. SAMUEL LONGFELLOW, (brother of H. W. LONGFELLOW, the poet,) entered upon his ministry on Sunday morning last. His church is situated at the corner of Clinton and Atlantic-streets. The Book of Hymns in use by this church was compiled by the new pastor, assisted by Rev. SAMUEL JOHNSON of Salem, Mass.

Mr. LEVI H. GALE, an old and highly respected citizen of New-Orleans, died in that city on the 19th inst., aged 63. He was a native of Maryland, but was resident in New-Orleans for thirty years. His remains will be conveyed to Newport, R. I.

La Gazza Ladra, BROADWAY THEATRE.--Othello--Little Toddlekins. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Young Quaker--The Review. BURTON'S THEATRE.-Civilization--Poor Pilticoddy.

WHAT IS THE INDIVIDUAL IN THE ROMAN CHURCH ? Pursuant to notice, Father GAVAZZI delivered his first free lecture at the Tabernacle last evening, The lecture, which was especially intended for the Irish Ro man Catholics of New-York, (though there were not many present,) attracted an exceedingly large audience. The reverend Padre was received with much applause.

From She London Times. The question of the POPE's intended journey to Paris for the purpose of placing an Imperial crown on the head of LOUIS NAPOLEON has been agitated with great interest in the palaces of the Tuileries and of the Vatican, for a ceremony which is of no very serious account when it is meant to recognise a right becomes momentous when it is to consecrate an usurpation. A manifesto of a singular description has just been issued by the philosopher of Lanark, addressed "to all Governments and peoples," having for its purpose to announce "a great moral revolution which is about to be effected for the human race, by an apparent miracle."
The steamship Falcon has arrived here from Aspinwall, bringing the California mails, 75 passengers and $100,000 in gold Dust.
A meeting of Liverpool shipowners, interested in the coasting trade, was held the other day, Mr. CHARLES MACIVER, of the Cunard Co., in thechair, in support of the new pilotage bill.

We have at last something more tangible respecting the doings of Gov. LANE. There is a letter from an intelligent citizen of Paso del Norte; and in it the Governor's proclamation; and the story between the two is told so explicitly, that there need be no further difficulty about the slightest particulars.

LAST MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.-- Last evening the present Board of Aldermen of Jersey City met at the Lyceum, for the last time, to transact business. President HARRISON occupied the Chair. A number of bills were passed, and papers returned, to be delivered up to the next Board.

UNITED STATES CIRCUIT CUURT--AT CHAMBERS.--Judge NELSON said: This case should have been disposed of at an earlier day; but having heard it in the midst of a circuit, the constant pressure of business upon the Jury calendar has compelled me to postpone the consideration of it.

STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Water.
The steamship Isabel has arrived from Havana and Key West, 22d inst. She brings no news of importance. The Captain-General was still on his tour.

The New-Orlease Picayune of the 20th, contains full details of the recent attempt of Governor LANE, of New-Mexico, to annex the Mecilla Valley to that Territory. This account also gives the proclamation issued by the Governor, entire.

The Express train which left here at 9 o'clock last night, on the Michigan Southern Railroad, came in collision at the crossing of the Central Road, with the Emigrant up train, and the most disastrous consequences ensued.

ARREST OF THE ROWDIES.--MICHAEL McEVOY, charged with riot and disorderly conduct on Saturday evening and Sunday morning, was yesterday arrested on a warrant, by officer VANDERWATER. The investigation of JOHN LAKE, JOHN LOLLES, PATRICK BURKE and JEREMIAH BROWN, arrested in a porter-house in Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, on a similar charge, on Monday, was commenced yesterday morning by Justice BOSWELL, and occupied a great portion of the day.
The bark Peacock, from Montevideo March 14, with 11,869 dry and 1,362 salted hides, arrived at Salem this morning.
On Tuesday, 26th instant, by Rev. Dr. Campbell, HENRY F. CRISTY to RACHEL ANN WALLACE, both of this City
Two hundred and fifty thousand dollars worth of the New Silver Coin, in quarters, dimes and half dimes, was issued from the Mint to-day.

The intelligence from France is entirely devoid of interest. The Moniteur publishes a circular from the Minister of Police on the subject of glee clubs and harmonic unions. Coffee-houses are not to be opened for that purpose without an express license from the Prefecture, and such licenses, when granted, may, at all times, be suspended.

The new number of the Quarterly has an interesting summary of what has been done, and of what is known, concerning the search for Sir JOHN FRANKLIN. Very little of it, of course, has the merit of novelty, though there are one or two points on which very little stress has been laid hitherto.

COMMON COUNCIL.-A regular meeting of this body was held Monday night, JOHN RICE, Esq, President in the Chair. After the presentation of a number of Detitions, Alderman HAWXHURST moved that the regular order of business be suspended to allow the Special Committee appointed with power to settle the difficulties existing between the Treasurer and Common Council opportunity to report.

On Monday evening, Mr. McGEE, the Editor of the Buffalo Celt, delivered a lecture in the Tabernacle upon "The Social Duties of Irishmen in America." The attendance was very large, and among the audience were several Roman Catholic Clergymen.

FOR LIBRRIA.--The ship Banshee sailed from Baltimore for Liberia on Monday, conveying 117 emigrants. This vessel was chartered by the Chesapeake and Liberia Trading Company for the voyage out, and will be discharged at Cape Palmas.

Our Legislature has been latterly busy with money matters, increasing the capital of a great number of the State Banks, and also passing a law by which every Bank shall keep 10 per cent. of its stock in hard cash. There were last year 137 Banks in the State, with a capital of $43,270,500, of which 8 1/4 per cent was in specie.

Dates from Brownsville to the 13th inst., reach us through New-Orleans. The following particulars are given of the arrest of CARVAJAL: Capt. SMITH, 7th U. S. Infantry, temporarily in command of Company B, U. S. Mounted Rifles, arrived at Brownsville on the 11th having in charge General CARVAJAL, Quartermaster DOWD, and Lieut. ROUNDTREE, of the Liberating Army.

I desire, through the medium of the TIMES, to offer my thanks to Mr. SMITH, the Keeper of the Eldridge-street Jail, and his exemplary lady, for their kind attention to me during a serious term of sickness, which nothing but Mrs. SMITH'S kind nursing, and the medical treatment of their family physician, (Dr. WITHERELL,) prevented from proving fatal.

By way of New-Orleans, we have some additional items from Texas, though the dates are no later. The San Antonio Ledger, of the 7th says: About 375 recruits--250 of infantry, and 125 dragoons--for the United States Army, under the charge of Lieut. GARASCHE, arrived and encamped at the Salado, on Monday morning last.

The Union of yesterday contains a statement of the award of Mail Contracts by the Post-Office Department, on Tuesday: "It being understood that the decisions of the Postmaster-General on the great mail lettings would be publicly declared, a large number of contractors who had remained here, as well as the representatives of those who had left, assembled for the purpose of ascertaining the result of his deliberations.

I suppose that a man has no right to congratulate and plume himself on the accident of having been born in any one particular country, Indeed, assuming an uncomfortably philosophical altitude in looking at the question, this same Nationality is a very local, parochial sort of feeling, the indulgence of which is perfectly irrational.

An election of a United States Senator, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Hon. PIERRE SOULE, is now the most important and exciting feature in our locality. Louisiana, at this time, presents to the country one of the most singular and extraordinary political anomalies that a combination of circumstances ever produced.

The Treaty guaranteeing the neutrality and protection of A.G. SLOO'S Tehuantepec Railroad grant has been placed in the hands of Secretary MARCY; but, as it cannot be sent to the Senate until next Winter, it is undoubtedly filed at presen for consideration after the disposition of more pressing business.

Lucrezia Burgia. BROADWAY THEATRE--Lady of Lyons--Little Toddlekins. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Lady of Lyons--His last Legs. ST. CHARLES THEATRE.--Military Execution-Eveleen Wilson--Rough Diamond.

The Board of Aldermen last night decreed the extension of the Russ pavement from the Park to Union-place, through Chatham-street and the Bowery. The work is to be commenced forthwith. The rate to be the same as that now paid for the work on Broadway; and the contractor, in addition, is entitled to the cobble stones.

A verdict was given on Saturday at Lowell, against Dr. Joseph Kittredge, of Andover, for mal practice, in the treatment of a lad named Ashworth, the damages awarded being $1,675. The lad had his arm injured by machinery in the mill where he worked, and the wound was dressed by Dr. K., who failed to make any further examination of the wound until four days after, when it was found that mortification had commenced.

We have been waiting some time for action on behalf of the sewing women. A strike among seamstresses can hardly be spared from the multitude of similar movements marking the day. Their prices are sadly low. The labor is exhausting, careful, health-destroying.

We are always glad to chronicle instances of successful enterprise in the newspaper press, and especially any advancement made by our neighbors in this respect. Yesterday's Herald contains the able and conclusive letter of Mr. EVERETT to our Minister in England, on the Fisheries, replying to the attacks of Lord MALMESBURY, and vindicating Mr. WEBSTER'S conduct from the imputations in which the English Secretary had seen fit to indulge.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: In an article headed "Pictorial Papers," which appeared in your colums yesterday, a glaring, but I am sure inadvertent wrong has been done, which I fully rely upon your justice to rectify.

We have already published a table issued from the Post-Office Department, giving a list of foreign countries, to which the postage on newspapers when sent from the United States in the British or open mail to Great Britain for transmission, is two cents instead of four, as heretofore charged.

PARADE.--The Williamsburg "Fancy Troop' proceeded on their Target Excursion to JOHN I. SNEDIXER's, yesterday morning. The dresses were of every imaginary description, and presented a fine appearance. This troop vary somewhat in their manner of firing at the target from most ether companies.

COUSINS OF TEMPERANCE.--This Society held an anniversary in the basement of the Wayne-street Reformed Dutch Church, on Monday evening. The exercises were interesting. Addresses were delivered by Rev. Mr. HOOVER and VAN CLEEF, and by some of the lads. There was singing, also. Twenty-eight children. joined "The Cousins." This Society was organized by six Cousins in 1850, and now has seventy members.

The Exodus of a nation is one of the most mournful events that can chequer History. The rending of the sacred ties of patriotic and historical attachment to the Father Land on so broad a scale is unusual and naturally a solemn sacrifice; the more so because an in expressible conviction springs up within us that some terrible internal disease must have induced so desperate a remedy.

WATER FOR BROOKLYN.--In the Brooklyn Common Council, on Monday evening, Alderman MARVIN. at Chairman of the Water Committee, made a report stating the position in the Legislature of the Brooklyn Water Bill, and also of the Williamsburg Water Work bill, expressing an opinion that without great exertion being made; the bill of the latter would pass the Senate at the Extra Session.
We have no mail south of Mobile this morning. A presentation of a suit of flags to the steamship Augusta, of New-York, took place at Savannah, on Monday.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--" La Gazza Ladra" was repeated last night in an entirely delightful way. Mad. ALBONI was in excellent voice; a little subdued at first, but animate and delicious in the final acts. Signor BENEVENTANO sang with much care, and merited more applause than he received, although his reseption was quite warm.

On Monday, 25th instant, SARAH, widow of Isaac Van Vleeck, formerly of Kinderhook, aged 60 years The relatives and friends of the family, and those of her son in-law, Spencer Kirby, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 21 9th-st., this day, (Thursday) at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M., without further invitation.

COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER.--Before Chief Justice EDWARDS, Aldermen PECK and DOHERTY. Yesterday being day appointed for the Court to pass the sentence on these miserable men. there was a considerable attendance of members of the Bar, and other citizens, at an early hour. Several ladies were also in the room, but it appeared that they were witnesses in a cause expected on before the Judge sitting, at nisi prius.

In the House of Representatives yesterday, several additional Bank bills were passed, and a bill was reported to allow the Merchants' Bank to increase its capital $2,000,000 under the General Banking law. The ten hour bill passed to a third reading by 40 majority, and the Hoosac Tunnel bill by 29 majority.

The steamships Georgia and Uncle Sam arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall. The Georgia brings the California mails and specie of the 1st inst. The dates from California are no later than we have already received.

We observe an announcement of new arrangements on the New-Jersey Railroads, in Which passengers are promised a transit from this City to Philadelphia in four hours; with a prospect of further reduction to three and a half. This is very well. Three hours and a half to Philadelphia is not the highest rate of speed.

The Foreign appointments have hitched again. None were officially announced to-day, although that of RICHARD KIBDER MEADE to Chili, is given out as certain. A long session of the Cabinet was held to-day, relative to the Foreign Missions exclusively. The rumor of the selection of Gen. DIX for the Mission to France, gains strength.

The annual meeting of the Marine Society of New-York, which was postponed last week, was held last evening at the Tabernacle. The attendance was by no means so numerous as the sterling merits of this benevolent institution should have attracted to its anniversary.

MARYLAND TRACT SOCIETY--The ninth annual meeting of the Maryland Tract Society was held at Baltimore, on Monday evening. The whole number of families visited, during the year was 16,982; volumes sold, 8,734; pages of books and tracts gratuitously distributed, 664,395.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: Father GAVAZZI thought fit to assail me, last evening, in terms I am not disposed to imitate in my defence. He used certain epithets, speaking of me, unbecoming a clergyman or a gentleman.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: There appeared in your paper a criticism of the New-York Illustrated News, which derives its importance from the wide circulation and influence of your paper, more than from the justice of the criticism itself. Being conversant with the views of its publishers, I deem it but fair to advocate their side of the case.

The Mercantile Character and Commercial Position of Eastern Virginia-- Railroads-Richmond, Petersburg and Norfolk--Ocean Steamers to Norfolk--Lieut. Maury--Effect of Slavery--Incidents--Tradespeople and Mechanics as affected by Slavery--Jealousy of New-York.

The City is in commotion. We might think that the pestilence was walking at noon-day,--that hourly bulletins were being issued from the office of the Health Commissioner, and that half the population expected to be buried before midnight.
