BROADWAY THEATRE--Gladiator--Little Toddlekins. WALLACK'S THEATRE--Money--The Ladies' Club. BURTON'S THEATRE--Lady of Lyons--Honey Moon. ST: CHARLES THEATRE.--Douglas--Therese-All a Mistake.

It will be remembered that, just before the adjournment, a call was made by the Senate upon the Department of State for copies of all correspondence between that Department and Hon. ROBERT C. SCHENCK, U. S. Minister to Brazil. The call was made too late in the session to be answered before adjournment;

A word with you respecting the present voyage of the good steamship Crescent City, from Aspinwall to your little village, and of matters and things on the Isthmus, will prove interesting to many of your readers.

FIRES.--Yesterday morning, about 3 1/2 o'clock, a fire broke out in a small wooden building, located at the corner of Marshall-street and Hudson-avenue, occupied for grinding coffee, by JOHN GRAHAM, which was entirely destroyed, together with the carpenter's shop of MOTT WRIGHT, adjoining, a small blacksmith and wheelwright shop, also belonging to Mr. MOTT, and a small dwellinghouse owned by THOMAS CULLIN, and occupied by a German shoemaker.

On Thursday morning, April 28, MARY WHITLOCK, wife of Wm. O. E Bourne. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this (Friday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from No. 70 Sackett-st., (near Hamilton-av. Jerry) South Brooklyn.

The African Slave Trade,--thanks to an improved public sentiment, and the consequent exertions of the great maritime nations of the world--has been almost entirely extinguished. It still has two strong-holds, where--while the eye of detection is quite successful in discovering its practices--the hand of punishment does not reach or prevent it.

Information having been received of the establishment of certain regulations by the German-Austrian Postal Union, requiring slight modifications of the instruction contained in the postage tables of 13th of October last, in regard to the United States and Prussian closed mail, we are ?? quested to publish the following list, as embracing all the countries and places to which letters and newspapers may be forwarded in said closed mail, with the necessary alterations.

Consolidation and Consolidation prices for Railroad shares are already producing the reasonable fruits of competition. The people of Newburg and Kingston, on the west bank of the Hudson, have long wanted a Railroad. The people, now isolated, of Delaware, Chenango and Cortland Counties also want a good through Road to the metropolis.

A valuable copper mine has been discovered in Randolph county, N. C. It is said it was worked for gold twenty years ago, and was abondoned on account of the copper ore interfering with the operations for gold. Then no one in North Carolina knew of the immense value of copper, and no notice was taken of it.

SPIED OF RAILROAD TRAINS.--The ordinances regulating the speed of the Railroad trains, which pass through Jersey City, have been so amended by the City authorities, that the cars are allowed to run at greater speed, than for some time past. The value of real estate is increasing because of the termination of important railroads from the South and West, in that city;

LECTURE III.--INFALLIBILITY OF THE POPE. The Tabernacle was well filled last evening on the occasion of Father GAVAZZI's Third Lecture. The lecturer, as usual, met with a hearty reception from his attentive audience. After announcing the subject of the lecture, as above stated, the reverend lecturer observed that, among Roman Catholics, the infallibility of the Pope was a point of faith.

We see that almost eve where the Whig press finds in our deprecation of any further inflation of our paper currency, and especially in our dissent to the project of making city stocks the basis of a new issue, a ground of accusation against us. We are denounced as radical, obstructive, destructive even.

To a man who has traveled through California with open eyes, examining thoroughly the character of her people, and her interests, the ignorance of our Eastern friends in regard to our State is astonishing. The announcement that a steamer has arrived at New York, bringing so many millions of gold dust, is sufficient basis for a judgment on our resources!

The Railroad interest of Northern Ohio, a year or two ago, earnestly sought a continuous chain with the State of New-York, around the southern shore of Lake Erie. In this they were seconded on this side. They built, under regular charter, a road from Cleveland, through Painseville to Ashtabula.

EBENEZER HILL, a patriot of the Revolution, died at Wakefield, N. H. a few days since. Mr. H. was at the battle of Bennington, and while stationed at West Point, was one of the guard over Major ANDRE the night previous to his execution.

The name of HEINE is familiar to those who have paid any attention to the strange portraits of German Literature. In 1825 he went from Germany to Paris, where he has resided ever since--the latter part of the time bed-ridden with a severe spinal disease.

It has been remarked, that "there can be no surer test of the advance of business and commercial enterprise generally, for any given time, than the increase of postage for the same period." From the statements already rendered, it is obvious that for many years, and through many reigns in England, there never prevailed any consistent and systematic arrangement in regard to the regulation of the mails.

Mr. VAN BUREN is in the City, ready to sail to-morrow in the Collins' steamer Arctic for Europe. He goes in company with his son, M. VAN BUREN, Jr., who is at present in ill health. The trip will probably extend over the Continent, as well as through England, Scotland and Ireland.

The most striking piece of intelligence by the English steamer is the announcement of the search of KOSSUTH'S premises in London, under a warrant from the Secretary of State. It appears that from intelligence received by the Police, the presence of munitions of war was apprehended, and a search-warrant at Rotherhithe produced the desired result.

The chimney of the Freeman office, Salem, exploded at about 12 o'clock on Monday, and the fragments in falling struck Capt. Poole, of Salem, who chanced to be passing at the time, and felled him to the ground, inflicting two severe but not fatal cuts upon. his head. Capt. Poole fortunately had an umbrella hoisted at the time, which probably saved him.

On Wednesday, April 27, by Rev. George Potts, D. D., JAMES ROOSEVELT to REBECCA B., daughter of the late Gardiner G. IIowland. On Wednesday, April 27, by Rev. G. T. Bedell, WM. H. DECKER to HANNAH LOUISE, eldest daughter of Theodore Crane, all of this City.

The Board of Aldermen met on Wednesday evening, being the twelfth sitting during the month. At 5:20 Alderman TIEMAN moved to call the roll, but was requested to withdraw his motion until a quorum had assembled. In the absence of the President, Alderman STURTEVANT was moved to the Chair.

THE NEW-YORK COLLEOTORSHIP.--The Republic has a local Correspondent, who thus dilates upon the position of the new Collector of this port: From what I learn I judge that Collector BRONSON will leave Washington to enter (on the first proximo) on the discharge of his official duties with much fewer misgivings than he entertained before starting for this point.

POLICE APPOINTMENTS.--The following are the names of the policemen elected in the Second Ward, by the Aldermen of that Ward, in conjunction with Mayor BERRY, on Wednesday evening: John Raddigan, William Bradley, Hugh O'Niel, Bernard McElroy, John Sterritt, Charles Van Dyke, Robert Murphy, Martin Brennan, James Calhoun, Henry Welsh, Peter Bennett and James Gallaudit.

COL. SUMNER AND THE NINTH MILITARY DEPARTMENT.-The St. Louis Intelligencer has the following respecting the conduct of the Military Department in New-Mexico: Col. E. V. SUMNER, who is now in command of the Ninth Military Department, will, at his own request, be relieved of that command, and, as we understand, will be succeeded by Gen. GARLAND.

Hon. EDWARD STANLY, long a Member of Congress from North Carolina, and well known to the whole country for the ability, integrity, and high-toned manliness of character which he always carried into the discharge of public duties, is now in this City on his way to California. He intends to resume the practice of law at San Francisco.

The Massachusetts House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to increase the compensation of members from $2 to $2 50. If it is worth anything, it is worth two dollars and a half, to be lobbied, and bored, and worried to death day after day, through tedious sessions--to be arrested by Sergeants-at-arms, and "bored" by constituents--to be "put through" by the papers,

A singular Life Insurance case will, it is said, soon be reached in one of the Boston Courts A Life Insurance Company is sued for a policy which they refuse to pay. The person whose life was insured committed suicide, and the policy of all Life Companies contain a clause that they will not pay in case a man dies by his own hand, ?? while fighting a duel.

The State of Delaware is just now in a ferment. A Convention is in session to revise the State Constitution:--and the main point at issue is, whether the Convention is Constitutional or not. The present State Constitution provides for a State Convention to amend or reform it,--but declares very explicitly that "a majority of all the "citizens having right to vote for representatives" shall be required to sanction the call for such Convention.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada Captain STONE, from Liverpool, shortly after noon, on the 16th inst.. arrived at this port at 2 o'clock this morning. The Canada left here at 5 o'clock--it is therefore doubtful if she will reach Boston in time for the afternoon train to-morrow for New-York. She brings 142 through passengers, and 9 for Halifax.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"Lucrezia Borgia" attracted another large audience last night. It is deservedly the greatest success of the season. Mad. ROSE DE VRIES gave the music of Lucrezia with greater ease and better effect than on any previous occasion. She is undoubtedly an acquisition to the already powerful troupe engaged by Mr. LEGRAND SMITH.
Orders have been granted by Judge MITCHELL, of the Supreme Court, against the proprietors of the Eighth-Avenue and the Harlem Railroads, to show cause why injunctions should not issue against them.

REVERSES OF LIFE.--The following sad story is from the Washington Republic. A very little inquiry, we suspect, would enable us to find many incidents not unlike it in our own City. What a pity that some of the sympathy and kindness which were so liberally bestowed at the last moment, could not have come before they were too late to be of use:

Gov. LANE'S coup d'etat in New-Mexico will be informally considered in the Cabinet to-morrow, but no action will be had until the Government is officially informed of the facts, which, it is understood, has not been yet.

SECOND FREE LECTURE--WHAT ARE THE NATIONS IN THE PAPAL SYSTEM? The eloquent Italian patriot delivered his second free lecture at the Tabernacle last evening. It is almost needless to say that the house was crammed--presenting a suggestive contrast to the somewhat slim audience that attended the Reverend Father's lecture on Wednesday evening, for the benefit of the destitute Italian Exiles about to arrive from Italy.

From the Washington Union of yesterday. The vague reports which have been lately received from New-Mexico have caused much hasty and improper comment in some quarters. In hot haste to espouse the cause of Mexico, a large portion of the Whig press has already denounced Governor LANE's action as unauthorized annexation, while some have gone so far as to stigmatise it as a violent and piratical spoliation of the territory of a neighboring nation.

TREATMENT OF SLAVES.--The Southern Agricultural Society some time since offered a premium for the best treatise on the management of Slaves. The Committee appointed to examine the essays sent in, has recently published its report on the subject.

Unfortunate individuals who have correspondents in Europe, or in the distant States of the Union, know what it is to have a Post-Office in an inconvenient locality. Further more, they are conscious of the vexatious annoyances which must always accrue from a lack of necessary space.

INDIGNATION MEETINGS.--We understand that the residents and property owners of the Second Ward intend holding an indignation meeting, for the purpose of expressing their disapproval of the nominations made by the Aldermen of that Ward, in Committee, on Wednesday evening last.
At the fire in this City yesterday morning, Mr. QUINN, one of the persons who was compelled to vacate the premises destroyed, was robbed of $100 which was locked up in a bureau.

THE ART UNION INVESTIGATION.--MEETING OF THE LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE.--The Committee of the House of Assembly of the State Legislature, appointed to investigate the affairs of the late New-York Art Union, assembled pursuant to adjournment, 'yesterday afternoon, at the Astor House. Present Messrs. D. B. TAYLOR, B. M. CHAMPLAIN, and A. M. CLAPP.

From the Independent. Some of the children may remember about a beautiful little girl, found by the missionary last Winter, in a very bad house with negroes. There is not such a house hardly in New-York. It is in "Cow Bay," and a man owns it who keeps a rum shop, and who makes a fortune from these poor creatures with his houses and his rum.

" Ichabod," the Local of the Republic, says the enterprise of running the mails on the Mississippi in low pressure boats is one of more magnitude than those not conversant with such matters dream of. The services stipulated to be performed by the contractors will require the outlay of a million and a half of dollars for a fair start.

A trip down the Alabama River to Mobile is quite an interesting chapter in the history of inland voyaging, and as it is a safe passage, there is ordinarily nothing to detract from its enjoyments. The company is generally very agreeable, and the officers of the steamers are polite and attentive.

About 1 o'clock this morning, the Rochester House, a Temperance hotel, was found to be on fire, and, sad to relate, four domestics--three women and one boy--lost their lives. There were about 120 persons in the hotel, many of them families, who were boarders; and the scene of confusion and dismay which occurred is inconceivable.

The long-winded McDONOGH Will case, in which the City of Baltimore is deeply interested, is now freed from all suits except one pending before the United States Supreme Court on an appeal from the United States Circuit Court of Louisiana.

Captain RINGGOLD, the Commander of the North Pacific Exploring Expedition, has received his instructions from the Department, and the squadron will sail from Norfolk for the scene of operations in a few days.
On Thursday evening, April 28, by Rev. Dr. John M. Macaulay, JOSEPH H. COWDREY to SILOAM VAN SOLINGEN, daughter of the late Lawrence Hill, Esq., all of this City.

It is well understood that the English Government has, for some time, descended to the baseness of employing spies to dog the foot-steps and watch the movements, and report the words and acts of those unfortunate friends of Freedom whom European despotism has driven to take refuge on English soil.

THE COURTS REMOVAL.--Next Monday, May 2, by virtue of a resolution of the Common Council, adopted January 10, the Justices' Courts of this City, will be held and permanently located as follows: The Justices Court of the First District, in the building known as the Third District Station-house, Court-street, between Butler and Douglass streets.

The French are proverbially a tasteful people. They have a fashion of devising ways and means, where a prosaic, matter-of-fact Yankee, or a phlegmatic Dutchman and a Yorkshireman would never dream of anything brilliant. In the application of harsh materials to elegant purposes, they particularly excel.

The Sectarian difficulties at Cincinnati look somewhat threatening to the peace of the City. The movement of the Mayor last Sunday, under the pretext of suppressing an outbreak, in silencing a Protestant preacher, in the Public Market Place, is warmly canvassed throughout the City and by the press.

NIELO'S GARDEN.--In consequence of some difficulty, (arising, we believe, from the caprice of a principal male singer,) the opera of to-night is postponed. In another column will be found the card of the management. Probably, on Monday there will be an expose of the whole affair.

In the Counties of Fairfax, Va., and Montgomery and Prince George's, in Maryland, may be found large tracts of land, which, in time past, has been so thoroughly overcropped by tobacco and corn, as to leave it nearly exhausted.

Seldom in this country do we witness a theatrical performance wherein is observed a strict regard for propriety in scenery, costume, and miscellaneous properties. Provided a few dresses are put together, of a sufficiently picturesque appearance, the manager deems all additional expense and research unnecessary.

The trumpeter who fell into the hands of the enemy pleaded hard for his life on the ground that he had taken no part in the fight, but he was nevertheless slain because he had sounded the call and given the stimulus to war. That is the precise case of the press.
The Anniversaries are close at hand. Some few of them take place during the ensuing week, and the remainder during the week commencing on Sunday, May 8.

The House, to day, in Committee of the Whole, discusssed sundry amendments to the Liquor bill. Among the amendments adopted was one making the owner or owners of a building in which intoxicating liquors are sold, contrary to the provisions of the law, liable to a fine of $100, if the said sale is with the knowledge or consent of the owner, after due notice thereof by an officer named in the act.
On Friday evening, April 29, LUCIA MARIA, daughter of Hiram A. and Catharine A. Maynard, aged 1 year, 8 months and 5 days.

Halifax papers of the 25th inst. are received. The trial of THOMAS CLARK, one of the crew of the New-York ship Winchester, for abuse and felonious assault on some of the female passengers from Liverpool, for which the crew were mobbed in the streets of Halifax, had resulted in his acquittal.

In the House of Commons, on the 14th- In the order of the day for the third reading of the Jewish Disabilities bill, Mr. CUMMING BRUCE protested against the measure, the opponents of which, he contendec, were constantly on the increase, and opposed to it on every ground.

Thursday was a day to talk about, and to feel joyous in. We shall not go into the poetry of the thing, but take it in the more utilitarian or business view, although if ever dull muse could be moved by the influence of a weather "medium," this glorious Spring-time would make her eloquent.
We left Enterprize this morning, and tomorrow morning shall be at the end of our river journey. I write by lamplight, in the little cabin of our boat, a few items which I neglected in my last.

We cannot help it. We do not know that we are more liable to contagion than other people, but we have taken the Spring fever, and our symptoms defy the treatment of any physician but Nature. We are off into the country to-morrow.
MANLIUS S. CLARKE, a member of the Suffolk, Mass. Bar, died lately at the age of 36. He was a man of a good deal of professional reputation, especially in matters pertaining to commercial law.

The Conference Anti-Slavery Society connected with the New-England Methodist Conference, in session at Ipswich, held its anniversary meeting last evening.

Col. SLOO, of Tehuantepec notoriety, is, we believe, at Washington. His objects in being there are, probably, the consummation of the treaty, guaranteeing his contract; the introduction of the Transit Stock into the market; and a very natural desire to realize and appropriate some of the fame to which his successful prosecution of the business entitles him. All this is unexceptionable.

THE GREATEST DISCOVERY OF THE AGE.--No remedy can be purchased equal to Dr. TOBIAS' Venetian Liniment, for the cure of dysentery, colic, sea-sickness, croup, chronic rheumatism, toothache, sore throat, coughs, cuts, burns, old sores, pains in the limbs, chest, back, If it does not give relief, your money will be returned. Price, 25 and 50 cents.

Marshal RADETZKY has refused the honors with which the Emperor wished to surround him at Vienna, and preferred not to leave Italy. It was apprehended, therefore, that the substitution of civil for military power in Lombardy would not take place.

" Hans Yorkel," the spirited and sensible New-York correspondent of the New-Orleans Bulletin, in a recent letter, gives the following graphic sketch, illustrating the style in which all kinds of business go ahead in this section of the world: NEW-YORK; April 9, 1853. I have just returned from Albany.
The reception of Mrs. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE at Liverpool is reported at length. To an address of welcome delivered by Rev. Dr. McNEILE, Professor STOWE made a suitable reply.

The Grand Jury made a special presentment this morning in relation to ??he RINK murder, embracing all the evidence, fastening the crime upon SPRING, which is deemed convincing of the innocence of JEROME FECKERT, arrested on suspicion of the murder, and his discharge is recommended.

Rev. Mr. Williams, a missionary at Canton, speaking of the Chinese emigration, says: "Emigration is taking the form of a transfer of Chinese laborers to the West Indies, Demerara, Lima and Havana, in a contract of five years' labor, after which the parties do as they please.

Before I ever heard of the good IZAAK WALTON, I used to listen with greedy ears to my Grand father's stories about Angling; and long before I ever read the Complete Angler, I was expert myself at taking trout. No doubt my inclination to this pastime was inherited, for my ancestors were as primitive in their tastes as in their piety.

We have already given, from the London critical periodicals, some account of this remarkable volume, and now avail ourselves of this neat republication to express our own estimate of its value.

The London Times has vigorously and earnestly espoused the cause of the poor seamstresses of London-exposing the sufferings and cruel treatment to which they are subjected by the avarice of employers, and insisting upon the necessity of providing a remedy.

TRAGEDY IN ULSTER COUNTY.--The Pough-keepsie Daily Press narrates the following story: A most horrible crime was perpetrated in this County on Sunday, the 7th inst., which together with the circumstances attending the history of those concerned, will form a chapter of exciting interest to the public.

Keligoland-Guernsey-Jersey, c. To hear the French swear about Keligoland and English rapacity, one would suppose, as they doubtless do, that it is a considerable piece of plunder. But it is only one of those "new-catched miles" which MARVEL probably speaks of--being but a mile long and less than half a mile broad, lying about 25 miles from the mouths of the Elbe, the Weser and the Eyder.

There are in the town of Danvers 27 schools, of all grades, which employ the services of 32 teachers; the average attendance at these schools is not much short of 200 scholars, and the amount of money expended on them exceeds $7,000 annually.

The Baltic brings the Financial Budget of the British Government, presented to the Commons by Mr. GLADSTONE, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, and explained by him at great length, on the 18th ult. The proposed changes of policy are unusually interesting. The practical results, owing to the complete harmony of arrangement, are regarded as likely to work favorably.

The Wing Convention for the nomination of candidates for City officers will Tuesday afternoon, several men at work on the Painfield Railroad, near Olneyville, were buried by the cavining in of a bank, and two of them were fatally injured.

INDIAN WAR.--The Fort Smith (Ark.) Herald learns from a Shawnee, that near the North Fork of the Canadian, several fights had taken place between the Pawnees, Delawares and Kickapoos, caused by a party of Pawnees Mohas having stolen some horses from the Delawares. The Herald says: "The Delawares followed them, retook the horses, and killed one Pawnee.

The town of Lynn, Massachusetts, was organized on the 9th instant, by the choice of Wm. F. Iohnson, Dexter Stetson, and Artemus Murdock, Selectmen; Washington H. Johnson, Town Clerk; Walter Johnson, Welcome W. Johnson, Treasurer and Collector. Five Constables were also chosen. John, of Lynn, must have been blessed with a large family of boys.

A case illustrating the extreme exactness of the law, recently occurred at Milwaukee. A suit having been commenced before a Justice in Milwaukee, was removed by affidavit to the nearest justice under the law. The offices of the two ministers of the law were at about equal distance, and resort was had to a surveyor's chain, to ascertain which was nearest. One was found to be nine links nearer than the other.

New-Orleans papers of Monday have been received. They contain Galveston dates to the 21st ult. The survey of the Galveston Railroad had been resumed. Another arrest had been made for the Post-Office robbery. A portion of the Harrisburg and Colorado Rail road had been opened with great rejoicing. HENRY SHELDON, of New-York, was elected President of the San Antonio and Mexican Gulf Railroad.

We have received several communications since the publication of the article entitled "The Skeleton on the Hearth," approving of the spirit in which we treated the subject, but disapproving of the remedy we pointed to, and suggesting others. When we advocated the placing of inhuman husbands in the pillory, we were, of course, to a certain extent, aware of the general impracticability of such a system.
The religious exercises prefatory to the anniversary of the above named organization, took place last evening in Rev. Dr. ALEXANDER'S Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Nineteenth-street.

By the arrival of the steamship Tay at Southampton, 17th, we have Buenos Ayrean papers of the 4th and Montevidean of the 6th March. At the former date, the city of Buenos Ayres was still besieged by URQUIZA'S forces, but no regular assault had taken place--the operations on either side consisting of merely guerilla warfare, in which much blood was uselessly spilt. We publish from our English files this morning, a very full account of the recent attempt of the London Times, with the connivance probably of the English Ministry, to subject M. KOSSUTH to the vengeance of Austrian despotism under the forms of English law.

In the DAILY TIMES of Thursday, we explained the circumstances under which the United States Post-Office Department has been for some time past, paying to the British Post-Office, considerable sums of money for transit postage on newspapers sent to or received

We learn by telegraph from Kingston, C. W., that the steamer Ocean Wave, was destroyed by fire on Friday night, six miles west of the " Ducks," and about fifty miles above Kingston. She is reported to have had sixty persons on board, twenty-two of whom, only, were saved, including Captain WRIGHT, the Mate, and the Purser. The Ocean Wave was owned at this place, by the Northern Railroad Company, and has been running be-

A. DUDLEY MANN, Esq., recently appointed Assistant Secretary of State, arrived in the Baltic yesterday, and will probably enter at once upon the discharge of his duties at Washington. We have already expressed our cordial approval of this appointment, as one of the very best the President has yet made. Mr. MANN has spent many years in Europe,--generally in connection with the public service, though not always in any recognized public capacity.
Presoyterion Board of Foreign Missions. At the Mission House, 4 o'clock, P. M. FRIDAY, May 6. New-York Magdalen Society.--New Asylum, Eighty eighth-street, between Fourth and Fifth-avenues, 11 A. M.

The British steamer Conway has arrived at this port, having left Jamaica on the 24th, and Nassan on the 28th inst. The American steamer Paraguay put into Kingston on the 24th, for coal--all well. A passenger from the steamer Uncle Saw, connected with the Sheriff's office, died in Kingston Hospital on the 21st inst.

NIBLO's GARDEN.--The first season of the "Combination Opera Troupe" has terminated, and Mr. LE GRAND SMITH announces that the house will be closed for a few nights in order that due preparation may be made for another campaign. Three new operas are stated to be in process of rehearsal.

We learn from Florida that throughout Alachua, Columbia and Marion Counties, Cotton is in an excellent state of forwardness, and bids fair for heavy crop, the additional ground planted this season warranting the estimate that the product this year will be double that of the last, or about ten thousand bales. The Tobacco, so far as transplanted, looks well, particularly in Marion County.

My dispatch, published yesterday morning, relative to Gen. LANE's coup d'etat in Mexico, was blundered a little in the transmission, and requires an explanation. I designed to be understood that SANTA ANNA is not so ready to come into armed collision with the United States as he was before the battle of Buena Vista, and that it will be difficult to provoke him to such an issue.

Rev. DAVID P. BAILEY died at Aurora, Ill., on the 15th ult. He had been the pastor of the Universalist Church in Aurora but a few months. Rev. Father DE HANN, formerly of St. Joseph's Church, New-Orleans, died a few days since. Dr. IRA CORWIN of Southold, Suffolk Co., died, 'aged about 70 years, at his home after a very brief illness on the 6th of April. He had practiced

On the evening of the 15th, the great source was given at Glasgow, in honor of Mrs. H. BEECHER STOWE. Two thousand persons were present, hundreds of whom had taken their place an hour, at least, before the proceedings commenced. Mr. McDOWALL, of Glasgow, presided. After tea, Rev. Dr. WARDLAW moved the first resolution, welcoming to Glasgow Mrs. STOWE, and including in the welcome Rev. C. E. STOWE.

JAMES GADSEN, South Carolina fire-eater, is now spoken of by many as the leading candidate for the Mexican Mission, and Governor SEYMOUR, of Connecticut, for Russia. Senator SHIELDS is also spoken of for the latter place, but declares he would not accept.

The following persons have been appointed Notary Publics, for the County of Westchester, by the Governor: WARD B. HOWARD of Peekskill, JOHN F. BANKER of Sing Sing, and WILLIAM TUCKER of Somers, in place of WILLIAM COFFIN, resigned. Justice STRONG will hold a special term of the Supreme. Court, at the Court House in White Plains, next Tuesday. This will be the first special term held in this county for a great while.

The business at the New-York Custom House, for the week ending on Saturday last, involved an Import of Foreign Merchandise, of nearly FIVE MILLIONS DOLLARS. The Cash Duties deposited with the Assistant Treasurer of the United States by the Collector of the Port, amounted to $1,036,024.

By the Canada, we had a brief notice that came by Telegraph from London to Liverpool, of the explanation in Parliament respecting the seizure of munitions of war said to belong to KOSSUTH. London papers by this arrival bring the debate in full.

Lishon dates were to the 9th. Nothing of political importance was going on. The Address to the throne had been at length voted by the House of Peers. A bill of indemnity legalising the dictatures of 1851-2 was under discussion in the deputies, and likely to be approved by both Houses.

DISTUBANCE.--At about 7 o'clock Sunday evening a disturbance occurred in Jersey City, near the Ferry, which at one time threatened to be an extensive row., Some difficulty occurred on the Ferry-boat, between two or three citizens who were in their buggies returning from Long Island, and a large party of young men who were said to be Irishmen. It was alleged that the larger party were the aggressors.
FROM PERNAMBUCO.--By the arrival of the brig Oak, at Philadelphia, Sunday, we have accounts from Bahia to March 18, and Pernambuco to the 22d. We subjoin the annexed commercial in. telligence:

The May Session opened yesterday. Owing to a protracted meeting of the Supervisors, the Board of Alderman did not organize unitil 5 P. M., RICHARD COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Petitions Referred--Of Solomon Kohnstamm, to be re-lieved from the purchase of real estate, amounting to $3,000. Of Wm. Coventry, to flag the sidewalk of Thirty.ninth-street.

The President will confer on Colonel H. L. SCOTT, General SCOTT'S son-in-law, the appointment of Inspector-General of the Army. The Union of to-morrow will announce, by authority, that the rumor that the President designs shortly visiting New-Hampshire is wholly unfounded. He will not leave the Capital during the approaching Summer.

It is too late in the day to present any arguments showing the importance to the United States of acquiring a right of way, and the power to construct a railroad across the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean. The subject has long claimed the attention of our statesmen and capitalists;

FROM DOMINICA.-Capt. MULLIGAN, of brig Truxilla, from Rio Janeiro via the above place, April 9, informs vs of the death of the American Consul, which took place about 1st March. Several American whalers had put into Prince Ruperts Bay for water and wood, among which were barks Oceola, of New-Bedford, out 10 months, 100 bbls. sperm; George and Mary, of do.,

A promenade in America is the appropriately Gallican title which Mr. JOHN JAMES AMPERE places over the head of his narrative of travel in the United States. Mr. AMPERE is a traveler by profession, like TAVERNIER, or CHAUDON, or BRUCE. He goes to see and to write books.

The Commercial is resolutely sceptical respecting the slave-trade in Cuba. Among other witnesses it cites a correspondent of the Express, who landed on the Island the other day; and who states that since his landing, he has discovered no foundation for the alarming stories of correspondents resident there.

The famous Dr. WILLIAM BEAUMONT, whose " Physiology of Digestion and Experiments on the Gastric Juice," based on the experiments he conducted upon the Canadian ALEXIS ST. MARTIN, have made him so widely and favorably known, died on the 25th ult., at St. Louis. Dr. BEAUMONT was a native of Lebanon, Connecticut, where he was born 1785. In 1812,

DAMAGES FOR INJURY ON A RAILSOAD.--The Circuit Court sitting at Morrisville, Madison Co., tried the case of Charles Lee vs. the Rochester and Syracuse Railroad Company, an action for damages received by plaintiff in October last, while riding on the cars of the above road. The injury was caused by a collision of the train with a loaded car. Mr. LEE sustained an injury of the spine,

From the Washington Union. We perceive that some of the Northern journals represent, on the authority of heir correspondents in this city, that our article of Friday, relating to the movements in New-Mexico, justifies and defends the conduct of Gov. LANE in taking possession of the valley of Mesilla.

Come boys, the sun will be up before you can get out of bed. It is a pretty morning,-the dew is on the grass, and every cow that has gone down to the spring to drink has brushed off so much of it as to leave her path marked out. They are standing now by the picket fence, lowing in turns for the forkful of timothy.

Powers of the air! What moving sights and sights of moving yesterday ! From early morn till the morning after, carts backed up to every door-we speak after the manner of men-bedsteads encountered bureaus; cooking-stoves walked through looking-glasses and family portraits;

FROM BERMUDA.-The steamer Derastation is crawling off and upward. She arrived at Bermuda, en route to the Newfoundland fishery grounds, on the 24th ult. The Triad is undergoing temporary repairs, to fit her for the voyage to this port, and will probably be ready in a fortnight.

As if the law-suit just brought against Dr. VERON for the sale of the Constitutionnel had not sunk both the editor and the paper into sufficient disgrace-for the revelations are such as will compromise them both beyond recovery-the chaste and pi ous organ of family and religion makes an announcement this week which opens the eyes of the Parisians to a width beyond their usual stretch.

On Sunday afternoon, May 1, Mrs. JOANNA WALKER, relict of John Walker, aged 76 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Wednesday morning, May4, at 8 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 374 Madison-st. Her remains will be taken to Hempstead, L. I., for interment.

Byway of New Orleans, we have dates from Texas (Galveston and Indianola) to April 21. The corner stone of the new Episcopal Church, in course of erection in Austin, says the Gazette, was laid with due ceremony on the 13th by the members of Austin Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons.

" Songs of Scotland," vol. 1; "Irish Melodies," vol. 1. J. A. NOVELLO, No. 389 Broadway, has sent us the especial American edition of the above compositions. They are included in two neat volumes, published at a low price, but possessing all the clearness and elegance which the best type, printing, paper and binding can impart.

Last evening, at 8 o'clock, the old Common Council met in the Lyceum, Alderman HARRISON, President of the Board, in the Chair. After approving of the minutes of their previous meeting they adjourned, and the new Board took their seats. A large proportion of the new Board were members of the late Council. Alderman MILLER was called to the Chair.

A letter from Santa Fe to the St. Louis Republican, under date of March 30, encloses the Proclamation of Gov. LANE, and adds a summary of news very similar to the account we have already copied from the New-Orleans Picayune. The writer adds:

The lamentable loss of life which ensued from the collision between the steamer Atlantic and the propeller Ogdensburgh on Lake Erie, on the 20th August last, is still fresh in the recollection of our readers. E. W. WARD and others, owners of the Atlantic, have lately brought a suit against the Proprietors of the Ogdensburgh in the United States Court at Columbus, O.

MOSES M. TYLER and THOS. ROCKHAM, the conductor and engineer of the Michigan Central Railroad, have been admitted to bail in the sum of $2,000 each, upon a writ of habeas corpus. Mr. WHITING, the conductor, and Mr. DAVIS, the engineer, and the firemen of the Michigan Southern train have also been admitted to bail by Judge WILSON in the sum of $2,000 each.

ENGLAND AND AUSTRIA.--The following paragraph confirming statements already made that England is rendering her police system subservient to the views and purposes of Austria, is from the Frankfort Pest Gazette, the semi-official organ of the Germanic Diet:

WELLAND CANAL TOLLS--The Official Gazette of the 9th inst., republishes the rates corrected. The material reductions are on the St. Lawrence Canals, discriminating in favor of the river route. Iron of all kinds, and salt coming through the St. Lawrence Canals, pass the Welland Canal free of tolls.

The ART-UNION investigation is at last under way. The Committee began taking testimony yesterday, and their proceedings will be found in this morning's TIMES. The only witness examined was Mr. MONCK, who had been employed by the Art-Union for a year or two, and naturally made diligent use of his opportunities to become acquainted with its affairs.

The Parliamentary proceedings of the week have not been without significance and interest, although no great party question has been mooted,at least, not one fairly striking at the vitality, or hardly the stability, of the Ministry. The latter, nevertheless, have had one or two ugly reminders that they are, politically, but mortal, and that their tenor of official existence is frailer, perhaps, than they imagined. First, however,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In common with many of your readers I am glad to see you advocating the enforcement of the existing excise laws, rather than urging the enactment of a law which, although more stringent in its terms, may prove altogether impracticable and inefficacious in its effects. The present statute,

THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER AT CLEVELAND.The murder of the woman near Cleveland, reported by telegraph, is commented upon, with particulars, by the Plaindealer: " CHRISTINA SIGSBY was the deceased's maiden name. She was formerly Mrs. CLERMONT, wife of JOHN CLERMONT. They lived in Elyria. About six years ago some dissatisfaction arising in the family, because her husband was unable to provide for her, (she was inclined to be extravagant,) she left the house.

We are now in the midst of those Anniversaries that,--as the Societies whose celebrations they are, interest so large a portion of the people of Ireland, as well as those of England and Scotland,--bring together vast numbers from all quarters; the sight of whom, no less than the objects that convene them, forcibly carries back the thought to past times, as well as the future of this country.

THE WAITERS' STRIKE.--The Waiters of Brooklyn, it seems, have in some instances, followed the example of their New-York brethren, and struck for higher wages. A few days since the waiters st the Mansion House, on the Heights, kept by Gen. YALE, demanded $18 per month, instead of $15, the old rate, threatening to quit him in a body, unless the demand was complied with.

FROM PORT-AU-PRINCE.--The schooner Samuel Clark, of Fredericksburg, SANDS, from Portau-Prince, April 16, with coffee, arrived yesterday; she left bark Charles E. Lex, HARPER, for Philadelphia next day; British brig Gem, MORRIS, for Boston 20th; schooner Boxer, SAWYER, for NewYork, loading, to sail next day. April 18, off Gonaives, spoke brig Active, from Boston for Port-auPrince.

TENNESSEE.--The Whig State Convention of Tennessee met at Nashville on the 25th ult. Delegates from thirty-three Counties were present. Gen. J. L. McKOIN, of Sumner, was called to the chair. A Committee on resolutions was appointed, who reported in favor of the principles embodied in the Address of the State Convention of May, 1851;...

The Washington Union, in an article printed elsewhere in the TIMEs, relieves the Administration of the charge of sanctioning the recent imprudence of Gov. LANE. It is obvious that the Union is not yet far enough within the penetralia of the Cabinet to speak by authority. There is no preestablished harmony between the President and the printer.

It seems pretty certain that Chatham-street and the Bowery are to be paved with the Russ pavement. The process will be expensive,--but the project, nevertheless, has the recommendation, (unusual enough to be noted,) that the City will have something to show for its money.

MORE ROWDYISM-ASSAULT WITH ATTEMPT TO KILL.--Late on Sunday night, a gang of six rowdies entered the Union Hotel, No. 1 Atlantic street, kept by TIhOMAS COSTIGAN, and made an attack upon the proprietor, without any provocation whatever. Decanters and tumblers were thrown at his head, and finally one of the party seized an oyster-knife aid attempted to stab him.

In this City, on Sunday, May 1, by Judge Green, EDWIN S. BROWN, of Boston, to MARY FITZGERALD, of this On Monday morning, May 2, at the residence of the bride's father, by Rev. Thomas H. Skinner, Jr., Captain AUGUSTINE E PRESSINGER to Miss MARY D., daughter of Cyrus W. Price, all of this City.

On Sunday, we heard a discourse on the conduct of a wise man. It was a very good Sunday sermon; but when the working days began, we thought there was left unsaid the staple for a lay sermon on the same topic.

Mr. WATKTNS LIROUX, the person on whose testimony Col. BENTON lays so much stress has written touching the route to the Pacific, a brief and pertinent letter. He says he knows no practicable wagon load west from Zuni direct to California, but he is firm in the belief that a road may be found by following nearly a due west course into California, falling into the Sacramento Valley, and to San Francisco.

EXTENSIVE LARCENY.--About 10 o'clock on Saturday morning, officer KIEHL arrested a Germau boy named FREIDOLINE HEBMAN, apprentice to CONRAD STEINHAUER, the proprietor of a boot and shoe Store, at No. 119 Messerole-street, charged with having, at various times within the last nine months, embezzled and sold about $150 worth of boots and shoes. At the time of his arrest, a small sack, containing twelve pair of women's shoes, were found concealed in his bed.

To H. E. the Provisional Governor of the Province of Buenos Ayres: It being impossible for me to remain indifferent to the daily secrifice of a portion of our fellow-countrymen, who are immolated in the disastrous civil war, tenasiously prolonged in that province,

LECTURE IV-PAPACY IS BLINDNESS AND MISERY. The fourth lecture of Father GAVAZZI'S second series was delivered last evening at the Metropolitan Hall. The attendance was not so large as on many previous occasions. The reverend lecturer observed that the Popish system was blindness.
Resuming the consideration of this subject, let us examine the history of the grant to Col. SLOO, and the treaty recently negotiated for its protection.

Another chapter is added in this morning's report to the history of the Art-Union inquisition. Mr. MONK is still the witness under examination "for the prosecution:" and his testimony yesterday was more direct and emphatic than had been given before.

FIRES IN THE WOODS.--The old Pine Bush, near Schenectady, took fire on Sunday. Some boys playing in the woods, set fire to the under brush, which blazed up fiercely, and wrapped the woods in flames. Several acres were burned over.

The mail to-night brings New-Orleans papers of Tuesday and Wednesday last. The steamship Albatross went ashore on Cabezas Reef, on the 18th April, ten miles from the shore, and twenty-six from Vera Gruz.

Traveling Adventures--Portsmouth to Gaston--Some account of Gaston--Statistics of Population, Arts--Agriculture. By the Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad from Portsmouth, Virginia, to Weldon, North Carolina, eighty miles, run in three hours and twenty minutes--twenty-five miles an hour--heavy rails, easy grades, and few curves.

The New-York Historical Society held their monthly meeting in the University last evening Hon. LUTHER BRADISH in the Chair. The minutes having been read and approved, Mr. MOORE, Librarian and Secretary pro tem., read a communication from J. D. GRAHAM, Esq., of Washington, enclosing a copy of his report upon the Mexican Boundary question.

In Williamsburg, on Tuesday, May 3, BENEDICT W. ROGERS, in the 32d year of his age. Friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral at his late residence, No. 46 South 6th st., Williamsburg, at 4 o'clock, this (Wednesday) afternoon.

The attendance last evening at Father GAVAZZI'S lecture in Metropolitan Hall was highly respectable, but not very numerous. The lecturer observed that the subject of the evening was as above stated, and intimated that he would treat the matter not theoretically, but practically.

Passengers left Buffalo yesterday by the Erie Railroad, at 7 A. M., and reached this City by 9.32 P. M.,--through in fourteen and a half hours. Rents are cheap in Buffalo, why don't some of our enterprising down town merchants buy country houses in that pleasant village, and save their little ones from the cholera infantum which is so apt to attack juveniles in crowded cities.

The Union of yesterday qualifies its endorsement of Gov. LANE's coup d'etat in New-Mexico--evidence that the Administration is not so ready, as at first indicated, to commend this unprecedented specimen of practical fillibusterism.

To THE PUBLIC.--I feel it a duty I owe to those who are suffering under the severe affliction of throat and lung complaints, to bear this unsought testimony to the superior skill and beneficial effects of Dr. LUTENER'S treatment, lately introduced into this country by the discoverer, Dr. LUTENER, an English physician of high reputation.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: MAY THE FIRST. SIR: An article entitled "Pictorial Papers," written by me, and published in the TIMES of April 26, has drawn forth two replies from gentlemen connected with the illustrated press, both of which appeared in your edition of last Thursday.

ANOTHER ASSAULT AND ROBBERY IN THE PUBLIC STREET.--About 1 o'clock on Monday morning a man named JAMES LEDDY, was knocked down in Atlantic street, by a party of men, and robbed of about $5 and his hat.

Generals WOOL and TWIGGS are here to at tend a meeting on Thursday next of Commissioners, having in charge the subject of the Military Asylum, of which they are members conjointly with Generals SCOTT, JESSUP, GIBSON, Surgeon-General LAWSON, and Adjutant-General COOPER.
With all our respect for the Supreme Court of Massachusetts, we find their late decision in the case of Simpkins vs. The Norwich and New-London Steamboat Company not quite satisfactory.

FLORIDA INDIANS.--We came through in the stage with Col. WINDER, of the U. S. Army, commander at Fort Myer. He says the delegation which went on to Washington left most of their presents at Fort Myer on their return, and have since declined receiving them, as they have failed to comply with their promise of emigration.
