The Lockport Courier speaks of the exhumation from beneath the floor of the old Temperance House in that village, of a document descended from Revolutionary times.

Yesterday morning, at 12 o'clock, M., a meeting, of the Catholic Clergy and Laity of New-York was held, pursuant to announcement, at Metropolitan Hall, for the purpose of presenting a ring, accompanied by an address, to the exiled prelate MANUEL JOSE DE MOSQUERA, Archbishop of Santa Fe de Bogota.
From the Evening Post. We have received the following note from Captain ERICSSON, in relation to the caloric engine which he has been constructing for the Evening Post: NEW-YORK, May 2, 1853.

The justification of Mr. Commissioner BARTLETT occupies one or two of our columns to-day. It is pretty thorough. Mr. BARTLETT surveys the proclamation of Gov. LANE critically, and runs through it the boundary between truth and error carefully.

General Remarks.--The Cherry is found in almost every part of Europe, also in the northern part of Africa, and in Asia, in which latter region it had its origin. It was brought by LUCULLUS, about half a century before the Christian era, from Cerasus, a city of Pontus, and from this its name is derived.

The document which we elsewhere repro duce from the Providence Journal, shows that France is disposed to push its demands upon King KAMEHAMEHA III. to extremities. The case is a painful one, and big with painful consequences.

The Committee met at 11 o'clock yesterday morning at the Astor House, pursuant to adjournment. The examination of JOSEPH MONCK resumed: I stated yesterday that a resolution was passed in June, 1850, creating the office of Actuary.

The night express train leaving Albany at 6 P. M., ran into an emigrant or cattle train going East just at the tunnel at the eastern end of this city last night. One car, loaded with cattle, was broken to pieces, and the cattle killed.

Mr. MONTECHI, of London, the friend and confidential agent of the renowned MARIO and GRISI, is now in this City to sign and interchange contracts for an American engagement with Mr. JAMES H. HACKETT; the preliminaries of which were agreed upon in England some months ago.

The trial of Scott, Doyle, Lavery and Magee, for burglary in the house of Col. J. M. Fessenden, at Jamaica Plains, in January last, was commenced before the Court of Common Pleas at Dedham, on Saturday last.

Our neighbor, the Journal of Commerce, whose general notions of trade are to the extreme of liberality to all alien interests and the reverse to our own, appears to grow uneasy at the course of the Foreign business this Spring.

THE ALDERMEN AND THE JUDICIARY.--Since the memorable contest between the members of the Common Council and the Superior Court in relation to the in junction against the grant of the Broadway Railroad, the City Fathers have exhibited a degree of petty spite and rancour against the learned Judges, which is quite unworthy of the great minds from which it emanates.

Early on Saturday morning, Lake Ontario witnessed another of those terrible calamities which have become so common of late that they fail to arrest attention unless accompanied by unusual recklessness or more than common loss of life.
None better than educated physicians, know the evils of over-eating or of living too well, and hence none better appreciate a dinner that is exactly right, and in all respects a good one.

THE GREATEST DISCOVERY OF THE AGE.--No remedy can be purchased equal to Dr. TOBIAS' Venetian Liniment, for the cure of dysentery, colic, sea-sickness, croup, chronic rheumatism, toothache, sore throat, coughs, cuts, burns, old sores, pains in the limbs, chest, back If it does not give relief, your money will be returned. Price 25 and 50 cents.

A tout seigneur tout honneur. In accordance with the sentiment of the proverb, I devote this initial paragraph to the Chief of the State. But I feel an embarrassment in approaching the august subject even at pen's length. His Majesty is in a delicate situation.

Judge GIBSON, of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania, and until recently, Chief Justice, died at 2 o'clock this morning, at the United States Hotel, in this city. He was one of the most distinguished members of the Bench in the United States, and had reached a very advanced age.

The semi-official returns of the Foreign Imports at the Port of New-York for the month of April, have just been made up, and present an aggregate larger by 47 per cent. than the corresponding month of 1852, viz.: $15,325,794, exclusive of $172,917 in Foreign Specie and Bullion.
The Union, this morning, denies, authoritatively, the statement that President PIERCE will shortly visit New Hampshire, and says he has no intention of leaving Washington at present.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--On Monday last, SHAKSPERE'S tragedy of "Macbeth" was produced at this establishment. The house was crowded, and many persons, we understand, were turned from the doors in consequence of inability to furnish accommodations.

The American Medical Association held their sixth annual meeting yesterday, in the Presbyterian Church, Bleecker-street, the President, Dr. BEVERLEY WELLFORD, in the Chair. The morning was occupied by the Committee of Arrangements, in receiving delegates from the several States.

MR. SOULE'S FLIGHT FROM FRANCE.--We met the other day, in reading the memoires of the great French author, ALEXANDRE DUMAS, a mention of the circumstances to which we are indebted for M. SOULE'S immigration to and settlement in the United States.

The Cabinet were engaged to-day upon Diplomatic and Home Appointments for New-York State, and it is understood made some progress, but will refrain from announcing further appointments until after the patronage of that State is disposed of, in order by sweeping the board at once to avoid the action of the disappointed.

From the Providence Journal. Private letters of recent date from Peru bring very important intelligence concerning these islands. The independence of the young kingdom is seriously threatened, and urgent demands for assistance have been forwarded to Washington, asking protection against the impending danger.

The Anti-Monopoly movement in New-Jersey begins to assume a hopeful shape. The press exhibits something like unanimity in regard to it. The Democratic side is silent, of course; gratitude forbids free discussion; but the Whigs and quondain independents are rapidly closing up their ranks, preparatory to a test struggle, which shall settle the question of State or Railroad definitely.

ATTEMPT TO KILL.-A German named CLEMAN LINKE, was yesterday afternoon arrested on a warrant, by officer DUNCAN, charged with shooting at a Mr. Sr UTZER, residing on the corner of Smith and Wyckoff-strects, with intent to kill. A difficulty has long existed between the parties, and on Tuesday afternoon LINKE met complainant, and told him he intended to kill him.

May has come in with its usual severity. This is May Day; but it might as well be the Idea of March-the winds are so high, blowing from the South with Auster-ity, and the dust flying everywhere. Seen from a short distance, Boston seemed yesterday and to-day, enveloped in a pale road colored atmosphere.

LIVES OF THE BROTHERS HUMBOLDT, ALEXANDER AND WILLIAM: From the German of KLENCKE and SCHLESIER; by JULIETTE BAUER. With portraits. New-York HARPER BROTHERS. The most world-renowned men of the last half century were born in the year 1769-to wit: NAPOLEON, WELLINGTON, SOULT, HUMBOLDT, and-no, not GOETHE;

The Association met yesterday (second day,) in Bleecker-street Prtsbyterian Church, at 9 A. M. There was a large attendance of delegates. Dr. E. L. BEADLE, Secretary, read the minutes, which were adopted.

The sixth lecture of Father GAVAZZI's Second Course was delivered last evening, in Metropolitan Hall. The attendance was not very large. The reverend padre said that the subject of the lecture of the evening was "PIUS IX." He would show them the character of that individual, in both a moral and a political point of viewas he had been fatal to the Church and to Italy.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Time: The subject of a Park or Parks on the upper part of the Island for the use of our rapidly-increasing population is one of great public importance, and in it the philanthropist as well as he who looks to the adorning of our noble city, have an equal in terest. I propose,

BERMUDA.--We have Bermuda dates to the 20th ult. The Bishop of Newfoundland, at present on a visit to Bermuda, which forms part of his diocese, has appointed Rev. F. J. LIGHTBOURN. of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States. to he his chaplain.

BOARD OF EDUCATION.-The regular monthly meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Education was held on Tuesday afternoon, the President, CYAUS P. SMITH, Esq., in the Chair, and twenty members present. In the absence of S. L. HOLMES, Esq., Secretary, on account of illness, J. G. BEROEN was appointed Secretary, pro rem. The minutes of the April meeting were read and approved.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A very few words will give the substance of the dispute between this country and Mexico in regard to the boundary, and this I purpose doing before it becomes involved by discussion beyond popular comprehension.

COMMON COUNCIL.-In the Common Council on Monday evening, the following among other business was transacted: A communication was received from the Mayor, vetoing the Resolution passed by the Common Council, on Monday evening the 25th of April, granting the Flushing Railroad the privilege of laying down a track through First and Second-streets, which was received and entered on the journal. After a long and warm debate,

Captain GREY and Captain GREY'S boy got away from Havana not a moment too soon. Tile Lady Suffolk which that skipper was charged with selling to the slave-trader, has returned from her voyage, and in spite of her notorious purpose, and the watch which it was reasonable to suppose would be maintained to catch her, has landed some six hundred slaves on the island. Of course,

The Constitutional Convention of the State of Delaware has decided that judges shall henceforth be chosen by the people. Salaries: chief justices, $1,500; chancellor and associate justices, $1,000 each. The convention voted that no clergyman, while officiating as such, shall be elected to any political office; also,

One of our Pittsburg cotemporaries is disposed to flare-up at the suggestion of Ohio retaliation in the article of Railway management. He even goes so far as to urge an immediate injunction against the Franklin Canal Company, under whose charter one of the links of the Lake Shore chain of road was built.

The Cincinnati difficulty and threatened riot to which we referred a few days ago grows less serious. The obnoxious Mayor has not yet resigned, though forced to back down from his high assumption in checking freedom of popular discussion.

In steamship Arabia, for Liverpool--Mr Addoms, lady and 2 daughters, Mrs. Bulpin, Miss Marshall, Mrs. Heidelback, servant and infant; Don Jose Pedroso and lady, Havana; Mrs. Giliespie, 3 children and main; Miss Cameron, Canada West; Miss Pincknett and servant, Mr. Chisobin, lady and child; Mr. Eho, lady and child; Mr. Shade and lady. D. s. Brown and lady. J. P. Brown, J. C. Howard and lady. A. Lewis, Rev. J. Eldridge,

The treaty with Mexico, guaranteeing and protecting the " Sloo Grant," negotiated by Judge CONKLING with Commissioners appointed by the deposed President CEVALLOS, has not yet been published. So far as affects the purposes of the grant, however, it must be in conformity therewith, as a treaty guaranteeing a grant, can by no possibility interfere or conflict with such grant.

A SUMMARY METHOD OF INJUNCTION--THE SIXTH AND EIGHTH-AVENUE CARS STOPPED.--The progress of the Sixth and Eighth-avenue cars was unexpectedly, and quite in a novel manner, arrested yesterday morning in Church-street. Some old houses in the rear of the spot lately occupied by the Fourth Universalist Church, in Murray-street, were being demolished,...

DEPARTURE FOR EUROPE.-The Royal Mail steamer Arabia sailed from this port at noon yesterday. Among her passengers were the Prince DD WIED and suite, Germany; Count DE PEDROSA and lady, Havana; Hon. HENRY J. RAYMOND, Editor of the DAILY TIMES, and Lieut. J. GRANT RAYMOND, Royal Navy.

The following statement of the recent difficulties with the Apache Indians in New-Mexico is communicated to the Ohio State Journal by a Santa Fe correspondent, who claims to have possessed superior opportunities for arriving at the truth of the matter: SANRA FE, Tuesday, March 29, 1853.

The Spirits have rapped another famous man's knuckles, and he confesses he thinks them no humbug. The marvelous tidings comes by way of yesterday's Washington Intelligencer. An article in that paper, entitled Impostures and Delusions, names the Rochester Knockings, with their kindred train of rascalities and abominations, as within the category of disorders which it may become necessary to suppress by the strong hand of the law.

The Address of Dr. WELLFORD, of Virginia, the President of the Medical Association, now in session in this City, was an eloquent exposition of the objects of the Association--a rehearsal of the good it had done, and an indication of certain modes by which it may do still more.

The U. S. Mail steamship Empire City, Capt. WINDLE, arrived yesterday morning from New-Orleans and Havana, bringing dates from the latter port to the 29th ult. On the 2d inst., in lat. 33[Degrees] 11', long. 76?? 40', the Empire City passed a bark showing a blue, white and red signal, with letter D in the centre, bound North.

A correspondent of the New-Orleans Crescent, writing from San Juan de Nicaragua, pats forth a statement of the recent difficulty at that port between the constituted authorities and the Accessory Transit Company, which places some of the facts in a new light. The particulars are interesting: SAN JUAN DEL NORTE. April 10, 1853.

The Committee met at 41/2 o'clock yesterday evening, and the cross-examination of JOSEPH MONX was resumed by Mr. FULLERTON. The witness observed that there had been a good deal of smirking and winking among the members of the C??mmittec of Managtment while he was giving his testimony; it was, no doubt, for the purpose of keeping up their courage.

THE BOARD OF ALDERMEN.-The Board met at 8 o'clock on Tuesday evening, at the Lyceum, pursuant to adjournment the previous evening. The President of the Board, Aldernan T. B. BETTS in the Chair. There was a full board. The President announced the appointment of the following Standing Committees for the ensuing year: Finance.-Aldermen James, Miller, and Lyon.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Your correspondent "Ignoramus," (quite a misnomer by the way,) has lately commented upon the Illustrated News, with considerable force. Per??nit me to offer a reply in favor of that journal. Its publishers stated, at commencement, "that no pains or expense would be spared to produce the best illustrated paper in the world."

Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera. Friday. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Macbeths King of Scotland. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The Rivals--Asmodeus. BURTON'S THEATRE.--A Bold Stroke of a Husband--Beeach of Promine.

It may not be generally known that the Legislature passed the bill incorporating the New-York State Agricultural College, since the thing was done only the day previous to adjournment. The Trustees named in the charter are John Delafield, of Seneca; Henry Wager, of Oneida; B. P. Johnson, of Albany;

HIPPODROME.--This extensive establishment is now in full operation. Two performances a day, afternoon and evening, absorb a good portion of our amusement loving citizens. The interior of the amphitheatre looks well in the day time. Ample light is thrown on the scene through the transparent roof, and a pleasant cool atmosphere may always he insured.

Mr. Commissioner BARTLETT has obliged the Providence Journal with the following epitomized account of that litigated region. So little is known, and so much is said about it, that the facts will be received with interest: Mesilla is the diminutive of the Spanish word mesa, table, i.e. table land, or plateau;

WINSTON, who was nominated to-day, is the Governor of Alabama, and a fire-eater. ExSenator CLEMENS may run against him on Union Ticket. Judge ALBERT CONSTABLE, of Maryland, is positively appointed Solicitor of the Treasury, vice Judge LE-GRAND who has declined.

Hon. JOHN BANNISTER GIBSON, Judge of the Supreme Court, and for many years Chief Justice of the State, died at 2 o'clock on Tuesday morning, at the United States Hotel, in Philadelphia, at the age of 73 years. His disease was an affection of the stomach. He was born in Carlisle, Pennsylvania, the year 1780.

By way of New-Orleans, we receive news from the City of Mexico to the 18th, and from Vera Cruz to the 22d ult. SANTA ANNA'S reception along the road from Vera Cruz to Mexico is said to have been most enthusiastic.

The State Canals have now been open over a fortnight, and notwithstanding the adverse influence of various rumors of breaks and obstructions, the business already indicates a season of unparalleled activity and profit. The capacity of the work will alone put a limit to the extent of trade.

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.-The receipts on this road for the month of April last amounted to $17,381 99. Receipts during the corresponding month of last year, $15,029 24-an increase in favor of April, 1853, aver April, 1852, of $2,352 75. During the month of April, 1852, there were $16,320 passengers conveyed over the road, and in 1853, same month, 20,190-increase, 3,770 passengers.

The Aldermen In Session. On Wednesday night, at the meeting of the Aldermen, R. T. COMPTON, President, was in the Chair. A quorum present. CORNER GROCERIES. Alderman TIEMAN rose and moved the reading of a message which he understood had been received from his Honor the Mayor.

MADRID, April 17.--The Ministerial programme promises the developement of the national credit and resources, but gives no indication of the course which will be followed on several important questions.

For the other City News of this morning, see Third Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars my be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Macbeth King of Scotlaand. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Combination Italian Opera. Don Giovanni.

The complimentary dinner to Hon. JOHN P. HALE took place this afternoon and evening in the immense hall over the Fitchburg Railroad De pot. Sixteen hundred people sat down to the banquet, about 300 of whom were ladies.

Having finished all their work, concluded their appointed labors, and adjourned sine die, the Association set "a thousand strong" at Metropolitan Hall, to partake of the great feast spread for them by their New-York brethren. Grace was said by Rev. Dr. KREBS.

The Porte has laid claim to three villages in the Eparchy of Karpenisi, and collected some troops in the neighborhood to give more effect to its demands. What reply the Greek Government has given to the note is unknown; but it immediately sent a reinforcement of 1,000 men to the garrison in the neighborhood.

There is an enterprise on foot in London and Scotland to push the North Britain Railway System into the Highlands of Scotland as far north as Inverness. The difficulty in the way has been the extravagant cost, hitherto, of building Roads through a mountainous region.

The President of the Piedmontese Council has submitted to the Chamber of Deputies a bill demanding a credit of 400,000 francs, which sum is to be distributed under the name of a loan among the Lombard refugees who had been naturalized in Piedmont, and whose property was confiscated by the Austrians.

Direct advices from Buenes Ayres to March 12, by the bark Manchester, at Salem, are confirmatory of the revolution being at an end. A private letter says: " The Commissioners have agreed upon a peace.

The equanimity of the Board of Aldermen was slightly disturbed on Wednesday evening by the advent of a petition from the Secretary of the City Temperance Alliance, accompanied by a note from Mayor WESTERVELT, to whom the petition had been originally forwarded, recommending it to the notice of the Board.

THE GREAT LOTTERY CASE.--The investigation respecting the great lottery case of a Broadway exchange broker, who victimized a down-town clerk out of some $8,000, is appointed to come off on Monday next, before Justice STUART, at the Jefferson Court.

The Royal Mail steamer Asia, Capt. LOTT, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having sailed from Liverpool at 10 1/2 o'clock on Saturday, 23d ult. The U. S. Mail steamship Franklin arrived off Cowes at midnight, Wednesday, 20th, and landed her mails and passengers on the morning of 21st.
The Canada Clergy Reserves bill was read a second time in the House of Lords last night (22d.) RASPAIL has been pardoned on condition that he will quit France.

TO THE PUBLIC.--I feel it a duty I owe to those who are suffering under the severe affliction of throat and lung complaints, to bear this unsought testimony to the superior skill and beneficial effects of Dr. LUTENER'S treatment, lately introduced into this country by the discoverer, Dr. LUTENER, an English physician of high reputation.

If, during the state of suspended animation occurring between election and inauguration, it ever entered into the dreams of General PIERCE that the early trials of his office would be confined to the distribution of patronage, the event must have proved a melancholy disappointment.

In order to facilitate the coming to a good understanding with Switzerland, the Austrian Ambassador has been instructed to treat verbally respecting the complaints made by the Federation. The New-Zurich Gazette, 17th, publishes the last note addressed to the Helvetic authorities.

POLICE APPOINTMENTS.--The First and Third Ward Aldermen met in Committee at the Mayor's Office on Wednesday evening, to complete the Police organization in those Wards. The First Ward Committee adjourned until this evening, without transacting any business.

The Coal business of the Lakes is growing into very considerable importance. The Cleveland Herald furnishes some interesting statistics on this subject, from which we learn that the average receipts of coal at Cleveland for ten years, from the year 1833 to 1842, inclusive, were 6,276 tons: and for the ten years from 1843 to 1853, inclusive, 59,840 tons.

The letters produced yesterday at the GAR DINER fraud trial evidently are the turning point in the case. JOHN CHARLES GARDINER, the writer, was a witness for the brother, to disprove the prosecution's evidence identifying GEORGE A. GAR DINER, the accused, at certain places in Mexico at specified dates.

BOARD OF EDUCATION.--This body held their monthly meeting at the City Hall, last evening. F SYLVESTER, Esq., President, in the Chair. A communication from the School Board of Finance transmitting the appropriations for the ensuing year, was received and ordered on tho minutes.

General SCOTT arrived here last evening in good health. The members of the Board of Commissioners upon the Military Asylum are all here, except Gen. GIBSON, who is expected to-night. Owing to his absence, it is understood nothing was done today.

By telegraph from Copenhagen we learn that the Chambers were dissolved. New elections were appointed; those of the Volksthing (Lower House) on the 27th of May, and those for the Landsthing (Upper House) on the 3d of June next. It is stated that the Ministers BANG and SIMON had resigned.

The Budget is out at last,--after being delayed as long as it decently could, doubtless in order to enable the ABERDEEN Cabinet to arrange its plans and consolidate the some what heterogeneous materials of which it is composed before settling down seriously to facts and figures.

The following Third Auditor's Clerks were removed to-day: Silas H. Hill, originally from New-Hampshire, but for some years a wealthy citizen of Washington, Wm. Hogaint, Jr., William Thompson, and Moore, of New-York, Winter, of Pennsylvania, P. M. Dickinson and Wm. Tyson, of Maryland, Quean, of the District Columbia, Coulson, of Virginia, Scott, of North Carolina, and Beatty, of Ohio. More removals are expected tomorrow.

The awful catastrophe of the loss of the Ocean Wave steamer, and a number of lives, noticed Monday morning, has cast a gloom over the community. In endeavoring to gather further particulars of the dreadful affair, we have ascertained that the second mate, who succeeded in rescuing Mrs. STEVENSON, and who was reported to have been afterwards lost, is among the list of those who were saved.

The Annual Message of Gov. SEYMOUR of Connecticut was delivered to the Legislature on Wednesday morning. It is of the moderate length,--as, Messages usually go,--of four columns; and treats of the affairs of the State in a strain which indicates a prosperous and settled condition of the finances.
Cato Smith, a wealthy colored man, and formerly a slave, recently committed suicide at West Chester, Pa., leaving a wife and children, and a thousand dollars in his pocket.

THE U. S. MAIL DETENTION ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--INVESTIGATION CONTINUED.--Yesterday at 3 o'clock, P. M., the judicial investigation was resumed in relation to the riotous proceedings of persons on the Hudson River Railroad, near St. John's Park. The accused parties were present with their Counsel, but the prosecutor, LEVI PECK, was absent, through sickness.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,) No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.)..Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

The brig Victorine from Rio de Janeiro, 29th of March, arrived here this morning. Her passage out and home has occupied eighty-two days. The following vessels had arrived at Rio: schr. John W. Muir, from Philadelphia; ship Mary and bark Plymouth, from New-York; schr. General Pierce from Boston.

The City Railroads are in embarrassed circumstances. One after the other has been enjoined and obstructed by divers legal impediments; and at last private enterprise has stepped in to complete the unfinished work of the Courts, by laying injunctions upon the track of the Sixth and Eighth-avenue Railroads.

If John Bull and Sawney had discovered the very pou sto of Archimedes, they could not go crazier than they are now about the authoress of Uncle Tom. Her progress, along with her reflectively distinguished lord and master, through the three kingdoms, is an amusing triumph.
The production of the letters from Mr. JOHN CHARLES GARDINER, in the interminable case wherein that gentleman's brother so conspicuously figures, has started the quidnuncs into unwented activity.

The Cabinet had been dissolved, and the following new appointments made: Foreign Affairs, M. VAN HALL; Justice, DUNNER CURTIUS; Home Office, M. VANREENEN; Finance, M. VAN DOORN. The resignation of the former Ministry arose from the recent attempt of the Pope to reestablish a Roman Catholic hierarchy in Holland.
On Thursday evening, after a short illness, SUSAN A., wife of Samuel R. Platt, and daughter of Peter Neefur. On Thursday, May 5, ISABELLA, wife of William Morrison, Sen., a native of Kelso, Scotland.

LAYING OF A CORNER-STONE.--The corner-stone of a new edifice for the Church of the Ascension, Protestant Episcopal, now worshiping in a hall at the corner of Sackett and Court-streets, was laid yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, at the corner of Third-place and Smith-street, to front on the latter street.

Prince MENSCHIKOFF'S propositions were still pending. He was reported to have threatened that if his demands were not speedily complied with he would leave Constantinople. Acting under the fear, real or exaggerated, of his presence there, measures of defence were going forward in all parts of the Turkish Empire.

An article in the Presse, headed "the Empire--1793 and 1853," has quite startled Paris by its boldness. It is the most unscrupulous attack upon Bonapartism that has appeared. The result will probably be a "warning." Political surmises were scarce and dull.
New-Orleans papers, of Friday last, are to hand. They contain Galveston dates to the 26th instant. The first five miles of the Harrisburg Railroad had been opened with great rejoicing.

From the London Daily News. Many people will observe, with regret, that Mrs. STOWE's stay in this country will be very short. The crowds that awaited her at every station from London to Glasgow show how great is the desire to obtain a mere sight of her.

The Crystal Palace is fast approaching to completion. Already the curved lines that indicate the dome are springing into the clear air. Already the morning sun strikes on the glazed portions, and illuminates the fabric till it gleams like a fairy palace. The hum of labor meets the morning, and the evening still finds it rising to heaven like a hymn of toil.

DEAR TIMES: You deserve a presentation of plate for your hearty warfare against abuses, only you have contrived to render presentations suspicious, and so barred remuneration in that line If you are not wearied to quiescence, by attacks upon derelict Street Commissioners, marketable Alderman, and hybrid women, will you make an effort to abate the nuisance of street-nudging.

The New-York appointments have many of them been settled today, the Softs stand a head and shoulders above their competitors, and MARCY is potential. The Secretary of State certainly seems to have allied himself completely to the popular wing of his party.

From the London Times In the present condition of Turkish affairs the public will probably receive with interest some brief notices of the men who compose the Sultan's administration. The Grand Vizier, MEHEMET ALI PACHA, brother-in-law to the Sultan, originally a midshipman in the Flag-ship of the Capondan Pacha Papoudsche Amet. was selected, in 1827.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is a mistaken notion to ascribe the bad effects resulting from crowded assemblies in illventilated rooms to a deficiency of oxygen gas and superabundance of carbonic acid, although more of the latter than usual is probably present; yet chemical analysis shows that there is as much oxygen as in the open air; there are always cracks and crevices through which it will intrude.

The town was startled yesterday forenoon by vague but dreadful rumors of a Railway disaster on the New-Haven Road, at the drawbridge at Norwalk, 45 miles distant from New-York. The first accounts were confined to the general statement that the passengers by the 8 o'clock Eastern Express train, hence for Boston, were the sufferers, and that 30 or 40 lives were lost ! These were too horrible,

The friends of the Union Theological Seminary will be glad to learn that the sum of One Hundred Thousand Dollars has finally been secured toward the proposed Fund for the complete endowment of the Institution. This amount, however, is not all that will be necessary for the attainment of the objects of the Seminary.

SCANDALOUS IMPOSITION OF CARTMEN.--Yesterdly afternoon a widow lady employed two carts (one the New-York and Erie Railroad's-no number-and the other No. 129) to convey two loads of furniture from the foot of Duane-street, New-York, to No. 34 South Fourthstreet, Williamsburg, at twelve shillings per load and ferrage. On arriving at the above number,

There are some who anticipate so steady and sure an advance of prices, as to invest money for long periods, depending upon vast profits in the end. In "the street," no practice is more common than to buy in and hold a promising stock against the chances of an advance.

A young man named MARTIN LAFFY, a notorious "short-boy," was arrested on Wednesday night by Licutenant DUNN, of the Twentieth Ward, and Officer BALDWIN, of the Eighth Ward, charged with committing burglaries in three houses in West Thirty-sixth-street.

My DEAR SIR: The decay of Statesmanship in the United States seems to be generally conceded. There are few topics of thought on which newspapers and reviews are more reflective; there are none on which they are more decided in their opinions.

Yesterday the medical guests of he tCity Physicians surrendered themselves into the hands of the Commitiee, beaded by Dr. GRISCOM. According to arrangement they met-a goodly number of them-at Pier No. 3, Nnrth River, on board the steamer Hero, at 9 A. M., and were speedily under way. As to the weather,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily limes: The article in your paper of the 5th inst., on the subject of "The Mexican Boundary," signed "W. H. S." is onc-sided, and partly erroneous in regard to the matter in dispute. For a correct view of the subject, the public should read the article in the National Intelligencer of the 5th of April, signed "P. F.,"

GUANO DISCOVERY.-We learn that parties in this city have ascertained the existence of a large deposit of Guano, on a barren and uninhabited island of the ocean, lying more than 200 miles from the mainland, and are negotiating with the United States Government for the protection of their rights, in case an effort should be made to secure these hitherto unknown treasures.
We learn from Albany that the Convention of Road Managers of the Central Line, have adopted the Syracuse valuation of the separate stocks, and a plan of operation for the Consolidated Road.

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.-The following Act, relative to the Long Island Railroad, passed the Legislature April 13, 1853: The People of the State of New-York, represented in Senate and Assembly, do enact as follows:

The St. Louis papers tell of a swindled man as follows: "An honest farmer of Indiana was in this city a few days since, in search of a man who had swindled him out of fifteen hundred dollars. He had entrusted the fellow with the sale of fifteen or sixteen mules, giving him a portion of the profits.

The death of Hon. ROBERT G. SHAW, of Boston, was announced briefly in our telegraphic news of Thursday. Mr. SHAW was a member of the first Common Council elected under the City Charter in 1822, and served in 1823, 1824, and 1833. Of the fifty-seven persons originally elected to both branches of the City Council, but twenty now survive. Mr.

The London News in the article which we copied yesterday on Mr. STOWE and his Cotten thrust, would make England independent of the American supply. She would be so, if she could, we know. The fact might teach us a lesson of commercial dignity ; we, who have means of being free, which she has not.

One of those frightful accidents which have of late been very frequent in our neighborhood, and the recurrence of which calls for some decided expression of public opinion, since either the law fails to bring the offending parties to trial, or juries refuse to convict, occurred yesterday morning at Norwalk, Ct.

The Cabinet meeting was but brief to-day. Mr. DAVIS is improving, but still confined to his room. Ex-Senator MERRIWEATHER, of Kentucky, is positively appointed Governor of New-Mexico. It is currently reported that the minister to Berlin has been appointed, but it is doubtful.

Turkey, feeling that she must follow close in the train of modern European civilization, possesses an Imperial cloth factory, an Imperial University, (its brick walls,) an Imperial Medical School, and an Imperial tannery, and other similar absorbents of the Imperial revenues.

FIRES.--About 6 o'clock yesterday morning, a house located at the corner of Hicks and Montague-streets, caught fire from the flue in the basement, through the carelessness of a servant. About $50 worth of damage was done. The flames were extinguished by the police of the First District.

Colored signals have for some time been used upon French railroads, as a means of acquainting the engineers of approaching trains with the state of the track, during the night. Each guardian has three bull's-eye lanterns, one white, one green, and one red.

The Committee met yesterday afternoon at 4 o'-clock. Present--Hon. D. TAYLOR, Chairman, CLAPP and CHAMPLAIN. The evidence on cross-examination, given by Mr. Monk, was read over to him, and subscribed by the witness. Examination in chief, resumed by Mr. SHANNON.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The last night of the combination Opera troupe attracted a large audience. " Don Giovanni" was well rendered, but not with the spirit and ensemble we have before witnessed. Possibly the consciousness that this was the last night of an unsuccessful campaign had an influence on the artistes.

MARRIED. In San Francisco, March 30, before Orrin Bailey, Esq., Lewis D. Reed to Miss Mary, daughter ot the late James Nesbitt, both of the City of New-York. In San Francisco, March 31, by Justice P. W. Shepheard, Frederick Ballhaus to Catharine Seemuller, both of San Francisco. On board ship Orpheus, January 31, by Rev. Mr. Marsh, Thomas M. Crockett to Miss Catharine Freeman, both of San Francisco.

[From the Boston Journal.] It will be remembered that some two months ago, the ship Golden Light, From this port for California, was struck by lightning and burnt, when only a few days out, and that her passengers and crew took the boats, four in number.

USE OF FIREARMS.-We learn from a gentleman who came passenger over the Long Island Railroad, on Friday, that on Wednesday last, at Hoppogue, Smithtown, Suffolk County, a girl named LAVINIA CONLEY, 9 years of age, was mortally wounded, by the accidental discharge of a pistol, by a colored man, whose name could not be ascertained. The contents took effect in the forehead of the girl. The negro was arrested immediately,

Tile Committee of the Board of Aldermen on Lamps and Gas held an adjourned meeting on last Friday, in the City Library. Present, Aldermen FRANCIS and WARD. The Company appeared by counsel, as on former occasions. Prof. W. H. ELLIOT was cross-examined by Mr. SMITH, and stated that he had examined the tables of the Report of the Committee, and compared them with URE'S Dictionary, p. 575;

The Washington Gossip in the Republic of yesterday contains the following: An impression has prevailed for a day or two that Secretary GUTHRIE has decided the 20 per cent. extra duty question in favor of the claimants--Messrs. MAXWELL, BOKEE, and other collectors, naval officers, and surveyors of three or four large ports.

There was a large audience assembled at Metropolitan Hall, Friday evening, to hear the Reverend Padre's discourse on " the Inquisition, especially at Rome, and the MADIAI family." He was, as usual, received with loud demonstrations of welcome. His discourse was in some respects a repetition of that delivered at the Tabernacle on the first part of his subject, with new matter introduced; and a long comment on the MADIAI trial,

The arrival of the steamer El Dorado, brings us California advices to the 9th of April. They are of less than ordinary interest. That a vast deal of disorder exists in the southern parts of the State; that murders of the highest atrocity are of daily occurrence; and that justice fails to secure and punish the criminals, are not pleasant tidings;

From the St. Louis Republican. Rev. Dr. WM. S. PLUMMER, of Baltimore, delivered an eloquent and impressive discourse in behalf of the New-York Bible Society last evening, at Rev. Dr. HUTTON'S Church, to a house well filled, in spite of the hard rain which continued late into the evening. His text was from Luke xii. 52: "We unto you lawyers! for ye have taken away the key of knowledge."

The public interest in the terrible tragedy which occurred on Friday at South Norwalk, continued to increase during the whole of Saturday, and every train that arrived at Norwalk, both from this City and the East, was crowded with relatives of the deceased, with parties anxious to discover the fate of some friend known to have been in the ill-fated train, or with curious strangers eager to gaze upon the scene of the calamity.

The Convention of Delegates representing the separate Roads on the New-York Central line, which met at Albany on 4th inst., adjourned last Saturday. The rules for consolidation previously agreed upon at Syracuse, were substantially adopted, and the premiums then scaled were confirmed.

STEALING ROPE AND CHAIN.-Two notorious characters named James Mullen and Barney McLaughlin. arrested in the Second District for stealing chains and a rope from Mr. Henry Breslin, at the foot of Washington-st. were brought before Justice SMITH, on Friday, tried, and sent to the Penitentiary. There are several other charges pending and against these parties.

The organ of the Government at Washington announces that the Commissioners, to locate the Western Military Asylum, have fixed upon Harrodsburg Springs, Ky., as the seat of this institution.

The U. S. Mail steamer El Dorado, Capt. DAVENPORT, arrived at this port, yesterday at noon, bringing the U. S. Mail and passengers, from steamer Columbus, which left San Francisco on the 9th of April. The El Dorado brings 300 passengers, and $50,000 on freight.

THOMAS M. RODNEY, Consul at Matanzas, will be retained, in consequence of the request of the late Vice-President KING. It is said that Mr. SCHROEDER, son-in-law of Col. SEATON, of the National Intelligencer, will be continued as Charge des Affaires at Stockholm.

The Annual Sermon before the American and Foreign Christian Union, was preached, last evening by Rev. Dr. KENNEDY, of Brooklyn, in Mercer-street Presbyterian Church. The services commenced by singing the 27th Psalm, followed by an impressive prayer by Rev. Dr. KEMBLE.

The Thirtieth Anniversary of this Society, to have been held at the Dutch R. F. Church, Lafayette-place, last evening, was postponed in consequence of the stormy weather. Rev. NATHANIEL WEST, of Pittsburg, reserved his discourse, prepared for the occasion, until the evening of the celebration, of which due notice will be given.

In steamship Florida, for Savannah-Dr. Leonard, T Trenary, J. Olmstead, J. McCosker, J. B. Bond, P. Smith, A. Benedict, Mr. Rodewald, Mrs. Callahan and children, C. II. Warner and lady, A. H. Chandler, lady and children, and 7 in the steerage.

By the arrival of the steamship Mexico, at New-Orleans, we have received Galveston dales to the 26th ult. The Brazos and Trinity are still navigable for steamboats, but there is but little cotton left on these rivers. The Southwestern American announces P. H. BELL and THOS. W. BLAKE, by authority, as candidates for Congress.

By the arrival of the El Dorado, we have received later dates from South America, with files of Panama papers to the 26th April. The Panama Herald gives the following account of the discovery at Old Panama of supposed Roman coins, nearly sixteen hundred years old.

The services in advance of the Anniversary of the above named Society, took place last evening in the Church of the Puritans, (Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S,) in Unionsquare. The attendance was not very numerous, owing no doubt to the inclemency of the weather. The exercises of the evening commenced with appropriate singing and reading of the Scriptures, after which a fervent prayer was offered up by Rev. Dr. CHEEVER.

From the Cincinnati Gazette, 4th. The Committee of one hundred having called a Mass Meeting of the citizens, to take measures in relation to the late conduct of Mayor SNELBAKER, a large assemblage of citizens met in Fifth-street, Market-Space, yesterday afternoon, and organized by electing LEWIS BROADWELL, President.

Spring is the Autumn of dwelling-houses. Like sere and yellow leaves, the buildings which American energy pronounces antiquated at ten years of age, begin to fall with the first of May. There is mortar among us in minute particles, insinuating itself into our eyes, and at night, in disrobing ourselves, we find calcareous reminders of our morning's walk lodging in obscure corners and plaits of our dress. We ride in a city car,

A man in health has a good deal of strength in his muscles, and his bones are full of marrow. It is hard work to choke him down. He loves to work, and until he has smothered it in rich puddings, or buried it up under bushels of beef steaks, or slaughtered poultry, to be idle is to he unhappy. However,

The Twenty-fifth Anniversary of this Society was celebrated in the Metropolitan Hall, NewYork, last evening. P. PERIT, Esq., President of the Society. occupied the Chair. There was a very numerous audience in attendance. The exercises of the occasion were opened with appropriate religious services, conducted by Rev. Dr. CHICKERING, of Portland, Me.

Monday morning, May 9, ADELA LOUISE, youngest child of Commander Henry Eagle, U. S. Navy, aged 18 months and 16 days. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of his father-in-law, Sheldon Smith, Esq., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral at 11 o'clock on Wednesday, at No. 74 Union-place. The remains will be taken to Newark, N. J., for interment.

A large meeting of the guests of the " Committee of Arrangements and Reception" of New-York, (members of the American Medical Association,) assembled on the steamer Hero, on return from the public Institutionis of New-York, on Friday, May 6. 1653. Dr WORTHINOTON HOOXER, of New-Haven, was called to the Chair.

HERRING, situated on the corner of Hudson and West Thirteeath streets.

OPERATIC.--Possibly in. a week from this date another Opera Company will be in operation. it will consist of all the old artistes minus Madame ALBONI. This lady has been thrown overboard; not so much from envy, as from an idea entertained by one of the gentlemen singers, that she is only a third or fourth rate attraction, and that he (the gentleman singer) is, or ought to be the greatest of all living artistes.

There was some talk on Saturday, in the business circles here, and a movement to the same point in the Connecticut Legislature at Hartford, in regard to the money indemnity to which Railroads should be subjected in cases like the melancholy loss at Norwalk. There would just now, we think, be a general,

The excitement aroused by the terrible tragedy at Norwalk, is not likely to die away very speedily. The citizens of that village have taken active steps to pre.,ent, if an expression of public indignation can prevent,-the recurrence of such a catastrophe, along the line of the New-Haven Railroad.

OLE BULL is doing a good work for the Norwegians in America. The statements of his enterprise in Pennsylvania are already familiar. At Chicago, last week, there was a gathering of his countrymen, at which he made a speech, and was rapturously received. The Norwegian Church was crowded with Norsemen.

CHILD STOLEN.-On Saturday evening, Mr. JAMES McMANUS, residing in South Third-street, Jersey City, went to market with his wife, leaving their child asleep in the cradle. When they returned the child had been taken, and up to Sunday afternoon had not been discovered or heard of by its parents.

FATAL ACCIDENTS.-A man named MILES GILLEROY was conveyed to the Hospital, at Flatbush, in ill health. On Saturday night, it is supposed that he walked in the corridor to the end window, and, through weakness, lost his balance, and fell to the ground, where he was found dead the next morning. Coroner BALL yesterday held an inquest, and a suitable verdict was rendered.

The Austrian press gives us little now about Hungary. What few journals we get from Pesth, are evidently published under the strictest Police-censorship. Travelers are rigidly excluded from the interior.

THE LACHINS CANAL.-We understand that the Provincial Government has made a very extensive purchase of land, adjoining the Lachine Canal and the River. The purchase in all amounts to 115 acres, say 27 acres on the north bank of the canal, immediately above Wellington-street bridge, and the remainder on the south side, extending from a point on the canal to a point on the St. Lawrence, including the whole of Point St. Charles.

The Committee met at the Astor House yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Present: Hon. D. B. TAYLOR and A. M. CLAPP. Cross-examination of Joseph Monk resumed by Mr. Fullerton. Q --When did you make out this extra bill against the Art Union ? what was the date ? A.-I think about a few days previous to its date; sever made out a bill previous to that time for extra services.

The great event of the week is over. JOHN SLIDELL, as the telegraph has told you, has been elected United States Senator, to fill the vacancy of Mr. SOULE! When the report reached here of the coalition between SLIDELL and SOULE, no one thought for moment that he could be elected.

Public opinion appears to have settled pretty firmly upon the guilt of Mr. EDWARD TUCKER, Engineer. There is a decided disposition to concentrate the whole storm of vengeance upon his head. The Company has no hesitation in offering him up as a scape-goat. Mr. TUCKER may therefore be considered as fairly implicated. He is doubtless, criminal.

We give place to the following acknowledgment with much pleasure: Capt. NYE begs leave to acknowledge the receipt from the State Department, through Judge BRONSON, of the subjoined copy of a communication from Her Britannic Majesty's Minister, accompanied by the beautiful and valuable articles therein mentioned.

I hasten to relieve the anxiety which the initial paragraph of my last letter may have caused, by announcing his Imperial Majesty's recovery from the topical indisposition therein spoken of It was really a more serious matter. than citizens of a regular constitutionally governed Republic, might, at first blush, take it to be.

A great fire occurred at Gorgona on the 26th ult., breaking out in the office of JAMES S. HERMANN Co. The offices of Messrs. WILLAcy Co., and HERMANN Co., were destroyed. The fire spread very rapidly, and there is not a house standing between the river and Barbarita. The Union, St. Louis and American Hotels, are all leveled to the ground.

Nothing of interest transpired at the Cabinet meeting to-day. No appointment was announced. Large sums of gold are going South and West, from the North and East, in charge of an agent of the Treasury, notwithstanding the fact that the rate of exchange is against the South and West. Merchants at St. Louis, at the same time, are sending gold to New-York to make payments. s.

M., on Saturday, at which time the old force was disbanded and the new ones entered on duty. The members of the old force reappointed are in italics:

RESCUE FROM A HORRIBLE DEATH.-About 11 o'clock Saturday night, a man named GEORGE SWAN, while wending his way home to Clinton-avenue, through Flushing avenue, fell or walked off from the road near the foot of Clinton-avenue into the Wallabout Bay Flats. The tide being out he sunk immediately into the mud, until only the top of his head and face was above the surface.

Traveling Notes-Gaston to Raleigh-Raletgh to Fayetteville--Working a Pastoge by Stage Coach-The Piney Woods-The Wealth of this District. The train left Gaston an hour and a-half after its advertised time. The road excellent and speed good, a heavy U rail having lately replaced the fat one.

Oregon, with all its boasted natural advanstages and productive power, is at this time bone of the very best of markets for all the necessaries of life. The people of this place are dependent upon "the States" for the butter, the bacon, the dried fruit, and a considerable portion of the flour of daily consumption. Cotton and woolen goods, hardware, crockery and good furniture are all imported.

General LANE'S apologists, and those writers who condemn the course pursued by Commissioner BARTLETT, in running the boundary line between Mexico and the United States, make one point which has the merit of plausibility until examined.

Pursuant to notice previously given, Father GAVAZZI delivered his last lecture in public in NewYork, at Metropolitan Hall, on Saturday evening, before a numerous audience. The reverend lecturer was very warmly received upon making his appearance:...

A CHILD BURNED TO DEATH.-A few days since a little child of HOWELL PHILLIPS, Good Ground, Suffolk County, lost its life by its clothes taking fire during the temporary absence of the parents. NAME CHANGED.-The name of a little village one and a-half miles east of Hempstead, Queens County, has been changed from "Turtle Hook" to "Union Dale."

The community here were not a little astonished at the decision Judge CRAWFORD, (presiding at the trial of Dr. GEORGE A. GARDINER,) against the admissibility in evidence, of the letters written by JOHN CHARLES GARDINER to certain parties in Mexico. This ruling may be good law,

Died on Saturday, 30th ult., at the advanced age of 120 years, MONICA, a servant woman of Mrs. ELIZA LANCASTER, of Cobb Neck, Charles County, Md. Incidents which she frequently related, furnished data front which her age could be nearly ascertained. She was a servant of uncommon industry and fidelity. She was devotedly at tached to her mistress.

THE TEXAS INDIANS-We learn from a gengentleman recently arrived from Texas, that Major G. T. HOWARD, the Indian Agent, has accepted offers made to him by several public-spirited city zens of that State, donating a large quantity of at present unoccupied land for the temporary settlement of the wild tribes now starving among the bar-ren rocks to which the necessities of the settlers have driven them.

The steamship Daniel Webster has arrived at this port from San Juan. She brings San Francisco dates of the 16th of April, one week later than previous advices by the El Dorado at New-York, having connected with the Pacific steamship Brother Jonathan,, which left San Franciseo on the above date.

Yesterday was anniversary day for the boys. All these other days are common; on them the children go to school, peddle matches, trundle hoops, do anything that pertains to a week day. But yesterday, they were dressed in their Sunday clothes, wore blue ribbons on the left breast, and marched in procession.

EXPLOSION-FOUR PERSONS INJURED.--Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, an explosion occurred at the Resin Oil and Varnish Factory belonging to the Gas Company, in North Eighth near Eighth-street, by which two men are supposed to be fatally injured, another man badly, and a fourth slightly, injured.

FATHER GAVZZI.--'The Padre delivered a lecture in the York-street Methodist Episcopal Church, Jersey City, last evening, on " The Popish System as incompatible with Civil and Rellgious Liberty." There was a large audience present. The church was about threefourths full. The lecture was listened to with marked attention.

THE LIABILITY OF RAILROADS.-A case of considerable interest to the public and Railroad Companies, has just been decided in the U. S. Circuit Court, now in session in this City, Judge DRUMMOND presiding. The parties were JOHN KUTER, a Pennsylvania Dutchman, as plaintiff, and the Michigan Central Railroad, as defendant, and two days have been occupied in hearing evidence and arguments of counsel.

SIR: I have the honor to present to the Department of the Interior the following observations in defence of the establishment of the initial point on the rio Grande at 32 22' north latitude, and the line of boundary from that point westwardly, connecting it with the river Gila.

The Fourth Anniversary of the American and Foreign Christian Union was held at Metropolitan Hall yesterday morning. Rev. Dr. DE WITT, President of the Society, occupied the Chair. After the usual religious exercises, the Treasurer's Report was read by Mr. VERNON, the General Agent, showing that the receipts of the Society during the year ending April 1, were $67,507, being an advance on the preceding year of more than $11,000. The expenditures were $65,742,

MAN KILLED ON THE NORWICH AND WORCESTER RAILROAD.--About 61/2 o'clock Sunday morning, says the Boston Courier, as the train from Norwich and Worcester, was approaching Westboro', the engineer discovered a man lying on the track, between the rails, and promptly reversed the engine and sounded the alarm.

There were, altogether, about 1,100 children, and one hundred and fifty teachers, and active friends of the Schools together. The exercises,

We have Barbadoes dates to April 8. March was not a very favorable month for crops, yet better than February was. Great improvements have been introduced in the manufacture; one of them, that has been most highly extolled, is the use of a centrifugal machine, for separating the molasses after the sugar has been boiled by the Gadesden of Vacuum Pans; which it effects in a marvelously short time, and leaves the sugar almost colorless.

Reform in railroading, that a ticket to the next city may not take us through to the last depot; reform in stealmboating, that sixty of us may not be scalded and twenty of us slain, when a party is obliged to make a trip on board these modern substitutes for war and the plague, for thinning out the ranks of mankind;

BODIES FOUND DROWNED.--The body of a young child washed ashore, yesterday morning, at the foot of Van Brunt-street, and was found by the Third District Police. The body of the man noticed as having been drowned at the Gas House Dock, was found yesterday in that vicinity by officer WOODS, of the Second District Police.

The California news, received this morning by way of New-Orleans, brings the melancholy tidings of yet another steamboat catastrophe, by which twenty persons have lost their lives, and thrice that number have suffered serious injury. Beside this calamity,

The Board sat on Monday evening-RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Fifteen members were present. Salariess of Police Captains-Alderman HALEY presented a petition from the Captains of Police, applying for an increase of salary. Alderman DENMAN moved that the Committee en Salaries and Officers be instructed to examine into the salaries of all the officers of the Comnon Council, and arrange them on some scale of proportionate equality.

Gen. M. HUNT has left Galveston for NewOrleans, in order to endeavor to secure the advantages of united action in the Railroads which will centre in Fulton, Ark., western frontier. Gen. HUNT and his associates have determined to run the Central, Railroad from Galveston to that point in as nearly a direct line as possible.

In another column of the DAILY TIMES will be found the Report of Mr. Commissioner BARTLETT to the Secretary of the Interior, in reference to the Boundary Survey. This, it will be remembered, is the document to which the Commissioner has appealed, as decisive of the business.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Mr. WALLACK, after a respite of some months, returned to his friends and patrons on Monday evening. SHAKSPERE'S comedy of " Much Ado about Nothing " was produced. We were unable to attend, and must therefore take another opportunity of speaking of the merits of the performance.

The provincial press occasionally indulges a little quiet humor over the doings in this Great Metropolis. The Philadelphia papers are not always so quiet, but we are accustomed to their jokes. They date from the days of Mr. CHANDLER and the United States Gazette.

TREATY WITH TIIE INDIANS OF THE GREAT PRAIRIES.-We learn that the veteran and experienced Indian Agent for the Upper Platte and Arkansas, Major THOMAS FITZPATIRICK, has been appointed to hold a council this Summer with the wild Indians of the Great Plains bordering on the Ar. kansas, consisting of the Camanches, Kiowas, .c., for the purpose of making a treaty with them, of a character similar to that with the Laramic Indians last year,

The journals of Panama are making merry with the lives of Consular Agents at that interesting spot on tile earth's surface. In these days of insane scrambling for the loaves and fishes, it is a pleasing reflection to the successful candidate for a diplomatic post, that he has fairly bitten at a most unpleasant hook.

The Boston Advertiser has received intelligence of an act of great liberality on the part of Russian merchants. LOUISIANA-The Legislature of Louisiana adjourned sine die, on the 30th ultimo. The great measures of the session were the acts, heretofore noticed, subscribing three and a half millions on the part of the State to the Jackson, Shreveport and Opelousas Railroads.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The Common Council held their regular weekly meeting at the City Hall, on Monday evening. Among other business transacted, was the following: The Mayor vetoed the reference of the Flushing Railroad question to the Railroad Committee. The Kings County Chronicle was appointed one of the Corporation newspapers.

The Boston Courier says the name of the young man so seriously injured at the NewBedford Tnd Taunton accident was DAVIS. He belonged to Fall River. His recovery is doubtful. His lower limbs were thought' to be utterly paralyzed. He was taken to Taunton for medical assistance. The axle was a new one, and used for the first time on Saturday.

THE MIILITARY ASYLUM.--The selection of the Harrodsburg Springs, with two hundred acres attached, for the site of the proposed Western Military Asylum, in preference to the Blue Licks, gives eminent dissatisfaction to the friends of the latter locality now in Washington. Some of them cannot realize how it comes that General SCOTT didn't cotton as much to the Bluc Licks on this occasion, as before the Presidential election.

THE ELECTION OF STATE TREASURER--DECISION OF THE COURT OF APPEALS.--The decision of the Court of Appeals in the case of the People vs. Cook, (claiming to be State Treasurer,) was pronounced at the late term of the Court, adversely to the claims of the defendant.

The Anniversaries get bravely on. The City is full of strangers, who go up to Metropolitan Hall, or down to the Tabernacle, in crowds, to attend these annual gatherings. At the meeting of the friends of Christian Union, yesterday, the Hall was full almost to suffocation. It is true,

FROM PORTO CADELLO.--We have advices from Porto Cabello to the 24th April. The political news is quite unimportant. The appointment of Mr. J. J. GOLDING, an old resident of Laguayra, as U. S. Consul at that port, has given general satisfaction. The markets were firm. Coffee,

This Society held their Anniversary Meeting in the Tabernacle, Broadway, at 71/2 o'clock. The attendance was numerous. The exercises commenced by the choir singing an anthem; after which, Rev. Mr. HOWE offered ,up prayer. Mr. McELLIOOTT, Corresponding Secretary, read the Report. He stated that the general result of the working of the Society, for the past year, was very satisfactory.

INDIAN FIGHT.--The St. Paul Pioneer of the 28th, says: About two weeks since a party of Chippewas killed a Sioux Indian near Six's Village. CROW'S bank, in retaliation, formed a war party, went up the St. Croix, and there killed a Chippewa and returned home. The Cippe was formed a large war party and followed the Sioux down. The accident on the Taunton Branch Railroad on Saturday afternoon, reported by Telegraph, occurred a mile and a half below Taunton, the axletree of the tender giving out, and causing a succession of mishaps. The tender was immediately thrown down an embankment, some thirty feet. The baggage car, directly behind,

From the Alton Telegrraph. From all accounts, the number of emigrants who will take the overland route this Spring for California will fall far below that of former years. Last season the emigration across the plains was estimated at upwards of fifty thousand, while this season it is not expected to exceed twenty.

EPISCOPAL LIBERALITY.--The Rector, Rev. Mr. CANFIELD, of Christ Church, Brooklyn, convened a meeting of his congregation on the 2d of May, for the purpose of calling their attention to it floating debt on the Church, amounting to $10,000. A subscription was im mediately taken up, and one-half the amount collected before the meeting broke up.

MISSISSIPPI.--The Democratic State Convention of Mississippi has made the following nominations: For Governor, JOHN J. McRAE; Treasurer C. F. Hemingway; Auditor, Madison AcAfee; Secretary of State, W. C. Muse; Attorney General, D. C. Glen; Fifth Congressional District, William Barksdale; Third Congressional District, O. H., Singleton.

From the Washington Union. It is manifest That the native Government of the Sandwich Islands exists only by sufferance. It is equally manifest that it is rapidly sinking front an inherent decay which nothing can arrest. In 1790, the aboriginal population of the Hawaiian Islands was but little less than 400,000. In 1830, it was but 150,000; and by the census of 1850, it was computed at scarcely 80,000 souls. In the precedine year.
