The undersigned were appointed a Committee at the great meeting held at the Metropolitan Hall, on the 5th of March last, to promote the measures of Reform in our City Government, that were then recommended by the unanimous voice of that meeting. These measures embraced appropriate remedies for the great evils under which the City is still suffering, to wit, a defective Charter, and incompetent and unfaithful public officers and representatives in the Common Council.

THE LATE ABEL L. PEIRSON, M. D.--The Salem Register says: Dr. PEIRSON has been, for a whole generation, one of the most eminent physicians and surgeons in this region, and has generally been consulted in the most difficult cases within a very extended circuit.

The annual meeting of the shareholders of the New-York and New-Haven Road takes place to-day. The Board of Directors will be chosen for the ensuing year. The present Board, through their President, have addressed a Circular to the shareholders, a copy of which appears on another page, touching the accident at Norwalk.

The Comercio de Tampico of the 20th of last month contains the following proclamation by the Governor of the State of Tamaulipas, dated Victoria, April 6: The Congress of the State of Tamaulipas has decreed as follows: ARTICLE 1. The liberal institutions of this State are hereby declared to be endangered by the agreement made on the 6th of February, in the City of Mexico, by the Chiefs of the United Military Divisions.

The Grand Jury of Hillsborough County, Florida, in their late general presentment, declare against the application of force, and avow their preference of a course of policy which shall quietly crowd out the Indians by settlement. They suggest a survey of the Peninsula, and a grant of 160 acres to each settler, with an armed force of Rangers operating in advance of the settlements to protect them.

I never see a willow but I think of Barbara's song in "Othello," with which poor Desdemona comforted herself when, like the unfortunate Barbara, she felt that the hour of her desolation had come. "She (Barbara) had a song of a willow," said Desdemona, "an old song it was, but it expressed her fortune, and she died singing it."

The examination of Mr. HALE, in reference to the seizure of war rockets at his factory at Rotherhithe, took place at the Bow-street Police-station on the 23d ult, but no decision was given by the presiding Magistrate.

For the other City News of this morning, see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Macbeth King of Scotlaand. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Merchant of Venice--A Handsome Husband. BURTON'S THEATRE--Bold Stroke for a Husband--Obstinate Family-Deeds of ??

A good deal of confusion vexes the public as to the distinctive characters of the two Anti-Slavery Societies that held their Anniversaries yesterday. Agreeing essentially in very many things they do not by any means enjoy each others heartiest good wishes, nor fancy being confounded.

MY DEAR SIR: There are few subjects that interest me more than the relations of sense to spirit. I pass, as yet, for a young man; but there are certain things that I notice in my own experience which tend to direct my mind in a peculiar line of meditation. Let me see if I can convey my reflections.

Judge BURNET died in this city to-day. The Bar of Hamilton County met, and passed appropriate resolutions relative to his decease, and resolved to attend his funeral in a body. All the Law Courts will adjourn over on the day of the funeral.

A gentleman of Henry County, Ala., has published a description of a new invention of a diving bell." It is to examine the bottom of the ocean. Take a bolt of iron of any size or length, say 7 feet square, with a wheel at each end and in the centre, so that if the boat or machine should turn over, it will keep running.

It is reported that JACKSON, of Georgia, a Unionist, will obtain a foreign mission. It is contemplated that the appointment will be made with a view to conciliating HOWELL COBB. Governor HUBBARD will get the prize of the Consulate at Honolulu.

A young man of about 19 years of age says the Fredonia Advertiser, named Charles Cooper, son of Mr. Benj. Cooper, was killed on Saturday last, while coupling the express freight train on the New-York and Erie Railroad, at Perrysburg.

The Portuguese Ministry is tottering. The French Emperor has made a demand on the Portuguese Government for the payment of the French subjects having claims arising out of the loan to Don MIGUEL. The Portuguese Ministers are in the utmost alarm at this demand, and have solicited the intervention of the British Ambassador.

The Anti-Slavery Society. The Twenty-second Anniversary of the American Anti Slavery Society, representing the extreme views of the Abolitionists, was held on Wednesday, at 10 o'clock A.M., in the Chinese Assembly Rooms. The room was filled at an early hour by a respectable audience. When FREDERICK DOUGLASS appeared in the room, he was greeted with considerable applause.

In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, May 11, May 11, CORNELIUS WENDELL, fourth son of Alfred and Anna L. Clapp, in the 5th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, on Friday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from No. 254 Hicks St., Brooklyn.

Among the very readable books of Literature, I have been particularly interested in an English work that bears the definite title of Self-Formation, or, the History of an Individual Mind. I call that a definite title. It answers to the nature of the volume, and I like names and natures to harmonize.

Among the victims sacrificed at Norwalk, on Friday last, was Dr. WILLIAM CECIL DWIGHT, of Moscow, Livingston County, N. Y. He was the eldest son of the late CECIL DWIGHT, of Northampton, Mass., and a nephew to the late Dr. DWIGHT, of Yale College.

The bark Shirley, Capt. SMITH, arrived at Baltimore on Wednesday from Liberia. Bishop SCOTT, of the M. E. Church, came passenger, after a brief sojourn in the new Republic. Dates are brought down to the 2d of March.

American and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society. The American and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society held their Anniversary on Wednesday evening, May 11, 1853, ??t the Broadway Tabernacle, which was well filled. ARTHUR TAPPAN, Esq., took the chair. The exercises began with a voluntary upon the organ. The Scriptures were read, and prayer offered, by Rev. Mr. FREEMAN, of Brooklyn, a colored clergyman. An abstract of the Annual Report was then read by the Secretary, LEWIS TAPPAN, Esq.

The information respecting French designs upon the Sandwich Islands, published in the TIMES some days ago, has excited lively disputes. The Courrier des Etats Unis of this City, always safe and judicious where its national prejudices are not concerned, thought proper to discredit the facts, and rather charged upon the Providence Journal, which first disclosed them, a blundering wish to excite disturbance, without very scrupulous regard to truth.

THURSDAY, MAY 12. American Bible Society.--Bible House, Astor-place, 9 A. M. Public meeting, Metropolitan Hall, 10 A.M. Institution for the Deaf and Dumb.--Metropolitan Hall, 4 1/2 P.M. Tickets, 12 1/2 cents. Associated Alumni Union Theological Seminary.--Chapel of the Institution, Annual Meeting, 3 P. M.

The London News contains the following letter from Gov. KOSSUTH to Capt. MAYNE REID, with an accompanying note from the latter gentleman. KOSSUTH'S letter is dignified and convincing: To the Editor of the News. SIR: M. KOSSUTH has addressed to me a letter, full of startling facts and puzzling questions.

To the Editors of the Courier and Enquirer: I noticed an editorial article in your paper this morning in which it is stated, on information, that nearly two-thirds of the flagmen who gave security to the traveler upon the Hudson River Railroad have been discharged.

The oath of office was administered, to-day, to several clerks recently appointed, among them EDWARD H. FULLER, who was shot by SCHAUMBERG, who appeared to have fully recovered his health. The three most prominent candidates for the Chargeship to the Hague are WALL, STEVENS, and VANDERPPOOL.

The news from abroad is unusually vapid. Three or four of these Spring days are insufficient to get up a respectable freight of incidents to burden a steamer withal. In English political circles, and especially in that inner circle, the House of Commons, the Budget is the principal subject of discussion.

A Correspondent of the Courrier des Etats-Unis has been at some pains to refute and discredit the ingenuity of Rev. Mr. HANSON. His latest stroke, and apparently a mortal one, appeared, yesterday, in the form of an affidavit from the mother of Mr. WILLIAMS, attesting the non-regal nativity of the child. The following is the document:

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Having had some fifteen years' experience in operating Railroads, and claiming to know something of the requirements necessary to the good management of them, and to a comfortable, speedy and safe transit for passengers, I beg leave, through your journal, to suggest a means for obviating many of the most serious accidents that are becoming almost of daily occurrence.

The correspondence of the Augsburg Gazette states that Lord STRATFORD has already assured the Porte of British protection, and, in conjunction with the French Minister, is prepared to address a note to that effect to the Divan

The U. S. mail steamship Isabel arrived at this port, to-day, from Havana, which port she left on the 8th inst. There had been a disagreement between the authorities, and LAVALETE, the second in command on the Island, and another officer, high in rank, were going to Spain in disgust.
The mail of Feb. 25, has important intelligence. The rebels threatened Shanghae with a force of 50,000 men.

The Spring trade is gradually decaying. All the heavier wants of country dealers have been satisfied, and few purchases are now making, but to either fill small orders or to replenish broken stocks. Still, the season is closing very satisfactorily, considering the extent of the past four months' movements, which have been characterized by a degree of vigor altogether unprecedented.

Dates from Sydney are to April 2. The yield of gold was unabated, and several new fields had been discovered. The improvement in the rate of exchange had advanced the rate of gold in Victoria to 70s. 3d.

The proceedings at Bow-street on Saturday last against WILLIAM and ROBERT HALE, the supposed proprietors of the house in Deptford-road at which a large seizure of rockets of war and other military stores was made by order of the Government about a week ago, were of a purely technical character.

M. KOSSUTH appears to have learnt from his experience in Hungary more of military tactics than he ever got credit for in his native land. There is such a thing as carrying the war into the enemy's country, and this is just what the Ex-Dictator is doing at the present moment.

The Board met yesterday at 5 P. M. RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair Present-Aldermen Haley, Sturtevant, Oakley, Boyce, Brisley, Francis, Tieman, Bard, Ward, Denman and Peck. Bull's Ferry.--Alderman WARD presented a petition from Messrs. Russ Reid, for the lease of a dock for ferry purposes, at some convenient point on the Island, opposite Bull's Ferry, on the Jersey shore.

GENERAL ASSEMBLY.--The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church are to meet on Thursday, the 19th inst., at the city of Buffalo. I will be a gathering of great respectability, and embrace a large number of distinguished divines from every part of the Union.

The Prefect of the Var has issued a proclamation, informing the authorities and inhabitants that the Socialist agitation is reviving in the district under his superintendence. The insurgents against the coup d'etat were more numerous in this department than in any other, and an immense proportion of the political victims lately pardoned, belonged to the Var.

A curious case of abduction is on trial at Geneva, N.Y. Three men named Asa B. Smith, Wm. R. Smith and Thomas Wright were indicted for forcibly abducting the wife of Addison J. Bennett. The defendants are Friends.

Accounts from Malta of the 15th announce that the English squadron still remained at its anchorage. An English steamer had arrived from Constantinople with dispatches from the English Ambassador for Admiral DUNDAS. It was to leave on the following day for Portsmouth with dispatches for the English Government. Two Russian vessels of war and an American frigate were also at Malta.

There is little or no news of importance, except the Emperor's severe indisposition. A story has been in circulation at Havre, that two passengers arrived on board the ship L' Empereur, had brought an infernal machine from Rio. They were arrested, but liberated, as no machine could be found. The Emperor has granted a large tract of land in Algeria, for settlement by a Swiss Whaling Company, formed at Havre.

The cholera has broken out in Moscow. Some difficulty has arisen between Servia and Russia--Servia refusing to dismiss M. JAH, an Austrian, from the Directory of the Military School of Kraghiebatz, on Russian dictation. The Servian Senate persist in their refusal. The St. Petersburg Tallow market on the 19th was very firm.

The new Spanish Ministers have published their programme. Letters from Madrid state that in that capital the programme was regarded by some as a promise that the Constitution should not be disturbed, the words favoring this view being those which declare the affection of the people for "the political system inaugurated by the fortunate accession of Her Majesty to the throne." Others believed this phrase to be a concealed jibe at the nation.

Two months or more since, it was announced in the public journals, (and among them the TIMES,) that arrangements had been made, whereby the fare for the coming season, between Cincinnati and New-York, would be very low. A matter of ten dollars for a through ticket.

The Royal Mail steamship Cambria, Capt. DOUGLAS, from Liverpool on the 30th April, arrived here at 12 o'clock M. to-day, during the prevalence of a thick fog. She brings 69 through passengers and 33 for Halifax, with a full freight.

The finding of the Jury of Inquiry at Norwalk, has now been before the public twenty-four hours. Every one interested in the subject, has doubtless read or glanced over the evidence and description of the scene which it presents.

A telegraphic dispatch states that on April 22, the reactionary party got up a serious emeute at Fribourg: "Three or four hundred peasants, headed by Col. PERRIER, got possession of the College. The fight was severe. There are many killed and wounded.

The Bombay mail of March 29 has arrived. There was little interesting from Burmah. At Prome and Mendy all was quiet. Near ??noben a combined attack by land and water was making against the robber chief NEATOON. The result was not known. No Burmesian Envoy had yet arrived at the British Camp.

There is a dispute going on in Ohio, in regard to the boundary line between the counties of Hamilton (Cincinnati) and Clermont. The County Surveyor of Hamilton reports that the line, as originally surveyed, is not in conformity to the line of 1802; and if now surveyed, according to that law, would add some six miles of territory on the Ohio river, and would include the town of New Richmond.

It has become the painful duty of the Directors to report the occurrence of a most appalling catastrophe on the New-York and New-Haven Road, on Friday last, the 8th inst., by which a loss of life, almost beyond precedent, has been occasioned.

The Governor has appointed MARTIN HEALD, as Judge of Hillsboro County, and MARTIN CHASE, Judge of Sullivan County. Hon. JOHN SULLIVAN has been re-appointed Attorney-General of the State, and ALFRED R. HATCH, Solicitor of Rockingham County.

Besides the Earl of ELLESMERE, Sir CHARLES LYELL, and Mr. DILKE, the Royal Commission which is about to be issued for the American International Exhibition, will, we understand, embrace the names of Professor G. WILSON, Mr. WHITWORTH, and Mr. WALLIS.

The bill to grant the call for 100,000 l??vres in aid of Lombard Exiles had passed the Committee of the Piedmontese Legislature. The Duke of Tuscany is said to have notified the British Government that Mr. CRAWFORD may reenter Florence, if hearing a British voucher, that he is not an agent of MAZZINI. There is nothing from Central or Southern Italy.

WALLACK's THEATRE.--"Much Ado about Nothing" was reproduced last evening, Mr. WALLACK filling his old character of Benedick. He is so well known in the part, and has at various times received so much flattery for its rendition, that it is hopeless to say anything new concerning it--at least, anything which we could say with pleasure.

The annual election of Trustees of the Smith Charities took place at Northampton, Mass., on Wednesday, 4th inst. From the annual report of the Trustees, it appears that the increase of both funds (Accumulating and Contingent) during the year past, has been $32,412 29, making the present amount of the Accumulating Fund $276,620 30, and the Contingent Fund $255,891 23--both together amounting to $532,511 53.

FOREIGN ITEMS.--The Gazette des Hopitaux says, that Professor PAUL DUBOTS has been appointed accoucheur to the Empress of France. It was LIEBIG's theory that arsenic proves poisonous not by virtue, so to speak, of its own venom, but by arresting those processes of decomposition and destruction, which are always going on among the solids and fluids of the body, as an essential agency of life.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Hermann, Lieut. HIGGINS, U. S. N., Commander, arrived yesterday afternoon from Bremen and Southampton, bringing four days later news from Europe. The Hermann left Bremen on the 22d, and Southampton on the 27th ult. She brings dates from London to the 27th, and Havre and Paris advices to the 25th April.

SAMUEL A. CRAPO, Esq., of this City, died at Providence, R. I., on the 9th inst. This will be sad intelligence to his large circle of friends, personal and professional. Mr. CRAPO was a partner in the law firm of TUCKER CRAPO, and for a period of twenty years has occupied a highly honorable position in the legal profession.

The Cabinet held a long special meeting today, and was also in session to a late hour to-night. The object is understood to be the disposition of Foreign appointments. No appointment of Inspector General has been made.

The Third Anniversary of the Association for the Suppression of Gambling was held last evening at 7 o'clock, in Broadway Tabernacle. Ihe objects of the Society are: 1. To prevent, as far as practicable, the formation of gambling habits among the young, by the dissemmation of facts, and by personal efforts with individuals known to be exposed to the temptations of the Card-room, or the Faro table.

Our dates are a week later, viz.: to March 8. All fear of the small pox on the Islands appears to have passed away. The Legislature was to be convoked on the 6th of April. The Pathfinder, of the Oriental Clipper Line, reached Honolulu on the 27th February in 14 days from this port. A successful operation for cataract was performed recently by Dr. FORD of Honolulu.

On Friday night last, 6th inst., as the steam propeller Uncas, Capt. Bates, of Bucks line, was on her passage from New-York to Boston, when off Bridgeport, she was run into by a schooner, which carried aw[Yen]ay the mainmast and pilot house of tile propeller, and came near killing Capt. Bates, who was at the wheel at the time.

The Board of Aldermen have elicited, through the Comptroller, a report of the traffic of the two City Railroads on the west side of the town. The figures were given in detail yesterday. The result is a gratifying evidence of he rapid growth of business and increase of population in tile upper Wards of the City. It is, too, a very profitable return on the capital invested.

BOARD OF EXCISE.--The Annual Meeting of the Board of Excise was held May 10. Present: Messrs, SHAW, CAVANAGH, CHAMPLIN, MEAD, EAGAN, FINNEGAN, and VAN MATER. Mr. SHAW was elected President protem. On motion, the Board then proceeded to elect a President. Mr SHAW having received all but one vote, was declared elected.

The American Bible Society celebrated their Thirty-Seveinth Anniversary, in Metropolitan Hall. yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock. The attendance--always good, on this interesting occasion-was unusually large ; the ladies, of course, being in the majority. On the plat. form. were several of the most eminent divines, with many distinguished citizens.

NAVAL.--The U. S. steamer Fulton, Lieut. A. MURRAY commanding, arrived at Norfolk on Tuesday, five days and twelve hours from Pensacola, and proceeded up to the Navy Yard. Te following is a list of her officers: A. MURRAY, Lieut. Commanding; ROBERT T. MACCOUN, Passed Asst.

The statement that propositions for the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands to-the United States have been renewed, is confirmed. I feel warranted in saying that the subject is now before the Administration of General PIERCE, and will receive the consideration its importance demands as soon as the legion of office-hunters shall have been driven from Washington, either by disappointment or banishment to the positions assigned them.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.)..Broadway, cor.Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Water.

The preparatory meeting of the Delegates of this Convention, in the City cf New-Yerk, during the World's Fair, took place yesterday morning, in the Brick Chapel, at 9 o'clock. Hon. Mr. BARSTOW, of Providence, was moved to the Chair.

Yesterday was fruitful again of Anniversary meetings, and the attendance on them suffered no diminution in comparison with those of preceding days. At the World's Temperance Convention of Delegates, there was quite a teapot tempest.

An inquisition was held on Wednesday, at the residence of Mr. TAYLOR, in One Hundred and Twenty-first-street, Harem, respecting the death of a male infant, named GEORGE WASHINGTON TAYLOR, aged 5 months, who lost his life through the carelessness of a druggist's clerk. The testimony of the afflicted mother explains the melancholy occurrence, which, in substance, was as follows: was as follows:

UNITARIANISM IN THE WEST.--We find, in our Western exchanges, detailed reports of the proceedings of a Unitarian Conference lately held at St. Louis. The declaration of the Convention on points of faith and practice, is of some importance. The Conference assembled on the 29th ult., and adjourned on the 2d inst.

A sick Bachelor! A dying camel in the desert! A sailor on a hen-coop in the middle of the Atlantic All the same. The same incident from different points of view. The same subject with varied accessories. If there is a preponderance of inisery on any side it is on the side of the sick bachelor.

We might have lost one of our best dramatic poets the other day, in a duel; of M. EMILE ANGIER, the author of La Cique, Diane and Philiberts, has fought one with M. MONSELET, fevilleturiste and theatrical critic. The poet thought he discerned in one of the critic's articles an attack upon his honor, and proposed a set-to with small swords.

The thirty-fourth anniversary of this truly benevolent Institution was celebrated in Metropolitan Hall, yesterday afternoon. The numerous attendance gave evidence of the deep interest felt in the proceedings of this Society. Every seat in the body of the Hall was occupied, and the passages crowded.

For the other City News of this morning, see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Macbeth King of Scotland. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Much Ado About nothing--Review. BURTON'S THEATRE--She Would and She Would not--Toodles. WT. CHARLES THEATRE.--Pirate Doctor--Macbeth--Wandering Minstrels.

We understand that the election held yesterday by the New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company, resulted in the choice of the old Board. The meeting of the Shareholders was a pretty full one, and there were a number of explanations, and much conversation touching the accident on Friday.

The Committee met yesterday at 12 o'clock. Present, Hon. D. B. TAYLOR and A. M. CLAPP. Junius A. Smith sworn. and examined by Mr. SHANNON.-I reside in Batavia. Genesee Co., N. Y.; I was one of the Secretaries of the Art Union for a number of years; I was a Secretary in the year 1851 ; I think I procured about screen Subscribers in that year.

It was THOMAS JEFFERSPSON who first proposed a complete and extended survey of the Coast of the United States. The early years of the present century are the only claims which that enterprise possesses for antiquity. Barely fifty years have elapsed since the project first began to be considered, and but little more than half that period has passed away since the first really effective movement was made toward the accomplishment of the design.

Who can tell but that by writing a brief chapter on the minor economics, we may save the price of year's subscription for the DAILY TIMES, to each of our several hundred of readers, who will glance along this page to-day--readers, who are strangers in town, having chosen Anniversary Week to visit the City and post themselves in such matters, as, to be settled, call for a visit to the Metropolis.

Tile funeral of the late JOHN FARRAR, LL, D., took place at Cambridge, Mass., yesterday morning. Professor FARRAR was for many years the Hollis Professor of Natural Philosophy and the Mathemnaties in Harvard University. He was a native of Lincoln, Mass., and graduated at Harvard with tile class of 1803, just half a century ago.

The ceremony of dedicating the Luther and Dutch Church edifice, recently erected on the corner of South-First and Nineteenth streets, by the German Lutheran denomination, was performed yesterday morning and afternoon. The services in the forenoon were in the German language. Rev. Mr. R. M. SCHLUETER, or Poughkeepsie, delivered the opening address, and Rev. Mr. HEILT, of the Sixth-street Lutheran Church, preached the sermon. n Church, preached the sermon.

The Central American Education Society held its thirty-fifth annual meeting, at the New Bible House, yesterday, at 3 o'clock P. M. Hon. JOSEPH C. HORNBLOWER in the chair. There were but a few members present. The Secretary reported that 38 young men had been assisted by the Society, in their course in the Union Theological Seminary, during the past year.

During the latter part of the week which has elapsed since our last review of the market, there has been a perceptible increase of activity, though without any corresponding improvement in prices. On the contrary, the transactions in most leading articles of consumption show a further decline, attributable to large additions having been made to previously heavy stocks, scarcity of money, difficulty experienced in obtaining fire-proof storage, and the holding back of the country trade.

The seventeenth Anniversary of the American Temperance Union was held in Metropolitan Hall, yesterday, at 7 1/2 P. M., Chancellor WALWORTH, sustained by Vice-Presidents, being in the Chair. Several Clergymen and Officers of Temperance Societies, occupied seats on the platform. Prayer was made by Rev. Dr. PECK, of Portland, Me.

The Steamer Prmethcus, Capt. CHURCHILL, arrived yesterday morning, from SanJuan del Norte. To the Purser we are indebted for favors. The Prometheus left San Juan on Wednesday morning, the 4th inst., bringing 400 passengers, and $170,000 in gold dust on freight, also a large amount in the hands of passengers, and dates to the 17th ult. from San Francisco, having made the passage in 7 days and 22 hours.

THE EXECUTION.--A large number of a most worthy and respectable portion of the citizens of Queens County, L. I., who are opposed to enforcing the death penalty, have petitioned the Governor of this State for a respite of the execution of THOMAS AITCHINSON, Convieted of the murder of ROLOF VooRIS, at Hicksville, on the 2d of March, 1852, and without effect.

In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, May 11, CORNELIUS WENDELL, fourth son of Alfred and Anna L. Clapp, in the 5th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral this afternoon, at o'clock, from No. 254 Hicks-st., Brooklyn. At Norwalk, Conn., on Wednesday morning.

The Royal Commission of England, appointed to visit the New-York Exhibition for the Industry of all Nations, is named to consist of a Peer of the Realm, the Earl of ELLESMERE, and two distinguishedd Geologists, Sir CHAPLES LYDLL and Sir HENRY THOMAS DE LA BECTHE. They will no doubt be in this City in the course of the Summer.
The frequently recurring question, What shall be done with the Canals? is about to be encountered by the Legislature, less trammeled by other considerations and interests than ever heretofore.

The Metropolitan Railroad bill has passed the Logislature of Maryland This work, now authorized by the united authority of Congress and Maryland, is one of the most important improvements on foot in any part of the country. It will furnish a direct communication between Washington and the West, intersecting the Ohio Railroad near Fredcrickton, and saving between that point and Washington more than forty miles of the travel now required by that circuitons route.

THOS. KENNIFF, alias "Tom the Tinker," under arrest charged with committing highway robbery and several h??nous offences, was brought before Justice CURTIS yesterday for examination. He was ordered back to jail under the charge of Deputy Sheriff O'ROUKE, but the prisoner managed to make his escape from the officer before reaching the jail. the jail.

The Rotharhithe rocket case had developed some interesting facts. The judgment of Justice HENRY was delivered on the 28th ult. The sentence was not severe; the Justice decreeing thas all the powder seized beyond the allowed quantity be forfeited, together with the barrels in which it was contained, and that the defendants pay two shillings for every pound beyond such allowed quantity.

The First Anniversary of this interesting local Society was held yesterday, at 7 1/2 o'clock P.M., in the Broadway Tabernacle. The children of the school (about two hundred in number) were arranged in the gallery, at either side of the organ. On taking their seats they were applauded by the audience, who were both numerous and respectable.

SILLIMAN's American Journal of Science and Arts for May, is an unusually interesting number. Prof. W.A. NORTON contributes an elaborate paper in examination of the Caloric Engine of Capt. ERICSSON, the author taking the ground that in respect to the space occupied by engines, coal, etc., the steam-engine is preferable, although a saving of one sixth to one-third in the amount of fuel required is freely admitted.

We learn from Milan that the deputations went to Vienna to present the address drawn up according to the intentions of Count GYULAI, who had objected to the one proposed by the Departments as being too independent and reserved in its expressions.

On Sunday week, a couple of young men, Mr. James Smith and Mr. Samuel Durham, brothers-in-law, met in Fayette Co., Tenn., some six or eight miles west of Somerville, where they engaged in an affray, which resulted in the death of Mr. Smith.

REMARKABLE DISAPPEARANCE OF A YOUNG LADY--$500 REWARD.--Great excitement reigned yesterday at Bergen Five Corners, and the vicinity, owing to the disappearance of Miss EMILY TEAL, the daughter of a gentleman residing at Bergen.

The Alton Telegraph says that the prevailing impression is that the Mississippi Valley is to be deluged by another flood not inferior to that of 1844. If there is any truth in the reports of the amount of snow on the mountains, there is much reason to apprehend a calamity of this character, though perhaps not to the same extent.

B. F. ANGEL has been determined on for Consul at Lahaina, Sandwich Islands, a dispatch to the contrary notwithstanding. GEORGE SANDERS, it is confidently believed, will be Consul to London, and ASPINWALL, the incumbent, will probably receive some other appointment.

At Lancaster, Mass, May 8, Mrs. ANNA P. LEE, aged 78 years, wife of the late Seth Lee, Esq., of Barre, Mass. In Brooklyn, on Monday, May 9, of scarlet fever, VICTOR B., son of A. J. and Elizabeth Hodenpyl, aged 3 years, 7 months and 14 days.

THE ANTICIPATED DUEL.--Yesterday morning quite a number of persons connected with the theatrical profession, assembled together at Hotels in different parts of the City, intent upon discovering who were the parties concerned in a duel that was anticipated to take place between two actors, engaged at two Theatres in Broadway.

The New-York Quarterly, under the able and judicious conduct of A.G. REMINGTON, Esq., fully vindicates the promise of its earlier numbers. The April issue has several capital papers; two of them, " Sparta and the Doreans," and "Flaxman's Drawings," are extremely elaborate and valuable; the one exhibiting the rarest learning, and the other the nicest artistic discrimination and taste.

STUYVESANT INSTITUTE.--Mr. FRAZER, a tenor singer formerly connected with the late Mr. SEGUIN, is delivering a series of lectures at this Institute, on "National Melodies." From a long; experience, he is enabled to offer many amusing illustrations of the peculiarities and perfections of composers.

Rev. R. S. STORRS DICKINSON has been released, by the Third Presbytery of New-York, from the pastoral cave of the Houston-street Presbyterian Church of this City, to become assistant to Rev. ALBERT BARNES, of the First Presbyterian Church of Philadelphia.

The following letter, addressed to Senator PIERCE by Hon. ALEX. H. H. STUART, late Secretary of the Interior, gives an interesting account of the troubles arising in the Mexican Boundary Commission from the conduct of Col. J. D. GRAHAM.

A Cabinet session, lasting three or four hours, was held to-day. The Foreign appointments are not yet completed. Favorites of Speaker LUDLOW, of the New-York Legislature, it is said, will all get places. SEAMAN will probably be Postmaster at Babylon, Suffolk Co., Long Island.

The execution of this murderer took place yesterday. The murder having been perpetrated over four teen months ago, the facts of the case may not be familiar to all our readers. They are as follows: Mr. VOORHIS, an aged and respectable farmer, engaged AITCHINSON as a farm servant.

The good old gentleman has seen seventy-four of them. They are strewn behind him like milestones by the side of a railroad track. From the high grade where he now stands, they seem to touch each other, albeit as he passed them, he toiled heavily from one to the next, laden with a weight of sorrows.

A dispatch from Berlin dated 21st ult., and published in the Debats, states that Herr NOERNER, an officer of the Crown, has left for London with several agents of our police, to collect evidence of the supposed connection between the plot discovered here and the machinations of the political refugees living in London.

A telegraphic message appears in the second edition of the Chronicle, to the effect that the Moniteur of Friday contains a decree for the levy of 80,000 recruits. The Breslau Gazette states that there are a considerable number of French Legitimists at present with the Count DE CHAMBORD at Venice.

Capt. Skinner, of the ship Hermann, from Baltimore to San Francisco, touched at the island of Juan Fernandez, on the 27th of March, for water, and says he was surprised to find there a settlement of about 300 inhabitants, who were directed by a Governor.

LUCY STONE.--We clip from the Syracuse Weekly Chronicle, the following notice of this lady's oratory: "As to LUCY STONE, the music of her eloquence sanctifies her very 'bloomer.' We well remember the first time we were brought under her influence.

The Washington Republic says: The Circuit Court recently decided a case of some interest affecting masters and apprentices. It appears that on the 5th inst., Mr. Michael McDermot addressed a note to the Marshal of the District of Columbia to the following effect: "You will receive into your Jail for safe keeping, the body of Thomas Fitten, my indented apprentice, who refuses to obey my orders.

The United States Review, for the current month, embraces its ordinary sum of matters. The leading article touching the relations between the United States and Great Britain, contains some sensible, some novel, and several very extraordinary ideas, the begetting principle of which is, implacable hostility to the Government of Queen VICTORIA, and a general Fourth of July spirit of defiance and braggadocio.
The professional man who dares wear a thread-bare coat until he is out of debt, was in town yesterday. A very good-looking, but melancholy sort of man he was, and no wonder.

The Diario states that some surprise had been caused on the Stock Exchange at Madrid by a sudden rise of 4 1/2 per cent. in what are called the Committee Bonds, which had been considered, to use its own expression, "definitely dead," and it requests that information as to what it is intended to do with them may be given, so as not to lead speculators into error.

The Dutch are anxiously looking out for the publication of the programme or declaration of political principles on the part of the newly-formed Cabinet, for it is now certain that the Chambers, which stand only adjourned for the present, will be dissolved; and it is now believed on all sides, that the VAN HALL Administration--for he is set down as the real soul of it--will take that opportunity to refer to its future policy.

The steamer Texas arrived to-day from Vera Cruz. Gen. URAGA, who is going to Prussia as Mexican Minister, came passenger in her. Gen. ARISTA sailed from Vera Cruz on the 9th, in the British Mail steamer Aron, for St. Thomas.

In the Senate to-day, a bill was reported to prohibit passenger-trains passing over drawbridges at a greater speed than six miles an hour; and in approaching such bridges, the train shall be stopped at from one to three hundred feet from the draw.

The Federal Council has received an address from 50 Swiss non-commissioned officers and soldiers now serving in the first regiment of the foreign legion in Algeria, offering their services to fight for their country in case of a declaration of war.

Dispatches from Frankfort state that the Diet had admitted the claim of Austria on the Germanic Confederation to the amount of 107,000,000 florins, for the expenses of the war in Italy and Hungary, on the ground that such wars had served to protect the frontiers of Germany.

The neglect and cruelty with which poor repontent inebriates are ordinarily treated by the present management of our City Prison, (of which the late packing of five of them, even to suffocation, in a single ill-ventilated, foul-aired cell, is but a sad example,) is rather suggestive of the kind of sentiment, and feeling too generally entertained and exhibited toward this unfortunate and truly to be pitied class of our suffering fellow creatures, in the community.

In the House of Commons on the same day, in reply to a question from Sir J. WALMSLEY and Mr. BRIGHT, Lord PALMERSTON stated that the proceedings relating to the seizure of warlike stores at Rotherhithe were instituted by his authority.

A terrible calamity has just occurred in this city. The building on Main-street occupied as a banking house by Messrs. ROBINSON Co. and ROBERT CODD, while undergoing repairs suddenly caved in, the roof and every story being carried through to the ground.

The brig Pembroke sailed from Mobile on Tuesday last, with about thirty Choctaw Indians, men and women, for Boston, under charge of Mr. McVoy, and their chief, William Fisher. The Advertiser says they were well equipped with the necessaries for a series of exhibitions throughout the principal cities, and started off in excellent spirits.

Science seems to increase rather than diminish the number of Quacks among us, on the same principle that an increased number of solvent banks, increase the number of counterfeit notes. I apply the term to all professions, not to Physic alone.

Bird's-Eye Sketch of Eastern North-Carolina--The Shad land Herring Fisheries--Employment of Negroes in them--A Hint for Dentists--Extraction of Stumps--Divers--Improved Negro-Power. If we could take a bird's-eye view of Eastern North-Carolina; coming from seaward we should observe a low narrow sand bar, sometimes broken into barren islands, but forming an essentially continuous frontier cordon along its entire coast.

Galveston dates of the 10th have been received by the steamship Mexico. The gold accounts are fully confirmed. The Galveston News says it is informed by a gentleman from Holkhart, that a party of citizens, who had just returned from an exploring expedition, found gold in the mountains, seventy miles north west of that town, both on the surface and by digging. They brought back several lumps, all of which were valued at $5,950.

We know of nothing that is more thoroughly at loose-ends in our State jurisprudence than the laws respecting the duties and obligations of Jurors. There is in fact neither law nor reason in the enactments which control this most important branch of official duty.

The English mail brings to notice several interesting subjects. The rejection by Parliament of the Jewish Disabilities bill is a heavy blow at the advancement of the peculiar people in Great Britain. The struggle has been prolonged and severe, and the result is not unexpected.

NOBLE CONDUCT OF A SHIP-CAPTAIN.--A correspondent directs attention to the humane efforts made by Captain WHITE, of the American ship Orlando, in the rescue of upward of one hundred persons from the burning wreck of the ship St. Gearge, late a Liverpool packet, which was destroyed at sea about three months since.

The Paris Correspondent of the Morning Chronicle says: Although both the Capital and the Provinces of France, are at the present moment in the enjoyment of apparently the most perfect tranquility, it may be doubted if the aspect of affairs is altogether satisfactory to the parties in whom the Government is vested.

The Chinese mail of the 12th of March has brought important intelligence regarding the progress of events in the Celestial Empire. The rebels have now got so far forth as to threaten Shanghai, and are stated to have a force of 50,000 men within a few marches of that port.

In the House of Lords, on the 29th ult., the Earl of ABERDEEN rose to move the second reading of the Jewish Disabilities bill. The subject, he said, had been already so fully discussed as to render it impossible to place it before their lordships in a new point of view.

Our progressive young State is just now aroused and excited on the subject of railroads to the Missouri River. Our speedy union with the East at three points--Burlington, Davenport, and Dubuque, and perhaps others--has made the subject one of immediate interest to the whole State.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Allow me to supply a deficiency, or correct an error, in your report of the petition against licenses. Four Wards only had granted licenses, leaving sixteen Wards to be acted upon.

The meeting last evening, to hear the Farewell Address of the eloquent Padre, and witness the presentation of $1,000, as a tribute of admiration, was one of the largest, most respectable, and enthusiastic, we have for some time seen assembled within the walls of Metropolitan Hall.

The Committee met yesterday, at 2 P.M., the hour to which it stood adjourned--Present Messrs. TAYLOR and CLAPP. J. M. CULVERHOUSE was called by the Petitioners, and having been sworn, testified as follows: I am an artist; I have had transactions with the Art-Union.

Lord STRATFORD delivered his credentials to the Sultan on the 7th, and addressed his Majesty as follows: "SIRE--At the express command of my most gracious Sovereign, I once again appear before your Imperial Majesty.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday are to hand. A Convention of the Georgia Railroad Stockholders met at Atalanta on the 10th inst., the question proposed, being the connection between the Georgia and Milledgeville Road--it was referred to the Board of Directors.

It is stated that Professor WILSON, the veteran reviewer, is lying very low, and slight hopes are entertained of his recovery. On Thursday a conference "to consider the state of mercantile law and the judicial system of the United Kingdom" was opened at the offices of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce.

EDWARD OWENS, the late tender of the draw on the Rancocas bridge, publishes a statement of the late accident at that place, showing that he performed his duty entirely according to the regulations of the Company, and the accident is attributable only to the carelessness of the engineer in disobeying instructions by running faster than he should when coming toward a draw-bridge.

AT CHAMBERS OF SUPERIOR COURT--Before Judge DUER--In re The People ex rel. Jacob R. Gibbr,--Yesterday morning, a little after 10 Mrs. Rose Porter and the negro child, Jane Trainer, appeared before the Judge pursuant to the order of Tuesday.

M. AYLLON, designated by General LERSANDI to the Spanish Foreign Office, declines the precarious honor. The Madrid Gazette of the 20th contains a circular addressed by the new Minister of the Interior to the Governors of Provinces.

The following is a closing paragraph of the last annual report of the Directors of the Vermont and Massachusetts Railroad, issued in February last: "The Directors are happy to say, at the conclusion of their Report, that not a person has been injured, in any manner, upon the road, during the past year.

A meeting on behalf of the American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions was held in Metropolitan Hall, at 10 o'clock, A. M., yesterday--Hon. THEODORE FRELINGHUYSEN in the Chair. The meeting was well attended.

THE STORM AT GALVESTON.--On the evening of the 2d inst., Galveston was visited by one of the severest storms experienced since 1846. The News of the 3d gives the following account of it: The damage among the shipping at Menard's wharf is very considerable.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: The Directors of Railroads should be men interested in the stock that they represent. They should he acquainted with the management of the road. They should reside in the vicinity of the road, and be distributed so that they can know the actual management.

The increase of our Census returns be comes a matter of wonder, when we think of the ingenious and wholesale modes which modern science adopts to hurry our race be yond the ken of the Census-taker. The science of slaughter is well nigh reaching perfection.

LUDWICK TIECK, Who has told multitudinous stories, over which two or three generations have hung rapturously, died at the first of this month in Berlin. TIECK was born in that city on the 31st of May, 1773, and was, therefore, within a month of completing his term of four score years when he died.

As mentioned per Cambria, via Halifax, the Earl of ABERDEEN in the House of Lords, on Friday evening, 29th ult., moved the second reading of the Bill for removal of Jewish Disabilities, and strongly urged the removal of this most intolerant restriction on the civil liberties of a section of British subjects.

The Moniteur announces non-officially that the Empress "qui etail enceinte depuis deux mois, et qui etail souffrante depuis quelques jours, a fait une fausse couche dans la soiree du 29 April." Her Majesty's state of health is again satisfactory.

COTTON.--Our market for this staple closed firmly on Friday last, in consequence of the large error in our own stock, discovered on that day On Saturday there was scarcely so much offering, and with an improved demand, full prices were obtained.
Advices from Melbourne are to the 25th January. Commercial accounts were satisfactory. The yield of gold continued abont an average; produce market high; provisions falling rapidly, especially flour.

DIED OF HIS INJURIES.--JOHN HENNESSY, who was so seriously burned at the fire in North Eighth street, on Tuesday last, died at his residence, corner of North Eighth and Sixth-streets, between 9 and 10 o'clock on Thursday evening.

For the other City News of this morning, see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Macbeth King of Scotlaand. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Don Ceasar de Bazan-Used Up. BURTON'S THEATRE.--She Stoops to Couquer-Sweethearts and Wives.

There is hope for the aspirants at last. Briefs of testimonials in favor of the applicants for diplomatic stations were sent from the State Department to the President three days ago, since when he has been continually examining them. It is generally believed that all the appointments will be announced on Tuesday, except those to France, which will be delayed some time.

ROBERT A. HAWKE, Messenger of the General Post-Office, cut his wife's throat, at 10 o'clock last night, an hour after they retired, completely severing the windpipe and arteries. He then made two cuts at his own throat, but was, as he says, prevented from killing himself by his wife knocking the razor out of his hand.

The President declined receiving visitors from twelve to two, as heretofore, Hundreds called and were disappointed. The Attorney General was sent for, and was engaged with the President for several hours.

It is said that a young lady of fashion in Paris, Mdlle. Virginie de T., having died very suddenly, her friends decided upon a post-mortem examination. It was found that three of the ribs had encroached upon the liver to such an extent as to produce death. The young lady perished of tight-lacing.

On Saturday morning, May 14, in the 38th year of her age, ELIZABETH CAROLINE, only daughter of Right Rev. Benjamin .T. Onderdonk. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral from her father's residence, No. 106 Franklin-st. to St. John's Chapel, On Monday afternoon at 3 o'clock, to move at 4 precisely.

By ship Hotspur we have advices from the Cape to the 8th of March. The pacification of the Colony was progressing. The Cane Town Mail of the 8th states that MACOMO, SANDILI, and the other Gaika chiefs had agreed to all General CATHCART'S conditions.

The health of the Isthmus was never better says the Panama Herald, than at present. On the 25th, a destructive fire broke out at Gorgona, consuming the entire village, with the exception of the office of Messrs. RAN RUNNELS and HINCKLEY.

The swift passage of the Atlantic carries our European advices along to the 4th inst. They are generally unimportant. The defeat of the Jewish Disabilities bill in the House of Peers had bitterly disappointed the friends of that measure, who had anticipated the deference usually conceded by the Upper to the decided sentiments of the Lower House.

FIRES.--There were two alarms of fire Thurs day night; one from Union-street, in a house occupied by J. R. DAVIS, which was soon extinguished by Officers FULTON and GILMORE of the Second District Police. Damage $50. The other was in a wooden house in Amity-street.

When it was announced that M. FRANCONI intended emigrating to this country in company with his famous stud of horses and artistes, much expectation was excited. Recollections of the Hippodrome in Paris were awakened, and a general impression established that we should be treated to something more than usually good and genteel.

In its sittings of 25th ult., the Swiss Federal Council received the answers of the Governments of Ticino and the Grisons, respecting the concessions to be made to Austria. Both Cantons refuse in the most positive terms to abandon the right of asylum, and insist that the Federative Government has no power to deprive them of that right.

Congress recently voted a large donation of the Public Lands to the State of Michigan, and the State contracted for the building of a Ship Canal around the Falls of the St. Mary's River, which connects Lakes Huron and Superior.

THE MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE OF MISS EMILY TEAL-A ROMANCE IN REAL LIFE.-The circumstances attending the sudden disappearance of MISS EMILY TEAL from her father's house, at Bergen Five Corners, reported in the TIMES of Saturday, have been rendered even more mysterious by the return of that lady to her home.

Letters from Constantinople, April 18, via Paris, state that the Russian negotiations were still enveloped in mystery. It was, however, known that the United efforts of the Representatives of France and England were directed towards a peaceful solution of the difficulty, and tended towards a final settlement of the Holy Places Protectorate, by joint treaty between Russia, England, France and the Porte.

AMERICAN MUSICAL FUND SOCIETY.-A dramatic and musical novelty of some importance comes off this evening at Metropolitan Hall. We allude to the reading of SHAKSPERE'S " Midsummer Night's Dream," with the musical accompaniments of MENDELSSOHN.

At a Cabinet Council held on the 16th ult., at which the King presided, it was resolved to reinforce the troops on the frontiers of Lombardy and the Italian Duchies. Alessandria, Casale, and even Genoa, are to be placed in a complete state of defence.

The cheval de battaille, both with the Ministry and its Parliamentary opponents, is still the Budget. A good deal of sharp shooting took place in the House on Monday evening, among the third and fourth class legislators, composing the small fry of St. Stephens; and many arrows were leveled at the different features of Mr. GLADSTONE'S measures.

Evening Session. The Committee reassembled at 8 o'clock, and continued the investigation. Mr. AUSTEN was again called to the stand. Mr. MONK thought that where a man was charged with an impropriety he ought not to be put on the stand.

Three vessels have arrived to-day from Australia, with gold valued at [pound]259,600. The Admiral, which left Port Philip on the 27th of January, brings 22,000 ounces; the Hero, from the same place the 20th of January, has 13,934 ounces; and the Kate, from Sydney the 12th of January, has 28,977 ounces. Concurrently with these arrivals from Australia, there have been [pound]40,000 from New-York, and [pound]12,000 by the steamer Bengal.

The First Prussian Chamber lately voted the exclusion of Jews from all public employments. On 26th ult. a petition on the subject, bearing the names of a thousand influential citizens, was presented to the Second Chamber. The petitioners, conspicuous among whom was the veteran philosopher ALEXANDER VON HUMBOLDT, demand full freedom of religious opinion, and the admission of Jews to civil offices.

The U. S. steamship Atlantic, Capt. WEST, arrived on Saturday morning from Liverpool, whence she sailed at 91/2 A. M., on Wednesday, the 4th inst. It will be observed that this passage of the Atlantic is one of the most splendid on record.

The Imports Of BACON hardly keep pace with demand; all keeps Cleared at full rates. CHEESE is wanted. In BEEF or PORK more doing at irregular rates. LARD tends unwards. TALLOW active. CLOVER SEED dull and nominal; the stock left over reaches 500 tons. RICE without change.

The subject of the Mexican Boundary is well worth the interest it has excited in the public mind, as it is also of careful study, by every man who wishes to be informed relative to the politics and policy of the country; for there is little doubt that this question will form a prominent feature In connection with our foreign relations a few months hence.

The search at the fallen building was continued all night by torch-light. About 5 o'clock this morning 3 more dead bodies were discovered-one was grasping a plane tightly, as though struck down while in the very ast of using it. It is supposed that five or six are still beneath the ruins not yet cleared out.

The Aldermen in Session. The Board met on Friday, at 5 o'clock, P. M., RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Present, at the calling of the roll-Aldermen Ilaley, Sturtevant, Oakleys, Boyce, Barr, Tweed, Tieman, Bard, Ward, Denman, Cornell.

On Saturday morning, three of these noble vessels were together at Canal-street dock; the Baltic, which arrived two weeks since, from Liverpool; the Pacific to leave port for Europe at noon, and the Atlantic, which arrived at 7 o'clock in the morning, in nine days and twenty-two hours, under command of Captain WEST, from Liverpool.

FIRE..--About 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the Foundry, in Pearl-street near Plymouth, owned and occupied by JOHN H. LESTER. The building was totally destroyed, together with most of the contents,principally in machinery and patterns.

The Steamship Illinois, Lieutenant H. J, HARTSTINE, U. S. N., commanding, arrived at her dock at a late hour on Saturday night. She left Aspinwall at 71/2 P. M., on the 5th inst., and reached Kingston, Ja., at 61/2 P. M., on the 7th, having made the run in forty-seven hours.

FIRE--Two PERSONS SERIOUSLY INJURED. Yesterday morning about 3 o'clock, a fire broke out in the cellar of the premises No. 48 North Second street, owned and occupied by Mr. COSGROVE as a grocery store, and several poor families as a dwelling-house. The firemen were early on the ground and succeeded in subduing the flames before material damage bad been sustained.

FROM PORTO CABELLO.--By the schooner Mary Wise, Capt. CROCKETT, from the above place, we have advices to the 27th ult,: The yellow fever had entirely disappeared. There had not been a case for the last two months, The Coffee and Cocoa crop would be very short this year.

The United States District Court "finds the Atlantia wholly to blame," and gives a decree in favor of the Ogdensburgh for $3,000 and costs of suit. This decision, so perfectly in accordance with strict justice, says the Cleveland Rerald, will be very gratifying to the friends of Messrs. Craw ford Chamberlain, owners of the propeller Ogdensburgh, who were most unreasonably censured at the time of the accident.

A botanist at Orleans has been trying the effect of chloroform upon plants and flowers. His best experiment stems to have been made upon a Sensitive Plant. As you know, this flower con tracts immediately upon contact with, or even at the approach of any foreign substance.

A noted living divine was once under the necessity of reading from his pulpit the announcement of a meeting to whose objects he was by no means favorable. What made the matter still worse was the fact that ladies were announced as among those who were to deliver the addresses.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. Our readers have doubtless read the paragraphs which have been circulating in the papers respecting the man PARKS, the supposed murderer of the Englishman BEATSON, at Cuyahoa Falls, and his imagined identity with a noted English burglar named DICKINSON, who fled from justice in his native land, and arrived in this country some years since.

DISASTER AT SEA.--The ship William Mary, of Bath, (Me.) STENSON, Master, from Liverpool for NewOrleans, with railroad iron and 208 passengers, arrived yesterday morning. The following is Capt. STENSON'S report: At 7 A. M., 3d May, strong breezes from S. E. and cloudy, passed the Hole-in-the-Wall. At 12 M. Stirrup Key bore South, 10 miles distant, after which the weather became thicker and wind increased with a heavy sea.

Another chapter is opening in the Mesilla business. Full official advices have been received from New-Mexico, giving reasons for Governor LANE'S course, which have not been heretofore presented. It in explained that Governor LANE'S seizure was consequent upon certain outrageous proceedings on tile part of the authorities of Chihuahua, in seizing upon and impressing American citizens under peculiarly oppressive circumstances.

The engineer on the morning train from Middletown, Conn., to Berlin Junction, on Friday, when within about two mailes of the latter station. discovered a man sitting on one of the rails of the track, and sounded the alarm, and used all other possible means of saving his life, but the man took no notice of the train, which ran over him, and cut his body in two.

On Wednesday, May 11, at Middlebury, Mrs. KATEY CLEVELAND, wife of the late George Cleveland, Esq., in the 88th year of her age. In this City, on Sunday, May 15, ANNE SALTONSTALL, wife of Rev. William Walton, and daughter of Rev. Samuel Seabury, in the 24th year of her age.

The New-York Young Men's Christian Association held its Anniversary last evening, May 16, at 71/2 o'clock, in the Reformed Dutch Church, on Lafayette Place. The house was filled at an early hour by a very respectable audience. The President, O. P. WOODFORD, 'Esq., occupied the Chair, supported by the Speakers and the Clergy.

THE CITY AND THE TREASURER--RESIGNATION OF THE TREASURER.--In the Brooklyn Common Council last evening, a communication was received from ADFRED S. MULFORD, tendering his resignation as Treasurer of the city, and asking that a Committee be appointed to examine his accounts.

We had frequent occasion, while the Legislature was in session early in the Spring to refer to this objectionable feature in the Free Banking Law of this State. It has scarcely been once practically tested by the Bank Department without developing some fraud or recklessness in the original valuation or some loss to the holders of the Circulating Notes, in part secured by pledge of Real Estate.

Were we to receive from Caraccas or Kingston, or some other town in that quarter of the world which experiences an occasional ague, advices of a "Terrible Earthquake-a thousand houses destroyed--innumerable lives lost," the news would fill us with grief.

AMERICAN COLONIZATION SOCIETY.-Mr. DANFORTH, Agent of the American Colonization Society at Washington, has issued an Appeal to the friends of the cause for aid. He says: Hitherto we have been obliged to depend chiefly on those resources which have been furnished by private benificence, and whatever aid uncertain legislation may hereafter render.

The Committee reassembled yesterday at 12 o'clock, M. Mr. MONK desired to have Mr. CLARKE, who was an assistant of Mr. W. V. BRADY, late Postmaster, examined relative to the bill for postage spoken of at an earlier stage of the proceedings.

Most stirring accidents and calamitous records may be looked for soon. The way they pile up the bricks and tumble down the old walls, is no caution to any but nervous people. Citizens do not run now when a wall is falling toward them, until it knocks their hats over their ears.

The three month's suspension of the order made by tile Postmaster General, in February last, directing the charge of the sea-postage on all letters sent to France, via Great Britain, whether by United States or British steamers, expired by its own limitation a day or two since.

At present Aquarius moves over the City like a knight. in chess. Broadway is cooled and watered in certain places, and a vast interval is left dry and dusty and suffocating. This game of intervals is repeated every day. Even this partial glimpse of the paradise of water is due to private enterprise. The City

A few days ago a Clerk was detected in the New-York Post-Office, abstracting money from letters. Those which passed through his hands were chiefly foreign letters, such as domestics and laborers send to relatives in Ireland, enclosing the means of emigrating hither.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In your article yesterday, entitled "The Collins' steamers," I notice an error, which, if not corrected, would mislead the public in relation to the performances of the CUNARD steamers.

The Buffalo papers of Saturday contain full particulars of the recent disaster in that city. By the fall of the large building occupied by ROBINSON Co., bankers, and others, on Main-street, five lives were lost and five to ten others are still missing. The building consisted of four stories, but the rooms were all lofty and the height of the whole was equal to the adjoining five-story buildings.

NAVAL.--The U. S. sloop-of-war Vincennes, and the U. S. schooner Fenimore Cooper, arrived here yesterday. They are attached to the North Pacific Exploring Expedition. The U. S. steamer Engineer, Master OLMSTEAD, commanding, arrived here Saturday from Washington, with guns and shot for the test baftery at Old Point.

C. Levi Woodbury has accepted the office of Postmaster of Boston, and will probably enter upon his duties on the 1st of July. John G. Saxe, editor of the Burlington Sentinel, has been appointed Deputy-Collector at Burlington, Vt. E. M. Urown, editor of the Woodstock Age, has been appointed Postmaster of Woodstock, Vt.; Hiram B.

METROPOLITAN HALL.--We were pleased to see a full attendance last evening on the occasion of the Anniversary of the American Musical Fund Society. The treasury will doubtless be benefitted; and we are glad of it, for the objects of the Society are praiseworthy and descrving of every encouragement.

In a paper recently presented to the Pennsylvania Historical Society, Mr. JOHN F. WATSON demonstrates that DANIEL BOONE was a native of Pennsylvania, and that his family were Quakers. Several of its members were "read out of meeting" in consequence of marrying outside the pale.

ANOTHER DEAD CHILD FOUND.--Yesterday afternoon, as some boys were fishing on the banks of the Bushwick Creek, they discovered part of a coffin lying close to the edge of the water, partially busied in the beach. They immediately notified Officer MURPHY, who, on examination, found it to contain the body of a dead infant. It was taken to the cells, where the Coroner, Dr. DICKNSON, held an inquest yesterday evening.

GENERAL REMARKS.--This is an easily cultivated fruit, and, by proper management, may be made the most profitable of any that engage the attention of the fruit-grower. At a comparatively small outlay, acres of waste meadow or bog land, which now yield nothing to the farmer, might be made serviceable in the production of this valuable culinary fruit.

The police of Buffalo have succeeded in arresting a man named Casper Lamparter, a German, who stands charged with having committed a murder in Butler County, Pa., in April last. The particulars of the murder were as follows: Lamparter had committed a felony, and was arrested on a warrant by the Deputy Sheriff of the county.

The Virginia Legislature, at its late session, passed a law appropriating thirty thousand dollars per annum for five years, and placing under the control of the Board, in addition, the amount raised by the tax upon free colored persons, and the sum received for issuing their registers, both of which sums, it is computed, will equal ten thousand dollars annually.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your papers of 9th of February and 7th of March last, containing a biographical notice of the late Doctor THOMAS COOPER, have just fallen under the eye of Mrs. COOPER, the widow of the subject of the Memoir. She resides with her youngest daughter, my wife, and is, though aged, in the enjoyment of good health and the possession of all the faculties of her mind.

Since the opening of navigation, Port Hope boasts of having exported 16,000 bushels of wheat; 5,500 bbls. of flour, and 1,390,000 feet of lumber. Its imports were 2,000 bbls. of plaster, 150 bbls. of salt, and 120 tons of merchandise.

The "Tong-hook-tong" Chinese Dramatic Company commence operations at Niblo's Garden on Friday next. This company must not be confused with the recent Jugglery troupe at the Broadway. It is totally different. There are some fifty members, and they illustrate the manners and customs of their country.

" The Preaching of Knox before the Lords of the Congregation." New-York, GEO. S APPLETON, No. 6 Barclay-street. This is an Engraving in line from WILKIE's celebrated picture, and forms one of a series of cheap engravings about being issued by Mr. APPLETON. The painting is one of WILKIE's best, and illustrates in a remarkably vigorous way a period of history which will ever be interesting to the Protestant.

CHARGE OF INHUMANITY AGAINST A SCHOOL-MASTER.--Yesterday moring, HENRY SNYDER, a gentleman residing at No. 5 Amity-place, appeared before Justice OSBORNE, and preferred a charge against a schoolmaster in Crosby-street, for inhumanly beating his son while a pupil under his care.

JESSE HUTCIIINSON, the telegraph informs us, is dead. The thousands who have heard the HUTCHINSON Family sing will regret the unpleasant tidings. There were many who particularly fancied their style and admired their unaffected execution;

The breezes from the Mexican side grow daily warmer, and more strongly impregnated with the taint of war. The questions at issue are still further from friendly solution. It may not be true, that Gen. PIERCE has taken a view of the Mesilla affair, implying hostile designs.

GENERAL REMARKS.--The name of the Currant is thought to be derived from Corinth, where grapes of a small size are extensively grown, dried, and exported in considerable quantity to distant ports. It is, however, indigenous in Europe, and is valued by every family for its culinary and medicinal uses. It is also easily grown, and is hardy and productive under good cultivation.

The annual election for Directors of the New-York and Harlem Road took place yesterday, and the President of the New-Haven Road, who is also the President of tile Harlem, again heads the successful ticket. To the Editor of the New-Yorks Daily Times: It is to be regretted that the Jury of Inquest did not find in their verdict more accurately what was the real velocity of the train, as it plunged from the bridge at Norwalk, as it is a very important item in estimating properly the conduct of the Engineer on that occasion.

A part of the property of the St. Louis University, known as the College Farm, on the West side of the Bellefontaine road, opposite Lowell, is offered for sale at auction. Part of the tract owned by the Institution is reserved as a site for a College, which it is expected will be erected at an early day. The lots to be sold are on the bluff, and are attractive sites for suburban retreats.

The Lancaster Examiner says that there is a German family resisting near the old Factory in that city. which was in the habit during the past winter of killing and eating such dogs as they could get possession of Being too lazy to work, they resorted to this method of obtaining a livelihood.

There was a fancy of our boyhood, a strange but constant fancy, that we loved to indulge. It had the sweetness of "stolen waters," and yet without guilt : for it was just irregular enough to be vehement, and still, sufficiently well-ordered to be decent.

In all relations to the fair sex, the American gentleman is one of the most gallant of mankind. He has not, perhaps, the delicate and constitutional politeness of the Frenchman, but he is infinitely more in earnest. The Gaul will take off his hat with unparalleled grace, smile, shrug his shoulders, and permit a lady to pass him with as much display as if, like RALEIGH, he was sacrificing a valuable garment in her honor.

DEAR SIR: In common with the readers of the TIMES, I have been very much interested in the series of letters you are writing upon the condition and resources of the Southern States. I have been pleased with the spirit in which they are written--with the moderation, the good feeling, and the intelligence they display; but above all,

I have no disposition ever to weary your readers with immaterial things, and if they appear trivial at times, it is because I fail in giving the explanation that associates them with the vitality of social organization here, or defines their intended influence upon the friendship and commercial intercourse of the "two races," a fault caused by imputing knowledge which can only be had by contact and residence in this community.

Prof. C. N. Shepard, who has just returned from a fortnight's exploration in the Counties of Mecklenburg, Union, Cabarrus and Rowan, N.C., states that the prospect of an abundant supply of copper ore's afforded by the indications presented in the mines of those Counties.

The Buffalo Commercial Advertiser gives the particulars of the examination before the Coroner's Jury, up to Monday morning. Nothing very definite has yet transpired. The Advertiser says: But one body has been recovered since the last reported in the Commercial Advertiser. This proved to be the remains of PHILIP NEIMAR, a carpenter who had been in the employ of Mr. HEFFORD.

The Committee appointed for the purpose have made choice, subject to the decision of the Executive Board which meets in July, of a location for the the site of the Rochester University. The site chosen is situated between New Main-street and East-avenue, and is hounded by Goodmanstreet on the cast, and a new street laid out west of Mr. Boody's residence, from Old to New Mainstreets.

Suppose good reader that you were taken down with a fever to-night; you have had pains in the back, headache, , for some days, and now you find that sundry cutaneous changes are making their appearance sufficient to warrant your fears in ordering the boy to run for a doctor.

We learn by the Florida papers that a movement has been made toward a Canal from Lake Newman to Orange Lake, thence to the Oclawaha River. The initial steps are so far taken that a Board of Managers have been selected to superintend immediate surveys, and upon whose report will depend further action relative to the enterprise.

The arrival of the R. M. steamer Avon at Havana, has placed the Diario de la farina in possession of Mexican news to the 5th inst. The advices are of the utmost importance. We translate from the Piario the following particulars, as especially interesting to our readers at the existing crisis:

The Merchants Exchange property in Wall-street, which was sold a year ago under foreclosure of mortgage for $805,000, and subsequently organized under a new charter from the State, with a capital of $1,000,000 by the parties who made the purchase in the hope of making good their own advances not covered by the mortgage, is now paying a second semiannual dividend of 3 1/2 ?? cent., making 6 1/2 ?? cent. for the first year.

The Cabinet held no meeting to-day, except as Regents of the Smithsonian Institute. The Union is familiar with the recent advices from New Mexico, at which I hinted last night. It is probably restrained from their publication by the fact that the Cabinet have not assented yet to the propriety of making it public.

A few months since, says the Pawtucket Gazette. H. A. Kendall Co. had a number of hogs poisoned by some malicious villain, one of which died. The fore part of the present week, Ira K. Killer had six hogs treated in a similar manner, two of which, valued at $35, died of the poison administered to them.

The transactions of the Provincial Medical Association, volume 19th, has a curious case, in which various symptoms of constitutional disease were excited by the presence of a local and unsuspected cause. A young woman, aged 18, a glovemaker, had for six months been troubled with distressing symptoms, alarmingly affecting the throat.

We published yesterday what purported to be a statement by Captain STINSON, regarding the recent disaster to the bark William and Mary. The account, however, was given very briefly and imperfectly. Capt. STINSON has since vouchsafed the public no further explanations and the narrative of the terrible scene, where so many human lives were sacrificed, can only be gathered at second-hand.

In this City, on Monday, May 16, DAVID TREMBLEY, in the 63d year of his age. The friends and relatives of the family are requested to attend his juneral I at his late residence, No. 123 Forsyth st., on Wednesday, the 18th inst., at 2 o'clock, P. M. On Monday, May 16, ANN ELIZA, wife of Mr. Wm. Allason, in the 36th year of her age.

SHIP BUILDING.--Messrs. PERRINE, PATTISON STACK, have just laid the keels of the following vessels at their Yard foot of North Sixth street: A ship for Messrs. SIFFREN IRONSIDE, destined for the California trade, to be commanded by Capt. SMITH. She is 167 feet on deck, 31 feet in breadth and 18 feet deep. A bark for Capt. EDMUND McKEIGE, (trade not fixed on,) to be commanded by himself.

GENERAL REMARKS, OBJECT OF THE OPERATION, has for its object the rendering of plants more productive either of flowers or of fruit, by regulating the number and position of their branches. If their number be too great they overshadow those below them, and by reflecting the heat and light, prevent that elaboration of the sap required for the production of fruit.

To the Editer of the New-York Daily Times: I read the communication signed JOHN JAY, in reference to the Norwalk disaster, which appeared in to-day's TIMES, with interest. It reveals a good way to get at the speed of the train, without much possibility of error, if the locomotive did actually strike against the opposite abutment.
