THE CASE OF THE SCHOONER FLIRT.--The Java Messenger of March 3, says that the commander, GIBSON, and mate, GRAHAM of the schooner Flirt, have been acquitted of the charge of high treason, but the Court ordered that they should remain in custody until the case had been reviewed by the Supreme Court of Justice for Netherland India.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (New School) meets this day at Buffalo. Subjects of much interest to this branch of the Church are expected to pass in review. The Old School Assembly goes into session at the same hour in Philadelphia.

PRISMATICS--By RICHARD HAYWARDE. D. APPLETON Co., New-York. Fugitive pieces are not generally very pleasant reading. The occasional outpourings of even clever men, do not always bear to be collected into a volume, and though generally serving well enough the evanescent mission for which they have been composed, are seldom worth resuscitation.

The papers have teemed for weeks with repeated accounts of disasters by field and flood. The frequency of these so called accidents has not diverted attention from the causes which induced the catastrophes, but the interest centering in one event has hardly arrived at its climax before the occurrence of something else, even more terrible in its nature, brings up a new subject for painful meditation.

HORSE AND WAGON THIEF.-Officer KIEHL, of the Third Ward, arrested a man named B. MOTT, on Tuesday evening, in Gowanus, Brooklyn, charged with having stolen a horse and wagon, valued at $75, from a man named NICHOLAS GUNCK, residing in Marshall-street. The property being found in his possession, he was required to give bail to appear and answer this morning.

The Seventh Anniversary of the "Society for Relief of Destitute Children of Seamen," was celebrated yesterday at the Home-a handsome brick building erected on an eminence near the Sailors' Snug Harber, Staten Island. A large company of the friends to the Institution with their families, assembled on board the steamboat Staten Islander, at 12 o'clock.

A large wooden building on St. John Smith's wharf, Portland, Me., was discovered to be on fire on Sunday evening. The building was occupied by Messrs. Ford Baker, who, in connection with Mr. William H. Davis, of Boston, were there largely engaged in the hermetically sealed provision business.

The Convention of Southern Planters assembled at Montgomery, Ala., on the 2d inst., and adjourned after three days session. The purpose of this Convention at Montgomery was to organize an Agricultural Association of the Slaveholding States, which shall hold its meetings, in succession, an all the slaveholding States that may participate in the Association.

He devoted himself with great assiduity to the completion of his studies, that he might obtain a diploma which would make him honorable in the estimation of his betrothed.

Our country affords but few more interesting fields for research, either to the scientific geologist, or the mere curiosity-seeker, than these mines situated in Carhondale, Penn. To the geologist they furnish material for the study of well nigh a life time, and the seeker after novelty would be well repaid by a visit thither.

Yesterday morning about 9 o'clock, the longshoremen, in the vicinity of the Atlantic Ducks, struck for an advance of wages, to the number of about two hundred. They demanded an advance of two shillings a day, and seven cents per hour for add work, making their wages twelve shillings per day or twenty-five cents per hour--the same as given in New-York.

The consecration of the recently completed Grace Church, Van Vorst, on Grove-street, took place yesterday, at 11 o'clock A. M., Right Reverend the Bishop of New-Jersey, (G. W. DOANE) officiating. A number of the Clergy of the Diecese assembled in the Chapel in which the congregation of Grace Church has been here. tofore worshipping, and in full canonicals attended the Bishop to the entrance of the new church.

THE OLDEST WOMAN I THE WORLD.-The Charleston Standard thinks that Mrs. SINGLETON, now living in the Williamsburg District, in that State, is the oldest woman in the world. She is now in the one hundred and thirty-first year of her age. Her mental faculties are still unimpaired,

INDIAN NAMES.--The Washington papars contain the copy of a treaty concluded between Commissioner LEA and the Med-ay-wa-kan-toan and Wah-pay-Keo-tay bands of Dakota or Sioux Indians, which is signed by large number of Indians, the translation of whose names in also given.

The St. Louis News has the following: From a file of Minnesota papers, received this' morning, by the Greek Slave, we gather the particulars of a serious difficulty with the Indians of that Territory, originating in an Indian murder committed at St. Paul. A Chippewa is reported to have been killed by the Sioux, not long since;

In its discussion of the French designs upon King KAMEHAMEHA, the Courrier des Elats Unis is unfair and evasive. While we gain from it the admission that the only existing treaty between France and the Sandwich Islands is that of March, 1846, we are still assured that the French demands are based upon infractions of that treaty;

H. R. Starkweather, of Northampton, Mass., says the Springfield Republican, raised last year from an acre. of land, near 1,600 pounds of tobacco, which he sold at 14 1/2 cents per pound, amounting to $230. William and Henry Dickinson, of Hatfield, raised last year, on three acres and threefourths of an acre of land, about 8,000 pounds of tobacco, which they sold in New-York for $1,200.

The Wild-Cat Bankers, beaten heretofore in all their contests with the Metropolitan Bank to arrest cheap redemption in this City, resorted sometime since, in a spiteful spirit of retaliation, to a penal statute of 1839, against circulating distant Bank notes, and brought some sixty odd suits in the nature of a claim for the penalty of $1,000 in each case, against the Metropolitan.

DAVID BROMBUSH was born in 1762, at Bergen, N. J., and at 18 years of age was employed by Gen. WASHINGTON to cart specie to pay off the troops and perform other duties as required. He was an industrious farmer and mechanic, and raised with his own hands in 1801 the old building which stood on the corner of Cedar-street and Broadway.

The Ohio State Medical Society will hold its next annual meeting at Dayton, on the 7th of June next, on which occasion the Montgomery County Medical Society is to entertain them. The same Society will present to the State Society, during the session, a gold medal, to be awarded to the author of the best essay on some topic connected with Medical Science.

Must a man "cut the legs and black of a poor boy with a rattan till the blood flows in many places," because corporal punishment is necessary to preserve order in schools? We believe that the roll should be used, like mercury in medicine as the resort when milder measures fail;

Pitch, Tar and Turpentine of North Carolina--How Produced and Obtained--The Slaves, Peasantry and Proprietors of the Turpentine Forests. TURPENTINE is the crude sap of the pine tribe of trees. It varies somewhat in character and in freedom of flow with the different varieties, the long-leafed pine, (Pinds Palastris), yielding it more freely than any other.

CATTARAUGUS INDIANS.-We learn by the Cattaraugus Chronicle, that the Seneca Indians of the Cattaraugus and Allegany Reservation, held their annual election on Tuesday of last week, when JOHN LUKE was elected President, Z. L. JIMESON, Clerk, ANDREW JOHN, Treasurer.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-- Monday evening's performances were repeated at this establishment last evening. "Don Casar de Bazan" is one of the most effective of modern dramas. The hero-dashing, careless, and brave--is sure to enlist the sympathies of the audience.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We should be satisfied with doing well, and not attempt to exaggerate, which I know you would not intentionally do. In your article on COLLINS fine steamers, you say: " All four of Mr. COLLINS'S ships have now made trips both ways under ten days."

At a meeting of the Members of the Smithsonian Institution or Establishment, as constituted by law, held on the 1st of Aug., 1848, President TAYLOR presiding, a Committee was appointed to draft a set of By-laws for the government of future meetings of the Institution.

When two people have made up their minds to quarrel, there is no trouble about the pretext. The most futile will serve. And as great is his fatuity, who shall propose to baulk the common intention, by reasoning on the folly of the pretext, as his who shall attempt to cure a violent case of hydrophobia, by enlarging on the diminutive size of the dog.

THE ITALIAN EXILES.--The Italian Exiles who arrived at this part on Sunday, in the Sardinian Frigate San Giovanni, have held two meetings at the Shakspere Hotel, relative to their treatment while on board that ship, by the captain, the officers, and the crew. They say that they were treated like prisoners during the voyage, constantly insulted and abused by the captain and sergeant;...

TO CLEAN COMBS AND BRUSHES.--We have often wondered at the obviousness of certain simple recipes, which have ever after their discovery saved much trouble and annoyance, but which we never should have thought of, but for the kindness of some good natured friend with a treasury of these bits of household law.

Speaking of the rust on wire fences, the Scientific American says: "It will be no easy matter to galvanize a rusty wire fence; but it certainly would be a good plan to prepare wire for fences by galvanizing it before it is offered for sale. If rusty wire is rubbed with boiled oil, in which some red lead has been mixed, on a warm day, the rusting process will be arrested."

The young year is jovial to-day, and has thrown off his winter coat that the gay sprigs may be seen on his vest in the smart sunshine. The heavens are perfectly cerulean, except when .little streamers, like flags of truce, float along the azure depths.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--The Board met last evening at the usual hour. Present--Aldermen Moore, Sturtevant, Oakley, Harr, Tweed, Brisley, Trotter, Tieman, Bard, Ward, Demman, Cornell, Doherty and Peck, A few unimportant documents were received and referred, and the Board adjourned at an early hour.

DYING DECLARATIONS.--An interesting and important question of evidence has been decided by the Supreme Court, now sitting at East Cambridge, in the trial of THGMAS CASEY for the murder of OUVRA TAYLOR and his wife at Natick. TAYLOR, it will be recollected, was dead when found, and Mrs. TAYLOR, although speechless and mortally wounded, was conscious nearyly up to the time of her decease.

From the New-Orleans papers we have a few additional items of Mexican news. Several addresses have been presented to the President, asking for the abolishment of the Federal system, which they state is the cause of the disorganization of the country.

LONDON ART-UNION.--The seventeenth annual distribution of the London Art-Union took place on the 27th April. Lord MONTEAGLE, President of the Society, occupied the Chair. The subscriptions of the year amounted to [Pound]13,318. The principal engraving for the year is the "Surrender of Calais," which has been delayed in the engraver's hands for five years. Impressions of the ruled engraving, " Christ led to the Crucifixion," are to be issued at the same time.

Countess BLAAKA TELEKY has just been sentenced to ten years' imprisonment for her share in the Hungarian revolt. She has already been immured three years in the Fortress of Pesth. A story goes that the Emperor has assented to the loan of a million of francs to the Count DECHAMBORD, on security of the domain of Chambord--the money to be advanced by the Bank Foncier.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have just been innoculated with your Small-pox remarks, which are sensible and to the point. But do you not think there ought to be a law made, which doctors should see executed, to this effect, that when they ascertain that the disease is really Small-pox, they should employ men, and the one carriage kept for that purpose to take the patient to the asylum?

TEMPERANCE ANNIVERSARY.-The first anniversary of the Williamsburg City Temperance Society was held in the North Fifth-street Methodist Episcopal Church last evening. Addresses were made by Revs. W. F. COLLINS and JOHN M. REED, of Middletown, Ct.
MY DEAR SIR: All the starch is out of me to-night. I cannot write you a literary letter, but I can extemporize a few incidents, that you may find sufficient for a column of the TIMES.

The Santa Fe mail arrived at Independence, Mo., on the 17th inst., making the trip in 17 days. The Cheyenne tribe were encamped near Fort Atkinson awaiting presents from Major FITZPATRICK. They were perfectly friendly.

SCHOOL MONEYS IN MICHIGAN.-There has been a largely increased sale of Primary School laid in Michigan during the last two years, but the State Journal, published at Lansing, says that, notwithstanding the amount of School moneys to be distributed this year, it will fall considerably short of the apportionment per capital of 1852; not that

This aerial structure engrosses more of public attention abroad than here in the very City that witnesses its growth. It is much talked of in other parts of the Union, and its opening will be made the occasion of visits to New-York by many who would else have never trod the streets of the metropolis.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, Captain HARRISON, arrived at this port at noon yesterday, bringing dates from Liverpool to the 7th inst. The Africa brings 76 passengers, whose names will be found under the appropriate heading. The steamship Washington had not been telegraphed from Southampton when tile Africa left Liverpool.

U. S. COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE--Thursday Before Mr. Commissioner BRIDGMAN.--Charge of cruel punishment at Sea.--The U. S. vs. Lockland McKay.--The defendant in this case was arrested a few days since on the complaint of Stephen Long, the negro cook of the ship Savereign of the Seas, of which vessel the defendant is the master, on a charge of cruel and unusual punishment inflicted on the cook about the 1st of March last.

Rev. MICHAEL EDGARE-VELYNE SHAWE, pastor of the Cathedral at Detroit, died on Tuesday week in the Hospital of the Sisters of Charity in that city. His age was 60. Father SHAWE was born in England, of a highly respectable family, and in early life received a commission in the British .army, and served with marked distinction in many of the sanguinary engagements that marked the continental war.

A spirited controversy has been going on at Boston, and in the Massachusetts Legislature, on the policy of granting the aid of the State to the Hoosic Tunnel, on the line of the new Troy and Greenfield Railroad, to the amount of $2,000,000. Most of the Boston press favor the appropriation.

A PRINTER JUDGE.--CHARLES FERNALD, Esq., a talented and energetic youg printer, who, four years ago, was a compositor upon the Boston Post--has been appointed, by the Governor of California, County Judge for Santa Barbara, of that State. The position to which he has been elevated is an extremely responsible one, embracing criminal, civil, and appellate jurisdiction.

COMMITTED IN FULL.--William Caden alias William Casey, heretofore notice 1 as being arrested by Officer Wolven of the First District Police, at the South Ferry, with a stolen horse in his possession, was yesterday brought before Justice Smith for examination, when he was committed in full on the charge of stealing the horse.

We are requested to publish the following reply of the Commissioners of Emigration to the Governors of the Alms-House, in relation to sundry resolutions touching insane emigrants, which appearel in the TIMES of the 5th inst.:

BROOKLYN ATHENEUM.-PAUL JULIEN gave his concert last evening at the Athenaeum Rooms. The attendance was good, and the entertainment passed off with considerable eclat. An orchestra of some twenty-five instrumentalists assisted, Mr. EISFIELD being Conductor, The overture to " Fra Diavolo" was the first piece.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT.--On Friday last, in Townsend, Mass., (East Village,) another accident occurred, by which twenty-six men came near losing their lives, all through the carelessness of workmen in erecting a staging. The facts are as follows: Between thirty and forty men were engaged in erecting the frame of a new Unitarian Church. Upon the upper beams were laid a few slender boards, unsupported in the centre.

THE STATE MONUMENT TO MR. WEBSTER.An attempt was made in the House of Representatives yesterday, to reconsider the vote by which the WEBSTER Monument resolve wag, the day before, passed to a third reading. The attempt was unsucccssful-the House refusing to reconsider by a majority of five votes only. The Daily Advertiser thus analyses the vote:

The latest Newfoundland advices state that Ambrose Shea, member of the Assembly, has been appointed a delegate to Washington, for the purpose of promoting the views of the House on the subject of free trade between the United States and Newfoundland, and to communicate with the British Minister.

We understand that Mr. CORNELIUS VANDERBILT has sold his Staten Island Ferry, together with a large portion of his valuable estates and Water-privileges on the Island, for $600,000. The sale was perfected the day before his intended departure for Europe in his steam yacht the North Star.

THE HAIL STORM.--The hail storm of Monday afternoon extended to Manchester, N. H., breaking glass and doing much damage. The Mirror says that some of the stones were as large as common red cherries. It is calculated that nearly 4,000 panes of glass were broken out of all the mills and the boarding-houses connected with them, in that city, to say nothing of the injury done to private residences and gardens.

The Navy of the Uinited States is in a lamentable state of decline. It is not wooden. walls alone which make the strength of a Navy, but the number, discipline, bravery, and skill of those who defend them. Small as is the number of national vessels in our Peace establishment, it is found quite impossible to procure the sailors to man them.

New-Orleans pavers of Friday have been received. They contain Texas news to the 10th inst. The most favorable accounts as to the gold discoveries are given by sonic, but they are flatly contradicted by others. The Victoria Advocate is of opinion that there is more hunbug and speculation than gold.

So much has been said about the hard treatment of emigrants by "runners," "agents," , that we doubt not there prevails very extensively an impression that the protection we afford to the sick and destitute who come to us from abroad is very much like the protection that wolves give to lambs.

The following named citizens of the United States have died, leaving no effects, in the Charity Hospital at Panama: Charles Lawrence, Hunts dale, Pennsylvania; James Burton Albany, New York ; Orion Aldridge, Ossippec, New-Hampshire; Patrick Clocklin, Rhode Island-name of town or County where he resided not known.

New-Orleans papers of the 13th have additional Texan items. The gold discoveries are much written of, and very variously. Some say they are veritable-some say they are a humbug. The editor of the Matagorda Tribune considers Gov. BELL'S election to Congress from the Western District as unquestionable, and says he will receive heavy majorities in all the most populous counties of the West.

We have no material change to notice in the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets this week; but we have an improved demand for SUGAR, in which large business has been done. COTTON firm. BREADSTUFFS dull and cheaper. The official returns of the Board of Trade for the three months ending 5th ultimo, show satisfactory deliveries of most articles of consumption; the decrease in TEA being accounted for by the intended reduction in duty.

In the Senate to-day a resolution was adopted authorizing the Committee on the Norivalk disaster to summon before them the President and Superintendent of the Railroad, and directing them to examine the condition of the bridge at Norwalk, and to give the Superintendent of the road reasonable notice when the investigation was to take place.

THE SENTENCE OF THE MURDERER THOMAS CASEY.--THOMAS CASEY, against whom a verdict of guilty of the murder of Mrs. ANGELINA TAYLOR, at Natick, Mass., on the 17th of September last, was returned on Tuesday evening, was brought up at 11 o'clock on the 18th for sentence.

The Diplomatic and consular appointments will be announced on Saturday. Among them may safely be named WISE to France; to Berlin, MEADE; to china, GADSDEN; to Mexico, TROUSDALE; to Chili, SEYMOUR, of Connecticut; to Russia, SAMUEL MEDARY; GILMORE, of Pennsylvania, Consul to Valparaiso; GEORGE SANDERS, Consul to London; and JAMES M. TARLETON, of Alabama, Consul to Acapulco.

SAUT STE. MARIE CANAL INJUNCTION DISSOLVED-We learn that in the matter of tile injunction against the Commissioners of the Saut Ste. Marie Canal, restraining them from executing a contract with Messrs. CORNING and associates, which has been argued before Judge JOHNSON, of the Supreme Court at Jackson, a decision was made yesterday, Judge J. dissolving the injunction.

The Presbyterian General Assembly (New School) convened at 11 o'clock this morning, in the North Presbyterian Church. The proceedings were opened by a sermon from Rev. Dr. ADAMS, of NewYork, the Moderator, of the last Assembly. His text was 1 Corinthians, 4th chap., first five verses. Theme-The Trite Ideal of a Christian Minister.

District Attorney FENDALL resumed his argument to-day, and proceeded with the third proposition, that there were no mines in Laguinillas. He referred to J. C. GARDINER'S letters to VERASTEof in one of which he inquired for the position of his brother's nines, being ignorant of their location, although he had visited them three times.

D., Bishop of New-Jersey, officiated, assisted by Rev. W. R. Gries, rector ; Rev. Mr. Leonard, of Emanuel Church, New-York; Rev. Mr Hart, of New-York; Rev. Mr. Sheldon, of New-York; Rev. Near Millerstown, on the 13th inst., Dr. S. E. Hall extracted from the right ear of Mr. Joseph Gelbach, two hundred live maggots. It seems that a fly or bug entered the drum of his ear, when the immediately started to the physician; but before he reached him, the insect had left its tenement.

THE VALUE OF THE MESILLA VALLEY.--The Washington correspondent of the New-York Times suggests that it will be well to inquire into the value of the Mesilla Valley, before going go war with Mexico about it. In the account which we have already given of this Valley, it was stated that it had never been populated till after the troubles between the two countries;

SHANNON, CHARLES STILLMAN and others were created a corporate and politic body, under the name and style of the "Brownsville and Rio Grande Railroad Company," the road to commence...

Senior CASTILLO LANZAS has been appointed Minister to London, and Senor LARRAINZAR, at present Minister to Washington, it is said, will be sent to Rome. Don JOAQUIN VASQUEZ DE LEON has been appointed Minister of Fometo, thus completing the Cabinet.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A few years since, three Germans, night scavengers, were suffocated by the mephitic, noxious and patrid gases in a sink in Anthony-street, the contents of which they were removing.

In the GARTINER trial this morning, the District Attorney, in continuation, called attention to discrepancies between the evidence before the Board of Commissioners and the testimony of ABBOT and SLOCUM. The latter saw none of the timbers or remains of the extensive building and mining machinery described in the deposition before the former. The mines they visited could not have been those for which claim was allowed.
CYPRESS AND PINE.--A gentleman in Liberty Co., Ga., has lately been instituting investigations as to the durability of cypress and pine, as exemplified in the Cemetery at Midway Church.

In the New-York mercantile community there appears to be a general opposition to the new mode adopted by the Treasury Department for making tile transfers of public money, as being adverse to the general interests of the business community, and not giving the legitimate facilities which the Treasury can afford with perfect safety to the public funds, and which the good people of New-York think the Treasury Department should extend to them.--National Intelligencer.

DEATH OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS.--SAMUEL L. HOLMES, Superintendent of the Public Schools, in this city, died yesterday morning about 8 o'clock, at the residence of his son-in-law, Rav. Mr. GENIN, of St. John's Church. He leaves a wife and family. Since 1848, Mr. HOLMES has, by his untiring and well-directed efforts, probably contributed more to the advancement of our Public School System than any other man. He was a man of marked ability,...

A trial for "homicide by imprudence," growing out of a death from the effects of chloroform, has excited so much interest here, that I give a somewhat detailed report. The deceased, named BRETON, was the son-in-law of RASPAIL, and, at his own request, chloroform was administered to him for the extirpation of a tumor on the right cheek.

Mr. H. WINTER DAVIS, a conspicuous orator in the late SCOTT campaign, has published a book with the fantastic title of The War of Ormuzd and Ahriman, in which he affects to regard the United States and Russia as the respective champions of the principle of liberty and the principle of despotism, and to foresee in the distant future a mighty and decisive conflict between these puissant combatants in the great drama of human history.

There was a good attendance in Allen-street M. E. Church last evening, to celebrate the Sixteenth Anniversary of the Youths' Missionary Society, which continues in a properous condition. Rev. Mr. GOODSELL presided, and opened the exercises by an appropriate prayer.

NEW YORK CORN EXCHANGE.--The Corporation under this title is now fully organized, NATHANIEL H. WOLFE, President; Henry Suydam, jr., Vice President; Issac T. Frost, Treasurer; Philetus II. Holt, Secretary; and T. C. T. Buckley, Counsellor to the Board.

A bold attempt to rob the Bedford Commercial Bank, of New-Bedford, was made on Tuesday night. A robber entered the house of Mr. Whiter the Cashier, stole from his chamber his pantaloons, with the keys of the Bank and $50, then entered the Bank, opened the first door of the vault, but was unable to open the second, notwithstanding he had the proper key.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. Perusing your excellent paper, as is our usual custom, our eye fell upon the following startling paragraph, entitled, "Singular, but True--Its our opinion," says a cotemporary, that if a number of gentlemen are sitting together, talking sensibly upon some sensible subject, and a lady enters, they immediately commence talking foolishly, and keep it up until she makes her exit."

In this City, on the 19th inst., of disease of the heart, RUTH ANNIS, wife of Henry H. Hills. The friends of the family, and those of her brother, Thos. W. Chadwick, are invited to attend her funeral at No. 133 Amos-st., on Saturday, 21st inst. at 2 P.M. May 20, Mrs. MARY CODDINGTON, in the 80th year of her age, widow of the late Abraham Coddington.

A severe gale occurred on Lake Erie yesterday, and numerous disasters are reported. The schooner Andes beached at Cleveland, The crew were saved, but the cargo of corn was badly damaged. The vessel will be saved. The propeller Ohio put into Tonawanda with five feet of water in the hold, having sprung alcak. The schooner Ellington, loaded with railroad iron sunk near Sandusky.

MARTIN KALBLEISCH, Esq., has been chosen President of the Mechanics' Bank. He was previously an efficient member of the Board of Directors of the Citizens' Bank of Long Island, and on tendering his resignation, last Monday evening, was presented with a massive silver pitcher by the President and Directors of the latter institution.

A new Reformed Dutch Church in North Brooklyn is to be commenced to-morrow, under the pastorship of Rev. WM. W. HOLLOWAY, late of the Third Reformed Dutch Church. A site for the Church edifice has been generously donated by Mr. BARNETT JOHNSON, on the Heights, east of the Wallabout; and until the completion of the building, the services will be held in a temporary location at the corner of Bedford-avenue and Hawesstreet.

We have waited since Thursday for some disclaimer from the Washington Union of its article upon Russia. It appeared unjust to indulge in any comments upon its startling tenor, and the results to which it pointed, without thorough assurance of its sincerity and authenticity.

MESSRS. EDITORS--I cheerfully comply with your suggestion in regard to the Calorie Ship. I have much pleasure in assuring you that nothing whatever has occurred in working the machinery indicating the difficulties that can prevent the successful realization of this important enterprize.

On Sunday night last, a drunken man, named Thomas McNeal, while laboring under a fit of mania potu, entered the residence of Archbishop Purcell, in the rear of St. Peter's Cathedral, Cincinnati, and threatened to kill the Bishop. He was armed with a large knife, but was arrested before any damage was done.

The estimated cost of building the sewer canal, which is to extend from Communipaw to Hoboken bays, is $73,414. The main and tribatary sewers, including side culverts and cess pits, will probably cost near $438,428, and ten percent. for contingent expenses, making the whole cost of sewering Jersey City $563,026.

RIO JANEIRO.--By the arrival of the bark Elvira Harbeck, Capt. EMERY, we are placed in receipt of Rio files to the 9th of April. The news is, as usual, without importance. Among the deaths announced, is that of Mr. WINDSOR FIESCHI HENEAGE, a popular attaehe of the British Legation. His funeral was attended by all the foreign Legations and many distinguished residents.

The Old School Prestyterian General Assembly, which commenced its sessions at Philadelphia on Thursday morning last, and is still in session. The proceedings are very interesting. The sessions are held in Dr. CLARK'S (Central) Church, corner of Eighth and Cherry streets.

LAMP.--BRIDGET McGINNISS, 13 years of age, a servant in the family of RANDOLPH LEXON, Esq., No. 257 Bridge-street, died on Friday night about 10 o'clock, from the effects of burns received about 7 o'clock on the same evening, by the bursting of a camphene lamp, which she held in her hand at the time.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As an incorrect notice appeared in your journal this morning, respecting Bishop SCOTT and his visit to Africa, and his recent return, I beg to present a few facts respecting him, Bishop SCOTT, of the Methodist Episcopal Church, sailed from Baltimore in the bark Shirley last December, for Western Africa, on behalf of the Church, and not on account of his health.

A true bill of indictment has been found against the Chagres steamship Illinois, for violating the quarantine laws. Mr. BLUNT, the District Attorney, has acted with promptitude and decision in laying this matter before the Court of General Sessions. The public health demands a strict observance e of the laws framed for its preservation.

The Providence Journal is facetious at the expense of American diplomatists. "The foreign appointments, it is believed, are made, but they are not announced. The telegraphic reporters send an infinite variety of rumors, but there is no certainty in any of the names that have been forwarded.

The steamship United States has arrived at this port in five days and two hours from Aspinwall. She brings San Francisco papers of the 30th of April, and a number of passengers brought down to Panama by the steamship Golden Gate. The run from San Francisco to New-Orleans has thus occupied but 19 days.

The many attractions now in progress all tend to beautify our City. In a few years Broadway will be an avenue of palaces, and unlike any other palaces we know of, devoted to the grandees of Commerce, rather than of indolence. With our streets all laid with the

DISGRACEFUL.--A woman named Margaret Wilson, residing in Brooklyn, appeared before Justice Boswell on Friday morning, and made a complaint against five young men, one of whom she met in the street at a late hour on Thursday evening, and inquired of him her way to Bedford-avenue.

MUNIFICENT BEQUEST.--We learn from the Boston Advertiser that the late ROBERT G. SHAW, of that city, bequeathed in his will the sum of $110,000, to be set apart at interest by his executors until it shall amount to $400,000. This sum is to be known as the "Shaw Fund," and to be appropriated for the benefit of destitute mariner's children under the age of ten years.
The Albany Atlas has taken great pains to correct what it termed a wrong impression in regard to the numerical force the two political parties will have in the Senate during the Extra Session.

The Boston Atlas says it is proposed that all the natives of Brookfield assemble in that ancient town on the Fourth of July next, for the purpose of becoming "better acquainted." Hon. Pliny Merrick, a native, has been named as the orator of the day. We hope the gentlemen in New-York

We have advices from Bermuda to the 13th inst. Three whales had been captured, one by the Port Royal Establishment, and two by the East End boats. The one taken at Port Royal was not captured without a great deal of troublethe animal struggling with the boats for three or four hours. Three shots were fired at it-the first

SUICIDE.-On Sunday afternoon the keeper of a lager beer shop, at No. 101 Essex-street, named FREDERIC BECHER, committed suicide by cutting his throat with a razor. It would seem, from the statement of the family, that for several days past the unfortunate man had been drinking freely, and on Sunday, on receiving some contradietion from his wife, he became excited and left the house, After several hours had passed

A few days ago a colored boy, belonging to Mr. Whitright, near Millersville, Anne Arundel county, Md., accidentally shot dead another colored boy, belonging to Mr. Carr. The mother of the deceased, also a slave of Mr. Carr, in consequence of over exercise in hastening to reach the remains of her son, and from great nervous excitement, brought on by the unfortunate affair, died in a short time after the accident occurred.

The Congregational Church at Lockport, was struck by lightning yesterday afternoon during service. It entered tile gallery occupied by the singers, instantly killing LUTHER CROCKER, one of the choir, and injuring six others, three of whom are ladies. Consternation and dismay seized on

PILLSBURY'S Buildings, and a fresh breeze springing up, the whole, in a few minutes, were completely enveloped in flames. To the South, they reached and
Imports (other than Dry Goods) at the port of New-York, for the week ending Friday, May 20, 1853:

The news from California possesses some interesting features, but is barren of important information. The condition of the country continues prosperous; the mines are yielding well, and general encouragement prevails among the business classes. The routes of inland communication have undergone essential improvements, and the multiplication of facilities for intercourse has had a favorable effect upon the produce markets.

The first business was the reception of a memorial from the New-Albany Theological Seminary, read by Dr. WOOD. The Board of Directors of the Seminary, in their memorial, made application to the General Assembly to take charge of the institution. The Seminary is located at New-Albany, and it is at present under the control of a number of Synods in the West.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your recent strictures on the Hippodrome, as conducted in this City, have been received with much approbation by the public, especially that too numerous class of it, the humbugged ones. But we dwellers in New-York have no conception of the height to which the joke may be carried. To see his acme one must be present at a provincial exhibition.

Salt Lake mail, under charge of Mr. HOBBS, arrived here on Saturday last in contract time. The contractor, Mr. WOODSON, has used every exertion to push the mail through, and has succeeded in spite of the snow to reach Fort Laramie. At every attempt from that place to the valley the mail has been stopped by the snow, since last November. By this arrival we have dates to the 15th from Fort Laramie.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On the evening of Monday, the 16th inst., a report was circulated extensively through the City that the express train from New-York to NewHaven on that day narrowly escaped being precipitated into the draw at Norwalk, and that the forward wheels of the locomotive hung suspended over the water, before the train could be stopped.

The U. S. Mail steamship Union, Capt. ADAMS, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, from Aspinwall, via Kingston, She brings dates from California to the 30th April the same as telegraphed from New-Orleans yesterday. The Union left Aspinwall on the 14th, and Kingston on the 17th inst. She made the run from Aspinwall to Kingston in 51 hours.

The Slare Trade, Domestic and Foreign: Why it Exists, and how it may be Extinguished By H. C. CAREY. A book of profound sagacity and research, though embodying political views not entertained, just at present by the majority of thinking men. Mr. CAREY has written variously upon Slavery, economically considered.

The Anniversary week of the various religious and moral societies commenced to-day. There is a large country representation present, and the meetings are fully attended. The House of Representatives to-day refused to instruct the State Directors in the Western Railroad, to use their influence against the running of Sunday trains. They also rejected the bill

CANKER.-This is a disease in fruit trees, which chiefly corrupts the juices, corrodes the substance and destroys the vitality of the young shoots and branches, and it has long been known and de. plored as a most fornmidable enemy of orchards. Its symptoms vary considerably in trees of the same species, and very widely in trees of different genera.

The Board met last evening, at 5 o'clock, RICE ARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the chair. Present, Aldermet Moore, Haley, Sturtevant, Oakley, Barr, Tweed, Brisley, Francis, Smith, Tieman, Pearsall, Bard, Denman, Cornell, Alvoid, Doherty, Peck.

The American Association for the Advancement of Science will hold its next Annual Meeting at Cleveland, Ohio, on the 28th of July. This is the meeting which was postponed, last Summer, in consequence of ap??D of the Cholcra.

Robert Anderson deposed: I am father of the deceased child; on Saturday evening I was writing at my desk; the fluid in my lamp was nearly out; I am almost positive

The Board of Alderman last evening finally authorized, by a vote of eleven to seven, the contract with Messrs. RUSS REID. The affirmative vote included the names of Messrs. Sturtevant, Moore, Haley, Oakley, Barr, Tweed, Francis, Smith, Bard, Cornell, and Doherty. Messrs. Compton, Brisley, Tieman, Pearsall, Denman, Alvord and Peck voted in the negative.

The Massachusetts House was yesterday afflicted with stubbornness, It refused to instruct the State Directors of the Western Railroad to use their influence against the running of Sunday Railroad trains, and rejected the bill for tile appointment of a Board of Railroad Commissioners.

All signs ran in dry weather, surely. Three religious bodies are this week in session, the meeting of any one of which, in old times, was deemed sufficient to insure an Easterly storm. Philadelphians will testify that the meetings of General Assembly in that city never before failed of a heavy shower, at least, in token of the Weather Clerk's approval of its object.
HORNER FOOT and HENRY ROSE, Esqrs., were assailed to-day in our streets, by FREDERICK DWIGHT, when a regular fight ensued between Messrs. FOOT and DWIGHT, in which the latter came off second best.

Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times. To-morrow, the election for District Judges comes off, and many of the candlidates are making the best of their time and money, in treating and making friends ! It is disgusting and humiliating to see men thus degrading themselves, with a view of obtaining a seat on the wool-sack, as if the manthe of Justice would hide their defectss and enormities, and support a new dignified character!

The purpose of a majority of the Legislature which reassembles at Albany to-day, to aid the Enlargement of the Canals, is gearcely a question of doubt. In the Senate, the opposition, in the absence of Senator MuMURRAY, will not be able to command half a dozen votes. And in the Assembly, if the measure can be fairly disembarrassed from collateral issues, success is well nigh sure.

The Assembly visited the Falls of Niagara on Saturday. Last evening, an eloquent discourse was delivered on " Ministerial Education," in one of the Churches, by Professor SMITH, of the Union Theological Seminary of New-York. His text was: " The harvest is great-the laborers are few." The Churches yesterday were all well filled.

The defence of a literary man who was arrested for drunkenness in Paris, is translated thus: " He who drinks well sleeps well, he who sleeps well thinks no evil, he who thinks no evil commits no sin, he who commits no sin shall be saved; therefore, he who drinks well shall be saved !"

ARREST OF A COUNTERFEITER-LARGE HAUL OF COUNTERFEIT MONEY.-This morning information was given to the Chief of Police that a man had passed upon a newsboy a counterfeit gold dollar. An officer was dispatched in search of the man, and found him in the street and arrested him: but while conducting him to the Second Distriet Station-house, he made an effort to run away.

The afternoon session of the General Assembly on the 20th, was one of considerable interest. After the presentation and reference of the records of the Synods, and the statistical reports and narratives of the Presbyteries, the report of the Committee of Conference with the American Home Missionary Society was presented by Rev. THORNTON A. MILLS, in the absence of Rev. Dr. DUFFIELD, Chairman of the Committee.

It would be positively refreshing to turn from the continually repeated record of bribes laken and frauds committed-of peculation and pilfering perpetrated by persons in official stationn , and bearing the reputation of honest men, to the robberies of acknowledged villains and professed highwaymen.

SAUNDERS.

Albany: makes little pretension to rank or special notice among the cities, on account of either beauty or hurried growth, yet it is decidedly a thrifty place, and possesses attractions in its public buildings, its shady parks, and luxurious hotels, which few cities can surpass.

The value of the products of the forest passed through the New-York Canals has been nearly quadrupled in ten years. The figures of 1852 show over ELEVEN MILLIONS DOLLARS. The trade is one which can only be successfully and cheaply prosecutted through water communication.

In Williamsburg, on Monday, May 23, of consumption. HANNAH, he wife of Robert McAdam, in the 35th year of her age. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 203 2d, near Grand st., Williamsburg, to-day, (24th inst.,) at 10 o'clock in the forenoon. Her remains will be interred in the Cemetery of the Evergreens.

The Criminal Court met this morning, and notified the GARDINER Jury that the Court was about to adjourn until Wednesday, and if the Jury agreed upon a verdict in the meantime, they might seal it and keep the contents to themselves. The Jury returned an answer that there was no proability of their agreeing before Wednesday.

PARK.--The state of DE WITT CLINTON, intended for Greenwood Cemetery, was fixed yesterday morning in its pedestal in front of the City Hall, under the superintendence of the Sculptor, Mr. HENRY K. BROWN. It is a colossal Pedestrian figure, and the first that has been cast entire in this country.

Suddenly, on Tuesday, May 24, XAVIER M. SCHMID, aged 37 years. The friends of his family, and those of his father-in-law, Ernest Keyser, Esq., are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, at his late residence, 50th st. near 5th-av., to day, (Wednesday) May 25, at 3 o'clock, P. M., without further notice.

The Complimentary Concert to Signor ARPITI, comes off on Thursday next, at Metropolitan Hall, instead of Castle Garden, as originally stated. We learn that it will positively be the last opportunity of hearing the charming Madame ALBONI, for that amiable lady sails on the ensuing Saturday for Europe. The progress of Mrs. H. B. STOWE Co, in England, is among the leading of our Foreign advices. Mrs. STOWE has been received at Stafford House. The London Daily News of the 7th gives a detailed account of a presentation to Gov. KOSSUTH of an elegant copy of the works of SHAKSPEARE. The speeches of DOUGLAS JERROLD and KOSSUTH are highly interesting. The News says:

Washington City is the stage of a national theatre. A new company just now occupies it, with new actors, new scenery, and a new repertory. The nation has been quietly waiting until the scene should be cleared of supernumerary office-seekers and hangers on, and the curtain lifted on the actual and prospective performances of the main figurants.

JAMES WALKER, D. D., was inaugurated President of Harvard College to-day. The escort of Governor CLIFFORD was the Boston Light Dragoons. The address and induction into office was delivered by the Governor, and was replied to by President WALKER.

The Conference re-assembled at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, Bishop WAUGH in the Chair. An application from Brother HARVEY CAMP, of Clinton, to be placed on a supernumerary relation, was granted. He had no claim, but made the request in consequence of family affliction.

Twenty two removals from office in the Custom-house were made to-day--mostly Inspectors, Weighers and Watchmen. A salute was fired at noon to-day from the Cunard wharf, in honor of the anniversary of the birthday of Queen VICTORIA.

ATTEMPT TO SET A CRIMINAL AT LIBERTY.-A few days since we noticed the arrest of a noted thief by Officer JOHNSON upon suspicion of his having stolen a lot of Valuable silk vestings, which were found in his possession. The accused was brought before Judge WELSH, at the Essex Police Court, but all efforts to ascertain the owner of the goods were unavailing.

The Singapore Free Press, of the 18th March, has from Java some news about Mr. GIRSON, proprietor of the American schooner Flirt, and his mate, who were taken last year to Batavia from Palembaug, accused of having endeavored to excite the Sultan of Jambi to hostilities against the Dutch Government. The Hoosac Tunnel bill has been defeated by the Massachusetts Senate; having previously passed the House by a vote so decisive that its friends entertained sanguine hopes of its ultimate success.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. SHANNON, frow Liverpool, at 11 o'clock, A. M., on the 14th inst., arrivedd at this port at 121/2 o'clock today. She brings 100 through passengers and 15 for Halifax. The screw steamship City of Manchester, arrived out at Liverpool at midnight on the 10th inst.

Both the Uncle Sam and Crescent City arrived from Aspinwall yesterday morning. Their California dates are no later than those by the Union. The Isthmus news by the Uncle Sam is one day later. We are indebted to Pursers BUCKMAN and BULLAY for early deliveries.

BRECKENRIDGE was submitted as Chairman of the Committee on the memorial of the Presbytery of Baltimore, instead of that of the mover. The Commercial Advertiser felicitates itself on the correctness of its doubts respecting a new French expedition to Hawaii. It rather exults over the Providence Journal and its official informant, and doubtless hugs itself in never being detected by the plausibility of such stories.

The Delavan House was robbed yesterday, by some professional hotel thief, of three dozen brass candlesticks, four dozen knives, a quantity of sheets and pillow-cases, and a ladies' gold watch, with a small thick old fashioned face.

I learn that the President disavows and repudiates, in the strongest terms, the sentiments of the Union's Russian article, and that he is deeply mortified that he should he supposed to endorse them. He will, probably, however, fail to disavow it publicly, on the plea that he has never publicly avowed the Union as his organ.

The Assembly opened at the usual hour. Pending the question of adopting the Minutes, a discussion arose upon the title which had been given the proposed Metropolitan Church. The Minutes were approved, after inserting the word " Presbyterian" before the word 44 Church," making the sentence read, " A Presbyterian Church at Washington.

The foreign appointments are generally regarded as of a high order, though of course dissatisfaction is felt by disappointed applicants. Many of those who drew blanks, left town to-day. CHARLES LEVI WOODBURY, set down for Charge to Bolivia, states to-day that he has declined the appointment.

The Legislative proceedings of to-day afford nothing of interest. Each House entered upon its business, where it was last month, without any formalities. In the Senate a joint resolution was introduced, fixing 9th of June, at 3 P. M. for tile adjournment. This is a Buncombe proposition.

By the arrival of the Union, we have advices from Kingston, Jamaica, to the 17th inst., with corresponding dates from various Islands of the group. The Yellow Fever was raging in the Public Hospital at Kingston to an alarming extent, the daily average admittance being six or eight.

The Extra Session of the Legislature commenced yesterday. The proceedings were quite unimportant, although both Houses began business at the point where it was suspended in April. The Senate has evinced a landable disposition to get at work and finish its business in respectable season, and for that purpose a movement has been made for a final adjournment early in June.

The Foreign appointments are at length officially announced, as far as determined up on. Several of the more prominent missions were understood some weeks since, and have already been referred to by press. The mission to Russia is now assigned to Gov. SEYMOUR of Connecticut, a gentleman of moderate abilities, but high personal worth, and a distinguished favorite of his party in his own State.

The Ministers of Buffalo took an universal respite yesterday--every Evangelical pulpit being occupied by some member of the Assembly, as well as those of most of the neighboring towns. We are beginning to get settled. In a month or two we shall be all to rights. From positive chaos we have issued into a neutral state, transitive to comparative Cosmos. I have no doubt the bedsteads will be up in another week, and provided the floors don't give way, the carpets down.

Macaulay's History of England, we are told, has been put in the Index, at Rome; the Index being a second Tree of Knowledge of good and evil, the leaves of which all Catholic children of Adam and Eve are forbidden to touch. But it doesn't matter. It could not possibly find better company.

The roll being called, twenty-four Senators answered to their names. The Senate Journal of April 15, was then read. Mr. VAN SCHOONHOVEN desired to have the journal corrected inasmuch as it represented him as having objected to the entertaining of a joint resolution. Such was not the fact. The Journal was corrected.

Three conspicuous facts have attended SANTA ANNA'S assumption of dictatorial power in Mexico. The first is, his apparent determination to subvert the Mexican federative system, and convert the Government into a military authority, based upon the power of a newly-organized army.

We are in receipt of dates from the City of Mexico to the 9th instant. Government was adopting severe measures against all whose opinions where considered pernicious. A decree had been published for the arrest of all who served in the army during the late war as guerillas, to be tried by Court Martial.

The Conference assembled at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, in the Ailen-street M. E. ChurchBishop WAUGH not being present. Rev. H. BANGS was called on to preside, but before he was seated the Bishop arrived, and requested him to read a portion of Scripture. After the usual religious exercise, the minutes of Tuesday's proceedings were read and approved.

The table of the Methodist Conference, now in session in this City, has lying on it a proposition which may be reckoned among the signs of the times. A resolution had been offered, which among other things, provided for aid to a new meeting-house; to thing Dr. FLOY offered an amendment to the effect that in said meeting-house the distinction of mens' and womens' sides should be abolished.

The Boston Anniversaries are now under way. The Evangelical Tract Society had its annual meeting on Monday. By the Treasurer's report, it appears that the funds of the Society consist of notes and bills receivable, $1,148 65; interest due, $63 92; balance from the NewEngland Sunday School Union, $165 75. Total, $1,383 32.

This phrase has its social as well as its political signification. Those who have associated it with certain feverish and reckless principles of progress, and seen it assumed as a badge by certain fiery politicians, will be scarcely prepared to find it the distinctive title of a strange and effeminate race of creatures by whom modern society is infested.

U. S. CIRCUIT COURT.--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The Homicide on board the ship American congress.--MICHAEL REARDEN was put to the bar on an indictment charging him with the murder of HENRY MILLER, while on board the ship American congress, on the 12th of April last, by striking him on the head with a belaying pin.

Mr. BABCOCK gave notice of a bill to amend the General Banking Law. BILLS PASSED UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED. To fix a permanent pier line for Brooklyn. To amend the law-relative to State Prisons. To amend the charter of Saratoga Springs. For the relief of HARRY HALL, (occasioned by the break of a railing over a canal bridge.)

FROM TAMPICO.--We have dates to April 30 Gen. WOLL, appointed by SANTA ANNA Comandante General of the forces of the State of Tamaulipas, had arrived and taken command. He has shown the spirit in which Mexico is to be governed by SANTA ANNA, by his first steps. He arrested and shipped off to Vera Cruz the entire ayuntamiento, replacing it by one of his own selection.

The Legislative proceedings yesterday were sensible. Both Houses worked well. The Senate produced a sparring scene, in which Messrs. VANDERBILT, PIERCE and COOLEY figured,-Mr. COOLEY charging PIERCE with dodging; and Mr. VANDERBILT seeking to end the fray by offering a resolution, declaring it the duty of the State to pay interest on the Canal Revenue Certificates, and directing the Canal Committee to bring in a bill to that effect.

Is the Union the organ?These are a few of the interrogatories on every tongue to-day. The comments made by the North.

It becomes our painful task, says the Augusta Constitutionalist, of the 19th inst., to announce the death of Major GEORGE L. TWIGGS, a well known, prominent and respected citizen of this community. After lingering and painful illness of thirteen weeks, he died on Monday, at his Summer residence, nine miles below the city, in the 64th year of his age.

We have accounts from Galveston to May 13. The requisite amount of stock having been obtained to build the telegraph line, from Galveston to Shreveport, La., a meeting of the stockholders will be held at Crockett, the first week in June, and the Company will be organized.

The steamship Texas with dates from Vera Cruz to the 22d inst., has arrived here. She reports that on the 17th a revolution broke out there among the National Guards, in consequence of an order from Government to incorporate the Nationals with the troops of the line. The revolution lasted three

In England, there were 94,416 persons married between Oct. 1 and Dec. 31, of 1852-more than ever before for the corresponding quarter of any previous year. The London Correspondent of the National Intelligencer thinks that this establishes the fact that with the growth of general prosperity the number of marriages increases.

The Lecture, by THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER, Esq., at the Metropolitan Hall last evening, in behalf of the sick and disabled New-York Volunteers, was an exceedingly brilliant affair. At an early hour the building commenced to fill-indeed by the time appointed for the delivery of the lecture, the Hall was densely thronged.

The New-England Anti-Slavery Convention met to-day at the Melodeon. WENDELL PHILLIPS was chosen President, with eight Vice-Presidents, including CHARLES REDMOND, colored, and ELIZA KENLY, both of Salem. HENRY C. WRIGHT offered resolutions against voting or taking any part under the Constitution of the United States, doing so being an approval of all the acts of Government.

The steamship Star of the West and Georgia, the latter bringing the California mails and specie, arrived at this port yesterday. The dates from California are no later. The Star of the West brings 437 passengers, whose names will be found under the appropriate heading, together with those of the Georgia.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser, Saturday. Some anxiety is felt here respecting the schooner Watts Sherman. She left Cleveland on Tuesday last for this port, and has not yet arrived. The schooner Koscvusko, which left Cleveland some hours after the Sherman. got in safely on Thursday evening. It is reported that

The Anniversary of the Methodist Episcopal Missionary Society was celebrated in Allen-street Church at 8 P. M. There were but a few persons present. Rev. Dr. BANGS presided, and after singing and prayer, introduced Rev. Mr. CHAMBERLAIM, who had consented to supply the place of Rev. Mr. WAKELEY, prevented from attending by illness.

By the steamer arrived yesterday morning, we have one day's later news from Kingston. The Legislature re-assembled on the 17th, for the third time this season. The Governor opened the session with a speech, in which he asks them to grant the ordinary supplies by revising and continuing the Import and Rum Duties acts of the preceding year. He says:

The steamship Isabel arrived here on Tuesday night, bringing Havana dates to the 22d inst. There is no political news. The Diario indulges in its usual invectives. MARKETS.--SUGARS were dull but prices firm, The crop is reported to be one-tenth larger than last year.

The Foreign appointments are very distasteful to our neighbor, the Evening Post. We copy, on another page, the characteristic comments which the official list has called forth from the organ of the Barnburner wing of the New-York Democracy.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Notwithstanding I have some half-dozen times contradicted in the public prints the reports of my being interested in the Hippodrome, I ob. serve that your Correspondent from New-Haven reiterates the old story, and insists that FRANCONI and BARNUM in this country are synonymous terms.

Mr. MEAGHER said: "Young Ireland " was so christened with a sneer. As in the days of PITT and WALPOLE, it was an atrocious crime to be a young man. But it mattered little about the mocking baptism. LICENCES.--The Board of Excise held an extra session yesterday afternoon, and granted upwards of 30 additional licenses. PLANK-ROAD.--The contract for constructing the Flushing and Greenpoint plank-road, was completed yesterday morning. The road will be at once commenced.

Yesterday afternoon the Special Committee was appointed to consider matters pertaining to the Slavery question, as follows: Dr. Thompson, Rev. Messrs. Monteath, Milligan and Mills, Elders Jefferson, Carey, Bishop.

SYSTEM OF SEWERAGE.--The plan of City Sewerage, comprised in the Report to the Water Commissioners of Jersey City, by WM. S. WHITWELL, Civil Engineer, has been submitted to the Board. The report says that the supply of water and the sewerage of the City, are so allied that they should be subject to the same control. Within the bounds of the City there are 1,154 acres

In the afternoon of yesterday, the reports of the delegates of the Assembly to the foreign ecclesiastical bodies in correspondence, were called up, Rev. Mr. CLARK reporting an agreeable visit to the General Convention of Vermont; Rev. Mr. PATTERSON, to the Presbyterian and Congregational Convention of Wisconsin-during which he assured

We are grateful to the President that, in making his selection of diplomatic representatives, he has weakened the home force of the Democratic party of the country in the least possible degree. He could hardly have chosen an equal number of prominent men whose absence would be less seriously felt than those whose names we copied yesterday from the official bulletin.

REMARKABLE FORGERY.--REAL ESTATE NOT ALWAYS REAL SECURITY.--A few days since, a homespun, farmer looking man, who gave his name as JAMES HUDSON, appeared in Parma, in this County. He represented himself as from Dutchess County, New-York, where he had recently sold his farm, and claimed to be in search of a new location in this section of the country.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Macbeth--Obstinate Family. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Don Caesar de Bazan--Used Up. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Our Gal--Uncle Pat's Cabin--The Happy Man.

Gov. HUBBARD, appointed Consul to Trinidad de Cuba, and GILMORE, at Bordeaux, have today formally declined. WOODBURY is also said to decline the Bolivian Chargeship, and MEADE probably will refuse to accept that of Sardinia. LEE, PIERCE'S biographer for the West, refuses the little Consulate at Basle, and the President offers him the Secretaryship of the Brazilian Legation.

Madame ALBONI makes her final appearance to-night. The occasion is the benefit of Signor ARDITI, of whom we have already spoken. The programme is an attractive one, if, indeed, any attraction be necessary beyond the presence of the gifted and genial ALBONI.

It is not with this subject as it is with the "rappings," where if one has said a word in defence of them even, if only half seriously, he feels the necessity of calling in his old friends and bringing on the affidavits to prove that he is possessed of common sense yet. But, seriously, of a woman's

Late arrivals at London of half a million sterling of silver, had sold at three-eighths of a penny deduction. New dollars are worth four shillings eleven pence farthing. Messrs. BELL SON report considerable amount of business done in American securities, at firm prices. Several transactions in Maryland Fives at

This City has participated in the agitations of various classes of laborers for increased wages. The movement here has not been productive of benefit to one class, the hotel waiters, who generally took part in it. Their places have, for the most part, been filled by others.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Can you, and will you, tell a Subscriber, what has become of the U. S. Post for the City Delivery at a cent a letter ? Is it dead, or moribund ? Waxeth it or waneth it ? The boxes are as scarce as eels in filtered Croton-almost.

An important movement has been made in the General Assembly at Buffalo. A large sum is appropriated, alter the Congregational fashion, for purposes of Church Extension in the West. On the second Sunday in November, a general collection is to be taken up in all the churches, in aid of the project.

The Imperial Society of Horticulture (last year it was the National Society,) is holding its 24th Annual Exhibition in the Champs Elysees. The most temporary construction built by the French, looks as if it were meant to stand for years. The Horticultural tent and the flower garden in shelters, seem quite as permanent as the Crystal Palace, just over the way.

What was the design of the name Whig ? Before the party shall break up and vanish--" Pierced through and through with cunning words," (for we are solemnly assured that it is as good as done for,) we may ask about its antecedents.

DEAR SIR :--I wonder whether all the fine things we used to read about sheep, shepherds, and shepherdess, pass now for anything more than humbug? You know they were once themes for ambitious poets, and if we look at old pictures we see that they monopolized acres of canvas.

A correspondence elsewhere in the DAILY TIMES assures us that the petty difficulies respecting the Sardinian corvette, San Giovanni, have been satisfactorily adjusted. This is very well. Nothing was clearer from the first than that the misdemeanors of the crew resulted from ignorance and timidity; certainly from no disposition to wanton outrage or violence. The affair concerned their own

MARETZEK'S OPERA TROUPE.--MAX MARETZEK'S Opera company will commence operations, in all probability, on Monday next, STEFFANONE is the prima donna; SALVI the tenor; MARINI basso profundo; BENEVENTANO principal baritone, and the chorus and orchestra as heretofore.

AMERICAN EDUCATION SOCIETY.-The Boston Anniversary season develops the following facts regarding this society. Receipts of the parent society, located in Boston, the past year, $22,729 15; expenditures, $19,828 12. Receipts of Philadelphia auxiliary, $5,311 22; expenditures, $3,756 22. No returns received from the central society at New-York.
The Diocesan Convention of the Episcopal Church in New-Jersey, assembled at Burlington on Wednesday and adjourned on Thursday of the present week. The business was of the usual routine character.

No exploring or surveying expedition has ever left our shores destined to so interesting and so wide a field of labor--to a field so little known-and one to the results of which, commerce alike with science, will look forward with anxiety and ?? deep-felt interest. Many imagine this to be the long-talked of Japan expedition , with which it has no connection.

PRESENTATION.--The Police of the First District presented their Captain, JOEL SMITH last evening. with a splendid gold watch and chain, valued at $142, as a mark of their respect and esteem for him as a man and an officer.
The Conference met yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, Bishop WAUGH presiding. Rev. Mr. NORRIS read a portion of Scripture, and after the usual religious exercises, the Conferencee proceeded to business.

The dates from the City of Mexico by the steamship Texas, are to the 18th inst. SANTA ANNA had issued many other arbitrary decrees. Legislative authority of all kinds had been suspended throughout the Republic, and the offices of Governor and Military Commandant were united in the same person. JACKSON'S EPITAPH ON HIS WIFE--The Richmond Enquirer says: A lady in the West has been kind enough to send us a copy of ANDREW JACKSON'S epitaph on his wife. It is known to have been his own composition, yet although it has been read by hundreds on her tomb in Tennessee, it has never appeared in print before. This singular inscription reads thus:

Jeferson County--Harper's Ferry and Bolivar Districts give FAULKNER, (Dem.) for Congress, 370, and BOTELER, (Whig) 173-being a Democratic gain since the Presidential election of 172. The same districts give BUTTON and GIBSON, Whig candidates for the Legislature, a considerable majority.

On Thursday, 26th inst., by Rev. W. W. Wallace, Miss TERISA W. GREELY to WM. W. FOWLER, both of this City. On Thursday morning, the 26th inst., by Right Rev. Bishop Wainwright, THOMAS HICKS, of New-York, to ANGELINE, daughter of Dr. T. F. King, of Brooklyn,

SABBATH SCHOOL UNION.-Notwithstanding the unpleasant weather of Tuesday, the representatives of the Brooklyn Sabbath School Union assembled in the Church of the Pilgrims, and a large number of persons were in attendance. The Committee on Statistics reported 75 schools connected with the evangelical churches of this city. in these schools are 710 male and 930 female teachers. Pupils--males 5,646; females 6,663, making a total of l2,269.

The Memorial of GRINNELL, MINTURN Co., and others, asking for the repeal of the Emigrant Passenger Law, which passed on the last night of the regular session, was taken up and debated, and committed to the Senators from New-York and COOLEY. Mr. MORGAN presented a memorial of PETER COOPER, and others, for aid to the New-York Juvenile Asylum.

SIXTH DAY--AFTERNOON SESSION. On the report of the Committee on Education, a substitute was offered by Rev. Mr. SPENCER, and adopted, recommending the Central and Philadelphia Societies, and appointing a Committee to digest a plan for prosecuting the work hereafter.

The afternoon of Tuesday was consumed in an animated discussion on an incidental aspect of the many-sided Slavery question. Rev. Dr. JUDD had prepared a History of the Division of the Presbyterian Church, for which the sanction and approval of the Assembly were desired.

Both branches of the Massachusetts Legislature adjourned sine die at 10 1/2 o'clock last night. During the performance at the Lowell Museum last night, a young man named WHEELER, acting as a supernumerary, was accidentally stabbed with a bayonet over the eye, which entered his brain, killing him instantly.

In the vicinity of Fayetteville there are many Scotch Highlanders.

Our country cousins of Boston and Buffalo are at us again. Good men, both, but they will have their humor. The North Star excursion is the subject of their present fun. The Post describes tile Commodore in his steam yacht cruising round the world as "Jonathan on a tear," which, outside of Boston, we presume, means a frolic.

The appointment of AUGUSTE BELMONT as Charge to the Hague, continues a topic of excited discussion, and has few apologists even among the warmest supporters of the Administration. The probability of his nomination had been suggested, and its possibility discussed; but the announcement of its consummation burst like a thunder peal upon the astonished Democracy.
The District appointments are now under the consideration of the Executive. RAMSEY (Dem.) has been appointed Chief Clerk in the office of the First Comptroller, vice SEAMAN, (Whig) removed.
The mails from Europe by the steamer Europa, at Boston, reached this City at one o'clock this morning, over the New-Haven Railroad. We add some interesting details of European intelligence.

Our Costa Rica dates and brought down to the 12th. President MORA'S Inaugural Message treats of the happy and tranquil state of the Republic. We have Halifax papers to the 17th inst. On the 16th, the British ship of war Cumberland, bearing the flag of Vice Admiral SEYMOUR, with the Admiral and his family on board, arrived from Bermuda. The Admiral is charged with the protection of the fishing interests of the Provinces.

Your editorial article of Wednesday does injustice to DUDLEY MANN. He is a man of no concealments, and whatever his part in any transactions, does not hesitate to acknowledge it. It is perfectly well known that he is not partizan--was not appointed on any such grounds; and it is notorious that he has taken not the least part in the selection of foreign appointees.

SALE OF THE PUBLIC LANDS IN MAINE.-A bill, which had previously passed the House of Representatives, was on Saturday passed by the Senate, authorizing the Land Agent, with the concurrence of the Commissioners, to dispose of the lands, with the timber thereon, in Maine, which belong to this Commonwealth.

The Washington papers contain a protest of the U. S. District Attorney in the GARDINER case, presented to the Court on Wednesday. Mr. FENDALL remonstrates against the decision of the Court in taking up the trial of GEO. A. GARDINER before that of JOHN CHARLES, his brother, and avers that he will not call up the case of the latter at the time designated by the Court, being Monday, May 30.

The last vestige of the Astor Place Opera has passed away. The interior of the house has been dismantled. The fixtures, furniture and scenery, have been brought to the auctioneer's hammer, and sold, aptly enough as some might say, for a song.

The Jury in the GARDINER case sent a communication to the Court, this morning, stating that after mature deliberation, and a full interchange of sentiment, they found it impossible to agree, and asking that some arrangement be entered into between the Counsel, and that they might be discharged.

THE WORD "SELAH."--The translators of the Bible have left the Hebrew word Selah, which occurs so often in the Psalms, as they found it, and of course the English reader often asks his minister or some learned friend what it means. And the minister or friend has most often been obliged to confess ignorance, because it is a matter in regard to which the most learned have by no means been of one mind.

The Report of Professor JOHN B. TRASK, communicating to the California Legislature the results of a geological survey of the Sierra Nevada, is a document of the highest importance. The examination by Prof. TRASK was extended along the whole range. The different rocks were subjected to careful scrutiny and chemical analysis.

The Evening Post claims Hon. PETER D. VROOM as a fellow Barnburner. No one will probably be more surprised at the announcement than Mr. VROOM himself, although the opportunity of fraternizing with the Post may not be rejected by him, when he comes to reflect upon all the advantages of the connection. In consideration of the difficulty of procuring seamen for the Navy, the Navy Departmnnt has issued an order, offering a bounty of thirty dollars for each able bodied, and twenty dollars for each ordinary seamen, who shall enlist on and after the 1st of June next.

EDUCATIONAL.-The proposals for the erection of a new School House for the Third Ward, will be received by the Board of Education until the 31st inst. and will be opened that evening. Miss MARIA F. SAVAGE has been appointed first Assistant Teacher of Public School No. 1. A room has been hired at No. 20 Grovestreet for the education of colored children.

THIRD DAY. The Synod met yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. The proceedings opened as usual with prayer, after which the Minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved. Sundry papers and memorials were received, read, and referred to appropriate Committees.

Among the most interesting movements of the Barnburners to defeat any useful action in favor of the Canals, is the contrivance of the Speaker of the Assembly to gain or save a few doubtful Democratic votes, by appointing sons and nephews of members and of door-keepers as pages to the Assembly.

On Wednesday, May 25, THOMAS R. LOWRY, aged 37 years. The funeral service will he performed at 12 o'clock Friday, at the residence of his brother, No. 90 Warren st., Brooklyn. On Fourth day, the 25th inst., REUBEN BUNKER, in the 81st year of his age.

SUICIDE BY DROWNING--At an early hour yesterday, a man named WM. HEANEY left his boarding house, No. 86 James-st,, near to the wharf, and leaped into the East river. All efforts to save his life proved unavailing, and he was drowned. The body was recovered shortly after. Coroner HILTON held an inquest,

A KEY TO " BLEAK HOUSE"--CHANCERY PRACTICE IN ENGLAND.--A report of a Parliamentary Committee states these facts A tradesman died, some ten years ago, possessed of personal property to the amount of ??1,000. The two executors under the will took no steps to wind up the affairs, and a creditor's bill was filed in Chancery twelve month's after the testator's decease.
The Isabel brings us Key West dates to the 22d instant. The bark Overmann, wrecked on the 8th inst., had discharged and hove out. She was badly injured. Her Captain arrived here in the Isabel.

Several of the Committees on the Records of Synods, reported. The Reports were approved, except in two cases, where the exceptions they reported were stricken out. Rev. A. TOBY, from the General Conference of New-Hampshire, appeared, and upon invitation, addressed the Assembly in relation to the state and condition of the churches and the body that he represented as a corresponding delegate.

IMPORTANT RAILROAD IMPROVEMENT.-Mr. ROBERT MILLS, of Washington, intimates to the public that an improved railroad engine has been perfected by him, that will be capable of running a mile a minute for any distance, and that he has nearly accomplished an improvement in the construction of railroads, by means of which this rate of speed may be made in safety.

The Norfolk Argus states that a curious phenomenon attended the hail storm in that city on Tuesday night. Quantities of catfish, measuring a foot in length, fell in different sections of the city, and some of the fields were literally strewed with them. Hundreds were picked up in the morning. This, says the Argus, is no piscatorial fabrication, but a fact which is attested by hundreds of citizens.

The alarm was immediately given, and a search instituted for her in all direcions. In the course of a few minutes...

Another fishing fleet has sailed to protect the cod and mackerel on the Provincial coast. The particular necessity for renewing the armed surveillance at this time is not indicated, though we may presume that it all arises from a prudent desire on the part of Her Majesty's Government to forestall any further difficulties.

The present week has been, in a Parliamentary point of view, quieter than its predecessor. The budget is deemed safe-that is, safe against another such a lengthy debate as occurred on Sir E. B. LYTTON'S amendment, but not against various side-wind attacks on different portions of the plan.

The municipality are making experiments with anew street-sweeping machine. By one class, improvements and innovations of this sort are looked upon with a very jealous eye-the chiffoniers. In 1832, dust-carts upon a new plan were introduced into Paris; their method of operations was such that the heaps of rubbish and refuse were removed with such celerity, that the rag-pickers found themselves all at once without a trade.

Seventh District-Alexandria gives Snowden, (Whig,) for Congress, 305 majority. As far as heard from, Snowden gains 219 over the last Presidential Election, when Pierce had 761 majority in the District. The result is doubtful. Eighth Districtt--Four counties give 238 majority for Faulkner, (Dem.) Pierce, in the same counties had 633. The result is in doubt.

At Newark, N. J., on the 26th inst., by Rev. Thomas Gallaudet, of this City, THOMAS SEALY to MARY L., daughter of John Meeker, all of the former place. On Wednesday evening, 25th inst., by Rev. Mr. Chrystie, Mr. JOHN GILLILAND to Miss AGNES McKINNIE, all of this City.

In connection with our announcement of operatic doings in yesterday's paper we have received the following communication: To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times "MARETZEK OPERA TROUPE.'"--MY DEAR SIR; Concerning a notice in your valuable journal of yesterday, with the above heading, I beg to inform you that since my return from Mexico nowhere has such a Troupe existed,

A SCOUNDREL AND HIS WIFE.-A milliner residing in Grand street, between Fifth and Sixth-streets, whose advertisements are frequently published in the New-York papers. has resorted to an old and most iniquitous dodge to obtain the work of needy girls without paying for it.
