Col. JAMES G. BERRET has to-day been commissioned as Postmaster of this City. He was formerly Chief Clerk in the Pension Office. The remaining District appointments are still under consideration. The report of cholera having appeared in Alexandria is erroneous.

A meeting of the Alumni of Andover Theological Seminary was held in the Central Church, Winter-street, Wednesday, to consider the subject of the monuments to the late Professors Stuart and Edwards. Rev. Dr. Anderson was chosen Chairman.

The Conference met at 8 o'clock A.M., yesterday, Bishop WAUGH presiding. Rev. Dr. CURRY opened the proceedings by reading the 80th Psalm. The minutes of the last meeting having been read and approved, Rev, Dr. FLOY offered the following, which was adopted:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Theseason of the year has arrived in which thunder storms become frequent. Those of the 16th, 17th and 18th of the present month were active over a great extent of surface, and the newspapers received from various quarters contain accounts of numerous cases of loss of life by lightning during those three days.

Mr. J. W. Whorter, who for eight years, has held the position of ticket-seller at Buffalo, to the Rochester and Buffalo Railway Company, and who is now compelled to resign his situation on account of declining health, having lost his eye-sight, has been presented by the Directors of the Company with the sum of $2,000.

The Legislature of Massachusetts, after a session of nearly five months, adjourned sine die on Wednesday, 25th. The session has been an extremely long one, but the amount of business has been proportionally large. The Governor stated that he had signed four hundred and twenty-two bills and ninety-nine resolves.

REPORTS. Mr. VANUERBILT, favorably, on the Seneca Connty Lien law. Also, favorably, on the bill relative to the partition of lands. Also, with amendment, the Assembly bill in relation to the debts of females before marriage. Also, adverse to the bill respecting the compensation of Justices in criminal cases. The bill was rejected.

Pursuant to notice a meeting of the friends of the Erie Canal Enlargement, without distinction of party, who desire that "a proposition to amend the Constitution, so as to provide for the more speedy completion of the public works, than at present, and without resort to taxation, may be passed by the present Legislature, preparatory to its submission to the people," was held last evening at the City Hall.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT.-Another accident occurred yesterday afternoon on the Camden and Amboy Railroad. The 2 o'clock train from this City, ran off the track six miles above Amboy, breaking no cars, and damaging nobody, but delaying the train for upward of three hours.

Harper's Magazine for June opens with 'GRAY'S Elegy," most profusely illustrated, mainly from the exquisite designs of the Sketching Club, Then follows an able and elaborate article upon Ancient Peru and its Inhabitants, evidently furnished by one who has thoroughly mastered the subject. It affords a satisfactory resume of what is now known respecting the history, polity, and art of the ancient Inca race.

LIQUOR TRAFFIC IN BROOKLYN.-Mayor LAMBERT having directed, through the Chief, the Police to make return of all the places where ardent spirits, are sold, their returns exhibit the following result thus far: FIRST DISTRICT--Including the First Third and Fourth Wards,-136 of these places, 56 are kept by Irishmen, 41 by Americans, 20 by Germans, 14 by Englishman, 1 by a Welshman, 3 by Frenchmen, and 1 by a colored man.

So far as the condition of American slaves and the hopes of American Emancipation are concerned, nothing could be more unfortunate and illtimed than Mrs. STOWE'S visit to England. * *The English Nobility, Press and People will utter and publish so much that is arrogant and offensive, that an American sentiment against British interference will be aroused and united.

Reader, we assume for granted that you are familiar with Ivanhoe, and have reveled in the glorious picture of the tournay of Ashby de la Zouch. Well, what think you of realizing the truth of the description and actually participating in the enchanting and animated scene, by a visit to the Hippodrome?

The Freeman's Journal demands, as the Completion of the diplomatic staff for Italy, the recall of Mr. CASS from Rome. The application, no doubt, rests upon the peculiar fitness of Mr. CABS for the place. He has proved it among the most trying circumstances; before and during the Republic, through the successive intervention of Austria and France, and under the nominal restoration of Papal sovereignty.

On Friday. the 27th inst., in the 39th year of her age, Mrs. ANN ELIZA, wife of Thomas A. Napier. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral without further notice, from the residence of her husband, Clinton-st. near Amity, Brooklyn, on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. On Thursday, 26th inst., EDWARD RALPH, youngest son of J. Ralph and Mary E. Sackett, aged 1 year and 10 months.

APHIS OR PLANT LOUSE, aphis, plant louse, puccron, or vine fretter, is a genus of insects comprising many species and varieties, which are so denominated from the plants they infest. They are got rid of sometimes, when on trees, by syringing with water, or elder leaves infused in water, or common soap suds; sulphur has also been found to promote the health of plants on which it has been sprinkled, especially Deach trees.

A serious street fight occurred at Alexandria yesterday, between JOHN M. JOHNSON, Postmaster of the United States House of Representatives, and EDGAR BROCKETT--both Democrats. The cause was a political dispute at the election, the parties belonging to rival factions. JOHNSON cut BROCKETT severely in the face with a knife.

One of the greatest curiosities which ever greeted a traveler's optics, is the Quaker driving around Philadelphia. It is original and peculiar, and as anything equal to it is unknown elsewhere, it must be regarded as indigenous to the people and the place. It so happens that we have taken our last degrees, and graduated with some of the rarest honors of tourization, but the Quaker driving caps the climax.

A floating and unaccredited rumor has been carried to us repeatedly for some weeks past, to the effect that SMITH O'BRIEN and his comrades had escaped from Van Dieman's Land, and are now in California. There is nothing positively incredible in the tale.

Dr. OLIVER BREWSTER died at Theresa, N. Y., on the 17th inst., of an affection of the lungs. He had visited Florida during the past Winter and Spring, with the hope of shaking off the disease, but without any good results. He was a descendant of old Elder WM. BREWSTER, who had a berth in the May Flower.

The Jury in the GARDINER case this morning sent word into Court that they never should agree to a verdict, there having been no change of opinion among them since they left the Court, and begged they might be brought into Court.

In the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets there has been more firmness shown this week, and a good business has been done in COFFEE, SUGAR and TEA. COTTON firm. BREADSTUFFS dull. The public sales of INDIGO proceed quietly. MONEY in great demand at 21@3 ?? cent. on fist rate securities for short terms, and higher rates paid for longer periods. CONSOLS leave off 100 5/8 for money. EXCHEQUER BILLS par to 4s premium.

Official information has been received at this Department that the British authorities at the Falkland island having complained to their Government that the wild cattle on those islands are frequently killed, and that other depredations are committed there by persons landing from vessels under the flag of the United States, it is the intention of the British Government to send a force thither competent to prevent a repetition of such acts.

A number of families residing in the vicinity of Carmansville, or Washington Heights, have associated together for the purpose of establishing a Reformed Dutch Church. A room, at the corner of Tenth-avenue and One-hundred and Fifty-secondstreet, has been furnished and opened for religious service.

The peculiar merits of Iron fabrics has been made the subject of remark since Civilizition first usurped the place of Barbarism. Before people in this world waked up to a realizing sense of the utility of the metals and minerals beneath their feet, the harder ores were applied to the most clumsy uses.

Majors HOARE, BLACK and company arrived here to-day, having left Santa Fe on the 3d inst. to attend a Court Martial. They bring but little news. They met large parties of emigrants, and immense herds of cattle. The Pawnees had killed a teamster, and run off with sone of the cattle.

The important and exciting subject of Ministcrial Education came up on Wednesday afternoon, and occupied the whole sitting. The Committee of one from each Syned reported through their Chairman, Rev. Mr. SMITH, a preamble and resolutions, of which the following are the principal:

In the afternoon session yesterday no business of interest transpired. To-day a heated discussion on the Slavery question arose. A series of resolutions were reported by the Special Committee recommending the appointment of a Commtttee of four from as many slaveholding synods, to inquire how many members of the Presbyterian Church hold slaves,

The Legislature of Connecticut yesterday took action on the subject of the Cosscob Bridge, on the line of the New-Haven Railroad. The precarious condition of that honeycombed and tottering fabric has already been made the heme of extensive comment. Its perils can scarcely he magnified too largely.

ENGINEERS IN THE UNITED STATES NAVY.-The Board of Principal Engineers, consisting of WM. P. WILLIAMSON, WM. W. W. MOORE, and DANIEL B. MARTIN, which convened at Philadelphia on the 2d of May, and terminated its labors about the 20th, passed the following candidates: First Assistant Engineers-Robert H. Long, Harman Newell, Andrew Lawton. Nathaniel P. Patterson, Francis C. Dade, Edmund De Luce, John M. Maury.

It was reported that there were four vacancies in the Board of Trustees of the General Assembly, occasioned by the death of the former incumbents. The election was, on motion, fixed for Friday morning. Dr. BRATTY, Chairman of the Committee on Education, read a report upon the subject under their care. The conduct and management of the Board met the approval of the Committee.

Great excitement has existed in the Episcopal Convention to-day. At the last session, a letter from the Standing Committee to Bishop WITTINGHAM, condemning the course of Rev. Dr, JOHNS for preaching in a Methodist Church, was read and entered upon the journal. Hon. JAMES CARROLL yesterday offered a series of resolutions to expunge the obnoxious letter, and reflecting severely upon the course of the Standing Committee.

While corrupt men are in power, it would be vain to look for purity of official action, although our laws were so nearly perfect as to beget a suspicion of their divine origin. But it is always well to make the path of transgressors as thorny, and to give feeble virtue as fair a chance as possible.

Senator Beach, the Evening Journal says, was in his seat on Tuesday, ready to vote for Senator Vanderbilt's Canal scheme, or any other good thing which may come up. He has not "paired off" with Senator McMurray on any question of legislation.

The Assembly met at the usual time. After prayer by the Moderator, the minutes of the preceding session were read. Dr. McDOWELL moved that the Assembly go into a ballot for four trustees of the General Assembly to fill vacancies in the Board.

The famous Russian Editorial of the Washington Union has been fathered by Mr. PRIOR, one of the Assistant Editors, who appears in Saturday's National Intelligencer in his own defence, and in support of the entire sentiment of the article.

The Monitor of to-day publishes an imperial de?? Prolonging the Session of the Legislative lady to the 28th of this month. It was to have terminated on the 13th. By way of motive to the decree, its author pleasantly says that he wishes to give the Body time for mature deliberation on several important bills now submitted to its examination.

The U. S. Mail steamship Arctic, Capt. LUCE, from Liverpool on Wednesday afternoon, May 18, about 2 1/2 o'clock, arrived at this port at 2 o'clock yesterday morning. Com. AULICK, of the U. S. Navy, who came passenger in the Arctic, has in charge, it is said, dispatches from the United States Commissioner in China, as also from the American Minister at London, for the Government at Washington.

In steamship Arctic, from Liverpool--H. N. Peters, lady and servant; Hon. W. C. Rives, late Minister to France, Mrs. Rives, Misses E and E Rives, A. L. Rives, Joseph Tryon, V M. Moore, B. B. Atterbury, Arthur Little, L. H. Morris, W. T. Whittemore, Com. Aulick, U. S. N, and servant. Joseph Rotham, lady and servant;

At Metchin, New-Jersey, on the 25th inst., by Rev Mr. Finnelly, Mr. CHARLES CAMPBELL to Miss JEAN NETTE E, daughter of Ellis Freeman, all of the former place. On the 26th inst., by Rev. W. Morris, L. L. D., PATRICK GULF to ANN MARIA JONES.

In the Criminal Court this morning, Judge CRAWFORD intimated his purpose of discharging the GARDINER Jury. Mr. FENDALL, in behalf of the United States, advocated their discharge, while Messrs. BRADLEY and CARLISLE, for defendant, opposed it.

A good deal of interest has been excited by the fact that the Arabia, the new CUNARD steamer which was built with special reference to competing with the COLLINS line in point of speed, made the passage on her out. ward trip in less than ten days, and some hours quicker than the Arctic, which sailed four days before her.

This day is coming to be more universally observed than almost any other of our holidays. And this is strange, too; for it is contrary to the spirit of our Christian institutions, contrary to good manners, and contrary to the moneyed interests of the people.

My DEAR E--My last was from Naples, after my visit to the ?? and to ??, If I recollect rightly. We completed a whole week in Naples, but, alas, had to leave many sights unseen, ?? unperformed, for lack of time, as our programme brings as to Switzerland by the 10th of June, and Rome and Florence are very rich fields to explore.

The State authorities of Pennsylvania, have remitted the interest on a collateral inheritance tax in a legacy of $20,000 left by a Roman Catholic lady of Pittsburg, to a benevolent institution. The interest, at 12 per cent., amounted to $625.

In this City, May 28, HUGH S. STEELE, Printer, aged 36 years. His remains will be taken to Philadelphia for interment. On Friday evening, 27th inst, after a short illness, SIMEON HYDE, Esq., in the 70th year of his age.

It has been the fate of all the great epics that their moral has not been very discernible, or at least so separable from the story, and so dependent on the caprice of the reader, that we are at liberty to admire to our heart's content without drawing any inference whatever.

A melancholy incident occurred on board the day before the Arabia's arrival at Liverpool, on her last trip out. Mr. H. D. SELDEN, wellknown in New-York from his long connection with the house of A. T. STEWART CO., as the head salesman in the Shawl department, in a moment, doubtless, of mental alienation, jumped overboard, and was drowned. He had been with that

Steamers-Roanoke, Cavendy, Richmond and Norfolk, Ludlam Pleasants; Alabama, Ludlow, Savannah, S. L. Mitchill; Marion, Berry, Charleston, Spofford, Tilestoa Co. Ships--Brittania, Atkins, Quebec, Logan Collins; Mediator, Coster, New-Orleans, Wm. T. Frost: Ashland, Benson, Savannah, Sturges, Clearman Co.; Mary, Marshall, London, Cook Smith.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA--Saturday--first Board--$1,730 Pennsylvania 5s, 96 1/4 ; $1,000 do., 96 1/8 ; $600 City Railroad 6s, '85, 107 ; $3,000 Reading Railroad 6s, '70,88 ; $1,000 West Philadelphia coupon 6s, '73,98 1/2 ; 100 Long Island Railroad, 17 1/4 ; 30 Lehigh Navigation, 72 ; 300 Schuylkill Navigation Preferred, 33 1/2 ; 61 Pennsylvania Railroad, 50 ; 10 Minehill Railroad, 69 7/8 ; 14 Manufacturers' and Mechanics' Bank, 30 3/4.

A memorial was presented from the American and Foreign Bible Society, for leave to hold additional real estate. Mr. BARTLETT reported a bill for the construction of a railroad in New Utrecht and Gravesend.

RUNAWAY HORSE--TWO PERSONS SERIOUSLY INJURED.--About 9 o'clock on Saturday morning, a horse attached to a wagon, the property of Alderman REMSEN, of the Sixth Ward, became frightened in Columbia-street, near Harrison, and started off a full speed down Columbia-street.

The Annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in New Jersey was held at Burlington on Wednesday last, Bishop DOANE presiding. After the general religious services and business, the Episcopal Address was read, which, among other things, communicated to the Convention the fact of another presentment.

Did we need any confirmatory proof of the inefficiency of our laws for protecting life from the assaults of heedless ruffians, we should find it in the horrible custom of drawing knives. There is no more alarming feature of our social depravity than this; none other which cries aloud more sternly for the interposition of the strong arm of Justice.

In the Presbyterian (New School) General Assembly, reports were made in favor of publishing the Confession of Faith and Christian Psalmody in the German; in favor of allowing each pastor and session to decide for itself as to the validity of Baptism when administered within the Catholic Church; and strongly protesting against religious oppression everywhere. A CHILD SHOT BY HER UNCLE.--A little girl, six years old, named MARY KATTARING, whose parents reside in Withere-street. near Lonmer street, died at 7 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, from a wound received from a pistol bullet, fired by her uncle, GEORGE KINGSLEY.

A large portion of our paper this morning is devoted to the foreign news, and its discussion by the English press. The accounts from England brought by the Arctic are of little political moment. The British House of Lords is discussing the affairs of the East India Company, the re-charter of which is soon' to be determined.

The rumor is renewed that Mr. MARCY will lease the Cabinet soon. This is very doubtful, although it may be that he will get the French Mission, after preparing instructions to BUCHANAN, SOULE, and others. It is stated that Mr. MEADE positively declines the Chargeship to Sardinia.

Last evening, at the time of the adjournment of the Assembly, a motion was pending to recommit the Canal resolutions to the Committee on Canals. A weighty member from Chenange, to whom the Barnburning caucus had given it in charge to move the previous question on the resolutions, mistaking his one, after the house had adjourned, yelled out.

This night, at 12 o'clock, merrie May must walk the plank. Sorry to part with her,--she has been very pleasant, very agreeable, very warm-hearted. But her hands are bloody! What hecatombs of victims she offered to recklessness by sea and land! What multitudes she has discharged from all earthly obligations, by violence! It has been a month crowded full of news and of anniversary meetings, of hot, sunny days, and of hard, rainy weather.

Suddenly, of congestion of the brain, on the 30th inst., FREDERICA, daughter of Joseph and Jeanette Giraud. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral from the residence of her father, No. 157 Greene-st., on Wednesday, June 1, at 4 o'clock, P.M.

" Work while it is called to-day, for you know not how much you may be hindered to morrow," as Poor Richard saith. To-day you are well, tough and hearty, to-morrow you may be sick, tender and of dainty appetite. Heave to, then lads, and end the job before you, to-day. You don't feel like it ? Then work the harder, for to-morrow you may feel still less like it.

The President this morning appointed JONAH D. HOOVER Marshall of the District of Columbia, vice RICHARD WALLACH. Mr. HOOVER is President of the Jackson Democratic Association, and was active in the late Presidential campaign. The Criminal Court Room was crowded this morning in consequence of a general expectation that the case of JOHN CHARLES GARDINER Would be taken up.

From the Washington Union. The following extracts are made for the Union from notes of travel in this country, entitled The Resources and Settlements of America, by Capt. McKINNON, Royal Navy. The Atlantic is now so completely bridged by the magnificent steamers of CUNARD and COLLINS, that a voyage across the ocean has become a mere pleasure trip.

Mr. MORGAN presented the petition of the Mayor, Messrs. FLAGG, C. W. LAWRENCE, and others, against Jones's Park. Mr. VANDERBILT reported. complete, the Brooklyn and Williamsburg Water Works bill. The Roman Catholic Society bill was made the special order for Thursday. The bill for appropriating $50,000 to the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents in New-York passed in Committee.

The Conference reassembled at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, (the tenth day of session,) Bishop SIMPSON in the Chair. The attendance was less than during the past week, several members having returned to their homes. Rev. Dr. FAIRCHILD, Secretary of the " American and Foreign Christian Union," was introduced by the President, and briefly explained the objects of the Union.

The little steamboat in which I left Wilmington in about half an hour reached a wharf on a creek flowing into the Cape Fear river from the Southward, where we found the end of an unfinished Railroad and a car for us to proceed in. There were but half a dozen passengers, besides as many negroes who were put in a separate car.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church is holding its Annual Session in this city. It is a large body collected from all parts of our country, with delegates on its floor from California and Northern India. It is also a body of great influence, and distinguished for the social position and distinguished ability of many of its clerical and lay delegates.

NIBLO'S SALOON.--Mrs. BOSTWICKS Concert was not so numerously attended as the entertainment seemed to merit. Possibly the weather had something to do with it; or it may be that the musical community have been satiated with Grand Concerts. Any way, the attendance of last evening was not encouraging, and scarcely calculated to stimulate a taste for Concert-giving.

The bark Arthur Pickering, Capt. JACKSON, has arrived at this port, with advices from Zanzibar to the 9th of March, and St. Helena to April 22. Letters from Zanzibar mention that the American brig Camargo, from Rio Janeiro, previously reported as having left the Cape of Good Hope, for Zanzibar, had not arrived there, but a slaver of that name had been on the coast, and succeeded in running off two cargoes of slaves.

The President has appointed B. B. FRENCH, Commissioner of Public Buildings vice EASBY resigned. ALBERT G. ALLEN, Navy Agent at Washington vice LATHROP, removed. Both the appointed were formerly of New-Hampshire, but for several years past have been well known residents of this district.

Three mortal columns of the National Intelligencer this morning, are occupied by Mr. PRYOR, of the Union editorial Corps, in a labored defence of his Russian article. The Union, however, maintains its silence, and Mr. PRYOR continues his connection with it, while he seeks elsewhere a medium for the reiteration and defence of the objectionable sentiments.

I have good reason to believe that dispatches have been received from England, declaring it as the British construction of the CLAYTON and BULWER treaty, that the British Government renounces its protectorate only on three points, specifically named; For colonization, occupation, and fortification,

A meeting of citizens of the Eighth Ward was held last night, in Colon's Hall, for the purpose of taking measures to secure a reform in the City Charter. The Chair was occupied by Mr. G. PAULDING. The Vice-Presidents were Jacob Anthony, Samuel B. Althause, Michael Gross, Henry Ellsworth. Secretaries, J. N. Philips, W. B. Aiken, Robert Henry and H. Wild.

GREAT FIRE IN CANADA.-- The destructive fire which occurred on the Attawa River, fifty miles above Bytown, Canada, involved a loss of property to a great extent, and it is feared that some lives have been sacrificed. The lire occurred about the 15th inst. The Montreal Gazette says; " From a private letter from a well informed source received in town yesterday morning, we gather the following particulars:

REPORT OF DEATHS.--The Health Officer re ports 43 deaths for the week ending May 28, from the following diseases: Cholera infantum. congestion of lungs, convulsions, dropsy in abdomen, ecrema, hemorrhage of uterine, inflammation of brain, inflammation of stomach, parturition, premature birth, scrofula--one each. Casualty, croup, heart disease, whooping cough, small pox--two each. Drowned and stillborn, three each; inflammation of the lungs, 4; consumption, II. Males 26; Females 17. Adults, 25; Children 18. Total 43.

The Patrie is beginning again with its pretty stories about the Emperor. The other day he was walking in the enclosed gardens of the Tuileries, with his arms folded behind him, and endeavoring to look as much like his uncle as possible, when he observed a municipal guard. This functionary was on duty at a point where unusual circumspection was necessary.

KEENE CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION.-- The Centennial Celebration of the incorporation of the neat town of Keene, N. H., took place on Thurs day, 26th inst., in presence of a large number of spectators, one of those healty gatherings that cluster about white tents and green fields on such auspicious occasions. The elements, however, were unpropitious, and this went to mar the festivities.

STRIKING A BOARDER.--A man named MAN GIN, the keeper of a porter-house in North First-street, was arrested on Sunday by officer MURPHY, charged with striking a boarder named McGUIRE on the head. He was remanded. TEMPERANCE.--Dr. C. S. PARSONS, of Maine, delivered a Temperance Lecture last evening, at the First Congregational Church.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Having been a subscriber to your paper from its commencement, and admired its impartiality, I was surprised to find the attack that was made in it on the Arabia and her officers. From what I know of them, I believe you must have been misinformed. Capt. JUDKINS is a veteran officer, against whom few complaints have ever been made.

The Slavery report was resumed yesterday, under the motion for an indefinite postponement of it. Rev. Mr. MONTEITH of Michigan, made a long speech in explanation of the report, and of the constitutional principles by which it was authorized. The Committee were unanimous in their conviction that it was unsafe to refuse to do anything to meet the general and urgent desire that was felt in the churches for action on this subject.

No one rides in an omnibus for pleasure. Long distances, rainy days or tender feet are the true causes that force people to imprison themselves in an oblong coffin lined with plush, ventilated with windows that won't open when they are shut, and won't shut when they are open, and driven by an uncivil man in oilcloth, who dispenses abusive language and bad coin to his passengers with equal facility.

A number of the ancient and honorable Order of Free and Accepted Masons assembled in the theatre of the Medical College, Crosby-street, for the purpose of presenting an address to their distinguished brother, Dr. KANE, on the eve of his departure for the Arctic regions. Deputy Grand Master JOSEPH D. EVANS presided, assisted by several of the officers of the Grand Lodge, all in full regalia.

The result of the election to Congress in the Seventh District of Virginia is very doubtful. One report gives it to SNOWDEN, Whig, by 50 majority; while another elects SMITH, Democrat, by 100 majority. BOND, Independent, is elected over DANIELS, Dem., for Commissioner of Public Works in the First District of Virginia.

From the London Times. It will he remembered that a few weeks back we had occasion to lay before our readers some communications which we had received with regard to the system followed in the large West-end dressmaking houses. In a letter, which will be found in another portion of our columns this day, it will be seen that the oppressive arrangements complained of are not confined to the west end of the town.

GIBBS vs. FREMONT,--An action was tried at Guildhall, London, a few days ago, before Mr. Baron ALDERSON, when the verdict passed for the plaintiff for [pound]3,988 12s. The Attorney-General has since moved in the Court of Exchequer for a rule nisi, pursuant to leave reserved at the trial to increase the damages by interest at the rate of 19 per cent., or such other amount as the Court might think fit.

The Leeds Free Press, (U. C.,) says that on the 18th inst., the house of Mr. Samuel Beach, near Brockville, was struck by lightning and shattered to pieces. The fluid descended down the stovepipe, pressed open the doors of the stove struck the floor, along which it prssed, and tore it up quite close to a sleeping child.

THE SOMMERVILLE TRAGEDY.--The remark able murder of one insane woman by another, at the Somerville Asylum, reported by yesterday's Tele graph, is a very curious case, and is exciting much attention. The Boston Times remarks as follows: This occurred, according to the report of the Directors, on the 18th inst., since which time there have been repeated attempts made to suppress all publicity of the transaction.

Were citizens in earnest a few months ago, when they cried out as one man for reform? when they demanded that new laws, and new men to administer them, should at once be substituted for the old. when the extravagance of city officers,--their corruptive and unscrupulous villainy was on every tongue? Did men believe what they said then, or were they carried away with an unjustifiable excitement?

CONVENTIONS TO BE HELD.--The "Working Men's National Convention" meets at Wilmington, Del., June 1. The "Women's State Temperance Society," of our State, holds its first meeting at Rochester on the 1st and 2d June.

TENTH DAY--MONDAY. The Assembly met at the regular hour. After prayer by the Moderator, the minutes of the session of Saturday were read and approved, after a Mr. MITCHELL moved that the subject of the election of Professors for Princeton and Allegheny be taken up. The Moderator read a letter from Dr. BOARDMAN, declining the nomination of Professor of Princeton Seminary.

BOAT RUN DOWN.-One of the Bridge street Ferry boats on Sunday afternoon run down a small sailboat, in which were eight persons. All were saved, after much difficulty, by the officers of the ferry-boat. EXPLOSION AT THE GAS HOUSE.-An explosion took place yesterday at the Gasometer in Plymouth-street, by which several men were nearly smothered by the gas. All were saved, however.

We find in the Baltimore Patriot a full re port of the proceedings in the Diocesan Convention of Maryland, in the case of Rev. Dr. JOHNS, under censure for preaching in a Methodist Church. It will be noticed that the censure was finally dismissed. On Friday morning, the resolutions in relation to the report of the Standing Committee, touching the case of Rev. Dr. JOHNS, of Christ Church, were again taken up for consideration.

SUPERIOR COURT CHAMBERS--Before Judge DUER.--In re the People, Rel. Lewis Tappan vs. Ros e Porter.--This morning the Judge decided that the child is not illegally restrained, and that the Court had no jurisdiction. The child is now free, and the Judge could make no order to deliver her to anybody--not to the Father-nor to the woman either. The father can exercise his parental rights as he may be advised, but not in any violent manner.

For the benefit of the traveling public who are intending to cross the Plains the ensuing sea son, I have deemed that a few suggestions might be timely and profitable, which, if considered of sufficient importance, you are at liberty to publish. Men traveling to the mines are often led by the impulse of speculation to assume duties and make engagements utterly impossible to be fulfilled, and to entertain expectations which must unavoidably fail.

The American Protestant Association held their Annual Session in the City of Philadelphia, on Monday, 23d inst., Grand Lodge opened at 11 o'clock A. M., and adjourned on Thursday, 26th, at 7 o'clock A. M., to meet at Pittsburg, Penn., on the fourth Monday of July, 1854. GENERAL GOVERNMENT.--The subject of forming Brooklyn, Williamsburg and Bushwick under one General Government is daily gaining favor with the intelligent public. Should this annexation be brought about, it is thought that the taxes on real estate will begreatly reduced.

We have Galveston dates to the 17th. Heavy storms of rain and hail have damaged the crops in sundry places, and carried away the roads --among others thee embankment of the Harriesburg Railroad. The work on this road is progressing slowly, and the contractors are confident that the rails will be laid to the Brazos timber, a distance of twenty miles, by November next.

PORTRAIT OF JOHN P. KENNEDY.--We have received a beautifully lithographed portrait, by GROZELIER, of JOHN P. KENNEDY, the renowned author of Horse-Shoe Robinson, Swallow Barn, , and late Secretary of the Navy.

Political aspects in this latitude have very materially changed since Friday. The fears of the State Officers, to which I alluded at the opening of the extra session, have proved stronger than the Herkimer influence, which I did not anticipate. A final surrender of the tax-feature, the only point in which any principle was involved, has been made by the Barnburners.

Yesterday witnessed another notable spectacle. The second American Expedition in search of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN, set sail from this port under the command of Dr. E. K. KANE, the Surgeon of the former Expedition.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As Captain JUDKINS'S official courtesy appears to have been both questioned and defended, I beg to chronicle my experience of that gentleman. Some time since, when Capt. JUDKINS was in command of the Asia, I made a voyage with him, and in the course of our eleven days' passage, had ample opportunity of forming an impartial decision.

The British and North American Mail steamship Arabia sailed from Liverpool 9:45 A. M., Saturday, 21st May, arrived 12:30 yesterday, making the voyage in 10 days 2 hours 45 minutes. The Humboldt, Capt. LINES, arrived off Cowes on Wednesday night, 18th, and having landed her mails and passengers proceeded on her voyage to Havre.

We have received from private sources in London a highly interesting account of a very splendid entertainment given to the American Minister, Mr. INGERSOLL, and his niece, Miss WILCOCKS, at the Star and Garter, Richmond, on the 18th of May, by Mr. GEORGE PEABODY:...

Full Particular may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Hunchback--My Young Wife and Old Umbrella. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Stranger--Popping the Question--Minibus. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Our Gal--Uncle Pat's Cabin--The Happy man ST. CHARLES THEATRE.--Ladies Right -- Soldier's Return Queen of the Abruzzi.

The petition of the Commissioners of Emigration, for a repeal of the Emigrant law of 1853 was presented. The Williamsburg Pier law bill was reported. Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill to amend the general banking law, by allowing a deposit of U. S. Stocks in full, instead of one half.

Halifax papers are received to the 24th inst. The following ships-of-war were in Halifax harbor: Cumberland, 70, Capt. Seymour, flag of Sir G. F. Seymour; Vestal, 26, Capt. Hamilton; Basilisk, 6, steam-sloop, Com. Hon. P. Egerton; Argus, 6, steam sloop, Com. Purves; Pyramus, 2, receiving ship; Espeigle, 12, sloop, Com. Hancock. The steamer Argus was to proceed to the fishing ground this week.

This morning, Commissioner MATHER sent in his promised communication to the Assembly. It is very long, (74 pages,) and goes over all the matters in relation to which he is charged with wrong. The Commissioner treats some of his Democratic compeers, and particularly the Auditor, with great severity. His document was ordered printed without any debate or other proceeding.

THE QUICKEST PASSAGE FROM SAN FRANCISCO. --The clipper ship Northern Light, Capt. HATCH, arrived at this port yesterday from San Francisco, in the extraordinary short passage of 76 days. This beats the passages of the New-York clipper ships Comet and Flying Dutchman-the former of which made the run in 84, and the latter in 85 days.

We are assured from several quarters that a desperate effort will be made to defeat the Amended Charter on the 7th instant. From one we hear of general activity, of quiet burrowings, of deep-laid schemes for undermining it.

SURVEY OF ST. MARY'S RIVER.--The Detroit Advertiser has the following: " We learn that Capt. SCAMMON, U. S. T. Engineer, with a strong force of fifty men, starts next week for the St. Mary's River, for the purpose of making a thorough survey of that river from Point Detour, at its entrance into Lake Huron, to the town of Saut Ste. Marie.

CASTLE GARDEN.--The NATIONAL GUARD BAND gave their final Concert last evening. The attendance was unusually good; indeed, consider ing the coldness of the weather, we were altogether surprised to see so many crowded benches. The entertainment fully merited the patronage bestowed on it. Instrumental music is destined to become a great feature in our summer amusements, and we could wish that the National Band had arrived at a different determination to its present one.

THE WIDOW OF GEN. HARRISON.--The estimable widow of Gen. HARRISON still occupies a portion of the old mansion at North Bend, where she is watched over by the filial care of the family of Col. TAYLOR. She is in the serene evening of a long and eventful life, and, though bearing the weight of many years, is still able to move about her room.

On Tuesday night, says the London Times of the 13th, the Chancellor of the Exchequer left the House of Commons soon after 11 P. M., having previously voted on the division, and went immediately to the Italian Opera House, Covent-Garden, in his brougham, which he then dismissed, and in returning by the shortest route look Long-Acre, Panton-street, , on his way to Pall-Mall, and the steps at the Duke of York's column.

The Slavery question is still under discussion in the Presbyterian General Assembly. The Committee modified their report, by recommending the Presbyteries of Slaveholding States to answer inquiries respecting the number of slave holders in the Church, , instead of appointing a commission to make such inquiries.

A fire broke out in the garret of a frame dwelling house in Yaret-street, near Graham-avenue, shortly after 10 o'clock on Saturday night. The house was owned and occupied by a German family named STRAUS. Officers SNEIDIKER and Cox of the Third Ward discovered and extinguished the fire before any alarm had been given. Less about $150. No insurance.

The Foreign accounts by the Arabia, three days later, present no special feature of political moment. The market news is favorable. On our first page we have given a very full and original report of the magnificent banquet given by Mr. GEORGE PEABODY to the retiring American Minister, Mr. INGERSOLL, at

The Catharine-street Ferry lease expired on the 1st of May, 1853. The lessees were SMITH and BULKLEY, and the old lease contained a provision for appraising the old boats at the end of the term, and the amount of this appraisement was to be paid by the City to the lessees.

The expedition, under Commander C. RINGGOLD, United States Navy, for the exploration and survey of the China and Japan Seas, North Pacific Ocean, sailed from Norfolk on yesterday for its destination. A very interest ting set of experiments and careful observations in Astronomv have been made at the Naval Hospital, in order to regulate the chronometers, upon which so much depends.

" It is a very easy matter to pick out the farmers and out door men from among the members of the Legislature. They look browned and vigorous, as if nature and they were on good terms; while in-door gentry appear as ghostly as spiritual rappers. Health and the plough-handle seem to be in partnership."--Albany Journal.

In a charming mansion in St. James's Place, secluded somewhat from the roar and tumult of the great city, still lives the venerable poet of the Pleasures of Memory, whose great age (ninety years having rolled over his bald ripe forehead,) disqualifies him from taking his long accustomed walks about the metropolis.

The Chief of Police, in compliance with a resolution offered at a previous meeting, asking for information relative to the efficiency of the Police Department, reported to the Common Council last evening relative thereto, and stated, in conclusion, that the Police Department could never he made as efficient as it should be, so long as the appointing and removing power rested with the Aldermen.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The closing paragraph your Albany correspondent's letter, of the 26th inst., is as follows: "The Assembly has spent the day, chiefly, morning and evening, in debate upon a Ship Canal around Niagara Falls. Nobody thinks it of any consequence."

CIVILIZATION OF THE WYANDOT INDIANS.-BIG TURTLE, a chief of the Wyandot tribe of Indians, who removed from Ohio to the Indian Territory, writes to the Ohio State Journal concerning the present condition of this tribe: "Our improvements, when appraised, amounted to upwards of 127,000. Which was paid us in the Autumn of 1845.

MURDER AND LYNCH LAW.--The Council Bluff Western Bugle contains a long account of a murder in those parts, which was revenged by Lynch Law in a summary manner. The murder was committed at the encampment of a party of emigrants, about half a mile from the town, upon a person by the name of J. C. Samuels, said to be from Columbus, Ohio.

The latest returns from Virginia show a gain of twelve Whigs in the House and three in the Senate. New-Orleans papers of Tuesday and Wednesday are received. They contain nothing of interest beyond what has been anticipated by telegraph.

The Aretic Expedition went to sea yesterday. The enterprise began under the most favorable auspices. The officers and crew were in the best of spirits, the day was clear, warm and beautiful, and the good wishes of many spectators were wafted to the voyagers at the very margin of the Ocean.

NAVAL--The U. S. brig Dolphin sailed on Saturday on a cruise for deep sonndings, She will be employed in the track towards England and the North of Europe, making a thorough examination for all shoals or rocks reported as existing in that route. The following are her officers.

After opening by prayer, A. STEVENSON, from the Committee on Theological Seminary, asked for instructions. Moved by J. CHRYSTIE that the Committee on Theological Seminary be instructed 1st, to inquire into and report upon the expediency of reviving the Seminary; and 2d, if they report affirmatively upon the former, that they report a plan for its reorganization.

As this nuisance, like a pimple on the face of a drunkard, appears to be spreading, we take the liberty of making public the law on the subject. We know that JAMES FURY, Esq., the Street Commissioner, trusts that there will be no fatal accident. We know that the men who are interested in keeping up the dangerous nuisance, tell him they can afford to pay for their violation of the law;

Those of our readers who have suffered a day's residence at a Panama Hotel, will he interested in the following discovery of an effectual remedy against the abuses and bad accommodations heretofore considered an "institution " on the Isthmus:

Brevet Col. J. K. F. MANSFIELD has positively been appointed Inspector-General of the Army, and will be so officially announced tomorrow. The Navy Department has received despatches by Commodore AULICK from Commodore PERRY at Singapore with the Mississippi, the flag ship of the Japan Squadron.

MONDAY-MORNING SESSION. The Slavery question has again engrossed the Assembly, and will probably continue to do so till within the briefest possible interval before its close. The excitement of Friday, though having two days to cool, is as warm this morning as ever, and the prospects of an amicable adjustment of the question as distant as at the first moment of the discussion, if not a little more so.

The Annual Commencement of Yale College will be held this year on Thursday, the 28th of July. The baccalaureate sermon will be preached on the Sunday, 24th, by the Rev. Dr. Woolsey, President of the College. On Tuesday evening the concio ad clerum will be preached by the Rev. Dr. Fitch, subject, "

PROGRESS OF THE WATER WORKS.--The construction of the Jersey City Water Works is progressing with considerable energy, and it is expected that water will be introduced into the city by the last of Autumn or fist of Winter. At Belleville, where the water is to be taken from the Passaic River, the work was commenced about six weeks ago.

The number of bills and resolves passed at the session of the Legislature which has just closed, was 422 bills and 99 resolves. The number passed at the session of 1852, which was only one day shorter, was 322 bills and 108 resolves. It will thus he seen that the last Legislature, although its session was protracted, was by no means idle.

The 25th and 26th of May witnessed another exhibition of Woman's Rights in Ohio. The Convention assembled in the Universalist Church in Ravenna, on the morning of the 25th, the following notorieties being among the parties assembled: Rev. Miss ANTOINETTE BROWN, Mrs. SEVERENCE, Mrs. M. A. BRONSON, CAROLINE STANTON, Mrs. ALDRICH, Ex-Rev. JOE BARKER and L. A. HINE. A few "Bloomers," just enough for variety, were scattered through the audience.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: HUDSON, Saturday, May 28, 1853. Do you know anything about this City of Hudson? I presume not. Few persons do, and yet the time was when it was a place of no mean importance. It was settled in 1783-4, by an enterprising Company, chiefly from Nantucket.

We learn from the Detroit Free Press that much excitement has prevailed of late in the village of Mackinaw, arising from the frequent and daily recurring instances of robberies, burglaries, and other depredations, committed by the Mormons of Beaver Island upon the fishermen along the shores and upon the waters of Lake Michigan.

We had occasion a week or two since to refer to the successful arrangements made in London for the projected trunk lines of Railway connecting the important cities of Nashville and St. Louis, with the North and East. Mr. BACON, one of the able negotiators for the Ohio and Mississippi Company, writes us from London, by the Arabia, that his sales are regarded there as the best yet made of new Railway obligations.

The Assembly this morning took up Dr. Cox's Report, sanctioning marriage with a sister's child. An amendment was proposed, declaring such a marriage contrary to the laws of God and revolting to human nature. This was carried almost unanimously.

THOMAS MCKEAN PETTIT, the recently appointed Director of the Mint in this city, died at his residence last night. He was an estimable man, and had filled many responsible offices, among them Judge of the District Court, and District Attorney under POLK'S Administration.
Cuba is the closing seal of the great problem of African emancipation in North America. Its solution is the especial mission of the Nineteenth Century. It cannot be accomplished until Cuba is free.

AN EXCITING CONTEST BETWEEN NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN HORSES ON THE UNION COURSE, LONG ISLAND--THE HORSE FROM THE NORTH VICTORIOUS.An exciting trotting match came off yesterday tt the Union Race Course, on Long Island, which was nearly equal to tile great race between the Southern horse Peytona, and a Northern horse known as Fashion, in the year 1843. On this occasion, $4,000 was the stake, and

The Cabinet is in session to-day. Doctor PATTERSON has been appointed Superintendent of the mint at Philadelphia, vice PETITT, deceased. A large delegation is expected here to urge the claims of another. Their mission will be a barren one. JOHN H. REYNOLDS--hunker hard--has been appointed Postmaster at Albany; JAMES J. JOHNSON having withdrawn and named his friend REYNOLDS, who was immediately appointed, and his commission placed in JOHNSON's hands.

Col. BERROTT took charge of the City PostOffice to-day, and appointed LAMBERT TREE Chief Clerk. L. D. MILLS, of Maryland, and WM. A. HACKER, have been appointed Clerks in the Patent Office. Incendiaries are again at work here, and two were arrested to-day.

At the Afternoon Session on Tuesday, the case of Rev. HEMAN BANGS was taken up, and the specifications on each charge put separately. The first charge was mal-administration, and this was declared not proven by a vote of 39 to 36. The second charge was oppression, and the vote was taken on the specification under the charge, and then on the charge itself, which was declared not proven, by a vote of 13 to 50.

CHRIST EPISCOPAL CHURCH.--We announced some few weeks since that an effort was being made to pay off the floating debt of this Church, amounting to $12,060. The appeals which were made by the Rev. Mr. CANFIELD, the Rector, were so effective as to produce the entire amount. Five Thousand Dollars was subscribed at

Prof. DE BOW is pushing the work of the Census Office with vigor. There is no better index of the progress of his labors, than the rapidity with which he throws out the clerks, just as we measure the work of a mill by the tailings. Six of these figurants have

The New-Hampshire Legislature met this day at 10 o'clock, and organized by the choice of JAMES N. RICE, of Lancaster, as President of the Senate, and J. EVERETT SERGEANT, of Wentworth, as Speaker of the House. GEORGE 0.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--The "Hunchback" was "produced" at this establishment last night. When we say it was produced we mean that it was placed on the stage in an utterly regardless manner; the dresses common and of all eras; the scenery dirty and wretched. We have never seen a play so miserably placed on the stage.

New-Orleans papers of Thursday last, came to hand this afternoon. Virginia election returns render certain the election of the entire Democratic Congressional delegation, and a Democratic majority in both branches of the Legislature.

KILLED ON BOARD A CANAL BOAT.--Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest at the New-York Hospital, on the body of a man named WILLIAM A. WEEKS, who on yesterday, May 31st, while stepping from a Canal boat. to the propeller City of Albany, lying at pier 4 East River, fell into the hold of the vessel fracturing his skull and otherwise injuring himself. He died about 5 o'clock.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT AT A FOUNDRY.--At about 9 o'clock yesterday morning an accident occurred in the foundry of Messrs. GUION BOARDMAN, at the foot of Eighth-street, East river, which will probably result in the loss of life. The workmen were hauling a boiler out of the shop, when the tackle broke and seven men fell. One of their number, named THOMAS TULLY, had three

U.S. CIRCUIT COURT-Wednesday-Before Chief Justine NELSON and Judge Betts. - The case of the Captain of the ship Rescias-the U.S. vs. Daniel Moloney.-The Chief Justice said the Court was ready to proceed with the criminal trials. MR. Dunning moved the trial of Daniel Moloney, charged with the murder of a seaman named "Emanuel."

New-Orleans papers bring Rio Grande news to the 22d ult. CARVAJAL, NORTON and ROUNDTREE were still in prison, being unable to give bonds to the satisfaction of the U. S. Marshal. The Flag thinks it important that some disposition should be made of them.

By the New Orleans Picayune of the 26th ult., we have city of New Mexico dates to the 18th and Vera Cruz to the 22d ult. When the news of the affair reached the city of Mexico, SANTA ANNA despatched immediately 2,000 veteran troops with 14 pieces of artillery for Vera Cruz. They had reached Puebla, but as the commotion was ended, it was supposed they would not continue their march.

A rare treat was afforded to the house full of ladies and gentlemen who gathered at Metropolitan Hall last evening to hear Mr. EVERETT discourse on the Discovery and Colonization of America. However high the anticipations of any might have been as to the production of this most brilliant and polished of our American orators, we venture to say that they did not return disappointed.

A CASE FOR THE CHARITABLE.--A gentleman, whose word may be implicitly relied upon, has sent us the particulars of a most distressing case, calling for the sympathies of the benevolent. A lady, whose connections and character are of the highest standing, has, within a few weeks, by the desertion of her husband, been left totally destitute.

The General Synod of the Reformed Pro testant Dutch Church in North America, convened Wednesday morning, at 10 1/2 o'clock, in the Third Dutch Reformed Church, Philadelphia. The Synod was called to order by Rev. GUSTAVUS ABEEL, D.D., Moderator of the last Synod, and the proceedings were opened with prayer.

Will it be believed, a hundred years hence, that in 1842 the Government of Great Britain paid about [pound]16,000,000 sterling per annum to keep up men-of-war and their appartenances, and less than one-hundredth part the sum towards educating the children of the people throughout the nation?

The attention of all persons interested in the City Reform movement, is Called to the notice of a public meeting to be held at Metropolitan Hall, on Saturday evening next, and to be found in our advertising columns. We understand that addresses will be delivered by Judge VANDERPOOL, WM. CURTIS

ALEXANDER FINLEY was arrested again today, on a charge of being concerned with forgeries passed upon the Trust Company Bank. Mr. MILLARD was brought in as a witness, but refused to testify, and Mrs. MILLARD refused to appear. The magistrate continued the case.

The chiefest question for all French Governments since 1789 has been how to satisfy the working and poorer classes of Paris. Overlooking, or not solving this question, they have one after another been overthrown. Any Government that rests on the empty stomachs of its subjects is sure to " cave in." Parliamentary, or other such opposition, is but the occasional cause of their fall.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Last Man--By Aunt--Two can Play at that Game. BURTON'S THEATRE.--John Bull--In Place and Out of Place.

AFTERNOON SESSION. The Session was opened with prayer by Dr. MURRAY. Dr. M'DOWELL, from the Committee of Overtures, presented overture No. 22, from a Church in the Presbytery of East Alabama, asking to be transferred to the Presbytery of Florida, in the Synod of Georgia. On motion, approved.

SOUTHWESTERN MAIL COMMUNICATIONS.-The Postmaster-General, having had under consideration the important mail arrangements between Louisville, Kentucky, and New-Orleans, has concluded to modify the acceptance of his predecessor, made on the 1st of March last, so as to dispense with the restriction of the service to low-pressure boats, and with the way-mails between Cairo and St. Francisville--the compensation to be adjusted by the standard of the lowest bids received under the advertisement therefore.

PROTESTANT EPISCOPAL CHURCH OF THE REDEEMER, YORKVILLE.--This edifice, which is just completed, was yesterday consecrated by Right Rev. Bishop WAINWRIGHT. The Bishop and a large body of clergy assembled at the house of Mr. GEERY, one f the Vestry, in the vicinity of the church, where they formed into procession, and entered the building at 11 o'clock.

ANNUAL CONVENTION OF THE CHI PSI FRATERNITY -The Thirteenth Annual Convention of the Chi Psi Fraternity, was held in the Irving House at 6 P. M. yesterday. About twenty delegates attended from the Lodges of Union College, William's College, Middlebury College, Wesleyan University, Bowdon College, University of Michigan, Columbia College, N. Y., and Princeton College. There were several members of the New-York

THE CHARTER ELECTION--EIGHTH WARD VIGILANCE COMMITTEE.--The Vigilance Committee of the Eighth Ward, met last evening at No. 100 Wooster-street, HENRY ERBEN, Esq., in the Chair. Mr. JONAS N. PHILLIPS, and Mr. WM TUCKER, were appointed Secretaries. Mr. ERBEN explained the object of the meeting to be to use measures for securing the election of the new Charter. Dates from the City of Mexico to the 9th May, are received by way of New-Orleans. The Government had ordered a Spanish gentleman, by the name of CARRERA, to leave the country, considering him a pernicious man. The Trait d'Union says this act had caused much commotion in the Cabinet, and the Ministers had all threatened to resign. The affair was arranged.

She is not what many have supposed, a tall, heavy-set, masculine woman, with ridiculous dress and sunburnt complexion, with brass enough in her face for the manufacture of several stew-kettles. No, nothing of that hind. She is a modest young lady of about

We have received St. John, N. B., papers of the 30th ult. They continue to be filled with articles relative to the fishing question. The Morning News states that H. M. ketch -- had recently arrived and would be stationed in the Bay of Fundy. The screw steamer Phoenix was fitting out in England, and would probably be stationed near St. John.

The Women's State Temperance Society organized this morning for its Second Annual Meeting, in Corinthian Hall. It was called to order by Mrs. E. C. STANTON, of Seneca Falls. Prayer was offered by a gentleman present, when the Address of the President was read. It was a long and well-written document, reviewing the history of the Society for the year past.

The Knoxville Register, of the 16th inst., says: Every day's intelligence from the copper mines assures us that the business is to prove lucrative to an extraordinary degree. We have been informed, and that, too, by a gentleman in whom we can confide, that in a single day one man took from the mines ore enough to net in the New-York market one hundred and seventy dollars.

SUCCESSFUL BURGLARY.--The residence of HARVEY FORCE, on Oxford-street, near Flushing avenue, was entered by burglars on Tuesday night, who succeeded in obtaining and escaping with $175 and a silver watch. The watch and money were in the sleeping apartment of Mr. FORCE, in the pockets of his pantaloons.

If gentlemen of the Legislature will remember the complacency with which they regarded themselves at the close of the last session, in view of the one particularly good thing they did, in giving us an amended Charter, we are sure they will eagerly adopt any method by which a repetition of the same Pleasant emotions may be secured.

PETITIONS. Mr. COOLEY, 0f J. PHILLIPS PHOENIX, J. WHITNEY, and JAMES LENOX against taking Jones' Woods for a public park, because it is not central. Mr. BABCOCK, remonstrance of Frederick Bronson and others, against taking Jones' Woods for a park.

People will no doubt receive the assertion with surprise that there is but one Poet Office in New-York. That in this huge City through which thousands of letters are circulating hourly, there is but one organised and responsible office where such missives can be deposited with any certainty of reaching their destination, or in case of loss, any hope of reimbursement to the suffering party.

Suddenly, on Tuesday, May 31, JANE ANN, eldest child of Joseph and Delia Campbell. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, at the residence of her parents, No. 108 Perry-st., this (Thursday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. On Wednesday, June 1, LEWIS R. CHESBROUGH, Jr., aged 6 years and 3 months.

To the Editor of the Washingten Union: SIR: You announced, some weeks ago, the decree of President BELZU, establihsing the freedom of the seas upon the Bolivian tributaries of the Amazon, and offering a reward of $10,000 to the captain of the first steamer that should ascend from the sea any one of these tributaries. This was the firstling of HERNDON's expedition to the Amazon.

On Wednesday, June 1, by Rev. Thomas H. Skinner, Jr., SILAS POTTER, Esq., of Boston, Mass., to CAROLINE D., eldest daughter of Henry Allen, of this City. On Wednesday, June 1, at the Church of the Saviour, Brooklyn, by Rev. Dr. Farley, THOMAS PROSSER, Jr., to ELIZABETH, second daughter of Mr. Thomas Woodward.

About this season trees and tailors begin to blossom. Spring leaves and Spring patterns make earth gay, and fashions and foliage leap into instant birth beneath the vivifying influence of the mighty sun.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--A son of Mr. A. Dows, No. 75 State-street, fifteen years of age, named GEORGE, was killed on Tuesday last at Morrisania, by the accidental discharge of a pistol, in the hands of a school-mate-the ball passing through his lungs. The boys were both pupils at Mr. CHISHOLM'S Academy. The remains were brought to thi, City yesterday.

THE MEMPHIS CONVENTION.- Gov. Foote has appointed seventy delegates to the Memphis Convention from Vicksburg, in addition to the large number from the State at large previously appointed. The Vicksburg Whig, in publishing that list, remarks:

The Lowell Vox Populi, speaking of the death of JESSE HUTCHINSON, says: "He was a firm believer in Spiritual Rapping, and during the last few months he spent in California it was apparent to his friends that he was laboring under a kind of monomania which rendered him quite as miserable as he believed that society to be, for whose reformation he professed a willingness to devote the labors of his life."

The steamer Princeton has been ordered to the Mediterranean. Capt. W. W. HUNTER, an experienced steam navigator, it is hoped and expected, will command her. A political war is raging in Missouri. The Marshal for the State and the Postmaster at St. Louis are yet unappointed.

The Womens' State Temperance Society met again this morning--Mrs. STANTON presiding. The fist thing in order was the discussion of the amendment to tile Constitution, proposing to admit men to hold offices in the Society. This was discussed long anal ell by men and women, and finally, on the motion of FREDERICK DOUGLASS, it was laid on the table until the next annual meeting.

A desperate attempt to escape from the Penitentiary was detected a day or two since. CAMPER, a prisoner in charge of the carpenter's shop, stole half a dozen rasps, which RADY, a master blacksmith, converted into huge bowle knives, with which as many prisoners, who were in the plot, were to defend themselves.

In the remark made by me a few days ago, in noticing the debate in the Assembly on the Niagara Ship Canal, that nobody thought it of any con sequence, I had reference to the absence of interest in the subject at that time.
