ATTEMPT OF A MOTHER TO MURDER HER FOUR CHILDREN.--Last evening, at an early hour, a Mrs. T. HARPER, residing in Jackson's court, between Ninth and Tenth, and Race and Vine-streets, while under the influence of mental derangement, attempted to take the life of her four young children, and to kill herself.

Pursuant to notice, the reception of Hon. Judge O'NEALL, of S. C., Most Worthy Patriarch of the Order of the Sons of Temperance, by the Grand Division of Eastern New-York, came off last evening in the Greene-street M. E. Church. A large number of the members of the Order were present, as also some of the Daughters and Cadets of Temperance, besides many of the friends of the cause generally.

GIBLS.-This case was called on yesterday afternoon, beforeJustlce BOSWELL. The following is the testimony as adduced on the examination: Ellen Sandison sworn: I reside in New-York; I was at Mrs Boyd's store, No. 103 Grand-street, on Tuesday, a week ago; Miss Eliza Hall was with me; we went there to take two bannets home which we had been making for Mis. Boyd;

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: I beg leave to send you for publication an extract from an official letter, written by Major WM. H. EMORY, surveyor and astronomer on the part of the United States to "run and mark the boundary line" between our territory and that of the Republic of Mexico, and sent to the Department of the Interior.

YORK-STREET M. E. CHURCH.--The Sabbath School attached to the York-street M. E. Church has recently increased so much in numbers that the present accommodations are entirely inadequate to meet the wants of the School. To remedy this, the Society are about to erect a suitable building on Bridge-street, 36 feet by 75 feet deep, and two stories high; material brick.

The brief Whitsuntide interregnum has afforded most of the Ministry an opportunity of exchanging the turmoil of legislation for the ruralities of their country seats; and as their energies have been severely tasked by much speech-making and late hours, it cannot be doubted that they have gladly availed themselves of the chances of obtaining pure air and recreation.

The following is the Message of Gov. SEYMOUR, transmitted to the Legislature of this State on Wednesday, vetoing the Bill for the Extension of the Basis of Banking Capital: Hon. WILLIAM H. LUDLOW, Speaker of the Assembly: In pursuance with the provisions of the Constitution, I return to the Assembly, with my objections to its becoming a law,

SECOND DAY. U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The case of the Captain of the Roscius--The United States vs. Daniel Maloney.--At 10 o'clock his Honor took his seat, and in a few minutes the eight jurors sworn in on the first day appeared in their places. Capt. Maloney and Dr. Christian had seats within the bar by their counsel.

The semi-official returns of the Foreign Imports at the Port of New-York for the month of May, have just been made up, and present an aggregate larger by 95 per cent. than the corresponding month of 1852, viz.: $14,332,319, exclusive of $207,924 in Foreign Specie and Bullion.

When Commodore C. W MORGAN, of the U. S. Navy, died, in January last, the obituary notices of him told that though long in the Navy, he did not participate in any of the actions which had reflected honor upon the country and the Navy. We were sure that this was doing Commodore MORGAN less than justice, but supposed that others who knew him better would vindicate his memory.

CORRECTION.--Our Telegraphic dispatch from Cincinnati, published in this morning's edition, contains a gross blunder, the fault of the Telegraph, which we hasten to correct. The dispatch states that ALEXANDER FINLAY had been arrested at Cincinnati for forgery, it should read:

Among the delegates present at the Baptist Convention in Albany, was a venerable gentleman by the name of Thomas-an old sea-captain, who had grown wealthy in the India trade. He first manifested his liberality by offering the use of his sons' ships for any missionary work to China, California, He then, to meet a certain expenditure, set down $100 each for his eight sons and sons-in-law.

A bill is pending in the Connecticut Legislature which provides for the appointment of a Board of Railroad Commissioners, invested with extraordinary powers, It is proposed to establish a rigid surveillance over the various lines of railway included within the limits of the State, of such as pass through its territory.

The Senate yesterday having spent the morning session in a debate more interesting than profitable, at the evening session came to a vote upon the resolutions that had been sent up from the Assembly. The motion to concur was lost--Ayes 6, Noes 19.

The New-York Exhibition for the Industry of all Nations, announced officially to open on the fifteenth of Jlly, will assuredly, without very unexpected additional embarrassment, open on or very near that day. It is the first authorized public announcement of any particular day.

In the beginning of this century, the perils which then hung menacingly above the power of England were dissipated by two very remarkable occurrences. At that time, while the military sway of France was extending itself over the European Continent, its trade was greatly damaged, and almost driven from the sea by the English armaments.
DEATH BY RAILWAY CARS.--We understand that a daughter of Mr. WILLIAM H. HOSMER of Willimantic, about ten years of age, lost her life at that place, yesterday morning, in a most distressing manner.

Governor MARTIN delivered his Message today. It is entirely of local interest. In reference to railroad accidents he recommends that a Life Protection Commission be established, to investigate such occurrences; with plenary powers to examine into all matters appertaining to railroads or other corporations, which may endanger the lives of passengers, operatives, and all having lawful business with such corporations;

The Washington Union persisting its claim to the dignity of organ, has ventured to issue a second edition of the inaugural, with important modifications. The document appeared on Wednesday. It endeavors chiefly to reconcile the broad difference between Mr. PIERCE, on the 4th of March, and Mr. PRYOR, on the 19th of May;

A letter received in Salem, dated Montevideo, April 5, says that great discontent prevailed there, placards having been posted at night bearing the words, "Death to the present GovernmentLive the Colorados."

Senator CHASE has addressed a letter to the Chairman of the Committee of Invitation of the Memphis Convention, in which great stress is laid upon the project of a Railroad from the Mississippi to the Pacific. Mr. CHASE says:

On Thursday, June 2, by Rev. J. M. Rowland, Mr. WILLIAM S. ROWLAND to SARAH NEINELL. eldest daughter of William Anderson, Esq., all of this City. On Wednesday, June 1, at St. John's Church, Stamford, Conn., by Rev. Dr. Todd, SAMUEL H. HOLMES, of this City, to MARY E., daughter of Dr. Haight, of the former place.

The furniture establishment of Messrs. RUSSELL BAKER, at Dedham, was destroyed by fire last night. Loss, $17,000. Insurance, $8,000. At Salmon Falls, N. H., last night, LEWIS MAXWELL, a stable keeper, was murdered, and a young man named PRAY badly stabbed, by two men named WATERS and one SCANNEL.

The much talked-of Convention for the discussion of the Bible, assembled, we presume, yesterday. We are without an account of the fact; and not having regarded the proceeding as of sufficient probable consequence to justify the trouble, we have no special verbatim reporter on the spot to supply us with daily minutes.

FIRE -Officers VANDEWATER and MURPHY discovered a fire issuing from the roof of a grocery store and dwelling house on the corner of North-Seventh and Firststreets, on Tuesday evening. They burst open the doors and succeeded with the aid of several citizens, in extinguishing it with about $50 damage to the premises.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Will you permit one who has long been an active member of the Ward and other Committees in this City, to make a few suggestions in regard to the subject we both have near at heart-success of the Reform Ticket on Tuesday next?

For the other City News of this morning, ses Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.-The Stranger-Doubte Bedded Boom. WALLACK'S THEATRE.-Rent Day- Teddy the Tiler. BURTON'S THEATRE.-Ireland As it Is-In Place and Out of Place.

FESTOVALS.--Strawberry Festivals will be held next week in Jersey City, by ladies connected with religious societies. The ladies of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church will hold the first one in the Commercial Buildings, on Tuesday evening, and on Thursday evenilg the ladies of the First Reforlied Dutch Church, will hold another. The proceeds are devoted to church purposes.

" Your memorialists would therefore respectfully pray your honorable body to cause the principal travelled streets of the City to be swept every morning, and other streets twice or thrice a week, or as often as may be required to keep them clean."--Extract from a petition to the Common Council of New-York.

If the design of the Mormon rulers in selecting the Great Basin as the seat of their power, was to isolate their people from the world, they certainly made a happy choice. This basin is a vast hollow or depression in the mountains, and the Mormon Capital is unapproachable from any civilized point, except by a tedious journey of at least one thousand miles. In the Winter it is entirely inaccessible.

" If it were not for these high rents," says the young man to himself, "I could get along swimmingly. Good health, a good wife, a good will, and a good business,-but these rents! they eat into my salary frightfully; they consume all the profits, and when I have toiled and tried to the utmost, they bring out a balance against me."

An invitation from the Buffalo City and New-York and Erie Railroad Companies, to pass over their roads and visit Cleveland, was accepted for some convenient time after the adjournment. The resolution for a Committee of Conference coming up Mr. COOLEY offered a preamble and resolutions as follows:

We left Constantinople for Galatz, by the Black Sea and the Danube, in an Austrian steamer of the LLOYD Company. This Company has encircled both Turkey in Europe and Turkey in Asia with her nineteen lines of steamers, which she sustains with fifty-seven boats.

THE WORKS OF SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE. Edited by Prof. SHEDD. New-York: HARPER BROTHERS. 1853. 7 vols. 12mo. This publication-a desideratum in literature-brings us round into the current of some recent thoughts on a very strange being-for such certainly was SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE; intellectually speaking, a man of large and lofty reaches; morally speaking, a helpless and disreputable member of society.

The General Synod of the Reformed Dutch Church convened in this city, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, in the Third Reformed Dutch Church, at the corner of Filbert and Tenth-streets. The proceedings were opened with prayer by Rev. GUSTAVUS ABEEL, D. D., the President of the last Synod.

Bremen brig Johns Ed. Grosse, Capt. WEIGHT MAN, 43 days from Bremen, with 1,475 boxes of pipes, and 142 passengers-all well, is at anchor on the bar. On the 1st spoke ship Georges, SMITH, for Liverpool, off Nantucket Shoals, foremast sprung and main-topgallant-mast carried away; carrying short sail on the foremast.

The May Anniversaries have come and gone--the proceedings of none being very remarkable except those of the GARRISON Anti SlaveryConvention, which generally does and says something to tickle public attention. The Abolition avant-guard has denounced the conduct of SUMNER and other

BALTIMORE will be largely and highly respectably represented at the Memphis Conventiion, which meets on Monday. Her people are not sectional in the party sense of the term; but commercially the city is, or desires to be so, while Southern capital and Southern custom are in prospect.

THIRD DAY. UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT-Before Chief Justice NELSON--The case of the Captain of the Rosczus-The United States vs Daniel Maloney.-In consequence of the absence of one of the Jurors, James H. Boyd, the trial did not proceed at the assembling of the Court. His Honor imposed a fine of $25; but on Mr. Boyd making an apology, the fine was remitted.

FURTHER MEXICAN NEWS.--A new bureau' having special control over public roads and tolls, has been created. It will take charge of the roads from Toluca to Vera Cruz, via Orizaba, from Mexico to Acapulco, from Puebla to Perote, from Perote to Vera Cruz, from Mexico to the interior, via Queretaro, and from Tampico to San Louis.

Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Love's Sacrifice--Obstinate Family. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Stranger-Used UP. BURTON'S THEATRE.--Ireland As it Is--Deeds of Dreadful Note ST. CHARLES THEATRE.--Queen of the Abruzzi--Ladies Rights--Jack Sheppard. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--St. Mary's Eve.

The Assembly brought its long and exciting session to a close last evening, crowding after the manner of public bodies, a large part of its important business into a small space, and leaving much undone. The closing scene, though animated and still sensitive from the excitement of preceding events, was cordial, kindly and in the best spirit.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your issue of the 26th ultimo, some one inquires, "What has become of the U. S. Post for the City delivery, at a cent a letter ?" He complains that the U. S. Mail boxes are scarce, and that BOYD's Express monopolizes the business.

The Managers of the American Bible Society have erected the States of New-Jersey and Delaware into a District, and appointed Rev. GEO. SHELDON, for several years Agent for this State, as Superintendent, with a clerical assistant to aid in the work. His office and residence will be as heretofore, Plainfield, N. J.

A private letter from the redoubtable Madame Pfeifer, dated Surabaya, December 12, 1852, mentions that she travelled through the greater part of Sumatra, had returned to Java, and was about to depart for the Molucca Islands, with the ultimate object of reaching New Guinea, and exploring the interior of the country, which has never been visited by an European.

A few days since we called attention to the supposed melancholy loss of life resulting from the wreck of the ship William and Mary, while on her passage from Liverpool to New-Orleans. To-day we publish the details of the rescue of all the passengers but two, and their safe arrival at the Bahamas.

On Thursday, 2d inst., FREDERICK A. BANFIELD, in the 36th year of his age. His funeral will tae place on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 173 Prospect-st., Brooklyn. His friends and those of the family are respectively invited to attend. His remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

What has been so repeatedly and vainly undertaken in this country-a magazine devoted exclusively to Botany-is now proposed by gentlemen who will certainly make it succeed, if success be at all possible. Messrs. H. W. DERBY Co., the well-known publishing house of Cincinnati, issue the prospectus of " THE AMERICAN BOTANIST: a Monthly Journal, devoted to Physiological, Geographical, Pictorial and Systematic Botany." Mr. JAMES W. WARD, of that city, a gentleman very

Readers of the DAILY TIMES must, we are sure, read with no little interest the papers of Mr. CHARLES L. BRACE, relative to the NewYork Poor. The details are in themselves so distressing,. and the disordered social Condition they indicate so alarming, that we may reasonably examine them with more than common care, as elements of the great problem to which the united benevolence and wisdom of the time must presently addict themselves.

A few days since, in our news from Santa Fe, it was stated that Governor LANE had replied to the communication of the Mexican Commissioners in regard to the Mesilla Valley question, but that it was thought best to withhold the letter from publication for the present.

FOURTEENTH DAY--CLOSING SESSION. The Assembly met yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. The first business was the reading of a report from the special Committee appointed at the last General Assembly to take into consideration some means for securing the right of conscience, in religious matters, to American citizens in foreign countries.

Our Canadian exchanges are full of accounts of the recent fires in the woods on the Ottawa, in the vicinity of Bytown. The extent of the calamity is as yet imperfectly known, but it is supposed that a soace of at least 2,500 square miles was burnt over, and that from four to five hundred families are rendered homeless. It is feared that a number of lives have been lost.

It will be gratifying to our readers to learn that the unfortunate passengers, one hundred and eighty in number, and the crew, of this ill-fated ship, have been saved, with the exception of two, who, in endeavoring to get into tile long boat, were drowned. The heroic and humane conduct of the two seamen, WM WARD and SAMUEL P. HARRIS,

The General Assembly of each branch of the Presbyterian Church dissolves in amity. The closing act of the .Old School body, yesterday, related to the preservation of religious freedom for American citizens abroad. The government was especially commended for the Treaty recently concluded with Uraguay. Some few members of the As.

The steam tug Eclipse burst her boiler in this port yesterday. The explosion was terrific, tearing the boat en irely to pieces. killing a fireman and boy, and severely injuring the engineer, cook, wheelman and one deck hand. The captain was also slightly injured.

Madame SONTAG will arrive in town to-day, after a successful tour in the New-England States. We hear sundry rumors concerning Madame SONTAG's future movements, but there is nothing, we believe, definitely arranged at present. The most noticeable of these whisperings is the one which hints at an English Opera.

The Free Democratic State Convention assembled yesterday at Harrisburgh, and nominated WILLIAM M. STEVENSON, of Mercer, for Judge of the Supreme Court. Dr. ROBERT MITCHELL, of Indiana, Canal Commissioner. NEVILLE B. CRAIG, of Alleghany, Auditor General, and L. E. CORSON. of Montgomery, Survey or General.

THE WOMEN'S CONVENTION AT RAVENNA.-The Women's demonstration at Ravenna, 0,, came to an end on the 26th ult., after a two days' session. Reverend Miss BROWN, being called upon, explained the circumstances connected with the late Temparance Convention in New-York, and read the call for the "Whole World's" Convention to be held in this City on the 16th of September next. The following resolutions were adopted among others.

The Assembly met at 4 o'clock, and Chancellor JOHNS, from the Committee on Finance, made a report, which, on motion, was made the order of the day for Thursday morning. The report of the Committee on Education was submitted. It recommends the last Thursday

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : Shall we have a Park ! While all we hear answer in the affirmative, no action is taken by our legislators to realize the wishes or necessities of our people. It took a long time to effect the introduction of the Croton. Everybody felt its need, but nobody had for years the will to act.

The feature of the day has been Senator COOLEY's speech on the Canal resolutions returned from the Assembly. The honorable Senator did not direct the attention of the Senate to the merits of the propositions before them, but devoted all his skill and labor to vindicate himself from the assaults made in a former speech by Senator JONES, and to most savage retaliation upon that Senator and upon the Barnburners at large.

Mr. JOHN J. HICKS 'has been detected in driving the first pile or excavating the first bucket of mud from his new Williamsburg Ferry, and forthwith stopped by an injunction. The ways of the transgressor are certainly not so easy as they might be.

THE OCEAN WAVE DISASTER.-The steamer Ocean Wave was burned on Lake Ontario a few weeks since, and many lives were lost. PENITENTIARY.-Mr. PETER STORMS has been appointed to supervise the agricultural department at the Penitentiary Grounds, and Mrs. GALLAGHER as Assistant Matron at the Alms-House.

Judge MORRIS, this morning at Chambers, gave a singular illustration of his fitness for the position which he now holds upon the bench of the Supreme Court. A member of the bar had occasion to ask his signature to a legal advertisement, to be published in one or more of the City papers.

GOV. LANE has published a letter in defense of his famous Proclamation on the Mcsilla Valley question. The document itself has not reached us, but we give elsewhere a very complete abstract of its leading points. GOV. LANE supports the tone of his Proclamation throughout, producing arguments to convince

I telegraphed you last evening that I had reason to believe important dispatches had been received from Great Britain, relative to the construction placed by the British Government on the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty. In the hurry of writing, I substituted the word " occupation " for "dominion."

Galinani's Messenger says that M. FORCEDAY, the only one of the Deputies of the Nord to the Convention who voted against the death of Louis XVI., has just died in the commune of Marcq-enBarceul, near Lille, at the age of 95. He was President of the General Assembly of the Electors

MURDER AT SALMON FALLS, N. H.--On Wednesday evening last, the Village 'of Salmon Falls, N. H., was startled by the intelligence that Mr. LEWIS MAXWELL, stable-keeper, and Mr. IVORY PRAY, of South Berwick, had been killed. In the early part of the evening some difficulty occurred at the little village on the opposite side of the river, where rum is sold indiscriminately, and where rows frequently occur.

When Dr. PATTERSON'S appointment was under discussion, the other day, in the Cabinet, it was strongly resisted by the Postmaster-General. The President and Secretary GUTHRIE insisted, and the appointment was positively made. Next day, a strong outside pressure came to CAMPBELL's

The Charleston Courier publishes the following elequent remarks of LEGARE on the subject of Slavery in the United States. They are suggestive. This is a great practical question, and needs to be treated by statesmen and not by sophisters and fanatics.

In pursuance to a requisition, signed by some of the most respectable and influential citizens of New-York, a grand mass meeting of the taxpayers convened on Saturday evening for the purpose of taking counsel in regard to the new Charter, to be voted upon next Tuesday.

The body of a man named CHARLES CONNELLY was found in the river this morning. Suspicions are entertained that he came to his death from foul play at the hands of two men named COYLE and CARROLL, with whom he had a quarrel at a dance house on the pier, on Thursday, since which time CONNELLY has not been seen alive. COYLE and CARROL have both left the city.

It has not occurred in our day that the Legislature of this State has been convened in Extraordinary Session for the transaction of ordinary business, till the present time. In 1851 a called session was held, made necessary by the resignation of near half the Senate, moved by implacable hostility to a measure which the Legislature had manifested its determination to pass.

The meeting at Metropolitan Hall may not have been so large as certain political gatherings we may remember in the same or other places. But it must not be forgotten that the impulses were different, and so were the objects of tile meeting. No whippers-in with sharp appetites for post and profit were busy for a week before, driving their friends to the demonstration.

To-morrow's Union will contain an able, carefully considered and grave article upon the subject of our New-Mexican affairs. It takes ground that the conduct of Governor Trias in seizing, with an armed force, Mesilla Valley, is an outrage combined with folly.

THE TRAGEDY AT SOUTH BERWICK, ME.--We learn from South Berwick, Me., that last night, a mob, estimated at two thousand, from all the surrounding towns, assembled there for the purpose of tearing down the rum-shop near where Mr. LEWIS MAXWELL was killed and Mr. PRAY injured, on Wednesday night.

We have no mails to-day beyond Mobile. The Washington Union of this morning publishes an official notification from the State Department, announcing that a large amount of bonds, purporting to have been issued by Hon GEORGE DECHACON, Spanish Consul at Philadelphia, payable in 1856 at Madrid, or at said Consulate, are in circulation at New-York and elsewhere, for which the Government is not responsible, said bonds having been issued without its authority.

The New-York School Bill, and Brooklyn and Williamsburg Water Bills are safely through both houses. The Legislature this morning received an invitation from the New-York and Erie and Buffalo and New-York City Railroad Companies, to pass over their Roads to Buffalo, and thence by steamboat to Cleveland, which was accepted by the Senate, and will be by the Assembly.

There is always an aristocracy in every city--an exclusive portion of society--who base their pretensions to superiority upon family rank or wealth, or both combined. This class is determined, too, as far as they are able, to set their claims to preeminence fully before the world, by monopolizing the best parts of a city, and by living in the finest streets and the most stately houses.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Miss LAURA KEENE takes a benefit to-night at this establishment. SHAKESPEARE's admirable comedy of "As you like it," will be produced for the occasion. Mr. WALLACK impersonates the melancholy Jacques; Mr. LESTER, Orlando, and Miss LAURA KEENE the fair Rosalind. New Scenery has been painted for the piece, together with new properties, costumes and machinery.
BROOKLYN BOARD OF HEALTH.--The first meeting of this Board was held on Friday at the City Hall. Present, his Honor the Mayor, and Aldermen MORRIS, HIMMAN, and NEELY.

We have received late Halifax papers, from which we learn that the Provincial fishing schooner Velocity has been driven from St. George's Bay by a French cruiser. The Halifax Recorder hopes that the haste of the French cruiser, in this instance, will wake up the vigilance of the Basilisk, Devastation, and other British vessels, engaged in the same line of business.

The Legislative Excursion came off to-day in fine style. The train, consisting of six cars, containing about 300 persons, left the depot at Albany, at 6 o'clock this morning, and arrived here at 2 o'clock this afternoon. The actual running time exceeded the time table about 66 minutes, owing to the unexpected size of the train.

The New-Jersey Railroad Company celebrated its Twenty-first Anniversary at Newark, on Saturday. Guests were present from all quarters of the State-public officers, judicial functionaries, the bar, the banks, the railroads were all properly represented, and the reports were heard, and the dinner digested will infinite good feeling.

THOMAS THORNLKY has been appointed Warden of the Penitentiary of the District, defeating DRANCH ROBINSON, the bold, vigorous, and self-sacrificing Democrat. Colonel WILCOX, Major DONELSON'S son-in-law, will probably go abroad as Charge d' Affairs, notwithstanding his Union Compromise sentiments. It is believed that Secretary DAVIS will magnanimously withdraw his opposition.

The session of the Common Council, commencing to-day, is more acticeable than usual, from the circumstance that several applications for increased pay will be made to it. Following in the wake of the Trades' Union; the members of the Police force, and the lighters of the street lamps, have determined on seeking a considerable advance in their present salaries.

U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON--The Jurore were all in their seats at the hour appointed by the Court, and, having answered to their names, the Jurors not empunelled in the came were discharged until 11 o'clock on Monday. The Court called upon the Counsel to proceed.

ARTHUR SPRING, THE PHILADELPHIA MURDERER.--The Philadelphia Bulletin on Saturday, has an account of a visit to the conviet SPRING, whose execution is close at hand: "We paid a visit to the Moyamensing prison yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of seeing ARTHUR SPRING. We found the condemned man in good health and cheerful spirits.

The Message of Governor MARTIN was delivered in the Legislature of New-Hampshire, on the 2d inst. Of course it is long. The State is prosperous. Too much legislation is condemned, is being liable to render the law and its application uncertain. The Banking System of the State is represented as sound and prosperous, embracing an aggregate capital of $3,226,000, all paid in, independently of Savings Institutions, the capital of which is $2,132,218.

From the Philadelphia Public Ledger. The new interpretation of the Sub-Treasury Law is creating great excitement, and will probably give rise to a warm debate in the next Congress. It is maintained here, by lawyers of great repute, that it is puerile for the officers of the federal Government to refuse to receive or pay out bank notes in the United States; but to do both within a marine league from shore.

FROM MONTEVIDEO.--MUTINY ON BOARD SHIP REINDEER.--A letter received in Salem, Mass., from Montevideo, dated April 5, says: The crew of the hermaphrodite brig Reindeer, (English,) from Valparaiso for this port, mutinied while off Cape San Antonio, killing the captain, chief mate, cabin boy and a clergyman who was passenger, and having loaded themselves with gold dust and doubloons, stolen from the vessel, they ran her ashore.

FATAL STEAMBOAT EXPLOSION--THE TUG PROPELLER ECLIPSE A TOTAL WRECK.--Last evening, about 8 1/4 o'clock, the boiler of the Tag Propeller Eclipse burst--while she was winding a few rods above Madison-street Bridge. All the crew were saved except the second fireman named CRAWFORD, who is supposed to be drowned.

On Saturday, June 4, the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company, attained its twenty-first year; and a goodly number of Stock-holders with their invited guests, assembled at the City Hotel, Newark, to celebrate the "coming of age," of this thriving enterprise.

At the afternoon session of the Senate on Friday, Mr. CONGER withdrew the pending resolutions offered by him at the morning session, and introduced series No. 2, which essentially embraced the same points. No. 1 provides instructing the Committee to communicate to the conference "that the Senate are desirous that no plan to amend the constitution shall be approved, which should by implication revive the operation of chap, 485 of the laws of 1851."

His Excellency, the Governor General of Canada, offers a reward of [pound]100 for the apprehension, in Canada or the United States, of William E. Brainerd, who shot his mother, in Wickham, on the 56th ult.

There is no longer room for doubt that we are on the verge of a fresh conflict with Mexico. Although negotiation on the boundary difficulty is still practicable, and the question is not one impossible of peaceful solution; neither Government is disposed to moderate means. Both have appealed to arms. Both have dispatched a large body of troops to the worthless strip of territory, with orders to occupy it.

What has become of the Union and its Russian article? Is it really true, as is whispered about, that the sentiments of that article are the sentiments of a majority of the Cabinet, and that the Union dares not disclaim them, lest it is in turn disavowed.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The ever fresh, ever acceptable, ever delightful comedy of "As You Like It," was produced here last night. Mr. WALLACK seems determined to end his season in good style. On Monday next, we believe, the theatre wherein we have so oft been amused will close.

THAT NINETY-EIGHT DOLLARS.--Several weeks since, the Common Council of Williamsburg gave a favorite contractor $98 for repairing a side-walk in North Second-street, which had been injured by rain. Several persons stored ready to do the same job for $25.

A Paris Letter-writer informs us that a new Library of the Fathers is about to appear under the auspices of his holiness. The fact may be considered supplementary to the late encyclical letter, in which Pope Pars took sides with that portion of the Galliean Church which advocates the removal of the Greek and Latin classics from the schools, and the substitution of the Ecclesiastical writers of the Decline and Lower Empire.

More than twenty years have passed since the use of the low pressure engine, in navigating the Mississippi and Ohio, was given up as unprofitable. Impracticable it was not, and for a time the experiment kept tolerable pace with the high pressure machinery, until the rapid improvement in the latter, giving in creased speed to nearly all the new boats to which it was applied, drove out the competition.

DANGEROUS FALL.--A little girl, at play with several others on Bergen Hill, on Friday, fell backward down a precipice, a distance of fifty feet. She would have been instantly killed had not her fall been broken in her descent. Her recovery is doubtful.

Fellow-citizens of New-York, we beg to remind you that if City Reform should, by possibility, be defeated to-day, one of the chief offices of your Press is virtually at an end. Unlike most party questions, this subject has enlisted the unanimous support of the daily and weekly newspapers of New-York.

The Municipal election to-day on the Liquor traffic resulted n the success of the Temperance ticket. The returns are not all in, but the majority believed to be overwhelming. There is great rejoining among the friends of the Temperance cause.

It is now tolerably clear that the cause of Christianity is to suffer no serious damage from the Hartford debates. The material was of the wrong sort. We can easily conceive of a body of men differently qualified, who might at least confound the faith of the weak, and provoke inquiry that might effectually, and perhaps fatally mislead the incompetent listener: men of subtle discernment;

The time has at last come for action. Talking in all its varieties of wonder, indignation, censure, vituperation, exhortation, suggestion, has had its year of days. This day is to crown the talking with fact. A simple work evolving a mementous revolution.

From the Washington Union. The Republic, of yesterday, sums up the whole course of SANTA ANNA since his return to Mexico, and concludes that "here are all the preliminaries of war." We trust and believe that the conclusion premature, and without adequate condition.

It is exquisitely refreshing to hear that a City ordinance has been enforced. There is something hopeful and invigorating in the circumstance. When a helpless invalid convalesces to the extent of crutches, we congratulate him on the improved symptoms of his complaint; and so, at this present moment, may we congratulate the body corporate of the City of Brooklyn no having hobbled out of its official sick chamber.

GENERAL REMARKS.--This fruit is a native of the temperate latitutdes, its name originating either in the practice formerly in vogue of placing straw upon and about the plants, in order to insure health and cleanliness, or from an old method of threading the berries on straws of grass, in which shape they were brought from the woods.

POEMS BY ALEXANDER SMITH.--TICKNOR, REED, FIELDS, BOSTON. Our readers must be aware from numerous allusions and quotations, which have appeared quite recently in the literary journals, that a new poet is said to have arisen in England.

THE POLLING DISTRICTS.--The Mayor, Alderman and Commonally of the City of New-York, in Common Council ?? do ordain as follows: ?? The Election Districts already established shall continue to be the Election Districts of the several Wards of the City of New-York, until otherwise provided.

FROM THE RIO GRANDE.--Details of news from the Rio Grande bring a few interesting items from Brownsville: The Flag states that the imported goods alone which passed through Brownsville during the past year amounted, according to the collector's statement, to the large sum of five millions of dollars in value, and that the domestic manufactures could not fall short of that amount.
The President has appointed SAMUEL PUMPBREY and H. LINDSLEY, of Washington, and RICHARD JONES, of Georgetown, Inspectors of the Penitentiary in the District of Columbia. Hon. EDWARD EVERETT is here.

The new Bishop of North Carolina, Dr. ATKINSON, is a native of Virginia, and a man of sound and moderate views. He was formerly a lawyer in his native State, and has since ministered to a wealthy congregation in the city of Baltimore.

About 3 1/2 o'clock I was awakended again by the whistle of the locomotive, answering I suppose, the horn of a stage-coach, which in a few minutes drove up, bringing a mail. A negro man and woman, sleeping near me, woke, replenished the fire; two other passengers came in and we started.

THE FISHERIES.--The policy of the British Government in so jealousy watching encroachments upon the fishing privileges of their colonies in North America, has recoiled somewhat upon those whose interests it was designed to protect. The French, it is well known, possess fishing grounds in the neighborhood of Miquelon.

FIRST DAY. U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON--The United States vs. Daniel Maloney--As this extraordinary case proceeds, it appears to excite a stronger interest in the mind of the public, for, long before the hour appointed for the proceedings to be resumed, every avenue to the courtroom was crowded with persons anxious to obtain admittance.

In response to a call from the Young Mens' Democratic Club, a large meeting was held last evening in the Park, of those favorable to the amendments proposed to the City Charter. A platform was erected for the accommodation of the speakers and reporters; a band was also stationed there, and at intervals performed several airs.

The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool at noon, on the 28th May, arrived at this port at 7 1/2 o'clock this evening. The Collins steamship Pacific, from New-York on the 14th May, arrived off Holyhead at 10 o'clock, A. M., on Tuesday, the 24th, and reached the Mersey at 3.45 P. M., the same day. Passage about 9 days 23 hours mean time.
FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT IN SOUTH CAROLINA.--The Charleston Courier of the 1st, contains the particulars of the late accident on the Columbia Railroad.

The gross revenues from the New-York State Canals for the fourth week in May, were $129,652, against $108,511 for the corresponding week of May, 1852. The total revenues of the season, from the opening of navigation to the 1st of June, amount to $593,917, against $546,005 in 1852, and $773,330 in 1851.
The smell of fresh turf is good, even when it comes struggling up through multiplied layers of dust from the Park of your great City, it is refreshing;

The steamship Daniel Webster from San Juan, Nicaragua, has arrived at this port bringing San Francisco dates to the 16th May. The Webster connected with the steamship Sierra Nevada, making the trip through in 20 1/2 days. The Prometheus sailed from San Juan for New-York on the 31st of May with 420 passengers.

The proceedings of the Reformed Dutch Synod, at Philadelphia, on Saturday, were not important. A report of the amount of contributing during the past year for religious and benevolent purposes from the various Classes, was laid before the Synod:

THE ALDERMAN IN ??.--The June session of the Board of Alderman ?? evening--RICHARD T. COMPTON Esq. in the chair. Alderman STUARTEVANT ?? from Bowen McNamee, and several ?? of the City, to have the principal ?? Crystal Palace swept every morning ?? in the neighborhood, as much as ??. We published the memorial in full, in Friday's TIMES.

Just as the hand on the dial pointed to the hour of 3, the doors of the ample dining room of the Cataract House were thrown open, and the invited guests, without any extraordinary noise or confusion, took their seats.

Our city election came off to-day, and was sharply contested, it being the first time of voting by Wards, and the first party contest at a city election in several years. The Whigs have elected their Mayor, A. W. SKINNER, by 359 majority, and chosen 3 Aldermen and 17 Councilmen.

A full meeting of the stockholders in the Ogdensburg Railroad was held here to-night, the attraction being the proposed consolidation of Northern railroads under one Board of Management. The annual report showed the total earnings of the year 1852 to be $180,127; expenditures, $281,290.

[Conclusion.] He was, I have said, a witty man; not that painful and laborious imposture, a professed maker of jests visibly gotten up with many a pang, for the opportunity, or for all opportunities, and then played off as impromptus, your blazes of wit, that go off like sky-rockets, and have just about as much as these the air of being unstudied;

FROM THE BRITISH PROVINOES.--The British Government has given notice that the troops stationed on Prince Edward's Island will be removed before the coming winter. The Barracks, Battery and Blockhouse have been recently valued, with a view of disposing of them to the local government, and if they should decline to purchase them, they will be offered to private individuals.

The Canada brings 92 passengers, as follows: Messrs. Sears, Sears, Jr., Miss Sears, Mr. and Mrs. Kohn, Sir Charles Lyell, lady and maid; Joseph Whitcomb, Mr. and Mrs. Chowing and two children, Mr. and Mrs. T. P. Tuckerman, Mr. and Mrs. Sweetzer, Mr. and Mrs. Hunan, three children and maid;

A MAN FOUND DROWNED.--On Sunday morning theo body of a man, apparently about thirty five years of age, was found floating in the river nearly opposite the Sybil's Cave, but so far advanced in decomposition as to make recognition impossible. An Inquest was held,

The Southern Convention met in this place this morning. Mr. DAWSON was reelected President, with twenty Vice Presidents, from ten Southern States. Rev. C. K. MARSHALL, of Miss., was chosen Secretary. After the organization, the Convention adjourned till 4 o'clock P.M.

Monuments are hard things to get up. That to WASHINGTON drags on slowly, and when finished will be, at best, a solemn looking obelisk. CRAWFORD is endeavoring to complete an equestrian statue of WASHINGTON, and two common ones of JEFFERSON and HENRY for the State of Virginin. Meantime, the WEBSTER project in Boston takes definite shape.

Yesterday, the Southern Convontion assembled at Memphis, and organized with a view to active business. The transactions, we apprehend, will not differ very widely from those of similar gatherings hitherto. Tile programme indicates the same topics of discusion : the same chimerical objects

The pleasant and portly town of Newburg was yesterday thrown into a comfortable state of excitement by the trial trip of the first steamboat ever built at her docks. It was a handsome Propeller, furnished with engines upon a new principle, and intended to carry freight. She will run regularly from New-York to Albany.

A Pronouncing Dictionary of the Spanish and English Languages, based on the Dictionaries of Neuman and Burelli, and Seoane; with extensive Additions and Improvements; by MARINO VELZSQUEZ DE LA CADENA.--New-York: D. APPLETON Co. A work of careful industry, research, and of great practical use.

THE MILLINERY CASE CONTINUED.--THIRD DAY OF THE TRAIL OF THOMAS W. BOVD, CHARGED WITH AN ASSAULT AND BATTERY ON A MILLINERY GIRL, NAMED ELLEN SANDISON.--This case still creates an immense excitement with the public. The court-room and passage way leading from the street being crowded; with anxious spectators throughout each session of the Court.

The Legislative Excursion over the New-York Central Railroad is provocative of revery. We seem to see the country as it was before the days of railroads--before the whistle of the alarm-pipe ever rung through these woods--even before the canal was used for rapid traveling.

The dates are to the 11th of April. The American, French, and English ships-of-war on the Coast of China, have, on the urgent request of the Emperor, and a requisition from the Chinese authorities, consented to guard Nankin, Shanghae, and the mouth of the great Canal, against the rebels. The Times says:--"
Owing to the suspension of telegraphic intercourse night before last, and its continued interruption through yesterday, we are only enabled to continue the particulars this morning.

ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--The Express train on this road, which left Albany Monday evening at 7 3/4, "stopping only at Hudson, Poughkeepsie, and Peekskill," made one stop which was not down in the bill.

The regular monthly meeting of the Society was held last evening at its rooms in the University, Washington-square. Rev. Dr. DE WITT presided, assisted by FRED, DE PEYSTER, Esq. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

The Memphis Eagle and Examiner learns from a gentleman direct from Galveston, that the wonderful stories of gold discoveries in Texas are unmitigated humbugs, got up by land-owners to enhance the value of their property. The account adds:...

Many Nationals of determination, from New-York and elsewhere, are here to exert their influence to prevent the appointment of DIX to the French Mission. They say the Free Soilers have received much the larger proportion of appointments, and the services and sacrifices of Hunkers should not be disregarded.

The excursion train set off from Albany precisely at 6 o'clock. There was a pretty general representation from the Assembly, but Senators were rather scarce. Very happily for us, the sun did not come out until the journey had been accomplished. There was no dust to complain of, and no unpleasant heat.

Yesterday morning, as two men named W. VAN TASSEL and J. G. SEGER, from Westchester County, who had been purchasing horses in this section, were passing through the woods in the southern part of this county, they were attacked by two highwaymen, and SEGAR was shot and instantly killed, whereupon his companion fled.

We have had the most cool and delightful Spring that I have known since my sojourn in this city, a period of over ten years. Summer has now fairly set in, bringing with it its delicious fruits. Just think of sitting down to a breakfast of figs and milk! Your figs are nicely peeled for you, in a large silver bowl, and covered with ice;

Arrived from New-York--17th, Stella, at Cadiz; Rasled, Deal; 19th. George, Utard; 23d, Liebenitz, Plymonth; sheridan, Liverpool; Charles James, Deal, 21st, Agnes Schilling, Seilly; 28th, Victoria, Gravesend; John Clements, Deal.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Miss JULIA DEAN continues to be the ascendant star at this establishment, and attracts good houses. Last night the very intense tragedy of "Fazio" was performed. The passionate jealousy of the Italian wife was well rendered by Miss DEAN.

Such meagre accounts as we obtain by telegraph, leave the Turkish difficulty in an extremely bad way. The Russian Envoy, whose unutterable name has become familiar to the eyes, if not to the tongues of our readers, has waited to the end of his patience for a reply to his ultimatum, and finally withdrawn to the deck of a war steamer.

BENJAMIN LOBER, Esq., the well-known head of the Erie Railroad Company, has resigned his trust into the hands of the Board of Directors, owing to continued weak health. His Physical well being, which, since his carliest connection with the Road, and while it was of extremely doubtful success, and surrounded by innumerable difficulties and embarrassments, to the present time, he has never stopped to consult, now absolutely demands relaxation.

Hon. DANIEL M. BARRINGER, our Minister in Spain, left Madrid, on the 11th of May, with his wife and family, for the purpose of making a short journey into Andalusia, previous to his retirement from the Spanish peninsula. After visiting Cordova, Sevilla, and Cadiz, he is to return to Madrid, where he will remain until the arrival of Mr. SOULE, who is expected to reach there in the month of July.

SIXTH DAY. U.S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The U.S. vs. Daniel Maloney.--The Jurors were in their seats at the usual hour this morning, and, having answered to their names, the Court called upon the Counsel to proceed. There were persons enough in attendance to fill the room twise over, but the U.S. Marshal allowed no more in the room that could be seated.

The popular Verdict has been rendered. The Amended Charter is overwhelmingly adopted. The City of New-York has vindicated its honor. The taint of corruption brought upon its good name has been removed by the action of the People at the ballot box. A noble day's work, was yesterday's.

As we anticipated, the result of the Election yesterday has been most triumphant. Our citizens have nobly done their duty, and the corruption of the Common Council, which made our City a by-word and a reproach, we would fain hope, is among the things which were.

The bill authorizing the appointment of thirty-five Notaries Public, in addition to the present number, was passed. The bill to alter the Commissioner's Map of Brooklyn was passed. The Senate concurred with the amendments of the Assembly to the Rome and Watertown Railroad Bill. The Oswego School Bill was ordered to a third reading.

Trade at San Francisco continued in a depressed state, and the transactions in general merchandize were very light. There had, however, been considerable transactions in flour, but at prices more favorable to purchasers.

A second edition of the Times has a telegraphic dispatch dated Vienna, the evening of the 26th, stating that MENSCHIKOFF and suite have left Constantinople, and that Russian subjects are placed under the protection of the Danish Ambassador. The French fleet is said to have received permission to pass the Dardanelles.

In the case of JANE TRAINER, the little colored girl, a warrant was issued, based upon an affidavit and a habeas corpus, by Justice HARCULO, of the Supreme Court, yesterday, to bring the child before him, at the Kings County Circuit. A difficulty interposed, owing to the officers of Kings County being reluctant to execute the warrant upon the New-York side.

After the Legislative Excursion to Niagara it will take more than one day to get down to the dry and dusty business of legislation. Both Houses met last evening pursuant to adjournment, but the attendance was slim and no business was done.

In this City, on Tuesday morning, of consumption, N. C. PALMER, aged 35 years, 5 months and 27 days. His friends and the friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, on Thursday afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock, at the residence of his mother-in-law, Mrs. E. Simonton, No. 85 Varick St.

THROUGH the black night blows the wind, Whistling, shricking round and round, And the dark stream, undefined, Gurgles with a stormy sound, Oh! the rain is thick and cold! Oh! the wind is sharp and chill! At the door stands young Gebhold Knocking at the silent mill.

ANOTHER DEMOCRATIC NEWSPAPER IN WASHINGTON.--A correspondent in the Baltitimore Sun confirms a "confidential" rumor which has prevailed here, that another Democratic paper is to be established in this city, under the editorial direction of N. BEVERLY TUCKER, Esq.

There is some spice in the Country Newspapers now-a-days. In fact, they have become readable, and that is saying a great deal. The ruins of the Owego (N. Y.) Advertiser have given birth to a sprightly hebdomadal, under the title of the Southern Tier Times, published by POWELL BARNES, whose van editorial partakes of an independency of thought that is quite refreshing.
The Boston Atlas says that $6,000 and upwards has already been subscribed in this city for the establishment of a National Democratic paper of the straightest seat.

The Peter Funks have not yet made their exodus. It takes something more than an act of the Legislature to frighten them from their impropriety. Imbued with the faculty of resistance, they seen determined to stand their ground until actually cleared off by a sweeping measure of justice.

We perform a sad duty this morning, in announcing the loss of one of our late associates, Mr. N. C. PALMER. Death could scarcely select from among the members of the Press in this City, one whose loss will be more sincerely mourned, or memory more tenderly cherished, by those with whom he has been professionally associated.

We have received Rio Janciro dates to the 25th April. The U. S. steamer Water Witch arrived there-on the 23d, on route for Rio Plate. The U. S. sloop-of-war Vandalia sailed from Rio on the 23d April for Macao. The U.S. ship Congress remained at Montevideo and the Jamestown at Buenos Avres-all well.

RIOT.--SEVERAL PERSONS INJURED.--About 10 o'clock on Tuesday evening, a most disgraceful row occurred in South Sixth-street, near Eighth, in which the porter-house kept by Philip McLaughlin was attacked with stones and greatly damaged. Mrs. and Mr. McLaughlia, a son and a daughter, who were in the house at the time, were also greatly injured from the same cause.

A letter from on board the United States ship Macedonian, dated at Madeira, May 1, says that the old ship, which many thought would not sail, has made a shorter passage than either the steamer Mississippi or the Powhattan. It seems that the alterations effected previous to her leaving New-York, makes her one of the fastest ships now in the navy.

SANDFORD'S PANORAMA OF THE MISSISSIPPI.--We did ourselves the pleasure of witnessing this new panorama last evening. It is by far the best we have seen. The artist has doviated in many particulars from the old beaten track.

Some six weeks since, a large quantity of cord wood, belonging to the Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana Railroad Company, at South Bend, Ind., took fire from the sparks of a locomotive. The citizens, and especially the ladies of that village, rallied, and saved the depot buildings from destruction, not with standing a strong wind was blowing at the time.
Petitions were presented for a division of the Nineteenth Ward, New-York; and in favor of JONES' Wood Park. BILLS PASSED. Amending the Charter of Brooklyn, in relation to the collection of taxes.

On Wednesday, June 8, in this City of consumption, CHARLOTTE STILWELL, aged 23 years. Her remains will be taken to Hempstead, L. L, for interment. At Newburg, on Monday, June 6, SAHAM JANE BRINKERHOFF, wife of Jacob V. B. Fowler.

Seattered over Palestine are spots consecrated in the traditions of piety as once especially hallowed by the presence of our Saviour. They are marked, some of them from apostolic times, others from the days of the good Empress HELENA, and others from the later days of the Crusaders, with churches and monasteries, where devotion has preserved its offices, and observed the rites of Christianity among perverse generations of infidels and Turks.

We have seen a letter from an officer on board the U. S. ship Plymouth, dated Hong Kong, March 24. He says that the almost universal topic was the rebellion. The rebel army was much larger than the regular army, and the head or chief represents himself as a descendant, of a former Emperor.

The motion in arrest of judgment in the gambling case against Joseph Smith, in Cincinnati, was fully heard on Saturday, before Judge Spooner, and overruled. A long bill of exceptions was then presented in behalf of the defendant, which after being variously amended, was finally sealed.

The stockholders of the Rutland and Burlington Railroad Corporation held their annual meeting at Bellows' Falls this morning. The report shows that the earnings of the Road, for the year ending May 31, have been $495,397 45; expenditures $228,858 33; net income over expenses $266,539 12--a gain of 60 per cent. over last year.

The records of the sea are fast becoming the moat painful portions of our daily intolligence. Hardships and cruelty seem to go hand in hand, and the Packet service constantly furnishes now causes of complaint. The reports of our Courts teem with statements

SEVENTH DAY. U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The U. S. vs. Daniel Maloney.--The Court room and the purlieus thereof were again crowded with the friends of Capt. MALONEY and others connected with the shipping interest. The trail appears likely to occupy all of this week. At 10 1/2 o'clock the Court called on the Counsel to proceed.

The steamship El Dorado, Capt. DAVENPORT, arrived here Wednesday, A. M., bringing the United States Mail, passengers, and treasure of steamer Panama, which left San Francisco on the 7th ult. Purser ROGERS furnishes the following memoranda: The El Dorado left Aspinwall the evening of the 28th, and Kingston the 1st June. She brings 230 passengers, and $692,792 treasure on freight.

Certain letters from Matanzas, describing the landing of 1,100 slaves at the Cayo Piedras, in Cuba, were published in the DAILY TIMES, of April 23. The peculiar Atrocity of the transaction led to the reproduction of the correspondence in the London papers; and it will be observed by extracts in another column, that the agitation of the case, has introduced it as a topic of remark into the British House of Lords.

THE TRAINER CASE--SUPREME COURT (KINGS COUNTY--Special Term--Before Hon, Judge BARCULO--June 8. This case was again before the Court to-day. Deputy Sheriff CROMBEY and Miss COOPER were brought in upon the attachments issued yesterday, but were discharged--the latter absolutely, and the former on his own recognizances to appear again tomorrow (this day.)

Since our last issue, ARTHUR SPRING has been induced to make a statement declaring his belief in the innocence of his son of the Federal-street murder. The declaration is as follows: MOYAMENSING PRISON, June 7, 1853.

The schooner Bonita, at this port, brings dates from the City of Mexico to the 24th May. Over 40 newspapers had been suppressed since the recent decree. SANTA ANNA being offended at officers smoking in the Theatre, had issued a decree suppressing the nuisance.

Padre GAVAZZI has got into trouble in our neighborhood of Canada. At Quebec, the day before yesterday, a mob, tantalized by his allusions to the influence of Ribbonism in the introduction of the Inquisition into Ireland, set vigorously upon the illustrious Italian, and gave him a profound drubbing.

Who is it that, turning back to the novelreading of his youth, does not recall the ideas then associated in his mind with the words " Spaniard," and " Italian 1" Those fine, onsanguined, absurd romances, so full of crime and secret stair-cases ; so brimming with intrigue and assassination; where princes and poisoned cups played so prominent a part, attached a terrible signification to the very name of a Continontal.

Majors HOARE and BLAKE, and Lieutenants ROBINSON, ALLEN and EVANS, with some other officers and privates, arrived at Fort Leavenworth, on the 25th inst., from Santa Fe. I have seen and conversed with an intelligent gentleman, who has only arrived in this City from the Fort this morning, and who conversed freely with those officers.

The absolute right of every man to breathe smoke instead of air, cannot be denied in all cases where the effects are confined to him self alone. If he chooses to say that the Almighty has not provided him with the proper element of respiration--has not compounded

A protracted Cabinet meeting took place today. SAMUEL B. GARVIN has been appointed District Attorney for the Northern District of New-York, vice SKINNER, resigned. The prospects of the selection of DIX as Minister to France are brightening.

The Synod assembled at 9 o'clock, yesterday morning, and after the usual preliminary business, the Committee on Correspondence made a report upon the state of the Church, which it stated is in a prosperous condition, with the houses of worship well attended, and the Theological Seminaries well supported and filled with students.

This has been a broken week,--for which, were it needful, various reasons might be assigned, all resolving themselves, however, into the great fact that it is the "Derby week." People living at a distance, and particularly in another land, can scarcely comprehend the significance of this phrase.

The Cabinet has had lengthy sittings daily since Monday--engaged, as is supposed, chiefly upon the Mesilla Valley question. LUKE DODGE has to-day been appointed Postmaster of Scheneetady, and SAMUEL DE WOLF, Postmaster of Bridgewater, N. Y.

The Secretary of the Atlantic and Pacific Junction Company, in London, has transmitted to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs of the Republic of New-Grenade, the formal guarantee of competent parties--capitalists in the city of London--for the payment of [pound] 4,000, being the amount of caution-money required by the Republic in terms of a concession made to Dr. FLORENTING GONZALES, of Bogota, bearing date 12th of Aug. last.

THE WILLIAMSBURG CASE CONTINUED.--Fourth Day--This case was resumed at 7 o'clock last evening. The Court Room was crowded with persons anxious to hear the examination of the case. Miss Mary Eldridge, recalled, and cross examination resumed by J. Deane, Esq, counsel for the prosecution. I heard the girls say "cheats and robbers,"

Mr. CHARLES B. NORTON, of the Irving House Book Store, has made such an arrangement with British periodical publishers, as to furnish the leading foreign Reviews and Magazines at extremely reduced prices. This list includes the Gentleman's Magazine, Frazer's Magazine,

Judge HALL, yesterday, in the U. S. District Court, decided a case of much interest. In a recent suit growing out of a collision between the steamer America and the propeller Oswego, by which the latter was sunk, it was decreed that $10,000 be paid by the owners of the America to the owners of the Oswego.

The Convention met again at the appointed hour this morning. The Committee of two from the several States on resolutions retired. Judge MOORE, of Arkansas, offered a resolution relative to the construction of a Railroad from the Mississippi to the Pacific,

Father GAVAZZI delivered his second lecture here last night at the Free Church. In the course of his remarks happening to say that the Inquisition was extended to Ireland by the agency of Ribbonism, a man in the body of the church exclaimed, "That's a lie."

BROOKLYN BOARD OF EDUCATION.--The regular monthly meeting of this body was held yesterday afternoon, at the City Hall--C. P. SMITH, Esq., President in chair. The following preamble and resolution was offered by Mr. Harris, and unanimously adopted by the Board:

Sir RICHARD BUCKLEY COMYN, an author, and formerly Chief Justice of the Indian Supreme Court, died recently in England. He was born in 1791; in 1825 was appointed Puisne Judge of the Supreme Court at Madras, and became Chief Justice in 1835.

The mails of the Canada reached this City last evening, from Boston. We add to the intelligence already given by telegraph, copious extracts from the London journals, touching Turkish, Chines, and Cuban affairs. In the House of Lords on Friday evening, the Earl of MALMESBURY gave a brief sketch

The U.S. Mail Steamship Washington, Capt. FITCH, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings dates from Bremen to the 20th, Havre the 24th, and Southampton and London, the 25th ult. inclusive. Her intelligence has been anticipated by the telegraphic dispatches from the Canada, at Halifax.

From the St. Louis Intelligencer. The reputation of these Pueblo Indians among the best judging Americans who have visited New-Mexico, is excellent. For industry, sobriety and chastity--for hospitality, kindness of disposition and mildness of manners--in short, for all the social and domestic virtues, they have the good word of all who know them.

Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Ingomar--Little Toddlekins WALLACK'S THEATRE.--As You Like It-Teddy the Tiler. BURTON'S THEATRE.-Sweet hearts and Wives--Toodles. ST. CHARLES THEATRE.--Captain Charlotte--Dead Shot--The Young Widow. AARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--St. Mary's Eve.

We are pained, says the Albany Argus of Tuesday, to be called to announce the death of CHAS. BRYAN, well known in and out of the city, for his unpretending and genuine worth, industry and usefulness, and as widely esteemed for his many generous and estimable qualities.

The whale ship Julius Casar, at New-London, brings dates from Cape Town to April to. We have received files of the Cape Town papers, from which we compile the following: A miner, just returned from Australia, expresses the opinion that gold exists in South Africa.

If the Legislative Assembly were a permanent body, the present week would probably be the last of its existence. But as it only has ten days to remain, the Emperor may easily overlook the symptoms of opposition it has lately manifested. These symptoms are serious, and have given rise to numerous commentaries.

The Halifax Sun contains a variety of documents relative to the Fishery movements in the Colonies. On Friday, May 27, Hon. WILLIAM YOUNG Speaker of the Nova Scotia Assembly, attended by the officers of the House, waited on the Vice-Admiral, Sir GEORGE SEYMOUR, to present a resolution of thanks to that gentleman for his efficient measures for the procution of the Fisheries.

A Pennsylvania paper says there assembled last week, in Chester County, at the Old Kennettsquare Meeting House pursuant to a call extensively published, a religious Convention, when a new Yearly Meeting was organized, called "The Pennsylvania Yearly Meeting of Progressive Friends."

THE TRAINER CASE.--This case was resumed yesterday morning before Justice BARCULO, in the Supreme Court, Special Term. CHARLES TRAINER, the father, was again called upon the witness-stand, but nothing new was elicited. Mr. BRADY went into a long argument, urging that the Court had no jurisdiction, and if it had there was nothing shown why the child JANE TRAINER should be taken from the custody of ROSE COOPER.

The U. S. frigate Columbia still remains at Pensacola. David Hunt, an extensive planter in Mississippi, has sent a donation of $5,000 to the American Colonization Society, which is in addition to the $1,000 which he has sent the Society yearly for the last ten years.

SUB-MARINE OPERATIONS.--A Boston Company have provided themselves with sub-matine apparatus for the purpose of exploring the weeks of sunken vessels and recovering property lost with them. The wreck of the Forest Queen packet ship, which was lost on Mad Cliff, in Seituate, in February last, has recently been successfully explored by the Company in question.

The polished and cultivated society of Havana have now a congenial amusement established for them, without the trouble of crossing the ferry to the village of Regla. "Bull-baiting" is to be the ton, alternating with the opera, for the coming season.

WEDNESDAY....MORNING SESSION. Prayer, Reading of minutes. The President announced the following named gentlemen as members of the Committee to take into consideration the modification of the Liturgy of the Church:

From the Independent. We perceive a passage of arms between the Syracuse Daily Chronicle and several of its co-temporaries, as to the propriety of Mrs. STOWE'S purchasing a homestead with the profits of her work, instead of employing her money upon the slave--they railing at, and the Chronicle defending, the lady.

The Memphis Convention adjourned yesterday, sine die. The closing proceedings of the session were chiefly important in regard to the Pacific Railroad. The Convention took strong ground in favor of the Mississippi project, and adopted a series of resolutions directingg the attention of the Government and the necessity of the work.

The London Times has taken to writing up Ireland; and the Ministry are sending the Queen over,--as soon as they have got the Income Tax saddled on the country, and a few other small matters adjusted, such as the Administration of India, and the settlement of Turkey,--to crown our Exhibition.

To fly from the active scenes of the Capitol, where personal and party strife mingle in all forms of contention, and avarice and ambition are toiling along in their restless career, to the fearful shades where final repose is found alike by the great and the humble, is suggestive of reflections which should bear fruit in the mind and in the life of every one.

The revelations regarding the new Treasury fraud, alluded to in my dispatch of yesterday, have produced quite a sensation here. The five thousand dollars said to have been recovered, have not been received at the Treasury Department. The transfer draft of WILLIAM MINOR was given upwards of two years ago. Secretary CORWIN employed THOMAS EWING and ROBERT CORWIN as counsel, but they failed to accomplish anything satisfactory.

Several remonstrances were presented against the Jone's Wood Park. A bill was reported, to allow the Buffalo and Pittsburgh Railroad Company to terminate their road at the Northern line of Pennsylvania. Mr. BENNETT called up the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Bill. The question pending, being on an amendment subjecting the Company to the provision of the Revised Statues--was rejected.

What, not avail myself of this capital opportunity for a bargain, just because tile money is not in my pocket There are a great many snug fortunes made by buying on time. But our mercantile friends who draw most largely on their credit, will agree with us in advising a young man to "pay as he goes."

The establishment of a weekly, in lien of the semi-monthly arrangement of California mail steamers by the Panama route, is already dividing the gold shipments from San Francisco, although it will require some months to accustom the trade on the Pacific to this mode of making remittances.

The Committee on Resolutions reported on the following subjects, namely: Direct trade with Europe-The Pacific Railroad-Teliuantepec route-Manufactures-Education-Steamers from Southern ports-Diplomacy-The Cotton trade-An Address to Congress on trade to the Oronoco, Amazon and La Plata Rivers,

A lecture was delivered in this city by Father GAVAZZI, this evening. A mob collected in such numbers that the police force stationed near the church required the aid of the military. After the meeting pistols were fired by the crowd, where-upon the military fired one round.

The steamer Prometheus, Capt. CHURCHILL, arrived yesterday morning from San Juan del Norte, having left that port on the evening of May 31. She brings 423 passengers and $310,000 in specie. To the purser, R. LORD, Esq., and to the Express Co.'s of BERFORD Co. and ADAMS Co., we are indebted for the prompt delivery of papers and letters.

Chief Justice SHAW, of Massachusetts, who for nearly a quarter of a century has filled his present office of Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, is about to depart for England, and intends to be absent three or four months.

For the year ending March 31, 1853, the number of intentions of marriages issued at the Registrar's office in Boston, has been 3,006, a larger number than for any previous year. It is a noticeable fact on the record book that more old bachelors than usual have lately entered into the bonds of matrimony, that is to say, that more first marriages of males and females of thirty years and upwards have taken place.

Com. E. W. Moore, late of the Texas Navy, has written an able letter to Senator Pearce, of Maryland, in relation to the debate in the Senate, when the bill was up to incorporate the surviving officers of the Texas Navy into the Navy of the United States. It is a complete defence of himself.

MORALS IN BRITISH GUIANA.--A late Demarara paper tells the following tales of crime in that locality: "The records of criminal sessions show an amount of crime unheard of in the history of the Colony; for, save the butcheries under martial law, it has never been known in that country that five persons forfeited their lives in expiation of violations of the law, of a character so heinous as to preclude the hope of mercy.
DISPENSARY REPORT.--At a regular of the Trustees of the Williamsburgh Dispensary, held last evening, the following report was submitted by H. P. HARDCASTLY, the spothecary for the month of May, 1853:

The telegraph for the past two days has been unpleasantly employed in brining us details of riots at Quebec and Montreal. M GAVAZZI has act with less sympathetic auditories in Canada than in New-York. At Quebec on Tuesday evening, and at Montreal last evening, the popular indignation ran so high against him, as to lead to disorder and blood-shed, and basten his departure from both those places with unseemly precipitation.

THE CASE OF THE MILLINERS--CONCLUSION OF THE TESTIMONY.--The testimony and summing up in the milliners case, which has created so much public excitement for several days, was concluded last evening. Miss SANDISON, the complainant, and a large number of male and female friends from New-York, were present to hear the conclusion and refute any testimony which might be offered by the defence, derogatory to her character and position in society.

There seems to be on foot an unusual gathering of various Indian tribes west of the Mississippi. The Fort Smith Herald says: "We learn from a gentleman just in from the Indian country, that the Grand Council of all the Indian tribes will be held about fifty miles west of CHOUTEAU'S

U.S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The Case of the Ship Roscius.--The U. S. vs. Daniel Maloney.--The Court room was full at an early hour, and the Judge directed officers to exclude those who had no business in the room. The Jurors having answered to their names, the Chief Justice called on Mr. FULLERTON to proceed.

Mr. E. C. DELAVAN writes, dating June 4, at Ballston Centre, a letter to the State Register, in which he reviews the history of the Temperance Reformation in this State, and expresses his opinion of the Maine law. From the beginning and the end we extract as follows:

The lands in the north part of the State of New Hampshire, (24,000 acres,) known as the "Second College Grant," are rising in value from their vicinity to the Atlantic and St. Lawrence Railroad, now leased as to the part lying in the United States, to the British Government, by a perpetual lease at 6 per cent.

The work of the German Philosopher GERVINUS, entitled an "Introduction to the History of the Nineteenth Century," which has drawn down unmiligated persecution upon the head of its author, contains the following allusion to the principles avowed and sustained by ROGER WILLIAMS, the founder of Rhode Island. The author is speaking of the doctrines of the Reformation and their legitimate results:

It was the intention, we believe, of the Hon. JAMES BUCHANAN, the newly appointed Minister to the Court of London, to sail for Europe tomorrow in the COLLINS steamer Atlantic, but subsequent arrangements were made for the Arctic, of the same line, sailing for this port on Saturday, 25th inst. He will be accompanied by Hon Mr. APPLETON, of Maine, the Secretary to the Legation.

The Legislative Committee on Railroad Accidents reported a bill to-day, to prevent injuries and the destruction of life upon Railroads, of which the following is a synopsis. SECTION I. provides that all passenger trains shall be brought to a full stop before passing any draw-bridge, or the point of intersection and crossing of any other Road.

ANOTHER CANAL PROJECT ON THE ISTHMUS.--Some gentlemen in this city have lately become interested in a project for a canal across the Isthmus of Darien, or more properly the northern part of New-Grenada, and one of them will shortly leave in the professional capacity of geologist, to explore the lands owned by the Company, as mines of coal and valuable metals are supposed to be located on them.

The Special Committee appointed by the Legislature of Connecticut on the subject of Railroad Accidents, has reported a bill of which a full abstract is given in our columns this morning. Its provisions are very stringent.

Few have an idea that a Revolution is now in progress in Asia, which, in the number of forces engaged and the gigantic results aimed at, is equal in importance to the greatest European wars of this century. The Revolutionary army have marched from the mountainous country behind Canton, following the line of the coast in a north easterly direction, some twelve hundred miles, to the neighborhood of Nankin.

On Wednesday, June 8, in Providence, R. I., by Rev. S. W. Field, H. R. BURNET, of New York, to ANN H. B. DENNETT, of Hellowell, Me. In this City, on Thursday, June 9, by Rev. Dr. Hawkes, ALEXANDER SEWARD of Utica, to CORNELIA L. daughter of Charles P. Kirkland.
The chair factory of Messrs. ATWOOD HUTCHINS, at Winchester, N. H., together with ALEXANDER GARNSEY'S grist mill, also, the adjoining property, were consumed by fire yesterday.

From the Courier and Inquirer. Within the field of our research, during a period of fifteen months, commencing with January, 1852, and ending with March, 1853, (four hundred and fifty-five consecutive days,) we have recorded earthquakes that have been active on the hundred and seventeen of these days, on each of which the place and places where the earthquakes were felt, are particularly stated, and the day of the month also.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--A most excellent domestic drama called the " Bello of the Faubourg" was produced here last evening. It is we believe a London piece, originally produced under the name of "Madeline" As a picture of the miseries produced by intemperance and dissipation, the "Bello of the Faubourg" may rank with the most effective melodramas on the stage.

The murderer, SPRING, paid the penalty of his crimes yesterday, at Philadelphia, by the forfeit of his wretched life. He died, as the reports say, bravely, and protesting his innocence--which means, that he left the world, the same hardened, unredeembale scoundred that he had too long existed in it.

The New Orleans mail, bringing papers and letters to Saturday last, being as late as due, came through this morning. HVATT McNEILL, a son of Gen. McNEILL, was killed at New-Orleans on the 3d inst., by being accidentally struck by the shaft of a railroad car.

A Railroad Congress is now in session here to discuss the general interests of the railroads of this State, in connection with those East and West. The lines represented are the New-York Central, New-York and Erie, Boston and Albany, Canandaigua and Elmira, Canandaigua and Niagara Falls, Buffalo and New-York State Line, Cleveland, Columbus, and Cincinnati, Sundusky and Mansfield, Mad River and Lake Erie, Michigan Central, Michigan Southern.

Prayer. Reading of minutes. The Synod took up the appeal of Rev. JOHN S. EBAUGH from the decision of the Particular Synod of New York. Numerous charges were made against Mr. EBAUGH to the Classis of New York.
BILLS PASSED. To authorise the Buffalo and Pittsburg Railroad to terminate at the Western line of Pennsylvania. To facilitate the acquisition of a new Reservoir in New-York.

The Tent-preaching enterprise goes on bravely. It has already been announced that the Alliance has removed its Tent from the vicinity of the Crystal Palace to the corner of Eighth-avenue and Thirteenth-street.
