The services to-morrow will be conducted in the afternoon by Rev. Dr. POTTS. In the morning, Rev. Mr. STINER will officiate. Sabbath-school observances will take place at 9 A. M. The work is succeeding beyond all expectation.

For the other City News of this morning, see Sixth Page Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns BROADWAY THEATRE.--Fazio-Double Bedded Room. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--As You Like It--Teldy the Tiler.

HENRY BAKER, of Catskill, N. Y., for Improvement in converting rotary into reciprocating motion. Dated June 7, 1853. THOMAS A. DUGDALE, of Richmond, Ind., for Improvement in Washing Machines. Dated June 7, 1853. HENRY W. HEWET, of New-York, N. Y., for Improvement in Propellers. Dated June 7, 1853.

LIBERALITY TO COLONIZATION.--Mr. DAVID HUNT, a wealthy planter of Mississippi, sent a few days ago, five thousand dollars to Rev. WM. McLAIN, Secretary and Treasurer of the American Colonization Society. The same gentleman gave to the same Society, in April last, five hundred dollars, and he has contributed five hundred or one thousand dollars annually, for the last ten or twelve years.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You may not be inclined to repeat your inquiry why sailors are searce, and why the navy ships remain in port in consequence of the want of hands, when you read attentively the trial of the captain of the ship Roscius; but you may feel a little surprised, when you refer to similar occurrences, that the guilty are seldom punished.

There was quite a scene at the Bois de Boulogne on Sunday. The press of carriages and the throng of promenadors was large, spite of the racos at Chantilly, which had drawn off nearly all that portion of the habitues who ride on horseback, or drive themselves in light wagons.

The Cabinet was in session to-day. M. W. IRWIS, (BENTON,) late Editor of the St. Louis Democrat, is appointed Marshall for Minnesota. MEADE has declined his diplomatic berth. The demonstrations against DIX by the "Nationals" still continue.

By the arrival of the British schooner Witch, Capt. HUTCHINS, at this port, seven days from Bermuda, we have received files to June 1. The Colonial Legislature met at Hamilton on the 28th ult., the Acting-Governor, Colonel PHILPOTS, delivering the usual address, in the course of which the Representatives are congratulated upon the general exemption of the Islands from the epidemics which have recently devastated some of the British possessions in the West Indies.
DEAR SIR: I remember of hearing, years ago, a legal gentleman endeavor to set forth, to a friend of his, in my presence, the character, scope and purpose of Sir THOMAS MORE'S Utopia.

The affair at Montreal has proved much more serious than the first accounts indicated. Several lives have been lost, not of the rioters, nor of persons present for vicious motives or idle curiosity, but of citizens of the highest repute and children incapable of criminal design. The event is deplorable. There is reason to fear that the action of the authorities has been hasty and ill-directed.

Judge Van Buren, of Kingston, Ulster Co., has recently opened a quarry of grey limestone, at that place, which is said to possess rare merits for building purposes. It is of the same species of stone substantially as that used for the construction of the eastern section of the Eric Canal. It presents a fine grey color; it is durable, and grows fairer to the sight every year.

WATERING PLACES.--LAKE GEORGE.-- A hand some and commodions house of entertainment--the " United States Hotel." has been opened at the head of Lake George, designed for the accommodation of pleasure-seekers during the Summer months.

There are two simultaneous movements with regard to the observance of the Sabbath which may pass as indices of American religious and irreligious sentiment. A number of petitions have been presented at the Post-Office Department craving the discontinuance of the Sunday mails.

Brevet Major-General BENNET RILEY, U.S.A., died at Buffalo on Thursday evening, at the advanced age of 66 years. Gen. RILEY has filled a prominent niche in the history of the Military heroes of the country. Born in 1790, in St. Mary's County, Md., he entered the Army at an early ago.

FROM NEW-BRUNSWICK.--By way of Boston, we have St. John and Fredericton papers, to the 7th inst. Mr. A. G. MORTON, Civil Engineer, with five Assistants from the United States, arrived at St. John on Saturday, for the purpose of surveying and locating the Railroad west from St. John to the Maine line. He has a party already engaged on the line east from Bangor.

In yesterday's Times, we gave from the Deseret News, the __ General Epistle of the Latter Day Sa__. We give below Governor YOUNO'S proclanition with reference to the hordes of Mexicans and __ who are hovering around the Mormon borders, and committing numberless aggressions upon their property. Our present receipts are to the last of April. The weather was mild, the peaches in full bloom, though snow lay inches deep in the gardens.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your able article in the TIMES of June 9, on the wretched condition of the much-neglected emigrant when on his voyage hither, suggests an idea of my own, which had laid dormant until aroused by perusing the peculiar evidence given on a recent murder trial in one of the courts of this City.

The stockholders of the Atlantic and St. Lawrence Railroad met in this city to day, to determine whether they would anthorise the Directors to lease the road to the Grand Trunk Railway Company. The meeting was very fully attended, and great unanimity prevailed throughout the proceedings.

These are the topics of an article in the Valparaiso Mercurio, for April 19. Gen. O'BRIEN, a native of Ireland, resided for many years in South America, and was the illustrious comrade of SAN MARTIN in the battles of Chacabuco and Maipio. In 1828, he returned again from his native land to Brazil, with Mr. ED. CRAWFORD, the miner, in his company.

Mr. BROWN of New-York, author of Sylva Americana, , has been appointed Collector of Agricultural Statistics at the Patent Office. TEMPLE CLARK, has been appointed local Agent for the improvement of the harbor of Manitowoc, Wisconsin, vice CHARLES, son of Governor DOTY, removed.

Capt. ERICSSON contributes to the June number of APPLETON'S Mechanics' Magazine a labored mathematical demonstration of the principles involved in the Caloric Engine. It is in reply to strictures published in a former number of that work by Major BARNARD. We believe this is the first attempt which Capt. ERICSSON has publicly made to refute the objections raised against his invention.

The Murder on the High Seas. NINTH DAY. U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The Case of the Ship Roscius.--The U. S. vs Daniel Maloney.--Yesterday morning the Court room was crowded to excess with the friends of the prisoner, and other parties interested in the result, anxious to hear the summing up of counsel. The audience included many ladies, ship owners, and members of the Bar.

GENERAL REMARKS.-- This fruit is generally thought to have original in Persia, where it is in digenous, and grows very abundantly. It is found at elevations of six thousand feet, in the regions of the Himalayas, flourishing in its wild state. From Persia it was carried to Rome, during the reign of CLAUDIUS, and is mentioned by PLINY.

A fire broke out last night in the liquor store of GUIRAND STARRAN, on Main-street, between Columbia and Front, and spread to the adjoining liquor store of R. A. LITTLE Co., the groeery of McCULLOUGH, MORRIS Co., and the iron store of NEAVE FREE--all of which were greatly damaged.

The Fifteenth Anniversary of the City Bible Society was held last evening, in the Oliver-street Baptist Church (Dr. Magoon's). The attendance was numerous. The President of the Society, WARREN CARTER, Esq., occupied the chair, assisted by Rev. J. A. STEWARD, of the Sailors' Bethel, one of the Vice-Presidents.

A letter received in this city, dated Payta, May 14, brings intelligence that a French steamer of-war had just arrived with information that the was between the French Admiral and Ecuador had been brought to a close under the dictation of the former.

FOURTH OF JULY PARADE.--The Fifth Brigade New-York State Militia, consisting of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth, and Seventieth Regiments, the whole under command of General DURYEA, will parade through the principal streets of Williamsburg and Brooklyn, on the Fourth of July next, forming on the corner of Ewen-street and Division-avenue, at 5 o'clock A. M.

The Montreal Herald of this morning contains the following particulars of the riot and melancholy loss of life at Father GAVAZZI'S Anti Catholic Lecture at Zion's Church, last evening: As advertised, Signor GAVAZZI met a numerous audience in Zion's Church at 6 1/2 o'clock P. M. yesterday.

The amended Charter is the law of the land. No higher sanction to its future influence could be given, short of entire unanimity, than the vote of Tuesday. The moral force thus imparted must be immense. The result cheers the very heart of hearts of all true men. It has nerved the press for fresh service, as it richly rewarded its past effort in the good cause of reform.

Home Life in Germany. By CHARLES LORING BRACE.--The author of this charming volume is already known to our readers by articles which have from time to time appeared in our columns over his initials (" C. L B.") While in Europe he de voted himself to a minute study of the social, domestic, religious and political characteristics of the people, especially of the different branches of the German race.

[BY OUR SPECIAL REPORTER] On the night of March 10, 1853, two unprotected females, named ELLEN LYNCH and HONORA SHAW, were assassinated at their residence No. 230 Federal-street, Philadelphia. The commission of the crime was traced to an Irish man, notorious for his bad character, named ARTHUR SPRING, who was subsequently tried, convicted, and sentenced to death.

The political circles here find some interest in discussing the recent movements of Mr. BURKE, in the New-Hampshire Democratic State Convention, to censure the President for repudiating the Union men in the distribution of his patronage. Albany is by prescription the head-quarters of political manacurving and combination, in the North--so regarded, at least, by the Democracy of this State--and much importance is attached to the impressions here established in reference to the next National campaign.

A writer in the London Times says: " Having noticed in the public journals a recent instance of death from sea-sickness, under very painful circumstances, I am induced to hope that the mention of a remedy which was entirely successful in a case which came under my own observation, may be useful to other sufferers from this distressing malady.

The Steamship Philadelphia, from Aspinwall, 3d inst. with passengers and the California mails of the 16th May, has arrived at this port. The Philadelphia connected at Aspinwall with the new steamer John L. Stevens, which left San Francisco on the 16th, with about two hundred and fifty passengers.
ANNUAL CRIMINAL REPORT.--GEO. C. CUTTER, Esq., Recorder, states in his annual report just made to the Common Council, that arrests were made during the past year, up to May, as follows:

The Rochester Democrat tells a pretty large story of a sleeper. He lives in Brockport, is son of a farmer in Clarkson, in Monroe County, and is named CORNELIUS BROOMER. He went to sleep June 19, 1848, but has been awake several times since. sky wakes him better than any.

MORMON ITEMS.--About eight hundred Mormons have left their camp ground at Keokuk, on their way to Salt Lake City. About three thousand in all have arrived there, and about eight hundred more are expected.

We have been favored with an early copy of the Report of his Highness, R. C. WYLLIE, the Hawaiian Foreign Secretary, to the Legislature of the Islands, on the 6th of April. At the conclusion of the document, we find the following reference to the relations of the insular Government with that of France. The state of the question, it will be perceived, is eminently satisfactory.

The Savannah Republican announces the death of Mr. WILLIAM DEARING, of that city, at the age of 68. Mr. DEARING was a prominent man in Upper Georgia some years ago, and was well known in Ahtens and Augusta, and also in Charleston. He was among the first, if not the first man in the State, to start a Cotton Factory.

We have been furnished with the particulars of a shocking affair that has occurred in West Troy, which ended in the death of one of the parties. It seems that a man named PAT'K. MANION, living in the alley between Ohio and Burlington-streets, in that village, on Wednesday last, had a quarrel with his wife.

The Earl of ELLESMERE and suite, and his distinguished colleagues of the British Commission to the Now-York Exhibition, could not have been favored by a more delightful season on their visit to the United States, than the present month of June.

THE SUPPLEMENTARY AMENDMENT TO THE NEW CHARTER.--The bill introduced by Mr. RUSSELL SMITH of the Assembly, and which has passed the Legislature, will relieve the Charter of some embarrassments, and make plainer the duties of officers administering its provisions between now and Jan. 1854. Following is the bill:

The U.S. mail steamer Illinois, Lieutenant HARTSTEIN, U. S. N., commanding, arrived at this port early yesterday morning. The Illinois left Aspinwall on the 4th inst., crossed the bar, and anchored at Quarantine on Saturday night, making the trip in seven days and twelve hours.

The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLINS, arrived here this evening, bringing Havana dates to the morning of the 8th inst., and Key West to the evening of the same day. There is no political news of importance. Heavy rains had occurred at Havana, and yellow fever was prevalent.

The Connecticut Editors met at New-Haven last week, organized a permanent association, and resolved that obituary notices and resolutions over five lines in length ought to be paid for, that when an advertiser fails to fulfil his contract the Editor imposed upon ought to give him a free notice for the benefit of the craft, and that editorial notices to promote private ends should not go in unpaid for.

I have just learned, from good authority, that the Committee of Conference on the Canal resolutions have agreed upon resolutions which will command the almost unanimous vote of both Houses. The basis of the agreement is briefly as follows:

FAMINE IN MADEIRA.--A paragraph, purporting to be an extract from a letter written at Madeira, on board the United State steam-frigate Powhatan, is floating through the press, which denies the existence of any famine on the Island, and insinuates that the provisions and money sent from this country would both be thrown away, or, at all events, not applied to the benevolent uses for which they were contributed.

The Clerks in the Census Bureau are on the Ist of July, to be reduced to twelve, and the office removed to the latent Office building. Prof. DE Bow conducts the Bureau with ability and economy. 'Tis believed that many appointments will be agreed on in Cabinet to morrow, both foreign and domestic.

In the same paper which brought us the proclamation of governor BRIGHAM YOUNG, was a long ranting speech of his, in the Temple at Salt Lake City, "putting through" the Gladdenites, or dissenters from the spiricula wife system, in his own peculiary style.

THE SANDWICH ISLANDS.--News is no later by the Illinois than by the last. But the Polynesian has some interesting items. During the year 1852, there were 2,918 convictions. Of these 1,114 were procured by drunkenness. 537 of the convicted were foreigners, 122 by natives--a most disreputable statement to all the world away from the Islands.

The paragon of South Carolina chivalry, General PAUL QUATTLEBAUM, has intimated his intention of resigning the high and responsible position of command of the Third Brigade of the invincible "Militia" of Palmettodom. His letter of resignation is a touching the dignified specimen of composition.

Our European mails, as will be seen in another column, bring us dates from China to March 28th; and a private letter, quoted in an English paper, gives an important item, as late as the 29th. From these, it appears that our surmises in a previous article, are substantiated.

PACIFIC ROAD SURVEYS.--There are four expeditions of survey organized by Government to examine the most practicable route for the Pacific Railroad. The first is under the command of Governor STEVENS, of the Territory of Minnesota, late of the U. S. Topographical Engineers.

Now, the Canals are to be enlarged. The Committee of Conference with commendable punctuality have agreed to report, and we are assured that their report will be almost unanimously acceded to by both branches of the Legislature.

FROM JAMAICA.--In the House of Assembly, lately, in Kingston, Jamaica, the Speaker attended in his place from 3 o'clock to 3 1/2. No members came in to keep him company, the minority determining to carry out the views of the majority, by not attending.

The Suffolk County Teachers Association held its Annual Meeting at Port Jefferson, last week, commencing Thursday afternoon, and closing Saturday morning. Rev. R. CRUIKSHANK, was elected President, vice J. H. TUTHILL, Esq., resigned, and S. I. C. SWEEZY, Corresponding Secretary, vice S. H. DE LOSS CRANE, resigned.

The U. S. Mail steamship Pacific, Capt. NYE, from Liverpool, Wednesday June 1, at 4.35 P. M., arrived at this prot yesterday at 2 P. M. The Pacific encountered strong westerly gales for five days during the passage A telegraphic dispatch was received by the officers of the arrival of the yacht of Commodore VANDERBILT at Southampton on the day of the Pacific's sailing.

LATER FROM THE WEST INDIES.--From some of the West India Islands, we have later dates by the Pacific, as from Barbadoes to May 13, Carthagena to May 11, Costa Rica, to May 21, Demarara, to May 11, Porto Rico to May 15, St. Thomas to May 17.

PROBABLE MURDER.--Two watchmen who were on duty in the eastern portion of the city, hearing a disturbance in Union-street, between 12 and 1 o'clock, proceeded to the sopt, and discovered three or four rowdies in the road, from whom the noise proceeded.

Father GAVAZZI writes a letter to the Editor of an Italian paper in this City, describing the attack made on him at Quebec. It is as follows, and will be perused with the greatest interest: QUEBEC, Canada, June 8, 1853. DEAR SIR: I only write a few particulars of the shocking case which happened the day before yesterday; you will perceive it more amply described in the papers I send you.

HEAVY RAILROAD DAMAGES.--JOHN MASSINO lately sued the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad for damages for the amount of $10,600. The Nashville Whig gives the following particulars of the Case:-"MASSINO, on the 20th of June, 1850. took passage on said road, which was in an incomplete state, no provision being made for passengers.

On Saturday, June 11, by Rev. William R Williams, D. D., WILLIAM AUSTEN MARTEN and ANNE MARIA GOODRICH, niece of the late William Willis, all of this City. On Thursday, June 9, at Christ Church, Hartford, Conn., by the Rt. Rev. T C. Brownell, Dr. J. S. CRANE, of Columbia, S. C., to Miss HARRIET DRAPER, of the former place.

The St. Paul's Minnesota, Democrat of June 1st, says that Gov. Stevens, J. M. Stanly, artist of the North-Pacific Railroad Expedition, and E. Evans, astronomer, arrived last Friday. Captain J. S. Osgood, disbursing officer of the Expedition, arrived yesterday.

A Treaty has been concluded between the United States and the Free and Hanseatic Republics of Hamburg, Bremen, and Lubec, for the mutual extension of the jurisdiction of the Consuls and Vice-Consuls of the contracting parties.

NEW-HAMPSHIRE.--The Democratic State Convention of New-Hampshire met at Concord, on Thursday. The Telegraph has reported the nominations. The Convention had under consideration the following resolution, intended as a gentle reminder to the President. It is quite unnecessary to add that it did not prevail:

The accident at the railway bridge, north of Waterford, yesterday, was caused by the breaking away of the tressel work built to support the railway track over the ravine at that place. The work was of extraordinary magnitude, the bents being upwards of forty feet above the surface of the ground.

TENTH DAY. U. S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--The Case of the Ship Roscius.--The U. S. vs. Daniel Maloney.--This exciting and very interesting investigation was brought to a termination Saturday morning and the case given to the Jury in a very elaborate charge from His Honor the Chief Justice.

The Pacific arrived last evening at about 2 o'clock, bringing English advices to the afternoon of the 1st inst. She has had an unusually rough passage for the season, having encountered violent head-winds from the third day out until the eighth; it is something,

The mail of this morning brought us New-Orleans papers of Sunday last. A collision occurred on the Lake Ponchartrain Railroad on Saturday, by which one man was killed, and five others wounded. Hon. Mr. STEPHENS, injured by the recent accident on the Macon Railroad--who had an arm broken, and received a severe contusion on his head -- is doing well.

In these days of luxuriant nature; In those days of balmy zephlyrs and glorious sunshine, we may " babble o' green fields" and fill our hearts with "the very pride of June," most pleasurably. Forgetful of our City doom,

The Enchanted Mountain in Texas is an immense oval rock, three hundred feet high, situated about eighty miles north of Bastrop. Its surface is polished, and in sunshine dazzles the beholder at a distance of three or four miles. Those who ascend it have to wear moccasins or stockings, and, like those who went up to Mount Horeb, must put off their shoes. The Camanches perform their religious rites on this singular hill.

THE CENTRAL AMERICAN NEWS.--Costa Rica dates to the 21st of May. On the 18th and 19th, official banquets were given in San Jose, the capital, to celebrate the reelection of Don JUAN RAFAEL MORA to the Presidency. It was officially announced, from Punta Arenas, that a cloud of locusts had fallen in the territory between the Bairanca and the Chacarife. The Bishop had appealed for prayers.

And we are glad to chronicle it. During a single ride on the Fourth-avenue cars, we heard three ladies thank the gentleman that gave up their seats for their accommodation.

During the session of the Baptist State Convention of Connecticut at Norwich, on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, last week, the Committee on Temperance submitted a report with accompanying resolutions, urging the importance of a stringent law in regard to the sale of spirituous liquors.

THE MARYLAND COLONY IN LIBERIA.--We learn from the Colonization Journal that Messrs. PROUT and CASSEL have been appointed Commissioner, by the Maryland Colony in Liberia, to visit this country and arrange their future relations with the Maryland State Colonization Society.

Turkey and Cuba are the two leading topics of the English papers. The one is in serious peril from the ardor of Russian acquisitiveness ; the other, tends with violent centripetal force to lose itself in the American Union. The fate of both is reduced to a question of years. The crescent is no longer a proper symbol of Islam.

PLEASANT.--A letter from an officer in the U. S. Navy, dated Funchal, Madeira, May 1st, is published in the Portland Advertiser. The following is an extract: The hill sides of Madeira appear pictures of fertility, and it is to be hoped a year of fruitfulness is to succeed the last year of famine.

Almost every hour records some new victim whose corpse or maimed body has been found by friends. So far as we can learn, after careful inquiry, the number of persons shot is about is fifty, and of those killed outright or mortally wounded, from ten to twelve.

The entries of Foreign Merchandise at this port during the past week were, in value, at the Custom House, over $4,000,000; a large sum for the season, and one that, a year ago would have have created surprise, if brought in at the top of the Spring or Fall trade.

Our regular Liverpool correspondent supplies us with a long account of the origin and concents of the Dublin Exhibition. We avail ourselves only of his description of the building and the articles exposed, having already published full particulars of the inception of the enterprise.

WALLACK'S.--The season at this beautiful little Theatre terminates to-night. The lessee, Mr. WALLACK, takes his benefit. "As you like it," with its splendid scenery and costumes, will be repeated for the last time. The season has, we understand, been highly satisfactory. Excepting for the last few weeks, the house has been constantly filled;

PAYING TAXES WITH RAGS.--The Raleigh (N. C.) Register, in noticing the paper mills of the State, shows that the stock of rags annually consumed by the mills is equal in value to the taxes paid by the people into the State Treasury. So that they may now actually pay their taxes with what has heretofore been thrown away as valueless. The Register says:

We would not torment our readers before their time. But it is our duty, as journalist, to warn people of any coming trouble, and by forewarning to forearm them. Only twenty three days are left, before the morning, of all the year most to be dreaded, will dawn upon us.

The steamship Texas, from Vera Cruz, the 8th inst., has arrived at this port. Senor ALMONTE, the new Minister to the United States, is among her passengers; also, the newly appointed Minister to France. The former leaves here for Washington, via Louisville, on Monday.

From the London Morning Chronicle. The Bank of England return for the week ending May 21, published this morning, shows a further decrease in the stock of bullion, a mounting to pound; 268,493. This continued drain of the precious metals, notwithstanding the recent large arrivals of gold from Australia, is still a matter of surprise to those who do not give a thoughtful attention to all the circumstance of the case.

The demon of religious fanaticism and intolerance stalks once more in our midst, and numerous victims have been ??lated on its blood-thirsty shrine. Montreal has again been placed under martial law. GAVAZZI'S arrival among us was the signal for the awakening of those evil passions which, in ignorant and prejudiced masses, are ever at the command of religious fanaticism.

LORD ELLISMERE'S PICTURES.--We hear that the Earl of ELLESMERE has brought to this country for exhibition among his friends the Chandos Portrait of SHAKSPEARE. This Portrait is of so much general interest that we hope his Lordship will exhibit it at the Crystal Palace.

The popular sympathies are with the early closing movement, particularly in its application to Saturday afternoon. Certain branches or daily business in a commercial City like New-York, can always be got through with from 9 to 4 or 5 o'clock, and a hour or two sooner on Saturday, if necessary, to make the out-of-town recreation of the Clerks, in Summer time, worth looking after.

We have received several highly interesting and important documents from the heads of departments of the Hawaiian Government, which shed much light upon the society of that Island group. The report of the " Minister of Public Instruction" will be found condensed and abstracted on another page.

A Ride on the Rice Coast--The Crackers--Southern House hold Markets--Birds of the Swamps--Plantations--Negro Settlements--Fine Trees. Having been provided by a kind friend with an excellent saddle horse, I rode out one fine morning to see the district in which the sea-island cotton is cultivated, and visit a rice plantation.

DON LUCAS ALAMAN, MInister of Foreign Affairs for the Republic of Mexico,--whose death was announced yesterday in our telegraphic dispatches from New-Orleans,--was a man of talent, great energy and remarkable perseverance, though tinclured by qualities that neither adorned his character nor added to his weight as a statesman.

The report of the Minister of Public Instruetion, to the Hawaiian Legislature, states that the number of Public Schools taught by natives during the year 1852 was 440, with an average attendance of 31. The number of Protestant schools was 344. The total amount of receipts of school tax, in 1852, was $26,486, which was less than the year previous, owing, mainly, to the great scarcity of money.

The China Mission is now considered by the President as particularly important. The appointment, though made, is not yet announced. DAVIS and DOBBIN generally consented to the selection of a "National." CHARLES GREEN is hero. The Cabinet is in session. Let the croakees conceal their heads. Let them dive into their native mud, and dream of other matters to scare the people with. How many folks broke up house-keeping last Spring because everything was going to be so high!

The Committee of Conference on the proposed amendments to the Constitution have to-day come to an agreement. The report will be first made in the Assembly. This constitutes the chief concession made by the conferces on the part of the Senate to the Barnburners of the Assembly.

The Minister of the Interior has just presented a report to the Express: the first, I believe, that Her Majesty has yet received. The subject of the document is Maternal Association. The Empress made them a present of 100,000 francs, and M. de PERSIONY submits to her a project for the division of that sum among the fifty--four Mothers Societies in Franco.

SUICIDE OF A FEMALE IN MERCER-STREET.--Yesterday morning Dr. LALANE, of No. 32 Rose-street, gave information at the Coroner's office, that a female had committed suicide by taking poison. Coroner GAMBLE proceeded to the house No. 105 Mercer-street, during the afternoon, and held the inquest. The deceased, it seems, had declared that she would destroy herself on more than one occasion.

THE MAINE LAW. -- The London Daily News, of May 23, publishes a long communication from Dr. MARSH, the Secretary of the American Temperance Union, directed to the National Temperance Society at London, giving a minute amount of the progress and results of the Maine Law in the States.

I have been requested to state to you, that the intimation, to which I alluded last week, that Mr. MATHER would be willing to let the subject of his impeachment rost, without further action in the Assembly, is wholly unfounded and erroneous. On the contrary, I am assured by those in his confidence, that no effort will be spared on the part of his friends, to bring the matter to a vote in that body.

EXAMINATION OF THE REMAINS OF ARTHUR SPRING.--The body of ARTHUR SPRING was taken to the dissecting room of the Philadelphia College of Medicine this morning, and anatomically examined by Prof. JAMES MCCLINTOCK in the presence of Dr. KIRKBRIDE, Dr. EVANS, and several physicians and other scientific gentlemen, and the students of the Medical class.

U.S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Judge NELSON.--CHARLES O'CONOR, Esq, U. S. District Attorney, came into Court yesterday morning, when the learned Judge inquired if there was any other criminal business to be brought before the Court this Term. The District Attorney replied that MICHAEL REARDON had been remanded for sentence. The Judge said the sentence could be passed to-morrow.

After leaving Tultcha, we arrived at Galatz on the same evening, in fifty-six hours from Constantinople. From Tultcha upwards, the waters of the Danube, confined to one single bed, spread out at times to a mile in width, and possess a grandeur worthy of the Mississippi of Europe;...

As the appearance of swallows foretells the coming Summer of Nature's year, so here a few "candidates " hovering around the Point during the letter part of May indicate that those summer of the academic year is approaching. They usually begin to make their appearance about the latter end of May, and those influx continues until the last day of grace-the 20th of June.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--After the performance of "As You Like It," last night, the curtain ascended, and the entire strength of the company made their final bow to their patrons. Mr. WALLACK then stepped forward, and in a nently. delivered speech, thanked the public for its loboral patronage of his establishment.

During the past week I have been attending the Commencement of the University of North Carolina. Some of the Exercises were of unusual interest. Among these I may mention a Valedictory Semon before the Graduating Class, and a Lectgure before the Historical Society of the University, by the Rev. Dr. HAWKES, of your City, who graduated here in1845;

RECEPTION OF MECHANICAL FIRE COMPANY OF BALTIMORE.--Yesterday, the Fireman of our City turned out in large numbers, for the purpose of participating in the reception of the Mechanical Fire Company of Baltimore, by the "Columbian," Engine Company No. 14, of this City.

COUNTERFEIT BILLS.--A quantity of counterfeit $5 bills on the Bank of North America, were distributed in this City last week. A Women, it is believed, put them in circulation, as she called, the latter part of the week, at a stone on the corner of Gold and Plymouth-streets and offered one of these bills in payment for some trifling article. The proprietor surprising it to be spurious,

Instructions, Intended to regulate their personal and official conduct, have been issued by our Government to its Diplomatic and Consular representatives in foreign countries. They are recommended to dress with Republican simplicity. They are charged to keep their offices open during business hours.

The Panama Herald makes some pointed remarks in reply to a Missouri paper's statement that the loss of life has been so great among the operative engaged in the construction of the Panama Railroad, that it is calculated there is a dead laborer for every foot of the road. He says that from Aspinwall to Barbaco, being the only portion of the Panama Railroad opened, (although there is more constructed,) is 22 1/2 miles.

The Times says--"We are impressed more and more each day with the necessity of a union of the North-American Colonies," and proceeds to advocate such a union, quoting with commendation, a speech on the subject, made in the Canadian Parliament. The article concludes thus:

The regular monthly meeting of this Society was held last evening at their rooms in the University, Washington Square. Hon. G. BANCROFT, President of the Society, occupied the chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT BRANTFORD, CANADA.--From the Brantford Expositor we learn that on the afternoon of the 6th inst., about 4 o'clock, a most destructive fire broke out in that town. At one time fears were entertained that the greater portion of the town would be consumed. Burning shingles were borne to a great distance.

The regular Havana correspondent of the DAILY TIMES insists, it will be noticed, upon the consummation of a bargain between Spain and the present Government of Mexico. If he may be believed, a large body of Spanish officers has already been introduced into the Mexican service.

The latest advices from the Argentine apprize us of a renewal of hostilities. The projects of peace had all proved unsatisfactory. The Buenos Ayreans had made a desperate rally to defend the city, while the country and environs were in the hands of General URQUIZA, who had established a blockade and created a famine within the walls.

THE COURSE OF EMPIRE AND OTHER PICTURES, by THOMAS COLE, with selections from his writings, illustration of his life. By LOUIS L. NOBLE, New-York, CORNISH Co. 1853. This book comes too late, we fear, to meet with a very extensive circulation. It should have appeared soon after the death of Mr. COLE, while he was still loved and remembered.

At. New-Haven, Conn., June 8, JAMES M. THACHER, M. D., of Philadelphia, aged 30 years, oldest son of the late Augustus Thacher, of Hartford, Conn. On Monday, June 13, of a long and painful illness, which she bore with Christian resignation, and in the full assurance of a blessed immortality,

SEAS.--U.S. CIRCUIT COURT--Before Chief Justice NELSON.--In re Michael Reardon, convicted of Manslaughter, in killing James Miller with a Relaying Pin.--The prisoner was put to the bar to be sentenced. His counsel, Hon. Frederick A. Tallmadge, addressed the Court, in mitigation, and urged that the prisoner was a total stranger in this country, and without means to support his family, much loss to pay a heavy fine.

On such a sultry day as yesterday, particularly refreshing is the vision of evergreens, that seem dripping with recent showers, even if the showers evidently come down through the Croton pipes, and are fresher from the hose than from the clouds.

EMBARKATION OF EMIGRANTS TO LIBERIA.--The bark Adeline received on board last evening one hundred and thirty-four emigrants for Liberia Ninety-six of these people are from Tennessee, and the remainder from this State--twenty-seven belonging to respectable colored families well known in Savannah. They leave here many sincere friends both among the white and colored people, and for vent prayers for their safety and success.

ARRIVALS YESTERDAY.--Among the passengers by the steamer Florida from Savannah, on yesterday, were sundry Southern notorieties--to wit: A genuine black bear from Florida, a young alligator, a fawn, and mocking-birds too numerous to mention.

The Pacific Railroad Charter has passed the Senate. When it shall have received similar attention at the lands of the Assembly and of the Governor, the Corporation will be in an attitude to solicit the sanction of the Federal Government.

STRAWBERRY FESTIVAL.--The ladies of the Second Presbyterian Church held their Strawberry Festival on Monday evening, at Commercial Buildings. It was well attended. Last evening the ladies of the Dutch Reformed Church held their Festival, which was also well patronized. This evening the ladies of the Trinity M E. Church hold their Festival. There will be music. Also, an address by Rev. J. B. WAKELY, of New-York.

We have received from Mr. GEO. APPLETON the following engravings: "The Signing of the Death Warrant of Lady Jane Grey." HUNTINGTON. Engraved by CHAS. BURT. "Sparking." F. W. Edmonds. Engraved by ALFRED JONES. "Anne Page, Slender and Shallow." LESLIE. Engraved by C. BURT.

On Friday night last, the shops of Mr. Beard and Mr. Murphy, in Neponset, Mass., were broken into, On the next day the goods were found in Tinean Grove, where they had been hidden by the robbers. On Saturday night, about twenty of the inhabitants of Neponset, fully armed, went down to the grove to arrest the robbers.
POWDER MILL EXPLOSIONS.--The powder mill of PAUL GREELEY, Esq., in Skitico, (Enfield Mills.) blew up on Thursday of last week, with a heave report. One of the workmen, Mr. WALTER LUCE, was killed.

The Board held their sixth meeting of this session last evening. RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Present: Aldermen Sturtevant, Boyce, Barr, Francis, Tweed, Bard, Ward, Denmen, Doberty and Peck--barely a quorum.

The sugar planters of West Baton Rouge, La, have held a meeting at which they resolved that the recent large importations, by certain parties at St. Louis, of sugar from foreign ports, under the name of concentrated molasses, is injurious to the interest of the Louisiana planters, and they, therefore, recommend all honorable means to prevent this infringement of the revenue laws.

The Stethoscope is a Virginia Medical Monthly, well edited by Dr. P. C. GOOCH. The June number is a fair specimen. The first article is by Dr. THWEATT, commending the use of Bibeerine in Intermittents.

NEARLY DROWNED.--A Mrs. ANN MARTIN, residing in Walker street, New-York, in her haste to get from the Peck-slip ferry boat Niagara before she had been properly secured to the bridge, fell between the bridge and boat, and was nearly drowned. She was rescued by WILLIAM FREESTONE, the Pilot of the boat, who jumped from the wheel house to the deck, and thence into the water, and thus succeeded in rescuing her in an insensible state.

At half-past three, precisely, I started on board "The Stuggard," from the bottom of --- street. Previous to my departure, I purchased a nautical hat, with a broad black ribbon, and all the way down the street practised that rolling gait which is the peculiar property of mariners--much to the inconvenience, I believe, of other pedestrians, who did not accommodate themselves to my style of progression.
The report of the Committee appointed to investigate certain charges against the management of the American Art-Union, has been submitted to the State Assembly.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Mr. CONWAY, a worthy and deserving actor at this establishment, takes his benefit to-night. The pieces for the occasion are the "Rivals," (with a good caste) and the popular Comedy of "All the Glitters is not Gold." We hope the theatre will be well attended.

FIRES.--A fire broke out in the rear of No. 6 Hamilton-avenue, about 2 o'clock on Monday morning in a stable owned by THOMAS DAWSON, which was entirely destroyed, together with three horses owned by GEORGE McMAHON Co, and one owned by JOHN WOODS.

The following bills were favorably reported on: For connecting the Lehanon Railroad with Massachusetts Railways. To enable the Eric and New-York City Railroad to require certain real estate. To allow the Pennsylvania Railroad to construct a road in this State. A bill was reported to incorporate the National Mining Company.

" All has been said," exclaimed a despairing Frenchman, when he found his last original sentiment could be proved a plagiarism. " Everything has been invented," matters an inventive Yankee, whose brain, though racked to the utmost, surrenders no new important secret.

Our prediction that the public would be dissatisfied with the new regulation adopted by the New York and New-Haven Railroad (in obedience to public clamor) is verified. The New-Haven Journal of yesterday says "the New-York Road is now trying this experiment, but we are informed it is unsatisfactory to passengers, and a general desire is expressed that flag-men shall be stationed at bridges and dangerous points, instead of delaying the trains." Journal of Commerce.

During the past week the gold fever has raged in this region to a considerable extent. New discoveries are constantly being made. Gold in small quantities has been found in the valleys, on the hill-tops, and indeed almost everywhere where search has been made. Scarcely a rock can be found that does not contain some sign of gold.

By the bark Leopold, we have dates from Buenos Ayres to the 24th of April--three weeks later. Letters by this arrival state that "all attempts to accommodate matters have been utterly foiled, and the most formidable preparations have been made on both sides--one to save, and the other to capture the city.

GROWTH OF GLOUCESTER FISHERIES.--We saw, a few days since, a list of the fishing vessels owned at the port of Gloucester, May, 1828, near twenty-five years ago. The total number then owned and sailing from that harbor was forty-nine! These were mostly "pinkies" of about fifty tons burthen, worth about $1,000 to $1,200 each and required 350 men and boys to man them.

The Triat d' Union says: "Conflicts are still taking place between the soldiers of the garrison, police agents and citizens. During the night of the 15th the dead bodies of three soldiers were picked up."

The examiner of Clerks for the office of Register of the Treasury, commenced to-day. Messrs. BIGGER, Register, JONES, Chief Clerk and OVERTON, Chief Clerk of the Post-Office Department, are the Examinations. The examinations of the Third Auditor's Office, are deferred until tomorrow. Messrs. BURT, Auditor, TAYLOR, Assistant Chief Clerk, and ELA, Clerk, are Examiners.

For some two months the bruit of preparation has been going on in our midst, exciting to the extreme periphery our civil, military, and social organization--the bosom of exalted dignity elate with undefined hopes, or the aspiration of inordinate ambition has caused an undulating influence through all grades of our very impressible material, without first digesting the proposition as its basis in justice or honor, or its consequences in the future.

Mr. BURROUGHS addressed the Assembly in an instructive speech, this morning, on the resolution to amend the Constitution, proposed by the Committee of Conference. He showed that a very great advance had been made by the friends of the Canals since the meeting of the Legislature in January.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: You are right in desiring to afford to your readers better information about European matters, than that drawn from the troubled sources of the London Press.

MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--An adjourned meeting of the Common Council was held at the Lycoum last evening--Alderman F. B. BETTS, President of the Board, in the Chair. A large number of bills were audited. The ordinance authorizing the Annual Tax for 1853, which was reported by the Finance Committee at its last meeting, was taken up last evening, together with the statements and estimates made by the Chairmen of the different Committees.

What a country this is in which an enterprising man may turn up a new territory every year. Mr. H. R. SCHOOLCRAFT has found one just west of the Rocky Mountains, running parallel to that ridge for several hundred miles, and about fifty miles broad. The Columbia River draws much of its water on its hills, and the Columbia's assistant streams drink out of the same springs.

The Foreign News is not very extensive, as the steamer brings only that of two days. The items of most interest, perhaps, are those that concern the strength of Turkey, and her state of preparation for any sudden brush with her neighbors.

There was some excitement here to-day, occasioned by rumors of an intended rising of slaves in this city. The information was gives to the police late last night by a free negro, who pointed out the ringleader. The latter was immediately arrested, and found to be heavily armed.
By way of New-Orleans, we have news from the City of Mexico the 29th May,-not solate by eleven days, as before received by Telegraph, but conveying some interesting items of intelligence:

The New-Bedford Mercury of the 10th says that the cabinet maker's shop belonging to S. T. Soule was burned on Wednesday. Loss $200, which was insured against. Several thousand acres of woodland have been burned during the last fire in that vicinity.
In the Sonate, yesterday, the Canal Resolutions passed with only one dissenting vote. The Pilot bill being up, a long discussion was ended by striking out the half pilotage feature--Ayes 13, Nays 8.

A long article in Blackwood, upon "Spiritual Manifestations," thus humorously and caustically closes: "Keep your mind easy, dear reader! You are not one whit more likely to be disturbed by ghosts than your fathers or grandfathers were, and you may set them thoroughly at defiance.

CRAWFORD'S MONUMENT TO WASHINGTON.--The following extract, says the Savannah (Geo.) Republican, from a letter from Dr. NEWMAN, Professor of the University of Munich, to his brother-in-law, in this city, has been kindly furnished to us for published. It is dated at Munich May 12, 1853:

LEARNING THE ROPES.--A Southerner was robbed of between $400 and $500, yesterday afternoon, in the following manner: It seems that previous to leaving his home, in Alabama, he drew the above money from out of the bank, all in gold. A stranger, standing by, entered into conversation with him, and uncertained that he had taken passage in a vessel bound for New-York.

It is rumored that JOHN R. THOMPSON, Senator from New-Jersey, will be offered the China Mission. THOMPSON was for many years Merchant and Consul at important Chinese ports, and is spoken of as better qualified for the Mission than any one heretofore named.
