HYDROPHOBIA.--Ten animals--the dog, wolf, fox, and cat, the horse, ass, mule, cow, sheep, and pig--are all which are said to be susceptible of this disease, while the first four only are said to be able to communicate it. These four have teeth of a similar form, capable of making a deeply-punctured wound.

Mr. PLATT reported the Pilot bill complete. A debate followed upon the merits of the bill, which was cut off by the arrival of the special order of the day--the Canal Resolutions--which, after some remarks by Messrs. PIERCE and CORNELL, were adopted--Ayes, 29; Noes, 1--Mr. JONES. Messrs. MURRAY and TADER were absent.

The Baltimore Mechanics' Exchange Company passed resolutions to-night opposing the acceptance of the propositions of either New-York or Philadelphia builders for the construction of steamships for the Baltimore and Liverpool Line.

Accounts from India state that an American ship, loaded with ice and apples, had been wrecked in the Bay of Bengal. It is feared that his vessel may prove to be a Boston vessel, which was about due at Calcutta, and which had several missionary passengers.

St. John, (N. B.,) papers of the 14th inst. are received: The New-Brunswicker states that two French war steamers, the Veloce and Cleopatra, had arrived on the coast of Newfoundland, to watch over the interests of the French fisherman.

William Fenton, a lad of 14, whose parents reside at Windsor, Conn., was drowned at Hartford, on Sunday morning, while bathing. He visited his parents on Saturday evening, and when he left them, took his mother and all the family by the hand, bidding them "good bye," and took up his little sister and kissed her--a thing he was never known to do before on taking leave of them.

A gentlemen who had several interviews with Arthur Spring during the last few weeks of his life, expresses the opinion that he refused to make a confession, from an apprehension of the indignant opinion of mankind, and the hope that in someminds, a belief would still be cherished of his innocence.

The machine shop and foundry of Mr. RODDEN were burnt last night, in Griflinstown. Parliament is prolonged until the 23d July. A reward of $200 is offered by the authorities, for the apprehension of the ruffians concerned in smashing the windows of the churches on Sunday evening.

The Excise Commissioners for the Nineteenth Ward are now acting upon the applications for licenses to sell liquor in the immediate vicinity of the Crystal Palace. How far their action is likely to be guided by those considerations which should control it, we are not aware.

GENERAL REMARKS.--This fruit is a native of Europe and America. It cannot well bear exposure to the vertical rays of the sun, the intense heat causing evaporation, and consequently death. It most probably derives its name from the use to which the fruit has been applied--namely, as an accompaniment, when made into sauce, for roasted goose.

We have details of the Texas news to the the 3d of June, previously sketched by the Telegraph. The latest intelligence from the gold dining district is continued in the following paragraph, which we copy from the Austin State Gazette:

The first Jury empanelled to decide the merits of the plea of insanity set up by the Counsel of the murderer NEARY, were unable to agree. The second Jury in the case, after a long and deliberate investigation of the evidence adduced to sustain the plea, decided at a late hour last night, that the wretched man was same.

The British Royal Mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, arrived this morning a little after midnight, having left Liverpool at 10 o'clock A. M. of Saturday, the 4th inst. Among her passengers is Hon. J. C. FREMONT.

We are by no means surprised to learn, from our Canadian correspondents, that there is a strong desire, on the part of a portion of the Roman Catholics in Quebec and Montreal, that GAVAZZI should complete the course of lectures there which were interrupted by the disastrous violence with which the public has been made familiar.

A LUCKY DISCOVERY.--One day last week the keeper of the State Prison had occasion to visit the cell of SHIELDS, the English burglar, who is confined for 12 years. As he left the cell he put his hand against the inner door, and discovered that it was blackened by coming in contact with the iron.

CASTLE GARDEN.--The first grand promenade concert of the National Guard Band, took place here last night. A fair audience was attracted by the novelty, and "promenaded" the balconies, passages, and other cool spots with evident appreciation.

The Boston Journal published a letter from an intelligent gentleman long resident in China, giving an account of the progress and prospects of the rebellion. We copy a few paragraphs, confirmatory of previous statements respecting the unpopularity of the reigning family, and the probable success of the insurgents:

Hon. P. W. TOMPKINS died lately at his home in California. He had acquired an enviable reputation in the legal profession in the country of his adoption, as he had before done in Mississippi. He formerly represented Mississippi in Congress.

We breakfasted at 9 o'clock, and immediately after carriages and horses were brought to the door to take us to Church. The family of my host, (whom I will designate as Mr. A.,) regularly attended the services of a Presbyterian Church, a few miles from the plantation; twelve miles in an opposite direction there was another house of worship, in which to-day a Baptist preacher was to officiate.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR--Happening to be at Ravenswood on Saturday afternoon, I was witness to an occurrence, the like to which I do not wish to see again.

KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER--Wednesday.-Before Judge HARCULO and Justices STILNELL and STRYKER -- Trial of Bernard Hagan for the murder of his wife, Bridget Hagan.--The trial of Bernard Hagan for the murder for his wife, Bridget Hagan, on the 12th of February last, at their residence, corner of Charles Tallman-streets, Brooklyn, by beating her, commenced this day. The first witness called:

The ingenuity of man in appropriating the whole range of animal, mineral and vegetable substances to the advancement of his comfort, is nowhere more wondrously exhibited than in his conversion of the sap of trees to a thousand uses of life.

In our remarks yesterday morning, upon the inefficiency of the police, we noted, as the world has done before us, the difficulty of finding an officer at the moment of need. The rarest desideratum by night light is a star.

We have been favored by the Surveyor General with permission to insert in out columns the following graphic communication intended to be forwarded to a London periodical, as an accompaniment to a sketch of the celebrated Maori Chief TANEWA. We have seen the portrait, which is an admirable likeness of "Old Hook Nose," and we have no doubt that both it and the narrative will be regarded with much interest at home.

I have just finished a railroad ride through Georgia starting at Columbus and ending in Savannah. A few days since, the connection between these two cities was completed, and now they respond by rails on the ground as well as by wires in the air.
The steamers James Millinger and Memphis, No. 1, were destroyed by fire at their dock last night. They had been laid up for some days in consequence of low water.

The Salt Lake mail, under the charge of Mr. ALISON, arrived here on Wednesday evening, the 25th inst.--the first entirely through from the valley for many months. Mr. A. and party made unprecedented time; they went from here to Fort Laramie and back again in twenty-five days, delaying two days at Laramie.

CUBA TRADE OF BOSTON AND PORTLAND.--This trade, once so extensive and so important to this port, is now passing rapidly away into the hands of our sister city, Portland. Formerly, although the trade was carried on mostly by vessels owned in Portland, yet their return cargoes of Molasses almost entirely came to this port.

There has been rejoicing in Albany to-day. The resolutions for the amendment of the Constitution to provide for the completion of the Erie Canal Enlargement and the lateral Canals, which passed the Assembly unanimously yesterday, came up in the Senate pursuant to order this morning, and after a harangue in Barnburning taste and style from Senator CORNELL,...

The Ocala (Fla.) Mirror gives the following description of one of the vegetable productions of Florida, called the "Paint Root," which is certainly a great curiosity: "This root grows in great abundance in the flat woods near the streams, and in the savannahs of the counties of Levy, Marion, Sumter, and perhaps many other counties of East and South Florida.

We have some additional items of interest from Buenos Aryes by the bark Leopold, in addition to those reported last night. On the 18th April an engagement took place between the squadron of URQUIZA, consisting of several steamers, and that of the Buenos Ayreans, consisting of 5 or 6 sailing vessels.

MOUNT VERNON.--We understand that Mr. JOHN A. WASHINGTON, the proprietor of Mount Vernon, has disposed of that venerated mansion, with two hundred acres of the landed estate, to a company comprising Northern and Southern men, for the large sum of $200,000.

THE BALTIMORE FIRE COMPANY--EXCURSION--Yesterday morning Mechanical Engine Company, No. 4 of Baltimore, headed by their Band, led by Professor LINHARD, were escorted from their quarters at the American Hotel, by a Committee of Columbian Engine Company No. 14, of this City, to their Engine House, corner of Church and Vesey-ste., preparatory to visiting and inspecting various Public, Charitable and other institutions of our City.

The story about the intended rising of the negroes is understood to have been greatly exaggerated, and the excitement has subsided. NEW-ORLEANS, Thursday, June 16. Several affidavits were made last night against an Englishman named DYSON, in regard to the recent insurrectionary attempt.

MILITARY PARADE.--On Wednesday, the 14th Regiment of State Infantry, Col. JESSE C. SMITH, made their annual parade, and the following Companies were in the line at 2 P. M : City Grenadiers, Capt. BURNETT; National Guard, Capt. SPRAGUE; Carroll Guard, Capt. MAGRATH; Franklin Guard, Capt. BALDWIN; Emmet Guard, Color Company, Lieut. O'ROURKE; Washington Guards, Capt. McCARTY; Steuben Guards, Capt. SCHIPPEN; East New-York Rifles, Capt. BEADLE.

A most lamentable accident occurred on the New-York and Erie Railroad, about 5 o'clock this afternoon. Engine No. 58 exploded her boiler, instantly killing eleven persons, and wounding several others.
We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a very brilliant speech made by Mr. MACAULAY a few days since, against a proposition to exclude the Master of the Rolls from the House of Commons.

The Southern and Western Trado Convention, lately held at Memphis, has been briefly reported in our telegraphic dispatches. Further accounts of its proceedings develope a number of interesting facts connected with the session.

THE MILLINERY CASE CONCLUDED.--SENTENCE OF THE COURT.--This case, which has occupied the public mind, was brought to a close yesterday afternoon. At the appointed, time, the parties, together with their counsel, were present Justice BOSWELL proceeded to pass sentence, (the decision of the Court has heretofore been given at length,) which was that THOMAS W BOYD pay a line of $20, and stand committed until paid.

A correspondence has passed between FREEMAN HUNT, Esq., of this City, and the Post master-General, in reference to the foreign postage on Pamphlets and Magazines. Mr. CAMPHELL states that the full postage on a magazine of the weight of six ounces, sent to or received from England, amounts to $5 76 annually.

Two destructive fires occurred at Lowell last night and this morning. The first fire destroyed WEBSTER LEWIS' sash and blind factory; ISAAC PLACK's sash and blind storehouse; GEORGE FRISK's storehouse for bobbins, and some others. Total loss, $12,000--no insurance.
During a suspension of the SASSCER case in the Criminal Court this morning, owing to the sick ness of a juror--the motion for a new trial in the WOODWARD case was argued and denied.

The Post-Office Department has aimed a blow at an abuse which has been growing space of late years, and calls loudly for reform. It is very well known that a large class of Agents and Attornies have taken up their residence at the Capital, who devote themselves to the prosecution of business before Congress and the Departments.

Two boats this morning reached Albany from beyond the late serious break on the Erio Canal. One was loaded with corn, and the other with corn and hams. Both cargoes were seriously damaged, the hams being an, entire loss, and the corn very much heated.

It is said that the Minister of the Interior has act one of his bureau to study out a plan to insure the better observance of the Sabbath. As the Chamber has just adjourned, and will not meet again for eight months, the question has no particular interest at the present moment.
LATEST FROM HAVANA.--The steamer Black Warrior, R. W. SHEDCELDT, Commander, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, from Mobile June 9, and Havana 12th, at 10 A.M.--4 days and 6 hours from Havana.

DURING ATTEMPTS TO COMMIT FORGERIES ON THE ALBANY BANKS--IMPORTANT ARREST, AND SEIZURE OF A COPPER ENGRAVED PLATE -- Through the in defatigable exertions of Police Officers DEVOE and WALLINO, attaches of the Chief's office, a very important arrest has been effected in this City, and an attempt to commit heavy forgeries on the Commercial Bank and Albany City Bank, of Albany, N. Y, has been frustrated.

GRACE CHURCH, WILLIAMSBURG.--A new corporation has been formed, and a plot of ground given, on which to erect an Episcopal Church and Parsonage, in a new and growing portion of Williamsburg. Rev. ALVAH GUION has accepted a call to the Rectorship, and has entered upon the work of gathering a congregation.

Most birds, except a few remarkable singers, almost all domestic animals, and the majority of men, do their work by daylight, or, at least, in the suburbs of day, retiring at night to sleep and repair the losses of their laboring hours by its refreshment.
Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER has been tendered the mission to China, but it is not certain that he will accept it, as the mission is laborious, and the climate unpropitious.

A long and exciting debate was had this morning on a motion to allow Mr. TABOR to rescind his vote on the Canal Resolutions, as requested by him by letter. The Chair decided that the request could not be granted, but the letter would go on the journal.

By the arrival of the Steamer Black Warrior from Havana and Mobile, we are placed in receipt of dates from Vera Cruz to the 4th inst., and from the City of Mexico to May 30th. A summary of these and of later advices has already been received by telegraph from New-Orleans.
At the breaking up of the Bank Court today, it was announced that the rate of discount had been advanced from 3 per cent., at which it has stood since the 20th of January, to 3 1/2 per cent.

EXCURSION OF THE FERRY-BOAT D. S. GREGORY.--On Wednesday, this new and elegant boat, built for the Jersey City Ferry, made its trial trip in a successful manner. A large party, numbering over 300 persons, including members and officers of the Company, members of the Common Council and others of the authorities of Jersey City, were on board.

By the steamer Avon, which arrived from Vera Cruz on the 8th instant, we have confirmation of the stringent measures which are being adopted by SANTA ANNA to strengthen his imperial purposes, and of the discontent which is spreading throughout the land, embracing the whole of its intelligence, not dependent and fed upon the public rents, of which he is assuming personal possession and care.

The Sixteenth Anniversary of the New York Union Theological Seminary, took place on Wednesday evening in the Mereer-street Church. The attendance was very numerous. The proceedings of the evening were pleasingly interpersed with some carefully selected music, very well rendered by the Haydn Society, Under the direction of Prof. G. F. ROOT. Rev. Professor ROBINSON, presided. The exercises opened with prayer by Rev. J. F. SMITH, of Newark.

A day or two since, an extensive jeweller on Washington street, Boston, was visited by a lady, who had long been one of his best customers, accompanied by another lady, whom she introduced as a cousin from the country, anxious to make purchases.

In the House of Commons on the night of the 2nd inst., the distinguished historian, Mr. MACAULAY, signalized his return to the House of Commons by a very eloquent speech against a proposition to exclude the Master of the Rolls from the House of Commons, on the ground that his judicial functions were in consistent with the proper discharge of legislative duties.

That the Common Council have resolved to pay the offal contractor is a matter of no surprise, considering the resolution of those gentlemen to do whatever is nefarious and vile. Mr. WILLIAM B. REYNOLDS is to receive the four thousand seven hundred dollars per month, claimed by him and questioned by the Comptroller, for carrying carcasses and refuse out of the City.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway A. T. STEWART Co., (do,).. Broadway, cor. Reade-at Agricultural Warehouse.

The Asia's advices are only three days later than had been before received, and re port no feature of special importance. An other increase in the rate of discount by the Bank of England, in the face of universal and unexampled prosperity,--while the receipts of gold continue unchecked and the rewards of productive labor are large and certain,--has naturally created a good deal of surprise and led to considerable speculation as to its cause.

SUSPICIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES,--Yesterday, four men, named DAVID HUMPHREY, MICHAEL HUSEY, PATRICK LAHEY, and JAMES MADDEN, were brought before Justice CURTIS, by the Fourth District Police. They were arrested while interring a child at the burying ground near the Barracks, late on Wednesday night--they having no permit.

The heart sickens at the recital of the wholesale butchery in the goodly City of Montreal. The sad news of the murder of a number of our citizens, which has filled Canada with grief, has been conveyed over the telegraphic wires to every part of the Continent, and the memory of the event will linger in the minds of the people of this country for many a long day.
Two youths, not yet twenty-one years of age, fought a duel near New-Orleans. One of them, named LESSESS, was killed, and the survivor succeeded in making his escape.

The GAVAZZI riots have attracted the attention of the Canadian parliament. On the 13th inst. a petition was received from sundry Protestants of the city of Quebee, praying that they may be made secure in the observance of religious worship, and that the City Municipality may be rendered responsible for all damages occasioned by breachers of the peace.

An interesting discourse was delivered on Thursday evening, in the Lecture-room of the Oliver-street Baptist Church, before a very numerous audience, by REV. JAMES TANNER, (ESH-QUE GONE-B1,) a Chippewa Indian, and a Baptist Missionary at Pembino, on the Red River of the North, lying some 400 miles west of Lake Superior, and 500 miles above the Falls of St. Anthony.

For the other city news of this morning, six sixth Page Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Anne Blake--To ?? ?? NIHLO'S GARDEN.--Monday, John Bail.

In the State Assembly, on Wednesday, Mr. WM. TAYLOR presented the Report of the Special Committee on the subject of Railroad Accidents, accompanied by the draft of and Act for the better security of Passengers and other travelling upon Railroads.

The strong interest excited by the position of affairs in Turkey has been evinced by the close "questioning" to which Ministers have been lately subjected in both Houses--in the Lords by Lord HARDWICKE, and in the Commons by Mr. DISRAELI. Both the Lord and Commoner were excessively desirous, on Monday evening, to extract some information as to the course of action contemplated by the Cabinet.

From the Boston Journal. The Prussian brig Leopold arrived at this port yesterday, with Buenos Ayres dates to April 2l, three weeks later. By this arrival we learn that all attempts at conciliation having tailed, the siege of the city was recommenced with renewed vigor on the 15th, and letters state that on the 21st all binds of provisions were scarce and in demand.

ACCIDENTS IN COAL MINES.--A Parliamentary paper which has just been issued, contains returns from the Government Inspectors of Coal Mines, of the number of accidents which happened in these mines during the years 1851, and 1852, with other particulars relative to the causes which produced the accidents, and the results of the judicial investigations,

We have a great many Temperance meetings,--a great many urgent Temperance addresses, and a formidable array of argument, of statistics and of exhortation, in favor of the enactment of a law positively prohibiting the sale of intoxicating drinks. But the most powerful advocates of the Maine Law in our City at the present moment, are its Excise Commissioners.

From the St. Louis Intelligencer. Capt J. W. GUNNISON, who, with his surveying party, has been in our city, for several days past, making some of his final arrangements for his departure to the line assigned him, left yesterday for Kansas, and will be on the Plains about the 25th of this month.

I returned yesterday from a most delightful trip on Bayou Lafourche, which has its embouchure at Donaldsville, about 75 miles up the coast, and empties into Lake Veret and the Atchafalaya River, which empties into the Gulf of Mexico.

Democratic Letters on European Matters and American Policy--Special Correspondence of The TIMES, No. I, The South.--Letters on the Industry, Productions and Resources of the South--special Correspondence of The TIMES, Nos. XXL and XXII.

Our reporter visited the City Prison at an early hour yesterday morning, and had an interview with the condemned criminal, PATRICK FITZGERALD, and the officers having charge of the unfortunate man During the previous night he was somewhat restless, and walked the corridor in company with THOMAS NEARY, the other convict under sentence of death.

The dates are to the 7th inst. The News publishes the following letter, dated Cincinnati, Walker County, May 29th, giving an account of the massacre of a Surveying party by Indians: Information has just been received here of a most melancholy character, to the effect that BENJAMIN HUBERT'S Surveying Party to the Red River, and Wachita Country have all been killed, with the exception of HENRY HINDS, who hes wounded at Fort Bethnap.

THE WILLIAMSBURG CASE.--THOS. W. BOYD, who was committed to the cello for the non-payment of his fine, on Thursday evening,--after remaining in his new quarters for several hours, concluded to pay up and depart. He accordingly gave Mayor DIKEMAN the amount, ($20,) and was discharged.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You have done well to call attention to the badly-protected state of your great City. Allow me to suggest that the DAILY TIMES can render no better service just now to the interests of New-York than by directing its editorial force and influence to this subject.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is the Turkish question, about which not only the speculation of idle politicians and stock-jobbers, but also intense hopes on one side, and intense apprehensions on the other side, of all the elementary powers of European policy are concentrated with us here now.

It is a beautiful thing to see such an Appeal as that which is there subjoined. It is subscribed by twelve pastors of New-York, well known to the public, and representing twelve branches of the Protestant Church. this Appeal

Having, since my arrival in New-York, engaged the services of J.C. BOOTH, Draper and Tailor, No. 486 Broadway, I am conscientiously prepared to recommend him to all gentlemen who, like myself, are strangers in the City, and in search of a handsome and fashionable outfit.

At the close of the Yale presentations exercises this morning, the President awarded the De Forest Medal to Mr. ANDREW D. WHITE, of Syracuse, N.Y. This prize, which is the largest of the kind given at this or any American College, is a gold medal one hundred dollars in value, and is awarded to the best oration from the Senior class, taking into consideration both composition and delivery.

Charles B. Fitch, of Galena, III., for improvement in Made of Cutting Tenons. Dated June 14, 1853 William G. Huyett, of Williamsburg, Pa., for Improvement in Harvesters of Grain and Grass. Dated June 11, 1853. Sherman an S. Lewett and Francis H Root, of Buffalo, N.Y., for Improvement in Stoves. Dated June 11, 1853. Ante-dated Dec. 14, 1852.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: My DEAR SIR: As the great interest of the Summer with be the approaching exhibition in the Crystal Palace, you must period a Southwestern friend to drop you a few lines.

CORONER'S INQUESTS.--On Thursday afternoon Coroner Dr. DICKINSON hold an inquest on the body of a boy named FRANCIS KHADES, whose parents reside at No. 128 Stagg-street. The Jury rendered a verdict of death from burns received from lighted shavings which were thrown on him by some buys, while playing in an open field, on the 1st of June.

REPORTS. Mr. BERKMAN, for relief of New-York Baptist Union Ministerial Society. [Third reading. Also for relief of Pabius Baptist Society. [Third reading. Mr. MORGAN, a bill for a farm and garden in New-York for horticultural purposes.

The New-York State Temperance Society organized in St. John's Methodist Church, yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock--Hon. HERMAN CAMP in the Chair. A motion was made by Rev. Dr. LUCKEY for the appointment of a Committee of five on credentials. A substitute was offered that all friends of Temperance be admitted to the floor of the Convention. A long discussion followed, and several resolutions were offered.

LADIES' HOME MISSIONARY SOCIETY.--This Society held their Fifth Anniversary on Thursday evening, in the M. E. Church, Sands-street. DANIEL AYRES, Esq., presided. Rev. W. F. COLLINS, Missionary, read the report, which was adopted. He stated that more church room is required to accommodate the numbers who wish to attend Divine service, but cannot procure seats.

The increasing activity in and around the Crystal Palace gives a good degree of assurance that the announcement made a few days since by the Directors, of their intention to open the Exhibition on the 15th July next, will be fulfilled. Several hundred workmen are employed upon the Palace. The inagnificent dome is nearly enclosed, and will contribute greatly to the beauty of the structure.

The boiler of engine No. 58, which was pushing a heavy freight train up grade, when about half a mile east of Susquchanna, on the 16th inst., at 4 o'clock, P. M., exploded, instantly killing, burning and scalding a large number of persons. Five are known to have been instantly killed, among whom was the engineer, Mr. ARNOLD.

A cold water steam engine is spoken of in the Cincinnati papers as a new invention. The steam is produced without boilers by simply injecting cold water into generators. The amount of steam required to force out or return the piston rod is made by the introduction to the influence of the fire at each moment of precisely the quantity of water needed, thus doing away with the necessity of boilers.
At the Anniversary of "The American Baptist Society," held in Philadelphia on the 5th May last, an Historical Department was organized under the name of "The American Baptist Historical Society."

LATER FROM NASSAU--By the arrival of the schooner Time, one of the two vessels chartered at New Providence, Nassau, to bring to this port the passengers from the ship William Mary, we have dates from that place to the 28th ult.

A Free Chapel is being erected in Forsyth-street, near Walker, by the church of which Mr. MANSFIELD has the charge. The structure is plain, pointed gothic in its style of architecture, and is in a good locality for a Free Church. It is to be opened in July.

The Court of Appeals meet at the Capital in this city on Tuesday, June 21. There are 217 causes on the Calendar, of which the following are the first in order: 1 John L. H. McCrackan, respondent, agt. William P. Morrie and others, appellants.

The first of July approaches. There are misgivings abroad, that this will be a memorable day in the private biography of sundry clerks at the seat of the Government. Over many a home the day has hung a sceptre, and the eyes of strong men and tender women are watching its motion.

Our Special Washington Correspondence announced yesterday, that Mr. APPLETON, the newly appointed Secretary of Legation at London, has resigned in consequence of domestic afflictions. The post will probably be filled immediately, as Mr. BUCHANAN intends to sad on the 25th.

An intelligent correspondent of the Burlington (Vt.) For Press, giving an account of the riots at Montreal, takes occasion to cast some consdle upon the Mayor of the City. We quote: Meanwhile the soldiers had formed at double line across the street; the mob had, for the must part, returned down, the street, and with the exception of an occasional pistol shot, no active noting was going on at or near the church.

A Petition was presented in the Assembly this morning, signed by more than fifty inhabitants of Amsterdam, Montgomery Co., including many of the most intelligent and respectable citizens of that place, representing that the Central Railroad Company is in the habit of treating emigrants with a cruel and barbarous disregard of the health, safety, and comfort, and asking for effective legislation to prevent the abuse.

The activity which pervades the Nineteenth Ward is not entirely commendable. The rattle of hammers and the hum of busy voices are not alone confined to the erection of industrial palaces. Interwoven with the parent trunk, are shapeless masses--like noisome parasites stealing the healthy nourishment which should give it life, and filling the mind with repugnance and alarm.

The Impeachment trial of Judge LEVI HUBBELL is under way in Wisconsin. The Milwaukee papers are filled with reports of the sayings and doings. The Lieutenant-Governor of the State presides, and Judge HUBBELL is present from day to day, attended by his counsel.
At Essex, Conn. on Wednesday, 15th instant, by Rev. J. H. Pettengill, CHARLES S. McKNIGHT, of New-York, to ADELINE LOCISA, daughter of Capt. Henry L. Cha aplia, of the former place.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I came to the corner of Barclay-street and Church-street at 6 o'clock this morning, to take the Sixth-avenue cars to go up to my job to the Crystal Palace.

EXCURSION OF LOCOMOTIVE BUILDERS.--On Thursday about 860 men employed in the locomotive establishment of ROGERS, KETCHUM GROSVENOR, at Paterson, made an excursion to Jersey City, with a new and superior locomotive, No. 11, for the Camden and Amboy Railroad.

The New Orleans Picayune publishes the following communication from Mr. MURE, British Consul at that port, concerning the passengers of the William and Mary, who have reached New Orleans from St. Thomas:

A CONJUGAL BATTLE.--About noon, yesterday, a conjugal brawl occurred at No. 149 Hadson avenue. An Irishman, named PATRICK FARRELL, beat his wife, and his wife beat him. They had quite a severe time. The police found PATRICK leaning against a wall of the room, learly senseless from loss of blood, caused by wounds in the head.

CORRECTION.--We stated that the Common council of the City of Brooklyn directed that Engine Company No. 2 be locked up. We learn that such is not the case, but that it was the house which was to be locked up, and the Engine sent to New-York, until a new house should be provided.

COTTON AND CEREALS FROM THE RIVER GILA.--Some samples of cotton, wheat, corn, and the seeds of vegetables, from the River Gila, which are cultivated by the Indians on that river, have been left with us by Mr. J. R. BARTLETT. The cotton seems to be of a very superior quality. He has also left with us some blankets and sashes, the manufacture of these tribes.

From the Albany Atlas. Mr. WEST'S proposition, for the amendment of the Constitution, to enlarge the Canals, and to cut off the contracts of 1851, passed the Assembly by a vote of 79 to 40, or about two to one.

The Board held their eighth meeting of the June Session, on Friday evening--RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Present--Aldermen Sturtevant, Boyce, Tweed, Barr, Bard, Ward, Denman, Alvord, Doherty peck--barely a quorum.

THE LIQUOR BUSINESS IN JERSEY CITY.--In accordance with the notice given a week ago by the authorities, the places where liquor is sold in Jersey City were generally closed yesterday. This was especially the case in the hostels and saloons in the vicinity of the ferry.

BUSHMEN,--Rev. Dr. ADAM SMITH, of Cape Town, Africa, gave an interesting address last Sabbath evening in the Old South Chapel, on the people of Africa, and the state of society in that part of the world. Dr. SMITH is a missionary of the church of Scotland, and has been in his field of labor for more than a quarter of a century.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A great many line things are being said, daily, in the newspapers, about the management of the New-York and Eric Railroad, drawn forth by the resignation of its late President, B. F. LODER Esq.

By the arrival of the U. S. Mall steamship Texas, Captain PLACE, we have dates from the the city of Mexico to the 4th instant, and from Vera Cruz to the 8th instant. Senor ALAMAN, SANTA ANNA'S Mexican Minister of Foreign Relations, died suddenly in the city Mexico, early on the morning of the 2d instant. The announcement caused a wide spread sensation. The funeral ceremonies took place on ?? following Friday.

NEW-Brunswick papers to the 16th inst., have been received. On Tuesday, H. M. steamer Argus, Commander PURBES, arrived at St. John, bearing the flag (white at the fore) of Sir GEORGE FRANCIS SEYMOUR, Kt. G. C. H., Vice-Admiral of England and Naval Commander-in-Chief on the the North American and West Indian station.

Gov. FARWELL, of Wisconsin, in answer to a call of the State Assembly, has furnished that body with his reasons for removing Mr. JOHN TAYLOR from the office of State Prison Commissioner.

The State Temperance Society met at 9 1/2 o'clock this morning--EDGAR B. DAY in the chair. Prayer was offered by Rev. Mr. HAMILTON. Mr. McELVOR, of Albany, was elected President. The Executive Committee was increased from seven to nine. HERMAN CAMP and BRADFORD R. WOOD were added to it.

Traveling has become an Institution; it should, therefore, be reduced to a science. From a rare and extraordinary necessity, it has become a practice of every day occurrence,. Of old, people were content to live at home; now, with multi tudes, home is but the central point in a scheme of travel, which leaves them but a scant fragment of time to enjoy its comforts.

Afternoon Session. THE PENNSYLVANIA COAL COMPANY. Mr. MORGAN moved to make the Pennsylvania Coal Company bill the special order immediately after the Canal bill. Mr. BENNETT objected. It requiring unanimous consent, it could not be received.

We have some additional particulars of the recent locomotive explosion at Susquehanna. The following is a complete list of the killed and wounded; WALTER B. ARNOLD, engineer of No. 58, aged about 50 years, and a resident of Susquehanna.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The philosophy of crime has occupied very considerably the attention of Theologians, and Philanthropists. The point of view from whence the subject is considered is the data by which to determine the propriety of the remedies suggested for the prevention of crime, or the amelioration of socity, considering that crime does and will exist in socity.

HAYDN'S ORATORIO, "THE CREATION." Edited by VINCENT NOVELLO. J. A. NOVELLO, Broadway. No better evidence of the growing taste for the highest class of musical compositions can be found than in the necessity which demands the publication of the principal Oratorios, in a form at once convenient and cheap.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times : DEAR SIR:--The object of this communication is to call your attention, and that of the public, to a very bitter article in this week's Freeman's Journal / on the subject of the Gavazzi riots in Canada.

CONNECTICUT NORMAL SCHOOL.--The New-Haven Journal says: A very voluminous report, containing a history of our State Normal School, and one or two recapitulations of the same history, as well as the previous annual reports, has been published by order of the Legislature.

The New-Brunstcicker says: "repeated refusals of the most peremptory character have at various times been given by the United States Government to the formal applications made by the British Minister at Washington, for permission to British subjects to fish on the southern coasts of the Union.

In the DAILY TIMES of the 4th of June we published a very fall summary of a letter addressed by Governor LANE to the Commissioners of the State of Chibuahua, in vindication of his seizure of the Mesilla Valley. The document itself has since reached us and will be found, retraslated from the Spanish by a City contemporary, in another part of this morning's TIMES.

Judge Livingston, of the Fifth District Court, New-Orleans, recently made a decision of great interest to steamboats navigating the Western rivers. Action was brought by Harkness Son against Church, owner and master of the steamer Bulletin No. 2, to recover the value of a quantity of merchandise shipped to New-Orleans, and thence on the Bulletin No. 2 to Napoleon, Arkansas.

The Fourth Anniversary of Bunker Hill Chapter No. 27, O. U. A., took place at the Tabernacle last evening. Considering the unpropitious state of the weather, the attendance was very good. The building was ornamented with the National colors, while a silken embroidered banner, bearing the title and date of the Institution of the Chapter, was suspended in front of the rostrum.

Rev. R. R. GURLEY, who was present at the embarkation (on the 10th)of one hundred and thirty-four colored emigrants for Liberia, states to us the following particulars. The outfit of these emigrants was under the direction of the Secretary of the American Colonization Society, Rev . WM. M' LAIN.

From the Universal of Mexico. "Our readers are already aware of the General LANE, Governor of New Mexico, who solemnly declared the territory of Mesilla, State of Chihuahua, to be part of the United States.

The season is firing up for the "Fourth." Not alone the thermometer, but other sky rockets of excitable temperaments. Youngsters are on the look out for stray pence, and ply you with killing affection to effectuate their mercenary ends. The match has been applied to their patriotic fusses, and they will continue in a state of slow combustion until the final burst of the "Fourth."

We have arrived at that season of the year when our immense Levee has become relieved from the enormous and weightly piles of produce, which the Valley of the Mississippi and our own soil has emptied upon its banks.

Persons at a distance from New-York may now feel assured, that the Crystal Palace Exhibition will prove the most interesting and attractive affair which our country has ever witnessed. No one can reasonably expect it to equal the great London display.

The Diario de la Marina reports a constant influx of the Orientals into Cuba, where all the immigrants find immediate employment. The contractors are supported and encouraged in the business of transportation by the Briish Government.

Secretary DOBBIN has returned from the South. During his late visit to North Carolina, a public dinner was tendered him by the citizens of Wilmington, but he declined it, on account of pressing engagements at Washington.

One of the hardest lessons for a countryman to learn on taking up his quarters in the City, is, that economy is not the same thing here as there. It takes several seasons for him to learn that what there would have been extravagance and waste, here is really thrift.

The Editor of the La Grange Reporter, while on a visit to Griffen, saw one day a mammoth mule, Henry Clav, five years old, nineteen and a half bands high, weighing 2,200 pounds; the model bog, Sam Houston, two years and nine months old, weighing 920 pounds; and lastly, the wonder of the world in the person of a living skeleton negro, Wade Hampton. five feet high thirty years old, and weighs only thirty pounds.

I have been spending some hours agreeably enough in strolling through the Exhibition Rooms of the Boston Athenaeum, where you find an excellent collection of paintings and sculptures. These consist--the paintings especially--of the productions of foreign artists and the independent or copied performances of Americans.

From the Philadelphia Ledger. The correspondence between Governor LOWE and Governor BIGLER, relative to the surrender of McCREARY, the kidnapper of the PARKER girls in Chester County, shows that Governor LOWE assumes to decide whether McCREARY is guilty or not, the fact which was to be tried in this State by a Jury.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The package of the TIMES containing the three first days of the week, and sent by the Wednesday British steamers, rarely reaches us. The package containing the three last days, and sent by the Saturday American steamers, always reaches us. Be so good as to send hereafter the whole week by the Saturday boats, Collins, Bremen, and Havre lines. In this way we shall get them all.

From all quarters we hear of insect ravages. In Maine, whose armies of black caterpillars are eating the oak forests. In Hartford a yellowish green caterpillar is stripping the maples of their foliages--some look as here as in Spring. the Hessian fly is said to be committing great ravages in the wheat fields of Virginia.

FRANCONI'S HIPPODROME.--A "gorgeous and astounding pageant" will be produced here this afternoon and evening. It is described by the managers as a new, grand historical spectacle, arranged from the French of MOLIERE, and is intended to realise the famous fete given by LOUIS XIV. before three Queens.
An interesting report on the Fisheries in the Gulf of the St. Lawrence by Capt. FORTIN, of the coast-guard schooner Alliance, has been published by order of the Canadian Legislative Assembly.

Various rumors have been afloat in reference to the final disposition of the body of ARTHUR SPRING, and the following paragraph in a morning paper has created some excitement: MISSING.--It is currently reported that the body ARTHUR SPRING was not interred, as requested by his son, but upon the coffin being opened, it was found to certain nothing but a log of wood.

A correspondent of the Evening Post, in a letter dated the 13th inst., refers to certain transactions reflecting severely upon the honesty of the late Administration, because of what certainly appears to be very doubtful proceedings of a late Collector at San Francisco.
NAVAL--Commander HENRY ENGLE of the Navy, was ordered by the Department to report himself at Norfolk on the 15th inst., where he takes command of the United States was steamer Princeton.

The Governor of Wisconsin has been engaged very extensively in vetoing of late. We are not vouchsafed his reasons,. though his Message was well stocked with them. It would be gratifying to know on what grounds the late one of the list was grounded.

In the recent critique of the TIMES on the American Almanac, not withstanding the amount of gross blundering which it exposed, one of the most extraordinary errors was left unnoticed. It pertains to the Lunar Eclipse of the present month. According to the Almanac, the eclipse occurs Monday, June 20, a little afternoon, invisible in the United States, but visible in South America.

HUDSON BRIGADE.--ANNUAL INSPECTION AND REVIEW.--Yesterday this Brigade, under the command of Brigadier-General, E R. V. WRIGHT, passed its annual Inspection and Review. The parade took place near Bergen Five Corners, in the town of Hudson.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your attention is respectfully called to the question, Can builders and other employing men at work outdoors, arrange their hours of labor during the Summer, so as to avoid the present terrible risk of life?

In 1804, Rucl Warriner of Agawam, Mass. then a lad of tender years, found a box turtle in the woods in Agawam, which he caught and after carving his own initials and the year upon the shell led him at large again. Twice since, at long intervals, and yesterday for the third time has Mr. Warriner fallen in with his early acquaintance.

The bark Argentine, from Montevideo, May 1, arrived at Salem yesterday afternoon, bringing later advices from Buenos Ayres. Commander COE, of ERQUIZA'S squadron, had ?? the Foreign Ministers and Commanders of vessels-of-war, that he should blockade the port of Buenos Ayres immediately, allowing vessels in the inner roads 6 days, and in the outer roads 20 days, to finish loading their cargoes.

Memorials and Correspondence of Charles James Fox: edited by Lord JOHN RUSSELL. If we were a great man, we should obtest all the suprenal powers to save our memory from Lord JOHN. His treatment of defunct excellence is most disastrous.

At a late meeting of the French Academy, M. Boussingault read an interesting memoir upon the determination of the quantity of amonia contained in spring and river water. M. Barral recently ascertained that rain water contained, on an average four milliemes of ammonia per quart, and it was natural to conclude that the same result would be obtained by analysing river and spring water.

HOW TO MAKE MONEY FAST AND HONESTLY.-Enter into a business of which you have a perfect knowledge. In your own right, or by the aid of friends on long time, have a cash capital sufficient to do, at least, a cash business, Never return on a credit business on commencement.

This has been a week of animation in this city. The Legisl.ature, Circuit Court, arll the FIriends' yearly meeting, have been in session at the same time, and each have had a busy time of it. The Legislatuire closed its session last night by an adjournment to Septemlber next.

The case of W. H. GREENE against the officer who seized his liquor under the law which the Court declared to be unconstitutional, was decided to day, in the Circuit Court, sitting at New-port--the verdict being for the plaintiff, damages $10, which does not carry costs.

FROM HAYVI.--We have Haytian advices to the 18th May. General tranquility prevailed in the Island, and military preparations on the part of both the belligerent powers were suspended. The yellow fever has subsided, and Port-au-Prince is healthy. The coffee crop is light, and the exports will be inferior to those of last year.

A BAD PRECEDENT.--Every one of the Judges of every one of the Territories has been removed for no cause assigned but his political preference, and their places have been supplied by Judges of the President's own way of thinking.

The Penitentiary Hospital, though dealing in general diseases, and containing within its wards cases of almost "all the ills that flesh is heir to," is more particularly appropriated to the care and cure of venereal diseases. It is the Syphilitic Hospital of New-York, and has come to be known as such.

The Directors of the Michigan Southern and Northern Indiana Railroad have declared a dividend of 7 per cent for the last six months, payable the 5th of July. They have also determined to issue to the stockholders, at par, 50 per cent, of new stock, for the purpose of constructing the air line road from Toledo to Goshen, which they have put under contract.

THE REMOVAL OF THE SIOUX.--His Excellency, GOV. GORMAN, is now absent on a tour to the country designated for the residence of the Lower Sioux, and some of the principal Chiefs and Braves accompany him, for the purpose of making locations for their future residence.

The never-ending disputes regarding the body of the murderer Spring, have taken a new shape. The Bulletin of last evening publishes a series of documents handed in by Rev. John Street, going to prove that Spring left his body to be disposed of by Mr. Street and Mr. Keasil, and that the remains were buried by them is good faith.

Dr. J. EVANS, U.S. Geologist for Oregon, is about to engage in a scientific examination of that portion of Nebraska known as the "Bad Lands." The region is rich in antediluvian remains, and various attempts have heretofore been made for a thorough investigation of its marvels, but Dr. EVANS is the first man who has received any encouragement therefor from the Government.

From the Washington Union. We gave yesterday, from a foreign source in which full reliance may be placed, a condensed chronological statement of the series of aggressions recently perpetrated by the Austrian Government upon the Swiss Confederation.

A remarkable concurrence of family misfortunes is narrated in a Vermont paper. At Fairhaven, on the 11th instant, as Mr. Cullen Hawkins was at work alone in his saw-mill, it appears that by accident he was thrown upon the log just forward of the saw.

Mr. BURKE, who presented certain resolutions in the New-Hampshire Democratic Convention, censuring President PIERCE for his course in regard to appointments, has addressed a letter to the Democrats of this State, in answer to the article which appeared in the Patriot.
MORE HORRID MURDERS.--It has become our painful duty to give an account of two, and we presume three, new murders committed in this county.

We copy, in another column, an interesting article from the Washington Union, upon the dangers which menace the Swiss Republic, from the aggressive despotism of Austria, The tone of the article is highly satisfactory.

ANCHORING FOR ANCHORS.--The ship Julius Caesar, from the Cape of Good Hope came to anchor in the stream opposite Holt's Wharf on Sunday, and on heaving up the next morning her anchor came very hard and seemed to be uncommonly heavy in coming up.

COLLATION IN A SOAP BOILER.--"DEDICATING THE KETTLE"--This ancient and honored custom was duly observed by our enterprising fellow-citizens Messrs. BOYD STREETER, Cream Soap manufacturers in this city, yesterday. The ceremony consists, in the first place, in flooring the kettle, (which in the present instance was some fifteen feet in diameter,) about five feet below the rim;

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. The steamship Yacht, arrived at New-Orleans with $124,339 in specie, and Rio Grande dates to the 4th. Unusual quiet prevailed at Brownsville, and other frontier cities. Most of the filibusters had dispersed.

The regular monthly meeting of the Association was held last evening at their rooms, in the Stuyvesant Institute, Broadway. The officers for the ensuing year, elected at the last meeting of the Association, entered upon the discharge of their respective duties.

The Annual Report of the Regents of the University has been received, and from it we obtain the following facts: In Columbia College the number of undergraduates, during the year was 112, of whom 26 were seniors, 22 juniors, 34 sophomores, and 30 freshmen. Sixteen of the students were receiving their education free from all charge of tuition.

A HEN STORY.--About the 1st of December last, one of my hens, that had "stolen her nest," hatched a brood of nine chickens; and, as they made their appearance so late in the season, it was thought they had a cheerless prospect before them, and it any of them survived the Winter, it would be at the sacrifice of sundry toes.

GREENWOOD CEMETERY FENCE STRUCK BY LIGHTNING.--During a recent storm, as we learn from the Brooklyn Eagle, the lightning descended upon the picket fense, on the southerly side of Greenwood Cemetery, but a few rode east of the lower gate. The marks left upon the fence present an instructive record.

At one of the stations a short distance out of Liverpool an interesting little girl was placed in the same carriage with me, after an inquiry by the porter that I was going all the way.

It is said that the wheat crop in Livingston County, New-York, has not looked better in five years. It is expected, if the weather continues favorable until harvest, that the yield will be five bushels per acre more this year than it was last. The fears of rust which were felt some time ago, are no longer entertained; Corn is growing fast,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I have read with interest your arguments in favor of a uniformed Police force. How long will it be that our authorities remain totally blind to its importance. No police can possess any efficiency without a regular uniform, that they may he distinguished at any and all times.

UNPROVOKED ASSAULT--On Monday, a constable of Bushwick, named McDONALD, committed an assault on a man named WM. MAHURE. The officer had seized on some furniture in Division avenue, on Friday Last, which was subsequently sold by the owner without the consent or knowledge of the constable.

We are one people. The word American--our word only--stands for a unit, that is nationalized in the hearts of our countrymen, no less than in our institutions. But the highest unity is nothing more than harmonious aggregate of diversities.

The patriot is out with nearly four columns of a bitter reply to Mr. BURKE, it charges that Mr. BURKE'S statement is mingled with "malignant falsehood" and "arrougunt threats;" it accuses him of "cowardice," and of being a "bully and asassin;" which trails it thinks he exhibited when he attucked the President through a committee in a State Convention, and failing to sustain himself before that body.

AN AMERICAN YACHT ABROAD.--The beautiful yacht Silvic, of 405 tons burden, owned by LEWIS A. DEPEAU, Esq., of locust Island, Westchester, sailed from the harbor of New Rochelle on Saturday last, for England, under the command of Captain COMSTOCK, for the purpose of contending for the prize at the yacht race off Cowes, on Tuesday, the 2d of August next.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Permit me, a Virginian, and an advocate for truth, to comment on "A Prarcan's" eulogy on Garland's Life on John Randolph, published in your paper of the 20th of the last month.

We commence this morning the publication of a somewhat extended notice of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," a hook which has been more widely read and more generally noticed already than any other over issued in this country, but which still has a fresh and profound interest for every class of readers, and in every section of the country.

If Common Sense were an article to be bought in the Market, doubtless there would be a great demand for it; or if not, it would be well for the Corporation to make an appropriation from the public moneys to buy up a lot, from which the needy night draw without any charge.

The natural Salt Ponds on the Florida Keys. which in 1840-'50 yielded about 75,000 bushels of Salt, have been, during the last Winter, greatly improved and extended, so that the evaporating surface is now 600 acres and will soon be increased to 800. During the Winter the ponds have contained pickle suffcient to make 500,000 bushels of salt,

The time has come for a calm review of Mrs. HARRIET BERCHER STOWE'S book,--a book which has attracted so much attention, both at home and abroad. It is quite clear that the review must come from the South.

JOHN B. GOUGH, the well-known advocate of Temperance, has been invited by the London Temperance League to visit England. The following is his reply: SOMERVILLE,(State of New Jersey,) May 14, 1853. DEAR SIR--Agreeable to our arrangements I shall leave Boston, Providence permitting,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: Allow me to felicitate you on your safe return from Europe. That you are well, in mind at least, I need not ask--your charming leader, "The Art-Union Inquest," in the TIMES of this day, is ample evidence.

It is generally known that the Recorder of the City has been engaged for some time past in taking testimony Concerning alleged abuses on the part of various members of our City Government, We learn from good authority, that in the process of this inquiry, a legal point of a good deal of importance has recently been decided by the Recorder.

Now the apothecary's apprentice, with a bitterness beyond aloes, thinks of the pond he used to bathe in at school.

The following replay by Mr. WEBSTER, to an invitation to attend a celebration of the Temperance cause in Harford County, Maryland, is published in a volume of personal reminiscences and sketches, by F. W. THOMAS, Esq., the Well-Known author of Clinton Bradshaw, which has just been issued by Mr. HART, of Philadelphia.

QUIET ON THE RIO GRANDE.--We learn from the Brownsville Flag, of the 1st instant, that Rio Grande City, Roman and in fact all the towns along the line, have become remarkably quiet since the recent arrests on that frontier.

To-day (June 17) is the anniversary of the battle of Bunker Hill. The scene has been often described, but fresh details of it will ever be of interest, and more especially such contemporary statements as give a view of the times. In preference to reflections on the day, or a narrative of its events, we present a letter written by Mr. WINTHROP to JOHN ADAMS. It is copied entire, and has never been printed:

Hon. EDMOND BURKE, formerly Commissioner of Patents, and who, it will be recollected, was Chairman of the recent Democratic State Convention, has addressed a letter to the Democracy of New-Hampshire, in answer to the covert attacks of the Patriot and of some of the prominent politicians of his party, and in defence of the resolutions in relation to the Presidential appointments recently rejected by the Gubernatorial Convention.
From the Washington Union. A considerable portion of the public press has given circulation, if not some degree of credence, to strange rumors, apparently emanating from Cuba.

This was Executive day in the Senate, and some Notaries were confirmed. Mr. CONGER made a report on a nomination from a Committee, of which Mr. COOLEY is a member, without having consulted the latter gentleman, which procured Mr. CONGER a scoring in Mr. COLLEY'S accustomed unsparing style.

In a notice, a day or two since, of the grand arrangements for exhibition at the Crystal Palace, the American Department was briefly alluded to, for the purpose, merely, of indicating the place assigned it in the Exhibition. The subject is of sufficient importance and interest to justify a remark or two in addition to what we then said.

The President has been quite ill for two days past. The Cabinet meeting was omitted yesterday, and the public reception to-day, in consequence. He is not confined to his bed, however; and Learn at the White House, to-night, that his health is improving.

The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool, on Saturday, the 11th instant, arrived here at 7 1/2 o'clock this morning, bringing 110 through passengers. The Baltic arrived out off Holyhead, at 11, A. M. on Tuesday, the 7th instant, and crossed the bar of the Mersey, at seven o'clock the same evening.

If you would see, for a moment, one of tile streams in the great current which is always pouring through NewYork, go down a Summer afternoon to the North River wharves. A German emigrant ship has just made fast.

We ask the attention of the Chief of Police, or of the Commission in charge of that Department, to the communication under our City head relating to the incidents of an outrage, perpetrated near Burling-sip on Monday night last, and marked by palpable dereliction of duty on the part of the Policeman present.

The markets during the week had been dull, notwithstanding the favorable advices from America. the Eastern laws having tended to depross prices. The current qualities of American, although regular closed a shade lower on the grades under Middling, while the better qualities were supported at previous rates.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Crescent City, JOHN McGOWAN commanding, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Aspinwall on the 13th inst., bringing the mails, passengers and treasure which left San Franchises on the evening of the 24th of May in the Pacific Mail steamship Republic.

A solitary family lives upon the shore of Richardson's Lake, above the White Mountains. It consists of a man, wife, and four children. The man was formerly a Boston merchant, but not being successful in business, retired to this secluded spot seven or eight years ago.
Broadway was strewn yesterday with the carcasses of dead horses. The weather and the driving were too much for them. They struggled and fell.

Last evening, pursuant to public notice, Father GAVAZZI appeared at Metropolitan Hall, where a warm welcome was extended to him, by a very large assemblage of citizens. The reverend lecturer was received with enthusiastic demonstrations of regard. He appeared in citizen's dress--his Italian costume, which he was wont to wear on former occasions, having been torn from his back at Montreal, by his Canadian assailants.
Our City columns this morning contain some very sad evidences of the intensely hot weather which has afflicted out citizens the past day or two.

An almost universal acclaim of public commendation has greeted the instructions to Consuls, issued a few days since by the State Department, directing that class of officers to exemplify, in their official dress, the republican simplicity of the country they represent.

Mr. PIERCE asked leave to report the Niagara Ship Canal bill. Mr. BABCOCK objected. Mr. COOLEY, by consent, reported on the "Joneswood Park" bill. He says a majority of the Committee are in favor of the central location, which is considered the beat, in all respects. He recommended the bill reported yesterday by Mr. MORGAN for the Central Park.

We put in a plea a day of two ago for the acquisition of both tracts proposed for a Central park. It was shown that a slight deviation from the report of the Aldermanic Committee would enable us to embrace both within the contemplated reserve;

Our City Police has almost wholly ceased to enjoy the confidence of the community, for whose protect of it is kept in being. Setting aside the exaggerations of language concerning its worthlessness, in which every one is prompted to indulge, by the outrages which are of such frequent occurrence, very little reliance is placed by any portion of out citizens upon its efficiency. No man feels safer,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The Hudson River Railroad Company ought to take more efficient steps to distinguish their Express Train from the Way Trains. The mistake of getting on the Express Train is frequently made by strangers who desire to stop at some of the Way Stations, and who have no means of finding out the mistake, until too late.

The Massachusetts State temperance Convention met here this morning, and is very thinly attended--not more than 100 being in the Hall when the meeting was called to order. J. M. USHER, of Medford, was chosen Chairman pro tem.

We have been favored with a private view of a new panorama now in course of preparation. It is intended to depict the natural beauties of Niagara. A subject so fraught with the beautiful cannot fail to inspire the artist with more than usual enthusiasm.

The President has been in his usual health to-day. The Rochester appointments are now under consideration. The resignation of DARIUS PERRIN, Postmaster, and JAMES R. THOMPSON, Collector, have been in the hands of the President since the 1st of April.

Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER has formally accepted the Mission to China, to-day, and received his commission. The appointment will be officially announced in the Union of to-morrow. Mr. WALKER is already making preparations for an early departure. He will take the Overland route, vid England.

A party of men arrived at St Joseph on the 10th inst., from the Upper Missouri. Some of the party were from the Arrieara villages, and the remainder from Fort Union, at the month of the Yellow Stone. The Blackfeet have been more than ordinarily ferocious and troublesome for several months past.
The official proceedings of this body have been given to the public through the Memphis papers. It proved a quiet, sensible and business affair, directed by cool heads and national hearts.

The Memorial of the Committee of Management of the American Art-Union. RESPECTFULLY REPRESENTS: That at the last session of your honorable body, a petition, signed by persons professing to be interested in the affairs of the American Art Union, was presented to the Assembly, by one of the members from the City of New-York , praying for the appointment of a Committee to investigate certain charges in said petition set forth against the said Institution.

The State Whig Convention met here today, at 11 ?? o'clock, and was called to order by Mr. BARKER, of Burlington, and was subsequently organized as follows: Hon. EDWARD SEYMOUR, of Addison County, President; SAMUEL II. KELLOGG, CHARLES S DANA, and R. GLEASON, Vice Presidents; E. A. ROGERS and J. A. VAIL, Secretaries; Messrs. BENEDICT, HARRIS, WALTON, BLAISDELL, HAYDEN and BARRETT, Committee to draft Resolutions.

Van Order sworn and examined by Mr. Field--I am, by occupation, a conductor on the Eighth-avenue Railroad; could not state the largest number of passengers drawn by two horses, but think about 60 or 65; I know I have had over 60 frequently, when I came to count the money; ?? no difficulty in two horses drawing such loads,

The Panama Herald and Star bring us some items from South America. The P.S.N. Company's steamer Lima, Captain BLOOMFIELD, arrived in port with the South American mail. Her dates are: Valapraiso, May 14; Callao, May 26 She brings forty passengers, most of whom are on their way from Australia to the United States, and $160,000 in specie and silverbars.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: Can you tell me how it is such little notice should be taken of Her B. M. Frigate, the Leaner, and her officers? I think it is quite time our City Fathers should extend to them a reception worthy of our country and people

The Supreme Court of Louisiana has decided that the act of the Legislature authorizing the Police Juries and Municipal Corporations to he stock of Corporations undertaking works of internal improvement, is constitutional. The New-Orleans Picayune of the 14th inst., which reports the decision in full, remarks that the importance of the decision can hardly be over stated.

Halifax papers to the 14th inst. are received, the Morning Chronicle of that date, says on the subject of the Fisheries: " The vexed question of our fisheries is every day assuming a more interesting aspect. The fact of a British Colonial vessel having been driven off a part of the coast by a French cruizer deepens the importance of the subject.

The Buffalo Commercial Advertiser copies our strictures upon the Excise Commissioners, for the reckless manner in which they distributed liquor-licenses for the Ward in which the Crystal Palace is situated, and proceeds upon the strength of it to denounce the proposed Exhibition as a stupendous humbug. Non sequitur.

The Bourse, at this moment, is like a blacksmith's bellows--one day it draws a monstrous inhalations, and the next exhausts itself of air, Monday it takes a fall, healthy breath, and Tuesday it has the death rattle in its throat; Wednesday its lungs are again inflated, and Thursday they are like a pricked bladder. The process of distension is renewed on Friday, to be followed again, on Saturday, by another escape of the oxygen.

Our accounts from Europe by the Halifax steamer, exhibit the same ambiguous character in regard to the Turke-Russian issue, as those by the Humboldt.

A correspondent writes to the Albany Evening Journal that the body of G. L. Houston, and Albanian, was lately found on the Cattaraugus Reservation, in Erie county, one mile from the mouth of Cattaraugus Creek, with his throat cut. A coroner's inquest was held Sunday. Verdict, that he came to his death by his own hands.

The Canal bills were taken up in Committee of the Whole. The question being on the amendment of Mr. VANDERBILT, to amend the Canal revenue certificate bill by carrying the appropriation for interest to 1855. Adopted, by 12 to 10--and the bill was reported to the Senate.

SHIP WILLIAM AND MARY.--Four of the crew and twenty-three of the passengers of the ship William and Mary, lost on the Bahama Banks on her passage from Liverpool to New-Orleans, arrived at Liverpool on the 6th inst, in the British bark Pollock, from New-Orleans. They were the potion that escaped in the long boat, and reported taken on board a British bark.

SUICIDE BY CHILDREN.--A few days ago a lad, named HENRY HAVILL, aged 12 years, son of an agricultural laborer, residing at Rockbeare, in Devonshire, was found hanging to the bough of an elm tree quite dead. It appeared from the evidence adduced at the inquest, that the lad worked for the Rev. J. ELLIOTT in his fields, and that he was occasionally in the habit of sleeping at the Rev. gentleman's house.

The Charleston papers record the death of Dr. JOHN W. SCHMIDT, who, with one exception, was the oldest practicing physician in that city, having commenced his profession in Charleston in the year 1805. He had filled various offices of trust in the municipal affairs of the city and the Legislature.

It is a World's Fair that is to be opened in the Crystal Palace on the fifteenth of July; and the world means to see it as it should. Not that all the world will be there--the beautiful building scareely accommodate them.

SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--A special meeting of the Board of Alderman was held at the Clerk's Office, yesterday afternoon, at 4' clock nine members present--F. B. BETTS, President of the Board, in the Chair.

The people of Continental Europe are not, by their ignorance, so unfitted for Republican Institutions as is commonly supposed. Our ideas of their intelligence originated from a knowledge of the intellectual condition of the English, and from believing that, of transatlantic peoples, the British are the most enlightened as well as the most free, or, rather, as the least enslaved.

MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--The Board held a meeting at the Lyceum on Tuesday evening. There was a full attendance. The resolution adopted by the Board of Education, asking that $3,000 be raised for the purpose of altering Public School No. 1, was received, and referred to the Committee on Schools.

Ardent as our aspirations for the good fortune of Mr. PIERCE'S Administration may be, it is impossible to view some of its circumstances without alarm. It is surrounded with grave questions. Some of them involve consequences reaching away to tile remotest future of the Republic; defining its possible limits, and affording precedents which time must render potent for good or mischief.

On Thursday, June 23, after a severe illness, MARY FRASER widow of the late James Fraser, of Wales. The friends of the Family and her son-in-law, M. C. Edy, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at St. George's Church Astoria, at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

HOW A CHAIRMAN WAS ELECTED.--At the first meeting of our newly-elected County Commissioners for Middlesex County, it became necessary to choose a chairman. It will be recollected that the Board is composed of D. S. RICHARDSON, Whig; LEONARD HUNTRESS, Free Soiler; and JOHN K. GOING, Democrat.

The Vermont Democratic State Convention was held here to-day--Hon. D. P. NOYES, of Burlington, President. The Nominating Committee reported the following names as candidates for State officers: Hon. JOHN S. ROBINSON, of Bennington, for Governor; JEFFERSON P. KIDDER, of West Randolph, for Lieutenant-Governor; J. A. PAGE, of Montpelier, for Treasurer.
Three school-boys, sons of Col. WALTER BOWIE RICHARD MULLIKEEN, and HASWELL MAGRUDER, of Prince Georgre's County, Md, were drowned on Monday last, while bathing in the Patuxent River.

The Canal receipts during the 21st and 22d inst., at this place, were as follows 36,000 bbls, of Flour 3.000 bbls Pork; 10,000 bushels Corn 14,0000 bashels Oats; 39,000 bushels Wheat; 600,000 lbs. of Bacon.

Much sickness is prevailing in the city. Among those who are down to-day, are Postmaster General CAMPBELL, Col. FORNEY, and Mr. EAMES of the Union. Senator SLIDELL arrived here to-day, in route for Europe.

SUCCESSFUL WHALERS.--The Whalemen's Last says. The bark favorite, Capt. PIERCE, just arrived at Fairhaven, from a three years' cruise has made one of the most profitable voyages one record. The total amount of her catching in 1,300 barrels whale, 330 barrels sperm oil, and 72,000 pounds of bone.

We commence on our second page this morning, the publication of a series of articles, which we commend to the attention of our readers and exchanges in the country. The indications are unmistakeable, that hundreds of thousands of persons, from every section of the United States, will visit the Metropolis this Summer, who have never been here before.

Elsewhere in this morning's TIMES, will be found the report of the Senate Committee, in favor of the Up-town Park. The bill referred to the Committee, was the one passed by the Assembly authorizing the purchase of Jones' Wood. For that measure the Committee is decided.

EGYPTIAN ANTIQUITIES.--The Museum of Egyptian Antiquities now on exhibition of Stayvesant Institute, is certainly one of the most interesting collections ever brought to this country. Mr. ABBOTT, the proprietor, has devoted more than twenty years to the object of this selection, peculiar circumstances (not the least of which was a fixed residence in the East.) enabled the ?? to pressure many rare and valuable religious of the past.
We have endeavored, as nearly as possible, to ascertain the daily expeases of the Legislature, applicable as well to the regular as to the extra session. The are about as follows:

On Tuesday, at Albany, the Coroner was called to hold an inquest on the body of a German, named John Shoemaker, who recently resided on the Schenectady Turnpike, in the second house West of the Orphan Asylum. About a fortnight since a portion of his family and furniture was removed to Utica.

NAVAL.--A detacment of U.S. seamen, under the command of Lieut. RING, arrived her Sunday afternoon, in the steamship Roanoke, from New-York. WM. BURNICE, Gunner U.S. Navy, has been ordered to the Navy Yard at Pensacola, vice JOHN MARTIN, waiting orders.

RUSSIA.--Two divisions of the fourth corps of the Army are at a certain distance from the Pruth. The third corps has scarcely quitted the Polish frontier, At St. Petersburg, June 4, there was sufficient uneasiness to cause general dullness in the markets.

POPULATION OF THE PRINCIPAL CITIES IN EUROPE AND NORTH AMERICA.--The Boston Transcript compiles from WEBER'S "Volks' Calendar," (People's Almanac,) for 1853, published annually at Leipsic, the following table of the population of the largest Cities in Europe and North America.

Sundry statements have recently appeared respecting the non-reception by William Sydney Smith of the plate presented to him by the citizens of Mobile, and the non-payment of the duties on that presented to him by the citizens of New-Orleans, and shipped to England.

Twelve years ago, geographers knew not of the pleasant spot called Tulipton. Blankness was upon the map where it should have been, and its bay gave back no shadow save those of the seagull and the deer.

The Morning Express train from New-York for Boston via New-Haven, met with a serious accident this afternoon, at East Brookfield. It seems the switch was misplaced, and the passenger train ran off the track, coming in collision with a freight train standing on a side track, smashing two freight cars, these baggage cars, and four passenger cars, fully--throwing the passengers from their seats, and creating an awful confusion.

The Minnesota Pioneer makes very light of the curious rumors going about the country, to the effect that several thousand Chippe was are collecting in the vieinity of the Falls of St. Croix, for the purpose of attempting a hostile demonstration against St. Paul and other towns.
