ATTACK ON A COLORED CHURCH. --On Tuesday evening, about 11 o'clock, a wanton attack was made on W. P. HODGES' Colored Church, Nos. 266 and 268 South-sixth-street, by a party of 59 colored persons known as the Kelley Guards, named after, and enjoying the immediate partronage of a Philadelphia outlaw, who keeps a Porter-House in that vermity, and headed by a colored loafer named STEPHENS.

In the Criminal Court of Washington City, on Thursday, a case of more than ordinary interest was disposed of , under peculiarly affecting circumstances, which are thus stated in the Republic. On that day Judge CRAWFORD overruled a motion for a new trial of DANIEL T. WOODWARD, who on Thursday, the 9th inst., was convicted of killing his wife, by shooting her on the 24th of December last.

A letter from ELIHU BURRITT, is reference to Ocean Penny Postage, says: A fact was stated, some time since, by two respectable captains of American sailing ships, which seems to supply an answer to a recent inquiry of the London Times, and to the declaration of Lord ABERDEEN.

EIGHTEENTH WARD, N. Y., near Madison-square. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. We have been so entirely dependent on you for all the information we have, that we feel quite forsaken, now we have lost the EVENING TIMES. The latest dates from below the City Hall were Friday evening, June 18.

DEDICATION OF A CHURCH.--The Fleet-street Methodist ?? Church was dedicated yesterday afternoon, with appropriate exercises. This Society was organized about two years since, and erected a large Chapel on the let adjoining the new ??, an Fleet-street, and now the Society have completed a commdious buildings of brick, at ?? about $21 000, all of which but a small has been past for.

Still another accident on the NewHaven Railroad is reported. Yesterday, the morning Express Train, from this City, ran off the track at East Brookfield, Conn., damaging nearly a dozen cars, and causing the death of one man and serious injury to a number of persons.

The Select Committee, (the Senator from the First District dissenting,) to which was referred, with power to report complete, the bill from the Assembly, entitled "An act relative to the purchase, possession and laying out of certain lands for a public park in the Nineteenth Ward of the City of New York, and the powers and duties of the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty relative thereto,"

BOWDOIN PRIZES.--The Cambridge Chronicle says that the Bowdoin prizes at Harvard College for the present year have been awarded as follows. TO ADAMS SHERMAN HILL, of the Senior Class, first prize of $10, for ?? dissertation upon "HEROPOTUS and THERVIDES compared as Historians:"

The Maine Law, which has been under discussion for three days, was this forenoon defeated in the House of Representatives. An amendment, striking out all after the enacting clause, and in setting a bill giving town and city authorities power to license, was adopted, by the casting vote of the Speaker. The bill, this amended, was this after noon adopted, by a vote of 108 to 98.

R. AUGUSTUS EWING, of Connectient, for some years past private Secretary to Governor SEYMOUR, of that State, has been appointed Secretary of Legation to Russia. The President has entirely recovered from his recent indisposition.

SUN STROKES.--A man named DANIEL McNAMARA, residing in "Jackson's Hollow," was prostrated with the heat Wednesday, and is not expected to recover. Another man in Furman-street was so severely affected that he cannot live. He was taken to the Hospital.

The Australian Intelligence, by way of California, is not as late as we had before received. By way of Panama we have Melbourne dates to March 23, 18 days later, The Panama Star farnishes us several interesting items:

THINGS IN MONTEVIDEO.--A telegraphic announcement of the Montevidean news was given yesterday. A letter since received in this City, says: "Flour is selling at $10 06 per barrel. A few day's previous, a cargo sold for $17. Prices had declined in consequence of the news of the blockage of the port of Buenos Ayers.
This Court commenced its June term at the Capitol, in Albany, this morning. Present--Ruggles, Chief Judge; Gardiner, Jewett, Johnson, Morse, Willard, Mason, and Taggart, Judges.

If a man violates the laws of nature and of health, he very properly expects to suffer for it. If he commits some gross violation, and and is none the worse for it, he grows skeptical about the penalty, does it again, and learns at last by experience what he would not learn from a cheaper teacher.

COLONIZATION.--The Legislative Committee on Colonization, of which Mr. OLMSTED, of this city, is Chairman, has made a report fully endorsing the scheme of emigration, and recommending a State appropriation of $1,000, to assist colored inhabitants of this State, who wish to go to Liberia.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The communication of "A Stranger," in Thursday's TIMES, reminds us of the admonition, "Be sure you are right, then go ahead" Yesterday morning, at Hudson, a gentleman and his wife were separated by taking opposite trains; the lady, to her surprise, found herself in Albany.

CONSEQUENCES OF RAILROAD ACCIDENTS.--At the recent term of the Essex Common Pleas Court, according to the Lowell Courier, an indictment against a Railroad company for an accident which resulted in the death of Mr. NEWELL of Lawrence failed to come to trial, on account of the want of testimony, caused by the death of Dr. PIERSON, of Salem who was among the victims of the melancholy calamity at Norwalk.

SUN-STRECK.--Miss RUSH, a young lady employed in THRUSHY'S Rope-walk, was prostrated by the Sun on Wednesday. A man employed in Mr. COOPER'S Glue Factory, at Bushwick, was prostrated by the same cause, yesterday. MICHAEL ROHAN, a laboring man, residing in First-street near North Second street, was conveyed home in an insensible condition, yesterday, from the effects of heat.

THE BROADWAY RAILROAD CASE.--SUPERIOR COURT.--Before Hon. Judge DUER.--Wm. J. Stewart was called by Mr. Field, and testified to the general benefit which be considered would result from the proposed railroad; he believed would result from the proposed railroad; he believed that the facility for turning a vehicle in Broadway would be much greater than under the present of state of things. gs.

GEROGIA.--Hon. HERSCHEL V. JOHNSON, State Rights' Democrat, has been nominated as the Democratic candidate for Governor of the State of Georgia. The vote in the nominating convention stood, on the first ballot: for H. V. Johnson, 129;

We mentioned, a few days since, that the Recorder, in the course of his investigation into alleged malpractices of members of the City Government, had decided that an attempt to bribe a public officer was a crime at common law,--and that a witness could not be compelled, therefore, to answer any question that would criminate himself.

THE NEGRO PLOT IN NEW-ORLEANS.--Further developments in relation to the New-Orleans negro plot have reached us--New Orleans dates being received to the 18th inst. The papers have full reports of the examination of the arrested parties. The following from the Delta contains all that is important:

The San Francisco Herald, of the 26th ult., which reached us yesterday, contains the following account of the progress of the rebellion in China, from which it would appear that the repulse of the insurgents at Nankin was not unattended with slaughter. The reports of twenty thousand killed, are, or course, apocryphal, and the whole story lacks confirmation. We give it, however, as received :

An election is to be held this fall for members of the City Government, under the amended Charter. The Evening post a few days since, strongly urged the Reform Committee, appointed at the great meeting at Metropolitan hall, not to venture upon the nomination of candidates for that election, but to leave the choice of City officer exclusively in the hands of the two great political parties.

A telegraphic error yesterday caused us to attribute an accident to the New-Haven Railroad, which really belonged to the account of the Western Railroad. East Brookfield, the locality of the catastrophe, is sixty-four miles from Boston . The accident was wholly owing to the negligence of the switchman.

June 16, by Right. Rev. Bishop Wainwright, Rev. ROBERT S. HOWLAND to Miss MARY E. W. WOOLSEY, daughter of the late Charles Woolsey, Esq. June 22, at Bowdoin square Church, Boston, by Rev. Mr. WIRES, Mr. S. M. PETTENGILL, of New York, to Miss SARAH H. KENDALL, daughter of Joshua Kendall, of Boston.

To the Editor of the New -York Daily Times; While the centre of population of New-York has been steadily moving northward, our bay and river steamers have very generally stuck to their old stations at the lower piers of city.

On the 9th of May Monsignor CAJETAN BEDINI, Archbishop of Thehes, former Commissary Extraordinary of the Pontificial Government to the Legations, left Rome as Special Envoy of his Holiness to the United States. At our latest advices Monsignor BEDINI was in Paris.

The Ten Hour bill was under debate for a long time. Mr. WARD moved to recommit the bill. A portion of the bill met his approbation, but he apprehended that if we should pass the provision, making ten hours a laborer's day, it would have the practical effect to encourage idleness.

The venerable General Association of the Congregational Ministers of Connecticut, one of the oldest ?? organizations in the country, has been holding its annual session in this thriving and beautiful village, fully attended, and intensely absorbed with matters of exciting interest and grave importance. Promptly,

The University at Urbana, O., is established and is to be sustained by the disciple of Emanuel Swedenberg. This is the first educational establishment in the country, of the rank of a University, devoted to the propagation of Swedenborgianism. Prof. J. W. Jenk, of Boston, and Prof. M. G. Williams, of Urbana, are to be inaugurated into office. A female department has been established in connection with the college.

ALLEGED LIBEL.--Yesterday morning the proprietor of ?? Hall, in Broadway, named Stophen Rates, appeared before justice Osborn, at the Lower Police Office, and preferred a large of libel against N. R. Simpson and D. C. Curtis, editors and proprietors of the Day Book.
On Thursday, June 23 at her residence in New-Brunswick, N. J., after an illness of four days, Mrs. PHEBE VAN NEST, relict of the late Rev. Dr. Eli Baldwin, in the 53d year of her age.

Before Chief Justice OAKLEY.--Sitting at Nisi Prius.--More Trouble--The petty Jury empanneled in this court, and whose term of service expires this week, made the following presentment, in writing, to Chief Justice OAKLEY:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I have observed in your excellent journal, of late, several articles upon the Police of this City. It is, undoubtedly, your desire to describe correctly, and to advise judiciously; but it is very easy to arrive at wrong conclusions when we start from false premises. You will pardon me,

The following is the order of exercises for class day at Harvard College, Friday, June 24; 1. Music; 2. Prayer, by the President; 3. Oration, by Adams Sherman Hill. Worcester; 4. Music; 5. Poem, by Elbridge Jefferson Cutler, Holliston; 6. Ode, by Charles Carroll, Cambridge. Exercises in the Chapel commence at 12, M. chapel is open for ticket holders at 11 A. M., and for the public at 11.45.

The Cabinet held a long Session to-day. There is a rumor about that European affairs, and especially those of Russia and Turkey, were the subject of discussion. This is positively a great error; foreign affairs were not broached. Secretary MARCY did not attend the meeting, but was busily employed all day in preparing instructions to our Foreign Ministers.

FROM SINGAPORE -- We have accounts from Singapore to the 15th April. The Cholera has disappeared; a fact ascribed by the Malays to the incessant invocations of Allah, which they had kept up overy evening for about ten days previous.

The Steamship Northern Light, Capt. THOS. MINER, arrived yesterday morning from San Juan, with the passengers from San Francisco by the Brother Jonathan, and the news to June 1. We are indebted to Mr. N. F. HEDOES Esq., Parser, BERFORD Co.'s Express, and J. B. DEVOE, Esq., of the Placer Times and Transcript for early papers and letters.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The remarks in your paper of this morning on the Roman Catholic Bill, are wise and true. Still, as far as I have observed, the danger and illegality of that Bill are imperfectly appreciated. Many who are watching its progress with great anxiety, hope that your vigorous and truthful pen will press the real state of the case on the public and legislative attention.

The Recorder announces, on good authority, that Rev. PHILIP SCHAFF, Professor in the Mercersburg Theological Seminary, has been employed us a translator by the Baptist Bible Union. Mr. SCHAFF is a German, who has been in this country a few years, and has been the prime actor in the Phseyistic movement which has so affected the minds of the younger ministers of the German Reformed Church.

THE MISSION TO CHINA. --We understand that Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER has so far recovered from the indisposition under which he has long labored, consequent upon a slight accident watch be fell him in England, that he has concluded to accept the office of Commissioner to Coins, offered him some time since by the President, and the he will probably set out on his mission about the first of October.

We trust that our State Legislature, in its party squabbles, will not lose sight of the important bill now pending in the Assembly, for the better security of Railway travel. Castastrophes of almost daily occurrence, and often of the most appalling character, illustrate the necessity of prompt and effectual action.

At Contra Costa. on Friday, May 27, by Rev. S. B. Bell, James Leonard to Miss Margaret Connolly, both of Lower Canada. In Sacramento City, on Sunday, May 20 by Rev. B. T. Crouch, Jr., Mr. James C. Rodgers, of Wellsburg, Va., to Miss Eliza Gilbert, of Evansville, Ind.

To-day's doings in the Asembly will mark an important era in the life and history of more than one public man. Three important subjects have had attention and action there, the votes upon which will be registered elsewhere than on the Journal of the House.

The arrival of the Northern Light puts us in possession of the history of the western shores of this continent down to the night of the 1st of June There is nothing of special interest in these last leaves, and they are all the better for that Prosperous times make dull newspapers.

The quarrel between Russia and Turkey is the great question of the day. All the daily and weekly journals was eloquent in speculating upon the probabilities and events connected with it. Not a little satisfaction is evinced at the unanimity which, wonderful to say, is shown by England, France, Austria and Prussia, on the question in dispute, which is far more important than appears on the smooth fact of the Russian ultimatum.
Our Albany correspondent states that a very strong lobby influence is at work in Albany, to defeat the bill now pending for the greater security of Railroad travelers.

Upon the second page of this morning's TIMES will be found a very sensible communication upon the subject of our City Police. The writer evidently appreciates the importance of the subject, is familiar with all the difficulties which surround it, and brings a cool and common sense to the consideration of the specific measures by which a reforms can be accomplished.

ERIE AND NEW-YORK CITY RAILROAD.--This road, we learn from the Chautanque Democrat, is being prosecuted vigorously, and will be speedily constructed. It is the design of the Directors to have a portion of the road completed by the 1st of January next. Thus far the people along the line,
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Permit me, in answer to H. C. GRIFFITHS, to corroborate your statement respecting the non-admission of "Foreigners" in the British Dock-Yards.

BILLS PASSED. In relation to the Lansingburg Plank Road Company. To facilitate the service of processes in certain cases. To authorize the Monterey and Cooper's Plains, and the Forest Valley Plank Road Companies, to borrow money.

It is stated that the family of the Earl of ELLESMERK will return England, in the Cunard steamer of this week. The frigate Leader, has already takes her departure from this port, for Halifax. The Earl himself remains, of course, to take part with the remainder of the Royal Commission, in the Opening of the New-York Exhibition. He is now, with his family, we believe, at Niagara.

The Commercial, after alluding to the evidences upon which they formed their opinion, says:

As the season for steamboat excursions in now upon us, the necessity for the most complete and through precautions against danger, cannot be too strongly impressed upon all who are in any degree responsible for their safety.

All great communities are doomed to great agitations. History delights to speak of the Guelphs and the Ghibellines; tile Mentagues and the Capulets; the Yorks and the Lancasters; the Catholics and the Huguenots. The pages of the poet and the folios of the sage, have been inspired with the fierce struggles of these various factions.

Solomon, in his beautiful song, says: "Let us go forth into the field; let us lodge in the villages. Let us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish; weather the tender grape appear and the pomegranates bud forth."

The oscillations of suspense are much more strongly felt by our neighbors, the French, than by ourselves, and accordingly we were prepared for the violent alternations of hope and apprehension on the Eastern question which are conveyed to us from day to day by the telegraph from Paris.

THE CANADIAN RIOTS--The Montreal Gazette, discussing the recent riots, says: "We have always deprecated the resort to the military, so common in this country, in cases of partial disturbance. The military are not trained to the work of putting down a row among parties of civilians.

The good man has gone. A dispatch received this morning, by his family, announces that Rev. Dr. SHARP last evening, at 7 o'clock, at the residence of ROBT. P. BROWN Esq., in Stoneley, a village about six miles from Baltimore, where he had gone, hoping that a change of climate and scenery. might be of benefit to his fast failing health. The deceased was 69 years of age on the 25th of December last.

The perils of the Budget may be said to have boon surmounted on Monday evening, when the Income Tax finally passed, nearly as originally proposed by Mr. GLADSTONE, thus setting the seal to his reputation as a financier.
We copy in another column, from the London Times, a very surly growl from some irate John Bull, about the Crystal Place Exhibition. Ill-nature is the Principal characteristic of this effusion.

The Georgia Whig State Convention assembled and elected General JOHN W. A. SANFORD, Union Democrat, President. One hundred and thirty seven delegates were present, representing fifty-two counties. CHARLES J. JENKINS, of Richmond County, was nominated for Governor, on the first ballet. The convention adopted the principles of the Union Convention of 1850.

In the House of Lords, on the evening of the 14th, Lord BEAUMONT rose to move for a copy of the correspondence respecting the law of the State of South Carolina on colored scamen arriving in their ports.
At 2 o'clock on Sunday evening, June 26, after a short illness in the 36th year of his age, PATRICK MURPHY. His friends and acquaintances, and those of his brother

The New-Orleans papers of Sunday last are received. The heat was intense in that city. A synopsis of SANTA ANNA'S new Mexican Tariff is published. The following ports are declared open to foreign commerce: On the Gulf of Mexico--Sisal, Campeachy, San Juan, Baritista de Tabasco, Vera Cruz, Tampico de Tamaulipas, and Matamoras.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT AT THE HIPPODROME.--On Friday evening, about ten minutes previous to the commencement of the performances at the Hippodrome, an accident occurred which may be attended with fatal results. It appears that in the course of the pica called the "Fates of Variailles, it is necessary for three or four of the ballet dancers to issue from a little alcove rear one of the fountains; there is a passage underground communicating with it.

We have papers from Galveston to the 10th instant. There are now in the field eight Democratic candidates for the office of Governor. Although the opportunity seems decidedly tempting for a Whig to step forward and appropriate to himself gubernatorial honors in Texas, the Austin State Gazette hopes none will be so ungenerous as to make the attempt.

Causes No. 237, 167, 196, 17, 165, 61, 1032, 40, 54, 88, 91 and 179 respectively, struck off, by consent. Nos. 86 and 245 exchanged by consent. No. 9 Beckwith, respondent, against the President, , of the Union Bank, N. Y., appellants; submitted. Henry E. Davies,. Counsel.

A bill abolishing capital punishment passed the Senate today. it substitutes solitary confinement, with a provision that the convict shall not be pardoned unless new evidence of his innocence transpires.

THIRD DAY. Rev. Mr. GULLIVER, From the Committee on Apportionment of Representation, introduced a report, altering the basis, so as to give to each District Association, one delegate for every four ministers, provided that every Association having less than four members, should also have one delegate.

The Baltic arrived yesterday afternoon, after an unusually long passage for this season of the year. Among the passengers are Senator FOOTE of Vermont, who visited England on behalf of the Savannah and Florida Railroad, of which he is President;

The steamer Armenia, between this City and Keyport, N. J., took fire on Saturday evening while on her return trip to this City. As it was, the accident amounted to nothing; but if the boat had been less efficiently supplied with the means of meeting danger, it would have been very serious.

The following is a copy of the remonstrance presented in the State Senate against the bill for laying out a public park in the upper part of this City: To the Honorable the Legislature of the State of New-York:

Our German population turned out in great numbers this evening, to receive the visiting Musical Societies attending the grand festival. Thirty-two visiting societies from Baltimore. New-York, Boston and other sections, are expected, and most of them have arrived.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Baltic left Liverpool on Wednesday, Jan. 12, at 3 P. M. From Tory Island to Cape Race, experienced a succession of strong westerly winds and rough sea. On the 18th, 19th, 22nd and 23d inst., encountered hard gales and heavy head sea from the W. S. W. The Baltic brought the following passengers:

COMMON COUNCIL.--At a special meeting of the Common Council, held on Thursday evening, two vetons were received from the Mayor--one vetoing the resolution in respect to the public printing, and the other, a resolution respecting the granting of certain privileges to parties on North Ninth-street.

Mr. BROLAND'S arrival and probale course is the subject of much debate and querying. The Nicaragua Transit Co. and the Greytown difficulties are not completely settled. And the particular demand of the people is to know whether they belong to Nicaragua, to Mosquito, or Great Britain, or whether they are independent.

It is rumored that several removals of Clerks are to be made in the Navy Department, where prescription heretofore has generally been prescribed. ALBERT C. GREENLEAF, lately connected with the Southern Press, has been appointed Chief Clerk of the Navy Agent's Office here.

Judge ANTHONY I. BLANCHARD, a native of this City, and long a resident of Washington County, died at Salem, N. Y., on the 14th inst., at the of the oldest inhabitants of Washington County Born in New-York, on the 21st of August, 1768; a descendant of Huguenot parent age on the paternal, and of Scotch on the material side; he received his academic and professional education in his native city.

GENUINE AND SHAM PHILANTHROPY.--We cannot sufficiently admire the pious philanthropy of those excellent women who constitute the Ladies' Home Society of this City, and who have just completed and witnessed the inauguration of a House of Refuge, erected through their means, in that execrable locality, commonly called the Five Points.

The Liverpool Courier waxes excessively indignant over our account of the remarkably quick passage of the CUNARD steamer Arabia, from this port the 4th of May. The Courier remarks that "it can only say, in straight-forward language, that all that the DAILY TIMES affirms, on anonymous authority, as to the incivility on board the Arabia, is untrue."

BOARD OF HEALTH.--Monday.--Present, Alderman MORRIS.--The Second District Health Warden reported Little-street, from Water to the East River, to be in a filthy condition; also, Marshall-street, from Gold to Little-street; also, John-street, from Little to Bridge-street; also, sink of No. 12 Water-street. Usual notice to abate.

The following letter to a warm friend in this City, and who is one of our first and most influential citizens, was written by Dr. SHARP. It is, so far as is known, one of the last which the good man ever wrote. This adds new interest and value to the beautiful production. We doubt not it will be perused with avidity.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Our Legislature is actively engaged in devising ways and means to prevent accidents on Railroads; and they would do well to look to the formation of the Directors of each Road in this State.

FROM GENOA.--The correspondent of the Newark Advertiser says a new journal, the Railroad, is to be started in Genoa. One the 1st October, the line of rails which are to connect Genoa with the railways of France and the rest of Europe, will be completed to Turn, and in December it will be opened to the foot of the Alps, at the Mt. Cenis Pass;

HOW STILL IT IS! Such, Mr. Editor, was the exclamation of a lady from your good City to me the other day, as she stood in fields and looked upon the unruffled Hudson, and away over the gorge of the Highlands, over which floated a dreamy haze, just dense enough to subdue and soften, without effacing their bold and rugged outlines.

So far from being disposed to quarrel with Mrs. STOWE on account of her book, we are really pleased to see that it has attracted so much attention. We had thought that the commercial spirit was in the ascendant so decidedly, as to make it a very difficult task to touch the heart of the great world, or to make it throb with generous impulses.

The Post is indisposed to adopt the views of the Administration, with regard to the emancipation of the Cuban negroes. The ground taken by the Washington Union is opposition to the act, not simply as an act or abolition, but as part of a political scheme hostile to American interests.

From the Boston Advertiser. The Curiosity of the public has been excited, to know what explanation Captain STINSON would make of the discrepancies between his original account of the loss of the William and Mary, and the facts afterwards ascertained;

It is rumored that Government has been advised, from quarters entitled to the highest credit, of the celebration of a treaty between Spain and Mexico, for the re-annexation of the latter to the former.

SUPERIOR COURT--Before Judge DUER--the Judge called on Mr. Field to proceed, and that gentleman produced some documentary evidence consisting of various ordinances for the opening of streets on Broadway. Mr. Hilton objected to the relevancy of this evidence, but it was received by the Court.

Notes from Life, in Seven Essays: By HENRY TAYLOR.--The author of "Philip Van Artevelde" has spent half his life in profound study of SHAKSPEARE and his cotemporaries. He has become intimately familiar with their modes of thought, and falls naturally, when unguarded, into their quaint forms of expression, and grave, stately humor.

ILLINOIS STATE UNIVERSITY.--The Faculty of Instruction in this Institution embraces the following gentlemen. Rev. FRANCIS SPRINGER, A . M. President and professor of Natural Science and Political Economy. Rev. S. W. HARKEY, D. D., Professor of Theology, and also for the time being Professor or Mental Science, Belles Letters., and the German Language.

The fire on the steamer Kate Swinney is more particularly described by the St. Louis Republican, as follows: On Sunday morning last a fire was discovered in the hold of the steamer Kate Summary, a short time after she entered the mouth of the Missouri River.

EMIGRANTS FOR TEXAS.--The bark Miltiades which arrived here on the 14th inst., from Cardiff, Wales, brought over twenty emigrants an route for their new homes in the beautiful valley of the Nueces, in Western Texas. Most of them are men of means, who come with the deeds to their lands in their pockets, having purchased from Col. KINNEY'S agent in Texas.

SIR: I find in your number for February, in an article entitled, "Have we a Bourbon among us ?" several assertions respecting my father almost all of which are incorrect, and one calumnious, It is on account of this last only that I trouble you with the present communication, for the others, in themselves, would not be worth noticing.

The Leader, under Capt. KING'S command sails for Halifax, there to join the squadron under Vice-Admiral Sir GEORGE SEYMOUR; but she will probably visit this port again, at about the period appointed for opening the Exhibition, for the purpose of conveying Lord ELLESMERE home.

AMHERST COLLEGE SOCIETIES--ATHENIAN AND ALEXANDRIAN.--Many old graduates will be gratified to hear, if they have not already, that these old names have been restored to the arenas of their early forensic efforts.

BOY DROWNED.--THOMAS HOWLAND, a lad 11 years of age, while playing with his brother on the dock, foot of South Second-street, on Sunday morning, ran of the end of the dock into the water and was drowned. His body was recovered that evening, when the Coroner held an in quest. The jury rendered a verdict of death from accidental drowning.

FIRE AND ACCIDENTS.---A fire broke out at 3 o' clock Sunday morning in a block of six three-story brick buildings, on the corner of Conover and Wolcott-streets, fronting on Conover. Before the fire could be checked three of the buildings were destroyed.

THE "MAINE LAW" IN NEW-HAMPSHIRE.--A dispatch from Concord to the Journal, dated 23d inst., says: "The fate of the Liquor Bill has been sealed for this session. The House refused to take the bill from the table, this afternoon, by a vote of 131 to 114.

At the close of the late Southern Convention at Memphis, Mr. BOTTS, of Virginia, who had been delayed in reaching Memphis, by obstructions in the navigation of the Ohio, being called on, made a speech, from which we make the following extract :

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: It is still the Turkish question which keeps in suspense all the world hero. The situation is the same as it was when I wrote you my last,--the issue Still depending upon the whims of one man-the Czar.

THE ART-UNION.--The Managers of the Art-Union have petitioned the State Legislature that the evidence, on which the late Report of its Committee is presumed to have been based, may be printed for the information of the public.

DISCOURAGES ON THE LATE HON, DANIEL WEBSTER.--we believe no event has called death of the great statesman. One of our public libraries has pamphlet editions, in a permanent form, of discourses or calogies By Messrs. Bartol, King,

RESIGNATION OF JUDGE JEWEL.--Hon FREEBORN G. JEWETT has resigned his office of Justice of the Court of Appeals. The state of his health rendered retirement and repose indispensable. But for the solicitation of his associates he would have resigned in January.

Mr. E. P. WHIPPLE discoursed last evening before the Literary Societies of the University. His theme was the "Means and Conditions of Intellectual Success." The Oration was a fine pieco of reasoning, and had a great deal of common sense in it.

Our talented legislators seem In no fret to get homo. Contemptibly little farms,--very small stores,-precious little law business,--not medical practice enough to feed them, they must have had in the localities they hail from, or they would not consent to do nothing so long and arduously for three dollars a day.

Mr. WALKER'S acceptance of the Mission to China, has given unbounded satisfaction to all parties here. The veteran is already engaged, with all the ardor of youth, in preparing for his departure at the earliest possible day and hopes to sail for England by the middle of July.

FROM CENTRAL AMERICA.-Advices from Point Arenas, Costa Rica, have been received, which state that the crop of cochineal in the States of Central America, is nearly wholly destroyed by severe storms. The indigo plant had suffered immensely from the locusts, and the crop will be very small.

SHIP AMAZON AND FISHING SCHOONER JUVENILE.--We have published a statement charging the fishing schooner Javenile, of Plymouth, with illegally taking from the wreek of the British ship Amazon, ashore on Sable Island, certain articles of rigging, sails, ,

We are in the midst of very dull times, and I fear worse are coming. The present Government is down on all that comes from the United States. We shall experience unpleasant times in Monterey, under the government of General AMPUDIA, who has been appointed Commandant-General and Governor of the State of New-Leon. You are aware that he is no friend to anything American.

Night before last, says the Cincinnati Commercial, of the 21st, ten slaves, belonging to citizens of Newport, Ky., made their escape. One was the property of Robert C. Todd, Esq.; one of Mrs. Mary Winston, and the others of Dr. Parker, Several free colored persons left in company, one of them a girl named Ellen, whose two children, belonging to Col. Taylor, escaped with her;

MERCANTILE LIBRARY.--We have noticed, with pleasure, at the desk of the Mercantile Library Association, a petition in favor of the early closing of that Institution on Saturdays. The long hours of business render some relaxation necessary to the health, as well as the comfort of its employees;...

SENT DOWN.--John Mahre, Ellen Curren, and Margaret A. Grady, three of persons arrested at a house of ill-fame in North Sixth-street on Sunday night, were yesterday sent to the Penitentiary, for sixty days each. Timothy Murphy, arrested for stealing a pair of pantaloons from Mr. Lewis' clothing store, in Grandstreet, on Saturday evening, was sent to the same place, for ninety days.

Crowds of curious and eager visitors daily throng the Crystal Palace, intently watching the constant progress, and visible improvements, which are almost hourly developing themselves in and about the building. The erection and enclosure of the vast dome, which overshadows the structure, have given it entirely a new aspect.

We have received, and publish with pleasure, the following communication, correcting a statement of our correspondent, concerning the meeting of the General Association of Connecticut, as it comes from what we presume to be a perfectly reliable source.

The Milwaukee Wisconsin of June 20, says the steamer Sultana, Captain Oil Appleby, arrived yesterday on her way to Chicago, in somewhat of a damaged condition, having broken one of her wheels to pieces.

Which of the two to choose, the Central or Jones' is the great question of the day, in Albany at least. The couplet of GAY-HOW happy would I be with either, applicable but trite. The majority of the Senate Committee has shown the very best reasons, founded upon extended and valuable testimony, why Jones' Wood should infallibly be bought.

The Riot Investigation before the Coroner's Jury at Montreal is still in progress, and develops a variety of interesting facts touching the recent disturbances. A correspondence has passed between the Coroner and Col. HEMPHILL, in relation to the act of the soldiers in firing upon the mob.

The Secretary of the Treasury has failed to provide for establishing a New-York Assay Office, hitherto, simply because he cannot get a suitable building. This difficulty will probably be overcome within a fortnight.

A Philadelphia paper copies surgery from the Columbian, a newspaper published at Olympia, Washington Territory: "This is the new Territory, formed at the last Session of Congress out of the northern part of Oregon, including the valuable region of Puget Sound.

The funeral of Rev. Dr. SHARP took place this afternoon, from Charles-street Church, and was largely attended by the citizens of Boston and the neighboring towns. Gov. CLIFFORD, R.C. WINTHROP, and many distinguished merchants, and clergymen of various religious denominations, were present.

MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--There was a meeting of the Board of Aldermen at the Lyceum last evening--Alderman F. B. BETTS, President of the Board, in the Chair Several bills, communications, , were offered. An ordinance relative to the Liquor traffic, offered by Alderman BETTS, was taken form the table and discussed.

THE FISHERIES.--The French cruiser are enforcing the fishery rights of their nation in the vieinity of Miquelon, with much zeal, and the British colonial fishermen are getting a taste of the same treatment which they accorded to the Yankee fishermen last Summer.
The first number of a new exponent of Democracy, in its literary aspect, is issued from Washington. Mr. OVID F. JOHNSON is the editor; the publishers, WILLIAM H. LEWIS Co.

Trusting that our advice will not be deemed impertinent, we respectfully suggest to our Legislators at Albany that the sooner they adjourn, the better it will be for their own reputation and the credit of the State.

Messrs. COLLEY, PLATT, and BABCOCK, presented remonstrances against the Catholic bill. TOUCHING ADJOURNMENT. Mr. WILLIAMS had consent to submit a resolution to adjourn the Legislature on Thursday. It was amended so as to make it read Friday, and adopted. THE TEN HOURS BILL REJECTED.

From the National Intelligencer. Having recently published several letters in relation to the proposed Railroad to the Pacific, it is due to the Senator from Ohio that the following letter of an analogous character should also have a place in our columns.

To the fields! The tide flows outward; away from nauseous streets, rowdyism, bad government, and away from the thronging thousands who are already in motion for the City; away from pestilence and torrid heat, and close corners, where respiration becomes a science, and motion a mystery.

The Panegyrics lavished by the obedient newspapers upon the Emperor, and his underlings, continue to be as amusing as ever. They have probably received instructions to furnish so much admiration a day, either addressed directly to his Majesty, or to his Ministers, or his system, or his Prefects--even down to his informers, his spies, and his secret police.
The Evening Post inevitably has a spasm at every intimation that the Washington Union represents in any degree the sentiments and purposes of the Administration.

COMMON COUNCIL ITEMS.--A regular meeting of this body was held on Monday evening--Alterman HABTEAU in the chair. The report of J. D. Velser, Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, was presented for the month of June, from which it appears that daring that time, 44 new members had been elected, 43 members resigned, and 20 were expelled.

You have no doubt seen frequent notices of the presence of the yellow fever here since 1849; and have, with the world at large, very possibly supposed that the mortality was principally confined to the sailors, and others of the poorer classes, who could not command proper medical attention.

TWO PRUSSIAN MEN-OF-WAR.--The Prussian frigate Gefion, Capt. SUNDENALL, bearing the broad pennant of Commodore SCHRWEDER, and sloop-of-war Amazone, Commander SCHIRMACKER, arrived here yesterday from Carthagena, via Havana, leaving the first port on the 6th June, and arrived off Cape Henry on the 21st.

The Brownsville Flag has dates from Tampico to the 8th inst., but there is little of interest in the news. The comercio says: The field of extermination and desolation now occupied by the Indians is so great that the State of San Luis Potosi is the actual frontier.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: GENTLEMEN: Your paper of to-day contains a communication from Louisville, Ky, signed "A Subscriber," asking for information regarding the system of the British Government in the disposal of recaptured Africans.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I read, with much interest, the recent communication in the TIMES, upon the subject which heads this article. Many have read it with that sympathetic interest which attaches to every benevolent and philanthropic enterprise, rising upon the agitated sea of human toil and struggle, self-seeking aggrandizement, ambitions graspings, and sectarian clashing and slashing.
Very possibly some readers will suspect that the printers have blundered this morning in the head of the address, reported as delivered last night before the Alumni of the University.

They are discussing in Philadelphia, the probable growth of that enterprising town. Governor Bigler and the military gentlemen connected with the First Division of Pennsylvania Volunteers, have been engaged in planning the site of the new State Arsenal.

Lewis Montague, convicted at Petersburg, Va., of the murder of Thompson, has been denied a new trial, and sentenced to be executed on the 5th of August. The prisoner made a speech to the Court, in which he admitted that he killed the deceased, but denied that it was his intention to commit murder.

At Cruces, on the 7th instant, of dysentery, JOHN FUNCK, a native of Abo, in Finland, a Lieutenant in the Swedish Navy, and at later periods, Colonel in the Mexican, Salvadorian, and Nicaraguan Armics.

A fire broke out this evening in STRAUSS' four-story grocery warehouse, on Broadway, Fell's Point. The building was entirely gutted. The flames then communicated to two stores below, and the hotel on the corner, which were consumed. The market-house then caught fire, and was also completely destroyed.

The Second Anniversary of this Club was celebrated, last evening, by a very numerous and fashionable audience, in Hope Chapel, Broadway The exercises were of a character calculated to reflect credit upon the exertions which the young gentlemen composing this Club have so energetically made for their individual improvement in the varied paths of literature.

BOARD OF HEALTH--Tuesday.--Present, Mayor Lambert and Aldermen, Morris, Neely and Hinman. The First District Health Warden complained of a cesspool in the yard in the rear of the Post-Office, constituting an offensive nuisance.

NEW CHUCH.--The corner stone of a German Catholic Church, is to be laid in Montrose avenue, between Ewen-street and Graham avenue, this afternoon, at 4 o'clock. Bishop HUGHES will officiate in English, and Rev. JOSEPH MILLER, of New-York, will preach in German.

The twenty-first anniversary of the Alumni was celebrated last evening in the University Chapel, Rev. Dr. FERRIS, Chancellor of the University, presiding. There was a good attendance of literary and professional gentlemen.

The Philadelphia Ledger has a notice of a noble institution, the "South-Western Infirmary," established for the treatment of disease among the poor of Philadelphia. The institution has been in successful operation for several months, and up ward of 300 patients have already received the benefits of its care.

Mr. Collector BRONSON has made the following appointments for the Custom-House at this port: Deputy Collector--Thomas A. Osborne. Weighers--Daniel Geary, Louis Duffon, John Cox, James B Cisco, Robert B Clark.

The resolution of the 1st proximo, required by Senator HUNTER'S law for the classification of Clerks, is the absorbing theme this week. The law reduces the permanent clerical force in the Executive Departments from upwards of 1,000 to about 750--the reductions being principally in the Treasury, Interior and Navy Departments.
The Washington Intelligencer says: An accident occurred in this city yesterday morning, the 27th, which placed the life of an esteemed and distinguished gentleman in extreme peril.

The mode of choosing the State Judiciary is about to be determined by the Massachusetts Convention, now in session for the revision of the Constitution. One of the Boston papers takes ground against the popular franchise, and quotes, in support of its views, a passage from the recent autobiography of Justice CATRON, of the Supreme Court of the United States, published in the Law Magazine.

In consequence of the friendly order of the British Government to withdraw the suit against the Sheriff of Charleston, in relation to the imprisonment of colored seamen under the laws of South Carolina the Charleston Courier recommends that the State should, in a friendly spirit, now revise the law authorising such imprisonment, and establish other police regulations.

The Broadway Railroad Case. SUPERIOR COURT--Before Judge DUER--Mr. Field called for the production of the power of attorney given by Mr. Boreal to Mr. Burroughs, and under which that gentleman acted in regard to signing the remonstrance against the Road,

Our special European Correspondent, in his letter published yesterday, upon the struggle now going on in Eastern Europe, as it involves the rights of independent nations and of the great masses of the people, expressed very natural surprise that our new Democratic Administration should not have even appointed its diplomatic agents at Constantinople and Vienna.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: While the number of these necessary conveyances are constantly increasing, there appears to be little or no improvement in their construction. By riding in them, we are obliged to stoop so much that we are fast becoming a round shouldered, crouching, narrow-chested, and, by consequence, a consumptive race.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: As you devoted so large a space in your valuable columns to the insertion of my last communication, referring to the evils of our former Police System, and their consequences; I am encouraged to pursue the subject, and to offer some remarks on the absurdities of the New Law.
At the close of the great World's Fair in London, certain well-skilled gentlemen were selected to lecture publicly upon the results of the exposition.

THE LATE REV. DR. SHARP.--The remains of the late Rev. Dr. SHARP arrived in this city, accompanied by his widow and other relatives, on Saturday afternoon, at 5 o'clock, and were taken to his late residence, in West Cedar-street. The funeral discourse will be delivered by Rev. Dr. WAYLAND, of Brown University; and not by Dr. STOWE, as has been stated.

The steamer Fashion arrived yesterday from Texas, bringing a mail, but we have only received a copy of the American Flag of the 15th inst., in which we find the following items: The welcome showers which have recently fallen in our town are comparatively of little consequence with the rains experienced in some parts of its vicinity, while in others no rain has fallen.
The Dublin Nation says: "The young and amiable wife of Thomas Francis Meagher has arrived in London, from Van Diemen's Land, and is at present with his father, the respected member for Waterford.

A WORD FOR MYSELF.--When I established the business of cheap Clothing, a few years ago, my views were based upon the production, in all cases, of the very best garments which could be made; and I have found the most gratifying success in punctuality, and fidelity to my premises.

EXECUTION OF JOHN S. WORMLEY, FOR THE MURDER OF HIS SON-IN-LAW.--JOHN S. WORMLEY was bung at Chesterfield Court House, Va., on Friday last, for the murder or ANTHONY T. ROBIOU, his son-in-law. The execution was witnessed by about 2,500 persons, whom the prisoner addressed for about a quarter of an hour.

Arrival of the Union. The steamer Union arrived yesterday afternoon about 1 P.M. She left Aspinwall, 19th inst., at 5 P.M.; arrived at Kingston 22d inst., at 8 A.M.; left Kingston same date, at 6 P.M. She encountered strong trades in the Caribbean sea. She brings nothing later from California.

On Tuesday evening, June 28, JOSEPH TAYLOR, aged 72 years. His friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral on Thursday afternoon, June 30, at 3 o'clock, from the residence of his son-in-law, James Donshee, No. 21 Clark-st., without further invitation.

VISIT OF LOCOMOTIVE BUILDERS. on Saturday next,. the Locomotive builders, to the numers of 500 employed by DANFORTH, BROOKS Co., of Paterson, will make a pleasure execursion to jersey City and dine at the Hudson House.

A very brilliant and numerous audience filled NIBLO'S yesterday morning, to witness the exercised of the Annual Commencement of New-York University. On no occasion during the season of Madame ALBONI'S triumph did the theatre present a brighter array of fashion and beauty; while the attendance of "Alumni," old and young, was large.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: While you are justly dealing with the City Government, and the "weightier matters of the law," you still find time and space to advocate justice and propriety in the minor matters of private and social life.

MAN CATHOLIC CHURCH--ADDRESS BY ARCHBISHOP HUGHES--RUFFIANLY OUTRAGE ON A REPORTER--Yesterday afternoon, his Grace, Archbishop HUGHES, laid the Corner-Stone of a new German Catholic Church, in Williamsburg, to be called "The Church of the Holy Trinity."

HOSPITAL AT CANTON.--A friend has sent us a "brief report of the hospital at Kum-le-fall in Canton, during the year 1852." This institution, we believe, is under the care of the American missionaries at Canton. In 1832, during hospital days, 19,972 persons attended the institution. 6,716 of whom were females; and on Sabbath days, 1,437, of whom 1,862 were females.

The Cabinet had another tedious sitting to-day. It is understood to have been concerning BUCHANAN'S instructions. I cannot learn that the question was definitely disposed of, but am quite certain that MARCY will be permitted to govern his own department.

We are very glad to learn from the Albany Evening Journal that our Correspondent was mistaken in supposing that the passage of the bill for the better security of Railroad passengers, is resisted by the influence of the Railroad Companies.
The Canadian Parliament has just terminated a rather protracted session, for, with the exception of a short recess about the Christmas holidays, it has been sitting for nearly eight months.

SONS OF PORTSMOUTH--CELEBRATION OF THE FOURTH OF JULY.--A meeting of the "Sons of Parts-month" was held at the Irving House, last evening, to perfect arrangements for an excursion to Portsmouth, by invitation of the Common Council there on the 4th July- Hon. WM. A. WALKER presided, and Mr. G. W. WENDELL acted as Secretary.

FUGITIVE SLAVE CASE IN INDIANA. --On Tuesday last, PLEASANT ELLINGTON, of Kentucky, filed an affidavit before the U.S. Commissioner SULLIVAN, at Indianapolis, claiming a negro, JOHN FREEMAN, as his slave.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: ALDERMAN NARINE'S MOTION.--Mr. Editor: In Wednesday's paper. under the head of "Jersey City." you say, "Alderman NARINE moved to lay the ordinare upon the table, and offered a substitute. The substitute was read and passed upon in section with amendments," The substitute, if substitute it may be called.
PRINCETON COLLEGE COMMENCEMENT.--The commencement exercises began Tuesday afternoon, with an oration before the Whig and Cliosophic Societies by W. B. BREWSTER, Esq., of Philadelphia.

FROM FORT LEAVENWORTH.--The Western Reporter contains the following, from Fort Leavenworth: The Court Martial which has been in session at Fort Leavenworth, for several days past, has not closed its labors. They have under consideration the charges preferred against Major How, while in New-Mexico.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: At this time, when public attention is so much occupied by the agitation among the various classes of workers, for an increased remuneration for their services, I desire to point out a class as meeting some degree of record--a class whose grievances have not been the less acutely fell be cause they their to been home in silence,--I mean Governersses.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your Correspondent (B.) of yesterday, desires that the members of the Mercantile Library Association should sign a petition in favor of closing on Saturday afternoons.

The Moral and Intellectual Culture of the Negro in Slavery--Evidence of a Missionary--How the South has Failed of its Duty--What Business this of Our's. In discussing the views presented in my last letter with Southerners, the labors of a society for the religious instruction of negroes in Liberty Country, Georgia, have frequently been referred to as an instance of the great privileges which the negroes may be blessed with in Slavery.

The late negro effervescence in New-Orleans, though ridiculous enough in itself, the Picayune says, has established the fact that white men have been tampering with the negroes, and shows the necessity of a rigorous enforcement of the laws in regard to inciting the slaves to insurrection, which are very severe, the penalty for this offence being imprisonment for life, or death, at the discretion of the Judge.
How many people are coming to New-York this Summer; how many come every Summer, are questions we are without means of determining.

SUPERIOR COURT--Before Judge DUER--At the sitting of the Court yesterday morning, Mr. Wood resumed his summing up on behalf of the plaintiffs. He commenced by adverting to the several authorities governing cases like the ?? before the Court, going to show the Courts had properly held that an injunction would lie in cases of grants of ground by Municipal corporations, though the grant took the form of a legislative act.

SUN-STROKES.--JACOB HENDRICKSON, a laborer employed on the farm a NATHANIEL NOSTHAND, Sen., Spring field, L. I., on Friday last died from the effects of heat. JOHN SWEELY, a laborer on the farm of WM. VALENTINE, at Flushing, also died last Friday from the effects of heat. Quite a number of persons were prostrated on different farms on the Island on the same day, but we hear of no other cases that terminated fatally.

Is it not possible to suppress the childish nuisance of throwing bouquels upon the stage at our College Commencements! Or have the absurdities of fashion so firm a hold upon all our habits, that even our institutions of learning must consent to be fooled by them!

FROM JAMAICA--The papers record the extension of an unconditional pardon to twenty of the prisoners, being the second lot that has been discharged since the Governor notified the Assembly of his intention.
The U. S. Mail steamship Georgia, Lieut. BULLOCK, arrived yesterday morning from Aspinwall and Havana. She brings dates from the former port to the 19th, and from the latter to the 24th inst.

The second wave of immigration has set in upon us. Canvas-covered wagons are as abund an as ever, on our ferry-boats and along the prairie-roads of Southern Iowa; but the men, women and children with whom they are filled, are no longer bound for the placers of California, and the plains of Oregon, but for the rich prairie country of our own State--

We have discovered no really novel feature in the Dry Goods trade, during the past week. The preparations making for the Autumn traffic seem to absorb the attention of the few of our local merchants remaining in town, while buyers from the country are waiting to hear of the Crystal Palace being opened, before leaving their homes,

BOARD OF SUPERVISOR.--A regular meeting of this body was held Tuesday. His Honor, Mayor BERRY, of Williamsburg, in the Chair. A communication was presented from the Superintendents of the Poor, asking an appropriation of $1,000 to be placed to the account of the Penitentiary and Workhouse. Referred to Alms-House committee for report.

We are not surprised to find those journals which opposed the Reform movement, that led to the adoption of the Amended Charter, resisting the nomination of a Reform ticket for our City Election this Fall.

The 1st July is hand, yet nothing has been done towards the establishment of the New-York Assay-Office. This results from the difficulty of obtaining a building suitable for the purposes of the Assay-Office.

We have furnished our readers, from time to time, with whatever matters of interest have come under our observation, relative to the progress of the Exhibition that is about to open at the Crystal Palace.

STATE SCHOLARSHIPS AND AID TO NORMAL SCHOOL SCHOLARS--The Massachusetts Board of Education has just issued a circular relating to the recent Act of the Legislature establishing State Scholarships to aid in educating young men, in school and college, for Principal Teachers of the High Schools of the Commonwealth.

Apropos of Hackney Coaches, a bill which originated in the British House of Commons, for the reform of the Metropolitan system, has, we learn by the Africa, just passed the House of Lords. The bill was devised by Government, the mover in the Commons, where it met with no opposition, being Hon. H. FITZROY. member for Lewes.

The watering places of America are superior to those of England in one respect-they are more rural. Leamington, Cheltenham. Bath, Wells, and Hastings, are but sections of the great metropolis transplanted to a purer atmosphere. All the elaboration of London life is found there. The streets are paved with correct Portland stone.

The usual storm of last evening knocked down the telegraph wires, and cheated our readers out of some news which their subscription for the TIMES, entitled them. It can't be helped, until Companies conclude to put up such wires and posts as will not be knocked down so very easily.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: GENTLEMEN: My attention has recently been called to Mr. ROBERTSON'S invention of the Cotton Mattrass, by accidentally meeting a specimen of cotton upholstery upon the plan of this invention, now in possession of Professor PAGE, of this city, late Chief Examiner of the Patent Office; and I feel it to be my duty to call public attention to the character and present condition of this most important invention.

It is the very general impression here, that Mr. BUCHANAN has thrown up the mission to England. This is not done yet, though the probability strengthens that it will be. MARCY is firm in refusing BUCHANAN'S demand, to write his own instructions.

The intelligence received here by the last mails, of action upon Spanish affairs in the British Parliament, in reference to the continued prosecution of the Slave-trade, with the cognizance of the authorities of Cuba, has roused the attention and the fears of General CANEDO.

The Washington Republic publishes a correspondence which has lately passed between the Cliosophic Society of the College of New-Jersey and the Washington Monument Association at Washington. A block of marble for the Monument was sent to the Capital, by the members of the Society, accompanied by sundry reminisences of the connection of Gen. WASHINGTON with the history of the body.

Lieut. MAURY'S theory relative to the course of prevailing winds and currents, is no longer a subject of experiment. Vessel after vessel, by passages which, for celerity, have startled the maritime world, has furnished practical exemplification of the value of MAURY's Charts.

From a private dispatch received at London, we have the following latest from China: "The India and China malls had arrived at Trieste, with advices from Canton to the 20th of April, and from Hong Kong to a later date. The capture of the city of Nankin by the insurgents is fully confirmed.

FROM ST. THOMAS.-By the arrival of the schooner Louisa, Capt. GASKILL, at this port, we are in possession of dates to the 10th of June. The ship Flying Arrow, for San Francisco, had finished reloading, and was waiting for lower and topsail yards. She had lost three of her passengers and four seamen, by yellow fever. Captain TREADWELL, and Mr. CLARK, first officer, had been down with it but had recovered.

ELAZER B. DICKEY, a revolutionary veteran, died in Monroe, Me., on the 8th inst., aged ninetythree years and three months. The services which Mr. DICKEY, in his vigorous youth rendered to his country, as well as the merits of his character in after life, demand more than a casual notice.

On Wednesday, June 29, HENRY VALENTINE, son of the late Winthrop Eaten. aged 16 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this (Friday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 169 South Fourth-st., Williamsburg.

From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. We noticed, some days since, the appearance of the first of a series of letters from a European correspondent in the New-York TIMES, and expressed our conviction that the writer was no less Important a personage than LOUIS KOSSUTH.

By the way of San Antonio, Texas, we have received a file of the Santa Fe Weekly Gazette to the 14th ult. We give the following condensed summary of the intelligence, regretting that the crowded state of our columns precludes more extended extracts: There had been no further steps, on the part of either the Mexican authorities or Gov. LANE, in relation to the Mesilla Valley.

The foreign news by the Africa, of which full details will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES, contains no feature of marked interest. The position of the Eastern question had not materially changed, nor had any new developments been made as to the designs of the Russian Czar.

None but the holders of these tickets, and invited guests, will be admitted into the interior, to witness the ceremonies of the inaugural tion, which are announced for the 11th of July-the day before the exhibition is opened to the public.

COAL FOR THE JAPANESE SQUADRON.-Baltimore, as a coal market, has an established and wellearned reputation, and we find that it is properly appreciated by the Government. Two large and well-built ships, attached to the Japan Squadron, are now in our port, loading with coal. One is the Roebuck, of 800 tons, the other. the Beverly, of 650 tons, nominal measurement.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, reached the Cunard dock at Jersey City, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning. She left Liverpool at 3 P. M. on Saturday, 18th June, and brings the London papers of that morning.

People thought that Dr. DRAPER was very cool in his assumption, the other evening, that the City was a debtor, in any sense, to its University. But inasmuch as he proved it, nobody was so much shocked at the announcement, as pleased at the proof. A cooler thing than that, the Doctor did, however. He took the wind out of the sails of one of our neighbors.

FORT KEARNY May 31, 1853. Col. A. B. CHAMBERS-Dear Sir: I send you a list of the number of cattle, sheep, horses, wagons, mules, men, women, and children, that have passed this point up to the 31st instant, for which I am indebted to the kindness of Capt. WHARTON, the commandant at this post, and a more courteous and hospitable gentleman I have never had the pleasure of meeting in my travels.

Peckham for respondents. No. 19. Johnson, respondent, against Carnley, Sheriff, , appellant. Submitted. N. Hill, Jr., counsel.

The State of Ohio will receive her full share of the pleasures and profits of public Conventions, during the coming Summer months. Science, Benerolence, Temperance and Politics each have their turn. No trip can be pleasanter than that to the Westward, whether by lake or railroad; and on the return trip no place could be more convenient to stop at than Niagara.

Two specimen cars for the Third-avenue Railroad have been put on the track near the City Hall, for inspection. They are very hand-somely made, and are mounted on elastic springs, of India rabbe. There will be fifty cars altogether, but not more than fifteen or twenty have yet been received. The cars are lettered "Park-row, Bowery, Third-avenue and Sixty-first-street."
The great commercial and political revolutions anticipated as a result of the Chinese Rebellion, do not absorb, entirely, the attention of the good folks at Washington.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As Mr. TABER's bill is still pending before the Legislature, I think it not amiss, as a member of the Church most interested in the subject, to ask a place in your columns for my opinion, and that of the majority of Catholics, in the premises.

Last evening, notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, a pretty full attendance assisted at the presentation of a Gold Medal to the eloquent Italian exile, by the Waldense Lodge, No. 9. of the American Protestant Association. Upon the reverend lecturer's making his appearance before his assembled friends and admirers, he was received with hearty demonstrations of applause. He was attired, as on former occasions, in his old monastic garb of the Barnabas Friars.

I send you the result of a preliminary examination had at Grand Traverse, a newly organized county, formerly attached to Michilimackinac, for judicial purposes, in the matter of the people against O. P. HUGHSON, charged with murder, rape, and assaults without number.

An extraordinary scene took place in Court, yesterday, during the trial of KISSANE and FINDLAY for forgery. WILLIAM F. JOHNSON, who was called as a witness for the defence, had called on KISSANE yesterday, and told him he was able to prove his whereabouts on the 14th, and correct a mistake made by witnesses for the prosecution.

We have dates from El Paso to the 9th of May, by way of San Antonio and New-Orleans. The following Proclamation had been addressed by Gov. TRIAS, to the soldiers of his division; FELLOW-SOLDIERS: Know, that the Governor of New-Mexico, has declared that the Colony "De la Mesilla," which is situated on Mexican territory, belongs to the United States.

From Indianapolis, I started for Evansville on Wednesday last, at 11 3/4 o'clock, A. M. Instead of the direct railroad route, which would have brought me to Louisville, or New-Albany, the samn night, I went by way of Madison, at which city arrived about 4 o'clock.

A. friend has just shown us a handful of beautiful-looking wheat heads, which, upon examination, proves to be filled with the weevil. The wheat comes from this vicinity, and we are informed that the crop throughout the whole country is more or less infected. From Seneca and Sandusky Counties we have no very late reports, but we fear for the crop in this whole section of country.--Satduskv (0.) Register, June 2.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: With your usual promptitude, a notice of the death of Dr. MANNERS appeared in the DAILY TIME, several days ago. Perhaps the life and character of the deceased gentleman may justify a further appropriation of your space to a few biographical memoranda, and I venture to enclose them.

We gave place yesterday to the following, from a correspondent, relative to THORWALDSEN's statuary at the Crystal Palace: "In the description to-day of works of art from Italy, and under the head of "Sculpture," to be exhibited at out great international meeting, you have made a slight over sight in supposing "THORWALDSEN's" Christ and his Apostles, to be from the Duchy of Modena.

The possibilities of war between Turkey and Russia depend upon a host of contingencies: The majority of them have been duly dwelt upon by the press. The belligerent attitude of Russia upon the immediate point indispute; the vrast naval and military prepara-

The "strikes" now occurring at Liverpool and Stockport, and many other places, are attracting considerable attention. They differ from many previous demonstrations of the same kind, in the fact that they apparently originate in the prosperity, not in the distress of the country.

The Democratic State Convention for the nomination of a candidate for Governor, assembled here this morning. Col. IRA T. DREW, of York, was chosen Chairman, and JAMES P. MCINTIRE, of York, and A. B. FARWELL, of Farmington, Secretaries.

THE MONTREAL INVESTIGATION.-The Canadian papers devote great attention to the Riot investigations at Montreal. We now have the testimony of C. J. COURSOL, Esq., Joint Coroner for the District of Montreal, and the gentleman to whom the Mayor made reference, in his account of the disturbance. Mr. COURSOL is severe upon the Mayor. He says:

The Cabinet held a protracted meeting to day. BUCHANAN'S instructions were again the subject of discussion. No final decision has yet been reached. The President will probably mollify the Minister, and he will go to London, notwithstanding MARCY's refusal to give him the Fishery question.
The Washington Union, assisted by correspondents, and the telegraph, assures us, triweekly, that Spain will, in no case, be permitted to Africanize Cuba.

Considerable excitement has been caused among the medical faculty of New Hampshire by the rendition of a verdict against Dr. Dixi Crosby, by a jury in Vermont, for mal-practice in treating a fractured leg. Damages to the amount of $800 were assessed.

The General Assembly adjourned sine ate this afternoon. The Flowage Bill was killed between the two Houses. The Governor has vetoed the Liquor Bill, and the House sustained him by avote of 126 to 71. Just previous to the final ad-

SCALDED TO DEATH.--Coroner O DONNELL held an inquest yesterday, in Fifty-eight-street, near Sixth-avenue, upon the boddy of a child,2 years of age, named JOHN OBERMUBER, who, on Wednesday last, fell into a pot of boiling coffee, severely acalding himself. He died this morning from the effect of the injuries. The Jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts.
The bill introduced into the Connecticut Legislature for the prevention of Railroad Accidents, has passed both Houses in an amended form. The Legislature adjourned yesterday, sine die.

LAST NIGHT'S DISASTERS.--Our reporter returned at 3 A. M., from the scene of disaster uptown, with the following, as the latest particulars: We saw two men lying dead at the Sub Station-house of the Nineteenth Ward, who were killed at the falling of the buildings near the Crystal Palace.

POLYTECHNIC COLLEGE--The Philadelphia Ledger says, of the new College of Mines, Agriculture and Manufactures: "We learn that, although a tempting offer of an extensive tract of land, in the mining region of the State, was made to the Trustees, yet they gave the preference to this city,

ARRIVAL OF A BALTIMORE FIRE COMPANY GRAND TORCHLIGHT PROCESSION.-To-night the Baltimore Company, Columbian Engine No. 9, will be received with a torchlight procession by Manhattan Company No.8, and thirty-five other fire companies of this City. The Baltimore Company will leave Philadelphia by the evening train, and arrive in New-York between 8 and 9 P.M.

The delay of the Administration, in filling the mission to France, is strangely unaccountable, and quite at variance with what must be conceded an enlightened consideration of the public good. At no European Court, and among no people, is the continual presence of a skillful and faithful representative of the American Republic more to be desired than at Paris, and among the people of France.
we are now having a foretaste of the celebration of the coming Fourth. While I am writing, the air is filled with the music of the fife and drum, those instruments excitive of patriotism.

Yesterday was fruitful in serious accidents. The explosion of the boiler of the steamboat New World, at her dock, early in the morning, occasioned the loss of six lives;--the burning of a bakery in the First-avenue caused two more deaths;-and

Church and Missionary Intelligence. The Houston-street Presbyterian Church of this City, have presented their late pastor, Rev. R. S. STORRS DICKINSON, (now of the First Pres byterian church of Philadelphia) six handsome pieces of silver, as a testimonial of their continued regard.

The Summer quiet of this little city is broken twice a week by the occurrence of "market days," at which time the farmers of the surrounding country occupy the principal streets of the town with their market-wagons, a cross between the Rockaway and the white covered vehicle used by emigrant travelers at the West.
