From the Boston Traveller of Wednesday. The steamer Occan, which left this port yesterday afternoon, for Bath, Gardner and Hallowell, ran upon the ledge of rocks known as the "Londoner,"' near Thacher's Island, between 9 and 10 o'clock last night.
Prospects of the Mines-Work, Profit, Expenses, We have the Lake Superior Journal of Jun 18. It gives encouraging accounts from the Coppemines. We copy a few paragraphs:

The presence of Mrs. STOWE at Paris has, at last, been made public, through the colunms of the Charivari. That most reliable journal relates, that several days after her arrival, each of her ten translators sent her his card, and received in reply a note, declaring his particular translation to be the, best and the most faithful version of the original.

Railroad travel through the City has rapidly risen in favor with the people. All other modes of conveyance-cab, coach, and omnibus-have fallen into disrepute, atd, let the Common Council, the grantees, and Judge DUER arrange the terms as they may, the public insist on traveling the full lenth of our Island City, smoothly running on a rail.

SICKNESS ON BOARD A BALTIMORE VESSLL.--The schooner D. L. Clinch. Capt. WATTS, of Baltimore, bound from Navy Bay to Cardenas, we have already stated, was fallen in within distress on the 16th inst, 20 miles from Havana, and towed into that port, where she was put in charge of the American Consul.

THE PEABODY INSTITUTE.--We learn from the Salem Register, that the Trustees of the munificent donation made by Mr. PEABODY; now of London, to his native town of Danvers, have finally adopted a plan for a building, and made contracts for its erection immediately, on the Wallis lot. The architect is RICHARD BOND, of Boston.

ARREST OF A BEGGAR.--An Italian named JOHN BOESE, was arrested yesterday by Officer KELLY, of the Tenth District Police, for soliciting alms in Grand-street. He had a card pinned on his breast on which was printed, " The bearer is blind, and also very poor and unable to support his three small children; his wife is dead, and he is now left alone to protect them."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In relation to ROBERTSON'S Cotton Mattress, I would state that cotton mattresses have been in use for upward of thirty years in Scotland, and are still very extensively used; an increasing demand, in fact, is made for them. I have helped to make many dozens of them, and at present, have one for my own use.

On Saturday, Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest on the bodies of the three men who were killed by the falling ofa building in Forty third-street, near the Crystal Palace, during the storm on Friday evening. The names of the unfortunate men were JAMES McCAULEY, WM. McCRACKEN, and MATTHEW McGRAUN. They were plasterers by trade, and were born in Ireland.

THE DAY.--Properly speaking, The Day commenced on Saturday night, and was continued with little intermission during the whole of Sunday; and last night, just after sunset, it began in good earnest. All this too premature patriotism, however, was mostly confined to small boys. This morning, at sunrise, The Day commenced in reality by a salute fired from the Batttery, by a detachment from the First Brigade.

For the other City News of this morning, ses Sixth Page Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Performance by the Ravel Family. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--American Farmers. WASHINGTON CIRCUS, Corner 39th-st. and 6th-ave.--Grand Equestrian Performances. FRANCONI'S HIPPODROME.--Performances every afternoon and evening.

Doctor CHAPMAN, (says the Philadelphia North American, of Friday,) an eminent physician and excellent man, died at his residence in Philadelphia, yesterday afternoon, at 6 o'clock. He had reached an advanced age, and for the last few years was rapidly declining in health. A native of Vir-.

In addition to the news given by telegraph this morning, we extract the following from the New-Orleans Picayune of the 26th: The Siglo Diez y Nueve having appeared several days in succession without leading articles. the editors published in explanation a note from the Government which they had received.

The political canvass in Kentucky this Summer has a single point of interest, and that relating to the Ashland District, which is looked to with very considerable anxiety in the West, where the parties are personally known.

The public exercises of the next anniversary of Rochester Theological Seminary will commence on Sunday, July 12, with a sermon before the Missionary Society, by Rev. J. L. Burrows, of Philadelphia. On Tuesday, President Wayland, of Brown University, will preach before the Union for Ministerial Education.

No. 28. Andrews and others, appellants, agt. Durant and others, respondents. Argued. N. Hill, Jr., for appellants; Samuel H. Hammond, for respondents. No. 29. Reserved generally. No. 30. Set down for July 12. No. 21. Oakley, respondent, agt. Morton. appellant. Argned. Samuel Beardaley, for appellant; Horatio Ballard, for respondent.

STEAMER OCEAN AFLOAT.--The steamer Ocean, after lying on the rocks off Cape Ann, for three days, was finally got off last evening, at seven o'clock, and was towed into this port this forenoon, by steamers Boston and Rescue. She did not receive so much injury as might have been expected, from the critical position in which she was placed.

From the London Times. Two huge volumes have just been issued, which will undoubtedly be the most interesting and remarkable Parliamentary publications of the season. They contain the results of the Census of 1851. There is, probably, no science so imperfectly comprehended as that of statistics. nor could anything be better calculated to improve the popular appreciation of this subject than the books before us.

In steamship Jamestown, for Norfolk, Petersburg and Richmond--Wm. Ferrand, J. Kindervater, H Kindervater, Miss C. Lawaon, J. H. White and lady, Thomas M. Smith, J. D. Lawson, H. Curtis and lady, J. W. Swindells, J. Hudson and brothers, A. Osborne, Miss C. Osborne, Mrs. M. Osborne, Capt. Bullock and lady, Samuel Latimer, Benjamin C. Bumpers, lady and child; J. Emmory and son. John Wood, J. T. Mason, C. C. Hudson.

The Baltimore American, one of the most dignified and carefully conducted daily journals in the country, now numbering fifty-eight years, changed part ownership on the 1st inst. Messrs. DOBBIN FULTON take the place of DOBBIN, MURPHY Boss. One of the retiring partners, Mr. MURPHY, the office-man of the establishment, was connected with the paper for nearly or quite forty years.

GRAND TORCHLIGHT PROCESSION.--The Fire Department of this City assembled in large numbers, on Saturday night, and formed in order of procession in the Park, to do honor to Columbia Engine Company No. 9, of Baltimore, who arrived on invitation of Manhattan Company No. 8, of this City. The greater part of the Fire Companies turned out, with their Engines, , and bearing a brilliant display of torches.

The season of College Commencements is at hand. Already, the University of this City, and the College of New-Jersey have set the example. Others will follow in the subjoined order: Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass.,-Wednesday, July 20.

To-morrow is the day, of all the year, when the New-England fleet weighs anchor, and departs for the fishing grounds. It is stated, on the pretty good authority of the 'long-shore press of Massachussetts, that the majority of the skippers have laid in an invoice of gunpowder, with some fowling, as well as fishing, implements, in case an opportunity occur for sports more animated than usual.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: THE ATTACK ON A REPORTER.--SIR: In your account of the proceedings at the laying of the corner stone of the German Catholic Church, in this City, published Thursday, you charge me with committing, during the services, a gross assault upon one of the New-York Reporters-said to be a Reporter for the Herald.

AMUSEMENTS FOR THIS EVENING.-We notice that at NIBLO'S, this evening, the RAVEL Family will appear in four entertainments. They will doubtless be warmly greeted by their numerous admirers. At the Broadway Theatre, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS appear in their characteristic pieces. Mrs. WILLIAMS is, by far, the best representative of Yankee character now in the States.

The sultry month upon which we have now entered, is the month, in all the year, most prolific of Collegiate honors. It may be called the Month of Commencements--not exclusively so, either--for, in the multiplicity of our Colleges, no one-twelfth ofa Gregorian year is sufficient to afford the several days it usually takes to get through with the exercises of each, without overlapping.

THE CRYSTAL PALACE.--A certain class of newspapers which appear to have a great penchant for every thing foreign, and a sovereign contempt for every thing American, are engaged in the very unpatriotic endeavor to cause the exhibition in New-York to be a failure--because, forsooth, it is not attended with all the display and royal magnificence of that of London.

THE STORM.--During the storm, on Friday evening, the electric fluid passed down the chimney of BROWN DEMAREST'S store, in Montgomery-street, Jersey City, on the second block from the Ferry, and prostrated one clerk and stunned another. Considerable of the plastering was torn off. The report of the thunder frightened a span of omnibus horses, and they ran up the street with three passengers, but were stopped, without doing harm.

The Picayune brings dates from Mexico considerably later than previous arrivals. The accounts are from the Capital to the 11th, and Vera Cruz to the 15th June. On the 5th inst. the first number of the Diario Official made its appearance. It is limited strictly to the publication of government orders.

SMALL GAME-AN AFFLICTED INDIVIDUAL.A poor old woman is going the rounds, who always wants a sixpence,-sometimes a shilling. She has weak eyes, and is a stranger in the City; and generally takes the wrong stage route, and in her confusion drops her money as she is leaving the stage.

I embraced an opportunity, a day or two since, to visit Mount Vernon, so long the cherished home, and now the honored grave of WASHINGTON. It was the fourth time my feet had pressed that hallowed soil. Each occasion presented something of new interest; and my emotions of reverence increased, rather than diminished, on growing familiarity with the scene.

The act requiring a Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages, which passed the Legislature at the regular session, has gone into operation. It requires as full statistics to be kept of the births and marriages, as have been of the deaths in this City. The law applies only to this City.

Mr. Commissioner MORTON decided, on Saturday, that the Fugitive Slave Law, and that clause of the Constitution requiring the return of " persons held to service or labor," who may escape from the State in which they are held, was intended to apply exclusively to slaves, and that fugitive apprentices cannot, therefore, be reclaimed under its provisions.

Mr. JOHN WEICKER, a German, who, for some years. has been engaged in the service of the American Tract Society, in distributing tracts among his immigrant countrymen. was yesterday afternoon abused by am emigrant runner in a shameful ard cruel manner, while standing at the corner of Greenwich and Carlisle-streets, and handing around tracts to a number of immigrants, who received item very eagerly and gratefully.

Nearly all the lower part of the City, except those portions of it which appear to be finished, are in a transition state. A few years ago, Greenwich-street, from the Battery up to Libertystreet, was the residence of the old aristocratic families. Now the street has been filled up, and the elegant old mansions are occupied by immigrant foreigners, principally Dutch, almost every house being a beer shop or boarding house.

COMMENCEMENT OF THE PENNSYLVANIA UNIVERSITY.--The Annual Commencement of the Collegiate branch of the Pennsylvania University, took place this morning, at the Musical Fund Hall. The degree of Bachelor of Arts was then conferred on the following members of the Senior Class: Richard Ashhurst, Jr., John K. Barclay, James C. Biddle, Robert C. Cornelius, Z. Poulson Dobson,

TO-DAY's CELEBRATION.--The Committee of the Board of Aldermen of Jersey City has announced the programme for the celebration of this, our National Anniversary. A gun will be fired at day-break, and a national salute at sun-rise. At noon thirteen guns will be fired; at sun-down the national salute of thirty-two guns will be fired; at 81 o'clock an exhibition of fire-works by Alderman Edge will be given in Van Vorst-square.

THE CITY OF CHURHES.-There are 78 Churches this City. Episcopal, 17; Roman Catholic, 7; Baptist, 7; Dutch Reformed, 6; Congregational, 10; Presbyterian, 8; Methodist Episcopal, 12; African Episcopal, 2; Universalist, Friends, Congreational Methodist, Primitive Methodist, Protestant Methodist, Second Advent, Reformed Presbyterian, one each, and 2 Unitarian.

As I have looked in vain for anything like a correct account of the disastrous wreck of the ship William and Mary, I here send you one, leaving it to you to make what use of it you may think proper. I should have sent it before, but I have had no opportunity of doing so.

DROWNED AT HOBOKEN.--On Saturday evening, about 9 o'clock, a German named MORRIS KLLIRE, about twenty-five years of age, and a young woman named SOPHIA GEISMER, aged about twenty, were drowned under the following circumstances: They wore at the ferry-house, on the Hoboken side, to take the boat to the foot of Canal-street.

ARRIVAL OF STEAMSHIPS.--The steamship Glasgow, Capt. CRAIG, arrived at this port on Saturday from Glasgow, whence she sailed on the 18th ult. She brings a large number of cabin passengers, and 353 in the steerage. The James Adger, Capt. DICKINSON, arrived Saturday morning, from Charleston.

The ghost of Free-Soilism seems to be troubling the Democracy. Neither its old friends nor its old enemies succeed in laying it. It will not down at the bidding of either, or of both. It is only fair to say that those who petted it most while it was in the body,--to whom, in fact, it owed its life,--are now most zealous in their efforts to exorcise and banish it forever.

Honest, hard-working man, will you allow us to give you a word of advice, before starting out to celebrate this Fourth of July? The day must be celebrated-on that we shall certainly agree. The memory of the bold men who risked their necks to secure independence for their country, demands it. You work hard all the week.

Judge EDMONDS, on Saturday, dissolved the injunction previously issued to prevent the proper Department from signing the contract with Russ and REID, for paving Chathamstreet and the Bowery. The ordinance authorizing the work, it will be remembered, was vetoed by the Mayor, and afterwards passed in spite of the veto, by the Common Council.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the search after novelty, which animates the pedestrian in this traveling age, I intend marking out a route, which he can pursue with advantage, particularly if he be a lover of the picturesque or what is beautiful in Nature.

Seventy or eighty years ago, public meetings and conventions were rare in this country, although they are the order of the day now. The Colonies were ripe for revolt, but there was no organization, and no united expression of public sentiment. There were not wanting distinguished men in the country to take the lead, nor was the fire of liberty unenkindled in the heart of the nation.

MR. MACAULAY.--A correspondent of the Inverness Courier says: "I met Mr. MACAULAY, one day last week, processionising along in the old way, and making Burlington Gardens re-echo the ferule of his umbrella. The step of the great historian was, to use a musical phrase, as staccato and firmly determined as ever.

OPENING OF THE THIRD-AVENUE RAILROAD.--On Saturday afternoon, the opening of the Third-avenue Railroad was celebrated by a festival, to which the shareholders of the line, the Aldermen of the City, and the members of the Prss, were invited. Twelve cars, filled with invited guests, and each drawn by four horses, decked with ribbons and flowers, went over the line to Sixty-first-street, the present terminus of the road.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The foregoing letter was accidentally omitted in the Morning Edition of Saturday's TIMES. There are many cases on record, well authenticated, of hail-stones falling from the sky weighing half pound; but until to-day, I never saw hail-stones much larger than a pigeon's egg.

THE TIMES' EUROPEAN LETTERS.-The NewYork TIMES is publishing a series of letters on European Politics, which are ascribed by the editor of the Buffalo Commercial to no less an individual than KOSSUTH.--To-ledo Republican. Commenting upon this paragraph, the New-York TIMES does not deny the correctness of this supposition.

It has been quite warm to-day, as much so as it is likely to be in this shady nook of the world. The immense court-yard of the United States Hotel is, as you are aware, planted with a magnificent growth of forest trees. They are certainly the finest of the neighborhood. Indeed I have not seen any elsewhere at all approaching them in richness of foliage, and general beauty of growth.

ACCIDENT AT THE HIPPODROME.--During the hurdle race by five young ladies, at the Hippodrome performance yesterday afternoon, the saddle on one of the horses slipped, and the rider, after being whirled at a break-neck pace around the entire course, still clinging to the reins and saddle, fell under the feet of the horse.

THE STORM IN BROOKLYN.--The storm of Friday evening passed over Brooklyn without doing any serious damage, other than the unroofing of a few buildings, and breaking of a large number of windows. This damage was almost entirely confined within the limits of that portion of the city bounded by Vanderbilt, Myrtle and Division-avenues, adjoining Williamsburg.

Gen. GADSDEN is still here, and as BUCHANAN did in English matters, so he desires authority to adjust all difficulties with Mexico. The Premier resists, as he did in BUCHANAN'S case. He has had several interviews with the President; but MARCY'S views will prevail.

The season for the migration of the birds of passage and varied plumage, has commenced much earlier this, than last year; and the different Meccas of the fashionable and pleasure-seeking world, are being rendered exceedingly lively, by the buzz of porters, cabmen, travelers, and well. dressed, polite clerks of the crack houses.

JOHN KELLY, a soldier of tile Revolution, died in Union township, Muskingum County, Ohio, on the 11th ultimo, aged ninety-three years. Mr. KELLY was born in North Carolina, in 1755. At the age of nineteen, he joined the American army, under WASHINGTON, and served during the war, with credit to himself and good to his country.

I have helped to make many dozens of them, and at present, have one for my own use.

On Sunday evening, alter a lingering illness, Mrs. MARY A., wife of John T. Clapp, and youngest daughter of Alexander Cascader, Esq., late of New-York, in the 30th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of her sister, Mrs. S. Alger, H. M. Soule, C. Hutchinson, W. Gregory, and her mother, Mrs. A. Cascander, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral,

Doctor CHAPMAN, (says the Philadelphia North American, of Friday,) an eminent physician and excellent man, died at his residence in Philadelphia, yesterday afternoon, at 6 o'clock. He had reached an advanced age, and for the last few years was rapidly declining in health.

The 'glorious Anniversary" was well observed in this city. The day was ushered in by a National salute of thirtytwo guns, fired at daylight by Captain TAFT'S Company of Light Artillery, which was repeated at I and 7 P. M. In the forenoon there was a fine parade of the militery.

The celebration commenced with a national salute. The Motgomery Guard, and the Irish Benevelent Societies, walked in procession, through the principal streets. At sundown another salute was fired, and at half-past 8 o'clock a display of fire-works took place in Van Vorzt's square. At Keyport and Communipaw, fairs were held and orations delivered.
The Seventy-stventh Anniversary of American Independence, was celebrated yesterday with considerable spirit. At sunrise, noon and sunset, national salutes were fired by Mayor POWELL, at Fort Green.

To-DAY'S CPLEBRATION.--The Committec of the Board of Aldermen of Jersey City has announced the programe for the celebration of this, our National Annivereary. A gun will be fired at day-brealk, and a national salute at sun-rise. At noon thirteen guns will be fired;

To-morrow is the day, of all the year, when the New-England fleet weighs anchor, and departs forth fishing grounds. It is stated, on the pretty good authority of the 'long-shore press of Massachussetts, that the majority of the skippers have laid in an invoice of gunpowder, with some fowling, as well as fishing, implements, in case an opportunity occur for sports more animated than. usual.

GRAND TORCHLIGHT PROCESSION.-The Fire Department of this City assembled in large numbers, on Saturday night, and formed in order of procession in the Park, to do honor to Columbia Engine Company No. 9, of Baltimore, who arrived on invitation of Manhattan Company No. 8, of this City. The greater part of the Fire Companies turned out, with their Engines, , and bearing a brilliant display of torches.

The ghost of Free-Soilism seems to be troubling the Democracy. Neither its old friends nor its old enemies succeed in laying it. It will not down at the bidding of either, or of both. It is only fair to say that those who petted it most while it was in the body,--to whom, in fact, it owed its life,-are now most zealous in their efforts to exorcise and banish it forever.

The season for the migration of the birds of passage and varied plumage, has commenced much earlier this, than last year; and the different Meccas of the fashionable and pleasure-seeking world, are being rendered exceedingly lively, by the buzz of porters, cabmen, travelers, and welldressed, polite clerks of the crack houses.

As I have looked in vain for anything like a correct account of the disastrous wreck of the ship William and Mary, I here send you one, leaving it to you to make what use of it you may think proper. I should have sent it before, but I have had no opportunity of doing so.

The Picayune brings dates from Mexico considerably later than previous arrivals. The accounts are from the Capital to the 11th, and Vera Cruz to the 15th June. On the 5th inst. the first number of the Diario Official made its appearance. It is limited strictly to the publication of government orders.

It is stated that the New-York and NewHaven Railroad Company have paid the sum of $5,000 to Mrs. M. W. Dimock, of Mansfield, whose husband was among the killed by the Norwalk disaster. This was the sum claimed by her, and it was promptly paid. It places Mrs. D. in comparatively comfortable circumstances.
Two huge volumes have just been issued, which will undoubtedly be the most interesting and remarkable Parliamentary publications of the season. They contain the results of the Census of 1851.

The public exercises of the next anniversary of Rochester Theological Seminary will commence on Sunday, July 12, with a sermon before the Missionary Society, by Rev. J. L. Burrows, of Philadelphia On Tuesday, President Wayland, of Brown University, mill preach before the Union for Minister Education.

In steamship Marian, for Charleston--Col. J. N. Bird, Mrs. Hampton and two children, J Preston, W. Preston and two servants, J. E. Dubose and lady, H. F. Prince and lady. S. Peck, B. Hood, Mrs. L. Fanshaw, N. Hendricks, T. Stewart, H. N. Conner, Jr., M. W. Wetmore, S. McGaughin, W. H. Lyon Miss Nelson, Mrs. Seixas, Miss Wainford, Miss Preston, Richard Manning, Robert Manning, Mr. E M. Gen. GADSDEN is still here, and as BUCHANAN did in English matters, so he desires authority to adjust all difficulties with Mexico. The Premier resists, as he did in BUCHANAN'S case. He has had several interviews with the President; but MARCY'S views will prevail.

In addition to the news given by telegraph this morning, we extract the following from the New-Orleans Picayune of the 26th: The Siglo Diez y Nueve having appeared several days in succession without leading articles, the editors published in explanation a note from the Government which they had received.

I embraced an opportunity, a day or two sing to visit Mount Vernon, so long the cherished home, and now the honored grave of WASHINGTON. It was the fourth time my feet had pressed that hallowed soil. Each occasion presented something of new interest; and my emotions of reverence increased, rather than diminished, on growing familiarity with the scene.

THE CRYSTAL PALACR.-A certain class of newspapers which appear to have a great penchant for every thing foreign, and a sovereign contempt for every thing American, are engaged in the very unpatriotic endeavor to cause the exhibition in New-York to be a failure-because, forsooth, it is not attended with all the display and royal magnificence of that of London.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the search after novelty, which animates the pedestrian in this traveling age, I intend marking out a route, which he can pursue with advantage, particularly if he be a lover of the picturesque or what is beautiful in Nature.

THE PBABODY INSTITUTE.-We learn from the Salem Register, that the Trustees of the munificent donation made by Mr. PEABODY, now of London, to his native town of Danvers, have finally adopted a plan for a building, and made contracts for its erection immediately, on the Wallis lot. The architect is RICHARD BOND, of Boston.
THE STORM IN BROOKLYN.-The storm of Friday evening passed over Brooklyn without doing any serious damage, other than the unroofing of a few buildings, and breaking of a large number of windows.

The act requiring a Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages, which passed the Legislature at the regular session, has gone into operation. It requires as full statistics to be kept of the births and marriages, as have been of the deaths in this City. The law applies only to this City.

THE TIMES' EUROPEAN LETTERS.-The New. York TIMES is publishing a series of letters on European Politics, which are ascribed by the editor of the Buffalo Commercial to no less an individual than KOSSUTH.-Toledo Republican. Commenting upon this paragraph, the New-York TIMES does not deny the correctness of this supposition.
Judge EDMONDS, on Saturday, dissolved the injunction previously issued to prevent the proper Department from signing the contract with Russ and REID, for paving Chathamstreet and the Bowery.

Mr. JOHN WEICKER, a German, who, for some yeas, has been engaged in the service of the American Tract Society, in distributing tracts among his immigrant countrymen, was yesterday afternoon abused by am emigrant runner in a shameful and cruel manner, while standing at the corner of Greenwich and Carlisle-streets, and handing around tracts to a number of immigrants, who received them very eagerly and gratefully.

SMALL GAME-AN AFFLICTED INDIVIDUAL.A poor old woman is going the rounds, who always wants a sixpence,-sometimes a shilling. She has weak eyes, and is a stranger in the City; and generally takes the wrong stage route, and in her confusion drops her money as she is leaving the stage.

The Lowell Journal says: Within a few weeks an entirely new worm has appeared upon the trees in this County, and seems to be doing great havoc. They strip the leaves from the trees. leaving large ranges as if entirely burnt over. They have been mistaken for the cauber-worm, by those who have not particularly noticed them, but on a little examination, they will be fund to be a very different animal,

MR. MACAULAY.--A correspondent of the Inverness Courier says: "I met Mr. MACAULAY, one day last week, processioninsing along in the old wya, and making Burlington Gardens re-echo the ferule of his umberlla. The step of the great historian was, to use a musical phrase, as staccato and firmly determined as ever.

Set down for July 12. No. 21. Oakley, respondent, agt. Morton. appellant. Argned. Samuel Beardsley, for appellant;

The sultry month upon which we have now entered, is the month, in all the year, most prolific of Collegiate honors. It may be called the Month of Commencements-not exclusively so, either-for, in the multiplicity of our Colleges, no one-twelfth ofa Gregorian year is sufficient to afford the several days it usually takes to get through with the exercises of each, without overlapping.

It is stated that the New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company have paid the sum of $5,000 to Mrs. M. W. Dimock, of Mansfield, whose husband was among the killed by the Norwalk disaster. This was the sum claimed by her, and it was promptly paid. It places Mrs. D. in comparatively comfortable circumstances.

The U. S. steamers Princeton and Fulton have been ordered from Norfolk, and the sloop-ofwar Decatur from Charleston, to Portsmouth, N. H., to await further orders. The Fulton and Decatur will be dispatched to the fishing grounds, and the Princeton also, if it should be decided not to send her to carry WALKER to China.

The National Anniversary passed off with the customary ebullitions of noisy patriotism. The unceasing detonation of implements of warfare peacefully handled, shook the quiet of the land from end to end;

THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER, the Irish patriot and ofator, lectured in this City, last evening, upon the subject of "Irish Politics in 1848." His audience, although not so large as might have been exTected, was highly respectable, and comprised many of his own countrymen.

To the Postmaster General: SIR : Your predecessor in the Post Office Department. under sanction of a Lawof Congress providing fr the manufacture of a stamped envelope, was plecasd to award to Mr. GEORGE F. NESDITT a contract for furnishing the said envelope. After an unreasonably long time, and need lessly protracted delay, Mr. NESDITT has produced all article by no means acceptable to the community.

Sixty years ago, a hunting party awoke the drowsy echoes in the sylvan shades of this quiet Saratoga. The sun was lapsing into another world, and pale Gynthia already shone in the rich robe of the parting day. The dogs were athirst,

It has not been expected, we believe. that the accused in the matter of the Cuban Slavetrade would expose themselves to the hazards of a defence. The attacks of the American press, followed by those of the British;

PUTNAM has a variety of good things in his July number. The " Educational Institutions of New York," is a well illustrated article, furnishing valuable and timely particulars respecting the colleges, medical schools, and schools for elementary education, in this City. "Life in Hawaii,"

Horatio Clarke, of Dedham, Mass.--For improvement in bobbins. Caristopher Duckworth, of Thompsonville, Conn.--For improvement in shuttle-box motion in looms.

We have had a great many exciting topics since the English steamer brought intelligence of the character of a late debate in the House of Lords, and Spanish houor-out here-has been most grossly outraged, for which instant reparation is to be made by the English Government, or they must abide the serious consequences of Spanish wrath, the vials of which are prepared for pouring upon the devoted heads of her ministry.

There has been a very general and a very just complaint of the prepaid envelopes recently furnished to the Government by Mr. NKSBITT,-principally on the ground that he affixed to each one his own private business card.

The Hagerstown Herald states that some new cases of what is supposed to be cholera, have occurred at Williamsport, within a few days. The total number of deaths since the disease appeared is 21, but it is hoped it will soon entirely disappear. The Rockville (Md.) Journal, says the yield of wheat in Montgorary County will be very heavy. The oat crop, it is feared, will be a failure,

The following appointments have been made in the Department of the Interior: SECRETARY'S OFFICE.--Fourth Class-K. Pritchett: J. Hood, Pa; A. J. H. White, Pa. Third Class.--Simeon Smith, N. Y.; O. W. Moore, Mich.: Geo. A. D. Clarke, Md. Second Class--Charles A. Packard; A. W Fletcher, Mass; S. G. Byde. Indiana; Robert Bowie, Md.

FROM YCATAN--A SLAVER CAPTURED.-A letter from Yucatan, dated June 14, narrates the capture of a slaver, which arrived at Laguna de terminus on the 30th May. She came in under Mexican colors, which was, as you may imagine, another matter of surprise to our people.

The case of Thomas Richardson against the city of Boston, relating to the common sewer at the foot of Summer-street will be tried before the United States Court, in Rhode Island, next month. Judge Sprague being a citizen and tax-payer in Boston, is interested in the case; and Judge Curtis, of the United States Court, has acted as counsel during a portion of the time since the suit was brought. The case is interesting.

The Crystal Palace was closed on and after yesterday, to all but Exhibitors and those who have business connected with the Exhibition. This course is rendered necessary by the approach of the day appointed for its opening, and by the fact that all the space is needed to facilitate the opening and arrangement of the goods.

A letter from Cherry Valley, Otsego County dated June 28, says: Mr. Clarke has just procured from the Arsenal here, six muskets, bayonets. , to be handed to Mr. Sherman, who occupies a farm belonging to Mr. Sherman, who occupies a farm belonging to Mr. Clarke, the former tenant having quietly surrendered and left the farm.

The Galena Jeffersonian says: Along the line of the Central Railroad, between Galena and Freeport, several new and thriving villages are springing up in the vicinity of depots, which bid fair to be populous and thriving villages.

The First Presbyterian Church at Morristown, N. J., was struck by lightning during the thunder shower on Wednesday afternoon. The fluid struck the steeple, melting the ball, and passed down into the ground, tearing it up for several feet. But slight damage was done.
FIRE.-Yesterday, about 9 o'clock, a fire broke out in the third story of house No. 9 South Fifth-street, owned by Mr. CARHART, and occupied by some twelve or fourteen poor families.

The Fourth was well honored by the Sons of Tammany, at the Old Wigwam. The Council Chamber was early crowded. The Grand Sachem-IsAAc V. FowLER, Esq.-being unavoidably absent from the city, his place was filled by GEORGEL S MESSERVE, the Father of the Council, who, after the company were comfortably seated, made a few introductory remarks in reference to the occasion that brought them together.

De Baun Thistle vs. City of New-York, Russ Reid, this case, these plaintiffs, as tax-payers in the City of New-York, for themselves and other taxpayers, have filed a complaint, asking that the Common Council of the City may be restrained from making a contract with the defendants, Russ Reid, for laying a portion of the streets with the Ruse pavement.

" Old Connecticut" had a glorious rally at Norwalk, on the Fourth. People gathered from far and near, to do justice to the occasion. The cars on the New-Haven Road went loaded down all day on Saturday, each train composed of not less than a dozen passenger-cars.

This has been an exciting day to the people of this place, being the appointed time for the exeention of GEOROE GATES for the murder of LILEY. At an early hour in the morning the different roads leading to the city of Ottowa were filled with vehicles of every description, loaded with men, women and children, hastening to see a fellow-mortal strangled to death.

HORSES.-The unusual high price of horses is a subject of constant remark. It is true that, during the last thirteen years, less attention has been paid to breeding than necessity demanded but the main cause of the scarcity of these important animals grows very much out of the large emigration to California.

An enterprise is in progress, under the aus pieces of the Peruvian Government, having in view the permanent establishment of a system of navigation on the South American River Amazon. Messrs. Lawrence Foulkes are constructing the pioneer steamers, two in number. One is 120 tons,

JOHN KELLY, a soldier of the Revolution, died in Union township. Muskingum County, Ohio, on the 11th ultimo, aged ninety-three years. Mr. KELLY was born in North Carolina, in 1755. At the age of nineteen, he joined the American army, under WASHINGTON, and served during the war, with credit to himself and good to his country.

SIXTH-AVENUE RAILROAD.-The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company is desirous of extending the double Brack of that Road down College-place to the new depot at the junction of that street with Barclay. Permission is only desired to occupy the street for a day or two,-a portion of the track being already laid down.

MORTALITY.-The Health Officer reports 71 deaths for the week ending July 2. 37 males, 34 females. Of these 18 were adults, and 53children. Diseases--Apoplexy, atrophy, cancer, convulsions, do. puerperal, dropsy abdomen, dysentery, erysipelas, bilious fever, scarlet fever, hooping cough, inflammation of brain, do. bowels, influenza, jaundice, premature birth, sprue, suicide, teething--one each. Cholera morbus, debility, drowned, small pox, sun stroke--two each.

It is gratifying to observe the generally favorable reports from the Middle and Western States of the Wheat harvest. The growth has been a fortunate one, and the yield will be almost universally large.

" The day is past. The Fourth of July, 1776, will be a memorable epoch in the history of Ameuica. I am apt to believe it will be celebrated by succeeding genera lions as a great Annivereary festival. It ought to be commemorated as the Day of Deliverance by solemn acts of devotion to Almighty God.
FIRE.-The residence of JAMES MARSH, at Centre Port, was consumed by fire on Tuesday night last. $1,500. Insured for $1,000 in the Huntington Mutual. The Flushing Railroad is progressing rapidly.

We are a good-natured people, and that is an excellently good sign. On the Fourth there was a riot in the Ninth Ward, where some five or six hundred Hibernians, and probably as many more of different taste and birth, banged each other zealously.

MORE APPOINTMENTS IN THE CUSTOM-HOUSE.--In addition to the long list which we published a few days ago, the following appointments have been made in the Custom House: Deputy Collectors--Charles C. Walden and John H. Hunt.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On this subject, which has, of late, received so much and such well-deserved attention will you permit me to offer a few remarks, trusting to you to make such use of them as you may see fit. Your paper has advocated both the proposed sites, urging that such public pleasure grounds cannot be too extensive. That principle is undoubtedly the true one.

At almost the eleventh hour, I seize my pen for the purpose of describing the proceedings of the people of the Puritan Athens of America, on this the anniversary of our National Independence--which, before my task shall have been completed, will have passed, with its three-score and fourteen predecessors, into the first of the two Eternities between which, Isthus-like, the Present Time is Situated.

THE CHEROKEE NATION.--We learn from the Cherokee Advocate, of the June 15, that meetings have been held in the Nation to nominate candidates for the National Committee, National Council, and Sheriffs. The Advocate announces the return of JOHN T. ADAIR, "one of the Ministers Plenipotentiary and Envoys Extraordinary from the Cherokee Nation to the Government of the United States of America." This is rather in the grandiloquent style.

GEORGE C. CHURCHWOOD and WM. SEARLS had a fracas here on Monday night. CHURCHWOOD fired three barrels of a revolver at SEARLS, each taking effect. The latter then drew a knife and rushed on CHURCHWOOD, inflicting on him four ghastly wounds, from the effects of which he died on the spot. SEARLS, it is thought, is so seriously wounded that he cannot recover.

The Union of this morning says Government is taking energetic steps in regard to the fisheries. and the rights and interests of fishermen will be fully cared for. The Republic says that the President will be accompanied, in his visit to the Crystal Palace, by Secretaries GUTHRIE and DAVIS, and Attorney General CUSHING.

Our Havana correspondent stated a few days since that Captain VINAS, the Spanish Captain of the Lady Suffolk, under whose command she made her voyage to Africa and back, becoming alarmed at the arrest of one of her owners, M. ZULUETA, by the Captain-General of Cuba, had taken passage in the Spanish steamer Isabel la Catolica for Spain. This is a mistake.

That Virginia belongs to the category of non-producing States, is a proposition which occasionally meets with contradiction. It grows ideas which are sometimes, as its tobacco is always, in the mouths of men--ideas often the obvious yield of an impoverished soil, though at times brilliant, and fanciful and eloquent, like a clump of palms stranded away in the Lybian Desert, where one is agreeably pleased to meet them.

We copy the subjoined article from the New-York TIMES of Monday last, for the purpose of correcting, promptly, the wholly erroneous impression which it is calculated to produce upon the public mind, in regard to the attitude assumed by the Administration upon the very important and interesting question of the protection of the rights of American fishermen, on their accustomed fishing-grounds, in the vicinity of the British North American Provinces.

The Anniversary of our National Independence was celebrated here to-day, with eclat and enthusiasm. The announcement that WASHINGTON HUNT would deliver the address drew together a large concourse of persons, who listened to it with the greatest satisfaction. The day was very fine, and all the arrangements admirable.

FROM THE RIO GRANDE.--We have Brownsville dates to the 22d June. The Flag calls attention to the card of the Commissioners of the Rio Grande and Brownsville Railroad Company, which Company was incorporated by the last Legislature of Texas. The card sets forth the conditions on which subscriptions will be received for the first section of the road, say from Point Isabel to Brownsville, a distance of about twenty five miles.

HALIFAX, Wednesday, July 6. The Royal Mail steamship America, Capt. LANG, from Liverpool, at 11 A. M. on the 25th June, arrived at this port, en route for Boston, at 6 1/2 o'clock this morning,--bringing 96 through passengers.

A long debate took place in the House of Commons on the 22d June, on the bill for the Inspection of Nunneries. Sir R. INGLIS moved its second reading. Mr. PHINN moved an amendment. that it be referred to a Committee for a revision of its details. The Government of India had been discussed two nights, and resulted in a further adjournment. Nothing else of interest has transpired.

Our Phiadelphia brethren make sad blunders in news items from abroad, every now and then. A correspondent of the Bulletin grew very indignant the other day over a telegraphic item, that Senator SLIDELL, of Louisiana, had reached Washington, on his way to his European mission.

Another fire broke out this morning about 1 o'clock in the large hardware establishment of KINYON, COLLINS Co., in West Oswego. The upper stores, occupied by three lodges of Odd Fellows and for law offices, are completely gutted. KINYON Co. saved their goods, though much broken and damaged by water. Their loss on goods is about $500.

It is customary in well-regulated families, for boys to wait, if the table is crowded, till company and the old folks have had their breakfast. The TIMES' table was very much crowded yesterday morning, and the boys of course waited.

The Boonsboro' (Md.) Odd Fellow, of Wednesday, says: "After a strong and foolish effort was made to deny the existence of the cholera in Williamsport, the paper published there and the citizens acknowledged the fact. Since our last, there have been numerous new cases and many deaths.
Considerable excitement appearing in Lombardy and Central Italy, from the prospects of war in the East,--and MAZZINI being again reported in Switzerland,--Austria has a large camp near Vazessa

The ticket for the Directors of the New-York Central Raiload is now being voted on at the City Hall. The following are said to be sure of success: For Directors--ERASTUS CORNING, Albany; JOHN V. L. PRUYN, Albany; EZEKIEL C. McINTOSH, Albany; RUSSELL SAGE, Schenectady; ALONZO C. PAGE, Schenectady; DAVID WAGER, Utica; JOHN WILKINSON, Syracuse; HORACE WHITE, Syracuse; JOHN H. CHEDELL, Auburn; HENRY B. GIBSON. Canandaigua: JOSEPH FIELD, Rochester; AZARIAH BOODY, Rochester; DEAN RICHMOND, Buffalo.

We copy on another page an article from the Washington Union, in reference to the Fisheries. The Union assures us that the negotiations are speeding towards a favorable conclusion; and repeats officially what the Telegraph has told us in advance, that two vessels are now under sailing orders for the protection of our fleet. We cheerfully comply with the organ's appeal, in acquitting the Administration of a design to neglect that exceedingly important interest.

The celebration of the Fourth in this City was a glorious one, in every respect. Notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather in the morning, the city was filled almost to its utmost capacity, at an early hour, with old men and women, young men and maidens, little boys and girls, and representatives from every class of people in our Valley.

We see it stated that the New-Haven Railroad Company have paid the widow of one of the Norwalk sufferers five thousand dollars, by way of indemnity. The statement is no doubt true. We have been apprised for some months past that private settlements are being made with the parties deprived of their family support, or otherwise damaged by the dreadful affair of the drawbridge.

J. Ross Dix, who was on board of the train of cars which was smashed up at East Brookfield recently, and who had his coat spoiled and his nervous system somewhat deranged in the course of the smash-up, has received $50 from the Railroad Company by way of damages.

We are to have Castle Garden Opera next Week, at ONE DOLLAR to all parts of the house. Preference seats will be distributed from four different ticket-offices, conveniently located through the City. The short season of eighteen nights will be directed under the auspices of Madame SONTAG, who secures, in advance, the services of MAX MARETZEK as Conductor.

DEAR SIR: I've been lingering around among the roses, this evening, until my heart has got the better of my head. I don't mention this as an unusual thing, for I'm notoriously subject to such accidents, only this has a flash more of the romantic. Certainly, there is something in these June evenings, that transforms one's brain into an enchanted land, and melts his heart into a pot of honey.

A pleasant rumor comes to us from over the sea, that JENNY LIND GOLDSCHMIDT is again to grace the Operatic Stage. The Briton Correspondent of the Morning Chronicle writes : If there be any truth in an assertion of the Dresden Echo, the prophecy of an illustrious composer to the effect that Madame LIND GOLDSCHMIDT would again appear on the stage, is likely to he realized.

The new Board of Public Works of Virginia, composed of Edward J. Armstrong from the northern, Archibald Graham from the central, and Thomas J. Boyd from the southern section of the State, originated at Richmond, on the 4th inst. Archibald Graham was chosen President, and William R. Drinkard Secretary.

The Hermann brings a few items touching the progress of the Chinese war, that have not been before received. Four hundred British troops were said to have been ordered to Shanghai for the protection of British interests.

As not only the highest and purest, but also the most powerful influence in every country are those which are exercised by what is called, par excellence, the Fair Sex, " An Englishman," in his " Stray Leaves on America," is bound, not only by courtesy, but by reason, to give them the precedence.

BILLS PASSED. To authorize the Grocers' Steam Sugar Refining Company to borrow money. To authorize the Supervisors of New-York to raise money by tax. The Jones' Wood Park bill was postponed till 11 o'clock tomorrow.

The U. S. Mail steamer Hermann, Lieut. HIGGINS, U. S. N., Commander, arrived yesterday morning. Her dates being the 17th ult. from Bremen, and the 22d from Southampton, have been anticipated by the America. She brings full cargo of German and French merchandise, and a large complement of passengers.

Why, hosts of omnibuses are passing every hour with the "Crystal Palace" shingle on them, and a sensible man will put his wife and ten children on board of any one of them, enjoy the scenery as he rides, and at last pull the strap, pay his family fare, and be set down at the very door of that gilded and beautifully-glazed institution.

The ship Grey Eagle from Rio Janeiro, 7th June, has arrived at this port. The Ludwig sailed for New-York on the 4th. Left at Rio U.S. frigate Congress--arrived on the 2d from La Plata, to sail for home on the 15th, June. Ships Ozark, from New-York for California:

The Swedish brig Alfrield, from Buenos Ayres May 22, nine days later, arrived here this morning. She reports in port ship Gondola, for New York, loading ; barks Sian, from Boston, arrived 22d; Thorndike, for New-York, soon; Roman, uncertain; brig Cronsladt discharging; schooner Henry A. If ever signs may be said to fail entirely in politics, they do so in regard to the Turkish question. The ordinary premonitions of war seem in this instance to be interpreted by the rule of contraries, and pass for the most satisfactory omens of peace.

The Reminiscences of an Old Doctor, now publishing in the Sunday Dispatch, form and interesting. Series of Sketches from Life in, New-York. From these articles we have become familiar with many of the curious doings in our City, and learned the secret histories of many domestic drains that have reached the public through no other channel. No professional such opportunities to know what is doing in the world, as the popular physician.

A part of the Baltimore train for this city was thrown off the track, near Wilmington, by a piece of wood being maliciously placed across the rails. The locomotive, tender, express and baggage ears were thrown off, the two latter being broken in fragments. The passenger cars were uninjured. Three persons got on the train between the express and baggage cars at Wilmington, unknown to the conductor, to avoid paving the fare.

On Wednesday, July 6, HENRY M. WESTERN, Engaged 55 years, one of the oldest members of the New-York Bar. The relatives, members of the Bar, and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, from his late residence No. 102 Lexington-av. On Friday afternoon July 8, at 4 o'clock. His repairs will be taken to Greenwood.

FINED FOR SETTING OFF FIREWORKS ON THE FOURTH--A Philadelphian named WILLIAM LONG, was brought before Justice SMITH, on Wednesday on a warrant charging him with violating a City ordinance on the 4th of July, by firing a pistol and making an undue noise, at a house where he was on a visic in Prince-street. The rooms described in my last are the only rooms now open to strangers. On a former visit, I was admitted to a large room in the north end of the mansion, extending entirely across from front to rear, and entered from the room last mentioned.

In reply to the attempts of certain presses to discredit my statement relative to the recent difficulty between Mr. MARCY and Mr. BUCHANAN, I have to repeat, on unquestionable authority, that exactly the serious difficulty named has existed, is not yet settled, and may not be; although the trouble will probably be ended by BUCHANAN yielding.

HENRY M. WESTERN, Esq., one of the oldest and most esteemed members of the New-York Bar, died at his residence is this City on Wednesday. For the last thirty years, Mr. WESTERN has occupied a prominent position as a legal practitioner and a Democratic politician.

COLORED TEMPERANCE CONVENTION.-The eleventh anniversary of the Delavan State Temperance Union, was held at Bergen yesterday. A large number were expected from the River Counties, as far up as Albany, but did not arrive. Several hundreds collected, principally from Jersey City, Newark, New-York and Brooklyn.

SENTENCE OF FOGARTY AT BUFFALO.--On Saturday, in the Special Term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, at Buffalo, Justice IRA HARRIS pronounced sentence upon LAWRENCE FOGARTY for the murder of JOHN BROWN. This act closed the labors of Judge HARRIS.

Broadway, cor. Reads-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Water.

The Convention of Colored Men had a long session last evening, when they debated a report submitted by the Committe on Social Position. The debate was continued through this morning's session, when the report was rejected by a large vote.

I have no need to tell you, at this late day, that LOUIS NAPOLEON'S system, having been founded upon treachery, is maintained by falsehood. It is rare that any newspaper dares to contradict or refute any assertions contained in an official report, however grossly untrue they may be.

The Steamship Europa arrived at "North-about," in the Mersey, at 5:30 P.M., on Saturday, 18th. Little was going on in Liverpool. ANDERSON, the Wizard, has taken the Aztec children to London, to exhibit to the Queen.

Justice rides in a slow coach, but generally manages to arrive in time to connect with the last train. It is gratifying to learn that she managed to get an introduction to two of the Tammany Hall rioters, on Wednesday; we hope she will enjoy a better acquaintance this very morning.

The Administration has awakened, at last, to the necessity of some energetic measures to prevent a collision between our armed fishing vessels, and the British Naval force, on the northeastern Fishing Banks. To-day, the Navy Department responded to the call of the President, by ordering three vessels-of-war to get in motion in that direction, although final orders to proceed to the Banks have not yet been issued.

At Hingham, Mass., at 12 o'clock on Monday, a very serious accident occurred. A number of persons were engaged in discharging a cannon, and Mr. Thomas Blossom and Mr. Eben Whitten were ramming home the charge, when a premature explosion occurred.

The case of John D. Hagar vs. John R. Thompson, Edwin A. Stevens, and others, was decided substantially on Wednesday, by Judge GRIKE, holding the United States Circuit Court at Trenton. The defendants in the case are the managers of the great New-Jersey Monopoly.

Our exchanges labor with the Cracker Question: whether the firing of squibs and crackers should be allowed on Independence Day, or not ? There are two sides to it--two very broad sides; and a talking man might find volumes to say on either side.

FIRE AND DISTURBANCE.--Near 8 o'clock on Wednesday evening a fire broke out in a house at No. 48 Gold-street. It was speedily extinguished. When the Fire Companies were returning through Peck slip, a disturbance occurred between Engine Company No. 2 and Hook and Ladder Company No. 1, which was, however, soon suppressed.

GENERAL CASS.--During our recent visit to Detroit, in company with a number of friends, we called on the venerable statesman and patriot, LEWIS CASS. We found him at his old mansion, in excellent health, enjoying a good old age, with all the comforts of life blooming around him.

DANGEROTS.-- The sidewalk on the corner of North Second and Ninth-streets, has been washed away by the late storm to such an extent as to render it extremely dangerous for night pedestrians to pass. It will be remembered that a certain contractor recently received $98 for doing about $25 worth of work on this place, some time since.

The water in the Ohio river has risen to about thirty-five inches, which enables light draft steamers to run to, and from Cincinnatti. Freights on the river are high. Dry goods, and other first class freights are at 30@35c. per 100 lbs. Fish, , from 70c.@$1 per bhI.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your intelligent correspondent, B. W. G., who noticed the article with the above title, and subjoined some valuable observations of his own, is informed that the mistake in Mr. DUCHE'S name occurred in the printing office, and not in the manuscript.

A SHARP BUSINESS LETTER.--A cotemporary publishes the following specimen letter from one of a class who think there is nothing valuable but trade in the world. It purports to come from a "cute" merchant, who writes, in reply to a boyish epistle from his son at boarding-school, to his master, to send him home, for reasons which he thus characteristically explains: "Sir: My son's of 10th inst. Came duly to hand, and cont's noted.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The propriety of having our public grounds adorned with works of art, has been justly advocated by many of our City papers; but some of them, in their hurry to make a beginning, have, I think, gone rather too far in suggesting that the statue of DE WITT CLINTON should be purchased, and remain, for the future, in front of the City Hall.

A MAN SWALLOWING HIS TEETH--Mr. EDWARD SCANLAN, a druggist in Cincinnati, recently had three teeth upon a gold plate, placed in his mouth. On Tuesday last, while asleep, the plate became loose, and Mr. S. swallowed it a short distance below the palate, when the suffocation it occasioned caused him to awake.

SHOCKING TRAGEDY.--The Lynchburg Virginian of the 4th inst., give the following particulars of a shocking tragedy in Buckingham County: We learn from a gentleman who came up the canal by Friday night's packet, that a most awful tragedy, resulting in the death of two brothers by the hands of a third, occurred in Buckingham County, on Wednesday or Thursday.

THE "MACHINE."--Opposite my dwelling is a fire engine, which is in a constant state of preparation for emergencies, to the great mystification of myself and of several small boys, which latter daily collect on the sidewalks, and look with profound curiosity into the dim recesses of the engine room. Never had engine such devoted attendants.

We shall have dull times here next week, though duller than the present were useless. With the President and three members of his Cabinet absent on their contemplated excursion to New-York, anything beyond the daily hum-drum of the departmental machinery of Government cannot be expected to develop itself here.

RIOT ON SHIPBOARD.--PROBABLE MURDER OF THE MATE.--Yesterday morning, near 2 o'clock, a riot occurred among the sailors on board the packet ship Jacob A. Westervelt, lying at the foot of Dover-street, East River. The crew fought with cutlasses, belaying-pins, and other weapons.

The Vestry of the Anglo-American Free Church of St. George the Martyr, have rented the building on the corner of Prince and Thompson-streets, heretofore occupied by the congregation of Emmanuel Church. Rev. ALEXANDER S. LEONARD has accepted the invitation to become the Rector of the Parish.

SUICIDE.--Mr. JAMES SUPPLE, an Engineer on the gravel train of the C. P. R., committed suicide on Friday evening last, by taking poison. He had made application for divorce from his wife, at the last session of the Court of Common Pleas, which was successful. His wife, however, had the decree set aside.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your correspondents who attempt historical criricism should be a little more familiar with their subjects. Besides the every-day authorities respecting the earlier chaplains to Congress, "B. W. G." might consult Bishop WHITE'S Memoirs, or Dr. GREEN'S--fifty books, indeed--and know from either of them more than he discloses in his article of this morning.

N., Commander of the second American Expedition for the rescue of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN, jointly fitted out by Mr. HENRY GRINNELL and Mr. GEORGE PEABODY, formerly of Danvers, Mass., now a Banker of the city of London. ST. JOHNS, Newfoundland, July 16.

It was a man named ESPY, if we remember rightly, who bore for some time the soubriquet of the "Rain-King," who caused to be introduced into the Legislature of Pennsylvania a "Bill for the Better Regulation of Storms and Thunder-Gusts."

FIRE AT THE QUARANTINE, STATEN ISLAND.--SIX HOUSES BURNED.--A fire broke out yesterday morning, about 3 o'clock, at the grocery store of MICHAEL McKEEN, (the upper part occupied by Mrs. FERRY and a German family,) owned by Dr. HARCOURT. The house and furniture were entirely destroyed.

Postmaster-General CAMPBELL and M. R. SCHLEIDEN, special representative from Bremen have just concluded an important arrangement, by which the mails will be conveyed between New-York and Bremen in the steamers Hansa and Germania, about to be placed on that line by FRITZE Co., a respectable commercial house in Bremen.

DEAR SIR: I wonder if any who have passed their youth in the country, ever forget the enjoyments which the season of berries brings to childhood? Who has not stooped down to caress a strawberry blossom, not merely because it was a flower, but because it was the earnest of the ruddy fruit.

ANOTHER CRIM. CON.--We learn that a certain Baptist preacher, who had been sojourning in Spencer County, in this State, was compelled to very suddenly leave the circuit last week, under rather peculiar circumstances. Madam Rumor, with her thousand tongues, has it that the reverend gentleman was entirely too familiar or attentive to a sister in the flock,--not his own, but another's wife.

DICKENS A WORKER.--DICKENS, is a real worker, as his works well prove. The last number of his Household Words, says: "In the last year we have read nine hundred manuscripts, of which eleven were available for this journal, after being entirely re-written.

The Russian Government has declared, in its Circular Dispatch to the several Courts of Europe, that the draught note to which Prince MENSCHIKOFF reduced his latest demands is the Gordian knot of the question now pending with the Porte, and that the sole desire of the Cabinet of St. Petersburg is to untie this knot in peace, without being compelled to burst it asunder.

COMMENCEMENT WEEK AT WILLIAMS COLLEGE.--The exercises will commence on Sabbath evening, August 14th, with an additional address before the Mills Theological Society, by Rev. Geo. W. Bethune, of New-York. Tuesday afternoon, Wm. Pitt Palmer, Esq., of New-York, will pronounce a poem, and Rev. Joshua D. Danforth, of Alexandria, D. C., will deliver the oration before the Alumni.

The President is coming; let us put our houses in order. If we may not give him a dinner,--and that he won't mind much, for there are plenty of eating-houses, and he does not lack for cash--any Yankee could get along well enough under such a combination of circumstances,--at any rate, let us sweep up and look respectable.

Given, six hundred Hibernians all in a row, to find the chances of a street-fight, and a score of bloody cock's-combs. The problem has been repeatedly solved, and the learner will not find it excessively difficult.

THREE-SCORE AND--When I was a boy I used to think three-score-and-ten years a very sufficient spell of this world. I wondered how anybody could grumble at so liberal an allowance of life; and indeed, for my own share, I would no more have hesitated to give up my claim to the odd ten years, than the gold-sellers do at the diggings to throw the odd ounces into the bargain.

Judge JOHN GLENN, of the U. S. District Court, Maryland, died this afternoon. At the special session of the City Council, resolutions were adopted appointing a Committee to make arrangements for the reception of the President, and authorizing the Mayor to draw on the Register for the funds necessary.

A HOTEL.--Some idea of the expenses attending upon a large hotel, may be gathered from the following, from a correspondent of the New-Bedford Standard, who writes about the United States Hotel, in Boston: "The hotel occupies 33,000 square feet of ground, has 380 rooms, easy accommodations for 550 persons, and capable of lodging and boarding 800.

A dispute occurred at Wallingford, Conn., on Saturday, between two Irishmen, (brothers,) living in the same house, in reference to the construction of a hog-pen, when from words they got to blows, and Michael, the aggressor, who was also the weaker, was between.

This morning, at 2 o'clock, the freight train which left Wilmington for Philadelphia, ran into Brandywine creek on the outskirts of the town. The bridge-tender says that he gave the proper signals of the bridge being open, but no attention was paid to them. The locomotive, tender, and two platform cars fell in, and the engineer, named GIRVIN, and a fireman, were drowned.

The Oswego Palladium of Wednesday, the 6th, furnishes the following details of the disastrous fire in that city, which was quite fully given by telegraph: We may sum up the calamity, in brief, as follows: All the Mills and Elevator on the east side are destroyed.

LECTURE ON LADIES' POCKETS.--At the Liverpool Borough Sessions, the Recorder said, there was a species of offence that seemed fast coming into vogue in that town, and all in consequence of women wearing pockets in their dresses. He found that in the year 1850, 163 children were brought before the Magistrates for picking pockets.

The Colored Convention discussed the subject of Colonization last evening, upon the report submitted by Rev. D. PENNINGTON. Speeches were made by FRED. DOUGLASS, REMOND, LANGSTON and GAINS, of Ohio, all in decided opposition to the scheme.

Mr. BEEKMAN moved to refer back the New-York Wharf and Pier bill to be reported complete. Objected to. The memorial of PETER COOPER and others, for a Committee to examine into the mode of electing the present Directors of Mutual Life Insurance Companies, was presented, with two others on the same subject.

Glancing back but two short years, and we find that not a house had been erected on the spot where Portland now stands. Presently, a location was made, a few houses erected, and even then, in order to bring the place into notoriety, it was necessary to notify the public that it was situated" twelve miles below Oregon City."
Dispatches received at the State Department from Hon. SOLON BORLAND, account for his silence by protracted sickness while traveling. He has now recovered and reports himself ready for instruction.

RAIN AT LAST.--Under this head, the Louisville Journal of Monday, remarks: "On the 18th of May last (nearly seven weeks ago) we were visited by a heavy shower, with thunder and lightning. A negro and his team were killed at the time in a lumber-yard on Walnut-street.

Cholera has entirely disappeared from Williamsport, Md.--no new cases having occurred since Saturday last. A special session of the City Council has been called to arrange for the reception of the President.

An attempt was made, at a meeting of the Common Council, Thursday evening, to quiet the feelings of opposition to the present Water bill, by adopting a resolution to the effect, that no Water Commissioner shall be elected but by receiving a two-third vote of the Common Council. The Water bill, as altered while at Albany, provides that the Commissioners may be elected by a majority.

The Aldermen yesterday stood upon their honor. A petition to remove a nuisance up town was held awhile in suspense, because it contained an indication that the petitioners would avail themselves of their rights, as expounded by the District Attorney, and do their duty for them, if the authorities declined to act in the matter.

The "event of the week" most talked of, if not the most important, has been the review of the troops encamped at Chobham, and now undergoing the hardships of a Summer campaign. It seems strange that a review of a mere handful of soldiers, compared with Continental gatherings, should excite so much interest among the huge miscellaneous body of sight-seers.

We have said that Slavery is one thing, and that the Slave-trade is quite another thing. In the popular mind they are confounded; and the thunderbolts which are hurled by indignant philanthropists against the system of domestic servitude which prevails at the South, are provoked by the atrocities of the Slave trade, in almost every instance.

The Courrier des Etats Unis publishes a list of the French contributors to the New-York Exhibition. They number five hundred names. The department of Minerals embraces specimens of white marble, white lead and ultramarine, and of painting in asphaltum.

On Friday morning, July 8, of cholera infantum, CHARLES EDWARD, only child of James Edward and Adelin Duff, aged 5 months and 28 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral this (Saturday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock from the residence of his parents. Franklin-av., between Willoughby and De Kalo-avs., Esq: Brooklyn.

A meeting of the Committee of Arrangements for the President's reception here met this morning, and appointed a sub-committee to report a plan. They met again this afternoon. The City Councils have tendered Independence Hall to the President to hold a levee in.

The Utica Baptist Register says that Rev. Dr. Beecher has resigned the pastorate of the Pearl street Baptist Church in Utica, and delivered his farewell discourse last Sunday. The affection of his throat was such that he was unable to endure the exercise of preaching, without great inconvenience and peril;

During Saturday, Coroners GAMBLE and WILHELM investigated three more cases of murder, perpetrated in various parts of the City. the details of which will be found in the following proceedings: THE CENTRE STREET SHOOTING CASE. An inquest was held on the body of a young man named Patrick McNulty, aged 26 years, a native of Ireland who came to his death by injuries received from the discharge

A Democracy is generally understood to be a form of Government in which the greatest good of the greatest number is steadily consulted, as its leading and controlling object. Under other institutions, the interests of individuals are often allowed to control arrangements designed for the public good.

The Dayton (Ohio) Gazette says the attorneys employed by John W. Carey, in the suit brought by him against the Commissioners of that County, received their fees the other day, amounting to the snug little sum of $10,500, $5,000 of which went to one firm. The case was litigated three years.

The Castle Garden season opens this evening, with a strong cast in Lucia di Lammermoor. The arrangements of the management, for the comfort and convenience of visitors, are upon a liberal scale, and the combination of vocal and instrumental talent such as can scarcely fail to make the Opera complete.

SUICIDE IN CHICAGO.--Dr. F. A. BESELIN, a German physician of this city, committed suicide yesterday afternoon, under the following melancholy circumstances: He had, a few weeks since a female patient on the west side of the river, and, after his professional services were no longer needed, he presented his hill to the employer of the girl,--a butcher.

The friends of the President will remember, we hope, that their friendship will be most eloquently expressed this week, by keeping out of his sight. A Presidential progress is a terribly trying affair.

The U. S. Mail steamer Atlantic, Captain WEST, arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Liverpool at 1 o'clock on the 29th ult. Among her passengers are Prof. MITCHELL. Hon. Mr. WILLIAMS, Mr. HABERSHAM, Mr. S. C. MASSETT, As telegraphed from Halifax, the Arabia arrived out at thirty-four minutes past ten o'clock, Saturday morning, 25th ult.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The public are not aware of the dangerous influence of organized bands of men, who surround the Legislature, selling their services to any bidder, in order to promote or defeat the passage of any bill, utterly regardless of its merits or demerits.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In common with many of your contemporaies, allow me to say, you have been led into a slight inaccuracy in regard to Mr. ADAMS' notice of Dr. DUCHE. The account given by Mr. ADAMS of "the First Prayer in Congress," is found in a letter to his wife, dated, September 16, 1774.

In another column will be found a brief letter noticing the Democratic celebration of the Fourth of July in Philadelphia. It comes from a Democrat, and has marked significance in its relation to current political events. It seems from its statements, although they are couched in guarded language, that this was strictly a Democratic celebration;

He was the Liberator's eldest son, and of all his family, perhaps the most nearly resembled him in appearance, and in the tones of his voice.

The Atlantic brings us nothing to end the suspense which hangs over the settlement of the difficulties in Eastern Europe. It seems to be settled that Russia has menaced Turkey with war, if her ultimatum were not accepted within eight days;--that Turkey positively refused to accept it;--that the eight days have expired, and Russia yet stands still.

Poor DE MAUPAS! Join with me in lamenting the downfall of the Minister of Police. Let us unite our regrets, and mutually endeavor to administer to each other the consolations of which we stand so much in need. In the first place, let me caution you against putting any confidence whatever in the " considerations " upon which the decree suppressing the Minister of Police is based.

The recent death of this gentleman, at Cincinnati, deserves something more than the mere record of the event in the columns of a daily journal. He was known to, and esteemed by, too many warm and attached friends, to permit even those who knew him not, to glance over his name in the records of death, and then to let it pass away and be forgotten.

THE RECENT HAIL STORM.--Judging from the accounts in the Pennsylvania papers, the recent hail sterm in that State was the most severe of any ever experienced. Near Shoemakertown, the top of a carriage was completely perforated by the hail, the stones passing through into the carriage.

The CRYSTAL PALACE is now pushed towards completion with great rapidity. An immense number of workmen are employed upon it day and night, and an army of exhibitors are engaged in introducing and arranging their goods. Very few of the boxes containing articles for exhibition have yet been opened, but a great deal will be done in this direction during the next three days.

FIRE IN CROSBY ST.-Near3 o'clock on Saturday morning, a fire broke out in the rear building of No. 85 Crosby-street, occupied as a smoke-house and paekingestablishment. The damage sustained was not less tha-, $500, which is fully covered by insurance in various City companies. The Chief of Police. and a strong foree of his men were present, together with several fire companies.

The storm of Saturday evening, which in this City amounted to little more than a succession of showers, attended at times with a good deal of wind from the North, elsewhere occasioned much damage. At Haverstraw, on the Hudson River, some forty miles from the City, the wind rose to a perfect hurricane.

GEORGIA.--Mr. CHARLES H. JENKINS formally accepts the nomination of the Conservatives for the Governorship of the State. He dislikes intervention and innovations, is in favor of economy in Government, and goes for the moral and social improvement of the people of Georgia.

The Joint Committee of the Common Council are making their arrangements for receiving President PIERCE. In another column they advertise for societies who wish to join in the procession to present themselves as soon as possible. This is well.
