THE CRYSTAL PALACE OPENING. Mr. TABER offered a resolution declaring the appreciation of the Legislature of the high importance of the great Industrial Exhibition, and accepting the invitation to attend the opening, which was adopted. THE ACKNOWLEDGEMENT OF DEEDS. Mr. BEEKMAN had consent to have the bill amending the act authorizing Commissioners to take proof and acknowledgement of deeds in other States, read, and it was passed.

It is asserted, and believed by many, that there was a very warm discussion between two members of the Cabinet, yesterday. Messrs. CUSHING anti MARCY are the parties named; and the subject of dispute is said to be the Fisheries. Gen. BAYLEY, Member of Congress from Virginia, arrived here to-day. It is conjectured that he may get the French Mission, and that WISE will succeed him in Congress.

On Saturday morning July 9, CATHARINE H, youngest daughter of Benjamin Haight, Esq. The relatives and friends of the family, and of her brothers, Rev Dr. Haight, and Augustus H. and Edward Haight, are invited to attend her funeral, without further invitation, on Monday afternoon, the 11th inst., at the Church of the Annunciation, 14th-st, at 3 o'clock precisely.

SQUADRON FOR THE FISHING GROUNDS -We learn that the steam-frigate Princeton, Commander EAGLE, sailed from Norfolk on Thursday for Portsmouth, N. H., whence she is to proceed without delay to the fishing grounds. The steamship Fulton, the repairing of which has just been completed at the Gosport Navy Yard, will sail in a few days for the same destination.

The weather for several days past has been variable-a day or two of the torrid zone succeeded by the rains and the moist coolness of Western Europe-enabling us to get along pretty fairly, and sparing us anything like the terrible sun-striking of your City. This is Independence Day; it revealed itself in our dreams, with crepitations.

NEWFOUNDLAND AND THE FISHERIES.--Considerable excitement has been recently caused in Newfoundland by intelligence transmitted by a private letter from England, that negotiations were going on between the French and English Governments for the cession of the island of Belleisle to France.

The Arabia has proved herself, in point of speed, the Eclipse of the ocean. She has fairly won the blue ribbon of the sea. The official report of her passage out,--leaving this port on the 15th of June,--which we copy in another column, from the Liverpool Courier, represents her as having made the trip in less time, by fifteen minutes, than it has ever been done before.

In San Francisco. June 15, Joseph S. Curdon, aged 7, formerly of Lowell, Mass. In Los Angeles, on the 27th May, Henry E., eldest son of Henry and Gusdalupe Dalton, aged 5 years. At Oregon Creek, June 1, of fever. Richard Thornton, aged about 35 years, from Arkansas.

The Springfield Republican says that PERSSE BROOKS, paper-makers, are erecting a large two-story mill at Windsor Locks, in addition to their present one, at a cost of $100,000. It is to be 300 feet long by 100 wide, and will be supplied with two 84-inch machines for making the paper, and 14 engines for beating up the stock.
VOTE ON THE WATER PLAN.-The vote on the Water Plan, submitted by the Brooklyn Common Council the citizens, yesterday, resulted as follows:

To the Editor of the London Daily News: SIR :-At the present crisis of affairs in China, it may be well to call attention to the secret associations, which are the prime movers in the rebellion. John Chinaman has been eminently successful in mystifying the "outer barbarians" with respect to these societies.
The President is on his route hither-ward. He rode on horseback through Baltimore, yesterday, and made a flattering speech to the Monumental citizens.

BOARD OF ASSISTANTS.--MONDAY.--JONATHAN TROTTER, Esq., President, in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Petitions referred--Of A. Arnous and others, for a sewer in Third-avenue to Eighty-sixth-street; of John Anderson, to construct a bay-window on the side of his house, corner of Thirty-eighth street and Madison-avenue.

General Remarks. During the week which has elapsed since our last issue, there has been a fair degree of activity in the general market. This, we may observe, however, is principally, if not altogether, confined to supplying actual demands for consumption, or assorting stocks; there being little inducement to invest speculatively in the present or prospective condition of business.

The accounts from the county are quite disheartening. On one plantation they have lost 280 negroes from cholera. The Chinese have also suffered terribly. In some instances the whole number taken on the estate have been swept off. If it comes to the city, it will make sad havoc, added to the yellow fever.

We have dates from Lahaina to the 13th May. A letter to the Alta says: Ships that have touched here from home have reported a very good fare of oil--from 75 to 350 bbls. sperm--the average about 150 barrels, which they would have been glad to ship, but were unwilling to incur the expense of going inside Honolulu harbor for so small a quantity.

The Committee of the Whole, Mr. OTIS in the Chair, immediately proceeded to the consideration of the Supply bill. RARE OLD BOOKS. In the item providing for the purchase of the GEORGE CLINTON papers, Mr. BABCOCK suggested that the State should wait until the collection had been thoroughly examined.

" He couldna' sleep for thinkin' o't--BURNS. Many thanks, Mr. Editor, for your kind suggestion that the country air would best suit my complaint. More thanks be yours, still,--thanks surcharged with gratitude, as a thunder cloud with electricity,--thanks heaped up, and overflowing, like a bushel of Jersey peaches,--for pointing an index finger to Niagara.

The annual meeting of this Company was held in Washington on the 6th and 7th inst., and the following officers were elected for the ensuing year, (ELAM ALEXANDER, the former President, and Hon. AMOS KENDALL, former Treasurer, having declined a reelection:) SMITH MOWRY, Jr., Esq., of Charleston, S. C., President; D. F. CLARK, of Macon, Ga., Secretary; and B. B. FRENCH, of Washington, Treasurer.
DELEGATES TO THE EXHIBITION.--Governor HEBERT, of Louisiana, has commissioned the following gentlemen to represent that State at the Great Exhibition in this City.

Our reporter yesterday again visited the scene of the melancholy disaster which occurred at Haverstraw, Rockland County, on Saturday. The brick-yards which line the shore from Lower Haverstraw (opposite Croton) for some miles up the coast to Colwell's, bore evidence of the violence of the gale of Saturday.

There is a gradual showing of hands in Spanish politics, which must presently let us into all the secrets and windings. The other day, the Gaceta de Habana enlightened us upon the future treatment of the Slave trade, not omitting to do exceeding justice to the transcendent merits already exhibited by the Captain General as a detective policeman.

The Hudson River Railroad Company is, we understand, applying to the Common Council for leave, in conformity with its Charter, to construct a third track through the whole length of the City, solely for the conveyance of City passengers.

A quorum of the Board was obtained last evening some time after the hour for assembling: the President in the Chair. A communication from Wm. Hall Son, soliciting the honor of the attendance of the Board at Madame Soutag's opening Concert on the 15th, on which occasion the President of the United States is expected to be present, was received, and the invitation accepted.

By the British steamer Quito at Panama, we have dates from Lima to June 12, and from Valparaiso to June 1. Among the passengers on the Quito was WM. F. NYE, Esq., of the house of NYE Co, Valparaiso, who is on his way to Washington, as bearer of dispatches from Hon. BALIE PEYTON, Minister to Chili from the United States.

A CHILD AND JEWELRY STOLEN AT MORRISANIA.--On Saturday last, about 3 o'clock P. M., a servant girl named ANN RICHARDSON, in the family of ALEXANDER FOLMER, Esq, who had come into the family only the day before, left the house under pretence of going to a store near by, taking with her Mr. FOLMER'S little boy, about three years old.

Major J. R. BENNETT, of Missouri, "Anti-BENTON" has been appointed Consul at Bahia, and WM. LILLEY, of Ohio, Consul at Pernambuc. General ST. JOHN B. L. SKINNER, of Clinton County, N. Y., has been appointed principal Clerk in the Appointment Office of the Post Office Department, vice SAMUEL NORTH, of Oswego County, who has been made Special Mail Agent for New-York.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The word of LUCANUS, "Liceat sperare timenti," "Be the fearing permitted to hope," will account for the fact, that the Democracy of Europe still clings to the sanguine idea that Republican America may yet do something for the principle of Democracy.

The world would certainly have been in a fit of the sulks if, on being shut out from its cronies for two weeks together, it had not a fine lot of news to tell. Seventeen days had elapsed between the arrival of the last California items by the Northern Light, and the reception of the first from the Illinois, yesterday morning.

The Committee of Reception go to Wilmington to-morrow morning in the steamer John Stevens, to meet the President. The number of the Committee will be much reduced, the members finding that they have to pay $3 each for the excursion and collation.

President PIERCE, accompanied by Secretaries GUTHRIE and DAVIS, and Post master-General CAMPBELL, arrived here at 5 1/2 o'clock this evening. They were met at the railroad depot by an immense concourse of citizens, and a large turn out of the military, who escorted them to BARNUM'S Hotel.
The President and suite left here, quietly, at 3 1/2 o'clock, on their northern trip. Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER goes to New-York to-night, to join Judge MACY, of Wisconsin, for a western trip.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Monday, July 11.--Before Hon Judge BEEBE--At the opening of the Court of General Sessions this morning, at the Halls of Justice, the Court-room was densely crowded with spectators to witness the sentencing of the convicted rioters, who were the leaders of the infuriated mob that made an attack on the drug store of Dr. GEO. H. WHEELER, corner First avenue and Seventeenth street, on the 22d ult.

The arrival of the Illinois brings us intelligence from Hong Kong four days later than had been previously received; but it gives us very little additional news concerning the actual progress of the Rebellion.

The Black Warrior arrived too late, last evening, to proceed on her voyage same day. She will leave this morning at 8 o'clock, for Mobile. We have well-grounded information of two more landings effected upon the coast by the incorrigible slavers--one near Matanzas, covering six hundred; and one at the Isle of Pines, said to be 540 or 550.

The Opening scene for the Summer Opera Season at this establishment was a bright and auspicious one last evening. The audience was a very large one, compared with the fullest Winter attendance at NIBLO'S, though the Garden was by no means crowded at the wings.

By way of San Francisco, we have later dates from China. The accounts are from Hong Kong to the 27th of April, and from Shanghae to the 15th. The intelligence is important as regards the movements of the United States Squadron and the progress of the rebellion.

Rev. HENRY CHASE, Pastor of the Mariner's Church, in Roosevelt-street, was struck with apoplexy on Thursday last, remained alive, but paralyzed on one side, throughout the night and succeeding day, and died on Friday evening, being nearly sixty-three years of age.

ATTEMPT TO COMMIT SUICIDE.--On Sunday morning a respectably-appearing woman undertook to commit suicide while under the influence of despondency, or temporary derangement, owing to trouble. She has been living at the West.

On Sunday, July 10, EDWARD M., son of Edward D. and Emily L. Webb. aged 9 months and 15-days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, at 5 o'clock, thrs (Tuesday) afternoon, from the residence of his parents, 87 Jane-st.
A train on the Hamilton Railroad ran into a milk wagon near this City to-day, killing the driver instantly.

From the Oswego Times. It has been currently and generally believed that the great fire of Tuesday originated from the friction of machinery connected with the smut mill of Messrs. FITZHUGH LITTLEJOHN'S flouring mill. This, we are assured by their miller, Mr. BROWN, is a mistake.

The U. S. Mail Steamship Illinois, Lieut. H. J. HARTSTENE, U. S. N. commanding, arrived at this port yesterday morning from Aspinwall, bringing the California Mails and specie of the 8th and 16th June. The news is two weeks later.

The Anderson, S. C. Gazette, says: "Complaints of the drought are still coming in upon us thick and fast. It is now almost a certainty that the Oat crop is completely cut off for the want of rain, the Oats not being high enough to cut.

Every traveler in England must have noticed the extent to which the second class Railway carriages, the city omnibuses, and other means of public conveyance are used as means of advertising, Their sides, and often their windows, are covered with business placards; and this is often carried so far, especially in the London omnibuses, as to obstruct the entrance of the light and interfere with the comfort of passengers.

PLYMOUTH CHURCH.--The recent deaths in Mr. BEECHER's family drew together an unusual number of persons at Plymouth Church, yesterday morning, expecting that the subject would be appropriately alluded to. They were not disappointed.

ALBANY, Friday, July 8, 1853.--No. 223. (A privileged cause.) The People, defendants in error, against Darry, plantiff in error. Argued. N. Hill, Jr., for plaintiff in error; John L Talcott for defendants in error. No. 59. Gates, appellant, agt. Brower, respondent. Submitted N. F. Graves, counsel.

The Brooklyn people must drink pump-water a while longer. They fancied that water drawn from the far-off springs which were proposed to supply them, would contract a metallic taste before reaching the goblets of citizens.
BUFFALO, every one in New-York knows almost as well as the City itself. It is one of those monster-growths on the frontiers of the great West, destined to be a yet greater inland centre of Commerce.

One of the late decrees of the Emperor meets with a good deal of opposition--that postponing the usual Exposition of Paintings of next year until 1855, and making the Gallery of that year a Universal one, to coincide with the Crystal Palace season.

The Santa Fe Weekly Gazette, speaking of the American title to the Mesilla valley, makes the following important declaration, which will, if rendered authentic by documentary and historical evidence, have an important hearing upon the decision of the question:

The Odeon closed for the Summer, with the 94th representation of Honneur et Argent. The re opening takes place in September, with a play imitated from the Spanish by M. MERY. It is entitled "Gusman," and the hero is one of the ancestors of the Empress.

We published, some days since, an admirable speech made in the House of Commons by T B. MACAULAY, upon the question of excluding judicial officers from Parliament. We find in the re port of Parliamentary Debates another long speech made by him on the 24th of June, upon the vexed question of a Government for India.

Mr. GADSDEN, our new Minister to Mexico, had several interesting interviews, before leaving this city, with Senor ALMONTE, who has just succeeded Senor LARRAINZAR, as Mexican Minister resident at Washington. Mr. GADSDEN has an ardent desire to cultivate amicable relations between this country and Mexico, through means of a more liberal commercial system; and to this point, probably, will he direct his best efforts.

For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns BROADWAY THEATRE.--Uncle Pat's Cabin--In and out Of Place. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--English Opera Company.

On Tuesday morning, July 12, at 7 o'clock, of hemorrhage of the lungs, Mrs. JANE, wife of Wm. Willson, aged 51 years. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday, the 13th inst, at 2 o'clock P. M., from her late residence, No. 192 Delancey-st. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment

Within the past ten days, says the Rochester Union, a number of cattle and swine, pastured in a lot on Cayuga-street, near the Erie Canal, have died suddenly, with all the symptoms of having taken poison. Several citizens have lost cows that were pastured in this lot.

We publish this morning a full report of the testimony taken yesterday before Justice STUART, in the case of the parties charged with causing a riot in the Ninth Ward on the 4th of July. We give also the application of their counsel for their discharge, and the reply of the Justice in refusing to comply.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: My attention has been called to an article is the Home Journal, of June 25, headed " Desecration of Niagara Falls." A sense of justice, and a feeling of proper resentment, requiring an answer from some one of the parties concerned, I beg, for this purpose, a limited space in your journal.

SLAVE THROWN OVERBOARD AND DROWNED.--In Recorder WINTER'S Court, in New-Orleans, on the 2d inst., the captain, mate and clerk of the steamboat Anna, now lying in the New Basin, were held to bail in $5,000 each, for an examination in reference to the death of the slave GODFREY, be longing to Mr. HART, under the following circumstances:

THE WESTERN RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--The supplementary accounts of this catastrophe, except so far as relates to individual disaster, add nothing to the statement which we printed yesterday. The Worcester Transcript winds up its relation with the following paragraph, which, we are assured, is substantially correct: " Upon whom the responsibility of this disaster falls, we will not presume to say ; but that it was the result of gross carelessness, is evident.

COMMENCEMENT WEEK AT ROCHESTER.--The Anniversary exercises of the University of Rochester. and of the Rochester Theological Seminary, take place this week, and promise to be of a highly interesting character. The public exercises commenced on Sunday evening, July 10, with a sermon before the Judson Society of Inquiry, by Rev. J. L. BURROWS, of Philadelphia.

PHILO WHITE, Esq., of Wisconsin, has been appointed Charge d'Affaires at Ecuador. Ex-President TYLER is sojourning at Old Point Comfort. His health is feeble, and he expects soon to visit the Mountains, under advice of his physicians.

DISGRACEFUL PROCEEDINGS.--Sunday evening, a party of twenty or thirty rowdies, from 14 to 21 years of age, proceeded to the porter houses of ANDREW WELLS, WM. BRAISTED, PETER SCHARNAGER, GABRIEL YENK, and others in the First Ward, and after drinking all they wished, assaulted the bar-keepers, and broke decanters, tumblers, windows, , indiscriminately.

We gave, in the DAILY TIMES of yesterday morning, full reports received by Telegraph of the enthusiastic welcome extended to the PRESIDENT on his arrival at Baltimore, and of the eloquent speech which he made in reply. The addresses of the members of his Cabinet were also briefly sketched, but we have since received full reports of them from our own Reporters.

Doleful accounts of the damage by the late tornado continue to come in. In Berks County, great destruction was done in Lower Heidelberg, Spring, Cumric, Exeter, Union, Amity, and other of the lower townships ; barns, dwellings, mills, and all kinds of houses being unroofed and other wise injured, crops beaten down,

The burden of debate yesterday in the Legislature, concerned the adjournment, and Impeachment question. By way of a breathing spell, the Senate had up the bill appropriating $200,000 of the remainder of the proceeds of the sales of Canal revenue certificates, $200,000 of the Oswego Loan, and $500,000 of the surplus revenues, to the Erie Canal Enlargement, and Black River and Genesee Valley Canals, and went through with it.

While it is difficult to tell what is a casus belli just now in Europe, in South America it is hard to tell what is not. Peru and Bolivia are by the ears. The essential subject, bad money; the immediate provocation, the expulsion of Messrs. PARADES and CEBALLOS, the Peruvian agents in the latter country, with circumstances of peculiar indignity.

The trial of JOHN HENDRICKSON, Jr., for the murder of his wife, has terminated at Albany, in a verdict of guilty. This seems to he acceded to, by most, as the only verdict that could be rendered, considering the evidence.

The Nautical College of Quebec is an important Institution. It has been established by the Provincial Government, for the purpose of giving instruction in Mathematics and their application to Nautical Science, to such persons as are desirous of qualifying themselves for the Naval or Merchant Service.

Visit to a Rice Plantation Continued. Mr. A has two rice plantations, a few miles apart, besides a large tract of forest land, reaching above the malarious district, in which there is a house for his overseer's family to retire to during the fever season.

It is related of some famous painter--BLAKE perhaps, who was the maddest genius of his time--that he once invited a large company of connoisseurs to his studio, to see a bit of atmosphere so naturally painted as to be quite indistinguishable from the real article.

American journalism, like American ship building, is beginning to show itself beyond every other. No doubt the foremost English journals--and the English are the only ones which at all enter into comparison with ours--exhibit a large amount of political science, ability, scholarship, , and are sustained by a high order of general intelligence and enterprise.
RECEIVED AT THE OFFICE OF THE NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES

Philip Greeley, Esq., of Boston, has re turned to Austin, Texas, on business, in connection with the Northern Railroad delegation now making a reconnoisance in that State. Mr. Greeley ex presses himself highly satisfied with Texas--says it has more than fulfilled his expectations, and he is astonished at finding so much greater a variety and abundance of natural resources, than he ever believed she possessed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your excellent correspondent, ION, in your issue of 11th July inst., makes some mention of Lord KINGSBOROUGH; and says that "it certainly looked odd to see him neglect the cabins of his poor peasantry at Mitchelstown, for the grotesque diableries of the Toltecs, Aztecs, and so forth."

A large and respectable attendance assembled, at the corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty fourth-street, last evening, and joined in the religious services, on the occasion of laying the corner stone of a new Presbyterian church, of which Rev. Dr. ADAMS is to be pastor. The foundations are laid 14 feet deep.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The progress of the Monument to the memory of our great WASINGTON is retarded, for want of funds. Every American is, or ought to be, interested in the completion of this national work. Cannot fifty thousand dollars be raised in the Crystal Palace, almost without an effort ? I answer yes and easily.

The Louisville Courier predicts that J. Ross BROWNE will return from his visit to China with material for the best book that has yet been written upon that country. We venture another prediction,-that he will write for the DAILY TIMES the most interesting and readable series of Letters ever published from that remote region of the Earth.

STEFFANONE reappeared last evening to very fine advantage. The audience was large, and grew enthusiastic under her truly dramatic rendering of Norma. The opera, at all times a popular one, appeared to double advantage under the lead of one whose finest successes in Havana and the United States are identified with the character.

In the DAILY TIMES of yesterday morning, we gave an account of the President's official reception at Independence Hall, in Philadelphia, with a report of the speech which he made on that occasion. After this was concluded, the President, and the members of the Cabinet accompanying him, reached his quarters at the Merchants' Hotel, on Fourth-street, shortly after 7 o'clock, P. M.

An extensive riot took place at Pembroke, near Long's Corners. Genesee County, on Wednesday last, resulting in the death of two persons. On Tuesday morning, Mr. RICHARDSON, foreman on CLARK, WOOD Co.'s job, on the Buffalo, Corning and New-York Railroad, gave directions that dump boxes, for the dirt wagons, should be procured, of larger size than those then in use.

ANOTHER WATER PLAN FOR BROOKLYN.-An adjourned meeting of the Common Council was held Tuesday evening, at the City Hall, Alderman HARTEAU, of the Sixth Ward, in the Chair. At a late hour of the Session, Alderman MARVIN, of the Fourth Ward, asked permission to offer a preamble and resolutions relative to introducing water into Brooklyn, which being granted, the following was submitted:

It is unfortunate that that side of Christianity and civilization-that outer edge which comes in contact with the rest of the world, is always the one we have the best reason to be ashamed of. California, if we except the Sandwich Islands, is the farthest dwellingplace of our population.

The first great Exhibition of the Industry of all Nations ever had on this Continent, is to be opened with due solemnities to-day. The building has been so far completed as to be very well prepared for the Inauguration. The decoration of the immense dome was finished yesterday afternoon;

The traffic in Dry Goods is steadily, but slowly, regaining vigor. Daily are city merchants reappearing at their old stands, and country jobbers arriving in the metropolis. Still, this does not lead to heavy operations, as our local traders are mainly occupied with preparations for the Fall business;

It is, to me, a source of unmitigated sorrow that St. Valentine's Day falls mid-winter instead of mid-summer. Indeed it is a thousand pities. The more I think of it, the more am I buried in a pro found source of regret. To be sure, I condole with young Sorrowsoft, and bid him take courage.

A HORRIBLE STORY OF DESTITUTION, MISERY AND CRIME IN BOSTON.-A few days ago, Constable E. J. JONES, discovered in a cellar in Stillman-place, a family who were living in a state of misery hardly credible. Their subterranean apartment, which was not over ten feet square, was occupied by a man, his wife, and a laughter about six years of age.

On Wednesday morning, July 13, by his Honor, Jacob A. Westervelt, Mayor of New-York. Mr FRANCIS JENKINS to Miss MARY E., daughter of Mr. Wm. Pearsall, Jr., all of Jersey City. On Tuesday, June 12. by Rev. Dr. Francis Vinton, JOHN GANDY of Liverpool to MARY MILDRED, daughter of Coleman Williams, Esq., of this City.

There was a great fire at Newark on Tuesday night, beginning in D. RIPLEY Cols planing mill. It originated from the engine-room, where, as the fireman was putting shavings into the furnace, a puff drove out the blaze into the room, setting on fire the combustible materials around.

On Tuesday afternoon, July 12. ROBERTINA, daughter of the late Robert McCane, of Philadelphia, in the Gth Year of her age. The relatives and friends of Joseph Dunn, and of her grandfather, Thomas Cumming. are respectfully invited to attend her funeral to-morroow(Thursday) afternoon, (without Further invitation) at 2 o'clock, from the residence of her parents, No 264 West 24th-st.

The Cunard steamship Arabia, Capt. JUDKINS, arrived at this port, yesterday morning, from Liverpool, whence she sailed on Saturday, July 2, at 3 P. M. She has accordingly made the passage in a little more than eleven days. There is little news by this arrival. What little there is respecting the Turkish difficulty, is far from definite.

The Act of Congress giving extra pay to officers, seamen, and mariners, which was for some time suspended, has been resumed to-day under a decision of the Attorney-General, and Navy Agent ALLEN is busily engaged in making payments. Major VANDEVENTER, of New-York, a gallant officer in the Mexican war, who was recently removed from his berth as clerk in the General PostOffice has been reinstated.

SECTION I.-Minerals. 1 C. M. Evrot, Charmes, (Moselle.) White Marble. 2 Bonzel freres, Haubourdin, (Nord.) white lead and ultramarine. 3 Eloffe, Paris. Minerals. 4 Beaudouin freres, Paris. Specimen of painting in bitumen.

Frederick Putnam was arrested in Wendell, Mass, on Thursday week, on a charge of forging notes on the Winchester, N.H., Bank, to the amount of some $4,000, about a year since. Upon the forgeries becoming known, about the time they were committed. he left for parts unknown, and remained away until the present time.

SOUNDRELISM.--We learn that Rev. Dr. FISKE,of West Cambridge, was called on on the 4th inst. by an Irishman, who said he had come to cut his grass for him. On the doctor's replying that he had no grass he wished him to cut, neither had he ever engaged him to do the work, the fellow demanded five dollars for calling accompanied with a threat to take the old gentleman's life if he did not comply.

The Franklin College, Indiana, had its 17th Annual Commencement, June 22. There was no graduating class, owing to a partial suspension during the year. The lumber of students of the year is ??. During the past year, tile friends of the College have secured an endowment of $60,000, which will be increased to S100,000.

NAVIGATION.--Lieut. F. H. STEPHENS, of the U. S. Coast Survey, has completed an examination of the Shoal near San Clemente and San Nicholas Islands, on the California coast. The Shoal or bank is in lat. 32[Degrees] 30' N., long. 119 10' 50' W.; the island of San Nicholas bears N. W. by ??., (by compass,) distant forty-six miles;

NEW-YORK STAT AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.-An Executive meeting of the New-York State Agricultural Society, was held at Saratoga Springs on the 7th inst., when arrangements were made for the approaching State Fair. A letter was received from Hon. Wm.. C. RIVES, of Virginia, announcing his acceptance of the invitation to deliver the Annual Address.

The Senate did nothing at the Tuesday night session, though they sat up till near midnight. The Assembly were in session till 101/2 The following gentlemen were appointed a Committee to confer with the Senate Committee on the Adjournment question: Messrs. SEMPLE, HADLEY, P. W. ROSE, CIIATFIELD and HOYLE.

On Tuesday afternoon the survivors of the New-York Regiment of Mexican Volunteers conveyed the body of their comrade, Lieut. JOHN WILSON, to his last resting-place in Greenwood Cemetery. The procession was escorted by the Atlantic Guards, Cantain W. A. BROUSIE. The real name of the deceased was HENRY ELLERT.

Work in the Crystal Palace went forward yesterday with a rush. During the whole day boxes and hales of goods continued to arrive, and were introduced into the building. The Exhibitors in every part were actively at work, though toward the latter part of the day many of them devoted themselves to the labor of procuring tickets of admission to the inaugural ceremonies of to-day.

ALTERED FIVE DOLLAR NOTES ON THE CITIZENS' BANK OF BALTIMORE.--During the past few days, numerous spurious $5 notes on the Citizens' Bank of Baltimore have been passed, altered from a bogus concern in Washington, D. C., called the "Citizens Bank," engraved as a fac simile of the same named bank in this City. Yesterday,

The Aralna was expected to bring the solution of the unusually knotty problem in Oriental politics. It has certainly helped us forward a step or two in the matter. The ultimalissimum has been rejected. The Porte has thrown himself upon the treaty of 1841, and the guarantees of England, France and Austria.

On last evening, a Farewell Missionary meeting was held in the Spring-street Prebbyterian Church, (Dr. CAMPBELL'S,) on occasion of the departure of Mr. and Mrs. WM. P. BARKER, for India. The exercises of the evening commenced by singing be 534th hymn, after which Rev. Mr. CAMPBELL offered up an impressive player. Rev. Mr. WOOD, Secretary A.

APARTMENTS FOR PRESIDENT PIERCE AND SUITE AT THE ASTOR HOUSE.-The President and suite will put up at the old established Hotel, the Astor House, during their stay in this City. The suite of rooms prepared for the Piesident's reception are such as well befit the Chief Magistrate of our Republic. More spacious, we believe,
" And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host, praising God, and saying, Glory to God in the highest, and on earth, peace, good will to men."

On Tuesday, three rowdies, (whose names we were unable to obtain,) went into the porter-house of Mrs. HANAGAN, corner of Union avenue and North Second-street, and after drinking, assaulted the landlady, and broke whatever glass that came within their reach. Officer RADDIGAN, of the Second Ward, was called in to restore peace, but no sooner had he opened the door, than he was knocked down and severely beaten by the villians.

The following is the reply of Dr. KANE to the address of the Masons of St. John's, Newfoundland, by whom he was presented with a Masonic flag during the stay of the Expedition at that port: WORSHIPFUL MASTER, WARDENS, AND BRETHREN : Unexpected as was the kindly and deep display of feeling which pervades the Address you have just presented to me, you will not be surprised that I should be unprepared with a reply;

A meeting of this body was held last evening, Alderman HEARTEAU, of the Eleventh Ward, in the Chair. The Board accepted an invitation from the Board of Aldermen of New-York, to participate with them in receiving the President of the United States on this arrival in New-York to-day.

At a special meeting of this body, last evening, a communication was received from the Mayor, transmitting an invitation from the Common Counsel of New-York, for them to join in the welcome to President PIERCE, this morning. The communication was received and filed, and the invitation accepted.

AN OFFICIAL FISTICUFF AT PENSACOLA.--The New-Orleans True Delta has been informed of a knock down and drag out affair which came off a few days ago at Warrington, near Pensacola, between two Government officials, attached to the Navy Yard, at that place. Chairs, tumblers, and other household articles of ornament and utility, were freely used as missiles by the belligerents.

There is a gentleman to whom we incline, a Mexican, by name Don AMBROSIO ARMIJO. That is about all we know of him, except one other fact, to wit: that being nominated for the appointment of Delegate to represent the Territory of New-Mexico, he peremptorily declined.

BILLS PASSED. Amending the Emigrant Law. For the punishment of assaults with deadly weapons. Consolidating the Municipal Government of Brooklyn, Williamsburg, and Bushwick. Incorporating the Westchester County Savings Bank. Also several local hills.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Everything concerning the old Continental Congress possesses great interest, and cannot be too often contemplated by Americans. Allow me to append to the communications of B. W. G. and his censor, a few facts in relation to the first Chaplain of Congress, which they have omitted.

VISIT TO THE PRESIDENT--President PIERCE was last evening waited upon, at the Astor House, by Messrs. GRAHAMN and BRAINARD, of the Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council, appointed to extend to His Excellency the hospitalities of the city. He re spectfully declined the invitation, stating that business of public importance demanded his attention at the Capital, which would make it necessary for him to leave New-York at an early hour this morning.

The PRESIDENT dined privately at the Astor yesterday afternoon, and in the evening was waited upon at his parlor by many citizens and strangers, among whom were General QUITMAN, Governor SEYMOUR, THOMAS F. MEAGHER, Esq., Senators THOMPSON and JAMES, Ex-Senators DIX, of N. Y., and BRADBURY, Esq., of Me.; Hon. GEO. ASHMUN of Mass.; AUGUST BELMONT, Esq., G.C. HEBRE, Esq., and Mr. HARDING, the Artist.

We now have some light upon the busi ness at Montreal. The verdict of the Jury, though by no means luminous, relieves the palpable obscure in which the previous contradictory stories had involved it; and teaches us the correctness of our first belief, that the worst results of the transaction are due to the Mayor and the soldiery.

Mr. MAURICE, the member of Congress from Long Island, writes to his constituents a letter explanatory of his connection with the distribution of the spoils within his district. He says he had no personal acquaintance with the President, and did not feel called on to go to Washington on any begging errand, soliciting favor at the saerifice of personal independence or self-respect.

UNLICENSED CARMEN.--On Wednesday the following named carmen were taken before Mayor BERRY, And fined $10 each, for driving carts without licenses: Terrence Donally, Michael Murray, Patrick Slaven, Michael Donally, and James Morris. Terrence Donally then complained of John McGrath, John Smith, Thomas Masterton, James Caloran, Patrick Buras, Thomas Farrel, James Glennan, Michael McCue, James Duffy, Michael Mills; John McCullen, and Hugh Lynch.

Had the deities who take especial charge of the weather been propitiated, beforehand, by endless sacrifices and adjurations, they could not have supplied a finer quality of the article than all the world enjoyed yesterday. Not excepting the shower.

COLLEGE COMMENCEMENTS.--The George town (Catholic) College Cemmencement took place on Tuesday. BENEDICT J. SUMNER delivered the valedictory. Fifteen persons took the degree of A. B. The degree of A. M. was conferred on John E. Develin, Esq., N.Y. Alphonso T. Semmes, M. D., Miss.; James Willie Rice, Esq., Md.: Julius A. Choppin, A. B., La.

By the arrival of the steamship Mexico at New-Orleans, we have received Galveston papers to the 1st inst. The expedition got up by Gen. RUSK, for El Paso. had not left Fort Graham at the last accounts Mr. GREELY, of Boston, has returned.

The City swarms with strangers. All our old friends are here from Maine and from the borders of Mexico, from California and the States whose locks are white with such age as is predicable of our fresh and green young land. We met old men yesterday who had not visited the City since it numbered less in population than Brooklyn does now.

During the voyage of the brig Eastern State, Capt. Nathaniel Gamage, of Bristol, Me., from Darien, Ga., (which arrived at Boston on Friday night, with a cargo of lumber,) the captain, mate, and crew of six men, by turns, all fell sick of fever and ague, so that at times there were scarcely enough well men to manage the vessel.

A correspondent of the Phliadelpola Ledger furnishes from Rio some interesting statistics of the Slave-trade to Brazil. The showing is important, as proving what we have had frequent occasion to reiterate, that Cuba is, to all practical intents, the only Slave-market of the Atlantic, and that once suppressed, the work Of CLARKSON and WILBERFORCE may be regarded as achieved.

NAVAL INTELLIGENCE.--The United States steamer Fulton, one of the fleet ordered to this port, and hence to the fishing ground, arrived at the Navy Yard on Sunday, having left Norfolk on the 6th inst. The first night out she passed the Princeton, which is also ordered here, and which is to be the flag-ship of Commodore SHUBRICK.

Before I had the high honor of a residence among the Latter-Day Saints. I supposed them the most harmonious brother-and-sisterhood the world ever saw. A more discordant set of harmonies, however, were never combined. A very short acquaintance with them, with some knowledge of their history, exhibits a very curious accumulation and loss of members constantly going on in the Mormon community.

A French Legitimist journal declares that the people of Europe are like the dwellers near a volcano, who, after an eruption, push their labors to the very verge of the crater; but are prepared, at a moment's notice, to dash away and save themselves, The simile is not entirely happy, but it furnishes a true idea, from unquestionable authority, of the actual state of things.

Further Demonstrations at Newark. After the President had retired to bed on Wednesday night, he received the compliment of a serenade from the German Glee Club, who assembled in great numbers, lighted by torches, and forming an imposing spectacle. The President soon appeared in the balcony, when he was greeted with loud and repeated cheers.

HUMPHREY MARSHALL'S ministerial career in China is certainly unenviable. His course towards the Celestials does not find favor with the Administration. The sentiment of Christendom is against tyranny, and in favor of liberty. HUMPHREY, in the opinion of men of elevated stations, has committed a faux pas. WALKER would have sided with the oppressed, or at least remained mutual.

The Boston Post records the death of SAMUEL APPLETON, at 5 o'clock on Tuesday after noon. The day previous, he appeared remarkably well and cheerful. Mr. APPLETON was one of our oldest and most respected merchants, and was distinguished for great generosity of character; and the remembrance of his charities, and of the liberality which characterized his life, will form an enduring monument to his memory.

The destitute Chinese of the Hook and Tongs Company, who were recently so unsuccessful at NIBLO'S, and who were thrown destitute upon the world, by the loss of both employment and wardrobe, (the latter seized for their passage from the Isthmus,) are to have a benefit this evening at Castle Garden.

The receipts of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, for the eleven months ending on the 30th June, were $270,972; leaving $29,692 to be raised during the present month, to complete the sum of $300,664, appropriated to the Missions for the year. The financial year of the Board closes on the 31st of July.

Mail steamer Yacht arrived at Brazos on the 5th, and crossed the bar on the 6th. Left at Brazos schooner Minna Schaffer, WILSON, unloading; schooner, Corah, Capt. SLICK, Roam, unloading. The Lake Superior Journal has a number of interesting items regarding the state of affairs at Lake Superior: This year, different from former ones, business is assuming great activity. We have an almost daily arrival of a boat of some sort from either above or. below. On their upward trip,

It seems from the testimony adduced on the ?? investigation, yesterday afternoon, that a wedding ceremony had been solemnized at the house of Mr WINDLER adjoining. Guns,

HORRIBLE SUICIDE.--Immediately after the sounding of the whistle of the 8 o'clock A. M. express train from New-York at the New-Rochelle depot, yesterday morning, a gentleman, very respectably attired. started up the road with his hands folded and head drooped. as if laboring under a depression of spirits.

Hackney-coaches. People tell you they were so called from the village of Hackney, near London, where they were first made, or used. But haquenay is the old French for a traveler's horse, or pad; whence, in England, where the word was early introduced, a vehicle for jog-trot journeys was called a haquenay (or hackney) carriage.

The Cherokee Advocate informs us that, a short time since, a Deputy Marshal of the Northern District of the State of Arkansas went into the Creek Nation and arrested a Creek, charged with selling whisky to the Indians. The Chief of the District, thinking it an insult to his municipal authority, and a violation of the rights of the Creek Nation, interfered, and set the Indian at liberty.

FROM THE BRITISH PROVINCES.--The St. John, (N. B.) Freeman thus speaks of the trade with the United States: " On Wednesday last the Eastern City took about 300 passengers to Boston and a considerable freight, one of the chief items of which was the enormous quantity of 32,000 pounder of salmon, for the American markets.

FROM PORT AU PRINCE.--By the arrival of the bark Charles E. Lex, at Philadelphia, we have advices to the 1st inst. from Port-au-Prince. The country generally was quiet, and business was extremely dull. The importations coming to hand from the United States were larger than ever known, and the prices obtained for fish were scarcely sufficient for the payment of duties thereon.

GEOGRIA.--Hon. RICHARD W. WALKER has accepted the Whig nomination for Governor. He comes out strongly and handsomely for Internal Improvements, approves of the plan of loaning the credit of the State for such purposes, endorses the new Railroad projects, and encourages the Common School system, for the complete establishment of which no sacrifice is too great.

For everything within a mile of the newly opened Industrial Palace is crystal. There are Crystal Stables, and Crystal Cake Shops, and Crystal Groggeries, and Ice-cream Saloons.

" What more felicity can fall to creature. Than to enjoy delight with liberty ?"-.Spenser. Your readers will perhaps smile, Mr. Editor, when I confess that this Niagara trip is the greatest event of my life hitherto. But so it is, and they must smile, or laugh outright, as their humor prompts them.

A correspondent of the Utica Gazetic, writing from Cape Vincent, Canada, says: At the 4th of July celebration here, a large draft was made on the British side for help. A gun now stands before the house, which was brought overfrom Kingston for the day. It was cast in 1775,

The Boston Atlas, a capital sheet and handsomely supported, has entered upon its twentysecond volume, and celebrates the event by putting on a new dress. Another newspaper change has taken place in Baltimore-Mr. ISAAC MUNROE, the venerable Editor of the Patriot, retiring from editorial labors, and resigning the responsibilities of the concern to Mr. JNO. F. McJILTON.

OPENING OF THE NEW BAPTIST CHURCH.--The Baptist Church situated on Grove-street, Jersey City. has been completed, and the doors will be opened for divine services to-morrow. The four Baptist Societies existing in Jersey City in 1848, then united, and formed the present Society, which has erected this Church. Rev. Mr. VERRIENDER is the pastor.

In Georgia, the wheat crop is acknowledged, on all hands , to have been very fine. The oat crop, on the contrary, is an entire failure. The same is true of early corn, except in a very few instances, upon swamp and bottom lands. The late corn is indifferent, but may be brought out by the recent rains. The vegetable gardens,

Mr. BUCHANAN'S friends say that Mr. MARCY has acted ungenerously towards him, especially on the "fish question;" while MARCY'S friends declare that BUCHANAN'S conduct has been scaly. BUCHANAN will go on the mission notwithstanding all that has been said. This is a fixed fact.

The City Post-Office ought to stand upon the lower angle of the Park. That is by all odds the most central and accessible point in the City. All the great routes of City travel,-all the modes of conveyance through the City,-centre there.

Yesterday the President accepted the invitation of the Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, to enjoy a trip around the harbor, and a sail up the river to Hurl-Gate, The trip was got up under the auspices of the " Committee on Encroachments on the Harbor of New-York." The steamboat selected for the occasion was the Josephine-the boat in which the President crossed from Jersey City to New-York.

The steamship Daniel Webster, E. CHURCHILL commander, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She left San Juan on the evening of the 6th. On the 14th inst., at 3 o'clock P. M., exchanged signals with bark E. A. Kinsman, 45 miles E.N.E. of Cape May.

The Directors of the Exhibition of the Industry of All Nations gave a magnificent complimentary banquet last night, at the Metropolitan Hotel, to the President of the United States and the Commissioners from foreign nations, in attendance upon the Exhibition. The dinner was laid in the large dining-hall of the Metropolitan, which was very handsomely and appropriately fitted up for the occasion.

The brief visit of the President of the United States and his military escort to Castle Garden, caused quite a sensation in the very large audience which had been drawn together by the double attraction of the Opera and His Exeellency's expected presence.

To the Editor of the New--York Daily Times: I noticed in your paper, a day or two since, an account of the procession of the children of the Day and Sabbath School of the " Five-Points Mission." I had read much in the daily papers of this operation for the last three years, but yesterday I learned more, by personal observation, than all I have heard and read during that time.

Hon. FRANCIS R. GOURGAS, a member of the Constitutional Convention, died at his residence in Concord, Mass., on Monday night. He was formerely an able member of the Democratic party, and edited the Concord Freeman. He has been a mere ber of the House and of the Senate, and one of the Council, and been a highly-valued citizen, respected by all who knew him. Lately,

The New-Jersey Press is of various opinions with regard to the gubernatorial question. While the nomination of Mr. C.REY, upon an Anti-Monopoly footing, is enthusiastically received by perhaps a larger portion, a soler and influential minority avow their preference for another candidate-always, however, with ample tributes to the eminent qualifications of the gentleman referred to.

As it has been my custom for some time to let you know of my whereabout, and to give you the benefit of my experience, I once more have the pleasure to-day, and address you from Newport, Providence Plantation, (as the town-sergeant pleases to add,)-the Queen of the sea and; the island of islands.

The New-York Medical Gazette for July has several interesting papers. Dr. A. TROWBRIDGE reports several cases of lithotomy, to extract foreign bodies from the bladder. Dr. C. H. CLEVELAND commends galvanism for uterine hemorrhage--a use of a very dubious remedy, which must be far more thoroughly tested than it has hitherto been, before the profession generally will accept it, we opine. Prof. PAUL. F. EVE,

Mrs. STOWE'S book is not to be regarded as a literary performance. It unquestionably possesses extraordinary attractions in that way, but it was intended to accomplish much more than to create a sensation in literary circles, or earn increased reputation for the writer, who was already a celibritc; it was written with a view to political results.

FROM CHIHUAHUA.--MAYER Co.'s train, which arrived from Chihuahua, at San Antonio, has performed this trip as an experimental one, and the success it met with has induced those gentlemen to make their head-quarters at San Antonio. The train passed through Presidio, and not El Paso, by which they saved a distance of some 250 miles.

Capt. JOHN PRICE, whose death occurred a few weeks since, at Burlington, Vt., was one of the best soldiers of the war of 1812. He was in four general actions, and in every service of danger that presented itself, and always earned the applause of his comrades, and the high approbation of his officers.

The India Bill has been debated in earnest since my last dispatch. MACAULAY came out in great force on Friday evening, and delivered one of those striking speeches which he knows how to render so captivating-not less by the subject matter than the extraordinary energy with which it is put forth. His oratory had, too,

The regular semi-monthly accident has occurred on the Hudson. The steamboat Empire of Troy has perished of a complication of disorders, the precise diagnosis of which is given in the very full and minute account of the circumstance, furnished by our reporters. A collision, it seems, occurred in the first instance, the steamer coming in contact with a sloop.

We pulished on Saturday the circumstances attending the death of Mr. FRANKLIN C. GRA.V, who was killed by the New-Haven Railway train near the depot at New-Rochelle. The Coroner's Jury returned as their verdict, after hearing the testimony, that " he came to his death by his own voluntary act, in throwing himself across the track in front of the engine, while the train was under full headway ;"

The following intelligence was sent out in the Arabia by our correspondent in Liverpool, but unfortunately miscarried, and did not reach us until yesterday; " LIVERPOOL, July 2.-Just as the Arabia is leaving the wharf, I am telegraphed from London, on the authority of an extra of the London Times, that an army of twelve thousand Russians entered Jassy on the 25th of June.

SALUTE IN HONOR OF THE PRESIDENT.-OR Saturday, as the President was crossing to Jersey City to take the train South, a royal salute of twenty-one guns was fired from the British Mail steamer Arabia, in honor of our Chief Magistrate. Salutes were also given by the flags of the steamer.

On Friday evening, July 15, LYMAN D. WILSON, aged 3 years and 2 month, only child of Henry P. Wilson. July 16, Mrs. BARBARA MOSSMAN, aged 78 years. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this Monday) afternoon, at 2 O'clock P. M., from her late residence, No. 185 West 25th st. Her remains sill be taken to Greenwood Cemestery for interment.

The question came on agreeing with the report of the Committee of the Whole on the Supply bill. Mr. CONGER proposed to strike out the appropliation to the Medical Colleges of Buffalo, Albany and Troy. These appropriations contemplate the establishment of an Eye and Ear Infirmary Department, also the appropriation to the Eye and Ear Infirmary of New-York.

Esq., Coroner, empannelled and swere in the following gentlemen as the Jury : Win. Ramsay.

Park or no park is the question over which the St. Louis people are brooding. They want a park worth calling by that name, and the young men seem bound to have one. The Philadelphians, before the coming of the President, were eloquent on the same topic. New-Yorkers have belabored the subject with equal vigor.

By the arrival of the British Mail steamer Avon,, at Havana, we are placed in receipt of news from the City of Mexico, to June 30, and from Vera Cruz to July 3. The Government of SANTA ANNA appears to be devoting itself especially to the enlargement and drill of the army.

SINGULAR ARREST OF A THIEF, AND RECOVERY OF $30,100.-A few weeks since, a Frenchman, named CHARLES JEAN GODARD, a manufacturer of fancy paper boxes, doing business at No. 490 Broadway, sold some articles to a lady, and was referred for payment to the firm of WILSON BROWN, No. 83 Beaver-street. He had made repeated applications for payment, but had not succeeded in getting the money.

The Universal, of the City of Mexico, contains advices from Central America to April 23. Much apprehension exists in San Salvador, as to the designs of the revolutionary, or federal party in Honduras. The Government of the former Stato has laid hands upon a number of private letters addressed to individuals whose sympathies are supposed to favor federalism.

Another steamboat disaster, attended with melancholy loss of life, has thrown its gloomy shadow over the waters of the noble Hudson; another tale of recklessness and calamity has been added to the blood-stained annals of our river travel. Before the public mind has well recovered from the terrible details of one disaster it is startled by the announcement of another, until even the feeling of indignation seems to die beneath the accumulation of horrors.

Rev. Mr. CHAPIN preached last evening, to a very large and attentive audience, at his Church in Broadway, an eloquent and impressive sermon on the Moral Significance of the Crystal Palace. He took for his text the sixth verse of the eighth chapter of the Psalms of David-" Thou madest him to have dominion over the works of thy hands."

The train which left Philadelphia at 41/2 o'clock on Friday afternoon, met with an accident about twenty minutes to 9 o'clock, immediately after crossing the Passaic bridge. The locomotive, tender, and a baggage car, were thrown off the track, and the track moved nearly two feet from the line.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: I resolved, a few days since, to enter upon a new Profession-the Profession ot Traveling--and to make a fair experiment upon it as a mode of living, if not as a means of livelihood. There were several reasons, good and strong, for it. In the first place, I do not think that this is fit weather for any man to work.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.-Saturday.-Before Hon. Judge BEEBE -The Court of General Ses-ions convened at the Halls of Justice, this morning, for the last day of the term. The brother s JOHN S. and ISAAC AUSTIN were arraigned for sentence upon a con-viction of being engaged in the riot at Tamm? Hall They were severally asked " what they had now to say why judgment should not be pronounced against them."

It was a day of frequent, sudden, unexpected and heavy showers ;--one of those days which tempt men and women out of doors without umbrellas, and then drench them with a flood of rain. In another part of this morning's TIMES, will be found an exceedingly interesting narrative of certain important events connected with the War of 1812, which have not hitherto found their proper place in the history of that period.

With that sense of justice which so eminently distinguishes the Captain-General, three American sailors have been arrested and thrown into the Moro, at Havana, upon a charge of having served on board a slaver. The island of Cuba probably contains five thousand Spaniards and natives obnoxious to the same charge.

The directors of the lottery for the restoration of the Church of Notre Dame de Perthes, announce that the time for the drawing is nigh; that a good many lucky numbers are believed to be still unsold; and that people desirous of contributing to a worthy object would do well to apply at once, as only a few tickets are left.

Mr. Secretary DAVIS, at the banquet on Friday night, took occasion to declare himself very warmly in favor of Free Trade, as a means of preserving peace among the nations of the earth. Those whose recollection of past political contests is especially sharp, probably thought the introduction of such a topic a violation of the proprieties of the occasion;

The Court is much gayer this year than usual, and what with roy ally-patronized reviews, drawingrooms and state balls, and palace concerts, the season is now at its height. For the last few years the Aristocracy has been rather given to stinginess and in lieu of keeping up their dignity in their town mansions, have broken up their establishments and quitted the metropolis, to study rural economy in the provinces.

The President and Cabinet, and the several gentlemen traveling with him, arrived here safely at 10 o'clock last evening, having come the entire distance from New-York in special trains provided by the liberality of the several roads. No accident occurred--no draw-bridges were open-no switches misplaced. The air was delightfully cool,

According to the latest intelligence from Europe, which we published yesterday, the Russians have occupied the Danubian Principalities. To the eastward of Hungary, intervening between the land of KOSSUTH and the land of the Czar, lies Moldavia.

From the San Francisco Herald. We consider it only an act of impartiality to render justice to the French vessels which have brought to California such a large number of French emigrants. These have all been well treated during the voyages, and have arrived here in perfect health, with little or no mortality.

On Sunday, July 17, 1853, of consumption, in full confidence of a blessed immateriality, FREDERICK VICKERY GREENLEAF, aged 24 years, 1 month and 25 days. Funeral on Tuesday (this) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from the residence of his mother, No. 4 Astor-place. The relatives and friends of the family are affectionately invited to attend. The remains will be interred in Union Cemetery, Bushwick.

MORTALITY.--The Health Officer reports 88 deaths in this city for the week ending July 17, males 47; females, 41; adults, 33; children, 65. Diseases.--Cholera infantum, 14; marasmus, 13: Consumption, 8; diarrhoea and still born, 5 each; dropsy in the head and dysentary, 4 each : cholera, congestion of the brain, convulsions, croup, inflamation of the lungs, 3 each; cancer of the womb, drowned,

The President was somewhat indisposed this morning, but not seriously. A short Cabinet session was held, but it is understood that nothing important was done. Commodore SHUBRICK carried his sailing orders for the Fishing Ground with him, but an accident to the Princeton may detain him for a short time.
The second performance of "Roberto il Diavolo," attracted a crowded audience last evening. In many particulars, the entertainment was a superior one.

The day of patriotism and powder, Independence and Roman candles, Catherine wheels and rebellion, broke upon us here in unwonted splendor. The sun, at an early period in the morning, came to the determination that we should not have all the blaze to ourselves, and, throwing off all disguise, came out with astounding brilliancy.

Here I am, in the very heart of the Switzerland of America, on the shores of a sheet of water which, for all that charms in romance and beauty, may well challenge a rival, at this season of the year, in this or any other country. Lake Winnipisseogee (Winni-pe-saw-ke) is, in its greatest length, about thirty miles, and perhaps half a dozen miles in its greatest breadth-containing some seventy square miles of surface.

He lies very still, very careless, very indifferent to what the doctors say about him. He has lain so long that there is some apology for those 'who propose to bury him out of sight. Enemies are agreed that it is time to put him under ground, and some good friends think that maybe it's best for the sake of the living to do so.

Just now our City is Cosmopolitan in its aspect. Our thoroughfares are gay, and our roads are blooming. Broadway is an unbent rainbow, and even sober Wall-street has burst the chrysalis shell of business, and come out in butterfly garb.

The laying of the Corner-Stones of the Westminister College and of the new Deaf and Dumb Asylum of Missouri, in Fulton, has already been mentioned, and we have now received fuller accounts of the ceremonies. The Governor being absent, the corner-stone of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, was laid by Gen. O. L. Price;

The fine bust of the late President KIRKLAND, standing upon an appropriate pedestal, from the chisel of Mr. THOMAs A. CAREW, is nearly completed, and will probably be placed in the Library of Harvard College on or before next Commeneement Day. The material is a beautiful specimen of spotless marble, and the work is executed with much accuracy and delicacy of finish.

We paid our farewell salutation to the City of Bethesda at 8 o'clock, A. M., for SHERRILL'S Lake House, distant thirty miles. It was not without a vein of sadness that we donned our travelers garb, and said farewell to Saratoga. What room for moralizing may be found at these oft-repeated changes in a pleasure jaunt.

Where can this town be said I to myself. I was invited to accompany some friend there. And that others may be induced to make the trip and enjoy a pleasure like mine, I beg, Mr. Editor, to tell them what they will see in that beautiful region of country. 1. They will see a magnificent prospect on the Delaware division of the Erie Railroad.

There is a monument of brick upon Nassaustreet, hard by the DAILY TIMES office, sacred to the memory of the departed Bible House. The architectural and artistic taste exhibited in its construction are not such as to impress the connoisseur favorably at first sight;

DEAR SIR: Most persons, whether reared in the country or not, profess to have some notions of the way things are managed on a farm. In reference to having, especially, nobody presumes to be entirely ignorant. Indeed, this is a matter that presents, to most minds, the most distinctive feature of country Employments.

There are no signs of the Franklin up to the present time. She is now in her thirteenth day. HALIFAX, Monday, July 18-Midnight. A thick fog prevails here, and there is no Appearance of the Europa, now in her tenth day out.

NEW-MEXICAN ROUTE FOR RAILWAY TO THE PACIFIC.-The Little Rock (Ark.) True Democrat announces the arrival of a portion of the corps of U. S. Topographical Engineers, ordered upon a survey of this route. The able and efficient officers who have charge of the party are: Lieut. A. W. WHIPPLE, U. S. Topographical Engineers, assisted by Lieut. J. C. IvES, of the same corps, and Lieut.

There is a brisk quarrel, of long standing, that is still going on, and is not likely soon to end,-all in respect to Uncle Sam's Armory at Springfield, with which the public at large got so well acquainted some months ago, through the pages of an entertaining Monthly.

Father GAVAZZI delivered a lecture in Italian last evening, to his countrymen, at Stuyvesant Institute. As it had been announced that this would be the last lecture of the season, the hall was crowded at an early hour. The subject of his discourse was, "Italy and the War against the Papacy."

Perhaps it is not to be expected in a daily or in a weekly newspaper-prepared, it may be, oftentimes, if not generally, by many separate persons, all of whom are in haste-that the requisite care should be taken to have the language appropriate, and always correct;

The opening of the new Baptist Church in Grovestreet, Jersey City, (Rev. Mr. VERRINDER, pastor,) took place on Sunday morning. The house was filled by an attentive audience. The services consisted of singing by the Choir, the reading of the Scriptures by Rev. Dr. AtMITAGE, prayer by the pastor, and an able discourse by Dr. ARMITAGE, on the subject found in Acts, chap. xxvi., v. 24 and 25.

Upon our sixth page this morning will be found a full report of the testimony taken yesterday before the Commissioners of Police, in the case of JOHN CUSICK and PATRICK KELLEY, two members of the Ninth Ward Police, charged with taking part with the rioters in the affair of the Fourth of July.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Permit me, through your journal, to protest, with all my energy, against the so-called second course of my Lectures, as published by Messrs. DEWITT DAVENPORT, of this City. From the manner in which that publication has been announced, many may be led to believe that I have revised and authorized it;

Yesterday at 1 o'clock, P. M., the investigation into the charges pending against the suspended policemen JOHN CUSICK and PATRICK KEILY, of the Ninth Ward police, was resumed in the Chamber of the Board of Assistant Aldermen, before the Honorable B ard ef Commissioners.

THE CRYSTAL PALACE.--Of the Crystal Place we have hitberto, we believe, said little, Not can we do much more to-day, than declare, on our personal conviction, and apart from all matter-of=course compliment, that the edifice, both withinside and without, has not been too much lauded. It very far surpassed our expectations. It is, in an architectural point of view, singularly beautiful.

The inquiry relative to the late melancholy catastrophe on board the Empire of Troy, was resumed yesterday morning, by Coroner VAN KLEEK, at Poughkeepsic. We are happy to be enabled to say that all of the sufferers who are lying at the Exchange Hotel, under the attentive care of Mr. VINCENT and the members of his family, have materially improved,

A VENERABLE CLERGYMAN.--On Sunday afternoon last, the pulpit of Dr. SPRAGUE'S Church was occupied by Rev. Mr. WALDO. Our informant states that, although the venerable man is now in his 93d year, he stood perfectly erect, spoke promptly and with great vigor, and delivered his sermon without notes.

Officer Sheldrake, yesterday morning discovered a mad dog in South second-street, between Ten ?? and Eleventh street, which he immediately dispatched with a shovel. A boy eleven years of age, named Augusta Wheelan, whose parents reside on the corner of South first and Ninth-streets, immediately came up with a loaded double burrel pistol, which he held in his hands,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In compliance with your wishes, I have promised a sketch of the literary life and performances of LEGARE. It was, to be sure, the proper complement of what I have already told of the more active part of his intellectual career;

On Sunday morning, about 31 o'clock, a fire broke out in an old wooden building, in the rear of, and adjoining the frame tenements, Nos. 151 and 153 First-street, formerly occupied as a bakery. The flames soon communicated to these houses, which were but partially destroyed, owing to the prompt arrival of the firemen and First and Second Ward Police.

Speculators on 'Change are evidently not satisfied with the opening of our great Exhibition. The stock has fallen steadily and somewhat rapidly. On Thursday, the day before the opening, it sold at 146 ;-on Friday it fell to 140;-on Saturday,

A letter from Memphis, in the St. Louis Republican, under the curious appellation of a "grand affair" of honor, narrates the particulars of another duel,--not in California, this time, but in Atkansas . It took place on the 4th of July, about four miles below President's Island, between two Illinoisans, or Suckers-one from Macoupin County, and the other from Madison Countynamed Thomas Clark and Thomas J. Denton.

In my last I promised some further account of the GIADDEN excitement. After the demonstrations by BRIGHAM and PARLEY, the heretics were forbidden to hold meetings anywhere, or to assemble together in a greater number than three. On Sunday, the 27th of March, the subject was resumed at the Tabernacle by Elder ERASTUS SNOW, in a sermon distinguished for its profanity and brutal ferocity.

A man in Philadelphia, named Brown, has been arrested on the charge of being accessory to the late forgeries on the Burlington Bank.. He was committed for a further hearing. It will be remembered that, on the 22d of June, two forged checks were presented and paid at that Bank, purporting to be drawn by Thomas Milnor.

The Princeton, we are told, is the same worthless hulk she has always been. An original sin in the construction of her boilers was discovered just late enough to spoil the Japan expedition. Returned upon the hands of the makers, she escapes just in time to be detailed for service at the fisheries;

Another mammoth Hotel is preparing to throw open its doors to the public. The "Prescott House," which has been under way for several months past, is finally completed, and will be open in a few days for the reception of visitors. Its proprietor, Capt. ALBERT DE GROOT, has omittted neither trouble nor expense to render the house perfect in its kind.

A fearful accident occurred yesterday at Niagara Falls. Three men, belonging to a scow which came down the river on Monday night, fell asleep in a small boat, which presently became loosened from her moorings, and two of the men were hurried over the Falls. Of course they were instantly killed.

Nothing of special interest has recently occurred in Tehuantepec. Since the late revolution everything has assumed its accustomed lifeless and dreary appearance. MAXIMO R. ORTIZ, who was condemned to be shot last year for heading a revolution against the State authorities, has again come into power and is now civil and military Governor of the Department of Tehuantepec.

This morning, July 10. CHARLES AUGUSTUS, eldest son of Augustus D. and Kezia C. Porter, aged 9 years, 9 months and 19 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday, July 20, at 4 o'clock PM., from the residence of his parents. No. 32 Sands st., Brooklyn. His remains will be taked to Green wood for interment.

COURT OF SESSIONS.--Before Judge MOORE and Justices STILWELL and STRYKER.--Tuesday -- Aaron Storer a defaulting petit juror, was fined 25. The Grand Jury came into court and presented five bill's of indictment-two for grand larceny. two for assault and battery, and one for bigamy. Augustus Masson, alias Augustus Masso, was arraigned and plead not guilty to an indictment for grand larceny. John Aldworh was arraigned and plead not guilty to an indictment for bigamy.

Three men belonging to a scow which came down the river last night, got into a skiff alongside the scow, and, it is supposed, fell asleep, when the boat got separated from the scow, and was hurried on by the current with fearful rapidity towards the Falls. This happened about 91/2 o'clock last evening.

TEMPERANCE CONVENTION.--A Convention composed of delegates from the various temperance associations of the city, has for some weeks been holding meetings at the Temple, to consider the best plan of bringing the subject of the Maine liquor law prominently before the people.

A short excursion which I have just taken in Argolis and over the Isthmus of Corinth, was crowded with interest and pleasure, and afforded a grateful relief from the hot air and arid soil of Athens. Rising before the break of day, on the 21st, our party, consisting of Mr. BLACKIE, tile learned Professor of Greek at the University of Edinburgh, another Scotch scholar, and myself, with our intelligent guide FRANCOIS, drove to the Piracus,

The Royal Mail Steamship Europa, Capt. SHANNON, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 9th inst., arrived at this port, en route for Boston, at 6 o'clock this evening, bringing 117 through passengers. The latest Telegraphic news holds out better hopes of peace, through the Convention of France, England and Austria.

FROM HAVANA.-Steamship Cherokee, Capt. BAXTER, arrived yesterday morning from New-Orleans via Havana. She left Havana on the 14th. She brings 130 passengers, and merchandise to M. O. ROBERTS. She made the trip in 4 days and 13 hours from Havana. U. S. ship Albany, GUERY commanding. arrived at Havana on the 13th inst.

The Legislature yesterday appropriated the sum of Ten Thousand Dollars for the relief of the New-York Volunteers. These unfortunate men will be glad of relief from any source. Many efforts have been made by the charitable, in their behalf, but with no substantial benefit.

The U. S. Mail steamship Franklin, CaptWOTTON, arrived at this port, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning. The Franklin sailed from Cowes at 6 A. M., on the 7th inst., having been detained there from 10 o'clock, the night before, by a dense fog. She brings about 90 passengers and over 800 tons valuable French and Swiss goods--valued at over two and a half millions.

From the New- Orleans Picayune. The U. S. Mail steamship Texas arrived yesterday from Vera Cruz, which port she left on the 8th inst. She brings $118,100 in specie. Among the passengers was M. LEVASSEUR, French Minister to Mexico. Gen. SANTA ANNA had taken up his residence at the village of Tacubaya, where he had declared his intention of passing the Summer.

RIOT AT MILWAUKEE.--A riot occurred at Milwaukee on Monday, which was put down without loss of life, though several persons, among whom was the Mayor, were somewhat injured. It arose from the failure of the contractors of a portion of the La Crosse Railroad to pay their workmen, as promised, upon a certain day.

The rain of yesterday morning, which lasted till nearly noon, prevented the attendance during the early part of the day from being as large as usual. A large number of visitors, however, kept coming in from the hour of opening, and during the afternoon the building was very fairly occupied in every part.

TO DR. A. A. L.--DEAR DOCTOR: Some time ago you insisted upon my writing you my "impressions" respecting the South. I take it as a compliment to my impressibility, if to nothing else; and encouragement from such a quarter has given me the confidence to attempt it.

The Commencement of Dickinson College took place at Carlisle, Pa., last week, and went off with spirit. The oath of office was administered to Dr. COLLINS, the new President of the Institution. The American Institute of Instruction, now some twenty-five years of age, is to hold its next annual meeting in New-Haven on the 16th, 17th, and 18th of August.

A meeting of the Board was held Monday evening, Alderman COMPTON presiding. The minutes of last meeting having been gone through the following petitions were read, and referred to Committees: From William A. Turnure and others, to have Fortiethstreet, between Fourth and Fifth-avenue, regulated, guttered and reset, where needed and the sidewalks flagged four feet wide;

The Coroner's Jury, after considerable deliberation, brought in their verdict at a late hour on Monday night--long after the Telegraph offices had closed. Had it been otherwise, the result of the investigation would have been forwarded for publication in extenso in Tuesday's issue.

I have been prevented, by serious indisposition, from making my usual report to you on the first of the month, of the progress of events in the Far West. It is not. however, of much consequence to your readers, inasmuch as we have had no news from Utah or New-Mexico, and until this morning. nothing from the Northwest.

" We are still in the same state of siege as before; the negotiation which had commenced, by the mediation of the Brazilian and Bolivian ministers, has not been successful.

Topographical Engineer, and party, were in San Antonio on the 10th ult., on their way to Albuquerque, New-Mexico, and would leave in the course of a fortnight. Lieut.
