To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: The strictures of some of the City Press, and especially of the Tribune, on the neglect to honor mechanical skill and talent at the opening ceremonies of the great Exhibition, would have had more point, and have been more particularly appropriate, had there been any PAXTONS or HENDERSONS connected with the enterprise ofdesign or construction.

The arrival of the Franklin supplies us with one authenticated fact and two documents, throwing broad light upon the position of the Oriental question. The fact is that the Russians have actually occupied the two Principalities. The documents are, in the first place, the reply of RESCHID, the Foreign Minister of the Porte, to the ultimulissimum of the Czar;

The keeper of a grocery store, corner of South Third and Ninth-streets, was riding on horseback, yesterday, through South Sixth-street, when a pocket-book, containing $191 in bills, slipped from his pocket, and fill in the street. A dirt-carman, named JOHN COCHRAN, in the employ of Messrs. KEMPS, was passing along, and saw the pocket-book drop. He sprang from his cart, picked up the book, regained his seat and drove off.

By the Black Warrior, I omitted particular notice of the action of the late American Consul, in relation to the Lady Suffolk. For the items of most interest, I never give them until they have been confronted with the best proof, by admission or declaration-to which I have access through a friendly influence that can neither be disturbed or broken under any circumstances;

From the New-Orleans Picayune, 12th. We have received a file of La Gaceta de la Costa Rica, published at San Jose, to the 18th ult., and a copy of the report of the Secretary of State of that Republic to the National Congress, dated 16th of May, 1853.

A writer in the Tribune advocates opening the Crystal Palace on Sunday. He says: "There are hundreds of motives why it should be so, but I will only cite a few. A great many workmen, clerks and other persons of both sexes cannot possibly, for different reasons, absent themselves during the week from their avocations.

Yesterday afternoon, at eight minutes before 1 o'clock, a terrific explosion of a large steam boiler took place at the extensive Iron-Casting Foundry of JOHN R. PRATT, Esq., situated at Nos 60 and 62 Attorney street. The buildings are occupied by Mr PRATT for the casting of iron arches, columns, railings, , and are erected upon four lots of ground, extending from Attorney to Ridge-streets.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Our attention was called to a letter of Father GAVAZZI in your paper of July 19, in which he has thought proper to repudiate the Report of his Lectures as published by us, and to make some reflections in relation to the publication and publishers, ,which we feel called upon to answe.

GENERAL REMARKS-OBJECT OF THE OPERATION, operation of pruning is one of the most important that engages the attention of the fruit-grower. It consists in depriving a plant or tree of a portion of its branches, buds, leaves, bark, or roots, in order to produce certain effects on that part which remains.

GOVERNMENT LUMBER IN MICHIGAN.--The Grand Jury in attendance on the Circuit Court of the United States, at Detroit, were discharged on Saturday, and have found many bills of indictment for stripping Government lands of timber. These depredations are chiefly upon valuable pine lands, and extend from Grand River to St. Clair, and in some cases red ceder and oak timber have been the subject of waste.

The country is thickly Intestd, just at this moment, with peddlers and colporters, forcing upon the small country authorities copies of the Life of Louis NAPOLEON. Their plan is to threaten mayors, municipal councillors, schoolmasters, , with the Emperor's displeasure, and some measure of extermination from the Prefect, if they decline to subscribe.

EPHRAIM CUTLER, well known to all the early settlers of Ohio, and especially in the Muskingum Valley, recently died at his residence in Warren, Washington County, aged 87 years. Judge CUTLER was a member of the first Constitutional Convention of Ohio. He is the last of that body which ushered Ohio into the confederacy.

Our European advices, over the telegraph wires from Nova Scotia, add nothing whatever to the Oriental news. The proposed interpellations of Lord LYNDHURST and the Marquis of CLANRICARDE, coming up in the House of Lords, the Foreign Secretary solicited a further postponement, on the ground that, in the present critical position of the question, any announcement of the Government views must be prejudicial.

The Theological Seminary at Columbia, S. C., is prosperous. It has 32 students, $106,000 invested funds, with more subscriptions to come inhas laid the foundations of a new building-numbers 5,000 volumes in its library, and gathers in its list not less than 174 alumni; of whom, however, 15 are dead.

July 20, MARY, infant daughter of James M and E Euretta Cromwell. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from the residence of her grandfather. Richard Cromwell, No. 225 East Broadway, on Thursday afternoon, at 3 1/2 o'clock. On Wednesday, July 20, of consumption. CATHARINE, wile of Wormuldes C. Kuypers, and daughter of the late John Crolius.

MURDER IN THE STATE PRISON AT CHARLES TOWN--This morning, as the State Prison convicts were being marched out in single file from their cells to work in the yard, one of them suddenly drew a knife upon the second man before him, cutting his throat so that he died in a very few minutes.

MEETING OF THE STATE TEACHERS' ASSOCTTION.-The annual meeting of the State Teachers' Association will be held at Rochester, on Tuesday, the 2d of August, and will continue for three days. All the Teachers of the State, as well as the friends cf Education, and teachers from other States, are respectfully invited to attend and take part in the exercises.

On the twelfth of April, 1853, Hon. WASHINGTON HUNT, Mr. HORACE GREELEY, and twenty-two other stalwart, well-tried, honest friends of the People, were constituted by the Legislature a body corporate, under the name of "The People's College," for the purpose of promoting Literature, Science, Arts, and Agriculture.

CASTLE GARDEN.-It is pleasant to have something good to write about in the languid days of Summer. There is but little comfort in mediocrity at any time, but in these days small comforts evaporate with the strong heats, and we are apt to be "crusty" long ere the cool breezes woo us to Castle Garden. When, therefore, we have an offering at once pleasant and refreshing, we may well make the most of it.

The Twentieth Ward Mission Sabbath School, located in Lamartine Hall, corner Eighthavenue and Twenty-ninth-street, celebrated its third anniversary, on Tuesday, of last week, with a visit to the American Museum, (in conveyances gratuitously furnished by Messrs. KIPP BROWN, MCCLELLAND Co., of Ninth and Tenth-avenue lines.) by invitation of Mr. GREENWOOD, the Manager, who has twice generously opened the establishment, with its various attractions,

MR. APPLETON'S WILL.-We are permitted, through the courteous attention of one of the executors, to publish an abstract of the will of the late SAMUEL APPLETON, Esq. It will be seen that his donations for scientific, literary, religious and charitable purposes, amount to the munificent sum of two hundred thousand dollars.

How long have I been out of the workingday world? Away from the thronged sidewalks of dusty, dearly-loved New-York? Certain recollections have I of a clay of explosive uproar, militiaparadings, fifes villainously squeaking, unjustifiablycastigated drums ; of the popping, whizzings and bangings of pyrotecnically-patriotic juveniles,-all clearly indicating the Fourth.

THE ST. REGIS INDIANS.-The Church Journal says :-At the request of the Rev. ELEAZAR WILLIAMS, we cheerfully lay the following before our readers: The Rev. ELEAZAR WILLIAMS, Missionary to the St. Regis Indians and others, has been enraged in preparing a Prayer Book in the Mohawk language for their use.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: I was much gratified in reading the letter from your correspondent at Burlington, touching some of the incidents of the War of 1812. If every one in our country, to whom such unpublished details have been entrusted, had done the same, we should now have materials for a history that never can be recovered.

FACTORY LABOR IN RHODE ISLAND.-The recent passage of an act by the Rhode Island Legislature, making ten hours a legal day's work, is creating considerable disturbance among the manufacturing villages of that State. Upon the day on which the law went into operation, many of the factories were closed-the proprietors not being willing to have the law obeyed.

Lieutenant M. F. MAURT, Superintendent of the American Observatory, leaves town this morning, we learn, en route for Europe, to attend the Scientific Convention which is to be held in Brussels nest month, under appointment and authority of the Naval Powers of Europe, to agree upon some uniform plan of observations, , connected with our distinguished countryman's Wind and Current Charts. After the Convention closes,

Commodore S??, who is to command the Naval Squadron for the protection of our fishermen on the Eastern coast, arrived here last evening from Washington, accompanied by the Secretary of the Squadron, Colonel JOHN S. CUNNINGHAM, who has been, we learn, detailed from the Navy Department for this special occasion, at the request of the Commodore.

We notice that some of our neighbors are speaking disrespectfully of our Legislature. This is all wrong. Let us speak well of the ruling powers, if we conscientiously can; if we can't, at least let us not use the hard language concerning them which they deserve. And if any should refuse to do them honor on account of their positions, let such speak gently out of policy. For who knows, if taunted,

All Winter long I trod the sidewalks of Gotham. The sun which slanted upon the pretty faces and flaunting equlpages of Broadway through the "brown air" of October stooped lower every day; snow alternated with mud; the fickle April smiled and wept its life away-still June found me crunching along the sidewalk.

TIMELY ADVICE.-Housekeepers about leaving the city fur the country, leaving their residences unoccupied, by notifying the police of such fact, may save themselves the mortification of finding their houses robbed upon their return to the city. Persons in Newark, N. J., wishing to advertise in the DAILY or WEEKLY TIMES, can do so by calling on M. DANILLS, NO. 176 Market-street.

It must needs be owned that a bird's eye view of New York discloses, here and there, places not at all sightly, even in the eye of a bird. Between Centre-street and the Bowery there are such. The West side enjoys them at the lower extreme of Greenwich-street, and along Washington-street, and in the vicinity of West Broadway.

BURGLARY IN BROADWAY.--Yesterday morning, abuot 5 1/2 o'clock, officers Mecham and Judge, of the Sixth Ward Police, conveyed to the station-house a large quantity of silk goods, vestings, , together with a roll of valuable cloth, which they found in a carriage in Elizabeth street, near Bayard.

ROGGIERI, Assistant Pastor; CAUVIN, (Hoboken,) Pozzo, O'NEIL,

The building, together with the contents, (consisting of a valuable horse, a cow, several sets of harness, and a large quantity of feed,) were destroyed, notwithstanding the exertions of the firemen. COMMON COUNCIL.-At a regular meeting of this body on Monday evening, the following, among other business, was transacted: The Treaurer reported having received, up to July 18, $223,078 57; paid, $224,184; overpaid, $1,105 43.

ARREET OF FIVE COUNTERFETTERS.--Since the arrest of MAXEY, our police have been on the lookout for his confederates. They tracked them from Worcester to Spectacle Island, and yesterday afternoon nabbed five of them in East Cambridge. Their names are CHARLES POMROY, aged 29; Lo RENZO MOULTON, 32; CHARLES VERBACK, 23; and LELAND A. WILKICNSON, 30;

Visit to a Rice Plantation continued- Women at Fieldwork-Gangs-Old and Young-Tasks-Drivers-Overseers--Punishment. The weather yesterday was propitious, and the number of visitors at the Crystal Palace sustained a corresponding increase. Every person entering passes through a turn-stile which records each admission; all that is necessary, therefore, at the end of the day to ascertain the aggregate number of visitors, is to add up the record of each turn-stile.

MARINE COURT.--Before Hon. FLORENCE MCCARTHY.--Eduard Lawrence vs. Thendore Hyatt.--This was an action by the plaintiff, as the assignee of his brother, William T. Lawrence, to recover $70 as broker age, on a sale of real estate in Thirty-eighth street, which Wm. T. Lawrence had made a contract for, under instructions from the defendant.

Nothing had transpired in public respecting politics. The general impression was, that peace would be preserved ;hut this belief was chiefly founded on the expectation that Turkey would sign the note required by Russia. A dispatch from Bucharest, July 2, states that the body of the army intending to occupy Wallachia, were that day crossing the Pruth, at Leora, General DAREMBURG commanding-and the next day the body intended to invade Moldavia would cross at Skoulin.

FAMINE IN INDIA-WHOLESALE MORTALITY--A late number of the Bombay Times says: " We have famines occurring almost decennially, some of which, within our time, have swept their millions away. In 1833, 50,000 persons in the month of September, in Lucknow; at Khanpoor, 1,200 died of want; and [Pound]500,000 sterling were subscribed by the bountiful to relieve the destitute.

The U. S. frigate Congress, commanded by GEO. F. PEARSON, and bearing the broad penant of Commodore ISAAC MCKEEVER, arrived yesterday morning from Rio Janciro, which port she left June 12. She had been absent three years and three months, and has been the flag-ship of the Brazilian squadron during the whole of that time.

A robbery took place on board the steamboat Chancellor, at Baton Rouge, on the 11th inst., and Lynch law was awarded to the culprits. Several men, deck and cabin passengers, lost amounts varying from $15 to $60 in cash, and drafts as high as $1,400.

The Tribune professes not to expect from the TIMES either "honesty, manliness, or candor." Then it will be disappointed. Not even its coarse and vulgar abuse will prevent us from the constant exercise of each of those cardinal virtues.

The amount of travel between Boston and Charlestown, is much greater, perhaps, than one might at first suppose. Warren bridge being closed last week, a careful account was kept. From 5 o'clock in the morning to 7 1/2 in the afternoon, the number of foot passengers from Boston to Charlestown was 3,515; the total number of carriages of all kinds for the same time was 3,560.
CASTLE GARDEN.--To-night another reproduction, "Don Giovanni," with a good cast. Mad. SONTAG as Zerlina, Signora STEFFANONE as Donna Anna, Signor BADIALI as the hero, and Signor ROVERE as Leperello.

The following are the very efficient arrangements for the security and protection of the Palace and its valuable contents from destruction by fire, as officially sanctioned by the General Superintendent: EDGAR F. RANDOLPH, Superintendent. RUBERT F. RANDOLPH, Assistant-Superintendent.

Mr. Ira B. Eddy was brought up in Court at New-Haven, on Monday, on a writ of habeas corpus, requiring the Insane Retreat to show why he should be detained by them as an insane person. The Superintendent of the Institution testified that Mr. Eddy's conduct for the week he had been in the Retreat had not been such as to satisfy him that he was insane.

Hurrah! We would throw it up, if we had our best hat on. Who cares for the expense on such an occasion? When the citizens of this great State read that blessed announcement at the end of the Legislative proceedings, that they adjourned sinc die, there will be a thrill of joy running, we will venture to say, through all hearts, everywhere from Montauk to Dunkirk.

From the Evening Bulletin. UNITED STATES COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE--Before Commissioner E. D. INGRAHAN.--An Alleged Fugitive Slave.--This morning a colored man, apparently about 25 years of age, was brought before Commissioner INGRAHAM, on a warrant issued by him, charged with being a fugitive from labor. His claimant is J. C. HOWARD, of Cecil County, Maryland.

The Courier is very anxious to have it understood that Mr. THOMAS HOPE is not the only person who pursues the dog-in-the-manger policy of refusing to allow the Sixth and Eighth-avenue Railroad cars to carry their passengers to Barclay-street.

The City of New-York is the Literary no less than the Commercial Metropolis of the country. What London is to England and Paris to France; what Edinburg was to Scotland and ancient Rome to the Empire, that the City of New-York is, not only to the State, nor to the North alone, but to the United States.

Another plot has been discovered in Paris. It was known that the Emperor and Empress were to visit the Opera Comique, which is on the Boulevards Italiens, nearly opposite the Rue Laffitte. From an early hour a crowd collected on both sides of the Boulevards.

The motives and objects of those who visit the CRYSTAL PALACE, will be almost as various as the individuals themselves. Thousands will go thither for the mere gratification of curiosity,--for the sake of casting a hurried and superficial glance over the vast variety of the Products of Industry and Art, which the Exhibition has brought together.

KEEPING SWINE.--James Carley and John Line, residing in Van Buren-street, between Bedford avenue and Skillman-st. were yesterday brought before Justice Smith, by the Chief of Police, charged with keeping a greater number of bogs on their premises than the law allows. They were fired $5 each, and in default of payment, were sent to jail for ten days each.

The Journal of Commerce copies from a Pennsylvania newspaper the following passage: "We learn from a private and reliable source that a new railroad project is on foot, to connect Doylestown and the great commercial port of New-York in a ride of less than three hours.

The Times correspondent has received a private letter from Constantinople, dated the 22d ult., of which the following is an extract: "All is tranquil here, and we await with impatience the steamer from Odessa, in order to ascertain in what manner Prince MENSCHIKOFF will view the answer of the Turkish Government.

FLORENCE, July 1--The Royal Court has to-day given judgment in the case of GUERAZZI and his fellow-prisoners. MM. GUERAZZI and PETRACCHI are sentenced to fifteen years' hard labor, (ergastolo.) M. CAPECCHI, a sub-officer, to sixty three months, and M. MONTAZIO, a journalist, to ninety months of the same punishment.

For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Custom of the Country--Ireland as it is. NATIONAL THEATRE--Uncle Tom's Cabin. CASTLE GARDEN.--Madame 'ontag in Italian Opera. SIBLO'S GARDEN.--English Opera Company. HOPE CHAPEL.--Frankenstein's Panorama of Niagara Falls. RANCONI'S HIPPODROME.--Performance every afternoon and evening.

STATED MEETING OF THE BOARD OF EDUCATION--Present--ERASTUS C BENEDICT, Esq., President, and Commissioners Stuart, Savage, T. E. Smith, Vulte, Foote, Murphy. Pinkney. Fell, Wright, Fraser, W Jones, Dodge, Ketchum, Morand, Davis, Beadle, DeLamater, Ransem, Hibbard, Addis, Waterbury, Mon'eith, and Blackburn.

There are now three great routes from Washington City to the Virginia Springs. No. 1 is by the Potomac steamboat to Acquia Creek; thence by Railroad to Fredericksburg; thence to the Junction; thence to Louisa Court-House, to Gordonsville, to Charlottesville, thence to Staunton.

The Senate met at 7 1/2 o'clock, Wednesday evening, and worked hard on the Assessment bill, but as every proposition was negatived, the Senate adjourned at midnight. Thursday, July 21. The Rensselaer County Supervisors bill came up in the report of the Committe of Conference and the report was disagreed to, and the bill declared lost.

According to the Globe, her Majesty's visit to Dublin is postponed, owing to the indisposition of Prince ALBERT. On the subject of Eastern affairs the Globe states that the importance of the Constantinople news of the 26th June, is very materially lessened by the fact, that at that date nothing could have been known at the Turkish capital of the Emperor's manifesto, or of the passage of the Pruth.

CASE OF BIGAMY.--FREDERICK FREELAND was yesterday arrested, on complaint of Mrs. FREELAND, charged with the crime of bigamy. The circumstances, as appears by the examination and confession of the parties, were these: FREELAND Was married at Kingston, in 1840, and afterwards removes to Syracuse.

THE CAFFRES OF SOUTH AFRICA.--In personal appearance and formation, these Caffres are a race of the most manly and handsome people known among savages, and in many of their points resemble the New-Zealanders. In stature they are generally tall, their height varying from five feet eight or nine inches to upwards of six feet.

KINGS COUNTY HOSPITAL.--The annexed is an abstract of the resident physician's report of the Kings County Hospital for the week ending July 20, 1853: Remaining July 13, 340; received, by order of the Superintendents, 64; born, 3; transferred to the Alms-House, I; discharged, 46; deceased, 4; eloped, 1. Total number remaining July 20, 355.

THE LOST FOUND.--The son of Dr. McCRAY of Agawam, who disappeared on the 27th April last from the Literary Institution in Suffield, Ct., and from whom not a word has since been heard by his distressed family, was found on Monday morning on the hay-mow in his father's barn.

By the arrival of the Indus steamer, bringing the remaining portion of the Indian and Australian mails, we have a variety of details concerning the progress of the various colonies. With regard to the colony of New South Wales, it appears that there is nothing in politics to notice.

A fire broke out to-day on the corner of Eighth-street and Broadway, in a blacksmith's-shop. One square is entirely consumed, and the flames are still spreading. It is now burning in three squares, and the wind blowing furiously. The firemen are on the ground, but as yet they do not abate it at all.

LA FAYETTE COLLEGE.--The Annual Commencement of La Fayette College will take place at Easton, Pa., on Wednesday, July 27. The Address before the Alumni will be delivered on Tuesday evening, July 26, by Prof. WM. H. GREEN, of the Theological Seminary at Princeton. The Address before the Literary Societies will be delivered by Rev. GARDINER SPRING, D.D., of New-York.

The partial information received from Halifax by telegraph is enlarged, and in some important particulars modified, by the mails of the Europa. While the firm and united position of France and England is substantiated; we get, besides, the very material statement that a new envoy has been dispatched from the Czar to the Sultan, with the aim of renewing negotiations.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I purpose, in my present number, to give you some account of negro festivities here. A ball or a party is rather an uncommon entertainment with them, as they are never permitted to hold public assemblies without the presence of some white persons, and those of good character and standing.

I telegraphed you this evening that Commodore PERRY'S Squadron would probably return to Macao, from his first visit to Japan, about October next, with the intention of repeating the trip the ensuing Spring.

Well, we have had our dinner, at the long table, with our host and hostess, sons, daughters, and an indefinite number of "hands"--for our host is a good Democrat, though he has voted with the Whig party since the days of JACKSON. Now we are "gifted with the freedom of the" premises; and we will find the whole family kind, agreeable, and communicative.

July 5, JESSIE, infant daughter of Andrew and Frances C. Leaman, of Union-st, Brooklyn, aged 13 months. At Upper Red Hook, July 15, WM. H. ELTON, aged 47 years. At his residence, Plainfield, N. J, on Thursday morning, July 21, SAMUEL MELBANK, late of this City, in the 78th year of his age.

One or two new branches of instruction have been introduced into the Deaf and Dumb Institution in this City, which promise useful results. They are intended to develop the resources of the Deaf-Mute mind, and to open up new sources of profit and pleasure to the members of that unfortunate class.
BOARD OF EXCISE-July 20.-Present: GEORGE L. SHAW, Esq., President, and Commissioners CAVANAGH, DE REVERE, CRAMPHIN, MEAD, TANDY, EAGAN, FINNEGAN, and VAN MATER. The following licenses were granted:

The Freeman's Journal contradicts the rumor that Rev. Dr. IVES, late Episcopal Bishop of North Carolina, was about to be divorced from his wife, that he might enter the Roman Catholic Priesthood, and publishes, in support of its denial.

Well, that is not out of the way for editors, sailors and watchmen, who, like beasts of prey, work all night. They must sleep, of course, or their life insurance policies will be paid over to their widows prematurely.

The house of Rev. HENRY TOWNSEND, of this city, was broken into this morning, while the family were temporarily absent, and robbed of a large amount of silver plate and some gold coin. Several pickpockets have been arrested and committed to jail.

I just write you a few words to say that my statements about the time of Russia's invading Moldo-Walachia have been literally confirmed. The Russian General, DANNENBERG, crossed the Pruth near Leova on the 2d of July with 50,000 men, and another army, about 10,000 men stronger, on the 3d of July near Skoulyanie. It is a concentrated movement towards Bukarest and the Danube.

FIRE IN THE BOWERY.--Yesterday, about 8 1/2 o'clock, a fire broke out in the boarding-house situated at the corner of Bowery and Fourth-street. The firemen were promptly on the spot. and succeeded, after some labor, in extinguishing the flames, though not before the upper portion of the building was destroyed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Hardly a copy of your paper is issued, but what contains some article, headed as above, showing a controversy between the old and new administration of this Institution, which amounts to a decided quarrel.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. Will you be kind enough to say something in your paper concerning the transportation of the Mails from New-York, North, through Lake Champlain. What reason can there possibly be for taking nearly three days between New-York and Ticonderoga? We are only 25 miles north of Whitehall on the Lakes. Were I in New-York, I could leave in the evening and reach home the next morning.

To the Editor or the New-York Daily Times: My task is to write you Democratic Letters on American Policy in European matters. In conforming to this essential nature of my communications, I have to state a fact which deserves to be seriously considered by every American duly sensible of his country's Republican dignity.

We publish this morning two letters from our regular Democratic Correspondent in Europe,--both of which, though bearing different dates, and mailed at different times, reached us by the last steamer. They will be found even more than usually interesting and instructive.

We regret to learn that the venerable, Chancellor JONES lies dangerously ill, at the residence of a member of his family, on Long Island. He is 86 years old, and has been remarkably fortunate in the possession of excellent health and a wonderful degree of vigor, for many years. He has long been known as one of the ablest and most learned members of the New-York Bar.

D. S. GREGG has been appointed Commissioner to the Sandwich Islands; JOHN F. BACON, Consul to Nassau, West Indies; and ISAAC T. GOLDING, to Laguayra. Hon. ALFRED GILMORE, Consul to Bordeaux, is in town. Senator JAMES left this evening.
Since the division on the India bill, which gave so unexpectedly large a majority to Ministers, and utterly confounded the hopes of the Opposition, there has been a comparative lull in legislation.
No mail south of Mobile this morning. The Mobile Tribune publishes a letter from New-Orleans, which reports a great prevalence of yellow fever in that city, many deaths occurring daily.

There has been, perhaps, no day since the opening of the Exhibition, when the interior of the Palace looked better than to-day. There were apparently more visitors; the hitherto imperceptible changes in the different departments made themselves felt for the first time, and we had a very excellent foretaste of the ensemble which will be produced when the arrangements are completed.
DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN PITTSBURG.--On Tuesday morning, at about 5 o'clock, a fire broke out in the extensive flour and salt warehouse of Mr. JAS McCULLY, on Penn-street, extending back to the canal.

DEAR SIR: Having been a reader of your paper for the last year, and approving of its "honest, manly, and candid" course, particularly with regard to Cuba, and noticing in one of your cotemporaries a denial of certain of your statements in regard to the pay and treatment of the Chinese, or Coolies, in said Island, I beg to add my testimony to the correctness of your assertions.

Some changes have taken place in Union Theological Seminary, consequent upon the resignation, by Prof. WILSON, of the Chair of Systematic Theology. The principal instruction in that department will hereafter be given by Prof. HENRY B. SMITH, who at the same time will continue his Lectures on the History of the Christian Doctrines.

PHI BETA KAPPA ANNUAL MEETING.--The Massachusetts Alpha of the Phi Beta Kappa Society held its annual meeting at Cambridge on Thursday. An election of officers was held in the morning, with the following result: Hon. Josiah Quincy. Jr., President; Professor Cornelius C. Felton, Vice-President, and Tutor Charles F. Choate, Secretary.

A most bloody and murderous assault was made upon JOSHUA L. MILLER, Sheriff of this (Emmet.) County, at Pine River, yesterday afternoon. Mr. MILLER went to Pine River yesterday morning, to summon three Jurors, residing there, who had been drawn for the July Circuit at this place.

How much ought we, who enjoy all the privileges of the City--its Crystal Palace, its Operas, its crowd of amusements, its varied and cheap markets, its genial weather, and its thousand facilities for social intercourse and enjoyment--to pity those, whose health or business, or whose slavery to fashion, compels into the country.
Ship Washington is passing the Bar. One ship, two barks and two brigs, bound out, are coming down by the Spit. All the other outward bound vessels have gone to sea, and have a good offing.

Very important measures have been taken in the Congress of New-Granada, in relation to liberty of religion. As nearly as we can make out by the Granadian papers that we have received, the Catholic party have joined with the moderate Liberalists, or, as they are again called, the consequent Liberalists, against the crazy, ultra, or inconsistent Liberalists, and have gained a victory.

On Sixth day morning, 22d inst., of consumption in the 50th year of her age, ABBY S, wife of isaac Carpenter. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to at tend her funeral this morning, 23d inst., at 8 1/2 o'clock. at No. 11 Attorney st The remains will he taken to Purchase, Westchester Co., for interment, via Harlem Rail road.

This is a great gala day among the Firemen, and the streets and house-tops are lined with spectators to witness their movements. Among the companies present, are three from New-York, two from Hartford, one each from Norwalk, Meriden, and Chicopee, and three from New-London.
For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns BROADWAY THEATRE.--Uncle Pat's Cabin--Our Jemiml--Irish Lion.

FROM HALIFAX AND NEWFOUNDLAND.--By the steamer Europa we have received Halifax papers to the 19th, and St. John's, Newfoundland, to the 13th inst. The Morning Chronicle of the 19th, speaking of the visit of Mr. CRAMPTON, says: His visit, we understand, was for the purpose of conferring personally with the provincial authorities and the Naval Commander-in-Chief on the subject of the Fisheries.

Through this section of country, the wheat crops are not so good as usual. Judging from the number of shocks in the fields, I should have supposed that there had been a fair harvest, but on inquiry, I learned that the grain had been injured by the joint-worm. Guanoed lands have escaped better than others.

The Annual Commencement at old Harvard this year was a pleasant occasion. The Boston people, glorying in the memories that cluster about the shades of Cambridge, always observe the day of Commencement as a season of rejoicing.

SHIP-BUILDING.--Mr. PATTISON has just completed a contract for building a ship of 1,000 tons burden, for Messrs. HURLBUT Co, of New-York. The keel is shortly to be laid at his yard, at the foot of North Seventh-street.

JOHN M. DANIEL, the Editor of the Richmond Enquirer, has been appointed Charge to Sardinia, vice RICHARD K. MEADE, declined. DANIEL S. GREGG, of Springfield, Illinois, is appointed Commissioner to the Sandwich Islands. DUNCAN R. McRAE, the newly-appointed Consul at Paris, is temporarily invested with the powers of Charge.

I have been a week at Niagara, and perhaps two or three days longer. I think I reached the Falls on a Monday; or was it on a Thursday, or a Saturday? I have lost an accurate perception of the flight of Time. I have read no newspapers.

ST. MARY'S CHURCH.--The foundation of a new Catholic edifice, to be called St. Mary's Church, has recently been commenced on the corner of Leonard and Remsen-streets. The outside of the building is to be of the Elizabethan style, of rough brick, with ornamented window and door lintels, and imitation pillars of brick.

In relation to the Marine Court of the City of New-York. Passed July 21, 1853. The People of the State of New-York, represented in Senate and Assembly, do enact as follows: SECTION 1. The Marine Court or the City of New-York shall have jurisdiction over and cognizance of actions of Assault and Battery.

The last day in the Legislature, always one of confusion, was rich in items of interest; though not all of them edifying. The bill adding three quarters of a mill to the present quarter mill tax was passed, which will raise enough to cover all anticipated deficiencies up to the 1st Sept. 1854.

CASTLE GARDEN.--The usual success attended the reproduction of MOZART'S "Don Giovanni" last evening. In point of numbers, the attendance was better than on any preceding occasion, excepting, of course, the President's night. It is strange we have so little good music when the experiment of reviving it is always attended with success.

The Santa Fe mail arrived at Independence, Mo., on the 20th inst. Major GORDON, U.S. Army, and J.S. WEBLE, of Santa Fe, came passengers by the mail. Everything remained quiet in New Mexico. They passed Col. SUMMER at Cottonwood, on his way to St. Louis, and Gen. GARLAND and Gov. MEREWEATHER on the Arkansas. They also met large parties of traders, all of whom were getting along finely.

REVOLT AT SEA.-Letters have been received in this city from Capt. VINALL, of ship Rockland, bound from New-York to Australia, with some 200 passengers, giving the particulars of a revolt which occurred on board that ship at sea, and which resulted in putting in irons six of the ringleaders, the vessel being obliged in consequence to put into Rio Janeiro on the 10th June.

We publish in another column, copied from the Celt, the Report of a Committee appointed by the Ancient Order of Hibernians, at the meeting in Grand-street Hall, "to rebut an unfounded charge" brought against the Society, of having caused a riot in the Ninth Ward, on the 4th of July.

FATAL ACCIDENT IN BOSTON HARBOR.--This morning, the steamship Europa, from Liverpool, while coming up through the Narrows, accidentally came in collision with a sail-boat, which was struck amidship, run over and sunk.

Americans abroad send baek to the States few letters from this old town, as it is almost a terra incognita to the many travelers who, in pursuit of health and pleasure, are rambling among the green strathes, or climbing the heathy braes of Scotland.

The Russian Government has followed up its circular dispatch of the 11th of May, and its manifesto to the Russian nation of the 26th of June, by a further communication to its agent at foreign Courts, intended to explain the position it has now assumed.

HEAVY DAMAGES.--In the case of Orrin S. Bonstee against Cornclius Vanderbilt and Daniel Drew, tried at the Ulster Circuit, the Jury rendered a verdict for the plaintiff for the sum of $10,000. The action was for cruel and improper treatment of a passenger, who took passage by the VANDERBILT new line of steamers between New-York and San Francisco, and for delay on the route.

If evidence were needed of the organship of the Washington Union, it might be found in the following paragraph, which closes an article on the "Mission to England," in this morning's issue: "The rumor of misunderstanding between Mr. BUCHANAN and Secretary MARCY has no better foundation than the idle fabrications of the news mongers about difficulties among the members of the Cabinet."
FRED. DOUOGLASS ON GERRITT SMITH.--GERRITT SMITH has been sick-has been through a surgeon's hands-but is better. He is a man of note.

The Freeman's Journal asserts that it is assailed by the TIMES "for having ventured to tell the truth" about the Ninth Ward Riot. This is a fair sample of the style in which that paper makes statements upon all subjects which it handles.

FOR THE WEST AND SOUTH.--BALTIMORE AND OHIO, AND WASHINGTON BRANCH RAILROAD, for WHEELING, ZANESVILLE, CINCINNATI, LOUISVILLE, ST. LOUIS, great road was first opened for through travel in January last. The tunnels then unfinished are now completed. The entire road is in fine order, and presents one of the most pleasant and picturesque routes in the world.

A startling piece of information was published in Paris, on the 9th, in three Government journals, the Pays, Constitutionnel. and Patrie, all of which announce that M. DE BRUCK, who was supposed to have been sent to Constantinople with conciliatory instructions, opened his mission by making fresh demands upon the Porte.

That the Crystal Palace has yet much be fore it in the way of interior decoration, is evidenced by the daily announcements of the arrivals of foreign goods registered at the receiving office. Contributions are every moment arriving, and the consignments to the Custom-House are exceedingly large.

From the Courtland Co. Whig (Extra), of July 21--3 P.M. PATRICK O'DONAGHUE, whose trial was to take place next week for the murder of Mrs. KINNEY and daughter, has just attempted suicide, by cutting the jugular vein with a razor.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: One of your correspondents (+) asks, "Can anything be more utterly contemptible and worthless than our City Post?" I reply, " Yes; our General Post." A letter was mailed to me in Rut land, Vt., and reached me five days after. A news paper took ten days to come; another letter was six days coming. Rutland is seven hours' distance from Chambers-street.

The London Times, writing editorially, and ostensibly from exclusive information, asserts that the rumored conspiracy against the Emperor's life was really founded on fact. Some weeks ago, as the Emperor and Empress were on their way to the Hippodrome, a plot was laid for intercepting the cortege.

GERRIT SMITH, Esq., has made another munificent donation to a public enterprise. The City of Oswego stood in need of a Public Library. Mr. SMITH learned the nature of the circumstances, was impressed with the importance of the project. and has set apart the sum of Twenty-five Thousand Dollars for the foundation of such an institution. The money is to be called for in installments of $5,000 each, commencing on the 1st March 1854.

For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Erin Our Home--In and Out of Place--The Irish Tiger. WIBLO'S GARDEN.--English Opera Company. CASTLE GARDEN.--Madame Sontag in Italian Opera.

--It will not be forgotten by some of our readers that a British welcome to Lord ELLESMEERE and his colleagues, in the shape of a public dinner, was long ago announced in these columns, as an affair that was really to take place. We regret to say that the project has been abandoned; and we deem it only respectful to the British community of New-York, to explain the circumstances under which this disappointment has occurred.

THE RAIN.--We hear from various quarters of the benefits received from the copious showers of Tuesday and Wednesday. It was attended with some discomforts, however. At Manchester, N. H., the people at the Hippodrome, some 4,000 in number, got a thorough drenching; damage to clothes estimated at $2.000.

To Dr. A. A. L.--DEAR DOCTOR: I have somewhere read that "a pair of modern eyes are the most significant things in the world," or something to that effect. And "a pair" may be insisted on, for a one-eyed man sees but imperfectly-at least ABERCROMBIE, (?) in his Mental Philosophy, tries to prove it so.

The Smyrna correspondent of the Marseilles Semaphore gives an account of the disturbance in Smyrna-of which mention was made in the TIMES of Saturday last, in the letter of our Special European Correspondent.

Count Nesselrode's last Manfiesto--Bellicose Language of the Document--The Russian Commandant's Proclamation to the Moldavians--Prospects of War--Reception of Commodore Stringham by the Sultan--Important Rumors--American Aid to Turkey:
CHURCH SALE.--The Wesleyan Methodist Church, in Grove-street, Jersey City, was sold at auction on Friday for $2,410. D. KEENAN was the purchaser.

Our circular advices, per Europa, on 8th inst., might almost be reiterated without further comment, so devoid of all interest of a novel character has been our produce markets since her departure. In COTTON the business that has transpired has been on an average scale with late operations, but conducted in such a quiet manner that the extent is not apparent till the day closes.

Although the details of the recent catastrophe at Niagara have been already fully spread before our readers, the following extract of a letter in the Albany Register, in regard to it, will be read with interest:

The Minister to France is undoubtedly appointed, but will not, it is expected, be announced until after the elections in Kentucky, North Carolina, and Tennessee. Mr. DIX will certainly be the man, unless the Administration is again frightened off by Southern demonstrations.

Friday was a great day at New-Haven. At the invitation of its stalwart sons engaged in a like enterprise, firemen from New-York, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and the old Nutmeg State, congregated in the " City of Elms," to do honor to the occasion, and to contend in manly rivalry for prizes given by the New-Haven Fire Department to those who should excel in the working of their machines.
New-Orleans papers of the 16th and 17th inst., have been received. They contain Tampico dates to the 8th inst., but the news is unimportant.

The U. S. Mail steamship Arctic, Captain LUCE, arrived on Saturday evening from Liverpool, whence she sailed on Wednesday, 13th inst. She has made the passage in a little more than ten days. The Arctic brings 149 passengers, whose names will be found under the appropriate heading.

CHURCH ROBBED.--The Presbyterian Church, at Bergen, was entered on Friday night, and the carpet was stolen. A reward of $50 is offered for the thief and carpet. It is quite certain that it was taken across the Jersey City Ferry to New York.
Last night about, 10 1/2 o'clock, the steamer St. Lawrence, a new Sandusky and Buffalo boat, bound up and the Queen City, bound down, came in collision on Lake Eric.

It is gratifying to find our Navy exhibiting symptoms of life. Commodore STRINGHAM, of the Mediterranean squadron, has made himself heard at Athens, and talked in the manliest and friendliest way with the Sultan. We cannot praise too warmly the guarded, yet sufficiently explicit language of sympathy addressed to ABDUL MEDJID, the defender of KOSSUTH, and the courageous antagonist of the Czar.

THE SAUT SHIP CANAL AND THE EXCAVATIONS.--The Lake Superior Journal of Saturday last states that, notwithstanding the unfavorable weather of last month, the great work has progressed steadily and rapidly, and the "big ditch" has already, in some places, taken the shape of as hip canal.

Our files of West Indian papers bear dates to the 13th inst. BERMUDA.--The most interesting intelligence is the action of the House of Assembly of Bermuda, directing the Receiver General to exempt from the payment of light dues all vessels arriving within their ports, that shall be engaged in whale fishing.

The Eastern Question is not to remain a question long. Perhaps, in the whole history of diplomacy, no correspondence has been carried forward with the same animation; never has note answered unto note with equal promptitude.

PARIS, Monday Evening, July 11.--It is said that a joint note from England and France has been addressed to the Russian Government, making pro positions for the pacific settlement of the impending question.

ARRIVAL OF THE U. S. SLOOP JOHN ADAMS.--The U. S. sloop John Adams, Commander BARRON, arrived at this port this forenoon, from the Coast of Africa. The following are her officers; Lieutenants--Henry French, James A. Doyle, Isaac G. Swain; Acting Lieutenant--James Higgins; Assistant Surgeon--James F. Huestis; Purser--Alfred A. Belknap; Acting Master--Charles W. Woolley; Midshipmen--Jesse Taylor, Marshall C. Campbell, Charles A. Babcock; Boatswain--Edward Brady; Gunner--John Owins; Carpenter--Wm. Hyde; Sailmaker--Wm. M. Mahoney; Captain's Clerk--James Conway.

During the first few years after its invention, the Telegraph found stirring business upon dry land. It traveled rapidly, and bound together with intelligent ties half the cities in each half of the world. In America alone it had played a part so marvellous as to rival Puck, with his famous girdle about the earth.

THE SUICIDE AT NEW-ROCHELLE.--The Buffalo Commercial Advertiser, concerning the suicide of Mr. GRAY, says: We have heard a cause alleged for the act, which renders the affair less strange. It is said that, for some time before, he had been la boring under great depression of spirits, arising from the fact that he was haunted by a lady with whom be has been connected in marriage, it is said, in California.

As I told you in my last, we started on Monday for the fifth centennial celebration of the admission of Berne into the Confederacy. It required some courage to affront a pouring rain, which has been a characteristic feature in these latitudes for some time.

Laborers are wanted in the country. In the City there is not, in many departments, a call for them. The lack of laborers on the farm is seriously felt throughout the country. Here, a copy of any daily paper which contains a column of "Wants," shows distinctly that the openings are not as numerous as are the men who are anxious to fill them.

The Union, of this morning, declares that the rumor of a misunderstanding between Secretary MARCY and Mr. BUCHANAN has no better foundation than the idle fabrications of newsmongers about difficulties in the Cabinet.

FIRE--FOUR HORSES BURNED.--Yesterday morning, about 1 o'clock, a fire broke out in a row of old shantees, in the rear of Nos. 226 and 228 South Fourth street, belonging to and occupied by JOHN GORMAN. These buildings, together with their contents--consisting of four fine horses, several sets of harness, and a large quantity of feed-were soon destroyed.

The following will he found to be an accurate list of the U. S. District Attornies, and U. S. Marshals, in the several States and Territories, with the places of residence of the respective officers, and a statement of their terms of service. Those in whose cases the words. "during the recess " are used, have been appointed since the adjournment of the Senate.

IMPORTANT ARREST.--Yesterday morning, officer JEREMIAH HIGGINS, of the Chief's office, succeeded in arresting a man named WM. HUGGINS, in the vicinity of the Catharine Market, New York, on a warrant issued by Justice BLACHLEY, in which he is charged with swindling a New-Orleans merchant out of $250 in gold coin, and a valuable gold watch.

THE $50,000 CHURCH FUND.--The whole amount received from Massachusetts up to the present time, in aid of the $50,000 for building churches at the West, is fourteen thousand one hundred and eighteen dollars and twenty-three cents-which, we believe, is some four thousand dollars more than the sum assigned to this State.

CASTLE GARDEN.--" Sonnambula" attracted a good house last evening. Without being crowded, the seats were comfortably filled. Considering the threatening aspect of the heavens, the audience was more numerous than we anticipated would attend. It is almost unnecessary for us to allude to the Amina of Mad. SONTAG.

Mr. JOHN O'DONOHUE, the Irish patriot, who stood in the same dock with MEAGHER and M'MANUS, and who, like his other compatriots, escaped from his place of deportation in Australia, arrived in this City from California yesterday morning. He came by the ship Northern Light, which vessel anchored in the bay at 2 o'clock in the morning,

The undersigned are compelled to call upon the Christian Public for prompt assistance in a ease of great urgency. On Sunday there arrived in this port seventy exiles from Madeira, whom recent enactments of the Portuguese Government have compelled to quit that island, to seek in this land of religious liberty that freedom to serve God according to their consciences, which they cannot find in their own.

The steamship Northern Light, Capt. J. MINER, arrived at this port yesterday from San Juan de Nicaragua, whence she sailed on the 17th inst. She left New-York on the 5th of July at 3 P. M., and arrived at San Juan on the 15th, at 11 A. M., stopping at Kingston for coal, which place she left at 5 P. M. on the 12th.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : Here I am, again, in ever gay, brilliant, fascinating Saratoga. I do not wonder so many throng her gardens, groves and bowers, and endure the inconvenience of small sleeping apartments, for the pleasure to be derived at her fountains and her festive scenes. Were there no other reason for coming, this one of meeting with one's friends, and all the world beside, would be sufficient.

CALIFORNIA PREACHING.-A reverend gentleman, holding forth to the sinners of Placerville on a late occasion, closed his address with the following exhortation to his hearers to loosen their pursestrings. We warrant he got a goodly contribution:

The arrival of the Northern Light yesterday, from San Juan, puts us in possession of fourteen days' later news from California. And far more pleasant it is than by the former arrival. The mining intelligence continues favorable, and the crops, so far as reported, are flattering.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: For several days the papers have teemed with various notices of the late melancholy catastrophe at New-Rochelle, when the late Mr. FRANKLIN C. GRAY was killed. One would suppose that so afflictive a dispensation would have enlisted the sympathies of the public on behalf of the sorrowing family of the deceased;

On the 11th July, the New Act for the regulation of Hackney-Coaches was enforced in London. The improvements introduced are several. The fares are established at 6d., or 12 cents, for the mile; and 2s., or 24 cents, for the hour. The main difficulty, however, is to insure compliance with the legal rates.

MRS. PUTNAM VS. FRANCIS BOWEN.--Gen. WILSON, the other day in the Convention, in reply to Mr. HILLARD, relative 'to the rejection of Mr. BOWEN, as Professor of History for Harvard, said: "Did not a lady of Roxbury, through the Christian Examiner. in articles of great ability and research, show the gross ignorance and falsehood of the man who edited the North American Review? Aye, sir;

FIRE AND ACCIDENTS.--At about 2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a house owned by PATRICK SHERIDAN, and occupied by JAMES CAVANNAGH, McGRINNISON, and DEMIT, No. 222 Gold-street, near Tillary. The fire soon spread to No. 220, occupied by three families, named BRINSALL, MOORE,

Senator BORLAND was unable to tear himself away from his Arkansas constituency, without delivering himself of a farewell address. It is always gratifying to observe the example of WASHINGTON finding favor with living statesmen; albeit, personal, and not general and political topics, are the staple of the imitation.

Information has been received at this Department, from the United States Consul at Smyrna, that the quarantine regulations of Turkey require that every vessel leaving a port of the United States, bound to Smyrna, should be provided with a bill of health from the proper authorities, in which the exact number of persons on hoard must appear;

Mrs. ESTHER BRADLEY, wife of B. BRADLEY, one of the most respectable citizens of North Haven, was murdered at her residence on Sunday morning, while the family were at church. When Mr. B. returned, he found her lying near the doorsill, weltering in blood. She had received a stab from a knife in the neck, which severed an artery. Several other severe stabs about the neck and arms indicated a hard struggle.

The appointment of Mr. JOHN M. DANIELS, of the Richmond Enquirer, to the Sardinian Chargeship, is a notable event in the history of the Administration. Mr. DANIELS is, in the first place, an editor :-a fact which elicits the regrets of silly people, who fancy incompatibility between editorial and diplomatic functions.

RAILROAD.--The forward axle of the first car of the 8 o'clock New-Brunswick train was broken, between Newark and Elizabethtown, yesterday morning. The fragmente tore the trucks from beneath the two first cars, aud threw two others off the track. Mr. ISAAC FRAZER, the conductor, was passing from one car to another at the time, and was thrown off by the concussion, and severely, but we understand not dangerously, injured.

ARREST.--On Saturday morning, officer HARVEY BALDWIN, of the Eighth Ward Police, arrested an old offender, named JOHN McKIEEIN on a charge of embezzling goods from his employer, in Hudson-street. While the officer was proceeding to the Police Court with the prisoner, he (the prisoner) communicated to him where the goods, as well as others, were to be found.

THE EFFECTS OF DRIVING CATTLE THROUGH THE STREETS-A SCENE IN THE PARK--SEVERAL PERSONS INJURED.-Last evening, about 7 o'clock, as a co., in charge of a colored man, was being driven along Canalstreet, she took fright near the corner of West-street, and ran at full speed towards Broadway. Along Canal-street she kept near the centre of the road, avoiding the cars of the Eighth-avenule Railroad with a happy sense of danger.

Last evening, the preliminary exercises before the first annual commencement of the Free Academy, took place at the Institution on Twentythird-street, before an exceedingly numerous audience. The exercises of the Academy at NIBLO'S to-day, will complete the course of four years and a half.

LODGINGS FOR THE DIGGERS.--A few days ago we entered the grounds of Clift House, Bristol, where Messrs. ACRAMAN, MORGAN Co. formerly carried on their extensive operations, and at first sight fancied we had discovered a new settlement. Scores of snug, compact, uniform little dwellings were ranged side by side, and larger constructions were in progress.

WOMEN AND LADIES.--In the days of our fathers there were such things to be met with as men and women-but now they are all gone, and in their place a race of gentlemen and ladies, or, to be still more refined, a rare of " ladies and gentlemen" has sprung up. Women and girls are among the things that were. But "ladies" are found everywhere.

ALFRED GILMORE, of Pennsylvania, to-day positively declined the Bordeaux Consulate. Letters received here from Commodore STRINGHAM, dated June 15, make no report of a salute to BRUCK, Austrian Envoy. It was not required by etiquette, unless some official correspondence had passed between BRUCK and STRINGHAM.

We have heretofore expressed our belief that the hour has not yet sounded for Russia to consummate either the conquest or the annexation of Turkey. But we none the less strongly believe, that while Russia also recognizes the truth of the same fact, she is anxiously studying the horoscope of the future, in fear lest when the supposed hour of conquest comes, the Christian inhabitants of Turkey should themselves refuse to be annexed.

A remarkable significance sometimes occurs in names, which renders them extremely suggestivc and instructive. The meaning of America is land-mark or sea-mark, a beacon or headland; and the immortal discoverer of the New World bore a gentle appellation signifying "THE DOVE." It was the third occasion in which the Dove was instrumental in rendering important benefit to mankind and the world.

Camphene explodes about as often as steamboat boilers. A German, employed on one of the Mauch Chunk boats, says the True American, while passing through the canal, was badly burned in the face on Saturday evening, by the bursting of a camphene lamp, which he was about lighting.

According to calculations in the Pittsburg Post, the iron manufacturers of this country have a sure demand before them of nearly $300,000,000 for fabrics to be turned out from their manufactoriesa demand that will require all, and more than all their capacity to supply fast enough. The calculation upon which the statements are based, is the extent of Railroad now in course of construction.

LICENSE QUESTION.--This subject is yet before the people and the Common Council of Jersey City. The ordinance to license inns and taverns at $50 each--intended to apply to a limited number-which passed the Board at its meeting three weeks ago this evening, was vetoed at the last meeting. a week ago, and that veto, wa sustained. Two ordinances to regulate tavern licensee, are now upon the table for further consideration.

Gov NEIL S. BROWN.-This distinguished gentleman, late our Minister to St Peterstburg, arriveted in Washington yesterday on his return to his home in Tennessee. He left Russia in rather delicate health, but we are glad to learn that the voyage has restored him to his usual health.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Erin Our Home--Our Jemima. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin. HOPE CHAPEL.--Frankenstein's Panorama of Niagara Falls. A Parliamentary paper just issued contains some interesting returns relative to the discipline of the above forces. It appears that in the four years, 1849 to 1852, both inclusive, 22 policemen of the metropolitan force were sent before the magistrates by the commissioners, and 262 by private individuals.

THE CLIMATE OF ITALY AND PULMONARY CONSUMPTION.-Much misconception prevails with respect to the efficacy of foreign climes in cases of pulmonary consumption; and, however agreeable to the senses warm air, sunny skies, and luxuriant vegetation may seem, they afford no proof of salubrity, nor of the beneficial effect of any climate.

DEATH OF JOHN PRICE WETHERILL.--We regret to learn that this well-known and useful citizen died at the United States Hotel, in Philadelphia, yesterday morning, at 3 o'clock, in the 59th year of his age. His disease was bilious dysentery, which was contracted during the recent visit of the President of the United States to New York--Mr. WETHERILL having been appointed to accompany the President, as one of the representatives of this city.

The Report of the British Emigration Commission has just been printed. The document abounds with interesting facts in reference to the outward movement of population; some of which may serve to correct very erroneous and exaggerated ideas as to the extent of the emigration to America.

The Poughkeepsie American, on its own responsibility, says: " Mr. James Thorn, of Clinton, has an ox that gives milk freely. He has a bag with four teats, each one of-which yields milk like that of the cow. The bag is divided into four sections, but, unlike the cow's, it has no udder.

The U. S. mail steamship Augusta, capt. LYON, arrived at 1 o'clock this morning. She left Savannah July 23, and on the 24th, at 7:15 P. M., she was 25 miles north of Hatteras, when she exchanged signals with the steamship Florrida. At 7:45 P.M., 30 miles north of Hatteras, she exchanged signals with the steamship Black Warrior.

THE MAN RETIRED FROM BUSINESS.--Almost every man sets out in life with the determination, when a certain sum has been accumulated, to retire from the cares of business, and enjoy the balance of his days "otium cum dignitate." Visions of sunny farms and rural retreats are ever before him, but, unfortunately, few men have the courage, when the required sum has been obtained, to be content and retire.

A LEAKY OMNIBUS.--Commend us to a leaky omnibus on a rainy day. We are caught in a sudden shower, and we congratulate ourselves, as we close the door, that for a sixpence we can escape a ducking. We have not fairly taken our seat, however, when we find that the coach is an old, wornout affair, and that the rain is pouring through the roof as if from a cullendar.

CITY MORALITY.--The police on Sunday made 18 arrests, as follows: Eight for drunkenness; five for rioting and assault and battery; four for begging, and one for arson. One was sent to the Penitentiary; three to the County Jail: four were recommitted for trial, and remainder were discharged.

I consider the Russio-Oriental affair as hopeless. I am far from sharing the Deaceful anticipations entertained by the British and French Cabinets. My grounds for alarm are the following: Prince GORTSCHAKOFF has sent the Russian General NIPPOKONTSCHINSKI to Chumla, on some errand connected with the ultimatum.

It is amusing to see how those sober people, who are such paragons at home, and, above all, so censorious concerning trifles, change their minds in such a place as this. What was sin there, seems to be transformed into an innocent amusement,--and they not only look on, but partake, and their consciences are not at all troubled.

The writ of habeas corpus in the Fugitive Slave Case was argued this morning before Judges THOMPSON and ALLISON. The Court was asked to remand the prisoner into the custody of his surety, to answer the offence before the Criminal Court.

Yesterday morning the first Commencement of the New York Free Academy came off before a large and fashionable audience, (notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather,) at Niblo's Garden. ERASTUS BENEDICT, Esq., President of the Board of Education, occupied the chair.

The negro man, says the Boonville Observer, belonging to H. FRANCE, of Heath's creek, Pettis County, Missouri, who murdered the wife of JOHN RAINS, living in the same neighborhood, was burned at the stake, at er near Georgetown, on the 13th instant.

It is not worth while to fight against fate,--to struggle against destiny. Men of the world like to see destiny manifested, however, before surrendering to it, and to know that it is the hand of fate which makes such marvellous moves.

By an arrival at Salem, we have Montevideo dates to the 5th, and Buenos Ayres to the 4th of June. Buenos Ayres was still besieged, and guerilla contests were of daily occurrence. in which many were wounded and killed, particularly among the outsiders.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Over the signature of the "President of the American and Foreign Christian Union," appears in the New-York DAILY TIMES of this day, (July 26,) in behalf of seventy-four Portuguese, just arrived from Madeira.

On Tuesday, July 19, a very destructive hail-storm occurred in this vicinity. The path of the storm appears to be about two miles wide, from north to south; and, as near as we can ascertain, commenced at JOHN Y. MANNING'S, on the west, and extends to Cayuga Lake, on the east.

The fugitive slave, BILL FISHER, was up again this morning before the Court of Quarter Sessions, and created considerable excitement. Last night, Marshal WYNKOOP surrendered him to the Court, on the writ of habeas corpus, which was issued on last Thursday or Friday, and he was handed over to the keeper of Moyamensing prison.

Likely to be bad work. What can you expect? All are playing at cross purposes. Our prince, ALBERT, took it into his head to take the measles,--just after we had got official notice published in the newspapers and placarded on the walls, that the Queen was "all ready" to visit our Exhibition.

THOMAS M. LOCKE, the venerable, President of the Baltimore Fire Department, died last night. The steamer Ohio, from Philadelphia for this port, was detained two hours on her passage last night, by the breaking of the lever pin. The engine was considerably injured, and the passengers were greatly alarmed, but no one was hurt.

The People's Wash and Bath House is one of the established institutions of the City. It deserves to be shown up as one of the curiosities of city philanthropy,--as one of the thousand forms that benevolence projects itself into, for the sake of the poor.

Rising betimes on a sunny Summer's morning is as rational, pleasant, and proper an act as lying abed on a wintry one. Wherefore, 5 o'clock A. M. saw our party astir, and all save one (who, ignominiously tarrying behind, preferred indulging in the slavish Chinese conventionality of shaving,) tracing the course of the little streamlet in the thicket, on bathing thoughts intent.

We have great respect for the butchers, as a body--great respect for the intelligent and sober portion of them, individually--and an attachment so strong, that we may properly call it an affection, for the wares they bring into market, after they have been dressed by our good friend the cook.

INQUEST ON THE LAST VICTIM OF THE GAVAZZI RIOTS.--An inquest was held at Montreal on the 17th instant, on the body of Michael Donelly, who died from injuries received at the GAVAZZI riots. The jurors could not unite upon one verdict, and therefore brought in two, one of which had eleven signatures and the other eight.

Circumstantial evidence is so strong against the Irishman, JENNINGS, arrested for the atrocious murder of Mrs. ESTHER BRADLEY, as to leave hardly a doubt of his guilt. Not only did the boots he had on when arrested, correspond with the tracks left around the house, but a knife found on his person had a point broken off which corresponded with a piece of a knife-blade found in the breast bone of the murdered woman.

On Tuesday, July 26, JOHN M. CAPE, only son of John M. Cape, aged 6 years, 6 months and 17 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his parents, No. 265 Broonie st., this day, July 27, at 2 o'clock P. M.

Could we set the fashion of diplomatic costumes for England, as readily as we do for our own representative corps, broad brims, and drab coats of the cut-a-way style would be the prescription. The latest dogma of the British Government is non-resistance.
SOUTHERN METHODIST CHURCH.--The eighth Annual Report of the Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Southern Methodist Church has appeared. We give the following synopsis of its contents.

THIEF ARRESTED.--Officers Boyce and Schneider, of the Third Ward, about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, arrested a German in North Second-street, near Graham-avenue, named Jacob Dunn, on suspicion of stealing a Buffalo robe, cushion, knife, and several other articles which he had in his bag on his shoulders.

EXTENSIVE ROBBERY OF MECHANICS' AND TRADERS' BANK.--During Monday night, the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank of Jersey City was broken open, and an amount of over $11,000 was taken from the safe--the key to which the robbers had in some manner obtained from the Cashier's residence.

FIRE AT WATERTOWN, N. Y.--On Saturday evening last, a fire broke out in the car manufactory, foundry, machine shop, , of HORACE W. WOODRUFF, Esq, and in a short time the whole establishment, covering nearly two acres of ground, was in ruins.

In the present state of European affairs, the following letters may be read with interest. Thirty years ago, Russia was at war with Turkey. JEFFERSON, when he wrote this letter, was 82 years of age, and JOHN ADAMS 90.

ATTEMPTED MURDER IN DEY-STREET.--On Monday night a shooting affray occurred between two Italian barbers, acquaintances, recently from Philadelphia, near the Dey-street House. It appears a dispute arose between them, when one of the party named PHILIP CORSO, slapped the other one, whose name is VICTOR RICH, in the face.

LETTER FROM DR. FRANKLIN.--The following letter from the philosopher FRANKLIN, has turned up among the papers of the Maine Historical Society, and the Portland Advertiser believes that it has never before been published.
The Michigan Central Railroad Company have paid $3,000 to the widow of Stephen D. Gray, of Wheelock, Vt., who was killed by a collision on that road a few months ago. No suit was instituted.

It is matter of historical recollection, that during the Revolutionary War, two British vessels were sunk near the City of New-York--one named the Hussar, in the East River, nearly opposite Stony Island, in about sixty feet water; and the other, the sloop Mercury, in the North River, six miles from the City.
The Boston Courier says: The State Temperance Committee of Maine have addressed interrogatories to the candidates for Governor of that State, relative to their opinion upon the Maine Liquor Law.

THE CELEBRATION AT PLYMOUTH.--Most extensive arrangements have been made by the citizens of the Old Colony, under the auspices of the Pilgrim Society, for the celebration of the Embarkation, on the 1st of August.

The Savannah Republican of 23d inst. contains an account of a thunderstorm on the 22d, during which the mansion of Isaac Minis, on Orleans-square, was struck by lightning, and a young lady of the family slightly injured. No other material damage was done.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA--Tuesday--First Board--150 Chester Valley Mining Company, 5; 5 Minehill Railroad, 72 1/2; $1,000 Susquehana Canal 6s, 67; $1,000 Susquehanna Canal 6s, 66 1/2 ; $3,000 Schuylkill Navigation 6s, '82, 83; $1,000 West Philadelphia Coupon 6s, 95 1/4.

THE ROTTEN-ROW OF UPPER INDIA.--MUSsoorie and Landour, situated in the lower range of the Himalaya mountains, form the favorite sanitarium of the upper part of India. The scenery is more beautiful than that of Simla; for Mussoorie and Landour command a view of Dehra Dhoon, which resembles (except that the Dheon is grander and more extensive) the plains of Italy, as seen from the ascent of Simplon.

San Francisco papers, received at the Treasury Department by the steamship Northern Light, announce that the Grand Jury have found a true bill of indictment against ex-Collector COLLIER, in which he is charged with misappropriating three hundred thousand dollars of funds belonging to the United States Treasury; and that probably a bill of a similar character will be found against another party for one hundred thousand.

Minister SOULE left here this afternoon. Hon. DAVID T. DISNEY, of Ohio; Gov. LANE, of Md ; and Prof. EATON, of the North Carolina Gold Mines, are in town. Col. PAINE, of Rochester, is here, relative, it is said, to the Bordeaux Consulship.

ATTEMPTED SUICIDE.--The somewhat notorious Mrs. ROBINSON, of Troy, appears to have a penchant for poisoning, so that even her duress has not overcome it, as is shown by her recent attempt to destroy herself, by a method somewhat similar to that in which it is alleged she "took off" LANNEGAN and the girl.

I sent you last night a sketch of the annual sermon to the Graduating Class, preached yesterday by Rev. JOHN LUDLOW, D. D., S. T. P. To-day I have to notice the Baccalaureate Address. Before doing so, however, it may be well to notice the rise and progress of the College, as it is not very extensively known.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I wish to call the attention of the Directors of the Crystal Palace to a matter alike affecting then own interests and the convenience of strangers. I refer to the difficulty of obtaining change at the ticket-office.

Beneath the twin peaks of the Delphian cliff, a bold rocky height connected with the chain of Parnassus, and near the still perennial waters of the Castalian spring, I attempt a description of the scenes through which I have passed in my excursion to this shrine of the Muses.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As a great deal has been said in regard to the short eastern passage of the Arabia, I have thought that a statement of facts would be interesting, (at least to those who have wagers;) and I am one that thinks, in all races against time, there should be, at least, a starting point; but the Arabia had none, but started, full speed, at 12:35 P. M.
By the steamship Texas, we have dates from the city of Mexico to the 16th instant. The papers are filled with discussions as to the Spanish protectorate, which is favored by the Government.

An individual who was cheated by a grocer out of a pound of sugar, by that quantity of sand being mixed with the material, put an advertisement in the paper, stating that if the rascal who cheated him did not make restitution by sending him seven pounds of good sugar, he would expose his rascality.

THE CURATIVE POWER OF MONEY.--An eminent surgeon from this city, says the Boston Transcript, was recently called to New-Hampshire, by the officers of a Railroad corporation, to make a professional examination of a number of individuals, who were injured by an accident upon a railroad last year, and who have put in high claims for damages.

COLLISION.--Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning, as loop loaded with brick, came in collision with one of the Montague Ferry boats, just as it was leaving the dock on the Brooklyn side. The ferry boat sustained but little damage; the sloop had her bow-sprit broken short off, and was split from the bows down to the cut-water. She was immediately towed into a ?? near the ferry, where she such few minutes after. .

At New-Hamburg, Dutchess Co. on Wednesday, July 27, THOMAS C. WILLIS, son of Edward Willis, in the 16th year of his age. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral on Thursday afternoon, from the residence of his father, No. 28 Laight-st., without further notice

LONGEVITY OF MUSICIANS.--The following list of musicians, with the age at which they died respectively, is well worthy of attention: Dr. Aldridge. 94 ; Dr. Ayrton, 74 ; Bartholemon, 74; Bird, 80; Dr. Burney, 88; Dr. Child, 90 ; Clementi, 80; Cervitto, 96; D. Corri, 81; Crosdill, 70;

THE CRYSTAL PALACE.-We learn that, in accordance with the suggestion of the TIMES, seats were yesterday introduced into the Crystal Palace. This addition to the comfort of visitorss cannot fail to be Kppreciated by the public. The receipts yesterday are reported ax follows:

Minister WALKER goes to New-York tomorrow, to arrange private business, preparatory to his departure for China, which is now likely to be about the middle of August. It is not determined, yet, how he will go. It has been proposed that Government make a requisition for a mail steamer for Mr. WALKER'S use, but I cannot learn that the project is seriously entertained.

The U. S. steamer Princeton, Capt. EAGLE, bearing the broad pennant of Commodore SHUBRICK, and the U. S. steamer Fulton, Capt. WATSON, arrived in our harbor this morning. The swift Fulton came in at 10, A. M., and the frigate at about 1, P. M. The Squadron left the Navy-Yard at Portsmouth, N. H., yesterday (Sunday), at 4, P.M.

INTERESTING CASE.--In the Toledo Republican, of the 14th inst., we find the following case, recently tried before the Court of Common Pleas in that city: Michigan Southern Railroad Company vs. The Owners of the Propeller Spoulding.--The jury returned a verdict yesterday afternoon, for the plaintiff, awarding damages to the amount of $2.28 85. This was a case of some importance.

It is not at all surprising that the Washington Union finds itself unable to appreciate the letters of our European Correspondent. We hardly looked for any lively demonstrations of satisfaction from that quarter. Any degree of familiarity with the contents shows how little the writer must have contemplated a favorable notice from the official organ;

THE EXILID ARCHBISHOP OF BOGOTA.-We are happy to learn that the illustrious Confessor, Archbishop MOSQUERA, has arrived safely in Paris, along with his brother and friends. His health however, was very poor, although the distinguished medical care that he now receives, and from which we hope much for him, gives encouragement that in a few weeks his case will mend.

Now for our excursion. What a difference between this lovely, pleasant July morning here, with the birds singing, the leaves waving, and the brooks babbling, and the same dull, dry, dusty morning in the city. If you are a sportsman, get your gun ready; if a botanist, put your tin case in your pocket; if neither,

I soon ascertained, as intimated in my last, that the lawyer was a great talker-great in quality as in quantity. Recovered from the mortification of soiled clothes and a dusty face, I immediately began to call out my new friend, and I found his responsiveness on a level with my wishes.

STEAMBOAT ACCIDENT.-The passengers by the steamboat Ohio, of the Baltimore and Philadelphia Line, who should have arrived here last evening about 7 o'clock, were detained more than two hours by the breaking of the pin which sustained one of the levers, just after the boat had passed Ford's Landing.
