The remarkably interesting exercises connected with the annual commencement of Yale, are attracting an unusually large number of visitors to this ancient seat of learning. The Hotels are already filled, and many are, of course, guests of friends in the city.

Nothing has transpired, of late, changing in the least the position of the Fishery question; and there is no reason to fear that the peace of the country will be disturbed by anything arising out of that subject of negotiation. It is, nevertheless, a true and an interesting fact that peace hangs upon a slender thread.

Our village has been visited by a destructive fire, which broke out out in A. B. RIDGWAY'S store about daylight yesterday morning. I have only time to mention the sufferers, viz: A. B. RIDGWAY, store, completely destroyed. Loss from $8,000 to $10,0000. Insured in Western Massachusetts for $5,000, and in the ?? (Hartford) for $1,000. JOSEPH TIBBITTS, dwelling destroyed. Loss not known. Furniture nearly all saved.

A telegraphic dispatch announces the death, at the Virginia Springs, of Rev. JUSTIN EDWARDS, D. D., of Andover, Mass., aged about 66 years. He has filled many responsible stations, and is widely known as the author of the able documents and manuals on Temperance and the Sabbath, and the comment on the New Testament.

SCHOOLS OF THE CHRISTIAN BROTHERS-DISTRIBUTION OF PRIZES TO THE PUPILS -This ceremony took place at the Tabernacle, Broadway, last night, and was accompanied by various recitations and numerous musical exercises, from the pupils. There was a large concourse of the Catholic public of New-York present, the great hall being quite filled with spectators.

The morning following our ascent of Parnassus we continued our adventure, and soon reached a height whence we had a view of the so-called Copais Lake. How in the world. in a land so destitute of water, a lake of the grand dimensions which Copais exhibits on the maps, could be found, had been a mystery to us; but what was our surprise, when,

As I sit in my window, looking out upon the noble Hudson, I cannot help feeling a sentiment of pity-or what very nearly approaches it-for the hundreds, who, slaves as they are to business, are unable to leave their offices and counting-rooms, in the hot, dusty City, and luxuriate here, amid the waving of trees and singing of birds. CASTLE GARDEN.--Benefit of Mrs. Skerrett. The Advocate--London Assurance. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Erin Our Home--Irish Assurance.

During the past two days we have had several very heavy showers, which have done immense good to the crops in the vicinity of the city. This morning a report prevailed that the rains had caused a freshet in the Schuylkill, causing much destruetion of property. It turned out, however, to be untrue.

THE OYSTER TRADE--A writter in the Monmouth Standard, in giving a history and statistics of the oyster trade in the vicinity of Keyport. says: "There are now engaged in the business about forty-five persons as planters, who employ some ninety hands eight months in the year, making about 135 persons employed in the business, independent of those engaged in the freighting business, who number about seventy-five--making, in all. 210.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of the 15th inst. I observed the following remarks, in relation to the New-York Exhibition building: "That the matter of iron construction, on a large scale, was and is entirely new in this country. No edifice entirely of iron yet existed in the United States."

At 11 o'clock the President of the Senate called the Court to order, and the roll was called by the Clerk of the Senate, and Chief Judge RUGGLES, four associate Judges, and twenty-one Senators answered to their names, as follows: President of the Senate--Lieut. Gov. CHURCH.

When the DAILY TIMES, immediately after the interview of SANTA ANNA with Gen. CANEDO, announced the project of an HispanoMexican alliance, the news was received with very general scepticism. The essential absurdity of such a league was certainly great enough to require a more than ordinary weight of evidence to render it credible.

GENERAL REMARKS. - Persia is generally considered the native country of the vine, though in our own land it is also found growing wild, in great abundance. The best grapes in the world are those of Shiraz and of Casvin; and from the Persian Gulf to the Caspian Sea-along the line ot mountains stretching therefrom-the best vine districts are situated.

How wonderful are the changes that have taken place in the appearance, the inhabitants, and even the scenery of Connecticut, within the last two centuries. Instead of the crowded cities, with their stately churches and houses, the clean, pebbled streets and smooth sidewalks, the well-planted fields, and rich orchards of fruit; the mixed population, derived from every country.

DEAR SIX: One of my earliest memories is of being carried in my father's arms, one Winter's morning, to the old grave-yard, to see an aged relative laid in her last resting place. Of death, then, I knew little or nothing; but I can never forget how the scene around impressed me. The dead weeds struggling up from the thick snow upon the mounds;

FIRE--About 1/2 o'clock last evening, a fire broke out in the front basement of MALDAS, TUTTLE BAILER'S Manufactory, corner of South Eight and First-streets. The firemen and police were early on the ground and succeeded in saving the establishment, with a loss of early about $500, fully insured Much credit is due officer MINOR, of the First Ward, for his activity in giving the alarm, saving valuable papers, $c.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: A gentleman over the signature of an *, in your paper of yesterday morning, undertakes to contradict the statement which the undersigned made in their card, entitled " An Appeal to the Christian Public," that appeared in the NEW-YORK TIMES and other papers, on Tuesday.

The Washington Republic in an article on the proposed removed of the Ind? of California to New-Mexico, says: "We do not feel warranted to pronounce an unqualified censure upon the policy of concentrating all the Indians whom we may have acquired as a charge open our territorial purchases;

The Alumni of the Theological Seminary gathered in large numbers, last evening, in response to a call issued by some of their number. The meeting organized by calling Rev. Dr. DEWITT to the Chair, and appointing Rev. E. S. PORTER, of Williamsburg, Secretary.

THE PSI UPSILON FRATERNITY.-The Boston Journal reports the proceedings of the annual meetingof this association, which was held last week, at Cambridge. The members met at Gore Hall, where a procession was formed, and escorted by the Germania Serenade Band, proceeded to Rev. Mr. NEWELL'S Church, to listen to an oration by EDWIN P. WHIPPLE, Esq.

TRADERS' BANK.--To-day, at 10 o'clock A. M., the girl, CATHERINE KENNEDAY, who was employed in the family of the Cashier at the time of the robbery, and was arrested on Wednesday, on suspicion of being connected with it, will be examined before Recorder CUTTER. She has engaged counsel to appear in her behalf at the examination.

The British Royal Mail steamship Asia arrived here late last evening. She left Liverpool on Saturday, the 16th, at about 1 P.M. THE WISCONSIN PINRIES.--The quantity of Pine Lumber manufactured in Wisconsin is very great. The Watertown Chronicle, having stated it at 95,000,000 feet, is thus corrected by a correspondent: "I see that you have published, under the head of "Our Pineries," an article making the amount of our pine lumber produced in the State 95,000,000, instead of which it is 211,000,000, which amount includes sawed lumber only.

A number of the admirers and friends of Mr. SOULE, from the different sections of the Union, determined some days since, to manifest their high regard for his brilliant talents by a farewell serenade upon tile eve of his departure for Spain.

Our Texas files of papers to the 16th have been received. The general features of the news have already been published under our telegraphic head. Politics appear to be the all-absorbing topic. The Galveston Journal says:

CASTLE GARDEN.--On Wednesday night, BELLINI'S opera of "Norma" was repeated for (we believe) the last time. The extremely unfavorable state of the elements affected the attendance. There were more empty seats than we have before seen this season.

A branch of the same family, from which our Commissioner of Streets was chosen, settled, at an early period, we are disposed to think, in New-Orleans, where the head has secured a similarly influential position with respect to the thoroughfares.

Engineer COPELAND, of New-York, declines the position of Engineer-in-Chief of the Navy, because he cannot drop his present business engagements. The steamer Princeton, on her trip from Portsmouth to Portland, made seven miles an hour.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of this morning there is a statement that a building corner of Centre and Duane-streets, erected in 1848, is not only the first building erected entirely of cast iron in this country, but the first in any part of the world.

TEACHERS' CONVENTION.--The first meeting of the Pennsylvania State Teachers' Association will be held in Pittsburg, August 5. At this meeting reports will be presented on Normal Schools, Teacher's Institutes, the uses and abuses of Text Books, and other subjects of deep interest.

For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. OPENING OF THE PRESCOTT HOUSE-BANQUET TO THE PRESS.-Last night a splendid banquet was given by Captain DEGROOT, the proprietor of the Prescott House, the magnificent Hotel, Just opened at the corner of Spring-street and Broadway, to the members of the New-York Press.

A MELANCHOLY TALE.-The Chicago Tribune informs us that five unknown persons, who were buried as such, killed by the collision, last April, at the junction of the Illinois Central and Northern Indiana Roads, were a family by the name of KELLOGG, moving from the State of New-York to Minnesota.

PROBABLY ANOTHER MURDER.--The Transcript, of yesterday afternoon, states that the body of a female named MARY ANN SMITH, recently deceased, was exhumed at West Troy yesterday, and that Dr. SWINBURNE, after making a post mortem examination, found arsenic in the stomach.

The European news, by the Asia, published in this morning's TIMES, is important. While the English and French Governments are straining every point to escape the contingency of war, Russia has ordered solemn religious service to be celebrated in the camp, at Warsaw, "to induce God to bless the arms of the ' Orthodox Faith' against the infidel.
The income from the indirect taxes and revenues during the first half-year of 1853, exceeds by 22,000,000f. the income of the corresponding half-year in 1852.

Burton, of Orange, Ohio-For improvement in plows. F. B. Hunt, of West field, Ind -For improvement in mills for grinding apples and other substances.

A letter from Key West, states that since January 1, a larger amount of property has been wrecked in this district than in any previous year. The number of total wrecks, vessels ashore and saved, and arrivals; in distress up to the last reported to-day, is 41.

The bill authorizing the formation of a steam-packet company, to connect Genoa with New-York and Buenos Ayres, has at length passed the Sardinia Chambers. It had been received in the Chambers with little or no opposition. The terms of the arrangement met with general approval.

DEAR SIR: I am of opinion that its utterly impossible for six or eight, or any number of persons, seated around a table, to produce an electrical current. Moreover, I am confident that if by any adequate means an electrical current were created, however forcible, it could not be productive of table turning.

The Commencement Exercises of UNION COLLEGE have just closed, having occupied the last four days. They began on Sunday evening, with an Address before the Theological Society, by Rev. R. S. STORRS, Jr., of Brooklyn. His subject was Romanism," which he took up, firstly, " In its essential character."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A correspondent signing himself "Fair Play,"has stated in the New-York Tribune, that" it was our fault that the Crystal Palace was not finished and opened on the 1st of May."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The next morning after our arrival at Orange Court-House, the day opened with decided promise. The tokens of an excellent breakfast, prepared with skill, and served with those minute attentions which the best Virginia servants so well understand, were speedily interpreted as good omens for the twentyfour hours that were to measure their mountain circuit over us.

During the past few days, the Exhibitions of the Public Grammar Schools in Boston have been given, and the Boston papers speak highly of the results. During the exhibitions on Tuesday, Lord ELLESMERE was present, and the Boston people rejoice and are exceeding glad that they have enjoyed the opportunity of showing to his Lordship what the Free School System can produce.

Big Turtle, a chief of the Wyandot Indians, who removed from Ohio to the Indian Territory, writes concerning their present condition as follows: " Our improvement, when appraised, amounted to upwards of $127,000, which was paid us in the Autumn of 1845.

The following correspondence, between Judge E. LEWIS, of Lancaster, Pa., and Mr. WISE, the celebrated Aeronaut, relative to the practicability of crossing the ocean in a balloon, we take from the Missouri Democrat, believing that it may be of interest to some of our readers.

THE MYSTERIOUS BOAT.--We published about a week since the fact of a mysterious looking boat having been found adrift in the East River, near the foot of Seventy-ninth-street. She was a four oared boat, but only two oars were then in her. She was besmeared with blood, as we have already stated.

The last advices from Persia state that a severe earthquake has levelled Shiraz with the ground, and 15,000 persons perished in the ruins. The earthquake took place on the 3d of May last.

In addition to the news already published, we give the following from a file of the Santa Fe Gazette to the 11th ult. With the exception of a small guard under the command of a sergeant, there are no troops at Mesilla. The silver mines in the vicinity are apparently inexhaustible, and the ore is of great richness.

The weather has been quite changeable during the past twenty-four hours. Last night it was quite cool, and thick clothing was not at all uncomfortable. This morning it was quite close and sultry, and, what was most remarkable, four thermometers, within half a block of each other, materially varied.

The second communication, which the minister of NICHOLAS has addressed to the diplomatic agents of Russia, deserves maturer examination than we have yet given it. It attempts, by a line of argument, that would not have disgraced any of the sophistical cotemporaries of PLATO, or SOCRATES, to justify the outrageous occupation of the Danubian Provinces of Turkey, by his "August Master."

HORRIBLE MURDER IN CANADA.--A few days ago, a horrible murder was committed in Kamouraska, L. C. The facts are narrated as follows, in a letter from Kamouraska, dated 3d inst., published in the Journal de Quebec, of Tuesday last: "The other day an individual by the name of PELLETIER, provoked a quarrel with his father-inlaw, LEBEL.

People, when they buy a dish at a china-shop, little imagine what a chain of events has led to the production of that piece of common ware in its present shape. House-keepers have probably never heard of LUCA DELLA ROBBIA, PALISSY, BOTTCHER, or WEDGEWOOD.

THE EXCURSION TO PLYMOUTH.--Last evening, a meeting of the New England Society was to have been held at the Astor House, to take further measures in regard to arranging for their proposed trip to Plymouth, Mass , to participa o in the exercises in commemoration of the embarkation of the Pilgrim Fathers from Delft Haven.

MEETING OF THE SYNOD.--The Synod of the Presbyterian Church of Canada, in connection with the Church of Scotland, which has been in session for the past week, brought its sittings to a close on Tuesday. A large number of ministers and elders were in attendance, and the business transacted indicated that the Synod itself, and the Church it represents, are in a most prosperous condition.

The last week has been devoted to charity and sympathy. The "hat passed round," with the prestige of authority, for the poor sufferers in Galicia, and the collections have been considerable, to send from the purses of the crushed serfs of Cuba to alleviate the wants of their countrymen in another land-which is asked for more after the manner of demand on the highway, than by proper appeal to the sympathy of the community.

TOMB OF BENJAMIN FRANKLIN.--Under this caption, we lately published a paragraph calling attention to a well-founded complaint made by the New-York Evangelist, of the obscure and inaccessible position which the grave of the great FRANKLIN now occupies. We find that it has attracted more general attention in all directions than we had expected, and it has afforded us much gratification to notice the unanimity with which the newspaper press has taken up the subject.

The Exercises of the Annual Commencement of Dartmouth College occupy the attention of this vicinity of the country during the present week. They are invested this year with an extraordinary degree of interest, in consequence of the appointment of a Eulogy upon Mr. WEBSTER, pronounced by RUFUS CHOATE, whose name is now almost universally recognized, since Mr. WEBSTER'S death, as that of the most eloquent American living.

We retract everything we have said against our navy in the Levant. Capt. INGRAHAM has shown himself a man of pluck, just when it was most needed. The previous servility at Constantinople is wiped away by the manliness of his procedure at Smyrna. We are assured the Administration will back up that or any similar assertion of American rights.

After some preliminary business, the following papers were announced to be read to-day, and the reading began. The recent discovery of the deep sea bank, on the Eastern side of the Gulf stream, off the Coasts of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, by Lients. Commanding CRAVEN and MAFFETT, U. S. N., presented by Professor BACHE. On the resistance of vertical plates on tubular bridges, by HERMAN HAUPT, Superintendent of the Pennsylvania Railroad, Philadelphia.

The Supreme Court has been engaged, during the past few days, in hearing the arguments of counsel in different Railroad cases, asking for injunctions to restrain corporations from subscribing to Railroad Stock. This appears to be a growing evil. Railroad schemes are projected by designing men, which are calculated to benefit nobody but themselves, and the municipal corporations in different parts of the State are called upon to subscribe large sums of money.

CANARSIE RIOTERS.--Seven of the Canarsie rioters were arraigned on eleven indictments for assault and battery, on two for robbery, and one for riot and tumult, to which they severally pleaded not guilty. Their names are George Higgins, Patrick Costello, Thomas Coggins, John Farrell, Henry Collins, Michael Tally alias Michael Tully, Jacob Siper alias Jacob Seip, and Nathan Swizer alias Nathan Sweitzer.

The Palace was to-day well attended. The fineness of the weather, after the very unpropitious days we have had lately, induced large numbers to attend. The Sixth-avenue cars and omnibuses received considerable accession to their usual numbers. Elderly gentlemen from the country, looking out of the windows, and devouring elastic peaches.

The statement of the defalcation of WM. C. ZANTZINGER, late Disbursing Agent of the State Department, undoubtedly has its origin in malice. His accounts had not yet been settled, illness having prevented his making them up. The difficulty yesterday would all have been avoided had the Department given him notice that his check for $10,000 had not been honored.

THOMAS E. MASSEY, of Alabama, has been appointed Secretary of Legation to Chili. The rumored defalcation of Mr. ZANTZINGER is generally discredited; but, if true, Government is unlikely to lose anything.

The United States Mail steamship Georgia, Capt. McGOWAN, arrived at this port yesterday, from Aspinwall July 20, at 6 o'clock P. M.--bringing the mails and treasure carried to the Isthmus by the San Francisco steamer of the 1st inst. The dates from California were anticipated by the arrival of the Northern Light.

RHENISH-BELGIAN GALLERY.--A collection of paintings, by living German and Belgian artists, was opened yesterday at 663 Broadway. The pictures are exhibited in the rooms of the National Academy of Design, and make but a poor show. The advertisement informs us that it is" the largest collection of modern paintings ever exhibited in America."

Having, since my arrival in New-York, engaged the services of J. C. BOOTH, Draper and Tail??r, No. 486 Broadway, I am conscientiously prepared to recommend him to all gentlemen who, like myself, are strangers in the City, and in search of a handsome and fashionable outfit.

THE BANK CASE.--Yesterday, the examination of witnesses relative to the late robbery of the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank, was held by Recorder CUTTER, in the office of Messrs. GILCHRIST SCUDDER. J. W. SCUDDER, attorney for the Bank, appeared for the Bank; R. McCLELLAN, Jr. for the prisoner, CATHARINE KENNEDY, arrested on suspicion of being accessory to the robbery.
DARTMOUTH COLLEGE.--At the Commencement, on Thursday, the following honorary degrees were conferred: D. D.--J. W. Putnam, David Thurston, Winthrop, Me.; Robert Brydon, of the Church of Scotland.
July 28, at his residence in New Rochelle, WILLIAM MEAD, aged 80 years. The funeral will take place on Saturday morning, July 30, at 12 o'clock A train will leave the station at Ga?? at 8:45 A. M.

DEATH OF AN ESTEEMED MERCHANT OF BOSTON.--JOSEPH TILDEN, one of the oldest and most esteemed merchants of Boston, died on Thursday morning last. He was seventy-four years of age, and had done much towards establishing the enviable reputation which Boston merchants enjoy.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday last are received. There were 43 deaths by Yellow Fever at New-Orleans, on the 23d inst. The telegraphic announcement of the death of Ex-Gov. PAINE, of Vermont, was made on the authority of a letter from P. GREELY, of Boston.

THE RAPPERS OUTDONE.--Some of the records of the times in which flourished the credulous and wonder-loving COTTON MATHER, show forth strange and queer accounts of the freaks of "ye unseen spirits." Here is one, copied by the Boston Chronicle from an old journal of a schoolmaster, who whilom resided in "ye ancient town of Ipswich."

THE MANAGEMENT OF THE FINGER NAILS.--According to European fashion, they should be of an oval figure, transparent, without specks or ridges of any kind; the semilunar fold, or white half circle, should be fully developed, and the pellicle or cuticle which forms the configuration around the root of the nails thin and well defined; and, when properly arranged, should represent as nearly as possible, the shape of a half-filbert.

FOUND DROWNED.--The body of a German, apparently about fifty years of age, was found floating in Newtown Creek, near the Maspeth road, on Wednesday evening. Deceased was very respectably dressed, having on a black broadcloth coat, black pants, old-fashioned blue vest, new fine boots, and a German linen shirt, with a false bosom; on the bottom of the shirt were the initials "L. W." A yellow cloth handkerchief was found in his coat pocket.

CASTLE GARDEN.--"La Favorita" attracted a moderate audience last evening. We are disposed to think that many of the "regulars" postponed their attendance in view of the attraction for to-morrow night. "Don Giovanni" is undoubtedly a greater favorite with the musical public than "La Favorita," notwithstanding its portentous name.

Our readers will not fail to peruse, with interest and admiration, the Eulogy of Mr. WEBSTER, pronounced at Dartmouth College, on Wednesday last, by RUFUS CHOATE. It is one of the loftiest and most eloquent tributes ever paid to one commanding character by the genius of another.

The one hundred and fifty-third commencement of Yale College marks an important epoch in its history. The resignation of Professor SILLIMAN, who for over half a century has been one of her most valuable professors, will be deeply felt by the institution; and long will it be ere the place left vacant will be filled by one as well fitted to perform the numerous and arduous duties pertaining to it.

QUOITING--ANNUAL MATCH BETWEEN THE MONTREAL UNION AND CALEDONIAN CLUBS.--The Caledonian Club, nothing daunted by their defeat last year, which they might have expected from their more experienced rivals, accepted the challenge of the Union recently given them for ten players a side.

Within a month, charges more or less serious have been preferred against sundry of our New-York policemen. The charges were not otherwise than publicly made. The Commissioners of Police not otherwise than publicly tried them, and it is very well known that the decisions have been rendered.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT SARATOGA.-There was an extensive fire at Saratoga on Wednesday night. The old Centre House was burned. Messrs. HOOD TOBEY, jewelers, ran a very narrow risk, but they finally saved most of their stock. Messrs. WISE, YOUNG, RICHMOND TIFFANY, and YOUNG ELLIS, are all burned out.

VALUABLE MEMORIALS.--We saw yesterday four Franklin Medals, of different dates, which were gained many years since by CHARLES SPRAGUE, Esq., the poet, of this city, and his brothers, at the Brimmer School, or the others which have previously stood upon its site.

The country is, at this time, reaping some of the disadvantages which result from the want of a Navy worthy to bear the flag of a great and prosperous Republic. Such we have not. I certainly intend no reflection on the gallant little band who have so often maintained the national honor against a more powerful foe.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. Your Correspondent, who bears the signature of an *, has replied in your columns of yesterday to our strictures upon his first communication. He avows himself "a native of Portugal." Perhaps lie is " a distinguished personage ;" if so, we should have been pleased to see his name attached to his note.

From the Washington Union. An editor is not entirely without sources of innocent amusement, even in the midst of his most laborious vocation. We had an illustration of this remark yesterday in a little incident which is worth recording. We indulged in a few remarks, some days since, upon one of the European letters addressed to the NEW-YORK TIMES, as we then supposed, by KOSSUTH.

At Fort Lee, N. J., July 30, MARY ALICE, only daughter of William C. and Cornelia H. B. Richards, in the 2d year of her age. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral services at their residence, No. 196 East 18th-st., this morning, at 9 o'clock.

It is gratifying to find ourselves the source of "innocent amusement" to the Washington Union, whose amusements are occasionally otherwise. The organ proposes to acquit itself of its suspected sympathies for Russia, by producing a diplomatic note from M. BODISCO, the Russian Minister, discontinuing the paper.

We find in the Boston Post a matter of intelligence, which, taken in connection with the present belligerent aspect of affairs in Europe, is of no mean importance: Bloodthirsty Mars will this day be darkened--literally cast into the shade--by her whose mild rays are said to engender a love for, and a strong inclination to be upon the most amicable terms with, a large, and certainly the most desirable portion of the human family.

The Hartford Times speaking of the proposed Monument to General DAVID WOOSTER, says: " The Legislature of this State at its last session voted the sum of 1,500 towards the erection of a monument to the memory of General DAVID WOOSTER, who was killed in battle with the British, at Ridgefield, in 1777. The Masonic fraternity have contributed $1,500 more, and the monument has now been contracted for at a cost of $3,000.

WILLIAMSBURG SCHOOL VACATION AND STATISTICS.--The City Schools of Williamsbury were all closed on Friday last, for the annual Summer vacation of four weeks, to reassemble on the 29th inst. The schoo's were dismissed by the teachers of the various Wards with appropriate ceremonies.

The city is crowded in every part. The numbers of people daily arriving from abroad are extraordinary. The Hotels are full, and private houses are beginning to be invaded. Some portion of this pressure is no doubt to be attributed to the meeting of the Scientific body whose annual session commences here to-day. The arrivals of scientific men from the eastward are very large, and the attendance at the Convention will undoubtedly be very general.

Although the attendance on Saturday was not quite equal to the two preceding days, there were perhaps as many strangers present as on any previous occasion. Visitors are beginning to flock hitherwards from all parts of the Union. Already the hotels are experiencing a satisfactory increase of business. At the Crystal Palace the number of happy faces who are intent of seeing and being pleased with everything is daily on the increase.

LAYING THE CORNER-STONE OF A NEW EPISCOPAL CHURCH.--On Saturday evening, the corner-stone of a new Protestant Epise 'pal Church was laid on the north side of Eighteenth-s reeth, Fifth-avenue. The particulars in connection with the history of its erection will be found in the address of the officiating clergyman. A large number of persons, the majority of whom were ladies, were present to witness the ceremony.

The weather has been excessively hot and sultry to-day, which was relieved, in some measure, by the heavy thunder-storm about 6 o'clock this afternoon. The New-York Light Guard arrived here this morning, via the Norwich and Worcester road. They were received at the depot by the Washington Artillery, and escorted to the Revere House.

The young lady who had lost here purse, called at a house near Union-square one day last week. She had just come, as usual, from NEW-Haven, and wished to see Mr.--on some important law business of her mother's. He was not at home, and she then desired to consult Mrs. _____.

The Albany Atlas, some days since, contained an Address, signed by seventy-two of the eighty-six Democratic members of the Legislature, to their several constituencies. It was a very droll affair, in every respect. It was signed by men who had taken both sides of almost every question that had been discussed during the session, and it asserted some very much disputed points.

The ship Mary Crocker, of Portland, bound from New-York to St. Stephens, N. B., went ashore in a thick fog on the north side of Niantic, on the afternoon of the 26th, and remained there at noon on the 27th inst. She had not bilged, and hopes are entertained of getting her off at high water. A vessel and men have been sent to her assistance from this place.

ANOTHER MURDER.--The editors of the Plaindealer have received a communication, dated July 28, which gives the following account of a cold-blooded murder in Carlisle: Last evening, a most horrible murder was perpetrated in Carlisle, of this County. It seems that some difficulty existed between a man by the name of ABRAM FULMER and two young men named BARBER and LOVELL.

ARREST OF AN EXTENSIVE SWINDLER.--CAUTION TO LIVERY-STABLE KEEPERS AND OTHERS.--We have heretofore noticed the arrest, on Tuesday last, of JAMES W. STONE, Commission Merchant in Water-street, New-York, by officer HIGGINS, of the Chief's office, Brooklyn, on a charge of obtaining a horse, wagon and harness, under false pretences, from PETER HENDRICKSON, livery-stable keeper in Fulton-avenue, Brooklyn.

Secretary M'CLELLAND has returned and resumed the duties of his office. Another new Democratic paper is starting here--$50,000 have been raised, and Mr. J. BACON, the veteran editor and essayist, is to edit it. It is said it will start in December next, and is owned by New-York and Northwestern members of Congress and politicians.
The British war steamer Medea, from Halifax, July 28, arrived at this port this morning. It is supposed she brings dispatches in regard to the Fishery question.

An interesting paper was read yesterday, in the Section of Geology and Mineralogy, by Dr. J. A. WARDER, of Cincinnati, on the subject of the Geology of the Arkansas River. The paper was very long, but was heard with interest. The following is an abstract of its leading points: GEOLOICAL RECONNOISSANCE OF THE ARKNSAS RIVER. RY DR. J. A. WARDER, OF CINCINNATI.

For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--English Opera Company. CASTLE GARDEN.-Madame soutag in Italian Opera. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Ireland as it is--Custom of the Country. NATIONAL THEATRE -- Uncle Tom'e Cabin.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your leader to-day on "The Austrian Outrage," with regard to "COSTA," you appear to be at fault for a fac simile.

A vessel of one hundred and eighty tons sailed from Delft Haven, near the town of Leyden, in Holland, two hundred and thirty three years ago, yesterday. Men, women, and children, there were one hundred souls on board that little vessel, when, about six weeks later, she left the shores of Plymouth, in England, whither she had put back for repairs, and gave her frail timbers to the keeping of God in the Atlantic.

CONSOLIDATION.--In the Common Council last evening, the following-named persons were appointed to carry the Consolidation Act into effect: DAVID LINDSEY, E HOPKINS, DOREMUS STRONG, JOHN LINDSKEY, L. T. COLES.

THE CONSOLIDATIONS BILL.--At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, held last evening, a communication was received from the Ma??or, enclosing an act passed at the late session of the State Legislature, for the Consolidation of, under one municipal government, the cities of Brooklyn and Williamsburg, and town of Bushwick.

The Navy Department has a letter from Commodore NEWTON, at Pensacola, dated 23d, three days after he is reported to have died. Mr. CRAMPTON went to the Springs with Mr. MARCY, by invitation of the latter. Each took a Secretary with him.

The Washington Republic states that a man named William McDonnell was suffocated while engaged in exploring the wreck of the steamer Erie, above Silver Creek, on Wednesday last. This was his first attempt at diving, but, being confident of success, he was engaged by the party having the wreck in charge, and made one descent without difficulty.

LATTER DAY DEVELOPMENTS.--In these latter days, when certain of our female friends exhibit potent desire to appropriate the mental pantaloons, it is refreshing, and in no small degree comforting, to the toil worn male biped, to learn that there is here and there a stray rib equally desirous of appropriating his overalls and the laurels appertaining to superior physical exertions.
St. John (N. B.) papers of 30th ult., state that fires were raging in the woods near Shediac, and had already destroyed a large quantity of valueable timber.

BEVERLY TUCKER--we confess that we are not sufficiently acquainted with Mr. TUCKER'S antecedents. positively to affirm of him a Col., an Esq., or an Hon.;--BEVERLY TUCKER has issued "The prospectus of the Washington Sentinel"

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In reading "R. C. Mc J's" article in yesterday's paper, concerning the means of rescue at Niagara, it seems to me that he forgets several important considerations.

CASTLE GARDEN.--The repetition of "L'Elisir d'Amore" was not so well attended last night as might have been desirable. A severe storm interfered with the pleasure-folks, determining a good many to sacrifice their tickets rather than face it.

The Machine Arcade is beginning to assume form. The two horizontal engines are on their beds, and one of their cylinders in place. The steam generating apparatus will furnish 120 horse power for constant driving purposes. An immense shearing machine for cutting iron plates, after the patent of D. DICKS' Anti-friction Press, is already set up; also an anti-friction punch for boiler plates.

The weather to-day has again been oppressively warm, the thermometer at 2 o'clock being at 93[degrees]. About 3 o'clock we had a refreshing shower. There was a good fall of rain, but no fall in the thermometer.

The Director of the Mint gives notice that from and after the 15th day of August next, payments for silver purchased for the Mint at Philadelphia, and at the Branch Mint, New-Orleans, will be made three-fourths in silver coin of new emission, and one-fourth in gold.

If there is one place ?? the face of the earth where Nature reigns triumphant, it is surely here. A perpetual Summer smile seems secreted in this green-belted Lake, and each sighing zephyr, or sparkling sunbeam, breaks into joyousness When I think of all I have lost in time and poetry elsewhere, I am disposed to be savage at the scanty residue that devolves to this most beautiful of all beautiful resorts.

I was sitting in my corner to-night, feeling particularly lonely, surrounded by a multitude whom I knew not and who knew not me, and more than all, who did not care, when I was accosted by a funny little red faced man, who took his chair and seated himself by my side sans ceremonie, and began immediately to entertain me after this wise:

Mr. GEORGE SAUNDERS has been appointed Consul to London. Good again for Young America. The star of the tribe is in the ascendant. Mr. DANIELS to Turin, Mr. SAUNDERS to London; the office of journalistic oracle removed from the fogy Union; the uprise of Mr. TUCKER'S new paper; these symptoms are all cheering, if not quite decided enough to turn the head of that sorely ill-used and neglected youngster.

New-Orleans papers on Monday and Tuesday last are received. They contain dates from the City of Mexico to the 16th July. The Mexican papers were bitterly opposing the project of a Spanish Protectorate, and all return, whether partial or complete, to the Spanish yoke.

Mr. MACAULAY appeals to be in demand in the literary as well as political market. Two publishers, (one of them Messrs. LONGMAN Co.,) announce editions of his speeches, culled specially from HANSARD; and carefully revised, with a view of their circulation in a new shape.

HONOR TO WHOM HONOR IS DUE.--In our foreign news of Friday, 29th, in giving the account of the gallant conduct of the captain of the United States corvette St. Louis, at Smyrna, in giving the lie to the captain of the Austrian ship-of-war Hussar, on his own deck, we were mistaken in the name. We spoke of him as Capt. STRINGHAM.

Interesting to Owners of Building--Contractors, Laborers, Material--Men, and Others. OPINION?? OF JUDGE THOMPSON, IN RELATION TO THE MECHANICS' LIEN LAW.--MARINE COURT.--Keenan vs Waller and Cunningham--The material facts in this case were, that on the 22d day of March, 1853, the defendant, Cunningham, agreed to erect two buildines for the defendant, Waller, agreeable to certain drawings and specifications, and to complete the same, on or before the twent??eth day of May, succeeding.

POLICE.--Yesterday there were 20 cases before the Recorder. Sixteen of the number were punished by fine or imprisonment for drunkenness, or disorderly conduct on the Sabbath, and four for attempting to rescue one of the sixteen from the hands of the officers. The places where liquor is sold were very generally in operation on Sunday.
On the scroll of American names there are many eminent for valor, goodness, and intellect. But there is one preeminent. It stands before all others. It is installed in the place of highest honor.

The Boston Traveller of Friday last, speaking of solar phenomena, says: This morning the disc of the sun presented a veined appearance all over. Near the edge of its right upper quadrant was perceptible a very large aud brilliant facula, or light streak, lying almost parallel with the edge.

The Charleston Standard of the 27th inst. gives the following account of the burning of the ship Galena:--"The ship Galena, of New-York, Lovett master, 11 days from New-Orleans, for Havre, with about 2,100 bales of cotton on board, was struck by lightning near the mizzenmast, on the 23d inst., near Abaco, one of the Bahama Islands.
The Tennessee Eagle, speaking of Major Donelson, says, it is said he is about to start a new national organ at Nashville, Democratic in politics,but that will not favor the present Administration.

A good deal of excitement has been recently created in this vicinity by the incidents connected with the action of the Supreme Court on an application for divorce. The petitioner was Mrs. ADELINE LANGDON, wife of JOHN B. LANGDON, whose harsh and cruel treatment of her has been for some time a matter of public notoriety.
Our Washington correspondent, S., is right in supposing the dispatch of Thursday night, relative to a rumored defalcation, was improperly attributed to him, by accident.

To the Editor of this New-York Daily Times: There have been published in the TIMES a Number of interesting, and so far as I have seen, faithful communications, descriptive of the condition of the lower orders of society in this city. This is well.

THE LATE GOV. PAYNE.--The Austin (Texas) American of the 11th inst., after mentioning the death of Ex-Governor PAYNE of Northfield, Vt., on the 6th, adds: "It may be a pleasure to his friends to know that Gov. PAYNE received every kindness and attention the citizens of Waco and the officers of the adjacent military post could bestow.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The intelligence about the gross outrage on the law of nations, and the rights of humanity, which the Austrian Consul at Smyrna (VECK-BECKER) dared treacherously to commit in capturing the Hungarian refugee, Captain KOSZTA, and the subsequent affray, in which an Austrian marine officer (the son of a general) lost his life, has been confirmed.

Hon. ROBT. J. WALKER'S departure for China seems to be still involved in doubt. We sincerely trust we are not to understand our Washington correspondent as intimating, in his letter published yesterday, the remotest probability that Mr. W. may decline altogether to fulfil the mission he so recently accepted. Still, we fear it may be so.

The Milwaukee Sentinel of Saturday announces the gratifying intelligence that the Directors of the Milwaukee and Mississippi Railroad Company at a special meeting held on Friday, and by a unanimous vote of the Board, closed the contract for the completion of their road to the Mississippi at $25,000 per mile, thoroughly equipped.

TERRIBLE DEATH.--EDMOND EMMONS, of Ridgeville, Loraine Co., was bitten by a mad dog, his own, in the month of April. Last Friday evening he was taken sick about 4 P. M., when his hand became inflamed, and pained him much.

We have had another hot and sultry day the thermometer varying from 90[degrees] to 93[degrees], driving a number of our folks down to Cape May. WILLIAM B. REED, our energetic Attorney General, took the initiatory steps this morning to bring our Quarantine officers to their senses.

The New-York State Teachers' Convention convened in this city this P. M., Professor DAVIS, LL. D., the President, in the chair. After some preliminary proceedings, and the appointment of a business Committee, a discussion arose upon the School Law. A lecture was then read by Mr OGDEN, of Binghamton.

The Philadelphia Bulletin discusses, with phrase of edifying gravity, certain of our remarks upon the odds of a war with Austria. Premising that we do not regard the event as in the least degree probable, we cordially assent to the Bulletin's statement of the case, and even wish it more cogent and striking. The horrors of war, regarded from the elevated outlooks of humanity, simply, cannot be exaggerated.

The story runs--we read it once when we were young, in a yellow-covered book, and thought it an excellent story then-the story runs that a young gentleman, of marvellous good luck, was possessed, amongst a variety of pretty and useful things, such as wishing-caps and such like, of a magical purse, that no matter how often it became exhausted was always found to be replenished on the next occasion on which it was required.

The Evening News is the title of a new daily paper, the prospectus of which is issued by Mr DANIEL E. GAVIT. It will be issued at Jersey City. Independent upon politics and social questions, it will devote itself to the verification of is title, by furnishing the latest intelligence, local and general, with such editorial comment as the topic suggests.

Mr. PRESIDENT: You bid me speak for the Senate. But I cannot forget that there is another voice here. of classical eloquence, which might more fitly render this service. As one of the humblest members of that body, and associated with the public Councils for a brief period only, I should prefer that my distinguished colleague, whose fame is linked with a political life, should speak for it.

CASTLE GARDEN.--To-night DONIZETTI'S Opera of "Lucrezia Borgia," with STEFFANONI as the Borgia, and other prominent members of the troupe in the subsidiary parts.

We learn that the Mexican Ocean Mail and Inland Company had just got their express route from Vera Cruz to Acapulco thoroughly arranged, and were about to begin running. We have received files of our Mexican exchanges to the 16th from the city of Mexico, and of the 22d from Vera Cruz. The news is of little interest.

Returning to our mountain hotel, (with sufficient trout and troutlings to warrant each unit of the party dogmatizing on matters piscatorial for evermore,) a goodly supper, and exciting stories await us.

FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE NEW-HAVEN RAIL ROAD.--An old deaf and dumb man, named HOUGH, a resident of Meriden, aged 70, was killed a little above that station on the New-Haven Railroad, at 1 o'clock, A. M., yesterday, by the Express train from Boston to New-York.

The bark Le Cocq arrived here to-day, with Rio Janeiro dates of 22d of June. She left in port barks Catharine Augusta, waiting orders; Canton, to sail next day for Australia; Martha Black, waiting orders; Francis and Louisa, to load soon. All the above are New-York vessels, and ship Ellerslie, of Philadelphia.

The Association has received invitations for the meeting of next year from the cities of Buffalo Washington, Providence, and the town of Nantucket. By a vote taken this morning, at the general session, the question is to be decided on Monday, at which time the Association will also proceed to the election of Officers for the ensuing year.

A correspondent forwards us the following complaint concerning the arrangements at this establishment. We give it insertion, without at all anticipating any result from so doing. The conveniences, even the courtesies, of a place of amusement, are determined by the number who frequent it.

An invitation front the citizens to attend a party to-night, at the American Hotel, was accepted. Washington was fixed upon for the next meeting in May, 1854. Professor DANA, of New-Haven, was elected President ; Professor LOVERING, Permanent Secretary : J. L. SMITH, General Secretary ; Dr. ELWYN, Treasurer ; Drs. HELDERMAN, LEIDY, and LECONTE, Auditing Committee.

It is only twenty-five feet by sixty, but that is large enough for our purpose. It is our oasis in this brown, dusty, dirty City. The business of the day rolls up to its edge in waves on every side, but they never submerge it.

We arrived in the town of Plymouth,--ground made classic by intimate association with the trials and triumphs of the Pilgrim Fathers,--this evening, by the Old Colony line from Boston, in company with the New-York Light Guards and a host of visitors, to witness the interesting ceremonies to-morrow, in commemoration of the Pilgrims' embarkation at Delft Haven on August 1, 1620.

Our City Comptroller finds the key of the strong-box useful for other purposes than the exclusion of Aldermanic paws from the deposits. Let us be grateful for every enlargement of his faculties. We admired the application of his financial functions to the protection of the Battery against encroachment, because the act had the joint merit of manliness and unexpectedness.
We have St. John (N. B.) papers of the 1st inst., and Halifax of July 30. A general election shortly takes place in Nova Scotia. Parties appear much embittered against each other.

On Tuesday morning, Aug. 2, LUCY ANN HAWLEY, wife of Joseph R. Skidmore, and daughter of Irad Hawley, aged 31 years, 10 months and 4 days. The friends of the family are requested to attend her funeral on Wednesday afternoon, Aug 3, at 3 P. M., from the residence of her father, No 21 Rutters-place. without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

The War Department will soon order twelve or fifteen hundred additional troops to garrisons on the Rio Grande. They will be drawn gradually from Texas and the Atlantic seaboard, as the exigencies of the service will permit.

When the sons of a widowed mother go up to their old homestead, to make their annual visit, they are accustomed to lay their heads together, to consider what their excellent parent may need to complete the circle of her comforts.

The list of papers read to-day numbered twenty-one; rather a good day's work accomplished. Of the number, a low were of general interest, mainly divested of repellant technicalities, and likely to be productive of hints useful to more than one reader of newspapers.

OYER AND TERMINER.--Yesterday morning, Mr. BLUNT, District Attorney, applied to his Honor Judge EDMONDS, sitting at Chambers of the Supreme Court, for a special term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, to be holden at the earliest day convenient to the Judge of the Circuit.

It may not be uninteresting to some of your readers to know in what direction to turn when they leave the heated, crowded, dusty city, to find this valley, much talked of since the time of Dr. JOHNSON, and often "sought but never found." I cannot well mention names, but I have found it, within a day's ride from New-York.

The Cleveland True Democrat reports an interesting case of an attempt to assassinate a magistrate of that city. It appears that a German, named Lamhertus Voskamp, on Saturday last entered the office of Justice Hessenmueller, and after some few minutes' conversation on business, Voskamp drew a double-harreled pistol, saying, " Now I'll shoot you," and fired, the ball passing through Mr. H's coat.

Fifth Congressional District--A few returns are received, indicating a very close race, and the result is doubtful. Seventh District--The majority for PRESTON, Whig, in this city, is 1,250. WOLFE, Whig, is elected State Senator.

The U S. steamers Princeton and Fulton arrived at Eastport on Sunday morning. The brig Isaac Carver, which arrived at this port to-day from Cardenas, was struck by lightning on the 18th ult., which shivered the mainmast, and killed ISAAC ELDRED, a seaman, aged 20 years.

The anniversary exercises of this Institution commenced on Sunday, July 31, in the Methodist Church, by the delivery of the Baccalaureate Sermon to the graduating class. The Sermon was delivered by BISHOP M. SIMPSON, D. D., from the text:" In Him was life, and the life was the light of men."

STORM AT ALBANY.-The Albany papers have interesting accounts of the storm that occurred on Monday night. The Evening Journal says: Last evening, for upwards of an hour, rain fell in torrents, flooding the streets, filling basements of houses, and uprooting the pavement in the streets. Maiden lane, after the storm had somewhat subsided, presented a wretched appearance.
To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: A pretty snip of a snob, Mr. Editor, has foisted off his cockneyisms upon the readers of the TIMES, while you are snuffing mountain breezes away in Vermont.

A circular, announcing a Convention in behalf of Women's Rights, appears in papers addicted to such things. New-York is to be the scene of the demonstration; for why, ask the authors of the Convocation--why is not the great commercial metropolis of the country appropriate for such movements?
A correspondent of the Kingston News, writing from the township of Seymour, July 21, says that a dreadful storm occurred in that township on the previous Tuesday.

The determination of the Secretary of War, largely to increase the number of our troops on the Rio Grande, will give rise to not a little speculation as to its object. We are supposed to be at peace with Mexico. SANTA ANNA'S protestations, through his new Minister here, and faithful follower, all forbid the possibility of rupture between us.

I accordingly hastened to visit it.

PROBABLE SUICIDE.-On Tuesday morning, at 5 o'clock, officer MOUNT, Pock Master of the Eighth Ward, found lying behind one of the spiles on the Spring-street Wharf, a full suit of gentlemen's morning apparel, with the exception of shirt and pants.

In the leafy and flowery month of June we made a flying visit to the home of our youth, in the quiet little town of Winchester, in the State of Connecticut. We wandered over the hills and through the valleys; over the mountains and through the dark, silent forests, where erst our young foot. steps loved to rove, and we felt almost carried back to the happy days of our youth.

During the storm on the 30th ult., at Sharen Springs, a stage containing eight passengers was precipitated into a deep ravine oil the edge of the road near that place. The night was very dark. The late rains had made the blanks of the ravine soft and slimy, and the driver could not see his way, for he had no lantern.

The following letter from Miss SINCLAIR, the authoress of Beatrice, the most brilliant and popular of polemical tales, has been received by Messrs. DEWITT DAVENPORT. It will be observed that Miss SINCLAIR, not withstanding the immense success of her books in America, is not friend to International Copyright.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn. In this season of the dog-days, when the populace of New-York read with avidity every description of country scenery, and when they peruse the morning paper, with a peculiar longing for all that relates to Saratoga, Cape May, and Newport, it would be, perhaps, unkind to depict any scenes different from that of their loved watering-places.

At Arachova we exchanged our horses for donkeys, and struck into a steep path winding through vineyards along the precipitous sides of the mountain, by which we soon gained a height commanding a large valley on the other side, fertile and well cultivated, though at so great an elevation, and diversified by a little village of stone, window-less houses, and two small sheets of water.

SIR: On the 3d inst., a most brutal murder was committed in Pettis Co., in this State. The victim was a Mrs. RAINS. She was killed while her husband was absent at church.

There can be but little doubt that of all the preventive of disease, or preservatives of health, systematic bathing holds the foremost rank. Any one who will take the trouble to reflect for a moment on the peculiar functions of the skin, and the influence they exert, sympathetically, over the functions of the internal organs of the body, must,I think, come to this conclusion.
GRAND REGATTA AT HOBOKEN.--A spirited match for $500, New-Jersey against Philadelphia, came off from the dock opposite Barker's Atlantic Hotel, on Tuesday afternoon.

It befals us this morning to record the most awful calamity that has ever occurred in this city. Last evening, a train of platform cars, conveying the laboring men of the Belvidere Delaware Railroad Co. and about one hundred of those assisting in the repairs of the Pennsylvania Canal, to their homes, was thrown from the track at Bull's Island, nine miles above here, and the fatal result announced above ensued.

In my last letter I alluded to Centre Harbor. With the exception of Wolfborough, this is the most frequented of any spot around the Lake. It is a small, quiet little village, with its church, two hotels, two or three stores, and a score or two of dwelling-houses.

THE CLIPPER SHIP "SWEEPSTAKES."--This fire vessel, now lying at Pier No. 5, North River, was the scene of festivity and good cheer for several hours yesterday afternoon. The enterprising owners, Messrs. CHAMBERS HEISER, had issued complimentary invitations to about five hundred of their friends, who, at 2 o'clock, g?? down to a cold collation, liberally prepared by Mr. HAGAN, of the "Pheasant," in Howard-street.

The annual session of this Association commenced on Tuesday, Aug. 2, in Rochester. There was quite a large attendance of the profession, members of the Association, and persons who have been active in educational matters, among whom was Mr. F. W. SHERMAN, State Superintendent of Schools in Michigan.

The Washington Union of Aug 3, in reference to the President's speech at the Crystal Palace, says as follows: We observe in some of the Whig papers a disposition to complain of the brevity of the speech of President PIERCE at the opening of the Crystal Palace.

The Boston Advertiser of yesterday, gives the following synopsis of the doings of the Massachusetts Constitutional Convention: The Convention was in session with the exception of a recess at one o'clock P. M., and another at 7, of an hour each, from 9 o'clock on Monday morning to 2 on Tuesday.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Our route from Gordonsville to Charlottesville lay through a beautiful portion of Virginia. For the extent and variety of its undulating scenery,-for the gratification of minuteness, which the eye loves, no less than range,-for mountains walling the distance, and forming the lowlands into complete landscapes,-I have seen nothing superior to it.

You publish a notice from the Hartford Times, about the new Monument to be erected to the memory of Gen. DAVID WOOSTER. The Times does not, however, state where the Monument is to be. It may be interesting to many of the "Old Danbury Boys " to know that it is to be located in this town-in the New Cemetery grounds.

This distinguished Composer and Conductor left Liverpool on Wednesday last by the Baltic, and may be expected to arrive here on Saturday evening next. We copy from the London Times of the 13th July, a description of the Farewell Concert given to him by his friends and admirers, previous to his departure for New-York:

The Bytown and Prescott Railroad Company have expended $400,000 in the work of grading, , and have also purchased the iron, cars and locomotives. They halve exhausted their means, hence they call on certain corporations to aid the completion of the road, by a subscription of $30,000-that sum being necessary to put the road in working order early next Spring.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It has long been contemplated to erect a new and more spacious building as a substitute for the old, worn-out, and contracted shed now used for the Washington Market-the largest, and by far the most important market in this City.

On Tuesday, Aug. 2, by Rev. Geo. L. Prentiss, J. HENRY SINCLAIR, of Jackson, Miss, to Miss FRANCES A CORWIN, daughter of Elisha Corwin, Esq, of this City. On Wednesday, Aug. 3. by Rev Wm. H. Lewis, at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, DUDLEY S. GREGORY, Jr. of Jersey City, to REBECCA F., daughter of James, N. Olney, Esq., of San Francisco, formerly of Brooklyn.

Philadelphians are trying again the often-repeated effort to consolidate into one Municipality the City and Districts of Philadelphia. We are assured that this project, the necessity for which no outsider can for a moment question, is greatly increasing in the public favor.

BROOKLYN-LAYING THE CORNER- STONE.-The congregation of Rev. WM W. HALLOWAY, who at present to the number of sixty or seventy, meet in a temporary building at the corner of Bedford-avenue and He wesstreet, have determined on building a new and handsome Church on the corner of Lee-avenlle and He wes-street.

There has been but little business doing today, owing to the anxiety to obtain later orders from Europe, now over-due. The FLOUR Market continues very quiet, and the receipts, both by Railroad and water, are small. There is but little inquiry for export, and holders are indifferent about realizing.

The Albany Evening Journal of the 2d inst. announces the death of Hon. JONATHAN RICHMOND, as follows: "Another of the Pioneers of Western New-York has passed away. The Hon. JONATHAN RICHMOND died at Aurora, Cayuua County, on Friday last, at the age of 79.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times : MY DEAR SIR: I enclose a letter from Bishop MEADE, on the subject of African Colonization. It is taken from the Virginia Colonizationist for the month of July. If your columns allow, please publish it.

NOVEL PUNISHMENT.--The Chinese Repository tells of a strange kind of death punishment which was inflicted on a Chinese criminal, who had been convicted of a very heinous offence. He was wound round with cotton, saturated with tallow, places being left for him to breathe.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The Board met at the Lyceum on Tuesday evening; Ald F. B. BETTS, President of the Board, in the Chair. The subject of licensing pedlars of fish, fruit and vegetables, came up for discussion, on an application for a license.
Four hundred and twenty-nine deaths from yellow fever, in one week and in one city, is awful. New-Orleans is, just now, a cursed city. And it is said to be a dirty city, too.

When the approaching change in the style of our Municipal Government shall have been consummated, an improved Charter taking effect; and when new, and in many respects, better men shall have assumed the management of City affairs, results will be anxiously looked for.

The order for increased military force on the Rio Grande has been issued. Senator MASON, of Virginia, who is here. is decided in his expression of opposition to the Pacific Railroad project advanced by the Administration, and he is supported by the Union. He declares he will never yield his approval.

PROPOSITION TO TUNNEL THE OHIO RIVER AT THE FALLS.--A correspondent of the Louisville Courter proposes to tunnel the Ohio River at the Falls, for railroad purposes. He thinks such a work would make the Falls the radiating point of a great number of railroads. He thus speaks of its practicability and expensiveness:

The Vincennes, Ind. Patriot publishes an account of a somewhat mysterious murder in that vicinity. It says. a few years since, a Frenchman by the name of Lafav (or so pronounced,) who lived alone in a cabin on the banks of the Wabash, about three miles below this place, on the Illinois side, was found dead in his yard, being shot through the bead with a rifle.

There is considerable excitement existing in Jersey City, on account of the committal of MARGARET KENNEDY to jail, on a complaint growing out of the robbery of the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank of Jersey City.

This entire country is unceasingly in a transitory state, under the magic power of the hammer and spade, direced by the enterprise of "Young America." The whole aspect of city and country is not cheering to the eye of the capitalist and immigrant.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Having spent nearly the whole day at the Exhibition, I wish to make a few remarks, mainly to second the advice given in your opening article on the subject, last week, to your country readers, sustained as it is by my own experience.

A SHOWER OF OATS.--On Thursday last, says the Marlboro (Md.) Gazette, our village was visited by the remarkable phenomenon of a shower of oat straw ! It appeared to have been recently threshed, no grain being found in the heads.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You will see in the papers a new circular dispatch of the Russian Minister, NESSELRODE, to the diplomatic agents of Russia, dated July 2, (old style, June 20,) intended to explain the bearing of the hostile occupation of MoldoWallachia.

The Wheeling Intelligencer of the 25th ult., says that on Saturday night, a freight train ran over a man lying on the track near Fetterman's. When the train was stopped, it was thought strange that no blood was seen flowing from the wounds caused by the passage of the cars over his body, and on examination he was found to be perfectly cold.

At Mayaguez Island of Porto Rico, on the 14th of July last, after a short illness, in the 30th year of his age, GEORGE FISK OAKLEY, son of Cornelius Oakley, of this City. In this City, CHARLES P., son of William and Isabella Andrus, aged 10 months and 8 days. In California, May. 1853, LANCASTER LUPTON, eldest son of the late William Lupton, of Wisconsin.

The Wheeling Intelligencer of the 25th ult., says that on Saturday night, a freight train ran over a man lying on the track near Fetterman's. When the train was stopped, it was thought strange that no blood was seen flowing from the wounds caused by the passage of the cars over his body, and on examination he was found to be perfectly cold.

The Examiner is the name of a new weekly paper started in Norwich, Conn., to be devoted especially to the advocacy of the Maine Law, the observance of the Sabbath, and the improvement of Common Schools. It is quite a clerical concern. Revs. H. P. ARMS, JOHN. P. GULLIVER, and J. A. GOODHUE, have editorial supervision at the office.

A significant editorial of Le Repulicain, a French liberal paper conducted in this City, with marked ability and energy, and representing the opinions of a vast mass of our French fellowcitizens, appeared in their issue of Wednesday, Angust 3. It well merits the attention of every American, and should be carefully pondered by those, especially, whose duty and- occupation it is to watch over the interests and safety of our

We learn that the Governments of Sweden and Norway have promptly adopted the suggestion made by Lieutenant MAURY, for simultaneous observations at sea by the navies of different nations, with a view to obtaining correct data for carrying out more completely the Lieutenant's system of Wind and Current Charts.

The news from China is of an astonishing character. It is not remarkable for any unexpected success of the Rebels, or any recovery of their lost fortune by the Imperialists. The Insurgents now hold Nankin, which is reported to be in a state of ruin, Chin-kiang, and Yangchow, and the possessions between these cities, all which are put into a complete state of defence.

In the city of San Francisco, a Mercantile Library Association has been formed, of which Mr. DAVID S. TURNER is President, and Dr. H. GIBBONS Corresponding Secretary. The necessity for such an organization in a city where few young men can enjoy the facilities of private libraries and reading-rooms, or even of retired apartments or congenial society at home,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Passing up Wall-street this morning, about 111/2 o'clock, the writer saw a man addressing a/ small knot of people from the centre pedestal of the Exchange. Curiosity prompted him to cross over and learn the nature of his remarks, and, from his style of speaking, was led to feel that he had suffered loss of either relatives or friends by the late sad catastrophe at Norwalk.

THE BONE CRYPT AP ROTHWELL.--It has often been remarked that, while the ends of the earth have been visited for the purpose of gratifying curiosity, we are too apt to neglect or overlook what is quite as interesting or wonderful at our very doors. The bone caverns at Rothwell afford an example of this.

Lieutenant PORTER is indebted, probably, to his own careless remarks, for the statement that he was going on a lawless Amazon expedition. I am happy to state now, much to his credit, that although anxious to go on the expedition, he ablndoned it when he ascertained its lawlessness. The expedition, however, is still contemplated.

Yesterday morning the members of the above named Society, together with many of the friends of the cause--Anti-Slavery-repaired to a grove surrounding the prermises of M. GOODERSON, Esq., in the vicinity of Flushing, Long Island.

NEW LINE OF STAGES.--The stages of Avenue A line commenced running on Wednesday. On that day the public were conveyed free of charge. The following is the rote over which they travel: From the corner of Twenty-third-street and Avenue A, through Avenue A to Essex, Division and Chatham-streets to Park-row, Park-row to Broadway, Fulton, Washington and Cortlandt streets to Jersey City Ferries.

A correspondence between W. H. LUDLOW, late Speaker of the Assembly, and twenty-four gentlemen of New-York, among whom are PETER COOPER, JOHN A. DIX, Mayor WESTERVELT, ISAAC V. FOWLER, W. C. BRYANT and JOHN VAN BUREN, appeared in last evening's Post. The letter to the late Speaker is in a high degree complimentary.

CULLINAN, resident priest of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Nicholas, Lawford's, and MARTIN FOLEY, a lay member of the congregation, were severally indicted for having, on the 19th day of June, in the Church of St. Nicholas aforesaid, unlawfully assaulted, beaten and ill treated the Chevalier ANTONIO BARACESCO DE MASCAREN HAS.

Mr. JOHN BROWN, Dragoman, has lent a lustre to his family name which shall forever redeem it from commonplace. It must hereafter be classic. It will rank in dignity, if not in euphony, with those of the TALLEYRANDS, NESSELRODES, and METTERNICHS, who have plucked deathless laurels in the walks of diplomacy;

The news frow Europe, by the Washington, and through tile telegraph, by the Niagara, we publish this morning. The Eastern difficulties are in about the same position as last reported. If anything, the aspect of affairs is not so belligerent. It is believed that the reception given by the Cabinet of St. Petersburg to the first proposition from the Powers.

A SLAVE OF GEN. WASHINGTON'S.--It is not generally known to our readers that there is yet living near Cookstown, a slave of Gen. WASHINGTON'S. He is 124 years of age, and can walk six miles in a day. He is so old that his fingers and toes are nearly all white. He belonged to WASHINGTON when he owned what is now known as WASHINGTON'S Bottom, on which Perrypolis now stands.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: It is with deep regret that I notice the decease of Mr. ELISHA RIGGS, of this City. He has for years been an influential man, and occupied offices, which show the great confidence entertained for him by those who act for their own interest purely.

For the other City News of this morning see Sixth Page. Amusements this Evening. NIBLO'S GARDEN--English Opera Company. CASTLE GARDEN--Italian Opera Company, BROADWAY THEATRE.--Barney the Baron--Bashful Irishman--Our Gal.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouse.

A good story is told of a Connecticut parson. His country parish raised his salary from $300 per annum to $400. The good man objected, for three reasons. " First," said he, "because you can't afford to give more than three hundred. Second, because any preaching isn't worth more than three hundred.

Messrs. E.B. S. WARD, of Detroit, have planned a tour and the shores of Lake Superior, fixing Saturday, the 13th of August, for the starting day. On that day the steamer Sam Ward is to leave the Sant Ste. Mari, bearing such excusionists as present themselves. The berts will accommodate one hundred and fifty passengers.

The United States Mail steamship Washington, E. M. FITCH Commander, arrived at this port, yesterday morning, from Bremen, bringing dates from that point to the 15th; Southampton and London, the 20th, and Liverpool, Havre and Paris to the 19th ult. inclusive. The Washington brings 150 passengers and a full and very valuable cargo of merchandise from Germany and France.

THE SPIRITS IN SYRIA.--The Sheik BECHIR is a personage of acquirements; he has a store of history and literature; his conversation is superior to that of his countrymen; and he has, to complete the superiority, the fame of a wonder-worker, and the advantage of interview with the spirits of another would! Who can resist such proofs of power as these?

The Press and public opinion in Europe are the dupes of a triple game, in which the circles of diplomacy are, at this moment, engaged. Instead of continuing to ask themselves the eternal question: Shall we have war in the East ?" without ever finding an answer, democrats would be better employed in seeking the solution of another enigma of the diplomatic sphynx, preparing to devour them, if they have not already divined it.

CASTLE GARDEN.--In consequence of the sudden indisposition of Signora STEFFANO, "Lucrezia Borgia" was not given on Wednesday evening. In its stead "Sonnambula" was presented. It is unnecessary for us to allude to it, except in terms of general satisfaction. It is a long time since we have seen the opera so well performed. .

SEWERAGE.--SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--There' was a special meeting of the consider the question of sewerage, together with other matters. Alderman F. B. BETTS, President of the Board, presided. After the organization of the meeting and some few remarks, the Board took a recess for a short time to allow conversation among the members on the subject. Order being resorted.

NEW CHURCH EDIFICE.--This afternoon, at 3 o'clock, will be laid the corner-stone of a new Church edifice, on the corner of Union-avenue and South-third-street, to be called the " First Mission Methodist Episcopal Church." The addresses will be made by Bishop JANES and Rev. JOHN INSKIP, of New-York.

On Wednesday evening, Aug. 3, of general debility, ELISHA RIGGS, in the 75th year of his age. The friends of the deceased. of his sons and family. are respectfully invited, without further notice. to attend the funeral from his late residence, No. 6 Bowling Green, at 4 o'clock P. M., on Friday, Aug. 5.

A severe storm swept over Bucks County, Penn., on Monday night, the 25th ult., flooding Tohickon, Pine Run, North Branch, and Tinicum creeks higher than they were known before for manny years, and doing a large amount of damage. The Delaware Division of-the Pennsylvania Canal was broken in some few places, and navigation suspended, but the injury was expected to be repaired by yesterday, when the water would be immediately let in and navigation resumed.

ARTIFICIAL MARBLE.--Mr. BENJAMIN HARDINGE, of Cincinnati, has made a valuable discovery in synthetic chemistry, by which he is enabled to produce an artificial marble from common pebbles and sand. It is stated by the Express Messenger that he is about to erect in or near the City of Montreal a model palace, to be built entirely of marble and precious stones.

The St. Louis papers say that Col. BENTON'S writings concerning the Territory of Nebraska have excited an immense emigration to that fertile land. They speak of it as a thing for which he deserves the highest credit; and for St. Louis, they hold the matter to be only second in importance to that of the Pacific Railroad itself.

The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool, on Saturday, July 23, with 115 passengers, arrived at this port at 4 o'clock this morning, and after taking in coals, sailed for Boston in a dense fog, but with calm weather. The screw steamer Sarah Sands sailed from Liverpool on the evening of July 21, with 220 passengers, for Quebec.

THE REVOLUTION IN VENZURLA.-By the arrival of the schooner New Republic, Capt. KAINE, from Puerto Cabello, July 22, at Philadelphia, we have news that the republic was agitated by the revolutionists from centre to circumference. A fleet of steamers and schooners, with troops on board, had sailed from Puerto Cabello, 18th ult., to put down the insurgents, and if not successful at the first blow, a civil war will be the consequence.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Time : A correspondent of your paper of Tuesday morning last, writing from Lake George, indulges himself in sundry witty remarks respecting the irregularity of trains at Saratoga Springs, from the South, which, if they afforded pleasure to any of your readers, without misleading them, would not be noticed.

AMERICA IN LESS THAN FOUR DAYS.--We are enabled to announce that by a new and much improved construction of vessels, it will be perfectly practicable to accomplish the voyage between the United States and the United Kingdom in considerably less than four days; in fact, in about three and a half-the ports connecting the Old and New Worlds being Halifax and Galway. This is no speculative statement.

A MODEL SHERIFF.--Worcester County boasts of a Sheriff far above the generality of his calling. Besides doing his duty as an officer to perfection, he fills (beautifully, says the Cambridge Chronicle,) the office of teacher in the SabhathSchool, connected with the House of Correction; goes as far as the law will allow in furnishing suitable hooks, and even expends his own money for such purposes.

Yesterday afternoon, the corner-stone of a Presbyterian Church was laid, in the presence of a large and most respectable assembly, on the rising ground above Dearman, on the cast bank of the Hudson River. The site is one of the most beautiful which could have been chosen, commanding au extended view of the lordly Hudson and the picturesque scenery along its banks.

The Baltic was telegraphed off Holyhead Tuesday afternoon, at 31/2 o'clock, and will reach Liverpool between 8 and 9. The weather was fine, but somewhat misty at sea. Nothing else important. A difficulty occurred, evening 15th, on board the ship Squantum, between boatswam RICHARD WILLIAMS and chief-mate ROBERT MCCRAE, in which the latter was stabbed, and thrown overboard, but was picked up and taken to the Hospital.

Miners say the finest gold is obtained by careful processes of extraction from the "tailings " of dirt, or powdered quartz, which have already been subjected to the ordinary operation of the amalgamating table. It is so, we faney, with matters of public interest which are brought before the people in a crude mass of voluminous documents.
The execution of THOMAS CONNOR for the murder of Capt. HUTCHINSON took place to-day. The culprit was taken on to the gallows at 11 o'clock, perfectly composed and firm.

PUTNAM opens with an article upon the Crystal Palace--short and sensible. Other notable contributions are, "Acadie; the Birth-place of Evangeline;" "School-keeping in Texas ;" the continuation of "Wensley, an Immoral Story;" "Russian Despotism and its Victims;" "Advantages of a Drift Log;" "Virginia, Past and Present;" "The Tree of Life;" the latter from a new hand.
"The dog-star rages! nay 'tis past a doubt, All Bedlam or Parnasaus is let out!" Yes, there is no question at all about it.
On Sunday I hired a buggy and drove to Tuscarora, an Indian village, about eight miles from the Falls.

The times have come to a pretty pass. The dirt is getting a little too thick i n the streets. We had stopped grumbling about it so long as it was evenly distributed over the surface; but when it is allowed to rise into little bills and miniature mountains, we cannot restrain ourselves from protesting.
