Charges against the street Commissioner. The Committee appointed to investigate the charges, brought forward by Alderman DOHERTY, in reference to the contract for grading One Hundred and Twenty-third-street, between Third avenue and Avenue A, sat again yesterday morning, pursuant to adjournment. Alderman DOHERTY asked Mr. FURY if he had got the Inspector's book with him.

The latest intelligence received from Constantinople is of the 9th instant, and it confirms the statement already transmitted to us by the Telegraph, that on that day the Grand Vizier and REDSCHID PASHA, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, had been dismissed from their respective offices.

BEFORE CHIEF JUSTICE GRIER, SITTING AS CHANCELLOR.--Archer Gifford, Executor of Elizabeth Hoyt, vs. Herman Thorn, and Mary Rutherford, deceased.--The controversy in this case arises out of the estate of WILLIAM JAUNCEY, deceased, late a wealthy resident of the City of New-York.

A NEW CHURCH.--The corner-stone of a new Church edifice, to be called the "First Mission M. E. Church." was laid, with appropriate exercises, on the corner of South Third-street and Union-avenue, yesterday afternoon, at 3 o'clock. The services were commenced with reading the 2d chapter of the 1st Ephesians, by Rev. WM. WAKELY. of New-York, after which a hymn was surg by the Choir.
DEAR SIR: Did you never feel the difference between a rainy day in the city and one in the country? For my part, I know nothing more perceptible.

THE "SAFE GAME" ONCE MORE-ANOTHER COUNTRYMAN SWINDLED - Yesterday a countrymen from the State of Maine, named EDWARD DAVIS, was victimized by two ??, after the old fashion. It realty is surprising that persons can allow themselves to be swindled in such a manner, after he repeated exposures made in the public journals.
CASTLE GARPEN.--The "Child of the Regiment" was presented last evening. Signor BADIALI as the Sergeant, was in excellent voice, and acted with unusual spirit.

THE GRAND LODGE OF ODD-FELLOWS OF NEW-JERSEY, met at Camden, on Wednesday. By the new Constitution of the State Lodge, the election for Grand officers is submitted to a vote of the several districts, and if the districts fail to make a choice, it then becomes the duty of the Grand Lodge to elect.
The American Navy! What a term of deep signification should that be. How comprehensive, portentous and magnificent.

Dr. ELWOOD HARVEY, of Philadelphia, writes correcting the statement we extracted into the TIMES from a medical journal, to the effect that the "Penn Medical College," had swallowed up the "Female Medical College of Pennsylvania."
The public exercises of Commencement week at Marietta College commenced on Tuesday evening, July 27, with the "Representation" of the two Literary Societies.

New-Orleans papers of the 28th July are received, but the two latest mails are still due. The Charleston papers give no particulars of the late duel near that city.

Six NEW REVENUE-CUTTERS.--We under stand that the six new revenue-cutters just built at Bristol, R. I., and Somerset, Mass., by J. M. HOOD, contractor--the builder of the celebrated clippership Pathfinder-prove to be perfect models in their way.
The following dispatch, from our Correspondent at Washington, gives us important information concerning the Postal arrangements between the United States and Bremen.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: ST. THOMAS' CHURCH CASE.--With reference to Mr. DOBSON'S affidavits, published in your paper of this morning, Mr. Cook's affidavit as to April, 1852, in no wise contradicts the statement of the Trustees as to March, 1853 The injuries in the Church Bible speak for them selves, Mr. PIERCE'S opinion, notwithstanding, to whom it appears the credit of disappreving of Mr. DOBSON'S proceedings was given on erroneous information.

On the evening of Aug. 4, of diarrhies, LEWIS OAKLEY, twin son of J. Oakley and Eliza A Nodyne, aged 5 months and 15 days. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral at No. 675 Greenwich st., on Saturday, Aug 6, at 3 o'clock P M.
WRECK OF THE BRIG RAPID AT TONGATABOO. --By the ship Emma, from San Francisco, we have news of the total wreck of the brig Rapid, Capt. CRESWELL.

I do not remain always in my little corner, but emerge every morning to go to the Springs; sometimes to one and sometimes to another-and there I walk to and fro, or stand by one of the posts, and take notes for you to print.

Accoring to appointment, the Armory Commission convened at the Hall in the East Work shop of the Armory, on Wednesday morning, at 9 o'clock--the full Board being in attendance--to give a hearing to such representations, from all persons interested, as might have a bearing upon the relative and respective merits of the military and civil superintendence of the Armories.

The Telegraphic report will have anticipated the mail announcement of the adjournment of the Convention to day. The vent was quite unexpected by many, who had looked for a session of at least eight days.

Wright, Gandy Co.'s Liverpool Circulars Per Niagara ?? CHAPEL STREET, Friday, July 23 '53. At the date of our circular, advices per Asia, on the 15th, the COTTON market closed quietly, with estimated sales of 8,000 bales that day.

The Vernon Banner tells a story about a young man in that village, who came near getting his brains blown out, the other day, with a broomstick. He was boarding in a private family, in which there was a rather attractive young lacy. As he was leaving the house after dinner, one day last week, in passing the window he espied the young lady sitting in a rocking chair.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.-An adjourned meeting of this Board was held on Friday afternoon, at the County Jail. In the absence of the President, on motion of Supervisor Bergen, Supervisor WYCKOFF, of Brooklyn, was called to the Chair.

At a meeting of the Liverpool Dock Committee, letters to the Mayor from Lieut. MAURY and Mr. DILKE, were read. The wind and current charts being under consideration, Mr. RANKIN remarked " that a great part of Lieut. MAURY'S book was taken from Mr. TowSON'S work without acknowledgment."

We need scarcely call attention to the first of a series of Papers from Strawberry Hill, of which we commence the publication in the TIMES of this morning. The signature identifies them as coming from the same accomplished pen to which our readers have been indebted for the able, candid and valuable review of Uncle Tom's Cabin, published in our columns within a few weeks past.

The St. Louis Repuolican has received a letter from Fort Laramie, dated June 22, portions of which are of sufficient interest to republish. The correspondent says: We made the trip from Fort Kearney here in two weeks, but have been detained here a day by the crowd of emigrants at the ferry over the Laramic-the bridge having been swept away by the late freshet.

PATERSON.-Not much damage was done in Jersey City. A few cellars were flooded, and the foundations for new buildings were somewhat damaged by the banks being washed, and by the collection of water in the cellars The Bergen Point Plank road was damaged for about two miles in extent, between Armstrong place and the tollgate at Communipaw-lane The planks were torn up.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Although you have able and wellinformed correspondents in London, I have thought a letter from a strange hand might not prove unwelcome; especially as in these times every man has his own theory about the solution of the political difficulties; and no two writers, having all EuroPe for the course, will be likely to run exactly on the same track.

The U. S. Mail steamer Baltic, from Liverpool, Wednesday, July 27, arrived at this port yesterday, at 1 P. M. The Baltic has a very heavy cargo, and nearly a second cargo had to be refused for want of room. On the 20th, the following notice was posted on Liverpool Exchange:

A young man--by name THOMAS CONNOR--was hanged at Baltimore on Wednesday. Whether of greater weight personally than the common run of convicts, or that the hempen cord of Jack Ketch had been selected from an indifferent lot, twice was the awful spectacle witnessed of the dying wretch quivering beneath the gallows, to be borne back and his neck thrust again into the noose.

The Boston Courier of the 6th, speaks as follows concerning the recent trouble between Mr. O'DONAHOE and Mr. TREANOR, the President of the banquet given in honor of THOS. F. MEAGHER: There is, in every large community in the United States, a set of oyster-house politicians,-without a habitation or a name,-chiefly foreign " patriots," who live by speculating on the credulity of their industrious countrymen.

Saturday was a very unfortunate day for the Hudson River Railroad. The Express train, which left this City for Albany at 6 o'clock in the morning, made its usual time; but with this exception, no other train passed over the road without more or less delay.

BOARD OF EDUCATION.-The regular monthly meeting of this Board was held on Thursday night. The Committee on Qualifications presented the following resolution: Resolved That Miss Hannah E. Willets is qualified to teach in the schools of this city, as third assistant teacher: Miss Retsey Vies as fourth assistant teacher:

The A?? investigation is still in progress at Springfield. The Commission on Friday, decided upon the points of inquiry which were pertinent to the objects of the investigation, and then proceeded to hear some testimony intended to show bad man?? on the part of Col. Ripley, in relation to the Armony.

DAMAGED BY THE STORM.-Extensive excavations have been made in the following places, in consequence of the late heavy rains: In the sidewalk at the junction of North Second and North Third-streets; in the sidewalk and street on either side of Ninth street, corner of North-second-street. Also,

" It will interest good Britons to learn that their Queen is recovering from her attack of measles," says our summary of news by the Baltic. Indeed it will; and Yankees, too, would be happy to take Mrs. VICTORIA by the hand, and tell her how glad they are that she has weathered her troubles--that is, providing the danger of catching the measles has past.

A highly interesting experiment with the vapor of chloroform as a substitute for steam in navigation, has been made in the harbor of Lorient. The Government aviso of 120 horse-power, Galileo, was fitted with an evaporating engine onehalf smaller than ordinary engines of the same power.

AMHERST COLLEGE COMMENCEMENT.--The exercises of Commencement Week at Amherst will be as follows: Tuesday, Aug. 9--Meeting of the Phi Beta Kappa Society at 2 P. M. Prize declamations at 71/2 P. M. Wednesday, Aug. 10Meeting of the Alumni at 8 A. M., together with a tribute to the scientific labors of the late Prof. ADAMS, by President HITCHCOCK.

M. JULLIEN, the projector and leader of the celebrated promenade concerts in London, visits the United States with a view to a similar musical season in the great cities of this country. He arrived here yesterday in the Baltic, and is at the Clarenden Hotel. His corps of instrumental artists will come out in the next COLLINS' steamer, due two weeks hence.

The task of delineating the characters of eminent men is a pleasing one. The interest which we feel in the history of the great events in which h they took part, is heightened by the charm which the personal narrative, intervoven with it, never fails to impart to important transactions.

From the London Morning Advertiser To those who look around upon the savage prospect of conspiring despotisms and triumphant force, who see might insolently trample upon right, and the conquests of civilization, and the legacy of ages, jeopardised by treachery and cowardice, there is one bright spot, one green oasis, upon which the eye may rest.

In pursuance of the death-warrant transmitted to High Sheriff HAYS, by Governor LOWE, the unfortunate, but guilty young man, THOMAS CONNOR, convicted of the murder of Captain HUTCHINSON, suffered the extreme penalty of the law, by hanging, this morning.

SWEARING IN OF THE RIVER POLICE.--Twenty-five young men--active and intelligent in appearance, and all boaring an excellent character--were aworn in at she Sheriff's office, "as Deputy Sheriffs, to assist in pre serving the public peace, as River Policemen, under the direction of Capt. CHARLES A. RAKIELEWITZ," (formerly United State Marshal.)

The Grand Jury. at Boston, have indicted the harbor thieves, recently arrested. as follows: Wm. McLaughlin, for an assault with a loaded pistol upon officers Moore and Leonard with intent to kill and murder; McLaughlin and Kelley, for stealing a yawl-boat, (with which they boarded vessels) the property of some person unknown;

If we may believe the European journals which have come to hand by the Niagara and Baltic, all the difficulties of the RussoTurkish question have vanished, and a speedy and pacific solution of it may with certainty be looked for.

The statement that Minister WALKER is going to Bombay, and there to take the steamer Powhatan for China, must be erroneous. When last heard from, the Powhatan was at Mauritius, under orders to join Commodore PERRY'S squadron. Ere this, she has probably reached Macao, and followed PERRY to Japan.

The two war-steamers of the fishing squadron are here to-day. The Princeton arrived on Saturday, after a thrilling escape from the fogs and rocks of the Bay of Fundy; and on Sabbath the Commodore and his officers attended Divince service in Eastport-probably to return especial thanks for the past, and to pray for the " security of the future."

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Doubtless correspondents without number have favored you with descriptions, this Summer, of their respective descents upon the village of Niagara Falls, with brief (or other) summaries of what they saw, felt, thought and did thereabout. But has anybody sent you his book of exodus therefrom?

A private watchman named MICHAEL DOYLE, employed on Commercial Wharf, at the Atlantic Docks, was shot at fr m the canal-boat Monarch of Clgde, about 11 o'clock on Saturday night. The contents of the weapon-a small pistol-ball-took effect on the inside of his right foot. The injured man was immediately taken to an apothecary-shop on Hamilton avenue, and he was subsequently sent to the New-York Hospital.

It seems to us that this valley now opens to the merchants of New-York a richer and more inviting field of adventure than those of the Amazon or La Plata. First, because it is the richest and most productive grain-growing valley on the Atlantic coast; and, secondly, because it will soon be the most direct route from New-York to the grain-growing portion of the West.

No official dispatches have yet been received by the State Department in relation to the KOSZTA affair. The delay can only be accounted for by a suspicion that they were sent by way of Trieste, and that the mail was violated by the Austrian authorities. Nothing was concluded upon at Berkley Springs between Mr. MARCY and Mr. CRAMPTON.

Messrs. MARCY and CRAMPTON Will return from Berkley Springs very little nearer a conclusion of their negotiations on the Fishery question than when they started. There is, I opine, less prospect than ever of a peaceful adjustment of the dispute.

A wet day among the mountains ! Now, I profess and entertain an equal abhorrence and dread of Quakerish weather. The prospect of a fortnight's rain would, at any time, reconcile me to garotting, or similarly unpleasant modes of termination.

The following correspondence, sent to Congross with other papers of the Mexican Boundary Commission, we believe has not heretofore been published. It consists of a challenge sent by Col. GRAHAM, late of the Boundary Commission, to Dr. WEBB, of Providence, who was also connected with that branch of the public service, at the same time.

In the Medical Examiner for August, there is a long and detailed statement of the mortality of Philadelphia during the months of April, May and June, 1853. The whole number was 2,235, which is a falling off of 15 per cent. from the aggregate of the same period of last year. The still-born were 150, deaths from " external causes " 82, old age 29,

The thermometer, at 2 o'clock, P.M., today, stood at 88 degrees. This morning the remains of a man were found in the cabin of a canal boat, which was sunk at South-street wharf, on the Delaware, in November 1852. The boat was not raised until to-day. The remains were those of one of the hands on board the vessel.

We copy from the Washington Union what, we doubt not, is the view taken by our Government of the conduct of Capt. INGRAHAM and Mr. JOHN P. BROWN, in protecting MARTIN KOSZTA from Austrian violence, in the port of Smyrna. We hail it with exultation,

MR. WEBSTER'S MARSHFIELD ESTATE.-The following information in relation to the Marshfield estate of Mr. WEBSTER, and its present condition, cannot fail to interest every reader. It is from the editorial correspondence of the Advertiser: "Everything at the house, at Marshfield, is just as Mr. WEBSTER left it.

The exercises of the Annual Commen ement of the University of Vermont have just closed. They began with the Baccalaureate Sermon reached on Sunday afternoon by the President, Rev. Dr. SMITH. On Monday evening Prof. BARROWS. of Andover Theological Seminary, delivered the Address before the Society for Religious Inquiry: his subject being the " Unity and Harmony of Truth."

We have previously, through our Vashington Correspondence, announced the conclusion of a Postal treaty reducing the rates of postage between the United States and Bremen, and now give the rates of postage on letters of the weight of half an ounce or under by the United States and Bremen line of steamers, hereafter to sail semi-monthly between New-York and Bremen, to go into effect with the first outgoing steamer

We have Indianola papers of the 19th, Galveston of the 22d, and our exchanges from the interior as late as due. There is a constant stream of young lawyers and doctors pouring into Texas. Texas is literally wooded with men in these professions, not one-half of them succeed to any reasonable extent. We want farmers and mechanics-men who produce something to live upon.

Further Account of the Rice Culture-The Harvest-Effect on the Health of the Negroes-Mode of Thrashing, Cleaning, -Preparing for Market--Extent of Culture-Best Mode of Cooking, In my last letter I described the operations by which a tidal swamp is enclosed, and ditched and prepared for Rice culture, and the subsequent process of tillage and irrigation.

The London Times throws out the suggestion that the conduct of Capt. INGRAHAM in the Smyrna affair may be made the subject of a demand by the Austrian Government upon the United States for reparation. Our New-York correspondent refers to this probable demand of the Court of Vienna upon our Government as being a prevalent topic of conversation in that city.

The following account of a daring leap is from the Nashville Banner of the 25th ult.: "A large number of persons collected together on Saturday evening to witness the leap of Mr. Watkins from the suspension bridge. At the hour appointed, he mounted the railing near the centre of the bride, on the lower side, waved his hat to the crowd, and boldly made the leap.

The Long Island Railroad-may it live forever ! Its managers-may they never grow old! Not that the former has yet done the first thing to accommodate the public intentionally, or that the latter have for a moment failed to look out first for their own interest, and, sometime after that, for the people's, providing it was perfectly convenient. We entreat for them long life, however,

Mr. J. S. CALKINS, the proprietor of the Baggage Express on the Hudson River Railroad, informs us that the failure to deliver baggage on Saturday night, at the private residences of passengers by the morning Express train, occurred solely in consequence of the delay on the road caused by the slide on the track;-and that our remarks upon the subject convey an impression unjust and injurious to his Express.

" From morning dawn till set of sun, I've seen the mighty Mohawk run." Is that quotation correct? It's true, anyhow--all but the "mighty." The mills and canal have taken so much water from it that it cannot be called "might," except by a stretch of the imagination too violent for me to make in Summer-time. However, it grows larger as we draw nearer its source.

Aug. 6, at the residence of her father, No. 535 Fourth st., ELLEN FANNY FITZHENRY, of consumption. in the 20th year of her age. At New-Haven, Conn., Aug. 5, JEANETTE BLISS, daughter of William H and Jeanette R. Adams, aged 10 months and 14 days.

We have assumed, with the rest of the World, that there is to be peace in Europe. It is said so on 'Change; published so in the newspapers; talked so in-doors over the postprandial claret. Peace is in all men's mouths. A certain degree of mental aberration is predicated of him who ventures to dissent and foretell trouble.

The ravages of the Indians still continue in the States of Durango and Zacatecas, and the lands were being rapidly deserted. Besides the revages of the Indians, bands of robbers were also prowling through the State. A child, six years of age had been ransomed from the Camanches for 35O. The General Government has contracted for 500 coats of mail to be used in the war with; the Indians.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Timmes: What has become of all the Yankees? Have they all departed to the land of Ophir? If not, have they expended all their boasted genius of invention? One would think that some sad accident had happened to them by the appearance of the stages on a rainy day.

Before His Honor the RECORDER.--The Medical Manslaughter Case--Charles Boemer, the alleged medical man, who on Saturday was found guilty of manslaughter, in causing the death of a woman whom he attended in child-birth, was called up for sentence, when the Recorder, after commenting in severe terms on his gross negligence and ignorance, and his barbarous treatment of the deceased, sentenced him to two years' imprisonment.

The Health officer reports 99 deaths for the week ending Aug. 6. Males, 44; Females, 55; Adults, 31; Children, 68. Diseases- Casualty, cholera morbus. congestion of the lungs, cyania, debility, drowned, scarlet fever, whooping cough, inflammation of the brain, tumor-1 each; diabates, typhus fever, inflammation of bowels, old age-2 each; dropsy in head, heart disease,

No, oh no"-the voice was soft, and the tones full of love; but the answer was harsh, and heard a quick and heavy step upon the floor as of one who was resolved to hid defiance to all gentle persuasion. Then again the voice grew more earnest. " Oh, no, you musn't go to-night-oh, stay with me to-night."

Every day produces fresh "telegraphic messages" dispatches, and correspondence, on the subject of the Russian quarrel, without any certain signs as yet of a decision, either hostile or pacific. Every day, too, each morning paper has its leader devoted to this question, without being able to throw much fresh light upon it.

CASTLE GARDN.--" Lucrezia Borgia" was performed last night for the last time. It attracted a good audience. We have seldom seen one more enthusiastic. Siga. STEFFANONE was demanded at the end of each act, and received on each occasion with exceeding applause.

The Legislature having at last conferred on our City the right and power to create two Parks which will bear some proportion to her wants and magnitude, it is hoped that the matter will not now be permitted to sleep, or "come tardy off." One of these sites may be made almost immediately available.

Those Bible House bricks are, it seems, beyond the reach of authority. Mr. JAMES FUREY, Street Commissioner, has exerted himself in vain. He has spared no pains to have the pile demolished. In his fervor he has even gone so far as to request the gentlemen owning the baked clay to remove it.

We have received New-Orleans papers from July 27 to August 1, inclusive. The Board of Health report 880 interments in the city for the week ending July 31, of which 692 were of yellow fever. The reports of two weeks compare as follows:

UTICA TROTTING-MATCH.--We learn by a dispatch, says the Albany Evening Journal of Saturday, that the trial between " Sllas Wright" and " Otsego," for a purse of $500, one mile heats, best in three out of five, came off yesterday afternoon on the Oneida Course, and resulted in favor of" Silas," he running three successive heats in 2,44, 2.46 and 2.43. The track was in fine order,

On Sunday afternoon, the Elders and Deacons elect were ordained and installed in their respecive offices, at the Presbyterian Church, corner of North First and Ninth-streets, at 31/2 o'clock. The ordination sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. FINLEY, Pastor of the Church.
CASTLE GARDEN.--A great treat for our readers to-night. "Lucia di Lammermoor," with Mme. SONTAG as the heroine. Signors BADIALI and SALVI sustain the characters of Ashton and Raymondo.

LONG ISLAND MAILS.--The Brooklyn Morning Journal says that the price offered by the Post-Office Department to the Railroad Company, was about $4,400, for a daily mail, including the transportation of mail agent.

THE BANK CASE.--The money which was taker from the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank, of Jersey City, has not been found, nor have the thieves been detected. The Directors of the Bank have offered $500 for the detection of the robber or robbers, in addition to $1,000 for the recovery of the missing funds.

We had the pleasure, yesterday, of welcoming back to the United States, Capt. WALTER M. GIBSON, of the American schooner Flirt, after an absence of over two years, one of which has been passed in the dungeons of the Dutch Government of the Island of Java, under circumstances in the highest degree deserving the attention of the American people, and of the Administration at Washington.

The news is one month later than by our preceding arrivals. Advices were received to the 11th of June. The Polynesian says the amount of drafts drawn by ships belonging to the American whaling fleet, touching at Honolulu and Lahaina during the last season up to Jan. 1, amounted to $300,000. The cost of exchange upon this large amount; was from 10 to 12 per cent.

Of dysentery, yesterday evening, at No. 8 Tillary-st., Brooklyn, CATHERINE H. EGAN, of Parsonstown, Kings County, Ireland, Gentle and amiable in disposition, she was generally beloved, and will be long remembered by a numerous circle of friends.
Capt. SKILLMAN left El Paso on the 25th of June and came through to San Antonio in thirteen days. The Indians still continue to be troublesome in Chihuahua. Capt. S. met several parties on his route.

The following paragraph, contradicting statements that have been widely made concerning the connection of Archbishop BEDINI with the execution of the Italian poet UGO BASSI, is from the Milwaukee Sentinel :

The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLIN, arrived here on Saturday, bringing Havana and Key West dates to the 4th inst. The news from Havana is quite unimportant. Sugars had undergone no change. Molasses was quoted at 2__ reals.

A young man, who refuses to give his name, was arrested here last night, charged with breaking into the Railroad Station at Grantville. He had in his possession a draft for $42 62, drawn by the Chautauque County Bank upon the Metropolitan Bank, in favor of E. GODEREY SON, of New York.

I had come to the conclusion, in the midst of my memorable stage-experiences, that Staunton ought to be a delightful place. Aftercalculating, as well as I could, how much I was entitled to in the ledger of compensation, I settle down in the belief, that the thirty miles of staging between the terminus of the railroad and Staunton, put me on very favorable terms with the law balancing good and evil.

The notice in your paper of the 4th inst. of the rough treatment of a respectable colored man, accompanied by his wife and another colored woman, on board of one of the Fulton ferry-boats, by the captain of the boat, induces me to mention another case at the same ferry, and probably by the same Captain.

We have again to chronicle another Railroad tragedy. The tidings of one catastrophe has scarcely time to die away, before the public mind is harrowed by the details of another. Yesterday afternoon, at 4 1/2 o'clock, a violent collision occurred on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, occurred on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, about eight miles beyond South Amboy,

We have had another hot day. The mercury at the Bulletin office, at noon, indicated 90 1/2 degrees. Officer GOULDY this afternoon arrested a butcher, named PHILIP WARNER, on the charge of retaining in his possession over $100, the property of HENRY RODEARMEL.

We live on the Avenue. We are very much in favor of the Railroad. We are quite proud of the handsome cars. We ride often up and down with our wife, and draw comparisons between the cars of to-day and the 'busses of the past, and we never tire of admiring the courtesy of the gentlemen conductors.

The Committee met again yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, Alderman TWEED in the chair. Alderman DOHERTY inquired if the Street Commissioner would admit that he had not made any official communication to the Common Council in a monthly statement as required by the ordinance?

A large thick glass vial--sealed airtight--was picked up on the beach of Lake Erie, at Dunkirk, a few days ago. It contained the following letter, written on a quarter of a sheet of letter paper, in a bold, mercantile hand.

The steamship Star of the West, Capt. E. L. TINKLEPAUGH, arrived at 10 o'clock yesterday, in 7 days 19 hours from San Juan del Norte, with 453 passengers and $537,337 in gold dust on freight and $500,000 in the hands efpassengers. She brings San Francisco dates per Pacific steamship Brother Jonathan, to 3 o'clock P. M. of 16th ult.

CONSOLIDATION--ORGANIZATION OF THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS--On Monday morning, at 10 o'clock, the Commissioners, appointed under the Consolidation act, from Williamsburg and Bushwick, assembled in the old Court-room at the King's County jail, in Raymond street. The following Commissioners were present, and answered to their names:

THE CENTRAL PARK--A meeting of persons "owning property within the area of the proposed large Central Park," was convened in Columbia Hall, junction of Broadway and Eighth-avenue, last evening, to ascertain who were opposed to, and who were in favor of, the proposed Park, and also the rate of compensation to be allowed by the Common Council. The attendance was limited to a few minor property-holders.

We are deluged with complaints from all quarters of the irregularity of the Mails. We hear from the West, the North and the South, that in repeated instances our daily paper fails to reach subscribers until days after it is due, and that two, three, and four days' issues are frequently received at once.

Dispatches from Constantinople, relative to the KOSZTA affair, have been received. I cannot learn that they vary from the published accounts materially. All the letters received, both private and official, declare a universal sentiment among native and foreign consuls in favor of INGRAHAM'S conduct, on the grounds of humanity and hospitality.

Intelligence received from the fishing grounds creates considerable uneasiness. Some 15 or 20 vessels have arrived there from Gloucester, Mass., New-Castle, N. H., and Kittery, Me , armed with muskets, boarding-pikes, cutlasses and swivels, determined to fight if interfered with.

A week since, one of the naves of the Crystal Palace was a miniature chaos. When all the rest of the builing was carefully preserved from encumbrance, the South nave was unavoidably devoted to the reception of unpacked cases, the appearance of which, to the wanderer among the avenues, was unsightly in the extreme.
Antioch College is situated at Yellow Springs, Greene County, Ohio, on a railroad connecting Cincinnati and Sandusky. The Institution was incorporated in 1852.

A letter from Captain LOVE, of the California Rangers, states that the has captured the brother of the notorious robber JOAQUIN, who has offered on a promise of being released, to conduct the Rangers to the place of concealment of JOAQUIN and his gang.

MEETING OF THE BAR IN RELATION TO THE DEATH OF HON. SAMUEL JONES, LL D, EX-CHIEF JUSTICE OF THE SUPERIOR COURT.--This venerable Jurist expired yesterday morning, at the residence of a relative on Long Island, where he has been for several weeks, lying in a helpless condition.

A Row.--About 6 1/2 o'clock, on Sunday evening, a party of rowdies went into a German porter-house in Marshall-street, near Ewen, and after drinking several times, asked for more, which was refused them. They then went into the street, and commenced stoning the house. Three Germans who were inside, becoming alarmed, ran out, and were received with a volley of stones.

The Republicain quite misapprehends our remarks upon the farewell address of Mr. SOULE. The language used on Friday evening was eminently proper from citizen SOULE; and would have been refreshing, and not entirely unbecoming, from SOULE, the Senator. But in the grave circumstances attending his mission to Spain, Ambassador SOULE erred seriously in not preserving that reserve so essentialto successful negotiation.

ELECTION AFFRAY IN KENTUCKY.--The Louisville Journal, of date Aug. 3, publishes the following account of an affray betwen THOS. D. BROWN and Hon. B. R. YOUNG: ELIZABETHTOWN, Ky., Aug. 1, 1853. The election to day has been a secondary affair; several difficulties, and lastly, an affray between THOS. D. BROWN, Clerk of the Court, and Hon. B. R. YOUNG, exciting more general attention.

A WIFE STARVED TO DEATH BY HER HUSBAND.--On Saturday Mr. BRENT held an inquest at the Clerkenwell Workhouse on the body of MARTHA GARNETT, aged 33, a married woman, with two children, alledged to have died from the effects of the refusal of her husband to provide her with food, although he is a cabinet-maker in full employment.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In an article in your paper of the 1st inst., you mention Mr. SKCCHI DI CASALE as " Superintendent of the Italian Department." Allow me to say that ou have been misinformed upon this point, as, from the commencement of the arrangements, I alone, CARLO CORGHI, of Turin, have had the honor to hold, and continue to hold, the appointment in question.

The Grand Jury in the Municipal Court, Boston, came in on Friday, with 76 indictments, having finished all the business laid before them. The following are the crimes for which indictments are found: Murder, 1; robbery by force and violence, 1; felonious assault, 1 ; burglary, 7; larceny from the person, 2; larceny from vessels, 2 ; aggravated larceny, 18; aggravated assault; 13 ;

Mr. PURVIANCE, of Natchez, Miss., after their injury on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, yesterday afternoon. The late calamity on the Camden and Amboy Railroad has been the all-engrossing topic today, and local items of interest have been exceedingly scarce. The heat is on the increase. At noon in day the Mercury at the Bulletin indicated 94 -- 3 1/2 ??uigher than at the same hour yesterday.

If there be a fault in the views' of the Government organ, with reference to the Smyrna affair, it consists in an apparent disposition to regard Austria as the offended power, and the one which should take the initiative in seeking redress. This disposition is, perhaps, only apparent.

The Albany papers are at it yet, with nails deep in each other's flesh, scratching and gouging each other. The Impeachment, of which no other paper has said a word for a long time, is still a topic; the legislative address is daily canvassed, and-the thing is susceptible of proof, we keep a file,-once during the past week the Argus and the Atlas have spoken rather disrespectfully of each other. This is very melancholy.

A reliable letter, received here from Smyrna, states that when it was momentarily expected that Captain INGRAHAM would fire upon the Austrian brig, KOSZTA was brought on deck, lashed to the mainmast, and two muskets levelled at his head; and also, that Captain INGRAHAM was notified that the first gun fired at the Husser, would be the signal to blow out KOSZTA'S brains.

A correspondent writing from Texas to the Dayton (Ohio) Journal, tells the following capital stories, for the truth of which he pledges his " sacred honor :" In the interior of the country, (writes he,) cornbread forms the staple article of diet-anything composed of wheat flour being about as scarce as ice-cream in Sahara.

MONS. MAILLEFERT'S SUBMARINE-BLASTING OPERATIONS.-This gentleman, it appears, is still busied in demolishing submarine obstructions to navigation. The results obtained at " Hell Gate," and other places of less note, have given the public full confidence in his method of blasting; and when the authorities become thoroughly awakened to the importance of removing dangerous rocks from the paths of commerce, many on which our vessels are often wrecked will be removed.

CASTLE GARDEN.--We were certainly within the bounds of strict fact when we predicted that our readers would have a great treat last evening. On no occasion this season has a prediction been so completely verified. With our contented feeling of gratification, it is a difficult task to turn to our critical pen. It would be more so,...

A PROTEST.--Nine members of the Board of Aldermen-Messrs. Wilson, Oliver, Remsen, Evans, Harteau, Wyckoff, Graham, Hawxhurst and Dayton--have published a card, protesting against the willful refusal of the majority to comply with the requirements of the Act to consolidate the cities of Brooklyn and Williamsburg, and town of Flatbush.

Minnesota is largely settled with New-Englanders, and its population is of a very hardy and industrious kind. The chief business yet in the territory is lumbering; and that of the Government with the Indians. Lumbering is carried on very largely,

It was the fault directly of the Managers of the Road. The Directors are distinctly and exclusively responsible for the lives lost, and the anguish suffered, by that catastrophe.

Near to noisy, hustling, enterprising NewYork, divided only by a narrow stream, is a city where the walking to and fro of business men disturbs, the rattling of a car alarms, and a whisper of enterprise spreads consternation among the denizens thereof. The man who laid its first foundation was ycleped Morpheus; his Christian appellation was Repose.

It will be well perhaps to embody all the points at issue, with the recent modifications, in one general. summary statement, that there may be no misunderstanding of the present position of this exceedingly interesting question.

THE EARTHQUAKE AT PORTLAND.-TWO shocks of earthquake were felt at Portland, Maine, and in the neighboring towns, Sunday morning, July 17, between 5 and 6 A. M. A shock of earthquake was also felt at Portland, between 4 and 5 P. M. of Wednesday, July 20.

S. PAYN'S PATENT DREDGING MACHINE.-We referred very briefly on Saturday, to the working of this new machine. The test was witnessed by a number of competent judges, and the manner in which the ordeal was passed, elicited universal commendation.

The Herald has found a fresh mare's nest. Its special correspondent at Washington announces to the world the advent of a new claimant to the fisheries, in the person of "ALEXANDER, Earl of STIRLING," who has sold his rights to an American company, which is about to fit out and arm a vessel to enforce those claims, and invoke the protection of the American Government.

COFFEE.-There are about a dozen species of the genus to which coffee belongs, but all of them are inhabitants of tropical countries. The Coffea Arabica alone is cultivated, and yields the article known in commerce. Its favorite locality is on hill-sides, at an elevation of from 1,000 to 3,000 feet above the level of the sea.

Another horrible accident took place on the New-Haven Railroad Tuesday night, by which the engineer was killed, and a fireman badly injured, and the locomotive, tender, and baggage-car smashed to pieces. At 11 1/2 o'clock, the express train to this City, when near Portchester. was thrown off the track. by an avalanche of rock, which had fallen a short time before the arrival of the train, and completely blocked up the road.

The process of widening Beekmanstreetis going on rapidly. Operations were yesterday commenced upon the large brick building on the corner of Nassau, from the south end of which about fifteen feet are to be taken off;-and the space in front of the Brick Church is also to be opened into the street.

Surgical instruments are probably the most disagreeable topics on which one can enlarge. There is, perhaps, no sight more awful to contemplate than the store of a surgical-instrument-maker. The articles are so keen and glittering, and are tortured into such strange forms, that it scarcely requires a very vivid imagination to conjure up scenes of unearthly pain, and operations of the most marvellous character.

COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS.-At a meeting of the Common Council, on Monday evening, the Spe cial Committee, to whom was referred the matter of changing the names of the streets, reported in favor of desiguating those running from the river, on the south side ol Grand-street, after the various Presidents of the United States, and those on the north side of Grand-street, after the various forest trees. The report was referred back for other names.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times; It is with much regret that we learned, yesterday, that Messrs. HOGG DELAMATER had withdrawn their application for space to exhibit ERICSSON'S Caloric Engine, constructed by them for that purpose. It seems to us that the public have a right to expect a full and fair test of this engine, with a view to a final settlement of its merits as a practical motor.

I have heard the remark that my notice of the three American sailors in prison here might be construed into reflection upon the late American Consul at Havana, which I can scarcely suppose possible, as I had no such purpose in mind; and when I do intend such application, my language is too plain to be misunderstood.

Everybody goes behind the Great HorseShoe Fall,-I mean, of course, everybody that is anybody. Only a cat's jump from the Table Rock is a house kept by a Jew, where you may buy bad brandy, and cigars made damp and soft by the spray of the cataract.

The Democratic Union, Watertown, of Friday, reports that during last week a fire commenced on the Plains, a few miles north of that place, which has done a great amount of damage. The flames spread with the rapidity of the wind, and the woods were soon a complete sea of fire. The destruction of property in the shape of green timber, has been, we understand, very extensive.

The United Stales Mail steamship Illinois. Lieut. H. J. HARTSTEINE, U. S. N., commanding. left Aspinwall on the evening of the Ist inst., and arrived at Quarantine on the morning of the 10th. In crossing the Caribbean Sea, she encountered very heavy weather, with strong head winds. She brings the California mails of the 16th July, and $1,301,743 in treasure on freight, and 291 passengers.

JONES, mason, for work and materials, $537; and with RYAN MITCHELL, painters, $420 The work is to be accemplished by the 15th of September.

From the Rochester Democrat. Some twenty-two years ago, there was born in this city to JOHN H. BISHOP, a colored man, wellknown to our citizens as a renovator of clothing, a son, whom he named after our still better known white fellow-citizen, WM. H. BISHOP, Esq.

CASTLE GARDEN.--This evening will be presented ROSSINI'S Opera of the " Barber of Seville." The cast includes SONTAG. POZZOLINI, BADIALI, and ROVERE. During the music lesson in the second act, Madame SONTAG will sing the French air " Ah ! Vous Dirai je Maman," with the flute variations.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In answer to the communication of "Stranger," this morning, I, as a simple " Citizen," having no pecuniary interest in stages, would say that a man has no business to get into a stage with nothing but a " three dollar bill" to pay his fare with; and the driver did perfectly right in holdin on to the bill until he could conveniently get it changed.

MARTIN KOSZTA, a Hungarian, was successively Lieutenant-Colonel in the Hungarian Army, and Secretary of the Ministry of the Police.

Thermal waters are supposed by Dr. JAMES JOHNSON, of London, to act in three ways on the human machine: 1st, through the medium of sensation on the nervous system; 2d, through the agency of their temperature on the vascular system; and 3d, by means of their chemical contents on the secretory and excretory organs. That celebrated man had great confidence in the warm bath.

ENCOUNTER WITH A CHOCODILE.--Letters received in this city state that Rev. JOHN A BUTLER, formerly of South Boston, now a missionary of the American Board in South Africa, met with a narrow escape from death. He was traveling to Amah Congera, and was forced, in his way, to cross the river Umkomazl. which he attempted on horseback.

There is a very heavy fight on foot in Richmond, Va. It seems to have grown out of a refusal by the Trustees of Hampden Sidney College to confirm the nomination made by the Faculty of the Medical College, and their appointment of a gentleman not recominended by the Faculty, to fill the chair of Philosophy. A heavy fight we called it.

Uncle John had a clock standing in his kitchen which had but a single fault,--it wouldn't go. So long as Uncle stood by and kept the pendulum moving. it went wel! enough. The wheels were perfectly true, the weights sufficiently heavy, the tick strong and well-defined.

Our streets smell to heaven. Dirt, filth, decaying garbage and dead animals, fill all but the most respectable of them. It is just the season for all manner of Summer diseases to be bred. Neighboring cities are already suffering, and we take no unusual precautions.

To the Editor or the New-York Daily Times: Amid the loathsome farce which European diplomacy still has the unexampled impudence to perform, it does good to the heart to have such a bright spot to rest the eye upon as the gallant conduct of Captain INGRAHAM, U. S. Navy, at Smyrna, and the correspondent dignified behavior of the American diplomacy in Turkey, with regard to the case of the Hungarian refugee, Captain KOSZTA.

UNION COLLEGE INVESTIGATION.--The Senate Committee, consisting of Messrs. VANDERBILT, JONES and WARD, appointed to investigate the affairs of Union College, commenced their duties on Thursday last. Hon. JOHN C. SPENCER appeared before them in behalf of Dr NOTT.

We have received our Texas exchanges, the latest being from Galveston, 31st ult. An extra from the office of the Indianola Bulletin, issued on the afternoon of the 27th ult., says that on the morning of that day a destructive fire occurred at that place, which consumed four houses and their contents.

NEW BUILDINGS.-Messrs. CLARKE MILLER are about erecting four fine stores and dwelling-houses, an the corner of Grand and Sixth-streets. Ex-Alderman WHITS .Co., have started a Fringe and Tassel manufatory in Fifth, near Grand-street. Several persons are already employed, and it is expected in a short time to be able to manufacture from $3,000 to $4,000 worth of work, per week.

I presume you will acknowledge that although Texas lies on the outer verge of the world, still it is in the world. Events here do therefore belong to the TIMES, and you will readily admit them on your sheet, if it were only that the whole world may be represented therein in its rounded whole--not even a fraction absent.

Mr. ALEXANDER KUMPRESS, the pretended Earl of STIRLING, has certainly shown sagaci-ty, in the selection of the organs through which to press his claim to the fisheries upon the attestion of the American public; for he has hit upon probably the only two newspapers in the country, which would have given him and his absurd pretensions the slightest consideration.

What causes the curled leaf in the peach The disease is coming to be a serious one. Out in Western New-York, some of the culturists complain that they will have to abandon the peach crop entirely, unless a remedy is soon discovered. Where are the peach doctors? Come, gentlemen, turn out. Hasten to look after your patient. The peach is our special favorite, among ruits.

WASHINGTON PARK.--Mr. E. L. WHITE, florist and landscape gardener, has been appointed to superintend the completion of the Washington Park, at a salary of $1,500 per year. CURIOUS LARCENY CASE.--Last Saturday a resident of Gowanus, named Michael Shanikan, accompanied by two friends, called at the grocers-store kept by Michael Haviland, corner of Court-street and Hamilton-avenue.

The Cunard steamship Africa, from Liverpool Saturday, July 30, arrived at this port at an early hour yesterday morning. The steamer Lady Eglintoun, PATON commander, arrived off the Rock, mouth of the Mersey, at 3 o'clock Thursday morning, 28th ult., having made the trip in 11 days, 1 hour, mean time.

Interesting religious services were held in Providence, on Wednesday, on the occasion of the departure of Rev. JAMES McGREGOR BERTRAM and family, missionary, for his station at St. Helena. Mr. BERTRAM sailed in the bark Warren White. His field is principally among the sailors who touch at that Island.

PROTECTIVE ASSOCIATION.--A meeting of this Society was held Wednesday night at POWERS' Montgomery Hall, No. 70 Prince-street. Mr. ROBERT BROCK, the President, in the Chair. ROBERT DWYER, the Secretary, read the minutes of the last meeting. He also read a report which he had drawn up, giving an account of the condition of the Society.

The Coroner's inquest on the bodies of persons killed by the disaster on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, has returned a verdict, charging the collision upon the conductor of the train from New-York, whose fault consisted in not comparing his watch with that in the Company's office,--and explicitly acquitting the Company from all blame whatever.

MEETING OF EIGHT REFORMERS OF THE BOD POLITIC.--For some time past, certain individuals, citizens of New-York, have been consulting together, and holding private meetings, preparatory to laying before the country their views upon the necessity of reform in the management of our Geneal and State Gavernments, as well as in Municipal matters, and also upon the expediency of the adoption of the Free Land question,

The knowing ones here are intensely amused at STERLING'S fishery claim. It was presented to this Government long since, but was never deemed worthy of investigation. The original ALEXANDER, Lord STIRLING, long prior to the Revolution, made over his Nova Scotia grant, right and title, such as it was, to another.

The Richmond Enquirer says: "We are gratified, as will be the whole country, to learn that the elaborate statistics of the Census of 1850 are now in the hands of the public printer, and are being passed through them with all the rapidity that the extensive machinery and manual power of the office will admit.

YELLOW FEVER AT NEW-ORLEANS.--The total number of deaths in New-Orleans, during the 24 hours ending at 6 A. M. on the 9th inst., were 182, of which 164 were from yellow fever; and during the 24 hours ending at the same hour on the 10th, the total number was 224, including 184 by yellow fever.

The steamboat Robt. Campbell arrived last night. She is owned by the fur-traders, whose posts are situated on the Upper Missouri, and makes a trip annually to the mouth of the Yellow-Stone, for the purpose of carrying up supplies of goods for the trade, and bringing down heaver and other skins and Buffalo robes.

AN EXTRAORDINARY MAN.--DAVID WILSON, an old revolutionary soldier, and a native of NewJersey, died after a short illness, in Dearborit County, Indiana, in August, 1853, aged one hundred and seven years, two months and ten days. He had, at different periods of his life, five wives and at the time of his death, was the father of forty-seven children.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As a constant reader of your sheet, and as one deeply interested in the prosperity of Brook lyn, as well as her fair fame, I claim the privilege of a few lines, to avert in part, at least, the severity of your satire in yesterday's TIMES against the "City of Repose."

Thursday night, about 11 3/4 o'clock, while officer BOWEN of the Ninth Police District, was patrolling his beat, he observed a young woman of genteel appearance wandering through the Sixth. avenue, near Fourteenth-street, in a mysterious manner. The officer approached the female, and made inquiry for her name and residence; but she refused to give either.

We are indebted to the kindness of Mr. MILLS, who is intrusted with the putting up of GREENOUGH'S ground of marble statues lately received at the Navy Yard, for the following descriptive information as to the group This group is the workmanship of the celebrated American sculptor GREENOUGH and is to be placed on the basis of the great staircase of the Capitol at Washington.

The annual circular of the University of Louisiana of 1852-3 has been laid upon our table. From it we learn that the number of matriculants of the past year was 219, and of medical graduates 72. The register of matriculants contains 1,700 names. The museum of anatomy is very extensive.

Our columns groan again with reports of wholesale slaughter by Railroad trains. Hard upon the heels of the catastrophe upon the Camden and Amboy road, come tidings of a similar and still more dreadful disaster upon the road between Providence and Worcester.

The Washington Star publishes the following list of new patents, issued during the week ending Aug. 9, 1853: Samuel Canby. of Ellicott's Mills, Md. for improvement in winnowers of grain. Flank gibbon and Lewis Rollman, of New-York, N. Y., for improvements in multiplying gearing.

In another part of this morning's TIMES, we publish a report of a month's doings at the Five Points House of Industry. The Report is full of interest, as all information concerning the progress of reform must ever he. The locality is one where crime, in all its hideous varieties, flourished for many years.

The shipyards, in which business, for the past two months, has been dull, have begun to assume an appearance of briskness. Orders for fast clipper-ships--the great proportion being for the California and China trade-are coming in from our enterprising merchants; and builders, in anticipation of future profits, and the absorbing rivalry of their profession, brighten up, half forgetting the losses which a sudden rise in materials and labor entailed on the contracts of last year.

CONSOLIDATION.--The Commissioners assembled yesterday at the County Jail. when the President, Commissioner KALBFLESCH stated that he understood the Brooklyn Common Council would be convened on Monday or Tuesday, and in order to afford an opportunity for the appointment of Commissioners from Brooklyn, to represent that City in their deliberations, the Board adjourned until Wednesday next, without transacting any business.

Disagreeable necessity obliges us to shock the sensibilities of our readers, by the recital of another terrible calamity from a collision of Railway trains. At 8 o'clock, yesterday morning, a collision occurred on the Providence and Worcester Railroad, which caused the death of fourteen persons, and seriously injured about forty more.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the Washington Correspondence of the TIMES, published on the 21st and 22d ult., we notice some remarks, which we think are calculated to convey very erroneous ideas, and, at the same time, create injurious impressions in regard to us and our business.

SOUTH OYSTER BAY, L. I.--On Thursday last, a Ladies' Fair was held in a large building on the extensive grounds occupied by -- CUMMINGS, Esq , as South Oyster Bay. The proceeds arising therefrom are to be appropriated to the parting and decoration of "Grace Church." Episcopil.

The Washington Union Copies from the TIMES the narrative of the long imprisonment and final escape of Capt. WALTER M. GIBSON, and appends the following remarks: From the same source we learn that an investigation was commenced by Mr. WEBSTER, as Secretary of State, but that it was arrested by his death.

Commodore SHUBRICK'S dispatches to the Navy Department were under consideration in the Cabinet session to-day. It was a prolonged session. The character of the Commodore's communications is unknown to outsiders yet, but it is rumored that the Commodore is apprehensive of a collision.
