CASTLE GARDEN.--Italian Opera Company. BURTON' THEATRE.--Luck the Laborer--A Day After the Fair--Rappings. NATIONAL THEATRE..-Uncle Tom's Cabin,

In Brooklyn L. I. on Wednesday afternoon, Aug. 10, JOHN G., youngest son of Samuel and Mary Fuller, aged 17 years, 6 months and 22 days His friends those of his parents, his brothers. James M. and Junius A Fuller, as well as those of his brothers-in-law. M F Gale and Thomas N. Rooker, are respect fully invited to attend his funeral on Sunday afternoon 4 o'clock, at St. Ann's Church Washington st, Brooklyn.

TWENTY SEVEN PERSONS KILLED BY HEAT OF THE WEATHER YESTERDAY.--The intense heat of yesterday produced some truly effects in the City. No less than TWENTY-SEVEN persons were prostrated by "sun-strokes," and lost their lives. The Coroners were occupied during the entire day in holding inquests. Annexed is a list of those cases returned to the Coroner's Office up to the hour of closing last night:

From the Albany Evening Journal. We see it reported that M. BODISCO, the Russian Minister, has undertaken to muzzle a Washington newspaper, after the fashion of St. Petersburg. We hope he will have "a good time." This reminds us of an incident we have heard related of this gentleman, in the earlier days of his mission.

All earthly things are transitory, and therefore even a College Commencement comes at last, and comes to an end, with all its preliminaries, concomitants and corrollaries ; with all its associa tions, funny, tender and dignified. The great day at Amherst has passed, and the world will return again to its ordinary, humdrum, every-day "revolutions and solar and lunar influences, and various gameA of that sort," for which see philosophical reflections of Sampson Brass.

They tell a good story of an old-fashioned, wealthy codger of this ilk. He was never known to have anything in the line of new apparel but once; then he was going on a journey, and had to purchase a new pair of boots. The stage left before day, and so he got ready and went to the hotel to stop for the hight.

The National Association for the Advancement of Education, commenced its session here yesterday. Prof. JOSEPH HENRY was chosen President, to succeed Bishop POTTER, and on taking the chair made a brief address, mainly devoted to a sketch of his own life.

A passenger train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, while passing the switch, at Cameron, 27 miles east of Wheeling, to-day, ran off the track, and three cars, containing over one hundred passengers, were upset, but fortunate to relate,

The past month has been one of much anxiety. many difficulties, and constant labor. Filthy streets, with the rain and excessive heat of Summer, have rendered our position by no means a comfortable one. It was not until compelled by the sickness of Mrs. P., to leave the City for a few hours to accompany her to a pleasant retreat near Troy, that we discovered the great difference between country and Five Point air.

CASTLE GARDEN.-Notwithstanding the unusual altitude of the thermometer, there was another good attendance last evening. This may be accounted for by the fact, that the river esplanade, or balcony, of Castle Garden is, on all occasions of extreme heat, one of the coolest places accessible to New-Yorkers.

Very perceptible progress has been made in the Picture Gallery, during the past few days, and tile painters are busily engaged in putting on the various colors. This splendid gallery will be one of the most pleasant features of the Exhibition, always provided the pictures are equal to the gallery in their way. From what we have seen of the pic.

THE NOVEL HAS BECOME A MISSONARY.Principles are propagated, attacked and defended by novels. The most abstract problems of metaphysics, the different systems of politics and religions, are no longer confined to long and dry treatises and dissertations-they have assumed the attractive form of the novel.

COUPS D'SOLIEL.-A man named NASH, while attending to some business in East Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, was prostrated by the heat. He was attended by Dr. BRADY. A man residing at the foot of North Tenth street, named PATRICK O'DONNELL, while at work in the Pennsylvania Coal Yard, at the foot of North Eighth-street, was struck by the sun's rays. He was attended by Dr. GREGORY.

" POOR RICHARD" REPUDIATED.--A writer in Blackwood's Magazine comes down upon the over-prudent men of the day in the following style: " We have no hesitation in saying that we consider the man who does not expend more than half his income, as a caitiff and a losel.

The prizes, medals, decorations, and honorary mentions won by the artists of the Exposition just closed, were distributed on Tuesday at the Louvre. The Emperor had commissioned his cousin, NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, to preside. As I have already given you specimens of this gentleman's eloquence, I need only say of his speech that its only merit consisted in its extreme brevity.

We have the New Orleans papers of the 5th inst-as late as due. The Bee says of the prevailing epedemic: "If the disease has not yet attained its acme, we can scarcely say when it will do so. One hundred and fifty-one deaths in a single day from amongst a moiety only of our population, presents a most appalling record.

The Grand Jury has done its duty. Itsmembershave fearlessly denounced some of the evils that hang over us, and that threaten us with wide-spread disaster. The condition of our streets, and the criminal neglect of our public officers, would not allow them to be silent.

ST. THOMAS'S CHURCH CASE.--To the Public : I have shown by testimony, "the utter base lessness and malignity of the scandalous and repeated insinuations," and assertions "to" my "prejudice" of Dr SCHROEDER and HENRY WHITTAKER, of the "Authors of the Statement and Appeal," respecting "the defacing" of the "marble font," "the ribald injury to the record of God's mercy and man's salvation," and the "fraudulent" character of my "claims against" St. Thomas's "Church."

CRANFORD: BY THE AUTHOR OF "MARY BARTON," AND "RUTH " We have read this little work with real delight. Such a welcome contribution toEnglish literature has not been made since the publication of Miss MITFORD'S Our Village; a work which, without the faintest tint of plagiarism, it may be said to resemble. It is a charming book,-the work of a true woman. No man could have written it.

For other City News of this morning set Sixth Page. Amusements This Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--English Opera Company. CASTLE GARDEN.--Italian Opera Company. BURTON'S THEATERS.--A Duel in the Dark--A Day After the Fair--Rappings. BROADWAY THEATER.--Ladies beware--The Forest Roe--A wife for a Day. NATIONAL THEATER--Uncle Tom's Cabin.

FOREIGN METHOD OP CHECKING BAGGAGE.-We find by one of our foreign exchanges, an account of a new method for checking baggage, which, we think, may be of interest to our friends on this side of the Atlantic. It has been introduced upon one or two of the leading English roads, and is said to answer the design admirably.

A hired ruffian, named Wendisch, attacked Alderman Malerz in a brutal manner, as he was about leaving Military Hall, on Thursday evening. They were separated before either party had sustained any injury.

The effects of the present unusually hot weather are truly tragical, and resemble more the results of an epidemic, than the ordinary consequences of an increased temperature. Since Tuesday morning no less than 188 deaths have occurred, in this City alone, that have been brought under the Coroners' notice, the whole of which were either from direct exposure to the sun's rays, or from overexertion in heated atmosphere.

The Castle Garden Opera season draws to a close. Only half a dozen performances remain Signor MARINI, the talented and popular basso, reappears to-night, for the first time since the accident on Long Island, which resulted in the loss of part of his right hand. Much sympathy was felt and expressed at the time for Signor M. in this misfortune, and he will, no doubt, be cordially welcomed on his return to the stage.

The closing scene of the late dreadful stragedy, the inquest of the Coroner, commenced yesterday afternoon, and has been continued to-day, but not brought toa close. The inquest was held in the Town Hall. at Valley Falls, before GEORGE L. DANA, Esq., upon the bodies of Mr. and Mrs PLANT, WM. FULLERLOVE, A. CHARLESWORTH and THOMAS BROWN, of Whitinsville; W. W. WOOD, and JOHN S. PERKINS, of Uxbridge, and JONATHAN BROWN of Northbridge.

The steamship Black Warrior, J. D. BULLOCH, U. S. N., Commander, arrived on Saturday morning, from Mobile and Havana. She left the former port on the 6th, and Havana on the 9th inst., at 9 o'clock A. M., making four days and one hour from Havana. The following letter from our correspondent gives all the news of interest:

We have no epidemic here to set us into a panic. Death does his work quietly, without frightening his victims before their time, or alarming survivors. The number of deaths reported to the City Inspector, for the week ending at 2 o'clock of Saturday, was 585, which is 14 more than the week preceding, and 18 more than the average of the corresponding week last year.

Great injustice is done to American Commerce by the action of the Government concerning the Chinese mission. Mr. MARSHALL, but recently appointed, is now there, and is doubtless competent to perform all the duties of the place. But the new Administration has seen fit to recall him, and appoint Mr. WALKER in his stead. This is well enough,--if they would only send him.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: "Common Sense," in his article in to-day's paper, headed " Stage-Drivers," says, "Please inform 'Stranger' that four three-cent pieces in this 'village' go for 121/2 cents." True, but suppose I give the stage-driver, orany other driver, an American quarter of a dollar, which all admit to be twenty-five cents, that he may take out two fares of six cents each-are four, three cent pieces the right change!

From the Boston Advertiser. The following letter will be of interest to those who have contributed to the relief of the suffering people of Madeira: FLAG-SHIP CONSTITUTION, MADSIBA. Funchal, July 2, 1853. DEAR SIR: A letter, purporting to come from the United States steamer Powhatan, dated Funchal, March 6, has recently gone the rounds of the American papers.

SEVOLA CAZOTTE is the name of an aged Frenchman, who died at Paris on the 21st June last, aged 91 years. In his youth, he came to America as a soldier in the French armed expedition, under Count O'ESTAING, which besieged Savannah during our Revolution.

An item was published under our Williamsburg bead, a few days since, stating that Dr. JAMES NEWMAN, of that city, had been arres ed and committed on charge of perjury. We have since seen a certificate signed by J A. RUE, the complainant, and his Attorney, JOHN D HOYT. Esq , stating that the charge has been withdrawn, as it "originated in a misunderstanding."

Although the organ is justly considered the king of all instruments, enabling, as it does, a tolerable performer to execute nearly every piece of orchestral music-yet the subject of this division of our analysis has become so familiarized to us, that it is almost impossible to view it in an inferior light. A piano has become a domestic necessity.

The telegraph brings us the mournful intelligence of the death of Brevet Lieutenant Colonel W. W. S. BLISS, Assistant Adujutant General, U. S. A. The trite adage, " Death loves a shining mark," is, in this case, most singularly confirmed. A more meritorious and promising officer the army could not boast than was Col. BLISS.

We have received Vera Cruz dates to the 7th inst., and City of Mexico to the 21st ult. The Government have called upon the Governors of States for correct returns of all foreigners residing in Mexico without license. with a view of imposing a fine or imprisonment upon them. Galveston dates to the 5th inst. are received. They convey a few election returns, but nothing definite.

Fable tells us of an alliance once formed by the bear, the wolf, and the hoar, which however convenient for themselves, boded no good to the other beasts of the forest. They agreed to hunt in company--dividing the spoil equally among themselves; and if their intended victims should be out of their reach, one of the parties was to act the part of a disinterested mediator, and decoy them from their place of refuge.

It is warm, even here in the country, while we are enjoying our blessed leisure beneath the thick foliage of weeping willows, where the refreshing south breeze comes up every evening from its river bath, and a fine water melon even now cools our mouth. Then what must it be for you, in the City, sweltering beneath a thousand hot bricks, without one breath of fresh air toiling in your office,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your article in the TIMES of the 13th, does by not meet the evil of which you complain; and with all the power of the press against these wholesale murders, with the license you approve, the Railroads will continue to kill by dozens. True, the heart sickens; but you forget that while dozens slain, themselves go unharmed."

FILTHY STREETS.-The Grand Jury of NewOrleans have made a presentment with regard to the present state of the city, in which they say: " Without discussing the question whether this epidemic is of foreign or local origin, we have no hesitation in saying that the disease, if not genrated, has been greatly augmented by the filthy condition of the city.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In a recent issue of your valuable journal, I observed a correspondence between Judge E. JERVIS, of Lancaster, Pa., and Mr. WISE, the Aeronaut, in reference to the feasibility of crossing the Atlantic by means of a balloon. The subject is undoubtedly one of the greatest interest, and deserves the attention of every person who is capable of understanding its importance.

On Saturday CATHARINE KENNEDAY went to Trenton, in the care of the keeper of the County Jail, to appear before Chief Justice GREEN, on a writ of habeas corpus. The case was argued before the Chief Justice by J. W. SCUDDER, Esq., for the prosecution, and Jude NEVIUS for the defence. R. McCLELLAND, Jr., was also present in behalf of the girl.

It is quite clear that the Pacific Railroad is to be pressed upon the country as an Administration measure. Hon. JEFFERSON DAVIS, during the recent tour of the Cabinet, sufficiently betrayed this fact in his various speeches. The measure will be popular with the whole country, except, perhaps, the school of Virginia abstractionists and the smaller party of strict constructionists at the North, who try hard to follow in the Virginia footsteps.

The funeral of Rev. SAMUEL PENNY, late of Rhode Island, whose death wrs caused by the collision near Providence, Aug. 12. will take place on Tuesday, l6th, at 4 P. M., from the residence of nis brother in-law, A. S. Marvin. No 77 State st., Brooklyn. His friends. and the friends of the family, are requested to attend without further invitation.

A pleasant gathering of the Instructors of the Institutions for the Deaf and Dumb in the United States, took place this morning at this breezy and hospitable quarter. Perhaps it borders on rashness to say that it is " breezy," for wind and air are at a great discount in this flat Western country. The sun shines with uncommon power.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 180 191 Water

CASTLE GARDEN.--It certainly must be a difficult thing to consult the public taste. Any ordinary person would have supposed that such a scarce opera as "Ernani" would have attracted an immense audience. It is so long since it has been performed, and is so justly estimated as one of the most able productions of the modern Italian school, that everything seemed to promise such a result. Notwithstanding, the house was thinly, badly attended.

The thunder-storm last night was very severe in this vicinity. At Georgetown the Baptist parsonage house was struck, and the wife of Rev. Mr. RUSSELL, the pastor, instantly killed. A child in her arms escaped injury. At Goveland the house of WILLIAM FOWLER was struck, and Mr. F. and wife knocked down senseless, but they afterward recovered.

TWENTY-THREE YEARS IN THE WATER--FOUND AT LAST.--Some twenty-three years ago in the year 1830--a man named Mr. McCLAY was missing from the neighborhood of Mr. HITNER'S quarries, Marble Hall, about five miles below the borough He was, at the time of the accident about 60 years of age.

Rumor, always a meddlesome goddess, has certainly taken an active part in the pending disputes between the Sultan and the Czar. She has been, from the very beginning, a most prominent actress, and her peculiar province appears to have been to cover with confusion the counsellors of France and England, and to promote in every possible way the interests and designs of the Autocrat.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I am in the country rusticating. To-day I have just got your paper of yesterday. In it I find a Saratoga reverie of Minnie Myrtle. I have no doubt sentimental juveniles will much relish this Miss Minnie's compositions. They evince care. They abound in sweetness. Unmarked by any great profundity of thought, their style is nevertheless easy and graceful.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have just finished reading the TIMES' report of the second day's proceedings of the Educational Convention at Pittsburg. and must ac knowledge myself particularly edified by the fanciful remarks of Professor HALDEMAN of Pennsylvania.
A curious statement has just been prepared, of the number and nations of the several visitors to SHAKESPEARE'S house, at Stratford-upon-Avon.

An evening paper intimates that Mr. WALKER'S delay in setting out upon his Chinese mission may be due to his desire to attend to some business interests which he has in Wisconsin. We hope the suggestion has no better foundation than conjecture, and that no private considerations will prevent Mr. WALKER from taking his departure at the earliest possible moment.

THE SUBURBS OF NEW-YORK.--In estimating the wonderful, yet inevitable growth of our City, few take into proper consideration the extent and importance of its suburbs, and their future destiny. Brooklyn, Williamsburg, and Jersey City, although the natural offsprings of our Metropolis are now cities by themselves, and are, moreover, separated from us by the rivers.

More Coroners' Inquests--Forty Additional Deaths Recorded Yesterday-Unfounded Rumors of Yellow Fever at Quarantine. The extensive list of deaths from the excessive heat of Saturday and Sunday, which we published yesterday, did not comprise nearly all the fatal cases that occurred on those days.

ATTEMPT TO ROB A BRIG AND MURDER THE CAPTAIN.--ONE OF THE RIVER THIEVES SHOT DEAD, AND ANOTHER WOUNDED.--About daybreak, on-Sunday morning, the cabin of the brig Alfred Hammond, Capt. THAYER, lying at the foot of Delancy-street, was entered by four thieves, who seized the captain while asleep, chocked him, and attempted to force him through the cabin windows. He, however, awaking, and extricating himself from their grasp, gave the alarm.

Hon. JAMES MAURICE has addressed a letter to the Glen Cove Plaindealer, which commences as follows: "JAMES L. CROWLEY, Esq.--Dear Sir: In your last week's paper you devoted a large space to the consideration of a subject purely political, growing out of a letter addressed by me directly to my constituents and intended exclusively for them.

Gunpowder, broad pennants and epauletted visits have been the order of the day between the British and American Fishing Squadrons, now at anchor in this capacious and splendid harbor. The U. S. steamer Princeton, Capt. EAGLE, bearing Com. SHUBRICK and his flag, came handsomely into port last night at 8 o'clock, notwithstanding the weather was dense with fog and rain.

For other City News of this morning see Third Page. Amusements This Evening. Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Performance by the Ravel Family. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Yankee Land-Wife for a Day-To Paris and Back. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin.

The Bulletin says the record for the week ending yesterday morning at 6 o'clock, is terrible. We have no words whereby we can characterise the fearfulness of the scourge. The plain statement,--the mute but awful figures,--tell the tale, concisely, but appallingly.

The U. S. mail steamer Humboldt, Capt. LINES, arrived last evening from Havre vid Southampton, bringing intelligence and files four days later than had been before received. The Humboldt brings 186 passengers and 630 tons of merchandise. Amongst the names of the passengers we notice S. B. GOODRICH, Esq., late U. S. Consul at Paris; Hon. CALEB LYON, of Lyons dale, member of Congress from New-York, and Hon. CHARLES A MANN, of Utica.

On Sunday evening, Aug. 14, 1853, after a short illness, of dysentery, Mrs ABIGAL ADEE, in the 83d year of her age wife of the late David Adee, Esq Her remains will be taken to Chatham, Columbia Co., N. Y. for interment. Albany papers please copy. On Monday, Aug. 15 HANNAH, widow of Joseph Brown, aged 70 years and 6 months.

Many of your readers will doubtless be interested to hear of the semi-centennial celebration of Bacon Academy, located in Colchester, Go Not a few of them have, at some time, been connected with this institution. It is beautifully situated in one of the most beautiful villages of New-England, and during its fifty years' history, has clustered around itself many precious and hallowed associations.
The following is a table of the interments for the week ending at 6 A. M., Saturday, the 6th inst., as furnished by the Secretary of the Board of Health.

The arguments in the India-Rubber Case were closed this morning; and Judge PITMAN intimated that he would immediately proceed to prepare his opinion. The decision will probably be made in the course of a week. The opening argument on the main question was made by T. A. JENKS, Esq., for DAY, the complainant. It was a clear and powerful statement of the complainant's position.

CHURNING BY ITSELF.--A machine similar to that for "rocking the baby," as noticed by us a little time ago, has been got up by a man named CRANE. with the difference that the baby rocker went by watch power, while this operated by clock power.

FOURTH AND LAST DAY---FORENOON SESSION Meeting opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. BRADFOED. Records of preceding day read and approved. The Secretary, R. L. COOKE, Esq, read a letter from Hon. HENRY BARNARD, of Connecticut, apologizing for his absence, and expressing his interest in the Association. Rev. Dr. AGNEW then addressed the Association on the subject of Female Education.

Some returned Californians give the following account of the great battle between Indians already referred to. The contest was between the Sioux tribe, aided by the Cheyennes, in all 5.000 strong, and the Paronies, aided by the Jawas, Sacs, Pottawotamies, numbering about 3,000. The fight lasted all day, the killed on both sides being from 500 to 600. It took place within 50 miles of Fort Kearney, and the Sioux party were defeated.

The Humboldt brings us an interesting budget of intelligence. The aspect of the difficulty between Russia and Turkey is not materially changed; certainly, not for the better. The Earl of CLARENDON, has stated, very explicitly, that the Emperor of Russia must forthwith evacuate the Danubian Principalities.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : We are off, at last, and beginning to realize what has been the subject of anticipation for many days. And here we are in the first stage of our flight. How like magic is the change from the hot and dusty streets of the Metropolis, which the fierce midsummer sun turns to a furnace, to the cool, fresh air of the country.

The annual trials of skill at the Conservatoire de Musique et de Declamation, are now in progress. One day is devoted to each speciality--to singing, to opera comique, commedy, tragedy, and to each different divertisement.

The following from the Crescent of the 9th, gives us a view of the mortality attending the epidemic, such as we do not receive from reading the statistics: On Sunday afternoon information was sent to the Mayor that numerous dead bodies were lying on the ground in the Lafayette Cemetery, unburied, for the want of force to perform the work of sepulture. The Chairman of the Committee on Ceme.

We have received files of papers from the City of Mexico to the 21st ult, and from Vera Cruz to the 27th The Orden of the 17th has a long article, in which it rabidly assails the press of the United States. Mexico and all that is Mexican. Spain and all that is Spanish, are said to he the especial marks at which this '' prostitute press" directs its "envenomed shafis."

GIBBON says the Turks are only encamped in Europe; and a prophecy long current-for over a century the weird and watchword of the House of ROMANOFF-HOLSTEIN--speaks of a time when that encampment shall be broken up. The Turks, themselves,
We are still suffering from excessive heat. Already there have been many deaths from this cause in the city. The thermometer at noon today, at MCALLISTER'S, stood at 96 1/2[Degrees].

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I, who lang syne addressed you on the subject of Railroads, beg leave to say a few words on the Statistics of Races in the United States. It has suited the purpose of political demagogues on the one hand, and Roman Hierarchs on the other very much to exaggerate both the Celtic and Roman element in the United States.

If there's a comfort in community, you are, doubtless, glad to hear that Shawmut is as hot as Manhattan-the mercury in our tubes floating between 96 and 101. For several years we have not had such a warm August.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: My attention has been called to an article in your paper of the 12th inst., headed " Asylum for Inebriates-once more." The writer is, doubtless, governed by a noble and philanthropic motive in calling public attention to his plan for saving the poor, miserable, degraded victims of the drinking usages of society and the grog-shops.

Our attention has been called to an instance which occurred about a year since, in which an American citizen, residing abroad, was subjected to the grossest outrage and injuries by the subordinates of a foreign Government, for which no redress has yet been received, although the particulars of the affair have been for some months on file in the State Department. The case is that of Dr. JAMES C.

On the 15th day of October, 1852, FRANCIS B. EDYMOIN, a young man, was convicted of burglary in the second degree. at. Owego, in the County of Tioga, and was sentenced to confinement at hard labor in the State Prison, at Auburn, for the term of five years.

Very marked progress has been made in the Machine Arcade and Picture Gallery, during the past two days. In the Arcade, there have been several machines unpacked and placed in position, including two very perfect machines for preparing and dressing flax, recently patented by the inventor, Mr. CHICHESTER, of this City.

PROVIDENCE AND WORCESTER RAILROAD--The Providence Journal, of the 16th, says: The Board of Directors of the Providence and Worcester Railroad were in session during the 15th inst., investigating the causes of the late collision.

SINGULAR CAUSE OF DEATH--On Saturday last, a young man, son of Mr. BOND, of the firm of BOND TIDD, curriers, Woburn, died; the circumstances attending his decease were remarkable. On Thursday last, while in his usual good health, he was called to remove some hides from a wagon;

The Cincinnati Commercial of Aug. 11 says the largest mass meeting ever assembled with in-doors in this city was held at the German Theatre last night. It was attended by German citizens of all parties, and embraced nearly all the influential men of that Class of our fellow-citizens. The proceedings were had in the German language.

From the N. O. Picayune. It appears that the disease which brought to so untimely and unexpected an end the life of this eminent and accomplished officer, was a bilious remittent fever. The first symptoms were visible yesterday a week ago. The lamented deceased had been at Pascagoula since the 16th June, not coming to the city once during the period that has elapsed since then.

Ex-Governor PAINE, of Vermont, at the time of his death, was engaged, in connection with several other Northern gentlemen of ability and enterprise. in exploring the route for a railroad through the State of Texas, intended to be one link in the great road leading to the Pacific.

On Saturday evening there was a gentle shower, accompanied by distant thunder and considerable lightning. Last evening, a heavy shower set in about dark, with heavy thunder and lightning. Rain fell in considerable quantities. A correspondent at Byfield writes us that that the storm in the vicinity of Byfield, Georgetown, and Haverhill, was the most terrific ever experienced in that region. The wind was Southwest.

FROM TAMPA BAY.--From a letter in the New-Orleans Picayune, dated Aug 3, 1853 we learn that the Indian news, by a boat from Fort Myers, was that " BILLY BOWLEGS had failed to come in at the post, though he had promised to do so directly after the "Green Corn Dance" This was over about the middle of June.

We have received Galveston dates to the 5th inst., and a full file of other Texan papers. The Civilian Gazette (Galveston) of the 2d inst., has the following items: The receipts for import duties at the port of Galveston, during the year ending March 31, 1853, were $25,072.

DISTRESSING CASE OF SALF-DESTRUCTION.MANCHESTER, N. H., Aug. 15 Last evening, at 6 o'clock, two young ladies, named CATHARINE B. COTTON, of Pownal, Me., aged 22, and CLARA B COCHRAN, of New Boston, N. H., aged 19, and jumpped into the canal in this City and were drowned. It is said that they had long contemplated the deed. Last evening, while eating supper, one said to the other--"Eat heartily, for you know this is the last."

A writer in the Picayune traces the Yellow Fever, that now desolates New-Orleans, to the men who discharged the cargo of the ship Adelaide, from Rio Janeiro. He says three successive gangs employed upon that job, sickened. He contends that every epidemic of the sort recorded, can be traced to importation.

The Philadelphia Ledger files to the defence of the Camden and Amboy Railroad with all the promptness, and more than the zeal, of a paid attorney. It declares the late disaster to have been " one of those unforeseen events that no human foresight can prevent," and pronounces the " arrangements of the Road to be as perfect as a single-track Railroad can be made."

YELLOW FEVER AT SEA.--We published a dispatch from Norfolk a few days since, with regard to the ravages of the yellow fever on board the ship National Eagle, of Boston, from New-Orleans for Liverpool, which had been spoken off the Capes of Delaware. The Captain of the steamer Roanoke, which spoke the Eagle, has furnished the Richmond papers with the following report:

The U. S. M steamship Florida, MERRITT S. WOODHULL. Commander, arrived yesterday in 57 hours from Savannah. On Sunday, at 10 o'clock P. M., 20 miles north of Cape Hatteras, she exchanged signals with steamship Augusta, hence for Savannah; same time exchanged signals with the steamship James Adger, for Charleston. Among the passengers by the Florida is Hon. HOWELL COBB ex-Governor of Georgia.

The Royal Mail steamship America, Capt. LANG, arrived at this port, en route for Boston, at 4 o'clock this afternoon, having left Liverpool at 9 A. M. on Saturday, the 6th inst. She brings 114 through passengers.

A NEW AN ESTHETIC.--At a recent meeting of the London Medical Society, Mr. RICHARDSON read a paper "On the Anaesthetic Properties of the Common Puff-Ball (Lycoperdon Proteus)." His attention was directed to the subject by the fact that in some parts of the country bees are stupefied by this agent before extracting the contents of the hive.

The people on the Isthmus of Panama complain greatly of the difficulty of getting vaccine matter in such condition as to be of any service. The Herald, of Panama, says that though he has known a good deal brought in, he has never known a case where it was successfully used.

We have received New-Orleans papers to the loth inst. The dates by telegraph are later, and show that the deaths by yellow fever are still increasing. The True Delta says: We had hoped, nay, expected, that the season was over, but we reckoned without our lost.

Our City column records another of those fearful outrages which, if they were less common, would startle the community with horror. A man, named FOGARTY, went to his home on Monday night, and, without the slightest provocation, began to beat his wife.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--On Monday evening, the monthly meeting of this Association was hell at their rooms, in the Stuyvesant Institute, Broadway. The attendance was numerous, considering the state of the weather.

Kate Hayes, at last accounts, was creating a great furore at Valaparaiso. Biscaccianti was shortly expected at the same place. Frank Earnest and Earnest Lubec were at Santiago, performing on the piano and guitar to crowded houses, patrouized by the Chilian President and all the Jesuits.

If all that is said of the Harlem Bridge be true, then will it some day surpass the famous Venetian Bridge, in the agonies it will witness, and the shrieks it will hear. That it is sufficiently elevated, and the pipe-stems that support it, ancient and slender enough, few of the many who have traveled over it have failed to perceive.

At Montgomery, Ala., on Sunday, 14th inst., on his was home from New-Orleans, JOHN CLARK, Jr., formerly of Boston, Mass. and late merchant of this City. In this City. on the 17th inst., EDWARD WALWORTH, son of Edward A. and Edna M. Price, aged 1 year, 5 months and 20 day.

HORRIBLE AFFAIR.--A desperate and deliberate number was committed in Gasconada County, Missouri, on the night of the 27th ult., by STEPHEN HOWSER, on the person of WILLIAM FARRIS. The murderer, the deceased, and others, had been spending the day together at a country store, and some difficulty had occurred between them in consequence of the refusal of deceased to play a game of cards proposed by HOWSER.

WRECK OF THE ATLANTIC.--We learn from the Buffalo Rough Notes. of Saturday, that arrangements have been completed for raising, or attempting to raise, the wreck of the steamer Atlantic, and what the attempt is to be made to-day. The Rough Notes states that the hulks of two steamers, the Madison and the Lexington, have been taken for the purpose.

GENTLEMEN : I have the honor to acknowledge your letter of the 14th inst., containing the inquity: "Whether, in the event of American property being destroyed or plundered by the rebels, we should he enabled, through the United States Goven merit, to recover the value thereof."

AND ESCAPE ARREST.-A man well known in the upper part of Grand-street. in company with several others, on Tuesday evening started upon a " spree." In Grandstreet, near Union-avenue, they attacked and knocked down several persons. Subsequently, they went into a small store, kept by Mrs MARSTON, and. after destroying whatever came within their reach, threw Mrs. M. over the counter, and otherwise ill-used her.

The Gobelin Tapestries and the specimens of Sevres Porcelain from the Government establishments of France, which have been awaited with so much anxiety, have at last arrived, and the workmen were busily engaged yesterday in putting them in their proper places. We believe only five pieces of the Gobelin tapestry were displayed yesterday.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Time : It would seem, from almost daily reports, that our railroads are fast becoming instruments of human slaughter, and to a terrific extent. As you say in your issue of the 13th, " these accidents are all unnecessary." In truth, do you not compromise the matter in calling them "accidents"?

QUICK MOVEMENTS OF A MAN-OF-WAR.-The U. S. ship Cyane, HOLLINS, commander, reached the outer entrance of Hampton Roads near sunset on Friday, the 12th inst. About 71/2 P. M. she was in tow of the steamer Selden, Capt. HICKS, and by 12 P. M. she was safely moored off the Fort.

FROM ST. THOMAS.--We have news from St. Thomas to August 3. There had been an insurrection among the negroes at the island of Tortola, one of the Caribbean Islands s, under British rule. A number of persons had been slain and the town burned. The whites were fleeing,

SINGULAR ASSAULT.--The Traveller relates a singular story of an assault upon a Mrs. HOGAN, of Charleston, which took place at Washington Village on Sunday. Mrs. HOGAN was sitting under a tree, in conversation with her brother-in law, "when a vicious cow grazing near them rushed up behind, and without the least warning attacked" Mrs. HOGAN and her brother-in-law."

The trial of the impeachment of Canal Commissioner MATHER has commenced at Albany, and will probably drag its slow length along for month or two. It will be inconceivably dull from beginning to end. The first day was occupied with a long argument in favor of striking out certain of the charges; the second was devoted to a long argument against it.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE FARMERS' CLUB.-The regular monthly meeting of the Club was held Tuesday at the rooms of the Institute in Broadway.-LAWTON, Esq., occupied the Chair. The subject chosen for discussion was entitled ' Soiling, and the best plants for it."

Eagle, apparently authorized, says that "the office was tendered to Gov. Briggs some three months ago, since which time he has had the matter under advisement, up to within a few days, when he consented to accept the appointment."

A correspondent, in another column, narrates the treatment of an American citizen by the authorities of France. His name was PETTY; and he seems to have shipped on an American whaler, deserted her and embarked on a French hark as sailing-master.

The President, MARTIN KALBFLEISCH,

CASTLE GARDEN.--"I Puritani" attracted an unusually large attendance last evening. Considering the number that were undoubtedly detined by the storm, it is certain that "Puritani" is the most popular of any recent reproduction. We are glad of it. The enterprise of the management is deserving, and must achieve success.

Not a thousand miles away from this City, which we are fond of regarding as the centre of christianized intelligence, lies a district of country containing a population of some 113,000 people. Captain GIRSON is engaged at the State Department making out a brief of his case from about three thousand pages of documents. The subject is to be presented to the Cabinet next Friday, if possible. Mr. BELMONT had already been instructed to make inquiry at the Hague, into the case, and will probably now receive instructions for his positive action.

SINGULAR HALLUCINATION.--A young man of about 24 years was last evening brought to the Second District Station House, and confined therein for his singular conduct in the streets. Upon being interrogated by the officer in attendance to ascertain whether he was sane or crazy, he told the official in answer to a question put to him concerning the cause of his singular conduct. "that he was either a trotting horse or a jackass."

APALACHICOLA.-The Apalachicola Advertiser of the 3d inst., recommends the adoption of measures to prevent the introduction of yellow fever front New-Orleans. It says: We would suggest respectfully to the city authoritles the propriety of enforcing the quarantine laws on all vessels coming from New-Orleans.

The arrival in this city of the group of statuary executed by Mr. GREENOUGH, under a vote of Congress, for the embellishment lishment of the Capitol, has been announced, accompained with a brief description. The work has not been examined since its arrival in this country, but arrangements are now in progress for putting it in the position which it is destined to occupy.

The registration of births, marriages, and deaths, is coming into general favor in the United States, as for a long time it has been in the best informed and most politic countries of Europe. The advantages to be derived from a well-devised system of registration are so obvious, that it seems strange to hear any man of intelligence objecting to the paltry expense necessary to secure it.

INROADS UPON THE INDIAN TERRITORY.We have reason to believe that the Indian Department is busily engaged upon the rather serious state of affairs that has been allowed to grow up in certain localities of the Indian Territory west of the Missouri River, whereby authorized white persons, in considerable numbers, are settling on lands specially reserved for Indian uses.

JOHNSON, Esq.. formerly Attorney General of the State of Pennsylvania, who is now under indictment for a violation of the neutrality laws of the United States in connection with that affair.

NEW-ORLEANS, OPELOUSAS AND GREAT WESTERN RAILROAD.-The Thibodaux Manerva learns from Col. IVES. of the firm of BATES, BESSON Co., contractors on the New-Orleans, Opelousas and Great Western Railroad, that there is now employed on the road between Bayou des Allemands and Tigerville, upwards of five hundred hands, and that the work is progressing rapidly, although the present rainy reason has been, and still is, a great hindrance.

The situation of the Red Sulphur Springs reminds a spectator of a huge cave, with its roof lifted off for the freedom of the sky, and one side thrown down for the freedom of the land. A beautiful seclusion it is, occupying the fairest portion of a romantic glen, and resting against the sides of parallel hills, with an air of quiet comfort that looks like a Sabbath converted into scenery.

Neither the position in which I stand, nor the necessity arising out of it, is of my own seeking.

The Assistant Secretary of State, A. DUDLEY MANN, Esq., I regret to state, was attacked with cholera morbus last evening, and continued seriously ill during the night. Upon inquiry this evening I was happy to learn that he was much more comfortable, though still confined to his bed.

From the Boston Traveller. Letters received in this city from Montevideo and Buenos Ayres. to the 1st of July, bring important intelligence. The squadron of URQUISA, commanded by Com. COE, and with which he was blockading the city, by the assent of the foreign powers, has been bought over by the besieged, and at last accounts was lying quietly in the harbor of Buenos Ayres.

We are indebted to the Whig for the following report of the race on Saturday last: The second contest, on this course, between "Centerville" and "Black Douglass," came off on the afternoon of Saturday last,and resulted inthewinning by "Centerville" of the first three heats.

A project is on foot in Cincinnati, to furnish the poor with wood, the ensuing Fall, at nearly 50 per cent. below present prices. The gentlemen who have undertaken the matter, contemplate procuring a large supply of wood, upon which they propose to make an advance of 12 per cent. upon its cost to those able to pay.

MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.-The Board met at the Lyceum Tuesday evening at 8 P.M , Aldermen F. B. BETTS, President of the Board, in the Chair. Alderman MILLER, from the Special Committee appointed to draft an ordinance approving the plan for the general system of Sewers, furnished by the Water Commissioners of Jersey City, presented such an ordinance.

TESTIMONIAL TO HON. MR. MARCOLETA. FROM THE GOVERNMENT OF NICARAGUA.--The following letter, addressed to this distinguished gentleman by the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Government of Nicaragua, has been furnished to us for publication, and we take pleasure in giving it a place in our columns:

It is said that in order to prevent any failure in the new machinery of the U. S. steamer San Jacinto, the Secretary of the Navy will have a survey upon her by a Board of Engineers. who will make a report, with estimates, and he will withhold a large portion of the pay of the contractors until six months after a trial, to find out if they have faithfully fulfilled their contract.

From the Boston Traveller. On the 27th of February last, the schooner S. R. Soper, Capt. SAMUEL SOPER, sailed from Provincetown. for a cruise in the Atlantic Ocean, for whales. Nothing unusual happened until about the last of July, when one morning a school of whales was discovered.

On Saturday last we visited Sing Sing, where we learned that a convict escaped from the State Prison the day previous, in a very ingenious and skillful manner. JAMES DUNN, the convict in question, although but 20 years old, had served one term in the prison, and had been but a few months returned on another sentence, which was for life.

THE NAVY-YARD.--On Saturday, the U. S. sloop-of-war John Adams was taken into the drydock for repairs, and work has already been commenced upon her. She has been carefully examiped, and, it is thought, will require extensive repairs.

From the Agricultor. The inhabitants of the Celestial Empire are famous for their economy in the use of all vegetable substances capable of being used as food, and the industry displayed in their management. Few plants are overlooked which can add in any way to the list of esculents, and many which in other countries would be considered as worthless are taken advantage of by them.

Great pains have been takenin Williamsburg, by certain parties, to keep from the ears of the public a very scandalous affair, which has recently come to light in that city. The facts of the case appear to be as follows. At present we only state them in a general way:

AN ASTONISHING YOUTH.-At the United States Hotel, yesterday, was stopping a colored boy, named WILLIAM MARCEY, whose extraordinary mathematical powers have greatly astonished all who have witnessed his demonstrations. He will add up columns of figures any length, divide any given sum, multiply millions by thousands within five minutes from the time the figures are given him, and with such exactness as to render it truly wonderful.

It is said that about 90 per cent. of all growing crops consist of simple water. In a very dry season, the hot air comes to the green herbage to get a drink, and the leaf affords every drop it has to spare; for plants and herbs are full of blessed charity.

HATFIELD, MASS--LARGE ELM -- We visited this fine rural town a few weeks since in order to see the Great Elm which we had read of so freqently. It is within the fence that encloses the ground in front of the meeting-house.

A CLERGYMAN'S WIFE KILLED BY LIGHTNING.--On Sunday evening last, between 6 and 7 o'clock, Georgetown, (Mass.) was visited by a terrific thunder shower. The lightning, as well as the rain, seemed to come down in torrents.

A negro, named GEORGE McQUEERY, alias WASH, was brought to this city last night from Piqua, claimed by HENRY MILLS, of Kentucky, as a fugitive slave. The colored people gathered in large numbers round the Galt House, where the Ingitive was guarded by the U. S. Marshal and a posse of police, and exhibited much feeling, but dispersed upon being assured that the prisoner should have a trial to-day.

LITERARY INBERITANCE.-It has been discovered that a speech delivered in the late Massachusetts State Convention. by Mr. A. L. STRONG, a delegate from the western part of the State, was by some mistake or other, printed almost verbatim thirty years ago.

SIMON PAGE, an intelligent mulatto barber, of Charleston, Kanawha, has left his master's service, and taken himself to Canada. SIMON enjoyed the unbounded confidence of his master, Mr. JOHN N. CLARKSON, and has been entrusted with large sums of money--at one time he drew $4,700 for his in Cincinnati.

ENGAMPMENT OF THE FIRST DIVISION MASSACHUSETTS VOLUNTEER MILITIA AT NORTH ABINGTON. --At an early hour this morning, the several military corps of the city were astir, and one by one marched to the Old Colony depot, where they took the cars for the camp-ground at North Abington.

UNPRECEDENTED TRAVELING.-We were informed on Monday of it feat of walking, by two females-mother and daughter-which, for its extraordinary character, we never knew equalled. The females are of Irish birth, aged about 42 and 20 years, respectively.

I left Savannah for the West by the Macon road; the train started punctually to a second, at its advertised time; the speed was not great, but regular, and less time was lost unnecessarily at way-stations than there usually is on our Northern roads.

The following letter from a Swedish Physician, M. FAGERGREN, in the service of Persia. gives a startling picture of the devastation caused by the recent Earthquake at Shiraz: SHIRAZ, May 14. "You already know that the town of Shiraz no longer exists, having been completely destroyed by an earthquake.

The Legislature of the islands, after a long and stormy session, adjourned yesterday. The United States frigate St. Lawrence, 44 guns, is now lying here. We had, a few days ago, a visit from a Swedish frigate of 36 guns--the first Swedish man-of-war that ever was here. They were the whitest looking sailors I ever saw, and looked as if they had never been in the sun in their lives.

BRILLIANT METEORS.--No less than three remarkable Meteors were seen on Sunday evening. The first about 7 o'clock, in an E. N. E. direction, and at an altitude of 35? moved toward the N. W. in a circle inclined to the horizon varying little from 15[degrees].

The Boston Journal, of the 16th inst., learns from a friend, who is now on a visit to the mountain region of New-Hampshire, that severe storms of wind and rain, accompanied by vivid lightning, occurred on the afternoons of Saturday and Sunday, the 13th and 14th inst.

The effect of the new English law abolishing the Advertisement duty, is apparent in the notices published in almost all the papers of a very large reduction in the rates of advertising. Hitherto the Government has levied a tax of Is. 7d. or thirty-seven and a half cents upon every advertisement without distinction, which the advertiser had to pay in addition to the charges of the journal.

Patrick McNally, a laboring man, residing in Ninth-street, was seriously injured yesterday morning, by the falling of a portion of the rear brick wall of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in South Second street, which is being torn down for the purpose of enlarging the building.

DEATH OF ANOTHER BOSTON MERCHANT.--Mr. ALBERT T. MINOT, of the firm of ALLEN MINOT, died in this city this morning after a few days' illness. His disease was the bilious colic. Mr. MINOT was formerly a member of the Common Council, and Chairman of the Committee from that body, on the Public Lands.

A CONTRAST.-Republics, it is proverbially said, are ungrateful-a saying which our own Republic has, by many an example proved to be a slander. A few months ago, and the whole nation voluntarily united, as if with one accord, to reward, with the highest honors of the State, one who had ??ed his life in the battles of his country.

THE LIQUOR LICENSE.--Mayor MANNERS has approved of the ordinance to license inns and taverns, which was adopted at the meeting of the Common Council, two weeks since. It will become a law after publication. It fixes fifty dollars as the price of a license, and requires application to be made by a recommendation of twelve freeholders of the ward in which the house is to be kept, and requires the publication of their names.

The opera of " I Puritani" was not played last evening, owing to the severe indisposition of Madame SONTAG. The opera of "Norma" was substituted, in which Madame STEFFANONE played Norma, and PATTI-STROKOSCH took the part of Adalgisa. The audience was very large, and appeared delighted with the choice musical entertainment.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I take it for granted, that our last intelligence from China is substantially correct, because it is a sequence to what we had previously heard A portion. seemingly a large portion, of the Chinese people have escaped from the equally barren (though mutually adverse) fields of false religion and false philosophy, to the genial and fruitful clime of Christianity. This event is a great one.

THE RED MAN'S COMPLAINT OF THE AGGRESSIVENESS OF THE PALE FACES.-The Cherokee Advocate, referring to the fact that the attention of our Government has been called to a strip of land bordering on the Rocky Mountains, called Alharra, expresses its opinion that any strip of unoccupied mountain land about where the Pacifc and Atlantic Indians meet, might be reserved for their burialground. The Advocate continues : " But alas ! No;

I see in your paper of Thursday, an account of the remarkable escape of a convict from the Prison at this place, and the spirited search made by the officers. Well, we have a finale, that is in keeping with the commencement. We have not caught the runaway, but we have caught a new dodge in the way of discipline, that is at least worth publishing.

LATER FROM HAVANA.-The U. S. Man steamship Cherokee, Capt. BAXTER, arrived yesterday, from Havana, whence she sailed on the 14th inst. She left New-Orleans on the 11th. There was no news of importance at Havana. When the steamer left, the bark Elizabeth J. was discharging. The bark Franklin, Capt. C. CARAUD, was to sail for Bordeaux on the 16th inst.

The tall young oystermen of the State of Connecticut have been "celebrating." A fleet of twenty sail, from along the western shore, (Greenwich, Stamford. Darien, Norwalk and Westport,) arrived at Bridgeport on Tuesday last, where they had a refreshing season, Their newly paint ed vessels, snow-white sails, streamers and flags, made a very handsome appearance.

We have received Costa Rica papers to the 23d of July. The news is interesting. The treaty between the Republic of Costa Rica and Pope PIUS IX., dated Oct. 7, 1852, has been concluded and confirmed with much ceremony. The high sounding titles of the agents to the formation of the ecclesiastical contract, do not savor much of the simplicity of republicanism.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Monarchical diplomacy has outdone the witches in "Macbeth." All the compounds of their famous caldron, from the "toad under cold stone " down to "nose of Turk and Tartar's lips," are nothing in comparison to the hell-broth of diplomatic gruel in the Oriental question.

An interesting Convention of the Instructors of the Deaf and Dumb in the United States has lately been held at Columbus, and a summary of the closing proceedings is given elsewhere in our columns to-day. The body held a brief and busy session. The results of its deliberations are valuable, and there is a considerable amount of instruction to be derived from the contemplation of the lessons set forth on all such occasions.

FIREMEN'S PARADE--On Thursday evening, a meeting was held at Firemen's Hall, in Henry--street, preparatory to making arrangements for the Annual Parade of the Brooklyn Fire Department. The Chief Engineer. Assistant Engineers, and a majority of the firemen of the different companies, were present, and signified their willingness to parade.

We have received late news from Cayenne,--news which the Patrie characterizes as encouraging. That anything encouraging should come from Cayenne is to me more astonishing than that anything good should come out of Nazareth could be to a Jew. The Patrie's reasons for considering the intelligence agreeable are the following: Several roads have been Macadamized; a vegetable garden has been laid out to furnish greens to the Hospital.

Hon. JOHN TALIAFERRO, a patriot and a good man. died yesterday at his residence in Virginia, aged about 85 years. He was for twenty years and upwards a member of Congress from Virginia, and for the last three years he was Librarian of the Treasury Department.

At Williamsburg, on Friday afternoon, Aug. 19, Mrs. LIVIA DAY REECHER, youngest daughter of President Day, of New-Haven. At Leedsville Dutchess County, N. Y., SARAH FRANCES, wife of E. D. White, in the 29th year of her age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from the First Baptist Church, Nassau st., Brooklyn, this (Monday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, without further notice.

The following extracts are from the Bermuda Royal Gazette of the 2d instant: A good deal of excitement has prevailed in the West India Islands subsequent to the receipt of the intelligence of the intention of the Imperial Government to withdraw the troops from the West Indies, and also of the intention of the Government to re duce the Ordnance and Commissariat establishments.

CONVENTION OF THE ZETA PSI FRATERNITY.- The annual Convention of the Zeta Psi Fraternity held at the Globe Hotel, Brooklyn, has just closed its session. The meeting was large and enthusiastic, full delegations from the various Chapters being present.

An evening paper replies to our structures on the management of the Crystal Palace, in regard to the price of admission, , by urging that. "the subject was carefully considered by the Managers, and that the rate of twenty-five cents was not adopted, for the simple reason that they found that they could not afford it."

The Pittsburg Despatch, of August 18th, stopped the press to announce the commission of a horrible murder in Allegheny city. It occurred as follows: At the fire at Criswell's, on Rebecca street, W. L. Gould accidentally splashed with his foot, some water on Hamilton Dawson. The latter would not accept an apology, but drew a knife which had been handed him by his brother, and made a thrust at Gould's heart.

Late sittings and hard work have been the order of the evening--and for that matter, the morning, too--in the House of Commons, during the past week. Honorable members work diligently from the same feeling as that which animates schoolboys when the hope of release is looming up at no great distance. About three weeks, or even less, will conclude the session; and hence the necessity of dispatching public business before partridge-shooting commences.

MESSRS. EDITORS: In the decision of judge McLEAN, upon the recent Fugitive Slave case, as published this morning, there is the following paragraph: "The declaration of the Senator from Virginia is alluded to in support of the argument that Slavery does not exist by law in the Slaveholding States. I am really sorry to hear this argument.

The Dispatches received at the Navy Department from Commodore PERRY, at Shanghai, are dated May 16. He expected to sail immediately for Japan, leaving one vessel of his squadron behind, for the use of the United States Minister. This fact is evidence that the Commodore considers that the revolution in China is approaching a crisis, as he has heretofore deemed it important to take every vessel of his squadron on the Japan Expedition.

The U.S. Circuit Court assembled at 8 o'clock this morning, and was called to order by Judge HALL. The case of the Government against J. D. NESBITT, for forging pension papers, which has occupied the Court during the term, was given to the Jury last night, and this morning they returned averdict of guilty.
CASTLE GARDEN--"Ernani" was repeated on Saturday evening, to an ordinary attendence. The performance went off well, but was not marked with any new feature.

Creeping along from the South comes the Cholera. At Cuba, it was raging terribly when the last news left there. The slaves were suffering most from it, and the newly imported and unacclimated ones were dying off frightfully. Nearer than this it has approached. At Cumberland, Md., fourteen fatal cases have been reported.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: We observed in your paper of the 17th inst., a notice of the progress made in the machinery exhibited at the Crystal Palace, in which article your reporter has been led into an error (unintentionally, no doubt,) with regard to the builder of our engine.

JEFFERSON DAVIS, Secretary or war, in company with Professor BACHE and family, arrived here yesterday morning, en route for the White Mountains. During the forenoon, General DAVIS visited Bunker Hill, the Navy-Yard, and several other places of interest. At the Navy-Yard he was received by Commodore GREGORY, who ordered a salute to be fired in honor of his guest.

from the New-Orleans Delta, Aug. 14. We greeted an old acquaintance yesterday, on Nayades street, whom we had not seen for a fortnight before. He had a care-worn and troubled countenance; his eves were sunken and his cheeks were hollow, and care had left its foot-prints on his brow--he looked at least ten years older than when we last saw him.

The clipper ship Telegraph arrived at this port this morning in the short passage of 58 days from Valparaiso. She spoke, on the 1st of August, in lat. 9? 12' North, lon. 41?, ship Norma, from New-York for Australia.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In your article headed " Crystal Palace Shortcomings," of this morning, you state that "Even the great London Exhibition assigned one day in each week for shilling admissions."

DEATH OF BENAJAH MALLORY.--The melancholy task of recording the death of this memorable soldier of the Revolution falls upon us to-day. He died at his residence in this village, at 10 o'clock on Tuesday morning, Aug. 8. With the history of Major MALLORY most of our readers are familiar. He enlisted in the service of the American army at an early stage of the Resolution, and served under General WASHINGTON in several important engagements.

The Colonization Journal says, early in October it has been contemplated to send from New-York a vessel to afford a free passage to as many emigrants as desire an opportunity. This will be effected, unless the company of sixty persons now getting ready to go from Pennsylvania shall decide to sail from New-York; in which case the expedition may be deferred until the first of November.

The Autocrat will presently discover that the manifesto of PETERHOFF was calculated to produce other and very different effects than those which he originally anticipated or desired.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: "Dick Tinto," your Paris correspondent, in the TIMES of yesterday, giving an account of the feat of jumping from a balloon, states that the jumper had accomplished a descent of 600 feet in two seconds. This, I think, is highly improbable, if a tall possible.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found a letter from Hon. T. BUTLER KING, in reply to strictures upon his public conduct as Collector of San Francisco, contained in a letter from our Washington correspondent, and published in the TIMES of June 19.

New-Orleans papers of Sunday and Monday are received. The whole number of deaths in New-Orleans, from May 28 to Aug. 13, were 5,674, of which 3,836 were by yellow fever. Returns from Western Texas give large majorities for OCKILTRER, the Whig candidate for Governor, and there is some probability of his election.

we have conversed with one or two gentlemen residents at New-Orleans, who left home since the epidemic became so fatal and malignant. They describe the mortality as frightful in some of the districts, but partial in its course. The deaths per day, now reported by telegraph, they compute equal to a daily mortality of over two thousand in acity of the population of New-York.

SUDDEN DEATH.--A man by the name of PATRICK CONWAY, a young man and an Irishman, lately returned from California. died very suddenly yesterday afternoon, at the Union Hall, on Third street, between Locust and Vine. He had been hut recently married, and day before yesterday had his wife arrested on suspicion of attempting his life.
FROM THE BAHAMAS--DEATH OF GOVERNOR GREGORY.--By an arrival at this port, we learn that Governor GREGORY, of the Bahamas, died on the 30th of July, of an enlargement of the heart.

THE IMPEACHMENT CASE.--The Court of Impeachment was in secret session on the 18th, and till the midday recess of the 19th; the motion considered being that of Mr. MATHER's counsel, to strike out the first five articles. On opening the doors, Mr. VANDERBILT moved the taking up the question.

Arrangements are on foot for opening the Exhibition in the evening. On Saturday a number of workmen were engaged in suspending the gas burners throughout the building. There will he a liberal supply of jets, and sufficient light for the minute examination of all the articles exhibited. A large portion of our resident population will doubtless avail themselves of this convenient arrangement for seeing the attractions of the Palace.

A writ of habeas corpus was granted in the case of FRANCIS B. EDYMOIN, returnable this morning, at 10 o'clock, at which hour our large Court room was filled, and EDYMOIN was brought in by Mr. TITUS, the Warden of the State Prison. Hon. CHRISTOPHER MORGAN and CLARENCE A. SEWARD, assisted by JAMES R Fox, appeared for the prisoner, and WARREN T. WARDEN and THEODORE M. POMEROY, District Attorney, appeared for the people.
NEW-YORK CITY.

It is not unlikely that NOWELL COBB, or Georgia, will go to France. So it is whispered to night. To-day being the anniversary of the battle of Contreras and Cherubusco, a number of officers belonging to PIERCE'S Brigade in the Mexican war, now resident in this city, called on the President to indulge in reminiscences suggested by the occasion.

We have received, at last, what may be considered reliable information relative to the late great battle between the Pawnees and their allies and the Sioux and their allies. As I anticipated, the numbers engaged have been enormously exaggerated, as well as the numbers killed and wounded.

FROM OUR SPECIAL REPORTERS. The paragraphs that have appeared in some of our issues of last week, have no doubt to a certain extent apprised our readers of the fact that measures were being taken to investigate a grave charge preferred against an old citizen of our neighbor city, Williamsburg, by a young orphan girl.

From the National Inteilingencer. This is the most scientific and important work that the United States has ever projected. The following letter, written by Mr. WEBSTER, while Secretary of State, in regard to the rights of American citizens residing abroad, is pub listed by the Herald, to which it was sent by J. S. THRASHER, Esq., whose case was then engaging the attention of the Government: DEPARTMENT OF STATE, WASHINGTON, July 5, 1852. W. L. SHARKEY, Esq., U. S. Consul, Havana:

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: SIR: On my return from Europe, some days ago, my attention was called to a letter from your Washington correspondent, published in your pa per of the 21st June last, assuming to give new and important information respecting my accounts, and the performance of my duties as Collector of the Port of San Francisco.

A large part of the invalids who repair to the Red Sulphur Springs are sufferers from disease in the organs of Respiration. The virtue of these waters in such cases has been repeatedly and thoroughly tested, both by ordinary patients and by intelligent physicians, and there can be no doubt whatever, that they are specifically adapted to the alleviation or removal of consumption and its kindred affections.

After the temporary cessation of Divine worship in many of the Churches in this City and Brooklyn, for the renovation of the buildings and the relaxation of the Pastors, the close of August commonly witnesses the ceremonies of reopening. Several were opened yesterday, for the first time in several weeks, and we give below brief sketches of two or three of the discourses.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We are getting on towards Niagara; but are perfectly willing to postpone the accomplishment of our hopes in that direction until we have enjoyed to our fill the beauty of our present position. Leaving the railroad at the junction, seven teen miles west of Syracuse, we take the stage over a plank road for five miles.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your remarks, in the TIMES of the 20th inst., headed "Crystal Palace Short Comings," will meet the approbation of the entire community. The policy which seems to have governed the Crystal Palace Association, ever since its opening, justly merits the censure of the Press.

A very elegant private entertainment, we understand, was given at the St. Nicholas Hotel on Thursday to Gov. JONES, of Tennessee by a number of his old friends and neighbors of Memphis, without party distinction. now adjourning in this City. on the ava of his departure for Europe.

The telegraph brings us some news of interest from the Plains, brought in by a party of Californians, who returned to Independence by the overland route. Our newspapers of this morning contained an inaccurate and very exaggerated rumor about it.

From the Courrier de l' Europe. In despite of the profound lassitude caused by this interminable Eastern question, we are still obliged to return to it. were it only for the purpose of following the perpetual oscillations which it undergoes, to the great detriment of the commercial and industrial interests of Europe.

Aspinwall,-a place which is so young yet that old fogies have scarcely adjusted their spectacles to look for it on the map,-boasts a noble charity under the name of the " Aspinwall Hospital." Beteen $7,000 and $8,000 have been contributed to establish it by the Railroad, U. S. Mail Steamship, and British Royal Mail Steamship Companies.

A witer is Blackwood, discussing the refusal of the English Government to address NAPOLEON as Emperor, during his imprisonment at St. Helena, says that "the custom of European diplomacy is never to acknowledge a new title but by treaty, and in return, if possible, for some concession on the part of the claimant."

You ask me, my dear friend, upon my return from Jamaica, my opinions as to the causes that have tended to the failure of the scheme of emancipation that has been carried into effect there. As you are aware, I have resided in Jamaica since the early part of the year 1836,-except, indeed, during the periods occupied in three or four brief visits to this City, and in one short sojourn in Europe.

The strike among the Journeymen House-Painters of this City has assumed a deinite and responsible shape. The number of men who are holding off is about five hundred. They evince a determination to stand the platform they have laid down.

Among the Virgin Islands. and "one, of them ' is Tortola It lies eastward of Porto Rico. and to the northeast of St. Thomas. It is no great affair of an island, being only twelve miles in length, by three or four wide. It is little else than a high range of barren, rocky hills, encircling a capital harbor.

From the New-Haven Register. The NEW-YORK TIMES, in a spirit which we carl not too highly commend, has a well written article calling upon the Government to see that redress is had from the authorities of Nicarauga, for the cruel and wanton attack committed upon Dr. DONAGHE, Of this City We hope to hear that the Administration of Gen. PIERCE has acted promptly in this case, and a speedy satisfaction demanded.

We published yesterday morning, (exclusively.) later and highly interesting intelligence concerning the movements of the vessels of the Japan Expedition, and the proceedings in China. Further details on all these points will be found in another column.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Judging from the reports in the papers, the late " Education Convention" in Pittsburg must have had a rather extraordinary stance. There seems to have been a premeditated attack on popular magazines and the press. while epithets were indulged in and accusations made, that hitherto have been confined to political meetings.
At the Commencement of the University of Vermont. at Burlington, on Wednesday, the 3d inst., he degree of LL.D was conferred upon HORACE GREELEY. of New-York.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As you have called the public attention to the wretchedly-conducted affairs of our naval steamships, I send you the enclosed advertisement, which speaks for itself. What a comment on naval administration !

At Jersey City, on Monday, 22d inst., JACOB CHAMBERLIN. merchant of this city. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from St. Matthews Church, (Sussex-st.) Jersey City, this afternoon, (23.) at 3 O'clock without further invitation. His remains will take to Cyprus Bill Cemetery for intermeat.

THE STATUARY.--Not with standing the continued efforts of Boatswain WILMETH and his crew of riggers all the week, the first and second of the four cases, containing GRENOUGH'S Statuary did not get lifted upon the base on which they are to rest until Saturday afternoon.

FIRE.-About 3 o'clock on Sunday morning a fire broke out in the clothing-store of TUCKER WYMAN, at the coiner of Myrtle-avenue and Adelphi-street. The building and its contents were entirely destroyed. Mr. CARMAN, who owns the building, will probably lose and about $3,000, the loss being covered by insurance.

THE WEALH OF NEW-BEDFORD.-New-Bedford, in proportion to population, is probably the wealthiest place in the United States. There are thirty-eight estates taxed for over one hundred thousand dollars. While there is not a single individual assessed for over one million of dollars, the number of moderate, substantial fortunes in NewBedford entitles it to the appellation of a "solid" place.

Photographic drawings on wood have lately been successfully produced in Manchester, Eng-land. Beautiful pictures of buildings, and perfect portraits of individuals, have been drawn by sun. light upon smooth blocks of boxwood, such as are ordinarily used by wood engravers.

FROM PERNAMBUCO.- Dates are to the 21st of July. The entries of sugar for the third week of July had been very limited, and no stock whatever had been held by packers for sale, which causes prices to advance.
MORTALITY.-The Health Officer reports 149 deaths for the week ending August 20-males, 91; males, 58; adults, 71, children. 78.

From Mr. CARROL HUGHES, who has just returned home from a trip out on the plains, as far as Sweet Water, about 900 miles out, the St. Joseph's Gazette learns the following facts: That there was an abundance of grass and water. The emigrants were all getting along well, and enjoyed unusual good health, there being less sickness on the plains among emigrants than ever was Known before.

THE RAPE CASE.-JOHN O'BRIEN was, yesterday morning, sent to the County Jail at Brooklyn for trial, at the next Court of General Sessions, on a charge of rape. The Thusnelda Lodge No. 6, of the Order of "Original Sons of Hermans," proceeded to Winfield, yesterday, to celebrate their anniversary.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times:: Regarding the consequences resulting from the licensed sale, and use, or rather abuse, of alcoholic poisons, there seems to have been for the last forty years, as there is now, among the better portion of all classes, but just one opinion-viz.: that it multiplies Crime, Poverty, Disease, Degradation, Taxation, and plunges its poor victims by myriads into the Eternal obyss, every year.

Andrew Simonson, of South Hempstead, L. I., was arrested by officer Ward, Saturday, on a warrant charging him with having caused the death of Edward Craig, a lad 4 years of age, whose parents reside at No 43 North Fourth-street. The accident which resulted in his death occurred, as is alleged. by carelessly driving a heavilyloaded wagon through the street, thereby knocking down and running over deceased. on Monday, the 8th instant.

From the Detreit Free Press.
