If this be true,

The non-arrival of the Pacific, though it creates no uneasiness on her account, stimulates the interest felt in the news expected from Europe, and exerts a very considerable influence on the transactions of Wall-street.

Men's wives differ in most things. Some of them prefer silks, and some of them bareges. Some like operas, and a few prefer to stay at home. Nature has provided that in their tastes and dispositions there should be a healthful variety. But in one matter they are all alike; or nearly all ;-there possibly may be exceptions.

The Syracuse people are teaching Philadelphians, and some others, a very wise lesson as to how the Press should be treated. Messrs. Moses SUMNER, JAMES TEL WILLIGER, CARROLL E. SMITH, and S. CORNING JUDD, constitute a Committee of Reception, and they publish the following notice, which is dated Aug. 19:

Another lamentable case of wholesale murder on shipboard is recorded in our City news this morning. The usual causes are found to lie at the root of this catastrophe, viz.: improper food and stinted supplies of water.

CASTLE GARDEN.--The third performance of "Don Giovanni," last evening, attracted a fill audience. It is with more than ordinary pleasure we observe the increasing popularity of this opera. It will, we hope, supplant the eternal "Somnamhula."

For Beeves, at the WASHINGTON DROVE YARD, corner of Fourth avenue and Thirty-Fourth-street, and at CHAMBERLAIN'S HUDSON RIVER BULL's HARD, foot of Robinson-street. For Cows and Calves, Sheep and Limbs; (and also for Beeves,) at BROWNINGS, in Sixth street, near Third-avenue, and alos at CHAMBERLIAIN's.

The arrangements for working the machinery in the Arcade are now perfected. A final experiment with the steam generated on the other side of the street, has answered the most sanguine expectations. It can be conveyed through the building with the greatest facility, and is, if possible, more easily regulated than were a separate boiler placed beside each engine.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Why not place the table, model, and boxes intended for the monument contributions, on the lower floor, near the statue of WASHINGTON ? Many now go from the Palace who do not see it in its present position, but would gladly contribute.

The ceremonies attending the laying of the corner-stone of this Institute were duly celebrated at Danvers on Saturday afternoon, in the presence of 2,000 people, cheered by a bright and genial sunshine.

We have an interesting letter from our Correspondent, located on the top of Mount Washington, dated Aug. 15, the day succeeding the extraordinary term of heated atmosphere experienced here for six consecutive days, ending the 14th inst.; he says:

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Permit me to thank you for your course in reference to Crystal Palace short-comings, and especially as to the charge for admission. Had that charge been fixed at twenty-five cents, I should certainly have visited the exhibition many times ere this; out fifty cents looks formidable when one knows they must be repeatedly disbursed, so I am among the patient ones waiting until it is completed.

It is announced, with a show of confidence, that the President has decided not to offer the Mission to France to Hon. JOHN A. DIX, although be had once resolved, with the assent of his Cabinet, to do so; and it is added that his change of purpose has been brought about by the assaults of the Hunker press of this State upon the policy of the Administration in its appointments thus far.

The Bininger Guards, Capt. DAVID HARRIS, of New-York, arrived at 1 o'clock P. M., under escort of the Elmira Guards, in good health and spirits. They have taken apartments at the Inter national Hotel. The corps visited the Canada side this afternoon, and were enthusiastically received. They have a grand banquet to-night at the International.

New-Orleans papers of Wednesday last are received. They say nothing as to the reported burning of bodies in that city. The body of a murdered man, partially cut up, supposed to be a returned Californian, had been found under mysterious circumstances, beneath one of the wharves of New-Orleans.

If anything would reconcile us to the frightful mortality reported for the last week from the City Inspector's Office, it would be the fact that our amiable neighbor, Philadelphia, lays the list so like a flattering unction to its soul. It reads it daily, to all appearances; and its staidest papers throw up their hats and hurrah, after the comparison with their own mortal statistics.

Quite a crowd gathered at the Court House, on Saturday morning, to hear the difference expounded between the letter n and re. This " battle of the alphabet " was set down for 10 o'clock. At the appointed time EDYMOIN was brought into Court by the Sheriff.

The Royal Mail steamer Arabia; Capt. JUDKINS, arrived yesterday morning at about 7 1/2 o'clock, having left Liverpool on Saturday, the 13th, at 2 o'clock P. M. She has thus made the pas sage, allowing for difference of time, in nine days twenty-two and a half hours.

Fears of Carllst Tronbles-Change In the Ministry. Senior MOYANO, Minister of Public Works, bad resigned, and was succeeded by Senior COLLANTES. The question of the railway concessions was settled, by all the concessions being confirmed. Senior AGUSTIN ESTERAN COLLANTES was former Director of the Post-Office.

TROT.-On Saturday afternoon, says the Washington Republic, there was, according to public advertisement," something worth looking at" over the Course--a match for $150, $50 a side, and $50 added by the proprietor, between " Scottie," of Philadelphia, to a skeleton wagon, and " Trenton," of Washington, to a sulky.

At Orange, N J., on Tuesday. Aug. 23, aged 51, MARY ONDERDONK, daughter of the late Dr. John Onderdonk, of this City. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral at St. Mark's Church, Orange, on Thursday, 25th.

The brig Chatham, front Sierra Leone July 15, arrived here this morning. She reports that in consequence of heavy rains the coast had become very unhealthy, and the officers and crews of several British vessels had died of yellow fever. No slavers had been captured on the coast since those at Rio Pongos, in June last.

FIRE IN GREENWICH AND VESEY-STREETS.--A fire was discovered last evening, about 9 1/2 o'clock, in the premises on the corner of Greenwich and Vesey-streets, occupied by S. S. REMSEN as a boot and shoe establishment. Thence it extended to the adjoining buildings, Nos. 208 and 210, the former occupied by Messrs. CLOSE STUIL as a clothing-store, and the latter by Mr JAMES McCLUSKY as a retail boot and shoe store.

Property of Married Women. SUPERIOR COURT-SPECIAL TERM. Before Judge Emmet. DECISION.--Jonathan Sturgis and others against Ann Kine, William Augustus Tucker and Catherine, his wife, and Henry Kine.--In Partition, August 22, 1852 - The referee has reported that the premises of which partition is sought, are so circumstanced that an actual partition thereof cannot be made without great prejudice to the owners, and that a sale is necessary.
The number of interments reported to-day was 270, including 248 from yellow fever. The total number of deaths, during the past week, has been 1,580, of which 1,350 were from yellow fever.

Victory of the Moors over the Kabyles Another Exploring Expedition to the Niger. A letter received at Marseilles, from Mogador, in Morocco, dated July 13, announced that the Emperor and his son had gained a complete victory over the Kabyles, who had not hitherto acknowledged the Emperor's authority. The victory was dearly purchased with the loss of 500 of the Emperor's best troops, and the loss of the Kabyles was still greater.

Proceedings In Parliament--Extraordinary Trial--Grand Naval Review--Petition for the Slave--Personal News--Various Interesting Items. The Board of Trade returns, for the month ended July 5, had just been issued. The total declared value of exports in the month was [Pound]6,772, 733 sterling, while in the corresponding months of l851 and 1852, they were respectively [Pound]6,228, 122 and [Pound]5,769,096.

Anxiety on the Eastern Question-The New Councils-Personal Intelligence-The Approaching Coronation-Paris a seaport-Proudhon's New Book-The Crops in France-The Duty off Corn from abroad-Improved Tone of Business-Imprisonments-Fetes, and Bull Fights. The Moniteur publishes a decree ordering that the surcharge fixed by the law of the 15th of April, 1832, on the importation of corn and flour in foreign ships, should cease to be levied till the 21st December next.

CASTLE GARDEN--MAX. MARETZEK may feel flattered with the demonstrations made yesterday afternoon and evening. The house was not only filled, but crowded; every seat from whence a view could be obtained had its occupant. Whether the same visitors sat through the entire performance, we are unable to say; but, judging front the enthusiasm, we should scarcely think it possible.

A serious collision occurred on the Sandusky, Cincinnati and Mad River Railroad yesterday. When the up Express train from Cincinnati arrived at Oregon, it had to pass another train of cars switched off the road ; through the careless less of the tender the switch had not been re placed; the Express train therefore ran off the track on to the switch, coming violently in contact with the other train, and badly smashing six cars.

Zollverian Exposition-Learned Men. The Frankfort Journal announces that the Bavarian Government has resolved to erect an edifice on the model of the Hyde-Park Palace, at a cost of 300,000 florins, for the Zollverein Exhibition.

In San Francisco, July 20, by P. W. Shepheard, Esq., Justice of the Peace, Adam Schuppart to Magdalena Hauser. July 21, by the same, Henry Albert Trammel to Eliza Amelia Schnabel. In San Francisco, July 19, by Rev. A. Williams, Mr. Wm. B Coville to Mies Mary E. G?bney.

To the Editor of the London Times: SIR: There can be no more any doubt about the new religion springing up in china. It is certainly Protestant Christianity, mixed yet, as it could not be otherwise in the beginning, with some heathenish customs and prejudices.

Review of the Market. From San Francisco Shipping List, July 30. The amount of business transacted since the sailing of the steamer of the 16th, has been unusually heavy, and in many articles of merchandise, particularly Bread stuffs and Provisions, we note a material improvement in rates. A 1arger amount of goods has, in fact, changed hands within the two weeks just past, than during any similar period for the previous six months.

Hon. HILLARY TEAGE, whose death on the 21st of May, at Liberia, has been announced, was editor and proprietor of the Liberia Herald, and one of the best read men in the Republic. He was Attorney-General of Liberia at the time of his death.

NEW CONFIDENCE GAME.--On Monday after noon, a well-dressed man entered the dry goods store of Mr. VAN BUSKIRK, corner of Charles and Greenwich streets, and requested to be shown some silk dress patterns. After examining the goods, he selected one valued at $17, and desired that it might be sent to his residence, No. 6 Abingdon-square, for the purpose, as he said, of permitting his wife to see it before completing the purchase.

In response to a call from the American Party, between two and three hundred respectable citizens assembled in the Northern Exchange, Beekman street, last evening. Dr. SHERRILL was called to the Chair, and briefly returned thanks. Mr. CHAS. J. HOLDEN, read the minutes of the previous meeting, which were approved.

The arrival of the Arabia yesterday morning, after a quick passage, and of the Pacific last evening, after a somewhat prolonged one, puts us in possession of European news a week later. The news is interesting, though not decisive as to the Eastern question.

Amusements This Evening. Full Particular may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Yankee in China-Yankee iu Time Perplexing Predicament. NATIONAL THEATRE-Uncle Tom's Cabin. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.-The Maid with the Milking Pail--Trying it on.

By the arrival of the steamship Northern Light, Capt. T. MINER, we are in possession of dates from California to August 1--two weeks later. We are indebted to PURSER N. F. HEDGES and WELLS, FARGO Co's Express Agent, and BERFORD Co., for memoranda and files of papers.

Switzerland will no longer Succumb to Austria. A letter vid Berlin states that the Government of the Swiss Republic is taking advantage at the present crisis to prepare itself to meet the issue with Austria.

The Queen will visit Dublin about the 29th, and will remain about a week. The crops in Ireland are very prolific, but there is a great scarcity of labor in some districts. There is no appearance of the patato rot. The visitors to the Dublic Exhibition continue to average 8,000 or 9,000 a day.

Political News Dull--Excellent Sanitary Regulations. The internal differences in the Cabinet have for the present, as on many former occasions, been smoothed down by the king's persuasive influence, and a working majority has been obtained. Report had said that Herr VON LADENBERG was about to resume his former post of Minister of Education and Public Worship, but this was incorrect.

A telegraph from Trieste, Wednesday, 10th, announces the arrival there of the steamship Calcutta, 111 hours from Alexandria, Egypt. The dispatch is dated Alexandria, Aug. 15, and says: "The Calcutta mail of July 2 has arrived, with the China mail of the 23d June ; and intelligence from Burmah to 22d June; from Sydney, May 31; Bombay, July 2.

A dispatch just received from New-Bedford says: "No news has been received here of any steamer ashore on Nantucket Shoals. The U. S. steamers Corwin and Bibb are surveying on the Shoals, and may have been taken for a steamer ashore. More will be known when the Nantucket ?? gets in."

Expert of Breadstuffs from Lombardy prohibited--More Political Severlties--Tuscan Finances--The Pope and the Dutch. SARDINIA.--A great review of Piedmontese troops was being held by the Duke of GENOA, on the Plains of Morengo. LOMBARDY.--Grape blight was causing uneasiness in Lombardy, and corn was scarce and dear.

ADDRESS TO WORKINGMEN. Speech of Mr. C. W Elliot, or New-York, to the Workmen of the New-Jersey Locomotive Works. We gave, in Saturday's TIMES, a sketch of the proceedings of the Workmen attached to the New-Jersey Locomotive Works, at Paterson, du ring their trip to this City, and their visit to the Crystal Palace.

Mr. WRIGHT moved, the procuring of the Report of the State Engineer, and the reply of Mr. MATHER, for the use of the Court. Carried. John Cuyler, Deputy Secretary of State, called for the People, and Mr. LOOMIS offered in evidence minutes of the proceedings in the Canal Board, October 14, 1851, refusing to give notice for the letting of the work for Erie Canal enlargement.

PROBABLE MURDER.--Yesterday afternoon a boy named JOHN SALMON, while driving a cart in company with a man named NOLAN, in Seventeenth-street, near Avenue A, was met by a party of rowdies, among whom was one who gave his name as PATRICK JONES, who, while in the act of crossing the street, struck SALMON's horse over the head with a stick. NOLAN jumped from the cart, and inquired why he had done so.

FROM THE BAHAMAS.--We have files of Bahama journals to the 12th inst. The Nassau Royal Gazette states that the anniversary of emancipation day--first of August--was celebrated with great eclat. The Bahama Friendly Society proceeded at 11 o'clock to Christ Church, where a sermon was delivered by the Rev. MrHILDEBRAND.

One of the most terrible and destructive fires that ever occurred in Penn Yan, broke out this morning, on the corner of Canal and Main-streets and consumed nearly the entire square on which it commenced,--the only building left being the large brick fire-proof store formerly occupied by STEW ART TUNNICLIFF, on the corner of Main and Jacob-streets, now occupied by CHAS READ CO.
It is rumored that Gen. GADSDEN, Minister to Mexico, is instructed not to offer money for the Mesilla Valley, but that he is authorized to agree to pay filthy lucre for a large slice of Sonora.

Cold weather has had its effect on the Crystal Palace. Heat, that expands everything else, contracts the number of visitors to places of amusement, while cold, though usually contracting in its influences, expands the list of admissions. The late warm weather was, in truth, no time for either work or amusement.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: If, in God's providence, we are to be afflicted with any of the epidemics now in different sections of the country, it behooves us, as civilized beings and Christians, to do all in our power to prevent, if possible, any useless sacrifice of human life.

Yesterday, the amateurs of the noble game of Cricket assembled in full force at the grounds of the St. George's Club, Red House, Third-avenue, anxious to witness the most interesting match made in this vicinity for several years. On the south side of the ground were three handsome marquees, one having the stars and stripes floating as the colors of the New-York Club, the other the blood-red cross of St. George ;

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The still unsettled condition of the Oriental question did not fail to exert a check upon the resolutions of the Federal Assembly of Switzerland in reference to the pending conflict with Austria.

Near the Clinton Market, a day or two ago, a poor man was fined $50 for leaving a pile of wood before his door till he could procure men to cut it up, while a few blocks further on,

Yesterday. MARGARET M., wife of Samuel Lounsbury. The friends and acquantances of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this day, Thursday,the 25th. st 3 0'clock, from her late residence, No. 172 Washington st. Brooklyn.

MR. WEED'S REPLY TO DR. FOOTE'S CARD. Persons charged with offences almost invariably betray themselves if they attempt to explain. Hence, by a humane provision of law, when arraigned, they are permitted to stand mute, after simply pleading "not guilty."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The high price charged for admission to the New-York Crystal Palace prevents many from visiting that exhibition. Tickets being placed at 50 cents each, excludes those who could not justly spare that sum for amusement, where half that amount could and would readily be given for admission to the Crystal Palace.

We have had another delightful day. The thermometer at the Bulletin office, at 12 o'clock, stood at 82 degrees. The firemen were kept busy after midnight last night. At 2 1/4 o'clock this morning, a brick tenpin alley, at Schuylkill Water and South-streets, was set on fire and destroyed.

TWO NUISANCES IN CLOSE PROXIMITY.-On one corner of Gold and 7 illary-streets, in Brooklyn, is a sianughter-house to which is attached an extensive yard and stables, no portion of which is kept in that condition of cleanliness which is usually connected with ideas of cleanliness, savoriness and comfort.
We devote a good deal of space this morning to an elucidation of the controversy that has arisen concerning sundry charges against Hon T. BUTLER KING, late Collector at San Francisco.

THINGS AT THE NAVY-YARD.-Great activity prevails at the Navy-Yard. Workmen are busily engaged in fitting up the U. S frigate Congress. The spars will be replaced in a few days, and the ship will be completed with dispatch. The Independence is lying at the yard, ready for sea, with the exception of a crew. If the Government required the immediate use of a ship, no doubt she could be dispatched forthwith.

Among the articles congregated in the Crystal Palace, few so much invite intelligent examination, or so imperatively require the aids of clear descriptive illustration, as the series of instruments and charts in the Coast Survey Department.

A destructive fire occurred here this morning, in North Front-street, entailing a loss of $8,000, which is mostly insured in home Companies. The following are among the sufferers: P. H. VAN KEWSEM, grocery; J. D. SLEIGHT, cabinet-maker; ANDREW NICHOLs, harness-maker W. H. FREIDENBURGH, sash and blinds.

SINGULAR CAFE.-A gentleman from Lunenburg says a remarkable case of droosy in the chest has occurred in that town, in the person of a young man by the mine of Henry. The disease having resisted all usual remedies, Dr. Hitchcock of Fitchburg, has performed the operation of tapping the cheat four times within a year, with great relief to the Patient.

We understand that orders have been received at Governor's Island, from the War Department, for the immediate transmission to the Rio Grande frontier of a very large quantity of artillery, ammunition and ordnance stores,-more in amount than General TAYLOR had during his whole campaign.

The comet may be spoken of as among our institutions. We have not personally seen it, for the vision from the highest house we have managed to ascend is obscured by some higher house close beside us, and the comet humbly hugs the horizon yet, they say.

We have received, Vid Texas, dates from Santa Fe to the 16th ult. The Gazette says: The probation extended to the Navajos to enable them to comply with the demand of Gov. LANE, for the delivery of the murderers of RAMON MARTIN, seems to have been used to little advantage.

Yesterday was appointed for the first annual excursion of the Thomas F. Meagher Club-a liberal Irish party, established in 1848, revived again on the escape of Mr. MEAGHER to this country, and how numbering 300 members. The steamboat Nimrod and barge Irene left the foot of Chambers-street at 9 1/2 A.M., having on board about 250 members, and a company. chiefly young ladies, of nearly 300 more. I have expended considerable effort during the week last past to ascertain whether there is really anything truthful and new in the recent Washington correspondence of the New-York Freeman's Journal, relative to the diplomatic instructions to Minister GADSDEN.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: While reading, in your paper of the 15th, Mr. WM. BATES' account of the disaster on the Worcester and Providence Railroad, I was forcibly reminded of a caution given me by a gentleman who has traveled much on the Eastern roads.

I perceive that very imperfect and general accounts have reached the States of the yellow fever prevailing for some time past on our island. Previous to the Fall of 1852, we had enjoyed, for many years, entire freedom from this dreadful disease. The Summer of 1852 was very wet,

The following letter, says the New-Orleans Picayune of the 18th inst., reached us last evening by the mall steamer from Texas. It was written at El Paso, Mexico, by a gentleman whom we know to have means of obtaining the best information. It was addressed to a merchant of San Antonio, who forwarded it to us:

" Nothing of importance occurred since our departure from Havre, until yesterday morning, (Friday, July 29,) at 5 o'clock, when we were startled by the cry of " Stop her !-Man overboard ! "The engines were immediately reversed, and we soon learned that the quartermaster, Mr. FLINT, had been knocked overboard by the jibing of the main spencer.

Full Particulars may be found in our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE--Yankee in Time--The Wool Dealer--Perplexing Predicament. NATIONAL THEATRE--Uncle Tom's Cabin. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--The Maid with the Milking HOPE CHAPEL.--Frankenstein's Panorama of Niagara Falls.

The World's Temperance Convention is to come off in this City, and in Metropolitan Hall, on the 6th of September, at 10 o'clock. That, at least, is the beginning; but the intention is to protract the meeting through four days. Each forenoon will be devoted to reading appropriate essays, discussions, and general business.

Roving valetudinarians, restless dyspeptics, and ridiculous health-seekers, who are never so well but a medicated water will make them better; who are ever on the alert for springs impregnated with an appreciable quantity of iron, an homeopathic solution of iodine, or the more sensible qualities of sulphuretted hydrogen--will read with joy the announcement that the Croton water is medicated.

The Board of Health has already informed the public that the yellow fever exists among us. We shall endeavor, while it lasts, to keep our readers accurately advised of its progress. so that there will be no occasion for the usual exaggeration in regard to it. We see nothing to be gained and much to be lost by concealments or misrepresentations.

From the Washington Union. It has already been announced in the columns of the Union that, by an arrangement between the respective Post-Office Departments of the United States and Bremen, the rates of postage by the Bremen line have been very greatly reduced.

The labors of Major B. B. FRENCH, the new Commissioner of Public Buildings, are well emplayed in the improvements he is making at the Capitol. The whole work now in progress there (except the extension of the two houses of Congress) is under the superintendence of the Major FRENCH, and be is acquitting himself admirably.

ANOTHER UNSUCCESSFUL EXPEDITION TO THE INFECTED DISTRICT.-Sheriff McEWEN and a posse of constables, police captains and special constables, for the occasion, on Saturday started for the anti-rent district, to arrest a man named DEITZ, charged with having brutally assaulted another party. The Sheriff lead off with his "spanking bays,"

CORRECTION.--Two or three weeks since, we published, in a letter from Montpelier, Vt., a notice of an application just then decided in Court for divorce, between JOHN B. LANGDON, Esq., and his wife, together with a statement of sundry incidents alleged to have occurred in connection with the case.

Yesterday was my first day, this season, at Saratoga. The air of quiet and repose which pervaded the village, impressed me very favorably. I have noticed at some other fashionable places that I could name, if it were proper to do so, a seeming want of regard for the Sabbath; but it is quite different at Saratoga. Of course,

The letter from T. BUTLER KING, late Collector at San Francisco, published in yesterday's issue of the DAILY TIMES, demands from me a prompt explanation of many points studiously concealed in that communication. It is not for me to try the charges made against Mr. KING. It matters not whether they be true or false, so far as I am concerned.

Dates from the east end of Long Island by mail are to the 19th inst. Potatoes were rotting, bathing was fine, the fish never better. The New-York mail came through safe the night previous. Great anxiety was manifested to know where the new-found mines of Dr. GARDINER are located. Whether, too,

A correspondent of the Boston Traveller says, that Capt. HOWARD. of the schooner Rosannah, which arriving at Gloucester on Saturday, brought the report of the seizure of Yankee vessels by the British, "has met with poor luck, and reports mackerel scarce, having been absent some ten weeks. Capt. HOWARD also reports that schooner Mary Niles and Ella Proctor, were chased out of the Bay by an English cutter and Fun boat.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE--NARROW ESCAPE--TWO HORSES BURNED.--Tuesday morning, between 3 and 4 o'clock, one of the most destructive tires which Williamsburg has witnessed for several months, broke out in a range of wooden stables in Second-street, between South Fifth and South Sixth streets, owned by J. M. Disbrow and Messrs. Davis Young, and occupied by Messrs. Ropke, Stratton. Davis Young. Shauderback, Platt, S. K. Hoggett, H. k. Hoggett and Pasly.

TREATY WITH THE WINNNEBAGO INDIANS.On Monday, the 8th inst., a treaty was signed at Watab, by Gov. GORMAN and Agent FLETCHER, on behalf of the United States, and the Chiefs and head men of the Winnebago Indians on the part of their nation. The treaty resulted in a free exchange of their present lands for the following valuable district of country:

The recent outbreak of the Hungarians on the seizure of KOSZTA, and their rapturous reception of Captain INGRAHAM, indicate more than appears on the surface. Such an emeute and clamor in that quiet place over a foreign refugee, is without a parallel.

The Vermont Statesman says it now takes four days for a person either side of Bellows Falls to write to any place on the other side, and get an answer. A mail matter passing Bellows Falls, either down or up, must lay over at that place one day.

SMUGGLING.--In the United States District Court, now in session, we understand that a Mr. SNELL, a pilot, living in New-London, has been found guilty of aiding and abetting in a smuggling operation, in Long Island Sound, in the latter part of last Summer.

The Washington Intelligencer of the 24th inst. learns that Col. FREMONT left Washington, on Tuesday last, to commence his explorations of the country between the Mississippi and the Pacific, and especially in the Rocky Mountains and Sierra Nev'ada.

PURCHASE OF THE PUBLIC LANDS OF MASSACHBUSETTS.-We learn that Governor CROSBY, having examined the report of the Commissioners appointed te purchase the lands of Massachusetts, lying in Maine, will issue his proclamation forcalling the Legislature together (on the 20th of September next) to act upon the question of accepting the terms of said bargain.

NIBLO'S SALOON.--A kind of advanced rehearsal was given last night by the Rhenish Glee Club. The artistes in this troupe have newly arrived from Germany, and purpose, we imagine, giving a series of entertainments. The selection, last evening, embraced some choice harmonized pieces, but scarcely came up to what we have a right to expect from a company that makes the Glee its speciality.

The Comet now visible was discovered June 10th, at Gottingen, by Mr. KLINKERFUES. It was first seen at the National Observatory in this city on the 28th July, and a notice was published in the National Intelligencer of its observed Place on the 28th, and that it was then probably visible to the naked eye.

THE TESTIMONIAL TO CAPT. INGRAHAM--An adjourned meeting of the Committee appointed to devise ways and means for presenting a testimonial to Capt. INGRAHAM, of the U. S. frigate St. Louis, was held at No. Ill Leonard-street, on Wednesday evening. There were present, on behalf of the Cubans, Messrs. GASPARI BETANCOURT and PORFIAIO VALIENTE; for the Hungarians, Mr. ASBOTH;

FOLLOWING THE FASHION.--Williamsburg appears to be taking New York for a pattern, more especially in street-cleaning and the affairs of the rubbish carts. It is now about two months since the street-cleaning contract was awarded, and many of the principal streets are still uncleaned. There is an ordinance providing for the regulation of the rubbish carts, in lieu of which the city...

The Richmond Dispatch acknowledges the present of a mammoth watermelon from John Stith, conductor of the Fredericksburg Railroad. This watermelon is the product of Old Stafford. and vindicates her claim to agricultural respectability. It was raised by Mr. Davis, near Aquia Creek, and weighs fifty pounds, and a fraction over. Its lengthwise circumference is four feet four inches, round; the middle three feet.

The eastern part of Alabama resembles the western part of Georgia, which I have described. In the North, there are rugged limestone ridges; below these, there is much rich and new land, until lately occupied by the Creek Indians, which is now being rapidly brought into cultivation, mainly by emigrants from Carolina and Georgia, who purchase it in small parcels, and labor upon it with their own hands.

We have already published the letter of Hon. T. BUTLER KING, in reply to the statement concerning his accounts, furnished by FRANK WARD, Esq., to the Treasury Department. Mr. WARD has sent us the following rejoinder, which we also feel bound to publish:

At Trinity Church, New-York, on Tuesday 23d inst., by Rev. Chas. Maison, Rev. R M ABERSROMBIE, of Staten Island, to MARGARET, daughter of the late George C. Mason, of Newport, R. I. On Monday evening Aug 22, by Rev. Charles Reynolds, Mr. J. FRANKLIN BROWN to Miss LOUISA C., youngest daughter of John C. Nixon Esq., all of Williamsburg. L. I.

Reader--when strolling leisurely along Broadway, or any other of our much-frequented streets, and, in the absence of any other amusement. you cast your eye upon the heterogeneous announcements which, in varied and attractive coloring, adorn every available space, did you ever ask yourself what manner of men are those who thus industriously cover with intelligence otherwise uninteresting walls, unpleasant and dangerous piles of bricks.

Issued from the United States Patent Office for the weel ending Aug. 23. 1853 and bearing date Aug. 23, 1853 Luther Atwood, of Boston, Mass.--For improvement in processes for punfying alcohol. Jean Baptiste Moinier and Pierre Hippolite Boatigny of Paris, Fracne--For improved method of generation steam. Dated Aug. 23, 1853. Patented in France, Jan 18, 1853.

The Picture Gallery is in process of completion, under the superintendence of Signor PIATTI. As yet the pictures are unhung, and lie on the floor or lean against the wall, in literally picturesque confusion. The spires of Oriental mosques may be seen peeping over the tops of American prairie scenes, while dignified ecclesiastics are standing on their heads, with an ease and abandon worthy of RAVEL.

The Musical World has an exclamatory article alleging that Madame SONTAG has been made to believe that $15,000 were expended on her behalf, in "procuring Complimentary Notices" in the TIMES and other daily papers of this City. The World is a paper of too much character to deal in intimations of this kind, without good warrant.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: In the Herald of Wednesday, a writer, under the signature of " Common Sense," undertakes to explain the cause of the backwardness of the preparation of the cabinet of minerals in the Crystal Palace. This he ascribes to the fact that Professor S1LLIMAN is "lying dangerously ill " at New-Haven.

DINNER TO HON P. D. VROOM.--On Tuesday afternoon the Bench and Bar of the State of New-Jersey, gave a Complimentary dinner to Hon. P. D. V ROOM, previous to his departure on his Mission to Berlin. The company is described as having been almost entirely confined to the legal profession, of which Mr. VROOM has been so long a leading member.

If I were a young man, which I am not,-- the snows of too many Winters have left their traces on my face and form,-- I should hasten to take unto myself a wife. But "Eheu.eheu Postume, fugaces Labuntur anni." Were I, then, young, I should incontinently rush into wedlock. How could I help it?

The Convention between the United States and Great Britain, concluded on the 8th of February last, has been made public by President PIERCE. The subject was the unsettled claims between the two countries since the treaties of Ghent; Hon. JOSEPH R. INGERSOLL and Lord JOHN RUSSELL the Pheipotentiaries.

Among the arrivals from California by the last steamer was Hon. BENJAMIN G. FERRIS, lately Secretary to the Territorial Government of Utah. Mr. FERRIS left Salt Lake some months since, and went across the country to California. He has lived among the Mormons long enough to become familiar with their customs and the character of their Society;

A PERTINENT INQUIRY.--When is Prince-street to be completer, and continued through to Concold? This is a question which has been anxiuosly mooted in certain quarters. The street is already cut through for a portion of the way, but farther it seems impossible to go. It is to be hoped that it will not be delaved longer than may be necessary, for its present condition is anything but agreeable to the denizens of the neighborhood.

Gen. John Wilson, who now resides in San Francisco, has written to Gov. Foote, of Mississippi, about a group of islands in the Pacific, known as the Navigator's Islands. With the letter, Gen. Wilson sends Gov. Foote some pickings of cotton taken from one of the cotton trees which grow on those islands.

In the way of news, there is but little to communicate which would interest New-York readers. The weather is cloudy to-day, with a breeze now and then from the northwest. The thermometer at noon stood at 83[degrees]. Our hotels are pretty well filled up with Southern and Western merchants, and a large number of visitors, on their way to the Crystal Palace.

By the kindness of a gentleman resident in this City, we are enabled to present to the readers of the TIMES the following interesting extracts from a private letter of Dr. NEUMANN'S to a relative in this country. The distinguished reputation of the author, who is Professor in the University of Muich, and Conservator of the Chinese Collection in Bavaria, is such as to command more than common respect for his opinions;

We have already announced the appointment of CARROLL SPENCR, Esq., of Baltimore, as Resident Minister at Constantinople, in place of Hon. GEORGE P. MARSH, who was appointed by General TAYLOR. Mr. SPENCE is not widely known, having never been connected with public affairs in any prominent capacity. But we learn that he is an able lawyer;

The farmers of Kentucky are turning their attention to introducing improved breeds of cattle. A few months since several gentlemen in Fayette, Bourbon, and Woodford Counties--all practical farmers--made up a purse, and sent three of their number to England, with instructions to buy the very best cattle, horses, and sheep, which money could procure.

A party of some forty gentlemen met yesterday morning, by invitation of the Long Island Water Works Company, at the City Hall, Brooklyn, and Wiltiamsurg Ferry, where states were in readiness to convey them on a tour of inspection from the site of the proposed reservoir, west of Cypress Hills, to the ponds from which a supply is to be derived.

EXTRAORDINARY HAUL OF FISH.--On Wednesday last, two boats from this place, engaged in Menhaden fishing. on drawing their seine, found that it contained five good-sized porpoises, and no other fish. The five would weigh about 1,500 pounds: the blubber would make about 10 gallons of oil.

At Cold Spring. on the 20th inst., after a short but severe illness, ELIZA, daughter of the late Dr. Charles H. Young. The funeral services will take place this afternoon, at 5 o'clock. from her late residence. Tne relations and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, 24th inst., EDWARD SPENCER, son of Charles and Libya Panlson, aged I year.

A decree in the Moniteur clinches the public conclusion that the imbroglio is unravelled. M. DROUYN DE LHUYS. Minister of Foreign affairs, is raised to the grade of Grand Cross in the Legion of Honor, for the eminently successful manner in which he has conducted the diplomacy of the country.

Now I must bid farewell to all these gay and busy scenes, and to many it is strange that I can regret leaving Saratoga. To them it is dull, mono. ionous and cheerless. They see nothing to read in all these myriad forces; they learn no lesson from all these changing scenes. But to me it would not he a waste of time, to study weeks in such a school.

The movements of the foreign residents of our country are particularly noteworthy, at a moment when the popular interest is so extremely engaged with foreign politics. It will be observed, by reference to the City column, that an expression of sentiment with regard to the KOSZTA affair is proposed by some of the leading gentlemen of the Emigration;

Justice Clark. of Enfield, issued twelve search-warrants, in order to enable the citizens of Ware Village, Mass , to look up the liquor that was supposed to be in the possession of certain individuals, who are milling and ready to sell without a salary-being satisfied with the profits of the traffic Five places were found where honor was kept whose aggregate amount, when seized, was 170 galions.

It is the privilege of great cities to he vexed with momentous questions. No sooner is a satisfactory solution discovered for one, than another usurps its place. From the beginning of the year to its end, we are constantly called on to determine if we have, or have not, such and such a thing among us.

The U. S. steamer Princeton, Commodore SHUBRICK, is preparing to leave the harbor for Prince Edward's Island. He will approach as near Charlottetown as the great draft of the Princeton will permit, and examine into the seizure of the American fishing schooner Starlight, of which we have just had advices.

BUILDING.--An immense amount of building is at present going on in this City. On Washington-street several buildings are going up which will cost from $15,000 to $20,000 each, and will be of the Fifth-avenu: style. On the old burnt district a new row of brown stone four story stores are going up, the rents of which are $1,200 to $1,500 per annum. In fact, in every par:

LOREN P. WALDO, Commissioner of Pensions, starts to-morrow on a visit to Connecticut. DAVID SALOMON has been appointed Pension Agent at Mobile, vice Doctor PERRINE. Major MORDECAI, of the Ordnance Department, is busily engaged in writing a report of the GARDINER affair.

The affair between two gentlemen of which I spoke in my letter yesterday, has been happily settled, without resorting to the very gentlemanly, but rather unpleasant "ultimatum" of powder and ball--the authorship of the offending paragraph having been promptly denied by the gentleman to whom it was imputed. To sum up the conclusion of the whole matter, there was, as railroad-accident story-tellers say, " not the slightest blame to be attributed to either party."

SIR: Lord MALMESBURY received, just before leaving office, the note addressed to you by Mr. EVERETT, and left it for the consideration of his successor. The absence from London of the Ambassador of France has hitherto prevented that communication between the two Governments which the circumstances of the proposal made jointly required.

There is reason to fear that large numbers of those who have correspondence with the Continent, do not realize the important advantages afforded them under the Treaty recently concluded with Bremen, which reduces the rates of postage between the United States and Bremen, and thus effects a very large reduction of postages to and from all places beyond Bremen, when letters are marked to go by that route.

In my previous letter, I enumerated all the charges that I have ever heard brought against the planters. I have done this, because I would not have it supposed that I write in a partisan spirit, and not because I believe that these charges are generally true.

The British schooner Dreadnaught, from Nassau 17th inst., has arrived here, bringing as passengers the widow and family of the late Gov. GREGORY, en route for England. The American brigantine Adelaide was wrecked on Egg Island Reef. Captain CLARK arrived at Nassau on the 14th, and reported the materials saved and disposed of at Harbor Island. We have no particulars.

A public meeting was held this afternoon, to consider the recent collision on the Worcester Railroad. Resolutions, mild and exculpatory in their tone, were reported, but were amended so as to strongly censure the Road. The first resolution was reported: " Wheleas, in the providence of God"--this was stricken out, and amended as follows: "Whereas, by the gross mismanagement of those having charge of the Providence and Worcester Railroad Corporation."

Last evening, at about 7 o'clock, a fire was discovered issuing from the hold of the steamship Cherokee, lying at the foot of Warren-street, North River and before the flames could be checked, the noble vessel, with her entire cargo, was completely destroyed.

GEORGE N. SAUNDERS, Esq., who has just been appointed by President PIERCE United States Consul at London, gave a dinner to a number of his political and personal friends at the Astor House last evening. It was a highly interesting and cordial festivity. Some twenty-five invited guests sat down, comprising not only distinguished Democrats, but prominent Whigs, from different sections of the Union.

The New-Orleans papers of Friday and Saturday are received. The Bulletin says: "There is nothing in the condition of the weather, atmosphere, or daily returns of deaths, to authorize any hope, at present, for the abatement of the epidemic. The fever now prevails in all parts of the city."

From the Republican. ERICSSOR and the United States of America had scarcely tendered to navigation and industry a motor, which, in its application, promised extreme economy, than France and M DU TREMBLEY responded to the noble challenge, by a rival invention, which already promises to effect the happies results.

M. DE PERSIONY has published a singular circular to the Prefect. He says that he notices that many Councils General, in assembling in their annual Fall meetings, are making preparations to issue congratulatory addresses to the Emperor, in spite of his dispatch of the 27th of July, forbidding any such manifestations.

As we came over the blow of the hill, and descended, the driver, walking by the side of his horse, pointed out the chief buildings of the city whereof all travelers are told by guides and guidebooks, which sum up the things to be seen, and the cost of seeing, with mathematical nicety.

MEETING OF THE FIREEEN.-A large meeting of members of the Fire Departmeut was held at Franklin Hall last evening pursuant to call, to take into consideration their grievances in regard to Chief Engineer, houses, alarm-bell, and other matters. JOHN SYLVESTER, Foreman of No. 3 Engine, was called to the Chair, and T. R. RODGERS, Foreman of Hook and Ladder Co., was appointed Secretary.

The N. O. Picayune, of the 19th inst., contains a correspondence from San Antonio, which, although it contains but few additional particulars of the El Paso difficulty, is of much interest. It is from Hon. J. L. ANKRIM, Judge of that District. He writes as follows: Some Californians had lost stock, which they had traced to the other (the Mexican) side of the river.

The independent is quite sure that Dr. Cox won't go to Owego to lay off, yet a while., It holds him good for 15 or 20 years yet. For all we can see, he promises to be good for as many years as shall be spared-him of life. H. C. BOWEN, Esq., regrets that the "Church plans" cannot be published before the middle or last of September.

At Brcoklyn, N. Y, Aug 25 by Rev S. Baylise, Mr. J. S. HARRISON, of Nevada City, Cal, to Miss ELENOR CHILD. of the former place In Westfield, N Y. on the 25th inst., at the residence of Hon. Alvin Plumber, by Rev. Charles Arcy. Rector of St. Paul's Church. Erie. Penn., JOHN T. FLEMING M.D., of Flemingsburg, Fleming County, Ky., to Miss ADELINE E. daughter of the late Samuel Budlary, Esq., of Westfield.

NIBLO'S SALOON.--An aspirant to instrumental honors makes her debut hero this evening. It is an interesting and curious occasion, the debugant being a lady. Madame the Baroness JULIE DE BERG is from Vienna, driven to this country, we believe, by political necessities.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have read, with unfeigned surprise, the paragraph in your paper alluding to a statement in the Musical World, that Madame SONTAG has been made to believe that $15,000 have been given to the TIMES and other papers, for complimentary not ices. I beg to inform you that I have sent the said paragraph to Madame SONTAG, and shall receive, tomorrow, her opinion about it.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Having noticed in the papers an account of a change in the letter carriers of the City, whereby the public were to be greatly benefited, I would give you my experience of the benefits the upper part of the City reap therefrom. Under the old system. letters mailed in York, Penn., always reached me the third day, and were brought to me without a murmur.

A TROT.--A trot between " Lady Vernon" and "Lady Litchfield" came off on Wednesday last. on LING'S Course, save the Portland Advertiser, which resulted us follows: Lady Vernon won the first heat in 2:40: Lady Litcfield won the 20 beat in 2:40 Lady Vernon won the 3D heat in 2:39. Lady Lichfield won the 4th heat in 2:40.

The total receipts in this City in aid of the Yellow Fever sufferers ill New-Orleans, up to yesterday, amount to $35,618. We published some weeks since, a report of a Lecture delivered in this City, by M. GAVAZZI, upon the connection of BEDINI with the execution of the Italian poet, UGO BASSI; and we also copied from the Milwaukee Sentinel a paragraph commenting upon statements made in that discourse.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Nothing has been done by the Trustees of this Institution since your seasonable admonition, under the signature of" Knickerbocker." The spirit of Rip Van Winkle seems to be infused into these, his worthy representatives and descendants.

A meeting of the American Party of the Eleventh Ward was held, last evening, at Manhattan Hall, No. 663 Fourth-street, to receive the report of the Nominating Committee, consider resolutions. There was a large and respectable attendance. At 8 o'clock Mr. J. P. CONCKLIN took the Chair, and the Secretary read the minutes of the previous meeting, which were approved.

RED SULPUR SPRINGS. There are forty-nine counties set down in the table before me as constituting the Trans-Alleghany District of Virginia. This section of the State, bordering chiefly upon Tennessee, Kentucky, and Ohio, and forming the western and southwestern portion of the Old Dominion, is mainly devoted to grazing and agriculture.

Yesterday, matters began to assume a more serious aspect than ever they have hitherto presented, in comequence of no proposition having, according to expectation, emanated from the employers. A meeting of the latter, an has already been stated. was held on the preceding evening, but it did not result in any proposition.

To begin my likeness, I have already admitted that I am far advanced in life--too far, I fear, to be very unwilling to tell mv age;

There is a well-settled understanding here that the President has finally abandoned his intention of appointing Mr. Dix to the French Mission. FRANCIS B. CUTTING'S chances for the appointment are improving.

To-morrow many of the churches in the City that have been temporarily closed will be reopened for public service. This reminds us that the Summer is fast passing away. Fall is coming, and with it a new series of remarks about the weather, new topics of conversation for the people that meet in the streets.

The trial gets along slowly. On Monday, Mr. JOHN CUYLER was sworn, and testified as to who constituted the Canal Board in 1851 and 1852. Nr. LOOMIS presented the proceedings of the Board relative to the lettings of 1851. Commissioner FOLLETT was examined on the same point; and the labor of the first day of the week was ended.

A German, named HILDEBRAND, who keeps a grocery in Ewen, near Messerolestreet, was arrested on Friday morning, on the complaint of his wife, charging him with having abandoned her and her child some six years since. It seems that he left his wife and child in Germany, for the purpose of coming to this country. whe e he proposed to engage in business, and then to send for his family.

ELECTION OF DELEGATES.--The primary election by the Democrats, in each ward, for the election of delegates to a convention to select deegates to the State Convention at Syracuse in Septamber, was hold on Friday, with the exception of the Eleventh Ward, where there was a warm contest between the friends of Sheriff LOTT and JAMES H. HUTCHINS, and resulted in no choice A new trial was had on Saturday evening, when Sheriff LOTT was elected.

I walked down to the Bonsecour's Market-House, quite a large building, of granite, making a better appearance than even the Boston Market but the stalls were, by no means, so neat. Berries of all kinds were very plenty and large ; vegetables generally not so good as with us. At one table, a market woman was giving a slight convivial entertainment to a couple of visitors in black.
